title: ATYPICAL 'LOAFING'
description: To the Editor:

title: SURVIVORS RECALL SCREAMING WOMEN AND FALLING BODIES IN DEADLY HOTEL FIRE
description: Carmen Tirado, who lived in Apartment 6 on the third floor of Pinter's Hotel, said she had been awakened by her 16-year-old daughter, Carmen. Mrs. Tirado said her daughter, who had got up to get a blanket, smelled the smoke.

title: CLORE PURCHASES HALTED
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation won a 10-day restraining order in State District Court in Salt Lake City yesterday preventing Alan Clore, the British investor, from purchasing additional shares of the diversified coal, oil and chemicals producer or voting the shares he holds, pending a hearing on May 7.

title: Further Delay for Alaska Gas
description: The companies sponsoring the Alaska natural gas pipeline announced today a delay of up to two years in construction of the $43 billion pipeline because of difficulties in financing the project.

title:
PATENTS;
A Method to Select The Sex of Mammals
description: A method of controlling the sex of mammalian offspring produced through artificial insemination, both animal and human, was patented this week by Wallace Shrimpton, head of an agricultural consulting firm in San Francisco.

title: Man, 20, Killed In Central Park
description: A 20-year-old man was fatally stabbed during a robbery attempt in Central Park last night, the police said.

title: Fluor Unit Signs Contract in China
description: The Fluor Corporation said its Fluor Mining and Metals subsidiary had signed a contract with the China National Coal Development Corporation to modernize and expand the Fushun West open pit mine in Liaoning Province.

title: STATE COULD CUT CITY SCHOOL AID BECAUSE OF ERROR
description: Because of an error by the New York City Board of Education in counting the number of handicapped pupils it serves, the city stands to lose about $30 million this year in state education aid, city and state officials said today.

title: JUDGE ORDERS IMMIGRATION AGENTS NOT TO ABUSE SALVADORAN REFUGEES
description: A Federal judge today ordered agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to stop threatening and abusing Salvadoran refugees and to advise them they have the right to seek political asylum in the United States.

title: Speakes Sends Aides Home for Being Late
description: Displeased over staff tardiness, Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, sent three aides home today after they showed up late for work.

title: MUSIC: THE HAGUE PHILHARMONIC, 'FIREBIRD'
description: The Hague Philharmonic under Hans Vonk paid a visit to Carnegie Hall Thursday, and for the first half of the evening at least sounded as well prepared and warmly musical as any visiting orchestra in recent memory. Haydn's Symphony No. 82 in C enjoyed carefully calculated dynamics that still managed to sound spontaneous.

title: A TOTAL LITTER BILL INSTEAD OF A BOTTLE BILL
description: To the Editor: We are all concerned about the problem of roadside and street litter and the complex problems relating to solid-waste management and disposal. We should and must have a cleaner environment, in the cities, villages and towns of our state and along its highways, and we must address ourselves to a better system of solid-waste management and disposal.

title: Tenants Ordered Out of Water Gap
description: A Federal judge in New Jersey has ruled that 100 seasonal tenants living on Government property along the Delaware River must vacate their homes by May 10.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must remember that the aggression was on the part of Argentina in this dispute over the sovereignty of that little ice-cold bunch of land down there, and they finally just resorted to armed aggression.'' - President Reagan. (8:1.)

title: Article 105648 -- No Title
description: The New York Philharmonic WQXR Radiothon, a 60 hour marathon, raised $358,632 for the orchestra last weekend. Since their beginning, in 1978, the Philharminic radiothoins have raised nearly $1.7 million.

title: AMERICA'S 'INVISIBLE' CHINESE
description: We've been called the model minority, the silent minority. Sometimes we're too insignificant in numbers to even count as a minority. Although the Chinese population in the United States has surged in recent decades, we are still only four-tenths of 1 percent of the entire population.

title: ALSANDS PROJECT IS CANCELED
description: Spurning an eleventh-hour offer of Government financial aid, the last two private companies participating in the $13.1 billion (Canadian) Alsands oil sands project said today that they were quitting, a decision that effectively kills the ambitious plan.

title: Your Money; Tax Shelters: New Stature
description: TAX shelters have come a long way since the days when many of the deals seemed shady and structured to generate as much tax loss as possible. Today, the industry has grown huge, and the emphasis is on investment as much as write-off.

title: Around the World; U.S. and 6 Other Nations Block Vietnam Food Aid
description: The United States, along with Argentina, Canada, West Germany, Japan, Thailand and Britain, have blocked a $5.3 million food-aid program for Vietnam at the executive council meeting of the United Nations World Food Program, the agency's officials reported today.

title: ISRAELIS DISMISS ANOTHER MAYOR IN THE WEST BANK
description: Israeli authorities continued their crackdown on Palestinian nationalists today by dismissing a fourth elected mayor on the occupied West Bank.

title: DEREGULATION TRIUMPH OVER AIR TRAVELERS
description: To the Editor:

title: New York
description: For more than four years Carol Bellamy, as City Council President, opposed Mayor Koch vigorously and sometimes bitterly on a host of major substantive issues involving fundamental city policies.

title: Spurs 99, Sonics 97
description: SAN ANTONIO (UPI) - Mike Bratz, a reserve guard, scored his only field goal of the game with five seconds left to give San Antonio the victory and a 2-1 lead in the Western Conference semifinal series. Seattle has won only one of 14 games played here since the Spurs joined the league in 1977.

title: REPORTERS OUT OF STATE'S SHOW
description: Citing the controversy that had been created, the State Commerce Commissioner said yesterday that he had withdrawn his invitation to a group of political reporters known as the Inner Circle to provide entertainment at a ''New York State Salute to the Media'' he had organized.

title: SMITH'S PINCH-HOMER IN 9TH DEFEATS METS
description: Reggie Smith pinch-hit a three-run home run off Neil Allen in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight to give the San Francisco Giants a 5-4 victory over the Mets.

title: New Head for College of Cardiology
description: ''I was very fortunate in that my father made no difference between what boys did and what girls did,'' said Dr. Suzanne Knoebel of Indianapolis, who on Wednesday became the first woman to head the American College of Cardiology.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: RADIO NETWORKS: NEW 'GOLDEN AGE'
description: Network radio, the venerable industry that carried Franklin D. Roosevelt's fireside chats, is having a baby boom. Of the 30 radio networks that some industry analysts classify as national, a dozen have been founded since 1978. This year, more than half a dozen new ones are expected to go into operation.

title: Whites in Zimbabwe Disband A Breakaway Political Party
description: A white political party formed in an attempt to improve relations between the black majority Government and Zimbabwe's whites has been disbanded, its leader confirmed today.

title: INDEPENDENT TRUCKERS CALL STRIKE IN A DISPUTE OVER HAULING RATES
description: Independent truckers called a strike for 12:01 A.M., Central daylight time today and said they expected about 200,000 truckers around the country to walk off their jobs in a dispute over the rates they are paid by hauling contractors.

title: Too Little, Too Late in Poland
description: The steps that Poland's junta announced this week to ease its martial law are four months overdue. Last December, the release of some persons never even charged with a crime and the relaxation of curfew and travel restrictions could have made credible the regime's proclaimed desire for national reconciliation.

title: 13 Religious Sect Members Are Killed by a Crowd in India
description: A crowd wielding spears and knives killed at least 13 members of the Ananda Marga religious sect today after rumors that they had kidnapped children in the southern outskirts of Calcutta, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.

title:
Patents;
Multiple Sensors for Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON A Control system used successfully in the second and third space flights of the space shuttle makes decisions by the ''votes'' of a number of sensors. The apparatus, invented by Hendrik J.C. Gelderloos, an employee of Honeywell Inc. of St. Petersburg, Fla., was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: 13 GIVE UP WEEK'S PAY TO KEEP CO-WORKER
description: Fred Barrick had become one of the recession's latest victims, but his 13 co-workers gave up a week's pay each and saved his job.

title: TEXT OF RESOLUTION ON THE FALKLANDS
description: Following is the text of United Nations Security Council Resolution 502 on the Falkland Islands crisis, which was approved April 3 by a vote of 10 to 1, with 4 abstentions:

title: COMPANY TRAINS UNSKILLED WORKERS
description: For Marva Eaves, the 15-minute walk to work is part of what she likes about her job as an assembler of high-fidelity equipment at United Sounds of America. It is also nice that she can walk to work with her oldest son, Johnny.

title: THE DANCE: TAP THEATER
description: Gail Conrad is a talented and imaginative tap dancer with an interest in going beyond the traditional and technical limits of tap. The Gail Conrad Tap Dance Theater presented her latest experiments Thursday at the Jazz Forum. To judge by the wild extended applause, Miss Conrad has found an eager audience.

title: 'The Road' Extended
description: Horton Foote's comic drama ''The Road to Home'' has been extended through May 16 at the Manhattan Punch Line, 260 West 41st Street.

title: COMPROMISE LIKELY ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: The outlines of a possible compromise on extension of the Voting Rights Act became clear Thursday as the Senate Committee on the Judiciary once more postponed consideration of the issue.

title: Briefing
description: Meg's Memo

title: Equitable Life In Hawaii Venture
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and an unidentified foreign investor have signed a letter of intent to buy most of the major income properties in Hawaii of Ala Moana Hawaii Properties for $233 million in cash, Ala Moana said in San Francisco. It said the Equitable joint venture would also assume $55 million in mortages and $42 million in construction notes, for a gross cost of $330 million.

title: Briefing
description: Lobbying v. Supreme Court

title: G.P.U.'s Net Rises Sharply
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1981 soared to $18.4 million, or 30 cents a share, from $7.8 million, or 13 cents, in the first quarter of 1981. Revenues rose 23.6 percent, to $647.8 million, from $523.9 million.

title: INCREASED ATTENTION TO COATS AND DRESSES
description: Coats and dresses, two categories of fashion that have seemed moribund in the last few seasons, showed new signs of life in the collections that completed two weeks of presentations for fall and winter.

title: TAPPING A MARKET IN EXECUTIVE TOYS
description: Richard Thalheimer does not own one of the bulletproof vests that he sells through his catalogue for $249, nor, when he goes for his daily eight-mile jog, does he wear one of the computerized runner's wristwatches (''brisk sellers'') that are offered in his catalogue at $49.95 apiece.

title:
PATENTS;
Stereoscopic System For Group Viewing
description: A stereoscopic picture system patented this week by George F. Hausherr of Lynbrook, L.I., offers a wide variety of equipment to provide three-dimensional views for one or many persons.

title: PYM PLANS A WEEKEND VISIT
description: Francis Pym, the Foreign Secretary, tonight welcomed American support for Britain in the Falkland Islands crisis and said he would fly to Washington and New York this weekend to keep alive efforts to find a peaceful settlement.

title: LICENSING INFORMATION
description: Congress should reject proposed legislation and resist a Presidential executive order that together would establish a Government right of eminent domain over ideas that would rival its jurisdiction over public lands.

title: Dow Rises by 3.42; Volume Is Lower
description: The stock market, helped by reports that the Argentines were willing to accept a United Nations resolution requiring them to pull out of the Falkland Islands, broke its three-day losing streak yesterday by registering a moderate gain in less active trading.

title: Books of The Times; Behind the Scenes
description: THE PAST HAS ANOTHER PATTERN: Memoirs. By George W. Ball. Illustrated. 527 pages. W.W. Norton. $19.95.

title: Around the Nation; Prisoner Disturbance Put Down in Michigan
description: Thirty-five inmates carrying makeshift weapons took over a cellblock at a prison for three hours today, injuring two guards and setting fires before the disturbance was put down by officers in riot gear.

title: Sports People; Dokes Arrested
description: Michael Dokes, the unbeaten heavyweight boxer, was arrested in Dania, Fla., and charged with reckless driving and impersonating a police officer. Dokes, who has scored 14 knockouts in his 26 fights, was released on $200 bond.

title: Lefrak's Day at University of Maryland
description: ''I believe,'' Samuel R. Pierce was saying, ''in cutting regulations which have stifled private initiative.'' A familiar enough sentiment for a Republican official, but those words from the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development took on a special significance yesterday.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF BY 0.5%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators declined in March for the 11th consecutive month, falling five-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Around the World; 2 Hostages in Honduras Released to Papal Aide
description: The Vatican representative negotiating with four hijackers holding 27 hostages boarded the plane twice today and brought off two of the hostages, whom the authorities identified as Hondurans.

title: Bridge: Sometimes Victory Comes In Spite of Great Obstacles
description: The highest pairs score any good player can expect in a bridge lifetime is about 75 percent, and many never achieve that figure. In a two-session regional pair championship, the winning score is hardly ever less than 64 percent, and sometimes considerably more.

title: Military Analysis
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s announcement that the United States was prepared to provide logistical support to the British naval task force off the Falkland Islands emphasized the difference between theory and reality in the North Atlantic Alliance, according to military and diplomatic authorities here. By offering support to Britain, they said, Mr. Haig underlined that America, like Britain, has strategic commitments that extend well beyond NATO's geographical area, which, at sea, is limited to the north and northeastern Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea.

title: News Analysis
description: In the inevitable post-mortem debate over who is to blame for the collapse of the bipartisan budget negotiations, one critical point of contention is the White House assertion that President Reagan went ''more than halfway'' in search of a compromise.

title: Braniff Loss Widened in the Quarter
description: The Braniff International Corporation, struggling to avoid insolvency, announced yesterday a first-quarter loss of $41.4 million, a sharp deterioration from the $24.7 million that the airline lost in 1981's first quarter.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 21.

title: Farmers Protest Jailing In Soybean 'Liberation'
description: Angry farmers formed picket lines today and planned a tractor protest this weekend in an effort to gain the release of a Missouri farmer jailed for shielding the identity of the persons who helped him ''liberate'' his soybeans from a bankrupt grain elevator operator.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 1, 1982
description: International The U.S. went to Britain's side in the dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands. President Reagan accused Argentina of ''armed aggression'' and ordered it placed under limited sanctions. The President also offered to provide British military forces with ''materiel support,'' but he ruled out any direct military involvement. (Page 1, Column 6.) British ships ringed the Falklands, putting into effect a 200-mile air and sea blockade.Sources in Buenos Aires and London said both sides appeared to be waiting for the other to fire first to avoid being accused of starting a war. The exact position of the Argentine fleet was not known, but NATO sources in London said it was far from the blockade zone. (1:5.)

title: Stallions Beat Arrows In Playoff Opener, 9-7
description: Germain Iglesias scored his second goal of the game to break a 7-7 tie and the Buffalo Stallions went on to a 9-7 victory over the New York Arrows tonight in the opening round of the Major Indoor Soccer League playoffs at Nassau Coliseum before 4,223.

title: BETTER CONTROLS IN TRANSIT PACT SEEN BY RAVITCH
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that Thursday's arbitration award in the transit dispute would give management better control of its operations.

title: Sports People; Axelson Rejoins Kings
description: The Kansas City Kings yesterday announced that Joe Axelson, who resigned as general manager three years ago to become director of operations for the National Basketball Association, was returning to the team as general manager and president. Paul Rosenberg, the club's principal owner, said that Jeff Cohen had resigned as general manager but would remain with the club.

title: EVENTS THAT LED UP TO THE SEA-LAW TREATY
description: Following are the major events that led to the the Law of the Sea Treaty: Sept. 28, 1945 - President Harry Truman proclaims American sovereignty over natural gas deposits and other resources of the continental shelf beneath the high seas, beginning three miles beyond a nation's coast. Nov. 1, 1967 - Arvid Pardo, Malta's delegate to the United Nations, warns the General Assembly that chaos threatens the seas. Nations are claiming the waters and marine resources 200 miles and more beyond their coasts, threatening the free passage of ships and aircraft and provoking conflicts over fish and minerals. Dec. 17, 1970 - The General Assembly endorses Mr. Pardo's concept that resources on the seabed floor, beyond any nation's jurisdiction, are the ''common heritage of mankind.'' The Assembly calls for an international conference to draft law for the sea. December 3 to 15, 1973 - The Law of the Sea Conference meets for the first time in New York to elect officers. June 20 to Aug. 29, 1974 - The conference has its first general debate in Caracas, and the United States accepts in principle that nations shall have exclusive rights to the resources in the sea for 200 miles beyond their shores. March 17 to May 9, 1975 - The conference, in Geneva, completes the first draft of a treaty governing use of the seas. Aug. 2 to Sept. 17, 1976 - Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, at a conference session in New York, proposes a compromise on the vexed question of mining the seabed.

title: Keating Nominated to a City Judgeship
description: When Mayor Koch named him coordinator of criminal justice for New York City two years ago, Robert G.M. Keating said his main task would be ''to improve the productivity of the courts.''

title: Going Out Guide
description: VIENNESE REELS

title: BRITISH WARSHIPS BEGIN BLOCKADE AROUND ISLANDS
description: Britain's air and sea blockade of the Falklands began today with ships of the British battle fleet reported in place around the islands in direct challenge to Argentina.

title: Korea Atom Fuel Plan
description: South Korea's state-run Korea Electric Power Corporation and the Korea Advanced Energy Research Institute will form a joint venture to produce nuclear fuel for power generation, officials of the Energy and Resources Ministry said today. The new company will soon start talks with foreign companies to set up a joint venture plant capable of fabricating 200 tons of nuclear fuel a year beginning in 1988, they added. Korea will build eight more atomic plants by 1989, the officials said.

title: SAFETY ISSUES IN AMUSEMENT RIDES
description: For the Consumer Product Safety Commission one of the first signs of summer appears on a computer printout that shows a sudden increase in injuries associated with amusement rides.

title: American General, NLT Hearing Set
description: John C. Neff, state insurance commissioner, says he plans a public hearing June 1 on the American General Corporation's $1 billion takeover attempt of the NLT Corporation.

title: Haig to Visit Aegean Nations
description: The State Department announced today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. would travel to Turkey and Greece May 12-16 ''for meetings with governmental leaders to discuss subjects of mutual interest.''

title: Kentucky Derby Field POST PROB. NO.  POS.  HORSE JOCKEY TRAINER ODDS
description: 12 1 f-Cupecoy's Joy Angel Santiago Alfredo Callejas 8-1 2 2 Bold Style Jeffrey Fell Jack Van Berg 15-1 13 3 f-New Discovery Jerry Balley Eugene Jacobs 8-1 3 4 El Baba Don Brumfield Dewey Smith 5-2 4 5 Royal Roberto Miguel Rivera James Iselin 20-1 5 6 Wavering Monarch Randy Romero George R. Arnold 15-1 6 7 Air Forbes Won Angel Cordero Frank LaBoccetta 7-2 7 8 Laser Light Eddie Maple Patrick J. Kelly 30-1 14 9 f-Music Leader Pat Day Tommie T. Gregson 10-1 19 20 f-Majesty's Prince Ruben Harnandez Joseph B Cantey 8-1

title: IF THE MONEY MARKET HAD TO BE A TREASURY CLIENT
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEX SETTLES CHARGES OVER WHEELER BENEFITS
description: The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the Telex Corporation with accounting deficiencies and with violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act in connection with perquisites given to Roger M. Wheeler, its former chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Wheeler was murdered last year.

title: Around the World; Former Premier Hua Hospitalized in Peking
description: Hua Guofeng, the former Chinese Prime Minister and Communist Party Chairman who was demoted to sixth deputy chairman last year, has been hospitalized here and is recuperating from an unspecified illness, the official New China News Agency said tonight.

title: GIANTS PICK SIMMS AS STARTER, FOR NOW
description: The Giants announced today that Phil Simms would be their No.1 quarterback. Scott Brunner, who started the last seven games last year and led the Giants to the National Football League playoffs after Simms was injured, will go into training camp as No.2.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect closing date for the Robert Goodnough exhibition at the Klonaridis Gallery, 50 West 57th Street.

title: LAW OF THE SEA PROVISIONS
description: Following are the main provisions of the Law of the Sea Treaty:

title: HATCH FACES HARD FIGHT TO RETAIN SENATE SEAT
description: Orrin G. Hatch, a conservative Republican Senator whose defeat would delight organized labor, civil rights groups and feminists, is in re-election trouble.

title: Handicapped in Protest Of 'Federalism' Policy
description: In wheelchairs, on crutches and using canes, more than 100 handicapped people left a meeting today with a Government official in protest of what they called Reagan Administration plans to weaken regulations that protect the disabled against discrimination.

title: Consumer Saturday; CCOMPUTER CLUB AIDS YOUNGSTERS
description: COMPUTER Eagle Scouts? Software merit badges? Most people would agree that the computer age is with us and that t he future of the age belongs to the young, but down in Richardson, T ex., they're doing something about it.

title: The Presidential Pen That Wouldn't
description: It was hardly the first time a pen hadn't worked when it was supposed to, but this pen belonged to President Reagan and when it failed during the President's televised address Thursday night there was a special embarrassment for the Marsh Stencil Machine Company of Belleville, Ill.

title: IN IRELAND, UNGREENING
description: Arriving at the small village port that serves as departure point for the island, off the west coast of Ireland, I shook hands with the boatmen. Then the skipper pointed to a large pile of wooden poles on the quay. ''Do you know what those are?'' I gaped, silent. ''Electricity,'' he declared, ''they're puttin' in the electricity.'' A couple of dozen tarred electric poles were already loaded onto the deck and I had to climb over them to find a place to sit.

title:
PATENTS;
Electric Device To Snare Body Tissue
description: A practicing surgeon in McLean, Va., has patented a surgical snare.

title: Sports of The Times; The Derby's One-Eyed Horse
description: The Derby's one-eyed horse in the 108-year history of the Kentucky Derby was munching hay in an outdoor stall that resembles a personal pagoda. But when Ron McAnally, in a blue blazer and gray slacks, called to Cassaleria and approached him, the dark brown colt stared at his trainer as intently as any two-eyed horse would.

title: U.S. BANKERS FEAR SLOW REPAYMENTS
description: American bankers, who have lent Argentina about $9.2 billion, said yesterday that their relationship with Buenos Aires had become far more precarious as a result of the American decision to impose economic sanctions on that country.

title: DERBY COMPETITORS AWAIT CALL TO POST
description: A forced sense of calm, born from feelings of resignation, settled over the backstretch at Churchill Downs this morning. The trainers of the 18 colts, the gelding and the filly who will run Saturday in the 108th Kentucky Derby had essentially the same thing to say: There was little left to do but wait for the call to the post.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS RISE BY 1.5%
description: Prices farmers get for their products increased by 1.5 percent in April, but they were still 5.6 percent below price levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Around the World; Salvador Troops Battle Rebels Near Honduras
description: Salvadoran troops tried today to trap guerrillas near the Honduran border, shelling rebel positions and dropping bombs from helicopters, military sources said.

title: No Reason for Retreat on Title VI
description: Moderate Republicans in Congress are using the case of a Mississippi basketball coach as an excuse to strip the Government of its power to deny funds to school districts that discriminate. A cutoff may be inappropriate in that case, but it is no reason for so drastic an assault on government's power to fight racism.

title: CITIES ARE WARNED ON ANTITRUST RULE
description: Members of the National League of Cities were urged today to support Federal legislation to help protect themselves against a multitude of antitrust lawsuits expected to result from a Supreme Court decision in January.

title: COURT UPHOLDS TAX DEDUCTION FOR TUITION IN PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a Minnesota law that allows parents to deduct private and parochial school tuition from income that is subject to state income taxes.

title: Israeli in Larceny Case Resigns From Cabinet
description: An Israeli Cabinet official who received a suspended prison sentence last week for larceny and breach of trust resigned from the Cabinet today, effective this weekend.

title: United Parcel Service Warns Shippers of Strike Possibility
description: The United Parcel Service informed shippers yesterday that its nationwide contract with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters would expire at 12;01 A.M. today and that customers should be prepared for the possibility of a strike Wednesday.

title: SARAGTOGA SANS EXOTICA
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN'S SPEECH ELATES LOBBYISTS
description: Of the millions of Americans who watched President Reagan on television Thursday night, it is doubtful that many were as happy as the lobbyists for the proposed constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget.

title: CATTLE RANCHERS FIND HOME IS A VANISHING RANGE
description: Ever since the San Juan Valley was settled, it has been cattle country, and many of the ranchers who still work the steep-sided hills here, on the scenic western flank of the Continental Divide, are descendants of the original homesteaders who staked out the area nearly a century ago.

title: Workers Strike Jersey Utility
description: A strike action began this morning against Public Service Electric & Gas Company after talks between the utility's 4,700 workers and management broke down, officials said.

title: LATTINS FEAR MOVE BY U.S. WILL HARM RELATIONS
description: The United States decision to impose sanctions on Argentina and publicly declare its support for Britain is regarded in Latin America as a serious step that will affect United States relations within the hemisphere for some time, according to Latin American officials.

title: STYLE TOO CAUTIOUS FOR ISLANDERS' FANS
description: Although they were leading their National Hockey League semifinal series by two games to none over the Quebec Nordiques, the Islanders found a new kind of criticism being directed toward them: They weren't exciting enough.

title: BRITISH SAID TO NEED LITTLE HELP FROM U.S. FOR NOW
description: British officials have told the United States that the fleet near the Falkland Islands could sustain operations for 90 days, and the Pentagon has therefore not made contingency plans for resupplying it, Administration officials said today.

title: ADMINISTRATION, IN SWTICH, TAKES TOUGHER LINE ON CLEAN AIR RULES
description: The Reagan Administration threatened today to ban construction in metropolitan areas in 11 states because of the states' failure to carry out smog control programs.

title: UNC Resources Plans Acquisitions
description: UNC Resources Inc. said at its annual meeting in New Orleans that it expects to make additional acquisitions this year that would produce up to $100 million in new revenue.

title: REAGAN CONFERS WITH REPUBLICANS ON NEW CONGRESS BUDGET STRATEGY
description: President Reagan met with Republican Congressional leaders today to plan budget strategy amid predictions that Congress would find it extremely difficult to adopt a budget for the next fiscal year.

title: ARGENTINA SAID TO AVOID BRITIAN'S BLOCKADE ZONE
description: The Argentine fleet was reported today to be at sea but far from the British blockade zone in effect within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands.

title: CHARTER, HEARST PACT
description: The Hearst Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Redbook, the women's magazine, and Charter Data Services, a magazine subscription fulfillment company, for more than $23 million from the Charter Company.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 1, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.5 percent in March, its 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported. The report was taken as another signal that the recession is continuing, though perhaps at a slower pace. (Page 33.) Orders for new factory goods rose 0.2 percent in March, the second monthly increase in a row. (42.)

title: Testimony Is Concluded In Retrial of Raider Suit
description: Testimony in the retrial of the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League ended today.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Jury Fails to Indict In Bully's Shooting Death
description: A Federal grand jury today failed to return any indictments in the case of a town bully whose death may have been witnessed by as many as 60 people.

title: Officer Convicted In Sale of Cocaine
description: A 39-year-old New York City police officer was convicted of cocaine-trafficking charges yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. The officer, Vincent Rossi, was found guilty of conspiracy and aiding and abetting an illicit drug sale.

title: OWNERS WILL KEEP THE NEWS AND SEEK UNION CONCESSIONS
description: The Tribune Company of Chicago said yesterday that it was ending its effort to sell The Daily News and that it would continue to operate the New York newspaper, which it had threatened three weeks ago to close.

title: 2 SUSPICIOUS FIRES KILL 16 IN JERSEY
description: Twelve people, including seven children, were killed in Hoboken yesterday in a predawn fire that consumed a small four-story hotel largely filled with women and children. Officials said they suspected arson.

title: FACTORY ORDERS SHOW RISE OF 0.2% FOR MARCH
description: New orders for factory goods edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in March, marking the first time that orders have climbed for two consecutive months since the recession started last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ARGENTINE UNIONS PROTEST IN CAPITAL
description: Several thousand workers from the General Confederation of Labor, an illegal organization, gathered today with left-wing splinter groups in the heart of this city to celebrate May Day. They chanted anti-British slogans and demanded a restoration of democracy.

title: THE ELDERLY WHO MUST FIND WORK TO SURVIVE
description: T o the Editor: I was pleased to see coverage of the distressing Reagan cutbacks planned for the Senior Community Service Employment Program (news story March 25), and I wish to add several points to those made in the article, points which I believe strengthen the case for the retention of this program.

title: Editor to Check Again on Life At University of Rhode Island
description: The education editor of The New York Times, whose college guide referred to the University of Rhode Island as ''a high school after high school,'' has said that he will distribute new questionnaires here.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HINCKLEY'S CRUSTY JUDGE
description: On the opening day of the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., who is accused of attempting to assassinate President President Reagan, the Federal marshal ordered all to rise as Judge Barrington

title: TOXIC SHOCK CASES DROP, BUT DISEASE PERSISTS
description: The incidence of toxic shock syndrome in the United States appears to be well below what it was in 1980, when it reached a peak, but the disease gives no sign of disappearing, according to the latest data compiled by the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: IRANIAN FORCES ATTACK IRAQIS OCCUPYING OIL-BEARING AREA
description: Iranian forces struck at dawn today in an attempt to oust Iraqi occupying forces, and the Teheran radio said 300 square miles of territory was quickly recaptured. Iraq, however, said its forces had blunted the attack.

title: Transcript of Haig remarks, page 8.
description: President Reagan accused Argentina today of ''armed aggression'' in the Falkland Islands and ordered limited sanctions against Argentina, placing the United States openly on the side of Britain in the monthlong crisis.

title: U.S. VOTES NO
description: Third-world nations adopted a wide-ranging treaty today to govern the use and exploitation of the seas, but the United States was in an isolated group that rejected the code. The vote, ending eight years of diplomatic bargaining, was 130 to 4.

title: Storage Contract
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said it would supply tape, disk and printer computer products for the Army. Storage Technology said the contract was expected to provide $80 million in revenues over a 10-year period.

title: EX-GENERAL BECOMES A KEY FIGURE IN SEOUL POLITICS
description: With his appointment as Home Minister by President Chun Doo Hwan on Wednesday, a retired general who played a key role in Mr. Chun's rise to power two years ago has emerged as a major player in South Korea's troubled political game.

title: WESTCHESTER ACTS ON REFUSE PLANT
description: Westchester County's proposed $180 million garbage recycling plant passed its final legislative hurdle today when county lawmakers voted unanimously to approve a tax district to help pay for the disposal of 1,000 tons of solid waste a day.

title: HOOKER COMPANY CLEANUP OF TOXIC DUMP UPSTATE APPROVED
description: A Federal judge today approved an agreement requiring the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation to start cleaning up a major toxic-waste dump outside Niagara Falls, N.Y.

title: Sports People; Dobler to Sit Out Year
description: Ten seasons in the National Football League have taken their toll on Conrad Dobler, the veteran guard of the Buffalo Bills and selfproclaimed meanest N.F.L. player. As a result, he said in an interview with The Dallas Times-Herald, there was simply no way for him to play next season, no matter how much he wanted to play.

title: RACING AS A NOVEL IDEA
description: Dick Francis was in town the other day, en route to his home in England from Florida, where he and his wife spend the winter months. That means he will be missing the Kentucky Derby. Bad planning, he said.

title: SOVIET TO AID CUBA WITH A-PLANT
description: The Soviet Union is helping Cuba build a nuclear power plant and will raise its aid to Havana over the next five years to its highest level ever, the official Cuban press agency said today.

title: UKRAINIAN BOY, IN LETTER, CONTRADICTS FATHER ON FAMILY LIFE
description: In a letter written in January but kept secret until today, Walter Polovchak said that he had never been close to his parents and that they had never been loving, contrary to his father's assertions in an interview in Chicago Tuesday.

title: FORMER WORKER OF MARTIN CAREY TESTIFIES ON TAX
description: A former employee of a major independent petroleum-distributing company told a State Supreme Court judge yesterday that the company's president, Martin Carey, had ordered him to underreport earnings in 1977 to avoid paying state sales taxes on income from a chain of gasoline stations that Mr. Carey controlled.

title: THE POLLOCK WHO BLAZED AN ARTISTIC TRAIL FOR HIS BROTHER
description: ''I see it as the work of a fellow artist. He was another person trying to carry on. I believe in the carrying-on. I believe we have responsibilities as artists to deal with the culture handed down to us and to find a way to hand it down to our progeny.''

title: Around the Nation; Spy Gets 25 More Years For Bank Robberies
description: Christopher Boyce was sentenced today to 25 years in prison for several bank robberies committed while he was a fugitive from prison.

title: TV BARRED FROM TAPES OF JODIE FOSTER TESTIMONY
description: Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker ruled today that television networks could not obtain or copy the videotaped testimony of the actress Jodie Foster after it has been played at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr.

title: Coke Era Ends In Johnstown
description: The last of the old coke ovens that produced fuel for huge steelmaking blast furnaces in this industrial city are cold, never to be used again.

title: Science Lab Odors Sicken 26
description: Fumes seeped through the science wing of Harrison Junior High School here today. Two teachers and 24 students were overcome by the noxious odors and hospitalized. The fumes were traced to two science laboratories but their source was not identified.

title: 17 Americans Remain On Falkland Islands
description: The State Department said today that 17 Americans still in the Falkland Islands had apparently decided to stay despite United States recommendations that they leave.

title: Jury in Penthouse Case Recesses Until Monday
description: The jury in the $522 million libel suit of the resort La Costa against Penthouse Magazine concluded six days of deliberation today without reaching a verdict. The five-man, seven-woman panel will resume studying the case Monday morning.

title: Soviet Gives P.L.O. Pledge
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko pledged today that the Soviet Union would continue to support the struggle of the Palestine Liberation Organization for the creation of a Palestine state.

title: NO MORE HANDPICKED APPEALS JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AIDES CALL THE SANCTIONS SYMBOLIC
description: The Reagan Administration's economic and military sanctions against Argentina will have little practical effect, State Department and Pentagon officials said today.

title: Sports Peo; Bates Hospitalized
description: Billy Ray Bates, a substitute shooting guard for the Portland Trail Blazers, is undergoing treatment at Holladay Park Hospital in Portland for what his doctor, Guy Parvaresh, described as ''exhaustion and depression.''

title: Sports People; A Split Bat and Decision
description: Lee MacPhail, the president of the American League, found that Bill Kunkel, the umpire, acted correctly in ejecting Toby Harrah of the Cleveland Indians and confiscating his bat during last Tuesday night's game against Seattle. But MacPhail also found, after inspecting the bat, that Harrah's tampering - sawing off the handle and then refastening it with glue and a wooden peg - had not involved any effort to produce more power illegally, and so no further action should be taken against him. Harrah had maintained his innocence all along, saying that he had shortened the bat because a new shipment of 34-inch types had not arrived on time.

title: Shock Therapy for Argentina
description: President Reagan's decisive tilt to Britain came just in time. With luck and more resourceful diplomacy, it may avert a tragic and pointless war over the Falklands.

title: Argentine Junta Issues Curbs for Journalists
description: The Argentine military command released a series of restrictions today that foreign and local journalists are supposed to obey or face the possibility of imprisonment.

title: Another Condor Egg Destroyed in a Fight
description: For the second time in two months, observers watched today as a rare California condor egg was knocked from a cliffside nest. A fight between the prospective condor parents and a raven was blamed for the loss.

title: ARGENTINA STANDING FIRM AT U.N.
description: Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina said today that his country was ''always ready to comply'' with a Security Council resolution calling for a cessation of hostilities with Britain, the withdrawal of Argentine forces from the Falklands and the resolution of the conflict through diplomacy.

title: U.S. CORPORATIONS CONCERNED ABOUT ARGENTINE SUBSIDIARIES
description: As rumblings of anti-American sentiment are heard in Argentina, American businesses with subsidiaries there are growing increasingly concerned about their visibility. Ford, Xerox, Pepsico, Coca-Cola and Goodyear are just a few of the more than 200 American companies that do business there, peppering Argentine cities with American trademarks.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday a $1.9 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply for the latest reporting week, a rise that the markets had expected.

title: LAKERS WIN AND LEAD, 3-0
description: Jamaal Wilkes scored a game-high 26 points and Earvin (Magic) Johnson and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar combined for 45 more as the Los Angeles Lakers beat the Phoenix Suns, 114-106, tonight and took a commanding 3-0 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Giuseppe Garibaldi is frozen forever in Washington Square Park, in bronze, in a most uncomfortable posture of pulling his sword from its scabbard, atop a pedestal pristine with graffiti-resistant white paint.

title: When Politicians Shrink From Politics
description: When three Federal judges decided that New York State needed a special master to redistrict in accordance with the 1980 census, they signaled doubts about the state's capacity to govern itself. Legislative leaders still have until May 10 to prove them wrong; otherwise the court's special master will do for them what they are expected to do for themselves.

title: Decision Deferred On Jailed Haitians
description: A Federal appeals court reserved decision yesterday on whether to overturn a lower court's order to release 53 Haitians held in an immigration detention center in Brooklyn.

title: Queen Mother's Trip
description: Compared with the other members of Britain's peripatetic Royal family, Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, or the ''Queen Mum,'' as she is known, has been something of a stay-at-home of late.

title: ROCK BAND: MISS HENDRYX FINDS BASE
description: Since the breakup of the theatrical pop-soul trio Labelle, Nona Hendryx, the group's chief writer, has pursued an unusually adventurous solo career that has included a pop-oriented album as well as guest appearances with avant-garde rock acts such as the Talking Heads, Material and Defunkt. And with her own band, Zero Cool, last year Miss Hendryx performed an ambitious mixture of funk, new wave and cabaret.

title: BALLET: DANCERS, 'SWAN'
description: The more one sees American Ballet Theater's current production of ''Swan Lake,'' the more incoherent it looks. Since it was re-staged in part last year it has become a hodgepodge of styles and dramatic ambiguity.

title: Washington's Homer Lifts Braves, 1-0
description: Steve Bedrosian and Gene Garber combined on a five-hitter, and Claudell Washington homered tonight to give the Atlanta Braves a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Briefing
description: A Vote Is a Vote Is a Vote

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY HAIG ON FALKLANDS
description: Following is a transcript of remarks by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. at the State Department this morning, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Nuclear Plant Failure Brings Wide Blackout
description: Officials said today that a broken motor at a nuclear generator caused a power failure that cut off electricity to 800,000 customers in south Florida for up to two hours Thursday.

title: Gilder Leads by a Stroke With a 65-132 at Dallas
description: Bob Gilder shot a 65 and moved into a onestroke lead today in the second round of the $350,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: REAGAN ENERGY POLICY
description: In early 1981, United States energy policy changed markedly. Reliance on manipulation of prices and Government regulation was replaced by an emphasis on market response as the best avenue to stable energy supplies, free of undue dependence on foreign sources of petroleum. As a result of these policies, perhaps the only Washington figures more pitiable than the energy lawyers, unemployed in droves, are the energy journalists, now frequently reduced to covering plane crashes and other real-world events rather than reporting administrative shadow-boxing with the ever-elusive ''crisis.''

title: YANKEES OFFERED RICHEST TV PACT
description: The Yankees are on the verge of concluding an agreement in which they will award rights to cable telecasts of their games for more than $100 million, the richest television deal ever negotiated by an individual sports team.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN AND ZAMBIAN MEET IN BUSH COUNTRY
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia ventured to the edge of white-ruled South Africa today and met with Prime Minister P.W. Botha in a mobile home that had been set down in the middle of the African bush across South Africa's border with Botswana.

title: Blush With Pride Wins Kentucky Oaks
description: On the ladies' day before the Kentucky Derby, the grand old gentleman of racing, Bill Shoemaker, rode Blush With Pride to a three-quarter-length victory over Before Dawn today before a record Kentucky Oaks crowd of 52,430 at Churchill Downs.

title: SOVIET NUCLEAR SUPERIORITY DISPUTED
description: Two former Secretaries of Defense told a Senate Committee today that they did not accept President Reagan's assertion that the Soviet Union had nuclear superiority. They strongly urged Mr. Reagan to make greater haste in seeking a resumption of nuclear arms control negotiations.

title:
PATENTS;
Recovery of Solvents In Industrial Painting
description: A means of recovering valuable organic solvents used in industrial painting has been invented by Richard K. Rathmell, a professional engineer in Ramsey, N.J. He was granted patent 4,326,343 for the method and equipment this week.

title: PERRY BEATS YANKS FOR 299TH VICTORY
description: Gaylord Perry of the Seattle Mariners, a 43-year-old peanut farmer two months ago, moved last night to one game of becoming the 15th major league pitcher to win 300 games.

title: Black Cleric Is Banned In South Africa Again
description: The Roman Catholic Church's top official in southern Africa received a three-year banning order today, the day his first five-year order expired, church officials said.

title: Coca-Cola Merger
description: Stockholders of Columbia Pictures Industries approved the planned merger of the company with the Coca-Cola Company.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO RULE OUT A PLAN FOR SANDINIST TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration has ruled out holding negotiations with Nicaragua under guidelines proposed by the Mexican President, Jose Lopez Portillo, according to Nicaraguan diplomats.

title: No Headline
description: Three major oil companies yesterday announced discoveries of natural gas and oil reserves. Mobil Oil Canada said that it had tested gas in four more zones near Sable Island, bringing to 10 the number of zones yielding natural gas in the Venture B-43 well off the coast of Nova Scotia.

title: Video-Game Law Upset in Jersey
description: A community ordinance requiring players of video games to be at least 18 years old has been declared unconstitutional.

title: News Analysis
description: Resolution of the contracts covering 35,000 transit workers clears the way, as it has for years, for the push to negotiate labor agreements for the city's 200,000 municipal workers.

title: TORREZ OF RED SOX ROUTS RANGERS, 7-1
description: Mike Torrez, backed by a 12-hit offense, pitched a four-hitter tonight as he led the Boston Red Sox to a 7-1 victory over Texas. It was the Rangers' seventh straight loss.

title: Claude de France Wed To Arnaldo La Cagnina
description: Claude de France, the Princesse d'Orleans and the daughter of the pretender to the French throne, and Arnaldo La Cagnina, a publisher and former newsman, revealed yesterday that they were married on April 27 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

title: Police Officer Kills Armed Assailant
description: A police officer fatally shot a man who lunged at him yesterday with a knife on a Manhattan street corner, the police said.

title: Expos 4, Dodgers 2
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Al Oliver drove in three runs with a double and a sacrifice fly to back the six-hit pitching of Scott Sanderson and Jeff Reardon for Montreal.

title: News of the Theater; REPRISE OF THE 'WHOREHOUSE' DISPUTE
description: The producer of ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'' said yesterday that she would reopen the musical at the Eugene O'Neill Theater on May 31, using only nine musicians, none of them ''walkers,'' or nonperformers. However, Max Arons, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, said she would not. Mr. Arons said that Stevie Phillips, the producer, was ''bluffing.''

title: De Gustibus; DESPITE DIET CONSCIOUNESS, MENU FAVORITES PERSIST
description: So much is heard about concern with diet and health these days that it is easy to get the impression that American eating habits have undergone radical changes. However, based on a national menu census of 1981 sales of food services taken by the trade magazine Restaurants & Institutions, such concern apparently exists only in the lofty and costly realm of high-fashion dining.

title: SOLIDARITY'S 2D RADIO BROADCAST CUT OFF
description: The Solidarity union made another radio broadcast in the capital tonight but the transmission was interrupted after several minutes just as Zbigniew Bujak, the Warsaw region's fugitive leader, was about to speak.

title: GOLD PRICE GYRATES WIDELY
description: The price of gold was on a roller coaster yesterday, rising in London, plummeting later in New York on a report that the Argentines had agreed to withdraw from the Falklands, and finally recovering somewhat on news that Argentina was still claiming sovereignty.

title: Lendl Rejects Contest on Fine
description: Ivan Lendl said last night he would not challenge the $10,000 fine and membership suspension threatened against him by the Association of Tennis Professionals.

title: Kennesaw, Ga., Delays Gun Ownership Law
description: Residents of Kennesaw have another month to choose their weapons. The City Council has again put off enforcing an ordinance requiring each household to own and maintain a gun.

title: IDEAS COME AND GO BUT THE CHRONICALLY UNEMPLOYED REMAIN
description: For more than 20 years the Federal Government has been engaged in a major effort to equip a growing number of chronically unemployed Americans to find jobs and thus become productive citizens rather than dependents. Just since 1975, the cost in Federal revenues has exceeded $53 billion.

title: FEMINISM PAVED ASTRONAUT'S WAY
description: One day about a year from now, if all goes as planned, the space shuttle Challenger, sister ship to Columbia, will lift off from Cape Canaveral to begin America's seventh shuttle flight.

title: COMING CLEAN IN ISTANBUL: THE WORKS
description: JOSEPH B. TREASTER is a reporter for The New York Times. BY JOSEPH B. TREASTER

title: Rhode Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Ryus Weds Linda S. Edwards In San Francisco
description: Linda Scott Edwards and Peter Rand Ryus were married yesterday in San Francisco. Canon George Foxworth performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Cathedral.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Avinoam Yosselevitch, An Israeli-Born Oboist
description: Avinoam Yosselevitch, an Israeli-born oboist, made his New York recital debut last Sunday in Carnegie Recital Hall with a program that included sonatas by Giuseppe Sammartini and Gordon Jacob and the premiere of Songs for Piano, Oboe and Soprano by Tsipora Yosselevitch, the oboist's sister. Mr. Yosselevitch handled the long expressive lines of the Jacobs sonata with ease and a sure sense of their mood, and was well partnered by the pianist, Kyoko Hashimoto. In the Sammartini his playing was accurate and smooth in rapid passages, and his phrasing in the more sustained movements showed remarkable finesse, if not the last word in feeling.

title: Harvard Crew Wins
description: Harvard toppled Navy's varsity heavyweight crew from the ranks of undefeated Eastern rowing teams in winning the Adams Cup this morning on a calm Severn River.

title: No Headline
description: Reggie Smith, who left the Dodgers as a free agent after the World Series last year and signed a one-year contract with the Giants in February, said he had refused a three-year guaranteed contract with the Yankees.

title: LICENSE IN JEOPARDY
description: AFTER a decadelong legal battle with the Federal Communications Commission, WLIR-FM, the rock music station that broadcasts from Garden City, remains in danger of losing its operating license, accused of transferring control by means of an unlawful lease agreement.

title: Lester Bangs, 33, Rock Critic For Many Publications, Dies
description: Lester Bangs, an influential rock critic who wrote for Rolling Stone, The Village Voice and scores of other magazines and newspapers, died Friday night in his Manhattan apartment. He was 33 years old.

title: THE NEW LOOK IN RHODODENDRONS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- G. David Lewis is professor of plant pathology at Rutgers University. BY G. DAVID LEWIS

title: INDONESIAN ELECTION IS NOT SO DEMOCRATIC AS TO BE IN DOUBT
description: backed Government party, Golangan Karya or Golkar, will win control of the House of Representatives. The Moslemsupported United Development Party and the non-Moslem Indonesian Democratic Party will come in second and third to form the loyal opposition.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES CUT DRUG TRAFFIC
description: A Federal task force assembled to assist Miami in its struggle against narcotics smuggling has apparently reduced the tide to a trickle, at least temporarily, according to leaders of the effort.

title: GARDEN WEEKEND
description: Thames Science Center in New London has planned a garden weekend of flower, vegetable, herb and shrub sales and a talk at 2:30 Saturday by Joan Lee Faust, garden editor of The New York Times, on the subject of ''Trends and Changes in Your Garden.''

title: Susan Clopton, John P. Levine Plan June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dean Howard Clopton of New York and Gallatin, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Marie Clopton, to John Pinsly Levine, son of Marjorie Pinsly Silver of Boston and Harold Eliot Levine of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Vade mecums. Most of the talk you'll hear along Publishers Row these early spring days strikes a gloomy note - about important houses that are up for sale, about talented editors, promotion and sales people who are out of work, about the ''none-too-good'' business being done by many bookstores across the country. If you're looking for smiling faces, you're most likely to find them in the section of the Row that's home to the people who create and distribute travel guides.

title: WOMEN AND SCIENCE FICTION
description: LAST fall science fiction writers and fans attending the World Science Fiction Convention in Denver awarded Joan Vinge the Hugo for her novel ''The Snow Queen.'' Suzy McKee Charnas won the 1981 Nebula, sponsored by the Science Fiction Writers of America, for her novel ''The Vampire Tapestries.'' That women won these awards, which are the Pulitzers and American Book Awards of the thriving science fiction community, bolsters a claim made by Alexei and Cory Panshin in ''Expanded Universe,'' a collection of critical essays about the genre: For the six or seven major male science fiction writers who emerged during the 70's, there are at least 15 or 20 women. ''The best writers are the women,'' declares Harlan Ellison, the controversial writer and editor of ''Dangerous Visions,'' a multivolume anthology of science fiction.

title: J.C. Keith Fiance Of Dita J. Dantine
description: Announcement has been made by Nicola Schenck Dantine and Helmut Dantine, both of Beverly Hills, Calif., of the engagement of their daughter, Dita Joanne Dantine, to Jonathon Chilton Keith, son of Jocelyn Freer Keith of Bethesda, Md., and Norman Clinton Keith of Mill Neck, L.I.

title: Mary Palmer Married To Philip M. Hammett
description: Mary Jane Dowd Palmer of Philadelphia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Dowd of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married yesterday to Philip Marriner Hammett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis P. Hammett of Medford, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the bridegroom's home in Philadelphia by Judge Lisa A. Richette of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas.

title: SPRUCE UP - OR ELSE; CHESTER GETS MAD
description: When residents of the Connecticut River Valley village of Chester (pop. 3,140) do spring cleaning, they clean up more than their own 18th-and 19th-century houses. They also make sloppy neighbors clean up yards cluttered with trash and rusty old cars.

title: The Region in Summary; The 'News' Looks Too Good to Sell
description: The New York Daily News may be fit enough to continue printing after all, or so its headline trumpeted yesterday. Its owner, The Tribune Company of Chicago, which had hawked The News for nearly five months, announced that it would not sell.

title: FROM NETTLES TO DANDELIONS, SPRING'S FREE DELIGHTS
description: IN the spring, the Irish have always liked to eat soup made from young nettles because they say it cleans the blood after the sluggish months of winter. Indeed, any soup, salad or vegetable dish made from fresh greens is more than welcome these days, now that the last snow seems to have gone and the price of leafy vegetables is no longer a bad joke.

title: CUTTING THE COST OF A NEW CO-OP
description: AFTER a long winter in which high interest rates kept buyers out of the housing market, renovators of Manhattan cooperatives and condominiums are trying to lure them back with financial inducements that are worth thousands of dollars.

title: Bugle on Derby Day 'Playing Our Song'
description: About six hours before the Kentucky Derby was run today, a bugle sounded at Churchill Downs for the first race and a roar resounded among the early arrivals of the 141,009 people who annually congregate for America's most famous horse race. Hearing the bugle call, one horseplayer smiled at another.

title: Reds' 11 Hits Rout Cards, 10-1
description: Dan Driessen hit his first career grand slam and Mario Soto pitched a five-hitter today for his first victory of the season, leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 10-1 rout of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: YALE IS A HOST TO 2 MEETINGS ABOUT POLITICS
description: Two historically divergent groups met at the Yale Law School the other day to discuss law and politics and how to make a mark on both.

title: 120 EVENTS PLANNED FOR MENTAL HEALTH
description: MORE than 120 free public events will mark this year's observance of Mental Health Month in the county through this month. The theme this year, ''Let's Talk About It,'' underlines the need to open up discussion of mental-health issues and to let county residents know about the extensive network of help and services available to them.

title: EVERYONE LOSES WHEN BORG SITS OUT THE BIG ONES
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council has ruled that all players must play in a minimum of 10 grand prix tournaments in 1982. Because he committed to only seven, Bjorn Borg was told that he would have to play the qualifying in any grand prix event he entered this year - including the French, Wimbledon and United States Open tournaments. Borg has said he won't try to qualify for the French or Wimbledon events. By HARRY HOPMAN

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Hold Back the Dawn' And don't miss this luminous romantic drama of 1941, beautifully written by Billy Wilder and Charles Brackett, and starring Olivia De Havilland, Charles Boyer and Paulette Goddard, none of whom has ever been more appealing. By the way, one of Mr. Wilder's blistering, cynical comedies, ''The Fortune Cookie'' (1966), can be seen Monday at 8 P.M. on Channel 9.

title: A LOST GENERATION OF YOUNG 'GYPSY SCHOLARS'
description: In 1979, Jason Berger collected his Ph.D. in American diplomatic history from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. He was anticipating a career teaching history, which, he says, ''was my love.''

title: Photography View; WHY THE HOLOCAUST DEFIES PICTORIALIZATION
description: Images of and about the holocaust test the limits of our understanding of photographs, just as the fact of the systematic extermination of six million Jews some 40 years ago tests the limits of our understanding of humanity. We seem to need photographs to comprehend the horror. Margaret Bourke-White, arriving in Buchenwald in 1945, wrote to her editors at Life, ''The sights I have just seen are so unbelievable that I don't think I'll believe them myself until I've seen the photographs.'' However, the photographs we have never quite satisfy our need for comprehension; they offer the facts without the motives. They, too, are ''unbelievable.''

title: Citizens Committee Awards $16,499 to Groups in the City
description: An arts program in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn will receive $500 on Tuesday to enable its teen-age dancers to buy costume material for a series of performances this summer.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO GET THE MOST FROM ANNUALS
description: IN last week's comparison of annuals and perennials, we innumerated their strengths and weaknesses. This week we will concentrate on getting the maximum results with annuals.

title: Southwestern Louisiana Is Going Independent
description: Southwestern Louisiana, after 11 years as a member, today withdrew from the Southland Conference during a meeting at Arkansas State.

title: GILDER LEADS BY 3 STROKES
description: Bob Gilder says he is nervous when he is leading golf tournaments, but he insists that even the most experienced winners feel that way. By extending his lead to three strokes in the third round of the Byron Nelson Classic today, Gilder put himself in position for an anxious final round Sunday.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: The only new title on the hard-cover fiction and nonfiction lists is Stephen R. Donaldson's ''The One Tree,'' a science-fiction fantasy about the search by Thomas Covenant for ''the One Tree'' that will save ''the Land.'' Needless to say, ''Covenant and his companions are assailed by powerful forces whose sole purpose is to ensure the failure of their quest.''

title: WALLACE LIKELY TO SEEK FOURTH TERM AS GOVERNOR
description: George C. Wallace, who first ran for the governorship of Alabama 24 years ago and served three terms as Governor, will formally announce that he will seek a fourth term on May 22 at a barbecue picnic here, an aide said today.

title: Around the World; Angola Reports Promise Of Soviet Military Aid
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Leonid F. Ilyichev of the Soviet Union has promised Angola the military aid it needs, the official Angolan press agency reported today.

title: MANY NATIONS ADOPTING INFANT-FORMULA CODE
description: The 35th World Health Assembly convenes in Geneva this week, and the director general of the United Nations agency will be reporting on international compliance with its voluntary code banning promotion of infant formula.

title: Turkey Hangs a Terrorist
description: Cengiz Baktemur, 21 years old, a rightist terrorist convicted of assassinating a political rival, was hanged today in eastern Turkey, officials announced.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS DEMOCRATIC RECORD ON THE BUDGET
description: President Reagan, opening the World's Fair here with an attack on the Democratic leadership in Congress, appealed today for public support to ''protect the people's tax cut'' and balance the Federal budget with new spending cuts.

title: The World in Summary; Egypt Gains More Than Sinai
description: It was as though Cairo had completed a rite of passage in regaining Sinai from Israel. Influential Arab nations gave grudging but definite signs last week that they were willing to accept Egypt back into the fold.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO GET THE MOST FROM ANNUALS
description: IN last week's comparison of annuals and perennials, we innumerated their strengths and weaknesses. This week we will concentrate on getting the maximum results with annuals.

title: PANEL TO CONTINUE RACIAL MONITORING
description: DESPITE the aquittal late last month of a Mount Kisco judge on charges of harassing two black men, a local committee formed to monitor the case has announced that it will not disband.

title: Around the World; Bush, Visiting Australia, Promises Strong Links
description: Vice President Bush said today that President Reagan was determined to maintain strong links with Australia and New Zealand.

title: John Bowman, Miss Gaughan To Wed June 26
description: Shannon Carol Gaughan and John Frederick Bowman, cum laude graduates of Harvard College, plan to be married June 26.The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent M. Gaughan of Hamburg, N.Y., and Singer Island, Fla., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hunter Bowman of White Fish Bay, Wis., and Largo, Fla.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
CHORAL MUSIC
description: With two of the Island's more prominent choral groups taking the stage Saturday, it will be a good weekend for folks who like their vocal music multiplied.

title: Mailbox; The Right to Change Coaches
description: To the Sports Editor: Seton Hall University's method of selecting a basketball coach may deserve a more objective treatment than provided by Ira Berkow in ''Thanks, but No Thanks'' (The New York Times, April 11).

title:
INVESTING;
IN UNCERTAIN TIMES, TRY CONVERTIBLES
description: AFRAID of stocks? Leery of bonds? Consider convertibles. They come i n two models - convertible debentures and convertible preferreds. A nalysts emphasize that not every convertible is an attractive p urchase, but the hybrid securities, with their two-way play, can p rove rewarding.

title: Once Upon A Huntington
description: As a nearly lifelong resident of Halesite, I read with a great deal of civic pride the recent article by Douglas Hill (''Once Upon a Halesite,'' Opinion Page).

title: SANDS CASINO SET TO EXPAND
description: ATLANTIC CITY MOMENTS after the Sands became this resort's seventh licensed hotel-casino last week, its executives announced expansion plans. The license was granted in a unanimous vote by the state's Casino Control Commission, which refused to impose conditions sought by the Division of Gaming Enforcement to insure that the Sands had severed alleged past ties to organized crime.

title: FRESH AIR FUND TO BEGIN ITS 106TH DRIVE TOMORROW
description: For 105 summers, the Fresh Air Fund has provided New York City children with two-week vacations in the country. For many underprivileged youngsters, these vacations offered them their first glimpse of rural life and provided friendships that lasted summer after summer.

title: THE 3 R'S GET A C--FOR COMPUTE
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVER IN THIS wealthy white-collar community of 8,000, kindergarteners who still have trouble buttoning their coats and tying their shoelaces are as handy with microcomputers as they are with wooden building blocks. Here, public-school pupils have gone beyond the three R's and have added a C - for computer literacy.

title: Andree Markoe to Be Wed
description: Frank Markoe Jr., of Far Hills, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Andree Sutherland Markoe, to Charles Winston Simone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Simone of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., and Lyford Cay, Nassau.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Has the Elusive Monopole Been Seen in Stanford?
description: In modern physics, where symmetries abound, the asymmetry between the interrelated forces of electricity and magnetism has been striking. Physicists theorize that magnetism should have negative- and positive-charge units comparable to the basic units of electricity. Indeed, standard theories attempting to unify all the fundamental forces of nature require the existence of such magnetic ''monopoles.'' The problem has been finding them.

title: CASH-SHY ILLINOIS TOWNS SEE PRISON AS ANSWER TO PROBLEM
description: The last time state officials looked for a site for a new corrections facility was five years ago. They found that few towns wanted a prison in their backyard.

title: A FRAIL BREZHNEV AT MAY DAY PARADE
description: Despite obvious frailty, Leonid I. Brezhnev led the Soviet leadership today at May Day ceremonies, remaining on the reviewing stand atop the Lenin Mausoleum for the full 90-minute spectacle on Red Square.

title: BRITONS SHOW GRATITUDE FOR AMERICAN SUPPORT
description: The United States support in the confrontation with Argentina was received in Britain today with enormous gratitude and a sense of relief at the sight of two old allies back in the same corner.

title: EVENTS TO BRIGHTEN SEASON
description: CHRISTOPHER WALKEN, John Kenneth Galbraith, Joyce Carol Oates, the British National Rugby team, 1,100 show riders and horses, and 16 women's college rowing teams will participate in events, seminars and performances that promise to make this Connecticut spring and summer exceptionally bright and lively.

title: Article 100143 -- No Title
description: IN a move that supporters say will affect virtually every aspect of life at Sarah Lawrence College, its board of trustees has announced plans to raise $30 million by 1989.

title: NATO'S ANTITANK WEAPONS AREN'T ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPPORT GROUPS: HELP AND DEBATE
description: THE setting is a living room on the North Shore. Or metal chairs in a borrowed church basement. The people involved, drinking coffee and listening to one another, appear to be friends.

title: Television Week
description: Instant Creativity ''I approach them both the same way,'' said Lesley Ann Warren, speaking in a recent interview about acting for television and acting for theatrical films. The actress will star in the TV-film ''Portrait of a Showgirl,'' on CBS Tuesday at 9 P.M. In it, Miss Warren plays a dancer who abandons her married lover and leaves Broadway for Las Vegas.

title: 'Rosy Future' Predicted For Cable TV in State
description: In ''The Future Lies with Cable TV'' by James Roman (March 7), the author is absolutely correct; the future does lie with cable television. However, the statistics cited are out of date.

title: The World in Summary; The Salvadorans Pick a Moderate
description: They didn't exactly observe Robert's Rules of Order. But after a month of wrangling and under pressure from the military and the Reagan Administration, delegates to El Salvador's Constituent Assembly last week elected a political moderate as interim President.

title: FOUNDATIONS BACK ARMS CONTROL PLEA
description: A number of foundations across the United States, perceiving a growing public anxiety about a nuclear war, are shaping programs in support of arms control.

title: Holly B. Hanes Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eldon C. Hanes of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly B. Hanes, to Henry R. Notle 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolte Jr. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Sound; FINE TUNING REFINED
description: The ancient Greeks assumed that, as an organizing principle of the universe, the sky is filled with music. It is a lovely idea and might not seem unreasonable to modern scientists, who are dealing with harmonies and resonances at the subatomic level in their exploration of quarks, charmed particles, and other such entities of matter. At any rate, what Walter Pater calls ''the condition of music'' might well have some cosmic counterpart independent of human composition.

title: VILAS WILL FACE LENDL
description: Ivan Lendl defeated the veteran Manuel Orantes, 6-4, 6-4, and Guillermo Vilas beat Yannick Noah, 7-6, 6-2, in the semifinals of the $200,000 Madrid Open tennis tournament today.

title: 20-YEAR OLD VIOLINIST LOOKS BACK ON LIFE
description: AT 20 years old, Dylana Jenson can look back on a career as a violin soloist that started about 13 years ago. ''I gave my first performance with an orchestra at Mount St. Mary's College in Los Angeles with my music teacher conducting.'' Since then, she has studied with Nathan Milstein for five consecutive summers and has won the silver medal at the Tschaikovsky Competition in Moscow. Her performance with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall was described by one New York music critic as ''phenomenal.''

title: REAGAN SAYS BRITAIN'S MOVE CAME AS COMPLETE SURPRISE
description: President Reagan said today that the British air attack on the Argentine-held Falkland Islands came as a complete surprise to the United States.

title: Illinois Bank Is Closed For 'Significant Losses'
description: The Coles County National Bank was declared insolvent today and the Eagle Bank and Trust Company of Charleston took it over.

title: COLLECTING CANS TO FIGHT CANCER
description: WHEN John Mullen of Stamford was 13 years old, his cousin Jackie, also 13, died of cancer. That was his first encounter with what he calls ''that disgusting disease.''

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has sent letters to 3,000 generators of hazardous wastes in New Jersey to find out more about what had been dumped at the defunct Lone Pine Landfill in Freehold Township and who might have dumped it.

title: Washington; 'THE LONG HOT SUMMER'
description: In Washington, D.C., unemployment is measured in statistics and percentages. Here in Arizona, where the summers are long and hot, it is measured these days by the number of teen-agers who are likely to be out of work and out on the streets.

title: SOVIET EMIGRATION: THE PENALTY FOR ASKING
description: To the Editor:

title: DISINCENTIVES TO WORKING
description: JOBS! That is the political battle cry as the recession sends the unemployment rate toward 10 percent. The current New Jersey reality is a tax structure that makes job creation very costly and an unemployment-compensation program that makes not working more profitable than honest labor.

title: PROFITING FROM AN UNSIGNED SEA TREATY
description: When Libyan planes next challenge American Navy aircraft in the Gulf of Sidra, the United States can remind Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi that last week his Government approved a new international treaty governing the seas and the air above them. Among some 320 articles and eight annexes, the so-called Law of the Sea will permit pilots of any nation to fly within 12 miles of Libya's coast, deep inside the gulf where Mr. Qaddafi lost two planes last summer.

title: Marie H. Collion To Wed in August
description: Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Andre Collion of Maison Forestiere Valnaveys-le-Haut, France, of the engagement of their daughter, Marie Helene Collion, to John W. Sutter, son of Dr. James T. Sutter of New York and Constance O'Connor of Setauket, L.I., and Le Bar-sur-Loup, France.

title: The World in Summary; Schmidt's New Faces of 1982
description: West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt dealt himself a new hand last week in a bid to improve his Government's political fortunes. Faced with the highest unemployment in 29 years, a public approval rating of 34 percent and an increasingly fractious party coalition, he announced a Cabinet shakeup.

title: RESIDENTIAL BUILDERS SHIFT TO ROW HOMES
description: IN marked contrast to previous decades, when the building of single-family houses on separate lots dominated residential construction in Connecticut, there has been a shift toward row or town houses.

title: ARMY MAY TRAVEL ON ITS SNEAKERS
description: Army recruits may one day wear sneakers of the same style as those worn by the Russian Olympic basketball team. The decision depends on tests under way at this Infantry post.

title: Bathtubs
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; RIGHTING A WRONG
description: In most of the major bridge-playing countries, the national team draws on a relatively small pool of players. This is not true in North America, which often sends a totally fresh team to battle, as it did in 1981. One reason is the wealth of talent ; Another is the relatively short qualifying period of one year which sometimes produces a surprise result.

title: JOGGING
