description: To the Editor: Dismayed by your letter-writer's attack upon an enterprising, innocent young woman who wishes to jog while in Europe, I would like to say that joggers are a superior breed who believe in cultivating both mind and body, and far from being monomaniacs, are generally interested in 147 or more aspects of life.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE SEX CONTRACT The Evolution of Human Behavior. By Helen E. Fisher. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $13.50.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
PEACE CENTER
description: The State University at Stony Brook calls its new Arms Control, Disarmament and Peace Studies Resource Center ''the Peace Center'' for short, and this week it will be abuzz with talks: Tuesday, when Seymour Melman, an industrial engineering professor at Columbia University, examines ''The United States and Soviet Plans to Reverse the Arms Race,'' and Thursday, when Richard Garwin of the International Business Machines Corporation, who co-designed the MX missile system plans, discusses ''Nuclear Weapons and National Survival.''

title: THE CRISIS IN OUR PRISONS AND WHAT WE CAN DO ABOUT IT
description: KEEPING a campaign promise, Governor Kean is supporting a legislative plan to restore the death penalty in New Jersey. Meanwhile, a more-serious problem for the criminal-justice system - overcrowded prisons - is receiving less attention from Mr. Kean than it deserves.

title: COMMUNITIES SPLIT ON AERIAL SPRAYING
description: A PLAN to spray pesticide from a helicopter over a residential community in Wading River to curb this year's gypsy moth population has pitted neighbor against neighbor in a development known as Woodland Acres, which has large homes on one-acre plots.

title: THE RIGHTS OF MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Paul Applebaum's article is an important discussion of one vital issue related to treatment outcomes. In New Jersey, we are faced with another key concern: Individuals who are admitted to state public psychiatric hospitals are required to be fingerprinted.

title: CLEARINGHOUSE ASSISTS THOSE IN NEED
description: DENVILLE TOWNSHIP ''SOMETIMES, what you need most in the world is a chance to talk to someone who's been there, someone who has gone through what is getting you down or hurting you, or causing someone you love to suffer.''

title: Robin Gottesman Wed To Dr. Richard Levine
description: Robin Illene Gottesman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Gottesman of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday in Livingston, N.J., to Dr. Richard Steven Levine, son of Murray Levine of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Shirley Schuman Levine.

title: The Nation in Summary; Justice at a Measured Pace
description: Reflecting the sensitivity of the case, the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. got under way in Washington last week at something of a slow-motion pace. Most of the week was devoted to a search for jurors who could still somehow be opened-minded, despite the ready availability of graphic recapitulations of that day 13 months ago when Mr. Hinckley shot President Reagan and three other men. Lawyers for Mr. Hinckley have conceded that he pulled the trigger but maintain that he was insane at the time.

title: HAIG AND HIS AIDES KNEW ON APRIL 19 THAT PEACE EFFORTS SEEMED DOOMED
description: For Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., the moment when he and his aides realized that his diplomatic efforts to resolve the Falkland Islands crisis would probably fail occurred in the early evening of April 19.

title: THE RIGHTS OF MENTAL PATIENTS
description: A determination of ''mental illness'' must, at least initially, be psychiatric. However, the term mental illness is a legal fiction. It is no longer used by most medical professionals.

title: Phyllis Yale Engaged to S. Tucker Taft
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Yale of Mount Vernon, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Phyllis Robin Yale, to S. Tucker Taft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seth C. Taft of Cleveland.

title: Sierra Club Election
description: Denny Shaffer, a businessman from Fayetteville, N.C., has been elected president of the Sierra Club, the nation's largest environmentalist group, replacing Joe Fontaine of Tehachapi. Michele Perrault of Lafayette, N.C., an activist on coastal protection and land use issues, was named vice president.

title: RATE TIGHTEN THEIR GRIP
description: Despite recent upward pressure on key short-term interest rates, the prime lending rate remained remarkably stable. Since last December, the prime rate has fluctuated between 15 3/4 and 16 3/4 percent, the longest period of relative stability it has experienced since early 1980.

title: ODDS AND ENDS BY GORE VIDAL
description: THE SECOND AMERICAN REVOLUTION And Other Essays, (1976-82). By Gore Vidal. 278 pp. New York: Random House. $15.

title: HEBREW TABERNACLE MARKING 75TH ANNIVERSARY
description: The Hebrew Tabernacle of Washington Heights will celebrate its 75th anniversary tonight at a dinner for 450 guests in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel.

title: WHEN A GREAT ROLE IS PASSED ALONG
description: The great performances of our theatrical past stand out like meteor trails in the night sky, fiery arcs of passion and artistry that retain their glow across the decades. One of the brightest performances ever to light up Broadway was that of Judith Anderson in ''Medea,'' of which Brooks Atkinson wrote in 1947: ''It would be useless now for anyone else to attempt the part. Using a new text by Robinson Jeffers, she set a landmark in the theater ....''

title: THE RIGHTS OF MENTAL PATIENTS
description: Over a period of years (as both an inpatient and outpatient), I was given antipsychotics such as Thorazine, Stelazine and Mellaril, all of which quickly produced unreasoning terror and uncontrollable body tremors; antidepressants such as Tofranil and Elavil which simply made me drowsy, and antianxiety drugs which were helpful for short periods. I have also had two doctors who felt I should not be given any drugs.

title: LEAVE EMOTION OUT OF THE ABORTION DEBATE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CAUTIOUS ROAD TO VOCAL STARDOM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark Steinbrink writes frequently about music and musicians. BY MARK STEINBRINK

title: LONGSHOT PASS THE TAB TAKES CARTER HANDICAP
description: Leopoldo Villareal's Pass the Tab, who had not reached the winners' circle since last October, showed lots of closing speed yesterday in scoring an upset victory in the $86,860 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Monitoring Radioactivity

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: DRBORAH DAUM ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Daum Jr. of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Leah Daum, to Charles Frederick Apoldo, son of Mrs. Mildred Apoldo of Arlington, Va., and the late John J. Apoldo.

title: A LIGHT THAT KEEPS SHINING
description: AS spring spreads through the land, it gets easier to rise in darkness occasionally and hurry outdoors, to plunge headlong into the first rays of dawn. One may even succumb to an impulse to pirouette and turn cartwheels, not caring a fig for how it strikes possible gapers. ''I was born in the Morning of the World, and I know what Morning is!'' I exult. The only line of Sandburg's that's ever thrilled me.

title: LET PUBLIC COMPETE PRIVATELY
description: A SHORT while ago my car broke down with a projected repair bill of $600. Since the car was almost six years old, I began to explore whether it was worth fixing or whether I should buy a new car. After a great deal of figuring the ''book value'' versus the ''trade-in value,'' projected future repairs, energy costs and comparing these costs with a variety of new cars, I ended up buying a new car.

title: WHEN KILLING THE KILLERS 'RE-CIVILIZES'
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HORSE-DRAWN TRAVEL
description: On Saturday, the Museums at Stony Brook take the carriage collection out for its annual airing, inviting the public to hitch a ride on wagons, carts and other horse-drawn vehicles.

title: Dancers for Disarmament
description: Dancers who perform with Alvin Ailey, Merce Cunningham and Twyla Tharp will be among those teaching master dance classes next Saturday and May 22 for the benefit of Dancers for Disarmament.

title: SAN DIEGO SUFFERING FROM GLOBAL TUNA GLUT
description: As the super seiners sit idle with their 1,200-ton loads of frozen tuna, waiting for weeks to unload, fishermen talk bitterly of ''those fish buyers.''

title: 30,000 POLES DEFY ARMY IN WARSAW IN MAY DAY MARCH
description: Chanting ''We want freedom!'' ''Release Lech Walesa!'' and ''Down with the junta!'' a throng of about 30,000 marched through Warsaw's Old Town today to show support for the suspended Solidarity union and opposition to military rule.

title: Aged Parents Seeking Son Missing Since 1977
description: Our son, William J.Gangwish, lived in East Brunswick and worked for Colgate-Palmolive at its research center in Piscataway. He attended a company meeting at the University Club in New York City on Dec. 7, 1977, and, after the meeting, gave a co-worker a ride to Ninth Avenue and 42d Street, where the co-worker got out of our son's car.

title: HERO IS HONORED AFTER 16-YEAR WAIT
description: DANIELSON THE oldest, John, is 18 now. He knows about Vietnam. His father, Armand Comire, was in and out of military hospitals while John was growing up. Danielle, the other child in the family, is only 4 years old. When she grows up, Mr. Comire had figured, she'll know about Vietnam only from the history books, which he says aren't enough, and the movies, which he doesn't like, and from the scarred story that shrapnel wrote all over him.

title: DOCTORS' REMEDY: PLAYING JAZZ
description: Hello Central, give me Dr. Jazz He's got what it takes, I'll say he has When the world goes wrong and I've got the blues He's the man that makes me get down both my dancin' shoes By LYNNE AMES

title: Janet Boden Wed To C.B. Campbell
description: Janet Matthews Boden, daughter of Janet Titus Boden of Essex, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Brant Campbell, son of Dr. and Mrs. David Marshall Campbell of Minneapolis. The Rev. Brandt Tefft, director of the Brandt Tefft Foundation of East Lansing, Mich., performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Essex.

title:
LONG ISLAND;
DIXIELAND JAZZ
description: Jazz, with a Dixieland beat, is on tap today in a concert to benefit the Nassau Center for the Developmentally Disabled.

title: Susan McCarthy Married to Stephen Worth Bates
description: Susan McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd F. McCarthy of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Worth Bates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Bates of West Hartford, Conn.

title: CENTRAL PARK KITE FESTIVAL SEES HOPES SOAR AND FALL
description: ''Angel, Angel,'' Daniel Morales called out into the mild Central Park air yesterday, ''Angel, don't step on the string.'' Angel Alejandro, at 10 years old the smallest and youngest of the three-man kite consortium, looked like a latter-day Laocoon, tangled in 250 feet of twine. Arthur Hoey, 11, toyed desultorily with their non-flying creation. Above them, the successes of the annual Kite Festival sponsored by City College were specks in the sky above the East Side skyline.

title: LENDL CASE ADDS TO MUDDLE OF PRO TOUR
description: Last Monday, the Women's Tennis Association held a news conference to announce that Virginia Slims would return as the tour sponsor next year on a tidy 30-tournament circuit that would offer more than $10 million in prize money.

title: COMPENDIUM OF CONCERTS
description: VERNON KIDD is a New York actor and writer. By VERNON KIDD

title: AT 12, HE'S LOOKING FORWARD TO JUNE AND A COLLEGE DEGREE
description: A professor of a senior-level college mathematics course says he has had bright young students before, but none like 12-year-old Jay Luo, who is about to become the youngest university graduate in United States history.

title: LETTERS SHOW STRAIN IN ROOSEVELTS' DOMESTIC LIFE
description: Personal letters written between Eleanor Roosevelt and her daughter, Anna, provide fresh evidence about the strains in the domestic life of Franklin Delano Roosevelt while he was Governor and President. Yet the letters also reveal the couple's mutual dependence, tolerance and respect for each other's roles in public life.

title: WORKS OF TWO LESSER-KNOWN PAINTERS DISPLAYED
description: NORWALK MINERVA CHAPMAN and Baekland Roll are names as unfamiliar as they are imposing. However, the current exhibitions by both artists should help to correct the imbalance.

title: STORYTELLING FESTIVAL
description: Connecticut College in New London has put together a statewide Storytelling Festival, to be held from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. Saturday in the Cummings Art Center and other locations on campus. ''Storytelling is not just for children,'' said a spokesman for the festival. ''That is the message we wish to get across.''

title: Military Analysis
description: The air and sea battles that erupted around the Falkland Islands throughout the day indicate that the British will not waste the tactical momentum won by the bombing of the islands' two airfields early this morning.

title: Headliners; Memories, Memories
description: Potter Stewart, who ended a 23-year tenure as a United States Supreme Court Justice 10 months ago, was benched again last week. This time, ''returning to the scene of my earliest crimes,'' he judged the annual Moot Court at his alma mater, Yale Law School. Mr. Stewart, 67 years old, triumphed there himself as a member of the class of 1937 in a case involving a woman wronged in a divorce. The Skull and Bonesman spent two weeks on campus, recalling, among other things, that period of youth when, ''without a life and family of your own, you make friendships you can't make the rest of your lives.''

title: DID MARGIOTTA TRIAL AFFECT ELECTION?
description: STATE Senator Michael J. Tully Jr. began working in Albany last week after a special election victory, but Nassau Republican leaders are still questioning the relative narrowness of the Tully victory and the effect of Joseph M. Margiotta's conviction on the vote.

title: DESIGNS FOR PRIDE IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK THE Architects' Community Design Center, spawned in a cauldron of burning buildings and shattered storefronts, then forced to move from this predominantly black city, has come back to its birthplace in time to celebrate its 10th anniversary.

title: AMY RIEMAN IS AFFIANCED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Francis Rieman of Highlands, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Bernadette Rieman, to Howard Charles Long Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Long of Bellmawr, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: DISEASES AFFLICT DOGWOOD TREES
description: THE dogwood trees are flowering now, but not every owner can look on them with pride this spring. The trees are in trouble; many are sick and others have died.

title: SHOREHAM BATTLE ENTERING A KEY STAGE
description: THE lawyers for all sides are ready, the technical experts have framed their conclusions, and on Tuesday the Long Island Lighting Company will square off against its opponents and try to prove to Federal regulators that its Shoreham nuclear power plant is safe enough to operate.

title: Police Recruit Is Arrested
description: A police recruit was arrested last night after he fought with two uniformed officers who had ordered him out of a closed section of a Times Square movie theater, the police said. They said the recruit - 24-year-old Virgile J. Higgins, a probationary officer enrolled in the police academy - was suspended from the force and charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest. The uniformed officers had been summoned to the Harris Theater, 226 West 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, after Mr. Higgins refused to move from an area closed to patrons, a police spokesman said.

title: UNEXPECTED DIVIDENDS AT A FESTIVAL
description: The New Directors/New Films Festival, sponsored jointly by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Film Department of the Museum of Modern Art, is, each year, a ride on a brand-new roller coaster. Though the selections always include a couple of ringers - films by directors who are not entirely new and unknown, there is, most of the time, no way of knowing in advance of any screening whether or not one's going to be sent into immediate slumber, mildly amused or rocketed into a heightened state of awareness, which is what good films do.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE room is crowded, and Robin Rabinowitz is speaking. A pretty 20-year-old with waist-length hair, an exuberant smile and a neck covered with burns from radiation treatment for Hodgkin's disease, a cancer of the lymph system, she introduces to the group her mother, Sandee Martin.

title:
LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
TWILIGHT WALK
description: With its landscape adorned with the tulips, English daisies, pansies, daffodils, primroses and forget-me-nots that bloom in early May, Old Westbury Gardens is the ideal place to take a stroll these days.

title: Q and A; Rights of the Elderly
description: Question:I have lived in my present apartment for 30 years. The last nine years I have been exempted from rent increases under the senior citizen rent increase exemption. Should the building go co-op, would the landlord or co-op board be able to evict me or, if they could not evict me, force me to pay a higher rent? ... S.K., Manhattan Answer:Under an eviction plan, tenants of rent-controlled and rentstabilized apartments in New York City who are 62 or older on the date the Attorney General accepts the plan for filing, who have lived in the building for more than two years before that date and who have an annual income of less than $50,000 cannot be evicted when their building is converted to a cooperative or condominium. Only one member of the household has to be 62 or older. Because you have a senior-citizen rent-increase exemption, the rent you now pay cannot be increased as long as you continue to qualify for the exemption each year.

title: Two Troopers Sue New York; Poisoning From Spill Charged
description: Two New York State troopers have sued the State Thruway Authority for $5 million each, contending that they were poisoned by chemicals spilled from a tanker truck in an accident caused by poor road maintenance.

title: Goal of $1.4 Million Set In WNET-TV Auction
description: TV, which earned more than $1 million last year auctioning arts and antiques, hopes to raise at least $1.4 million through today in its fifth arts and antiques auction telecast.

title: PAMELA G. FRAME TO BE JUNE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dudley Frame of Holmdel, N.J., and North Falmouth, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Griggs Frame, to James Roy Carlson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Gerald Carlson of Neenah, Wis. A June 5th wedding is planned.

title: GLASS ART EXHIBIT
description: A comprehensive display of contemporary glass art may be seen through June 3 at the Westlake Gallery at 210 East Post Road in White Plains. The staff is well versed on the various techniques of fuming, etching, sandblasting, cutting, slumping, litticino, plateglass construction, electroplating, neon and the uses of blown glass.

title: WHERE WRITERS GO FOR ADVICE
description: PRINCETON KATHARINE CARTER is a 28-year-old writer and editor for The Princeton Packet, a newspaper here. But the most formidable writing challenges she faces are to finish her play and novel.

title: C.W. Post Senior Wins Triple Jump a 4th Time
description: Frank Alston of C.W. Post College today broke his own meet record and won a fourth consecutive gold medal in the Collegiate Track Conference Championship with a leap of 53 feet 51 1/4 inches in the triple jump.

title: ALIVE AND 90 IN THE JUNGLES OF BRAZIL
description: THE PORTAGE TO SAN CRISTOBAL OF A.H. By George Steiner.170 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.50.

title: Liz Claiborne To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Tyler Claiborne Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Warren Claiborne, to Everett Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Recall of Wound Treatment Announced by Drug Agency
description: The Food and Drug Administration has announced the nationwide recall of a powder and gel wound treatment it said was contaminated with a bacterium capable of causing serious injury or death.

title: Wesleyan's New Class Chosen 'Aid-Blind'
description: With a record 4,647 applicants for 650 places in the Class of 1986 entering this fall, Wesleyan this year turned down more highly qualified students than ever before. The reasons are many, but financial need was not one of them. Thus our admissions process was ''aid-blind'' as in the past@ (''Campus Activity Turns to Politics,'' April 18).

title: Susan M. Wey Will Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. James S. Wey of Needham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan M. Wey, to William Colyer Crum, son of Prof. and Mrs. Colyer Crum of Weston, Mass., and Sunapee, N.H.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: INDIAN MUSIC For Ravi Shankar and Ali Akbar Khan to appear together in recital, as they will do Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall, is the North Indian equivalent of, say, Itzhak Perlman and Mstislav Rostropovich doing duets together. The two artists last appeared on the same stage at the Concert for Bangladesh a decade ago, and Wednesday's concert will be recorded.

title: 42 Held in May Day Protest
description: Forty-two demonstrators were arrested today in separate incidents at two city housing projects in protests sponsored by the Revolutionary Communist Party, a radical Maoist group, according to the Atlanta police. About 100 other demonstrators, flanked by police lines and jeering, cursing spectators, later marched without incident to the gates of Fort McPherson, an Army post.

title: Arab Women
description: To the Editor:

title: A BITTER PILL FOR WORLD'S SUGAR TRADE
description: Ever since Congress first imposed a tariff on sugar imports in 1789, the Federal Government, every few years, has acted on this essential commodity and invariably someone has gotten angry.

title: Overseas Press Club Awards
description: The Overseas Press Club last week announced awards for foreign reporting in 1981. The Hal Boyle Award for the best reporting by a daily newspaper or wire service went to David Ottaway of The Washington Post for coverage of the assassination of the Egyptian President, Anwar el-Sadat.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO GET THE MOST FROM ANNUALS
description: IN last week's comparison of annuals and perennials, we innumerated their strengths and weaknesses. This week we will concentrate on getting the maximum results with annuals.

title: WHY JAIL CROWDING IS SO HARD TO CURE
description: HAUPPAUGE WITH Long Islanders demanding tough anticrime measures, the courts have responded by sending more prisoners to jail and for longer periods of time. This has left the Island's aging prison system overcrowded, with no cure in sight, unless additional prison facilities are provided.

title: JOHN GUARE: A DISTANT WAY OF DOING THINGS
description: John Guare is capable of imagining such bizarre and bitterly amusing theatricalized truths that I am at a total loss to account for his apparent determination to make ''Gardenia,'' now being given a trial flight at the Manhattan Theater Club, almost as undramatic as its companion-piece, ''Lydie Breeze,'' done earlier in the season at The American Place. When I speak of Mr. Guare's specifically theatrical qualities, I mean qualities that play better than they read, qualities that make the most of strongly contrasted vocal effects, qualities that reverberate aurally and visually when they appear under appropriate lighting in a playhouse.

title:
LONG ISLAND;
YOUTH AND POPS
description: Cindy Betancourt, an East Northport violist; David Ciolkowski, a Great Neck clarinetist; Willa Henigman, a Long Beach oboist, and Margret Pols, an Albertson violinist, have more in common than just their age (they are high school students) and their dedication to music. They also won this year's Vincent S. Rossitto Scholarships offered by the Long Island Musicians Society.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 7 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 13 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 3 1 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Ray, $14.50.) Book Two in the science fiction series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 4 3 3 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A greedy gang at large in the world of horse-racing and computer programming. 5 4 2 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt two young men. 6 5 3 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way love the same woman. 7 11 13 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer. (Putnam's, $14.95.) A woman caught between the clashing ambitions of two brothers during the springtime of this century. 8 6 24 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord.

title: CARTER ASKS BIPARTISAN EFFORT IN BUDGET CRISIS
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, attracting an overflow crowd to a Democratic fund-raising dinner, said today that this was not the time ''to find fault or throw stones'' over the Reagan Administration's proposed budget for fiscal year 1983.

title: THE NEO-CONSERVATIVE ANGUISH OVER REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: Norman Podhoretz is the editor of Commentary and author, most recently, of ''Why We Were in Vietnam.'' By Norman Podhoretz The night Ronald Reagan was elected President of the United States, I watched the returns in the company of a group of intellectuals who were so jubilant at the news of the mounting landslide that a passing stranger might have taken them for professional Republican Party workers or perhaps for fervent ideological conservatives.

title: Around the Nation; Truckers' Strike Called, But With Little Effect
description: By The Associated Press An Indiana trucker said he had begun leading independent haulers out on strike nationwide at 12:01 A.M. yesterday. But a spot check at truck stops later indicated he had few followers.

title: Zino Wins Photo Finish In the 2,000 Guineas
description: Zino, trained by Francois Boutin of France, won the 2,000 Guineas today, defeating Wind and Wuthering, ridden by Steve Cauthen, in a photo finish.

title:
DEMOGRAPHICS;
THE BOOM NEXT TIME
description: THESE are hardly times that encourage optimistic economic e xpectations. But as we look beyond our immediate troubles, the f uture does seem promising, for we are experiencing major structural c hanges in the age composition of the population which could make fore xtraordinary differences in our economic affairs.

title: PAGE UNFAZED BY CONTROVERSY
description: While rival promoters pursue legal battles that began at the side of his father's deathbed and continued over his grave, Greg Page will calmly enter the ring today with ''Controversy'' printed on the back of his robe. Beneath will be written ''OK,'' a pronouncement that the world may be crazy, but Page won't worry about it.

title: The Nation in Summary; U.S. Job Squads Arrest Aliens by the Hundreds
description: The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service last week did what it could to free up jobs for bona fide Americans, though not everyone appreciated its efforts.

title: Liza Wick, C. H. Rice Will Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Robert Wick of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carlotta Elizabeth Wick, to Christopher Hawkinson Rice, son of Margery Hawkinson Rice of New York and Edward Rice Jr. of Sagaponack, L. I.

title: A SPECIAL CATEGORY: YOUNG AND DISABLED
description: HOWARD GREENE had spent a long day in Philadelphia, holding meetings for the St. Regis Paper Company that went on into the evening. Like most up-and-coming young executives - Mr. Greene was 34 years old - he was torn between staying overnight or driving home.

title: 3 FAMILY FEUDS STIR NEW DELHI AS HEAT SETS IN
description: Hot weather has arrived, and Indians, as usual at this time of year, are moving their wood-framed rope cots, or charpoys, out onto the roofs and lanes in search of breezes and company.

title: Headliners; Parole for Sirhan?
description: Sentenced to death for the murder of Robert Kennedy, Sirhan B. Sirhan went on trial for his freedom last week.

title: GROWING UP IN THE BOMB'S SHADOW
description: NUCLEAR weapons have been in existence for as long as I've been alive, but I didn't always know about them. The nuclear age began for me in 1962, when I was eight years old. That summer my family moved back to the United States after spending two years near London. For me, this meant leaving the placid rural atmosphere of my British school for the seething social awareness of a public school in Westchester County.

title: Future Events Honors All Around
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. A Tribute Luncheon May 5 - Burton M. Tansky, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, will receive the Achievement Award for humanitarianism from the Beauty and Fashion Industries Division of the New York Foundling Hospital/ Center for Parent and Child Development at a luncheon in his honor at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof. Similar events have in the past netted as much as $60,000 for the Foundling Hospital, which serves more than 7,000 needy children and families annually. Tickets, $200 from 879-7979. A Triple-Header May 6 - Joseph Papp, founder of the Public Theater; Clara Hale, who heads Hale House for the treatment of children born to heroinaddicted mothers; and the Rev. M. Moran Weston, rector of St. Philip's Episcopal Church and chairman of the Carver Federal Savings Bank, will be honored at the 17th annual Frederick Douglass Awards Dinner of the New York Urban League for their contributions to the cause of equal opportunity. Tickets for the event, at the Sheraton Center, $125. Proceeds will go to the league's educational program.

title: DAUGHTER OF PLAYBOY
description: Like father, like daughter. Christie Hefner (right) became president last week of Playboy Enterprises.

title: Television Week
description: Type Casting ''In the kind of neighborhood I grew up in New York I used to get the stuffings kicked out of me because I wasn't Irish,'' said Telly Savalas, who was born in Garden City, Long Island, of Greek immigrant parents, and who lived for a while in the Bronx. ''I used to call myself 'Kelly the Greek.'

title: MARYLAND TOWN TO VOTE ON NUCLEAR ARMS BAN
description: Residents of this small suburban town outside Washington will be asked Monday to approve an ordinance forbidding the use of nuclear weapons in, on or over their 123-acre bedroom community, 14 miles northwest of the White House, by declaring it the nation's first nuclear-weapons-free zone.

title: BALLET THEATER: RONALD PERRY AND LISE HOULTON IN 'SPHINX'
description: Glen Tetley's ''Sphinx'' was as enigmatic as ever when it received its first performance of the season by American Ballet Theater on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Set to a concerto by Martinu, for which Howard Barr was piano soloist, and retelling the story of how Oedipus solved the riddle of the Sphinx, it is a ballet based upon a verbal conceit that resists choreographic treatment. Therefore it may be incomprehensible to anyone not already versed in Greek mythology.

title: 'THIS IS THE WAY SHE IS'
description: THIS year, for the first time in almost two decades of teaching, I am teaching a class of six autistic children. There is a full-time aide with me who works very hard and is caring and concerned about the children. She has one quality you don't learn in school and can't get from books. It is the invaluable quality of good common sense.

title: The World in Summary; Talking Is Also Allowed
description: The Reagan Administration's policy toward the Russians has often seemed long on tough-sounding one-liners and short on a conceptual framework. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. tried to correct that imbalance last week in a speech that called for combining an American military buildup with a readiness to negotiate arms limitation.

title: THE RIGHTS OF MENTAL PATIENTS
description: As I see it, the various right-to-refuse-treatment cases are most constructively viewed not as statements of what Rubie Rogers et al. do not want, but, rather, as statements of what they do want; and they want nothing more than what we all want: validation, understanding and respect. L.A. FROST Cambridge, Mass.

title: TV View; ANN JILLIAN DELIVVERS A FRESH PORTRAIT OF MAE WEST
description: If nothing else, television biographies are remarkable for their sheer variety. Golda Meir, as portrayed by Ingrid Bergman, is the subject of one production currently in circulation (the second half will be broadcast locally on WPIX-TV tomorrow evening at 8). In a couple of weeks, NBC will devote 10 hours to Marco Polo and his travels in the 13th century. And tonight at 9, ABC is offering ''Mae West,'' described by the network as the story of an actress ''who built her stardom on sex, yet struggled to find fulfillment with the one man she truly loved.''

title: WOULD WAR WITH GAS MEAN HOLOCAUST?
description: SHOULD the United States produce new binary chemical weapons? The question is scheduled for debate in the Senate this week when Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, holds hearings in the Appropriations Committee and amendments to the Pentagon's authorization bill are offered on the floor. The Administration would like a go-ahead, and has asked for $32 million to develop the new munitions, which consist of two nonlethal components that are packaged separately and combine to form a toxic agent only after a shell or bomb is in flight. The amount is relatively small as military budget/ go. But the question itself is highly charged. The Week in Review asked Maj. Gen. Niles J. Fulwyler, director of the Nuclear and Chemical Directorate, Department of the Army, and Matthew Meselson, professor of biochemistry at Harvard University, to talk about the pros and cons. Excerpts of their discussion with Richard Halloran, a correspondent in The Times's Washington bureau, and Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Review, follow.

title: THE 'R' RATING-A LURE OR A BARRIER
description: It was a typical Saturday afternoon at the movies. On Manhattan's East Side, youngsters were flocking to ''Porky's,'' ''Cat People,'' ''Quest for Fire,'' and two Richard Pryor films, ''Live on the Sunset Strip'' and ''Some Kind of Hero.''

title: The Nation in Summary; Voting Rights Stuck in Senate
description: Far from breezing to passage as had been widely predicted, an extension of a landmark of the progress of the 1960's is having trouble just geting out of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: A COMPETITOR; EIGHTY YEARS AFTER
description: For its 80th birthday this year, the Flatiron Building, once the soaring symbol of New York's pre-eminence, is getting a new neighbor, a 30-story apartment house that will compete with the tower's prowlike domination of Madison Square's southern skyline.

title: COMMUNITIES GARDENS SPROUTING AROUND STATE
description: With hoe and rake, trowel and seed, and perhaps a trusty green thumb, too, Connecticut residents have been signing up in record numbers over l the last few weeks to grow their own vegetables in a community garden.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: BASIS FOR U.S. ACTION IS CITED
description: The legal basis of United States support for Britain in the dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands was touched upon though not spelled out Friday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. But legal experts said that international law appeared to justify the action.

title: Small Loans
description: To the Busiess Editor: Regarding ''How the Banks Are Squeezing Small Business'' (April 25), the reports of large losses by banks in servicing loans to small businesses may be greatly exaggerated.

title: DEMOCRATS TURN SENATE PRIMARY INTO FREE-FOR-ALL
description: TRENTON WHILE the Republican primary for the United States Senate remains the virtual head-to-head contest it has been from the start, the Democratic campaign has become the type of free-for-all that last year's primary contests for Governor turned into.

title: Antiques View; A RANGE OF OLD STOVES
description: Cast-iron stoves - outmoded artifacts that were banished from the nation's living rooms with the introduction of central heating at the turn of the century - are back in the spotlight. A decade ago the energy crisis resulted in these heaters being reevaluated and reinstalled in homes across the land. Modern versions of the Franklin, Shaker, parlor and pot-bellied designs became fashionable fixtures in American interiors. And period examples were studied and collected by those who admire the architectural revival styles that shaped them in the 19th century.

title: CONSISTENT QUALITY IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD IN the restaurant business, where whim, skills, foibles and personnel changes play havoc with quality control, it is a pleasure to find a few constants. One such is La Bretagne in Stamford, which has maintained consistently high performance in food and service for the past six years.

title: 4 DIE AS PLANE HITS OFF-CAMPUS HOUSE
description: A small private plane crashed today into a building housing students at Bowling Green State University and burst into flame, killing four persons aboard the aircraft, officials said.

title: Janet Steinmayer Is Married to Victor Guaglianone
description: Janet Lee Steinmayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alwin G. Steinmayer Jr. of Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to Victor Francis Guaglianone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor J. Guaglianone of Castro Valley, Calif. The ceremony was performed in Old St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., by the Rev. Richard W. Hess.

title: TOWN WITHOUT A POLICE FORCE REJECTS PROPOSAL FOR 4TH YEAR
description: Police officers are a waste of money, say the residents of this rural town of 4,500 people, where the only law officer is a part-time elected sergeant who carries no gun and has nothing to do with criminals.

title: Sports People; Runners' Wedding
description: If all goes as planned, one pair of competitors in today's Trevira Twosome 10-mile race in Central Park -Neil Cookrish and Pamela Kekich of New York - will be married at the finish line. Heading the field of the race, in which the winners are determined by the couple with the fastest combined time, are Frank Shorter, the 1972 Olympic marathon champion, and Kiki Sweigart, who finished fourth in the recent Boston Marathon. About 1,500 couples are expected to answer the starting gun at 10:30 A.M.

title: SHIPS REPORTED HIT
description: The Argentine military command said Saturday night that its forces had repelled repeated British bombing runs on the Falkland Islands and damaged three British ships.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: ART Watercolor is traditionally the province of the amateur painter. People who wouldn't dream of coming home with oil paints and canvas are perfectly happy to get out into the countryside and splash away with watercolor and a fine thin brush.

title: BETTER WAY TO FIGURE SOCIAL SECURITY RAISES
description: To the Editor:

title: BACKSTAGE WITH BALANCHINE
description: The atmosphere is at once frantic and calm. Will the New York City Ballet be ready in time for its Tuesday opening at the New York State Theater? Rehearsal space is catch as catch can until the New York City Opera finishes its season. The dancers are off on Mondays, so City Ballet won't hold its first stage rehearsal until the morning of opening day. With a Stravinsky Festival in mid-June, there are too many new ballets to rehearse to pay much attention to the repertory. The company draws into itself, an impervious aristocracy, as photographers click their cameras and a reporter scribbles at the fringes of the measured fray. Another season is at hand.

title: INTIMIDATION OF WITNESSES CALLED 'WIDESPREAD'
description: Attempts to intimidate victims and witnesses to keep them from reporting crimes or testifying in court is a ''widespread problem'' and criminal-justice officials are not dealing with it adequately, a study by the New York City Victim Services Agency has found.

title: Three-Master Cruises
description: ''She's a classic,'' says Frederick B. Guild. The speaker, though not a disinterested party, is, nevertheless an authority. ''She'' is Victory Chimes, believed to be the last remaining three-masted schooner on the Atlantic.

title: A PIP OF A PLAY AT THE CROSSROADS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ''ILOVE the land,'' beams Cephus Miles as he revives the mishaps that swept him from a backwoods cranny in North Carolina to a Raleigh prison and then to ''a very, very large city,'' where he met a persnickety welfare worker, a hot tootsy in a satin shawl and the rogues who almost duped him into forgetting his honorable ancestors.

title: Ray Manning Helterline Marries Doren Greenberg
description: Doren Roe Greenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Greenberg of New York and Hyde Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ray Manning Helterline, son of Bickie Helterline of Portland, Ore., and Russell Helterline of Boring, Ore. Justice Harold Birns of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Hyde Park.

title: 2 Children Watch as a Cabby Shoots Wife and Kills Himself
description: A Queens man shot his wife early yesterday, then turned the gun on himself and committed suicide in front of his two children, the police said.

title: State Official Proposes a Cut In Some Milk-Price Supports
description: The state's top agriculture official has suggested that Federal milk-price supports be lowered - but in a way that would favor dairy farmers in New York.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
AUTHOR, AUTHOR
description: Not one but ''two'' novelists will be in the spotlight Friday in the drawing room of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art when the lecturer Sandra Rosencrans interviews her latest Long Island author, Michael Hinkemeyer.

title: U.S. SAYS ARGENTINA CAN MAKE A-BOMB SOON
description: Argentina will soon be able to make its own weapons-grade nuclear material, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: Television Week
description: Bird Watcher The Dance Theater of Harlem has become ubiquitous. Presenting Stravinsky's ''Firebird'' in the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in the nation's capitol, the troupe was filmed by public-television station WQED of Pittsburg and is currently on a West Coast tour.

title: DOGWOODS IN AREA TERMED IN TROUBLE
description: THE dogwood trees are flowering now, but not every owner can look on them with pride this spring. The trees are in trouble; many are sick and others have died.

title: FOLK: KENNY RANKIN'S SONGS
description: Kenny Rankin is a decided change of pace for Marty's, where the singers, backed by small instrumental groups, usually sing old pop standards, as Helen O'Connell was doing before Mr. Rankin opened last week, or blues-and-pop standards, as Joe Williams will be doing after Mr. Rankin leaves next Saturday.

title: BOOM, SCHUSS, SURF; Revisiting The Battle Of New Market
description: Through the long, bloody day the battle raged. And when its outcome hung in the balance, Confederate Maj. Gen. John C. Breckinridge asked the forgiveness of God and committed to action 247 cadets from the Virginia Military Institute at Lexington.

title: BOAT OPERATOR BILL INTRODUCED
description: In an effort to curb accidents on increasingly congested New York waterways, two Long Island lawmakers have introduced a bill in the State Legislature that would require the licensing of motorboat operators.

title: Around the World; Mubarak Puts Emphasis On Egypt's Economy
description: Preident Hosni Mubarak said today that Israel's withdrawal from Sinai marked a ''new dawn'' of efforts to raise Egypt's standard of living and correct its balance of payments deficit.

title: David Rockefeller to Get The MacDowell Award
description: David Rockefeller, banker and art collector, will receive an award for ''outstanding contributions to the creative process in America'' from the MacDowell Colony next Tuesday at the Institute of Fine Arts, 1 East 78th Street, at 6 P.M. J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery in Washington, will make the presentation.

title: TAPPING THE HOMOSEXUAL MARKET
description: Major film studios made a hedged bet this season that the healthy, wealthy and-or wise homosexual was a marketable commodity. Paramount Pictures's ''Partners,'' which opened this weekend, is a comedy about two New York cops (one's straight, the other isn't) who pretend to be lovers to solve a murder. It follows: 20th-Century Fox's ''Making Love'' (a doctor leaves his wife for another man); Warner Bros.'s ''Personal Best'' (two female Olympic teammates fall in love) and ''Deathtrap'' (Michael Caine and Christopher Reeve play lovers), and M-G-M/ U.A.'s ''Victor, Victoria,'' in which Julie Andrews finishes off her nun and governess image by playing a woman pretending to be a man who is a female impersonator.

title: SYLVIA FRUMKIN AT CREEDMOOR
description: IS THERE NO PLACE ON EARTH FOR ME? By Susan Sheehan. Foreword by Robert M. Coles. 333 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $14.95.

title: A PREVIEW OF NEXT FALL
description: If the new fall collections for men are any indication, it may finally be impossible for even the most conservative among us to purposely wear dull clothing.

title: NOTES: THE RETURN OF LEON FLEISHER
description: Leon Fleisher, the American pianist who - because of a malfunctioning right hand - has been unable to perform the standard piano repertory for the past 17 years, has been announced as the soloist for a performance of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4 with the Baltimore Symphony on Sept. 16.

title: Jane Whitehead Wed in Greenwich
description: Jane Helen Whitehead and Peter Bernard Guenther were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Edward Berger.

title: Miss LeSage Plans Bridal
description: Mrs. Bernard Russell LeSage of Madison, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Nancy Russell LeSage, to William Koerner Hellmuth, son of Mrs. Clarence J. Rhodes of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and Christmas Cove, Me., and the late Theodore N. Hellmuth.

title:
ENVIRONEWS;
Marine Life Exhibit
description: The State Museum in Trenton is preparing an exhibition on marine mammals and reptiles that should be ready next year. So far, it has received the skeletons of an antillean beaked whale and two harbor porpoises.

title: A MEETING OF THE PRINCIPALS BUT NOT OF THE MINDS
description: Representative Richard Bolling spoke for the more charitable of his Democratic colleagues as he replied to President Reagan's version of the collapse of budget negotiations last week. ''I know,'' the chairman of the House Rules Committee said in his party's formal response, ''he was perfectly sincere in what he said. He believes his program is working. And he believes that he hasn't hurt anyone.''

title: THE DAY TAXES CEASE
description: Lower Federal income taxes, decelerating rates of inflation and the recession have combined to produce a rare event. As a result of these factors, Americans this year will finish earning the money to pay their Federal, state and local taxes three days earlier than they did in 1981.

title: MORE HOSPITALS REFUSING EMERGENCY CARDIAC CASES
description: An increasing number of private hospitals in New York City are turning away ambulances carrying heart-attack victims because of overcrowding in emergency rooms or intensive-care units, according to health-care officials.

title:
ENVIRONEWS;
Mrs. Fenwick Endorsed
description: The League of Conservation Voters, a national coalition of environmental organizations that includes the Environmental Defense Fund, the Sierra Club and the Isaak Walton League, has endorsed Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of Bernardsville, for the Republican nomination for United States Senator.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AT its meeting tomorrow, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors is expected to approve a $15 million bond issue for the construction of a new Nassau District Court complex in Hempstead.

title: G.M. Tobin Weds Jeannette Buckley
description: Jeannette Lois Buckley, daughter of Dr. Daniel John Buckley Jr. of Decatur, Ill., and the late Shirley Johnson Buckley, was married yesterday to Gregory Michael Tobin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Joseph Tobin Jr. of Albany and Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Anselm Hufstader, chaplain of the Portsmouth (R.I.) Abbey School, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: TRYING TO HALT THE ARMS RACE
description: IWAS somewhat aware as a child of the atomic bombing of two Japanese cities in 1945 - but mainly I was happy that the war would soon be over. In young adulthood, the Cuban missile crisis stirred fear, but this subsided as our President was praised for his bravery in forcing the Russians to back down. The idea that ''the bomb'' could drop from the skies at any moment hung over me, for sure, but anyone who thought about it too much was assumed to be suffering from ''free-floating anxiety.'' I put it in the back of my mind and went on with my life.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: life L.A. lawyer. THE FATE OF THE EARTH, by Jonathan Schell.

title: GALTIERI'S NEXT WAR MAY BE DOMESTIC
description: For the first time in a century, Argentina's armed forces last week entered a war - and a fragmented and troubled society faced a most uncertain political future.

title: ADULT VILLAGE ENTERS MATURITY
description: THE adult community known as Jefferson Village looms up suddenly as R oute 6 makes a sweeping curve in the northeastern corner of the Towno f Yorktown, in northern Westchester County. The low tan roofs c lustered at varying angles form an unusual pattern on the hillside.

title: Martha Jane Reilly Married
description: Martha Jane Reilly and William Rossiter Hinchman Jr., both officers of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: THE RIGHTS OF MENTAL PATIENTS
description: The Rights of Mental Patients

title: COLUMBIA EVICTS 4 STORES AFTER A POLL
description: Four businesses on Broadway between 115th and 116th Streets are being evicted by their landlord and neighbor, Columbia University, which has decided that a new 4,000-square-foot delicatessen will more effectively fulfill the community's needs.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My husband and I will be in Dublin the last week in July. We expect to follow this with a 10-day bus tour of Ireland. What kind of temperature range can we expect? How do we go about getting tickets for the Abbey Theater? Are slack suits acceptable attire? Are Laundromats commonly found there? - T.K., Mount Holly, Vt. Answer:Simon O'Hanlon of the Irish Tourist Board in New York says that in July temperatures range between 60 and 70 degrees Fahrenheit; the average temperature during July and August is 66, and it goes down to about 50 at night. Intermittent rain comes throughout the year.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN INNSBRUCK
description: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, is a writer who lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: KEY INDICATORS OFF, DIMMING RECOVERY HOPES
description: Key indicators declined in March for the 11th consecutive month. The index of leading economic indicators fell five-tenths of a percent, signaling that the recession is continuing into the second quarter, with recovery prospects pushed well into the summer.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN TAX-FRAUD TRIAL OF REV. MOON
description: The prosecution has rested its case in the tax-fraud trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon after presenting 30 witnesses and approximately 1,000 documents.

title: PHOTO SHOW AT DREW
description: A collection of 30 black-and-white photographs by Jill Freedman, who rode in the back seat of New York City police cars to get pictures for her book ''Street Cops,'' is on exhibit at Drew University in Madison.

title: SCULPTURE IN PRINCETON: ATONE WITH ITS ENVIRONMENT
description: PRINCETON RELATING to art in a museum can be an artificial experience. Art objects that were meant to be seen in villas, palazzi, tombs, churches and elsewhere have been removed from their intended ambience and placed in one foreign to their spirit.

title: MICHAEL ABSATZ TO WED LIZA DEBRA GOLDWASSER
description: Nathan Goldwasser of New York, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Lisa Debra Goldwasser, to Michael Glenn Absatz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour I. Absatz of Plainview, L.I.

title: JANE FONDA'S EXERCISE SALONS AIDING HER HUSBAND'S CANDIDACY
description: Americans have bought enough copies of ''Jane Fonda's Workout Book'' to keep it on the best-seller lists for weeks; every weekday, hundreds of women exercise at ''Jane Fonda Workout'' salons in Beverly Hills, San Francisco and Encino, Calif.

title: U.S. FORGING A NEW CONCEPT FOR CURBING STRATEGIC ARMS
description: The Reagan Administration is developing a new concept for controlling strategic nuclear arms with the goal of reducing the destructive power of Soviet and American intercontinental missiles by 30 to 50 percent, according to officials involved in the policy review.

title: POLYGLOT ARMS: WHY THE WEST'S JOINT EFFORTS ARE IN JEOPARDY
description: BRUSSELS THE British marines were probably unaware of it when they stormed the inhospitable shores of South Georgia last Sunday, but part of their mission's success stemmed from greater cooperation in the design and development of arms among the nations of NATO. But that cooperation was suddenly placed in jeopardy earlier this year when new ''Buy American'' legislation was pushed through the United States Congress.

title: AMY STEINER PLANS BRIDAL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Monroe J. Steiner of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Beth Steiner , to Richard Anders Schafrann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay H. Schafrann of Scarsdale, N.Y. A June weddings is planned. Miss Steiner is a vice president and associate research director of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising Inc. in New York. Her fiance is a lawyer with the firm of Ober, Grimes & Shriver.

title: HIKERS PROTEST; END OF THE TRAIL?
description: Would you rather commune with nature or get to Kennedy Airport faster? Then pick your side in a tug-of-war between the Port Authority and a community group over a 5.4-mile stretch of abandoned railroad track in Queens.

title: NEW YORK ROCK: AN UPDATE
description: Critics and fans discerned and pounced on a ''new wave'' in rock back in the mid-1970's, when a phalanx of new bands came barreling out of CBGB, the long, dark Bowery bar.

title: TELLING TALES FOR FUN
description: WHEN Barbara Reed tells people that she is a storyteller, they frequently say, ''Well, I'm a storyteller, too'' and start to tell her a story, she said.

title: N.H.L. Delays Meeting On Shift of the Rockies
description: The National Hockey League has postponed for a week a board of governors meeting that had been scheduled for tomorrow to deal with the request by the Colorado Rockies to move to Byrne Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey.

title: BASES ARE SHELLED
description: A major air and sea battle erupted around the Falkland Islands Saturday as the conflict between Britain and Argentina over the former British colony turned into open warfare.

title: Sports People; Dailey to Join Pros
description: Quintin Dailey of the University of San Francisco plans to skip his senior year and make himself available to the National Basketball Association college draft June 29. The 21-year-old guard told The San Francisco Chronicle that his decision had nothing to do the charge of sexual assault that is pending against him surrounding an incident with a nursing student last Dec. 21.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: 42, of the Nazis' hardly successful attempt to keep it a secret, and of the reluctance of people in the ''outside world'' - including many Jewish leaders -to believe it when they learned of it. Our reviewer Telford Taylor commented: ''After reading this book, with its proof of how much was known, I am astonished at our state of ignorance then.''

title: FROM CHINA: A 'NIGHTMARE'
description: The following letter, smuggled out of China and received this month, was written by a Chinese citizen whose application for a passport was denied. This prevented him from studying at a university in the United States. The recipient of the letter, who made it available to The New York Times, edited it to prevent the writer from being identified.

title: MAN OF MANY MAPS
description: MONTCLAIR FROM Shell File in Cumberland County to Ho-Ho-Kus in Bergen, New Jersey is filled with unusually named towns, and that's just one more thing about his work that Dr. Robert Wylie Brown enjoys.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ SAY THEY GAIN IN WAR
description: Heavy fighting was reported in the western Iranian province of Khuzistan today, the second day of an offensive by Iran to regain Iraqi-held territory in its oil-producing province at the northern end of the Persian Gulf.

title: Chess; THE OFFBEAT DEFENSE
description: Trying an offbeat defense to surprise your opponent is a two-edged proposition. Presumably you play it after having ascertained that it has not come up in your opponent's published games, but there is no way to be sure about what his homework has covered.

title: Miriam Z. Kramer, Cofounder Of Bookstores in Washington
description: Miriam Z. Kramer, who, with her husband, Sidney, established the Washington bookstore called Sidney Kramer Books, died Friday. She was 70 years old.

title: J..R. West Weds Eileen C. Shields
description: Eileen Catherine Shields, a reporter with the Washington Bureau of CBS News, was married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church, Georgetown, to J. Robinson West, Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Policy, Budget and Administration. Bishop Coadjutor-elect Mellick Belshaw of New Jersey and the Rev. Joseph Doty performed the ceremony.

title: Cubs 5, Braves 1
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Chicago ended a string of 19 scoreless innings and Keith Moreland's fourth-inning single broke a 1-1 tie en route to the victory.

title: About Cars; TURNING HEADS IN TURIN
description: longer perhaps than in America - and despite an inflation rate of 16 percent and an energy crisis that has produced $3-a-gallon gasoline, the automobile is still on its pedestal.

title: William Robert Hansen To Marry Wendy Howes
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oliver P. Howes Jr., of Great Neck, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Griswold Howes, to William Robert Hansen, son of Mrs. Harry John Hansen Jr., of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Mr. Hansen.

title: PLANNING SAFE HALF-LIFE OF RADIOACTIVE WASTES
description: Scientists once contemplated burying toxic nuclear wastes in polar ice caps. Others proposed using rockets to shoot the ominous substances into outer space. On Thursday night, however, the Senate endorsed a less exotic solution. Voting 69 to 9, it approved the National Nuclear Waste Policy Act. The act attempts to establish a plan for developing suitable sites to store, bury and isolate radioactive wastes, some containing materials that will be lethal for 240,000 years.

title: RULING PERMITS WOMAN TO SUE OVER STERILIZATION
description: A panel of appellate judges has ruled that former members of a North Carolina eugenics board can be sued for ordering the sterilization in 1968 of a 13-year-old girl who had been diagnosed as mentally retarded.

title: DR. ANN ELIZABETH BALLEN AFFIANCED TO JUAN AGUILAR
description: Dr. and Mrs. Peter H. Ballen of Old Westbury, L.I., and Caesarea, Israel, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Ann Elizabeth Ballen, to Juan Pedro Aguilar, son of Dr. and Mrs. Juan Aguilar of Milledgeville, Ga.

title: American Lost in Thai Gulf
description: An American oil company worker and a Canadian pilot were among 12 people missing when a helicopter crashed en route to a natural gas production rig in the Gulf of Siam, a provincial police officer said today. He did not identify the men.

title: WINE
description: A MUTUAL GRATIFICATION SOCIETY

title: Water in the Wild Can Be Drinkable
description: IN the dear, dead days beyond recall, many of us who visited wilderness areas scooped our drinking water from the nearest rill and never gave it a second thought.

title: TWINS THROUGH TIME: A WOMAN AND A WALNUT TREE
description: THE summer before my November birth, my parents planted a walnut tree near the driveway of our home in a small Illinois town. For years I watched that tree, recognizing it as my birth partner and comparing its growth to mine. At first, I was taller. Then it overtook and surpassed me, and I recall looking up at the bright green leaves of its young growth.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Holdout Saloon
description: Like a tiny oasis in the great Sahara, Gorman's Tap stood amid an acre of urban-renewal rubble in downtown Peoria, Ill., last September, foiling the grand plans of civic boosters.

title: Saving Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MODERATE REPUBLICANS' DILEMMA ON THE BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON THE spirited scrapping that broke out after the collapse of budget negotiations last week pitted the Reagan Administration against Congressional Democrats. The unhappy group caught awkwardly in the middle are the Congressional Republicans.

title: THERE'S A SONG IN THEIR ART
description: KRONENBOURG Beer commercials have upbeat, waltzy music to connote g ood feeling and Old Europe. Almay Inc.'s new television advertising u ses song and dance to tout Colorplus cosmetics. Domino Sugar has p ut warm, nostalgic music into radio ads meant partly to counter s ugar critics.

title: Town Seeking Nixon Library
description: The City Council has authorized a committee to look into the possibility of having Richard M. Nixon's Presidential library built in this community of 9,400 people. Several cities and schools have expressed reluctance to become the home of the library for Mr. Nixon, who was driven from office in the Watergate scandals. If the citizens' committee finds that the library would not require city funds, it is authorized to offer Baker as a potential site.

title: THE CIVIL WAR AND ELEGANT PARTIES
description: WATCHFIRES By Louis Auchincloss. 348 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: 4 Latin Nations Assail British Raid on Islands
description: At least four Latin American countries tonight deplored the British attack on the Falkland Islands.

title: 4 EX-GOVERNORS DISCUSS THE OFFICE
description: TRENTON HISTORY of a sort came alive here last week, when the state's Governors from 1954 to last January - Robert B.Meyner, Richard J.Hughes, William T.Cahill and Brendan T. Byrne - returned to the State House to mark the publication of a book that salutes the office.

title: Stilton
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PARTY THAT LOST ITS WAY
description: Copyright c 1982 by Theodore H. White This article is excerpted from Theodore H. White's ''America in Search of Itself: The Making of the President, 1956-1980,'' which will be published this month by Harper & Row. A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book. By Theodore H. White By 1980, the Democratic Party as the nation had known it for half a century had collapsed. The Democrats had always happily worked both sides of many streets: They were pragmatic yet idealistic; they were for full employment at home and free trade abroad; they were for peace everywhere and for a bold foreign policy; they were for black and white, for women and youth, for the workingman, the farmer, the small-business man. But now the Democrats were split, as if they hadlost their nerve or sensed a growing loss of public faith in their leadership, in Washington and in community life. And abroad, America had been humiliated by the Moslem tyrant of Iran. All that bound together the interlocking power groups as they approached the election of 1980 was their common belief that the purpose of Government was to govern. But none of their three candidates could agree on how that Government should conduct the affairs of the nation.

title: AN EXCLUSIVE HAVEN FOR FISH
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley. BY R.V.DENENBERG

title: Natasha Pray Married
description: Natasha Boissevain Pray and Frank Richards Ford 3d, both of Greenwich, Conn., were married there yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. J. Russell Maguire.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT is difficult for Fred Friendly, who has achieved fame in television news, in the teaching of journalism and as an activist in First Amendment issues, not to dominate any gathering he attends. As his wife, Ruth, put it last Sunday at a meeting in the Sheraton Plaza Inn in New Rochelle, ''We all come under Fred's gravitational pull.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Picure captions on the Style page last Sunday, with an article about par- ties held before the Kentucky Derby, were transposed. Kay Timmons, Pat de Bary and Leslie Combs 2d were in the picture on the upper right; Peggy Kumble, Juliette Trapp and J.L. Jackson were at the upper left.

title: Nicholas Matthew Mascio Marries Karen Ann Alcorn
description: Karen Ann Alcorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Russell Alcorn of Alexandria, Va., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Matthew Mascio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Edward Mascio of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. James W. McMurtrie performed the ceremony in St. Louis Roman Catholic Church.

title: BEING MOVED? IT PAYS TO NEGOTIATE
description: AS summer approaches, and with it the end of the school year, m illions of Americans will uproot their families and head off for newj obs in new locations.

title: ADVERTISING: SOME BILLBOARDS ARE FULL OF AIR
description: Thought the spread of billboards had finally been halted? Don't count on it. Robert Keith & Company, a six-year-old San Diego firm, makes giant-sized replicas of things.

title: BRITAIN CRITICIZED BY PRESS IN SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union published press commentaries today attacking Britain and the United States over the Falkland Islands dispute but gave no indication of any direct Soviet involvement in the crisis.

title: Sniper Shoots Marine Guard
description: A sniper opened fire on a guard post at the Quantico Marine Corps Base today, critically wounding a sentry, a Marine spokesman said. Maj. James Pendergast said Lance Cpl. James Jaeger of Chicago was listed in critical condition at Potomac Hospital in nearby Woodbridge.

title: POLITICAL LIGHT FALLS ON COUNTY CLERK POST
description: THE post of County Clerk, a $50,000-a-year job, is little known to most Westchester voters although they use its services regularly in obtaining automobile registrations, records, permits and other documents. That level of visibility may change this year.

title: FAIR'S ENERGY MESSAGE FOCUSES ON FADED CRISIS
description: Just when it seemed that it was safe to go back to the filling station, a reminder of the energy crisis have reappeared.

title: CUT IN MEAT PRICES A BLOW FOR FARMS
description: New York farmers sold more meat animals and wool last year than they did in 1980, but lower prices pushed their receipts from sales down sharply, according to new state figures.

title: LEARNING HOW TO RELAX WITHOUT GUILT
description: WHY do I always feel guilty when I'm not doing anything? I mean, what's the big deal? The cat sits around all day and never lifts a paw, yet I feel like a degenerate when I'm idle. Maybe the cat has a better analyst. Who knows. But me, I'm like a kid caught robbing the cookie jar.

title: NEW MUSIC: THREE PREMIERES AT CARNEGIE
description: Three of the six offerings on Friday's American New Music Consortium program at Carnegie Recital Hall were vocal settings, two of which - John Graziano's Three Songs for Voice and Chamber Ensemble and Dinos Constantinides's Reflections I for Soprano and Three Instruments -received their premieres in the performance. Mr. Graziano got little of interest out of the three instruments that made up his chamber ensemble, and his settings were not particularly memorable. The rather speech-like declamation he favored did give the pieces some bite, however, even if the tessitura seemed a bit low for Catherine Rowe, the soprano who sang them. Mr. Constantinides's settings of four rather platitudinous poems by Peggy Bach, also sung by Miss Rowe, incorporated some curious quasi-Baroque sequences and progressions, an occasional atmospheric or madrigalistic touch, and were eminently forgettable.

title: JAPANESE SPOT BRIDGES EAST, WEST; by M.H. Reed
description: ACROSS the Tappan Zee Bridge in Nyack waits Ichi Riki a promising young Japanese restaurant even now worth the traveling to. Its one-star rating, a breath away from two, reflects the average of dishes that were at best excellent and at worst ordinary. John Koshiba, the restaurant's ambitious owner, has spent as much time planning the menu, which offers a good selection of familiar and unusual dishes, as he has creating the authentically rendered, Japanese-style dining room, turning the long, unwieldly rectangle into cleverly divided areas accommodating a sushi counter that seats 10; a row of three semiprivate tatami rooms, each seating eight, and two areas for Western-style dining. Kimono-and-obi-clad waitresses move gracefully throught the rooms.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Flamenco Solo Guitar Performed by Rodrigo
description: A flamenco guitarist who performs under the name Rodrigo appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on April 24, offering 12 selections characteristic of the flamenco solo guitar repertory. The recital was admittedly something of a sampler, conducted in an atmosphere more formal than that of a high-spirited juerga; nonetheless, the playing had immediacy and a high level of technicl sophistication, and generated a fair measure of enthusiasm among the listeners.

title: A TV Failure Was 'No Surprise'
description: Having read the recent article on the demise of Telicommunity on Long Island (''How TV Access Faded Out''), I feel compelled to write that its failure comes as no surprise to me.

title: SEATTLE'S SPACE NEEDLE UNDERGOES A FACE LIFT
description: The 605-foot Space Needle, Seattle's symbol since the 1962 World's Fair, is undergoing some changes. The 20th anniversary of the Space Needle's opening April 24 found workers renovating the Space Needle Restaurant, which revolves at the top of the U.F.O.-shaped structure, to include a second restaurant. But workers are also building a new restaurant at the landmark's 100-foot level.

title: NEW VIEWS ON REGULATION OF STATE UTILITIES
description: THE desired goal of regulation should be to balance the aims of both consumers and the stockholders of the regulated company. Consumers expect adequate service at a fair cost while stockholders expect a reasonable return on their investment. Unfortunately, in Connecticut this balance has not been achieved as stockholders, especially of electric utilities, have been forced to subsidize consumers.

title: YOUTH GROUP FOLLOWS MARINE TRAINING
description: WHEN Lisa Meizies' younger brothers don't stay in line she gives them push-ups to do, makes them wash pots and pans, or brings them to the captain.

title: WOMEN AND MEN AND MORALITY
description: IN A DIFFERENT VOICE Psychological Theory and Women's Development. By Carol Gilligan. 184 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15.

title: HIS FORTE IS MASSIVE SONIC GRANDEUR
description: The stereotype of the ''modern music concert'' is a small, polite group of people assembled in some dingy hall for a program of academically uninteresting, knottily dissonant music. What, then, are we to make of Glenn Branca? His concerts attract hundreds of people, who fill downtown performance spaces and rock clubs for sonic onslaughts generated by massed hordes of electric guitarists.

title: COMMUNICATIONS: A TELEPHONE FOR AIRPLANES
description: Beginning this fall, passengers on twelve major airlines will be able to pick up a telephone and call any place in the continental United States. ''It will be just like a public phone on any street corner,'' said William Gordon, director of network planning for Air-Fone Inc., ''except you'll be 40,000 feet above ground'' - and paying $7.50 for a three-minute call.

title: Music View; ANTHONY TUDOR PROVIDES INSIGHTS INTO HIS WORK
description: ''Inever do a ballet that doesn't concern the bourgeoisie,'' Antony Tudor said casually the other day. Considering the range of Tudor ballets, a statement of this sort might be taken with a grain of salt. Yet it is one of the sharpest clues any choreographer has thrown out about his work. Certainly, it is applicable to ''Pillar of Fire,'' the Tudor landmark that American Ballet Theater will revive on Tuesday.

title: THE STATE OF THE N.F.L.: IT'S STILL WINNING MORE THAN IT LOSES
description: TWO years ago, the National Football League struggled to find a commissioner to replace the late Bert Bell. The owners went through one ballot, five ballots, 10 ballots. A compromise candidate was suggested. Why not Pete Rozelle, the affable general manager of the Los Angeles Rams?

title: WRITER TO VISIT STOCKTON
description: John Barth, who won the National Book Award in 1973 for ''Chimera,'' will be at Stockton State College in Pomona on Tuesday as part of the school's Visiting Writers Series.

title: Sports People; 2 Ex-Saints Testify
description: In an investigation in New Orleans concerning use of cocaine by members of the New Orleans Saints football team, two former Saints, Chuck Muncie and Ricky Ray, testified for more than two hours Friday before a Federal grand jury. The investigation centers on allegations that Mike Strachan, another former running back, sold cocaine to his teammates.

title: D.E.P. FORMULATING NEW APPROACHES
description: TRENTON UNDER a new administration, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has been undergoing a reorganization that has been imposed not only by existing and anticipated cutbacks in Federal financing but also by what officials say has been a desire to streamline the agency's operations and increase its efficiency and responsiveness.

title: TROUBLED ATLANTIC CITY TO CHANGE GOVERNMENT
description: While gamblers flock to this city's nine casinos, residents are preparing to elect a Mayor and Council to deal with severe housing, crime, transportation and other problems, many of which have worsened since the casinos began opening four years ago.

title: 'Out There' for City Children
description: ''It's not like the city,'' wrote Michael. ''You can go swimming in the lake or the creek. You can catch lightning bugs. It's not loud out there, and the country is clean.''

title: YOUNG LIFE OF PROMISE ENDED BY A STABBING IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A 28-year-old computer salesman who was stabbed to death Friday night in Central Park had built a comfortable life for himself on a quiet West Side street, his friends said yesterday.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE TRIBAL INSTINCT
description: There is something whimsical going about the Middle East, where people habitually turn on the radio on the hour because they expect bad news any moment, hearing reports on the Falklands crisis, and considering plaintive new calls for abolition of the nation-state.

title: Cynthia Canellos Wed to David Witter
description: Cynthia Mary Canellos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Canellos of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to David Gordon Witter, son of the late Dean Witter Jr. of New York and the late Faith Atkins Witter. The Rev. Ann Jones performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church.

title: Around the Nation; Michigan Man, Stabbed On Florida Yacht, Dies
description: The president of a Michigan concrete supply concern has died five days after being stabbed by an unknown assailant aboard his yacht in Florida, officials said.

title: SINGING THE PRAISES OF SALZBURG
description: ELISABETH SCHWARZKOPF, the German soprano, is the author of ''On and Off the Record: A Memoir of Walter Legge'' (Scribner's). By ELISABETH SCHWARZKOPF

title: Around the Nation; Man Charged as Spy Is Treated at Hospital
description: A Hungarian native charged with spying has been returned to Georgia for arraignment after undergoing treatment at a Federal hospital in Missouri, officials said today.

title: CHARITIES ASSAIL PLANNED RISE IN 3D CLASS MAIL RATE
description: Buried in the 1983 Federal budget is a proposal to increase by half a cent the postal rates paid by nonprofit organizations, many of which say they may be forced to curtail their fund raising and services severely as a result.

title: Headliners; Make That 'Playperson'
description: Critics may charge that Hugh Hefner made a fortune exploiting women, but last week the founder of Playboy magazine demonstrated that he is willing to put women in the executive suite as well as the centerfold.

title: The Nation in Summary; C.I.A. No. 2 A Technical Man
description: The earth rumbles when a top Central Intelligence Agency job switches hands, even if the agency's demeanor stays mostly the same. President Reagan named an intelligence veteran, John McMahon, to succeed Adm.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Getting On With It

title: Miss Ughetta Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Ughetta 2d of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Elizabeth Ughetta, to Arthur Seymour Thomas 3d, son of Mrs. William Wright of Albany, Ore. and the late Dr. Arthur S. Thomas Jr. of New London, N.H.

title: DREDGING: VIEW FROM CONNECTICUT
description: AMID sighs of relief and howls of protest, the Corps of Engineers, New England Division, has designated an open-water disposal site in Long Island Sound off Stamford. The sighs come from the permit holders in Mamaroneck, N.Y., who have been waiting to receive the goahead to dredge for more than a year. Their relief is also shared by the users of other small, largely recreational ports in Westchester and Fairfield Counties where maintenance dredging is needed to retain port and marina viability.

title: MUTI'S PHILADELPHIA SOUND
description: It may interest Linda Blandford to know that the Philadelphia Orchestra was noted for its string sound long before Eugene Ormandy appeared on the scene.
