This unique tone was, in fact, developed by Leopold Stokowski, Mr. Ormandy's predecessor, through careful experimentation with the seat arrangements of the players.

title: RADIO'S LATEST BOOM: LATE-NIGHT TALK SHOWS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kevin L. Goldman is a freelance writer with a particular interest in broadcasting. By KEVIN L. GOLDMAN

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'All Quiet' The closing scene of Hollywood's filming of Erich Maria Remarque's novel ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' (1930) - it starts as a young German soldier of World War I reaches from a trench to cup a butterfly - will nail you to your seat, if you're not already riveted. Many still consider this old movie the most powerful antiwar drama ever made.

title: Palsy Victim From TV To Get Social Security
description: Larry Ham, a cerebral palsy victim whose case was highlighted on a CBS News program about three persons affected by Reagan Administration budget cuts, has been told his Social Security benefits would be reinstated, Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, said today.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Across the Pacific' In a case of rounding up the usual suspects, Warner Bros. reassembled the leads and director from ''The Maltese Falcon'' - Humphrey Bogart, Mary Astor, Sydney Greenstreet and John Huston - to bring forth ''Across the Pacific'' a year later, in 1942.

title: Bishop Loughlin Wins Title in Sprint Medley
description: Bishop Loughlin had better luck yesterday at the New York Relays than it did last weekend at the Penn Relays.

title: No Headline
description: Frost King, the top Canadian-bred 3-year-old of 1981, scored a two-length victory in his first United States start in the $110,250 National Jockey Club Handicap at Sportsman's Park today. Owned and bred by Ted Smith and Bill Marko, Toronto industrialists, Frost King, a gelding, carried high weight of 127 pounds and completed the mile and an eighth in 1:49 4/5.

title: The Gory Price Of Glorious Veal
description: As a lover of good food, and an admirer of your coverage of it, I feel I must comment on the article, ''What Price the Glory of Veal?'' (by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, March 21) The title brings to mind much more than dollars and cents. The methods used for raising today's ''gourmet'' veal are currently the subject of widespread protests.

title: A STEEL COMPANY FIGHTS FOR ITS LIFE
description: LAST Monday evening, hundreds of steelworkers and members of their families boarded a fleet of buses in the industrial ''downriver'' area here. All night they rode, more than 600 miles, to Washington. There, they demonstrated loudly at the Capitol and the White House, demanding Federal aid for the bankrupt McLouth Steel Corporation.

title: Adelphi Topples Hobart in Lacrosse
description: Adelphi withstood a late surge by Hobart and won its eighth lacrosse game of the season, 14-12, today at Stiles Field.

title: OUTDOOR GEAR FOR MILORD AND LADY
description: DOUGLAS SUTHERLAND is the author of some 30 books. ''The Fourth Man'' is the latest of his books on espionage. By DOUGLAS SUTHERLAND

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS EMPHASIZING UNITY
description: Many of the conservative Democrats who provided President Reagan with his margin of victory in critical economic battles in the House of Representatives last year are indicating that they want to work with their own party leadership to produce a budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: HOTEL TENANTS DEMAND 'RIGHTS'
description: TENANT groups in some of New York's 150 residential hotels are o rganizing to have their buildings reclassified as apartment houses t o gain benefits of rent stabilization that are currently unavailablet o them.

title: The Region in Summary; A Relapse Found At Willowbrook
description: There may be fewer patients at Willowbrook but, a Federal judge ruled last week, the Staten Island center for the retarded seems to have almost as many problems as ever.

title: 'SWEAT SHOP' REPORT BY STATE IS DISPUTED BY APPAREL INDUSTRY
description: Apparel manufacturers in New York City are strongly opposing protective legislation recommended by the State Labor Department as a means of curbing sweatshop abuses in the garment industry.

title: Prisoner, 16, Hangs Himself In an Isolation Cell at L.I. Jail
description: A 16-year-old youth who was awaiting trial on a murder charge hanged himself in an isolation cell at the Nassau County Correctional Center, the police said today.

title: HOLLYWOOD PUTS ITS MONEY ON ANNIE
description: Kenneth Turan is the film critic for California magazine and for National Public Radio's ''All Things Considered.'' By Kenneth Turan On a certain afternoon last spring, in the glittering entrance hall of Shadow Lawn, a 130-room, 19-bath mansion on the New Jersey shore, spraying shaving cream on a dog was the order of the day. After an assistant director shouted, ''Stand by to put foam on!'' the trainer brought his charge to attention, a trio of makeup people aimed and fired cans of Barbasol Beard Buster, and the animal was presented to the director for approval. That gentleman turned in his chair, gave the dog the full benefit of his attention and said with quiet finality, ''Just a little bit of lather on his nose, I think.''

title: GOLF COURSES LURING JAPANESE
description: ROCKLEIGH TWO major languages are spoken at the 27-hole Rockleigh Golf Course here: English and Japanese. Among the weekend golfers who crowd the small coffee shop at sun-up are scores of Japanese-born sportsmen, who have taken to golf the way ducks take to water.

title:
Stamps;
COMMEMORATIVE PAYS TRIBUTE TO HORATIO ALGER
description: It is a measure of Horatio Alger's imprint on America that his name has become part of the language -when we describe a man's life as a ''Horatio Alger story'' no one doubts that the man rose from poverty through virtue and hard work to achieve success and riches and thus realize the American Dream.

title: YANKEES WIN ON SMALLEY SLAM, 5-1
description: Just when the latest failures of the new, speedy Yankees could have caused more rumbling in the pit of George Steinbrenner's stomach, a bad hop ground ball and Roy Smalley's grand slam rescued them from further embarrassment and produced a 5-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: NOT FOR THE FAINT OF APPETITE
description: NEW owners reopened Mona Lisa in Smithtown on the first of January. Despite a fine reputation, the comfortable Italian restaurant tucked into a shopping center had been closed and remained shuttered for a couple of years.

title: BRITISH REPORTERS DESCRIBE NEAR-PERFECT RAID
description: In a series of dramatic late-night dispatches and broadcasts from the carrier Hermes, flagship of the British battle fleet in the South Atlantic, British correspondents sketched a picture of a near-perfect bombing attack against airfields on the Falkland Islands early this morning.

title: THEATER: ROBERT AULETTA'S 'RUNDOWN' AT HARVARD
description: There's so much to admire about the playwright Robert Auletta that one can't help but root for his success. Mr. Auletta, whose work has infrequently been seen in New York, is a daring imagist whose nonlinear plays try to burrow right into the center of the American consciousness. He throws out plot, structure and conventional characterization until he creates a desolate, almost lunar theatrical landscape inhabited by phantasmagoric images and fragmented lives.

title: POMP AND FESTIVITY PREVAIL AS KNOXVILLE OPENS WORLD'S FAIR
description: The 1982 World's Fair opened in the historic East Tennessee hills today with a festival flavor of flags and bands and balloons, prayers and pomp, dances, songs, speeches and the special mountain and country music for which the region is renowned.

title: TURKS AND GREEKS FIND A NEW DISAGREEMENT
description: A couple of hundred farmers from the region of Xanthe in northeastern Greece got on their tractors and began plowing their fields recently in defiance of a court order expropriating their land.

title: ALVIN AILEY TO OPEN WITH ELISA MONTE PREMIERE
description: Elisa Monte can consider herself lucky. Not many young choreographers have their first works taken into the repertory of a major company. But that's what happened last spring when Miss Monte's ''Treading,'' created for a workshop, was produced by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BUDGET cutbacks and contract differences may spell the end for New Jersey's only professional statewide television newscast - at least in its present form. ''New Jersey Nightly News'' has been co-produced by the New Jersey Network and Channel 13 for the last four years, but Channel 13 has halved the funds it is willing to contribute.

title: DELEGATES SEARCH FOCUSES ON TOWNS
description: HARTFORD NEW BRITAIN, Torrington and a few other towns will move into the political spotlight on Tuesday as the scramble for delegates to the Democratic and Republican state nominating conventions in July intensifies.

title: Daniel Flanagan Weds Kristine Johnson
description: Kristine Maxine Johnson, personnel supervisor of the Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Savage Flanagan, a partner in Josephthal Company, stock brokers in New York. Canon Charles Alexander Shreve performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Murray Hill, N.J.

title: ARGENTINE SAYS SECURITY OF THE WORLD IS IN DANGER
description: The British air attack on the airfields of the Falkland Islands caught Buenos Aires on a languid, hot, May Day holiday. On the city's deserted streets, people voiced anxiety and quiet patriotism.

title: Mary McInerney, W.H. Stephens Jr.  Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. McInerney of Greenwich, Conn., and Wianno, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Virginia McInerney, to Willis H. Stephens Jr., son of Republican State Assemblyman Willis H. Stephens and Mrs. Stephens of Brewster and Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: RADIATION FROM 1953 NUCLEAR TEST FELL ON ALBANY
description: Radiation from a 1953 nuclear bomb test in Nevada fell in the Albany area during a rainstorm several days later and in three days exposed residents to as much as 10 times the normal annual dose, very slightly raising their risk of cancer, according to a Federal study.

title: Death Valley
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY'S LARGEST UTILITY STRUCK
description: More than 4,600 employees of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company went on strike at midnight Friday, but workers represented by five of the seven unions at the utility stayed on the job, a company spokesman said today.

title: HOW TO GET GOOD PAY IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON THE scenario would astonish some: The American head of a flourishing British multinational company predicts its biggest source of profits this year will be Britain, where its productivity has risen substantially, while its most stubborn obstacle will be the United States, where demand is being strangled by the current recession.

title: Elizabeth Kenedy Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Ann Kenedy and Karl Swanson, reporters with The Associated Press in New York, were married yesterday in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Robert L. Charlebois performed the ceremony.

title: VIRGINIA DEMOCRATS' SENATE BID IN PERIL
description: A series of political and racial miscues are disrupting the plans of Virginia's long-exiled Democrats to capture the United States Senate seat being vacated by the retirement in next January of Harry F. Byrd Jr.

title: 'Tooth Ferry' Provides Inspiration
description: The article concerning Dr. Stanley Frankel, the dentist who practices in Greenport Harbor on board what was once a menhaden fishing boat (''Dentist's Office a 'Tooth Ferry' ''), inspired the following limerick: A graduate dentist named Billing To practice at sea was quite willing. He acquired a boat, Opened an office afloat, Now he's famous for offshore drilling. HARRY H. KAPLOWITZ Sag Harbor

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Think Electronic, Publishers Urged
description: The American Newspaper Publishers Association was warned last week to prepare for a day when the very notion of a news ''paper'' may be outdated by information transmitted to video screens. ''If you don't get into the business, someone else will,'' said Albert J. Gillen, senior vice president of Knight-Ridder Newspapers, who was one of several speakers to sound the theme at the assocation's meeting in San Francisco.

title: Getting The Message
description: When letters were in vogue 40 years ago and I could afford 2-cent stamps, I went off to college and carried on an extensive correspondence with a dear friend (''Getting the Message,'' Sunday Observer, by Russell Baker, Feb. 28). But as the years went by and postage rates increased and my fingers became quite dexterous at dialing 10-digit numbers, our correspondence waned, and gradually passed out of existence.

title: 43 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Health Department released the names of 43 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. In addition, the department listed three that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and one that was closed for failure to do so.

title: MAGAZINE'S FOCUS: THE HANDICAPPED
description: GUILFORD YOU could say Eugenia Greco has overcome a handicap. For more than two years she battled the odds and risked what others would not attempt.

title: Pilot in 1980 Crash of Vessel Into Bridge Ruled Negligent
description: A Federal district judge has found John Lerro, a former Tampa Bay harbor pilot, negligent in failing to anchor in a storm two years ago, when the ship Summit Venture struck the Sunshine Skyway Bridge, killing 35 motorists.

title: Theater Mailbag; 42D STREET THEATER HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: LAST year, the marching bands at Yale and some other Ivy universities ruffled the feathers of some alumni and neighbors with their halftime shows. Yale hasn't had the problem this year but there are other matters common to the Ivy bands, notably money. Late last month, representatives of the bands convened at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia for the first meeting of an association of Ivy bands, to compare notes.

title: Rising Sun
description: To the Business Editor: William S. Anderson's ''Don't Be Blinded by the Rising Sun'' (April 4), is another apology for American managers. There is truth in the points he makes, but he avoids the most pertinent. Japanese businessmen, while far from being ''a new breed of supermanagers,'' appear to be more than they are because American managers are much less than they once were. Consider the following:

title: DIPLOMACY IS ALSO AT THE MERCY OF EVENTS IN FALKLANDS DISPUTE
description: The world is filled with diplomatic fault-lines - underlying and unresolved problems within or between nations that threaten upheaval at any time. The struggle in the Arab world between modernizers and traditionalists, the border dispute between China and the Soviet Union, Northern Ireland, the Palestinian problem, the division of Germany are examples.

title: BREZHNEV REPLIES TO DOCTORS' UNIT
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, responding to an appeal by an international group of physicians, has said that the Soviet Union is prepared to negotiate ''radical agreements'' on nuclear arms control, it was disclosed here today.

title: IT'S SINGLE PARENTS WHO NEED HELP; BY BARBARA BERGMANN
description: ONE of these days, the nation will have the good sense to address i tself constructively to the problems of the single-parent families i n our midst.

title: RANGERS MANAGING HERDS OF BISON, TO A POINT
description: Yellowstone is no Disneyland. By policy, the Park Service avoids interfering in natural cycles, letting disease, starvation and winter kills in the national park operate to control the balance among the herds of various animals and vegetation.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Dead Cat on a Line

title: John Bunyan Fiance Of Evangeline C. Ames
description: The engagement of Evangeline Carroll Ames to John Albert Bunyan has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Paul Ames of Stamford, Conn., parents of the future bride. Mr. Bunyan is a son of Mrs. Ernest Farley of Darien, Conn., and Richmond, and the late George Humphrey Bunyan. The wedding will take place on June 19.

title: SOME OF THE BEST
description: PRIZE STORIES 1982 The O. Henry Awards. Edited and Introduced by William Abrahams. 321 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $15.95.

title: TALK WITH GEORGE STEINER
description: George Steiner teaches at the University of Geneva, Switzerland, and at Cambridge University, England. His novel, ''The Portage to San Cristobal of A. H.'' has been adapted by Christopher Hampton for the London stage. The following interview was conducted by telephone with Mr. Steiner in Cambridge.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
CRAFTY CELEBRATION
description: The spring fair season gets off to a specialized start today when the Old Village of Great Neck turns its streets into a marketplace for a celebration of crafts. From 11:30 A.M. to 6 P.M., Middle Neck Road from Hicks to Fairview Streets will be the setting for 225 contemporary craftsmen who will display and demonstrate their arts, while musicians, mimes and comedians provide entertainment. Except for what you buy, it's all free.

title:
SEA TO SHINING SEA;
A little over a hundred years ago, the novelist Gustave Flaubert observed that ''our ignorance of history causes us to slander our own times.''
description: He made the statement because people were complaining then about how much worse things were than they used to be. Actually, Flaubert realized, it was the other way around.

title: VISITORS REMEMBER NATION'S FIRST HERO
description: COVENTRY NATHAN HALE was the nation's first hero, although he didn't receive much formal recognition from his countrymen until long after he was hanged by the British in New York in 1776.

title: Around the Nation; Inmates Say Treatment Led to Prison Uprising
description: The way guards treat prisoners and racial tensions between inmates and guards could have prompted a disturbance at Michigan's newest prison, inmates said today.

title: Astros 6, Pirates 3
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Terry Puhl and Jose Cruz homered in Houston's 13-hit attack, and Nolan Ryan got his second victory in a row.

title: Maryon Guthrie Becomes Bride Of Roger Noble
description: Maryon Lee Guthrie, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Claiborne Guthrie 3d of Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Roger Warren Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Barnes Noble of Edwards, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Charles Cowell. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. John Andrew, rector of the St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Headliners; TV Can Look at a King
description: Since 1951, when he abdicated in a swirl of controversy, Leopold III of Belgium has maintained silence on his wartime relationship with Nazi Germany and his role in World War II.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Fourteen Hours' ''Fourteen Hours'' (1951), a colorful and seldom seen New York story, will be broadcast on Thursday at 1:10 A.M. on ABC. It's a teeming, often gripping film embroidery of a true incident.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Emmanuel Quintet Gives Lerdahl Premiere
description: The Emmanuel Wind Quintet arrived at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday night for its formal midtown New York debut with lofty credentials -not only the 1981 chamber-music award co-winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, which presented the concert, but also, individually and collectively, leading musicians on the Boston music scene.

title: Topics Semantics, Acoustics
description: Christening

title: Linda J. Davidson Married
description: Linda J. Davidson of New York and Albert M. Hartig of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Rebecca L. Spencer performed the ceremony. Mrs. Hartig, who is in the sales department of Asarco Inc., is a daughter of John Carl Davidson of Pontiac, Mich., and the late Louie Capling Davidson. Mr. Hartig, a managing partner of Gruntal & Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Hartig of New York. His first wife died.

title: JERSEY INQUIRY CONFIRMS ARSON CAUSED FATAL FIRE
description: Shortly before 1 o'clock this afternoon, Tom McNamara leaned into the controls of his 50-foot diesel-powered crane and began dismantling, wall by wall, the four-story residential hotel in which seven children and five adults died in a fire on Friday.

title: LUXEMBOURG: A QUICK VISIT ISN'T ENOUGH
description: JOHN VINOCUR is chief of The New York Times bureau in Bonn. BY JOHN VINOCUR

title: HOUSE FOR RETARDED DIVIDES WATER MILL
description: WATER MILL TELEPHONE lines are burning and neighbors are dividing here over a proposal by the New York State Department of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities to house eight severely retarded men and women in a $175,000 home on Head of the Pond Road.

title: BEACH MANSIONS AND EROSION: WAVES OF CONTROVERSY
description: EAST HAMPTON EVER since the late 1950's and early 60's, when a group of East Hampton's wealthy oceanfront property owners, their holdings threatened by erosion and storms, joined forces with the Army Corps of Engineers and the state to begin installing a string of beach fortifications in front of their houses, the effects of such structures have been the subject of heated, sometimes bitter debate in this East End resort community.

title: Alberto Training Harder
description: The Cosmos' practice had ended, but Carlos Alberto was still working in preparation for today's game against Jacksonville. ''I practice much harder now than when I was young,'' the 38-yearold Brazilian sweeper said, sweat flowing freely on his forehead and chest. ''When I don't practice, I feel it in the game.''

title: RUSSIAN HELD BY AFGHANS TELLS OF MIG LOSSES
description: A Soviet officer reportedly captured last month by Afghan guerrillas said in an interview arranged by his captors that a Soviet airbase north of Kabul had lost a number of fighter planes in raids by the insurgents.

title: MOST INHABITANTS OF STANLEY HAVE FLED TO THE COUNTRYSIDE
description: Most of the 1,000 civilian residents of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, have fled to remote parts of the countryside, according to people here who have knowledge of the islands.

title: M.T. Vandersall, Laura Mendelson Wed; Wed
description: Laura Miriam Mendelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Mendelson of Northampton, Mass., and Mark Thornton Vandersall, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thornton A. Vandersall of Huntington, L.I., were married yesterday in the Helen Hills Hills Chapel of Smith College in Northampton. The Rev. Vernon B. Vandersall, the bridegroom's grandfather, a retired Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: THE POLITICAL TOUR BY A LOYAL DISSENTER
description: THE PAST HAS ANOTHER PATTERN Memoirs. By George W. Ball. 527 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $19.95.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Boston Study: Back to Basics
description: At a time when critics of the Reagan Administration's education budget cuts are alarmed over long-range consequences, a new study of the future labor markets in Boston has brought a twist to the debate. The report urges Boston schools to emphasize broad and basic skills, on the ground that ''pragmatic'' vocational training may have some very impractical effects.

title: OSSINING, ALBANY AT ODDS OVER PRISON
description: IT was bad enough, in the view of many residents, that Ossining's shorefront had been occupied for a century and a half by a maximumsecurity prison, first known as Sing Sing and now as the Ossining Correctional Facility.

title: C.B. MATTHEWS TO WED PRISCILLA WHITLEY
description: Priscilla Ann Whitley, an actress and radio announcer, and Christopher B. Matthews, sales manager for the book publishing house of Walker & Company, plan to be married June 26 at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Chruch Around the Corner.)

title: SALT II RATIFICATION IS SECURITY NEED NO.1
description: It's time for the Senate to ratify SALT II. Nearly three years after its signing, the treaty remains the most detailed, the most comprehensive, the most carefully negotiated armscontrol agreement yet concluded between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: JOGGING
description: To the Editor: Either anti-jogging letter-writer Olga Ragusa is kidding or she doesn't know what she is missing.

title: HOW TO TELL IF YOURS IS TOO HIGH
description: NO one knows how many tenants in New York City are being charged higher-than-legal rents, but the numberi s thought to be quite large. Sometimes the overcharge is deliberate; sometimes it is the result o f a clerical error caused by complex regulations affecting the rentso f more than a million apartments that are subject to either rent c ontrol or rent stabilization.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO GET THE MOST FROM ANNUALS
description: IN last week's comparison of annuals and perennials, we innumerated their strengths and weaknesses. This week we will concentrate on getting the maximum results with annuals.

title: No Headline
description: Beth Daniel blistered the back nine with five birdies today and took a two-stroke lead over Patty Sheehan going into the final round of the $100,000 Birmingham Classic.

title: THEATER: BRIAN BEDFORD IN 'TARTUFFE'
description: The first words that we hear from Brian Bedford in ''Tartuffe'' are: ''Lay out my hair shirt and my scourge.'' In Simon Gray's colloquialized adaptation, the actor is offstage issuing a matter-of-fact directive to his valet. It is as if he were asking for something as simple as a fresh towel or a glass of water. When he enters, to a background of liturgical music, Mr. Bedford retains that air of calm resolution. He is a willful rather than a maniacal Tartuffe. He is a man very much in control even as he moves from pronounced dyspepsia to a face-broadening, toothy grin of selfappreciation.

title: The Talk of the Yankees
description: For several weeks, rumors have popped in and out of Yankee Stadium that George Steinbrenner was planning to sell the Yankees. Warner Communications, the mushrooming conglomerate that sired the video game

title: Follow-Up on the News; Chewing Nicotine
description: To help American smokers stop smoking, the Dow Chemical Company proposed in December 1980 to fight nicotine with nicotine. The company said it had applied to the Federal Food and Drug Administration for permission to market a nicotine-based chewing gum called Nicorette.

title: Times Columnist Is Honored
description: Flora Lewis, foreign-affairs columnist for The New York Times, has been awarded the first Joe Alex Morris Jr. lectureship and will speak at Harvard University later this month. Miss Lewis, who is based in Paris, will speak on ''America in 1982: How Does It Look From Europe?'' The lectureship was set up in memory of Mr. Morris, a Harvard graduate and longtime Middle East correspondent for The Los Angeles Times who was killed during street fighting in Teheran while covering the Iranian revolution in 1979.

title: SEASON'S FINALE
description: IT has been a resoundingly good musical year in Westchester, with dozens of successful local series, an increasing number of visiting celebrities and much imaginative programming. All these elements will be reflected in some of the season finales that have been scheduled for the next fortnight.

title: Aid to Abused Women Limited to the Married
description: Faced with a cut in Federal financing, New Mexico officials have decided that battered women will not be accepted at state-operated shelters unless they are married.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
All ABOUT BIRDS
description: Everything you ever wanted to know about birds, but never had the opportunity to ask, will be answered in four easy sessions of ''Learning About Birds'' at the Tackapausha Museum and Preserve in Seaford.

title: RECITAL: ARKADY ARONOV
description: Arkady Aronov devoted a full recital at the 92d Street Y Thursday to etudes and etudelike works, and in the process proved himself a pianist of high caliber, with abundant technique and an affinity for the Russian repertory of the 20th century. If, outside this repertory, he did not always exhibit interpretive insight to match his technical skill, he did manage to achieve a level of proficiency in his accounts that made them reasonably satisfying.

title: REMARRIAGE: NEW STRESSES FOR FAMILIES
description: A DIVORCED woman recently married a man with two children, a man she had known as distant kin for 30 years, when she related to him mainly as the husband of her beloved cousin. (Not long ago the cousin died.) ''Primarily I married him because I felt obligated to take care of the kids, whom I love,'' the woman said.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 2, 1982
description: International The British-Argentine dispute over the Falklands turned into warfare as sea and air battles erupted around the islands. The fighting started after British bombers attacked two airfields on the Falklands. Later, British destroyers and frigates bombarded Argentine shore bases from close range, dispatches from the South Atlantic said. The British Broadcasting Corporation reported that fighters ''cartwheeled across the sky in a fierce dogfight'' with Argentine aircraft. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title:
ANTIQUES;
A NEW SPACE AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: TRENTON INADEQUATE exhibition space is a common complaint these days among collectors, including those of antiques, and museums are no exception.

title: THE VIETNAM WAR: WINNING IT AND LOSING IT
description: THE ENDLESS WAR Fifty Years of Struggle in Vietnam. By James Pinckney Harrison. 372 pp. New York: The Free Press/Macmillan. $17.95.

title: The Netherlands
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the April 18 Westchester Journal about Guggenheim Fellowships erred in reporting the number of fellowships awarded earlier to the writer Cynthia Ozick. She received one, in 1968, from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: ZORAN: PARED DOWN
description: Zoran, fashion's ultimate minimalist, closed the current season of fall fashion shows in New York with a low-key, elegant presentation in his Greenwich Village loft. There wasn't an extraneous line in his collection of superluxurious separates that flowed liquidly over the body and were made almost exclusively in black, white and red.

title: NASSAU STUDY VERY POSITIVE ON ECONOMY
description: Nassau County has been ''spared the worst ravages of inflation and been bypassed by the national recession,'' County Executive Francis T. Purcell said in his annual report on the state of the county's economy.

title: Ferne Traeger and Bruce D. Batkin to Be Married
description: Mrs. Peter Rado of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ferne Traeger, to Bruce D. Batkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Batkin of Valley Stream, L. I.

title:
Numismatics;
BRAND SALE TTO OPEN WITH ROMAN, FOREIGN GOLD
description: One of history's most spectacular ''remnant sales'' will get under way in Zurich, Switzerland on July 1 when Sotheby's launches its sale of the last remaining coins from the Virgil M. Brand Collection. Barely five percent of the original Brand Collection is left, but it will still take at least six auctions to disperse this final portion, which includes about 20,000 coins and is worth perhaps $10 million.

title: MARX AS COLLEAGUE AND FATHER
description: KARL MARX FRIEDRICH ENGELS Selected Letters. The Personal Correspondence, 1844-77. Edited by Fritz J. Raddatz. Translated by Ewald Osers. 194 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $13.95.

title: Britain and Argentina Come to Blows
description: Incredibly, Britain and Argentina went to war over the Falkland Islands, a barren archipelago in the South Atlantic that President Reagan last week called ''that little ice-cold bunch of land.''

title: L.I. IS NEAR FOR 'TOO FAR TO GO'
description: WHERE is ''Updike Country?'' Geographically, it's in Ipswich, Mass., close to Cambridge and just across the river from Boston. Cinematically, one can see its semblance in Port Jefferson, Setauket and Stony Brook.

title: Muti's Philadelphia Sound
description: Linda Blandford's profile of Riccardo Muti and the Philadelphia Orchestra was filled with entertaining observations (''The New Philadelphia Sound,'' March 14). However, she might have mentioned an important thing Maestro Muti brings to the podium - a repertory filled with music and musical styles of the 20th century. From a Philadelphian three times over - native, Ann Arbor educated (where the orchestra spends a week each April), and Saratoga resident (where the orchestra spends August as part of the Saratoga Performing Arts summer) - a long life, Riccardo! KENNETH C. ROBERTS JR., Professor of Music, Williams College, Williamstown, Mass.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Rewriting The Codes
description: The ultimate crossword puzzle may be the human gene, where myriad subunits link together to spell out instructions for every biologic function. Scientists are slowly filling in the squares, as evidenced by a recent report in the British journal Nature that researchers had created and transmitted artificial commands to correct defective genetic behavior.

title: 2-BOOK AUTHOR, 20 AT WORK ON HIS THIRD
description: PRINCETON LAST summer, Lawrence O. Graham, a Princeton University junior, recommended to a high school senior a book containing some sound advice on getting into college.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CHELSEA
description: ELSIE LEVY has lived in Chelsea for 25 years, but she considers herself a newcomer compared to many o ther residents. ''That's not really a long time as far as Chelsea isc oncerned,'' she said.

title: Jayne Farrell Married
description: The marriage of Jayne Edna Farrell to William Roger Hasler, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Ardsley, N.Y. The Rev. Benedict J. Groeschl, O.F.M., performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Joanne Gorman Farrell of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and John L. Farrell Jr. of White Plains. Mr. Hasler is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Hasler of Cheshire, Conn.

title: Political Notes; DEMOCRATS CRITICIZE KOCH FOR ENDORSING 4 IN G.O.P.
description: Mayor Koch's endorsement of Republican legislators is becoming more of an issue in the Democratic primary for governor than Koch aides had anticipated.

title: CHURCHILL'S DECEPTIVE STRETCH
description: The stretch at Churchill Downs is deceiving. Coming around the turn, with an open lane in front of him and plenty of horse beneath, a jockey can be forgiven for believing he is about to win the Kentucky Derby.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ/ROCK The soprano saxophonist Steve Lacy and the pianist Mal Waldron don't get to this country very often. They have been expatriates, living and playing jazz in Europe, since the 1960's.

title: FOOD
description: SAUSAGE AND SPICE IN BISCUITS ARE NICE

title: Canucks Set Back Black Hawks, 4-3
description: Stan Smyl scored a breakaway goal in the final period to lead the Vancouver Canucks to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight. The Canucks lead their four-of-seven National Hockey League semifinal series, two games to one.

title: FUGARD TRIES A LIGHTER TOUCH
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Steve Lawson is literary manager of the Williamstown Theater Festival. By STEVE LAWSON

title: GARDENS, NATURE AND ART
description: ''Gardening is so little esteemed in this country,'' complains Eleanor Perenyi in her ''Green Thoughts'' that perhaps we ought to try to dignify this ancient art by reviewing its history and its esthetics with the help of some recent books. As the authors of these volumes might argue, an unexamined garden is not worth growing.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE The recent history of dance in this city has been immeasurably enriched by several small ballet companies - the American Ballet Company, Manhattan Festival Ballet among them - that had a sure sense of character, a large measure of ''integrity and sweetness,'' as one critic put it, and an absorbing curiosity about dance. The Mercury Ballet is such a company, devoted to preserving an important moment in modern ballet's past.

title: MIXING CONCRETE: PROPORTIONS COUNT
description: MIXING concrete for patching an outdoor patio, walk or driveway is a job that can be done by hand or by renting a power-driven mixing machine. The choice will usually depend on the size of the project. If a sizable quantity of concrete is needed, it probably pays to rent a mixing machine; otherwise it is generally simpler (and less expensive) to mix by hand.

title: O'Hare Airport Plans To Kill Its Deer Herd
description: Officials at O'Hare International Airport say it is easier to shoot a herd of deer than move it to keep strays from wandering into the path of departing planes.

title: ICE-CREAM PARLOR IMITATES THE PAST
description: ON one of the coldest days of last winter, two Wilton residents, Care Heeks and Shelley Lawson, opened their first business venture, Scoops. They patterned it after the ice-cream parlors and candy stores of the 1930's and 40's, where customers lined up to buy a homemade confection for a nickel a scoop.

title: PLAY ABOUT WHITMAN
description: The Whole Theater Company of Montclair will present the first performance of a new one-man play, ''Walt Whitman, the Messiah of Mickle Street,'' tomorrow at 8:30 P.M.

title: TYPO
description: One of Wall Street's best known advisory letters is The Outlook, published each week by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. It costs $4 an issue, or $145 a year.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Scott Dudak, a 210-pound fullback who set 13 school records while playing at Gettysburg College, has signed a contract as a free agent with the Philadelphia Eagles. Dudak became the first Bison player to sign with a professional team since Herb Ruby, a quarterback, joined the Washington Redskins as a free agent 12 years ago. ... Nelson Skalbania, the financially troubled owner of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, is facing other monetary problems. Friday, he appeared in a British Columbia Supreme Court in Vancouver to appeal a decision that ordered him to pay $1.1 million to the former owners of Memphis Rogues, a North American Soccer League team that he bought in 1980.

title: BARGAINING FOR THE TV DOLLARS
description: By promising to keep the threat of cable television (and pay-forview television) away until 1987, and by dealing separately with the three major television networks, Commissioner Pete Rozelle was able to extract the remarkable $2 billion package that will ensure a profit for every National Football League club this year.

title: METS DEFEATED BY GIANTS, 6-3
description: The Mets lost to the San Francisco Giants again today, 6-3, prompting Manager George Bamberger to say that he was ''very disappointed'' because his team ''looked like the Keystone Kops.'' Bamberger called for a team meeting before Sunday's doubleheader here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are a people known for dreaming with our eyes open.'' - President Reagan, at the opening of the United States Pavilion at the world's fair in Knoxville, Tenn. (28:5.)

title: CELTICS BEAT BULLETS AND TAKE 2-1 LEAD AS PARISH SCORES 25
description: The Boston Celtics, reigning champions of the National Basketball Association, flexed their muscles today and showed the Washington Bullets just how serious they are about retaining that title.

title: PACKWOOD AND REAGAN BURYING THE HATCHET
description: Senator Bob Packwood and President Reagan are burying their differences in the name of party unity, with Mr. Packwood, an Oregon Republican, promising to maintain a lower profile as the Senate's chief campaign fund-raiser.

title: NOT A BAD GIRL BUT DULL ONE
description: L.A.WOMAN By Eve Babitz. 160 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $13.50.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW ATTEMPT AN OLD STAND
description: CAFE LA CAMPAGNA stands smack in the center of tiny Meyersville's four corners. Formerly Phillipe's, this attractive little Morris County spot was taken over a few months ago by Rita Caruso, an accountant by profession who is now engaged in her first restaurant venture.

title: Camera; NEW CAMERAS AND EQUIPMENT AT ANNUAL SHOW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper.

title: Reagan's 'First Friend'
description: How refreshing to learn from Steven Roberts's article on Paul Laxalt that President Reagan can count on a loyal friend (''Reagan's 'First Friend,' '' March 21)! Loyalty, a virtue that seems to be going out of style these days, is highly esteemed by the Basques. By offering this gift to the President, Senator Laxalt proves to be a true son of his people. Of course, to get this kind of tenacious loyalty from a Basque, you have to earn it, so it says something about the President also. E. DOYAGA Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Music View; CITY OPERA'S SEASON-THE HIGH HOPES WERE ITS SOPRANOS
description: It's that time of year once more when music critics traditionally set aside their other weighty cares to write about the New York City Opera's identity crisis. This topic has been a staple of critical discussion ever since the company's inception in 1944, but has become an obsession with analysts since the City Opera moved from West 55th Street to Lincoln Center in 1966. The original idea was to provide moderate-priced opera for the mythic character that politicians in the euphoric 40's called the Common Man. To a surprising extent, the plan worked, too. However, keeping the democratic flame burning brightly has become increasingly more difficult in the marbled precincts of Lincoln Center. With the comparatively wealthy and socially upscale neighbor, the Metropolitan Opera, only a few yards away across the plaza, the temptation on the City Opera's part has been to try to compete, both artistically and financially, with the grande dame. And the temptation for critics to compare the two companies, almost invariably to the detriment of the one with the smaller budget, has not been resisted. That is hardly fair or sensible.

title: Sharon Leigh Kratz Wed
description: Sharon Leigh Kratz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth K. Kratz Jr. of West Rockhill, Pa., was married yesterday to John Kendall Thornburgh, son of Gov. Richard L. Thornburgh and Mrs. Thornburgh of Harrisburg.

title: Judge Assailing Jeeps' Maker
description: Despite efforts by the American Motors Corporation to keep it sealed, a state district judge is making public copies of an opinion harshly critical of the corporation's assertions that roll-over accidents involving Jeeps are the fault of the drivers.

title:
ENVIRONEWS;
Meeting on Pollution
description: Energy conservation and the treatment of waste water and chemical waste incineration are among the topics on the agenda of the 67th annual conference of the New Jersey Water Pollution Control Commission in Atlantic City May 11-13.

title: THEATER: DOUGLAS TURNER WARD DIRECTS PREMIERE
description: To follow up his triumphant staging of Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play,'' Douglas Turner Ward has migrated north to direct the world premiere of a new drama by the Trinidad-based poet Derek Walcott. It's an unusually ambitious venture. Mr. Walcott's play, ''The Isle Is Full of Noises,'' is a highly populated epic that wishes to summon up the entire history of the Caribbean third world. Mr. Ward's production is a large-scale collaboration of two estimable theatrical troupes - his own Negro Ensemble Company and his host, the Hartford Stage Company.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Banknote Diplomacy

title: No Headline
description: The Senate committee that considered Raymond J. Donovan's confirmation as Secretary of Labor in January 1981 has made public a new set of unsubstantiated allegations passed on to it by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: May 2, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE DAUGHTERS OF KARL MARX: Family Correspondence 1866-98. Commentary and Notes by Olga Meier. 15 THE ENDLESS WAR: Fifty Years of Struggle in Vietnam.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Book Fair Moving To County Center
description: The Vassar Scholarship Book Fair is moving to the County Center in White Plains this year for the first time in 23 years, avoiding the winds, the rains and the leaky tents of the last few fairs in Port Chester. The organizers promise ''50,000 bargains in good used books'' as well as records marked and ready for sale beginning at noon on May 20 and going through the weekend. Each day the sale continues to 8 P.M. Prices will be cut to half the entire last day, May 23.

title: SANITY RULING AIDS HINCKLEY DEFENSE
description: Judge Barrington D. Parker ruled today that to convict John W. Hinckley Jr. of shooting President Reagan and three other men, prosecutors must prove beyond a reasonable doubt that he was sane at the time of the shootings, March 30, 1981.

title: THE POWER AND GLORY
description: It is a fact of life that whereas big museums are admired and prized and respected, small museums are loved. At the thought of the Frick Collection and the Morgan Library in New York, the Phillips Gallery in Washington and the Queen's Gallery in Buckingham Palace, people the world over lift off into dreamland. For these museums, and for their equivalents elsewhere, they feel from the heart in a way that they do not feel for museums that are three city blocks long.

title:
ART;
WHIMSICAL 'STORIES' AT MUSEUM GALLERY
description: ACURIOUS, sometimes whimsical and almost always interesting exhibition is now on view at the Museum Gallery on the second floor of the White Plains Public Library. Entitled ''Stories Your Mother Never Told You,'' it will continue through next Sunday.

title: The Region in Summary; There May Be No Last Laugh On the Budget
description: Outsiders sometimes are amused by the circus-like qualities of politics in Albany, but last week it appeared that the fun was gone from the month-long budget balancing act in the center ring. With negotiations between Governor Carey and Senate Republican leader Warren M. Anderson at a standstill, Mr. Anderson threatened to move this week to override $941 million in gubernatorial budget vetoes.

title:
COMMENT;
CONGRESS: YOU GET WHAT YOU PAY FOR
description: IN business, you should expect to get what you work or pay for, and t o some extent, the same is true in politics. To date, the nation's s mall-business community has been totally ineffective in supporting t he campaigns of those in Congress who support it, and the results a re showing.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
SUMMER RENTALS AT THE SHORE
description: CONVERSIONS of rentals into condominiums will complicate this s eason's search for a place in the sun along the Jersey Shore, where t here has also been a continuing rise in the number of single-family h omes being converted to year-round use.

title: The Region in Summary; A Transit Pact The Quiet Way
description: The Metropolitian Transportation Authority and the transit unions learned the price of labor peace last week when an arbitration panel awarded 35,000 city bus and subway workers wage increases of 20 percent over three years. It will be a while before the cost to riders is clear.

title: The World in Summary; Poles Show True Solidarity On May Day
description: It couldn't have been more appropriate. More than 30,000 people took to the streets of Warsaw yesterday to mark the official workers' holiday by showing support for what they regard as the authentic representative of Polish workers, the Solidarity trade union.

title: Jogging
description: To the Editor:

title: Television Week
description: Walking a Fine Line Mae West, the actress-writer who neither drank nor smoked and who was noted for her sexy personna, double entendres, a liberated life style and unique mannerisims, is now the subject of a television movie, on ABC on Sunday at 9 P.M. Ann Jillian, who first earned major critical notice for her singing, dancing and comedy turns in ''Sugar Babies,'' plays the audacious Brooklyn-born Miss West, who died at 87 in 1980. James Brolin, Piper Laurie and Roddy McDowall are also featured.

title: TOKYO BACKS COMMON MARKET
description: Japan notified Argentine that it had decided to take economic actions against the South American country in response to official requests from Britain, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: WHY THE TAX CUT WORRIES BUSINESS
description: NOT so long ago, various economists were assuring their clients that come the first of July, the economy would burst out of the recession like a shot from a Roman candle. For July 1 is Tax Cut Day, the day when working Americans will find their paychecks a little fatter thanks to a 10 percent reduction in tax rates. Also on that day, people who receive Social Security benefits may be a little richer with cost-of-living increases that will add $27 to the average monthly payment scheduled to go into effect.

title: Dido Twite
description: To the Editor:

title: A MOVING EXPERIENCE OF MOVING ONE'S BELONGINGS ONESELF
description: WHAT do Allied, Mayflower, North American, Neptune and Joe's Moving and Storage have in common? If you think they are all moving companies, you've never taken an in-depth look at Joe's Moving and Storage.

title: THAI DIPLOMAT HELD ON HEROIN CHARGE IN CHICAGO
description: A Thai diplomat who is said to have operated a ring that smuggled as much as $20 million worth of heroin into the United States in diplomatic pouches is under arrest on drug charges, officials say.

title: Lesley Behan Married To David Walter Ford
description: Lesley Ann Behan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald J.A. Behan of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Lieut. (jg.) David Walter Ford, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Ford, also of Rye.

title: WEST BANK OCCUPATION LEAVES SCARS ON ISRAEL TOO
description: JERUSALEM AS the death toll among Arab demonstrators in the West Bank and Gaza Strip mounted last week and Prime Minister Menachem Begin called for a parliamentary resolution barring any future dismantling of Jewish settlements in occupied lands, a few Israelis were swept by deepening grief and worry. Some demonstrated at one of the new Jewish settlements inaugurated on the West Bank. Others wrote anguished letters to newspapers, comparing their country to South Africa and even Nazi Germany. Many more talked in the privacy of their own circle of family and friends about what occupation was doing to Israel and its people.

title: Fleur Alison Marks Married
description: Fleur Alison Marks, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Marks of Princeton, N.J., was married in the Princeton University Chapel yesterday to William Dodge Rueckert, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Rueckert of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. Shirley C. Guthrie Jr. performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Mailbox; Steinbrenner Is No Patton
description: To the Sports Editor: Thank you very much for George Vecsey's column, which said what had been on everyone's mind these last few weeks (''Bob Lemon's 14-Game Year,'' The New York Times, April 26).

title: John C. Kaiser Marries Nancy Lou Grohman
description: Nancy Lou Grohman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Grohman of Ross, Calif., was married yesterday to John Christopher Kaiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Kaiser of Wheeling, W.Va.

title: OPENING GATES FOR GRANDDADDY
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. IN the winner's circle, Arthur B. Hancock 3d was in the back row, one of more than a dozen around Gato del Sol and the jockey Eddie Delahoussaye, but Arthur Hancock was the one the onlookers were most interested in.

title: SINGERS CREATICNG THEIR OWN AUDIENCE
description: SOMETIMES, the tenor Peter Pesco concedes, he does his ''best singing in my own music room.'' But because singers, even tenors, do not live by singing alone, he and a mezzo, a soprano and a bassbaritone have set out to create an audience for themselves in suburbia.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: FOR BERMUDA, ANXIETY OVER A SISTER COLONY
description: Sir Richard Posnett, the Governor here, sat calmly overlooking the choppy ocean while the wind drove rain against Government House, where a predecessor and his aide-decamp were assassinated in 1973.

title: RED SOX BEAT RANGERS IN 12TH
description: Bill Stein, whose single in the top of the 12th had given Texas a 5-4 lead, threw away a relay throw to first base in the bottom of the inning today to let in the winning runs as the Boston Red Sox rallied for a 6-5 victory. The loss was the Rangers' eighth straight.

title: Alison Jane Oresman To Be Married July 4
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Oresman of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Jane Oresman, to Warren E. Wilson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren E. Wilson of Neenah, Wis.

title: U.S.C. STILL GETS TV PROFITS
description: Despite its complaints about losing television revenue because of a two-year National Collegiate Athletic Association probation, the University of Southern California can earn about $4 million from regular-season football television in the next four seasons.

title: Denise Lee Kearns Is Bride Of Frederick C. Witsell 3d
description: Denise Lee Kearns, an offset lithographer at the Offset House in Burlington, Vt., was married there yesterday to Frederick C. Witsell 3d, art director of Atkins Advertising Inc., in Burlington. The Rev. Francis Holland performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception.

title: MANATEE DEATHS IN FLORIDA LINKED TO RED TIDE
description: Since early February, 41 manatees have been found dead in the Caloosahatchee River system in southwestern Florida.

title: HIGHER MEAT PRICES
description: Recent trends in production of pork and beef suggest that meat price inflation, which has been moderate for more than a year, may be about to pick up.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; British Gabrieli Strings Play Haydn Quartet
description: Britain's Gabrieli String Quartet -Kenneth Sillito and Brendan O'Reilly, violins; Ian Jewel, viola, and Keith Harvey, cello - is 15 years old, and enjoys a considerable reputation. But New Yorkers had to wait until Friday night at Alice Tully Hall to hear the group in concert.

title: NEW FOSSIL SHOWS THE AGILITY OF AN ANCIENT HOOFED ANIMAL
description: New evidence indicates an ancient ancestor of such hoofed mammals as cattle, sheep, deer and camels was far more agile and sophisticated than scientists had thought.

title: LAND MANAGEMENT
description: A new dimension in land management will be explored when a daylong workshop on ''archeological conservancy'' is held Saturday at the American Indian Archeological Institute, Route 199 in Washington.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Errant Computer
description: Just as elementary school pupils sometimes have trouble with mathematical fractions, so did a new personal computer put out by International Business Machines.

title: PUEBLO INDIAN BREAD
description: CATHERINE C. ROBBINS is a writer who lives in Albuquerque, N.M. BY CATHERINE C.ROBBINS

title: CARLISLE WAS A COLLEGE TEAM WITH A PROFESSIONAL APPROACH
description: THE current brouhaha over the National Collegiate Athletic Association's never-say-die striving for both greater profits all round and a touch more propriety in the ranks suggests that it is again time for a brief history lesson. I offer the early case (1907-13) of the Carlisle Indian School and its coach and athletic director, Glenn S. (Pop) Warner.

title: John Harris Panzer Marries Elizabeth Livingstone
description: Elizabeth Moffat Livingstone, a daughter of Dwight H. Livingstone of Glenview, Ill., and the late Margaret Mills Livingstone, was married yesterday to John Harris Panzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Panzer of Rossmoor, N.J. The Rev. William Wood 3d, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in New Hope, Pa.

title: Margaret Laurie Blinder Engaged to Bradley Tolkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seton Laurence Blinder of Hewlett Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Laurie Blinder, to Bradley J. Tolkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Tolkin of East Hills, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: GATO DEL SOL, 21-1, RALLIES AND WINS THE DERBY
description: It will be remembered as the Topsy-Turvy Derby, the one in which the last finished first. By the end of the mile-and-a-quarter race today at Churchill Downs, Gato del Sol had come from last place in a field of 19 to win the 108th Kentucky Derby.

title: PROTESTERS AGAINST REAGAN POLICY MARCH TO CAPITOL
description: Thousands of demonstrators gathered in downtown Washington's Franklin Square today to denounce the economic and social policies of the Reagan Administration, then marched two miles to the Capitol.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Irene Simonsen Offers Bach Partita for Flute
description: Musical seriousness can leave a deeper impression than virtuosity or musical polish. That quality was evident in Irene Simonsen's flute recital in Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night, despite certain musical and technical difficulties.

title: MOTHERHOOD LIMITED; *
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTY'S HERITAGE FOCUS OF FESTIVAL
description: EVER wonder how you came to be where you are or why your town is the way it is? What were your forebears doing 50 years ago, 100 years ago or even 200 or 300? If your history is a bit hazy or your family knowledge a bit sketchy, and whether you are of Italian, German, English, Dutch, Spanish, African, Asian or Eastern European descent, you may be able to find out some of the answers May 22 and 23.

title: PRINCIPALS AT THE HEARINGS
description: THE Shoreham licensing hearings will involve the following participants: - The Atomic Safety and Licensing Board, which will present its findings to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for final action. Lawrence Brenner, chairman of the board, is a lawyer. Dr. James Carpenter, an environmental scientist, and Dr. Peter Morris, a nuclear physicist, are the other two members.

title: 'This Is the Army' Reunion
description: The former privates and corporals and sergeants in greasepaint who made theatrical history in Irving Berlin's ''This Is the Army'' on Broadway and on the road in the European and Pacific Theaters will assemble next Saturday for their 40th reunion, in the Belasco Room of Sardi's Restaurant.

title: SENIOR SENATOR: A TITLE THAT FITS
description: WASHINGTON SOMETIMES, big men are nicknamed ''Junior,'' an irony that acknowledges size or prowess, and such types tend to be good sports about it.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYEE PENSION CHANGES PROPOSAL
description: A commission appointed by Governor Carey last week recommended that the state eliminate a requirement that some public employees contribute a portion of their salaries toward their pensions.

title: CONGRESS'S TAX-WRITERS NOW HAVE A TRICKIER PATH TO TREAD
description: WASHINGTON WITH the collapse of the three-sided budget talks last week, Congress's tax writers resumed their customary free-wheeling style, seeking ways to raise additional revenues without trampling Democratic sensibilities or inviting a veto by the Republican President. The Ways and Means Committee plans its formal start Wednesday with testimony by Donald T. Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury. Some Administration strategists doubt that he will offer anything more than the proposals the President made three months ago, in his budget for fiscal year 1983, and a partisan tone is expected.As one Democrat put it, ''it's the day when we have our pound of flesh, and then hopefully we'll get down to work.''

title: ELISABETH DAMON ENGAGED TO DUNCAN MITCHELL TOLL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund H. Damon of Greenwich, Conn., and Kennebunk Beach, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth D. Damon, to Duncan Mitchell Toll, son of Mrs. Dawn Toll of Greenwich, Conn., and Princeton, Me., and Phillip Toll.

title: Anne Rogers Engaged to Seaver Leslie
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Clark Rogers of Longmeadow, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Cleland Rogers, to Seaver Warland Leslie, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Leslie of Wiscasset, Me.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE season is irrevocably, one hopes, headed toward balmy times. Others may sense this from observation of green shoots thrusting through topsoil or of the slow and ever-later descent of the sun in the soft western heavens. Not me. My first realization that spring is here comes from the sight of children, young children.

title: Around the Nation; Coast Fishermen Protest Delay of Salmon Season
description: Fishermen frustrated with Federal restrictions that delayed the opening of California's salmon season until today gave away half a ton of fish in protest.

title: BRAZIL OPPOSITION OPTIMISTIC ON VOTE
description: A Government maneuver to guarantee victory for its party in scheduled nationwide elections appears to have failed, and opposition leaders have recovered their belief that they will end up with significant gains.

title:
ART;
A SHOW THAT CAPTURES SPRING'S MOOD
description: NORTHPORT THE recently expanded Verzyl Gallery, now situated downstairs from its former quarters in the same building at 377 Fort Salonga Road, is offering a group show that effectively captures a light, airy mood appropriate to the spring season. Works in various media by five artists are featured through May 22.

title: A MUSIC LOVER'S GRAND TOUR
description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG is cultural correspondent and former chief music critic of The New York Times. By HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: MARKET FOR OFFICES SOFTENING
description: FOR real estate brokers, there are at least two sides to e verything. At the moment, they are saying, the market for clients w ho are seeking prime office space in Manhattan is not great, but it i s getting better.

title: More Grits
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURAS HIJACKERS RELEASE HOSTAGES, FLY TO CUBA
description: The hijacking of a Honduran airliner that began Wednesday ended today when four leftist gunmen freed their remaining hostages and were allowed to leave for Cuba on a second airliner, army officials said.

title: THE SUMMER RUSH FOR PASSPORTS
description: W ith the Federal offices that issue passports deluged by applications this spring, a colleague of mine thought of a way to avoid a major delay. When she first applied - and stood in line two hours to do so - a passport was promised her by mail in about a month. Much too late, she thought, because she planned to fly standby to Europe within a week, which meant she would buy her ticket on the day of departure, if space was available. The passport officer told her that there was no way his procedure could be speeded unless she could produce an airline ticket with a confirmed reservation on a specific date.

title: LAB OFFICERS IN MOCK WARFARE
description: UPTON ASECLUDED site at the Brookhaven National Laboratory became a battleground the other day, and a vacated building here was the target of a potentially deadly terrorist takeover. But the weapons fired only blanks.

title: SUBURBAN HOUSING GROWS IN THE BRONX
description: A world apart but only blocks from Charlotte Street in the South Bronx, several rows of single-family homes continued their improbable rise last week. At some, workers were finishing the plumbing. At others, kitchen cabinets were installed and concrete was poured into the basements. It may not be much longer until patches of grass are visible in backyards.

title: ANDREW F. BRIMMER, MODEL
description: WASHINGTON Dressed in a three-piece suit, Andrew F. Brimmer nurses a glass of vodka on the rocks. Mr. Brimmer, member of the Federal Reserve Board until 1974, now head of Brimmer & Company, financial consultants, is singing the praises of Smirnoff.

title: Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA LURING JERSEYANS
description: VENICE, FLA. NOT all of the nearly three million people that Florida gained between the 1970 and 1980 censuses are from New Jersey. It only seems that way.

title: Latin America
description: To the Editor: Regarding the Q and A item on South America (Travel, April 4), a source that gives bus routes in Latin America is called the ''South American Handbook: A Traveller's Guide to Latin America and West Indies.''

title: FROM GLADNESS TO MADNESS
description: THE JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH Foreword by Ted Hughes. Consulting Editor, Ted Hughes. Editor, Frances McCullough. Illustrated. 370 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $16.95.

title: Sports of The Times; Ted Williams: Good Field, No Hit
description: THE last time Ted Williams swung a bat in Fenway Park was on Sept. 28, 1960, a cold, nasty afternoon with the season winding down. Only 10,453 fans were watching when Williams lashed a pitch from Baltimore's Jack Fisher straight into the icy breeze for his 521st and last home run. Most fans were cheering when he went out to left field for the next inning, and they cheered even more when Carroll Hardy was sent out to replace him.

title: STARTER GETS DERBY OFF WITHOUT HITCH
description: There was a nervous filly who had been kicking since she was put on the plane to come here. There was a oneeyed horse and a colt who had to be blindfolded. And one of the favorites had developed a dislike for starting gates.

title: CHANGES ON HUNTINGTON LINE
description: HUNTINGTON STATION COMMUTERS on the 7:08 A.M. train out of Huntington Station like being at the terminus of the electrification on the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road. The express to Penn Station is empty when it arrives at the station, takes a relatively fast 1 hour and 5 minutes to New York City, with no change at Jamaica, and is fairly reliable. At the station, everyone gets a parking space since a three-level parking garage with 750 spaces opened last year.

title: Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS WIN NO.3 IN EXTRA PERIOD, 5-4
description: Wayne Merrick scored a goal at 16 minutes 52 seconds of overtime tonight to give the Islanders a 5-4 triumph over the Quebec Nordiques and a commanding three-games-to-none lead in their semifinal playoff series.

title: Thomas Wolfe Society Will Meet at Harvard
description: The Thomas Wolfe Society will hold its third annual meeting at Harvard next Friday and Saturday, with various scholars presenting papers on the author.

title: THE VOICE OF THE YEGG AND THE GRIFTER
description: THE papers and articles collected in "Language of the Underworld" represent the 50 years of research that the late David Maurer devoted to the language and customs of American pickpockets, confidence men, forgers, narcotics addicts safcrackers, moonshiners and other colorful types. Though he presented himself as a "groundbreaking: maverick scholar, his work really fits into a tradition of popular lexicography that stretches back to the Renaissance. It was Maurer's misfortune to have outlived it, but therein lies the interest of this book now.

title: Topics; SEMANTICS, ACOUSTICS; Studio I.R.T.
description: If The Gap, a chain of jeans stores, had forgotten about the loudspeakers and just kept the radio behind the counter - like our local dry cleaner, newsstand and grocer - they would-n't have had all that trouble with ASCAP. But noisy they had to be, so on came the lawsuit, and down came the Supreme Court, which now says that playing radio music over loudspeakers infringes on copyright laws.

title: A Freelance Decries 'Lack of Respect'
description: Regarding the article ''Freelancers Press for Writers Union'' (March 21): To paraphrase Rodney Dangerfield, ''Us freelance writers don't get no respect.''

title: JOSEPH PAPP GOES ABSTRACT
description: ''The theater is supposed to be a living force which absorbs in some way what is happening in the world, and in some way expresses it,'' Joseph Papp began, by way of introduction to his current state of thinking - and considerable dismay - about the contemporary theater. The producer and director was perched on the edge of an armchair in his second-floor office at the Public Theater, and words were tumbling from his mouth at a brisk clip, as usual.

title: Gardens in Ireland
description: To the Editor: What have you against Ireland? The article on ''Where to Find Europe's Finest Flowers and Gardens'' (Travel, March 14) failed to mention or show in the accompanying map any gardens in the Emerald Isle. Any reputable book on gardens refers to Garnish Island (at Glengarrif in Bantry Bay) and Rossdohan, Sneem, County Kerry. Also, of course, there are the National Botanic Gardens in Dublin and Muckross Gardens in Killarney. FINBARR SLATTERY An Chomhairle Oiliuna Talmhaiochta (Council for Development in Agricul- ture) Killarney, Ireland

title: Woodsmen's Museum
description: In these days of the plastic and metal that constitute the substance of hi-tech decor, it is easy to forget wood, woodworking implements and the fact that lumbering was once a source of great revenue in many parts of eastern North America.

title: Around the World; 9 People Are Killed In Clashes in Guatemala
description: Five guerrillas, a policeman and a soldier have been killed in clashes near the Mexican border and on the fringe of the capital, police and army sources said today. Two civilians also died in political violence, they said.

title: FOLK: GABRIEL YACOUB
description: In a style that gracefully blended the 15th century with our own, Gabriel Yacoub, the French singer and guitarist, sang of weddings, of nightingales, and of girls and their lovers at his one-man concert Friday evening at the Alternative Museum.

title: The Region in Summary; Kean's Call for More Prisons
description: Ever since New Jersey toughened its penal code to make the punishment fit the crime, it has had a hard time making the punished fit its prisons. Last week, predicting the number of inmates would rise to 15,000 by 1988, Governor Kean proposed that the state's prison facilities be doubled to keep pace.

title: DISKS DISPLAY TWO HAYDNS
description: With this year's celebration of Franz Joseph Haydn's 250th birthday well under way - the actual occasion was March 31 - the record catalogues are beginning to swell with new entries in virtually every genre the productive composer addressed. Naturally, many of the new releases, particularly on larger, more easily available labels, offer performers' latest thoughts on familiar Haydn works. Meanwhile, some of the smaller labels and import firms are helping to fill out the picture with recordings of pieces that have been explored less frequently, if at all, on disk.

title: SCULLING STILL THRIVES ON SHORELINE
description: PELHAM MANOR MOTORISTS driving along Shore Road here on Saturday and Sunday mornings often do double takes as they spot T-shirted oarsmen in shells skimming down the Pelham Bay Lagoon. From about 7 to 11 A.M. on weekends, all types of rowing shells can be seen - some propelled by single oarsmen, four-oared boats with coxswain or sleek narrow shells, about 60 feet long, manned by eight sweeps. The fleet of assorted sizes often numbers more than 30 craft.

title: WHITNEY MUSEUM SEASON
description: The Eli Whitney Museum's 1816 Barn at 945 Whitney Avenue, Hamden, is open for its fourth season of summer arts and performances. Visitors to the various events are encouraged to stroll around the grounds, inspecting the restoration work in progress on Whitney's arms factory, his office, powderhouse, covered bridge and the waterfall that powered the machinery for manufacturing.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
MEET VIRGIL THOMSON
description: To help the Long Island Chamber Ensemble celebrate his 85th birthday, the composer Virgil Thomson will be at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University on Saturday to discuss his work. Featuring music that spans 50 years of Mr. Thomson's very productive career (including ''a world premiere'') and a screening of the film ''The Plow That Broke the Plains,'' the program, ''Meet the Composer - Virgil Thomson,'' will be at 8:30 P.M. on the Hempstead campus. Tickets are $6 and reservations may be made by calling 560-3283. Barbara Delatiner

title: NEW MALL; SAVING A BLUE
description: Among its features, the Crossgates Mall in suburban Albany will have 150 stores clustered around a cafe square, a J.C. Penney outlet, a threatened species of butterfly, wooden tables and chairs, fountains and fast-food outlets. It's the butterflies that will set Crossgates apart.

title: WEEKEND CALENDAR FOR SHOW-AND-SELL
description: When the calendar pages flip over to May, it is a signal to antiques aficianados that the outdoor show-and-sell season is about to begin.

title: Finally, Hope for Voting Rights
description: A breakthrough is at hand for a renewed, strengthened Voting Rights Act.

title: Mr. Reagan vs. Reality
description: The President went on television the other night to blame it on the Democrats. Their decades of bloated Federal budgets sent inflation into orbit, their overspending has sapped the private economy and now their stubbornness has aborted a budget compromise that might have saved the sick economy. Would that it were all so simple. The economic policy battle is not between Republicans and Democrats. It is more nearly between the President and Congress, between Mr. Reagan and economic reality.

title: TEEN-AGE CONFIDENTIALITY AND HEALTH CARE
description: MOUNT KISCO THREE or four years ago, a teen-age girl walked into the Planned Parenthood center on Main Street here, asked for and received birth control pills and left.

title: PATIENT ISLANDERS IMPRESS NORDIQUES
description: As they sat numb and silent in their dressing room, the Quebec Nordiques said they knew exactly what had happened to them: the best team in professional hockey, the Islanders, had won in overtime because they were experienced and a bit lucky.

title: Communist Party Chief Slain In Sicily Drive Against Mafia
description: Pio La Torre, the head of the Communist Party in Sicily, was shot dead Friday amid a campaign against Mafia bosses involved in international heroin trade.

title: Elizabeth Horowitz Married
description: Elizabeth Phillips Horowitz, an account executive with radio station KPLX-FM in Dallas, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Scott Darrow, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Dallas.

title:
ENVIRONEWS;
Vital Statistics
description: From Douglas Costle, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in the Carter Administration, comes the following food for environmental thought:

title:
NEWARK'S VOTE, THEN AND NOW;
HELP WANTED
description: Mayor to govern a 316-year-old city with shrinking population and resources, but prospects of economic revival. Also, nine City Council members.

title: PROVINCE OF HIDDEN TREASURES
description: FREDERIC RAPHAEL is the author of film scripts and novels, among them ''Darling'' and ''The Glittering Prizes.'' His most recent book is a biography of Byron, to be published in the fall by Thames and Hudson. By FREDERIC RAPHAEL

title: Bucks Defeat the 76ers at Buzzer, 92-91
description: Sidney Moncrief's driving bank shot at the buzzer gave the Milwaukee Bucks a 92-91 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers today, their first in the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinals. The 76ers lead the four-of-seven game series, 2-1, with the fourth game at the Milwaukee Arena Sunday afternoon.

title: No Headline
description: Peter Sanders, a freshman midfielder, scored four goals, and John Buzanga and Dennis Fantoni had three goals each today as C.W. Post beat Southampton, 14-5, in lacrosse.

title: CREATING A BUSINESS IN BUSINESS PAPERS
description: WHEN the National Computer Conference convenes June 7 in Houston, Gerard G. Leeds's family of newspapers will grow to six. Mr. Leeds is the president of CMP Publications Inc., with headquarters in Manhasset - a business-newspaper publishing concern he started in April 1971 in his home in Great Neck.

title: DIFFERENCES OVER ENDING HARTFORD'S TAX DIFFERENTIAL
description: For four years, homeowners here have enjoyed a property tax break available in no other Connecticut locality. The well-organized neighborhood groups that helped push the ''tax differential'' through have come to accept, grudgingly, that the provision's days are numbered, but a sometimes acrimonious battle has been joined over the cutoff date.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Munson Case
description: After a ruling by the National Transportation Safety Board that pilot error had caused the 1979 crash that killed Thurman Munson in his twin-engine jet, the Yankee catcher's wife, Diane, and three children sued for $42.2 million. FlightSafety International and the Cessna Aircraft Company, both in Wichita, Kan., were named as defendants.

title: 2 Jersey Policemen Sue For '60 Minutes' Tapes
description: Attorneys for two law enforcement agents from New Jersey say they will try to force CBS to turn over tapes from a ''60 Minutes'' segment that featured the officers.

title: PROVIDE
description: The United States informed Britain in general terms today of the kinds of military assistance it will provide now that it has taken Britain's side in the Falkland Islands dispute with Argentina.

title: Hospital Talks Starting in City
description: Negotiators for 69 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes in the New York City area and their employees will open contract talks today to replace a pact that expires June 30.

title: Auto Racer Killed
description: Ernest Maynor, a racing driver from Bay Shore, L.I., was fatally injured Saturday night when his car crashed into a wall at Islip Speedway, the police said. A police spokesman said that Maynor, who was 47 years old, was taken to Southside Hospital, where he was pronounced dead on arrival. The cause of the accident was not known.

title: HOYT (5-0) WINS STARTING SLOT
description: The good times keep rolling for Lamarr Hoyt. The 27-year-old right-handed pitcher realized what he called a nine-year-old dream by being named yesterday to the starting pitching rotation of the Chicago White Sox by Manager Tony LaRussa.

title: CART and Pocono Settle Dispute
description: Championship Auto Racing Teams and the owners of Pocono International Raceway have settled their differences, clearing the way for Indianapolis-type cars to return to the Pocono track this year.

title: JUDGES IN COMPLEX STRUGGLE OVER PHILADELPHIA'S COURT SYSTEM
description: Philadelphia's 110-judge court system, a perennial target of criticism, is facing the threat of an administrative takeover by a State Supreme Court justice who has called problems of the judiciary here ''a national disgrace.''

title: HEROISM IN MODERN TIMES
description: HEROISM has been an issue recently - not so much the heroism of w arriors in elite commando units fighting for honor and country but, r ather, the heroism of ordinary people suddenly trapped in situationso f great menace.
