title: THEATER: ZOE CALDWELL PLAYS MEDEA
description: EURIPIDES has a strong ally in Zoe Caldwell, who brought her special flame to the otherwise routine revival of ''Medea'' that opened last night at the Cort. Possibly the most modern of Greek dramatists, Euripides demands an intense psychological realism from actors - and that is what Miss Caldwell has bestowed on her marathon role. This actress makes us believe in the warped logic by which Medea murders her two sons to wreak vengeance on Jason, the ambitious husband who has betrayed her for a Greek princess. And because she does, we are, by evening's end, brought right into the thunderclap of Euripides' tragedy.

title: OSTOMIES: NO LONGER 'THE SECRET SURGERY'
description: It used to be called ''the secret surgery,'' because the people who had it didn't want others to know. Nowadays, more and more men and women who have had ostomy surgery are talking openly about their operation and how it has affected their lives and their relationships with their families, friends and employers.

title: 'Little Gloria' Planned As 4-Part NBC Series
description: Bette Davis, Angela Lansbury, Maureen Stapleton, Glynis Johns, Martin Balsam, Barnard Hughes, Ken Howard and John Hillerman will head the cast of ''Little Gloria ... Happy at Last,'' a four-hour NBC-TV series based on the 1934 child-custody case involving Gloria Vanderbilt.

title: CHIEF AT BRUNSWICK RESIGNS SUDDENLY
description: K. Brooks Abernathy, 63 years old, chairman and chief executive officer of the Brunswick Corporation, a diversified conglomerate based in suburban Chicago, abruptly resigned as chief executive officer at the company's annual meeting Friday.

title: THE TOUGH EUROCREDIT MARKET
description: As it moves from gawky adolescence to mature middle age, the international lending community is encountering some of its roughest going.

title: AIRLINES WILL GET NEW FARE LEEWAY ON ATLANTIC RUNS
description: The United States and 10 European countries agreed yesterday to establish a new fare structure for North Atlantic routes that allows airlines more freedom in raising or lowering plane fares.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article April 22 about hearings in Washington on videotaping incorrect- ly described the testimony of the actor Charlton Heston. He said he supported a special royalty fee on the manufac- turers of home videotape recorders.

title: MISCONCIEVED WORRIES ABOUT THE MIDEAST CONFRONTATION
description: To the Editor:

title: House Approves Funds To Fix Western Dams
description: The House has authorized $550 million to repair or replace scores of potentially dangerous Bureau of Reclamation dams in the West.

title: Holloway Started Drug Use at Pitt
description: Randy Holloway, the Minnesota Vikings' defensive end who has completed a month of treatment for drug and alcohol abuse, said Saturday that he used the substances almost every day before he decided to quit.

title: Ayala Wins Again
description: Unbeaten Tony Ayala stopped Steve Gregory in the third round of a junior middleweight fight at Curtis Hixon Hall today.

title: HOW JOHN GREGORY DUNNE PUTS HIMSELF INTO HIS BOOKS
description: ''I'd written a morgue scene in 'True Confessions,' and when it came time to do the movie, we needed a location. So Ulu Grosbard and I went to the L.A. morgue with two homicide cops at 2 in the morning. There must have been 500 bodies in there. They're stacked in the cold room on Tiffany blue stretchers - you know, the light blue color of Tiffany boxes - five stretchers to a tier. The smell isn't too bad, but it's a little high, so you smoke a cigar. The whole thing just blew me away. It just blew my mind. I came home and woke Joan up and said, 'Babe, this is something you've got to see.' ''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The world should understand that the people of El Salvador are not cannon fodder for any appetite, for any dictator or for any cold war.'' - Alvaro Alfredo Magana Borja, the provisional President of El Salvador. (A10:1.)

title: Carey Son Held After Crash
description: Governor Carey's 28-year-old son, Michael, was arrested early today after a three-car accident on a charge of driving while intoxicated, according to the police. He pleaded not guilty at an arraignment in Police Court before Judge Thomas Keegan, and Judge Keegan scheduled a trial for May 11. A hearing in the case was scheduled for May 15 by the State Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: U.N. CHIEF INTENSIFIES EFFORT TO COME UP WITH SOLUTION
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar began an intensive diplomatic effort today to find a solution for the conflict over the Falkland Islands.

title: GILDER'S 67 FOR A RECORD 266 WINS NELSON
description: Bob Gilder attributed his winning the Byron Nelson Classic today to two factors: He wanted to make it worthwhile for his wife to have taken an all-night flight from Portland, Ore., and Curtis Strange missed so many birdie putts.

title: BLUCHER A. POOLE
description: Blucher A. Poole, an authority on environmental health and water pollution, died Friday at a hospital in Fort Myers, Fla.

title: Angola Lists 7 Killed in April By South African Air Attacks
description: Seven people were killed and 18 wounded when South African warplanes made three raids on Angolan villages last month, the official Angolan news agency said today.

title: Washington Watch; Price Support For Air Routes
description: WASHINGTON IN the multibillion dollar Federal world of housing subsidies and dairy industry price supports, the Civil Aeronautics Board casts a scarcely discernible budgetary shadow. What's more, the small agency is scheduled to go out of business by the end of 1984, perhaps sooner.

title: L.I. MARATHON WON BY ARMY SERGEANT
description: The Long Island Marathon proved a successful exercise for the United States Army today, as it captured first place with an intelligence sergeant nicknamed Bones and placed six soldiers among the top 20 finishers.

title: Article 108877 -- No Title
description: ''Pastor Olson Sells Heaven for $1 Million,'' said the headline in a recent issue of Expressen, a Swedish newspaper. Next to it was a photograph of the Rev. Evert Olson of the Church of Sweden. He was standing on the roof of his church on East 48th Street in Manhattan, hands reaching to the sky, a smile of triumph on his face.

title: SYNAGOGUE'S GARDEN OF REMEMBRANCE
description: A serene courtyard of gravel terraces framed by young honey locusts and a limestone wall was dedicated yesterday by the congregation of a Gramercy Park synagogue as a memorial not only to family members and friends who have died but also to the six million Jews who perished in the Holocaust.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Stiff Opposition

title: A COMPROMISE SOUGHT ON KOCH'S SURTAX ON INCOME
description: New York City officials were striving yesterday to work out a compromise on Mayor Koch's embattled plan for a 5 to 10 percent surcharge on city income tax.

title: CITY OFFICIALS STUDY SMALLER FERRYBOATS FOR S.I. NIGHT RUNS
description: In an effort to save money, New York City is studying the possible purchase of ferryboats smaller than those now running between Manhattan and Staten Island, according to the Department of Transportation.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Can the ball carrier in the National Football League punt or drop-kick once he has passed the line of scrimmage? On a kickoff, can the receiver punt, drop-kick, place-kick or pass the ball?

title: LIBERTY RETAIL CHAIN OF BRITAIN CHANGING
description: If Harrods is an institution, it is often said here, then Liberty is a monument. But while that description of this city's other large department store may befit its splendid mock Tudor facade and high-priced gentility, it is not always the best way for a retailer to sell goods.

title: UPSTATE TOWER CLEANUP: UNCERTAINTY AND DEBATE
description: More than a year after the explosion of an electrical transformer spread dangerous chemicals through the 18-story State Office Building here, scientists and politicians are still pondering how best to proceed with the cleanup.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, has named Michael S. Wasacz executive vice president-ocean transportation.

title: Rick Devlin Out As WOR Manager
description: Robert H. (Rick) Devlin has left WOR-AM, the country's first radio station in revenues, where he was vice president and general manager. ''Officially, he resigned,'' Robert Bruno, program director, said.

title: Metal Shoe Shanks Used In Michigan Prison Fight
description: Inmates tore metal shanks from the soles of their prison shoes and used them as knives in an uprising last week at the Huron Valley Correctional Facility, a prison official said today. Six people were reported injured.

title: U.S. Navy Maneuvers Open in the Caribbean
description: The United States Navy has begun maneuvers in the Caribbean. They involve 45,000 servicemen, 350 airplanes and 60 ships, including two aircraft carrier battle groups.

title: Fumes Injure Polish Firemen
description: An explosion and fire at a chemical plant here led to the hospitalization of 30 firefighters suffering from exposure to toxic fumes, the Polish press agency PAP said today. Seventeen were later released, but the others remained for further treatment.

title: Cars to Carry Lead Ballasts
description: Independent Grand Prix teams will use lead ballast in Sunday's Belgian Grand Prix to meet a controversial weight rule, a team owner, Frank Williams, said today.

title: Spain Offers to Mediate Dispute
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo said today that Spain had offered to mediate the Falkland Islands dispute between Britain and Argentina ''although it may be too late.''

title: PRESIDENT CANUTE SPEAKS
description: From the beginning of Ronald Reagan's spectacular political career there has been a question about his grasp of substantive policy matters. Watching him react to the failure of his economic program, we know the truth. As Gertrude Stein said of Oakland, Calif., there's no there there.

title: Cartoonist Gives His Hollywood View of the U.S.; Feiffer's View
description: Speaking at an Arizona Civil Liberties Union dinner Saturday night, Jules Feiffer, the cartoonist and playwright, said the Reagan Administration and the New Right were giving the nation ''a lot more energy'' and ''a lot more passion'' than it had a few years ago.

title: U.N. PARLEY WILL EXAMINE HOW ENVIRONMENT HAS DONE IN THE LAST 10 YEARS
description: Mother Earth is about to get another physical checkup. Next week, 10 years after the first United Nations Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm, United Nations members will gather in Nairobi, Kenya, to re-examine the state of the world's life-support systems and plan future action on crucial environmental problems.

title: NEW HEAD OF OPERATIONS AT SYNTEX CORPORATION
description: Richard G. Rogers, 53, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Syntex Corporation, a major pharmaceutical and health-care company with headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif. As president, he succeeds Albert Bowers, 51, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: A NORMAL ZIMBABWE
description: Since independence in 1979 Z imbabwe and Prime Minister Robert Mugabe have been beneficiaries - a nd victims - of high expectations abroad.

title: The One-Man Generation
description: AS the old Red Sox jogged onto the field for the first old-timers game ever held at Fenway Park, one ancient Boston hero never got a call. He sat on the top step of the dugout in a T-shirt, watching and smiling, a link between the old players on the field and the current players already dressed for the real game on Saturday.

title: LAKERS SWEEP THE SUNS
description: PHOENIX May 2 (AP) - Earvin (Magic) Johnson of Los Angeles scored 6 straight points late in the fourth quarter today, and the Lakers swept their National Basketball Association playoff series with the Phoenix Suns.

title: Montana Blaze Burns In Wildlife Refuge
description: Firefighters battled a 5,500-acre blaze on rugged private and public lands in central Montana today. A spokesman for the Bureau of Land Management said he could not guess when the fire might be contained.

title: N.& W. Rail Merger Yields Account Merger
description: J. Walter Thompson, Washington, had been agency for the Norfolk & Western Railway, while the Southern Railway used Cunningham & Walsh. Now that the carriers are merging June 1 to form the Norfolk Southern Corporation, there was a need to consolidate the advertising as well. J.W.T. will get it, and reports have it that the corporate image campaign will go for $3 million. C.& W. will do some of the ads to announce the consolidation.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Hospital Reborn
description: Ever since St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J., opened in 1867 two things seemed constant: It would serve the city's poor, then immigrant mill workers, now indigent blacks and Hispanics. And each year would end with a big deficit.

title: WHAT FREE TRADE WITH CUBA COULD DO
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSICAL: 'CHARLOTTE SWEET'
description: ''CHARLOTTE SWEET,'' the new musical at the Chernuchin Theater, 314 West 54th Street, takes place in a British music hall; it is also done in the style of the British music hall, more or less as if the Crummles from ''Nicholas Nickleby'' had stumbled onto the set of ''Sweeney Todd.'' ''Charlotte Sweet'' mixes the adorable and the strange, and it is delectable.

title: MARCHERS IN MANHATTAN SHOW THEIR SUPPORET FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: Bearing placards with the names and faces of Jews denied exit visas by the Soviet Union, tens of thousands of protesters jammed Dag Hammarskjold Plaza in Manhattan yesterday to shout ''Let my people go.''

title: CONCERT: A FESTIVAL OF HUMMEL
description: JOHANN Nepomuk Hummel (1778-1837) - the foremost pianist of his age, a student of Mozart and Haydn, a friend of Beethoven - has not had very good press in recent decades. But this week a Hummel Festival at Rutgers University is attempting to call attention to the once-celebrated musician whose compositions now lie untouched and unheard; it is partly sponsored by the Hummel Classical Foundation, founded by the composer's descendants.

title: CELTICS DOWN BULLETS, 103-99, FOR 3-1 EDGE
description: Before Bill Fitch, the coach of the Boston Celtics, would impart any thoughts to reporters about his team's 103-99 overtime victory over Washington at the Capital Centre today, he had one question for them.

title: Hit-and-Run Auto Kills Brooklyn Boy
description: A 5-year-old boy was killed yesterday when he was struck by a hitand-run driver near his home in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: JAPAN'S CHERRY FESTIVAL RE-CREATED IN BROOKLYN
description: For many Japanese living in New York, it was a chance to go home again. Looking at the rows of cherry trees in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and listening to the music of the stringed koto, Eiko Sakashita from Fort Lee, N.J., sighed to her husband, ''Don't you think it's like Japan?''

title: BRAVES BEAT CUBS BEHIND WALK, 10-3
description: Among the many streaks that major league teams have compiled in less than one month of the 1982 baseball season, the most impressive was the Atlanta Braves' record season-opening 13 straight victories. But after that, the Braves lost their next five decisions, all at home.

title: For the Reagans, Barbecue and a Football Sermon; Reagan's Tennessee
description: Fifty miles from Knoxville, Tenn., where he had opened the World's Fair, President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, ate barbecued chicken and ribs Saturday night at Huntsville with their host, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., and a collection of Tennessee talent.

title: DAY CARE IN A FAMILY SETTING
description: Celia Riahi is instantly noticeable in Riverside Park. In good weather she is accompanied by five children ranging in age from 15 months to 3 1/2 years, and she is pushing a large wooden surrey containing a table, benches, sandbox toys, games, a plastic motorcycle, lunchboxes, towels and first-aid supplies. At lunchtime the children scamper into the surrey.

title: Marjorie Sue Gaba Married To Stephen Paul Shapiro
description: Marjorie Sue Gaba, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Gaba of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there yesterday to Stephen Paul Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Shapiro of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi George B. Lieberman performed the ceremony in the Central Synagogue of Nassau County.

title: Hockey Player Suspended a Year
description: Tim Coulis of Dallas, who knocked a referee unconscious during a Central Hockey League playoff game April 24, has been suspended for the rest of the playoffs and all of next season.

title: Doyle Dane and F.C.&B.  Conclude Merger Talks
description: The driving desire for hugeness brought Foote, Cone & Belding and Doyle Dane Bernbach together for quiet exploratory talks on the subject of merger. But they ended Friday with an announcement that the ''discussions have be amicably terminated.''

title: News Analysis
description: The afterglow of the restoration of Sinai to Egypt last Sunday is fading. The crucial date of April 25, which marked the return of the desert by Israel, also marked the end of the honeymoon period President Hosni Mubarak has enjoyed since he came to power after the assassination of Anwar el-Sadat last Oct. 6. Mr. Mubarak is now faced with a long roster of issues - some foreign, but mostly domestic - that command his attention.

title: TV IN LEBANON FOURISHING AMID CIVIL STRIFE
description: Night life in Beirut these days features mainly shootouts, explosions and kidnappings. Understandably, most people prefer to stay at home and watch television.

title: REUNION RECALLS MOVIE ON HISPANIC STRIKERS MADE AT TIME OF FILM BLACKLIST
description: Almost three decades after the completion of ''Salt of the Earth,'' the 1954 movie about a militant union's successful strike against a zinc mining company, participants in the movie and the strike itself gathered here this weekend to remember the filming and its impact.

title: INSURGENT'S LAWSUIT A TEST OF POLITICS AS USUAL
description: Long after most insurgents have forgotten their legal and political battles with the Democratic organization in the city, a Democrat who was removed from the primary ballot last September is pursuing a potentially far-reaching damage suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Arco Gas Pipeline
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company's Arco Oil and Gas Company announced a joint venture with Exxon Company U.S.A. to construct a 405-mile pipeline in the Sheep Mountains in Colorado.

title: COACH IS CRITICIZED
description: Vlado Bogicevic scored the Cosmos' first goal in a 2-0 victory over Jacksonville today, but afterward, instead of being happy, the Yugoslav midfielder was incensed. In the locker room, he severely criticized his coach.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 3, 1982
description: International An Argentine cruiser was torpedoed and severely damaged by a British submarine in the South Atlantic, the British Defense Ministry reported. The ministry said the cruiser General Belgrano had been a significant threat to Britain's fleet maintaining the air and sea blockade around the Falklands. The General Belgrano is Argentina's only cruiser. It was commissioned by the United States in 1939 and sold to Argentina in 1951. It carries a crew of about 1,000. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Argentina denied the British report that one of its cruisers had been torpedoed and said that it was ''a lie'' and ''psychological warfare.'' Western diplomats in Buenos Aires could not immediately confirm the statement by the British Defense Ministry. They said that the General Belgrano, a former American cruiser, was in poor mechanical condition and that they thought it was being withheld from combat. (A1:4-5.)

title: Kathryn Papenfuss Wed To Dr. Arthur J. Ross 3d
description: Kathryn Ann Papenfuss and Dr. Arthur J. Ross 3d were married yesterday at the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C. The Rev. Paul Wesley Aitken, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: TO THOSE WHO WOULD ABOLISH ADOLESCENT SEX
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ISSUES ELIGIBILITY RULES FOR COLLEGE STUDENTS' LOANS
description: Students attending most private colleges can qualify for full Government-guaranteed loans this fall if their families have adjusted gross incomes of $40,000 a year or less, according to Education Department regulations made public today.

title: Polish Hijackers in Custody
description: Eight Polish men who hijacked a domestic airliner to West Berlin on Friday were remanded in custody by a magistrate today, the police said. The men and 28 passengers, many of them relatives of the hijackers, asked for political asylum after the plane landed at the United States Tempelhof military airbase here Friday night.

title: OREGON TOLD REFUGEES TO GO TO CALIFORNIA
description: California's welfare chief has complained that Oregon advised 5,000 jobless Indochinese refugees to move to California where they could collect welfare.

title: 100 NEW G.M. BUSES SIT IDLE IN DISPUTE OVER REAR DOORS
description: More than 100 new General Motors buses are sitting idle in New York City bus depots because of a dispute between the Transit Authority and General Motors over the operation of the vehicles' rear exit doors.

title: ALLEN HAS THE RIGHT STUFF
description: SAN FRANCISCO ASK Neil Allen to list the characteristics of a young pitcher capable of moving from the starting rotation to the bullpen and then learning to relish the job, and - with an impish giggle - he describes himself.

title: Ted Bates Worldwide Gets Beiersdorf Lines
description: Ted Bates Worldwide, which already handles the advertising for the Nivea line in France, Belgium and the Netherlands for Beiersdorf of Hamburg, has just been assigned the skin care products in the United States. Billings could go as high as $4 million.

title: Playoff Overtime Pays Off for Islanders
description: When it comes to overtime, the Islanders seem to have their opponents just where they want them. That was the situation again Saturday night when the Islanders beat the Quebec Nordiques, 5-4.

title: FISHERMEN GET FORMAL EDUCATION
description: IT used to be that one went to school to master reading, writing and arithmetic. But affluence, free time and mobility have created a demand for instruction in endeavors one previously picked up at father's knee, in mother's kitchen or by tediously learning alone.

title: CHARLES FROESSEL, EX-JUDGE, IS DEAD
description: Charles W. Froessel, a former associate judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He lived in Forest Hills, Queens, and was 89 years old.

title: A's 5, Indians 2
description: CLEVELAND (UPI) - Jeff Newman hit a two-run homer, and Mike Norris pitched a four-hitter as the A's swept a three-game series. Jeff Burroughs walked with one out in the fourth and raced to third when Joe Rudi's long fly to right dropped out of Bake McBride's glove for a double.

title: ILLEGAL PAYOFFS FROM JERSEY DRIVERS CALLED BY AN EX-OFFICIAL
description: New Jersey's motor vehicle system is a marketplace of illegal payoffs from drivers who want their records altered and their suspended licenses returned, according to a former director of the State Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Hitting Hollywood

title: O.E.C.D. IS GLOOMIER ON GROWTH
description: Industrial nations face another year of stagnant economic growth and higher unemployment because of the continuing high interest rates in the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned its 24 member countries.

title: BRITAIN GETS SAUCY NEW SUNDAY TABLOID
description: Britain got a new national newspaper today - a gesture of optimism in an industry more accustomed to failures and closure threats.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL IS LEADER IN DEMOCRATS' RACE IN TEXAS
description: Mark White, the Texas Attorney General, who is regarded as a moderate conservative, emerged from Saturday's primary election as the front-runner in a Democratic scramble to determine who will challenge the incumbent Republican Governor, William P. Clements, in November.

title: Changed Judicial Life
description: Judicial life is not what it used to be, Chief Judge Wilfred Feinberg of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, said yesterday. He noted a change - for the worse - as he was awarded the Federal Bar Council's annual Learned Hand Medal for ''excellence in Federal jurisprudence.''

title: DARTMOUTH URGING ARMS HALT
description: David T. McLaughlin, the president of Dartmouth College, yesterday urged all those connected with the school to join the search for ''realistic answers'' to the growth of nuclear armaments, which he called ''the most immediate, challenging and compelling issue of our time.''

title: The Reagan Crew at Sea
description: A great venture came to a sour climax last week when the Reagan Administration cast one of four votes against the Law of the Sea, which American diplomacy helped initiate. This ambitious charter aims to bring harmony out of discordant territorial claims and remove from legal limbo the seabed wealth of copper, nickel, cobalt and manganese.

title: West German Outlook
description: West Germany's five leading economic research institutes, in a gloomy report on the country's economy, warned today that unemployment could stay high for years as economic growth was likely to remain weak. The joint study dismissed the Government's $5.4 billion job-creation program as ill suited and not long enough to have much impact. The study predicted economic growth at a rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in 1982, after a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in 1981, but a decline in unemployment to rise further, to an average 1.8 million, or 7.5 percent of the labor force, from 1.3 million in 1981.

title: BALLET SCHOOL STARTS FUND-RAISING DRIVE
description: The New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet has announced the start of a two-year campaign to raise $15 million.

title: MOROCCO, BACKED BY U.S., SPURS ECONOMIC BUILDUP IN WEST SAHARA
description: Garbed in a French designer suit, Mohammed Hossain Matala drives around this dusty desert town in a Mercedes limousine. The 33-year-old builder has become wealthy in Western Sahara's construction boom.

title: News Analysis
description: In an era when political campaigns often are what people see on television, ideas have to be packed into 22-second segments, Mario M. Cuomo complains. And, he continues, Mayor Koch is very good at it.

title: Business and the Law; Starting Pay: No Going Rate
description: AT the big New York law firms, this year's salary news is that the ''going rate'' may be gone. Since 1968, when Cravath, Swaine & Moore nearly doubled its starting salary to $15,000, the rates the top firms pay for lawyers fresh out of school have almost tripled. Last year, the going rate for the most sought after law graduates was $43,000, up from $37,000 the year before. Summer interns who had completed the first two years of law school earned $850 to $900 a week.

title: THE RETURN OF FAMOUS NATIVES TO GREENVILLE, MISS.
description: The Mississippi Delta town that says it is a cradle of progressive thought in the South has been congratulating itself while it staged a marathon celebration honoring some of the famous people it gave to the world of the arts.

title: TESTIMONY LINKS SOUTH AFRICAN ARMS TO COUP
description: Col. Michael Hoare, the mercenary leader of the bungled Seychelles coup attempt, testified Monday that the South African Government had approved the attempted takeover and supplied the weapons, South African television reported.

title: REPORT ASSERTS CUTS ARE MAKING WELFARE PREFERABLE TO WORK
description: Federal budget cuts in the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program have, in many cases, made it profitable for the working poor to leave their jobs and become totally dependent on welfare, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Urban League.

title: EDUCATION
description: CONCERNED that they may be caught short with low enrollments as a result of cutbacks in student aid and economic uncertainty, many private colleges, including some of the nation's most prestigious, have increased the number of applicants they are accepting for next September's freshman class and have expanded their waiting lists.

title: THRIFT GIANT PICKS OUTSIDER AS CHIEF
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, a big savings and loan holding company based in San Diego, said yesterday that Matthew J. Shevlin Jr., executive vice president at the Avco Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., had been named chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Bridge In Bidding, the Key Word Can Sometimes Be 'Pass'
description: Almost half a century ago two English experts indulged in an experiment that would nowadays draw an official reprimand. Playing in a club tournament, they agreed that they would pass throughout, irrespective of their hands.

title: SOVIET BLAMES U.S. FOR BRITISH MOVES
description: The Soviet Union depicted the United States today as having touched off the flurry of British military actions in the South Atlantic, but a series of official press commentaries offered no sign that the Kremlin intended to involve itself more directly in the conflict.

title: An Angry 'Truck'
description: The hostility that frequently erupts within a badly beaten team was stirring in Phoenix on Sunday after the Suns had been eliminated from the playoffs in four straight games by the Los Angeles Lakers. The angered party was Len (Truck) Robinson, the veteran power forward, who was upset that he had been benched for much of the second quarter and all of the fourth in the Suns' 112-107 fourth-game loss.

title: STOCKS UP IN QUIET TRADING
description: Stock prices advanced slightly yesterday in quiet trading, although several issues showed wide price changes in response to corporate developments. Utility stocks, reversing their decline of the four previous sessions, moved higher.

title: Six Young Pianists Gain Orchestra Residencies
description: Affiliate Artists and the Xerox Corporation have announced details of a residency program in which six young pianists will appear for two-week residencies with 14 American orchestras.

title: TV: FIRST 'BOOK OF LISTS' AND A GREEK GOES HOME
description: IN our current Age of Marketing, ''Book of Lists'' somehow had to make it to television. Created by the Wallechinsky/Wallace clan - Irving, David and Amy - the best-selling books are to serious publishing what the Pet Rock was to serious collecting. The point, however, is that they sell and, just maybe, they can be repackaged and sold again. Tonight at 8 o'clock, then, CBS-TV is beginning the first of four ''Book of Lists'' hours, somewhat anxiously described as action-packed variety shows.

title: ARMS PACT REVIVAL IS BEING PROMOTED
description: Several members of both houses of Congress and some former high Government officials, spurred by the campaign to halt the growth of nuclear arsenals, are pressing for a revival of the 1979 strategic arms treaty.

title: Grey's Net Drops 12.8%
description: Grey Advertising released its first-quarter results Friday, showing its net income declined 12.8 percent, to $437,000, or 84 cents a share, from $501,000, or 75 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues increased 24.7 percent, to $29.1 million, from $23.3 million in the first quarter last year.

title: Books Of The Times
description: A HISTORY OF VENICE. By John Julius Norwich. 673 pages. Knopf. $22.95. VENICE: The Most Triumphant City. By George Bull. 192 pages. St. Martin's. $16.95.

title: Lemon Oil Shrinks Bugs
description: Oil from the seeds of the sacred Neem tree, a relative of mahogany and native of India, has long been used in Asia as a treatment for skin diseases and as a hair tonic.

title: SUFFOLK COUNTY TO EXPAND ITS JAILS
description: County Executive Peter F. Cohalan of Suffolk proposed today a $133.6 million capital program for 1983-85 that includes plans to expand the county's jails.

title: SAUDIS GET STAKE IN IBH
description: A Saudi Arabian group, in a major Arab entry into Western European industry, has acquired a 17.87 percent share of IBH Holding A.G., the West German construction machinery group that is partly owned by the General Motors Corporation, IBH announced today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report on April 26 in the Advertising column of Business Day incorrectly stated a relationship between American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Executone phones. Executone phones are produced by Executone Inc., a unit of the Continental Telephone Company.

title: 3 MONTHS INTO STRIKE, BOMBAY'S WORKERS BEAR UP
description: For the last three months, Bombay's quarter of a million textile workers have been on strike, following the lead of a physician who has confronted both industrialists and established labor unions and seriously disrupted the economic life of India's richest city.

title: Advertising; Premiums, Incentives And Sales
description: THE first prospect to pass the comparatively small exhibition booth that Laurence F. Good of Wheeling, W.Va., was manning at the Premium Incentive Show at the New York Coliseum yesterday was inundated with a enthusiastic flood of information about the Personal History System. It is Mr. Good's creation.

title: Southwest Leasing
description: The Southwest Leasing Corporation, a Los Angeles-based car and truck rental company with annual revenues of about $70 million, said yesterday that it had begun discussions regarding a possible merger. The company refused to disclose further details.

title: Hearns Hurting
description: Thomas Hearns has an injured hand that could force a postponement of his May 24 middleweight title bout with the champion Marvelous Marvin Hagler, Hearns's manager said tonight. Emanuel Steward, the manager, told radio station WJR in Detroit that Hearns ''hurt his hand when he was running a few weeks ago,'' and cannot punch at full strength. He said a decision would be made Tuesday.

title: Carter's Tour
description: Former President Jimmy Carter is off on a tour of Scandinavia, where he will speak on nuclear weapons, world peace, the Middle East, environmental quality and human rights.

title: AMERICAN FALL FASHIONS: THE NEW FUNCTIONALISM
description: Fashion is in transition. The contest is not between long or short skirts, narrow or full skirts or 1950's hourglass styles versus 1960's rectangular shapes. It is between clothes for leisured, moneyed women who use them as a symbol of their social status and women who think of fashion in a functional way.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American General Corporation, Houston, has elected to its board Wendell L. Dixon, chairman and chief executive officer of Credithrift Financial Inc.

title: OPEC Output Off in Quarter
description: For the first time in 20 years the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries produced less oil in the first quarter of 1982 than the rest of the nonCommunist world, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday.

title: Chess: Korchnoi and Pinter Finish First in Rome Tournament; Ry ROBERT BYRNE
description: The grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and the international master Jozsef Pinter of Hungary shared first place in the Banco di Roma Tournament in Rome. Each scored 7-2.

title: Carolina Election Shifted
description: The North Carolina Board of Elections voted Sunday to reschedule primary elections from June 10 to June 29 in compliance with United States Justice Department terms for accepting the state's new redistricting plans. The decision at a special board meeting was the latest in a long series of maneuvers designed to win Federal approval of North Carolina's redistricting plans.

title: SALVADOR'S LEADER BARS NEGOTIATIONS
description: El Salvador's new President, Alvaro Magana, today ruled out negotiations with the country's leftist rebels as a means of ending the civil war here.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE: U.S. PREPARES MONUMENTOUS STEP TOWARD DISPOSAL
description: covered land at the edge of the Atlantic coastal plain, has been producing plutonium and tritium for nuclear warheads. Now it is here that scientists are preparing to take the first momentous step in this country toward permanent disposal of the enormous quantities of radioactive waste generated.

title: Sports of The Times; His Goal Is to Play
description: GAME after game, Roland Melanson watches with admiration as Billy Smith protects the New York Islander goal like a samurai swordfighter protecting his home. Melanson knows his place with the Islanders but admits ''it's very disappointing to me'' to be sitting as the champions chase their third straight Stanley Cup.

title: Soviet Culture Center in Laos Is Bombed by Guerrilla Group
description: Soldiers ringed the Soviet Culture Center today after attackers believed to be anti-Communist guerrillas blew up part of the three-story building in downtown Vientiane.

title: Conservationists in an Offer Of Peace, but Challenge Watt
description: An environmental group called Sunday for an end of the ''cold war'' between the Reagan Administration and conservationists. At the same time, it denounced Interior Secretary James G. Watt for what it called ''exploitation'' of public resources.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Anybody who says that what we are trying to do is corny doesn't understand how fragile this democracy is.'' - Frank J. Macchiarola, Schools Chancellor, on new citizenship course. (B1:5.)

title: BILLY WILDER HONORED AT LINCOLN CENTER GALA
description: In ''Sunset Boulevard,'' the screenwriter hero complains, ''Audiences don't know anyone writes a picture -they think the actors make it up as they go along.'' Be that as it may, the author of that line, Billy Wilder, has earned international acclaim for writing and directing such pictures as ''Sunset Boulevard,'' ''Double Indemnity,'' ''The Lost Weekend,'' ''Stalag 17,'' ''Some Like It Hot'' and ''The Apartment'' - he has won 6 Oscars and been nominated for 20 Academy Awards - and last night, many of his colleagues from Hollywood and New York turned out to honor his achievement at the Film Society of Lincoln Center's annual gala.

title: A VARIABLE OIL IMPORT FEE TO HOLD OPEC AT BAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Security Forces Raid Leftist Hideouts
description: Iranian security forces killed or arrested more than 50 members of the leftist People's Mujahedeen in raids on their hideouts in Teheran today, the Teheran radio said.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Saving Lives - and Detroit

title: News Analysis
description: The love-hate relationship Congress has had with its budget process is undergoing its most severe test, as the lawmakers try to put together a budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: CHILDREN TO GET A COURSE IN RESPONSIBLE BEHAVIOR
description: Concerned about antisocial behavior among many youngsters, the Board of Education has begun a broad new effort to teach the responsibilities of citizenship in New York City's public schools.

title: For Oil, Magic; for Gas ...
description: The Reagan Administration is bragging up a storm over its energy policy. In a weekend Op-Ed article in The Times, Danny Boggs, a White House policy adviser, wrote that ''In early 1981, United States energy policy changed markedly.'' Oil prices were decontrolled, bringing a welcome drop in imports and consumption and a welcome increase in production. At the Knoxville World's Fair Saturday, President Reagan described similar benefits. They derive, he said, from his reliance on the ''magic in the free marketplace.''

title: Braves Top Pirates
description: Claudell Washington hit a three-run homer in the fourth inning and Glenn Hubbard had four hits and drove in three runs tonight to pace the Atlanta Braves to a 10-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: 2 Models Built On G.M. Line
description: Workers at the General Motors Corporation's Oklahoma City plant began operations today on the auto maker's only assembly line capable of building more than one car model, a G.M. spokesman said.

title: Germans Jail Journalist
description: A West Berlin court sentenced an East German journalist to two years in jail today after convicting him of trying to recruit the son of a West German press spokesman to spy for East Germany. The court said Hans-Joachim Kittelmann was clearly a member of the East German state security forces and had been involved in espionage activity posing as a journalist.

title: STATE SENATE TO LET CAREY'S BIG BUDGET CUTS STAND
description: Warren M. Anderson, the Senate Republican leader, announced tonight that the Senate would let stand virtually all of Governor Carey's $941 million in budget vetoes.

title: STRUCK JERSEY UTILITY SAYS IT'S OPERATING NORMALLY
description: Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, maintained normal operations today despite a strike by more than 4,600 electrical and professional workers, a spokesman for the utility said.

title: Cable System Purchase
description: Affiliated Publications, publisher of The Boston Globe newspaper, said that it and the McCaw Communications Company had jointly bought the Southern Oregon Broadcasting Company, an operator of cable television systems in southern Oregon, for an undisclosed amount. Affiliated, which owns 45 percent of McCaw, said that as part of the same transaction the two companies had also purchased Pacific Teletronics Inc., a microwave common carrier, and certain assets of California Oregon Broadcasting Inc. Southern Oregon Broadcasting has 55,000 basic subscribers and 21,000 pay units in 15 southern Oregon communities.

title: Thais Smash Heroin Refinery
description: Border police stormed a heroin refinery in northern Thailand, killing one defender and seizing 44 pounds of heroin, the police said today. The police said the refinery was being run by Haw tribesmen, most of whom retreated into the forested countryside.

title: ROLL UP THE RED CARPET EXTENDED TO MOBUTU
description: Before a revolutionary situation develops in Zaire and undermines United States interests there, the Administration ought to re-examine its relationship with President Mobutu Sese Seko.

title: CABLE TV, BUYOYED BY POPULARITY, LOOKS TO FUTURE
description: The 31st National Cable Television Association convention began Sunday in a sudden and unexpected rainstorm that flooded the streets but hardly the buoyant spirits of the cable industry.

title: 18 Arrested at Derby In a Pickpocket Ring
description: The police say a Chicago man directed a ring of pickpockets at the Kentucky Derby made up of at least 18 youths whose parents owed him money.

title: CITIFIED AUSTRALIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Carbide to End $1 Billion Pact
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it was withdrawing from a $1 billion Government contract under which it has operated four nuclear research facilities in Kentucky and Tennessee since the mid-1940's. The company said it had offered to extend its current Energy Department contract, however, for three years to give the Government enough time to find a replacement.

title: HIGH COURT REBUFFS APPEAL TO DEFER STATE REDISTRICTING
description: The United States Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by the State Senate's Republicans to defer reapportionment of the New York State Legislature until next year, and officials here said the decision cleared the way for agreement by the end of the week on new lines for Congressional State Senate and State Assembly districts.

title: The U.N. Today; May 4, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WHITNEY MUSEUM SUED OVER 1980 'LIGHT SHOW'
description: A ''light show'' that reportedly caused injury to spectators at the Whitney Museum in December 1980 is the subject of two recently filed lawsuits that have lawyers here searching for precedents.

title: MOVEMENT GROWS TO CREATE GUIDELINES FOR MENTAL THERAPY
description: WHEN a man asked his insurance company to reimburse him for $14,000 worth of primal-scream therapy, during which he had spent many hours screaming to relieve himself of various traumas, the company refused to pay and the judge ruled that it did not have to. Primal therapy was not a ''usual and customary treatment'' for his condition, the judge agreed.

title: UNCERTAINTY IN SHALE OIL TOWN
description: Like most of the others who moved here to work on the nearby Colony Oil Shale Project, Jerry Ferguson figured he was making a solid investment when he sank most of his life savings last February into a new $72,000 home.

title: CAUGHT IN A WORLD OF CHANGE, BALINESE GO THEIR OWN WAY
description: The fighting cocks fly into the air in a flurry of feathers and squawks. When they land, one is dead, dispatched by the blade tied to its opponent's leg.

title: Former Aide to Reagan Cleared in Loan Case
description: The Justice Department has concluded that Joseph W. Canzeri, a former White House aide, did not violate Federal law when he accepted mortgages from friends at favorable interest rates and submitted double billings on two expense accounts.

title: HERPES NOW BLAMED FOR MORE ILLNESS THAN ANY OTHER HUMAN VIRUSES
description: THE herpes viruses, among the most ubiquitous, persistent and resistant of infectious organisms, are fast gaining notoriety as a cause of human ills. Indeed, every species of animal seems to have evolved with its own contingent of disease-causing herpes viruses, and few herpes infections in any species have thus far proved curable or preventable.

title: Japanese Population Growth
description: Japan's population grew this year at its slowest rate in postwar history, the Government announced.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: AFTER almost two months of American and European fall collections, the judgment of all d iscerning observers was that there was, finally, too much to look a t. In two weeks of New York showings over 50 major and minor new f ashion trends emerged: the return of the peacoat, suit and tailored j acket, layered leggings, knitted stockings that match the shoes, s heer to see-through blouses, vests layered over coats, and petal w rap skirts.

title: ALGERIAN AIDE DIES IN PLANE CRASH
description: Foreign Minister Mohammed Ben Yahia of Algeria, who played a key role in efforts to free the American hostages in Iran, was killed in the crash of an official Algerian plane on a flight to Teheran, Iran announced today. He was 49 years old.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING DOWN BY 0.8% IN MARCH
description: Spending on new construction in the United States fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in March as a steep decline in industrial building dragged the overall construction figure to its lowest level since last October, the Government said today.

title: WEST BANK IS ISRAEL'S, BEGIN ASSERTS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel would demand sovereignty over the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip at the end of the five-year transition period envisioned by the Camp David accords. He also vowed that no Jewish settlements in the territories would be dismantled as a result of any future peace negotiations.

title: Army Basic Training Ends Male-Female Units
description: The Army will end a 4-year-old practice of having companies made up of men and women in basic training because it feels the men are not being sufficiently physically challenged.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why does a shadow have blurry edges when the object casting the shadow has sharply defined edges?

title: PRESIDENT IS RETIRING FROM GOLEDEN NUGGET
description: Golden Nugget Inc., which operates casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., and in Atlantic City, said yesterday that its president, Robert R. Maxey, 45 years old, planned to retire from active service on June 30.

title: INDIA SEIZES 350 AFTER RELIGIOUS CLASHES
description: More than 350 militant Hindus and Sikhs were arrested throughout the state of Punjab in the last two days as the police tried to quell disorders that flared after two severed cow's heads were left at Hindu temples last week.

title: LONDON REPORTS NEW CLASH AT SEA
description: The Defense Ministry reported today that missilefiring British helicopters sank an Argentine patrol vessel and damaged another ship early this morning in a clash off the Falkland Islands.

title: Disney Title Suit
description: Walt Disney Productions said that it had filed suit against Williams Electronics Inc. for infringing on its ''Tron'' trademark.

title: Article 110946 -- No Title
description: The State Attorney General said today he would ask the Legislature to restore $1 million to the budget of the Division of Motor Vehicles to begin a computerization program designed to eliminate corruption.

title: Florida Asks Court Ban On Mining in U.S. Forest
description: The Governor of Florida, its two Senators and half a dozen state and national environmental groups joined today to sue Interior Secretary James G. Watt and Agriculture Secretary John R. Block in an attempt to halt the granting of phosphate strip mining leases in the 157,000-acre Osceola National Forest.

title: Borden Purchase
description: Borden Inc., which manufactures a variety of consumer and industrial products, announced its intention to purchase a line of car care products from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company for an undisclosed price.

title: VIOLIST KNOWEN FOR PURITY OF TONE
description: William Primrose, the greatest violist of his time, died Saturday of cancer at his home in Provo, Utah. He was 77 years old. During a career of some 50 years, Mr. Primrose was soloist, chamber-music player, orchestra musician, teacher and proselytizer for his chosen instrument. He also found time to fly a plane, play chess on a high level, play cricket and golf and become an authority on certain phases of American history.

title: Bid to Delay Bell Case
description: The Justice Department filed a request today with a Federal court judge here asking for a delay until June 11 on its deadline to reply to comments on the proposed antitrust settlement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. In addition, the department asked Judge Harold H. Greene to modify his order requiring publication of all the comments in the Federal Register, a project that would cost about $500,000, Justice Department officials say. Wednesday is the deadline for the department's report on the comments.

title: TALK OF THE KENNEDY BOOK AWARDS
description: It could have been a Kennedy campaign reunion, or even a curtain-raiser for a future race. There was Arthur Schlesinger Jr., sipping a daquiri on the terrace overlooking the swimming pool, while Fred Dutton, David Hackett, John Siegenthaler and Louis Martin chatted nearby.

title: Earnings Decline 20% At Ogilvy & Mather
description: Like the JWT Group, which announced its first-quarter results last week, Ogilvy & Mather International suffered from the Mexican peso devaluation.

title: Savard Is Fined
description: Denis Savard, a center for the Chicago Black Hawks, has been fined $500 for spitting in the direction of Referee Andy van Hellemond at the end of last Saturday's playoff game against Vancouver, the National Hockey League announced yesterday. The league also said that a hearing would be held later this week to decide what action to take against the Bruins' Terry O'Reilly, who punched van Hellemond April 25 in the final playoff game between Boston and the Quebec Nordiques.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Fri- day about company profits incorrect- ly reported the per-share earnings of Dart & Kraft Inc. for the first quarter of 1982. They fell to $1.77 a share, from $1.90 a share.

title: Seymour Begins Race For Moynihan's Seat
description: Labeling Daniel Patrick Moynihan's record in the United States Senate ''bankrupt,'' Whitney North Seymour Jr. began a campaign yesterday for the Republican nomination for Mr. Moynihan's job.

title: Drinking Age to Be 19 In Connecticut July 1
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed a bill today raising Connecticut's drinking age to 19 as of July 1. He said it should help reduce alcohol consumption in high schools.

title: BARNS HOUSE LONG SHOTS AND LOST HOPES
description: Other than the race itself, the significant dramas of the 108th Kentucky Derby had unfolded during the last two weeks at Barn 41 on the Churchill Downs backstretch.

title: QUESTOR'S GOAL: TO BUILD A FUTURE FROM DIVERSE PARTS
description: ''If I were a securities analyst,'' Dan W. Lufkin told a meeting of Questor Corporation executives in February 1981, ''I would be bullish on Questor.''

title: A's GET 4 IN 8th, TOP YANKS, 5-2
description: Less than a week after Reggie Jackson dramatically returned to Yankee Stadium, Billy Martin made his first appearance of 1982 last night. The Yankees would like to forget both visits.

title: Opera Group to Present Herbert's 'Enchantress'
description: Victor Herbert's ''The Enchantress'' will be given its first New York performances in nearly 70 years by the Bel Canto Opera Company beginning Friday.

title: Chase's Money Fund Program
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that it had begun a program in which a customer can have the bank automatically invest all checking-account funds in excess of $7,500 in money market mutual funds.

title: BLACK SCHOOL CHIEF ON COAST FACES CHALLENGE
description: Wilson Riles, the first black to win a statewide race in California, faces a serious fight for re-election for the first time since he became State Superintendent of Public Instruction in 1970.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Public Service Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a sale of two million cumulative preferred shares, series O, to be offered through a Dean Witter Reynolds group.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON PLEA BY INDEPENDENT CANDIDATE
description: The Supreme Court, revisiting the 1980 Presidential election, agreed today to decide whether states can require independent candidates to abide by special rules that do not apply to Presidential nominees of recognized political parties.

title: INVESTOR GROUP IS SUED BY SOUTHEAST BANKING
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation filed a suit yesterday charging that a group of local investors tried to manipulate its stock. The group already has obtained a 9.59 percent interest in Southeast, Florida's largest banking organization.

title: PIANIST: VARSANO'S FRENCH FOCUS
description: IS it possible that the piano works of Satie, Ravel, Chabrier, Faure and Debussy all were written by one composer whose identity musicologists have not yet uncovered? Daniel Varsano's recital last night at Alice Tully Hall was so unchanging in style from start to finish that such idle speculations began to come to mind. Mr. Varsano, a young Frenchman has been making a name as a specialist in Satie and Faure, in particular, and in Gallic music in general. However, he played in a cosmetic fashion, tickling the skin of each piece but rarely penetrating it in any way.

title: NCC Plans to Sell Simplicity Stake
description: NCC Energy Ltd. is seeking to sell its 20 percent interest in the Simplicity Pattern Company, the large sewing patterns producer, which had suspended a planned merger with NCC Energy. That merger was halted in March in an effort by Simplicity to concentrate on making acquisitions in domestic and foreign oil and gas operations.

title: Pioneer Gas Wells
description: The Pioneer Production Corporation, a unit of the Pioneer Corporation, yesterday announced two gas discovery wells. Its Hicklin No. 1-9 well in Washita County in western Oklahoma flowed at a daily rate of 8 million cubic feet through an 11/64th inch choke from perforations at 12,263 to 13,588 feet, Pioneer said. A second well in Roberts County, Tex., flowed 3.6 million cubic feet of gas daily through a 20/64th inch opening from perforations at 11,067 to 11,036 feet.

title: MUSIC: TWO GROUPS SING BERLIOZ'S REQUIEM
description: BERLIOZ'S Requiem attempts to wake the dead as much as recall them for the living. The brass proclamations coming from four sides of the concert hall, the shouts of the chorus, the groans of basses, the modal chants -at its worst, all this can become Romantic kitsch, an alarm clock for the concertgoing soul.

title: Military Analysis
description: With Britain again making successful use of the helicopter as a weapon against Argentine naval vessels, British naval sources say the Argentines have shown a significant lack of understanding of the power and accuracy of air-launched missiles.

title: SOME AIRLINES' SELF-INFLICTED WOUNDS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Former Representative Takes on an Incumbent
description: ''I'm not doing this,'' John C. Dow was saying yesterday, ''out of any animosity to Samuel Stratton.''

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Judaism and Psychoanalysis

title: A Better Pollinator
description: The hornfaced bee, a small insect imported from Japan, is helping to increase fruit yields in United States orchards by pollinating apple, peach, cherry and plum blossoms more efficiently than the Italian honeybee, the common pollinator of American orchards and gardens.

title: U.S. OFFERS JORDAN NEW ARMS AND PROSPECT OF MORE
description: The Reagan Administration has offered to sell newly developed jet fighters and antiaircraft missiles to Jordan in the first phase of an arms sale that could eventually include advanced fighters and missiles, Administration and industry officials said today.

title: QE2 IS TAKEN AS TROOPSHIP BY THE BRITISH
description: The Queen Elizabeth 2, one of the world's most elegant and luxurious ocean liners, has been commandeered by the British Navy to take troops to the South Atlantic.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Craig Littlepage, considered smallish as a 6-foot-6-inch starting center for Penn's highly successful basketball team a decade ago, got a big prize from his alma mater yesterday: a three-year contract as the Quakers' new head coach, succeeding Bob Weinhauer, who was hired by Arizona State last month. Littlepage, 30 years old, inherits a team that has won the Ivy League championship in 10 of the last 13 years, including 1971 to 1973, when he played for Penn as a student at the Wharton School.

title: LONG STRIKE IS CALLED KEY McCARDELL ERROR
description: At the International Harvester Company's annual meeting several weeks ago, Archie R. McCardell told a questioner that being called a failure by stockholders and union members did not bother him.

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR POVERTY
description: If the Reagan Administration adopts a Census Bureau report that discusses the inclusion of noncash benefits in defining poverty, the poor may wind up in even greater trouble than they are in now.

title: 'DROPOUTS' SPUR YALE CREW
description: Chuck Papesh comes from Aurora, a small town in Ohio, where he played high school football with some distinction. Before going east to college, the only thing he knew about rowing was that you did it when you went fishing if your outboard motor failed.

title: Indonesian Troops Put On Alert for Elections
description: More than 50,000 troops and militia were put on full alert today as Indonesians prepared to vote in general elections Tuesday for a new Parliament.

title: Red Sox Subdue Twins, 6-2
description: Two-run homers by Dave Stapleton and Rick Miller powered Boston to a 6-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight to give the Red Sox their fourth consecutive triumph and 12th in the last 13 games.

title: Maryland Town Votes Against Nuclear Arms
description: Residents of this small suburban Washington community voted overwhelmingly today for an ordinance that makes the town, which is 14 miles from a hypothetical atomic bomb target at the White House, the nation's first nuclear-weapons-free zone.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 4, 1982; International
description: U.S. Steel will file new unfair trade complaints against foreign competitors on Friday, the company said. The action will widen the industry's case against the foreign steelmakers to include every major category of steel imports. The company also said that, because of a sharp decline in steel demand, it is thinking of shutting down its huge integrated steel mill at Fairfield, Ala. (Page D1.)

title: Coca-Cola Merger
description: Shareholders of the Coca-Cola Company voted to approve the merger of Columbia Pictures Industries into Coca-Cola. The merger, which is valued at $750 million in stock and cash, was approved by Columbia Pictures' shareholders on April 30. Coca-Cola officials would not speculate on the timing, but Francis T. Vincent Jr., president and chief executive officer of Columbia Pictures, said that he expected to complete the merger by the end of June.

title: THE WAR ON INFLATION IS NOT THE VILLAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: HARVESTER CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: The International Harvester Company said today that Archie R. McCardell, its chairman and chief executive officer, had resigned, effective immediately. His departure followed by a month and a half the abrupt departure of Warren J. Hayford, who had been president and chief operating officer.

title: Metromedia-Radiofone Link
description: Metromedia Inc., which owns and operates seven television stations and 14 radio stations around the country, and the Radiofone Corporation, a smaller company that provides radio paging and twoway mobile radio telephone services, said they had agreed to a cash merger under which Radiofone's holders will receive $26 a share.

title: PARTIES' OUTLOOK: DISTINCTLY NATIONAL
description: Lengthy obituaries for the major political parties have long been required reading in any government course, but reports of the parties' demise seem to be premature.

title: TRAILBLAZER IN DESEGREGATION GIVES UP ON PUBLIC EDUCATION
description: Six-year-old Ruby Bridges braved stonethrowing mobs to become the first black child to attend an elementary school in the Deep South. Twenty years later, she has given up on public education and is sending her three children to private school.

title: Louis Menk
description: Louis W. Menk, 64 years old, new chairman of the International Harvester Company, retired as chairman of Burlington Northern Inc., a Seattle-based transportation and resource company, in December 1981 ... a Harvester director since 1974 ... Key in the creation of Burlington, of which he was president, formed of the Burlington & Quincy, Northern Pacific, Great Northern and several smaller railroads in 1970 ... Combination was considered largest and most successful railway merger of the time . . . Burlington's first president, elected chairman and chief executive officer in 1971, resigned the latler post in 1978. In tenure at Burlington, put together a $2 billion expansion, adding 100 miles of new track in Wyoming and rebuilding miles more of track to haul coal from Montana and Wyoming to Middle West and southern United States ... Mr. Menk also engineered merger of St. Louis & San Francisco Railway, where he was president and chairman during the 1960's, into Burlington in 1981 ... Graduate of Northwestern University, Mr. Menk lives in Care Free, Ariz., owns a cattle ranch in Montana. Donald Lennox

title: BELL ASSAILS CRITICISM OF PLANS TO CUT STUDENT AID AS UNJUST
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell charged today that college students had been misled about the effect of the Reagan Administration's proposed cutbacks in student aid.

title: Reed Enshrined
description: Yesterday was induction day at the Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., which welcomed seven new members. Those enshrined as star players were Willis Reed, the Knicks' center in their championship years; Hal Greer of the Syracuse Nationals and the Philadelphia 76ers, Slater Martin of the Minneapolis Lakers and the St. Louis Hawks, and Frank Ramsey, the famed ''sixth man'' of the Boston Celtics. Along with them went two college coaches, Clarence (Big House) Gaines of Winston-Salem and the late Everett Case of North Carolina State, and Al O. Duer, who for nearly 25 years headed basketball activities for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

title: Prices of Treasury Notes Cut; 6-Month Bill Up to 12.78%
description: Securities dealers cut prices and raised yields yesterday on $9.25 billion of three- and 10-year Treasury notes in the hope that more investors would be attracted to the new issues.

title: BRIEFING
description: You Are What You Charge

title: METEORITE FOUND TO BE 'LEFT-HANDED'
description: APERSISTENT puzzle, in seeking to understand how life came into being, is why the structure of amino acids, the chief building blocks of life, is always ''left-handed.'' Yet when such acids, of which proteins are formed, are synthesized in the laboratory, half are right-handed and half left-handed, like a factory turning out equal numbers of gloves fitting both hands.

title: Treasury Note Futures Traded
description: Trading began yesterday at the Chicago Board of Trade in a new futures contract for 10-year Treasury notes. The trading volume for the first day was estimated at 22,000 contracts, compared with 35,000 for the Treasury bond contract - the most active financial futures contract.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ANTIOCH College lived up to its long history as an unconventional institution by announcing last month that it would not raise its tuition for the 1982-83 academic year. The decision comes at a time when most colleges are increasing tuitions by 12 to 18 percent.

title: BOTH SIDES TRY TO INFLUENCE REPORTS OF COMBAT
description: From the first shot in the fighting between Britain and Argentina in the South Atlantic, each side has in its own way tried to influence the news reports emanating from the battle area.

title: JOHN S. KOCH
description: John S. Koch, a partner in the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling, died last Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington of a pulmonary illness. He was 50 years old and lived in Washington.

title: U.S. STEEL WIDENING IMPORT PLEA
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced today that it would file a fresh batch of unfair trade complaints against foreign steelmakers on Friday, widening the industry's cluster of petitions to include every major category of steel imports.

title: U.S. ALLOWS REVIEW OF 2 HAITIAN CAMPS
description: The United States has agreed for the first time to let an international body examine conditions at two camps where Haitians are being detained, in Florida and in Puerto Rico.

title: Cooper Unit Sale
description: Cooper Laboratories Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif., maker of specialty medical and dental products, said it had completed the sale of its ''A'' Company - acquired by Cooper only last December - to the Johnson & Johnson Company for $37.5 million in cash. James L. Plastino, director of special services for Cooper, said the ''A'' Company, a producer of orthodontic braces, accounts for about 10 percent of the Sterndent Corporation, which Cooper acquired last year for a total of about $45 million. Mr. Plastino said two other units of Sterndent were on the block as well, and that the total divestiture would come to about $75 million.

title: NO MOHASCO TAKEOVER, BUT BAIL OUT ANYWAY
description: ''Golden parachutes,'' the latest perquisite in the executive suite, help officers bail out of a bad situation if their company is taken over by another.

title: Suit Settled At Firestone
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that it had reached a tentative agreement of more than $2.2 million in a shareholder suit filed against the company, several former officers, members of the Firestone family and Coopers & Lybrand, the company's independent auditors.

title: Park's Car Rules
description: Summer restrictions on auto traffic in Central Park went into effect today. Until October, northbound and southbound roads will be closed Monday through Friday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M., except for the section of the East Drive between Central Park South at Avenue of the Americas and 72d Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: Alabama Sets I.R.S. Accord
description: The State of Alabama and the Internal Revenue Service have settled a disagreement that could have blocked the May 11 delivery of $520 million of general obligation bonds the state sold last month.

title: IC to Buy Shares
description: IC Industries, a diversified consumer products company and the operator of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, announced that it had agreed to reacquire 2,149,319 shares of its common stock from the Union Pacific Corporation. IC is paying $72 million for the shares, which account for about 14.3 percent of IC's total outstanding. Union Pacific is under an order from the Interstate Commerce Commission to sell its IC holdings by Aug.10.

title: Getty Oil Planning Coast Energy Plant
description: The Getty Oil Company and the Southern California Edison Company said that they had signed an agreement to contract for a proposed cogeneration plant in the Kern River oilfield near Bakersfield, Calif.

title: CAPITAL JURY PICKED IN HINCKLEY TRIAL
description: A jury of seven women and five men was chosen today to try John W. Hinckley Jr. for shooting President Reagan and three other men.

title: ALIENS SEIZED BY U.S. REPORTED BACK AT WORK
description: Several companies in the New York metropolitan area where illegal aliens were rounded up last week reported yesterday that many of them had been released from custody and were back at their old jobs.

title: A JOLLY GOOD FELLOW
description: If there were an award for the Congressman who flouts the law most and seems the least perturbed by it, it would certainly have to go this year to Representative Frederick Richmond of Brooklyn.

title: CABLE TV BILL URGED IN '82 BY GOLDWATER
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, chairman of the Subcommittee on Communications, has announced that he will try to get a new comprehensive cable-industry regulation bill through the Senate this year, even though the chances for passing such legislation in the House appear slim.

title: CONFLICTING ADVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1
description: As the cause of cold sores and fever blisters, this virus infects about 90 percent of people, although only half ever get the annoying lip sores. The first attack commonly occurs as multiple lesions inside the mouth. It never again recurs inside the mouth, but may re-emerge to produce blisters on the border of the lips. It can also cause herpes keratitis, a potentially blinding ulceration of the cornea that is treatable with idoxuridine, and it sometimes causes encephalitis, with a mortality rate of 75 to 80 percent in untreated patients. Vidarabine cuts encephalitis mortality to less than 30 percent, but the drug itself is highly toxic. Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2

title: U.S. EXPRESSES 'DEEP REGRET' OVER REPORTED LOSS OF LIVES
description: The Reagan Administration expressed ''deep regret'' tonight over the reported heavy loss of life in the sinking of the Argentine cruiser Belgrano.

title: PROXY FIGHT IS SET AT GULF RESOURCES
description: Alan E. Clore, the British investor, said yesterday that he would wage a proxy fight against the management of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation in an attempt to unseat top management of the coal, natural gas and chemicals company.

title: Market Place; The Spark In Options
description: STOCK options are like firecrackers with short, damp fuses. They may fizzle, expiring valueless in a few weeks' time. Or they may explode, providing manifold profits before their demise.

title: SONG: MARNI NIXON IN RECITAL
description: MARNI NIXON'S evening of songs Saturday at the 92d Street Y aimed more at light entertainment than anything else. There were some serious matters on the agenda - three songs by Debussy and then six by Hugo Wolf - but Miss Nixon's soprano was never quite sensuous enough for the Debussy, and lacked the dramatic flexibility to penetrate the Wolf.

title: Reliance Unit Lifts Holdings in Tiger
description: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation, a unit of Reliance Group Inc., announced that it had increased its holdings in Tiger International Inc., the air cargo concern, to 22.51 percent, and planned to increase that stake further to more than 25 percent.

title: PYM UNINTERESTED IN ANY U.N. EFFORTS NOW
description: Francis Pym, Britain's Foreign Secretary, displayed a marked lack of enthusiasm today for any early efforts by the United Nations to resolve the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: HIGH COURT ALLOWS SUITS BY COMMODITY INVESTORS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that investors in commodity futures are entitled to sue their brokers and the commodity exchanges for damages resulting from fraud or market manipulation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bechtel Petroleum Inc. said it had begun construction of a new lubricating oil producing facility at Chevron U.S.A.'s refinery complex in Richmond, Calif.

title: CLEAN AIR ACT VS. COMPETITION AND THE CONSUMER
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK SEEKS A STATE STRATEGY ON COCAINE USE
description: Alarmed by the popularity of cocaine and the deaths that have accompanied its abuse, New York State took a step yesterday toward devising a uniform statewide strategy for helping users of the drug.

title: Indiana Primary Today Is an Early Reagan Test
description: Indiana voters are to choose candidates Tuesday for the United States Senate, Congress and their Legislature in a prelude to what has been billed as November's referendum on the Reagan Administration's economic policies.

title: Greyhound Net Tumbles 55%
description: The Greyhound Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit fell 55 percent from its operating income of a year earlier while revenue was flat.

title: DUPONT OFF IN FIRST QUARTER
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's biggest chemical producer, reported yesterday that net income in the latest three months totaled $250 million, or $1.06 a share, down from $528 million, or $3.38 a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: VICTIMIZED FAMILY VISITED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan paid an impromptu visit late today to a suburban Washington home to reassure its black owners that the cross-burning they experienced five years ago was ''not something that should have ever happened in America.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KNOCKOUT SHOW

title: Macmillan's Schools To Della Femina
description: Be nice to everyone on the client side. You never know where they will turn up next.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bert Blyleven, the Cleveland Indian pitcher, was placed on the 60-day disabled list and is to undergo surgery on his right elbow today or tomorrow. The operation on the right-handed Blyleven is to be performed in Los Angeles by the noted orthopedic specialist Frank Jobe, who examined him yesterday. The Cleveland team physican, Earl Brightman, said an examination over the weekend indicated that Blyleven had torn muscle fiber.

title: U.S. SAID TO FAVOR INFORMAL REAGAN-BREZHNEV TALK
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a full-fledged summit meeting in October between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, but prefers an informal get-together of the two leaders, Administration officials reported today.

title: POLISH PROTESTERS CLASH WITH POLICE IN SEVERAL CITIES
description: Polish policemen battled demonstrators in Warsaw and other cities today with truncheons, water cannons, flares and tear gas as protests against the martial law Government increased.

title: DINOSAUR UNDER SIEGE
description: The Mesozoic Era was a tough 165 million years, no doubt about it. With great upheavals of the earth's crust, dramatic changes of climate, mountains forming, volcanoes erupting, flora and fauna coming and going, your swamp draining one day and going under 50 feet of water the next, you could become extinct. But for a 26-foot pink dinosaur that stands out on Route 6 in this day and age, life is no picnic either.

title: METS DEFEAT DODGERS, 6-3 IN 12
description: Hubie Brooks, struggling at the plate and benched for Sunday's doubleheader, drove in the first two runs of a three-run 12th inning tonight as the Mets beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-3.

title: U.S. Adds Chemicals To List of Cancer Ties
description: The Government has added 63 chemicals to its list of 25 substances known or expected to be capable of causing cancer in humans.

title: HUGH MARLOWE, 71, ACTOR OF STAGE AND SCREEN
description: Hugh Marlowe, an actor on the stage, in the movies and on radio and television for more than 50 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: PRESIDENT REPORTED SET TO ENDORSE AMENDMENT ON PRAYER IN SCHOOLS
description: President Reagan plans to announce his support of a proposed constitutional amendment authorizing voluntary group prayer in public schools, according to White House and Congressional aides.

title: MARION BARBER IS STARTING OVER
description: Marion Barber, who was around the team but not part of it last season, rejoined the New York Jets today. It was more than just his physical presence at the start of the veterans' minicamp that marked his return. Perhaps for the first time Barber felt he belonged. He did not isolate himself in a corner of the locker room, as he did throughout 1981, when he was, for the most part, the Jets' invisible man as he sat out the season on the injured-reserve list.

title: DANCE: CAROLYN ADAMS ADIEU
description: THE Paul Taylor Dance Company, playing to a packed house, closed its City Center season Sunday afternoon on a special heartwarming note.

title: Disco Cotillion
description: It's true that the cadets will have to catch a bus back to West Point just about the time things start picking up at the Manhattan discotheque tonight. But, according to Rabbi Avraham Soltes, the United States Military Academy's Jewish chaplain, they will have some consolation.

title: Cadwell Davis Savage Gains Thorn EMI Unit
description: Thorn EMI Video, an American affiliate of Thorn EMI of London, has become an advertising account of Cadwell Davis Savage, a subsidiary of Compton Advertising, which will soon become a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi, also of London.

title: NIKKO SECURITIES NAMES NEW HEAD OF U.S. UNIT
description: In Japan, says Toshio Mori, such business practices as hostile takeovers are taboo. Compromise, negotiation and consensus, he says, mark business deals, and the name for such behavior is ''nemawashi.''

title: CONCERT: SYMPHONIA ANTIQUA PLAYS WORKS OF LUDWIG SENFL
description: THE concerts presented by Music Before 1800 at Corpus Christi Church are intriguing examples of early-music programming, combining inventive variety with scrupulous musicianship. But on Sunday afternoon LaNoue Davenport directed the Symphonia Antiqua in the music of Ludwig Senfl, with mixed results.

title: Right Guard Goes To Y.&R.
