description: The Right Guard line of deodorants and antiperspirants has been switched by the Gillette personal care division from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn to Young & Rubicam, which has secretly been working for Gillette on new product assignments for a year.

title: ALBERT FITZGERALD, 75, FORMER UNION LEADER
description: Albert J. Fitzgerald, a former president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, died Saturday at the Boston University Hospital after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Lynn, Mass., the city of his birth.

title: McENROE LABORS TO GAIN
description: John McEnroe is not talking or playing like the world's No.1 tennis player, even after winning his opening-round match against Chris Johnstone of Australia, 6-4, 6-1, in the Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills last night.

title: Vietnam Has Sent 7,000 To Work in Soviet
description: The Soviet Union confirmed today that Vietnam had sent 7,000 people to work in Soviet industries, including some in Siberia.

title: JUDAIC CASE LAW IS GATHERED INTO A 'DATA BANK' IN CHICAGO
description: The computer screen in Rabbi Isaac Rosenbaum's office is like a window through which there appear glimpses into the trials of lives long past. Together, these cases represent a body of knowledge in question-and-answer form that has been compiled for 1,200 years in the Jewish tradition of the responsa.

title: Point-Fixer Draws A 10-Year Sentence
description: Paul Mazzei, the last of five men to receive punishment for a point-shaving conspiracy involving Boston College basketball games three years ago, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in Federal prison.

title: News Analysis
description: A drawn-out struggle for the Falkland Islands could exact a toll on United States relations with Argentina and other Latin American nations, policy analysts both in and out of Government believe.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Pan Am Seeking Braniff's Routes
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday filed requests with the Civil Aeronautics Board for some of Braniff International's Latin American routes, saying that the plan by Eastern Airlines to take over the routes would leave some serious gaps in United States flag service.

title: ANN LANDERS DIPS INTO OLD-MAIL BAG
description: Ann Landers, whose column of personal advice appears daily in newspapers reaching 70 million readers, said yesterday that about 30 columns this year and last contained letters or answers that were essentially unchanged from items in her column 15 years ago.

title: Willowbrook, Back in Court
description: If New York legislators are upset that a Federal judge has placed the state's Willowbrook Development Center for the mentally retarded in the hands of a special master, they have only themselves to blame.

title: AIRPORT SAFETY HEARINGS OPEN
description: Airline industry representatives and airport operators agreed today that information about runway conditions in severe weather often was imprecise and that accurate reports sometimes failed to reach pilots.

title: NEW PLAN FOR COUNCIL LINES OPPOSED
description: Eleven months after he approved the original boundaries and six months after they were struck down by the Justice Department, Mayor Koch held a surprisingly short and tranquil hearing yesterday on a new plan setting the lines for 35 districts of the New York City Council.

title: Pittston Controls Burlington Unit
description: The Pittston Company, a diversified Connecticut-based coal producer, said it had completed the aquisition of Burlington Northern Airfreight Inc., a unit of Burlington Northern Railroad, for $177 million.

title: Detroit Suburb Decision Ruled Racially Motivated
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Detroit suburb of Birmingham was ''in part racially motivated'' in its efforts to block construction of a housing project that would include apartments for low-income families.

title: Prince Andrew Flies Patrols in Helicopter
description: Prince Andrew, Queen Elizabeth II's second son, flew patrols in a Sea King helicopter from the British aircraft carrier Invincible on Saturday but was not involved in combat off the Falkland Islands, British correspondents reported in a pooled dispatch published today.

title: PRESIDENT BACKS BIPARTISAN PLAN ON VOTING LAW
description: A bipartisan group of Senators today agreed on a compromise version of the Voting Rights Act that won the backing of President Reagan. The broad-based support for the compromise virtually assured passage of an updated version of the measure, which was enacted in 1965.

title: I.T.T. Oil Venture
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said that its Eason Oil Company subsidiary of Oklahoma City had entered into a joint venture for oil and gas exploration with Moore-McCormack Oil and Gas, and Total Petroleum Inc. I.T.T. said that the three companies would each have equal interests in the exploration venture and that Total, which is half-owned by the Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles of Paris, would act as the operator. The venture extends the partners' current activity in their Port Acres-Hackberry Sand field in Jefferson County, Tex., I.T.T. said.

title: A CANDIDATE ON THE MOVE FOR POINTERS
description: Pat Bosch came to town from Arizona last week looking for two things, ideas and money. Mrs. Bosch is the Democratic candidate for Congress from Arizona's Third District, and only here could she meet ''eyeball to eyeball,'' as she put it, with the national party professionals who chart the themes and raise the funds that shape elections across the country.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 4, 1982
description: International Argentina's only cruiser sank after being torpedoed by a British submarine Sunday, Argentina announced. It said that 123 survivors had been picked up and that rescue operations were continuing. But an Argentine navy spokesman said that many of the 1,042 men aboard the 43-year-old American-built cruiser General Belgrano had probably been lost in the icy seas. (Page A1, Column 6.) Britain reported new navy victories. The Defense Ministry said that several hours after the Argentine cruiser was hit, missile-firing British helicopters had sunk an Argentine patrol vessel and damaged a second ship in the 200-mile blockade zone around the Falklands. (A1:5.)

title: Shawmut Bank Merger
description: The Shawmut Corporation and the Worcester Bancorp said today that they had completed their $47.3 million merger.

title: Former Oklahoma Back Dies During Operation
description: Mike Babb, a former defensive back at the University of Oklahoma, died today during surgery to repair a knee injury suffered in a recent varsity-alumni game.

title: Daughter for a Mezzo
description: A follow-up: Last Valentine's Day, after spending several years together, Maria Ewing, the mezzo-soprano, and Sir Peter Hall, the director of Britain's National Theater and winner of a Tony award for directing ''Amadeus,'' decided to marry.

title: Saab-Fairchild Aircraft
description: The first Saab-Fairchild 340 twin-turboprop airliner will roll out of the new Saab-Scania aircraft plant here on Oct. 27, Saab-Scania A.B. said today. The first flight is scheduled for early next year, it added in a statement. Saab-Scania and Fairchild Industries are cooperating on the joint development, production and marketing of the 34-passenger airliner and executive aircraft.

title: LIFE IN SUBURBS: SINGLES ADJUST
description: To be young and single in New York's northern suburbs is, to Tom Butler, ''utopia.'' To Carole Thompson, the same equation is ''not 'Fantasy Island.' ''

title: 16 TENEMENTS TO BECOME ARTIST UNITS IN CITY PLAN
description: Two blocks of abandoned city-owned tenement buildings on the Lower East Side will be renovated, some by artists themselves and others by developers for eventual sale to artists, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: HAZARDOUS NEIGHBOR TO A BRONX PROJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: Foothills Seeks New Financing
description: Foothills Pipelines Ltd., the primary contractor for the 2,060-mile Canadian portion of the Alaska Highway Natural Gas Pipeline, said it is working on a new financing and construction schedule to begin operations by late 1989.

title: Defense for Moon
description: Lawyers for the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the leader of the Unification Church, began presenting his defense against tax-fraud charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: SAYS 123 OF 1,042 ON BOARD HAVE BEEN SAVED
description: Argentina announced tonight that its only cruiser, carrying 1,042 sailors, had sunk after being torpedoed by a British submarine in the South Atlantic on Sunday. It said that 123 survivors had been picked up and that rescue operations were continuing.

title: POLITICS VS. ECONOMICS
description: The predictable collapse of 39 days of two-party negotiations for a budget compromise confirms one of the iron laws of government: politics beats economics every time.

title: Big 10 Basketball Moves On 3-Point Experiment
description: The Big Ten Conference is moving to adopt an experimental 3-point field goal for the coming basketball season, Commissioner Wayne Duke said today.

title: Vietnamese in Cambodia Said to Pull Back
description: Vietnamese forces in Cambodia have pulled back from several areas near the Thai border that were captured in a four-month offensive against guerrillas of the toppled Pol Pot regime, a senior military officer said today.

title: STAGE: 'MASTER HAROLD,' FUGARD'S DRAMA ON ORIGIN OF HATE
description: THERE may be two or three living playwrights in the world who can write as well as Athol Fugard, but I'm not sure that any of them has written a recent play that can match '' 'Master Harold' ... and the Boys.'' Mr. Fugard's drama - lyrical in design, shattering in impact - is likely to be an enduring part of the theater long after most of this Broadway season has turned to dust.

title: American Can Deal
description: The American Can Company will sign a definitive agreement with the James River Corporation shortly for James River to buy much of its paper business for $420 million in cash and stock, William S. Woodside, chairman of American Can, said yesterday, in a move out of the paper industry into ''faster-growing'' financial services.

title: Seaver Beats Astros by 5-2
description: Tom Seaver held Houston to four hits in seven innings tonight to gain his first victory of the season as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Astros, 5-2.

title: Dear Ann
description: To tell you the truth, I was getting a little suspicious myself. But it wasn't the letter from the woman who washed the peeled banana (March 1982) that was so like the one from the woman who washed her money (April 1967) that got me.

title: Fact Magazine Is Sent To Value Line List
description: Arnold Bernhard & Company, which has been selling Value Line, the country's largest investment advisory service, to upscale interested parties for $330 a year, is now sending the 100,000 subscribers a free monthly magazine called Fact and subtitled The Money Management Magazine.

title: Advertising; Kensington Fragrances Gearing Up
description: IN the fall when the fragrance industry begins to come to a boil over impending Christmas sales, consumers will first start to hear about Pascalle for women and Cameron for men.

title: OLD, RARE COOKBOOKS ON DISPLAY
description: Cookbooks more than a thousand years old prove that health fads and good food are hardly new ideas. ''Elaborate and inventive recipes appear in every age,'' said Walter Johnson, associate director of the Rosenbach Museum here, which is exhibiting 35 rare cookbooks dating from the ninth through the 19th century.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I believe that you once described a technique for ridding clams of sand. Would you please reprint it?

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 5, 1982
description: International A British destroyer was disabled and set afire by an Argentine jet fighter, Britain announced. The destroyer Sheffield, struck by a high-explosive missile, was abandoned and was said to have sunk. Defense Minister John Nott said that as many as 30 members of the crew, which normally totals 299, might have died despite intensive rescue efforts. In Washington, intelligence sources said that a major naval battle was still raging off the Falklands. Earlier, Britain announced that a fighter-bomber had been shot down during a raid on air strips in the islands and that the pilot had been killed. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina announced the rescue of at least 680 survivors from the torpedoed cruiser General Belgrano and said that a search was continuing for the 362 other crew members. The American Embassy in Buenos Aires said it was evacuating ''nonessential personnel'' and dependents. (A1:5.)

title: Nuclear Plant Reports Leak
description: About 1,300 gallons of slightly radioactive water leaked into the Mississippi River from a nuclear power plant today, but officials said the spill posed no threat to public health. Wayne Kaplan, a spokesman for the operator of the plant, the Northern States Power Company, said, ''Apparently a gasket leaked in the residual heat system of the plant.''

title: Dow Up 5.42 as Trading Rises
description: The stock market registered a moderate advance yesterday in accelerated trading with some of the technology and energy-related issues making the best gains.

title: TURKISH CONSUL IS FATALLY SHOT
description: A gunman wielding two pistols fatally shot an honorary Turkish consul as he drove through this Boston suburb tonight, the police said.

title: SONG RECITAL: MISS BATTLE
description: KATHLEEN BATTLE, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, sang some lovely music Sunday at Alice Tully Hall. The songs were by Purcell, Schubert and Strauss, with a cantata by Bach and spirituals at the end.

title: THEATER: 'K2,' A DRAMA OF MOUNTAIN-CLIMBING
description: WASHINGTON TWO mountain-climbers are trapped on an icy ledge 27,000 feet above sea level. They have lost most of their life-saving equipment in a snowslide and they are miles away from potential rescue. It looks as if they will perish before the sun sets. So what do they do? At the top of his voice, one of them yells, ''Helllp!'', and they both laugh helplessly.

title: LOGISTICS PROBLEM FOR QE2 SLAES CHIEF
description: James R. Sullivan heard the news on the radio Monday morning. The Queen Elizabeth 2 had been requisitioned by Britain to carry troops to the South Atlantic. Mr. Sullivan, senior vice president for worldwide sales and marketing at the Cunard Line, owner of the ship, knew he had a problem. The QE2 was scheduled to leave the next day from Southampton, England, on a 12-day Mediterranean cruise with 1,250 passengers.

title: SENATORS BRIEFED ON SOVIET MILITARY
description: The Senate, moving into debate on President Reagan's military spending requests, met in an unusual closed session this afternoon for a briefing on Soviet military capabilities.

title: Sports of The Times; Run, Rickey, Run
description: ALMOST anybody else would have coasted into second with a stand-up double, but Rickey Henderson kept churning and dived head-first into third for a triple. Almost anybody else would have been out on a routine three-hop grounder to short, but Rickey Henderson beat the throw for an infield single. Almost anybody else would have been picked off first base, but Rickey Henderson took off and stole second. And on all three plays Monday night, the Yankees did not mishandle the ball. Rickey Henderson simply outran it.

title: A'S TOP YANKEES IN 13, 9-7
description: Even on a night when both Rich Gossage and Dave Winfield put it together the Yankees couldn't win. Despite Winfield's game-tying three-run homer and Gossage's sizzling six-strikeout pitching, the Yankees continued to stagger, losing to Oakland, 9-7, last night when Tony Armas doubled home two runs against Dave LaRoche in the 13th inning.

title: U.S. Report Says Lighter Caused Fatal Mine Blast
description: A cigarette lighter taken into a coal mine in violation of Federal regulations touched off a methane explosion that killed 13 men last December, the Labor Department said today.

title: MADE IN AMERICA: AN ELEGANT NEW
description: CUISINE By MOIRA HODGSON

title: Donaldson Sues County
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, a New Yorkbased securities firm, announced yesterday that it has sued the County of Los Angeles and Sol Levin, a county official in charge of investments, for more than $65 million. Last week the county filed a suit in Federal court against Donaldson, asserting that the firm, acting as the county's broker, made improper, unauthorized transactions in Government securities that resulted in losses for the county.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Friday incorrectly indentified Charles L. Schultze. He served as Director of the Budget in the Johnson Administration and as man of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration.

title: VIEWERS' RETURN HOME SEEN AS HELPING CABLE TV
description: After two decades of footloose travel and constant eating out, the American consumer has returned home, a circumstance that can only be of benefit to cable television, according to research by Yankelovich, Skelly & White that was presented to the National Cable Television Association's convention. The research points up economic and social trends that will affect the industry during the 1980's.

title: Swede Kills 2 in Rampage
description: An outpatient at a Stockholm medical center went berserk today, killing two doctors with a knife and injuring four staff members and a policeman, the police reported. The male assailant was caught by a taxi driver outside a nearby subway station after seriously wounding a policeman who pursued him as he fled from the medical center, the police report said. The attacker was not identified.

title: Miles Davis Returns
description: In recent years, he has been weakened by health problems, but Miles Davis, the 56-year-old jazz trumpeter, is making a triumphant return to the European scene after a 10-year absence.

title: Autopsy Fails to Show Why Athlete, 23, Died
description: An autopsy has failed to show why Mike Babb's heart suddenly stopped minutes after routine knee surgery, the State Medical Examiner said today.

title: Tentative Accord Is Reached On Contract at United Parcel
description: United Parcel Service and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters reached a tentative agreement on a new contract, averting a threatened strike against the nation's largest package carrier, a Federal mediator said tonight.

title: RIGHTS GROUPS FIND REAGAN POLICIES FAVOR WHITES
description: Civil rights advocates said today that President Reagan's policies on the budget, taxes, housing and education tended to harm blacks and other minority groups whose members are generally poorer than the white population.

title: FOR WEEKEND FATHERS, TOO MANY COOKS DON'T SPOIL THE BROTH
description: Mother's chicken soup, move over. Father's chicken soup, specifically, divorced father's chicken soup, is advancing from the back burner. The recipe appears in the current issue of Divorced Father, a new monthly newsletter. ''Your kids can take it home in a jar,'' the publisher suggests. ''They'll think of you all week while eating chicken soup.''

title: West German Workers Strike Military Bases of Allied Units
description: A strike by a West German transport workers union today gave some children of American servicemen a day off from school.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Arthur Ashe, captain of the United States Davis Cup team, said that John McEnroe and Peter Fleming would play against Sweden in the quarterfinal series July 9 to 11 in St. Louis and that Jimmy Connors had promised to let him know within a week whether he would be available. ... Carlos Alberto, the Cosmos' sweeper, will miss tonight's game against the Blizzard in Toronto because of a bladder infection.

title: ARAB STUDENT, 18, IS SHOT DEAD IN GAZA
description: An 18-year-old Palestinian schoolgirl was shot dead today and another teen-ager was wounded as Israeli troops clashed with demonstrators in the occupied Gaza Strip.

title: BILL WOULD GUARANTEE BENEFITS TO C.I.A. SPOUSES
description: Barbara Colby, the wife of William E. Colby, former Director of Central Intelligence, remembers the times overseas when she turned on the washing machine at their home to make sure that no one could overhear her husband's conversation with an intelligence source.

title: Closing Arguments Call N.F.L. Defense 'Sham'
description: Lawyers for the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission contended today that the National Football League is a monopoly and its legal defense ''a sham'' in closing arguments of the retrial of an antitrust suit brought against the league.

title: BREZHNEV ASKS NEGOTIATIONS IN LATIN DISPUTES
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev today denounced what he termed a return to ''colonial brigandage'' in Latin America and urged negotiated solutions for conflicts in Central America and over the Falkland Islands.

title: PEKING ANNOUNCES A BUREAUCRATIC SHAKE-UP
description: China announced a Government shuffle today that removed all but two of the country's 13 Deputy Prime Ministers and named many new ministers.

title: The Reluctant Driver
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The driving instructor (''Fear of Driving - It's Not Uncommon,'' April 28) who told his student that an automobile could be a lethal weapon made more sense than the interpretation put forth by ''a number of psychiatrists'' who interpret fear of driving as a means of control through dependency, among other things.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's ''new federalism'' proposals, greeted with applause by many state and local officials three months ago, have become entangled in the stalemate over the budget for the 1983 fiscal year.

title: FALKLANDS CASUALTIES BRING DISMAY IN EUROPE
description: Britain's allies reacted with shock and dismay today to the sinking of the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano, with the presumed loss of many lives.

title: Ella Fondren, Whose Husband Was Involved in Exxon's Start
description: Ella C. Fondren, whose late husband founded what is now Exxon USA, died Monday in Methodist Hospital less than a month short of her 102d birthday.

title: BOBBY SHORT (A BIT) AND BILL BLASS (A LOT)
description: IT was billed as ''An Evening With Bobby Short,'' but it turned out to be an hour with Bobby Short and an evening with Bill Blass. The designer was chairman of the dinner-dance Monday in the Rainbow Room to benefit the Third Street Music School Settlement. He arrived shortly after 7:30 P.M. with Nancy Kissinger on his arm (''Henry is at a stag party tonight, so I came here,'' she explained) to greet the 220 guests during the cocktail hour, see that everyone was seated in the right places for dinner and then send Ahmet Ertegun of Atlantic Records to get the sound system fixed for Mr. Short's performance.

title: LOCALITIES IN STATE REPORTED IN DISARRAY FROM CAREY CUTS
description: The decision by the State Senate to let stand virtually all of Governor Carey's $941 million in budget vetoes has created disarray in local governments, state and local officials said today. And, they said, it has left the Legislature with a broad array of unresolved problems.

title: E.P.A. Head Asks $2.4 Billion For Sewage Treatment Plants
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, wrote to Congressional leaders today urging them to appropriate $2.4 billion in the current fiscal year for sewage treatment facilities around the country.

title: LIBERAL WINS INDIANA PRIMARY
description: A liberal Democrat who lost his Congressional district in reapportionment defeated a State Senator from southwestern Indiana tonight in the state's Democratic United States Senate primary.

title: Stock Futures Win Approval
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved a proposal by the New York Futures Exchange to trade futures based on the New York Stock Exchange Composite Index.

title: Blinka Pact Unsettled
description: Stan Blinka's contract dispute with the Jets is still not officially settled, and Blinka acknowledges that the team caused him to wonder by choosing Notre Dame's middle linebacker, Bob Crable, on the first round of the National Football League draft last week. But these are not dark days for Blinka, who has been the starting middle linebacker in every game since 1979, his rookie year. ''It crossed my mind that they might have drafted Crable because it went back to last year and my contract,'' he said yesterday at the middle session of the three-day camp for veterans. ''But when you think about it, there are a couple of third-round linebackers on this team and some free agents, and this upgrades the linebackers.'' Last summer, Blinka asked to be traded. He was sulking during training camp, when the team refused to renegotiate a five-year deal he had signed as a fifth-round draft choice out of Sam Houston State. He contended that he would get less than $50,000 for the season, the third year of his contract. But now he spoke optimistically about his future with the club. ''They told me that if I had a good season in 1981, they would give me a new contract at figures close to what I wanted,'' he said. The Jets say they do not renegotiate contracts, which technically may be true. But they could extend Blinka's contract, starting with 1983, his option year, and give him a substantial signing bonus. ... Meanwhile, Richard Todd is recovering from a torn rotator cuff in his left shoulder.

title: News Analysis
description: The nation's synthetic fuels industry, started with great fanfare and billions of Federal dollars less than two years ago, today stands demoralized and uncertain. Its future is jeopardized by falling oil prices, high interest rates, soaring construction costs and an Administration determined to leave energy development almost entirely to the free market.

title: Edward Martin Jr., Decorator And Partner of Billy Baldwin
description: Edward Martin Jr., a retired interior decorator who was the partner of the designer Billy Baldwin for more than 20 years, died Sunday night at New York Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in New York City and Amagansett, L.I.

title: Forget About Municipal Cable
description: Scratch the Cable Television Department from the organization chart of the city of St. Paul. Its voters have resoundingly vetoed municipal ownership of the local cable system.

title: A SPATE OF BOOKS ON COOKING TECHNIQUE
description: FOR decades cookbooks have been detailing the preparation of scores of cuisines, offering recipes for every category known to man and covering countless special subjects from salt-free diets to clay-pot cookery. Now there seems to be a move back to basics: A number of books have been published recently that attempt to explain the how or the why in what all those recipes require.

title: WHEN EINSTEIN'S RIGHT. HE'S RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Salomon Bochner Of Princeton Is Dead
description: Dr. Salomon Bochner, professor emeritus of mathematics at Princeton University, died Sunday in Houston. He was 82 years old and lived in Houston.

title: BEACH THEATER EXPANDS BILL
description: Jones Beach, the summer home in the past of a single Broadway type of musical, will change its entertainment policy this season. It will open the season with a revue starring John Davidson and then put on revivals of ''Grease'' and ''West Side Story.''

title: GRITS, CORN BREAD AND OTHER HAUTE CUISINE RECIPES
description: THE following new American dishes offered at three Manhattan restaurants have been adapted here for home cooking. In the pheasant recipe, Lawrence Forgione of the River Cafe uses wild mushrooms instead of cultivated ones, uses a green called lamb's quarters instead of spinach and adds eight wild garlic mustard leaves to the corn bread mixture.

title: New England Writers To Join Nuclear Protest
description: Two busloads of prominent writers from the Boston-Cambridge area are planning to participate on June 12 in a demonstration against nuclear war -at the United Nations second special session on disarmament.

title: DEATHS PUT NEAR 30; ARGENTINES DOWN JET
description: An Argentine jet fighter set afire and disabled the British destroyer Sheffield in the South Atlantic on Tuesday and the ship was abandoned, the Ministry of Defense announced.

title: HINCKLEY JURY FOCUSES ON TAPE OF 'FACE IN THE CROWD'
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. put on his eyeglasses, leaned back today in his courtroom chair and watched himself on videotape, a face in the crowd in Dayton, Ohio, admittedly stalking President Carter in the 1980 campaign.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate.

title: DOMENICI PRESENTS OWN BUDGET PLAN
description: Defying President Reagan, Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Budget Committee, today proposed a farreaching budget compromise that included a one-year freeze on Social Security benefits and most social programs and a three-year tax increase of $125 billion.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Briefing column on the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly stated the political party of Representative Richard L. Ottinger of Westchester. He is a Democrat.

title: IN CORDOBA, ARAB HOAXER ISN'T OIL RICH
description: For a time there were visions at City Hall here of a great infusion of Arabs' surplus oil revenues to bolster Cordoba's sagging finances. But these visions seem to be fading.

title: Rubenstein Quits as Consultant to 4 Agencies
description: Stung by criticism of his role in fashioning a ''salute to the news media'' by Governor Carey, Howard J. Rubenstein yesterday quit as public-relations consultant to four New York State agencies.

title: USING NURSES TO SAVE ON HEALTH CARE
description: Health-care costs could be dramatically reduced by bringing nurses out of the background as ''handmaidens to doctors'' and into a more central role as advisers on nutrition, diet, exercise, child care and pregnancy, according to the dean of the School of Nursing at the State University of New York at Binghamton.

title: 5 STRAIGHT FOR RED SOX
description: Glenn Hoffman's two-run single broke a 3-3 tie in the third inning, and Red Sox defeated the Minnesota Twins, 5-3, tonight for Boston's fifth consecutive victory.

title: U.S. PLANS QUOTAS ON SUGAR IMPORTS
description: President Reagan agreed today to impose quotas on sugar imports as a means of saving the Federal Government several hundred million dollars under the price support program for domestically grown sugar that he accepted last year in return for farm-state Democratic votes for his budget.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Budget Capital Corp., a unit of Financial Corp. of America, approved a merger into Financial Corp. of America. According to terms of the merger, F.C.A. common stock and F.C.A. preferred stock will be exchanged for 6 percent serial preferred shares of B.C.C. outstanding at the effective time of the merger at an exchange rate of 0.38 of a share of F.C.A. common stock, or at the election of any holder of B.C.C. preferred shares, one share of a like F.C.A. preferred stock, for each B.C.C. preferred share.

title: Union Oil Sees Future for Shale
description: The Exxon Corporation's scuttling of the Colony Oil Shale Project does not mean the death of oil shale development altogether, says Fred L. Hartley, chairman and president of the Union Oil Company of California.

title: Real Estate; Big Project In Midtown Hits Snags
description: FAIRVIEW, the giant Canadian developer, may be backing away from its plan to build a major office tower opposite the Citicorp Center at 53d Street.

title: POP: 5 DOO-WOP GROUPS AT THE BOTTOM LINE
description: WOP, the harmonized street-corner style of rock-and-roll that produced several dozen of the best known love songs of the 1950's and early 60's, isn't simply the echo of a bygone era. Ambient Sound, a CBS subsidiary label, has recently brought out albums by five veteran doo-wop groups - the Capris, the Harptones, the Mystics, Randy and the Rainbows and the Jive Five - that combine 50's-style versions of contemporary songs with remakes of standards.

title: COMPANY FIGHTS GOVERNOR'S MOVE TO BLOCK OIL PIPELINE UNDER PUGET SOUND
description: The builders of a transcontinental oil pipeline say they are determined to overcome Gov. John Spellman's move to block plans to construct the pipeline beneath Puget Sound, the centerpiece of western Washington's evergreen slopes, snow-capped peaks, freshwater lakes and salt water inlets.

title: BUSINESS VS. FARMERS IN JAPAN
description: No guns have been brandished nor shots fired, but a ''bloodless war,'' as one Government official put it, is raging in Japan.

title: NEW PROCESS MAY IMPROVE U.S. CHEESE
description: Because of a new commercial enzyme, better-quality cheese may soon find its way to American tables, according to Dr. Orrie Friedman, president of a Lexington-based biotechnology company.

title: Why Britain Raised the Stakes
description: It's no longer a jolly little war. First an Argentine cruiser was sunk, and now a British destroyer has been attacked and set afire, carrying with them the first grim casualties in a wretched conflict. But however poignant the death of hundreds of Argentine sailors, their chiefs in Buenos Aires should not be allowed to pose as victimized pacifists.

title: Gunman Kills a Police Officer In Clash in Northern Ireland
description: One policeman was shot and killed and another was wounded seriously today in Northern Ireland on the eve of the first anniversary of the death of Robert Sands.

title: Richard Jamieson Memorial
description: A memorial service for Richard Jamieson, the actor, who died April 15 in Burlington, Vt., will be held next Monday at the Circle-in-the-Square Theater, at 159 Bleecker Street, at 7 P.M. Al Pacino will officiate.

title: Tuna and Its Symbols
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I read the interesting article ''Successes in Packaging'' by Bryan Miller (April 14). I believe the mermaid is the symbol for Chicken of the Sea Tuna, and Starkist's symbol is Charlie Tuna. ETHEL DAUM Staten Island.

title: Knapp Communications Adds New York Officer
description: Knapp Communications in Los Angeles is continuing its top-talent kidnapping raids and its latest grab is Constantine J. Kazanas, 56-year-old senior vice president of marketing development of the Magazine Publishers Association, a job that is more of a springboard to bigger things more than any association job we can think of.

title: Moffett Beats Downey In New Britain Voting
description: United States Representative Anthony Toby Moffett easily defeated John T. Downey, his challenger for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, in a primary election today for this city's 41 delegates to the party's state nominating convention in July.

title: On Personal Questions
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most quoted lines in the history of gastronomy belongs to Brillat-Savarin. It is, ''Tell me what you eat and I will tell you what you are.'' I would like to alter that to say, ''If you tell me how you cook rice, I will tell you what your nationality is.''

title: ENZYME DEFICIENCY IS THE REASON MANY CAN'T DIGEST MILK
description: MILK is indisputedly the ideal food for infants and an excellent food for young children. But as people get older most lose their ability to digest it fully. This happens because intestinal production of the enzyme lactase declines with age in all but a small segment of the world's population. Lactase is needed to split the two-part milk sugar lactose into its component sugars, glucose and galactose, so that they can be absorbed through the intestinal wall.

title: Sugar Futures Decline On Reagan Quota News
description: Prices of world sugar futures fell again yesterday as President Reagan agreed to the reimposition of quotas on foreign sugar. While the move had been expected, the lack of details about the quotas endorsed by the President caused wild price swings in the world sugar ring of the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.

title: FAMILY PLANNING IN INDONESIA TAKES ON AIR OF A CIVIC DUTY
description: In this mountain town in west Java, it is chic to be an ''acceptor.'' Those who have been acceptors in good standing for more than 10 years may be invited to the presidential palace in Jakarta to be praised for their contribution to Indonesia's development and awarded a plaque by President Suharto himself.

title: ISLANDERS SWEEP NORDIQUES, GAIN STANLEY CUP FINAL
description: The Islanders completed a four-game sweep of their National Hockey League semifinal series by defeating the Quebec Nordiques tonight, 4-2. The victory advanced the two-time defending Stanley Cup champions to the final round of the playoffs, where they will meet the winner of the Vancouver-Chicago series.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt JEWS WITHOUT MERCY. A Lament. By Earl Shorris. 191 pages. Anchor/Dou- bleday. $14.95.

title: INTERNORTH OFF 8.9%
description: The Sperry Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 fell 11.5 percent, while revenues edged up 1.9 percent.

title: 'Dreamgirl' Reaping Pleasure as She Sews
description: There were two shows yesterday for some members of the cast of the Broadway musical ''Dreamgirls,'' even though it was not a normal two-performance day. The first performance was a fashion show at noon at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, and it presented some of the evening wear designed and sewn - sometimes backstage between numbers - by Loretta Devine.

title: Polaroid Enters 35-Millimeter Field
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which has experienced a steady earnings decline in recent quarters, displayed several new products at its annual meeting today, marking the company's long-awaited entry into the 35-millimeter camera market.

title: SUSPECT LABOR REFORM IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: A Correction:
description: Because of a typographical error in a letter by Harold J.T. Isenberg published on April 30, the annual amount nonpublic schools save taxpayers was given as $8 million. Mr. Isenberg's figure was $8 billion.

title: MYRA JORDAN POLAN
description: Myra Jordan Polan, a former research officer at the United Nations, died April 29 at her home in Lincolnville, Me.

title: California High Court Backs Damages for Child Born Deaf
description: A girl born deaf to parents who say she should not have been born at all is entitled to damages, the State Supreme Court ruled Monday.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 5, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan agreed to impose quotas on sugar imports. His aim is to avoid having to buy and store domestic sugar under the price support plan he accepted last year in return for votes for his economic program. One result will be to raise the price candy companies and soft drink producers pay for sweeteners. (Page A1.)

title: SHOREHAM TESTIMONY BEGINS
description: A three-judge Federal atomic safety and licensing panel began hearing testimony today on challenges to the application of the Long Island Lighting Company for a license to operate its $2.49 billion nuclear power plant at Shoreham.

title: PIANO RECITAL: VARIED BILL
description: GRUZEN, a New York pianist, played music by Mozart, Beethoven, Debussy and Chopin at the Abraham Goodman House Monday evening.

title: DEATHS PUT NEAR 30; ARGENTINES
description: DOWN JET By EDWARD SCHUMACHER

title: SOME ARAB LANDS WARMING TO EGYPT
description: A leading Egyptian Foreign Ministry official said today that there had been encouraging signs in the Arab world about resuming diplomatic relations with Egypt but that he did not feel that the restoration of ties was imminent.

title: Careers; Software Engineers In Demand
description: THE fast pace of technology has already pushed the computer programmer into the spotlight of job demand. Now there is also a new subspecialty: the software engineer, a kind of programmer's programmer.

title: RETAIL SALES IN NEW YORK OFF IN APRIL
description: Sales of New York City's big retailers last month slid below the 1981 level for the second month this year, with volume down an average three-tenths of 1 percent from April of last year, according to a monthly spot-check.

title: PAY RISE FOR LEGISLATORS MAY COST THEM AT POLLS
description: As a weary General Assembly nears adjournment of its annual session of making and unmaking Connecticut's laws, some legislators are getting a little touchy.

title: Central Park for the Birds
description: April and May are bird season in New York. The flyway over which dozens of bird species travel north passes near the city, and Central Park is an attractive oasis for the travelers. So in addition to the birds a lot of New Yorkers can be found in the park these mornings, many with binoculars and birding lists in hand.

title: Market Place; 10-Year Notes: Opinions Differ
description: IN August 1976, the United States Treasury sold an issue of 10-year notes that won fame as the ''magic 8's,'' in recognition of what was then considered an appealingly high yield of 8 percent.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FOOD NOTES
description: How About Tofuburgers?

title: SPRING: WASHINGTON DOES IT WELL
description: The capital city's final blast of winter intemperance came not from the North Pole but from the Republican Senator who represents the state closest to it. Ted Stevens of Alaska took the Senate floor one chilly morning a few weeks ago to describe his loathing for Washington. ''I destest it,'' he said, adding that he could think of no ''worse place to live.''

title: Webb Sells Hotel
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 932-room Sahara Vegas hotel and casino for $50 million as part of a continuing sale of assets to reduce its debt. The property will be purchased by Paul W. Lowden, president and owner of the Hacienda Resort Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and a former condominium developer in Hawaii. Mr. Lowden was also granted options to purchase a 22-acre parking lot and an 18-hole championship golf course.

title: ABUSE IN CONSTRUCTION HAS A PROVEN REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: A Financial Beating
description: To the list of pro basketball teams well known to be taking a financial beating, you can add the Atlanta Hawks, says Ted Turner, their owner, though things apparently aren't as tough they are as with such clubs as San Diego and Indiana.

title: M-G-M/U.A.  Payment Delays
description: The M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company said it was asking its creditors, which include several New York banks, to consolidate and extend the corporation's credit lines beyond a May 14 deadline for the $109 million payment due on loans taken by Metro-Goldwyn-Meyer Inc. last year when it acquired the United Artists Corporation for $380 million.

title: Opposition Party Ahead In St. Lucia Elections
description: St. Lucia's United Workers Party won in Monday's general elections on this Caribbean island, according to a preliminary count announced today.

title: ANGER GONE, GRAHAM PARKER IS BACK
description: AYEAR before Graham Parker embarked on his first tour of America as the most promising angry young man of British rock's emerging new wave, he was pumping gas for a living. And his first two albums, ''Howlin' Wind'' and ''Heat Treatment,'' both released by Mercury in 1976, sounded like the throaty roar of a young man who had filled the tanks of too many surly motorists - and had found a way to talk back and make them listen.

title: Funds Obtained By Saxon Oil
description: The Saxon Oil Company, based in Dallas, said yesterday that its chairman and founder, Bill D. Saxon, would sell his 80 percent interest in the company and that the buyers would extend $65 million of credit to it.

title: PAN AM IS SUING BRANIFF OVER ROUTES
description: Pan American World Airways filed suit against Braniff International yesterday, asking for $100 million in damages and the return of a $7 million down payment that Pan Am had made for the right to lease Braniff's Latin American routes.

title: Mitterrand, on Tour, Defends Administration
description: LA-GAILLARD, France, May 4 (Reuters) - President Francois Mitterrand ended a rare provincial tour today that he has used to defend his administration's record after one year in office and to appeal for national unity.

title: RCA HEAD REASSURES HOLDERS
description: Thornton F. Bradshaw, chairman of the RCA Corporation, reassured stockholders yesterday that RCA would ''resist to the utmost'' any attempt by outsiders to acquire the company or dismember it.

title: BRIEFING
description: Take That, Democrats!

title: UNDER THE OIL GLUT
description: Today's surplus of oil - the oil glut - has come as something of a relief to a nation with plenty of other problems on its mind. Instead of outraged motorists waiting in line to buy gasoline, there are price wars. People who are cheerful about the glut remind me of a doctor who closes the case on a patient who has stopped suffering because the patient can no longer feel the pain.

title: CHINA EXHIBIT CAPTIVATES CROWDS AT WORLD'S FAIR
description: China's participation in a world's fair for the first time since 1904 has produced a dramatic exhibit that grew out of difficult negotiations that came within a breath of failure.

title: INFORMATION LAW IS EXPANDED
description: Governor Carey today signed a measure strengthening the state's freedom of information law. The measure allows courts to award legal fees to people who successfully sue government agencies to obtain documents.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has appointed William G. Bishop 3d vice president-audits.

title: Economic Scene; Reaganomics: Critics Grow
description: IS Reaganomics a failure? Many conservatives as well as liberals share the belief that it is. Kevin Phillips, author of ''The New Conservative Majority,'' declares in an article in the current issue of The New York Review of Books: ''The question for the political analyst is no longer whether Ronald Reagan will succeed or fail. He is failing, and attention must now focus upon the ramifications and dimensions of that failure.''

title: 2 UNIONS AND G.E. BEGIN BARGAINING
description: Two major electrical unions, calling for greater job security and higher pay, began negotiations for new contracts with the General Electric Company yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: The economic and military sanctions imposed by the United States against Argentina have provoked South American governments far more than the accompanying American declaration of support for

title: Regan Sees Argentina Paying Debts
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he expected that Argentina would keep its payments current on its $35 billion of foreign loans outstanding, despite the intensification of the conflict with Britain over the Falklands.

title: Refugees Told of StatesWith Better Welfare
description: Florida welfare officials, upset with the Reagan Administration's decision to curtail refugee aid, are suggesting that Cubans and Haitians might move to states that have better welfare programs.

title: HERMETITE OFFICIALS CHARGED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused the Hermetite Corporation, a Massachusetts-based manufacturer of electrical components, and two senior executives of numerous violations of the accounting and reporting provisions of the Federal securities laws.

title: COURTING GUATEMALA
description: Guatemala's new Government is only six weeks old, but the Reagan Administration already has embraced it. The State Department is lobbying Congress hard to approve resumption of military aid, suspended since 1977 because of Guatemala's horrendous human rights record. So eager is the Administration that it is pushing for renewed aid even though Guatemala has not requested it. More seriously, it has rushed blindly ahead before a clear notion of the new regime's direction has emerged.

title: Hearns Injures Hand
description: Only hours after the disclosure that Thomas Hearns had injured his right hand while trying to break a fall during roadwork, it appeared virtually certain yesterday that his challenge to Marvelous Marvin Hagler for the world middleweight championship would have to be put off. While United Press International was reporting that a delay was already set, Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager and trainer, said the fight will be postponed. The bout had been set for May 24 in Windsor, Ontario.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: 'JUNK THOUGHT'
description: I used to see a great deal of complaint a few years ago about junk food. Junk food is food that has almost no real nutritional content, has a lot of calories and salt to make the eater feel good, and might contain additives that are life-threatening. I always thought the problem of junk food was overdrawn. To my mind, the real problem in our society is not junk food but junk thought. That is thought that looks appetizing, makes the thinker feel good, but is either empty or harmful. The best example of junk thought to appear in years is the nuclear-freeze movement.

title: A.T.&T. Absorbs Pacific Telephone
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company received permission of the state Public Utilities Commission to merge with its majority stockholder, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which had owned 91.5 percent of Pacific Telephone.

title: The U.N. Today; May 5, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: Texaco in Pact With Halbouty
description: Texaco U.S.A., a unit of Texaco Inc., announced a joint drilling and exploration venture with the Michel T. Halbouty Energy Company of Houston, a private energy concern.

title: 'Medea' of 1947 and of Today: Some Familiar Faces
description: The ''Medea'' opening-night party at Sardi's hummed with reminiscence the other night as aging theatergoers boasted, with a certain rueful bravado, of having seen the 1947 production starring Judith Anderson. Hands reached out to make contact with the tiny, 81-year-old actress who had already been given a welcome-back ovation at the Cort Theater, this time in the part of the Nurse.

title: SALVADOR REBELS REPORT DEATH OF AN AMERICAN ON THEIR SIDE
description: A rebel radio broadcast reported today that an American fighting alongside Salvadoran guerrillas was killed by Government troops last month in northeasten Morazan province.

title: TURNOVERS: A DISH WITH AN INTERNATIONAL HERITAGE
description: ta-meat pies of Louisiana that indicate a borrowing from the Spanish.

title: Quebec Secessionists Weigh a Federal Race
description: Premier Rene Levesque's Parti Quebecois will decide next month whether to enter candidates in Canadian federal elections for the first time, a party spokesman said today. The party's national council will discuss the issue on June 12 and 13 in Hull, near Ottawa.

title: TV: THE HARLEM DANCERS' 'FIREBIRD'
description: THIS evening's ''Kennedy Center Tonight'' presentation, on WNET-TV at 9, has a long title: ''Stravinsky's 'Firebird' by Dance Theatre of Harlem.'' But even that much doesn't quite cover the entire content of the hour. In a format devised by Arthur Mitchell, co-founder of the dance company, the program consists of two separate parts: a documentary showing how this production of ''Firebird,'' choreographed by John Taras, was assembled in rehearsal studios; and a finished performance at Washington's Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: DODGERS DOWN METS IN 9TH, 2-1
description: Neil Allen's throwing error in the bottom of the ninth inning led to a 2-1 victory by the Dodgers tonight as the Mets ended a two-week road trip on a dispiriting note.

title: PROJECTED MALL IN TIMES SQ. AREA LOSING SUPPORT
description: Support for Broadway Plaza, the pedestrian mall planned for the Times Square area and described by the city as necessary to the proposed Portman Hotel, has eroded substantially in recent weeks. The likelihood, according to city officials close to the situation, is that the mall will never be built.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MESSAGES FROM JAPAN

title: McLouth Seeking To Delay Closing
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation has asked its secured lenders to let it operate for at least 60 days beyond its June 18 deadline for closing if no buyer is found.

title: Fouts and Unionism
description: For his stand against paying dues to the National Football League Players Association, Dan Fouts, the quarterback of the San Diego Chargers, was named the winner of the National Right to Work Committee's top annual award.

title: Bridge:; Sweden's Eric Jannerstein Recalled for His Versatility
description: One of the great personalities of the international bridge scene, Eric Jannersten of Sweden, died on April 18 at the age of 69. In a long and distinguished career in the game, he had filled almost every possible role.

title: MRS. THATCHER UNDER ATTACK AT HOME OVER CRUISER
description: The torpedoing of the Argentine cruiser General Belgrano, bringing the first major casualties in the Falkland Islands crisis, provoked sharp debate here today over the propriety of sinking a ship outside the 200-mile maritime exclusion zone imposed around the islands by Britain.

title: HAD LEADING ROLES IN SEVERAL MUSICALS
description: Virginia Vestoff, a stage and screen actress who played leading roles on Broadway and Off Broadway and in musicals around the country, died Sunday in New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 42 years old.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: New York is a city where dreams come true, where a girl named Barbra from Brooklyn can become a household name, where a mailroom clerk named Manilow can eventually make platinum records and lots of money, a city of limousines with gray-black glass in the windows and parties with paparazzi.

title: No Photos Being Sent From the British Fleet
description: For the last four days, British journalists traveling with the naval task force have been unable to provide photographs.

title: Required Reading; The Second City
description: Excerpts from ''Who Runs Washington?'' a new book by Michael Kilian and Arnold Sawislak published by St. Martin's Press: Washington, D.C., is quite circumspect about itself, in all candor, with good reason. Built in a pestilential swamp, burned by the British and left for dead, for decades a ramshackle Southern town noted most for its bawdy houses and slave markets, a crude hicksville that, until the Kennedys came along, lacked even one first-class restaurant, the Federal City has been for most of its life more like Paducah than Paris.

title: FORMER ALBANY CONGRESSMAN
description: Leo W. O'Brien, an Albany Democrat who served in the House of Representatives from 1952 until his retirement in 1966, died of a heart ailment yesterday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 81 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AWHILE back William Cole, the poet and anthologist, unveiled a new poetic form in this space - the Poipetrator Verse. Its moment in the literary sun, while glorious, was tragically brief. For now, the muse has spoken again to Mr. Cole, and Metropolitan Diary is able to reveal his latest innovation: a new verse medium that can take its place beside the sonnet and, well, the clerihew.

title: EFFECTS ON BUDGET VETOES ON NEW YORK PROGRAM
description: The budget cuts vetoed by Governor Carey focus on a variety of local aid programs, particularly school aid. And they also affect a variety of smaller programs added by the Legislature for specific purposes or constituencies.

title: Saudi Oil Estimate
description: Saudi Arabia's oil output last month was apparently well below its 7-million-barrel daily ceiling and the country seems ready to cut its production further this month if necessary to defend OPEC's $34-a-barrel base price, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry said Monday. The minister, Shintiro Abe, visited Saudi Arabia on Monday and had private talks with its oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani.

title: WARSAW RENEWS CURFEWS AFTER CLASHES
description: The Polish military Government moved swiftly today to reintroduce curfews, cut telephone service and impose other restrictions in selected regions after clashes Monday between anti-Government demonstrators and the police.

title: WINE TALK
description: ONCE upon a time, before table wines at mealtime became fashionable in the United States, many oenophiles followed a standard procedure in accumulating wine for their own consumption: they waited for the best vintages in Bordeaux and Burgundy, bought them as soon as they reached the market and waited 10 or perhaps 20 years for them to mature.

title: ALGERIAN FOREIGN MINISTER IS KILLED IN PLANE CRASH ON WAY TO TEHERAN
description: Foreign Minister Mohammed Ben Yahia of Algeria, who played a key role in freeing the United States hostages from Iran, was killed Monday in a crash with all others aboard a flight to Teheran, Iran announced today.

title: HAIG ABRUPTLY SUMMONED TO MEET WITH BRITISH ENVOY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. abruptly canceled a trip to New York tonight and rushed back to the State Department for talks with the British Ambassador on the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: IRANIANS SAY AN IRAQI COUNTERATTACK IS IN PROGRESS
description: Iran said 3,500 prisoners it claims to have taken in its latest offensive in the war against Iraq were evacuated from the battlefront today to Teheran.

title: HARASSED TROTTIER MAKES HIS POINTS
description: Bryan Trottier was still hurting a half hour after the Islanders had eliminated the Quebec Nordiques from the Stanley Cup semifinal playoffs tonight.

title: JOHN LUCAS TRIES TO RECAST HIS IMAGE
description: Even when John Lucas realized he had major problems that were strangling his basketball and personal lives he did little to stop them. After all, he had always been important, the best at everything he attempted, and things always seemed to work out smoothly.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: NOT too long ago, an invitation for a 10 P.M. party arrived at the home of a woman comfortably ensconced in Manhattan's social swing. She was about to accept when a friend casually inquired if she would be at Mr. X's dinner party. As Mr. X was also the host of the later party and the dinner was scheduled for the same evening, the woman was in what might be called a snit. A late party was one thing, but a late party with a preceding dinner to which she had not been asked was another.

title: Grumman Net Up by 28.9%
description: The Grumman Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest defense contractor, reported yesterday that net income in the latest three months rose by 28.9 percent, to $7.6 million, or 55 cents a share, from $5.4 million, or 39 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1981.

title: Classic Rum Punch
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Nurse, 24, Slain At Montefiore
description: A 24-year-old nurse was found slain last night in a parking garage in the Montefiore Hospital complex in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: F.B.I. Confirms Inquiry Into Nevada Politicians
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has confirmed it is investigating possible political corruption in Nevada, and published reports indicate a 10-month undercover operation was used against city, county and state officials.

title: Military Analysis
description: The margin of qualitative superiority with which Britain has managed to impose an air and sea blockade around the Falkland Islands has eroded under the impact of a single attack by sophisticated weapons.

title: A 'LIE DETECTOR' GIVEN TO TELLING LIES
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES DEMOCRATS IN SPEECH AT A G.O.P. DINNER
description: President Reagan, in a speech here tonight, attacked what he termed the ''liberal leaders'' of the Democratic Party for favoring ''a bargain-basement military'' and for trying ''to protect every lord and fiefdom in the Federal bureacracy.''

title: 3-YEAR NOTE DEMAND STRONG
description: Investor demand was very strong at yesterday's auction of new three-year Treasury notes, and dealers said buying of the new issue spilled over into other sectors of the credit market, where it helped raise prices modestly.

title: THE FORGOTTEN LESSONS
description: The sinking of the Argentine cruiser, General Belgrano, and the loss of the British destroyer H.M.S. Sheffield are only the latest reminder of the unexpected but inevitable result of trying to settle political disputes by force of arms.

title: FOR HOMEOWNERS: A 2% RETURN ON MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT URGES U.S. TO KEEP JOB ROLE
description: Job training for people in the most disadvantaged groups should remain the Government's responsibility since privately managed programs tend to ''seek out the most job-ready candidates,'' according to a study to be made public today.

title: 3 Stroh Directors Join Schlitz Board
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company said it has increased the size of its board of directors, adding three representatives of the Stroh Brewery Company, in accord with Stroh's takeover of the Milwaukee company April 14.

title: BALKY LOCAL IN OHIO BLOCKS U.A.W. PACT AT AMERICAN MOTORS
description: The United Automobile Workers said today that one of its locals at an American Motors Corporation plant had rejected a proposed labor contract, essentially killing the union accord.

title: APPEALS COURT GETS CASE ON MORGANTHAU v. COOKE
description: The New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest tribunal, heard arguments today in a case that cast the Chief Judge and the Manhattan District Attorney as adversaries.

title: LEWIS OFFERS PLAN ON TRUCKS AS EXCHANGE FOR A TAX RISE
description: In his continuing campaign to obtain new revenue for highways and mass transit, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis is favoring new Federal rules to permit large double-trailer trucks in all states.

title: KOCH ASKS PLAN TO REDUCE POLITICS IN DRAWING COUNCIL DISTRICT LINES
description: Mayor Koch, who was a City Councilman for two years during the 1960's, called yesterday for a new system to ''reduce the role of politics'' in the way that boundary lines are drawn every 10 years for Council districts.

title: 2 Bishops for Latin America
description: Pope John Paul II has named new bishops in Chile and Argentina, the Vatican announced today. The Rev. Gerardo Sueldo, 45 years old, episcopal vicar of Catamarca, Argentina, is the new bishop of Oran, Argentina, it said. The Rev. Alberto Jara Franzoy, 52, chancellor of the diocese in the Chilean capital, Santiago, has been promoted to bishop of Chillan, Chile.

title: Library / Lovelorn; Capital Porridge
description: For nearly 20 years the Beaux-Arts masterpiece that is the New York Public Library's main building has been the architectural equivalent of Oliver Twist, waiting in line for city maintenance and restoration funds.

title: Sheffield; History
description: The Sheffield, which was set afire yesterday by a missile fired by an Argentine Super Etendard fighter-bomber, was the first of 14 Sheffield-class destroyers built for the Royal Navy. One of its most modern warships, she was commissioned on Feb. 16, 1975 at a cost of $47.3 million.

title: Daylight Saving Time
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Canucks Win, Lead, 3-1
description: Ivan Boldirev scored two second-period goals, and Richard Brodeur continued his brilliant play in goal as the Vancouver Canucks defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 5-3, tonight to take a three games to one lead in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: DAVID WASSNER
description: David Wassner, president of the board of trustees of Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, was killed Sunday evening in a two-car collision in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Weinberger Off to Brussels
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger left today for Brussels to attend a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on Thursday and Friday to discuss the Falkland Islands crisis, alliance plans to modernize nuclear and conventional forces and efforts by member countries to increase military spending by 3 percent a year.

title: 'DON'T MAKE WAVES' IS POOR ADVICE FOR WIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Ashbrook's Will Probated
description: Representative John M. Ashbrook, who died April 24, left an estate of about $1.7 million, according to a will admitted into probate in Licking County Probate Court. The seven-page document stiputaltes that Mr. Ashbrook's widow, Jean, and his three children will inherit the bulk of $1,728,000 in personal property and real estate, Probate Judge Robert Moore of Licking County said Monday.

title: Acquisition by Dun Unit Rumored
description: According to unconfirmed Wall Street rumors yesterday, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, the leading information service and publishing company based in New York, is planning to acquire McCormack & Dodge, one of the nation's top three financial software concerns and a private company based in Needham, Mass. Both companies, however, deny that the acquisition will take place, and Dun & Bradstreet's stock traded normally, closing at 70 3/8, up 7/8 on a volume of 27,900 shares.

title: U.N. PLAN PUSHED AS CASUALTIES RISE
description: The attack on a British destroyer today gave added urgency to the peace proposals for the South Atlantic put forward by Secretary General Perez de Cuellar, who said he expected replies to his plan on Wednesday from Argentina and Britain.

title: MUSIC: HARP, YOUNG STRINGS
description: THE harpist Heidi Lehwalder and the Downeast Chamber Orchestra joined forces yesterday in a matinee concert in the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House. The Downeasterners, a youth string orchestra under the direction of Burton Kaplan, replaced the Annapolis Brass Quintet, originally scheduled to perform with Miss Lehwalder.

title: Searle and Meiji Drug Marketing
description: G.D. Searle & Company announced an agreement with Meiji Seika Kaisha Ltd. of Japan to exchange anti-infective drugs and certain interferons. O.B. Parrisch, president of Searle's pharmaceutical division, estimated the market for such drugs at $6 billion worldwide and $1.5 billion in the United States and Canada.

title: VW America Posts Profit
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. said today that it made a $506,115 profit last year, mostly because of increased sales of cars it imports from West Germany and the strength of the American dollar.

title: THE STORY OF A SWINDLE: PROFIT, FRAUD AND DEATH
description: The following article is based on reporting by Ralph Blumenthal and Selwyn Raab and was written by Mr. Raab.

title: Phils 9, Giants 4
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Steve Carlton won his third straight game after starting the season by losing four in a row, striking out 10 batters and hitting a three-run homer for Philadelphia.

title: People
description: * John R. Blaney, a senior vice president in Ogilvy & Mather's New York office, was given the additional title of general manager.

title: 1. A Unisex Fedora
description: Hats are back for men and women. A SoHo boutique has a unisex fedora that's both becoming and practical since it serves as a sun or rain hat. Made of strips of beige nylon sewn together and adorned with a neatly pleated band, it is a good idea for travelers since it can be packed and bounces back into shape. It comes in small, medium and large and costs $20 at Diddington's, Prince Street and West Broadway.

title: MUSKIE TO MONITOR NESTLE ON BABY FOOD
description: Nestle, the Swiss-based food company, is financing a committee to monitor its marketing practices for infant formula, it has just been announced here.

title: Zimbabwe Rail Link Cut in Blasts, Police Say
description: Zimbabwe's main rail link to South Africa was cut and electrical installations and a water tank were damaged by five explosions Saturday near the southern border town of Beit Bridge, the police said today.

title: 2 Russians Climb Everest
description: Eduard Myslovsky and Vladimir Balyberdin today became the first Russians to climb Mount Everest, the Nepalese Tourism Ministry announced. Mr. Myslovsky, 44 years old, of Moscow and Mr. Balyberdin, 32, of Leningrad reached the top of the 29,028-foot-high peak this afternoon and stayed 30 minutes before beginning their descent, the ministry said.

title: U.S. JURY INVESTIGATING PAYMENTS TO MEXICANS
description: A Federal grand jury is hearing evidence in an investigation of charges that several American companies have paid millions of dollars in illegal bribes to officials of Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's Government-owned oil company, the Justice Department confirmed yesterday.

title: India to Investigate Murders Of Religious Sect Members
description: The government of India's West Bengal state decided today to open a judicial inquiry into the killing last week of 17 members of a religious sect.

title: SOFT OIL PRICES FORCING CUTBACK IN NORTH SEA PLANS
description: Faced with stagnant oil prices, soaring development costs and high taxes, big oil companies operating in the North Sea are sharply scaling back plans to develop new fields.

title: VOTING LAW COMPROMISE CLEARS SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a compromise version of the Voting Rights Act that would make it easier for voters who are members of minority groups to prove that they were victims of discrimination.

title: EDWARDS UPSETS KRIEK, 6-3, 7-6
description: Eddie Edwards upset his South African countryman, Johan Kriek, and upstaged Ivan Lendl and Jose-Luis Clerc in the Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills yesterday.

title: MUSIC: DAVIES 'AVE MARIS'
description: PETER MAXWELL DAVIES'S ''Ave Maris Stella'' (1975) was given a poignant, lyrical performance by the New York New Music Ensemble Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The work, for piano, marimba, viola, cello and registral varieties of flute and clarinet, invokes a variety of styles and includes Monteverdian intonations, a virtuosic marimba cadenza and wry glances backward at modernist agonies.

title: General Belgrano; History
description: The General Belgrano, which was sunk Sunday by two torpedoes from the British submarine Conqueror, was launched 1939 at a Camden, N.J., shipyard as a cruiser of the Brooklyn class and commissioned as the United States Navy's Phoenix.

title: MELLON'S FLORIDA LEADER PURSUES TRUST BUSINESS
description: Florida is still one of the greener pastures for wealthy, retired folks from the Northeast, if a recent move by the Mellon National Corporation, holding company for the big Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, is any indication.

title: U.S. GOES TO ECOLOGY PARLEY UNDER CLOUD OF DOUBT
description: With the second United Nations Conference on the world environment about to meet in Nairobi on Monday, there is growing concern among environmental groups here and abroad that the United States is abandoning its role as the leader of the international effort to protect the global environment.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp. said it had entered into a $36 million long-term revolving credit agreement with a group of banks led by the American Security Bank of Washington.

title: CLERKS TO ANNOUNCE LATE SUBWAY TRAINS
description: When a subway train is stopped for two minutes, the conductor will inform the passengers why there is a delay and how long it will last. Clerks in token booths will be equipped with bullhorns so they can address large crowds on the platforms during major delays.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We felt that Argentina was the first aggressor and originally backed Britain. But obviously the British themselves are very much the aggressors now, and we are taking a neutral stance.'' - Defense Minister Patrick Power of Ireland. (A18:1)

title: HARD ASSASSIN AND LIFELONG LOSER
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. heard himself portrayed by a Federal prosecutor today as a ''calculating'' would-be assassin who had carefully planned to kill President Reagan with exploding bullets and had ''mowed down'' people who stood in his way.

title: 4 HELD IN MEXICO IN TAX CASE
description: The Mexican Government has charged four directors of a Mexican company with tax evasion involving commissions received from an American oil equipment concern.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES DROP 5.1%
description: The Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that auto sales fell 5.1 percent in late April. Consumers were unresponsive to incentive programs, analysts said, amid the continuing recession and high interest rates.

title: 1.1 MILLION JEWS RESIDING IN CITY, A SURVEY SHOWS
description: There are 1,118,800 Jews living in New York City, representing 15.8 percent of the city's population, according to the first results of a survey announced yesterday by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.

title: Japan's Plans For U.S. Coal
description: To improve its trade balance with the United States, Japan plans to buy more American coal, a Japanese newspaper reported today.

title: THE FACTORING SCHEME
description: A scheme based on a little-known financial practice led to the slayings of a Federal witness and three men who tried to aid her, law-enforcement officials believe.

title: PIONEER VIDEO NAMES NEW CHAIRMAN
description: There are three video recording technologies - videotape, disks played by stylus and disks played by laser. The Pioneer Electronic Corporation of Japan, which has put its money on the laser system, has announced the appointment of a new chairman and chief executive officer, Hobart C. Kreitler, to head its video subsidiary in the United States.

title: U.S. AUTHORITIES DETAIN AFGHANS AT BROOKLYN SITE
description: Thirty-four Afghans who said they fled political persecution in Afghanistan are being held in the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in Brooklyn. Some have been detained for as long as four months pending deportation hearings.

title: SPATULA FOR BARBECUING
description: WITH the recent glorious weather, thoughts inevitably turn to that great American institution the cookout. Barbecues are one of the main pleasures of summertime because they are informal and because food tastes especially good prepared out of doors on a sunny afternoon or on a cool evening at the beach.

title: Soviet Agrees to Compensate Sweden in Submarine Incident
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to pay compensation following the stranding of a Soviet submarine near Sweden's Karlskrona naval base last October, Swedish sources here said today.

title: Hearns-Hagler Put Off
description: The world middleweight title fight between Thomas Hearns and Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the champion, was officially postponed yesterday by the bout's promoter, Bob Arum.

title: C.A.B. Fines Head of Airline
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board issued a consent order yesterday against Neil G. Bergt, chairman of Western Airlines, and against Western Airlines and Alaska International Airlines, with penalties of $15,000.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 6, 1982
description: International Britain is exploring new ideas to halt the battle for the Falklands, according to Foreign Secretary Francis Pym. Addressing an agitated House of Commons, Mr. Pym said that the ideas included an early cease-fire but that no truce was possible without a withdrawal of Argentine troops from the islands, a condition that Buenos Aires has repeatedly rejected unless it is coupled with recognition of Argentine sovereignty over the islands. Responding to a question, Mr. Pym said that one possibility was the creation of ''a United Nations trusteeship'' in the archipelago. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina devalued the peso by 17 percent as part of a series of economic moves designed to spur exports and help finance the war against Britain. Buenos Aires said that about 800 survivors had been rescued from the cruiser General Belgrano. (A16:1.)

title: Former Teamster Leader Convicted in Bomb Plot
description: A former official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has been convicted of two counts of criminal solicitation in a suspected plot to blow up a business near Newark, Del.

title: CABLE TV SEES MORE CENTRALIZATION
description: Until 1978, owning a cable television system was considered a risky investment. Today, ''Cable television is a gold mine,'' said one executive at the 31st National Cable Television Association convention here this week. ''How high is up?'' Lucille Larkin, an industry consultant, asked. ''Nobody knows yet the outer limits of what the consumer will buy.''

title: News Analysis
description: New York State now has a budget that just about everyone agrees is balanced. But it is based on a series of almost random cuts that no one is happy with.

title: SCREEN: 'LA COMMARE SECCA,' WHERE BERTOLUCCI BEGAN
description: ''LA COMMARE SECCA'' is the film that launched Bernardo Bertolucci's directorial career, and it's easy to see why. At the age of 21, Mr. Bertolucci took over direction of this 1962 film from Pier Paolo Pasolini, who had written the screenplay based on his own short story. The story, revolving around the murder of a prostitute in a Roman park, is structured as a series of vignettes about the various suspects, each of whom is seen being interrogated by the police.

title: YANKEES TRADE REVERING TO JAYS FOR MAYBERRY
description: The Yankees, staggering and stumbling through the early part of the season, left New York on a two-week road trip today in a rebellious mood. By the time they arrived here six hours later, one of their unhappy players, Dave Revering, had been traded to Toronto for John Mayberry.

title: 4 AREAS DEFERRED FROM LEASE PLAN
description: The Interior Department announced today that four ecologically sensitive basins would again be excluded from a pending sale of oil and gas leases off the northern coast of California.

title: Beirut Bombing Wounds 4
description: Four people were wounded today when a booby-trapped car exploded near the house of Lebanon's Moslem leader, Mufti Hassan Khalid, in southern Beirut.

title: STAGE: PATRIZIA NORCIA IN DRAPER MONOLOGUES
description: RUTH DRAPER spent her lifetime writing and performing monologues richly populated by figures of her imagination. Among her many fervid admirers was Sir John Gielgud, who said that she was, along with Martha Graham, ''the greatest individual performer that America has given us.'' Miss Draper continued acting into her 70's and died in 1956, during her final Broadway engagement. Since then, she and her monologues have lived on in memory and on records.

title: More Cutbacks At Caterpillar
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the huge Peoria, Ill., manufacturer of earthmoving and construction machinery, announced today that it was planning further cuts in its production schedules, with resulting additional layoffs of employees.
