The extent and the timing of the cuts in production and employment were not disclosed.

title: SEXTETS: CLEVELAND QUARTET PLUS TWO
description: AFTER the two Brahms String Sextets were played at the 92d Street Y Tuesday night this listener felt that he had feasted on an enormous repast without having tasted much that was memorable. There was even a touch of indigestion from all the starch and pretense.

title: FINAL CHAPTER WRITTEN IN SAGA OF WESTGATE
description: C. Arnholt Smith's financial empire has officially disappeared. With the filing of final liquidation papers in a Nevada court on Tuesday, the ill-starred Westgate-California Corporation, which had struggled along for eight years under Chapter 10 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, vanished from corporate rosters.

title: BLOCK SEEKS MILK SUPPORT CUT IN ATTEMPT TO REDUCE SURPLUS
description: In hopes of persuading American dairy farmers to reduce a mounting surplus of milk, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block asked Congress today for authority to lower Government price supports on dairy products.

title: ARGENTINA FAVORS U.N. NEGOTIATIONS
description: Argentina said tonight that it was ''willing to negotiate a peaceful solution'' through the United Nations of its conflict with Britain over the Falkland Islands.

title: Dole Asks Smaller Cut In Food Stamp Funds
description: Senator Bob Dole, breaking with the Reagan Administration and with the Agriculture Committee chairman, Senator Jesse Helms, today proposed cutting $700 million from the food stamp program instead of the $2.3 billion requested by the White House.

title: News Analysis
description: By leaving intact more than $900 million in budget vetoes this week, the State Senate gave a big fiscal headache to Edward I. Koch, the New York City Mayor, and political pain to Edward I. Koch, the candidate for Governor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The President of the United States will endorse and support this proposal.

title: REAGAN'S LINK TO LABOR FINDS UNIONS IN REVOLT
description: Robert Bonitati, President Reagan's special liaison agent with organized labor, appears to be one of the loneliest men in town these days.

title: Sports of The Times; Quebec Proves It Belongs
description: FOR most people with only a vague awareness of hockey, there is only one team in the National Hockey League. Every spring, that kind of semifan glances to see if the Montreal Canadiens win the Stanley Cup again.

title: OFTEN PLAYED ARROGANT NAZI
description: Helmut Dantine, an actor best known for his portrayal of arrogant Nazis in World War II films, has died of a heart attack at his home in Beverly Hills, family friends announced today. He was 63 years old.

title: Copper Mine Outlook Dim
description: An official of the Phelps Dodge Corporation said today that the company's copper facilities will probably stay shut well beyond June 1, the earliest date that they were likely to reopen. In New York, the company declared a dividend of 10 cents a share for the second quarter, half the level paid a year earlier.

title: An Ex-Hostage of Iran Faces Charges of Criminal Mischief
description: A freelance journalist who spent nine months in an Iranian prison during the hostage crisis has been charged with criminal mischief, the police said today.

title: BUSH IN CHINA IN EFFORT TO CLEAR THE AIR
description: Vice President Bush arrived in China today to assure the Peking leadership that the United States wanted to ease the strain in relations caused by disagreement over American military sales to Taiwan.

title: ABC-TV PLANS 7 NEW SERIES
description: ABC Television will present seven new series in its 1982-83 primetime schedule beginning Sept. 27: three half-hour comedies, three one-hour comedy-adventure dramas and ''Ripley's Believe It or Not!'' Six series are being canceled: ''Taxi,'' ''Barney Miller,'' ''Mork & Mindy,'' ''Strike Force,'' ''The New F.B.I.'' and ''Code Red.''

title: TECHNOLOGY STOCKS OFF
description: Stock prices registered only minor changes yesterday in active trading. Some of the technology issues posted the biggest losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose almost 10 points in the previous three sessions, ended unchanged yesterday at 854.45. However, in the overall market yesterday, stocks that advanced outnumbered declining issues by 785 to 661.

title: TORY FARMER AT THE HELM
description: Defense Secretary John Nott has been a rapidly rising star in the Conservative Party since the middle 1970's, and much mentioned as a likely Chancellor of the Exchequer one day. But despite all his evident ambition, he has often displayed a curious lack of the single-minded drive that is usually needed to get a politician to the top. ''Perhaps public office does not make the adrenalin course through my veins at quite the speed that it does with some of my colleagues,'' he said once. ''I love public life, but the only thing I care about really passionately is my farm.''

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET OPENER
description: THE New York City Ballet likes to do it with aplomb. So Tuesday's opening of the spring season at the New York State Theater was neither the best nor the worst of evenings at the ballet.

title: BRENDA FRAZIER, WHO CAUGHT EYE OF PUBLIC AS DEBUTANTE, DIES AT 60
description: Brenda Frazier Kelly Chatfield-Taylor, whose name was once synonymous with glittering debutante balls and the social whirl, died of cancer Monday at Newton-Wellesley Hospital in Boston. She was 60 years old.

title: POLISH BISHOPS CONDEMN RIOTS AND URGE TALKS
description: Roman Catholic bishops today condemned the disorders that swept a dozen Polish cities, and appealed for reconciliation talks between martial law authorities and the suspended Solidarity union.

title: 'LUCKY BABY' OF 30'S HUNTS HER PARENTS
description: Mary Ann Walker's scrapbook is filled with the yellowed photographs and clippings that chronicle her childhood - the nurses, the sunny pink nursery high above East 72d Street and the doting couple who adopted her in March 1936: James J. Walker, New York City's flamboyant former Mayor, and his wife, the actress Betty Compton.

title: The Economy
description: The White House and Senate Republican leaders agreed on a budget compromise, and it was approved hours later by the Senate Budget Committee. The plan would increase taxes by $95 billion over three years. It envisions a deficit of $105 billion for the fiscal year 1983, $70 billion for 1984 and $42 billion for 1985. (Page A1.) Earlier, at a House Ways and Means Committee hearing, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and House Democrats discussed possible tax increases. (D19.)

title: ZONING PLAN BENDS UNDER LOBBYING
description: Real estate developers, lawyers, theater owners and other powerful interest groups are rushing about City Hall and making telephone calls trying to influence the politicians who have the final say on proposed changes for zoning regulations in midtown Manhattan.

title: Solidarity Calls Again
description: They waved red flags on May Day in Poland and a caged people roared forth with predictable wrath. The defiant Solidarity marchers were tolerated for a day. When that inspired more provocative challenges, the regime answered with tear gas, arrests, curfews and dead telephones. So much for the ''normalization'' that was going to yield relaxations of martial law this week.

title: ARAB GIRL DIES OF GUNSHOT INFLICTED BY ISRAELI DRIVER
description: A Palestinian Arab girl died in a Jerusalem hospital today of gunshot wounds reportedly inflicted three days ago by an Israeli motorist in the West Bank. Her death brought to 12 the total killed in violent clashes in the last six weeks in the occupied territories.

title: CELTICS ADVANCE IN DOUBLE OVERTIME
description: In a fitting conclusion to a physical playoff series, the Boston Celtics, defending champions of the National Basketball Association, defeated the Washington Bullets, 131-126, in double overtime tonight at Boston Garden.

title: Yale Head Faults Defense Spending
description: Yale University's president, A. Bartlett Giamatti, said today in his annual report to the university that spending billions of dollars on national defense would be meaningless unless the United States also took steps to reaffirm its commitment to education.

title: COLOR IT GRAY
description: The debate on foreign policy as well as nuclear affairs is swelling across the country, after years when an apparently indifferent public left these issues to specialists.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: EARLY WORRIES ON WORLD'S FAIR SEEM UNWARRANTED
description: Many of the early concerns of World's Fair officials here seem to have been unwarranted. Traffic jams have not materialized in the first five days of the fair and parking has not been a problem. It seems that thousands of out-of-town visitors, especially the elderly, have arrived by tour bus.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
MAKING PAINTING EASIER
description: MAY to October is prime time for painting the house or apartment. Home centers and paint stores have many aids to make the job easier.

title: The U.N. Today; May 6, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Reliance in Buy-Out
description: The Reliance Steel and Aluminum Company said today that it had acquired the stake held by Japan's Mitsui & Company in a joint venture that the two companies formed in 1980.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rate.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SAYS U.N. MIGHT HAVE A ROLE; ARGENTINA; CALLS FOR TALKS
description: Foreign Secretary Francis Pym said today that Britain had begun to explore new ideas for ending the battle for the Falkland Islands.

title: PUSAN'S 'MOB' OF FOUR
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: He will continue with the organization as a scout. ... Despite the team's 17-45 record after he replaced Coach Tom Nissalke early in the season, Frank Layden was rehired by the Utah Jazz for a year as both coach and general manager. ... Martina Navratilova has displaced Chris Evert Lloyd as No.1 in the rankings of the Women's Tennis Association. Mrs. Lloyd had held the top spot since July 1980, when she replaced Tracy Austin. ... Francis Schreiber, the 23-year-old Miami Dolphin fan who snatched a football from a ball boy in the end zone last Nov.15, has been placed on six months' probation. The original charge of armed robbery had been reduced to petty theft, to which Mr. Schreiber pleaded no contest.

title: Arnold Palmer's 'Fore!'
description: Some golfers on the PGA Tour face ''major disciplinary actions'' unless they behave properly, says Commissioner Deane Beman, reacting to a letter of complaint sent to him by Arnold Palmer. In his letter, Palmer, though identifying no one and citing no specific incidents, said that some of his colleagues were guilty of ''discourteous and ungentlemanly behavior and thoughtlessness'' on the course and that ''abusive language and displays of temperament'' had too often been met with mere ''wrist-slapping.'' Suspension of such players is in order, said Palmer, who added, ''Flashes of temper when directed at one's self is one thing, but when it becomes abusive and insulting toward the volunteer workers and spectators, it is another thing entirely.''

title: House Panel Defeats Ban on Bight Dumping
description: The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee today defeated an amendment that would have prevented New York City from continuing to dump sewage sludge in the New York Bight.

title: AERIAL SPRAYING OF MOTHS PLANNED FOR 4 CITY PARKS
description: The Parks Department will use aerial spraying to combat gypsy-moth infestations in four city parks, Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis announced yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Says Raiders Would Abandon Their Fans
description: By attempting to move to Los Angeles, the Oakland Raiders told the people of Oakland they are ''suckers,'' Patrick Lynch, the chief attorney for the National Football League, said today.

title: Roof Collapses Kills Woman
description: A section of a supermarket roof collapsed under the weight of rain water tonight, killing one woman and critically injuring another as thunderstorms flooded streets in southern Oklahoma, the police said. The dead woman was not immediately identified. The injured woman was identified as Helen Trivey, 27 years old, a store employee.

title: Motet Choir Requiem
description: The New York Motet Choir under the direction of Stephen Sturk will present the Requiem Mass by the Renaissance composer Pierre de la Rue on May 16 at 7 P.M. at Grace Church, Broadway and East 10th Street. Tickets are $5. Call 254-9703.

title: English City Mourns Loss of Its Namesake
description: Flags flew at half-staff in the Yorkshire steelmaking city of Sheffield today in tribute to the destroyer, named for the city, that was lost in the South Atlantic yesterday.

title: HINCKLEY JURY TOLD OF NOTES AND LETTERS BY DEFENDANT
description: A hijacking note and a postcard addressed to the actress Jodie Foster, with a picture of President and Mrs. Reagan on it, were found in John W. Hinckley Jr.'s hotel room in the capital the day he shot Mr. Reagan, according to evidence at Mr. Hinckley's trial today.

title: China Plans Output Gains
description: China plans to increase the value of its industrial and agricultural output by 4 percent in 1982, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Trimble Steps Down
description: Jim Trimble, who is 63 years old, has stepped down as director of pro personnel for the Giants, a position he had held since 1969.

title: AKRON, ITS TIRE BOOM OVER, TRANSFORMS ITS FACE AND STYLE
description: In a classic case of industrial raiding, Melrose, N.Y., saw its little factory lured away by boosters from a town in a booming Western state.

title: Oil Drilling Costs Rise
description: The cost of drilling for oil and equipping wells in the United States rose 16 percent in 1981, double the 8 percent increase the year before, according to statistics presented to a meeting here of the Independent Petroleum Association of America yesterday.

title: SHOILD DANCE SELL ITSELF ANY WAY THAT WORKS?
description: HOW should dance sell itself? In a time when dance companies are beginning to look increasingly like endangered species, the answer may be any way that works. A frisson of dismay ran through the dance world just over a month ago, nonetheless, when the first advertisement appeared in a new campaign for the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which was about to start a three-week season at the City Center. ''Suddenly you'll understand sex, power, gravity, music, fear, humor and joy better than ever before,'' the advertisement promised. (''All that tonight?'' one newcomer to Mr. Taylor's dance murmured nervously.)

title: WHEN A PERSON MAKES SOCIETY PAY HIS DEBTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANCIS A.  COX, 69, A TIMES EXECUTIVE
description: Francis A. Cox, former vice president and chief financial officer of The New York Times Company, died yesterday at Palm Beach-Martin County Medical Center in Jupiter, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and had lived in Juno Beach, Fla., since 1978.

title: ROCK: ASIA, A 'SUPERGROUP,' MIXING ART AND HARD STYLES
description: ONE of the shrewdest examples of corporate packaging in rock-music history has been the formation of Asia, a 1980's ''supergroup'' consisting of Steve Howe, the former lead guitarist from Yes; Carl Palmer, Emerson, Lake and Palmer's drummer, the keyboardist Geoff Downes, and the bassist and singer John Wetton. The quartet, whose debut album is high on the charts, has achieved instant success with a homogenized adaptation of the frilly art-rock style of Yes into a streamlined hard-rock style popularized by bands like Foreigner.

title: Morris Quits Race
description: Robert Morris of Mantoloking withdrew today from the Republican primary for United States Senate, saying he had accomplished what he set out to do when he entered the race at the start of April.

title: SOME UNDER RENT CONTROL TO GET REDUCTION OF UP TO $20 A MONTH
description: Because their landlords failed to pass along slight reductions in fuel oil prices, thousands of tenants living in rent-controlled apartments may be eligible for rent reductions of up to $20 a month, New York City housing officials said yesterday.

title: British Free Captives From South Georgia
description: About 150 Argentine soldiers and 30 civilians captured when British forces retook the island of South Georgia, southeast of the Falklands, are on their way home, Defense Ministry officials said today.

title: 3 'HAROLD' ACTORS REVEL ON THEIR BRAND-NEW HIT
description: YESTERDAY morning was a sweet time for Zakes Mokae, Danny Glover and Lonny Price. The night before they had opened on Broadway in Athol Fugard's new play, '' 'MASTER HAROLD' ... and the Boys.'' By the time the curtain came down, the audience was on its feet, roaring its excitement. And by the time the reviews came out a few hours later, it was clear that the critics were no less enthusiastic.

title: IRANIAN COPTERS RAID IRAQI TOWN FOR FIRST TIME, TEHERAN REPORTS
description: Iranian helicopters attacked targets in Iraq for the first time in the war, the Teheran radio said today. Thirteen sorties were flown Tuesday against the Iraqi town of Fuka, just inside Iraq and about 200 miles from Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, according to the broadcast monitored here. Iran has American-made helicopter gunships.

title: MUSTO MISTRIAL BID IS WEIGHED
description: Judge H. Lee Sarokin of Federal District Court said today that he would decide by the end of the week whether to declare a mistrial in the Federal racketeering convictions of State Senator William V. Musto and seven co-defendants.

title: WHEN A PERSON MAKES SOCIETY PAY HIS DEBTS
description: To the Editor:

title: WARSAW PLANS TALKS ON '82 DEBT
description: The renewed unrest in Poland raised obstacles today to the rescheduling of loan and interest repayments that Warsaw is due to make this year.

title: Marlboro Opens June 27
description: The Marlboro Music School and Festival will open its 32d season June 27.

title: ROCKEFELLERS TAKING I.R.S. TO TAX COURT
description: For Nelson A. Rockefeller, the price of the Vice Presidency, a job a biographer says he considered ''beneath his interests,'' is turning out to be quite high indeed.

title: U.S. AND PERU PRESENT A NEW SET OF PROPOSALS
description: The United States and Peru discussed with Britain and Argentina today a new set of proposals for ending the fighting over the Falkland Islands, Administration and diplomatic sources said.

title: BURROUGHS TO SELL SMALL COMPUTERS
description: The Burroughs Corporation yesterday introduced a family of small computers that will sell for between $8,000 and $20,000. The computers, made for Burroughs by Convergent Technologies Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., will be available in June.

title: Earthquake Rattles Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake rocked Anchorage and two smaller cities today. There were no reports of damage or injuries. Workers in high-rise office buildings scurried outdoors and worried residents made so many telephone calls that some circuits went dead, but no damage to the system was reported.

title: F.B.I. SEIZES HEAD OF BANKRUPT DIAMOND CONCERN
description: The head of a bankrupt diamond company and his wife, who have been linked to the embezzlement of $6 million by a slain Federal witness, were arrested on mail fraud charges yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: VOLCKER ON BUDGET BALANCING
description: In an unexpected shift of view, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, moved close today to support of a constitutional amendment that would require a balanced Federal budget. But he warned against allowing the amendment proposal to divert attention from solving the Government's present fiscal crisis.

title: PROMOTING A U.S.-FLAG ISN'T 'SHAMELESS PROTECTIONISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: British Auto Outlook
description: British car sales in 1982 are expected to fall slightly below last year's 1.48 million units, Geoffrey Moore, president of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, said today at the trade group's annual meeting. It would be the third consecutive year of decline from the record of 1.72 million units, which was set in 1979.

title: BRIEFING
description: By Private Arrangement

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. SETS NEW CODE TO BENEFIT DISABLED
description: A special board representing the Federal Government and the public set new standards Tuesday for making buildings owned or leased by the Government accessible to the handicapped.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Crown Zellerbach's senior debt and publicly rated I.R.B.'s have been rated BBB by Standard & Poor's, down from an earlier A rating.

title: EDITORS SAY THEY WILL KEEP LANDERS COLUMN
description: Editors of some of the nation's major newspapers say the disclosure that Ann Landers, the widely read advice columnist, had been using letters or answers first published 15 years ago to fill out her current columns has put them in a curious quandary.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a proxy fight against the Gulf Resources and Chemical Company incorrectly identified Gary A. Childress. He is a former president of the Warner Company.

title: ILLINOIS SUIT AIMED AT PEOPLES ENERGY
description: The Peoples Energy Corporation, a holding company that owns two public utilities here, was accused today by the Cook County State's Attorney of conspiring to defraud natural gas consumers of $100 million.

title: Advertising; High Cost Of TV Ads Examined
description: THE art director on the set where a television commercial was being shot rejected a dining room table that was scheduled to be used in the ad.

title: Nofziger Condition 'Good'
description: Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political adviser, is ''in good condition and resting comfortably'' after suffering a mild stroke, but no paralysis, a White House spokesman said today. The deputy press secretary, Larry Speakes, said that Mr. Nofziger, 57 years old, who was taken to the hospital in Arlington, Va., early Tuesday morning, expected to be able to go home in a week or 10 days.

title: Canadian Pacific Net Falls 64.8%
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., a diversified transportation, natural resources and financial services concern that is Canada's biggest company, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter of 1982 plunged 64.8 percent, to $46.9 million, or 65 cents a share, from $133.4 million, or $1.86 a share, in the first quarter of 1981. Revenues, however, increased 10.4 percent, to $3.09 billion, from $2.8 billion.

title: CHINA RAISES ITS MILITARY BUDGET
description: China said today that its spending on ''preparations against war'' would increase to more than $10 billion this year, ending two year's of reductions in military spending.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: LIFE, AND DEATH, IN SALVADOR
description: It is easy enough to tell the visitors from the residents here. The visitors are the ones who jump when a car backfires. The residents are the ones who neither flinch nor miss a conversational beat when a bomb goes off.

title: THE CUBAN OVERTURE
description: With all the drama in Latin America these last weeks - the Falklands crisis, the move to the right in El Salvador - relatively little attention has been paid to a development of potentially deep significance. That is the Cuban Government's signal that it is ready ''to seek a relative accommodation'' with the United States, based on ''mutual restraint.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard Late Innings. A Baseball Companion. By Roger Angell. 429 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.50.

title: STEEL UNION GIVING AWAY FOOD TO JOBLESS WORKERS
description: Laid-off steelworkers lined up for free bread, milk and canned goods today as their union opened a food bank. Retired members of the United Steelworkers of America volunteered their time to hand out grocery bags filled with canned meat, tuna fish, soup, beans and other staples for those whose unemployment benefits were nearly exhausted.

title: MCENROE AND LENDL IN LAST 16
description: John McEnroe, Ivan Lendl, Vitas Gerulaitis and Jose-Luis Clerc won in the stadium yesterday, and Eddie Dibbs sharpened his strokes in the grandstand. But Mel Purcell labored on a field court in the Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills.

title: WHEN A PERSON MAKES SOCIETY PAY HIS DEBTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES THRIFT UNIT AID PROGRAM
description: A House subcommittee today approved a financial assistance program to aid thrift institutions and commercial banks. The bill would authorize Federal regulatory authorities to issue ''guarantees'' - a form of Government promissory note - to a savings and loan association, mutual savings bank, commercial bank or credit union whose net worth had dropped below two percent of its assets.

title: ECONOMIC DEMOCRACY IN GREECE
description: Focusing primarily on foreign policy, most outside observers of Greece's Socialist Government have ignored or discounted the most radical feature of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's domestic reform program: its promise of democratic participation in economic policy.

title: GARAGE WORKER, 22, IS HELD IN SLAYING OF NURSE IN BRONX
description: A young garage maintenance man was charged yesterday in the bludgeoning death of a 24-year-old nurse at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx after he confessed to the police, according to the office of the Bronx District Attorney.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Absolute Coatings Inc. has appointed Donald J. Miner vice president, sales.

title: A YEAR OF ATTACKS ON HOCKEY OFFICIALS
description: Bob Hall, who is 29 years old and Canadian, harbors a professional ambition that is not unusual for a man of his nationality. He wants to become a National Hockey League referee.

title: EXXON SETS 'SHELF' DEBT ISSUE
description: The Exxon Corporation joined the trend toward ''shelf registration'' yesterday with the announcement that it planned to issue $500 million in company-guaranteed debt securities under the Securities and Exchange Commission's new Rule 415. This allows a company to issue securities ''off the shelf,'' without further disclosure, after the initial filing has been made. Exxon filed the notes with the S.E.C. yesterday.

title: Letter: On Special Education; Children Who Need Their Own Track
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Crossword Puzzle Ran in Times April 16
description: A California man submitted a 20-year-old crossword puzzle to The New York Times, which unwittingly ran it April 16 before the subterfuge was discovered, an assistant managing editor of the newspaper said yesterday.

title: Pupils Walk Out Over Budget Cuts
description: About 150 pupils, protesting proposed cuts in the Board of Education budget, stormed out of East Haven High School today and marched around Town Hall, ignoring school administrators' pleas to return.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Chicago Tuesday on the codification of Judaic case law gave an incorrect first name for the director of the Institute for Computers in Jewish Life. He is Rabbi Irving Rosenbaum.

title: GRIEF AND SUSPENSE FOR SHEFFIELD'S HOME PORT
description: The blue-and-gold flag of Portsmouth hung at half-staff today as this city 70 miles southwest of London absorbed the loss of the destroyer Sheffield, which normally was based at this port of longstanding naval tradition.

title: Dance Talks to Discuss Japan, Israel and Egypt
description: The dance of Japan, Israel and Egypt will be the subject of a free film and lecture series sponsored by the Performing Arts Research Center at Lincoln Center's Dance Collection on Thursdays at 6:30 P.M. this month.

title: SALVADOR LEADER INSTALLS 3-PARTY CABINET
description: President Alvaro Magana installed his new Cabinet Tuesday night, and it gave virtually equal representation to the three major political parties, as he had promised.

title: COURT RULES CASINOS MAY NOT BAR CARD COUNTERS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled 5 to 0 today that casinos could not bar skilled blackjack players known as card counters who often beat the house by memorizing what cards have been played and which ones remain undealt.

title: NEW U.S. ARTS-AGENCY AIDE
description: Hugh Southern, executive director of the Theater Development Fund in New York City, today was appointed deputy chairman for programs of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT CUT IN QUARTER
description: The deficit in the United States merchandise trade balance with foreign nations narrowed to $5.9 billion in the first quarter of this year as imports of oil and other products fell, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Lancia Imports Halted
description: Fiat Motors of North America Inc. has stopped importing and distributing the sporty Italian car Lancia in the United States because of poor sales and a halt in production in Chivasso, Italy, Fiat's national marketing manager said today.''We've had problems with the Lancia line over the years, and production has been stopped with the 1982 models,'' William Rude said from Fiat's American headquarters in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J.

title: Death Toll Now 13 In Hoboken Fire
description: The death toll in last week's hotel fire in Hoboken has risen to 13 with the death of a 20-year-old woman who was being treated for burns.

title: Gulf Resources Dissident Move
description: A dissident group that had proposed its own slate to run against the official slate of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation said that John D. Murchison Jr., the 34-year-old Dallas oil executive, had joined its team to replace Claude L. Ganz, president of the OMA Products Corporation, who had withdrawn.

title: Indonesian Government Wins Legislative Election
description: The army-led Golkar coalition, which has governed Indonesia for 17 years, scored an overwhelming victory in national legislative elections, officials reported today.

title: YIELD FALLS ON 10-YEAR U.S. NOTE
description: Despite the prospect of large budget deficits, the United States Treasury sold $4 billion of new 10-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 13.77 percent, down from 13.93 percent in Monday's preauction trading and well below the 14.68 percent yield for similar notes sold in February.

title: Castle's Repairs Shut Park Weather Station
description: Weather-recording instruments in Central Park were damaged and made inoperable by restoration work at Belvedere Castle, the National Weather Service said yesterday.

title: Market Place; The Recession And Guardian
description: WHEN a company's primary markets are depressed, Wall Street may not notice if it is doing well at the expense of competitors. That, at least, is the approach Shearson/ American Express takes in viewing Guardian Industries. Among other products, Guardian offers glass for new cars and private homes - two of the hardest-hit markets in the recession.

title: SLAYER OF TURKISH ENVOY IS HUNTED IN BOSTON AREA
description: As President Reagan branded the killing of the Turkish diplomatic representative to New England ''a cowardly assassination,'' more than 20 Federal, state and local officers searched the area today for leads to the gunman who killed Orhan R. Gunduz Tuesday night.

title: STUDY SEES WAY TO CUT COSTS ON WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION
description: A study of the cost of workmen's compensation insurance has concluded that companies could save as much as $1.8 billion a year in insurance premiums if a more competitive ratemaking procedure were adopted nationwide.

title: South Tucson Again Told To Pay Man $4 Million
description: A judge today ordered the City of South Tucson to pay the more than $4 million it owes a man permanently injured in a police raid. He said the payments should be made in five annual instalments in the next five years.

title: Gold Loses Its Glitter For Investment Adviser
description: They used to call him ''Mr. Gold.'' But ''Mr. Gold'' - James E. Sinclair - is not hot on the metal anymore. ''I would advise my customers that the only recovery in gold is cyclical in nature,'' Mr. Sinclair said yesterday. ''The great drama of gold is past. A move from $35 to $887.50 is a once-in-a-lifetime event. If that's what you're loking for, you've missed it.''

title: Rail Crash Kills 6 in Spain
description: Two commuter trains collided today outside this city 215 miles north of Madrid. Railroad officials said six people had been killed and 25 injured. They gave no cause for the crash.

title: CLARINET: JEWISH BILL
description: GIORA FEIDMAN'S concert at the Abraham Goodman House yesterday afternoon began as the former principal clarinetist of the Israel Philharmonic played wisps of sound as he walked down the aisle, twisting his instrument in the air, teasing out a melody. The slow patter played by his accompanists - Jeff Israel, guitar, and Peter Weitzner, double bass - began to quicken, and the clarinet nearly became a human voice, celebrating a long tradition of song.

title: DESIGN NOTTEBOOK
description: SPRING is the season of house tours. People are enormously curious about other people's houses, and well-intentioned nonprofit groups across the country, in city and suburb, mobilize that curiosity to raise money for worthy causes.

title: Yemenis in Peace Talks
description: The President of Southern Yemen arrived in rival Yemen today for peace talks. The arrival of President Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani came a day after Yemen's pro-Western Government reported wide-scale operations against the rebel National Democratic Front, which is supported by Southern Yemen.

title: Penn Central Settlement
description: An investors' group that had opposed a plan by the Penn Central Corporation to acquire Colt Industries said today that Penn Central had agreed to reimburse it $975,000 for expenses incurred during the proxy fight. The group, which was known as the Penn Central Stockholder's Committee, included three members of the Hunt family of Dallas.

title: Bridge: Player of Long Experience May Turn It to Advantage
description: An advantage that bridge has over most other forms of recreation is that age is no deterrent. At one end of the scale, play is possible in grade school. At the other end are some centenarians and plenty of nonagenarians.

title: Gasoline Inventory Dip
description: Despite steady production, gasoline inventories fell for the seventh consecutive week and were slightly below the Department of Energy's average range for this time of year, a trade group reported yesterday.

title: BARON JANNER
description: Baron Janner, who as Barnett Janner served four decades in the House of Commons, died early today after a long illness, his family announced.

title: Beatcha Is 5-2 Favorite In World Cup Pacing
description: Two American horses are favored over San Simeon, an Australian pacer, in Thursday night's first race of the World Cup Pacing Series at the Meadowlands.

title: EVEN DEERE FEELS THE PINCH
description: This area has its own unmistakable signs of spring. John Deere turns its swans loose to strut around the manicured grounds of the company's headquarters. And the Deere factories usually switch into high gear to get ready for the year's peak selling season.

title: NUCLEAR ISSUE YIELDS RUN ON POLLSTERS
description: When a new issue catches Washington's politicians by surprise, some of them go to specialists on it to find their bearings and some rely on their instincts. But a lot of them go to polltakers.

title: A Way to 'Survive'
description: Marv Goux is the assistant football coach at Southern California who arranged to sell complimentary tickets for U.S.C. players and thereby committed the infraction that led to the football program's being placed on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Now Goux, in an interview with The Los Angeles Times, says the reason he broke the rules was to help his athletes ''survive.'' The cost of living in Los Angeles is higher than in other sections of the country, he said, and a scholarship doesn't always meet the needs of the players, some of whom come from impoverished homes.

title: 'This Is the Army' Cast Plans Its 40th Reunion
description: The former privates and corporals and sergeants in greasepaint who made theatrical history in Irving Berlin's ''This Is the Army'' on Broadway and on the road in the European and Pacific Theaters will assemble Saturday for their 40th reunion, in the Belasco Room of Sardi's Restaurant.

title: Petro-Lewis
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said its proven oil and gas reserves were estimated to be 74.4 million equivalent barrels of oil, split evenly between gas and oil, representing a 44 percent increase from a year ago. The acquisition of producing oil and gas properties, as well as successful drilling efforts, accounted for the increase, said Jerome A. Lewis, chairman and chief executive of Petro-Lewis.

title: NEGOTIATORS SAY ACCORD IS NEAR ON FEDERALISM
description: Officials of the National Governors Association said today that they believed they had reached a tentative agreement with the White House on a framework for realigning Federal and state responsibilities for welfare and Medicaid.

title: ...AND IN ARGENTINA, ELATION AND A CALL TO ARMS
description: The posters went up on the walls of the city overnight. They show a bullet-spattered British flag and the words in Spanish, ''And now to the death.'' In small print, in English, are the words, ''I'm sorry.''

title: LEGISLATORS TOLD OF A TRANSIT GAP UP TO $400 MILLION
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority told legislative leaders here today that the authority faced a shortage of $300 million to $400 million in the coming year, state officials said.

title: FIRST PRESIDENT SELECTED FOR U.S. CHINA VENTURE
description: Norman F. Young was named president of Wheeling-Minmetals International Inc. yesterday. The company is a newly formed venture of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and the Chinese Government.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PROFESSIONAL mechanics know that regular servicing will keep any piece of equipment working longer and more efficiently. Homeowners should adopt this policy for their power lawn mowers. A few hours spent at this time of year in servicing the mower will help to prevent unexpected breakdowns, will make cutting the grass quicker and easier and is almost certain to extend the life of the machine.

title: DEMOCRATIC RACE IN VIRGINIA IS WIDE OPEN AGAIN
description: With less than a month before the Democratic nominating convention in Roanoke, the party has no clear choice for a candidate to run for the United States Senate in November.

title: SONG: LIVINGSTON-EVANS DUO
description: JAY LIVINGSTON and Ray Evans are songwriters who have been working as a team for 45 years, turning out songs that have won three Academy Awards and have sold 220 million records. They also managed to find a way to cover their songwriting careers that was not merely a chronological succession of hits as they performed in the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series Sunday evening and last night at the 92d Street Y.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I am planning a sizable addition to my home in the near future, and all the carpentry work will be done by a contractor. However, I intend to install the electrical wiring myself. Should the wiring be put in before or after the insulation is installed in the outside walls? If I wait the wiring will be on the inside of the insulation and thus protected from extremes of outside temperature. - D.G., Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: AT THE BRITISH EMBASSY, A STATELY RENOVATION
description: Sir Edwin Landseer Lutyens would surely have been pleased. Were the great English architect alive today, he would have appreciated the renovations just completed in the British Embassy, which he designed more than 50 years ago. Some 250 guests have been invited by Sir Nicholas Henderson, the British Ambassador, and his wife, Lady Henderson, for a viewing Thursday night of the mansion on Massachusetts Avenue, the only Lutyens building in America.

title: Taking Over at U.D.C., but Not for Long
description: When Richard A. Kahan resigns as president of New York State's Urban Development Corporation on June 1, he will be succeeded by Donald S. Glickman, but not for long.

title: A BALKY DRAWER: HOW TO REPAIR IT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese repairs furniture for antiques dealers and collectors. BY MICHAEL VARESE

title: MRS. GERALD S. SHIBLEY
description: Florence M. Shibley, the widow of Dr. Gerald S. Shibley, a former professor of internal medicine at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York, died Tuesday at Meadow Lakes Residential Community in Hightstown, N.J., where she had lived since 1973.

title: Mexican Bus Plunge Kills 9
description: A bus driver taking religious pilgrims home dozed off at the wheel, and the bus fell off a 350-foot cliff, killing nine Mexicans and injuring 36 others, a Mexico City newspaper reported today. The 45 passengers on the bus were returning Tuesday from a religious trip to Puruaran, in Michoacan State, when the accident occurred nine miles north of Huetamo, about 120 miles southwest of Mexico City.

title: Program on End of World
description: ''Poetry Against the End of the World'' will be the theme of a program featuring writers and performers May 26 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, at 8 P.M. Among those planning to participate are David Ignatow, June Jordan, Galway Kinnell, Stanley Kunitz, Denise Levertov, Derek Walcott, Jill Clayburgh, Ossie Davis, Amiri Baraka, W.S. Merwin, Simon Ortiz and Robert Bly. Admission will be $5 in advance from Poetry Against the End of the World, 207 East 85th Street, P.O. Box 423, New York, N.Y. 10028, or $7 at the door. Call 935-0497.

title: THE CHILD-SOLDIERS OF LATIN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Suffer Their 11th Loss in Row
description: Larry Herndon's single scored Kirk Gibson with the go-ahead run as the Detroit Tigers rallied for three runs in the eighth inning for a 6-4 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight. The Rangers' losing streak was extended to 11 games.

title: Trading Stays Heavy In Treasury Futures
description: Trading in the new 10-year Treasury note futures continued at a hectic pace yesterday. Although prices closed slightly higher, this was considered less important than the huge open interest - the number of contracts outstanding - that has developed in just three days of trading.

title: Basque Guerrillas Kill Nuclear Plant Director
description: Separatist guerrillas killed the director of a nuclear plant in Spain's Basque region today in an apparent attempt to stop it from coming into operation, but the Government said the project would go ahead.

title: Unicorp to Raise Real Estate Stake
description: The Unicorp Financial Corporation announced that its Unicorp American Corporation unit planned to increase its holdings in San Francisco Real Estate Investors to more than 50 percent during the second quarter.

title: WHITE HOUSE AND G.O.P. LEADERS AGREE ON BUDGET PROPOSAL FOR '83
description: The White House and Republican Congressional leaders today agreed on a Federal budget proposal that was tentatively passed hours later by the Republican-dominated Senate Budget Committee.

title: Spurs Oust Sonics in 5
description: George Gervin scored 26 points to lead San Antonio to a 109-103 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics tonight that clinched the Western Conference semifinal series for the Spurs, four games to one.

title: RESPONSE TO THE SECRETARY GENERAL CITES A U.N. ROLE BUT NOT PULLOUT
description: Argentina has given a ''positive reaction'' to the United Nations' peace plan for the Falkland Islands, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said tonight.

title: Player Sues Paper
description: Bobby Lee Hurt, a freshman basketball player at Alabama, has filed a $1.6 million libel suit against The Birmingham Post-Herald, the newspaper that first reported that Hurt had been coerced into enrolling at the university by Glenn Johnson, an alumnus to whom he owed money. The suit charges that Hurt, formerly an all-America forward at Butler High School in Huntsville, Ala., was subjected to ''public contempt, ridicule, shame, embarrassment and great mental anguish'' as a result of that Post-Herald article and several others.

title: Wilson Declines Mets' Praise for Hitting
description: Despite the disappointment of Tuesday night's 2-1 ninth-inning loss to the Dodgers, Mookie Wilson's Met teammates flocked to his locker after the game to congratulate him on becoming the first man to get four hits off Fernando Valenzuela in one game.

title: Senate Panel Overrides a Ban On Food Assistance to China
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee on Wednesday rejected the Reagan Administration's request for legislation declaring China a ''friendly nation'' as far as American food aid is concerned.

title: Amtrak's Chairman Plans to Step Down
description: Alan S. Boyd announced yesterday that he was stepping down as chairman of Amtrak, the Government-backed National Railway Passenger Corporation formed a decade ago to run the nation's passenger lines. Mr. Boyd, 59 years old, has headed Amtrak since 1978, and relinquishes his post effective June 30.

title: COSMOS LOSE IN OVERTIME, 2-1
description: The Cosmos played their most uninspired game of the North American Soccer League season and lost to the Toronto Blizzard, 2-1, in sudden-death overtime tonight at National Exhibition Stadium before a crowd of 10,740.

title: NO SURTAX. FORGET IT.
description: In the dark ages before Marcus Welby and Ben Casey, doctors thought they could cure sick people by bleeding them half to death. These days, some modern-day economic witch doctors are claiming that the way to cure our sick economy is to squeeze a few more drops of blood out of the taxpayer.

title: U.S. NAVAL DEBATE SHARPENS
description: The naval engagements between Britain and Argentina in the South Atlantic have added urgency to a debate here over the future of naval forces in an era of advanced guided missiles and torpedoes.

title: News Analysis
description: The antigovernment demonstrations of recent days indicate that time is running out for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's proclaimed policy of reaching a national accord. The protests, which turned violent on Monday when the police charged marchers here and in a dozen other cities, underscored both the depth of popular support for the Solidarity union movement and the depth of opposition to martial law.

title: Hope for the Capture Of Mengele Is Revived
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the hunter of Nazi war criminals, said today that he was close to catching Dr. Josef Mengele, who has been accused in the deaths of 400,000 people at the Auschwitz death camp during World War II.

title: JAZZ: WYNTERS-WELSHMAN BILL
description: LYNN WELSHMAN'S TENTET, which, despite its name, is an 11-piece jazz band, is bringing jazz to Little Italy on Sundays with performances at 6 P.M. and 8 P.M. at S.P.Q.R., a restaurant and cabaret at 133 Mulberry Street. A vocalist is featured with the band each week.

title: AN 'OVERWHELMING' VIOLENCE -TV TIE
description: A Federal analysis of a decade's research on the behavioral effects of television viewing has concluded that there is now ''overwhelming'' scientific evidence that ''excessive'' violence on television leads directly to aggression and violent behavior among children and teen-agers.

title: THE DANCE: PREMIERE OF GOH'S 'CONFIGURATIONS'
description: CHOO SAN GOH often choreographs ballets as if he were solving arithmetic problems. Treating the members of his casts as parts of clearly defined choreographic units, he proceeds to add, subtract, multiply or divide the dancers in them.

title: AN UNDERSCALED, OVERSTUFFED LOOK
description: ''THEY'RE exact copies, not adaptations,'' said Howard Kaplan, right, of his new upholstered furniture, based on Napoleon III pieces.

title: Transit Work Rules, Unzipped
description: The arbitrated settlement that averted a New York City transit strike is no peace treaty; it's only a truce for which each side pays a heavy price. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority gives its workers a 21 percent pay increase over three years. The unions agree to negotiate the often-wasteful work rules in transit departments and shops.

title: A DAVID VS. MOBIL IN $2.2. BILLION SUIT
description: Coastal Caribbean Oils and Minerals Ltd. is a tiny company with a big claim against Mobil Oil - $2.25 billion to be exact - for phosphate mined from land to which Coastal says it owns the mineral rights.

title: REAGAN SPARS WITH DEMOCRATS
description: Trading gibes and sarcasm, House Democrats and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan challenged each other today to propose tax increases that go beyond President Reagan's Feb. 8 budget proposals.

title: NATO Backs Britain, Weinberger Declares
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that there had not been any lessening of Atlantic alliance support for Britain in the Falkland crisis despite the naval losses suffered by both sides.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: POTTERY AND PLANTS
description: Pottery Show and Sale, Green Meadow Waldorf School, Hungry Hollow Road and Route 45, Spring Valley, N.Y., 914-356-2514.

title: Wickes Closes 12 Stores
description: The Wickes Companies, the diversified retailer now in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, has begun a streamlining program by closing nine Wickes furniture warehouse showrooms in the East and Middle West and three Attitude furniture stores in Illinois.

title: IN BRITAIN, THE OLD FIGHTING MOOD IS AROUSED...
description: Whatever the politicians call it - armed hostility, self-defense, confrontation - the British know it is war. When men are killed, aircraft shot down and ships sunk, the national instinct tells them this is war and wars are fought to be won.

title: LEAKAGE OF U.S. TECHNOLOGY TO THE SOVIET BLOC IS CHARGED
description: Senate investigators said today that sensitive technology was being sent to the Soviet bloc because of weaknesses in the Commerce Department's bureau that enforces export controls.

title: China-Canada Grain Accord
description: China has agreed to buy $1.8 billion (Canadian) worth of wheat from Canada over the next three years, the Government announced today.

title: House Panel Supports Veto of Used Car Rule
description: A House committee voted today to strike down a consumer protection rule requiring automobile dealers to tell customers about mechanical defects in used cars offered for sale.

title: Ulster Security Forces Find 3,000 Firebombs
description: Northern Ireland's security forces found more than 3,000 gasoline bombs in Belfast today as Irish nationalists commemorated the first anniversary of the death of Robert Sands, the hunger striker, the police said.

title: Miss Bellamy, in Moscow, Discusses Jewish Issue; Bellamy Visit
description: Though she is in Moscow this week for what is described as a ''private visit,'' Carol Bellamy, the New York City Council President, has met with Soviet officials on a variety of topics.

title: GEORGE SCHLATTER FINDS THE FUN IN TV
description: LOS ANGELES GEORGE SCHLATTER is fresh from a failure and feeling buoyant. What is a failure, anyway, but a chance to try something new? This particular fiasco was a variety show called ''The Shape of Things,'' and with women as hosts. It lasted three weeks on NBC-TV, and by then it was a tossup as to whether the audience-popularity ratings or the reviews were more miserable.

title: A GUIDE TO BUYING THE RIGHT SOFA
description: FOR a while there in the 70's, the sofa, arguably the best piece of furniture ever invented to lazily read a book on, seemed dangerously close to the edge of extinction. Minimalist interior designers had decreed that it was out, that banquettes, those immovable seating structures usually built into walls, were not only in, they were indispensable.

title: Gould Plans Sale Of Electrical Unit
description: Gould Inc., an electrical products and batteries manufacturer, announced that it expected to sell a part of its business this quarter. The company, based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., plans to sell its low-voltage distribution and controls and its electrical components operations.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arcata Corp. set June 3 as the date for shareholders to vote on adoption of a plan to complete liquidation and sale of the company to A.L.B. Ventures.

title: HOUSEWARE MAKER THRIVES AS FAMILIES STAY AT HOME A LOT
description: Although American families are reluctant to put money into new cars, houses, furniture and appliances, many are spending more time at home, entertaining and relaxing, and they are buying things for their kitchens, dens and bedrooms.

title: DANCE: 2 PREMIERES AT OPENING OF AILEY SEASON
description: EVERY opening of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is like a celebration, and Tuesday night was no exception, launching the company's three-week season at the City Center with the usual high spirits and two out-of-the-ordinary New York premieres.

title: GENNARO REA
description: Gennaro Rea, a former vice president of the Buitoni Foods Corporation, died Tuesday at St. John's Hospital in Yonkers. He was 67 years old and lived in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Bell Denies Cable Plan
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company sought today to mollify some of the concerns of the cable television industry by saying that it had no interest in ever entering the ''traditional'' cable business.

title: A Guitarist's Photographic Talents
description: Since its beginnings on the Bowery in the mid-1970's, the rock group Blondie has risen to international fame and multimillion record sales. Some of the joys and trials of that rise were captured by Chris Stein, the group's lead guitarist, who also carried a camera.

title: 'CHARACTER' FORTIFIES ISLANDERS
description: As the Islanders happily waited today to find out their opponent in the Stanley Cup final, the question most often asked was: How did they manage to sweep the Quebec Nordiques in four games?

title: Technology; Electronics Vs. Optics
description: MESSAGES once carried by electricity flowing through wires or by radio waves are increasingly being transmitted by pulses of light zipping along hair-thin glass fibers. A single fiber can carry as much information as hundreds or even thousands of copper wires.

title: Sybron Cites Bids For Pfaudler Unit
description: The Sybron Corporation of Rochester, a diversified producer of hospital products and waste treatment equipment and chemicals, said it had received several bids for the company's Pfaudler division, which makes equipment used for the manufacture of corrosive chemicals.

title: Richard Saltonstall, 84, Dies; Financier and Philanthropist
description: Richard Saltonstall, financier, farmer and philanthropist and a member of one of the oldest families in Massachusetts dies Tuesday at his Charalescote farm. He was 84 years old.

title: Hungary Set To Join I.M.F.
description: The 145 countries that make up the International Monetary Fund have voted to accept Hungary as a new member in their organization, an I.M.F. spokesman said today.

title: ASSEMBLY ENDS ITS 1982 SESSION IN CONNECTICUT
description: The General Assembly adjourned its 1982 session this evening after a long day of disagreements between the two houses over several bills and, at the end, an ovation for the Speaker of the House, who is leaving to run for Governor.

title: News Analysis
description: The sudden announcement Friday that the present owners of The Daily News would continue to operate the paper reflected a variety of factors, according to officials of the paper and its unions and also representatives of would-be buyers.

title: Guilty Plea Made In Cocaine Case
description: A defendant in a Federal cocaine case who had claimed entrapment by Government agents withdrew an earlier not-guilty plea to three drug counts and pleaded guilty to a single conspiracy charge before Judge Thomas C. Platt of District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Kaiser Steel Pact
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said that it had signed an agreement for Kawasaki Steel of Japan to provide Kaiser with technical assistance to develop a system to move and control steel slabs to the Fontana plant. The study, scheduled for completion in September, will cover a system to transport up to 64 shiploads of purchased steel slabs a year, Kaiser said. Terms were not disclosed.

title: CRISIS IS EXPECTED TO AID TORIES IN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: The battle for the Falkland Islands is expected to help Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party in Thursday's local elections and thus strengthen her hand.

title: 'Very Anxious Time,' Queen Elizabeth Says
description: Queen Elizabeth II is closely following the news of hostilities in the South Atlantic, not only as the head of state but also as the mother of one of the fighting men there.

title: STATE MAKES $300 MILLION AVAILABLE FOR MORTGAGES
description: New York State will make available $300 million in conventional residential mortgage loans to lending institutions around the state, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan announced today. The mortgage rates would be set at market levels.

title: RARE LIGHT BULBS ARE FOR THE FINDING
description: SOME light bulbs are out of the ordinary. It is said that in the old Palace Theater in Fort Worth a bulb that first shed light in 1908 burned continuously through 1977. In that year it was bought by a suburban Fort Worth resident and flickers to this day.

title: Thousands in Portugal Mourn 2 Slain Workers
description: Tens of thousands of mourners, including the Portuguese Communist Party leader, Alvaro Cunhal, joined a silent funeral march today for two young workers who were killed Saturday during clashes with the police.

title: WHITNEY MUSEUM RAISES FUNDS TO BUY CALDER 'CIRCUS'
description: The director of the Whitney Museum of American Art announced yesterday that contributions exceeding $1.25 million had been received in a 15-day campaign to enable the museum to keep Alexander Calder's ''Circus,'' which was lent to the institution 12 years ago.

title: NOW IS THE TIME TO START A GARDEN OF WILDFLOWERS
description: WOODLAND flowers are beguiling and surprising. For weeks the leafy litter under shade trees lies dormant, reminiscent of the winter gone by. Suddenly, it comes to life, with something new appearing each day.

title: Imperial Bank Plans Unit
description: Imperial Bancorporation, a Los Angeles-based holding company for the Imperial Bank, plans to introduce today the Imperial Securities Corporation, an investment subsidiary.

title: Standard Metals Dissident Action
description: The Oklahoma Publishing Company, which will attempt to oust management of the Standard Metals Corporation at its annual meeting next Monday, announced its nominees to the mining company's board.

title: A Sermon for Prayer Day
description: When you pray, do not be like the hypocrites; they love to say their prayers standing up in synagogue and at the street corners, for everyone to see them. I tell you this: they have their reward already. But when you pray, go into a room by yourself, shut the door, and pray to your Father who is there in the secret place; and your Father who sees what is secret will reward you.

title: BUCKS WIN, 110-98, CUT 76ERS LEAT TO 3-2
description: At 34, Bob Lanier sometimes calls himself an old man. With tendinitis and arthritis in knees that have numerous surgical cuts, every game causes him pain. Tonight, though, with his team facing elimination, the 6-foot-11-inch Milwaukee Bucks' center played with youthful abandon.

title: Edwin Clark, Lawyer And Ex-Army Officer
description: Edwin N. Clark, a lawyer who served in the Army in World War II, leaving the service as a brigadier general, died Saturday in Fairfield, Conn. He was a resident of Easton, Conn., and was 80 years old.

title: RUSSIANS DEFEND VIETNAMESE LABOR
description: After months of rumors about planeloads of Vietnamese being transported to Soviet factories to work off Hanoi's debt to Moscow, the Soviet authorities have offered an account of the program designed to silence ''slanderers in the bourgeois press'' who made an issue of it.

title: AGENCY SEEKS TO RELAX CARBON MONOXIDE RULES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has drafted a new rule that would substantially increase the amount of carbon monoxide permitted in the air, according to agency documents made public today by several Democratic members of Congress.

title: TV: CLASSIC FROM 1956
description: ''THE Golden Age of Television,'' returning to public television as a three-part series, brings back drama productions from the 1950's, when television broadcasting was live and, at least as seen through a haze of nostalgia, more imaginative and exciting. Memory often tends to exaggerate, of course, but there are enough productions extant to demonstrate that, at least occasionally, the age could indeed be golden.

title: Air Products Merger Accord
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., a major industrial gas and chemical producer, said its board had approved a definitive merger agreement to acquire the Stearns-Roger Corporation, an engineering and construction concern, for $210 million in cash. The companies also agreed to a $20 million reduction from the previously announced price of $230 million.

title: Italy Suing Sindona
description: Italy is seeking to recover $6 million that it contends was diverted by Michele Sindona from two of his now-bankrupt Milan banks. Mr. Sindona is serving a 25-year sentence after having been convicted on charges relating to the 1974 failure of the Franklin National Bank in New York.

title: NEW RESPONSIBILITIES BORNE BY CHILDREN OF SINGLE PARENTS
description: SINGLE parents report that their children are becoming more independent and responsible as a result of the increased roles they have to play in the management of the household. As the children contribute more to the decision-making, according to psychologists in the field of family relations, it is natural for single parents to allow them even greater responsibility. Moreover, the psychologists report, as the children help make decisions on an equal basis with their parents, the traditional hierarchical family structure is further eroded.

title: WHEN A PERSON MAKES SOCIETY PAY HIS DEBTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuela Giving Parts For Jets to Argentines
description: Venezuela, one of Argentina's strongest supporters in its Falkland Islands dispute with Britain, is providing spare parts to Argentina for Mirage fighter-bombers and Canberra light bombers, United States intelligence sources said today.

title: Going Out Guide
description: VARIATIONS

title: Bonn Foreign Minister Plans To Visit Israel to Mend Ties
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher will visit Israel next month to try to improve relations, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: SWEET AND SOUR
description: ''Protectionism'' and ''subsidy'' are dirty words: they denote practices that harm free trade, reward the inefficient, drive up prices. Boo.

title: THE 7-ELEVENS' BATTLE TO CURB CRIME
description: On East 22d Street, there is a 7-Eleven store with a bright light signaling ''Thank Heaven for 7-Eleven'' 24 hours a day, and many of the people in the neighborhood feel just that way.

title: Building a Rail System To Serve New England
description: Timothy Mellon said yesterday that his New England rail system should be in place by Labor Day. Mr. Mellon, 39 years old, a descendant of the wealthy Pittsburgh family, has been working for a year and a half to build the system out of three railroads - the Maine Central, the Boston & Maine and the Delaware & Hudson.

title: Arizona Town Makes Offer to Paraplegic
description: The city of South Tucson today offered $3.8 million to settle a judgement of more than $4 million awarded to a crippled policeman. The city is trying to avoid a court order requiring it pay the full judgment in five years.

title: McLouth Wins Debt Reprieve
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation announced that it had won a second reprieve from its secured creditors and was granted a 75-day extension to its scheduled shutdown date of June 18.

title: Transactions
description: %BASEBALL

title: THE FACTS OR FICTION OF MURDER
description: The subject was murder. Not any one specific murder. But rather, murder in general - a kind of esoteric inquiry by those for whom murder is a living.

title: PAY TV MAY GET 'PIRATES' FILM DEBUT
description: For the last four months, Universal Pictures has been quietly considering showing ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' its new multimillion-dollar movie, on a pay-per-view basis on television before it is shown in theaters. It would be the first time for a major Hollywood movie to be shown in this fashion.

title: CAPITAL CENSUS: FAR FROM AVERAGE
description: For those who may wonder why Washington is a city that Presidential candidates run against, that people in places like Pocatello love to berate but that defeated Congressmen seldom want to leave, the Census Bureau has come up with some helpful statistics.

title: STAGE: 'HOTHOUSE,' A NEW-OLD PINTER
description: ''SOMETHING funny's going on here,'' says one of the characters in ''The Hothouse,'' and he's not kidding. Harold Pinter's 1958 play, which had its New York premiere last night, can be very funny. Now that we've seen this writer's bleaker, later works, it's amusing to rediscover him in youthful form - pouring jokes into a slight but frisky jape. Though ''The Hothouse'' at times resembles Mr. Pinter's other plays, right up to ''Betrayal,'' its overall nuttiness recalls the wacky British humor of its time -from Ealing film farces to ''The Goon Show.''

title: Shale Line Halted
description: The Exxon Corporation, which earlier this week closed its $5 billion Colony Shale Oil Project in western Colorado, said it had also abandoned plans to construct a $100 million pipeline that would have run from the Colony project to Casper, Wyo., where it would have been linked to other pipelines. The project had not progressed far enough even to survey its route, Exxon said. The 279-mile-long pipeline had a proposed capacity of 50,000 barrels a day.

title: West Village Chorale
description: ''Songs for a City,'' a cantata by Michael Ward, based on poems by Bertolt Brecht, and Brahms's ''Zigeunderlieder'' (Op. 103) are the highlights of a performance to be given by the West Village Chorale tomorrow at 8 P.M. in St. Joseph's Church, 371 Avenue of the Americas, at Washington Place.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. has named Harvey Peskin vice president-investments.

title: BOND PRICES SOAR ON BIG DEMAND
description: Prices advanced and yields fell sharply on both short- and longterm Treasury securities yesterday in one of the most buoyant markets in weeks.

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: BAY STATE GOVERNOR'S RACE NARROWS
description: The man who has been Lieutenant Governor to the last two Governors of Massachusetts today bowed out of the fight to beat them both and left them to battle it out themselves.

title: HOWARD KETCHAM, AUTHORITY ON COLOR USE TO CORPORATIONS
description: Howard Ketcham, an authority on color who applied the principles of color engineering to products to increase their merchandising power, died Tuesday in his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and had been a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: CAREY ORDERS CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY INQUIRY
description: Governor Carey yesterday ordered a state investigation of corruption in the building and construction industry. The inquiry will include public hearings and focus on purported organized-crime influence and racketeering, the effect of corruption on public building projects and the effectiveness of law enforcement, the Governor said.

title: GIANTS GET 2 IN 9th TO DEFEAT METS, 5-3
description: After an early three-run Met lead had vanished, and with the remains of a soggy Shea Stadium crowd standing and cheering with two out in the top of the ninth, Chili Davis lined a two-run double on a 3-2 pitch to give the San Francisco Giants the winning runs in a 5-3 victory last night.

title: Colt Share Issue
description: Colt Industries said its shareholders had approved a company request to increase the number of common shares outstanding to 100 million from 30 million. A Colt spokesman said the company has no ''specific plans at the moment for its issue or for the use of proceeds from it.'' The president, David I. Margolis, told shareholders attending the annual meeting in Detroit that the company has spent $75 million to date buying back 3 million shares of the company's stock, out of a total planned buyback of 8 million shares.

title: BELL SELLS 'SHELF' ISSUE TO MORGAN
description: In its first use of the new shelf-registration process, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is selling 2 million newly issued shares of common stock for $110.8 million to Morgan Stanley & Company, the company announced late yesterday.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 198 money market mutual funds rose $301 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $191.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Bid for Alden Is Canceled
description: Gustav & Gretz Schickedanz Holding K.G., which operates Quelle, Europe's largest mail order house, said yesterday in Nuremberg, West Germany, that it had revoked its letter of intent to buy 51 percent of the Alden Corporation, a mail order subsidiary of the Wickes Companies. Wickes, based in San Diego, is operating under the Chapter 11 protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: News Analysis
description: After a period of watching awkwardly while his aides negotiated with Congressional leaders on the budget, and then following with a volley of partisan denunciation of Democrats, President Reagan has burst into the open this week with a series of startling accommodations.

title: WINI SHAW
description: Wini Shaw, who gave the original performances of ''Lullaby of Broadway'' and ''The Lady in Red,'' died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital.

title: U.S. REPORTS 628,000 JOBLESS NEARING CUTOFF OF BENEFIT PAY
description: More than 628,000 people in 31 states are in their final 13 weeks of eligibility for unemployment insurance payments, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CARTER DISCLOSES HE OFFERED FREEZE IN ATOMIC ARMS TO BREZHNEV IN '79
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said here today that he had proposed a freeze on deployment and production of nuclear weapons to Leonid I. Brezhnev three years ago, but that the suggestion had been turned down by the Soviet leader.

title: Federated Buys Twin Fair Unit
description: Twin Fair Inc., a discount store chain, said yesterday in Buffalo that it had reached agreement with Federated Department Stores Inc. for the sale to Federated of all the outstanding stock of Twin Fair Distributors Corporation, a subsidiary which operates discount stores in the western portion of New York State.

title: Concordes to Keep Flying
description: The Concordes won an indefinite reprieve today when French and British ministers decided to allow the supersonic airliners to continue in service. The project has cost Britain and France more than $1.6 billion so far.

title: Explosion in a Chemical Plant Leads to Evacuation in Duluth
description: An explosion destroyed three walls of a chemical plant today, raising a black cloud of chemical smoke and fumes.

title: TO CARE FOR A CHILD WITH DOWN'S SYNDROME
description: To the Editor:

title: West Bank Mayors Plan Disobedience Campaign
description: Occupied West Bank, May 6 (Reuters) - Palestinian mayors in the West Bank are planning a new campaign of refusing to cooperate with Israeli occupation authorities.

title: ARGENTINES SAID TO SEEK MORE OF FRENCH MISSILES
description: Argentina will be hampered in following up on its initial success at sea because it has only a few more of the Exocet missiles used to demolish a British destroyer on Tuesday, military analysts in the United States Government said today.

title: FEDERAL ANTI-CRIME EFFORTS MUST GO ON
description: To the Editor:

title: First City Adds Stake
description: The First City Financial Corporation, a British Columbia-based company, said yesterday that it had purchased 2.1 million shares, or 8.6 percent, of United States Industries, a New York-based apparel and building products producer, for about $21 million. The shares were purchased from the Clabir Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., for $8.9 million in cash and a promissory note for $12 million. A spokesman for U.S. Industries said the company did not expect that First City Financial would attempt a takeover. U.S. Industries stock, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at $10, down 12.5 cents a share.

title: Salvadorans Home From Fort Bragg
description: About one-third of the Salvadoran soldiers sent for 14 weeks' training at Fort Bragg, N.C., returned here today, and military sources said they would be in the field within two weeks.

title: THE NEW LE CYGNE IS ALSO A DESIGN EVENT
description: THERE has never been an easy relationship between the ideas of modern architecture and the notion of a classic French restaurant. Indeed, the two have often seemed completely at odds - modernism summons up associations of sleek, hard materials, cool surfaces devoid of ornament; by contrast, the image of a luxurious French restaurant is of a soft, plushy kind of luxury, of surfaces upholstered and decorated. It is no surprise, then, that most new French restaurants in the luxury class have tended to look like their predecessors, for contemporary architecture has until recently provided them with no way of meeting their needs. The only way such restaurants have had to provide the symbols that they require has been to fall back on imitation.

title: Ann Landers Admits Naivete Over Letters
description: Ann Landers is telling her readers that she was wrong and naive to have recycled 15-year-old letters for her daily advice column, but she says disclosure of the practice was a ''tempest in a teapot.''

title: Waldheim Is Hit by Streetcar, But Is Not Seriously Injured
description: Former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations was injured today when he was struck and tossed several feet by a moving streetcar while crossing a downtown avenue in the Austrian capital.

title: ART: MET SALUTES GEORGE BELLOWS ON CENTENARY
description: GEORGE BELLOWS could have been a professional ballplayer, but his ambition was for art. To this end, the young man from Columbus, Ohio, broke off his education at Ohio State University in 1904 and headed for New York City. He enrolled at the New York School of Art, becoming an outstanding student and, in due course, the friend of his teacher, Robert Henri. Evidently, the artist maintained relations with the school for some time. Stuart Davis speaks in an autobiographical essay about going there in 1910 and being required to pay his dues as a new student with ''a large quantity of beer.'' To persuade him of his obligation, ''the athletic George Bellows'' was called in from an adjoining studio.

title: Mr. Reagan and Black America
description: President Reagan has often seemed indifferent, even uncaring, toward minorities. But in the last week or two he has shown a new concern.

title: Posner Denies Tax Charges
description: Victor Posner, the financier, pleaded not guilty yesterday to an indictment charging that he evaded $1.2 million in Federal income taxes from 1975 to 1979 by falsely inflating the value of land he donated to the Miami Christian College.

title: News Analysis
description: In its effort to move the long-stalled plan for Namibian independence to the point of being put into effect, and thus resolve Southern Africa's most intractable diplomatic issue, the Reagan Administration now finds itself in a position that can be described as a mirror image of the one the Carter Administration was in before it left office. According to the original timetable that was optimistically projected from Washington last year, the first United Nations officials should have been arriving just about now in South-West Africa, as the disputed territory is formally known, to pave the way for a pre-independence election. Instead, after a meeting in Dar es Salaam this week with the key African countries that support it, the insurgent movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization has firmly rejected the voting formula proposed by the so-called contact group of five Western nations.

title: San Simeon Runs 6th; Beatcha Wins Cup Leg
description: San Simeon, the horse of the year in 1981 in Australia, failed again tonight to live up to his reputation and finished sixth in the opening leg of the World Cup pacing championship at the Meadowlands.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC TRIPLE-DECKER
description: RANK has its privileges in any organization, but especially in those that are modeled as closely along military lines as the symphony orchestra. One of the perquisites traditionally awarded to musicians who occupy front-desk positions is the right to appear now and then as full-fledged soloists in concertos of their choice. Although these performances are usually distributed through the season, Zubin Mehta decided to make a triple-decker of last night's concert by the New York Philharmonic, calling on three of the orchestra's leading men to step up and show what they could do.

title: Notes on People; Tax Commissioner to Run for Comptroller
description: The New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, James H. Tully Jr., said yesterday that he would resign next month and announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for State Comptroller.

title: Worker Hurt by Mail Bomb
description: A package addressed to the chairman of the Vanderbilt University computer science department exploded in the hands of a secretary Wednesday. Janet Smith, 39 years old, was sorting mail about 4 P.M. when the package, about the size of a cigar box and addressed to Patrick Fischer, exploded.

title: 'CABIRIA,' SILENT EPIC FROM ITALY, ON TOWN HALL SCREEN
description: EVEN in 1914, Italian film makers knew it was essentially the simple things in life that sell movies and so they made certain that ''Cabiria,'' a film released that year about Rome's wars with Carthage, contained the following:

title: STUDY FINDS GROUPS THAT HELP THE POOR HURT BY BUDGET CUTS
description: The Reagan Administration's budget cuts are striking hardest at people who depend on the Government for job training, cash assistance, basic health care and housing, a private study reported today.

title: New Composers' Residency Program
