description: A new Composer/Orchestra Residency Project designed to place six composers in two-year residencies with six major American orchestras was announced yesterday by Meet the Composer. Financing for the program is being provided by the Exxon Corporation, the Rockefeller Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: NCC Energy Stake Raised
description: Cook International Inc., a pesticide and insurance company in Memphis, said yesterday that it had increased its holdings in NCC Energy Ltd. to 48 percent. Cook purchased 13,320,126 shares of NCC, a British company, from the Birmingham and Midland Counties Trust Ltd. for $6 million.

title: REAGAN'S DARK SHADOW
description: California Republicans thought they had a shot this year at knocking off Jerry Brown in a U.S. Senate race, while replacing him in the governorship with one of their own. But that dark shadow now hanging over their prospects is cast by the most illustrious California Republican of all, former Gov. Ronald Reagan.

title: TALK WITH WIFE DENIED WALESA
description: The Polish authorities have refused to allow the interned leader of Solidarity, Lech Walesa, to see his wife this week after violent street clashes involving supporters of the suspended union, a Government spokesman said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULING ON THE UNIFICATION CHURCH
description: Following are excerpts from the decision of the New York State Court of Appeals on the Unification Church:

title: Shell Canada Plant
description: Shell Canada Ltd. said that it would complete its planned petrochemical complex in Scotford, Alberta, despite the departure of its joint venture partner, Husky Oil Operations Ltd. Shell said it expected to complete construction of the $1.4 billion (Canadian) project by 1984. The Scotford project includes a 50,000-barrel-a-day synthetic crude oil refinery, a benzene plant and a styrene monomer plant with a planned capacity of 300,000 tons a year.

title: Apple Is Upheld On Termination
description: A suit brought against Apple Computer Inc. by a former Apple dealer was dismissed in a New York Federal court.

title: BRITON DEMANDS TOTAL WITHDRAWAL BY ARGENTINA
description: Defense Secretary John Nott, taking an unyielding line on the Falkland crisis, declared today that the British Government would never agree to a cease-fire without a ''total withdrawal'' of the Argentine forces now occupying the disputed islands.

title: DODGERS SET BACK EXPOS, 3-2
description: Rick Monday, returning to the scene of his 1981 pennant-clinching homer, tripled in one run and scored another in the first inning today as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Montreal Expos, 3-2.

title: Control Data Pact
description: The Control Data Corporation will make its Plato educational courseware compatible with a line of home computers manufactured by Texas Instruments Inc., the companies announced. Control Data said the agreement provided for it to receive an unspecified flat fee from Texas Instruments, which would manufacture and market the material.

title: Indian Industries Move Into Malaysia
description: India's huge, family-run business houses are venturing out of their sheltered home environment and seeking a place in the Southeast Asian market with products ranging from diesel-driven pumps to palm oil.

title: Algeria Liberalizes Its Socialist System
description: Two decades after Algeria embarked on a path of socialist development following its independence from France, its leaders are acknowledging their economic mistakes and moving to liberalize their system.

title: JITTERY ROOKIE OUT
description: Cecil Cooper singled home the tiebreaking run in the sixth inning, and Ben Oglivie had a three-run double in the eighth to lead the Milwaukee Brewers over the Minnesota Twins tonight, 6-3.

title: Steelworkers Union Seeks P.&G. Boycott
description: The United Steelworkers of America called yesterday for a consumer boycott of Procter & Gamble products. The union, which represents workers in the company's Kansas City, Mo., soap plant, is protesting the company's use of a suspected carcinogen in detergents.

title: EGYPT GETS ENCOURAGING SIGNALS FROM OTHER ARABS
description: President Hosni Mubarak flew to the Sudan today for talks with President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, amid continuing friendly signals from some Arab nations that severed relations with Egypt after it signed a peace treaty with Israel.

title: HINCKLEY'S MOTHER TELLS JURY OF FORCING SON FROM HOME
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s mother broke down and wept on the witness stand this afternoon as she described how she had left her despondent son at the Denver airport with instructions not to come home again, less than a week before he shot President Reagan.

title: Miss Kyvallos Resigns
description: Lucille Kyvallos, whose women's basketball teams at Queens College won more than 300 games during the 13 seasons in which she was the coach, announced her resignation yesterday. Influencing her decision, she said, was that ''budget constraints at the college limited maneuverability in recruiting and in sustaining a nationally competitive Division I program.''

title: BUDGET ACCORD PLAN SENDS DOW UP 8.75
description: Stock prices advanced sharply yesterday in heavy trading, spurred by the news of a tentative plan to settle the battle over the Federal budget deficit.

title: LASER USE REPORTED EFFECTIVE IN AVERTING BLINDNESS IN ELDERLY
description: A new laser procedure has proved highly effective in treating the leading cause of newly developed cases of blindness among the elderly, the National Eye Institute reported today.

title: EFFECT ON JERSEY SHIELD LAW IS BROADENED FOR REPORTERS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court held today that reporters and news publications were fully protected in libel cases against the forced disclosure of their confidential sources of information and their ''editorial processes'' leading to publication.

title: Three on a Dime in Albany
description: New York State may now have a budget that Governor Carey, Senator Anderson, Speaker Fink and State Comptroller Regan can certify is balanced. But local officials and school board members are howling that while the budget's income equals its outgo, its outgo doesn't cover their needs.

title: AUTHOR HELPED START SYSTEM OF NEW MATH
description: Dr. Howard F. Fehr, professor emeritus of mathematics education at Columbia University Teachers College and a founder of new math in the 1960's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: PEREZ DE CUELLAR TERMS BRITISH REPLY 'POSITVE'
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today his Falkland Islands peace plan had won a ''positive'' response from Britain to match the ''positive'' reply from Argentina. But he acknowledged there were still unresolved ''details'' to be settled before a cease-fire takes place.

title: Italian Party Gets A New Leader
description: The Italian Christian Democratic Party elected a new leader today who has pledged to revive the party and put it back in the driving seat of Italian politics.

title: Auctions; Prints sales at 3 houses.
description: HUNDREDS of period and modern prints by Agam through Zorn will be auctioned over the next two weeks at Christie's, Sotheby Parke Bernet and Phillips, Son & Neale. The sale at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Street, on Monday at 2 P.M. and Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. includes two important works by Picasso - ''Le Repas Frugal'' (''The Frugal Repast''), a 1904 etching, and his 1958 ''Bust of Woman After Cranach the Younger.'' Each is expected to sell for as much as $90,000. There are also three etchings by Rembrandt -''Landscape With Trees, Farm Buildings and a Tower'' (up to $70,000), ''The Goldweigher's Field'' (up to $55,000) and ''St. Jerome Beside a Pollard Window'' (up to $45,000).

title: Bridge: Strong Field Will Compete For International Pair Title
description: The annual International Pair Championship organized in New York City by the Cavendish Club will be played tomorrow and Sunday; it will have one of the strongest fields ever assembled on such an occasion.

title: A Celebration of Books
description: The ''Book Variety Show'' at the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association, 111 Willoughby Street, offers books in unexpected forms through May 28.

title: CUOMO, MAYOR GIVEN BACKING FOR STATE RACE
description: Mayor Koch was endorsed for governor yesterday by four of New York City's Democratic leaders. His rival for the party's nomination, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, was endorsed by the city's Central Labor Council. The party leaders - Meade H. Esposito of Brooklyn, Stanley M. Friedman of the Bronx, Donald R. Manes of Queens and Nicholas LaPorte of Staten Island - said they could not deliver 100 percent of the vote to Mr. Koch.

title: A CIGARETTE PERIL THAT SHOULD BE OUTLAWED
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama's Voting Plans Rejected by Justice Dept.
description: The Justice Department today blocked Alabama's reapportionment plans for its State Legislature, saying they ''clearly would lead to a retrogression in the position of black voters.''

title: Blyleven Out for Year
description: Bert Blyleven, the Cleveland Indian pitcher, underwent surgery on his elbow on Wednesday and will be lost to his team for the remainder of the season. ... Mike Ivie, the first baseman with a history of emotional problems who was released unconditionally by the Houston Astros last week, has signed a one-year contract with the Detroit Tigers. Ivie, 29, has a career batting average of .274.

title: Crocker Arrives for Talks
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, arrived here today for a meeting with South African officials to discuss South-West Africa. The talks will begin a new round of Western diplomacy aimed at achieving independence of the South African-controlled territory, also known as Namibia. The State Department spokesman, Dean Fischer, said in Washington that there would soon be a meeting of the five Western nations that have a United Nations mandate to seek a settlement.

title: Java Volcano Erupts Again
description: The Galunggung volcano in West Java erupted Thursday for the fifth time since April 4, spewing out lava, flames and black smoke that combined with clouds to darken skies 70 miles away, the authorities said. No injuries or damage were reported.

title: Matuszak's Troubles
description: To hear John Matuszak tell it, he can't even go out for a beer without being harassed by a public that is not always so admiring. Matuszak, the 285-pound defensive tackle for the Oakland Raiders, was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct last week in connection with a scuffle at a tavern in his hometown of Oak Creek, a suburb of Milwaukee.

title: Higher Cable Commissions
description: It is the observation of John Slaven, ad director of Volkswagen, that most interest in cable television is coming from the client rather than the agency side. Nicely, he exempts his own agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: Restaurants; Good news for fans of haute cuisine.
description: SINCE it opened in 1969, Le Cygne, has been one of the city's outstanding haute-cuisine restaurants. Almost always distinguished by food that was long on flavor and short on chichi, this restaurant for a long time maintained a four-star rating. But last year the kitchen fell far below par, making a two-star rating more appropriate. To judge by four recent visits, however, the chef, Jean-Yves Piquet seems to be newly inspired, and the food he is turning out is excellent and well worth three stars.

title: Nations Cup to France
description: France won the Nations Cup for the fifth consecutive year at the Rome international horse show today.

title: THE INSURANCE INDUSTRY'S WAR ON AUTO THEFT
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW LOOK AT AMERICAN SCULPTURE
description: AMERICAN 19th-century sculpture has lagged quite some way behind American 19th-century painting in terms of current esteem. When the American Wing was opened at the Metropolitan Museum, for instance, American painting stayed the course very well, but a lot of people thought that the American sculpture on view looked soapy, derivative and second-rate.

title: SNEED'S 64 PACES HOUSTON GOLF
description: Ed Sneed and Scott Hoch finished strongly in the gathering darkness early this evening and took the first two places in the rain-delayed first round of the Houston Open.

title: THE ENIGMA OF DATAPOINT
description: DATAPOINT may represent the biggest disappointment or the best buying opportunity in recent recollection. Or it may simply represent the decline and fall of a storybook success of the computer age.

title: WOMEN DECRY REAGAN BUDGET
description: A coalition of women's groups sent Mother's Day greetings to President Reagan today accusing him of promoting economic policies that penalize women at home and at work.

title: Tosco's Shale Gain
description: The Tosco Corporation said the sale of its interest in the Colony Shale Oil Project would contribute about $100 million, or $4 a share, to the company's net income this year. The Exxon Corporation announced last Sunday that it was withdrawing from the $5 billion synthetic fuels project. As part of its operating agreement with Tosco, Exxon is required to acquire the Los Angeles-based company's interest in the project for $380 million.

title: ACCUSED POLLUTER WAS PAID TO CLEAN UP SITES
description: A state investigating committee was told yesterday that a New Jersey company accused of illegally dumping millions of gallons of toxic wastes in the New York area was awarded nearly $3.5 million in public contracts to clean up two sites that it had originally polluted.

title: 'DEATH VALLEY'
description: ''DEATH VALLEY,'' which opens today at the Rivoli and other theaters, is a thriller about a group of ordinary tourists who stumble into a dangerous situation. Not surprisingly, it is based on somebody's actual tourist experience. The production notes reveal that Richard Rothstein, the film's screenwriter, actually took a vacation in Death Valley with family and friends. Like the characters in the movie, Mr. Rothstein watched a car approach his on a lonely road in the middle of nowhere. What, he asked himself, if somebody bad were in that car and wanted to hurt me? From this, ''Death Valley'' was born.

title: JOHN J. CONSIDINE OF MARYKNOLL DIES
description: The Rev. John J. Considine, a writer and educator who helped promote the missionary role of the Maryknoll Society around the world, died Tuesday at St. Teresa's Residence at the Maryknoll headquarters in Ossining, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: SHEFFIELD SKIPPER TELLS OF 'ROARING MASS OF FLAMES'
description: Capt. Sam Salt, the commanding officer of the destroyer Sheffield, says the Argentine missile that hit his ship on Tuesday turned it into ''a roaring mass of flames.''

title: 53 ARE CHARGED WITH FRAUD OVER MEDICAID PRESCRIPTIONS
description: Fifty-three indictments involving Medicaid fraud were handed up yesterday by grand juries in New York City's five counties against 27 persons and 26 corporations operating in 41 different pharmacies.

title: ALIEN RAIDS OPENED UP JOBS, AIDE SAYS
description: A series of raids by the Immigration and Naturalization Service rounded up 5,440 employed aliens and persuaded 4,071 of them to leave the country, according to Joseph Salgado, the agency's associate commissioner for enforcement.

title: 3 Nonfood Units Sold by Beatrice
description: The Beatrice Foods Company, a Chicago-based food processor, announced that it had completed the sale of its A-1 Tool, Acme Die Casting and Artistic Texturing divisions to Lovejoy Industries, a small concern in suburban Chicago.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber GANGLAND. By David Winn. 226 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: MORTGAGE SUBSIDIES BACKED
description: In a drive to provide emergency help for the hard-pressed housing industry, House Democratic leaders cleared the way today for quick House action on legislation that would immediately allot $1 billion to subsidize mortgages for middle-income home buyers.

title: IRAQIS SAY IRANIANS ARE RETREATING AFTER AN ASSAULT ON RIVER POSITION
description: The Iraqi press agency reported that Iraqi troops attacked Iranian positions today on the west bank of the Karun River in Iran's Khuzistan Province.

title: MET MUSEUM SIGNS ACCORD WITH ITALY
description: The Italian Government and the Metropolitan Museum of Art have signed a longterm cultural-exchange agreement that will foster cooperation between the Met and the museums of Italy. It will facilitate joint arrangements for the organization of major international shows, the longterm loan of art works and the exchange of professional personnel.

title: Pontiac Gives 'P'-Car Plans
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to build its sporty Pontiac ''P'' car, expected to be introduced in the fall of 1983, at the Fisher Body complex in Pontiac, Mich., according to a vice president of the company.

title: Moscow Denies Warsaw Pact Leads in the Military Balance
description: Moscow today denied assertions by the Atlantic alliance that the arned forces of the Soviet Union and those of its Warsaw Pact allies held the edge in the East-West military balance.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Babcock & Wilcox, an operating unit of McDermott Inc., said it had received $22 million in contracts for nuclear components from Westinghouse Electric.

title: CBS CANCELING 'LOU GRANT,' 'WKRP'
description: CBS Television, announcing its plans for the 1982-83 season, said yesterday that it was dropping five series, including ''Lou Grant,'' and would present seven new series -four half-hour comedies and three one-hour dramas. The other series that will be canceled are ''House Calls,'' ''WKRP in Cincinatti,'' ''Mr. Merlin'' and ''Nurse.''

title: ROCK: JOOLS HOLLAND DROLLERY
description: USUALLY when sophisticated buffoonery and rock music are brought together, the humor comes at the expense of the music. But Jools Holland, the former keyboardist and former resident clown from the British pop group Squeeze, blends a Monty Python-inspired zaniness with 1940's-style bar-band rock into an act as musically crisp as it is funny.

title: Notes on People; Starting Day Early and Topping It Off With Kern
description: Leigh Beery got up at 6:30 in the morning to portray a fashion designer in a television commercial, and that, the actress-singer learned from her dinner partner many hours later, had been a master stroke for getting into the professional mood.

title: N.Y.F.E. BETS ON STOCK INDEX
description: At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, the New York Futures Exchange began trading in stock index futures. Amid shouts and frantic armwaving in a pit lined with stylish electronic equipment, James McManus of MKI Securities bought two June contracts in the New York Stock Exchange composite index from Bradley Jordan of Merrill Lynch at 68.00 apiece.

title: BOARD CURBS FACULTY UNIONS
description: College professors may not form unions if they play a role in the management of educational institutions, the National Labor Relations Board has ruled.

title: Brazilian Asks Navy Buildup
description: The Navy Minister, Adm. Maximiano da Fonseca, said Wednesday that the Falkland crisis had created a need for a Brazilian naval buildup. He called for spending $15 billion over the next 10 years on naval expansion.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 7, 1982
description: International Britain accused Argentina of ''intransigence'' in announcing that the effort by Peru and the United States to arrange a cease-fire in the Falklands dispute had collapsed. Meanwhile, London's Defense Ministry disclosed it had lost two more jets in the South Atlantic conflict, further reducing the British flotilla's meager air power. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina repeated its demand that it be granted sovereignty over the Falklands. Britain has repeatedly rejected the demand. (A14:1-2.)

title: The Police Blotter
description: A man suspected of shooting at a couple in Queens at 9 A.M. yesterday was chased into a Brooklyn candy store about noon by two officers. The suspect, 49-year-old John Doherty of 485 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, barricaded himself in the bathroom of the store, at 118 Kane Street, and fired a single shot.

title: YANKEES ARE UPSET BY COCAINE MENTION
description: Already fighting a myriad of problems, Yankee players were upset yesterday when they learned that some members of the team had been mentioned as cocaine users in a wiretapped conversation between two defendants in a narcotics case.

title: ASSAD SAYS HE WILL SEEK MORE ARMS IN SOVIET
description: President Hafez el-Assad of Syria says that, on his next visit to the Soviet Union, the source of Syria's arms, he will seek to achieve a strategic balance with Israel, according to a French Arabic-language magazine.

title: BRIEFING
description: Onions, Sweet Onions

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 19.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 15.20 15.74 18.41 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.34 12.58 16.49 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.37 12.68 15.52 7-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.62 13.87 14.45 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.10 13.33 13.71 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.57 15.74 15.36 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.21 13.38 11.62 6-MONTH SAVINGS 13,030 CERTIFICATES * Maximum rate.

title: DISPUTES CONTINUE ON NICARAGUA PROGRAM
description: William J. Bennett, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, today defended before a skeptical audience his criticism of a television documentary on Nicaragua, asserting that it had been a ''learning experience'' for him but declaring that it was not his intention to become a television critic for the press.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have never believed that the oft-quoted amendment was supposed to protect us from religion.

title: GENTEEL CANDOR
description: To the Editor:

title: 'LAME DUCK' CONGRESS MAY ACT ON TAX ISSUES
description: The Republican proposal to save the Social Security System $40 billion in three years leaves it up to Congress to decide, probably in a session held after the November elections, whether to raise the payroll tax, trim future benefits or harness new sources of revenue.

title: BUSING BILL BACKED BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration, breaking its long silence on Congressional efforts to limit the jurisdiction of the Federal courts, gave its blessing to an antibusing bill today. But it warned that a bill to remove the Supreme Court's jurisdiction over school prayer was probably unconstitutional and, in any event, unwise.

title: DAYS ON ANGUISH OVER DISTRICTING NEAR RESOLUTION
description: The 39 members of New York State's Congressional delegation are worried these days. For five months now, the Representatives have been waiting. As they see it, their jobs, their careers, their personal lives are at stake as decisions on reapportionment are haggled over behind closed doors and in secret meetings in Albany and New York City.

title: Owner of Cannon Mills Applies Personal Touch
description: David H. Murdock, the West Coast financier, has been in and out of a town called Kannapolis, N.C., these days. Kannapolis is a mill town supported by Cannon Mills, and Mr. Murdock is the new mill owner.

title: JAZZ: STRING FEVER PLAYS
description: WHEN String Fever, an almost all-string band, consisting of 13 strings and a drummer, gets on the bandstand at Mikell's, Columbus Avenue at 97th Street, where it plays every Sunday night, the first thing that catches one's attention is that all 14 members are women. But once they start playing, they take on a different distinction: This is a large string ensemble that really swings.

title: Buying Plans Reported Off
description: Consumer confidence in business conditions steadied in April, after two consecutive monthly dips, but buying plans declined sharply, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS NET OFF BY 8.1% IN QUARTER
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, one of the nation's largest defense contractors, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter, ended March 28, dropped 8.1 percent from the year before, while sales slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Laws for Sale
description: Abscam-style bribery that buys legislation outright may be the exception in Congress. But the evidence grows that perfectly legal campaign contributions are having the same effect. Special interests are buying laws they like. It's hard to find a clearer example than the present effort of professionals to gain exemption from scrutiny by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: 2d-Ranking Austrian Official Starts on Official Trip to U.S.
description: Vice Chancellor Fred Sinowatz of Austria left here today for an official visit to the United States during which he will meet Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., a spokesman at his office said today.

title: FERRY DAYS LIVE ON IN TOUR OF HOBOKEN TERMINAL
description: When Ted Scull stands at the Hudson River waterfront and talks of the old days, it is not hard to imagine the ferryboats docking, the steam-powered trains sounding their whistles and the freight yards busy with fresh produce from the Great Lakes region.

title: THRIFT UNITS GRANTED BROKERAGE ROLE
description: In an historic widening of the powers of savings and loan associations, the Government agency that regulates the units authorized them today to offer investment and brokerage services to their customers.

title: SOME U.S. COMPANIES PULL AIDES OUT OF ARGENTINA
description: Some major American companies -among them Eli Lilly, Firestone Tire, Eastman Kodak and Exxon - have advised their American employees in Argentina to leave that country, the companies said yesterday.

title: TV Weekend; ALBERT SPEER'S VIEW OF THIRD REICH
description: ONCE again, television is tackling the subject of Nazi Germany and, perhaps unavoidably, the treatment is likely to generate heated reactions. The vehicle this time is ''Inside the Third Reich,'' a five-hour production to be shown on ABC-TV Sunday at 8 P.M. and Monday at 9 P.M. It is based on the memoirs of Albert Speer, the confessed war criminal who spent 20 years in a German prison for his slave-labor program to manufacture munitions in World War II.

title: JERSEY SENATE AAPPROVES BILL TO REINSTATE DEATH PENALTY
description: The New Jersey Senate today approved a bill that would reinstate the death penalty for some types of murder. The measure now goes to the Assembly, where it is expected to receive quick approval. The Senate vote was 31 to 5.

title: Budget No. 2
description: At long last there is a second Reagan budget. It arrives three months after the first disastrous plan and barely in time to give hope that future deficits can be reduced enough to drive interest down. In rough outline at least, the new budget is a marked improvement.

title: ARGENTINA REPEATS DEMAND FOR SOVEREIGNTY OVER ISLANDS
description: Argentina repeated its demand today that Buenos Aires be granted sovereignty over the Falkland Islands in negotiations on ending the fighting in the South Atlantic.

title: A Golfer's Regrets
description: One day after the disclosure that Arnold Palmer had complained to Commissioner Deane Beman about ''abusive language and displays of temperament'' on the part of some touring pros, Curtis Strange, the ninth-leading money winner on the tour last year, said that he misbehaved at the Bay Hill Classic in Orlando two months ago. Strange, in an interview with The Washington Post, said that he lost his temper twice and now regretted being abusive to a photographer and a scorekeeper.

title: AUSTERE ARGENTINE ADMIRAL
description: The sinking of the British destroyer Sheffield by an Argentine Super Etendard fighter-bomber in the icy waters of the South Atlantic on Tuesday has all the earmarks of an operation ordered by the austere commander of the Argentine Navy, Adm. Jorge Isaac Anaya.

title: TEST LINK OF EXCHANGES IS AUTHORIZED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved an experimental computerized trading network that links leading brokerage houses with the nation's seven major stock exchanges.

title: Notes on People; Tough Talk About TV
description: The South Carolina Legislature held a special joint session on Tuesday to hear a well-known speaker blame television for the nation's reading problems.

title: Construction Women
description: A good, skilled woman is hard to find, according to the construction industry and the Department of Labor seems to agree. For the past several years, the department has required contractors on Federal projects to make a ''good faith effort'' to try to fill 6.9 percent of each job category with women.

title: MOTHERS AND DAUGHTERS: FACING UP TO FINANCES
description: Frances Pope keeps no secrets from her 13-year-old daughter, Adrienne Giacinto, about their financial situation. Last month they discussed the necessity for economy after paying taxes. Now they are talking about the decision to purchase a cooperative apartment and what sacrifices that might entail. They also discuss more mundane matters, how many summer clothes Adrienne ought to buy, for example.

title: Rijksmuseum Ship Prints at Museum
description: More than 90 prints from Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum, depicting Dutch sailing vessels from the mid-1500's to 1900, are on view through May 30 at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: Grolier Book Show
description: Books, manuscripts, prints and drawings from the Library Company of Philadelphia, the oldest library in the country, will be on view through June 17 at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street.

title: HIAS QUITS ISRAELI PLAN FOR SETTLING SOVIET JEWS
description: The American Jewish refugee organization Hias, after a three-month trial, has withdrawn from an Israeli plan to deter Soviet Jewish emigres from going to countries other than Israel.

title: ISSUE AT MEDGAR EVERS IS NO 'FAMILY AFFAIR'
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Is Treated for Cancer
description: Carl Albert, former Speaker of the House of Representatives, is undergoing radiation treatment this week for cancer, a former aide confirmed today. Charles Ward, now an aide to Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, said a malignancy was discovered when Mr. Albert underwent prostate gland surgery Feb. 5 at Oklahoma Memorial Hospital.

title: PUBLISHING: DOUBLEDAY GETS WALLACE
description: CATCHING the publishing industry by surprise, Doubleday has acquired the rights to Irving Wallace's new novel, ''The Almighty,'' which is scheduled for publication in the fall. ''The book was out to seven publishing houses on multiple submission, and Doubleday just reached out and grabbed it,'' said Ed Victor, Mr. Wallace's literary agent. ''Funny enough, Doubleday was the joker in the pack, since the rest of the competition consisted entirely of hard-back-paperback arrangements.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE week jumped. Irving Paul Lazar held a dinner at Mortimer's for 82 last night. Lee Thaw gave h er annual spring gala at Doubles for 250 ''friends from abroad.'' G aya Pallovicini gave a markedly smaller one for Christina Ford. And F ran,coise de la Renta had one of her private little dinners where M arie-Helene de Rothschild and Arianna Stassinopoulos wore the same d e la Renta dress and tried not to bat an eyelash.

title: ON SUNDAY AFTERNOONS, THE TREND IS ROCK AND JAZZ
description: FRIDAY and Saturday nights are no longer enough. New York's hyperactive rock, jazz and folk scene, which used to be confined to the after-dinner hours, has reached such a pitch on weekend nights that is has been steadily spilling over into Sunday afternoons.

title: DEERE SELLS STAKE IN MEXICAN UNIT
description: Deere & Company, the Illinois-based manufacturer of farm machinery and industrial equipment, said that it had agreed to divest itself of the majority interest in John Deere manufacturing operations in Mexico for $11.8 million.

title: REAGAN'S REMARKS ON PRAYER
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's remarks at a ceremony yesterday afternoon in support of a constitutional amendment that would permit voluntary prayer in public schools, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: A PREVIEW OF REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY DRIVE
description: While public attention has focused on the Falkland Islands crisis and the President's negotiations with Congress over the 1983 budget, the White House has been quietly preparing for the most concentrated and sustained foreign policy offensive of the Reagan Presidency.

title: ART: NAM JUNE PAIK HAS SHOW AT WHITNEY
description: to the hypnotic sound of waves - a soothing videotape collage on ceilingmounted monitors. Visit a ''TV Garden,'' where, partly concealed among lush shrubbery, some 20 monitor screens gabble and glow in an audio-visual jamboree.

title: Rockies' Owner Sees Jersey Move
description: Peter Gilbert, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, said last night that he expected to receive permission from the National Hockey League to move his club to Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., for next season.

title: Economic Scene; Military Costs Vs. Inflation
description: IS the military buildup planned by the Reagan Administration likely to rekindle inflation? Or, with so much slack in the economy, is there a ''window of opportunity'' for rapid military expansion?

title: MGM Stock Swap
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. said that approximately 9.6 million shares of its common stock had been tendered under an exchange offer that expired on Wednesday. Company officials said that 5 million shares of the total number tendered had been received from the company's largest shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian, through his wholly owned Tracinda Corporation. Under terms of the offer, one share of $20 redeemable preferred stock was exchanged for every common share.

title: Mego in Dispute On Debt Payment
description: Mego International Inc., the financially troubled worldwide toy manufacturer and distributor, said it believed that its lenders have violated a previously announced agreement to defer debt that is owed by Mego's Hong Kong manufacturing unit.

title: ARGENTINES IN ANTI-U.S. MOOD
description: Small signs of anti-American sentiment have cropped up here since the United States sided with Britain in the conflict over the Falkland Islands.

title: U.S. AND PERU FAIL TO GAIN CEASE FIRE IN FALKLAND CRISIS
description: Britain announced tonight that the effort by Peru and the United States to arrange a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands crisis had collapsed. The Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, blamed ''Argentine intransigence.''

title: At the Movies; How to get out of school by acting.
description: A CRITIC who disliked ''Soup for One'' called Marcia Strassman ''the only performer in the film with any class.'' As it happens, the kind of class he meant is the only kind of class you'll find Miss Strassman within a mile of. She became a performer to escape ''from school and from New Jersey.''

title: Military Analysis
description: The acute shortage of air cover for the fleet, which has been a calculated risk from the start of the British intervention in the Falkland Islands, may have drastically reduced the tactical options open to the task force.

title: COURT BARS RULE ON CONTRIBUTIONS TO COMMUNISTS
description: A Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that the Communist Party did not have to comply with an election law that requires disclosing the names of campaign contributors.

title: Armenian to Stand Trial In Consul's Slaying
description: An Armenian teen-ager who is a Lebanese national has been ordered to stand trial for the assassination of a Turkish diplomat who was shot to death while sitting in his car at a busy intersection.

title: Canucks Advance, 6-2; Finals Start Saturday
description: Stan Smyl scored two goals and Lars Lindgren had three assists tonight to lead the Vancouver Canucks to a 6-2 victory that eliminated the Chicago Black Hawks in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: THE SERIOUS GIANT WITH A LIGHT SIDE
description: Not all the stories they tell about Jim Trimble are true. And few of the stories Jim Trimble tells can be printed uncensored. He was not, for instance, in a South Pacific foxhole under heavy Japanese fire when he and his fellow Navy officer, Wellington Mara, made a bargain to take care of each other if they ever got out alive.

title: SENTENCING SCHEDULED FOR MONDAY
description: Defense motions for a mistrial were denied today in the racketeering and extortion convictions of State Senator William V. Musto and seven co-defendants.

title: Jury Starts Deliberating 2d Raiders-N.F.L. Case
description: A six-woman jury ended its first session of deliberations today in the retrial of a suit by the Oakland Raiders and Los Angeles Coliseum against the National Football League.

title: PERRY GAINS 300th VICTORY BY DOWNING YANKEES, 7-3
description: As 27,369 satisfied Mariner fans looked on at the Kingdome with certificates proclaiming that ''I was in attendance for Gaylord Perry's 300th career victory,'' baseball's oldest active player tonight guaranteed himself a place in the Hall of Fame with a 7-3 complete-game victory over the Yankees.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; SALUTE TO A JAPANESE ACTOR
description: Takashi Shimura, the Japanese actor, who died last February, played leading parts in films directed by Akira Kurosawa. He was the woodcutter in ''Rashomon,'' the samurai leader in ''Seven Samurai,'' and in ''Ikiru'' he was a bureaucrat dying of cancer who devotes himself to accomplishing a meaningful final task. As a tribute to Mr. Shimura, the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, will show two movies this weekend in which he was featured. Scheduled tonight at 7:30 is ''Stray Dog'' (1949), in which Mr. Shimura plays a police detective who helps a young colleague (Toshiro Mifune) through a difficult search for the younger man's stolen pistol. ''Ikiru'' (1953) will be shown tomorrow and Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets are $4 and go on sale at 5:30 tonight and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Information: 752-0824.

title: 'THE MEADOW,' FROM ITALY
description: ''THE MEADOW,'' by Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, who were introduced to American audiences in 1977 with their ''Padre Padrone,'' is a gravely romantic Italian film, a triangular love story about three contemporary young people who have been invested with a 19th-century sensibility toward matters of love, death and social reform.

title: 20 Are Put on Trial in Palermo Over Mafia Heroin Trafficking
description: Twenty people went on trial here today charged with involvement in the Mafia heroin traffic to the United States, a week after gunmen killed Sicily's Communist Party chief, Pio La Torre, who had campaigned against the trafficking.

title: Sports of The Times
description: IN baseball's computerized era, some players appear to have been imported from another planet. In order to fit into newspaper box scores, their names are deliberately garbled. Ystzmk is Carl Yastrzemski, Cncpcn is David Concepcion, KHrndz is Keith Hernandez, and ReJcksn is Reggie Jackson, alias MrOctbr.

title: House Votes to Reduce U.S. Irrigation Subsidy
description: The House voted overwhelmingly today to reduce an 80-year-old program of subsidies for water diverted from Federal projects to irrigate arid Western lands.

title: TEXAS DEMOCRATS AVOID A RUNOFF
description: Texas Democrats, working to recapture the governorship, were spared a divisive runoff election today when the candidate who finished second in Saturday's primary dropped out, conceding to Attorney General Mark White.

title: PRIVATE DONORS' SHORTFALL
description: The nearly $54 billion in private charitable contributions made last year - a record - lends substance to President Reagan's belief that the private sector can fill the gap created by reduced Government spending on social welfare.

title: Clemson Sets Inquiry
description: Bill Atchley, Clemson's president, told an assembly of 500 faculty members that he was appointing an internal committee to investigate charges that the university had violated football recruiting rules. Mr. Atchley noted that the National Collegiate Athletic Association had officially alerted the university that the N.C.A.A. had undertaken an inquiry into allegations ''of a number of rules violations,'' but he declined to say what specific areas the association had cited. It is known, however, that the N.C.A.A. inquiry began last year after two prospective recruits from Tennessee had charged in a letter to Commissioner Bob James of the Atlantic Coast Conference that a Clemson alumnus had offered them money to attend the university.

title: UNIFICATION CHURCH RULED ELIGIBLE FOR TAX EXEMPTION BARRED BY CITY
description: New York State's highest court ruled unanimously yesterday that religion was the ''primary purpose'' of the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and that the church was therefore eligible for tax-exempt status.

title: Ex-Rep. Herman Schneebeli; Served 16 Years in the House
description: Former Representative Herman T. Schneebeli, who served 16 years in Congress and was the ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee, collapsed and died today while his wife underwent eye surgery, officials said.

title: Uniformed Unions Begin Pact Talks
description: The Uniformed Coalition, representing 36,000 members in the police, fire and correction services, opened contract negotiations with the city yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; May 7, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BALLET: 'PILLAR OF FIRE' BACK
description: ''PILLAR OF FIRE,'' one of Antony Tudor's greatest works, was revived by the American Ballet Theater Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Created 40 years ago, this dance-drama to Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht'' remains a remarkable achievement.

title: THREE FALKLAND LESSONS
description: In invading the Falkland Islands, Argentina violated two crucial principles: the ban on the use of force for the settlement of political disputes, a principle without which there can be no order in international affairs, and the right of selfdetermination, which is the basis of modern international society.

title: Broadway; 'Von Richtofen' in park grounded for a 'Don Juan.'
description: A FOOLISH consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, and with consistency a great soul has simply nothing to do. Joseph Papp will not produce ''The Death of Baron von Richthofen as Witnessed From Earth'' in Central Park, as he announced only last week; he will produce it at the Public Theater, and put ''Don Juan'' in Central Park, instead. On the other hand, Mr. Papp did open David Rabe's ''Goose and Tomtom'' at the Public Theater last night, although Mr. Rabe, changing his mind about things, too, disavowed it. In a message to The New York Times, Mr. Rabe explained the disavowal this way:

title: TO CARE FOR A CHILD WITH DOWN'S SYNDROME
description: To the Editor:

title: NAGRIN ON HOW TO DANCE FOREVER
description: Daniel Nagrin has an unmistakable style. His dances are dramatic. His way of moving, with the intense, precise deliberation of an animal, can be stunning. Say that to Mr. Nagrin, however, and his reaction is likely to be equally stunning. ''It's got nothing to do with form or content,'' he says, straining up and away from his chair as he makes his point. ''It's got to do with giving a damn about other people.''

title: Indonesian Opposition Charges Election Fraud
description: Opposition political parties charged today that the military-backed Golkar organization received an overwhelming victory in national legislative elections because of fraud.

title: BUSH TO START TALKS WITH CHINESE LEADERS TODAY
description: Vice President Bush, who declared Thursday that agreement and cooperation between the United States and China ''far outweigh'' any differences, arrived here today for talks with Chinese leaders on the Taiwan issue.

title: REAGAN ENDORSES VOLUNTARY PRAYER
description: President Reagan, saying that he wanted to foster ''faith in a Creator who alone has the power to bless America,'' announced today that he would propose a constitutional amendment to allow ''voluntary prayer'' in public schools.

title: EASIER STATE RULES ON INSURERS URGED
description: A special panel appointed by Governor Carey to study the insurance industry today recommended a sweeping program of deregulation that would substantially ease restrictions on how insurance companies can invest their money.

title: MUSIC: SCHULLER CONDUCTS
description: GUNTHER SCHULLER conducted the world premiere of Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Three Movements for Orchestra and presided over the New York premieres of his own Concerto for Contrabassoon and Orchestra and George Perle's ''A Short Symphony'' at a concert of the American Composers Orchestra Wednesday in Alice Tully Hall.

title: NIGERIAN CAPITAL: A TORRID, IRASCIBLE, BOOMING CITY
description: There is a ritual in the wealthier parts of Lagos, the Nigerian capital, these days, and the program is always the same.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 7, 1982; Markets
description: Prices advanced and yields dropped on both short- and long-term Treasury securities. The trading was the most buoyant in weeks as investors, perceiving yields topping out, rushed to buy. At the close, three-month Treasury bills were quoted at yields of 12.32 percent, down 30 basis points on the day. (Page D1.)

title: Phillies 12, Padres 7
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - George Vukovich had four hits and drove in five runs, the best offensive production of his career, as Philadelphia beat San Diego. Vukovich led an offensive effort that produced 25 hits and 19 runs between the teams, coming against eight pitchers.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO PUSH CAMPAIGN FOR BUDGET PLAN
description: President Reagan today pledged to campaign for the new Republican budget alternative, hailing the proposal as ''an important step toward the balanced and fair compromise the American people want and our economy needs.''

title: Ecuadorean Costumes
description: Dance costumes worn by the Indians of Ecuador for the feast of Corpus Christi are on view through Sunday at the Queens Museum in the New York City Building in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: U.S. USING TOUGHER POLICY ON ASYLUM FOR AFGHANS
description: The Federal Government has taken a tougher stand to bar Afghan applicants for political asylum. It is charging some with attempting to ''circumvent our immigration law,'' even though they might face persecution at home.

title: BOOMING U.S. BANKING ZONES
description: The nation's international banking zones, created only five months ago, are booming. Already their assets have grown to more than $100 billion and the expansion is continuing at a rapid rate.

title: 'Golda' Helps Stations Get Lucrative Ad Rates
description: At WPIX-TV, Channel 11, and probably at 119 other TV stations around the country there is management elation over the success of the program ''A Woman Called Golda,'' a critical and commercial success.

title: CARIBBEAN AID EFFORT ENCOUNTERS PROTECTIONIST TROUBLE IN CONGRESS
description: President Reagan's plan to aid the nations of the Caribbean and Central America is in deep trouble in Congress after its first trial in the House Ways and Means subcommittee on trade.

title: Insurer to Broaden Role of President
description: The Continental Corporation, a large diversified insurance company, announced yesterday that its president, John P. Mascotte, would add the titles of chairman and chief executive later this year and take over direction of the company.

title: Advertising; Magazine Ad Survey Findings
description: IN the battle between broadcast and print advertising media, every weapon is important. That's why the movers and shakers in magazineland were upset. A $1 million piece of research by Alfred Politz shows magazines to have a number of special and very positive qualities as carriers of advertising that agencies have not been using in the media evaluation process - probably because the last Politz project was 16 years ago.

title: Pop Jazz; JIMMY LYON PLAYS PIANO IN 2 STYLES FOR 2 JOBS
description: JIMMY LYON is a pianist who leads a double life. Tonight and tomorrow, from 6 to 10 P.M., he will be in the Waldorf-Astoria's elegant Peacock Alley, playing on a fruitwood Louis XVI Steinway grand piano on which Cole Porter composed from 1939 until his death in 1964. From 10:30 P.M. until 2 A.M. tonight and tomorrow he will be behind a small studio upright piano that is backed into a corner of the bar in Broadway Joe's, the convivial hangout for theater people at 315 West 46th Street.

title: 3 MASTERS OF SWIZZLE AND FIZZ
description: Many of us tend to regard bartenders not only as keepers of the secrets of swizzle, flip, sling and fizz, but also as courts of last resort for such trivial wisdoms as pitchers' earned run averages and the uncollected aphorisms of Brendan Behan, or as psychologists behind varnished countertops, dispensing homilies along with their whiskies, trying to make it all better.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Two photographs in the Business People column in Business Day on Wednesday were transposed. The top photograph is that of Hobart C. Kreitler and the bottom of James R. Sullivan.

title: TORIES TAKE LEAD IN LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party made an extremely strong showing on Thursday in local government elections that were widely interpreted as a kind of referendum on her conduct of the confrontation over the Falkland Islands.

title: 12 Philippine Justices Resign in Scandal
description: Twelve of the Supreme Court's 14 justices submitted their resignations today after repeated allegations that the court fixed the bar-examination score of a member's son so that he would pass.

title: 40% FARE RISE POSSIBLE, M.T.A. CHAIRMAN SAYS
description: Fares on subways, buses and commuter lines could go up by as much as 40 percent this summer, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority warned yesterday.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air-play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 11Chariots of Fire* Vangelis 25Asia* Asia 32Beauty and the Beat Go-Go's 44Success Hasn't Spoiled Rick Springfield 53I Love Rock 'n' Roll Joan Jett & Blackhearts 66Freeze-Frame J. Geils Band 77Get Lucky Loverboy 89Escape Journey 914Always On My Mind* Willie Nelson 1011Aldo Nova* Aldo Nova Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 12Chariots of Fire* Vangelis 23Ebony & Ivory* McCartney & Wonder 31I Love Rock 'n'Roll Joan Jett & Blackhearts 45Don't Talk to Strangers* Rick Springfield 54Freeze-Frame J. Geils Band 68867-5309/Jenny* Tommy Tutone 76We Got the Beat Go-Go's 89'65 Love Affair Paul Davis 910I've Never Been to Me* Charlene 1011Did it in a Minute* Hall & Oates Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from Israel yesterday gave an incorrect figure for deaths in the occupied territories during the dis- turbances of the last six weeks. It should have been 15.

title: Gerulaitis Is Ousted By Purcell, 7-5, 6-2
description: Mel Purcell, the ambitious young Kentuckian, knocked Vitas Gerulaitis out of the Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills yesterday, 7-5, 6-2, and John McEnroe's mettle was tested by Shlomo Glickstein, a tenacious 23-year-old Israeli army veteran.

title: Notes on People; Recalling Hindenburg Fire, 45 Years Later
description: Herb Morrison remembers that 45 years ago yesterday he was wearing a blue serge suit and a topcoat. ''It was right after a thunderstorm,'' he recalled.

title: Antiwar Activist Out of Jail
description: Susan Saxe, an honors student who made the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most wanted fugitives after a 1970 bank holdup in which a guard was killed, was freed today from the state prison at Framingham after serving eight years. Miss Saxe, 33 years old, was an antiwar activist at Brandeis University before she was convicted of armed robbery and manslaughter in the holdup.

title: FOCUS ON EAST SIDE RESIDENTIAL DESIGN
description: Despite all the growth of luxury residential development in various parts of Manhattan in recent years, the East Side - especially from Sutton Place just above the United Nations to the mid-90's - still reigns as the neighborhood with the most appeal by such measures as income level, population density and cost of housing. Developers who study demographics continue to stake claims in this vicinity.

title: Teamster Locals Cool To United Parcel Pact
description: A tentative labor contract negotiated by union leaders with the United Parcel Service ran into opposition from local teamster officials, raising once more the specter of a strike.

title: OPEC OIL NEEDED, MOBIL OFFICER SAYS
description: Non-Communist nations will continue to be dependent on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for oil until the end of the century, the president of the Mobil Corporation, William P. Tavoulareas, told shareholders at the annual meeting here today.

title:
PATENTS;
Canister Stores Metal And Chemical Wastes
description: A canister for storing radioactive chemicals and metallic waste produced in reprocessing nuclear fuel was patented this week for the Energy Department.

title: A Salary Comparison
description: The Cleveland Brown rookie, Tom Cousineau, will earn more in his first National Football League season than the team's entire starting defensive unit did last season, according to a spokesman for the N.F.L. Players Association. Cousineau, an all-America linebacker for Ohio State in the 1970's, chose to play three seasons with the Montreal Alouettes rather than join the Buffalo Bills, who selected him No.1 in the 1978 draft. Buffalo last month traded the rights to Cousineau to the Browns, who then signed him to a five-year contract reported to be worth $500,000 annually, with a $1 million signing bonus. Mike Duberstein of the players association said the defensive starters for the Browns last season earned $1.02 million. ...

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: When the people who clean F.A.O. Schwarz are starting work, the center of Manhattan is still fresh, like an egg just cracked. The elegant little table lamps glimmer dimly inside I. Miller, and the mammoth metal doors shut over the entrance to Tiffany & Company shine in the thin sunlight. A sparrow even sits sometimes on the sign that says 57th Street and Fifth Avenue, and it can be heard, singing loudly, all around the intersection.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Belated Celebration at St. John the Divine
description: Last November, when Canon Edward Nason West of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine turned 72 years old, the mandatory retirement age in the Episcopal Church, there was no rush to mark his retirement,

title: BRIEFING
description: By Any Other Name ...

title: PEANUT FARMER'S BIGGEST HARVEST
description: ''It was like Christmas,'' Gaylord Perry, the 43-year-old North Carolina peanut farmer, said Thursday night after he defeated the Yankees, 7-3, and became the 15th pitcher to win 300 games, the first since Early Wynn in 1963.

title: G.M. Plant Delay
description: The completion date for the General Motors Corporation's new $500 million auto assembly plant has been delayed until 1985, G.M. officials reported today. The plant, under construction in Detroit and adjacent Hamtramck, was previously scheduled for completion in the spring of 1984. A company spokesman cited model review as the cause for delay in equipping the Hamtramck plant, where G.M. will build front-wheel-drive luxury cars.

title: WHEN FOOD AND EATING ARE A PART OF THE FICTION
description: If ever there were two literary characters in search of each other, they are John Updike's Harry Angstrom (''Rabbit Is Rich'') and Anne Tyler's Ezra Tull (''Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant''). Reading ''Rabbit'' after ''Dinner,'' I kept wishing those two characters could jump the pages and get together, not only because both hanker after women named Ruth but because what Harry Angstrom hungers for is precisely what Ezra Tull longs to serve.

title: No Headline
description: The night was filled with a festival of fans, a profusion of chachas and an abundance of Adolfos. The occasion was the Casita Maria Fiesta in the Plaza Hotel's Grand Ballroom, a black-tie fund-raising dinner-dance for the oldest Hispanic settlement house in New York City, and the guests of honor were Kathleen Donnelly de Romero, the wife of the Governor of Puerto Rico, and Adolfo, the designer.

title: Mitterrand to Visit Britain
description: President Francois Mitterrand will visit Britain May 17 for talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in preparation for the Versailles economic meeting of industrialized nations June 4-6, a French presidential spokesman said today.

title: F.B.I. JOINS POLICE IN SEEKING ROBBER OF HEIRESS AT LA GUARDIA
description: On the evening of March 15, Carolyn Skelly Burford, a 65-year-old oil heiress with residences in Manhattan, Southampton, L.I., and Newport, R.I., arrived at La Guardia Airport on a chartered flight and got into a waiting rented limousine. While the chauffeur put her luggage in the trunk of the late-model Cadillac, a well-dressed man brandishing a gun pushed in beside her. He ordered the chauffeur to get in and drive off.

title: Walter S. Baird Is Dead at 73; Headed Instrument Company
description: Walter S. Baird, founder of the Baird Corporation, a world leader in the development and manufacture of scientific instruments, died Tuesday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 73 years old.

title: Bridge: What Should Dummy Do?  Just Keep Quiet, Probably
description: Many players have quite the wrong idea about the appropriate behavior for dummy. One misconception, common in domestic games, is that dummy should scrutinize the play, waiting for partner to ruff something or to discard.

title: 2 CHEERS FOR FRENCH SOCIALISM
description: One year after Francois Mitterrand's election as the Fifth Republic's first Socialist President, his Government's domestic policy rates two cheers.

title: BUSINESS ECONOMISTS ARE PESSIMISTIC
description: The economists for the Business Council, a group made up of the chief executives of 200 of the nation's largest corporations, predicted today that the economy would recover in the second half of this year and show moderate growth next year.

title: William Gresser Dies; Lawyer and Musician
description: William Gresser, a corporation attorney, author and musicologist, died Thursday at his Manhattan home. He was 85 years old. Mr. Gresser had completed a manuscript entitled ''The 'Don Giovanni' of Mozart and DaPonte,'' which is awaiting publication.

title: TALK OF SOCIAL SECURITY CUTBACKS CAUSES ALARM IN RANKS OF G.O.P.
description: Republicans around the country fear that the Senate Budget Committee and President Reagan have handed the Democrats a devastating election weapon by proposing $40 billion in unspecified future savings in Social Security.

title: WARNING ABOUT HINCKLEY IS RECALLED
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s parents, acting on the advice of a psychiatrist, decided not to send him to a mental hospital and forced him out of their home to fend for himself in the months before he shot President Reagan and three other men, Mr. Hinckley's mother testified at her son's trial today.

title: DINING OUT IN A DECLINE, SOME RESTAURANTS FIND
description: New York City restaurants are beginning to feel the effect of the recession -some more than others. The restaurants, according to interviews with their owners, managers, suppliers and patrons, are following hotels and theaters, on which they depend to a certain extent, in experiencing a drop-off in trade.

title: BRIEFING
description: Of Sticks and Stones

title: TEXT OF THE BRITISH STATEMENT ON EXTENDING BLOCKADE AREA
description: Following is the text of a statement by the Ministry of Defense here today announcing the extension of an air and sea blockade to within 12 nautical miles of the Argentine coast:

title: Tribune Co. Net Off
description: The Tribune Company, publisher of The Daily News in New York, said today that its first-quarter profit plunged to $468,000 from $14.6 million a year earlier. Revenues edged up 2 percent, to $332 million. The privately owned company also publishes The Chicago Tribune and has interests in radio and television and newsprint.

title: Europe Defends Right To Use Trade Sanctions
description: The European Common Market today defended its right to impose trade sanctions against Argentina in support of Britain in the Falkland Islands dispute.

title: TESORO IS OBJECT OF DECISION
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation was the mystery defendant in a Federal appeals court decision requiring it to turn over internal documents to a grand jury investigating questionable overseas payments.

title: MINERS THREATENING WALKOUT OVERSAFETY CHANGES
description: The United Mine Workers, who previously won concessions from the Reagan Administration by threatening to stage walkouts, raised the threat again today in a dispute over proposals to streamline the enforcement of Federal mine safety rules.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $4.9 BILLION
description: The nation's money supply plunged by $4.9 billion in the financial week that ended April 28, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday, but many money-market participants were disappointed that the decline was not bigger. As a result, interest rates rose slightly following the late-afternoon announcement.

title: BUENOS AIRES ASSAILS BRITAIN FOR EXPANSION OF WAR ZONE
description: Argentina tonight denounced Britain's coastal blockade as an escalation of hostilities and as evidence of a ''lack of good faith'' in negotiations. It said the latest move virtually expands the war zone to all the South Atlantic.

title: SIT-IN PERMITTED
description: A judge yesterday granted a preliminary injunction against students occupying the office of the president at Medgar Evers College. But he stipulated that four of the students could continue their sit-in at the office during the school's regular business hours.

title:
Patents;
Aid for an Oil Substitute
description: WASHINGTON TWO business executives were granted a patent this week on a system to improve the yield of a process that has been likened to growing oil on trees. In more formal terms, it is a system for increasing the growth potential of plants arranged in rows under beneficial sunlight and wind conditions.

title: JOBLESS RATE RISES TO 9.4%, A RECORD IN POSTWAR YEARS
description: Unemployment in April rose to 9.4 percent of the labor force, the highest level in 40 years, largely because of layoffs in manufacturing industries and a decline in retail jobs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Because of the proximity of Argentine bases and the distances that hostile forces can cover undetected, particularly at night and in bad weather, the Government warns that any Argentine warship or military aircraft which is found more than 12 nautical miles from the Argentine coast will be regarded as hostile and are liable to be dealt with accordingly.'' - The British Ministry of Defense. (4:6.)

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: INSIDERS ON JOURNALISM
description: In his swan song as the outgoing president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, Michael J. O'Neill of The Daily News in New York offered a surprisingly sharp criticism of the way journalism is practiced by his own paper and other news organizations.

title: Arrows Beat Blast, 6-5,
description: A goal by Paul Kitson in overtime gave the New York Arrows, defending champions of the Major Indoor Soccer League, a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Blast tonight in the opening game of their two-of-three semifinal series. The Arrows tied the game at Nassau Coliseum on a goal by Omar Gomez with 7:19 left in regulation.

title: REGAN SEES TRADE GAIN FROM DECLINE IN DOLLAR
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he was ''pleased'' at the sharp decline of the dollar this week on foreign exchange markets and that he expected the drop to improve America's trade position.

title: Your Money; Replacement Cost Insurance
description: IF you suffer a loss of some or all of the contents of your home because of a fire or theft, will your homeowner's insurance cover the replacement cost?

title: News Analysis
description: For viewers who care about quality and originality, the fall primetime schedules announced this week by the three networks carried bittersweet tidings.

title: INTEREST RATE HOPES SEND STOCKS HIGHER
description: The stock market, buoyed by expectations that interest rates will soon decline, rose moderately yesterday in active trading, with the energy-related issues leading the advance.

title: Point-Shaving Figure Is Seeking a New Trial
description: James Burke, one of five men convicted last fall of conspiring to shave points in Boston College basketball games, is seeking a new trial on the ground of ''newly discovered evidence.''

title: Difficult Choice in Newark
description: Tuesday's nonpartisan mayoral election in Newark is not an inspiring contest.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BancOhio Corp. said it had agreed to acquire the mortgage banking divisions of W. Lyman Case & Co. for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Merger Approved For Sun Banks
description: Sun Banks of Florida Inc. said yesterday that it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board for its merger with Century Banks Inc. The combined company will have assets of more than $4.5 billion.

title: IRAN REPORTS CAPTURE OF BORDER STRIP
description: Iran said today that its troops had breached Iraqi lines and taken a 22-mile stretch of the southern Iran-Iraq border that the invaders had occupied since the first weeks of the war, which began in September 1980.

title: Canucks: A Puzzling Success
description: Hockey fans may have snickered when the Vancouver Canucks made the playoffs this year. They had never won a series in the 11-year history of their franchise.

title: News Analysis
description: The news of the jump in the unemployment rate comes at a time when the Reagan Administration, the financial markets and a large majority of economists have begun to forecast an upturn in the business cycle. They say the upturn should come either in the current April-June quarter or, at the latest, in the next quarter, following the scheduled 10 percent cut in personal income taxes next July 1.

title: Moreland Drives In 7 As Cubs Rout Astros
description: Keith Moreland drove in seven runs, six with two three-run homers, as the Chicago Cubs beat the Houston Astros, 12-6, today.

title: Mendelssohn 'Te Deum' Will Get U.S. Premiere
description: The American premiere of Felix Mendelssohn's ''Te Deum,'' written in 1826 when the composer was 17 years old, will be presented June 2 at 8 P.M. by the Pro Arte Chorale at the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House.

title: 3-HOUR BUS STOP DROPS A CURTAIN ON BROADWAY
description: To some New York City officials, it has become known simply as Matinee Day. They mean a recent Wednesday afternoon when a chartered bus broke down in Manhattan's theater district, backing up traffic on Broadway for blocks and making a stretch of West 45th Street impassable.

title: The Economy
description: Unemployment in April rose to 9.4 percent, the highest level in 40 years, the Labor Department reported. It said the rise of 0.4 of a percentage point was largely the result of layoffs in manufacturing industries and a decline in retail jobs. Since the recession began last July, unemployment has risen more than two points. (Page 1.) New York State's jobless rate fell 0.1 point in April, to 8.1 percent. (9.) The nationwide increase in unemployment doesn't necessarily run counter to widespread predictions of an upturn in the economy, but it does raise concerns that the recession will continue. (1.)

title: POLICE IN NEWBURGH SEIZE MAN ON CHARGE OF ACTING AS DOCTOR
description: A 36-year-old man who the police say was living in an motel near here in Orange County has been charged with practicing medicine without a license.

title:
PATENTS;
Computer Improvement Corrects Spelling
description: A computer improvement patented this week for the International Business Machines Corporation provides automatic spelling corrections. Patent 4,328,561 was obtained by Danny B. Convis and two associates on the I.B.M. staff in Gaithersburg, Md.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 8, 1982
description: International Britain extended its blockade zone in the Falkland crisis to 12 miles from Argentina's coast. Implicit in the enlargement of the 200-mile blockade imposed by Britain around the islands April 30 was a warning to Argentina to keep its planes and ships at their home bases. The move, British politicians believe, sharply increases the prospects of renewed military action. (Page 1, Column 6.) The British fleet lacks the power to enforce the new zone, Argentine naval officers said. They said the British did not have enough fighter planes and that their nuclear-powered submarines were inffective in Argentina's the shallow coastal waters. (4:1-2.)

title: SOCIAL SECURITY ISSUE CAUSING PROBLEMS FOR NEW BUDGET
description: The budget plan worked out earlier this week between President Reagan and Senate Republican leaders appeared today to be headed for a difficult struggle on the Senate floor, with the Republicans divided and the opposition Democrats unusually united. Most of the opposition was rooted in reluctance to accept cuts in the Social Security program.

title: RECYCLERS OF WISDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAFFIC AGENT SEIZED
description: A 63-year-old rabbi was killed in Queens yesterday when the car he was driving was struck by an automobile driven by a city traffic enforcement agent, the authorities said.

title: Syzmanski Quits Colts
description: The Baltimore Colts announced last night that Dick Szymanski had resigned as general manager of the team, a post he held for five years. No successor was named.

title: N.H.L. Meeting Put Off
description: The National Hockey League yesterday postponed for a week the board of governors meeting that is to take up the issue of whether the financially troubled Colorado Rockies should be permitted to move to Byrne Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey. The governors, who were to have met Monday in Chicago, will instead convene May 18 in New York, the league said.

title: By Nicholas Wade; The Editorial Notebook; The Strange Wasteland at Kyshtym
description: Some 60 miles south of Sverdlovsk in the Soviet Union, in a terrain of hills, lakes and deer forests, lies a radioactive wasteland of perhaps 400 square miles. It is the site of the worst disaster of the nuclear age. For 20 years Soviet censorship hid all news of the catastrophe. That its details have been brought to light at all, most recently in a report from Los Alamos National Laboratory, is a small masterpiece of intelligence work.

title: Around the Nation; N. Dakota Water Project Cleared by U.S. Court
description: A Federal appeals court today ruled invalid restrictions that had halted work on a 250,000-acre Federal water project in North Dakota.

title: CLERC, LENDL, DIBBS AND McENROE GAIN
description: Jose-Luis Clerc yesterday said that he was not intimidated by Ivan Lendl. ''I'm only intimidated by the girls, not him,'' Clerc quipped, in anticipation of his match today at 12:30 P.M. against the hottest player on the men's tour in the semifinals of the Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills.

title: BRIEFING
description: Alien Roundup: A Backfire

title: HIGH COST OF LEATHER KEEPS REPAIRERS BUSY
description: A decade or so ago, when a handbag or a wallet showed signs of wear or looked dated, one simply threw it away or gave it to a thrift shop. But then one could buy a Gucci wallet for $25 or an Hermes handbag for $200. Now a leather Gucci wallet is $90 and the famous Grace Kelly bag is $1,450 at Hermes. With the prices of leather goods gone through the roof, one thinks twice about discarding what was originally a good handbag.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times; Poems of Our Climate POETS IN THEIR YOUTH: A MEMOIR. By Eileen Simpson. 272 pages. Random House. $15.50.

title: NINE GUITARS: SYMPHONY BY GLENN BRANCA
description: There has always been a transcendentalist strain in Glenn Branca's music for massed electric guitars. One could probably trace it back through La Monte Young to Ives, Ruggles and other American tinkerers whose method of courting the ineffable was essentially do-it-yourself pragmatism.

title: NEWS FROM FLOTILLA SLOW TO REACH LONDON
description: British newspapers have been experiencing considerable delays in the arrival of dispatches from their correspondents on board ships of the Falkland task force.

title: HIGHEST RATE IN 40 YEARS
description: The Canadian Government announced today that unemployment in April had reached 9.6 percent, the highest rate in more than 40 years.

title: TULIPS' GLOW WARMS FEELINGS ON PARK AVE.
description: There are 82,000 brilliant yellow tulips on the Park Avenue malls these days, shimmering in the sun and causing an odd feeling along the stately avenue. It could almost be called neighborliness.

title: And Now the Bad News
description: No wonder President Reagan struck a deal with rebellious Senate Republicans this week to produce his second budget of the year. The President needs every good headline he can get to offset the dismal news about unemployment.

title: BRITAIN EXTENDS BLOCKADE, TELLING ARGENTINES TO STAY WITHIN 12 MILES OF MAINLAND
description: In an effort to protect its task force in the South Atlantic and to increase military pressure on Argentina, Britain announced tonight that it would treat as hostile any Argentine warship or plane found more than 12 miles from the mainland coast.

title: STATE SANCTIONS BUS ALTERNATIVE FOR WESTCHESTER
description: Despite objections by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, state officials today granted permission to two bus lines to run express services between Westchester County and Manhattan as an alternative to Conrail's commuter lines.

title: A BOMB EXPLODES AT JERSEY COLLEGE
description: A bomb apparently fashioned from a candle and a quarter-stick of dynamite exploded in a locker at Bergen Community College here today, the last day of the spring term. There were no injuries.

title: THE CRUISE MISSILES DEPLOYED BY RUSSIA
description: To the Editor:

title: LOA ANGELES POLICE END USE OF CHOKE HOLD THAT STOPS AIR
description: The Los Angeles police will no longer use a choke hold that cuts off the air supply, Chief Daryl Gates said Thursday.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Dutch Heritage
description: Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands plans to visit Albany next month, and that should have real estate developers rubbing their hands in anticipation.

title: DIPLOMAT WANTS DIPLOMATS ABROAD
description: When Malcolm Toon left his post as United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union and retired from the Foreign Service in 1979, he came home disappointed and angry that his replacement would be a businessman, not a Foreign Service officer.

title: Elan Magazine Halted
description: Publication of Elan, a national magazine for black women, was suspended Tuesday after three issues, and most of the staff was dismissed. Cecile D. Barker, founder and chief executive officer, said the bimonthly would be restructured and would resume publication within 30 days.

title: MUSICAL: 'IS THER LIFE AFTER HIGH SCHOOL?'
description: ''Is There Life After High School?'' wants to bring back its audience's teen-age salad days, and in at least one way it succeeds. This musical, which had its much-delayed opening at the Barrymore last night, is an almost perfect simulation of high-school detention hall.

title: ISSUE AND DEBATE
description: The airline industry's huge financial losses have raised the question whether the deregulation of air fares has gone too far, indeed whether it may be the cause of many of the industry's troubles.

title: Continental Air Has Loss
description: Continental Air Lines reported a first-quarter loss of $23.1 million yesterday, slightly narrower than its loss a year earlier of $25.8 million.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S PARTY BOUYED BY ELECTION GAINS
description: Conservative leaders said today that their party's very strong showing in the local elections around Britain on Thursday was more than just a solidarity vote growing out of the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: A CHURCH'S POSITION ON A NUCLEAR ARMS FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME INC. TO CANCEL BOOK LINE
description: Time-Life Books, the troubled Time Inc. unit that is one of the world's largest marketers of books by mail, said yesterday that it would cancel its Library of Health, a major book series, because of disappointing sales resulting from the recession and lack of reader interest.

title: Around the World; Reagan-Brezhnev Talks Termed 'Highly Possible'
description: A meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev is ''highly possible, even probable'' in 1982, though no arrangements have been made, Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, said today.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: POP: BETTY GARRETT'S SHOW
description: Betty Garrett has been doing a one-woman show, ''Betty Garrett and Other Songs,'' since 1974, mostly on the West Coast. She has also played a few Middle Western colleges and finally reached New York on Monday evening at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Thursday on the ap- pointment of a deputy chairman for the National Endowment for the Arts, a quotation incorrectly described the citizenship of the poet W.H. Auden. He became an American citizen in 1946 and did not retain his British citi- zenship.

title: U.S. EXPECTS INVASION OF FALKLANDS BY BRITISH UNLESS AGRENTINA YIELDS
description: A senior State Department official said today that the United States felt that unless Argentina agreed soon to withdraw its forces from the Falkland Islands, Britain would invade the islands ''and prevail in the end.''

title: BELGRANO'S CAPTAIN RECOUNTS SINKING
description: The captain of the General Belgrano, the Argentine cruiser sunk by a British submarine Sunday, said today that the British submarine that torpedoed his ship intended to sink it rather than disable it.

title: Mets Players Mentioned In Drug Case Testimony
description: A Stamford man who is charged with conspiring to buy heroin from Federal undercover agents once bragged that he had supplied cocaine to several Met baseball players, two undercover agents testified today in United States District Court here.

title: STATE-INFLICTED DEATH AT $1 MILLION A PERSON
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSIT IMPROVEMENT RULING STIRRING HOPE IN LOS ANGELES
