description: A construction surge under way in downtown Los Angeles is raising not only the central skyline but also a concern in government and business quarters that the center will strangle itself in the resulting freeway tie-up.

title: CHINESE TELL BUSH OF 'SERIOUS OBSTACLES'
description: Vice President Bush was welcomed by the Chinese leadership today and was immediately told that ''serious obstacles'' over Taiwan were obstructing the development of Chinese-American relations.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Federal National Mortgage Association plans to sell $2 billion of new debentures in two separate issues next Friday.

title: TRESPASSING ON HISTORY
description: It is early on a June morning in 1934. My father has taken me by trolley car and on foot to the shore of the Hudson River under the new George Washington Bridge. The great armada of the U.S. Navy - 80 warships strong -rides at anchor in mid-river after a month-long passage from the West Coast via the Panama Canal. I am interested only in the biplane I see perched on the foredeck of the battleship directly opposite us. My father explains that the plane is launched by catapult from the ship and it can return by landing on the water and being craned back up on board. I listen, then turn to watch a man farther down the strand who is repeatedly tossing a stick into the river for his German shepherd to retrieve. So much for my first memory of a historic event.

title: BILLY GRAHAM, DEFYING CRITICS, JOURNEYS TO SOVIET
description: Against the urgings of the Reagan Administration and in the face of strong opposition from some religious groups here, the Rev. Billy Graham arrived in the Soviet capital today to preach and to participate in a Kremlin-backed conference of religious leaders on nuclear arms control.

title: BROOKLYN WOMAN KILLED BY BOMB MAILED INSIDE HOLLOWED-OUT BOMB
description: A 54-year-old Board of Education supervisor was fatally wounded in her Brooklyn home yesterday afternoon when she opened a parcel containing an elaborate bomb inside a hollowed-out cookbook, the police reported.

title: VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTER
description: To the Editor:

title: MAJ. GEN. R.M. LITTLEJOHN DIES
description: Maj. Gen. Robert McGowan Littlejohn, retired, who served as General Dwight D. Eisenhower's chief quartermaster in preparing the 1944 invasion of France, died here Thursday of a heart attack. He was 91 years old.

title: 76ers BEAT BUCKS, WIN SERIES
description: Maurice Cheeks scored 26 points and directed a relentless fast break, leading Philadelphia to a 102-90 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight. The victory clinched the Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series for the 76ers, four games to two.

title: GIVING YOUR GEMS A BATH
description: IT'S a chore Lorelei Lee would no doubt have adored. The task is c leaning diamonds and other jewels and if nothing else it certainly s ounds more glamorous than cleaning closets, kitchens or carpets.

title: OBOE RECITAL: HEINZ HOLLIGER
description: One has come to expect certain things when Heinz Holliger plays the oboe: phenomenal control of embouchure and phrasing, brilliant fingerwork, and a lightness and purity of tone close to the French ideal. While these attributes are extraordinary in combination, and the despair of solo oboists worldwide, they are expected of Mr. Holliger, and were much in evidence on Thursday evening during his recital in the Metropolitan Museum.

title: STEH THOMAS PLANS A MOVE AND SHOCKS NAMESAKE
description: Walter Babey has worked at the Seth Thomas Clocks factory here for 43 years, and even during the brief interruption caused by World War II, he always felt proud of his association with the company and the town.

title: Around the Nation; Lawyer Gets Five Years For Soliciting Payoff
description: William A. Borders Jr., a prominent Washington lawyer, was sentenced today to four concurrent five-year prison terms for soliciting a payoff for a Federal judge and obstructing justice.

title: YANKS LOSE, 5-2, DROP INTO LAST
description: The Yankees ran their losing streak to four games tonight, dropping a 5-2 decision to the Seattle Mariners and falling into last place in the Eastern Division. The latest failure came on a night when one of New York's starting pitchers faltered, a second was confirmed lost for at least six weeks with a broken finger, and a third was called on to make the first relief appearance of his major league career.

title: COURT BARS RKO PLEA ON TV BAN
description: The Supreme Court today turned down, without comment, the appeal by RKO General Inc. of the Federal Communications Commission's decision to strip the company of its right to operate a highly profitable Boston television station.

title: Harvester Loses Bid to Dismiss Suit
description: The International Harvester Company, the troubled farm and construction equipment manufacturer, has been denied a motion in the Circuit Court of Rock Island County to dismiss a suit filed by four Harvester shareholders, company officals confirmed.

title: THEATER: 'GOOSE AND TOMTOM' OPENS
description: David Rabe has disavowed the production of his play, ''Goose and Tomtom,'' which opened Thursday night at the Public Theater. Perhaps it would have been more judicious of him to disclaim the play. It is difficult to believe that the author of the searing ''Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel'' and ''Streamers'' could have created such an impecunious caper comedy.

title: Steinberg Hints At Bid for Tiger
description: Saul Steinberg, chairman and president of Reliance Group Holdings, may seek control of Tiger International Inc., the air cargo concern, according to a filing by Reliance with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: VON BULOW GETS 30 YEARS IN MURDER ATTEMPTS
description: Claus von Bulow was sentenced to 30 years in prison today for twice trying to murder his wife. He left the courtroom under bail increased to $1 million from $500,000.

title: 2 South African Blacks Plead Not Guilty to Treason Charges
description: Two men charged with being members of the banned African National Congress pleaded not guilty today in a magistrate's court here to charges of treason in connection with attacks on police stations and a power plant.

title: YOUNG, BLACK AND OUT OF WORK IN OHIO
description: The first thing Derek Heflin learned last month when he was laid off from his job was how long the lines were wherever he looked for a new one.

title: 572 WEAPONS NATO WON'T NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: Maximum rate.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CO-OP CITY: LIFE BEGINS TO IMPROVE
description: Since it opened in 1968, Co-op City has been confronting a host of problems -financial insecurity, periodic breakdowns of heating and hot water systems, crumbling brickwork and conflict between the state and New York City over the complex's outstanding mortgage.

title: Hagler-Hearns in June
description: The Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Thomas Hearns middleweight title fight was rescheduled yesterday for either June 8, 9 or 10 and will now be televised live by Home Box Office. The fight was originally scheduled for May 24 in Windsor, Ontario, but Hearns, the challenger, injured a finger during training.

title: Eisenreich Treated
description: Jim Eisenreich, a 23-year-old rookie center fielder for the Minnesota Twins, pulled himself from the starting lineup in Milwaukee on Thursday night and then underwent tests at a local hospital, Mount Sinai Medical Center. Eisenreich, who suffers from a neurological disorder, received treatment and was then released.

title: STATE JOBLESS RATE DROPS TO 8.1%
description: New York State continued last month to be more resistant to recession unemployment than the nation as a whole, but New Jersey's jobless rate edged upward slightly, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday.

title: Arrow Electronics Loss
description: Citing weak semiconductor prices, Arrow Electronics Inc., distributor of electronic parts, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $1 million, contrasted with a year-earlier profit of $670,000, or 15 cents a share. Arrow also said that it had acquired two companies, Computrend Inc. and the Computer Products Supply Company; prices were not disclosed. Arrow said it would use the acquisitions to enter ''a prospectively major field for electronics distributors.''

title: U.S. CALLED READY TO PROPOSE LIMITS ON NUCLEAR WAR
description: President Reagan has decided to propose that the United States and the Soviet Union adopt a common ceiling of 850 intercontinental nuclear missiles with no more than 5,000 warheads on those missiles, according to Administration officials.

title: Gulf Skips Rent And Loses Well
description: Congress was told today that the Gulf Oil Corporation lost a $2.5 million oil well in New Mexico when a Gulf employee forgot to send in a $400 rent check.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE, YES
description: I have come out of my private closet to speak out for a nuclear freeze.

title: REVISED INDUSTRY STRATEGY TO KILL THE NEW YORK BOTTLE BILL
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Britons Say El Salvador Held Fair Elections
description: Britain's two official observers at the March 28 elections in El Salvador said today that the elections were fairly conducted.

title: GENTRIFIERS: THE GREED
description: You don't read about it much in the papers, but those special landlords dedicated to rapacity are still throwing poor and elderly and disoriented people out of buildings because of the enormous profits to be wrung out of converting the structures into co-ops and other luxury housing.

title: By United Press International; GEORGE HARRIS
description: George Harris, one of the first glitter rockers who most recently sang as Hibiscus of the rock group Hibiscus and the Screaming Violets, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital, relatives said. He was 32 years old..

title: SNEED HAS 70-134 AT HOUSTON
description: Ed Sneed, enjoying a comeback from a dismal 1981 season, stretched his lead today in the second round of the Houston Open to two strokes. Successfully coping with a brisk wind that swept over the Woodlands Country Club, Sneed added a one-under-par 70 to his opening-day 64.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON VIEW

title: A.& P.'s Loss Sharply Wider
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company said today that it posted a $72.9 million net loss in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Feb. 27, compared with a net loss of $4.2 million a year earlier.

title: U.N. CHIEF PRESSES BID FOR SOLUTION
description: Aware that time is working against him, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar intensified his efforts today to halt the conflict over the Falkland Islands.

title: Avalanche Victim Loses Toes
description: A woman who survived five days under an avalanche last month has lost two toes on her left foot and all five on her right because of frostbite. Anna Conrad's doctor, Roger Mason, said Thursday that the seven toes were amputated because they were gangrenous. Miss Conrad, 22 years old, was reported in stable condition at Tahoe Forest Hospital.

title: Charles Samuels, 79; Journalist, Biographer
description: Charles Samuels, the journalist and biographer of Clark Gable, Tex Rickard, Ethel Waters and other celebrities, died April 27 in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where he had lived in retirement for the last several years. He was 79 years old.

title: An Arms Race Worth Losing
description: At least when it comes to arms sales to less developed nations, the Reagan Administration seems delighted to credit the Soviet Union with having become No. 1. The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency says Moscow forged ahead in 1979 with transfers of $10.4 billion, compared with a mere $5.6 billion for the United States. Tass, in rare agreement with Western scholars, returns the honor to Washington; America alone, it says, has long accounted for more than half the world's arms sales.

title: The King of the Minors
description: STAN WASIAK remembers the morning clearly. It was in March 1950, at the spring training camp in Vero Beach, Fla., and he was beginning his seventh season as a second baseman in the high minors of the Brooklyn Dodger organization. He was 30 years old, and not advancing.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Sibling Rivalry
description: They are brother and sister - Jim Yardley and Donna Yardley Peterson - but they are far apart when it comes to politics. Mr. Yardley is a Republican and Mrs. Peterson a Democrat. Now they are both running for the same seat in the Utah House of Representatives from their hometown of Panguitch.

title: U.S. Steel Files Import Complaint
description: The United States Steel Corporation, as it had said it would, filed unfair trade petitions against South Korea, Italy, France, Brazil and West Germany, charging them with subsidizing steel sold in the United States.

title: METS TOP GIANTS BY 3-2
description: The Mets needed two double-play balls in the ninth inning last night, since the first one was misplayed. A double play became urgently necessary because three pitchers had walked the first three batters. And George Foster, their $10 million investment, inched his batting average up to .202.

title: INQUIRY IN NEVADA LOOKS AT OFFICIALS
description: A Federal undercover investigation into political corruption in Nevada has caused an uproar among public officials and has touched off criticism of the methods used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Around the Nation; Slain Turkish Envoy Memorialized in Boston
description: Memorial services were held today for Orhan Gunduz, the honorary Turkish diplomat assassinated on a suburban street Tuesday, apparently by a member of an Armenian terrorist group.

title: Equal Status for Wives Urged By South African Legal Panel
description: The South African Law Commission, a legal review panel, recommended to Parliament today that it pass legislation giving wives equal status with their husbands.

title: Around the World; 4 Polish Union Leaders Warn of Further Unrest
description: Four top underground Solidarity leaders warned today that an explosion of unrest could overwhelm the nation if mounting anger among workers is ignored by martial law authorities.

title: CHIEF DEFENSE COUNSEL FOR HINKLEY
description: The chief defense attorney for John W. Hinckley Jr. is a short, stocky man who has a reputation among lawyers as a legal mastiff who will not let go and who frequently works legal miracles.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
Full Disclosure
description: Full disclosure is one thing, but when the Governor of Indiana, Robert D. Orr, saw the form the United States Senate Commerce Committee wanted him to fill out before it voted on his nomination to Amtrak's board of directors, he decided enough was enough.

title: Around the World; Soldier Is Indicted In Jerusalem Shooting
description: An American-born Israeli Army conscript who was arrested after a shooting on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem last month was indicted today on one count of murder and five of attempted murder.

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
The Rigors of a Commuter on Broadway
description: Tomorrow was to be a special Mother's Day for Karen Akers: She is to make her Broadway debut in the musical ''Nine,'' and her two sons, Jeremy, 8, and Christopher, 6, were to be in the audience.

title: HOW LEBANON BANKS PROSPER
description: For Lebanon, it has been another normal year - Moslems battled with Christians in Beirut, Palestinians fought with Israelis in the south, no one paid their taxes and the country's banks did more business than ever before.

title: Yankees Reach Cable Accord
description: The Yankees yesterday concluded their prolonged negotiations for cable-television rights by reaching agreement with SportsChannel, according to a source with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: NO LONGER LOVELY, NOR DARK, NOR DEEP
description: I remember the day a few years ago when I found ominous orange flags running straight through the woods. I followed them, refusing to believe what I knew, up and down the ravines, until they quit at an abandoned field. I followed them back, soaking up that spring day, thinking all the while that these woods would never again exist for me in my life, or for anyone else except the landowners who bought the lots and the bloated houses - expensive, tattered patches of woodland where lawns do not grow because of the shade.

title: News Analysis
description: The inconclusive fighting off the Falkland Islands, which has revealed the qualitative inadequacy of some weapons systems and the shortage of others, is apparently forcing Britain to rethink its military planning for the rest of the century.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Muse Isn't News

title: News Analysis
description: One of the central premises of the strategy of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain in the South Atlantic conflict -that gradually increasing military pressure will generate concessions from the

title: RKO Agrees to Sell Boston TV Station
description: The New England Television Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire WNAC-TV, a Boston television station, from the RKO General Corporation for $22 million.

title:
PATENTS;
Dental Floss Dispenser In Form of Credit Card
description: A dental floss dispenser in credit card form has been invented for diners to use away from home.

title: QUEBEC TRIES TO OVERRIDE PART OF CONSTITUTION
description: Quebec, which has always proclaimed the right to be different, moved this week to prevent the application of large sections of Canada's new Constitution to the province.

title: TRANSCATIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Buffalo Coke Plant
description: Citing sharply lower steel demand, the National Steel Corporation said that the Bonner-Hanna coke plant at Buffalo would suspend its operations indefinitely, beginning Monday. The plant is jointly owned by National and the Republic Steel Corporation.

title: Dr. Eva S. Van Dow, 73, Dies; Ex-Director of Bronx Hospital
description: Dr. Eva S. Van Dow, a former administrator at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, died Wednesday at the Albert Einstein College Hospital in the Bronx. She was 73 years old and lived in Kent Cliffs, N.Y.

title: RABE DISAVOWS THE 'GOOSE' HE THOUGHT HE HAD CLOSED
description: David Rabe, whose ''Goose and Tomtom'' opened Thursday night at the Public Theater, said yesterday that he had thought the play was closing, at his own request, last weekend. ''If I hadn't looked at the newspaper,'' he said, ''I wouldn't have known that my own play was opening.''

title: HOSPITALS' DIVERSION OF EMERGENCY CASES IS ASSAILED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Koch warned the city's private hospitals yesterday that they were closing their emergency rooms to too many ambulances carrying heart attack victims and seriously injured persons. The practice, he said, threatens ''the city's entire emergency medical system.''

title: PATENTS
description: A weather forecaster patented this week by a Japanese inventor bases its predictions on changes in atmospheric pressure.

title: FOR NEW BUSINESS DURING RECESSION, START MUST BE LEAN
description: A year ago, James C. Pearson had a retail furniture business with an extensive inventory. As interest rates rose, however, his profit margin fell. Last summer, amid an expanding recession, he cleaned house and started a new business, Susan James Associates.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's announcement Thursday that he plans to introduce a constitutional amendment to allow organized voluntary prayer in public schools is vigorously opposed by a wide variety of the nation's major religious groups.

title: CAN ART AND ARCHITECTURE COEXIST WITHOUT CONFLICT?
description: LOS ANGELES This is a tale of one city, but of two museums. One is a new institution, the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, and the other is one that has been around for some years, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. They are both poised to create major new buildings - and the altogether different ways in which the two institutions have gone about their business is a lesson worth watching for museums and all cultural institutions around the nation.

title: The Nation in Summary; Texas Primary Ends Peaceably
description: It was a sharp break with the Texas party's rowdy tradition, but Buddy Temple dropped out of the race for governor last week, giving the Democratic nomination to Attorney General Mark White.

title: OLD STRAINS, NEW BALANCES IN POST-SINAI ARAB WORLD
description: In its attraction for conflicting forces, the Middle East is a magnet. But the poles keep shifting. Israel's full withdrawal from Sinai in compliance with its first peace treaty came at a time of movement for the whole area. Alignments, allegiances and assumptions are coming unstuck, creating new risks and opportunities. In the Arab-Israeli conflict, attention has turned to the fate of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Menachem Begin last week reiterated Israel's claim to the occupied areas, where Jewish soldiers and settlers killed two more demonstrating Palestinian youths.

title: BREWERS 12, TWINS 1
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Gorman Thomas hit a three-run homer and a run-scoring single, and Mike Caldwell pitched a five-hitter for Milwaukee.

title: Leida Snow Plans Summer Nuptials
description: Leida Snow, theater critic for radio station WINS in New York, and Louis Sepersky, a freelance writer and photographer, plan to be married in the late summer.

title: A SWISS CONDUCTOR'S FRENCH TOUCH COMES TO CANADA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Glenn Plaskin is the author of a biography of Vladimir Horowitz to be published next January by William Morrow. By GLENN PLASKIN

title: BRINGING 'SOPHIE'S CHOICE' TO THE SCREEN
description: It isn't 1947 here, but it might as well be. Extras stroll through Rockaway's Playland in vintage summer clothes, the women wearing impeccable 40's makeup and hairdos. ''Hey, sailor, I got a dame for you,'' jokes one gray-haired extra to another, who's in uniform. Little girls in ringlets play catch for the camera, then slip anachronistically into down jackets between takes, since the morning is chilly. Children who seem to have stepped out of old photographs are coddled by moms in 1982 running clothes. They are gathered here for the filming of ''Sophie's Choice,'' the best-selling novel by William Styron that is now being adapted for the screen by Alan Pakula.

title: BY JOHN B. FORBES
description: ON Wednesday or Thursday the oceanographic research vessel Regina Maris, a 144-foot barkentine, will sail through New York Harbor and up the East River and enter Long Island Sound - the same passage that sailing ships made for more than three centuries, few of them lately.

title: FRESH AIR FUND CAMPS DRAW EAGER YOUNGSTERS
description: On a cool spring evening last week that belied the coming of hot summer nights in New York, children played basketball on the asphalt courts near the Brevoort Housing Project in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: PRAISE AND PROTEST AWAIT REAGAN'S VISIT TO COLLEGE
description: Taverns are forbidden in pristine little Eureka. Movies like ''Wilderness Family'' play at the downtown theater, and posters propped in shop windows around the square promote the upcoming visit of the Hoxie Brothers Circus. This is a conservative, family town.

title: THE ROOTS OF WESTERN DISUNITY
description: James O. Goldsborough, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, was a European correspondent for The International Herald Tribune and Newsweek from 1965 to 1979. By James O. Goldsborough It does not surprise many people that the United States and Western Europe have had differing views lately on everything from interest rates and Siberian gas pipelines to Poland and Central American revolutions. Over the last few years, trans-Atlantic differences on foreign policy have become so frequent that most of us regard them as the normal state of affairs. That is why the accord of December 1979 - to deploy new American missiles on European soil unless limits on European-based nuclear weapons can be negotiated with the Russians - sent such a thrill through Western chancelleries. Not that the agreement was perfect, but at least the alliance had demonstrated political cohesion on something.

title: Around the Nation; Citizens May Be Polled On Civil Defense Plans
description: Federal civil defense officials are planning to conduct a poll to assess public confidence in plans to evacuate cities in the event of a nuclear attack.

title: A Cherished Memory Of Merce Cunningham
description: The interesting article on Merce Cunningham, and especially his early history, prompts me to share this anecdote (''Merce Cunningham: The Maverick of Modern Dance,'' by Anna Kisselgoff, March 21).

title: ARTS AGENCY NAMES GNAM
description: Adrian Gnam, an oboist and conductor, has been named director of the music program of the National Endowment for the Arts, succeding Ezra Laderman, who resigned to resume his composing career.

title: ELLY AMELING TOURS THE WORLD OF LIEDER
description: Elly Ameling has attained a position as one of our most valuable lieder singers, and her recent releases, on three different labels with three different pianists, of German-language songs provide an overview - if hardly a comprehensive survey -of the form's evolution from the late 18th century to the late 19th century. The releases range from the ''complete original solo songs with keyboard'' of Haydn (Philips 6769 064, three disks) to a collection of Mendelssohn songs (CBS 36678) to a fine new recording of Wolf's ''Italienisches Liederbuch'' with the baritone Tom Krause (Nonesuch NB-78014, two disks).

title: David Melrose to Wed Patricia J. Fitzgerald
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donal F. Fitzgerald of Winsted, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Jean Fitzgerald, to David William Melrose, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Melrose of Leatherhead, England.

title: TRICKLE DOWN? NOT IN THIS NECK OF THE WOODS
description: WHEN the headline caught my eye, I was taken aback. Perhaps I had read it wrong. I looked again. No, I had read it correctly. There it was, in big black letters:

title: Misdirected Criticism Of Public Education
description: Schools don't teach because most public school educators are not interested in scholarship and because John Dewey exerted a negative influence on American educational thought and practice. So contended Paul Q. Beeching in the opinion article ''Our Schools: Why They Don't Teach'' (April 25).

title: APPEARANCES BY RIZZO KEEP PHILADELPHIANS ABUZZ
description: It should have been Representative Joseph F. Smith's night, and it was, for a while. The short, ruddy-faced Democratic candidate for re-election, the highest official on the scene, stood near his table and gripped outthrust hands of people wishing him well in his Congressional race.

title: SURVEY FINDS STUDENTS MORE WORRIED ON JOBS
description: High school students, apparently worried about the American economy, care most about preparing for jobs, according to a recent nationwide study of 6,000 students.

title: BOY,10, DREAMS VACATION
description: CARLOS PIZARRO heard a woman's voice telling him to wake up. ''I didn't know who she was,'' the 10-year-old said. ''I was in this big train. I was drinking a Coke. I fell asleep and when I woke up this lady told me I was in Connecticut.''

title: BY MICHAEL STRAUSS
description: VALHALLA WANTED: Seventy-seven lifeguards to work at seven public pools and beaches. Best qualified personnel desired, to be rewarded with the highest salary the county has ever paid lifeguards.

title: A DAY TO REFLECT ON THE TIES OF HOME
description: THE gentle ones ... where have they all gone? I just looked around, and I cannot find any of them left. Perhaps I forgot to look for too long, and only remembered too late. Have they become extinct?

title: Hisle Is Disabled
description: When Larry Hisle signed a six-year contract as a free agent for more than $3 million with the Milwaukee Brewers after the 1977 season, his career was blossoming. But he suffered a rotator cuff injury to his right shoulder early in 1979 and has been troubled by it ever since.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $98,000 6 Clover Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old bi-level; *2*fenced yard, central vacuum system; taxes $2,418. Edison $84,000 29 Roxy Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-oldCape Cod; *2*carpeting, two-car attached garage; taxes $1,600. Metuchen $80,000 77 Carson Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old all-brick split level; *2*fireplace in living room; taxes $1,986. North Brunswick $111,000 333 Independence Boulevard *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; fireplace *2*in living room, full basement; taxes $2,013. South Brunswick $85,000 52 Chipper Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old bi-level; *2*central air-conditioning, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $1,817. Woodbridge Township $77,000 540 Butler Street *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old 2-story; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, full basement; taxes $1,529. OTHER SALES Greenwich, Conn. $300,000 26 Shady Lane *2*9-bedroom, 5-bath, 80-year-old Georgian-style house; *2*1 acre, 8 fireplaces, library, butler's pantry, *2*Long Island Sound views; taxes $2,813. Yonkers, N.Y. $88,200 240 Rumsey Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old frame ranch; 90-by-75- *2*foot lot, ground-floorwaiting and office; taxes $2,110. Mount Sinai, L.I. $69,900 40 Ross Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; *2*formal dining room, basement, in-ground pool; taxes $2,703.

title: A CORNER OF EUROPE IN INDIA
description: MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN is chief of the New Delhi bureau of The New York Times. By MICHAEL T.KAUFMAN

title: Elisabeth Long Is Wed To Arthur E. Olmstead
description: Elisabeth Walsh Long, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Long of Kings Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Arthur E. Olmstead, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Olmstead of Pulaski, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. T. Peter Ryan at the St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church in Northport, L.I.

title: HOW THE COMPUTER FAILS THE COURSE
description: SCHOOLCHILDREN are - in many ways - captives, lacking any substantial freedom of choice and almost defenseless against unwise indoctrination. Any major educational innovation is liable to affect a generation of students in profound ways. It is a sobering thought for educators, but one they too often forget.

title: FRESH AIR PROGRAM ALSO BENEFITS HOSTS
description: THE bunk beds will soon be set up in 6-year-old John Allison's room at his home in Greenburgh. His friend Vincent Pearson, also 6, is coming for a two-week visit.

title: Cairo Demands Death for 299 In Group Tied to Sadat Killing
description: The state prosecutor today demanded the death penalty for 299 leaders and activists of a Moslem extremist organization linked with the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: OMAN LEADER VISITS EGYPT FOR FIRST TIME SINCE TREATY SIGNING
description: President Hosni Mubarak welcomed Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman to Cairo today on the start of a four-day official visit, his first since the Camp David peace treaty was signed.

title: CORNELL HAS HOPES OF LACROSSE HONORS
description: This is the time of the year that Cornell makes plans to begin its second season in college lacrosse, awaiting a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament.

title: JURY RECEIVES LIBEL SUIT AGAINST TV NETWORK
description: An ABC News broadcast two years ago never said explicitly that Sandra Boddie was a prostitute, but if a Federal jury in Cleveland decides that the broadcast left that impression, the network could be forced to pay heavy damages in a libel suit filed by the Akron woman.

title: The Nation in Summary; MIxed Signals From Washington On Civil Rights
description: Despite steady progress in voting rights protection, supporters of a tougher Voting Rights Act say that, in many respects, it's the same old North and South. Even as the Senate moved closer to approving some sort of extension of the Voting Rights Act last week, the Justice Department moved under the law to block reapportionment plans for the Alabama Legislature.

title: Susan Brown Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Brown of Riverside, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Brown, to John H. Colehower, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Harris Colehower Jr. of Merion, Pa. The wedding will take place next month.

title: REHABILITATION LAGS IN THE BETTER AREAS
description: AGENERAL contractor named Thomas Delmazio has his office on the c orner of 71st Street and 20th Avenue in the Bensonhurst section of B rooklyn. He has done apartment-renovation work in northern Flatbush a nd Coney Island, but not in Bensonhurst.

title: Dr. A.A. Hannenberg Marries Dr. Williams
description: Dr. Carol Irene Williams, a surgeon in Boston, was married yesterday to Dr. Alexander Austin Hannenberg, resident in anesthesiology at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. Rabbi Samuel Umen of Manchester, N.H., and the Rev. Edwin A. Lane, a Unitarian Universalist minister of Cambridge, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church.

title: BUSH FAILS TO ASSUAGE PEKING ON TAIWAN
description: Vice President Bush asked today that China not let differences over Taiwan dominate its relationship with the United States.

title: NOTES: NEXT, A TEXACO 'PARSIFAL'?
description: What do du Maurier cigarettes, Amoco gasoline and Martini & Rossi spirits have in common? On the surface, not very much, but they are among a growing number of businesses that are underwriting classical recordings -especially in Britain. In some instances, they share the limelight with the record-label name, much as PBS and Mobil share the TV credits here for ''Masterpiece Theater.''

title: Around the World; Polish Primate Urges Youths to Avoid Clashes
description: The Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, urged Polish young people today to avoid further street clashes and said they risked manipulation by ''irresponsible people'' in the movement opposing martial law.

title: No Headline
description: Peter Steinhart's article depicts the coyote as almost a human creature. This is a somewhat foolish way to examine the animal.

title: Tricia Roth Becomes the Bride of Nicholas Tetrick
description: Patricia Suzanne Roth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Roth of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Tetrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril E. Tetrick of Kokomo, Ind. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert Rothman at the Hotel Pierre in New York.

title: Best Films on TV
description: Sherlock Holmes Here is real fun, scheduled for 11:45 P.M. on Saturday over ABC. Herbert Ross's puzzler, ''The Seven-Per-Cent Solution,'' is one of two brilliantly realized variations on Sherlock Holmes in recent years (the other is Billy Wilder's ''The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes'').

title: LEARNING POLITICS BY OSMOSIS
description: PRINCETON BARBARA BOGGS SIGMUND wears colors like hot pink and blueberry, and her slightly offbeat, cavernous house near the university campus here is done up to match.

title: Topics Piercing Secrets
description: Red Alert

title: THEATERS: 7 WINNERS BY YOUNG PLAYWRIGHTS
description: In collaboration with the Dramatists Guild Fund Inc., the Circle Repertory Company is presenting a Young Playwrights Festival. The admirable purpose, of course, is to encourage young people to write plays, but at least from this year's selections, chosen from 732 submissions, there would seem to be a shortage of quality work.

title: Around the World; South African Police Seize Reporters' Notes
description: The police confiscated reporters' notebooks and documents about the South African National Intelligence Service from three Johannesburg newspapers, The Rand Daily Mail, a major English-language newspaper, reported today.

title: NARCISSUS THE REVOLUTIONARY
description: MICHAEL BAKUNIN Roots of Apocalypse. By Arthur P. Mendel. 517 pp. New York: Praeger. $35.

title: ROLE OF MINORITIES ON CITY'S COUNCIL
description: Despite a likely increase in their numbers in New York's City Council next year, black and Hispanic members probably will not be able to increase significantly their influence over legislation, many Council leaders and members believe.

title: Dining Out; DELICIOUS TASTES OF SPAIN
description: THE latest tenant in the large A-frame building just east of the Village of Huntington, La Mansion de Goya, suits the surroundings. The white stucco interior with dark heavy beams, wrought iron light fixtures and comfortable red leather banquettes and chairs provides an appropriate setting for a Spanish restaurant.

title: Westchester Journal
description: STARTING tomorrow, No. 60 buses once again will rumble through their old neighborhood along Old Mamaroneck Road and Bryant Avenue in White Plains, thanks to some vocal elderly people and some attentive politicians.

title: WHY THE TV SEASON WENT WRONG
description: LOS ANGELES Last spring, Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment, was feeling desparate. It was nearly time to announce the network's prime-time schedule for the fall and the pieces just weren't falling into place. ''I was running around to Rock Hudson's house trying to persaude him to do a series,'' Mr. Tartikoff remembers, ''then to Gabe Kaplan's to get a script finished for his series, and then to James Garner's place to try to talk him into doing a new series based on his 'Maverick' character.''

title:
Dining Out;
CLASSIC TASTES IN HOUSE J.P. BUILT
description: WHO would not like to wander through the house that J. P. Morgan built in South Salem? Most guests would like to live there; at least many imagine how they would decorate it. The fantasy comes easily. Wood-paneled corridors and anterooms remain intact, as do huge fireplaces, leaded-glass doors and garden terraces that overlook miles of undulating, verdant acres. Joseph and Monique Jaffre, the present owners of Le Chateau, the restaurant that occupies this mansion, have enhanced it with careful renovation of the public rooms, with stunning flower displays in Chinese vases lavished everywhere and with a kitchen that prepares dishes largely in keeping with this elegance.

title: Headliners; New Editor at Le Monde
description: After two years of infighting the battle for Le Monde, France's most noteworthy newspaper, ended last week with the naming of Andre Laurens as the editor. Mr. Laurens, formerly deputy political editor, will succeed Jacques Fauvet. Mr. Laurens was elected by Le Monde's editorial staff, whose 40 percent share in the newspaper's management gives them effective power over the nomination. The staff previously had selected Claude Julien (in 1980), but canceled the appointment after a dispute over his plans to reorganize the newspaper.

title: NATIONAL GROUP FORMED TO HELP THE HOMELESS
description: A National Coalition for the Homeless has been formed in response to the growing number of individuals and families nationwide who, because of indigence, incompetence or crisis, have no resources for housing.

title: THE AGE OF MISSILES GIVES ANYONE A SHOT AT GOLIATH
description: The British destroyer Sheffield, once proudly known in the Royal Navy as ''the Shiny Sheff,'' lies gutted by fire in the South Atlantic. Her loss in the trial of strength between Britain and Argentina around the Falkland Islands emphasizes the brutal facts of modern war and mocks grandiose claims about the effectiveness of unassisted sea power in bringing unruly nations to heel.

title: DEVICE THAT KILLED BROOKLYN WOMAN HELD THREATS TO FAMILY
description: An incendiary device that exploded and killed a Brooklyn woman on Friday contained a note that made threats against other members of her family, the police said yesterday. They also said they had determined that the device, a hollowed-out cookbook, had been mailed from Staten Island.

title: LOTTERY WINNINGS PAVE ROAD TO BANKRUPTCY FOR COAST MAN
description: Ken Proxmire thought the $1 million he won in the Michigan State Lottery was the answer to his dreams, but instead it has led to bankruptcy.

title: WHEN MACHINES TALK, BUSINESS LISTENS
description: Machines are increasingly able to talk. From grocery cash registers to exit signs, American manufacturers are retrofitting products with speech synthesis technology featuring fingernail-size circuits, or microchips, that generate electronic voices.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices; JAZZ
description: Joe Williams's fame as a singer began when he joined Count Basie's Orchestra on Christmas Day, 1954. But he had spent a long time and been through a lot of bands getting here.

title: Sports of The Times; An Ex-Knick Still Winning
description: THE first time John Gianelli was a champion, he was just out of college and a little itchy about sitting on the bench. ''I didn't like it at first,'' he said by telephone from Milan, Italy, where he is a champion again. ''But then I realized I was playing behind Willis Reed and Jerry Lucas, and that wasn't so bad.

title: Teen Drinking Proposal Called but One Step
description: It was with considerable interest that I read State Senator C.Louis Bassano's article on April 18, entitled ''Of Adolescents and Alcohol.'' (Mr. Bassano is a Republican of Union.)

title: THE ARTFUL SPECTATOR: LOOKING ON IN REVERIE AS OTHERS PLAY
description: WHETHER you follow the Davis Cup, the Stanley Cup, or the America's Cup, you are among the millions of Americans who participate in the greatest sport of all - I call it ''spectating.'' We sit on wood bleachers, stand in cold and rain, drive all night to see our favorite teams and players hit and throw; in effect, we chase one another in circles. The athletes, too, subject themselves to such abuse. At least in professional sports, the reason why they do it is all too obvious. But more to the point: Why do we take such pleasure in being spectators?

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices; ART
description: We can do with some more good Old Master galleries in Manhattan. So it is good news that the Maurice Segoura Gallery at 58 East 79th Street has made a very promising start with an exhibition called "From Watteau to David: A Century of French Art."

title: Thank You, Mr. Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor: I am startled that so many Yankee fans have resorted to making Reggie Jackson our next American saint, and have relegated George Steinbrenner to the role of a Quasimodo!

title: ART CENTER IN STAMFORD IS UNCERTAIN
description: STAMFORD THE fate of a proposed Center for the Performing Arts in Stamford could be decided this week when the city's Board of Representatives votes on a $500,000 bonding proposal for the center. If the 40-member board rejects the bonding proposal, the state will withdraw its contribution to the $5 million center, putting its eventual construction in jeopardy.

title: DANCE: 1970'S 'STREAMS' REVIVED BY ALVIN AILEY
description: In the early 1970's Alvin Ailey's choreography became very watery -by choice, it should be added, for it was then that Mr. Ailey began creating dances with such titles as ''Streams,'' ''The River'' and ''Archipelago'' that equated the movement of water with the lifeforce itself.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Just a Beginning

title: The Nation in Summary; HInckley Defense Opens Its Case
description: Defense lawyers last week began painting a painfully detailed portrait of John W. Hinckley Jr. as a disturbed young man who had taken refuge in a fantasy world and thus was not responsible for his actions when he shot President Reagan and three other men last spring.

title: MORE NEW PRODUCTS FROM LAS VEGAS SHOW
description: Many new cameras and items of photographic equipment were introduced at this year's conventiona of the Photographic Manufacturers' Association in Las Vegas, some of which were described here last week. Here are some additional new products which were not included in last week's roundup:

title: Headliners; Play It Again, Ann
description: In time a columnist comes to realize that most new ideas are little more than old ones in a differnt guise.

title: A TIDE OF UNCERTAINTY ON FLOOD INSURANCE
description: TO the dismay of many owners of vacation houses in low-lying, f loodprone areas, the Reagan Administration is rewriting the rules onF ederal flood insurance to restrict the extent of coverage, raise thec ost of premiums and redefine the way damage is measured.

title: TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: NEIL BOGART, ENTERTAINMENT EXECUTIVE, DEAD AT 39
description: Neil Bogart, the entertainment executive whose discoveries ranged from Donna Summer, the disco singer, to Curtis Mayfield, the composer of ''Shaft,'' died of cancer today at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. He was 39 years old.

title: CITY PLANS SCREENING OF LANDFILL WORKERS FOR TOXIC CHEMICALS
description: A leading occupational health specialist has agreed to advise New York City's Sanitation Department on a possible medical screening program for sanitationmen working at landfills.

title: Berlin to Welcome Reagan
description: Mayor Richard von Weizsacker called on West Berliners on television on Friday to welcome President Reagan when he comes for a five-hour visit June 11 after addressing an Atlantic alliance conference in Bonn. ''The Berliners do no forget those friends who stand by them in difficult times,'' the Mayor said, recalling American assistance in the airlift of 1948-49, when the Soviet authorities closed off West Berlin from West Germany, and since 1961, when East Germany built the wall between West Berlin and East Berlin.

title: HOW 'SMASH PALACE' PLUMBS THE RUINS OF LOVE
description: Falling in love is as easy as getting married. You simply do it, without asking too many questions. However, falling out of love, in a way that doesn't wreck the lives of all concerned, is today more difficult than it ever was, certainly far more difficult than getting a divorce. If advertisements are to be believed, it's now possible to obtain a divorce for $99 in 30 days without even using lawyers.

title: A Portrait Of Levittown
description: If Florence Fabricant would take her nose out of the clouds, she might learn to appreciate more than the ''glorious North Shore.'' Her recent review of Divino (''A Menu Spiced With Specialties'') was offensive and arrogant, and the community of Levittown deserves an apology.

title: MIAMI TO OPEN RISKY FESTIVAL OF ARTS NEXT MONTH
description: In a month, one of the world's more ambitious, more expensive and surely one of the riskiest arts festivals of all time will open here.

title: Ernie Kovacs's Daughter Dies
description: Mia Susan Kovacs, 23 years old, the daughter of the late comedian Ernie Kovacs and the actress Edie Adams, was fatally injured early today after her car ran off the shoulder of a road and crashed.

title: FAMILY'S ODYSSEY ENDS IN REUNION
description: BRIDGEPORT ROCKING her granddaughter on her shoulder, Phoukhao Sylaphet yawns. It is 3 P.M. and the sun floods the room. But it is midnight to her body, which still abides by the time zone of a refugee camp in the Philippines. Two days earlier, Mrs. Sylaphet lived there.

title: REAGAN, IN RADIO TALK, URGES APPROVAL OF BUDGET
description: President Reagan today deplored last month's unemployment rate, the highest in 40 years, and urged Congress to ''get off the dime'' and pass the new Republican budget alternative that he endorsed Wednesday.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
HELLENIC FESTIVAL
description: Four days overflowing with Greek food and music, followed by a chance to win a trip to Greece for two. What is it? It's the eighth annual Hellenic Festival of St. Athanasios Greek Orthodox Church in Paramus, and it gets under way Thursday.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; The McDermott Sisters, Piano, Violin and Cello
description: Three young sisters studying at the Manhattan School of Music played at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon as the McDermott Trio.

title: Sports People; Bowler Is Banned
description: Marshall Holman, the fifth leading money-winner on the Professional Bowlers Association tour this year, has been banned from further participation until he attends a three-day school mandated by the P.B.A. executive committee. The 27-year-old Holman is a right-hander from Medford, Ore., with tour earnings of $47,633.

title: Robin Hall Plans June 26 Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Poole Hall of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Hayward Hall, to William Scott Conrad, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Conrad of Levittown, Pa.

title: IMAGES THAT RECALL THE POLISH PAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Margaret Croyden writes frequently about the arts, and is the author of ''Lunatics Lovers and Poets: The Contemporary Experimental Theater'' By MARGARET CROYDEN

title: Yogurt
description: To the Editor: As someone who has lived and worked as a journalist in Turkey for 13 years, I admire Marvine Howe's coverage there, including her article on ''Yogurt: Turkish Delight'' (Travel, April 18). owever, she apparently does not fully understand the essence of yogurt making. The milk is simmered gently, not boiled, for 15 to 20 minutes so as not to evaporate the water but to kill the bacteria in a sterilizing or pasturizing process.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Your editorial ''Shock Therapy for Argentina'' (May 1), endorsing U.S. support of the United Kingdom in the current conflict in the South Atlantic, raises some troublesome questions.

title: Cardinals 8, Braves 7
description: ST.LOUIS (AP) - Lonnie Smith walked to lead off the bottom of the ninth inning, stole his second base of the game and scored on a bunt single and error to give St. Louis the victory.

title: Follow-Up on the News; College Pricing
description: With college tuition climbing but student aid on a downward course, nearly three dozen seniors at South Commack High School on Long Island were reported unable to attend select colleges that had accepted them. The article last month cited as an example Beverly Ballaro, the school's salutatorian.

title: Pac-Man and Movie Plots
description: No Hollywood executive seems to realize that the industry's future lies in remedying its greatest weakness: movies frozen in single plots (''Hollywood's Video Gamble,'' by Aljean Harmetz, March 28). Steering Pac-Man around a child's maze will not satisfy us forever, but it has given us a taste for something new.

title: 3 MEN SHOT DEAD ON QUEENS STREET
description: Three Queens men were slain and a Long Island man was critically wounded early yesterday in a fusillade of shotgun blasts and pistol fire that erupted on a street near Kennedy International Airport in Queens, the police said.

title: Sharon Benziger Wed To Richard S. Taylor
description: Sharon Larmon Benziger and Richard Scott Taylor were married yesterday at the First Church, Methodist, in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Olafson performed the ceremony.

title: ON THE BLOCK
description: A New Jersey industrialist who died five years ago will bestow a sizable sum on the Borough of Mendham in southwestern Morris County on Saturday when Three Fields, his 49-acre estate, will be sold at public auction.

title: 3 CONGRESSMEN VOICE CONCERNS ON REDUCTIONS BY WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON FOREIGN crises, war over the Falkland Islands and riots in the West Bank in Israel have dominated the headlines of American newspapers in recent weeks. But it is domestic politics, specifically the proposed 1983 budget cuts in social programs, that has captured the attention of Westchester's Congressmen.

title: Sports People; Bergey Dons Hard Hat
description: After a 13-year career in the National Football League, Bill Bergey of the Philadelphia Eagles has donned a harder hat. The 37-year-old linebacker, who retired April 1 after failing to recover from knee surgery in 1979 and spending all of last season on the injured reserve list, has accepted a position as executive vice president of marketing for John J. Hennelly Inc., a masonry contractor.

title: STAGED READINGS
description: The first of five staged readings of new plays took place Friday in the Westport Town Hall. The ''works-in-progress'' series, dedicated to the theatrical agent Audrey Wood, offers an opportunity for the public to hear new plays in their formative stages read, directed and discussed by theatrical personalities who live in the area.

title: William Ervin to Wed Carron Meaney
description: Carron Meaney and William E. Ervin plan to be married in Boulder, Colo., June 19. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Meaney of Los Angeles, parents of the future bride.

title: Awaiting the I.R.S.  .
description: To the Business Editor: We, who originated the Shared Apreciation Mortgage concept through our affiliate, Advance Mortgage, read Deborah Rankin's fine article (April 18) with great interest.

title: Sports of The Times; N.F.L. Franchises Now Free Agents
description: ALL along Al Davis insisted that his Raiders were justified in deserting Oakland for Los Angeles because the franchise needed millions more if it were to compete with other National Football League clubs when ''some form of free agency'' eventually evolved. Al Davis was talking about free agency among players. But when a sixwoman jury in Federal District Court in Los Angeles agreed Friday with Al Davis's antitrust argument, the verdict virtually turned the N.F.L. franchises into free agents instead.

title: THE NEW ASIAN IMMIGRANTS
description: Robert Lindsey is chief of the The New York Times's Los Angeles bureau. By Robert Lindsey Walking along Broadway on Manhattan's Upper West Side, you glance over at the greengrocer's where you've shopped for years and discover a Korean behind the counter where an Italian used to stand.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: TWO hospitals in the Hartford area are about to spend $1.8 million on diagnostic equipment, and the Commission on Hospitals and Health Care, which is known for holding down health costs by blocking requests for new technology, is crowing about the purchases.

title: SOME INCUMBENTS MAY LOSE SEATS
description: After months of infighting, the Legislature's Democratic and Republican leaders said today that they had reached agreement on a reapportionment plan that will eliminate five Congressional seats and endanger some Democratic State Senators and Republican Assemblymen.

title: SAVING THE INTERSTATE HIGHWAYS
description: WASHINGTON DREW LEWIS is out to make another mark. By most accounts, the Transportation Secretary has already made the mark that history will remember him by, as the first cabinet secretary in more than half a century to shatter a labor union.

title: AMERICANS AND THE WHITE HOUSE
description: AMERICA IN SEARCH OF ITSELF The Making of the President, 1956-80. By Theodore H. White. 465 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Ariel Holdsworth Is Wed to Lawyer
description: Ariel Holdsworth and Thomas Franklyn Berner were married yesterday in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, the associate rector, and the Rev. Donald Cutler, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Severe Blow Seen In 'New Federalism'
description: The League of Women Voters is totally opposed to further budget cuts in human services and the Federal Administration's proposal for a ''New Federalism.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN MONTCLAIR
description: YOU might think a suburb that boasts of having about one mature s hade tree for every two residents and has within its six square m iles 14 parks and playgrounds brimming with swimming pools and s kating rinks, as well as a college with a stadium, a professional t heater troupe, three general hospitals, 42 churches and a Katharine G ibbs School would have enough with which to concern itself.

title: Television Week
description: A Preference for Fiction

title: STAN O'CONNELL BURKE
description: Stan O'Connell Burke, vice chairman of the board of trustees of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness.

title: COURT FIRM ON RETURN OF 2 D"URERS
description: An appeals court has upheld a decision made by a Federal judge last year that two portraits by Albrecht Durer stolen from a German castle during World War II must be returned to an East German museum by the New York lawyer who bought them in 1946 for $450.

title: IN A JAPAN LIKE LIMBO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Edith Milton has written a novel, ''Corridors,'' and short stories. LAST QUADRANT By Meira Chand. 194 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $10.95. A PALE VIEW OF HILLS By Kazuo Ishiguro. 183 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $11.95. By EDITH MILTON

title: About Westchester
description: SCARSDALE THEY were not at home, and for the time being at least, they seemed happy about it. Fifty-two women who work out of their houses were now gathered at the modern, ski-lodge-style Girl Scout meeting house on Wayside Lane here, leaving behind one of their primary modes of communication - the telephone - in favor of face-to-face contact. Chatting with each other, socializing and establishing business connections, they discussed the pros - independence, flexibility - and the cons - isolation, not being regarded seriously - of trying to make a living in the same space they live in.

title: THE MAKING OF A WRITER
description: OF the making of writers there is no end till The End unmakes them. Here's how Yours Truly tells his Once upon a time: Twins

title: James N. Benedict Weds Jeffy Fagal
description: Janet E. Fagal and James N. Benedict were married yesterday in the Congregatioinal First Church of Christ Center Church on the Green in New Haven. The Rev. Wayne Shuttee, a Unitarian minister performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Bruce Whittemore, a Congregational minister.

title: THE SINGULAR POWER OF A GIANT CALLED EXXON
description: MR. ROCKEFELLER was right. Although we pay homage to Jeffersonian democracy, Americans have built an economy that relies on goliaths to get the job done. And the biggest of all is Exxon, the most prominent descendant of the vast empire that John D. Rockefeller, who made no bones about the end of individualism, put together piece by piece.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE PRESS CORPS.
description: As a distanced if not detached observer, Jody Powell looks at the Reagan White House press office with a mixture of envy at the skillful way the Reagan people handled the news media during the first year of their Administration and of skepticism that they can continue to control how the President is portrayed to the American public. In a display of cynicism rare for him but not uncommon in others who have labored at the task, Jimmy Carter's press secretary notes that ''there is some tendency for the press, having just savaged the predecessor, to get some blood off their hands before they set out on the next one.'' As he watches David R. Gergen, President Reagan's communications director, speaking on national television of ''journalistic fantasy'' in the coverage of Mr. Reagan's bungled news conferences, Powell senses that both sides have finally squared off against each other in the time-honored fashion of press and Presidents.

title: COAST PANEL URGES REMOVAL OF JUDGE
description: A state committee that oversees the conduct of California judges has recommended the removal of a municipal judge in Los Angeles who was found to have engaged in sexual harassment, intimidation of jurors and racial and ethnic slurs.

title: Miners Lose Benefit Appeal
description: The West Virginia Employment Security Board has ruled that members of the United Mine Workers cannot receive jobless benefits for the 72 days of their walkout last year. The board's ruling affirms a decision in October by a three-judge administrative law panel.

title: SPANISH PAINTING AT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON WITH its cherry blossoms and its squirrels, which come in black as well as gray, Princeton is a nice place to be on a spring day. And if the relatively new building that houses the university's Art Museum does not measure up to the campus's older structures, its contents, which extend from pre-Columbian sculpture to Cezanne (and a stunning little Kensett sunset), make hours of rewarding perusal.

title: SENATE PRIMARY TAKES A NEW TURN
description: TRENTON ROBERT MORRIS of Mantoloking has ended his second campaign for the Republican nomination for United States Senator by withdrawing and leaving the field to the front-runners, Representative Millicent Fenwick of Bernardsville and Jeffrey Bell of Leonia.

title: PSYCHOLOGY: ON THE IMPORTANCE OF CREATIVE DISAGREEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; PIERCING SECRETS; Useful Tips
description: To the moviegoer, New York cab-drivers are incessant talkers, endlessly obliging, quintessentially witty and better at tracking than the best bloodhound.

title: PAST'S PRESENTS
description: National Historic Preservation Week begins today and 3,000 events are planned across the country to mark it. But in New York City, where preservation is a hotly debated topic, the celebration will be definitely low-key.

title: Agee's Cache
description: To the Business Editor: William Agee, chairman of the Bendix Corporation, has written a prescription for companies that are in the fortunate position of having excess cash - ''How Companies Should Use Their Cash'' (April 25).

title: Washington; BEYOND THE FALKLANDS
description: In recent days, the intelligence services of the United States Government have been watching, with the utmost care, the communications between the Soviet Union and Argentina.

title: FALKLANDS-AND THE FRAGILITY OF WORLD PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SURVEY LISTS THE LIKELY CAUSES OF INJURY
description: Dancing may be romantic, but it can also be dangerous. So, too, can cheerleading, owning an aquarium, walking up or down stairs and getting into and out of bed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Certainly we are moving. The negotiations are on the move. It is too early to predict what the results are going to be.''

title: WESTPORT AWAITS FACE-OFF
description: WESTPORT WHEN Arnold J. Kaye thinks he has been wronged, he said, ''I get vindictive.'' Mr. Kaye contends that he has been wronged by Westport officials and he is preparing, he said, his revenge.

title: MOTHER-NURTURERS: A PRIZE FOR SOCIETY
description: WITHIN America today, there is a subculture composed of angry, frustrated and humiliated individuals. They are neither rootless, idle nor impoverished. On the contrary, they are linked to our society in the most fundamental way of all: they are the nurturers of future Americans. They transmit values to the next generation.

title: A DAY TO REFLECT ON THE TIES OF HOME
description: IHAVE a confession to make. I still live at home with my parents. I am, in the words of a friend, a ''homing pigeon.'' Although my friend, an aspiring family psychologist, feels that this label is more appropriately attached to those young adults who come home to live after trying it on their own, I believe I could add greater dimension to her observations. You see, I never left in the first place.

title: COPYCATTING IN THE SOFTWARE PATCH
description: WITH 1.5 million personal computers now in use, producing the s oftware that drives them has become big business, and with it has c ome a byte-sized headache for the software makers: protecting the c opyrighted programs from illegal distribution.

title: HALT TO GUN PERMITS DRAWS IRE IN TOWN
description: CANAAN ''I NEVER wanted this to become an emotional issue,'' said Henry E. Pozzetta, the soft-spoken, 58-year-old funeral director who was elected Canaan's First Selectman last November.

title: ZOLDER, Belgium, May 8 (AP) -Gilles Villeneuve, a Canadian driver, was fatally injured today in a 170-mile-an-hour crash during the qualifying for the Belgian Grand Prix.
description: After the crash, the 30-year-old Villeneuve was rushed to a hospital in nearby Louvain and put under intensive care, with ''severe neck and brain-stem injuries.'' He never regained consciousness, hospital officials said.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SACRAMENTO
description: ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of The Times bureau in Los Angeles. BY ROBERT LINDSEY

title: THE ART OF COLLECTING
description: SINCE 1898, when Samuel Longstreth Parrish opened a museum in Southampton devoted to his personal art collection, the cultural life of Long Island has been significantly enriched through the generosity of its resident collectors. Whether as trustees of and donors to its institutions, lenders to its exhibitions or patrons of its artists, they have played a decisive role in shaping popular taste, stimulating artistic activity and establishing the region as one of the nation's foremost art centers.

title: TROUBLED COSTA RICA GETS NEW CHIEF
description: Luis Alberto Monge, a pro-American social democrat, began a four-year term as President of Costa Rica today in the midst of the country's worst economic crisis in 30 years.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: life L.A. lawyer. HANNAH ARENDT, by Elisabeth Young-Bruehl. (Yale University Press, $25.)

title: FLORIDA BACKERS OF LEGAL GAMBLING TRY AGAIN
description: After a defeat at the polls four years ago, Florida's proponents of casino gambling have regrouped and are trying again to legalize gambling in this resort state.

title: Fathers, Mothers and Children
description: For Michael Harbert, Mother's Day came early this year, on a winter day in Saigon. Mr. Harbert and three other Vietnam veterans were there to discuss unresolved legacies of the war. They ran into some on the street. ''You can see bomb craters and understand that people can fill them in,'' he says, ''but when you see a 16-year-old child who looks like your brother....''

title: Foreign Affairs; BRAINS IN THE BOOM
description: Even if the undeclared Falklands war can now be stopped, and that's to be ardently hoped, it has already shown dramatically how much technology has changed modern warfare and how many old axioms as well as weapons are obsolete.

title: BALLET: SCHOOL PRESENTS WORKSHOP PROGRAM
description: The School of American Ballet held two of its annual Workshop Performances on Monday at the Juilliard Theater, with interest centered on premieres choreographed by the New York City Ballet's two great classical dancers, Helgi Tomasson and Peter Martins.

title: NEW LIVES FOR THE DISABLED
description: IN 1971, Dr. Margaret Symonds, medical director of the Children's Specialized Hospital in the Union County community of Mountainside, became concerned over the number of young patients being transferred from that institution to nursing homes, for want of a better solution.

title: Chamber of Commerce Challenges Air Report
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce says that a new survey of more than 150 industrial plants contradicted a study on toxic air pollutants issued by environmental lobbyists in March.

title: HOMESTYLE INDIAN DISHES IN FORDS
description: GIVEN the risks involved in opening a restaurant during these financially depressed times, it's amazing how many amateurs are taking the plunge. But those who succeed usually have more than a dream to help them. The best of all guarantees is a good cook.

title: Sports People; Knick Trade Talk
description: Although the name of Denver's 6-foot-4-inch David Thompson, a former all-star guard, has come up in talks between the Nuggets and the Knicks, Carl Scheer, Denver's president and general manager said the discussion has not yet reached the ''hot-and-heavy'' stage, and that no Knick players have been mentioned for possible trades.

title: Television Week
description: Building on a Joke Rodney Dangerfield has for some years now succesfully parlayed a one-line bit -''I don't get no respect'' - into a comic routine. And now he has parlayed it even further: he is not only getting respect, he is also getting his first prime-time special.

title: A STEEL SCAPEGOAT
description: To the Business Editor: As American citizens we do not have to look further than our own State of Hawaii for similar economic and political polices in favor of Japan and Japanese companies. Take it from one who lived there for eight years.

title: CHANCES INCREASE FOR RAISING OF STATE DRINKING AGE
description: A proposal to raise New York State's drinking age to 19 is now expected to come to a vote in the Legislature this year, and officials here say that after years of languishing in legislative committees the proposal stands a strong chance of enactment.

title:
OTHER BUSINESS;
TEXACO'S NEW ENGINES IN U.P.S. BROWN TRUCKS...
description: Perhaps, finally, its time has come. After more than 30 years on the back burner in a Texaco research lab, the ''stratified charge'' engine is scheduled to hit the road by midyear in its first commercial application, under the hoods of 500 United Parcel Service delivery trucks.

title: KEY BATTLE WITH IRAN LOOMS
description: Iraq announced today that part of its forces that had occupied the southwestern Iranian province of Khuzistan for the last 19 months had retreated.

title: No Headline
description: One aspect of equality between women and men is economics. Anatomy has determined that only women have the right to choose natural parenthood.

title: THEATER WORKSHOPS
description: The Darien Dinner Theater is broadening its operations this summer to include an eight-week session of workshops, a paid apprentice program, and the production of an original play selected from manuscripts now being accepted for consideration.

title: PLEA TO KEEP PROGRAM ON HUMAN RELATIONS
description: IT would be too bad if those preparing the 1982-83 budget for the White Plains Schools decide to cut back on financing of the district's model human-relations program. In the making over the last 10 years, the program helps White Plains youngsters deal with their emotions and solve social problems. Entire families are helped by these education programs specifically tailored to family cares.

title:
Gardening;
PERENNIALS VALUED FOR THEIR DIVERSITY
description: MUCH of the value of using perennials in a flower garden lies in their seemingly infinite diversity. In height they vary from a few inches to five or more feet; in their blooming, from early spring until late fall; in foliage texture, from fine to coarse; in form, from narrow, upright spikes to globe-shaped mounds, and in color, from one end of the spectrum to the other. However, this diversity is also the source of the greatest dilemma in their use - the need for careful planning prior to planting. Only the most knowlegeable perennial specialist would plant a border without first sketching out a plan. Even then, most would make changes from year to year to obtain the desired balance and overall effect.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: Civil War Underground Railroad and then formulates a ''myth'' that he believes his race needs to survive in America. This intricate, ambitious novel was named one of 1981's outstanding books by the editors of the Book Review.

title: 'HAPPY,' PERHAPS; 'GAY'?-WELL...
description: WHEN I was young, a ''gay'' person was someone who laughed a lot and always seemed to enjoy life, and the Gaiety was a theater that catered to the heterosexual fantasies of immature males.

title: Paige Callen, T. L. James Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Holmes Callen Jr. of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paige Palmer Callen, to Thomas Lipscomb James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allan James of Meadville, Pa.

title: Naval Quotes
description: To the Editor: As a former Naval person, I was interested in the article on the Naval Academy by Francis X. Clines, ''The Calm Waters of Annapolis'' (Travel, April 25). However, a cloud somewhat bigger than a man's hand appeared on the horizon when I read, ''When you're ready, you may fire, Gridley.''

title: Pirates 4, Reds 2
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Johnny Ray and Jason Thompson delivered runscoring singles in the 15th inning to give Pittsburgh the victory. The Pirates were held to one single for eighth innings by Bruce Berenyi, but tied the score, 2-2, in the ninth on run-scoring singles by Bill Madlock and Thompson.

title: BRITISH TASK FORCE STARTS PATROLLING ARGENTINA'S COAST
description: British ships and planes patrolled the new war zone along the Argentine coast today as the conviction grew in political and diplomatic circles that all-out fighting over the Falkland Islands could be imminent.

title: Ties to the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal Rights Prayer Day Set
description: The National Organization for Women has asked churches to issue a call on Mother's Day for equality and social justice. The group said it would observe Sunday as a national day of prayer for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: BRAZILIAN MOTIFS IN JEWELRY
description: Jack Brusca is an artist first and foremost, but from time to time he makes jewelry. In the early 1970's, when he was painting threedimensional numbers and letters, he and Joseph Dante, his partner then, turned them into chunky gold pendants. Now that he is painting sinuous wavelike forms, he is using them as the basis for a collection of jewelry that combines gold with semiprecious stones and, in a few pieces, diamonds.

title: Palmer Stirs Action On Golfers' Conduct
description: The problem of boorish behavior by professional golfers surfaced this week as the result of observations by Arnold Palmer.

title: The Region in Summary; The Start of A Revenue War?
description: State legislators usually end their sessions voting on a spate of hurried compromises aimed at tying up loose political and fiscal ends. As the Connecticut General Assembly voted its way toward the final gavel last week, however, it may have birthed more controversy than it buried.

title: SUMMARY OF 1982 SESSION OF LEGISLATURE
description: HARTFORD

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Halfway through Paul Taylor's ''Airs,'' three men sink to the ground in a line, torsos bent forward and arms extended before them. A woman, either Susan McGuire or Cathy McCann of the Taylor company, has just plunged deeply into a bold version of an arabesque penchee.

title: Long Islanders; SEEKING GROWTH IN 'HUMAN CAPITAL'
description: ''THERE were no economists on the council,'' said David Machlis, ''no specialists on human resources.'' He was talking about the President's Council on Bilingual Education as it was constituted before last Oct. 1. That was the day when Dr. Machlis was appointed by Secretary of Education T.H. Bell to the 15-member body established by Congress to further its policy of establishing equal educational opportunity for children.

title: HUMAN RACE IN ART
description: The most ambitious exhibition yet attempted in the 17-year history of Larry Aldrich's Museum of Contempory Art in Ridgefield opens Tuesday, titled ''Homo Sapiens: The Many Images.''

title: City Hall Notes; KOCH'S NAME IS DOIN' FINE ON RELEASES
description: Over the last several weeks, Mayor Koch's name has appeared prominently on an unusual number of government announcements that might be expected to have been made by lower-ranking officials.

title: ...AND A FAREWELL TO LANCIA IN THE UNITED STATES
description: DETROIT Another famous marque in autos is joining MG and Triumph in an exodus from the American car market - the Lancia. Fiat, the big Italian auto-maker, has decided to discontinue production of Lancia's Zagato model, it announced last week, and so it has notified its 140 Lancia dealerships that it will terminate Lancia sales and service franchise agreements in the United States.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Snake-Check

title: THE MAN WHO LOVES PENSION FUNDS
description: LOS ANGELES VICTOR H. PALMIERI has been shuttling between private, highly profitable business ventures and public life for more than 15 years, and now the maverick businessman with a taste for crises is at it again.

title: NEW HAVEN STROLL
description: Artours, a new service offered by Annabel Simon Cahn, art historian and teacher, will take lovers of art and architecture on a Sunday morning stroll through Yale University and downtown New Haven for $12 with brunch.

title: Robin Rubinstein, Eric Hutner to Marry in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abe Rubenstein of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin L. Rubinstein, to Eric S. Hutner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer M. Hutner of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Strike Closes Italy's Airports
description: A strike by firemen closed all Italian airports today and brought civil flights to a halt, airport officials said. The firemen are protesting legislative delays involving the fire service. They plan another strike on May 13.

title: The World in Summary; What's in the Name for Nuclear Arms Control
description: The Reagan Administration has renamed the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks START, for strategic arms reduction, to show it really would slash nuclear arsenals if only the Russians agreed. Talks are expected to begin this summer and President Reagan was reported last week to have decided on an opening position. It would set a ceiling of 850 for each side's incontinental nuclear missiles and of 5,000 for the warheads on those missiles.

title: Jack, or Jill, in the Pulpit
description: For those who prefer their Sunday sermons in the woods, nature's purple-and-green hooded spring preachers, the Jack-in-the-pulpits, are now coming into their own. What is remarkable about these righteous plants, whose aliases include Indian turnip, bog onion, brown dragon and starchwort, is that the Jack you see may, in fact, be a Jill.

title: A CHINESE STUDENT'S PECULIAR COMPLAINT
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARIDGE HEARINGS TO BEGIN
description: ATLANTIC CITY OF THIS resort's nine gambling casinos, all but those at the Claridge and Tropicana Hotels have been licensed, and the licensing hearing for the Claridge begins tomorrow.

title: Gretchen Phillips To Be June Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. James F. Phillips Jr. of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gretchen Anne Phillips, to Myles Hannan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Hannan Jr. of Springfield, Va.

title:
CAMERA;
ON PREVENTING FATIGUE IN THE DARKROOM
GIANTS GET 6 RUNS IN 8TH TO BEAT METS, 8-3
description: One by one, the relief pitchers for the Mets rode to the mound, and one by one they slowly walked away, disappointed. For the second time in three days the Mets built an early three-run lead over the San Francisco Giants at Shea Stadium yesterday and then lost, this time, 8-3, after allowing six runs in the eighth inning.

title: THE ENDURING ART OF CAMEO GLASS
