description: Since ancient Rome, glassmakers have wrestled with the problems of creating cameo glass - plaques and vessels of two or more glass layers of contrasting colors, the surfaces of which are carved with flowers, neo-classical scenes, portraits and such. Costly and technically challenging as a craft, the results have delighted glass enthusiasts for centuries. And with glass collecting at an all-time high, cameo glass in recent years has commanded increased attention and impressive prices.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE 'AVERAGE MOM'
description: THIS Mother's Day I'm doing it up big for a change. I'll pin on my orchid corsage, weep over my Hallmark and gracefully accept dinner for four plus highchair at Ho-Jo's with all the clam strips I can eat.

title: Extra Body-Checks Don't Limit Bossy
description: Before the first game of the Stanley Cup final began tonight, Dave Williams, the Vancouver Canucks' forward, promised that he and his teammates would check the Islanders hard throughout the night.

title: WHAT'S ENOUGH?
description: BRITAIN and Argentina spent heavily in lives and treasure last week to advance their warring versions of national honor in the Falklands. The losses -hundreds dead, Argentina's only cruiser sunk, a modern British destroyer laid waste - had a sobering effect on many people on both sides and spurred efforts at the United Nations and by Peru and the United States to halt the conflict.

title: ARGENTINE SHIP'S SINKING
description: The General Belgrano, Argentina's only cruiser, was sunk in the icy waters of the South Atlantic last Sunday by two torpedoes from a British submarine patrolling just outside the 200-mile British blockade around the Falkland Islands.

title:
Gardening;
PERENNIALS VALUED FOR THEIR DIVERSITY
description: MUCH of the value of using perennials in a flower garden lies in their seemingly infinite diversity. In height they vary from a few inches to five or more feet; in their blooming, from early spring until late fall; in foliage texture, from fine to coarse; in form, from narrow, upright spikes to globe-shaped mounds, and in color, from one end of the spectrum to the other. However, this diversity is also the source of the greatest dilemma in their use - the need for careful planning prior to planting. Only the most knowlegeable perennial specialist would plant a border without first sketching out a plan. Even then, most would make changes from year to year to obtain the desired balance and overall effect.

title: Cosmos Top Tulsa, 3-2
description: Steve Moyers scored two regulation goals and Richard Chinapoo got the winner in a shootout to give the Cosmos a 3-2 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks tonight in North American Soccer League play.

title: May 9, 1982
description: NONFICTION AMERICA IN SEARCH OF ITSELF: The Making of the President, 1956-80. By Theodore H. White. 1 HAMAYUN: The Life of Alexander Blok.

title: Maryland Court Rules All-White Jury Is Valid
description: A Maryland appellate court has ruled that prosecutors may use peremptory challenges in jury selection to insure that all-white juries decide the guilt or innocence of black defendants.

title: Kathryn Knauss Will Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William D. Knauss of North Andover, Mass., and Ticonderoga, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Lindsay Knauss, to Carl David Rosenblum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Rosenblum of Long Beach, L.I.

title: VISIT TO A MEXICAN SPA
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL's latest novel is ''Crossing in Berlin.'' BY FLETCHER KNEBEL

title: Rutgers, Led by Quow, Takes Met Track Title
description: Elliot Quow won the 100- and 200-meter dashes, helping Rutgers to win the 49th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate track title at St. John's University yesterday.

title: ARGENTINA ADVANCES TO TENNIS SEMIFINALS
description: Argentina gained the fourth spot in the Nation's Cup tennis semifinals by defeating Australia today, 2-1.

title: THEATER: ROCHELLE OWENS'S 'VIDAL'
description: Playwrights are sometimes their own best critics. In Rochelle Owens's ''Who Do You Want, Peire Vidal?'' at Theater for the New City, the author repeatedly has her characters tell us that the play is pointless and that certain scenes do not work. We have no reason to question her veracity. Similarly, we believe her when she says that the evening is a good opportunity for actors.

title: UNINSURED MAN DENIED CARE
description: A badly burned man was denied treatment by about 30 medical centers around the nation, with most of them rejecting him because he lacked health insurance, according to a spokesman for the hospital here that finally accepted him.

title: PROPOSED CENTER IN HEMPSTEAD DIVIDES COUNTIES
description: THE proposed construction of a Long Island Performing Arts Center in Hempstead Village, a complex eagerly sought by business leaders and others, has been welcomed by most officials in Nassau County, but has struck some sour notes in Suffolk.

title: Mr. Block on the Lysenko Trail
description: What is going on in the office of John Block, the Secretary of Agriculture?

title: A WEALTH OF READING ARRIVES AT COUNTY JAIL
description: FIVE HUNDRED 1981 almanacs, a full set of ''McKinney's Consolidated Laws'' and three boxes of fabric swatches may not be the answers to a prisoner's prayer. Nonetheless, all have arrived recently to help inmates pass the time at the County Jail and the Penitentiary.

title: Home Clinic; USING POWER TOOLS AND APPLIANCES: WATCH GROUNDING
description: SOME power tools and appliances are double-insulated on the inside and have special nonconductive plastic housings, so they can be used with ordinary two-conductor, ungrounded cords and plugs. However, except for these ''shockproof'' or ''shock-resistant'' models, all other electric power tools and appliances are supposed to be grounded - that is, the cord has a third wire, called the ground wire, that connects the machine's housing and other metal parts directly with the ground.

title: A GREAT WRITER-NOT A GREAT MAN
description: THOMAS HARDY A Biography. By Michael Millgate. Illustrated. 637 pp. New York: Random House. $25. By GEORGE LEVINE

title: MX MISSILE OPTIONS NARROWED TO TWO
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has narrowed to two the choices for basing the still homeless MX intercontinental missile, according to senior Reagan Administration officials. The alternatives are putting the missiles in revolutionary new aircraft that would be continually in flight or placing them in a closely packed, fortified and defended land base.

title: A LIFE OF LUXURY AT THE TOP OF THE CITY
description: FOR people with lots of money and the need for an elegant, secure, h eadache-free base in New York, four new luxury buildings, one c omplete and the three others in construction, may provide the a nswer.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Church's Assets Go Straight Up
description: The next best thing to pennies from heaven may have been the dollars for the piece of heaven just above the Church of Sweden, at 5 E. 48th St., N.Y. - $999,999 to be exact. That's what David Solomon, president of Solomon Equities, paid for the church's air rights, to insure unobstructed views and to provide overhang space for the 43-story glass tower he's building next door.

title: SMALL COMPONENTS-BIG ON SONIC PROWESS
description: Back when the first Volkswagen Beetles scurried around the bloated, tail-finned gas-guzzlers dominating the road in those days, few people believed that compact cars stood much of a chance. Since then we have learned that size isn't everything.

title: Mailbox; Ways to Upgrade College Athletics
description: To the Sports Editor: I read with great interest Dick Holub's article in The New York Times sports section (''Some Applause for What's Already Right,'' April 11). It appealed to me because I played at Fairleigh Dickinson (1963-1966) and felt that the F.D.U. sports department was generally insensitive to the athletes' academic needs.

title: Arrows Eliminate Blast And Advance to Finals
description: Steve Zungul scored four goals to lead the New York Arrows to a 6-2 victory tonight and a sweep of their twoof-three-game semifinal playoff series against the Baltimore Blast in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS STORAGE IN EUROPE CALLED VULNERABLE
description: Installations in Western Europe used for storing American nuclear warheads continue to be vulnerable to assault by terrorists and antinuclear demonstrators, according to Congressional and Administration officials.

title: VANITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Johnston to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Joan Johnston of Riverside, Conn., and H. Frederick Johnston of Southport, Conn., and Warwick, Bermuda, of the engagement of their daughter, Martha Isobel Johnston, to Bradway Griscom Widing, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Widing Jr. of Duxbury, Mass.

title: Dining Out; A COZY SPANISH HIDEAWAY
description: DARIEN WHO would ever guess from the trim colonial brick facade and the bland Anglo-Saxon name that inside The Peak in Darien is a Spanish restaurant?

title: YANKEES CONQUER MARINERS
description: Rich Gossage halted an eighth-inning threat by the Seattle Mariners tonight and preserved a 9-4 victory for Ron Guidry that ended the Yankees' losing streak at four games.

title: THE DAY THEY MOVED AWAY
description: MY neighbors moved away the other day. We had met 23 years ago, when we were the first two families to live in what used to be woods. It was a hot day near the end of May in 1959. All around us, the frames of split-levels were going up.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: NO COMEBACKS Stories by Frederick Forsyth. 256 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95.

title: Denise Williams, K.B. Kunhardt Jr.  Married in Jersey
description: Denise Daria Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward David Williams of Franklin Lakes and Avalon, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Bradish Kunhardt Jr., son of Edith Woodruff Kunhardt of New York and Mr. Kunhardt of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Frederick J. Warnecke Jr. performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: ISLANDERS WIN OPENER IN OVERTIME
description: Mike Bossy scored his third goal of the game with two seconds remaining in overtime tonight as the Islanders beat the Vancouver Canucks, 6-5, in the opener of the National Hockey League championship playoff series.

title: Around the Nation; 173 Carolinians Sued For Student Aid Debts
description: The United States Attorney's office and the Veterans Administration have filed 173 civil suits against South Carolinians who have defaulted on student loans or failed to pay other education benefits.

title: CUNNINGHAM: AN UNLIKELY COACH MAKES HIS WAY
description: FEW people believed that Billy Cunningham could be successful as coach of the Philadelphia 76ers. Certainly, Billy Cunningham never believed it.

title: Television Week
description: Another Mrs. Roosevelt

title: Zahringer Winner In Richardson Golf
description: Playing with methodical consistency in the final, George Zahringer 3d of Sands Point, L.I., today won the William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament for the third time in four years.

title: B. and B.
description: To the Editor: We have a couple of reasons for noting with pleasure the Advisory item by Lawrence Van Gelder about ''bed and breakfast spreading across the U.S.'' (Travel, April 25). One is the memory of such overnight encounters with friendly Britons in the West Country and Wales.

title: FELLINI'S '8 1 2' INSPIRES A MUSICAL
description: It began one night at the movies in 1962. Maury Yeston, then an idealistic high school senior with dreams of becoming a composer, went to a neighborhood movie house in Jersey City, N.J., to see Federico Fellini's Academy Award-winning picture, ''8 1/2.'' He was instantly taken with Fellini's beleaguered hero, Guido Anselmi, a great Italian film director suffering from a midlife crisis - a crisis that at once made shambles of his career and his personal life.

title: EVANGELIST MEETS SOVIET AIDE
description: The Rev. Billy Graham smiled, chatted and had lunch with his Soviet hosts today and met a high-ranking Communist to discuss United States-Soviet relations. The evangelist called him a ''very wonderful official.''

title: OPERA: CHILDREN'S THEATER GIVES 'NIGHTINGALE'
description: The familiar Hans Christian Andersen fairytale ''The Emperor and the Nightingle,'' has been transformed in a production by the First All Children's Theater into a charming and whimsical short opera, ''Nightingale,'' that is designed to appeal to adults as well as children.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: SESSION ENDS WITH FEW CHANGES
description: YEAR-OLDS will find it harder to get a drink, and new-car buyers may have an easier time with ''lemons'' as a result of the General Assembly's work this year, but those may be the only effects felt by the general public.

title: Military Analysis
description: Time and options are running out for the British task force at the Falkland Islands. Time because the troops at sea are unlikely to retain their fighting edge much longer after more than three weeks tossing in the tumultuous South Atlantic and with the weather worsening daily.

title: Dancers for Disarmament
description: Eight dancers and companies will perform next Saturday at 6 P.M. at Wollman Auditorium, Ferris Booth Hall, Columbia University, in a dance-film program presented by Dancers for Disarmament.

title: Miss Stephenson Leads by 2 Strokes
description: Jan Stephenson, the defending champion, birdied three of the first five holes for a six-under-par 67 and took a two-stroke lead over Kathy Whitworth today after two rounds of the $125,000 L.P.G.A.-United Virginia Bank Classic.

title: 'I GUESS I'M BLESSED WITH GOOD LUNGS'
description: When Arturo Toscanini heard Ethel Merman sing ''I Get a Kick Out of You'' he said: ''Hers is not a human voice. It's another instrument in the band.'' The great Italian conductor was not the only listener to get a kick out of the Merman voice. Another musical celebrity, the tenor Luciano Pavarotti, wrote in his autobiography about her singing: ''Ethel Merman's voice is remarkable. It is all one register. She has no passagio to worry about. She never has to shift gears.''

title: THE VIOLA MAKES A BID FOR STARDOM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. BY ALLAN KOZINN

title: GYM CLASS 'WALKS' ON AIR
description: NEW HARTFORD FOR students at the Ann Antolini Elementary School here, gym class can mean archery or basketball, a chance to scale a wall as if it were a sheer rock face, or ''walkin' on air'' while dangling from a 30-foot-high ceiling beam.

title: ARTISTIC STAGNATION BESETS COUNTRY MUSIC
description: Only two years ago, when American popular music was seized with ''Urban Cowboy'' mania, country music seemed on the verge of becoming the dominant commercial style. The population growth of the Sun Belt, the new affluence of a white blue-collar class, and an increasingly conservative political climate all fed the theory that a grass-roots style of diatonic folk-pop celebrating America's pioneer heritage might take over the airwaves, as disco had done briefly two years before.

title: TEACHING CHILDREN HOW TO VIEW TV
description: PARENTS and educators who guide the television viewing of children only through restrictive and selective viewing are doing their children and students a disservice. In fact, we may be creating a disability as crippling as the inability to read. Young boys and girls who cannot infer, deduce, critically evaluate, differentiate fact from fiction, find the main idea or determinine the meaning of new vocabulary in a visual medium are as shut off from information and enjoyment as children who lack the same skills in reading.

title: The Nation in Summary; A Look Into Haitian Camps
description: Apparently weary of fending off charges of concentration-camp conditions, the Reagan Administration last week agreed to let an international body examine facilities at two detention centers for Haitian refugees.

title: Mancini Stops Frias in First
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini earned the World Boxing Association lightweight title today by knocking out Arturo Frias. Mancini dropped Frias to the canvas and then pounded him on the ropes before the fight was stopped with six seconds left in the first round.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Patmore Lewis, Violin, Presents Kupferman
description: Patmore Lewis, a violinist born in St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, played works by Corelli, Chausson, Brahms, Sinding and the American composer Meyer Kupferman in his New York recital debut on Tuesday. The program, in Carnegie Recital Hall, went beyond the usual run of recital repertory, and for that Mr. Lewis is to be congratulated.

title: PALEOANTHROPOLOGY IS MORE THAN BARE BONES
description: The study of human origins, paleoanthropology, was once dominated by individualists who made great discoveries through inspired hunches, lonely persistence and luck. A paleoanthropologist, Donald C. Johanson, described early efforts in the field this way: A person ''would raise a little money, go out and find a few fossils and decide he needed a little geology done. So he would go home, raise a little more money and get a geologist. The next year he would realize he needed an archeologist, and so on. It was like putting patches on a pair of pants.''

title: Karen Ciovacco, Ira Fuchs to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ciovacco of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Regina Ciovacco, to Ira Howard Fuchs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Josef S. Fuchs of Forest Hills, Queens.

title:
FOOD;
EATING SENSE
description: It is not given to everyone to greet the world with Elizabeth Taylor's hyacinth gaze. Perfect profiles and flawless legs are for the few. But health can raise ordinary endowments to a level pleasingly close to beauty. With a slim, trim figure, blue-white eyeballs and shampoo-ad hair, it's hard not to be somewhat good-looking no matter what heredity did about your height or jawline.

title: 'OPPENHEIMER'--EXAMINING THE SCIENTIST'S RELATIONSHIP WITH SOCIETY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington frequently reports on the cultural scene in London. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON At a time when the debate on nuclear arms control is beginning to dominate both public platforms and private lives (more than 40 new books on nuclear issues are being published in the United States this year), it seems appropriate to have a television series about the responsibility of the scientist toward society. And that is precisely the moral territory occupied by ''Oppenheimer,'' a sevenpart dramatized biography of the American physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer; it stars Sam Waterston as ''the father of the atomic bomb.'' (The initial one-hour installment will be shown Tuesday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, as part of the weekly ''American Playhouse'' series.)

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Oil Becomes Too Cheap for Synfuel Project
description: The nation's synthetic fuels industry, which arose out of the worldwide oil droughts of the 1970's, may sink in a flood of foreign crude.

title: OIL GLUT HAS TURNED A DREAM INTO A BURDEN
description: On the grounds of the polo club in Lagos, where wealthy men from the north ride fine sleek ponies, there is a humble wooden crate filled with dirt on which someone - with tongue in cheek - has arranged a few pieces of broken stone to resemble an urban crossroads. On the side of the crate is the word ''Abuja.''

title: HOMEGROWN FIGS ARE TOPS FOR FLAVOR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Maria T. Cinque is a turfgrass specialist for Cornell University's Cooperative Extension. By MARIA T. Cinque

title: CAPITALISM AND THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN
description: Is capitalism inherently evil? No, says Michael Novak in his new book, ''The Spirit of Democratic Capitalism,'' published by Simon & Schuster. In fact, Mr. Novak pronounces democratic capitalism the best of all political-economic systems, in ideal as well as in results. His book is an against-the-grain examination of the theological and moral foundations of capitalism and of why, as he sees it, the system works so well. WHAT do I mean by ''democratic capitalism''? In short, three d ynamic and converging systems functioning as one: a democratic p olity, an economy based on markets and incentives and a m oralcultural system which is pluralistic and, in the largest sense, l iberal. Social systems like those of the United States, West Germanya nd Japan (with perhaps a score of others among the world's nations) i llustrate the type.

title: QUARTETS: FITZWILLIAM IN SHOSTAKOVICH CYCLE
description: Musical performances can always claim esthetic importance, but some go beyond that to invoke history as well. It was that kind of significance that attended the Fitzwilliam String Quartet's cycle of the complete 15 quartets of Dmitri Shostakovich, the first time the cycle had ever been done in this country. The cycle began on April 24 at Alice Tully Hall and the fifth and final concert took place there Thursday night.

title: Peltier Excels In 2 Events
description: Brooklyn athletes fared well today at the 15th annual Loucks Games at the White Plains High School field. Dave Peltier of Wingate participated in two meet-record performances and the girls' team from Boys and Girls won three events and the team trophy.

title: HE HAS AN EYE FOR HEAD-ON CONFLICT
description: Percy Granger's ''Eminent Domain,'' which was described by Walter Kerr as ''a fascinating experience'' with ''impeccably characterized people'' when it opened late in March at Circle in the Square, had a long period of gestation. The play, about a professorial couple in the midwest, took Mr. Granger six years to complete, he says. And it evolved from two impulses, one of which nudged aside the other.

title: Around the Nation; Air Controllers Allowed To Keep Jobless Pay
description: Six former air traffic controllers will get to keep $25,000 in unemployment benefits awarded them when the Government failed to challenge their claims, according to a ruling Friday by a state appeal board.

title: EVEN A TRIMMER MILITARY WOULDN'T BE ANY BARGAIN
description: The steady and seemingly uncontrollable increase in the cost of modern weapons has led several scientists to calculate that, if present trends continue, sometime fairly early in the next century it could take the entire military budget to purchase one combat aircraft and, not long after that, the entire gross national product.

title: Headliners Susan Saxe Gets Out
description: After serving eight years of a sentence for manslaughter and armed robbery in connection with a 1970 bank robbery, Susan Saxe, the former Brandeis University honor student turned radical, was released from the State Correctional Facility at Framingham, Mass., last week.

title: SUMMATIONS TOMORROW IN REV. MOON'S TRIAL
description: Summations will begin tomorrow in the trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Unification Church leader charged with fraudulently failing to report more than $150,000 of taxable income.

title: REMEMBRANCES
description: The Greenwich Village of a century and a half ago will come to life on Wednesday evening when Bayrd Still, a historian with a special interest in the area, presents a free slide show at the Salmagundi Club on lower Fifth Avenue.

title: SENATE'S BUDGET BECOMES PRESIDENT'S PROBLEM
description: WASHINGTON IT was one of those scenes that remind everyone of where the buck stops. Seven Republican Congressional leaders joined President Reagan in the Rose Garden as he announced their new budget proposal. Then, after posing for photographers, the seven hastily withdrew, leaving Mr. Reagan to face questions about the proposal's most politically sensitive component.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a postponement, a list- ing today in The Guide, section 2A, for Sheryl Lee Ralph's club engagement at Les Mouches is incorrect. The new date is Saturday, May 22.

title: HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR FATALLY STABBED IN DISPUTE
description: A Manhattan teen-ager celebrating the end of his senior year in high school was chased and fatally stabbed during a dispute between two groups of youths early yesterday in Greenwich Village.

title: IT'S GIBSON ON DEFENSE THIS WEEK
description: In 1970, a 38-year-old civil engineer ran a rather traditional campaign for Mayor of Newark. He promised to replace the incumbent's scandal-tinged administration with one marked by honesty, integrity and improved city services. On that platform, Kenneth A. Gibson soundly defeated two-term Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, who was then on trial on charges of conspiracy and extortion involving city contractors.

title: Kathy Farrell Is the Bride of Richard K. Weinroth
description: Kathy Farrell, a freelance interior designer in Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard K. Weinroth, a partner in the law firm of Sterns, Herbert & Weinroth in Princeton and Trenton. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Sebastian Weber in St. James Roman Catholic Church in Pennington, N.J.

title: SUMMER RENTALS: PROCEED WITH CAUTION
description: THE approach of summer stirs the longing to get away from it all, a nd many people begin thinking seriously about renting a vacation s pot. At the same time, owners of country houses who have summered int he same place for years may want a change and decide to become t emporary landlords for the first time.

title: RENT CONTROLS; Suburbs Have Own Regulations
description: MANY communities in the New York metropolitan area have no rules g overning residential rents, and in those places tenants must pay w hatever the market will bear and the landlord demands. But there area few million apartments in other communities outside of New York C ity that have some form of rent regulation.
To the Editor:

title: THE NEW SCHOOL SELLS 'PIONEERING' BENTON MURAL
description: The work that established Thomas Hart Benton's national reputation as a muralist - a four-wall panorama of American life that he painted for the New School for Social Research in 1931 - has been sold by the school. The 10 panels that compose the work were removed Friday.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 9, 1982
description: International An all-out war over the Falklands could be imminent, politicians and diplomats in London said as British ships and planes patrolled the new war zone along the Argentine coast. Efforts to negotiate a settlement continued at the United Nations. Britain's delegate, Sir Anthony Parsons, told a British radio audience that ''it is very difficult to be optimistic.'' Authoritative sources said Britain was now prepared to accept a United Nations trusteeship over the Falklands. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Gary Robert Rosenblum To Marry Donna Eskwitt
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Eskwitt of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Lynn Eskwitt, to Gary Robert Rosenblum, son of Ruth Rosenblum Slosberg of Whitestone, Queens, and the late Herbert Rosenblum.

title: AT U.N., TALKS ARE 'MOVING' BUT NEW PROBLEMS CROP UP
description: An intense round of talks to end the Falkland Islands conflict took place here today, but new problems reportedly raised by Argentina and Britain suggested that a substantial gap remains between the two sides.

title: Jingle Bell Rock
description: To the Business Editor: About the maxim attributed to David Ogilvy, ''If you don't have anything to say, sing it,'' which appeared in ''There's a Song in Their Art'' (May 2), I advise, if you don't have anything to say, get a new creative team. RICHARD O'NEILL Executive Producer Yellow Brick Films Inc. New York, May 4, 1982

title: Around the Nation; Diplomat Indicted Again As a Heroin Smuggler
description: A Thai diplomat accused of helping smuggle up to $12 million in heroin in diplomatic pouches has been indicted on other drug charges.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The Word Is Out On Student Loans
description: For college students and parents awaiting the specifics of President Reagan's plans for cutting Government-guaranteed loans, the eligibility rules published by the Education Department last week may not have assuaged all anxieties, but they probably offered no nasty surprises.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
EXPANDING HORIZONS FOR CHAMBER MUSIC
description: For most music-loving Americans, only a generation or so ago, the words ''chamber music'' probably evoked one stereotyped image: four musicians, arranged two versus two on a stage, sawing away at a Beethoven quartet. Chamber music concerts, which is to say quartet concerts, were popularly thought to be the preserve of amateur string players, doctors, lawyers, mathematics teachers and other serious, analytical folk. Music commentators reinforced this image by treating these initiates as a highbrow cult whose esthetic purity was proved by its meager numbers and disdain for showmanship and personalities.

title: Correction
description: In the review of ''A Great Love,'' by Alexandra Kollontai (April 25), an incorrect year and publisher were given for ''Love of Worker Bees.'' The book was published in 1978 by Academy Chicago Ltd.

title: ZIEGLER CITES A DECISION
description: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, is confident that the jury verdict that frees the Oakland Raiders to move to Los Angeles would not apply to the Colorado Rockies' attempt to move to Byrne Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey.

title: DR. IRA J. FINK TO WED PAMELA SHORT ON JUNE 5
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roderic Malcolm Short of Anchorage have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Short, to Dr. Ira J. Fink, son of Alice Lefton Fink of New York and the late Dr. Seymour A. Fink.

title: A MODEST GAMBLE
description: Doubled contracts can be divided into two major categories, and a few minor ones. The commonest are the hands in which both sides have a fit: one partnership has bid to a high level as a save and has duly been doubled. The next largest group, in expert play, is the lowlevel misfit: One partnership has the majority of the high-card strength and tries to take advantage of the fact.

title: A March by 50,000 Basques Protests Separatist Slaying
description: About 50,000 Basques marched through central Bilbao Friday night to protest violence by separatist guerrillas, especially the killing Wednesday of the director of a nearby nuclear power plant.

title: Lisabeth Conn Wed to Michael Hayes
description: Lisabeth Ann Conn, a sales representative with the Chemical Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Christopher Hayes, a trader with the finanical-futures division of Salomon Bothers in Chicago. The Rev. Richard Morrow performed the ceremony in St. Ignatius of Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: VENEZUELA'S TERRITORIAL CLAIMS WORRY GUYANESE
description: The Government of Guyana has begun to worry - in part because of the Falkland Islands crisis - that Venezuela, its rich and more powerful neighbor, is about to press its claim to five-eighths of Guyana's territory.

title: Diane Gail Irvin Married
description: Diane Gail Irvin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tinsley Hoyt Irvin of Greenwich, Conn., and Michael Orren Christian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Orren Douglas Christian of Tampa, Fla., were married yesterday in St. John United Methodist Church in Atlanta. The Rev. James Budd performed the ceremony. Mr. and Mrs. Christian were graduated from Mercer University.

title: THE THIRD REICH ACCORDING TO ALBERT SPEER
description: MUNICH Making a filmed dramatization of Albert Speer's memoirs, ''Inside the Third Reich,'' poses great problems. Those problems become enormous if you assume that the version presented by Hitler's Minister for War Production of how it all happened might be a selfserving, disingenuous account that no one ought to confuse with history, final or authoritative.

title: Television Week
description: The Wooing of de Kooning

title: FARMLAND SINGS THE DISINFLATION BLUES
description: THE good news about inflation is bad news for Farmland Industries, the economic oddity that has swelled into one of the nation's largest agricultural and energy conglomerates.

title: No Headline
description: Regarding the coyotes versus the ranchers, perhaps the latter, as business operators, should be willing to take occasional losses.

title: Around the World; Greece to Investigate Finances of Newspapers
description: The Government has ordered an investigation into the financial resources of all Greek newspapers after a growing dispute over allegations that the Soviet Union is financing a major daily.

title: ISRAEL SAYS IT WILL NOT MAKE NEW ARMS SALES TO ARGENTINA
description: Israel, which is a minor supplier of weapons to Argentina, said this week that it would make no further arms deals with Buenos Aires but would deliver anything already contracted for.

title: A SENSE OF PALESTINIAN URGENCY
description: Palestinians of many political persuasions seem to agree on one point: During the last six months, the Israeli military occupation of the West Bank and Gaza has become more burdensome. Few now seem to doubt that annexation lies ahead. This has produced both resistance and a sense of urgency. Curiously, it may also have spawned an element of pragmatism that may offer one avenue out of the impasse - if the United States is prepared to take a strong initiative.

title: DE KOONING POSES FOR TV PORTRAIT
description: OVER the years, many interpreters and apologists have come forward to speak for the painter Willem de Kooning. Poets, musicians, photographers, critics and art historians have been fascinated by him for decades, but apart from a few short essays and interviews, the artist himself has had little to tell us of his life and work. Tomorrow night at 9:30, however, when the film ''De Kooning on de Kooning'' is shown on WNET-TV, he will speak for himself.

title: Long Island Journal
description: SIX utility poles that have been particularly hazardous to motorists will either be moved back to safer positions or affixed with luminous reflectors within the next six months.

title: Leonard Is in Hospital With Unknown Ailment
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the world welterweight champion, was admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital tonight with an undisclosed ailment, hospital officials said.

title: THE WOODPILE AS A STATUS SYMBOL
description: IT'S chic. It's organic. It builds muscles and pollutes the environment. It helps to fill in that spot in back of the house where no grass will grow.

title: Theater In Review; NUTTY NONSENSE NICELY STAGED
description: EAST FARMINGDALE THE delectations of Georges Feydeau's ''A Gown for His Mistress'' are delivered to a tasty turn by Arena Players Repertory Company, which is, in all nominal truth, as close as the Island has come to developing and nurturing a real homegrown group of actors who appear here with variety and consistency.
To the Editor:

title: BLESSED ARE THE FURRY ONES
description: NORTH SALEM WHILE the lion failed to show up and lie down with the lamb, there were two ferrets from Mahopac, just behind Ralph and Stewart, the pet mice, in the processional line of the Interfaith Blessing of the Land and Animals held last Sunday at the Hammond Museum. Despite Isaiah's prophecy, Jason Glick, the 12-year-old boy who owned the mice, kept Ralph and Stew safely stashed away from their mortal enemy, the ferrets, by carrying them around in a beer cooler.

title: WHAT HUCK FINN SAYS TO A BLACK CHILD
description: To the Editor:

title: ON LOCATION WITH MARCO POLO
description: Christopher Wren is The New York Times bureau chief in Peking. By Christopher Wren But I believe it was God's will that we should return, so that men might know the things that are in the world, since, as we have said in the first chapter of this book, there was never man yet, Christian or Saracen, Tartar or pagan, who explored so much of the world as Messer Marco, son of Messer Niccolo Polo, great and noble citizen of Venice. - ''THE TRAVELS OF MARCO POLO,'' CIRCA 1298.

title: SHUTTLE MAY MAKE MORE DESERT TESTS
description: Astronauts may not be landing the space shuttle on a runway until sometime next year because project officials are considering perhaps two more test landings on the desert floor to be sure of the vehicle's performance.

title: The Region in Summary; Card Counters Win This Hand
description: Gambling casinos don't have to give their patrons an even break, but in Atlantic City, at least, they can't bar players simply because they do better than break even. So the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled last week in a case that pitted casino owners against highly skilled blackjack players.

title: SHEARER UP BY 5 ON 64-200
description: Bob Shearer, who is riding the hottest streak on the PGA Tour, opened a five-stroke lead today in the third round of the Houston Open with a 64, seven under par for the Woodlands Country Club. He swept by Ed Sneed, the leader after the first two rounds, who in effect stood still with a par 71.

title:
VIEW OF SPORT;
WYNN'S BETTER-LATE-THAN-NEVER 300TH
description: WELL, I sent Gaylord Perry a telegram early last week about his 300th victory. The telegram said: ''Good luck, but don't be in too big a hurry. Wait and go for No.300 next Tuesday or Wednesday and I will be in Seattle to broadcast the game.''

title: SAVING THE PLAN TO SAVE THE SUBWAYS
description: By the end of last summer, things were looking up for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and for the 4 million passengers who use its subway, bus and commuter rail lines each day. The New York Legislature had enacted a host of taxes to raise $793 million to help cover the cost of running the system. Richard Ravitch, the authority chairman, had put together an ambitious $7.2 billion capital program to help rebuild it.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: A stream of environmental legislation continues to flow from the halls of the State House. Following are a few examples: (1) - Four beverage-container deposit bills have been introduced so far this year and assigned to the Assembly's Committee on Agriculture and the Environment. About 30 Assemblymen have indicated a willingness to support or co-sponsor a ''bottle bill'' (41 votes are required for passage).

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: The Many Ways To Catch Smelt
description: ALTHOUGH overshadowed by the spring spawning runs of the larger shad and alewives, the smelt's identical endeavor is greeted with delight by many fishermen.

title: The Nation in Summary; Inching Toward 'New Federalism'
description: Officials of the National Governors Association last week said they had moved a notch nearer an agreement with the Administration that might take the stalled ''new federalism'' off the drawing boards.

title: BRITISH TASK FORCE COSTS $365 MILLION
description: The cost of stationing Britain's military task force in the South Atlantic has reached at least $365 million, and could climb far higher, according to military experts here.

title: Politics; KOCH AND CUOMO LINES FORM
description: THE contest between Mayor Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination has already started in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which will cast at least 14 percent of the vote at the Democratic State Committee designating meeting in mid-June.

title: Around the Nation; Governor Says Florida May Help Refugees Move
description: Florida might help Cuban and Haitian refugees whose Federal aid is expiring to move to states that have better benefits, Gov. Bob Graham said today.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices; DANCE
description: For years people have been saying that Dan Wagoner resembles a cherub. And Mr. Wagoner, a former member of the Martha Graham, Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor companies, has been making warm-hearted dances for 14 years - dances that often look to a gentler past or celebrate some private moment or nostalgic giddiness.

title: 2 Geneva Banks Are Bombed
description: Bombs exploded at two downtown Geneva banks, causing considerable damage but no injuries, the police said today.

title: WHERE PEOPLE LIVED, LOVED AND MADE ART
description: THIS WAS HARLEM A Cultural Portrait, 1900-50. By Jervis Anderson. Illustrated. 390 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Wendy Whiteman Is Bride Of William L. McLean 4th
description: Wendy Ruth Whiteman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Whiteman Jr. of Canaan, N.Y., was married in Hawley, Pa., yesterday to William L. McLean 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. McLean 3d of Wynnewood, Pa. The Rev. Loren House Jr., a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Blooming Grove Club.

title: Person-to-Person
description: To the Editor: Regarding the article ''Travel Tips for Europe'' (Travel Advisory, April 18), there is really no need to make a person-to-person call from Germany.

title: FRESH AIR FUND SEEKS HOST FAMILIES
description: WHEN Kristin Neufeld piled the four youngsters into her 11-year-old Volkswagen van, it looked, she said,''like an ethnic wagon.'' Pressed against the windows, she said, were faces belonging to ''two Japanese girls, one black boy and one racially mixed boy.'' The Japanese girls and the racially mixed boy were Mrs. Neufeld's adopted children. The fourth youngster was her Fresh Air Fund child last summer.

title: A Steel Scapegoat
description: To the Business Editor: I was distressed to read ''In Ohio, the Enemy Is Japan'' (April 25). The narrow focus of the article and the photo of workers tearing down a Japanese flag reflects neither the basic problems facing American industry, nor the solution being developed. Instead, it perpetuates the emotional view of Japan as the bad guy and the American producers as the good guy.

title: Miss Cortes Is Married To Sterling Stoudemire
description: Dora-Beatriz Cortes, who is with the international department of Goldman Sachs & Company, was married yesterday to Sterling Cranford Stoudemire, who is with the government bond department of Kidder, Peabody & Company. The ceremony was performed in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Anthony Della Villa and the Rev. Peter James Lee, an Episcopal priest of Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Cubs 3, Astros 2
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Bump Wills scored one run and singled in another to pace Chicago. Wills bunted for a hit in the first inning, stole second and went to third on a passed ball by Alan Ashby.

title: Mary Chamberlin Engaged To William A. Durgin Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Stephen Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Katherine Chamberlin, to William Augustine Durgin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Durgin of Newport, R.I.

title: Margaret Ruth Brungraber Is Married
description: Margaret Ruth Brungraber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Brungraber of Lewisburg, Pa., was married yesterday to John C. Ruttenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Derald H. Ruttenberg of New York. Mayor Winthrop Pike of Princeton, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Prospect House in Princeton.

title: John Graves to Wed Donna Schneider
description: Donna Schneider, a trust representative with the Fidelity Service Company in Boston, and John P. Graves, who is a public accountant with Coopers & Lybrand in Boston, plan to be married June 12.

title: Sports People; Expos Drop Scott
description: The Montreal Expos dropped Rodney Scott, an infielder with lots of base-running speed but not enough hits, from their roster. The 28-year-old Scott, who batted only .205 last season but stole 30 bases, was hitting .200 this season in 25 times at bat.

title: Visit of Pope Protested By 2,000 in Liverpool
description: About 2,000 demonstrators opposed to Pope John Paul II's planned visit to Britain marched peacefully through central Liverpool today led by fife-and-drum bands of the Orange Lodge, a Protestant group.

title:
Long Island Guide;
TO THE HUNT
description: If not exactly a thriving pastime these days in suburbia, fox hunting is still alive and well on the Island. And members of the Smithtown Hunt, which in 1900 was recognized by the Master of Foxhounds Association in America and remains one of the top hunts in the country today, will be on hand today at Old Westbury Gardens to tell the public all about their sport. From 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. the aficionados, in full-color dress, will lecture on and demonstrate such subjects as equipment, courtesy in the field, terminology and history. The gardens are on Old Westbury Road, and admission is $3 or $1 for children 6 to 12 years old; an additional $2 and $1, respectively, for admission to Westbury House; or $2 for both for the elderly.SLAVIC BAROQUE

title: VANITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Teen-Ager Cleared of Charges In Jersey City Blaze Fatal to 4
description: Authorities have dropped charges against a teen-ager accused of setting fire last week to a house his father owned here and causing the deaths of four children found trapped in a shower stall.

title: EXECUTIVE PAY RISING
description: Recent statistics confirm that the recession and a slower rate of inflation are having a tangible impact on wage settlements among organized workers: First-year pay increases on contracts negotiated in the first quarter rose a paltry 2.2 percent. But assessments of trends in executive compensation differ on just how much the downturn is affecting what managers are paid.

title: Rent-Control Increases
description: Question:I live in a rent-controlled apartment. I am aware that the landlord can legally raise my rent 7.5 percent a year, but is the landlord required to perform certain maintenance to gain the 7.5 percent increase? Also, how can one obtain lists of rent-controlled apartments? ... T.T., Manhattan Answer:Yes, the landlord is required to perform certain maintenance to gain the annual rent increase. According to city rent-control officials, the landlord must certify to the Office of Rent and Housing Maintenance that he has removed any and all hazardous violations and 80 percent of any lesser code violations. The landlord must also certify that he is spending 90 percent of the building's revenue for the operation and maintenance of the property.

title: Westchester Guide; TROUT CLOSE TO HOME
description: ''Late May is the best time to fish the Amawalk Outlet.'' So says the Croton Watershed Guide, published by the Croton Watershed chapter of Trout Unlimited, a national nonprofit conservation organization with more than 25,000 members. Fly-fishermen who are new to the county may not be aware of the availability of trout streams so close to home.

title: 'MAKING PEOPLE LAUGH IS A HIGH CALLING'
description: Robert Klein is in his ''funky room,'' a room with a view of the upper floors of several other New York City cooperatives, a space painted flat, dull blue all over, its shelves filled with Robert Klein albums and the albums of others, Robert Klein cassettes and the videotaped works of others, books and films of those he has learned from including W.C. Fields and the Marx Brothers. There is a television set, a couple of deep leather chairs, one by Eames, a desk full of litter and a wheelless exercise cycle.

title: Florida Tech Crew Excels at Vail Event
description: Florida Institute of Technology was the big winner at the Dad Vail Regatta today, capturing the Tom Conville Cup for varsity heavyweight crews and the Jack Bratten Point Trophy for overall regatta results.

title: OBSCURE VARIATIONS CALL FOR GREAT CARE
description: The opening theory most to be distrusted is that which deals with obscure or rarely played variations. Conclusions about them are based on too few examples to be reliable, and in these meager samples, brilliant play by one side may conceal the truth that the other side defended dismally. The upshot is that the supposed test cases were nothing more than evidence of human fallibility. Yet this is all that books of theory are largely based on.

title:
INVESTING;
GOLD'S GLITTER THROUGH DARK GLASSES
description: Just how far can gold slide? Recession, unusual Soviet selling, high interest rates and declining inflation have knocked the stuffing out of gold. Not even a full-fledged shooting war has managed to revive the precious metal, traditionally the first refuge of frightened money.

title: ABUSE OF ELDERLY IS DISCUSSED
description: SOCIAL service workers and professionals who work with the elderly gathered recently at Westchester Community College for the first conference in the county to address the growing problem of abuse of the elderly.

title: COMPULSORY ALCOHOLISM TREATMENT GAINING
description: Programs under which alcoholics are being coerced into treatment are being adopted in many states and foreign countries, according to a 60-nation survey by the International Council on Alcohol and Addictions.

title: THE INTENSE WORLD OF JOHN TONELLI
description: WHEN they were just boys, 16 or 17 years old, John Tonelli and Mike McEwen played junior hockey together for the T oronto Marlboros. One night, they went with a group of teammates to s ee a new movie, ''The Exorcist.''

title: MCENROE IS TOPPLED BY DIBBS, LENDI BEATS CLERC IN SEMIFINAL
description: Goals? What goals, Eddie Dibbs asked yesterday. He had just eliminated the top-seeded John McEnroe, 7-6, 6-3, in the semifinals of the $300,000 Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills.

title: BLUE JAYS 2, ROYALS 1
description: Willie Upshaw tripled in a run in the first inning today to help the Toronto Blue Jays to a 2-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: HEEDING CALL OF THE 'GORGEOUS' BASSOON
description: SYOSSET WHEN it comes to virtuoso solo instruments, the bassoon doesn't rank high on the musical public's hit parade. Despite a heady history that saw the woodwind emerge as a star of 18th- and 19th-century ensembles -Vivaldi wrote more than 30 concertos for it, for example - the bassoon generally has been a stepchild of the concert stage.

title: RESIGNATION AT HARVESTER
description: International Harvester's beleaguered chairman, Archie McCardell, (left) stepped down Monday at his board's request.

title: CITIZENS ON WATCH FOR CRIME
description: IN Camden and Burlington Counties, growing numbers of respectable citizens - grocers and grandmothers, laborers and lawyers - have taken to roaming their neighborhoods, often late at night, looking for trouble.

title: Susan Marie McGuirk Is Wed to Matthew C. Blank
description: Susan Marie McGuirk and Matthew Charles Blank, who are with Home Box Office Inc. in New York, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Robert Keck, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Douglas Riva, Pianist, Interprets Granados
description: Enrique Granados's piano music has a virile lyricism, but an active imagination is required to bind its broad rhythmic and melodic strokes into dramatic coherence. Such an engagement with the music was missing when Douglas Riva played a program of the piano works at his recital at Town Hall Tuesday afternoon as part of the Dollar Debut Series.

title: CONTEMPORARY MODERNISTS-A DREADFUL MOUTHFUL
description: LIVING BY FICTION By Annie Dillard. 192 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: PEACEMAKERS STRIVING TO AVERT WIDER WAR
description: WASHINGTON UNITED States officials, trying with little success last week to halt the dangerous conflict in the Falklands, began examining the lessons to be drawn from their frustrating experiences. As Britain raised the pressure again, threatening to attack Argentine ships and planes that venture beyond the country's 12-mile territorial waters, senior American officials warned that unless Buenos Aires could be persuaded to withdraw its troops from the islands in return for a cease-fire, London was virtually certain to increase the level of fighting.

title: Wrong Name Given In Chaucer Contest
description: The winner of the Chaucer-reading contest held on the Florham-Madison campus of Fairleigh-Dickinson University was Elwood Verduin of Philadelphia, who was graduated from the university last year.

title: MUST WE PAY FOR NEGLECT IN LIVES?
description: THE heat was intense as we moved down the long corridor. Not only was it a difficult blaze, but the July heat made things even worse as we struggled to get the best of the flames.

title: TALKING SENSE
description: Here is how several well-known men and women, of different ages and professions, treat their skin in the sun. Some venture out in all types of weather. Others avoid the sun with a passion. And still others seek extra precautions, having learned from painful experience that the sun can burn and blemish the skin. Here is how several well-known men and women, of different ages and professions, treat their skin in the sun. Some venture out in all types of weather. Others avoid the sun with a passion. And still others seek extra precautions, having learned from painful experience that the sun can burn and blemish the skin. REPRESENTATIVE MILLICENT FENWICK, Republican of New Jersey: I wish I had been far less careless about my skin in the sun. Only now that my cousin Mary has given me a bottle of Oil of Olay have I started taking care of my skin. But the time to have started all this was in my late 20's, long before wrinkles. GEORGE FOSTER, left fielder for the New York Mets:

title: Kim Davies Plans Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Edward Alfred Davies of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Kim West Davies, to Carey Alexander O'Rielly, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Crothers O'Rielly of Carmel, Calif.

title: HAWAII G.O.P. LEGISLATORS ASSAIL VOTING PLAN
description: A State Republican Party challenge to a reapportionment plan has backfired, in the opinion of most Republican legislators. They feel that the voting plan that came about as a result will diminish their power in the 76-seat Legislature where they are already in the minority.

title: Joan Schaff Is the Bride Of a Doctor
description: Joan Alice Schaff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Schaff Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Victor Paul Terranova, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Terranova of Little Falls, N.J. The Rev. Robert Nelson Back performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: SUMMER JOBS LAG AS U.S. CUTS FUNDS
description: IT will be more difficult this season for youths to find summer employment on the Island than last year because Federal funds provided to Nassau and Suffolk Counties to hire economically disadvantaged youths have been drastically cut. To take up the slack, the Nassau County Office of Employment and Training, along with the Private Industry Council of Nassau County and the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry, has started a campaign to induce private industry here to hire poor youths, from the ages of 16 to 21, for the summer and possibly for long-term employment.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Sight-Saving Laser Advance
description: When something as beneficent as a technique for saving human eyesight is proven highly successful during an experiment, prolonging the study unnecessarily would involve a kind of cruelty. That was apparently the decision taken by the National Eye Institute, which last week disclosed a new laser procedure for treating senile macular degeneration, the leading cause of blindness among the elderly, two years before the study was to have ended.

title: Allison C. Hague Married
description: Allison Crafts Hague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fremont Hague of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Stephen Sargent, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Sargent of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Yorke Peeler performed the ceremony at the Union Congregational Church. The bride is fabric coordinator for Lord & Taylor in New York.

title: Ann Durell Is Married
description: Ann Durell, publisher, children's books, at E.P. Dutton, was married yesterday in the Calvary Episcopal Church to James T. McCrory, corporate director of public affairs for Borden Inc. The Rev. Stephen S. Garmey performed the ceremony. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mrs. Thomas Durell of Wildwood, N.Y., and the late Mr. Durell. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a son of Mrs. Willard L. McCrory of Sussex, Wis., and the late Mr. McCrory.

title: Theater; 'LOCK UP DAUGHTERS' KEY TO WITTY EVENING
description: IT would be dishonest to say that I found myself involved with the plot of ''Lock Up Your Daughters,'' the musical that has opened the new season at the Goodspeed Opera House. In fact, it was a problem trying to recall who had charged whom with rape in this musical adaptation of Henry Fielding's 18th-century Restoration comedy ''Rape Upon Rape'' - a musical, I hasten to add, in which rape does not occur, either on-or offstage.

title: Food; THOUGHTFUL USES FOR BRAINS AND OTHER VARIETY MEATS
description: IN France and Mediterranean countries, variety meats such as brains, sweetbreads, kidneys and liver are given special respect. But in America these meats are often overlooked, with the result that they can be a bargain.

title: FRESH AIR AND A NEW OUTLOOK
description: IN the spring of 1980, when Claudia Moriarty volunteered to open her home to two little girls from the city as part of the Fresh Air Fund program, it never occurred to her that only two years later she would be in charge of organizing and supervising the program for the entire North Shore of Suffolk County.

title: CRIME
description: Peter Turnbull is a social worker in Glasgow, and in his first novel, DEEP AND CRISP AND EVEN (St. Martin's, $10.95), he stays at home, giving us a procedural about a psychopathic killer who knifes women. With just about nothing to go on, the police swing into action, even recruiting the underworld.

title: WOMEN'S LACROSSE TAKES OFF
description: AT Greenwich Academy on North Maple Road next weekend more than 70 women will be competing in a lacrosse tournament that could lead some of them to national recognition and a trip to England.

title: Around the World; 12 Killed and 50 Wounded In Lebanese Fighting
description: Twelve people were killed and about 50 were wounded last night and today when new fighting broke out between rival groups in the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli, security and party sources said today.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Airship Revival?
description: A few Goodyear blimps were all that were left of a once promising lighter-than-air transportation mode when the Coast Guard proposed in May 1980 to revive such craft.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I plan to vacation in Cuernavaca, Mexico, in July. What health and food precautions should be taken, particularly if I am on a semi-bland diet? - E.C., New York, N.Y. Answer:Among basic precautions (even if you are allowed spicy food): Eat in restaurants; do not buy fresh fruit, tacos or drinks from street vendors. In a restaurant choose dishes that have been cooked; avoid salads and dairy products.

title: The Region in Summary; Death Penalty Clears Senate
description: The debate over whether capital punishment deters crime hardly seems to deter politicians from approving it. In Trenton last week, the Senate, by 31-to-5, voted to make New Jersey the 37th state with a death penalty, and backers predicted the measure would win quick approval in the Assembly.

title: Flying Phones
description: To the Business Editor: The article, ''Communications: A Telephone for Airplanes'' (May 2), describing AirFone's development of public telephones for use by commercial airlines, was an accurate report of this new development.

title: YACHTS TO RACE FOR BIG PURSE
description: A 33-boat fleet that includes some of the foremost European sailors and world's fastest ocean-racing yachts will cross the starting line in the French harbor of La Rochelle at noon next Saturday for the start of a new 5,800-mile trans-Atlantic race to Gulfport, Miss.

title: Future Events Springtime Frolics
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Grateful Alumni May 12 - The parents and alumni of the Riverdale Country School are donating their services and talents to a gala evening to raise funds to renovate the auditorium at the independent co-educational institution in the Bronx. Patrick O'Neal, who has a son at Riverdale, and his brother Michael are arranging the dinner in the school's dining hall. Calvin Hill, former running back for the Dallas Cowboys and a Riverdale alumnus, will be the master of ceremonies at the program to follow in the auditorium. Performers will include alumnae Joanna and Carly Simon, along with their sister Lucy. Tickets, $500 for the whole evening, $100 for the performance only from 549-8838.

title: SUN SENSE
description: The summer beckons, but no matter how brilliant the day, an invisible cloud can lark overhead.

title: Topics; PIERCING SECRETS; 21 and Counting
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that while a casino has the right to rig the odds, it cannot evict the more skillful blackjack players. Only the state's Casino Control Commission can decide rules of play and admission.

title: MRS. KING BEATS MISS HANIKA
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, Billie Jean King and the American teen-ager Lisa Bonder won quaterfinal matches in the $100,000 Italian Women's Open tennis tournament today.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: Once again this year, Europe's big travel bargains include the passes that allow unlimited rail travel within a stipulated period for a flat fee. Before you rush off to buy one, however, be sure that it suits your needs. Otherwise, you may find that instead of saving money you have squandered it. You may also feel pressured to travel when you'd rather settle into a place because as the clock ticks away, you can't bear to have the pass lie unused in your wallet.

title: DAY CARE MAKES SLOW GAINS
description: WITH the encouragement of day-care advocates, some of the Island's corporations have slowly begun to help working parents obtain care for their young children. One company recently set aside money to subsidize the cost of such care, and last fall a day-care center financed in part with corporate contributions opened in Dix Hills.

title: Plastic Trees
description: When the spruce budworm, a timberland scourge that is highly resistant to pesticide programs, infected trees in Ohio, the remedy seemed clear enough: attract insect-eating downy woodpeckers to the forests. The problem was that growers had weeded out the deadwood in which the woodpeckers dig their nesting holes.

title: DECOYS IN SHOW
description: Images of wildlife will abound from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Friday through Sunday at the Burr Homestead, Old Post Road, Fairfield, in a rare exhibition of bird carvings and wildlife paintings.

title: YOUNG OFFENDERS LEARN FLORAL TRADE
description: Spring has never smelled sweeter to most of them. Jimmy Collins, now aged 17, was a confirmed truant when he was picked up for burglary in 1980 and spent two nights on Rikers Island before his mother made his bail and he was put on five years' probation.

title: TASTY SLICES OF RATTIGAN AND BAGNOLD
description: Drama is always a bit like Chicken Little, running about screaming that the sky is falling. And, of course, the sky is always falling, cracking open and tumbling down upon the heads of unlucky individuals or of whole going-to-rot societies. In its two current revivals - well-chosen and handsomely cast - the Roundabout Theater is giving us glimpses of both kinds of catastrophe: Deeply personal in Terence Rattigan's ''The Browning Version,'' sneakily cosmic in Enid Bagnold's ''The Chalk Garden.'' Miss Bagnold's is certainly the more outrageous and in all probability the richer play, but, thanks to happenstance and some very fine stage direction, it is Mr. Rattigan's piece that comes off best this time around.

title: The Region in Summary; Carey's Vetoes Stand, Local Budgets Shake
description: Sometimes, inaction also speaks louder than words. So the Republican-led New York State Senate let virtually all $941 million of Governor Carey's budget vetoes go unchallenged last week, confident Mr. Carey would pay the price for cutting spending.

title: Hard of Hearing Group Receives Service Award
description: The state's Department of Health has cited the New York League for the Hard of Hearing for its 72 years of work in rehabilitating the hearing-impaired.

title:
Gardening;
PERENNIALS VALUED FOR THEIR DIVERSITY
description: MUCH of the value of using perennials in a flower garden lies in their seemingly infinite diversity. In height they vary from a few inches to five or more feet; in their blooming, from early spring until late fall; in foliage texture, from fine to coarse; in form, from narrow, upright spikes to globe-shaped mounds, and in color, from one end of the spectrum to the other. However, this diversity is also the source of the greatest dilemma in their use - the need for careful planning prior to planting. Only the most knowlegeable perennial specialist would plant a border without first sketching out a plan. Even then, most would make changes from year to year to obtain the desired balance and overall effect.

title: PROWLING THE FLEA MARKETS OF THE WORLD
description: For travelers who are addicted to flea markets and bazaars, the hunt is the thing. Few of us ever walk away with priceless items bought for a few coins. But what fun! From the Paris Marche aux Puces to Delhi's Chandni Chowk and from Rome's Porta Portese to Cairo's Khan el-Khalili, I have seen just about everything -mountains of trash (mostly cheap) and a few beauties (usually expensive). My advice; Go to the flea markets of the world but don't expect to get a Ming vase for the price of a cup of coffee.

title: BAKER BATS IN FIVE AS DODGERS WIN, 10-8
description: Dusty Baker led a 15-hit Los Angeles effort with five hits and five runs batted in today as the Dodgers beat the Montreal Expos, 10-8.

title: The World in Summary; 'Frank' Talk About Taiwan
description: Vice President Bush went to China last week to defuse the issue Peking has called a ''time bomb'' for American-Chinese relations. But the clock kept ticking as Mr. Bush heard Deng Xiaoping and other Chinese leaders reiterate that United States arms sales to Taiwan, which Peking regards as an unrecovered province, must cease.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 8 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 3 2 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Ray, $14.50.) Book Two in the science fiction series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 3 2 14 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 4 6 4 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way love the same woman. 5 5 3 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men. 6 4 4 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A greedy crew at work in the world of horse-racing and computer programming. 7 11 3 PUBLIC SMILES, PRIVATE TEARS, by Helen Van Slyke with James Elward. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A woman has to choose between a career and marriage. 8 7 14 A GREEN DESIRE, by Anton Myrer.

title: DONA KATE, A FIRST LADY FROM L.I.
description: The first lady of Puerto Rico looks and sounds as though she was made to order for the job. Often referred to as Dona Kate, she has silky dark hair and expressive brown eyes, speaks Spanish with a Latin lilt, and quietly boasts that she knows the island ''like the palm of my hand.'' In fact, as she is the first to concede, there are some who say she is more Puerto Rican than the Puerto Ricans.

title: NAVY CLEARS NEWS FROM FLEET
description: British correspondents with the Falkland Islands task force must submit their dispatches for approval to military officials before relaying it to London, the Defense Ministry said today. But ''there is certainly no censorship as such,'' a ministry spokesman added.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The romantic revolution. The Borough President of Brooklyn came over the Bridge to Manhattan to welcome the guests at the opening ceremonies. Rosemary Rogers and Jennifer Wilde, a.k.a. Tom E. Huff, told how devoted they were to each other and to each other's novels. One delighted woman won the drawing that entitled her to dinner at a posh French restaurant with an Indian prince, Khedker of Khed Anjanvel, as her escort. Fifty authors autographed books for their fans. At a score of seminars, writers, editors and art directors described how they work. All the while, reporters and television cameramen roved about, looking for good angles for their stories. Such was the spirit of the two-day Romantic Book Lovers Conference, attended by 350 writers and readers from all parts of the country, held last month at New York's storied St. Regis Hotel under the auspices of Long Island University's Institute for Continuing Education and a fan magazine named Romantic Times.

title: BERGEN SHOW INCLUDES HOUSE TOUR
description: HACKENSACK THE banks of the historic Hackensack River will be the setting for an antiques show here next Sunday. About 100 dealers plan to sell from their vehicles on a field where three pre-Revolutionary War houses stand.

title: PATERNITY LEAVE: IS IT A CIVIL RIGHT?
description: NEWTON WHEN Mike Taugher and his wife, Lynn, learned last year that they were expecting a second child, the decision about which of them would stay at home here and care for the baby rested on basic economics.

title: CHINA BOUND? PACK SMART
description: PATRICIA A. LANGAN is a reporter for Fortune magazine. BY PATRICIA A.LANGAN

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Perfectly matched pairs are said to be made in heaven, but with Gordon and Jay Gottlieb, the musical duo takes on a biological tinge. Gordon Gottlieb is a percussionist, Jay a pianist; and their Theater of Piano and Percussion at the Abraham Goodman House Saturday night at 9 will be the music-making of identical twins.

title: Tapestry Artist Defends Her Approach
description: I read with great interest the critique by Patricia Malarcher (March 21) of the tapestries that I recently created for the lobby of Temple Emanu-El in New York City.

title: RECORD UNEMPLOYMENT RATE STIRS ASSESSMENT OF HARDSHIP
description: Although unemployment rose to a 40-year high of 9.4 percent last month, changing patterns of work and the broad availability of unemployment insurance suggest that the overall situation now may not be so bad as it was in 1941, when the effects of the Depression still lingered.

title: Jodi Levy to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Levy of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jodi Lou Levy, to Robert Edward Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Collins of New Hyde Park, L.I. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: CRUEL AND CRUCIAL YEARS
description: STALIN'S SECRET WAR By Nikolai Tolstoy. 463 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $18.50.

title: VANITY
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO NEW DISEASES A THREAT TO CROPS
description: As the spring planting season began in New York this week, upstate farmers were warned to be on the lookout for two new plant diseases that could damage or destroy their corn and alfalfa, two of the state's major crops.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
ONCE AGAIN: DOES THE CAMERA LIE?
description: Does the camera lie, or does it not? There are fashions in answering this question as there are in most other things. When photography was introduced in the 19th century, it was hailed as a truth-teller far superior to painting. Because there was no intervention of the human hand and eye between the subject and the picture, because the picture was ''drawn'' by the action of light on chemicals in a clever little machine, the chances of human error were greatly reduced, if not eliminated.

title: Magic Johnson Learns Lesson
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson, the effervescent Los Angeles Laker, can recall one of the first times he was humbled. He was a 6-foot-6-inch adolescent when his father, Earvin Sr., 6-4, taught him the subtleties of backyard one-on-one at home in East Lansing, Mich.

title: Index; International
description: Bush fails to sway Chinese lead- ers' stand on Taiwan issue 3 U.S.-Canadian ties examined at private conference in Toronto 4 Protection of nuclear storage sites in Europe inadequate 6 Around the World 7 Reagan ready to propose ''sub- limit'' on missile warheads 8 Leader of Oman makes an offi- cial visit to Egypt 8 Israel halts new arms sales to Ar- gentina 16 Stationing British fleet in Falk- lands has cost $365 million 17 Guyana, with eye on Falklands, worry over Venezuelan claims 18 A Thai journalist tackles the country's seamier side 20 Government/Politics Florida's backers of legal gam- bling try again 13 Reagan, in radio speech, urges Congress to act on budget 23 Californal panel urges removal of a Los Angeles judge 24 Hawaii Republican legislators assail voting plan 25 Inquiry on Donovan said to have broadened 39 General National coalition is formed to aid rising number of homeless 14 Jury to consider libel suit against television network 21 Around the Nation 24 Winning lottery just created problems for businessman 28 Device that killed woman con- tained threats to her family 30 Program turns ex-youth offend- ers into apprentice florists 34 Two new diseases a threat to al- falfa and feed corn crops 39 Health/Science Compulsory alcoholism treat- ment gaining in U.S. 10 Arts/Entertainment Miami taking risk with arts festi- val next month 38 Fairytale turned into children's opera ''Nightingale'' 44 Eric Burdon, early British rock leader, making comeback 45 The debuts of young musicians are reviewed 45 School of American Ballet presents workshop program 48 Court upholds ruling on stolen Durer paintings 48 Alvin Ailey Dance Theater re- vives ''Streams'' of 1970 48 Obituaries Neil Bogart, entertainment exec- utive 32 Style Dona Kate, a First Lady from Long Island 49 News Analysis Drew Middleton examines Brit- ain's military options 16

title: THE TROPIC OF MILLER
description: ''Black Messiah: A Tribute to Henry Miller,'' edited by John Bennett and including essays by Erica Jong, Norman Mailer and Alfred Perles, is a current example of the way Henry Miller has been stubbornly misunderstood ever since he published ''Tropic of Cancer'' in 1934. Though T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound and William Carlos Williams also praised Miller, no other American writer has been so congratulated and censured for being what he was not.

title: John McDermott, Margaret Hiscano Will Be Married
description: The engagement of Margaret Heyn Hiscano to John J. McDermott has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raphael A. Hiscano of Short Hills and Andover, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Eileen F. McDermott of Norwalk, Conn., and Peter A. McDermott of Annapolis, Md.

title: A Correction
description: A caption under a picture of the Long Island Vocal Ensemble in last week's Long Island Weekly should have read: From left, Jean Anderson, Peter Pesco, Martha Tibbetts, Ron Meixsell and Mary Grudzinski.

title: Phillies 5, Padres 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Mike Schmidt hit a home run, two singles, drove in three runs and stole a base as Philadelphia posted its sixth consecutive victory.

title: At Least 1 Dead in Fire
description: Fire broke out in an high-rise condominium building this evening, killing at least one person and forcing at least 200 residents from their rooms, a fire department spokesman said. The fire at the Inwood Manor Condominiums began at about 8:30 P.M., according to a statement by the spokesman, Johnny Ogg of the Houston Fire Department. At least two firemen were injured in the blaze, which was brought under control by 8:50 P.M., he said.

title: INQUIRY ON DONOVAN SAID TO HAVE BROADENED
description: The special prosecutor appointed five months ago to investigate corruption charges against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan has expanded his inquiry well beyond the initial allegation that led to his appointment, according to officials familiar with the investigation.

title: Elizabeth Brown, T.A. Dubbs Wed
description: Elizabeth Margaret Ruth Brown, a lawyer with Ogilvy & Mather International Inc., an advertising agency in New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Allan Dubbs, an associate with the New York law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside & Wolff. Justice Arnold L. Fein of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony in the Union Club.

title: CANDIDATES IN 2 CITIES FACING JUDGES, TOO
description: NEWARK VOTERS going to the polls here Tuesday will confront ballots on which the two leading contenders in the mayoral race - Kenneth A. Gibson, the incumbent, and City Council President Earl Harris - are under indictment.

title: ROCK: ERIC BURDON BACK
description: Eric Burdon, the leader of the Animals, one of the earliest and finest British Invasion groups from the 1960's, has been an important unsung influence on younger rock singers, among them Bruce Springsteen. And on Thursday at the Ritz, where he played his first New York performance in many years, the 41-year-old singer displayed enough gusto, stamina and humor to suggest that he has the potential to mount a full-scale comeback.

title: SWELLING DEBT LEVELS
description: Volatile swings in long- and medium-term interest rates, which have pushed more and more corporations to the short-term credit window over the last several years, are having the same effect on borrowings by developing countries. As a result, a recent report suggests that conventional methods of measuring the debt of developing countries may understate the financing problems these nations face.

title:
Gardening;
PERENNIALS VALUED FOR THEIR DIVERSITY
description: MUCH of the value of using perennials in a flower garden lies in their seemingly infinite diversity. In height they vary from a few inches to five or more feet; in their blooming, from early spring until late fall; in foliage texture, from fine to coarse; in form, from narrow, upright spikes to globe-shaped mounds, and in color, from one end of the spectrum to the other. However, this diversity is also the source of the greatest dilemma in their use - the need for careful planning prior to planting. Only the most knowlegeable perennial specialist would plant a border without first sketching out a plan. Even then, most would make changes from year to year to obtain the desired balance and overall effect.

title: WITHERS CAPTURED BY ALOMA'S RULER
description: Almost everyone at Aqueduct yesterday expected that a speedy 3-year-old colt who won the Withers Stakes might have a lot to say about the outcome of the Preakness Stakes next Saturday. But few expected that the colt would be Aloma's Ruler and not Shimatoree.

title: AGGIE GREY'S A FABLED INN
