description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, a retired Times correspondent, lives in Honolulu. BY ROBERT TRUMBULL
To the Editor:

title:
Art;
A CLOSE-UP ON CURRENT PHOTOGRAPHY
description: OF all the museums and galleries in the Westchester-Rockland area, none is more dedicated to serious and wide-ranging exploration of the art of our own day than the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill. The latest in its series of exhibitions of contemporary art is devoted to color photographs, entitled ''Artist Photographers and a Photographer of Art,'' and it will be on view only through next Sunday.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Seven Moons' ''Madonna of the Seven Moons'' (1946) is a strange one, seldom shown but oddly satisfying, although it also taxes credibility -it will shown Sunday at 12:30 A.M. on Channel 9. Based on a supposedly true case of schizophrenia, it centers on a sedate wife and mother, in a Florentine villa, who every six years resumes another kind of existence with a band of predatory gypsies, including a handsome, evil lover.

title: PROFESSORS WORK FOR BOSSES, TOO
description: Time used to be when unions were a blue-collar custom, and doing without them was one sign of a profession's prestige. No longer. Under the pressure of tighter budgets and reduced employment opportunities, one after another profession - doctors, engineers, symphony musicians - has gone the collective bargaining route. The latest group to succumb to the advantages of unionization are university faculties. They have been organizing rapidly, especially at public colleges and the large university systems, such as the State University of New York, the State University System of Florida, the New Jersey State College System and the University of Connecticut.

title: DESCENT INTO THE SAMARIA
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The Times from Athens. By PAUL ANASTASI

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Daniel Berman, Pianist, Plays Bach to Earl Wild
description: Daniel Berman, a young pianist who has studied in New York and West Germany, played Bach, Schumann, Beethoven and some Earl Wild arrangements of Gershwin songs at Carnegie Recital Hall on May 1.

title:
ANTIQUES;
130 DISPLAYS AT OUTDOOR SHOW
description: WOODBRIDGE STORAGE boxes made of a variety of materials, dating from early in the 18th century through the middle of the 19th century, will be featured in numerous exhibits next Saturday at the 10th annual Woodbridge Outdoor Antiques Festival.

title: MOTHERS-AND THE BEGINING AND END OF LIFE
description: I learned just recently when human life begins. This question has plagued man through the ages, and for centuries it has been the subject of study, decisions, reconsideration and new conclusions.

title: MOTHERS-AND THE BEGINING AND END OF LIFE
description: MOTHER'S DAY will not be the same this year without my mother-inlaw. Mama Lutto died last January, ending a career in the strangest cottage industry that I ever saw: macaroni-stringing.

title: Mailbox; Ruling on Borg Hurts the Sport To the Sports Editor:
description: Harry Hopman is right (''Everyone Loses When Borg Sits Out the Big Ones,'' The New York Times, May 2). Everyone loses when Bjorn Borg does'nt play.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Wuthering Heights' Yes, there's a second version, usually thrown away at a late hour, and it's extremely interesting. In contrast to Hollywood's great romantic beauty adapted from the Emily Bronte novel, this is realistic, piercing drama.

title: RED SOX DOWN RANGERS, 2-1
description: Chuck Rainey and Mark Clear combined on a six-hitter and Jerry Remy scored the winning run after reaching base on an error in the sixth inning as the Boston Red Sox beat the Texas Rangers tonight, 2-1.

title: Letters; First Apartments
description: To the Editor:

title: China Criticizes Britain For Widened Blockade
description: China accused Britain today of embarrassing nations seeking a peaceful solution to the Falkland crisis by widening its blockade against Argentine warships and aircraft.

title: A NEW LOOK FOR THIRD AVENUE
description: THREE megastructures, all of them taller than anything that now e xists on the prime residential-retail section of Third Avenue north o f 60th Street, are being planned for full blockfront sites along thea venue.

title: Miss Ryder Is a Bride
description: Pamela Mary Ryder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Ryder of Watertown, Conn., and Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to William Bartram Fox, son of James B. Fox of Darien, Conn., and the late Mrs. Fox. The Rev. Jeffrey L. Kittredge performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Watertown.

title: City Council Schedule For This Week Listed
description: The following City Council activities scheduled for this week are open to the public: MONDAY - The Committee on State Legislation, 11 A.M., City Hall.

title: SELF-HELP FINANCING FOR COOPERATIVES
description: AS condominiums and cooperatives must repair or replace roofs, b oilers and pool decks or make other large capital expenditures, theya re finding that high interest rates and unpredictable loan terms a re making bank financing unattractive.

title: Vanity
description: To the Editor: I write to correct an important error of omission in N.R. Kleinfield's discussion of Marquis James as a writer of corporatefunded trade books in the article ''The Business of Vanity and Vice Versa'' (March 28). Mention is made of the unusually high price Mr. James could command for business histories, but not of the very unusual provision without which he would never have written them. This was a contractual agreement that if there were anything the company wanted added, deleted or changed in any way which did not seem consonant with the facts as he saw them, his name could not be used. Thus, he hardly ''hired himself out as a corporate pen.'' Indeed, he held to the agreement so rigorously that one book was delayed for months before the company finally gave in on a disputed passage, and an entire biography of the fascinating founder of a large company has never been published

title: THRIVING PACE U. IS EXPANDING AGAIN
description: FOR more than a decade, Pace University's president, Dr. Edward J. Mortola, has been reaching out to educate new college populations. ''We're a hands-on school,'' he said last week, describing how the school prepares older men and women for today's business world and how it teaches those seeking more traditional liberal-arts and science training.

title: COUNTY OFFICIALS REACT TO THE BUDGET DECISION
description: THE decision last week by the State Senate to abandon efforts to override Governor Carey's budget vetoes resolved a major impasse in Albany but created severe new problems in Westchester communities, which now face the loss of millions of dollars in assistance.

title: Virginia Reynolds Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton 4th of Richmond have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hamilton's daughter, Virginia Weir Reynolds, to Michael Raeburn Parker, son of H. Lawrence Parker of Bedford, N.Y., and Mrs. David Delamater Mackintosh of Dover, Mass.

title: A Plague Of Coyotes Peter Steinhart's article brings to light the sad story of the California child who died from an alleged coyote attack this past summer (''A Plague of Coyotes,'' March 28). Equally disheartening, however, is the death of three Oklahoma children who ingested a compound called 1080, even after the 1972 ban on its use as a poison to destroy coyotes. Although it has been proved deadly, the Environmental Protection Agency is currently considering its reauthorization.
description: As the author points out, compound 1080 is nonselective. This poison is known to have killed countless numbers of wildlife, including eagles, black-footed ferrets, bobcats, foxes, racoons and badgers, as well as domestic dogs.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RISES TO 9.4%, A POSTWAR RECORD
description: Unemployment rose to 9.4 percent in April, a postwar record and up from 9 percent in March, the Labor Department said. The Democrats used the report to sharply criticize the President's economic program.

title: NO MORE DEFICITS-OR ONLY SMALLER ONES?
description: WITH the Republicans controlling the Senate and President Reagan now urging public support, this year could bring the first full test of of the idea of a ''balanced-budget amendment'' to the Constitution - a notion that has been circulating in conservative circles for several years.

title: On Appointing A Nassau Judge
description: The impetus for this letter is the article by Frank Lynn (Politics column, April 25) concerning the delay in commencement of confirmation hearings on Abbey Boklan's appointment for a Nassau County Court judgeship. Mr. Lynn reports that State Senator Barclay, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, acknowledges that he is ''holding up'' the hearings at the request of the Nassau Republican organization.

title: REVIVAL ON L.I.
description: For nearly a century until it closed in 1971, the Garden City Hotel was one of the more familiar fixtures of the Long Island landscape. The four-story red brick structure, torn down three years later, had a rich history, serving as the suburban headquarters for New York society figures including the Morgans, Vanderbilts, Whitneys and Belmonts.

title: TOKYO'S TRENDIEST BOUTIQUES
description: TERRY TRUCCO is a freelance writer living in Tokyo. By TERRY TRUCCO

title: Numismatics; Washington Half Dollar
description: The United States Mint has finally removed the wraps from the new George Washington commemorative half dollar and the coin will portray the nation's first president on horseback. Months of official silence on the subject ended at last on April 27, when the Mint released preliminary sketches of the coin, the first new U.S. commemorative coin in three decades.

title: John Joseph Sheehan 3d Marries Lucy Hutchinson
description: Lucy Gordon Hutchinson and John Joseph Sheehan 3d were married yesterday in St. John of the Cross Roman Catholic Church in Middlebury, Conn. The Rev. John G. Fanning performed the ceremony.

title: THAI JOURNALIST TACKLES COUNTRY'S SEAMIER SIDE
description: The 26-year-old woman who has edited this provincial capital's only daily newspaper for the last three years, still prints articles about the robberies, killings, bombings, kidnappings, official corruption and extortion by gangsters in southern Thailand.

title: Tall Ships In Virginia
description: With their soaring masts, rakish bowsprits and gleaming canvas, the tall ships seem to be the sine qua non of celebrations these days. Next month, such vessels as the Sagres from Portugal, the Bluenose II from Canada and the Eagle, Providence and Pride of Baltimore from the United States are scheduled to make port at Norfolk, Va., for the city's annual Harborfest.

title: Guidebooks
description: To the Editor: To supplement the excellent article on guidebooks ''Baedeker and His Heirs'' (Travel, April 18) I must mention the publication ''The Ireland Guide'' published by the Irish Tourist Board that is a must for anyone touring Ireland.

title: The World in Summary; Playing Nice In Salvador
description: After weeks of wrangling, Salvadoran politicians were on their best behavior last week. Roberto d'Aubuisson, leader of the far-right Nationalist Republican Alliance, went so far as to administer the oath of office to Alvaro Magana and to warmly embrace the new provisional President, whose nomination Mr. d'Aubuisson had bitterly opposed. Mr. Magana, in turn, called for unity and installed a Cabinet that gave nearly equal representation to the nation's three major political parties - the Christian Democrats, the Nationalist Republicans and the conservative National Conciliation Party.

title: JUILLIARD PLAYS WOLFE'S NO. 6
description: The principal interest at the Juilliard Symphony's Alice Tully Hall concert Friday night was Stanley Wolfe's Symphony No. 6. Mr. Wolfe describes his music as aloof from most present-day musical fashions. It may have been aloof from one contemporary musical world - the postwar avant-garde - but it was dangerously chummy with another.

title: BRITONS TRY TO SORT OUT LESSONS OF SHEFFIELD'S LOSS
description: Rodney Johnson looked down from the cab of his truck, momentarily distracted from the squawking on his radio of a debate over the role various sophisticated new weapons played in the destruction of the destroyer Sheffield.

title: Anglican Primate Bids British Weigh Effects of New Action
description: LONDON (AP) - The Most Rev. Robert Runcie, the Archbishop of Canterbury, said today that Britain's conflict with Argentina over the Falkland Islands had entered a new phase and British leaders must now weigh the cost of new military moves against their possible benefit.

title: Mark Haesloop Weds Mary C. McCarthy
description: Mary Catherine McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence McCarthy of Ridgefield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Mark Haesloop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gordon Haesloop of Roslyn Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Charles W. Stubbs performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Music; BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL LEADS BUSY WEEK
description: ''IT'S our big bang to end the season,'' P.J. Prokop, promotion director of the Hartford Symphony, said about the orchestra's third Beethoven Festival. ''It's also our most ambitious festival to date, with more concerts than before, more soloists and a debut guest conductor, and everybody here is really very excited about the way our listeners have been responding. The chamber concerts are already sold out, and we're hoping the weekend orchestral programs will do just as well.''

title: MAKING UNREALISTIC PLANS FOR IMPROBABLE NUCLEAR ACCIDENTS
description: The principle is simple: There is no ''threshold'' dose of radiation below which exposure is guaranteed harmless. It's the corollary that's troublesome: Any plan to protect the public from radiation released in a nuclear power plant accident must be suspect, since such a plan assumes certain ''permissible'' doses.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CRAFTS
description: MONTCLAIR THE current rash of exhibitions of glass art has spread to the Montclair Art Museum, where innovative works by 10 members of the New York Experimental Glass Workshop are now on view.

title: CANADIAN-U.S. TIES CRITIQUED IN TALKS
description: Concerned over deterioration in relations between Canada and the United States in recent months, three dozen businessmen, lawyers and former Government officials from both sides gathered here this week in an unusual three-day series of private meetings.

title: Sports People; Resch Wins Trophy
description: Glenn (Chico) Resch, goaltender for the Colorado Rockies of the National Hockey league, was named recipient of the Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy.

title: N.F.L. WEIGHS NEXT MOVE AFTER VERDICT
description: The National Football League, a symbol of strength and stability in professional sports, was close to turmoil yesterday, one day after having lost its court struggle to keep the Oakland Raiders from moving to Los Angeles.

title: The World in Summary; Bolt From The Bench
description: Fiddling with Government examinations is not unheard of in the Philippines, but a scandal implicating President Ferdinand E. Marcos's hand-picked Supreme Court may be in a class by itself. Justice Ameurfina Melencio-Herrera disclosed that her colleagues had fixed the bar exam scores so that Justice Gustavo Ericta's son would pass.

title: Toyland
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article by Paul Lewis ''What's Doing in Monaco'' (Travel, April 11) but was sorry to see that he neglected to mention the National Museum, with its collection of automatons and dolls dating from the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: SUMMER SENSE
description: Summer. It's a time when almost everyone wants to look their best, feel their best, play their best. The challenge, though, is how to achieve that healthy glow without damaging the skin. It is a question of degree and of discipline. There was a time, around the turn of the century, when women took every precaution to keep the sun off their faces, wearing wide-brimmed hats and shouldering parasols. Then in the 1920's, Coco Chanel, the legendary Paris designer, launched sunbathing as an ''in'' - that is to say, acceptable - sport as she exposed her face and figure to the sun for hours. And thus, starting with a few fashionable imitators, the pursuit of suntanned bodies proliferated into an international mania. Later, in the 1950's, the bikini also started to gain acceptability, appearing more and more frequently on public beaches. After that, it was only a matter of time before topless beaches sprang up all over Europe and the United States. As swimwear covered less and less, the yearning for deep, dark tanned bodies increased more and more.

title: BUENOS AIRES SAYS IT IS RESUPPLYING TROOPS BY AIR
description: Argentine military spokesmen said today that the Government had resumed resupplying its troops on the Falkland Islands by air and that its forces were ignoring the blockade of the Argentine coast announced by Britain.

title: MAKING THE OXBRIDGE CONNECTION
description: JAQUELINE WREN, a writer who lives in China, earned an M.A. at Oxford after studying there at St. Hilda's College. By JAQUELINE WREN

title: The World in Summary; Claiming More Land of Israel
description: Giving up Sinai has not only stiffened Israel's resolve to hold remaining occupied territory but appears to have revived claims, at least rhetorically, to a larger ''Eretz Israel.''

title: No Headline
description: Earnie Shavers opened a deep cut over Joe Bugner's eye and stopped the Briton at 2 minutes 14 seconds of the second round in their scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout tonight.

title: DIED AND SURVIVED
description: SELECTED POEMS By Alexander Blok. Translated by Alex Miller. Introduction by Pavel Antokolsky. 327 pp. Moscow: Progress Publishers. Distributed by Imported Publications, Chicago. $9. HAMAYUN The Life of Alexander Blok. By Vladimir Orlov. Translated by Olga Shartse. 477 pp. Moscow: Progress Publishers. Distributed by Imported Publications, Chicago. $14.50. THE LIFE OF ALEKSANDR BLOK By Avril Pyman. Volume I: The Distant Thunder 1880-1908. Illustrated. 359 pp. $24.95. Volume II: The Release of Harmony 1908-21. Illustrated. 421 pp. $39.50. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: U.S. Holds Nuclear Test
description: Scientists detonated the seventh announced underground nuclear test of 1982 Friday at the Nevada Test Site, 80 miles north of Las Vegas. The device was exploded after a delay of more than 24 hours because of adverse weather conditions.

title: ECONOMIC HISTORY, AS REAGAN TELLS IT
description: One of the clever things President Reagan has done as he tries to squeeze inflation out of the system by putting the economy through a recession ''wringer'' is to boldly proclaim that 40 years of ''economic mismanagement'' cannot be remedied in a year or two.

title: About Long Island
description: OCEANSIDE ''FOUR doctors!'' the man in the bed near the hall said when Dr. Alan Geller, the preceptor, and Alicia Romano and G. Lawrence McNally, the first-year medical students in charge, and the Observer walked into the room at South Nassau Communities Hospital. ''Ah,'' the man said, ''doctors make too much money. They don't know what to do with it.''

title: Hot Line for Employers
description: The Nassau County Office of Employment and Training has a hot line - 483-4777 - available for employers who wish to hire youths for summer employment or who are interested in more information about the RISE program.

title: FAIRNESS OF REAGAN'S CUTOFFS OF DISABILITY AID QUESTIONED
description: In the last seven months the Reagan Administration has ended disability insurance benefits for more than 106,000 families, including some who are almost certainly entitled to them, according to Federal and state officials.

title: U.S. PROPOSE SUBLIMIT ON MISSILE WARHEADS
description: President Reagan is expected to propose to the Soviet Union that coming talks on limiting strategic nuclear set a ceiling of 2,500 warheads on land-based intercontinental missiles, officials said today.

title: MIGHT FAILS TO MAKE THINGS RIGHT
description: In the center of Victory Square in downtown Warsaw, on the cracked square-foot paving stones, lay a 20-foot-long cross made entirely of flowers. It appeared after Pope John Paul II held mass there in 1979. But since last May, when the coffin of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski was placed on the same spot for a requiem mass, the cross has been tended with the care and reverence accorded a shrine. Poles have come to light candles, pray and replenish the flowers.

title: Men and Abortion
description: I am firmly committed to the principle that the final decision about abortion or childbirth must rest with the woman (''Abortion Affects Men, Too,'' by Pamela Black, March 28). It is she who faces the risk of mortality during childbirth or abortion.

title: JAPANESE TRUCKS IN NEUTRAL
description: Although the dismal sales figures suggest that Detroit has been singularly unsuccessful in convincing consumers that its new, fuelefficient passenger cars are worth their high sticker prices, recent entries into the lightweight truck market are proving highly popular.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Piece of Space For the Pentagon
description: The difference between a civilian space agency with a national security commitment and a military agency with a civilian science component can be a subtle shift in projects and priorities. A Congressional report on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration budget suggests this shifting has begun.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Recycling Cars
description: It was an appealing idea that Governor Carey put forth to the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington in September 1980, since it promised benefits to all. It called for setting up centers in New York State where motorists could have their old cars rebuilt to enhance fuel economy, environmental impact and safety.

title: PLAN TO REPLACE A BRIDGE HAS TOWN UP IN ARMS
description: BETHLEHEM TOWNSHIP RESIDENTS of this rural Hunterdon County community have been clamoring for years for a new bridge over the Musconetcong River. One finally seems to be on the way, but not the kind the residents expected.

title: FORMER PROSECUTOR IS SLAIN IN A BURGLARY AT L.I. HOME
description: A lawyer and former assistant district attorney was shot to death in his garage early today when he and his wife returned home from a party and surprised at least two masked burglars, the Nassau County police said.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
CANADA'S SELF-DESTRUCT ENERGY POLICY
description: A radical experiment in political economics is under way north of t he border, and the first results do not seem encouraging. During the1 970's, the Canadian and American Governments developed energy p olicies along the same lines, but over the last year and a half t heir ways have parted.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Franz Beckenbauer, a member of West Germany's 1974 World Cup championship team and a former Cosmos star will make his last professsional appearance in Giants Stadium in the World All-Star Game for the benefit of UNICEF on Aug.7 ... The English Soccer Writers Association has named the Tottenham Hotspur captain, Steve Perryman, player of the year. ... Ray Floyd, last year's winner, has entered the $400,000 Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Golf Classic, June 24-27.

title: CABLE IS ECHOING TV'S EARLY YEARS
description: When television veterans get misty eyed about the good old days, talk inevitably turns to how ''primitive'' working conditions were way back then in the early 1950's. Studio space was limited, camera technology was unsophisticated, rehearsal time was at a minimum and, most of all, the programming was live. Ready or not, when the clock reached its appointed hour, you were on the air. This kind of atmosphere could be limiting. Subtle nuances, for instance, were at a premium. Yet, the veterans insist, the constant teetering on the edge of chaos or, at the very least, a career-damaging flub produced a special energy of its own, a tension that can rarely be duplicated on taped products. Weep for the passing of an era, we are solemnly told.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TO Camden High School students, ''A'' is for ''Antstronaut,'' their ants-in-space program that will be part of a NASA space-shuttle flight planned for this fall or next spring.

title: TEACHING CHILDREN HOW TO VIEW TV
description: PARENTS and educators who guide the television viewing of children only through restrictive and selective viewing are doing their children and students a disservice. In fact, we may be creating a disability as crippling as the inability to read. Young boys and girls who cannot infer, deduce, critically evaluate, differentiate fact from fiction, find the main idea or determinine the meaning of new vocabulary in a visual medium are as shut off from information and enjoyment as children who lack the same skills in reading.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED AT HARMON RAIL SHOP
description: ON-HUDSON IT has been a year since the Metropolitan Transportation Authority castigated Conrail's Harmon Shop here as a railroad-maintenance facility out of control, where employee abuses were rife and where many of the answers to one of the railroad's key problems - poor maintenance - could be found.

title: Indians 8, A's 5
description: Miguel Dilone hit two doubles and drove in three runs, and Mike Fischlin scored three times to lead Cleveland. The Indians reached Mike Norris (2-3) for four runs in the second.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVE MARKS CANADIAN MILESTONE
description: A special commemorative has been issued by Canada to herald ''patriation,'' an historic action that severed the last vestiges of colonial ties with Britain and gave Canadians full control of their destiny more than a century after the nation had gained its independence.

title: ILLEGAL ENROLLMENTS IRK SCHOOL DISTRICTS
description: MALVERNE IT was only a piece of street gossip at first, passed around by teen-agers, but it reached the ears of the attendance officer of the Malverne School District. He decided to check it out and found that the rumor was true: a freshman newly enrolled at Malverne High School was not a bona fide resident of the school district, despite written statements to the contrary signed by his parents. So the freshman was sent packing -back to the community and the school where he legally belonged.

title: SIRENS SYSTEM COMPLETE
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES has completed installation of emergency siren systems covering the areas within 10 miles of its two nuclear plant sites, Haddam Neck, in Haddam, and Millstone Point, in Waterford.

title: BROTHER AND SISTER-MADMAN AND ARTIST
description: LEAH AND LAZAR By Elizabeth Swados. 267 pp. New York: Summit Books. $13.95.

title: Merly Stone Engaged To Dr. Reed Stone
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Stone of West Brighton, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meryl Ilene Stone, to Dr. Reed Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Stone of Brooklyn. The families are not related.

title: PROSPECTS
description: An Interest Rate Window

title: Theater; A BIT OF FROTHY FUN AT THE GOODSPEED
description: IT would be dishonest to say that I found myself involved with the plot of ''Lock Up Your Daughters,'' the musical that has opened the new season at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam. In fact, it was a problem trying to recall who had charged whom with rape in this musical adaptation of Henry Fielding's 18th-century comedy, ''Rape Upon Rape,'' a musical in which a rape does not occur either on or offstage.

title: WHEN CITY BARGAINING FAILS, 5 COLORADO TOWNS ASK VOTERS
description: When bargainers in some Colorado cities reach an impasse in negotiations with municipal employees, residents settle the dispute by a vote.

title: SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Hens' Teeth

title: SCHOOL PRAYER ALSO MOVES TO THE FORE AGAIN
description: FROM time to time in its history the Supreme Court has made decisions so unacceptable to the public that they were overruled by constitutional amendment. The Dred Scott case, holding that slavery could not be prohibited in new territories, was set aside by the post-Civil War amendments. After the Court found the Federal income tax unconstitutional in 1893, the 16th Amendment was passed to authorize the tax.

title: No Headline
description: Until men share the political battle of women to maintain control over their own reproductive lives, it seems unlikely that they will truly be able to share the personal decision of whether or not to have an abortion, or to participate in the experience and the pain of abortion. While leadership of the movement to pass a constitutional amendment criminalizing abortion is largely male, our liberal male leaders continue largely to remain silent.

title: Henry Clay Irons Jr. Marries Constance E. Howard
description: At the Church of St. Christopher-by-the-Sea in Gibson Island, Md., yesterday, Constance Elaine Howard, daughter of Charles Earle Howard Jr. of Pasadena, Md., and Mary Louise Howard of Baltimore, was married to Henry Clay Irons Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Irons of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Walter J. Paulits performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Gifts From Everywhere At Discount Prices
description: An international bazaar of gifts is on display at Nardin Fine Arts in Mount Kisco until May 16, marking the departure of this painting and-sculpture gallery, which will reopen under the same name at The Yellow Monkey shopping complex in Cross River in September. The gifts are from nearly every continent and include wall hangings, masks, sculpture and jewelry at prices 20 percent to 50 percent below the original price here or at comparable shops.

title: Best Films on TV
description: Movie buffs might have more fun this television week exploring the less familiar byways - however, some well-known films, comfortably slotted for home viewing, are also worth considering.

title: FINDING PLEASURE IN EARLY WORK
description: ''With one bound, he was free,'' the pulp thriller writers used to say. No matter what troubles their hero had, those six words did the trick. Even when fettered in an underground cell and trapped in a tete-a-tete with a tarantula while biting on a strychnine sandwich, he rose to his feet, strode forth unmarked and was all set to fight another day. It was primitive magic, but magic all the same, and we loved it.

title: GOURMET'S GUIDE TO HUNGARY
description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The Times. BY R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: Market Place; Analysts Scan Sears Outlook
description: SOME eyes are starting to glow over the longer-term prospects for Sears, Roebuck & Company, the retailer-turned-financier. On April 21, the Chicago-based giant assembled a large group of analysts in the Sears Tower to review its short- and long-term prospects. The prognosis on Sears's stock potential seems to be uniform: short term, average; middle term, above average; long term, excellent to terrific.

title: S.I. YOUTH, 14, SHOT IN THE HEAD BY POLICE OFFICER
description: Halted after a police chase, a 14-year-old Staten Island boy at the wheel of his parents' van was shot in the head by a police officer yesterday when he refused an order to turn off the engine and instead backed up and struck a police sergeant with a side-view mirror, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Freedom Savings said it is seeking regulatory approval for a proposed $85 million, 800,000-square-foot commercial and financial office development in Tampa, Fla.

title: Brezhnev Accepts Offer For Visit to Nicaragua
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, accepted an invitation today to visit Nicaragua on an unspecified date. The invitation was made at the close of a six-day tour of the Soviet Union by Daniel Ortega, head of the Central American state's three-man junta.

title: Israel Hardens Position On Site of Talks
description: The Israelis, in a hardening of their postion, said today that they would not tolerate any attempt to remove Jerusalem as a site for negotiations with Egypt and the United States on Palestinian autonomy.

title: Andrew Kalmykow 2d, Expert On Compensation Insurance
description: Andrew Kalmykow 2d, assistant general counsel and vice president of the American Insurance Association and an authority on workers' compensation laws, died of a heart attack Friday night at La Guardia Airport on his return from a trip to Dallas. He was 70 years old and lived in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: Military Analysis
description: Argentina's most urgent military problem is the acquisition of more advanced weapons from the Western European powers that have sold arms to the country's military establishment for 15 years but that have now imposed an embargo on such sales to Argentina.

title: FATHERS PICK DAUGHTERS TO HEAD FAMILY BUSINESS
description: For years Herbert Setlow had his eye on a rising young executive to fill a top job in the family business. He dangled the usual inducements of salary and bonuses - to no avail. Then, a few months ago, he offered to make the executive a consultant and, eventually, president of the company. ''Dad,'' Carolyn Setlow told him, ''you've got a deal.''

title: Argentine War Fund Increased by Telethon
description: Argentina's Falkland Islands war fund grew to more than $7 million today with money raised during a telethon featuring sports, film and music stars and the wife of a missing sailor.

title: BIT OF HUMOR LIGHTENS MOOD AT REV. MOON'S TAX-FRAUD TRIAL
description: Legal sparring in the tax-fraud trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has been consistently polite, occasionally humorous and sometimes edged with sarcasm. One day recently, the chief defense lawyer, Charles A. Stillman, focused on prosecution efforts to describe the expensive estate where Mr. Moon lives in Irvington, N.Y.

title: FALKLAND ILLUSIONS
description: It is five weeks since Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands, and the crisis seems no nearer solution. But amid the frustrations of the politicians and diplomats it is already possible to see some larger implications of the Falklands affair. It has in particular shattered two dangerous illusions.

title: CHIEF OF VW HERE EXPLAINS PRICE CUT
description: Consumer prices have been rising for so long that it takes a moment to realize that the prices of some goods are actually being cut. One such visible price reduction came last week when Volkswagen of America trimmed $625 from the cost of its Rabbit L, to a suggested retail price of $5,990.

title: Fighter, in Coma, Has Brain Surgery
description: Andy Balaba, a Filipino flyweight boxer who underwent brain surgery Saturday, remained in a coma early today and a medical doctor gave him a ''very slim'' chance of recovering.

title: CITY OF SHEFFIELD MOURNS SAILORS LOST ON DESTROYER
description: Under lazy spring skies the people of Sheffield gathered today for a memorial service to the 24 sailors lost last week off the Falklands.

title: Algerian Gas Talks Snaf on Price Issue
description: The Algerian Government, having reached an agreement to sell natural gas to France at prices well above market levels, has been pressing the United States and Italy to sign similar long-term contracts. But after prolonged negotiations, it seems unlikely that the parties will be able to come to terms.

title: NEWARK AND ATLANTIC CITY TO ELECT MAYORS TUESDAY
description: While voters here will be deciding on Tuesday whether to re-elect Kenneth A. Gibson to a fourth term as Mayor of the state's largest city, voters in Atlantic City will be taking part in the first direct election of a Mayor in 70 years.

title: A Move to Y.& R.
description: Michael Slosberg, 48-year-old president and chief operating officer of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, is moving beneath the Young & Rubicam umbrella to become executive vice president and creative director of Marsteller, a slot that has been open for a year.

title: NEW DISTRICTING BEING WEIGHED BY CONGRESSMEN
description: Members of New York's Congressional delegation, presented for the first time with official information on the reapportionment plan agreed to in Albany, began yesterday to assess the implications of new district lines that will put some of them out of office.

title: Jeffrey Emanuel Epstein Marries Sue Ellen Hoover
description: Sue Ellen Hoover, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Samuel Hoover of Lake Forest, Ill., and Palm Desert, Calif., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Emanuel Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Epstein of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Joseph Asher performed the ceremony in the gardens at Holbrook Palmer Park in Atherton, Calif.

title: MEXICANS PESSIMISTIC ON TALKS BETWEEN U.S. AND CARIBBEAN LEFTISTS
description: Mexico feels it has done all it can to promote negotiations between the United States and leftist forces in the Caribbean region and is planning no new initiative, according to senior officials.

title: ON BRITISH CARRIER, PILOT RECOUNTS ORDER: 'ENGAGE'
description: British forces launched an attack on Argentine military installations around the Falklands' capital, Stanley, early today. Officers commanding the naval task force said no troop landing was attempted.

title:
RELATIONSHIPS;
WHEN LESS THAN TRUTH IS BETTER
description: ''O UR marriage is dull, repetitious. The magic has gone.'' Such thoughts occasionally cross the minds of most people who have been married for a long time. But need they be said aloud? Or should that passing wave of boredom and dissatisfaction remain a secret?

title: PHOSPHATES SHUTDOWNS IN FLORIDA
description: Many of the nation's largest chemical companies are shutting down their phosphate operations in Florida in the face of sharply lower sales of chemical fertilizer in the United States and abroad.

title: CODY SUCCESSION: FROM ABSOLUTISM TO DEMOCRACY?
description: As Roman Catholics in Chicago await the appointment by Pope John Paul II of a successor to the late John Cardinal Cody, the issue of how changing patterns of leadership could influence that choice is receiving increasing attention from priests, nuns and the laity.

title: 3 Relievers Help Red Sox,
description: The Boston Red Sox, a team once known for power hitting and indifferent pitching, are depending this season on a strong bullpen in the American League East Division. Manager Ralph Houk has acknowledged that the relievers - Bob Stanley, Mark Clear, Tom Burgmeier and Luis Aponte - must do well.

title: MUMPHREY BREAKS THUMB
description: Tommy John, who had insisted repeatedly that he was pitching better than his 1-4 record indicated, limited the Mariners to four hits in eight shutout innings tonight as the Yankees recorded a 3-0 victory over the Mariners and moved out of last place in the American League East.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 10, 1982
description: International A U.S.-Soviet arms control plan was proposed by President Reagan in an address to the graduating class of Eureka College in Illinois, his alma mater. It would initially call for both sides to reduce by onethird their nuclear warheads on land-and sea-based ballistic missiles. This would reduce to about 5,000 the number of warheads possessed by each country, the first step toward their acceptance of an ''equal ceiling'' on the ''throw weight'' or total payload of nuclear weapons of all kinds, the President said. He said that he has written to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, suggesting that formal negotiations start at the end of June. (Page A1, Column 6.) Soviet leaders will not approve any strategic arms reduction deal that requires a ''unilateral reduction by the Soviet Union while permitting a buildup by the United States,'' the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said. The article appeared before President Reagan's speech in Illinois proposing that the United States and the Soviet Union reduce nuclear warheads by one-third. (A15:2-5.)

title: LAKERS TOP SPURS IN OPENER, 128-117
description: It was bad enough for the San Antonio Spurs that the Los Angeles Lakers were so hot they beat them, 128-117, today. But the Lakers also left the Spurs in the cold after the game, as someone turned off the hot water in the Spurs' locker room.

title: 2 ARRESTED AFTER STAGING KIDNAPPING
description: An 18-year-old Long Island woman and her boyfriend staged a kidnapping that ended this weekend with the arrest of the woman, disguised in a blond wig, after she collected $100,000 of her parents' money in a movie theater.

title: TRIAL GIVES PEEK AT SOUTH AFRICA INTELLIGENCE WEB
description: The testimony of Col. Mike Hoare, the mercenary leader who is now standing trial on a charge of hijacking arising from his attempt to oust the Government of the Seychelles in November, has focused attention on the influential role played by Military Intelligence, a branch of the South African armed forces.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY PROFITS AND SALES AT 271 U.S. COMPANIES
U.S. Advances
description: The United States and Australia advanced to the final of the Nations Cup tennis tournament with 2-1 victories today.

title: ECONOMIC REPORTS BUOY BOND TRADERS
description: Fixed-income markets open for business today with a sense of renewed optimism that contrasts with the worries prevailing a week ago. ''We see a set of conditions that could bring interest rates down meaningfully by June,'' declared Irving M. Auerbach, of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, dealers in Government securities. ''The prime rate, now 16 1/2 percent, could fall to possibly as low as 14 1/2 percent.''

title: BRAVES USE 4 PITCHERS TO SHUT OUT CARDS
description: Although the Atlanta Braves have cooled off considerably after winning their first 13 games of the National League season, they still maintain a three-game advantage in the Western Division. The second-place San Diego Padres have been able to stay close on the strength of their recent 11-game victory string.

title: ISLANDERS CASH IN PLAYING CANUCK WAY
description: ''Hockey is a funny game,'' Coach Al Arbour said after the Islanders captured the opening game of the Stanley Cup championship series with a 6-5 overtime victory against the Vancouver Canucks at Nassau Coliseum Saturday night.

title: PARK TO RIVER AND BLOCK TO BLOCK, CRIME IS THE THREAD THAT BINDS
description: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime First of a series appearing periodically. By M. A. FARBER

title: A Shameful Sugar Policy
description: Not surprisingly, the White House did not really announce the decision to impose quotas on sugar imports. It merely confirmed the rumors that President Reagan will bring joy to a few thousand American sugar growers at a cost of about $1 billion to consumers and a further drain on the incomes of poor countries that depend on sugar exports.

title: LET TAXES BY SIMPLE, BUT NOT FLAT
description: To the Editor:

title: NANCY HUANG WINS COMELY
description: Nancy Huang, unbeaten in her three previous career starts, yesterday established herself as a top contender for New York's filly triple crown.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a man on first, the batter hits a low line drive to the center fielder. He makes what appears to be a spectacular catch, but he falls to the ground and is knocked unconscious. Both the glove and the ball are pinned beneath his body. What is the ruling?

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: 'Smatz' vs. Cable

title: Matches Put Off
description: Stormy weather today postponed the semifinal singles matches at the rain-plagued Italian Women's Open tennis championships. The matches were re-scheduled for Monday. Chris Evert Lloyd meets Lisa Bonder, and Billie Jean King faces Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia.

title: Sian Ballen Married To Gregory P. Speiser
description: At Temple Emanu-El yesterday Sian Ballen, daughter of Irving W. Ballen of New York and the late Adrienne Ballen, was married to Gregory Paul Speiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Speiser of New York and Ghent, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: An indictment made public on Saturday accusing an undergound group called Jihad of trying to overthrow the Government shows that its members were spread throughout the country in a wide range of professions, including strategically sensitive posts.

title: U.S. Cyclist Wins
description: Sheila Young Ochowicz, the world sprint champion of the United States, won the women's 26.5-mile Tokyo international cycling road race today, beating 35 entrants. Mrs. Ochowicz finished ahead of Britain's Pauline Strong by 43-hundredths of a second. Mrs. Ochowicz was clocked in 1 hour 9 minutes 26.84 seconds. Japan's top racer, Wakako Abe, was third, and Debbie Deluca of the United States was fourth.

title: Athletic Director Quits Over Deficit
description: Ed Swartz, athletic director at the University of Texas-El Paso, has resigned after 13 months as head of a financially troubled department.

title: Tower Warns On Takeover
description: Senator John G. Tower has issued a warning that the attempted takeover of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation by dissident shareholders could threaten national security. The company produces lithium, which is used in nuclear bombs.

title: Pirates 6, Reds 3
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Jason Thompson extended his hitting streak to 17 games with his 10th homer, a two-run shot in the third inning, and Johnny Ray walloped four hits for the winners.

title: ARGENTINES DETAIL RENEWED ATTACKS BY BRITAIN'S FLEET
description: Argentina said today that British warships and helicopters attacked Argentine positions in the Falkland Islands and that British fighter planes sank a fishing boat offshore.

title: CELTICS WIN BY 121-81
description: Rick Robey, the Boston Celtics' 6-foot-10-inch, 240-pound backup center, has never been noted for his scoring. In his four pro seasons, Robey's role has been to provide strength off the bench.

title: POP: HUMAN LEAGUE AT THE PALLADIUM
description: AMONG the rash of new English synthesizer-oriented bands that have been lumped together under the catchword electropop, the Human League is the most melodic, as well as the most intellectually edifying. The band's best tunes echo the sleek, international-style pop hooks of the Swedish supergroup Abba.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air Express International has appointed Guenter Rohrmann vice president and general manager-North America.

title: O.& M. to Join Tokyu In Japanese Ad Venture
description: There are about 17 American ad agencies doing business in Japan, all through some relationship with Japanese agencies except for J. Walter Thompson, which got there before the law preventing independent foreign agencies.

title: LEONARD IS IDLED BY EYE SURGERY
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the world welterweight champion, underwent two hours of surgery at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore yesterday to repair a partially detached retina in his left eye. Doctors said they believed he would be able to resume his boxing career before the end of the year.

title: STAUB PINCH HOMER LIFTS METS
description: Craig Swan giggled at the idea of gaining a victory with just one and one-third innings of work, and he smiled at the thought of being able to throw a baseball without pain. Rusty Staub's emotions were kept inside, just as his physical problems have been kept as private as possible.

title: Advertising; Ally Team Dominates Awards
description: THE only breaks that relieved the tedium of the Federal Express creative team from Ally & Gargano going up for awards at the One Show on Friday night were the Xerox team from Needham, Harper & Steers; the BMW team from Ammerati & Puris, and the General Electric team from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.

title: FOR NOW, LET THEM FASTEN THEIR SEAT BELTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Mary Cantwell AN UNSUITABLE ATTACHMENT. By Barbara Pym. 256 pages. E.P. Dutton. $12.50.

title: SOCIAL COMMENT IN 'LADY CHATTERLEY'S LOVER'
description: ANAIS NIN once observed that ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' included crudeness of language because D.H. Lawrence wanted ''to dethrone mentally directed love.'' The latest movie version of the 1928 novel makes an effort to do that in a number of scenes that seem faithful to the general outlines of the story. It is a pretty film that wavers between soft-core pornography and social comment, without ever involving the viewer emotionally.

title: Cooper Labs Correction
description: Cooper Laboratories, a Palo Alto, Calif., maker of specialty medical and dental products, last week completed the sale of its ''A'' Company - acquired by Cooper only last December - to the Johnson & Johnson Company for $37.5 million in cash.

title: Boomerang Takes Overnight Race
description: Boomerang, a 65-foot sloop owned by George Coumantaros of Greenwich, Conn., today captured first place in the grand prix fleet to win the New York Athletic Club's Stratford Shoals overnight race on Long Island Sound.

title: Ballesteros Wins
description: NOM-LA-BRETECHE, France, May 9 (AP) - Severiano Ballesteros of Spain shot a seven-under-par 65 today and won the $76,000 French Open by four strokes.

title: 2 Atlanta Newspapers To Merge Operations
description: The Atlanta Constitution and The Atlanta Journal, both owned by Cox Enterprises Inc., have announced plans for combining their news operations this summer to ''make possible broader news coverage'' for readers of both newspapers.

title: Bridge: Foreign Pairs Added Zest To Cavendish Competition
description: A top-quality field of 40 pairs, including a sprinkling from South America and Europe, battled over the weekend at the Cavendish Club in New York in the annual Invitational Pair Championship.

title: SUIT REVIVES OLD REPORT TYING APODACA TO CRIME
description: An old feud between former Gov. Jerry Apodaca of New Mexico and the state's largest newspaper, The Albuquerque Journal, has broken out anew because of new developments in a libel suit filed by a criminal lawyer who is a close friend of Mr. Apodaca.

title: U.N. CHIEF CITES PROGRESS IN TALKS TO END FIGHTING
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, after a second day of talks with Argentina and Britain, said tonight that ''important progress'' had been made in the effort to end the fighting over the Falkland Islands.

title: PRINTING OFFICE KEEPS EYE ON 'BOTTOM LINE'
description: All over Washington, conservative Republican businessmen are attempting to remake huge Federal agencies in the image and likeness of the Reagan ideal, the corporation. Nowhere is the experiment going on more quietly or more aggressively than up on Capitol Hill in a red-bricked complex with 33 acres and more than 6,000 employees under its roof.

title: BESET BY FIERCE COMPETITION, ACME STORES FIGHT TO SURVIVE
description: Acme Markets Inc., a Philadelphia-based supermarket subsidiary of the American Stores Company, has been fighting hard to survive in its home city and the Middle Atlantic States, where supermarket closings have become a way of life.

title: KOCH SUBMITS BUDGET TODAY AMID GRAVE DOUBTS ON AID
description: Mayor Koch will propose today a $15.6 billion executive budget for the coming fiscal year amid grave uncertainties about Federal and state aid and about how much revenue the city can count on from both Albany and Washington.

title: Iran Says Its Army Captured Another Town
description: Iran said today that it had recaptured another southwestern town from Iraqi forces and that Iranian troops were rapidly advancing on the Persian Gulf port city of Khurramshahr.

title: A JOB FOR JIMMY CARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's first comprehensive speech on East-West relations seems to mark a major shift in his own thinking about dealing with the Soviet Union that may even overshadow his specific proposals on sharply reducing each side's strategic arsenals.

title: TRUST ISN'T THE ISSUE IN ARMS REDUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: INDIAN CLASSICS BY SHANKAR AND KHAN
description: RAVI SHANKAR and Ali Akbar Khan, two of the giants of Indian classical music, used to perform together frequently; indeed, they shared the same teacher, Mr. Khan's father. But before Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall, they had not concertized together in a decade.

title: 'OUTCAST' NEEDS CONGRESS AID TO STAY IN U.S.
description: Eight years after he was found near death in the Ecuadorean jungle, Juan Ramirez is educated, healthy and fighting to keep from being returned to South America, where he believes he would be an outcast.

title: Article 125471 -- No Title
description: WITH another New York club owner on another New York team in another New York borough, George Foster would have been publicly flogged by now. ''I'm paying him a lot of money,'' that other club owner has been known to gripe about a player, ''and he hasn't produced.'' But for a $2 million slugger in a slump, life with Nelson Doubleday on the Mets in Queens surely is more mannerly than it would be with George Steinbrenner on the Yankees in the Bronx.

title: 'THIS IS THE ARMY' CAST REUNION RECALLS TRIALS AND TRIUMPHS
description: On a day in May 40 years ago, 310 soldiers - many plucked from training camps all over the country -gathered at Camp Upton on Long Island to form a most unusual unit. In civilian life, they had been actors, musicians, designers and stagehands. In the military, they became the company for ''This Is the Army,'' the Irving Berlin musical that opened to acclaim on Broadway on the Fourth of July 1942.

title: BRIEFING
description: Somebody Else's War

title: DUAL ROLE OF OUTSIDE DIRECTORS
description: For some years, it has become quite the rage for companies to increase the number of outsiders who make up their boards in order to stem criticism that directors can't be master and slave to their boss at the same time.

title: Fighter Could Win by a Chin
description: It's time to take Randall (Tex) Cobb seriously, even if he won't. In less than a month, the third eldest of Norma Cobb's four boys from Abilene, Tex., could be a world heavyweight boxing champion.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: TWO TREASURY OFFERINGS THIS WEEK
description: After its May refunding operation last week, the Treasury will make two trips to the debt market this week. Today, it will auction $9.4 billion of three-month and six-month Treasury bills. As of midafternoon Friday, the latest three-month bill and sixmonth bill both were trading at levels to yield 12.18 percent on a discount basis. At last Monday's auction, the three-month bill showed an average yield of 12.675 percent, while the average return on the six-month bill was 12.78 percent.

title: Mr. Smith Does His Duty
description: At last, Attorney General William French Smith has told Congress what he thinks of laws that would strip the Federal courts of power in school prayer and busing cases. Not much.

title: ARTIST DELIGHTS IN WORK'S LIMITED LIFE
description: It arrived, rather informally, by way of an aging Volkswagen bus. It came from a refrigerator at the Waldorf- Astoria - where it had been freezing for more than a week. And it broke in two at about chest level as it was being heaved, also rather informally, onto a bier in the main hall of the Center for Inter-American Relations at 680 Park Avenue.

title: EXECUTIVES PESSIMISTIC, UNCERTAIN
description: The top executives of the nation's major corporations, who gathered here over the weekend for the semiannual meeting of the Business Council, were generally pessimistic about the economy and uncertain about what the future holds.

title: ISRAELI BORDER AREAS SHELLED AFTER RAID ON PALESTINIANS
description: Some 100 rockets and artillery shells were fired into northern Israel today after Israeli air strikes against Palestinian bases, sending residents in the area running to their air raid shelters.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions Saturday incorrectly described the circum- stances under which Alan M. Dersho- witz is serving as an attorney for Claus von Bulow. Mr. Dershowitz said that Mr. von Bulow asked him to work on the appeal of Mr. von Bulow's con- viction on charges of attempted mur- der and that a fee would be paid for his legal services.

title: EUROPEAN AGRICULTURAL POLICY VIOLATES NO GATT RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: EXILES FROM COMMUNISM WEIGH ROLE OF NATIONALISM
description: ''We use the word 'dissident' here as if it were an occupation,'' complained the Russian writer Vasily P. Aksyonov after a literary discussion yesterday turned into a mild political imbroglio.

title: AT HARVARD, THEY REMEMBER THOMAS WOLFE
description: Reading Thomas Wolfe, like falling in puppy love, may be no more than a rite of passage for many sensitive young men. But as this weekend's meeting of the Thomas Wolfe Society made clear, youthfulness, if not youth, can last a lifetime.

title: OUTDOORS: MAY IS THE FINEST MONTH
description: HAVING languished in inactivity all winter - unless one was fortunate enough to make a trip south or foolish enough to shiver on some ice-locked lake - the Northeast angler will soon be overwhelmed by opportunities.

title: Meredith Willis Bride of Dr. Andrew Weinberger
description: Meredith Sue Willis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Willis of Shinnston, W. Va., was married at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture yesterday to Dr. Andrew B. Weinberger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Weinberger of Roslyn Heights, L.I. Michael Grupp, leader of the society, performed the ceremony.

title: WOMAN PRESSES BATTLE AGAINST SEX-BASED DISABILITY INSURANCE RATES
description: A national insurance company has stopped selling disability policies in Pennsylvania in the hope of short-circuiting one woman's battle against rates based on sex.

title: Michigan Budget Session
description: The Michigan Legislature has been called into an emergency session Monday to consider a temporary income tax increase that would help balance the budget and perhaps save the state's credit rating. State officials, facing a deficit of more than $300 million, say Moody's Investors Service Inc. is preparing to lower Michigan's credit rating to Baa from A, which would make it more difficult for the state to borrow money.

title: SHELLING FOLLOWS
description: Israeli fighter-bombers raided a string of Palestinian guerrilla bases in the hills south of Beirut today, and the guerrillas immediately responded by firing artillery salvos into northern Israel.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Tuesday on Cooper Laboratories included several items of erroneous information supplied by a company spokesman. A corrective article appears on Page D4.

title: Bomb Blast in Jerusalem Bus
description: A bomb exploded today in a bus in Jerusalem, injuring two children, the Israeli radio reported. No one took responsibility for the incident.

title: Cubs 6, Astros 3
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Jody Davis hit a three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning for the sweep of a three-game series.

title: INFIGHTING ON EUROPE LOANS
description: WASHINGTON THE Treasury is still smarting over the State Department's contacts with bankers on lending to Yugoslavia. The whole question of credits to Eastern Europe is causing fierce disagreement within the Cabinet Council on Economic Affairs.

title: Hicks & Greist Adds a Bakery
description: Hicks & Greist, which has considerable strength in the food marketing area, has become agency for the American Bakeries Company, Chicago, which produces regional bread brands such as Taystee and Merita, as well as snacks, cakes and other baked goods.

title: Customs Commissioner Lectures Florida Bankers
description: Florida banking leaders angrily ended a meeting Saturday when the United States Commissioner of Customs attacked ''sleazy'' banks in the state that assist drug dealers in hiding their transactions.

title: 12 Groups of Japanese Start 'Peace March' to Hiroshima
description: Demonstrators starting from 12 points around Japan were walking toward Hiroshima today to call for an end to nuclear weapons as part of a three-month ''People's Grand March for Peace.''

title: John Paul to Pray at Fatima On Anniversary of Shooting
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he would pray at the shrine of Fatima in Portugal this week to give thanks for having survived the attempt on his life a year ago.

title: LET TAXES BE SIMPLE, BUT NOT FLAT
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAHAM PREACHES AT CHURCH IN MOSCOW
description: The Rev. Billy Graham preached his message of disarmament and Christian rebirth at a tightly guarded Baptist church here today while outside 250 Christians sang hymns from behind police barriers.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED IN CASE AGAINST QUEBEC MOUNTIE
description: The first case in Quebec against a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police charged with wrongdoing has ended in a mistrial after Premier Rene Levesque denounced the testimony of a defense witness.

title: BRITAIN ATTACKS FALKLANDS AGAIN
description: British forces launched a fresh attack near the airport at Stanley, the Falkland Islands capital, today and captured an Argentine fishing boat offshore after opening fire on it from the air.

title: College Testing Groups Sued Over Fees for Poor Students
description: A coalition of college students has filed suit against the the College Entrance Examination Board and the American College Testing Program, saying they illegally charged 500,000 needy students for processing financial aid forms.

title: Text of address is on page A14.
description: President Reagan proposed a two-step plan today in which the United States and the Soviet Union would initially reduce by one-third their arsenals of nuclear warheads on land- and sea-based ballistic missiles.

title: Admiral Rickover on Making Life Meaningful
description: His announced topic was nuclear disarmament, but when he mounted the pulpit at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, before the congregation of 900 people, Hyman G. Rickover had something else on his mind - what makes life meaningful.

title: THE DEBT BURDEN ON ALFA OF MEXICO
description: For the best part of six years, foreign bankers jostled each other for the chance to finance the Alfa Industrial Group's dizzying pace of expansion and diversification. And, with Alfa's profits leaping by about 50 percent each year, not a furrowed brow was to be seen.

title: THE PREAKNESS: A NEW LEADER FOR THE PACK
description: ANY respectable racetracker is expected to know that 11 colts have won the Triple Crown - the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes - and to be able to fire off their names like a solemn 11-gun salute to the thoroughbred breed. The five weeks that encompass the three events each spring are racing's season of high seriousness, an annual rite of pursuing a hallowed peak.

title: DANCE: COMIC LEON FELDER
description: THERE seemed to be two Leon Felders at work in a concert Friday by the Leon Felder Dance Company at Julia Richman High School. One was a choreographer with a cool but friendly way with dance, mixing ballet and jazz-dance idioms with sports and an understated street toughness to make a stunning dance called ''The Surge.''

title: SPECIALIST CALLS TERRORIST TACTICS PREDICTABLE
description: When Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier was kidnapped by the Red Brigades in Italy last December, Brian M. Jenkins kicked himself.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will negotiate seriously in good faith, and carefully consider all proposals made by the Soviet Union.

title: Seamy Side Of Hockey
description: IF the National Hockey League is looking for a new corporate logo, it could create a fitting design from Bob Nystrom's forehead: a circular knot, glowing from blood and iodine, and decorated with six fresh black stitches.

title: Precise Arms Figures Difficult to Pin Down
description: Reagan Administration officials estimated today that the Soviet Union and the United States each had 7,500 nuclear warheads.

title: CHURCH LEADERS CONFER ON NEW ROLE OF MISSIONS
description: Many American missionaries, once the main force in world evangelism, now say they feel that the continued growth of Christianity in other lands depends on the work of indigenous Christians.

title: Padres 6, Phils 0
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Tim Lollar singled home the game's first run and pitched a four-hitter, snapping Philadelphia's six-game winning streak.

title: Local Issues Dominate Primary in Nebraska
description: A battle over two issues on the ballot in Lincoln is generating most of the interest in the Nebraska primary Tuesday in which no Congressional incumbent is opposed.

title: Sally Little Is Winner In Playoff
description: Sally Little, the leading money-winner on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour this year, birdied the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to defeat Kathy Whitworth by a stroke in the 54-hole, $125,000 L.P.G.A.-United Virginia Bank Classic.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Object of Affection

title: Gasoline Prices Rising
description: Gasoline retailers have begun to put prices back up after a steady decline, with rises averaging 0.66 cent a gallon since mid-April, an oil industry analyst, Dan Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, reported today. During the April 16-May 7 period the average retail price, including taxes, for all grades of gasoline rose to $1.1849 from $1.1783.

title: SOLIDARITY RADIO URGES POLES TO STAGE PROTESTS THURSDAY
description: A clandestine Radio Solidarity broadcast called tonight for a 15-minute strike in the capital and other acts of symbolic protest on Thursday to mark five months of martial law.

title: News Analysis
description: For all the fierceness of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's words, for all the reiteration of lofty principle, Britain has considerably scaled down in the last month its terms for settlement of the deepening crisis in the Falkland Islands.

title: Pipe Bomb Is Defused Near Brooklyn Bakery
description: A pipe bomb discovered in front of a Brooklyn bakery was safely dismantled and removed early yesterday, the police said. A police spokesman said the pipe bomb was discovered at Scotto's Bakery, 3807 13th Avenue, at about 4 A.M. by an employee who had arrived to open the shop.

title: U.S. ABSOLVES NEW YORK CITY OF FRAUD WITH FOOD STAMPS
description: A Justice Department report on New York City's $600 million-a-year food stamp program has absolved the Human Resources Administration of charges of fraud, cover-up and corruption made last fall by former investigator members of the city agency.

title: Extra SSC&B Task
description: The Olympus Camera Corporation, marketer of Japanese-made photographic equipment, has given an additional assignment to its agency, SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies. It is for its new portable video photography system. The ad budget has not been set yet.

title: Emma-Louise Bouvier Allan; Worked for Hospital Charities
description: Emma-Louise Bouvier Allan, who was involved in charitable hospital activities, spending much of her time at the Children's Hospital in Washington, died at her home here Friday after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

title: THE WORTH OF A DEFECTIVE NEWBORN'S LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: A MARRIAGE IN PROBLEM LAND
description: ''THE Rules of Marriage,'' which begins on CBS at 9 this evening, is a terribly sincere and even more terribly earnest ''contemporary drama.'' Joan and Michael Hagen (Elizabeth Montgomery and Elliott Gould) are walking images of a golden couple living the comfortable good life in Fairfield, Conn. Friends celebrate their 15 years of marriage, their two model children, their ability to survive together so gracefully. Obviously, this being television problem land, surface impressions can be deceiving.

title: The U.N. Today; May 10, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory committee for second special session on disarmament - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: WATSON, IN A MCLAREN, IS FIRST
description: John Watson of Britain won the Belgian Grand Prix today in what wrapped up an emotional weekend of Formula One racing.

title: Panel to Study Degree Given Kean Nominee
description: The president of Fairleigh Dickinson University has appointed a faculty committee to investigate the circumstances under which a doctorate was awarded nine years ago to Governor Kean's nominee for State Education Commissioner. The committee will meet today.

title: Sanchez Retains Title on Decision
description: Salvador Sanchez, the World Boxing Council's featherweight champion, threw everything he had at Jorge (Rocky) Garcia Saturday night but could not knock him out. The champion won a 15-round unanimous decision in his eighth title defense.

title: Salvador Army Builds Defenses Against Rebels
description: The army has stepped up its defenses north of the capital to fend off leftist guerrillas who have shifted activity from the northeastern corner of El Salvador, witnesses said today.

title: DEMOCRATS SAY REAGAN PLAN ON ARMS MOVES TOO SLOWLY
description: Democrats warned today that the reduction in long-range nuclear missiles and warheads proposed by President Reagan could take years to negotiate, and they called for adoption of the second strategic arms limitation treaty in the interim.

title: Commodities; Proposed Options Criticized
description: NOW that stock-index futures have been successfully introduced, the commodity industry is preparing its next wave of new ''products'' - exchange-traded options on futures. Unlike the stock-index futures, which were widely backed by the industry, these options, as they are now proposed, are provoking quiet but fierce opposition from some leaders in the industry.

title: MAX STOLLER
description: Max Stoller, retired president and co-founder of the Altman, Stoller, Weiss advertising agency in Manhattan, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital.

title: MONDAY, MAY 10, 1982; The Economy
description: Many top executives expressed concern over the budget battle in Washington and said that the outcome of the fight could make or break their confidence in the future of the economy. Some executives attending a meeting at Hot Springs, Va., said that they had not seen any signs of a recovery occurring this year. Many were pessimistic and uncertain about the economic future, but said they still supported President Reagan's economic program. (Page D1.)

title: It Was a Mixed-Up Derby
description: Racing fans who watched the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs or on television were not the only ones who had trouble keeping track of the 19 horses in the crowded field.

title: EGYPT CITES PROGRESS ON A RECONCILIATION WITH ARAB NATIONS
description: President Hosni Mubarak made ''some progress'' today in his talks with Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman on a reconciliation with Arab nations that ostracized Egypt after its peace treaty with Israel, the official Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Dodgers 5, Expos 4
description: MONTREAL (AP) - Pedro Guerrero hit a three-run homer in the fifth and Fernando Valenzuela scattered eight hits as Los Angeles swept the four-game series.

title: POLICE SEEKING CLUES IN SLAYING OF LAWYER ON L.I.
description: As 450 mourners attended a funeral service for a former assistant district attorney slain at his home early Saturday by a masked burglar, the Nassau County police continued to search for clues.

title: THEATER: 'NINE,' A MUSICAL BASED ON FELLINI'S '8 1/2
description: THERE are two unquestionable reasons to cheer ''Nine,'' the extravagantly uneven musical that opened at the 46th Street Theater last night. Their names are Tommy Tune and Maury Yeston. In this, his most ambitious show, Mr. Tune provides the strongest evidence yet that he is one of our theater's most inventive directors - a man who could create rainbows in a desert. Mr. Yeston, a newcomer to Broadway, has an imagination that, at its best, is almost Mr. Tune's match. His score, giddily orchestrated by Jonathan Tunick, is a literate mixture of show biz and operatic musical genres that contains some of the season's most novel and beautiful songs. Together Mr. Yeston and Mr. Tune give ''Nine'' more than a few sequences that are at once hallucinatory and entertaining -dreams that play like showstoppers.

title: Lendl Routs Dibbs In Final by 6-1, 6-1
description: If Ivan Lendl is ''on a roll,'' as John McEnroe observed the other day, where will it lead this year? The French and United States Open titles? A Davis Cup crown for Czechoslovakia over the United States?

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Hidden Weakness

title: 184 CASES ARGUED, 98 DECISIONS DUE
description: The Supreme Court is about to enter the stretch, the final seven weeks or so of the term in which the Court issues at least half of the entire year's load of opinions. This term's 184 cases have now all been argued, and the courtroom itself will be nearly deserted as the Justices work behind closed doors on the 98 cases that remain undecided.

title: SNEED WINS HOUSTON PLAYOFF
description: Ed Sneed, the 37-year-old Virginian best known as the player who blew the 1979 Masters with bogeys on the last three holes, won the Houston Open today on the first hole of a playoff with Bob Shearer.

title: Indiana Prison Ordered To Begin Reform Plan
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the State Department of Correction to reduce the prisoner population and make other reforms for the welfare of inmates at the Indiana Reformatory at Pendleton.

title: CALL TO ARMS IS HEARD IN STREETS OF NEW YORK
description: The British and Argentine Consulates in New York say they have received offers from people willing to join in the battle for control of the Falkland Islands.

title: Merrill Hong Kong Tie
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has reached agreement in principle to acquire a minority interest in the brokerage and banking businesses of Sun Hung Kai of Hong Kong, Merrill Lynch announced yesterday. Details will be disclosed after a definitive agreement is negotiated. In 1981, Sun Hung Kai Securities had revenue of $74 million and a net income of $38.7 million, and the group's bank had revenue of $117.3 million and net income of $12.6 million.

title: MOET-HENNESSY NAMES CHAIRMAN OF U.S. UNIT
description: Is there any difference between selling champagne and perfume? Bernard Picot will soon find out. Mr. Picot, 59, has been chief executive and chairman of Christian Dior Perfumes worldwide. Its parent company, Moet-Hennessy of France, has just named him chairman of the Moet-Hennessy U.S. Corporation, which includes champagne and wine companies as well as the Dior business in the United States.

title: RKO GENERAL CHOOSES PRESIDENT FOR TELEVISION
description: RKO General Inc., which is losing its Boston television station, has named the station's vice president and general manager, Pat A. Servodidio, to be president of RKO General Television. Mr. Servodidio, 44, will be in charge of all RKO television operations - WOR-TV in New York, KHJ-TV in Los Angeles and WHBQ-TV in Memphis.

title: Natan Wekselbaum Weds Nancy A. Cohen Upstate
description: Nancy Augusta Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Avron Cohen of Schenectady, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Natan Wekselbaum, son of Mrs. Israel Luski of Miami Beach and the late Samuel Wekselbaum of New York, formerly of Havana. Rabbi Michael Szenes performed the ceremony at Temple Gates of Heaven.

title: Bache to Assist Health Sector
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. has announced the formation of a unit to provide financial services to the health care industry.

title: PRINCIPLE VS. PROPORTION; WASHINGTON - The Falklands War is producing two strange sets of bedfellows in the United States. On the surface, we support our traditional ally whose subjects were attacked by a jingoistic dictatorship; beneath the surface, a debate is beginning that scrambles the usual lineups. ''All the wrong people are making the right arguments,'' complains one hardliner to a normally-aligned rightwinger.
description: The core of the argument, which has also begun in Great Britain, is the issue of principle versus proportion. Should the U.K. defend its national honor, or is the cost too high? The corollary here is: should the U.S. stand behind its closest ally, or would it cost too much?

title: G.O.P. FEARS THIN MARGIN IN '82 SENATE RACES
description: Republicans are concerned that this year's elections for the Senate, which they once thought would provide them enough new seats to hold their majority through the 1980's, will produce a gain of only one or two seats, a superficial victory that might foretell a real defeat in 1984 or 1986.

title: 'NO FIRST USE'
description: I gathered my political experiences in Berlin during those years when the American occupiers became our friends. This experience taught me that neutrality is not a way out and that we Germans have no security without America. Today, however, the example of Berlin can also be used to demonstrate that an American renunciation of a nuclear first-strike strengthens the Atlantic alliance and does not diminish our security.

title: People
description: * Edward M. Lebar and Marc S. Bromberg appointed senior vice presidents at Young & Rubicam USA.

title: DOUGLAS VAN RIPER
description: Douglas Van Riper, a real estate broker on the North Shore of Long Island, died Friday at the Sands Point (L.I.) Nursing Home on his 83d birthday.

title: MUSIC: COLLEGIATE CHORALE IN MOZART PROGRAM
description: IT was all Mozart at the Collegiate Chorale's concert Saturday night at Carnegie Hall -first the ''Vesperae solennes de confessore'' and then the Requiem.

title: HINCKLEY: A 'MEDIA FREAK'
description: It was 7:20 P.M., network evening news time, on March 30, 1981, when the Secret Service began interrogating John W. Hinckley Jr., five hours after the shooting of President Reagan.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Faithful to Baseball

title: An Executive Switch for Conrail Commuters
description: The 85,000 commuters who ride Conrail's Harlem, Hudson and New Haven Division trains into and out of Grand Central Terminal each weekday have a new man at the throttle this morning.

title: Bernie Glow, 56, Trumpeter On the Stage, Radio and TV
description: Bernie Glow, a trumpeter who was a studio and recording musician, died of a blood disorder Saturday in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 56 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: THE TRANSFER OF A CITY AIDE STIRS DISPUTE
description: On the surface, it seemed to be a routine bureaucratic reassignment in the city's Department of Probation when a probation officer, Wallace Cheatham, was transferred from Brooklyn to Staten Island last month.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STILL LIFE

title: Required Reading Thanks to Japan
description: Representative Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, in a statement before the House of Representatives, May 4, 1982: I take this occasion to express my thanks to the nation of Japan for agreeing yesterday to offer treatment for one of my constituents, John Smitherman, who was the victim of two atomic bomb blast tests near Bikini Atoll when he was stationed on the USS Allen M. Sumner.

title: MOSCOW CAUTIONS U.S. ON ARMS CUTS
