description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that the United States should have no illusions that Soviet leaders would approve a strategic arms reduction deal that required a ''unilateral reduction'' in the Soviet arsenal while permitting a buildup of United States strategic forces.

title: Deerhound Picked As Best in Show
description: A Scottish deerhound was named best today in a field of 2,990 at the 53d show of the Trenton Kennel Club at Mercer County Park.

title: Expos Drop Lee For Leaving Park
description: The Montreal Expos, angered after Bill Lee left the ball park during Saturday's game with the Dodgers, placed the left-handed pitcher on waivers today.

title: News Analysis
description: The New York Legislature, which has finally broken the impasses on reapportionment and the state budget that nearly paralyzed it for four months, must now confront a broad range of divisive issues, including matters affecting the financial futures of New York City and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: McDonald & Little To Keep Mello Yello
description: McDonald & Little, Atlanta, learned Friday that it had survived an agency review and will continue to do the advertising for Mello Yello soft drink from Coca-Cola.

title: Ski Slope Advertising
description: Do you ever get the feeling that things that really don't belong in a particular setting - such as graffiti or litter - create discordant vibrations that affect the human psyche? How about advertising where you don't expect to find it, like on the top of a ski lift tower surrounded by the majestical snowy slopes? That is the concept of Joseph J. Kohler 3d, president of Ski View Inc., of Canandaigua, N.Y., which has already affixed two-foot by four-foot poster holders to the tops of 2,000 towers in 50 ski areas in 14 Middle Western and Northeastern states. The company says that the signs relieve the boredom on the long ride to the top. How about during the fast run to the bottom?

title: GARLAND EYES THE ROAD BACK
description: NASHVILLE AT Herschel Greer Stadium, home of the Nashville Sounds, there is background music, country and western. Not unusual because country music is everywhere in Nashville, the capital of tuneful twang - they even named the minor league baseball team for the music. The motif seems as natural a part of the town as the warmth of Southern sunshine and the sweet smell of magnolia trees.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Jerseyan in Ontario

title: BUSH LEAVES CHINA WITH NEW IDEAS FOR RESOLVING TAIWAN ARMS DISPUTE
description: Vice President Bush left China today with what he called ''some specific ideas'' for President Reagan on resolving the impasse that has developed over the issue of United States arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Backdoor Bonus for State Legislators
description: When Congress selfishly granted its members a $75-a-day tax deduction for expenses last fall, attention focused on the break for Washington lawmakers. Only lately has another dimension of the windfall come to light.

title: Mears Sets Mark For Indy Practice
description: Rick Mears, the pre-race favorite for the Indianapolis 500, set an unofficial track record of 203.7 miles an hour today on the first weekend of practice for the May 30 event.

title: POLICE WIDEN SEARCH FOR GUNMEN WHO KILLED THREE MEN IN QUEENS
description: Detectives ordered ballistics tests, canvassed homes for witnesses, sought out underworld informants and studied the records of organized crime figures yesterday in a widening search for the gunmen who killed three men and wounded a fourth on a Queens street early Saturday.

title: 'PARADISE,' AN AWAKENING IN THE DESERT
description: ''PARADISE,'' at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, is ''The Blue Lagoon'' with camels. It is also, without doubt, the best camel movie of the year to date, though the producers probably mean it to be romantic, and camels are not, by any stretch of the imagination, romantic. They are lumbering, dull-witted, ridiculous-looking creatures who slobber a lot. They are more efficiently functional than esthetically pleasing. To be cruelly blunt, camels are comic.

title: BALLET: 2 BRILLIANT KALEIDOSCOPES
description: A KALEIDOSCOPE of brilliant images - that is the best way to describe the dancegoing experience at Lincoln Center now that New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater are both going full steam ahead there.

title: RENAULT CRECHE PROVIDES DAY CARE, FRENCH STYLE
description: They arrive early in the morning, the older ones trudging up the stairs holding a parent's hand, the babies peering over a parent's shoulder. But when the moment comes for the parents to leave, there is rarely an outcry because, in a sense, they have come to their other home.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S ADDRESS ON NUCLEAR POLICY AND EAST-WEST TIES
description: Following is the text of the commencement address prepared for delivery by President Reagan today at Eureka College:

title: Columbia's Dean Has an Au Revoir Reception
description: ''Five years ago,'' Michael I. Sovern, the president of Columbia University was saying, ''Arnold Collery walked into his office and said: 'Well, here I am. Where do I sit and what do I do?' ''

title: Dean Martin Arrested
description: Dean Martin, the singer and entertainer, was arrested Saturday night in West Hollywood for investigation of drunken driving by California Highway Patrol officers, the sheriff's department said. Mr. Martin, who is 64 years old, was booked at the West Hollywood sheriff's station and later released on his own recognizance.

title: LOS ANGELES LACKS FUNDS FOR RAIDERS
description: With the proposed move of the Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles Coliseum approved by a six-woman Federal court jury last Friday, the issue may now depend on finances.

title: Dr. Margo Ann Rubenstein Wed to Peter Amil Winkler
description: The marriage of Dr. Margo Ann Rubenstein of Phoenix, Ariz., a dentist, to Peter Amil Winkler, a partner in the Phoenix law firm of Lewis & Roca and general counsel for the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Central Arizona, took place yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Tarrytown Hilton Hotel.

title: Account
description: * Science Digest magazine to Geers Gross Advertising Inc. for circulation advertising.

title: Roundup of Quarterly Profits and Sales at 271 U.S. Companies; Many Concerns Report A Continuing Fall in Net
description: Profits of the nation's major corporations took a giant step backward in the first quarter of 1982 as high interest rates and a depressed economy helped to cause some of the worst earnings declines in years.

title: Geosource Move
description: Geosource Inc. said its board had approved a definitive agreement for the merger of the company into a subsidiary of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.

title: ANGELS BEAT YANKS BEHIND ZAHN, 2 TO 1
description: The Yankees, beset by a series of injuries, lost a chance for their first three-game winning streak of the season tonight when the California Angels bunched three singles in the eighth inning for a 2-1 victory.

title: Wife Makes New Effort to Leave Soviet Union
description: Six years ago, in an effort to bolster their effort to leave the Soviet Union, Edward Lozansky and his wife, Tatyana, the daughter of a Soviet general, were divorced.

title: Susan Bloch, 42, Dies; Public Relations Agent
description: Susan Bloch, who owned the Susan Bloch Agency, a public-relations ogency that specialized in theater and dance, died yesterday in Tiburon, Calif. She had suffered from kidney disease and was 42 years old.

title: ALEXANDER TO PAY YANKS FOR INJURY
description: The Yankees gained perhaps as much as$65,000 today when Doyle Alexander offered to forgo one month's salary because an injury he suffered last week was self-inflicted. The club accepted the offer.

title: DISINTERMENT OF AN ERROR BY EINSTEIN
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZILIAN SET FOR TICKLISH VISIT TO U.S.
description: The President of Brazil, Joao Baptista Figueiredo, begins a state visit to the United States on Tuesday that, in the words of a newspaper here, has suddenly become ''Malvinized.''

title: IMPARTIAL COVERAGE OF CRISIS INFURIATRING SOME IN BRITAIN
description: The crisis over the Falkland Islands has provoked a debate about press and television coverage, with angry charges that some British journalists are behaving treasonably.

title: HOW VOLUNTARY IS VOLUNTARY GROUP PRAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Supply Rises Slightly
description: Inventories of new domestic cars rose less than 1 percent in April from the previous month, but the total supply remained 6.5 percent lower than in April 1981, Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry journal, reported today.

title: FINAL ARGUMENTS HEARD IN APPEAL ON ALBANY AID TO SCHOOL DISTRICTS
description: The state's highest court heard final arguments today in a case that could reshape the way public education is financed in New York State.

title: SENATE PANEL SUPPORTS $5 BILLION MILITARY CUT
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today supported the Reagan Administration's proposal for a $5 billion cutback in the increase in military spending next year.

title: News Analysis
description: The great question looming as John W. Hinckley Jr.'s trial for shooting President Reagan entered its third week today was what would be done with him if the jury upheld his plea of not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: LOGISTICAL LOGIC; High Wire Act
description: For many who've seen Alexander Calder's ''Circus'' at the Whitney Museum, half its charm lies in its having been an entertainment for the sculptor. Calder, who made the troupe of cloth-and-wire performers and animals in 1926, used to play ringmaster.

title: EDUCATION
description: AYEAR ago, after 10 months as acting president of Barnard College, Ellen V. Futter was named president of the institution, one of the nation's leading women's colleges. At the age of 32, Miss Futter, a graduate of Barnard and Columbia Law School, is one of the nation's youngest college presidents. Much of her attention during the last academic year was devoted to negotiating the future of the relationship between Barnard and Columbia University, the across-the-street neighbor with which it has long been affiliated. After Barnard and Columbia failed to agree on a formula for coeducation, the university announced that it would admit women undergraduates. In this interview with Gene I. Maeroff, an education writer for The New York Times, Miss Futter reflects on those negotiations and the implications for the future. She was first asked to identify the high points and the low points of the eventful first year of her formal presidency.

title: DEC ADDS 3 PERSONAL COMPUTERS
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, which is generally considered the leading American computer company after the International Business Machines Corporation, entered the personal computer business yesterday with three new products.

title: PLANES SOAR INTO STRATOSPHERE TO SNARE BITS OF THE COSMIC PAST
description: HOUSTON EVERY few days a U-2 or some other high-altitude reconnaissance plane takes off and climbs to the stratosphere. There, at 65,000 feet, almost twice as high as airliners routinely venture, the air is rarefied and largely unadulterated by terrestrial pollution, either man-made or natural. The plane begins sweeping this ethereal environment for dust.

title: Aid to Thrift Units
description: President Reagan agreed to sign legislation that could provide Federal loan guarantees to the ailing thrift industry, the Administration said. The Treasury Department announced that the President had endorsed legislation similar to that prepared by Representative Fernand St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, chairman of the House Banking Committee, which would authorize Government regulators to issue ''promissory notes'' to thrift institutions.

title: TASS INDICATES MOSCOW VIEW OF WARHEAD CUTS IS NEGATIVE
description: The Soviet Union did not comment today on President Reagan's proposal for missile reductions but indicated, in a Tass account, that it would apparently not accept his proposal for both sides to reduce their stock of warheads.

title: THUMBLESS GLOVE RULE EXTENDED
description: The State Athletic Commission has decided to make the thumbless boxing glove mandatory for eight-round bouts, Jack Prenderville, the commission chairman, said yesterday.

title: Military Analysis
description: The sea and air fighting between Britain and Argentina around the Falkland Islands has demonstrated that electronic guidance has added another dimension to war, with the attack, at least for now, well ahead of the defense.

title: NEW BID TO RAISE DEBT CEIILING IS DUE
description: ''Dear Mr. Chairman,'' the letters will begin. Signed by Donald T. Regan, the Secretary of the Treasury, they will tell the chairmen of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee that Congress - for the third time in 16 months - must again raise the ceiling on the national debt or the Government will be unable to pay its bills.

title: A.C. Dutton
description: The A.C. Dutton Lumber Corporation, which two years ago was among the 10 largest lumber wholesalers in the country, has asked for court protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws. About $2 million is owed to 56 unsecured creditors, said Arthur Dutton, president of the company.

title: Ex-U.S. Attorney Dies in Fall
description: Devoe Heaton, the former United States Attorney for the southern district of Nevada, fell to his death in a freak accident on the outskirts of San Jose, officials of the American Embassy said today. Mr. Heaton was touring the mountains northwest of San Jose Sunday when he began feeling dizzy. He got out of a car after asking the driver to stop, then fainted and fell over a cliff, said Marilyn Sparks, an embassy spokesman. He leaves his wife, Patricia, and eight children.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY MAYOR KOCH ON CITY BUDGET
description: Following is the text of a statement by Mayor Koch yesterday when he submitted his budget to the City Council and the Board of Estimate:

title: Esso Exploration
description: Canada and Esso Resources Canada Ltd. have concluded six agreements on the company's plans for a $600 million exploration program in the Northern Mackenzie Delta-Beaufort Sea region, the Government said today.

title: PRESIDENTIAL CRITIC GETS A HIGH-LEVEL MESSAGE
description: Representative Marc L. Marks, Republican of Pennsylvania, remembers the two telephone calls he received on March 19, a few days after he stood on the House floor to denounce President Reagan's economic policies as ''Hoover revisited.''

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: HE shaves his head, wears huge boots and lets his suspenders hang byh is side. Hardly what one would expect of a hatter, but that is e xactly what Stephen Jones is. In fact, some of the newest and b rightest hats to be found in New York right now are those made by M r. Jones, a 24-year-old Briton whose current handmade hats buck the m usty mainstream of fedora and fez.

title: Solar Plant Dedicated
description: The nation's largest industrial solar generating facility - a $27 million test project that will provide about half the energy needs of a knitwear factory - was dedicated here today. The Georgia Power Company, which won a 1977 contest for the Solar Total Energy Project, will operate the plant under an agreement with the Department of Energy.

title: HAIG SAYS TRUCE BREACH IN MIDEAST WORRIES U.S.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States was ''very concerned'' over the latest breakdown in the cease-fire between Israeli and Palestine Liberation Organization forces in southern Lebanon and was actively trying to ''shore up'' the 10-month truce.

title: NEW HOMOSEXUAL DISORDER WORRIES HEALTH OFFICIALS
description: ASERIOUS disorder of the immune system that has been known to doctors for less than a year - a disorder that appears to affect primarily male homosexuals - has now afflicted at least 335 people, of whom it has killed 136, officials of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta said yesterday. Federal health officials are concerned that tens of thousands more homosexual men may be silently affected and therefore vulnerable to potentially grave ailments.

title: CTS Buys Stock
description: The CTS Corporation, an electronics company based in Elkhart, Ind., said it had purchased the 252,800 shares, or 5.7 percent, of its common stock, held by concerns associated with the Belzberg family for about $8 million, or $31.50 a share.

title: PRIME COMPUTER SUES ON SALES LIST
description: Prime Computer Inc. has filed suit against a privately owned competitor, the EMC Corporation, charging it with penetrating Prime's computer bank containing a confidential sales list of 2,600 Prime customers.

title: MAYORAL PANEL TO STUDY EDUCATING HANDICAPPED
description: Mayor Koch, who has often expressed concern that education programs for handicapped children were growing too rapidly, announced yesterday the appointment of a panel to study the effectiveness of the programs and to recommend ways of cutting costs.

title: MODERATE REPUBLICANS FEEL THEY CONTROL HOUSE PASSAGE OF BUDGET
description: Moderate Republican Congressmen from the Northeast and the Middle West, who voted for President Reagan's tax and budget bills last year, say that the budget compromise worked out last week is unacceptable to them.

title: PRESIDENT IS REPLACED AT HIGH STOY CORP.
description: Joel M. Rudenstein, 32, has been elected president and chief executive of the High Stoy Technological Corporation of Lake Success, L.I. Mr. Rudenstein, who was controller and vice president of the company, succeeds Charles W.B. Wardell 3d, 37, who has resigned. Mr. Wardell will serve the company as a consultant and will stay on as a director.

title: A $417.5 MILLION OFFER BY COCA-COLA FOR BOTTLER
description: The Coca-Cola Company yesterday announced an agreement to buy one of its largest independent bottling companies for about $417.5 million, with the intent of subsequently selling the bottler, the Associated Coca-Cola Bottling Company, to new owners.

title: Ormandy Conducts Rachmaninoff's Second
description: Eugene Ormandy did not whip the Philadelphia Orchestra into a frenzy Wednesday night, when he conducted Rachmaninoff's Second Symphony in Avery Fisher Hall. He did not turn the work into a major statement of the human spirit or bind its meandering phrases into compelling edge-of-the-seat melodrama.

title: Eisenreich Sidelined
description: Jim Eisenreich, the rookie outfielder for the Minnesota Twins, was hospitalized and put on the 15-day disabled list yesterday in Minneapolis for treatment of a nerve disorder. Club officials said that he was undergoing a self-hypnosis and bio-feedback program to determine the cause of hyper-ventilation and muscle-spasm problems that caused him to miss five games in a row. Last week, Eisenreich was treated at a Milwaukee hospital after taking himself out of the lineup in a game against the Brewers.

title: THOSE FORBIDDEN TO KNOW THEIR HERITAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: LOW RATES NO CURE-ALL, REGAN WARNS O.E.C.D.
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, taking the offensive in the growing international dispute over American economic policy, warned Western finance ministers today that the lower interest rates they want in the United States ''will not be a panacea for the world's economic problems.''

title: BALLET: 'AFTERNOON OF FAUN'
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S ''Afternoon of a Faun'' is a sophisticated gloss upon the original Nijinsky-Debussy ballet, and since its premiere in 1953, it has supported a surprising range of emotional nuances from its various casts.

title: May 18 Hearing Set On Raiders' Move
description: A hearing has been scheduled for May 18 to determine whether the Oakland Raiders will be permitted to move to Los Angeles immediately or must wait until the National Football League has appealed the verdict that cleared the way for the Raiders' relocation.

title: Standard Metals Delay
description: The Oklahoma Publishing Company, as expected, attempted to oust the management of the Standard Metals Corporation in a proxy fight at the annual meeting yesterday. After the vote, the meeting was adjourned until Friday, and the chairman of Standard Metals, Boris Gresov, said the results of the vote on directors would be announced then.

title: Van Heusen Account
description: McCann Erickson March, a direct marketing subsidiary of McCann-Erickson, has become the agency for Van Heusen Corporate Markets Company.

title: Prices Off on Rate Uncertainty; 6-Month Bills At 12.236%
description: Prices of debt securities drifted lower yesterday as the credit markets continued to be buffeted by conflicting interest rate forecasts. The specter of vastly increased sales of Treasury bills, notes, and bonds later this year was cited by many analysts as a major worry in the marketplace.

title: FREQUENT QUESTION: WILL REAGAN RUN AGAIN IN '84?
description: A perverse kind of curiosity has emerged in the capital. As political and economic troubles threaten the success of President Reagan's first term, people are asking themselves with increasing frequency whether he will run for a second.

title: MURRAY POWERS
description: Murray Powers, a retired newspaper executive and professor of journalism, died Friday after a short illness.

title: WARSAW EXPELS TWO U.S. DIPLOMATS
description: In the first incident of its kind here in years, two United States diplomats were expelled tonight for receiving papers from a Polish scientist in his apartment Sunday night.

title: ADVANCES HELPING RETINA-CASE ODDS
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard, the world welterweight champion, suffered a detached retina that sent him to the operating room Sunday, he became one of 25,000 Americans who are victims of the eye disorder each year and who are benefiting from therapeutic advances that have vastly improved the chances for restoring vision.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's proposal for cuts in the strategic nuclear arsenals of the Soviet Union and the United States seems as if it ought to meet the common objective of reducing fears on both sides. But it is generally agreed that it is going to be very hard to translate the proposal into an agreement.

title: Father and Son to Be Given Law Degrees
description: At 59, Kenneth Kopelson will be the oldest member of his class when he graduates from St. John's University School of Law on June 6. At 22, Kevin Kopelson will be the youngest in his class when he graduates from Columbia Law School on May 19.

title: A $2.3 BILLION OPERATING BUDGET IS PROPOSED BY TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: The cost of operating New York City's subway and bus system in the coming fiscal year will be $2.3 billion, about $300 million more than in fiscal 1982, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: Kheel Sues to See Opposition Memo
description: Theodore W. Kheel, who recently resigned after 33 years as official arbitrator in Transit Authority labor disputes, has filed a suit under the state's Freedom of Information Act to see an authority staff memorandum and other documents unfavorable to his reappointment.

title: REAGAN SYMPATHETIC, BUT CAUTIOUS ON A KING HOLIDAY
description: Although he asserted that he sympathized with blacks' desire to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., President Reagan said today that making a holiday of the civil rights leader's birthday might start a trend toward too many holidays that cost the Government too much money.

title: CITY AIMING AT $1.8 BILLION TO FINANCE CAPITAL PROJECTS
description: The Koch administration yesterday proposed a $1.8 billion capital budget for the coming fiscal year, but acknowledged the unlikelihood of being able to commit all of that amount to construction projects during that time.

title: SIRHAN MAKES PLEA TO KEEP PAROLE SCHEDULED FOR 1984
description: Sirhan B. Sirhan pleaded passionately for his freedom today before a panel that is considering whether to rescind his scheduled parole in 1984 from the life term he is serving for the 1968 assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

title: Advertising; Dancer Pushes Popsicles
description: THE people behind the proud name of Popsicle, and their agency, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, are determined to add new luster to the brand that is already the oldest and biggest in the $1 billion frozen novelty business. The weapon is advertising, and an enormous program is under way on the West Coast.

title: North Sea Link
description: Marathon Oil UK and Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine are negotiating an agreement to pipe oil from Elf's Heimdal Field in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea to Marathon's Brae Field in the British sector, a Marathon spokesman said. The link, which is expected to cost about $135 million, would enable Heimdal, which is mainly a gas field, to channel its oil ashore to Scotland via the Brae and Forties fields. Production from the southern reservoir of the Brae Field is scheduled to begin next year.

title: Saving (Some) Excellence in Congress
description: A court's threat to have a master draw new maps for electing New York's Congressmen and state legislators worked. On the brink of yesterday's reporting deadline, Republican and Democratic leaders compromised, dividing the loss of five seats in the House of Representatives as equally as possible.

title: LEGISLATORS APPROVE PLAN TO REMAP THEIR DISTRICTS
description: The New York State Legislature approved a new set of political maps for itself this evening amid threats by the Assembly Republicans and some Senate Democrats that they would go to court to keep the plan from going into effect.

title: DEFICITS AND 'DEFICITS'
description: Alarmed at the size of the mounting deficit, President Reagan has come out for a constitutional amendment to enforce a balanced Federal budget. After the amendment is ratified, the Government will be allowed to spend only what it takes in as taxes. No more borrowing, with its horrendous consequences. Financial virtue will have been restored.

title: Citibank Aide to Call For Copy Testing Panel
description: As the annual marketing conference of the American Marketing Association got under way at the Grand Hyatt Hotel yesterday, Citibank announced that Ellen Sills-Levy, a vice president and director of communications for the bank, would call tomorrow for the formation of a Financial Copy Council to bring the wonders of copy testing into this exotic area.

title: A GALA PREVIEW FOR GIVENCHY RETROSPECTIVE
description: When Hubert de Givenchy was told 30 years ago in Paris that an actress named Hepburn wanted him to make some clothes for her, he was elated: he thought it was Katharine Hepburn. When the woman arrived, she turned out to be a tall, skinny wraith named Audrey, who had scored a big success in ''Roman Holiday'' and wanted him to design some clothes for her next film, ''Sabrina.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LEADING DRUG EPIDEMIOLOGIST
description: Dr. Dennis Slone, an epidemiologist who did research in identifying adverse reactions to drugs, died yesterday in Lexington, Mass., after a long illness. He was 52 years old.

title: Col. James M. Higgins Dead; Retired Engineer for the Army
description: Col. James M. Higgins, retired, an Army engineer who helped design the distant early warning radar system in Alaska and Canada and worked on the construction of the Guatemalan port of Santo Tomas, died Friday at Community Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Montclair.

title:
MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
92d St. Y Offers Jewish Opera 'Mikhoels'
description: ''Mikhoels the Wise,'' an opera by Bruce Adolphe and Mel Gordon tracing the rise and fall of Solomon Mikhoels, the Yiddish actor and director, received its world premiere at the 92d Street Y over the weekend in a production directed by Mr. Gordon and David Yakir and conducted by Amy Kaiser. Set in Soviet Russia, except for a single scene at New York's Polo Grounds, and covering a period of 30 years from 1918 to 1948, the opera focuses on Mikhoels's role as a symbol of Yiddish culture, rather than on his personal life or artistic activity per se.

title: MCADOO PLAYS FOR A WINNER
description: During one swift and emotional moment here at the Forum on Sunday afternoon, Bob McAdoo realized just how much he wanted to play for a championship team.

title: Lebanon Clashes Leave 19 Dead and 40 Wounded
description: Nineteen people were killed and 40 were wounded today in battles between factions in the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli, security and party sources said.

title: Weaver Bout Off
description: The World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight between the champion Mike Weaver and Randall (Tex) Cobb has been postponed because of a shoulder injury suffered by Weaver, according to Weaver's attorney. The bout had been scheduled for June 2 in Atlantic City.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE UNDERCLASS. By Ken Auletta. 348 pages. Random House. $17.50.

title: Iran Says Army Advances on Port
description: Iranian forces are advancing in a multipronged attack on the strategic oil port of Khurramshahr, the only major Iranian city still in Iraqi hands after 19 months of the Persian Gulf conflict, the Iranian press agency reported today.

title: U.N. ECOLOGY PARLEY OPENS AMID GLOOM
description: The second United Nations conference on the global environment opened here today amid deep concern about the state of the world's ecological systems and considerable pessimism about the world's ability to deal with what many see as a growing crisis.

title: Kean Delays Naming Chief Education Aide
description: The nomination of Ronald H. Lewis as New Jersey's education commissioner was withheld today as inquiries began on possible plagiarism in his doctoral thesis.

title: Tigers 3, Rangers 1
description: Mike Ivie's first American League home run, a two-run shot in the first inning, backed Milt Wilcox's eight-hit pitching in Detroit's victory. The loss was the Rangers' third in a row and 15th in the last 16 games.

title: OPERA: THREE ONE-ACTERS GET PREMIERES AT SOHO
description: THROUGH an association between Golden Fleece Ltd., which presents new American musical-theater works, the SoHo Rep presented the premieres of three one-act operas last weekend -to be presented with alternating casts, in four performances each weekend through May 23. As the word ''opera'' implies, the music, directed by John Klingberg, plays as big a role as the characters. On Saturday night, neither drama nor music was slighted, though each work used music with varying success.

title: Coast Guard Chief Approved
description: The nomination of Vice Adm. James S. Gracey as commandant of the Coast Guard was confirmed without dissent today by the Senate.

title: Laura Plaut, Who Long Aided Joint Disease Hospital, Dies
description: Laura Plaut, a philanthropist associated with the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York since 1907, when it was founded, died Sunday at a nursing home in Manhattan. She was 101 years old.

title: Fatal Fall
description: Those familiar with Del Carroll, the well-known thoroughbred trainer who died Sunday, are baffled by the circumstances surrounding his fatal fall from a horse. ''If there was an animal that was hard to control, Del would be able to handle it,'' said John Clark, the Kentucky horseman, of the trainer who started riding at the age of 10 and became a world-class polo player.

title: Doyle Dane's Earnings Up by 43.8% in Quarter
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International reported yesterday that its revenues in the first quarter were up 13.4 percent, to $38.9 million from $34.3 million a year earlier, while net income rose 43.8 percent, to $690,000, or 12 cents a share, from $480,000, or 8 cents.

title: Lehman Sued Over Nucorp
description: Two California investors have filed suit against Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., accusing the investment concern of fraudulently promoting the purchase of securities issued by Nucorp Energy Inc.

title: THE LIGHTS ARE DIMMED AS THE WAR COMES HOME AT LAST TO BUENOS AIRES
description: A sense of being at war has seized Argentina. It started in what is called ''the south'' - which these days means just about everything south of Buenos Aires -with blackouts, children crouching under their school desks for air-raid drills and then, most chilling, the tearful survivors of the cruiser General Belgrano, sunk a week ago, and the coffins.

title: Chess: West Germany's Huebner Wins Cloverline Tourney
description: West Germany's Robert Huebner scored a convincing triumph in the Cloverline International Tournament in Chicago, taking first place with a 2 1/2-point margin. The former finalist in the world championship candidates matches had no trouble in any game in the double-round event. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Huebner 6 0 4 8 Browne 3 2 5 5 1/2 Korchnoi 2 2 6 5 Dzindzikashvili 1 2 7 4 1/2 Lein 1 3 6 4 Martz 0 4 6 3

title: Steel Output Off in Week
description: Steel production fell to 1.454 million tons, or 49.1 percent of capacity, in the week ended last Saturday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Castro Urging Steps to Halt 'Imminent' U.S.-British Move
description: Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, has sent a letter to leaders of nations professing nonalignment urging that steps be taken to halt what he called ''imminent Anglo-American aggression'' against Argentina in the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: DANCE: MISS MAKAROVA, BUJONES IN 'RAYMONDA'
description: THERE are times when one hopes that a theater is full of dance students. One of them was Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, when the American Ballet Theater's Natalia Makarova and Fernando Bujones provided a lesson in style with their performance of divertissements from the second and third acts of ''Raymonda.''

title: LOGISTICAL LOGIC; Reredundant
description: Reports from Buenos Aires revive a repellent redundancy favored by American military planners.

title: HILDA BRUNGOT
description: Hilda Brungot, a former Democratic State Representative from Berlin, died Sunday at a nursing home here. She was 95 years old. Mrs. Brungot served in the Legislature from 1931 to 1937 and from 1941 to 1975, when she was in her late 80's. At that time she was the oldest female legislator in the United States.

title: Talking Business with Reddy of Charles River Associates
description: SIgnificance Of Sea Treaty

title: PALESTINIANS REQUIRE MORE THAN 'PROMISE'
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 HELD IN EXTORTION OF YONKERS TOY STORE
description: The chairman of the Democratic Party in Yonkers and the head of the city's Planning Board were arrested with three other men today. They were charged by the F.B.I. with extorting $13,500 from a local branch of a nationwide toy-store chain.

title: Earlier Menstruation
description: For years, scientists have been debating whether menarche, the onset of menstruation, has been occurring at an earlier age. In the latest of these studies, researchers at the Harvard Center for Population Studies have concluded that menstruation begins almost two years earlier now for women in the United States and Europe than it did a century ago.

title: New I.B.M. Chip
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's general technology division said it was manufacturing a new 64,000-bit computer memory chip that is 62 percent of the size of its previous 64,000-bit chip. It said the new chip is intended as a direct replacement for the earlier chip and has the same performance and voltage requirements. It said 240 of the new chips could be arranged on a silicon wafer four inches in diameter, compared with 145 for the earlier design.

title: Don Ohlmeyer to Work With Nabisco Brands
description: Don Ohlmeyer, a 37-year-old network TV sports producer, has founded the Ohlmeyer Communications Company, and Nabisco Brands announced that it would become his partner on a project-by-project basis.

title: House Passes Copyright Bill
description: The House passed today and sent to President Reagan for signature a bill designed to curtail the billion-dollar-a-year business of illegally counterfeiting and selling copyright motion pictures, tapes and records.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Graphic Scanning Corp. said it had acquired all of the stock outstanding of California Satellite Systems in exchange for 457,523 shares of Graphic common stock valued at about $7 million.

title: DAYCOM GROWS IN OFFICE TECHNOLOGY
description: The Daycom Corporation, a small research and development company that grew out of a Muzak franchise, is making its presence felt in the automated-office industry.

title: Grace Spending
description: W.R. Grace & Company plans to increase capital spending to $700 million this year from $650 million in 1981, J. Peter Grace, chairman, said after the annual meeting. He said spending on energy operations would rise to $200 million from $145 million, while research and development expenditures would rise to $65 million from $54.7 million a year earlier. The company is still considering the separation of certain subsidiaries, he said in reply to a question, but did not elaborate.

title: Yale Repertory Theater Given Vaughan Award
description: The Yale Repertory Theater and School of Drama, of which Lloyd Richards is director, has been named this year's winner of the $10,000 James N. Vaughan Award by the Shubert Foundation.

title: PIPELINE REJECTION CHALLENGED
description: The Northern Tier Pipeline Company filed suit in Federal District Court today asking that Gov. John Spellman's rejection of a proposed oil port at Port Angeles and a 1,500-mile pipeline be overturned on grounds of national security.

title: Girl Gets 2 Years For Drowning Playmate
description: A 12-year-old girl convicted of second-degree murder for drowning a playmate at a swimming pool last summer was sentenced today to the two years at the New Mexico Girls School.

title: CHOIR CONCERT: CONCORDIA COLLEGE
description: THE Concordia Choir, a chorus of Concordia College students directed by Gerald Patrick Coleman, sang works by Hugo Distler, Michael Haydn, Bach, Respighi, Randall Thompson and Paul O. Manz on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall.

title: 'DREAMGIRLS' AND 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY' LEAD IN NOMINATIONS FOR TONYS
description: ''Dreamgirls,'' the Broadway musical about a trio of women rising to the top in the pop-music world, has been nominated for 13 of the American Theater Wing's Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards, including best musical of the season. It led the field among musicals, closely followed by ''Nine,'' which received 12 Tony nominations.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Joe Cowley, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list because of a shoulder sprain and activated Al Hrabosky, pitcher, from the list.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AT THE KEYBOARD

title: El Al to Keep Sabbath?  High Court Says No
description: The Israeli Supreme Court today overturned a Government decision to eliminate El Al Israel Airlines flights on the Jewish Sabbath and on holy days and said the order demanded by Orthodox activists needed endorsement by Parliament.

title: SENATOR MUSTO GETS 7 YEARS IN SENTENCING OF 7 FOR GRAFT
description: William V. Musto, a State Senator who has been a legislator since 1946 and Mayor of Union City since 1954, was sentenced today to seven years in prison for sharing in hundreds of thousands of dollars in kickbacks from a contractor doing business in Union City.

title: MILK SHORTAGE FORCES A DAIRY IN HAWAII TO ORDER 496 COWS
description: In an effort to recoup the loss that occurred when more than 200 of its cows were found to be producing contaminated milk, Hawaii's largest dairy has had a herd of blackand-white Holsteins flown in from the mainland.

title: HUGE COAL EXPORT TERMINAL PLANNED FOR NEW YORK
description: If the Koch administration and the Port Authority have their way, New York could become the largest coal export terminal in the country in the next five years.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ANXIETY over the search for jobs is creating new academic, social and emotional problems for college seniors, career and mental health counselors report. Students in their final semesters face pressure to travel to off-campus interviews, while at the same time completing academic requirements. Competition for jobs is destructive to campus friendships and to the social life that ought to carry over from college to the postcommencement world.

title: Late Start for Arms Control
description: What is wrong with START - President Reagan's bid to negotiate strategic arms reductions instead of only limitations - is the assumption that technology will wait for every Administration to take a new approach. What is dramatically right about the offer, however, is Mr. Reagan's recognition at last that the Soviet Union and United States share an ''overriding interest'' in restraining the race. Finally divorcing this negotiation from other issues, the President wants to get on with it. His proposals deserve serious response.

title: Hindus Riot in India
description: Members of rival Hindu social categories fought with stones, bricks and acid today until Government troops broke up the rioting. Police reported 32 arrests, scores of people injured and more than 350 houses damaged.

title: 6 ISRAELI ARMY OFFICERS CONDEMN TROOP BEHAVIOR IN OCCUPIED AREAS
description: Six Israeli army officers who have faced rioting Arabs recently in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip held a news conference today to condemn the behavior of soldiers and to denounce a Government policy that they said had placed troops in a dangerous, dehumanizing situation.

title: Decision File; Good News For Travelers
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, which is being phased out over the next three years, is tearing up its rule book page by page. Just recently, it decided that airlines no longer have to charge consumers the highest possible price on connecting flights.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Ford Motor Credit Co. filed with the S.E.C. to offer $250 million of one-year extendable notes.

title: 30 Stocks Tied Electronically
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers today released a list of the 30 stocks to be traded on a new electronic system linking the seven major stock exchanges with hundreds of broker-dealers in the over-the-counter market.

title: AN OBITUARY TOO SOON
description: Here's one reason why reports of the political death of Governor Jerry Brown (owing to eggs laid by medflies and in Presidential primaries) may have been greatly exaggerated:

title: A Hometown Victory
description: Sometimes a prophet's neighbors are the last to get the message, but for the record, Adams, Mass., the hometown of the 19th-century feminist, Susan B. Anthony, has finally selected a woman as selectman.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we lose faith in our elected and appointed officials to carry out their duties for the public good rather than their personal gain, then democracy and freedom are lost.'' - Federal Judge H. Lee Sarokin. (B14:2.)

title: ARGENTINA EASES TERMS FOR PEACE IN THE FALKLANDS
description: Argentine officials indicated a softening today in their terms for peace in the dispute with Britain over the Falkland Islands.

title: POLAND CENSURES OLD ANNOYER: RADIO FREE EUROPE
description: As the unrest in Poland's cities spread last week, the Polish authorities revived a rationale for the outbursts that has become a standard over the years.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 11, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumers expanded their buying on credit in March, increasing total installment debt by $990 million, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The increase was the biggest since October and was seen by some analysts as a sign of growing consumer confidence that the recession would end soon. (Page D1.)

title: Ex-Ranger Arraigned
description: Pete Stemkowski, who played hockey for six years with the New York Rangers, pleaded guilty yesterday in Nassau County District Court to a charge that he offered $20,000 to a police undercover agent to break the ankle and wrist of a business associate who owed him money. Stemkowski will be sentenced on June 22 for criminal solicitation, a misdemeanor punishable by a year in county jail and a fine of up to $1,000.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Takes Final For Her 5th Italian Title
description: Chris Evert Lloyd won her fifth Italian singles title today, beating Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia in the final, 6-0, 6-3.

title: Voters Across Jersey Going to Polls Today
description: Voters across New Jersey will go to the polls today to elect local officials.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 11, 1982
description: International Britain's flotilla advanced to within sight of Argentine positions in the Falklands after bombarding shore installations for the second successive day, according to correspondents' dispatches from the combat zone. Frigates and destroyers armed with anti-aircraft missiles were said to be lying only a few miles off Stanley, the capital of the islands. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Argentina confirmed an easing in its terms for a peace settlement with Britain. A high official acknowledged that Buenos Aires had dropped its insistence on gaining recognition of its sovereignty over the Falklands before its troops are withdrawn. (A1:5.)

title: BRITAIN ASKS U.S. TO LEND IT AN AIR FORCE TANKER
description: Britain has asked the United States to lend the Royal Air Force a long-range KC-135 aerial tanker to refuel British bombers and reconnaissance planes based on Ascension Island in the South Atlantic, Administration officials said today.

title: Nu-West to Sell Transalta Stake
description: Nu-West Group Ltd. said it would sell its 20 percent interest in Transalta Utilities to Canadian Utilities Ltd. for $200.6 million.

title: EROSION-WARY FARMERS ARE SPURNING THE TRADITIONAL PLOW
description: SPRING plowing has long ranked alongside the return of the robin, Mother's Day, April showers and June brides as a symbol of the American heartland's annual renewal. No more. The moldboard plow, traditionally used to prepare cropland for planting, has become a costly villain blamed for alarming rates of erosion of precious farm belt topsoil, and farmers are abandoning it in droves.

title: HURWITZ GROUP BUYING 33% OF SIMPLICITY STOCK
description: Charles E. Hurwitz, chairman and chief executive officer of MCO Holdings Inc., an expanding oil and gas company, appeared today to have outmaneuvered Cook International Inc. in taking control of the Simplicity Pattern Company.

title: 'Barnum' Closes Sunday
description: ''Barnum,'' the musical with book by Mark Bramble, music by Cy Coleman and lyrics by Michael Stewart, will close after Sunday's matinee at the St. James Theater. Directed by Joe Layton, the play will have run for 854 performances and 26 previews.

title: Rates Lower On Certificates
description: Declining interest rates in the Treasury securities market reduced the maximum yields available on various kinds of savings certificates.

title: Sports of The Times; Hockey's Dark Age and Space Age
description: ONE incongruity of the Stanley Cup finals is that Roger Neilson, the acting head coach of the British Columbia wrestling grizzlies, is one of the most advanced and intelligent coaches in his business.

title: DOW SLIDES 8.28
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday in less active trading as a result of profit taking and investor concern that interest rates will rise.

title: Wifely Wisdom
description: Everybody, as Jimmy Durante used to say, wants to get into the act.

title: TV: 'OSSIE & RUBY' RETURNS
description: ''WITH OSSIE & RUBY'' is back on public television for a second season starting tonight at 10:30 on WNET-TV, and before you shrug it off as a ''special interest'' series, that is, a series of special interest to blacks only, it is suggested that you look in on it. It promises to go beyond that.

title: The Special Prosecutor Works
description: This is an odd moment for the Reagan Administration to disparage the special prosecutor section of the Ethics in Government Act.

title: KNICKS' HIERARCHY SPLIT OVER NEW COACH
description: A split has apparently developed within the Madison Square Garden hierarchy over the selection of a coach to replace Red Holzman, according to sources close to the team and corporation. The split could jeopardize negotiations that would bring the former Knick forward, Dave DeBusschere, into the organization as executive vice president and general manager.

title: Great Southwest
description: The Great Southwest Industries Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to buy 90 percent of the shares of the Collins Well Service Company for $4.3 million in cash and notes.

title: THEATER: 'DISPOSSESSED,' A NEW CITY HOUSE PARTY
description: THE handsome, high-ceilinged modern apartment would be right at home on the pages of Architectural Digest. Behind a low, comfortable-looking loveseat -the kind you sit in and sink into - is a tall white curtain acting as divider between the living room and the music room. The designer is Ron Kajiwara. Remember his name if you have a loft or a play that you want decorated.

title: World Wildlife Fund Plans to Market Symbol
description: The World Wildlife Fund-U.S., taking a lead from American Greetings' Strawberry Shortcake and the National Football League, both of which are making a bundle in the licensing area, has announced that its giant panda symbol is now available to companies for appropriate tie-ins.

title: JURY FINDS IN FAVOR OF ABC IN SUIT OVER '20-20' PROGRAM
description: A jury ruled today in favor of the American Broadcasting Company in a multimillion-dollar libel lawsuit brought by an Akron woman who contended she was defamed in an ABC-TV ''20-20'' program.

title: Buckley and Burt Appointed To New Posts at State Dept.
description: President Reagan named Richard Burt today to be Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs and James L. Buckley to be State Department counselor.

title: Texas Prisons Barred From Accepting Inmates
description: The Texas Board of Correction today ordered that no more inmates be accepted into the state's overcrowded prison system until space requirements of a Federal court order can be met.

title: College Testing Groups Sued Over Fees for Poor Students
description: A coalition of college students has filed suit against the the College Entrance Examination Board and the American College Testing Program, saying they illegally charged 500,000 needy students for processing financial aid forms.

title: GENTRIFIERS: THE LAWYERS
description: The lawyers who represent the landlords now emptying old buildings of the poor and elderly for the vast profits to be gleaned from renovation pretend they are performing two public services. One, they say, is improving neighborhoods by helping convert run-down dwellings into luxury co-ops for the upper middle class. Their second virtue, in the lawyers' view, is providing counsel, in the best constitutional tradition, to controversial tenants.

title: TV: 7-PART SERIES ON OPPENHEIMER BEGINS ON PBS
description: PUBLIC television's ''American Playhouse'' is devoting seven weekly hours to a BBC production made with the help of some money from WGBH-TV of Boston. In any event, the subject is American. ''Oppenheimer,'' beginning tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET-TV, is a biography of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the theoretical physicist who died in 1967, at the age of 62, but whose life and career remain controversial.

title: Islanders Expecting Grab Tactics Again
description: With the second game of the four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup series set for tonight at Nassau Coliseum, the Islanders were expecting more of the grab-and-hug tactics the Vancouver Canucks utilized Saturday night.

title: Opera Ensemble Offers 'The Rake's Progress'
description: The sense of preparation and professionalism in the Opera Ensemble of New York's production of ''The Rake's Progress'' by Stravinsky more than overcomes the modesty of its two-piano accompaniment and cramped stage. The action generates from a slightly elevated space within the stage area, and scenes change by means of sliding panels and blackouts.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN STATES FEEL DELAYED EFFECT OF RECESSION
description: The full force of the nationwide recession is at last raking the Rocky Mountain states, deflating the region's energy boom and forcing widespread layoffs among the tens of thousands of workers drawn here in recent years to make their fortune.

title: SIR RUDOLF PROVIDES EXCITEMENT AT AUDITION
description: Far from the crimson and gilt of the Metropolitan Opera, in a modest auditorium in Greenwich Village, Sir Rudolf Bing was again auditioning singers yesterday - for the first time, he said, since he retired 10 years ago.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: THE case of Nancy, a 33-year-old nurse, was bizarre. Periodically, Nancy told her doctors of becoming hungry, feeling shaky and sensing her skin turn cold. Her weight dropped from 295 pounds to 145 with the aid of medications she was unable to name.

title: BONUS DEAL FOR STALLONE
description: Sylvester Stallone will star in Robert Evans's $20 million ''Cotton Club,'' and, according to Mr. Evans, the financial arrangement involved is unique.

title: PENSION MEETING ENDS IN CONFLICT
description: Partisan conflict broke out today at a meeting of the National Commission on Social Security Reform over a Senate committee's budget blueprint urging $40 billion in retirement system savings.

title: Market Place; Rosy Outlook At Matrix
description: THE Exxon Corporation ran into a problem about a year and a half ago with huge compressor pistons used in its North Sea oil and gas operations. They were breaking too often, bringing operations to a halt until the pistons could be replaced.

title: JERSEY LAWMAKERS BACK A REFERENDUM ON ARMS
description: The New Jersey Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would enable voters to express their opinions about the nuclear arms race.

title: Bates Ousts Executive
description: Isabel Ziegler, senior vice president and head of the TV spot buying unit at Ted Bates New York for eight years, was dismissed last week by Walter E. Reichel, director of the media and program department, because of differences in management philosophy, he said. Reached at home, she said that she agreed with that assessment.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Standard Inc. has elected Gerald A. Tonges a vice president.

title: BRITISH OPEN FIRE ON ARGENTINE SHIP, LONDON ANNOUNCES
description: A British warship opened fire on a large Argentine vessel near the Falkland Islands on Monday night, the Defense Ministry announced in a terse communique this morning.

title: VIOLINIST: GELMAN
description: GREGORY GELMAN, a Russian violinist who came to this country five years ago, played sonatas by Beethoven and Ravel in the first half of his Carnegie Recital Hall concert Sunday night and then joined a group called the International Symphony Orchestra in Shostakovich's Second Violin Concerto.

title: Michigan Governor Asks $326 Million in Cuts
description: Warning that Michigan could suffer the poorest credit rating in the nation, Gov. William R. Milliken today outlined plans to cut the state's $4.3 billion budget by $326 million unless the Legislature raises the state income tax temporarily.

title: Spending Plans Down
description: American consumers generally are pessimistic about the economy and are wary of going into debt or dipping into their savings to make major purchases, according to University of Michigan study released today. The quarterly survey of consumer attitudes said it found no evidence during the first quarter of the traditional signs of economic recovery - consumer interest in home, car and major consumer good purchases.

title: ABUNDANT HARVEST SEEN IN U.S. WHEAT FORECAST
description: The Agriculture Department estimated today that the 1982 winter wheat harvest would be 56.2 million metric tons, or 2.06 billion bushels, the second largest in history and only 2 percent smaller than last year's record of 2.1 billion bushels

title: L.I. Man Guilty In Transit Murder
description: A 22-year-old man was found guilty yesterday of second-degree murder in the shooting death of a Transit Authority bus driver in Brooklyn last October in a dispute over free transfers.

title: Chief Executive Named At Exxon's Zilog Unit
description: Franc R.J. de Weeger, vice president of the Signetics Corporation, has been named president and chief executive officer of Zilog Inc., a subsidiary of Exxon Enterprises, the oil company's venture into advanced electronics.

title: Bridge: Cayne and Hamilton Take 8th Cavendish Invitational
description: The eighth Cavendish Club Invitation Charity Pairs event ended Sunday night in an overwhelming victory for a newly formed partnership: Jim Cayne of New York and Fred Hamilton of North Lauderdale, Fla.

title: BLOCKER CHAIRMAN TAKES 2 NEW ROLES
description: John R. Blocker, chairman and chief executive of the Blocker Energy Corporation, a Houston-based offshore and onshore drilling contractor, said yesterday that he would assume the additional titles of president and chief operating officer because the company was cutting back on its operations. As a result, he said, its management was overstructured.

title: MANY ON COAST FIGHT OIL LEASE MOVE
description: Many residents of coastal California are reacting angrily to Interior Secretary James G. Watt's decision last week to accelerate oil and gas exploration off some of the coast's most scenic portions.

title: U.N. TALKS CONTINUE BUT NO PROGRESS IS REPORTED
description: The diplomatic search for an end to the hostilities in the Falkland Islands resumed here for the third successive day today, but the negotiators did not make their customary assertions that the talks were advancing.

title: NEW YORK STILL BECKONS THE NATION'S YOUNG
description: To those who track their migration, the coming of young Americans to New York City is proving a relentless and vital exception to nationwide population patterns.

title: Article 128150 -- No Title
description: Mayor Koch, announcing a budget that relies on $519 million in state actions yet to come, called yesterday for new statewide taxes to give New York City and other municipalities the money they are counting on to cover expenses.

title: REAGAN PHONES
description: As Sugar Ray Leonard lay recuperating yesterday from surgery to repair a partially detached retina in his left eye, President Reagan and hundreds of others from all over the world flooded him with good wishes and advice. Many people, the President excepted, urged the 25-year-old world welterweight champion to retire from boxing.

title: Hayakawa Backs Ex-Dean
description: Senator S.I. Hayakawa, who decided not to seek a second term after a large group of Republicans challenged him in the primary, has endorsed Ted Bruinsma, a party dark horse, for the post, it was announced today. Mr. Bruinsma, a businessman, is a former dean of Loyola Law School in Los Angeles.

title: Boy Shot by Police Is Still in Hospital
description: A 14-year-old boy who was shot in the head Sunday by a police officer was conscious and in stable condition yesterday at St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island.

title: BRITAIN'S INDUSTRIAL TRIBUNALS
description: The long arm of the law was grappling with a question of sandwiches. The publican initially contended that he had received $70 for sandwiches he supplied to a wedding reception. But his employer determined that $430 had been paid, and sacked him on the spot.

title: Scandal Has Emptied Philippine High Court
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in an effort to restore what he called the ''prestige, integrity and good name'' of the Philippines Supreme Court, accepted the resignation of all 14 justices today.

title: Carter Backs Mondale For Presidency in 1984
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that he supported Walter F. Mondale, his former Vice President, as Democratic candidate for President in the 1984 elections.

title: METS TOP PADRES IN 9TH, 3-2
description: For the second straight time, a pinch-hitter won a game for the Mets in the ninth inning last night. Bob Bailor, batting with two out, doubled in a pair of runs for a 3-2 victory over the San Diego Padres at Shea Stadium.

title: Slowing of the Inflation Rate Threatens Koch Budget Plan
description: The decline in the rate of inflation over the last 12 months, while a boon to consumers, threatens to create difficulties for the New York City budget.

title: IC Industries Stock
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said it had completed the sale of its 14.3 percent interest in IC Industries to the company for about $72 million.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When did the ability to make a noise evolve?

title: Brooklyn Philharmonia And Miss de los Angeles
description: The program presented Sunday by the Brooklyn Philharmonia at the Brooklyn Academy of Music combined the musical accents of Spanish and French, mixing the syncopations and percussive thrusts of the one and the liquidity and grace of the other.

title: THE BELGRANO'S DISTINCTION IN HER FIRST LIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawkins Likely to Play; Leg X-rays Negative
description: Darryl Dawkins, the Philadelphia 76ers' center, practiced with the team yesterday after X-rays on his right leg were negative.

title: Gilman Services
description: Gilman Services Inc., a drug and cosmetics distributor in Braintree, Mass., announced that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws for three of its units: Gilman Brothers Inc.; Rogers Wholesalers and Three P Products. The company said that it had sought relief after three creditors filed a Chapter 7 involuntary petition in Federal court in Boston last week against Gilman Brothers. The creditors, Du Pont, Abbott Laboratories and Baxter Travenol Laboratories, refused to enter into a standby agreement that Gilman reached last January with other creditors.

title: Energy Secretary Says He Won't Quit June 30
description: James R. Edwards denied today a published report that he would quit as Secretary of the Energy Department on June 30.

title: CONCERT: YOUTH SYMPHONY
description: SALVATORE SCECCHITANO appeared Saturday for the last time as music director of the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York, conducting the final concert of the ensemble's 19th season in Carnegie Hall. Next year, the baton will pass to David Alan Miller, the orchestra's assistant conductor, whose appointment as Mr. Scecchitano's successor was announced at intermission.

title: Logistical Logic; The 1040 Tin Cup
description: Jack Fields of Texas and a hundred other Congressmen have an idea for financing the United States Olympic team: amend the income tax form to allow taxpayers to earmark $1 for the Olympic Committee.

title: Accounts
description: * Science Digest magazine to Geers Gross Advertising Inc. for circulation advertising.

title: Tosco to Meet
description: United States District Judge Robert Takasugi denied a motion by Kenneth Good, a Tosco dissident shareholder, to delay the company's annual meeting here tomorrow.

title: The U.N. Today; May 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: CITY BALLET: MISS ASHLEY PAIRED WITH LUDERS
description: ALTHOUGH, strictly speaking, a pas de deux is simply a dance for two persons, balletic tradition has tended to regard it as a dance of love for two persons. However, yet another choreographic tradition has made the pas de deux an opportunity for two persons to show off. Both traditions were honored at the New York City Ballet's Sunday night performance at the New York State Theater.

title: A WORLD SHORT OF FREE, PRODUCTIVE FARMERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE MAN'S RADIO STATION, BUT F.C.C. DOESN'T LIKE IT
description: Simon Geller's one-room basement apartment contains a rumpled bed, a sink, a hotplate, two oak desks and a radio station.

title: PALESTINIANS REQUIRE MORE THAN 'PROMISE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Gato del Sol Impressive In Workout at Belmont
description: In his first serious workout since winning the Kentucky Derby, Gato del Sol yesterday worked five furlongs over Belmont Park's main track. He was clocked in 1:00 4/5.

title: OPERATION ON FETAL KIDNEY SUCCEEDS
description: THE endangered kidney of an unborn baby has been saved by medical scientists of University of Connecticut Health Center who performed a preliminary operation on the fetus in the womb and followed it by corrective surgery after the child was born about three weeks later by Caesarean operation.

title: SOVIET SIGNS NICARAGUA AID PACT
description: The Soviet Union has signed its first major aid pact with Nicaragua's leftist junta, involving $166.8 million in technical assistance and credits for Soviet-built projects, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the coordinator of the junta, announced today.

title: Atlanta Editor Resigning
description: Hal Gulliver, editor of The Atlanta Constitution, has announced he is resigning to become a senior fellow and editorial director of the Southern Center for International Studies. The privately endowed research and educational institution is devoted to keeping Southern business and political leaders informed of international issues affecting the region. Mr. Gulliver says he will join the center June 15.

title: Reagan Economic Aide Sees Jobless Rate Exceeding 10%
description: The national unemployment rate is likely to continue rising and may exceed 10 percent, William Niskanen, a Presidential economic adviser, said today.

title: PSYCHIATRIST STATES HE NEVER SAW SIGN OF MENTAL ILLNESS IN HINCKLEY
description: The Colorado psychiatrist who treated John W. Hinckley Jr. in the five months before he shot President Reagan testified today that he had never observed delusions or other symptoms commonly associated with mental illness, and had never thought there was much ''cause for concern'' that Mr. Hinckley could not care for himself.

title: Reading in Deal To Buy Regency
description: The Reading Company, a Pennsylvania real estate holding and development company, said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Regency Electronics Inc., an Indianapolis-based communications equipment manufacturer, for $80.4 million, or $15 a share.

title: CONSUMER DEBT JUMPS $990 MILLION
description: American consumers increased their buying on credit in March, pushing up their total installment debt outstanding by $990 million, the biggest gain since last October, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Polish Official Visiting Bonn
description: Edward Kowalczyk, a Deputy Prime Minister of Poland, arrived here today on a three-day visit. West German officials said he planned to meet with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff.

title: DANCE: 2 GIRLS TELL A 'STORY'
description: ONCE upon a time, two friends went out in search of adventure, and before they returned home they took rocket-ship rides and discovered an island made of bubble gum. Natasha Leibel, who is 11 years old, wrote down their voyages, and Toni Smith, a grownup who is young at heart, choreographed them in ''Story,'' which Toni Smith and Dancers presented May 2 at the Westbeth Theater Center.

title: METROMEDIA'S NEW VENTURES
description: At the age of 67, John W. Kluge, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Metromedia Inc., might be expected to be playing less at big business and more at his favorite backgammon board - especially since Metromedia's operating income was a handsome $123.4 million on revenues of just $461.8 million last year.

title: MUSIC: MONTREAL SYMPHONY
description: THE Montreal Symphony Orchestra and its music director, the Swissborn conductor Charles Dutoit, are not the most frequent of visitors in New York, which brought an element of suspense to their performance Sunday at Carnegie Hall. The stakes were heightened by a program that harnessed a big-name soloist to a warhorse concerto on one side of the intermission, unleashed Stravinsky's potent Symphony in Three Movements on the other, and threw in two orchestral showpieces for good measure.

title:
REDUCING TENSIONS WITH MEXICO;
WASHINGTON - Relations between the United States and Mexico are close to a boiling point because of immigration disputes, economic woes in both countries, and ideological differences. Rarely has a United States Administration committed to improving relations with Mexico both caused and been subject to so many conditions that promote tensions.
description: Washington's traditional case-by-case approach to diverse issues has increased difficulties between the two countries and will complicate Mexico's management of its severe economic downturn.

title: ISRAELI-LEBANESE BORDER AREA QUIET AFTER ATTACKS
description: Northern Israel was reported quiet today after Palestinian guerrillas shelled the area from southern Lebanon on Sunday. The shelling, the first since July's cease-fire, followed an Israeli air attack on Palestinian targets south of Beirut.

title: Ex-Addicts Tell Story
description: One of Nancy Reagan's pressing interests has been drug abuse. Yesterday on Chicago's North Side, the First Lady toured Gateway House, a recovery program for drug abusers founded in 1969.

title: BRITISH DEBATE PRIMOGENITURE
description: A feminist campaign is being waged in Britain in behalf of someone who is not yet on the scene and might not even be female: the baby expected by the Princess of Wales.

title: BRIEFING
description: Protest by Russians

title:
MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
The Da Vinci Players Present Rare Works
description: The Da Vinci Players put on an evening of chamber music Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall, offering little-heard songs for piano, clarinet and soprano by Louis Spohr and the New York premiere of ''Reflections'' by Herbert Feldman - a work for the same combination, plus viola - on a program that included a string duo by Mozart and a piano trio by Brahms.

title: HELD HIGH POSITIONS AS A U.S. DIPLOMAT
description: W. Beverly Carter Jr., a career Foreign Service officer who retired as an Ambassador at Large in January 1981, died Sunday at Suburban Hospital of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS AGREE ON BUDGET WITH HIGHER TAXES
description: House Democratic leaders reached tentative agreement today on a budget plan that would preserve Social Security benefits and raise taxes by 50 percent more than the Republican plan endorsed by President Reagan and the Senate Budget Committee.

title: A STRIPPED-DOWN QE2 TO SET SAIL FOR WAR TODAY
description: A bustling horde of technicians, suppliers, workmen, sailors and soldiers swarmed over the Queen Elizabeth 2 today as the giant ship prepared to sail for the South Atlantic.

title: HUNGARY OFFERS POLES 'BENEFIT OF EXPERIENCE'
description: Hungary is trying to help Poland out of its political-economic morass by ''placing our experiences at their disposal,'' according to Jozsef Marjai, the Deputy Prime Minister in the Budapest Government.

title: 3 Audition Winners
description: The winners of the International Young Concert Artists Auditions are the cellist Carter Brey, the baritone William Sharp and the pianist Dominique Weber. They will be presented by the Young Concert Artists Series at the 92d Street Y and in the Terrace Theater at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts next season.

title: Synthetic Crude
description: Sasol Ltd. said its Sasol 3 plant had produced its first synthetic crude oil and that refined petroleum products from the plant should be marketed in August.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has elected Ronald R. Komar, Roy P. Lanza, James A. Mottola and Kenneth G. Pittius vice presidents.

title: Urban League in Los Angeles Asks Police Chief Suspension
description: The Los Angeles branch of the Urban League, a civil rights group, has called for the suspension of Police Chief Daryl Gates because of his comment that blacks might be more likely to die from chokeholds because their arteries do not open as fast as they do on ''normal people.''

title: Commonwealth Edison Penalties
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company said it might have to pay up to $88 million in penalties to the Allied Oil Company for not buying oil under contract. Commonwealth, which is trying to raise capital for construction of a nuclear power plant, as attempting to stem its use of oil.

title: THE ROTH OF KEMP-ROTH FIGHTS FOR HIS TAX PLAN
description: Senator William V. Roth Jr. has been nurturing his cub for six years. Now his offspring is in danger, and he is fighting desperately to save it.

title: REDISTRICTING
description: In the Legislature in recent weeks, the power to draw was the power to destroy - and, sometimes, to create. In many cases, the drawings of Congressional, State Senate and Assembly district lines, in some politicians' eyes at least, wrecked or enhanced political careers.

title: SPOONS FOR MARROW
description: IN Victorian times marrow bones were cooked and served in starched napkins with long silver spoons to scoop out the marrow. Not many Americans are familiar with this delicacy, which was popular at grander dinner parties at the turn of the century. These days butchers in many neighborhoods give the bones away and people use them for stock or for flavoring soups or give them to their dogs.

title: Coast Savings Unit in Suit
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association today filed a suit charging Severyn Ashkenazy and a group of business associates with violating securities laws in attempting a takeover.

title: EDMUNDS'S NEW ALL-WELSH BAND COULD MAKE FANS FORGET ROCKPILE
description: throated rockabilly and country-boogie vocalist in Rockpile, the superb British rock quartet that broke up last year. After Rockpile's demise, he returned to Wales, put together a all-Welsh band, recorded a sizzling album called ''DE7'' (Columbia) and hit the road. He will be at the Ritz on Sunday and Monday.

title: Philip Fears Whales Will Perish in Conflict
description: The Duke of Edinburgh expressed his regret today that the conflict over the Falkland Islands would probably lead to the death of many whales.

title: TO FIND HELP
description: If you know or suspect someone has eaten a poisonous plant, call the nearest poison control center and your physician.

title: BRITAIN TO SEND ARTIST TO FLEET
description: The British are sending an artist to portray their fighting men in the conflict with Argentina. The artist, Linda Kitson, 37 years old, is to sail for the South Atlantic this week aboard the requisitioned luxury liner Queen Elizabeth 2, along with 3,000 troops.

title: CHAMBER: BRONX ARTS ENSEMBLE
description: SOME programs are unusual; others are downright eccentric. That of the Bronx Arts Ensemble Chamber Orchestra on Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House tipped slightly toward the eccentric. Yet the second half was interesting and appealing enough to allay most doubts.

title: Realignment of Officers Announced at A.N.R.
description: The American Natural Resources Company of Detroit, which operates interstate gas pipelines, among other businesses, yesterday announced a realignment in top management.

title: WOMEN IN PRISON SUE KENTUCKY FOR SEX BIAS
description: When an inmate enters the Kentucky state prison for women, no matter what her age or crime, her street clothes are taken away and replaced with dull, shapeless, green state-issued dresses; she is not allowed to wear makeup or display pictures of her children or other loved ones; she must turn out the lights and go to bed at 9:30 P.M.

title: USING 'ON PURPOSE' LEFTOVERS TO MAKE WEEK'S MEALS EASY
description: By Marian Burros c. 1982 N.Y. Times News Service

title: PETER WEISS, 65, AUTHOR OF 'MARAT SADE,' DIES
description: Peter Weiss, author of ''Marat/ Sade,'' one of postwar Europe's most important plays, died, apparently of a heart attack, Monday in Stockholm. His wife, Gunilla Palmstierna, said in Stockholm yesterday that the German-born playwright entered a hospital Sunday after complaining of chest pains. He was 65 years old.

title: Pan Am Head Predicts Profit
description: C. Edward Acker, the chairman of Pan American World Airways, said that the company would show a moderate profit for the month of June and a substantial operating profit for the third quarter. He made his prediction in a press conference before the annual meeting, held in Houston.

title: 3 ON STATE PANEL CHALLENGE BUDGET FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: The three business representatives on the State Financial Control Board warned yesterday that they would withhold their required full approval of New York City's budget for as long as it continued to be based on more than $500 million in uncertain state aid and taxes.

title: Lawyer Advised J. Paul Getty
description: Cornelius Lansing Hays Jr., senior partner of the law firm of Dechert, Price & Rhoads of Manhattan and Philadelphia, died Monday of heart disease at Monterey (Calif.) Community Hospital.

title: Nelson Joins Vikings
description: Minnesota was not the place that Darrin Nelson had wanted to be, but he was there anyway yesterday, wearing Viking purple at the team's minicamp in the town of Eden Prairie. There had been a big question whether Nelson, the Stanford running back who was the Vikings' top choice in the recent draft, would make the trip.

title: G.O.P. IN HOUSE OPPOSES BUDGET OF SENATE PANEL
description: House Republican leaders today rejected the budget plan endorsed by President Reagan and the Senate Budget Committee, objecting to proposed changes in the Social Security system and to a major tax increase in a recession.

title: U.S. LOSES ON INFORMER DATA
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Government must disclose much of an inquiry into allegations of misconduct in the handling of an Federal informer within the Ku Klux Klan in the 1960's.

title: JETS' NO. 1 CHOICE IS CALLED FIT
description: Dr. James A. Nicholas, who discovered by chance at a news conference 17 years ago that a rookie named Joe Namath had a wobbly knee, looked over another No.1 draft choice of the New York Jets more closely today and had a different diagnosis.

title: A FREEZE AND ITS ANTI-
description: ''No taxation without representation!'' was the battle cry of a popular uprising that gave birth to our nation. ''No cremation without representation!'' could become the cry of a popular movement based on the belief that the death of our nation can be prevented only by bringing a quick end to the nuclear arms race.

title: FOR FAMILIES, A FOCUS ON PREVENTIVE SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Undersea Artifacts Found
description: Sixteen cannons and an ancient anchor are among five tons of artifacts recovered from a 16th-century shipwreck in the Turks and Caicos Islands of the British West Indies, archeologists said today.
