The wreck has been identified by some as that of Columbus's Pinta, lost during a voyage to the New World in 1500, but the archeologists, from the Texas Institute of Nautical Archeology, said there was no evidence to determine either the name of the ship or its age, other than that it is likely to date from the early 1500's.

title: Damson Oil Gets 49% of Juniper
description: The New York-based Damson Oil Corporation said it had acquired 49 percent of the common shares of the Juniper Petroleum Corporation, based in Denver, for a total of $25.6 million, or $12 a share. The purchase was negotiated with a third petroleum company, the Buttes Gas and Oil Company, based in Oakland, Calif.

title: Bridge: A Partnership May Reach New Levels at Card Table
description: Partners in one capacity may be friendly rivals in another. This can happen in more than one way for bridge players: a marriage partnership or a business partnership can find itself in a state of temporary divorce at the card table.

title: A POSTAL SERVICE RETORT
description: The United States Postal Service and one of its competitors, Federal Express, are having at each other these days over television commercials for the private delivery service that recently won four gold medals and two silver ones at an advertising award show.

title: Books: Survivors Speak
description: THE BLACK BOOK. Edited by Ilya Ehren- burg and Vasily Grossman. 594 pages. Holocaust Library. $19.95.

title: HAIG'S SECOND THOUGHTS
description: Secretary of State Haig is surrounded by problems these days, as usual, but for some reason he seems more secure and even more confident about the future.

title: Rep. Bolling to Teach in Boston
description: Representative Richard Bolling is not running for re-election this year, but when his 17th term expires in December, the Missouri Democrat will not go home to Missouri, at least not right away.

title: GIBSON IS FACING RUNOFF VOTE
description: Mayor William V. Musto of Union City, N.J., won re-election yesterday, 24 hours after being sentenced to seven years in prison on racketeering charges.

title: FOOTBALL LEAGUE PLANNED
description: Plans for a new professional football league, comprising 12 teams and with a season running from March to July, were announced yesterday.

title: STRANGERS SHARE REVIVAL AT IMMANUEL LUTHERAN
description: For 32 years' worth of Sundays, Robert Meyer says he stayed away from church except for an occasional wedding or funeral. Like millions of other unchurched Americans, he had his reasons.

title: Fiat's Profit Up
description: Fiat S.p.A. said today that its net income last year rose to 97 billion lire, or $76 million, from 51 billion lire a year earlier. The auto maker also raised its dividend to 140 lire from 125.

title: MRS. THATCHER CALLS ON BRITISH TO EXPRESS PROTEST AGAINST BBC
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher encouraged a public protest against the BBC today, calling on viewers to write and telephone complaints of the network's coverage of the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: COAST MUDSLIDE VICTIMS FACE DILEMMA ON LOANS
description: A 20-foot tree fell over not long ago in front of Ron and Carolyn Heine's $400,000 house. The fallen tree was a sapling by the soaring standards of the Santa Cruz redwood forests, but the Heines are much more upset by the implications of its fall: that the ordeal in their neighborhood at Love Creek is not over.

title: SQUARE-OFF AT TOSCO MEETING
description: A crowd of unhappy shareholders squared off against the Tosco Corporation's testy management today in a tightly orchestrated, 90-minute annual meeting that drew cries of protest from the outnumbered dissidents.

title: QUESTIONS OF LIFE AND DEATH FOR AN 'INFANT DOE'
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL CURBS F.T.C. ROLE
description: The Senate Commerce Committee voted today to eliminate the Federal Trade Commission's jurisdiction over ''unfair'' advertising and to completely exempt state-regulated professionals from agency scrutiny. The legislation would also reduce the agency's $68 million budget to $54.6 million by 1985.

title: POSTAL SURPLUS IS FAR HIGHER THAN PREDICTED
description: The Postal Service, which had predicted surpluses of only $120 million for all of the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, announced today that it had cleared more than $436 million by March and would do even better in the months ahead.

title: QUESTIONS OF LIFE AND DEATH FOR AN 'INFANT DOE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Keith Fischer Resigns As Agency Chief
description: Keith P. Fischer, 49, president and chief executive for the last six years of Avrett, Free & Fischer, resigned last week.

title: Tokyo Says a Japanese Boat Has Been Seized in Yellow Sea
description: A Japanese fishing boat with a 12-member crew was reported to have been captured by what appeared to be a North Korean vessel in the Yellow Sea, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency said today.

title: TV: MOVIE ON ELEANOR ROOSEVELT
description: ''ELEANOR, FIRST LADY OF THE WORLD,'' a CBS-TV movie at 9 o'clock this evening, lovingly traces part of the life of Eleanor Roosevelt after the death of her husband, Franklin D. Roosevelt, in April 1945. Although the story picks up where the two productions of ''Eleanor and Franklin'' left off, there are no production or writing connections with the earlier films. This dramatization, based on a story by Rhoda Lerman, was written by Caryl Ledner and Cynthia Mandelberg. John Erman is the director. And Eleanor Roosevelt is played, with a glowing dignity required for this kind of celebratory biography, by Jean Stapleton.

title: 'Marco Polo' TV Epic Gets Big P.& G. Push
description: When the world's biggest advertiser takes its biggest step in TV program sponsorship, that's news. And, when that advertiser, the notoriously close-mouthed Procter & Gamble, makes some of its executives available for press interviews, that's even bigger news.

title: The U.N. Today; May 12, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for Second Special Session Devoted to Disarma- ment - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Conoco Card Fee
description: Conoco Inc., the oil subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical company, said that it would begin charging its distributors a 2 1/2 percent processing fee on all Conoco credit card invoices, beginning June 15.

title: G.& W. Stake In Munsingwear
description: Gulf and Western Industries said it had raised its stake in Munsingwear Inc. to 34.19 percent, or 647,900 shares, with the purchase of 22,600 shares on the New York Stock Exchange at between $12.50 and $14.125 a share.

title: I.T.T.'S PROFIT DOWN AMID GLOBAL RECESSION
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation today reported an 11.7 percent drop in its first-quarter operating earnings, to $162.7 million, or $1.10 a share, from the previous year's $184.3 million, or $1.25 a share, before an extraordinary charge of $17.8 million.

title: CERONE OUT FOR 3 TO 6 WEEKS
description: The Yankees added two more casualties to their ward tonight even while defeating the California Angels, 3-2: Rick Cerone suffered a chip fracture of the left thumb and will be lost for three to six weeks, and John Mayberry, acquired only one week ago, was spiked on the left foot.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Friends of ours who recently returned from Turkey expressed great admiration for something called doner kebabs. Are you familiar with them?

title: COAST INQUIRY ON VOTER REGISTRATION CRITICIZED
description: A Federal attempt to discover if significant numbers of aliens have registered to vote has been attacked by several groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union and the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund.

title: ANNEXING ARAB ANGER
description: The present deterioration in the West Bank has accentuated the deep divisions that cut across Israel's public opinion regarding the future of this territory.

title: FIRESTONE ENDS TALKS ON HERTZ
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had ended its talks with the RCA Corporation regarding Firestone's possible acquisition of the Hertz Corporation.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Fergus Gonzalez was buried yesterday. The church, its walls a pale lemon yellow, was filled with children, and those people caught between childhood and maturity, mired in adolescence. Some of them wept, and some of them tried not to weep with painful contortions of the mouth and brow.

title: FORT WAYNE OFFERS PLAN TO HARVESTER
description: The International Harvester Company disclosed today that the city of Fort Wayne, Ind., had offered a $20 million financial incentive plan in an effort in keep that city's Harvester truck manufacturing plant open. The plan matches a similar incentive plan made last month by the city of Springfield, Ohio, which hopes to keep its Harvester truck manufacturing plant open.

title: House Panel Cuts Aid To 3 Nations in Africa
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today cut back Administration requests for military and economic assistance to Zaire, Tunisia and Morocco.

title: POPE MAY CANCEL VISIT TO BRITAIN
description: Basil Cardinal Hume said tonight that Pope John Paul II would cancel his visit to Britain, scheduled to begin on May 28, if hostilities between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands had not ceased by the middle of next week.

title: Market Place; Basic Industry Issues Favored
description: IF the recession is almost over, as some of the economic indicators seem to suggest, wouldn't this be the time to consider investing in steel, paper, chemical and other basic industry stocks that come to life along with the economy?

title: Hisle Injury Confirmed
description: Larry Hisle of the Milwaukee Brewers learned yesterday that his career was in jeopardy after Dr. Paul Jacobs, the team physician, confirmed that there was at least a partial tear in the rotator cuff of his right shoulder.

title: BRIDGEPORT JURY TO PRESS INQUIRY INTO CORRUPTION
description: A Federal grand jury will be impaneled here Wednesday to continue a five-year-long investigation into municipal corruption in Bridgeport. The inquiry has led thus far to the conviction of nine officials, and five others are awaiting trial.

title: Babb Death Finding
description: An autopsy has found that Mike Babb, a former University of Oklahoma football player, died of cardiac arrest believed to be associated with the stress of knee surgery and a scarring of the heart. Babb, 24 years old, a former defensive back who graduated in 1979, died May 3, shortly after undergoing surgery for a knee injury suffered in a game between the Oklahoma varsity and alumni on April 24. The cause of the heart scars was not known.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO REVIVE HOUSING
description: Brushing aside Republican charges that it was reverting to the ''big spending'' policies of the past, the House of Representatives voted today to authorize an emergency expenditure of $1 billion in this fiscal year to rescue the staggering housing industry. The vote was 349 to 55, and all but 12 of the negative votes were cast by Republicans.

title: MUSIC: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA AND YOURI EGOROV
description: IT is perhaps inevitable that a pianist who looks like Youri Egorov would be expected to play Chopin in great sighing phrases and Romantic flourishes. The Soviet-born musician, who now lives in the Netherlands, is dark and slightly built, somewhat in the Dinu Lipatti mold, and he has a lost-puppy look that encourages an audience's protective instincts. Furthermore, as an also-ran in the Van Cliburn competition, Mr. Egorov reportedly played with so much panache that he immediately picked up a fan club among those who deplore the objective style of pianism that comes out on top in most such contests. His playing, we were told, was personal to the point of being wayward.

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan Calls Podhoretz

title: HARVARD CURRICULUM STUDY ADDS TO FERMENT OVER GOALS OF LEGAL EDUCATION
description: The Harvard Law School, its faculty factionalized and its student body restless, has begun the painful process of re-examining itself and its responsibilities to the profession and to society at large.

title: Dr. Pasquale Marino Is Dead; A Dean at Manhattan College
description: Dr. Pasquale A. Marino, dean of the School of Engineering at Manhattan College, died Monday night, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 49 years old.

title: Iranian Oil Price Down
description: Iran is selling oil on a spot basis for under $28 a barrel, well below the $34 benchmark price of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, West German oil industry sources said today. They added that the National Iranian Oil Company had begun a major marketing drive, increasing sales during April to around two million barrels a day, though some of this appeared to be from stocks.

title: INDUSTRIAL COUNTRIES FAIL TO AGREE ON HOW TO MEET ECONOMIC CRISES
description: Government ministers from the 24 major industrial democracies completed a two-day review of the world economy this evening on a pessimistic note. They agreed that no early end to the recession is in sight and that six million more people are likely to become jobless this year, raising the total number of unemployed in their counries to more than 30 million.

title: RIFT ERUPTS AT MOSCOW CHURCH TALKS
description: A religious conference on nuclear weapons being held here broke into controversy today when two American clerics appealed from the rostrum for Soviet and third world delegates to abandon attempts to turn the meeting into a propaganda attack on the United States.

title: IF YOU CAN PACKAGE ORANGES AS GIFTS, WHY NOT POTATOES?
description: KETCHUM, Idaho THE way Bill Ricktor figures it, if you can package oranges from Florida as gifts, why not potatoes from Idaho. ''What could be more appropriate in the current economy than giving someone a gift box of potatoes?'' asked Mr. Ricktor. ''It's the perfect gift for the recession.''

title: Hong Kong Bids Its Governor Farewell
description: In his 10 years as Governor of Hong Kong, Sir Murray MacLehose must have made an impression.

title: No Headline
description: NOTE: The following recipes, intended to serve two people, can be made to serve four simply by doubling the ingredients. Chicken Oreganato 1 3 1/2-pound chicken, cut up 2 tablespoons crushed, dried oregano Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste 1/4 cup olive oil Juice of 1/2 to 1 lemon.

title: Allstate Unit in Japan
description: Japanese Finance Ministry sources said today that the ministry would approve an Allstate Insurance Company plan to establish a wholly owned subsidiary in Japan to start nonlife insurance business. Allstate, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, will be the first foreign non-life insurance concern to form a wholly owned subsidiary in Japan, the sources added.

title: STUDENT DESIGNS OPEN A FASHION SALUTE
description: New York City's third annual Salute to the Fashion and Beauty Industries - a weeklong celebration that includes fashion shows, dedications, demonstrations, dinner dances and parties - was opened Monday with the first fashion show ever held at City Hall, which is 170 years old.

title: Letter: On Turkey's Government Ankara Wants Real Democracy
description: To the Editor: Turks read your April 21 editorial ''Ankara's Shame'' with great surprise, wondering how so prestigious a newspaper could publish editorial commentary so thoroughly erroneous in its content. Did it stem from bias or from blindness to Turkish reality?

title: '108 and Going Great'
description: He is the nation's oldest living veteran, and on Monday at the Bay Pines Veterans Administration Medical Center in St. Petersburg, Fla., they gave Harry Chaloner a party for his 108th birthday. There were three cakes - one of them was iced with the message ''108 and Going Great'' - a brand new motorized wheelchair and a special greeting from President and Mrs. Reagan.

title: Mother, Alleging Racism, Seeks Return of Her Son
description: A white woman who lost custody of her son after giving birth to a black man's child asked the Georgia Supreme Court today to give back her boy, contending she was the victim of racism.

title: HINCKLEY'S BROTHER AND SISTER TESTIFY FATHER REJECTED HOSPITALIZATION ; IDEA
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s older brother and sister both testified today that they and the sister's husband agreed in early March 1981 ''that John should be institutionalized.''

title: Shamrock Lifts Its Price for Oil
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, a diversified chemicals and energy company, has raised its buying price for domestic crude oil by $2 a barrel in a change that it says reflects ''a stabilizing market'' in its purchasing areas.

title: TO MAKE CIVIL RIGHTS ENFORCEMENT MORE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN M. STEELE JR.
description: Dr. John M. Steele Jr., assistant professor of clinical medicine at the New York University School of Medicine, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 44 years old.

title: Rates Register Slight Drop; Treasury Bills Unchanged
description: Short- and long-term rates fell slightly yesterday as market participants waited for news that would send prices higher or lower. By the end of the day, rates for three- and six-month Treasury bills were about unchanged at about 12.22 percent for both issues. In advance of tomorrow's auction of new one-year Treasury bills, the outstanding one-year bill was bid at 11.96 percent, well below the 12.73 percent rate at the April 15 sale of year bills.

title: President is Appointed At London and Leeds
description: Kurt K. Kilstock says that the United States is the ''last bastion of democratic capitalism'' and thus any European company ought to have an operation here. Mr. Kilstock, 51, has been named president and chief executive of the newly formed London and Leeds Corporation (U.S.), which hopes to develop real estate projects all over the country.

title: NEALE, A COACH IN EXILE, WATCHES CANUCKS FROM A NEW SEAT
description: Harry Neale, the Vancouver Canucks' head coach, continued to stay aloof from his team tonight while it was losing the second game of the Stanley Cup final series, 6-4, to the Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: DOCTORS ASSAIL REAGAN ARMS REDUCTION PLAN
description: Several prominent doctors and scientists today criticized President Reagan's new proposal to reduce Soviet and American strategic forces and called instead for a freeze in the superpowers' nuclear arsenals.

title: ISLANDERS TOP CANUCKS BY 6-4, TAKE 2-0 SERIES LEAD
description: The Islanders scored four goals in the third period tonight to overcome the Vancouver Canucks, 6-4, and take a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup championship series.

title: TRADE BAN ON INDEX EXTENDED
description: A Federal District judge has extended for 10 days an order barring the Commodities Exchange Inc. from trading a futures contract that the Standard & Poor's Corporation says is based on its index of 500 stock prices.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S STATEMENT TO ARMS
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on strategic arms control policy : Special to the New York Times

title: THEATER: 'RED AND BLUE,' A TALE OF 2 LIGHT BULBS
description: THE only two visible performers in ''Red and Blue,'' the theater piece at the Public Theater's Other Stage, are a pair of light bulbs. If you've seen the human acting on display in the Public's current production of ''Antigone,'' you can instantly appreciate that this is not necessarily a bad thing. Light bulbs are bright. They are rarely hammy. And when they're red and blue, they can be kind of cute.

title: DEBUSSCHERE EXPECTED TO ACCEPT HUBIE BROWN
description: Dave DeBusschere is expected to accept the foreseen hiring of Hubie Brown as coach of the Knicks and become the team's executive vice president and general manager.

title: JURY TO BEGIN DELIBERATIONS TODAY IN REV. MOON TRIAL ON TAX CHARGE
description: Federal prosecutors and defense lawyers completed their summations yesterday as the jury prepared to deliberate in the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's trial on charges of filing false income-tax returns.

title: LILCO SUBMITS AN EMERGENCY PLAN FOR SHOREHAM DESPITE OBJECTIONS
description: The Long Island Lighting Company yesterday asked New York State's Disaster Preparedness Commission to approve its emergency response plan for the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant. Suffolk County officials have described the plan as incomplete and superficial.

title: Boat and 4 Seized With Marijuana
description: A 30-foot cabin cruiser loaded with bales of marijuana was seized off the New Jersey coast yesterday morning and four people were arrested, officials said.

title: THE MASTERS OF THE ART OF BLACK PUDDING
description: AU-PERCHE,France AMONTH of tense waiting ended recently in this small town in Normandy as the national champions of France, Britain, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Luxembourg and Austria met for the final judging in the annual world black pudding championship.

title: Acquisitions Up in Quarter
description: The number of mergers and acquisitions in the first quarter of the year rose to 604 from 599 for the similar period last year, according to a merger intermediary.

title: Ohio Bank Group in Bid
description: Huntington Bancshares Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, said yesterday that it would press its bid for the Union Commerce Corporation of Cleveland, a bank holding company, despite an announcement yesterday morning that Union Commerce had entered into a friendly merger agreement with the Cincinnati-based Central Bancorp.

title: International
description: O.E.C.D. ministers voiced doubt that the recession will end soon. The officials, in a pessimistic report after a two-day meeting in Paris, said six million more workers were likely to become jobless in their countries this year. In Washington, the Labor Department said unemployment was at record and near-record levels in Canada, France, West Germany, Britain and Japan. (Page A1.)

title: DANGERFIELD: 'IT'S NOT EASY BEIN' ME'
description: THIS is no joke. A visitor sits down in one of dining room chairs in Rodney Dangerfield's Upper East Side apartment, and the chair breaks. The comedian, dressed in a blue polka dot bathrobe and black slippers, apologizes profusely and hastens the visitor into another chair. It breaks, too.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: 'WE ARE FIGHTING TO STAY ALIVE'
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK-RUN BUSINESSES RANKED
description: Energy-related companies dominated the top of the list of the 100 leading black-owned businesses in 1981, while construction, hightechnology and services that cater to black consumers showed the strongest growth, an annual survey by Black Enterprise magazine shows.

title: Miss Welty's Work, Past and Future
description: Finding a quiet place to work can be a losing battle for a writer in New York City, which is why a group of them banded together a few years back to establish a community workshop of sorts on 42d Street.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allied Stores Corp.'s $175 million of 6 percent notes due in 1992 are offered by Goldman, Sachs & Company at 56.741 to yield 14.25 percent.

title: A.C.L.I. Changes Top Management
description: Jay C. Huffard has been named president and chief executive of A.C.L.I. International Inc., a worldwide commodities trading firm that has been owned since October by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the Wall Street brokerage firm.

title: Vanity Fair Names Art Director
description: When Bea Feitler, the art director, died of cancer at the age of 44 recently, it stunned many in the fashion and media worlds, especially her associates at Conde Nast. Miss Feitler had been art director there for the planned revival of Vanity Fair magazine, last published in 1936.

title: British Survey Ship Returns Home From South Atlantic
description: The survey vessel Bransfield sailed into Southhampton today after a nonstop 8,000-mile voyage from the South Atlantic.

title: HOUSE APPROVES 3 NEW TRAILS
description: The House voted today to prohibit entrance fees for any national recreation area, wild and scenic river area or national trail.

title: Injuries Leave Fight Picture in Disarray
description: As Sugar Ray Leonard rested comfortably in his hospital bed yesterday, an entire sport planned uneasily and uncertainly for a future with its biggest attraction either permanently or temporarily sidelined,

title: SOVIET HAS EDGE, U.S. GENERAL SAYS
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., nominated to be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the Soviet Union ''had more intercontinental ballistic missiles and more nuclear explosive power than the United States and the ability to threaten American missiles.

title: Economic Scene; Crises Feeding On Each Other
description: THE fighting between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands is the latest example of the ways economic and political instability play off each other and intensify each other. The Argentine attack on the Falklands itself largely stemmed from economic troubles.

title: OTB Set for Preakness
description: New York's offtrack betting shops will begin accepting wagers Friday on the 107th running of the Preakness Stakes Saturday at Pimlico Race Course, according to John F. Keenan, president of the OTB Corporation. He said yesterday that bets would be accepted until just before post time, scheduled for 5:40 P.M.

title: HAIG PRESSES FOR MORE MILITARY SPENDING
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the chances of persuading the Soviet Union to take seriously President Reagan's proposals for reducing strategic arms hinged on Congressional support for the Administration's $180 billion military modernization program.

title: IRAN-IRAQ FIGHTING AT KEY CITY
description: Iranian and Iraqi troops fought fiercely outside the Iranian city of Khurramshahr today, both sides said. Iran said its troops had advanced three miles toward the partly occupied port, but Iraq said it had repulsed the assault and killed thousands of enemy fighters.

title: DONOVAN TALKS 5 HOURS TO BROOKLYN GRAND JURY
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan testified for more than five hours yesterday before a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn investigating charges that he was involved in corruption while he was a construction company executive in New Jersey.

title: ALBUM SHOWS THAT 'DREAMGIRLS' COMPOSERS CAN EVOKE AN ERA
description: ONE thing the original-cast album from the Broadway musical ''Dreamgirls'' (Geffen) makes abundantly clear is that the show's composer, Henry Krieger, and musical arranger, Harold Wheeler, share an affection for and an impressive ability to recreate the black rhythm-and-blues styles of the last 20 years. Their re-creations of the Supremes' coolly sensuous pop rhythm-and-blues are so uncannily accurate that some listeners have mistaken all the ''Dreamgirls'' music for recycled Supremes. In fact, the show's musical canvas is much broader than that. The ''Dreamgirls'' music is least successful when it veers closest to traditional Broadway fare, most successful when it recaptures specific rhythm-and-blues styles in vivid, knowing detail.

title: Your Pension or Your Vote
description: Sensing Republican vulnerability, the Democrats are out for blood. Republicans would ''raid and loot the Social Security system,'' says Senator Riegle. President Reagan is ''mortgaging the economic future of the elderly,'' says Senator Byrd. The party that created Social Security will not hear of a Republican plan to find savings of $40 billion in the next three years. House Democrats have already prepared a budget counterproposal that leaves the sacred cow untouched.

title: Sugar Quotas Challenged
description: A group of sugar refiners said today that it had filed suit challenging the legality of President Reagan's decision to impose quotas on American sugar imports.

title: Three Afghan Incidents Are Reported in Week
description: Afghan Government troops and their Soviet allies were involved in three incidents with the insurgents last week, Western diplomats said here today.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SELL 7 HOUSING PROJECTS IN 3-STATE REGION WITHOUT BIDS
description: Federal housing officials said today that they were negotiating the sale of seven Government properties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to a private company that included the lawyer for the Reagan campaign committee.

title: Portuguese Dies in Melee Over National Strike
description: One man was killed and three injured today in a fight between bus drivers supporting and opposing a nationwide strike on the eve of a visit by Pope John Paul II, the police reported.

title: Cuba's Stevenson Upset In World Title Boxing
description: In a stunning upset, Teofilo Stevenson of Cuba was outpointed by Francesco Damiani of Italy in the quarterfinals of the world amateur boxing championships today.

title: USED-CAR RULE: LESSON IN LOBBYING
description: Used car dealers around the country began complaining to their Congressmen late last year that Federal regulators were at it again, trying to interject a lot of red tape and expense into what the dealers contended was an ever-improving seller-buyer relationship.

title: Sports of The Times; Out of the Mouths of Babes
description: THE morning after Sugar Ray Leonard's 14th-round knockout of Thomas Hearns last September, the undisputed world welterweight champion and his son, Little Ray, then 7 years old, stopped to talk to some friends in the Caesars Palace coffee shop.

title: Kitty Hart Renamed
description: Kitty Carlisle Hart has been named by Governor Carey to another term as chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: WINE TALK
description: IN the foothills of the Alps of northwestern Italy, not far from the Swiss border, some of the greatest red wines of the world are produced, robust wines of unusual intensity and flavor that often require a decade or two of aging to become drinkable. The region is known as the Piedmont, and the noblest grape cultivated there is the nebbiolo.

title: House Takes Gluten Stand
description: The House today passed a resolution urging President Reagan to oppose European efforts to restrict imports of corn gluten, an ingredient in animal feed, with a warning that the issue could start a trade war.

title: TAX BREAK REPEAL IS SOUGHT BY LONG
description: Russell B. Long, the chief Democratic tax writer in the Senate, said today that he was sponsoring legislation to abolish the special income tax deduction of $75 a day that Congress gave itself last December. He said he expected the Finance Committee to approve it.

title: Mobil Curtailment
description: The Mobil Corporation said it intends to cease oil refining at its Amsterdam plant in September. A statement from its Dutch subsidiary, Mobil Oil B.V., said that losses at the refinery were running $600,000 a week and the plant had been operating at only 50 percent of its full capacity of 120,000 barrels daily. Some 160 jobs would be lost when refining stops, but the plant would still employ 40 people for the storage and transshipment of oil products, Mobil said.

title: FALKLANDS' IMPACT ON LATIN BORROWING
description: Lending officers for big United States banks can usually be found traveling through Latin America at this time of year, meeting with government and corporate officials eager to arrange new loans. This year, however, the war between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands has kept the bankers at home.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SINCE moving to eastern Long Island more than 20 years ago, I have spent many hours foraging for mussels in the waters close to my home. Some years ago I could take my boat into Gardiner's Bay and within half an hour or less rake up a bushel of mussels, enough to serve 25 guests or more.

title: Cluett Layoffs
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company said that it plans to end the last of its Arrow shirtmaking operations here within the next six weeks, resulting in 200 layoffs. Some 400 administrative workers will remain on the payroll at the company's 150,000-square-foot factory, which will be half empty. Manufacturing operations will be shifted to other plants, mostly in the South.

title: HAPPY HOUR HAIKU
description: Sun bleeding bright red O ver distant horizon. Ice tinkling in glass.

title: GOLDEN PALOMINOS BREAK FUSION-ROCK MOLD
description: THE fusion of rock, funk, jazz, noise and performance art that is proceeding apace in downtown clubs, lofts and performance spaces hasn't been very conducive to career-building. Musicians who are career-minded tend to find something they can do well and stick with it, using a single, catchy group name and a recognizable group format whenever possible.

title: STRINGS: GUARNERI QUARTET
description: THE Guarneri String Quartet played the second in its six-concert Beethoven cycle Monday at the 92d Street Y. There were the Quartets in D from Opus 18, the F minor (Op. 95) and the great A minor (Op. 132). The first two pieces seemed a study in opposites - the D major with its lingering traces of 18th-century formality and the F minor fiercely dense, its mysterious chord progressions somehow looking forward to the mysteries of the Opus 132.

title: 2 Killed as Tornadoes Rip Towns in Oklahoma
description: A spate of at least 40 tornadoes ripped through Oklahoma, Texas and Kansas yesterday. Susan Michelle Cook, 4 years old, and Rhonda Price, 25, were killed, at least five other persons were injured and three houses and more than a dozen mobile homes were destroyed when twisters struck near Friendship and Blair, Okla., officials said.

title: POP: ETHEL MERMAN AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: ETHEL MERMAN fell back on an old wheeze to explain how she got to Carnegie Hall on Monday night to give her first concert there at the age of 73.

title: Schoolboy Player Dies
description: John McCorvey, an 18-year-old basketball player at Choctawhatcee High School in Fort Walton Beach, died today in a hospital, two days after he suffered a stroke, officials said.

title: Panel on Cable TV
description: ''Cable Production: What Every Arts Organization Should Know'' is the topic of a conference to be sponsored by the Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts on May 20 and 21 at New York University's Law School.

title: VOTE IN U.N. HEALTH AGENCY
description: Hard-line Arab countries lost their bid today to have the World Health Organization transfer its Eastern Mediterranean regional office from Alexandria to Amman. However, in a secret vote in committee, the United Nations Agency's annual assembly of member states decided by 57 to 37, with 21 abstentions, to shelve the issue until next year.

title: OF DISPUTE
description: Argentine officials expressed slight but increasing optimism today about a peaceful settlement of the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Greetings Corp. said it and Christian Publishing Co., a South African concern, together had acquired greeting card businesses in several European countries. The cost was not disclosed.

title: Advertising; Heekin Helps Start An Agency
description: William S. Doyle, 37-year-old director of worldwide marketing resources at the Chase Manhattan Bank, has wanted his own agency since he was a copywriter at Wallace-Blakeslee Advertising in Grand Rapids, Mich. Recently, in search of that goal, he retained the services of James R. Heekin Jr., who, at age 54, with a number of agency presidents behind him, is one of the more prominent consultants in the business.

title: General Manager of Ballroom Accused of Arson in Cafe Fire
description: The general manager of the Agora Ballroom in New Haven has been charged with first-degree arson in connection with a fire that damaged the Night Owl Cafe in Wolcott on March 7, authorities said.

title: DIFFICULT DAYS FOR FAIRFIELD COUNTY OFFICE DEVELOPERS
description: Rudi Lazarus says the office market in Connecticut's Fairfield County has never been worse. He ought to know. Mr. Lazarus, senior vice president of William Pitt Inc., has been in the real estate business in the county for 17 years. He followed the market for office space through the boom years that began in the early 1970's. He watched as about 12 million square feet of office space was built along highways, nestled among dogwood trees or tucked along the shore. He saw this area grow to international prominence as major corporations relocated here.

title: GOODRICH MAY BE FIRST TO GET IRAN PAYMENT
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it expected to be the first company to receive a payment from the $1 billion security account set up to pay settlements of claims between the United States and Iran.

title: AMERICAN BEER: HOW CHANGING TASTES HAVE CHANGED IT
description: MORE than twice as much beer is consumed in the United States as in any other country, so American taste preferences are followed closely by international brewers. Two significant -and somewhat contradictory - movements seem to prevail among American beer drinkers these days.

title: 1. Easy Bottle Opener
description: Bottle openers are often unnecessarily complicated. We welcome a new one from Denmark that is both excellent design and easy to use. The brainchild of Rud Thygesen and Johnny Sorensen, it's a circle of steel enameled in bright red or black, with two bars inside. The cap is placed inside the bars and easily levered off. The opener is $10 at Sointu, 20 East 69th Street.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PLEASE don't eat the daffodils (the daisies, however, are O.K.), or the buttercups, bleeding heart, caladium, lantana, lily of the valley, privet, sweet pea, yew, oleander, azalea, mountain laurel, rhododendron, philodendron, dieffenbachia, delphinium, hens and chickens, lupine, May apple, jimson weed or any of several dozen other plants and flowers that commonly grow in homes, gardens, roadsides, fields and woods.

title: Military Analysis
description: The pressure increasingly exerted by the British task force in the South Atlantic, exemplified by the close bombardment of fuel tanks and military installations at Stanley, could be preliminary either to an assault by helicopters and landing craft on the Falkland Islands or a further tightening of the blockade.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GERMAN IMMIGRANTS' STORY

title: STATE HIGH COURT UPHOLDS WOMAN IN CASE INVOLVING CANCER AND DES
description: New York State's highest court yesterday upheld a damage award against a manufacturer of the drug DES, even though the plaintiff could not prove that the company had produced the DES that she said had caused her cancer.

title: Not Guilty Plea in Spy Case
description: Otto Attilla Gilbert, the Hungarian native accused of attempting to buy classified military documents from a United States soldier, pleaded not guilty today to charges of espionage. Mr. Gilbert, 50 years old, was arrested April 17 and indicted by a Federal grand jury in Savannah last month on four counts. He is being held without bond.

title: ARGENTINES SEE JUMP IN INFLATION
description: Short-term emergency measures adopted since the outbreak of the Falkland crisis more than a month ago have injected a bit of stability into Argentina's recession-struck and hyper-inflationary economy.

title: OCCASIONAL POETS TAKE TOP AWARDS IN CONTEST
description: The Poet of the Day was discussing inspiration. Or, at least, she was explaining why she had written the poem that yesterday won the highest prize in the 12th annual High School Poetry Contest, winning out over entries from 70 city high schools.

title: Mystery Writers Honor 7 With Edgar Awards
description: The Mystery Writers of America have announced the following winners of their annual Edgar Allan Poe awards: Novel: ''Peregrine'' (Congdon & Lattes) by William Bayer. First novel: ''Chiefs'' (W.W. Norton) by Stuart Woods.

title: 2 Crane Eggs Termed Fertile
description: At least two of six rare Siberian crane eggs at the International Crane Foundation are fertile, researchers report. Joan Fordham, administrator of the foundation, said Monday that one of the fertile eggs was put in an incubator and the other in the nest of a sandhill crane. The first Siberian crane to be successfully bred in captivity was hatched at the foundation last year.

title: VANCE URGES REDUCTIONS OF CONVENTIONAL AS WELL AS NUCLEAR FORCES
description: Former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that negotiations to reduce strategic nuclear arsenals should be accompanied by renewed efforts to reach agreement with the Soviet Union on reduced and roughly equal levels of conventional military strength.

title: A Wobbly New York Budget
description: Mayor Koch's ebullience could hide the hole in a bagel but not the problems of his 1983 budget.

title: LAKERS GO UP, 2-0, WITH 110-101 VICTORY
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, who were eliminated by the Houston Rockets in the first round of the playoffs last season, are making up for that disaster with their best basketball since winning the league title in 1980.

title: 'Dear Abby' Also Admits Recycling Some Letters
description: Abigail Van Buren has admitted that she reused letters in her advice column without labeling them as such, but said today that she would make sure that all repeated letters were identified from now on.

title: ARGENTINE VESSEL IS REPORTED SUNK IN THE FALKLANDS
description: British forces have sunk an Argentine ship, believed to be an oil tanker, in the narrow waterway that separates East and West Falkland Islands, a correspondent's dispatch from the scene said tonight.

title: FOR WALLENBERG AUTHOR, 2-YEAR, 10-NATION QUEST
description: WHEN she was 9 years old in Budapest in the mid-50's, Kati Marton asked her father whom Wallenberg Street was named after, because it was obviously not a Hungarian name. ''I remember getting a highly unsatisfactory answer about this Wagnerian hero who came to Budapest and then vanished,'' she recalled recently, ''but I didn't think anything more about it for almost 25 years.''

title: GOVERNOR ORDERS 4-DAY WEEK FOR 7,000 EMPLOYEES IN IDAHO
description: With the state facing a projected $12.1 million deficit, Gov. John V. Evans has ordered that more than half the state's 13,000 employees, including his housekeeper, go on a four-day workweek, at least until June 30, the end of the fiscal year.

title: REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY HAS LOST MANY OF ITS HARD EDGES, AIDES SAY
description: The foreign policy of the Reagan Administration has shifted in the last year and a half, in the view of Government officials, moving away from its roots in the conservative wing of the Republican Party toward the traditional center.

title: KINGMAN POWERS METS
description: No ninth-inning pinch-hits were needed for the Mets to win last night at Shea Stadium. Dave Kingman drove in four runs with a home run and a double, and Charlie Puleo pitched his first complete game and first shutout in the major leagues as the Mets registered a 6-0 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC FOR YOUNG ENSEMBLES
description: THERE was something mildly amusing about the program offered Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall by New Music for Young Ensembles Inc. With major works by the late Samuel Barber and the very late Maurice Ravel being offered by the likes of the Dorian Wind Quintet - which is celebrating its 20th anniversary this season - and the Burdette Trio, one couldn't help wondering whether the name ''Older Music for Established Ensembles'' might have reflected more accurately what was being performed by whom.

title: 2 SIDES AT U.N. SEE PROGRESS IN CRISIS
description: Argentine and British envoys said here tonight that they were moving closer to an accord that would end the fighting over the Falkland Islands.

title: Guatemalan Rebels Accused of Killings
description: Guatemalan military authorities said today that leftist guerrillas had killed 20 men, women and children in a highland hamlet because the townspeople refused to give them food and money.

title: Careers; The Field Of Caring For Horses
description: THERE is no evidence of recession in at least one industry: the business of raising and caring for horses. That opinion comes from Cecile Kirby Hetzel, who supervises the equestrian science program at Stephens College in Columbia, Mo., a college town that is also the home of the University of Missouri.

title: Convicted Slayer To Get New Trial
description: A state appeals court today ordered a new trial for Robert Reldan, who was convicted by a jury of raping and murdering two Bergen County women in 1975.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Acquired Doug Corbett, relief pitcher, and Rob Wilfong, infielder, from the Minnesota Twins for Tom Brunansky, an outfielder, and Mike Walters, a relief pitcher, both with Spokane of the Pacific Coast League, and cash.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THOMAS HARDY. By Michael Millgate. Illustrated. 637 pages. Random House. $25.

title: Earlier 'Annie' Curtain
description: ''Annie,'' the long-running musical by Thomas Meehan, Charles Strouse and Martin Charnin, will have a 6:45 P.M. curtain Saturdays beginning June 5 at the Uris Theater. The show, starring Allison Smith, Harve Presnell and Marcia Lewis, will play Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at 8 P.M., Sunday at 6:45 and matinees Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays at 2.

title: POLICE LINK SLAYING OF 3 TO ARGUMENT ON MONEY
description: Detectives investigating the murder of three men on a Queens street Saturday morning say they now believe they know who did the shooting and the motive.

title: ISRAEL BURIES BONES OF ANCIENT WARRIORS
description: The bones of 25 Jewish warriors from Bar Kochba's revolt against the Romans in A.D. 132-135 were interred today with full military honors in the stark wilderness of the Judean desert, where the men fought and died.

title: EXCELLENCE OUTSIDE THE IVY LEAGUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Goodyear Contract Ratified
description: The United Rubber Workers union has ratified a new three-year contract with the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company,

title: News Analysis
description: In two days of testimony, John W. Hinckley Jr.'s psychiatrist has given the broad outlines and some of the details of the treatment he chose for the youth who shot President Reagan.

title: SOVIET APPLIES CARROT-AND-STICK POLICY TO RELIGION
description: An American clergyman invited to an officially sanctioned religious conference in Moscow last fall was surprised when customs officials at the airport seized all his religious books.

title: FALKLAND CRISIS IS STAINING BRITISH-IRISH RELATIONS
description: The crisis over the Falkland Islands is having a chilling effect on the tortured relationship between Britain and Ireland. The new troubles between these neighboring islands grow out of this country's often overlooked neutrality in international affairs, and the instinctive Irish antipathy to the British presence abroad.

title: U.S. JUDGE TELLS CITY NOT TO HOLD AT-LARGE VOTING
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred New York City from electing atlarge City Council members this fall, but he said the 10 members now holding those seats could remain in office, possibly up to November 1983.

title: PLAN FOR MERGER SET IN BROOKLYN BY 2 HOSPITALS
description: St. John's Episcopal Hospital and the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn announced yesterday that they would merge. They said they had reached agreement in an ecumenical effort to preserve medical care for predominately black and impoverished neighborhoods in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Crown Heights sections of northern Brooklyn.

title: U.S. TELLS ECOLOGISTS TO TRUST FREE ENTERPRISE
description: The United States called on the nations of the world today to place more reliance on private initiative and the free market in dealing with environmental problems.

title: Clock Company To Discuss Move
description: Representatives of Seth Thomas Clocks say they are willing to discuss Gov. William A. O'Neill's offer of up to $11 million in aid and loans to keep the concern in the state.

title: THRIFT UNIT AID BACKED IN HOUSE
description: The House Banking Committee, seeking a way to help the beleaguered savings and loan industry, today approved a measure that would set up an $8.5 billion Treasury-backed fund to guarantee the net worth of failing thrift units.

title: Gulf Oil Spending
description: James E. Lee, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, told the annual meeting that the company would lower its capital spending in 1982 to $4 billion from the previously planned $4.5 billion. He said that lower oil prices were resulting in less cash than the company had projected earlier.

title: South Africa Reports Exchange of Spies
description: South Africa has exchanged a Soviet spy for eight high-ranking Western intelligence agents and a South African soldier, Prime Minister P.W. Botha told Parliament today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are certain fundamental principles that we cannot fudge in any way.'' - Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. (A13:1.)

title: Sirhan, the Scapegoat
description: Foul, cries the man who murdered Robert Kennedy. California has already said he could be paroled in 1984. To withdraw his parole date now, the assassin says, would deny him equal treatment under the law. Why, he insists, his victim would be among the first to say so!

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE: 'WE ARE FIGHTING TO STAY ALIVE'
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY FINDS THAT MAYONNAISE CAN INHIBIT SPOILAGE OF FOOD
description: Commercial mayonnaise may have been unfairly labeled as a source of food spoilage during the warm months, according to a study by the Food Research Institute of the University of Wisconsin. The study found that mayonnaise in salads actually helped reduce spoilage.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on April 30 misstated an analyst's interest in the General Nutrition Corporation. The analyst, George Quint of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, still follows the company.

title: DEFICIENCIES REPORTED IN MEAT INSPECTION
description: Meat products headed for consumers' tables were adulterated or misbranded in one of every five packing plants surveyed recently by a special branch of the Department of Agriculture, The Kansas City Times has reported.

title: Gulf Resources Proxy Fight
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, which faces a proxy fight from the British investor Alan E. Clore adjourned its annual meeting in Houston after 20 minutes yesterday until May 21, when it will receive results of the contest.

title: Pryor Ends King Pact
description: Aaron Pryor, the World Boxing Association's junior-welterweight champion, has ended his exclusive contract with the promoter Don King, saying that he wants the freedom to schedule his own bouts. The contract, to which Pryor agreed a year ago, gave King one year of exclusive rights to schedule fights for Pryor, with an option for a second year.

title: SOME LOCAL OFFICIALS REFUSE TO PLAN MASS RELOCATION IN AN ATOM THREAT
description: Marilyn Braun, a soft-spoken city official in charge of a three-person civil defense staff here, had no idea she would be setting off alarms in the nation's capital when she recently ordered ''fallout shelter'' signs removed from public buildings throughout the city.

title: Control Data Cuts
description: Faced with lower computer orders, the Control Data Corporation said it would temporarily lay off 9,500 employees by shutting down 13 Magnetic Peripherals Inc. plants, which make disk drive memories, for up to 12 days in late June and early July. Affected are plants in Minnesota, South Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma and Texas.

title: Business Failures Rise
description: The 530 business failures reported for the week ended May 6, by Dun & Bradstreet - the most in 40 years -were just a fraction of the concerns that actually closed their doors, according to an industry economist.

title: Strife Subsides In Lebanese Port
description: Battles in the north Lebanese port of Tripoli subsided today but sporadic shooting continued and sounds of explosions were heard in several parts of the city, security sources said.

title: WHERE MOTHERS CAN GATHER FOR CAMARADERIE AND SUPPORT
description: THE basement room at St. Matthew's Church in White Plains was a cacophany of nursery sounds. While about a dozen preschool-age children played noisily, their mothers sat chatting at a white circular table, keeping a wary eye on their charges and swapping the sort of tips mothers have been trading for generations.

title: OMANI WINDS UP CAIRO TALKS
description: Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman left today after several days of talks with President Hosni Mubarak about a possible Egyptian reconciliation with the Arab world.

title: KNOTTY, KNOTTY
description: I have been viciously abused for supporting the school-necktie amendment. I don't know why. It seems obvious, doesn't it, that the decline of American education began when the Supreme Court, or somebody in authority, maybe gym teachers, said you couldn't stop a child from going to school dressed like a slob.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday about a libel suit in New Mexico incorrectly character- ized the departure of John Donahue in 1980 from a job as an investigator for the New Mexico Attorney General's office. He resigned.

title: Three Killed in Cave-Ins At Arizona Copper Mine
description: Two miners trapped 3,400 feet underground by a mine cave-in were found dead by rescue crews today.

title: EUROPE'S SURGING HOME VIDEO MARKET
description: West Germany's video pioneers first set up business in this Bavarian capital several years ago, peddling prerecorded cassettes of B movies and pornographic films from what had once been candy stores. Early owners of videotape recorders, with little to chose from in the way of cassettes, flocked to the new shops.

title: Schmidt Increases Pabst Offer by $5
description: C. Schmidt & Sons, the Philadelphia brewer that last month made what it then said was its ''best and highest offer'' to buy the Pabst Brewing Company for $20.50 a share, increased the offer to a total of $25.50 a share in cash and other compensation, or about $209 million. In a proposal submitted to Pabst, Schmidt offered to pay Pabst holders the original $183 million, or $20.50 a share in cash, plus an extra $5 principal amount subordinated debentures for each common share.

title: AIRLINES' L-1011 OPTIONS
description: A majority of the airlines that hold options to purchase the Lockheed L-1011 jet aircraft will not exercise them, Roy A. Anderson, Lockheed's chairman, said at the stockholders' meeting today.

title: Jockey in Preakness Is '16 Going on 50'
description: Cowboy Jack Kaenel usually dons his Stetson before he drives to the race track each morning. Today, for no particular reason, he put on his padded riding helmet instead. As a result, he will have a chance to become the youngest jockey to win a Triple Crown race when he rides Aloma's Ruler in the Preakness here Saturday.

title: Dow Gains 4.95; Oils Strong
description: Energy-related issues led the stock market to a modest advance yesterday in accelerated trading. Analysts attributed the new strength in the oil group, which has been depressed, to the growing belief that oil prices have reached bottom and may be heading higher.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 12, 1982
description: International British forces sank an Argentine ship, believed to be an oil tanker, in the narrow waterway between East and West Falkland Islands, according to a British correspondent at the scene. The Defense Ministry said the action showed that Britain had established total military superiority around the archipelago. There was no word on casualties. (Page A1, Column 6.) Progress toward a cease-fire in the Falkland dispute was reported by Argentine and British envoys at the United Nations. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is serving as a mediator, said the negotiations were ''at a very delicate stage'' and ''at least two or three days'' were needed to complete them. (A1:5.)

title: ALCOHOLIC CONTENT
description: If you want to know the alcoholic content of a bottle of beer purchased in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut, don't look at the label; it's not there. You would have to call the brewer to find out.

title: Joseph A. Carrucci Jr., Lyndhurst Mayor, Dies
description: Mayor Joseph A. Carrucci Jr. of Lyndhurst died early this morning after he apparently suffered a heart attack while driving on the Garden State Parkway, officials said.

title: Skalbania Retains Club
description: Nelson Skalbania, the Montreal Alouettes' owner, yesterday won his fight to keep the Canadian Football League team from being seized by Sam Berger, the former owner, as payment for outstanding debts. Justice Jacques Dugas of the Quebec Superior Court upheld Skalbania's motion to nullify a writ of seizure for the franchise that Berger had obtained in March.

title: G.M. to Start New Steel Bidding
description: General Motors Corporation chairman Roger Smith said that G.M. plans to begin new bidding procedures with major steel suppliers.

title: A Real Big Cookie
description: Whether it's the ultimate chocolate chip - if it is possible to crown a single cookie with that title - Cookie Courier's chocolatechip cookie can probably lay claim to being the largest and heaviest.

title: OILS' LAYERS ANALYZED BY SPACE SCIENCE
description: SPACE scientists, using image-enhancement technology, have succeeded in extracting the image of one oil painting that had been overlaid by another without disturbing the later work.

title: DEHYDRATED MAPLE SYRUP ON THE MARKET
description: Until recently no one stepped up to a counter and said, ''I'll take a bag of maple syrup.'' They can now. To be precise, it is not exactly maple syrup, but it once was, for it is the pure granules of maple syrup that remain after dehydration. The product is on the market for the first time.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 13, 1982
description: International Two Argentine jets were shot down when they attacked a British warship off the Falklands, the Defense Ministry announced. Reports reaching London said that the two American-made A-4 Skyhawks had been escorting transport planes trying to run the British blockade when they were brought down in dense fog and clouds by missiles about 25 miles west of the islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) Foreign journalists were abducted or detained in Buenos Aires. One American journalist was said to be under detention, and two Norwegians were reported by Norwegian diplomats to have been put on separate planes and sent out of the country. (A1:5.) Military aid for El Salvador totaling $60 million was approved overwhelmingly by the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The Reagan Administration's request was granted after a heated debate in which the panel struck down proposals to halt or limit the assistance.(A1:2.)

title: JACOB BURCK
description: Jacob Burck, a Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial cartoonist, died Tuesday of injuries sustained in a fire at his home.

title: FACULTY AT CALIFORNIA STATE U. IS UNDECIDED ON UNION ISSUE
description: Professors at California State University have again failed to choose between two rival unions vying to represent the faculty at the country's largest four-year college system.

title: CHIEF OF CONSUMER SAFETY PRESSES INDEPENDENCE
description: The appointment of Nancy Harvey Steorts as chairman of the 10-year-old Consumer Product Safety Commission was hailed by Reagan Administration officials as the end of the ''era of confrontation and antagonism'' with the American business community and the beginning of the ''era of cooperation.''

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL'S $33,000 INVESTMENT IN TAX SHELTER SCRUTINIZED
description: Attorney General William French Smith found his finances under scrutiny today because of an oil and gas drilling tax shelter in which he invested $33,000. The investment made him eligible for $99,000 in Federal income tax deductions.

title: RECESSION IS SLOWING THE PEN INDUSTRY
description: Years ago, Calvin K. Clemmons said, there was an inside joke in the pen industry that explained why the business was so good. ''They used to say there was a big hole in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean where they were dumping all the millions of pens,'' he said. ''Now they're saying, 'Do you think we've filled it up?' ''

title:
NOTES OF MUSIC;
SAN FRANCISCO OPERA OPENS SEASON SEPT. 10
description: THE San Francisco Opera has announced its plans for next season, its first under Terence A. McEwen, general director. The opening will be Sept. 10, with Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' conducted by the company's general director emeritus, Kurt Herbert Adler. Montserrat Caballe and Luciano Pavarotti head the cast.

title: MAJOR EXPANSION IN LATE 70's OVERWHELMED COLORFUL BRANIFF
description: Braniff International Airways, one of the most colorful of the major American airlines, was run from 1965 to 1980 by Harding L. Lawrence, a flamboyant and controversial Texan whose enthusiastic expansion of the line in the late 1970's strained its finances to the breaking point.

title: Honeymooner's Kiss Results in a Stabbing
description: A honeymooning couple paused too long at a stop sign to grab a kiss, and apparently made the driver behind them angry enough that he stabbed the bridegroom.

title: E-SYSTEM PROTESTS FOREIGN ARMS DEAL
description: A leading defense contractor, E-Systems Inc., has enlisted the support of several Congressmen in a campaign to stop companies of Western Europe, Canada, Egypt and Israel from selling weapons and equipment to the United States armed forces under special diplomatic agreements.

title: Omega Watch to Scali
description: The Omega Watch Corporation is moving its $3 million account to Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a subsidiary of Ogilvy & Mather, from Blair Advertising, Rochester, a subsidairy of BBDO International.

title: GIVE PENSIONERS A STAKE IN NATIONAL PRODUCTIVITY
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE UNHURT AS MAN MENACES HIM AT PORTUGAL SHRINE
description: A young man in clerical garb moved toward Pope John Paul II with a knife today at the Shrine of Fatima, but security guards overpowered him, the Portuguese ANOP news agency said.

title: NEW ACT TO REQUIRE LAWBREAKERS TO HELP PAY COST OF COURT SYSTEM
description: With no fanfare and little notice to judges and lawyers, a new state law went into effect yesterday requiring lawbreakers to help pay for the costs of operating the criminal-justice system.

title: MIDTOWN MANHATTAN ZONING: THE BATTLE OVER 'GRANDFATHERING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Polish Stowaways Ask Asylum in Baltimore
description: Two young Polish men who stowed away on a Polish freighter jumped ship today while the vessel unloaded and later surrendered and asked for political asylum, officials said.

title: PANEL IN HOUSE VOTES ARMS AID FOR EL SALVADOR
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today overwhelmingly approved the Reagan Administration's proposal for $60 million in military aid to El Salvador.

title: REPORTERS SEIZED BY THE ARGENTINES
description: The authorities expelled three foreign journalists today and three others were abducted by unknown people and later released naked.

title: Owens-Illinois Regroups Lines
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., a packaging producer based in Toledo, Ohio, said it had reorganized its domestic and international operations into product groups rather than geographic areas.

title: Books: Suburban Sleuth
description: C.B. GREENFIELD: No Lady in the House. By Lucille Kallen. 224 pages. Wyndham. $13.50.

title: Michigan's Credit Rating Cut to Lowest Level
description: A Wall Street service today cut Michigan's credit rating, making it the lowest of any state. Officials here said they might have trouble borrowing $500 million for schools and local governments this fall.

title: Brown: 'Just a Candidate'
description: Hubie Brown, reported to be the prime candidate to replace Red Holzman as the Knicks' coach, said tonight at a news conference that he was ''just a candidate.''

title: DANCE: AILEY PRESENTS 'FONTESSA AND FRIENDS'
description: IT'S fitting that Alvin Ailey calls his company the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, for he and his dancers have been holding the fort for dramatic dance for a number of years. And Tuesday's program at the City Center showed the company at its most vividly theatrical. Here were dancers who made each moment on stage count to reveal character and emotional nuance in a way that is uniquely theirs, in dances that showed Mr. Ailey at his most humane as choreographer and company director.

title: The U.N. Today; May 13, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session Devoted to Disar- mament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: BRIEFING
description: Message for Kissinger

title: Pabst Holder 'Pleased'
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, whose coalition of Pabst Brewing Company shareholders was defeated last month in its proxy battle for board control of the Milwaukee-based brewery, said yesterday that he was ''pleased'' with the increased offer for Pabst made Tuesday by C. Schmidt & Sons Inc. Mr. Jacobs's group, which controls 16.3 percent of Pabst's common shares outstanding, has waged a battle for control of the company since last fall. Schmidt, a Philadelphia brewer that has been seeking to buy out Pabst since February, increased its previous offer of $186 million, or $20.50 a share, to $209 million, or $20.50 a share cash plus $5 in debentures.

title: Korchnoi's Son to Be Freed
description: The son of Viktor Korchnoi, the exiled Soviet chess grandmaster, will be released from a Siberian labor camp Thursday, a relative said. Igor Korchnoi, 23 years old, was convicted of draft-dodging in December 1979 and sentenced to two and a half years' imprisonment.

title: NOW 'ALL THINGS CONSIDERED' IS A BOOK
description: THE closest thing in the United States to the BBC's estimable radio service is National Public Radio, which is financed in part by the Government but is also pretty much immunized from the static of news- and arts-watchers in Washington.

title: WORD FROM ISLANDERS: STANDING FIRM
description: A resident of Southampton received a telegram this morning from a relative who lives in the Falkland Islands. Reflecting what appears to be a pattern of determination among the people of the occupied islands, it read, in its entirety, ''Happy and kicking.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Florida State Board of Education's $43 million of tax-exempt bonds are being offered by Bear, Stearns & Company at yields ranging from 8 percent in 1983 to 10.75 percent in 1992 and 12.15 percent in 2002.

title: THE NEW SCHOOL, A MAVERICK, GETS READY TO REBUILD
description: Since its founding in 1919, the New School for Social Research has lived by its wits in Manhattan. Take the way Alvin Johnson, who founded the school in 1919, obtained the main building.

title: IT WAS A FULL FASHION SHOW, BUT THE FOCUS WAS ON LEGS
description: fledged fashion show. Only for this kind of show, the focus was on the legs, and the fashions were merely accessories.

title: Q & A
description: Q. How can I protect the finish on my mahogany dining-room table so that I may set the table without need for using pads and a cloth? -J.V., Forest Hills, Queens

title: Solar Cell Development
description: Sumitomo Electric Industries said it had developed with the Kansai Electric Power Company of Japan a new solar cell using a gallium arsenite semiconductor device. The company said it needed more time before it begins commercial production as gallium arsenite is still costly, but said the new cell could attain a much higher heat-electricity conversion efficiency than cells using other devices such as silicon. Sumitomo said it would be suitable for highly concentrated photovoltaic systems including a power source for satellites, as its resistance to high temperature and radiation is strong.

title: C.W. Post Nine Loses
description: Jim DeShaeis, a senior left-hander, pitched a two-hitter and struck out 12 today in leading LeMoyne (27-4) to a 3-2 victory over C.W. Post (28-7) in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II Northeast Regional baseball tournament at MacArthur Stadium.

title: Market Place; Beneficiary Of an Upturn
description: ANALYSTS seem to be differing widely these days on the state of the economy and when it will turn upward. But once the upturn gets into full swing, one of the beneficiaries is expected to be the Parker-Hannifin Corporation of Cleveland, an industrial giant with $1 billion in annual sales, 21,000 employees, 131 plants and 100,000 products for 300 industries.

title: VESCO DETAINED BRIEFLY, EXPELLED BY COSTA RICA
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive American financier, was briefly detained when he landed in Costa Rica this morning and then expelled from the country as ''an undesirable,'' a Costa Rican Government spokesman said.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The American Petroleum Institute weekly oil data are not published today because of a delay in the gathering of statistics. The figures will appear tomorrow.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about Harvard Law School incorrectly identified the institution with which it has jointly sponsored a Boston legal services pro- gram. It is Northeastern University School of Law.

title: Glocca Morra Revisited and Relocated
description: When ''Finian's Rainbow,'' the musical about a leprechaun, a pot of gold and a bigoted Southern Senator, opened on Broadway in 1947, one of the songs that won the critics was the wistful ''How Are Things in Glocca Morra?''

title: Stroh Brewery Names Fridholm as President
description: The Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit, the largest family-owned brewery in the United States, has elected Roger Fridholm, 41 years old, as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Fridholm becomes the second president in the 200-year history of the company who is not related to the Stroh family.

title: Harvester Reaches Pact With Indiana
description: The International Harvester Company, the debtridden manufacturer of farm equipment and construction machinery, announced today that it had reached an agreement in principle with Indiana officials on a $9.2 million loan guarantee plan to keep open the company's truck building plant in Fort Wayne.

title: MINE BREATHING UNITS NOW REQUIRED
description: Twelve years after Congress directed the development and installation of emergency breathing devices to supply oxygen in the nation's underground coal mines, the Federal Mine Safety and Health Administration has begun enforcing the requirement.

title: REAGAN WARNS SCHOOLS ARE FAILING TO MEET SCIENCE AND MATH NEEDS
description: President Reagan said today that the education of American schoolchildren in science and mathematics had reached such a deplorable state that it threatened the nation's military and economic security.

title: KENNEDY TOPS REAGAN IN POLL ON 1984 PRESIDENTIAL CHOICES
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy would defeat President Reagan if the next Presidential election was held now, according to the Gallup Poll, and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale would run even with the President.

title: MEXICO'S ELUSIVE OIL BOOM
description: From the hundreds of piles of neatly stacked steel pipe in steamy southern jungles to the skyscraper being built in Mexico City for Petroleos Mexicanos, the state petroleum monopoly, it is apparent that oil has become something of a king in this democratic nation of 70 million.

title: Civil Defense Plan To Save Fittest Is Urged
description: A million residents of the Los Angeles area survive a nuclear attack should concentrate on saving young, healthy and educated people, a retired Army major says.

title: SOUTH AFRICA GETS SHARED-RULE PLAN
description: South Africa issued long-awaited constitutional proposals today that would bend the political color bar by allowing an indirectly elected president with authoritarian powers to appoint nonwhites of mixed race and Asian descent to his Cabinet.

title: Volvo Plans Stock Offering
description: Volvo plans to offer its shareholders 25 percent of the stock of the Scandinavian Trading Company, its oil trading subsidiary, when the unit's shares are listed here next fall, a company spokesman said today.

title: At First, Ecumenical
description: Because a newly built expressway had made a dead end of his street in Toledo, Ohio, Rabbi Edward Garsek found he had to take a long, circuitous hike to get to his synagogue, Congregation Etz Chayim, on holy days, when he was not able to use his car.

title: Chicago Risks Losing 2 Stores
description: Two of the nation's biggest retailers, Sears, Roebuck and Company and Montgomery Ward & Company, may close their stores on State Street, once one of the nation's busiest shopping districts.

title: DANCE: NEW NAGRIN SOLO LOOKS INTO THE ABSTRACT
description: AS both dancer and choreographer, Daniel Nagrin is intense, powerful and rather angry. All these qualities come together in his 1981 solo ''Poems Off the Wall'' and, more obliquely if just as forcefully, in his newest solo, ''Dance.''

title: THE REALITY PRINCIPLE
description: An American President who hopes to break through the inertia and suspicions of international life to reach significant new agreements must sometimes deliberately change his tone in a public speech. President Kennedy did so in his American University speech of June 1963, laying the ground for the test ban treaty. President Reagan did so at Eureka College.

title: BRAZILIAN MEETS REAGAN ON CRISIS
description: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo of Brazil met with President Reagan today and told him that a solution to the Falkland crisis should avoid the appearance of victory or defeat for either Britain or Argentina.

title: HOUSE UNITS MEETS 15 HOURS BUT QUITS WITHOUT A BUDGET
description: The Democrat-dominated House Budget Committee adjourned at 1:15 this morning, just short of adopting a $780.5 billion budget plan for the fiscal year 1983 that has a projected deficit of almost $104 billion.

title: Lewellyn Faces 5 More Charges
description: Gary Lewellyn, a stockbroker, was arrested today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on five charges that he made false claims to the University Bank in Ames, Iowa, to obtain loans and then misapplied $1.5 million of the money.

title: Technology; Aerodynamics As Fuel Saver
description: SINCE it takes less energy to slice through the air than to plow it aside, automobile designers throughout the world are trying to improve vehicle aerodynamics as a way to get better fuel economy.

title: Massey Layoffs
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said it would lay off about 700 employees, or about half a shift, at its Brantford combine plant next Monday, and about 100 of the 1,000 hourly paid employees at its Toronto combine-parts facility. The company cited depressed worldwide sales for machinery.

title: 16 CHOSEN BY O'NEILL CENTER FOR PLAYWRIGHTS CONFERENCE
description: Sixteen playwrights chosen from 1,500 who submitted scripts for the theater and television will participate in the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's 18th National Playwrights Conference. Lloyd Richards, dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, is artistic director of the conference, which will run from July 11 through Aug. 8.

title: Reds Keep Hurdle Idle
description: Life in Cincinnati seemed to hold great promise for Clint Hurdle when he was acquired by the Reds in the offseason to be a part, with Cesar Cedeno and Paul Householder, of a completely renovated outfield. These days, though, Hurdle is playing hardly at all.

title: Florida Bank Merger Gains
description: The merger of the Citizens National Bank of Naples, Fla., into Flagship Banks of Miami has received Federal Reserve approval, Flagship reported yesterday, and should become effective within two months.

title: 29 Children Hurt As Bus Rolls Over
description: Twenty-nine children were injured today when a school bus carrying 45 students went out of control and rolled over near here, authorities said.

title: Car Phone System Proposed by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to allocate a portion of the radio spectrum for a new consumer-oriented mobile communications service.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CRAFTS AND ANTIQUES
description: Crafts Fair, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street, 860-6868.

title: Celanese Canada To Omit Dividend
description: Celanese Canada will omit its next quarterly dividend, Richard M. Clarke, president and chief executive, told the annual meeting.

title: JUNE DISARMAMENT RALLY IS BEING SHIFTED TO U.N.
description: A mass nuclear disarmament rally scheduled for Saturday, June 12, has been moved from Central Park to First Avenue and 42d Street, below the United Nations, because of logistical problems.

title: 76ers WIN, 121-113; TIE PLAYOFF
description: In the aftermath of a 40-point loss to the Boston Celtics last Sunday, Coach Billy Cunningham of the Philadelphia 76ers made some offensive adjustments tonight.

title: 2d Vote Set at A.M.C. Plant
description: Employees at an American Motors Corporation plant in Toledo, Ohio, will vote again on a new contract that they rejected May 3, the United Automobile Workers said Tuesday. The vote was scheduled for next Tuesday at the Jeep plant after the executive committee of Local 12 granted its approval. The pact was approved by locals in Milwaukee and Kenosha, Wis., but must be ratified at the Toledo plant to go into effect.

title: Physical Set for Weaver
description: Mike Weaver, who holds the World Boxing Association's version of the heavyweight championship, will appear in New Jersey tomorrow for a physical examination to confirm that his injury was sufficient enough to have forced postponement of his title defense against Randy Cobb. Weaver hurt himself, apparently while exercising with weights about three weeks ago, and his June 2 bout against Cobb was canceled.

title: One China for Mr. Reagan, Too
description: So there is, after all, only one China and President Reagan has belatedly found real merit in Peking's bid to promote a gradual peaceful political link with Taiwan.

title: JURY IN MOON'S TRIAL BEGINS DELIBERATIONS
description: Jury deliberations began yesterday in the tax-fraud trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The jury of two men and 10 women heard three hours of final instructions from Judge Gerard L. Goettel, then deliberated for three hours and adjourned for the day at 5:30 P.M. without any sign of nearing a verdict.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
VERSATILE DRAPERY RODS
