description: THOSE who have tried to find unobtrusive curtain rods or rods for unusually shaped windows will be delighted with a versatile line of drapery hardware called Swish, recently introduced here.

title: U.S. SENATE PANEL CLEARS TRANSIT AID
description: After two days of negotiations, the Senate Banking Committee today approved a bill that authorizes more money for mass transit than the Reagan Administration requested. It also continues operating assistance at present levels for one year.

title: NEW BOMB FOUND AS INQUIRY GOES ON
description: A nine-inch pipe bomb was discovered yesterday in a vacant lot on the Lower East Side as police experts tried to explain what appeared to be a rash of recent bomb explosions.

title: Brazil Line Buys Airbuses
description: VASP, the Brazilian airline, confirmed today that it would buy nine European Airbus A310 jets for almost $400 million, but no American-made Boeing 737's.

title: THREE GUIDEBOOKS FOR PUBLIC GARDENS
description: HOME gardeners regard the perfect-looking plants in public gardens with a mixture of joy and awe - and an occasional twinge of envy. Having left their own chores behind, these aficionados will often ignore miles of detours for the pure pleasure of a special wildflower walk, a particularly fragrant herb or rose garden, or an array of rare trees.

title: CONGRESSMAN HEEDS THE CALL OF CAROLINA
description: Gaffney, S.C., has 13,000 people and the world's largest peach. Actually, it's a water tower painted to look like a peach, but even this ersatz symbol of civic pride holds more allure for Representative Ken Holland than the Capitol dome. After eight years of representing South Carolina's Fifth District, the Democratic lawmaker is quitting Congress and going back home to Gaffney to practice law.

title: Cosmos Win by 2-1
description: Goals by Steve Moyers and Georgio Chinaglia late in the first half tonight held up to give the Cosmos a 2-1 victory over the San Diego Sockers before a crowd of 14,805 at Jack Murphy Stadium.

title: Reed, in Rare Start, Foils Dodgers, 11-3
description: Ron Reed, making his first start in five seasons, pitched seven strong innings and batted in two runs tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11-3, for their ninth victory in 10 games.

title: Borg Seen Out Of Grand Prix
description: Bjorn Borg has withdrawn from the Player's International tennis tournament, officials of the event said today. The tournament is scheduled for August.

title: NATO'S NUCLEAR POLICY
description: NunnWASHINGTON - NATO faces a dilemma. There is a growing consensus among NATO experts that less reliance should be placed on the use of nuclear weapons in response to a conventional attack by the Warsaw Pact, but there is also a widespread feeling that a credible non-nuclear defense is not attainable. Any resolution of this dilemma must start with a NATO commitment to a credible conventional defense capability. To put it simply, the ''conventional horse'' must be in front of the ''nuclear cart.''

title: IN SWEDEN, ASSUMPTIONS COME TUMBLING DOWN
description: Sweden relishes its myths, when it is not being tormented by them. The parts about being moral, endlessly progressive and profoundly humane are fine; the darker side - the righteousness, the benevolent big-brotherism - is uncomfortable because there is usually a Swede around to say yes, it's all true.

title: Good Noose News
description: There's a way, as clear as a tape measure, to tell how tight the OPEC oil noose is pulled around America's neck: count the number of barrels of oil the nation imports every day. This spring the noose is not only loosening, it now seems likely to stay slack for quite a while.

title: Texaco to Explore Louisiana Leases
description: Texaco Inc. and the Superior Oil Company said that they had signed a letter of intent to begin a joint exploration venture covering about 137,000 acres, most of which are leases from the state of Louisiana.

title: MONTANA JOB PROTEST QUELLED
description: Police officers used tear gas and dogs to keep more than 1,000 construction workers at bay today in a demonstration protesting the use of nonunion workers on a highway project near here.

title: Lab Develops Herpes Salve
description: Automated Medical Laboratories Inc., based in Miami, said yesterday that it had filed a patent application for a transfer factor ointment to be used in the treatment of Herpes Simplex viruses, Type 1 and Type 2.

title: Nailing Down Broadway's Bed
description: The Broadway theater, in the words of Moss Hart and George Kaufman, has long been a Fabulous Invalid. It remains the only New York performing art able to survive without subsidy or charitable aid. While amending midtown zoning to nudge developers west, the Department of City Planning properly fears that they may seek to build on sites occupied by legitimate theater buildings.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: E. Bradley Jones, 54 years old, was elected yesterday to succeed William J. De Lancey, 65, as chairman and chief executive of the Republic Steel Corporation.

title: APRIL SALES AT RETAIL GREW 1.4%
description: Retail sales, virtually stagnant since last spring, rose 1.4 percent in April with gains for cars, furniture and other durable goods, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ALAN G. RINEHART
description: Alan G. Rinehart, a former editor and producer of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, died Sunday at a hospital in New Orleans, where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Mercedes Parts Depot
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America today opened its largest parts distribution center in the United States. The 207,000-square-foot, $5 million facility in the Chicago suburb of Carol Stream, Ill., consolidates operations of two smaller depots in nearby Franklin Park, the company said in a statement released in Detroit.

title: CHURCH ON PARK DEBATING PLAN FOR DEMOLITION
description: The congregation of the Second Church of Christ, Scientist, is debating whether to sell its white-marble home on Central Park West at 68th Street to developers who would replace the imposing 82-yearold structure with an apartment tower and a smaller chapel.

title: LASER LIGHT'S TRAINER SAYS 2d IN PREAKNESS IS NOT HIS STYLE
description: The morning after Laser Light finished second in the Kentucky Derby, Pat Kelly stood outside the colt's stall and told passers-by and visitors, ''I hope you bet him to place. I didn't.''

title: MARTHA GRAHAM TO RECIEVE MEADOWS AWARD
description: Martha Graham will receive the 1982 Algur H. Meadows Award for Excellence in the Arts from Southern Methodist University's Meadows School of the Arts. Ingmar Bergman, the Swedish film director, was the first recipient of the $25,000 prize last year.

title: THE MAN UNION CITY BELIEVES IN
description: Residents of Union City, N.J., believe that they know their Mayor, William V. Musto, quite well by now; better, certainly, than a band of Federal prosecutors who they believe are out to do him in.

title: ILLINOIS GOVERNOR FACES STIFF OPPOSITION
description: When James R. Thompson ran for Governor in 1976, he did so on his record as a tough United States Attorney who had sent numerous public officials to jail for misuse of public funds. Once elected, he sought to keep his administration above reproach and instituted a variety of policies that opened it to wide public scrutiny.

title: STARTING THE PEACE RACE
description: At last, nearly four years after the dramatic signing of the SALT II treaty in Vienna, the United States has moved to revive the effort for strategic arms control.

title: Apple Computer
description: Apple Computer Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., will establish a subsidiary in Japan in July to market personal computers, a company spokesman said. Apple's two-year sales contract with Toray Industries of Japan will have expired by then.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Duty on Brazilian Steel
description: The European Economic Community said it was imposing a provisional antidumping duty of at least 15 percent on imports of Brazilian steel plate. Brazilian undercutting of Common Market prices on the products concerned reached more than 22 percent in some cases, the Commmon Market said.

title: TO REJOIN WOOD SUCCESSFULLY
description: WOODEN furniture joints fail for a variety of reasons: wood cells collapse, breaking the bond of the glue; glue softens through dampness; joints come apart under unusual strain.

title: ADDED JOBLESS PAY ENDORSED
description: A bill to extend unemployment insurance payments for 13 weeks was approved today by a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Costa Rica Planning to Move Embassy Back to Jerusalem
description: The Costa Rican Embassy, which took part in the 1980 diplomatic exodus from Jerusalem in response to a United Nations resolution, announced tonight that it would move back there next week.

title: Nationwide's Net Up
description: The Nationwide Life Insurance Company said today that its first-quarter net income was up 49 percent, to $11.7 million, or $3.25 a share, from $7.9 million, or $2.19 a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

title: GUARD HURT, TOO
description: An assistant principal and a security guard at a Bronx junior high school were clubbed to the ground and severely injured yesterday after they waded into a crowd of 250 teen-agers to go to the aid of one of their students who they thought were about to be attacked by a gang of youths armed with baseball bats and homemade clubs, the police said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A recurrence of the ankle injury that he suffered in Brussels will keep John McEnroe out of the Italian tennis championships starting Monday. ... In her first competitive match since January, Tracy Austin defeated Betsy Nagelsen, 6-2, 6-0, in a $200,000 tennis tournament in Tokyo. Miss Austin had been resting to ease a sciatic nerve problem that has bothered her for the last two years. ... Don Cherry, former coach of the Colorado Rockies, has won a summary judgment in a $35,000 suit against the club. Cherry, now a television commentator in Toronto, said the money was due him under his old contract because the Rockies, who dismissed him in 1980, had agreed to pay him that amount if they did not extend the pact. ... Nancy Lopez-Melton has filed for divorce after three years of marriage to Tim Melton, a sports broadcaster in Houston.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS OPPOSED AID
description: Led by United States Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, finance ministers from 10 major industrial countries today rebuffed demands from less developed countries for a vast infusion of aid.

title: 1902 VAUDEVILLE HOUSE TRYING FOR AN ENCORE
description: Cottrill's Opera House, with red brick exterior and burgundy velveteen interior, was once as flashy as some of the vaudeville acts that graced its stage in the early part of the century.

title: CRISIS CALLED LIKELY TO SPUR SOVIET-ARGENTINE TRADE
description: Adm. Bobby R. Inman, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, says that one outcome of the Falkland crisis may be to turn the Soviet Union into an arms supplier of Argentina in return for Argentine wheat and beef.

title: A TREE HOUSE ON A ROOF
description: BECAUSE David Stiles happened to have designed a number of playgrounds and his daughter, Lief Anne, was at the school, the Dalton Lower School thought it would be appropriate for him to submit a proposal for a rooftop play area.

title: St. John's in Opener
description: St. John's has been selected to play North Carolina, the national champion, in the Tip-Off Classic. The game, which marks the opening of the college basketball season, is scheduled for Nov. 20 at the Civic Center in Springfield, Mass.

title: Doctor Tried on Rape Counts Acquitted in Massachusetts
description: A jury today found a doctor not guilty of charges that he raped one patient and attempted to rape another in their hospital beds.

title: Pennzoil Oil Well Find
description: The Pennzoil Company has announced the discovery of a well in the Williston Basin of North Dakata flowing at a rate of 866 barrels of oil and 1.3 million cubic feet of gas a day. Pennzoil said the well, which was drilled to a depth of 13,000 feet, was being operated in conjunction with a subsidiary of Burlington Northern Inc., which owns the property.

title: On Mixing Sports With Religion
description: THE story is told about a guy at the track who can't win a bet. If his horse doesn't trail from the start, then it staggers in the stretch. Nothing works for him. A friend tells him the reason is that he doesn't live right. He is urged to attend church. Well, he has never been one to bother heaven with his problems, the story goes, but now he'll try anything.

title: DOWNEY DROPS OUT OF SENATE RACE
description: John T. Downey today withdrew his candidacy for the United States Senate, leaving Representative Toby Moffett unopposed for the Democratic nomination.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am the cause of John's tragedy.'' - John W. Hinckley Sr. (A1:1.)

title: MIDTOWN MANHATTAN ZONING: THE BATTLE OVER 'GRANDFATHERING'
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPERINTENDENTS GO WHITE COLLAR
description: THESE days that man in the pin-striped suit behind the mahogany desk with the push-button phone could be your superintendent. No longer do all superintendents fit the traditional mold of men who push brooms and replace electrical outlets. The new breed, particularly those who function in the ever more expensive world of the urban high-rise, are no longer uniformed workers waxing lobby furniture and sweeping public foyers, but executives supervising substantial budgets and large staffs and earning $25,000 a year or more.

title: Accounts
description: * Subaru of Northern California Inc. to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver Inc.

title: Codi Corporation Files for Chapter 11
description: The Codi Corporation and its principal subsidiary, Codi Semiconductor Inc. of Linden, N.J., announced they had filed petitions under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: U.S. ENVOY SEES MUBARAK ABOUT SITE OF TALKS
description: Egypt's refusal to hold talks in Jerusalem on a plan for Palestinian autonomy continued to impede efforts today by a special United States envoy to get the long-stalled Egyptian-Israeli negotiations resumed.

title: IRAN'S TROOPS CONSIDERED ABLE TO LUNGE INTO IRAQ
description: Western diplomats here say that, in view of recent Iraqi military reverses, Iranian forces appear to have the capacity to push all the way to the Iranian-Iraqi border in all areas held by Iraqis, and in some places even beyond.

title: HAIG, IN VISIT TODAY, MAY FIND THE TURKS ARE FIRM
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig, when he begins his visit here Thursday, is likely to find that Turkey is eager to demonstrate what it says are urgent military needs but is not prepared to make significant concessions to Greece in return for increased military aid.

title: Korean Bank Heads Resign
description: Two of South Korea's leading bank presidents resigned today and a former deputy chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency has been arrested in a black-market lending scandal that has threated to implicate President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: DATA HINT VENUS ONCE HAD OCEAN
description: Although scorchingly hot and dry now, the planet Venus may have once had a more benign climate and been covered by an ocean of water, according to an analysis of data from a United States spacecraft.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alpha-Portland Industries said had it sold its cement plant in Cementon, N.Y., to Lehigh Portland Cement Co. for about $11.6 million.

title: Armco to Lay Off 450 Coal Miners
description: Armco Inc., citing poor market conditions and low productivity, said that it would lay off 450 coal miners in West Virginia this week.

title: GRAHAM OFFERS POSITIVE VIEW OF RELIGION IN SOVIET
description: The Rev. Billy Graham said here today, at the end of a visit to the Soviet Union, that he had seen no evidence of religious repression and that the churches he had visited were at least as full as those in his hometown, Charlotte, N.C.

title: COAST POLICE CHIEF ACCUSED OF RACISM
description: The commission president, Riva B. Tooley, spoke at a hearing called at the request of Mayor Tom Bradley to look into complaints that Chief Gates had conducted himself improperly in an interview published Saturday by The Los Angeles Times.

title: FURNITURE RENTALS: AN ALTERNATIVE
description: FOR the newly separated or divorced, those facing a temporary job assignment in another city or those unable to afford the relatively high costs of purchase, renting furniture and other items that they need to set up housekeeping is becoming increasing popular.

title: CHAMBER: GARDEN STATE AND A FIRST
description: A CONCERTO for two harpsichords and strings by Georg Christoph Wagenseil received what was hailed as its ''first performance in modern times'' when it opened Tuesday evening's program of the Garden State Chamber Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall. Aside from the question such disclosures invariably raise - just when did modern times begin? - the piece, which featured Jens Nygaard and Mary Alderdice as the soloists, proved a remarkably pleasant example of the Italianate influences that infiltrated mid-18th-century style in Vienna and the south German cities.

title: Flash Gordon Writer Sentenced to Jail
description: Since 1951, long before men made the leap into space, Daniel Barry has been writing and drawing the Flash Gordon comic strip. ''The scientist's job,'' he told an interviewer in 1969, ''is to get man into space and onto the planets.

title: American Satellite, Tandem Venture
description: Tandem Computers Inc., based in California, said it had agreed to work with the American Satellite Company of Maryland to develop and market a computer satellite network that will be available next year.

title: ISRAEL CANNOT TRADE MORE LAND FOR PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: I'M told by a witness that on the morning of the day my father moved out of our house, I tore across our yard and into our nextdoor neighbor's kitchen. ''Please!'' I cried, wrapping my arms around the waist of Mrs. Walsh, mother to Carl, my closest friend, ''Please don't let my daddy leave!'' The story has been garnished over the years, I'm sure - I was 7 when it happened - but it's more or less true, and when I've had too much wine to drink, thinking about it makes me want to cry.

title: BRANIFF, IN FINANCIAL CRISIS, CANCELS ALL FLIGHTS
description: Braniff International Airways announced yesterday the suspension of all its domestic and foreign flights, and it urged the thousands of passengers holding Braniff reservations to make other arrangements.

title: Questor Is Moving
description: The Questor Corporation will move its headquarters from Toledo to Tampa, Fla., this summer, James Milligan, president and chief executive officer, told the 50 employees at the company's headquarters building. The company, which makes Spalding sporting goods, Evenflo, Lullabye and Kantwet baby products, and Leslie-Locke building products, said the move would be ''consistent with its new growth strategy and permit greater accessibility to the company's principal continuing businesses.''

title: Mets' Game Put Off by Rain
description: The Mets' attempt to win their fourth straight game fell two outs short last night at Shea Stadium.

title: TV Networks to Carry Reagan News Parley
description: President Reagan will conduct a news conference tonight at 8 o'clock Eastern daylight time.

title: EASY PERENNIALS KEEP GAINING IN FAVOR
description: PERENNIALS are getting more popular with home gardeners every year. The most obvious reason is that these flowering plants are exactly what their name indicates - perennial. Once planted they stay around for a long time if given good garden homes.

title: KISSINGER URGES APPROVAL OF 1979 ARMS PACT
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, while praising President Reagan's new approach for reducing strategic nuclear arms, said today negotiating such an agreement would be ''enormously time-consuming.'' Instead he urged taking the interim step of modifying and ratifying the treaty that was signed in 1979 but never approved.

title: Incident in 1980 Vanderbilt Recalls One of Saki's Tales
description: The inimitable short stories of H.H. Munro, generally known as Saki, make occasional references to bridge as it was played early in this century.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK
description: HOW DO TONY AWARD NOMINATORS DECIDE WHO'S A STAR AND WHO ISN'T ? By MEL GUSSOW

title: CITY TO SET UP ISLAND WORK CAMPS TO PUNISH 'LOW LEVEL' OFFENDERS
description: On a patch of Hart Island gone to tall weeds and tumbledown structures, not far from where the penniless and the nameless are buried in potter's field, the Koch administration plans to set up a prison work camp this summer for offenders convicted of what the Mayor calls ''quality-of-life crimes.''

title: LOW-PRICE HOUSING FOR BRITISH SINGLES
description: LONDON FOR some young people in Britain, the problem of finding affordable and comfortable housing may have been solved by two builders here. Each is now offering studio apartments for sale with no down payment for first-time buyers.

title: DANCE PROJECTS GET EXXON'S $60,000
description: The Exxon Corporation has contributed $60,000 to two projects of the American Dance Festival, which will be held from June 18 to July 25 in Durham, N.C. It is believed to be the largest grant made by a corporation to modern dance.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LAST WALTZ IN VIENNA. The Rise and Destruction of a Family, 1842-1942. By George Clare. 272 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.50.

title: Japanese Writer for Times Decorated by Hirohito
description: A Japanese journalist who has worked for The New York Times for 50 years yesterday became the first journalist to be decorated by Emperor Hirohito of Japan.

title: 39 Yugoslavs Are Killed In a Mine Explosion
description: Two methane gas explosions ripped through a coal mine in central Yugoslavia early today, killing 39 men in one of the country's worst mine disasters.

title: TAXING THE RICH: HUNTS VS. I.R.S.
description: Documents filed in the United States Tax Court for cases involving Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Texas billionaire, provide a rare public glimpse into the finances of one of America's most fiercely private and wealthy families.

title: YANKEES ACQUIRE WYNEGAR IN TRADE, BEAT ANGELS BY 6-5
description: The Yankees made their seventh trade in seven weeks when they acquired Butch Wynegar from the Minnesota Twins tonight to replace Rick Cerone as their catcher.

title: MIDTOWN MANHATTAN ZONING: THE BATTLE OVER 'GRANDFATHERING'
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON - Space, according to the experts, is the next battlefield. It will be an arena for laser death rays, orbiting battle stations, and heroic acts. Yet the vision holds a flaw, one carefully brushed aside by those in the defense industry and the military who are pushing for exotic new arsenals. The weapons could be knocked out of action by a single nuclear blast in outer space.
description: Such a blast would instantly set up an electric pulse of up to a million volts in hundreds of satellites and battle stations, zapping their solid-state circuits, and replacing the Pentagon's heady vision of valor in space with the dreary reality of a nuclear junkyard.

title: 151 Nationalists Set Free by China
description: China released 151 former Kuomintang prisoners today, 33 years after the end of the civil war that brought the Communists to power, the New China News Agency reported.

title: Seven Airmen Feared Dead
description: A C-130 transport plane from Little Rock Air Force Base exploded and crashed near this east-central Arkansas town tonight, officials said, apparently killing all seven aboard. Cpl.

title: RICHMOND FACES AN INQUIRY BY HOUSE ETHICS COMMITTEE
description: The House ethics committee announced yesterday that it had voted to conduct a ''preliminary inquiry'' into ''public allegations against Representative Frederick W. Richmond.''

title: Guayana Reports Incursion By Soldiers From Venezuela
description: Guyana formally protested today what it said was an incursion into its territory by Venezuelan troops at a remote jungle border post.

title: BRAZILIAN AIDE SPEAKS OF SHIFT TO CONCERN FOR ENVIRONMENT
description: One of the surprises at the second United Nations conference on the environment is that developing nations such as Brazil now favor environmental activism.

title: MUSTO'S OUSTER FROM OFFICE DELAYED BY JUDGE IN JERSEY
description: A judge today delayed ordering the removal from office of Mayor William V. Musto of Union City, who was reelected Tuesday - a day after being sentenced to seven years in prison on Federal racketeering charges.

title: SOAP SPRAY CLEARED TO FIGHT CROP PESTS
description: An insecticidal soap spray has been cleared by the Environmental Protection Agency for use on edible crops. This means nuisance pests such as white fly on tomatoes, leaf hoppers on beans and squash bugs on cucumbers, melons and squash can be controlled without any waiting period up to day of harvest.

title: Eleanor Powell Tribute
description: The late Eleanor Powell will be paid a tribute in a program Sunday by the Jerry Ames Tap Dance Company at 7:30 P.M. at Town Hall. The program will include ''Tapper's Waltz,'' a song-and-dance number for two couples dedicated to Miss Powell.

title: GERERAL FOODS NET DROPS 27%
description: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that net income in its fiscal fourth quarter ended April 3 declined 27 percent, to $52.9 million, or $1.07 a share, from $72.5 million, or $1.47 a share, a year earlier.

title: COPING WITH THE ODD SPACES OF THE 80'S
description: Today's available residential spaces in the city - often found in renovated factories and modern high-rises - are smaller and more angular than their older counterparts. Their inadequate storage, tiny kitchens, windowless bathrooms and nonexistent dining space seem almost standard.

title: AMID LEBANON'S TURMOIL, CREATIVITY THRIVES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon IN trying to explain the cultural revival blossoming in Lebanon today, artists here like to refer to the classic line from the ''The Third Man,'' where Orson Welles observes that 30 years of warfare, terror and bloodshed in medieval Italy produced the Renaissance, and 500 years of peace, democracy and brotherly love in Switzerland produced the cuckoo clock.

title: PEACE NEGOTIATIONS AT U.N. SAID TO BE IN 'DELICATE STAGE'
description: British and Argentine diplomats offered no assessment tonight in their negotiations to halt hostilities over the Falkland Islands.

title: WILL THE NATION-STATE DOOM HUMANITY...
description: To the Editor:

title: VOLUME HEAVY
description: The stock market declined slightly yesterday in heavy trading that featured General Motors as the stellar attraction for investors. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range through most of the session, closed off 0.10 point, to 865.77. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored stocks that advanced in price by a 780-to-681 margin.

title: Poetry Award Is Won By Anthony Petrosky
description: Anthony Petrosky has won the 1982 Walt Whitman Award of the American Academy of Poets.

title: FRANCE'S BANKS TOLD TO INVEST
description: The French Government said today that it would require the country's newly nationalized banking industry to invest about $1 billion in the major French companies that the Government took over earlier this year, as part of its controversial plan to stimulate the economy.

title: Total Petroleum
description: Total Petroleum Ltd. said talks were taking place for the possible sale of all or part of its Canadian operations, which have interests in oil and natural gas properties in Ontario, Saskatchewan and offshore Labrador. The talks may result in an increase in the Canadian ownership of those operations, Total said.

title: Gates Learjet Fills Two Executive Posts
description: Bermar S. Stillwell, the former auto racing champion and successful Australian aviation executive known in the business as ''Bib,'' has been elected president of the Gates Learjet Corporation of Wichita, Kan.

title: JAPANESE PRIVATE MUSEUM BLENDS THE NEW AND OLD
description: spring resort, there is a view through trees of a new honey-colored building high on a mountain 1,000 feet above the ocean. This is a $104 million museum and arts center, a sort of Japanese Beaubourg-by-the-Sea.

title: NO BELLS FOR BOUT OR WEDDING
description: The injury to Sugar Ray Leonard's left eye not only forced the abandonment of his welterweight title defense against Roger Stafford tomorrow night, but it also postponed the challenger's marriage and wrecked his financial planning.

title: NEW MUSIC: RON KUILIVA'S ELECTRONICS
description: RON KUIVILA and Nicolas Collins both studied electronic music with Alvin Lucier at Wesleyan University, and they have presented performance pieces, concerts and installations together around the country. This week they are at the Kitchen; Tuesday night was Mr. Kuivila's turn, and last night came Mr. Collins.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, has elected Howard A. Slack a senior vice president.

title: A CEMETERY FOR MILITARY PETS
description: Between the rusted cannon mounts on the rampart walls surrounding Fort Monroe's moat is the military pet graveyard, where hundreds of pets that once belonged to military personnel are buried.

title: MARGE THURMAN
description: Marge Thurman, the chairman of the State Democratic Party, died Tuesday after lapsing into a coma last week. She was 53 years old.

title: Index; International
description: South Africa gets racial power-sharing plan A2 In Sweden, some assumptions come tumbling down A3 Brazil illustrates 3rd-world shift to environmental protection A4 Efforts to resume Palestinian autonomy talks remain stalled A6 Haig, in visit tomorrow, may find Turkish positions firm A9 Iran's forces seen as capable of pushing all the way to border A10 Around the World A11 Soviet-Argentine trade called worrisome A16 British agree they are right, but quiet questions come up A20 Government/Politics Illinois governor faces tough opposition in campaign A22 Mine agency now enforcing rule on breathing devices A22 Los Angeles police chief accused of insulting blacks A24 DelBello and Dyson in New York race for Lieutenant Governor B2 Downey drops out of U.S. Senate race in Connecticut B2 Large tax writeoff places the Attorney General in the spotlight B17 New law requires lawbreakers to help pay court costs D27 Washington Talk Briefing B16 Decision File B16 One Congressman's decision to go back home B16 Consumer agency head shows her independence B16 General Around the Nation A22 Disarmament rally to be staged near U.N., not Central Park B2 Pipe bomb found as police study rash of recent explosions B3 Home Section Home Coping with the odd spaces of the 80's C1

title: Decision File; Sun Vac Maker Asks Recall
description: Sun Vac is a device used in conjunction with an ordinary vacuum cleaner to extract water and other liquids from rugs or floors. However, Sun Hill Industries Inc., the manufacturer, and the Consumer Product Safety Commission have found that the machine sometimes sucks up too much water, causing the vacuum's electric motor to get wet.

title: CONGRESS ASSUMES CURB ON MONEY WILL LOOSEN
description: The budget committees in both the Senate and the House of Representatives have based the forecasts underlying their proposed 1983 budgets on the assumption that the Federal Reserve Board will significantly ease its monetary policy, producing relatively strong growth in the economy in 1983 and 1984 that would help to lower budget deficits.

title: RISE OF $6 BILLION IN CURRENT BUDGET IS VOTED BY HOUSE
description: As a parade of lawmakers bemoaned the stagnant economy, the House of Representatives approved a supplemental spending bill that adds almost $6 billion to this year's budget.

title: Koch, North of City Line, Tries to Get His Bearings
description: Ever since he used a series of wisecracks in an interview with Playboy magazine to express a city slicker's disdain for the rural populace, Mayor Koch, a candidate for governor, has taken pains to travel outside New York City.

title: Lilco to Recheck Shoreham Plant
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today it had agreed to Suffolk County's demand for an independent inspection of all 32 safety systems in the utility's partly completed Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: Hong Kong Financier May Get Merrill Stake
description: On Sept. 25, 1980, when Fung King Hey was in New York on a business trip, Manhattan' Borough President, Andrew J. Stein, saw fit to proclaim ''Fung King Hey Day,'' characterizing Mr. Fung's financial conglomerate as ''the Merrill Lynch of Hong Kong.''

title: Advertising; 'Upscale' Magazine Flourishes
description: THE old tagline ''. . . and the rich get richer'' is an appropriate description these days for Hearst Magazines' Town & Country, the grande dame of American magazines.

title: HINCKLEY'S FATHER TELLS THE COURT, 'I AM THE CAUSE OF JOHN'S TRAGEDY'
description: The father of the man who shot President Reagan testified this morning, in a voice laden with emotion, ''I am the cause of John's tragedy'' and ''I wish to God that I could trade places with him right now.''

title: U.S. QUESTIONS PRACTICALITY OF ANTI-COMMUNIST BILL
description: An official of the Justice Department hesitated today to give unqualified support to legislation that would require citizens of Communist nations to give written notice before they attended a public hearing of Congress, requested copies of a non-secret Congressional document or attempted to speak with a member of Congress or a Congressional employee.

title: 9 IN JERSEY RACE FOR U.S. SENATE ADDRESS ELDERLY
description: Democrats with different political styles delivered the same political message today as the primary campaign in New Jersey's race for the United States Senate came to the state's largest city and county.

title: NATHAN BAKER
description: Nathan Baker, senior partner of the law firm of Baker, Garber, Duffy & Baker of New York City and Hoboken, N.J., died last Thursday at Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Artificial Heart Sustains Patient for 42 Hours
description: Doctors said today that an artificial heart had sustained normal bodily functions for 42 hours in a patient considered brain dead.

title: MARCH 25 LANDING ON ISLE REPORTED
description: Argentine commandos landed on the South Atlantic island of South Georgia a week before the invasion of the Falkland Islands, according to three French sailors who were witnesses.

title: Lower Republic Payout
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said today that it had halved its quarterly dividend, to 25 cents a share, payable June 21 to shareholders of record May 28. The company said that the reduction reflected its loss in the first quarter and the continued low level of steel demand.

title: OFFICIAL FACING INQUIRY ON EFFORTS FOR EX-CLIENT
description: James L. Malone, the chief Law of the Sea negotiator for the United States, lobbied in behalf of a former client seeking an $850 million loan from the Export-Import Bank, according to officials of the bank and the State Department.

title: U.S. May Ask Steel Penalties
description: The Government will press for retroactive penalties if its investigators find that foreign steel exporters are guilty of unfair trade practices.

title: News Analysis
description: Despite Sunday's air strike by Israeli planes against Palestinian guerrilla bases in Lebanon, and the subsequent Palestinian shelling of northern Israel, the nine-monthold cease-fire in southern Lebanon still seems to be in effect -for the time being.

title: GUATEMALANS SEIZE AN ENVOY
description: About 20 people took Brazil's Ambassador and seven other people hostage in the embassy here today in a protest against what they said was repression by Guatemala's military Government.

title: People
description: * Burt Blum, executive vice president, has been named head art director, and Melisse Shapiro, senior vice president, copy chief, at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson Inc.

title: Greenpeace Ship to Russia
description: A vessel equipped with antinuclear banners and balloons left Amsterdam today bound for Leningrad, a spokesman for the Greenpeace environmental organization said.

title: COONEY USES RING FOR HIS PLATFORM
description: By 3:15 on a perfect desert afternoon, a line has already formed outside the white nylon tent behind the Canyon Hotel. Blondes in halter tops and men wearing shorts slap $5 bills on a table ($3 for standing room) for a seat to watch Gerry Cooney's 5 o'clock workout.

title: Johnson & Johnson In Deal With Enzo
description: The Johnson & Johnson Company said it had signed a letter of intent with Enzo Biochem Inc., a genetic-engineering company based in New York, to develop and market Enzo's DNA-based diagnostic products.

title: MOLITOR BELTS THREE
description: Hal McRae and Greg Pryor each drove in three runs for the Kansas City Royals tonight in a 9-7 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers. Paul Molitor hit three homers and drove in four runs for Milwaukee.

title: Rob Williams Goes Pro
description: Rob Williams, the star guard at the University of Houston, said yesterday that he would forgo his senior season to become eligible for next month's pro basketball draft. Williams, at a news conference, acknowledged that his decision was something of a gamble, since his value had likely declined as a result of an 0-for-8 shooting performance in a national championship semifinal against North Carolina two months ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press published Monday, on the use of amniocentesis to test for sickle cell anemia, incorrectly stated the risk of spontaneous abortion after the procedure. The risk is less than 1 percent.

title: Two Men Are Shot to Death In Separate Attacks in Ulster
description: A Protestant and a Roman Catholic were shot to death in separate attacks in Northern Ireland today, the police said.

title: QUESTIONS
description: ON-TEES, England, May 11 - All up and down Britain, the white and pink apple blossoms are giving way, leaving green leaves behind, and the front-porch herbaceous borders, in one of the few publicly sanctioned forms of English licentiousness, are putting forth wild tangles of blues, reds and yellows.

title: A.& P. Accord In Philadelphia
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company plans to reopen ''a large number'' of its closed supermarkets in the Philadelphia area by the end of the year under a tentative agreement with union members that would lead to employee ownership of some of the stores, a union official said today.

title: MACCHIAROLA CALLS SCHOOL BUDGET WORST IN 5 YEARS
description: Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola told a crowded meeting of Board of Education members and political representatives yesterday that the proposed budget for 1983 was the ''worst the city public schools have faced'' since Mayor Koch took office five years ago.

title: Ballet Theater Benefit Schedules 2 Premieres
description: Company premieres of ballets by Merce Cunningham and Roland Petit will highlight benefit gala Tueday by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: ABNER M. FRIEDLAND
description: Abner M. Friedland, founder and chairman of Harper Industries Inc., New York City apparel manufacturers, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 67 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: Foote, Cone Gains
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications yesterday reported its results for the first quarter ended March 31. Net income rose 1.5 percent, to $1.38 million, or 50 cents a share, from $1.36 million, or 49 cents, a year ago. Revenues for the quarter increased 6.3 percent, to $40.3 million, from $38.4 million in 1981.

title: STUDIES FIND SEXUAL ABUSE OF CHILDREN IS WIDESPREAD
description: NEW research on child molestation shows that individual offenders are responsible for abusing unexpectedly large numbers of children, and that child molestation is more widespread and a more violent crime than was formerly supposed.

title: U.S. Gypsum
description: The United States Gypsum Company began a temporary freeze on salaries last month and recommended that no bonus or incentive payments be made this year, Graham J. Morgan, chairman, told the annual meeting here. He said that bonus or incentive payments would be made after earnings equaled or exceeded the $2.40 annual dividend paid to holders of common shares.

title: Polish Farmers Rally To Urge Union's Revival
description: Ignoring hundreds of riot policemen, 3,000 Polish farmers prayed and sang today at a mass marking the first birthday of their Rural Solidarity union, now banned under martial law.

title: Cleaner Coal, Gentler Rain
description: ''I don't want to stop acid rain because 99.9 percent of all rain is of an acid nature.'' Thus does James Edwards, the Secretary of Energy, carry simplification close to the point of simplemindedness. True, even pure rain is mildly acid. The problem, however, is that the rain over much of the Northeast, including New York State, is 20 times more acid than that.

title: Collins and Bibby Hired
description: Doug Collins and Henry Bibby, former pro basketball stars, were named to Arizona State's staff by Bob Weinhauer, the head coach. Collins, 30 years old, assisted Weinhauer at Pennsylvania last season. Bibby, 32, was a player-coach last season for the Lancaster Lightning, champion of the Continental Basketball Association.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLEAN SLEIGHT

title: Cuts in Student Grants Draw Capital Protests
description: Higher education groups met on Capitol Hill today to challenge the spending plan recommended by the Senate Budget Committee last week and to urge passage of a ''socially just'' budget plan.

title: 2 ENTER RACE FOR LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR
description: Alfred B. DelBello and John S. Dyson both said yesterday that they would seek the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor of New York State.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: How Appraisers Work
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I wish to correct some misconceptions your readers might have about the American Society of Appraisers (''Protecting Your Possessions With a Professional Appraisal,'' March 18).

title: Steelworkers March To Appeal for Help
description: About 2,000 steelworkers affected by mill cutbacks and closings marched today to make a public appeal for help.

title: Four-A's Meet At Greenbrier
description: The top executives of the nation's advertising community began converging today on the Greenbrier Hotel here for the 64th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: POTVIN SAYS SERIES WILL GET ROUGHER
description: The second game of the Stanley Cup final was still in its scoreless stage after 14 1/2 minutes Tuesday night when Denis Potvin, the Islanders' captain, was called for his second consecutive penalty. Potvin threw his stick high in the air in disgust and glared in disbelief at Referee Ron Wicks.

title: REATION IS MIXED ON BILLY GRAHAM
description: Reaction in the United States was generally mild to comments made by the Rev. Billy Graham at a Moscow news conference yesterday about the status of religion in the Soviet Union.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN one of the sashes of a double-hung window (the type that slides up and down) refuses to stay put, the trouble is almost always a broken sash cord or a weak tubular balance of the kind used in more modern construction instead of sash cords and weights.

title: ...OR WILL HUMANITY DOOM THE NATION-STATE?
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW JONES SUIT IS DISMISSED
description: A Federal Court judge today dismissed a Dow Jones & Company suit seeking to block the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's approval of a proposal by the Chicago Board of Trade to trade futures contracts based on stocks in various Dow Jones averages.

title: Payment to Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had received the final payment from the sale of its Australian and New Zealand magazine operations.

title: Wesleyan Students Protest Aid Policy
description: Twenty-two students began a sit-in in administration offices at Wesleyan University today, demanding that the university reinstate a policy of admitting students without regard to financial need.

title: Threat Against Israel In Health Agency Ended
description: Arab and other Moslem and Communist countries withdrew a threat today to have Israel boycotted by the World Health Organization after the United States warned it would walk out if they pressed their move.

title: Interest Rates Move Ahead; Rise in Retail Sales a Factor
description: Interest rates rose yesterday as traders were discouraged by new economic data indicating a stronger than expected economy and high financing costs.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 13, 1982; Companies
description: Braniff began the suspension of all its flights and urged passengers with reservations to make other plans. The move was seen as a possible prelude to bankruptcy. Braniff, among the top 10 trunk carriers, told its 9,500 employees not to report to work today unless they were notified specifically to do so. (Page A1.) Braniff's major expansion in the late 1970's, led by Harding L. Lawrence, its chairman, severely strained the carrier's finances. (D6.)

title: 2 ARGENTINE JETS DOWNED IN ATTACK OFF THE FALKLANDS
description: Two Argentine A-4 Skyhawk attack planes were shot down today when they attacked a Royal Navy warship off the Falkland Islands, the Ministry of Defense announced tonight.

title: Julian Hemphill, an Executive Of the Hershey Chocolate Co.
description: Julian Hemphill, former director of purchases and a director of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation and past president of the New York Cocoa Exchange, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Editor Stepping Down
description: When Peter C. Newman took over as editor of Maclean's magazine 12 years ago, the venerable Canadian periodical was a monthly with a circulation of 640,000.

title: Caldwell Sees Profit for Ford
description: Philip Caldwell, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, told shareholders at today's annual meeting that he expected the No.2 United States auto maker to turn a profit, but he stopped short of saying when.

title: SEEING FOR OURSELVES
description: Viktor Pavlovich Karpov and his Kremlin colleagues are now at work drafting a reply for Mr. Brezhnev to Mr. Reagan's letter proposing a beginning to serious arms reductions. They had to wait for the American President's speech at Eureka College for a few more details, and for the follow-up press conference; now the time is ripe for an answering letter from the Russians.

title: WHITNEY MARTIN
description: Whitney Martin, a former sports columnist for The Associated Press, died May 5 at Greenwich Hospital.

title: Horowitz 'Retinue'
description: In London for his first European concerts in 31 years, Vladimir Horowitz said yesterday that he had brought along his his constant companions, his own American-made Steinway grand and his own piano tuner.

title: TOTAL OIL PRESIDENT TAKES A WIDER ROLE
description: Philippe Dunoyer, president and chief executive officer of Total Oil (North America) Ltd., was given the additional post yesterday of chairman. Mr. Dunoyer, who is 52, will replace Linden J. Richards, who is 73. Mr. Richards, who had asked not to stand for re-election, will continue as a board member and consultant.

title: CANUCK FAN'S OFFER AMOUNTS TO NOTHING
description: Murray Goldman, a prominent clothier, is putting his discounts where he says his heart is: On the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Comex Denied S.& P. Index
description: The Commodity Exchange has been temporarily barred by a Federal judge from trading futures contracts based on Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks.

title: ARTISTS FLOCK TO GREENE STREET'S WBGO JAZZATHON
description: MORE than 50 of this county's most outstanding jazz musicians - among them Dexter Gordon, Dakota Staton, Arthur Blythe, Tal Farlow, Woody Shaw, Lou Donaldson and Chico Freeman - are going to be performing Sunday at Greene Street, the nightclub and restaurant at 101 Greene Street in SoHo. And they aren't getting paid.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP 20.6%
description: The Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that sale rose a substantial 20.6 percent in early May, renewing hopes for a successful spring selling season.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT CANUCKS, 3-0, AND LEAD SERIES, 3-0
description: The combination of Billy Smith's peerless goaltending and goals by Clark Gillies, Mike Bossy and Bob Nystrom gave the Islanders a 3-0 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight at Pacific Coliseum and a 3-0 lead in their Stanley Cup championship series.

title: Grey Obtains New Accounts
description: Grey Advertising has received additional assignments from two existing clients. International Playtex has awarded the agency the domestic business of its Danskin Inc. subsidiary, the world's largest manufacturer of dancewear.

title: MUSIC: POMERIUM MUSICES
description: THE name of the group, Pomerium Musices, is off-putting, and a program title that reads ''Heinrich Isaac: Musical Wizard of the Renaissance'' hardly sets the pulse racing, but the concert Wednesday involving the two at the Abraham Goodman House was delectable indeed. In addition to music by Isaac (1450-1517), however, there were works by several of his contemporaries - Josquin Desprez among them.

title: A.M.C.'S HOPES FOR A NEW CAR
description: Inside turn-of-the-century buildings that once produced mattresses and bicycles, the American Motors Corporation is preparing for what is probably its last effort to remain a volume manufacturer of passenger cars.

title: THROUGH THE FENCE
description: What is going on outside the White House? It isn't the start of executive aerobics, or the 1984 campaign, or a sweep for leftover Easter eggs, or a search for holes in the safety net.

title: Economic Scene; Tight Money, Loose Money
description: THE essence of the Reagan Administration's economic approach is a combination of a loose fiscal policy, marked by big tax cuts and big budget deficits, and a tight monetary policy, with the White House and the Treasury providing strong encouragement to the Federal Reserve System to bring down the rate of growth of the money supply.

title: PENTHOUSE MAGAZINE CLEARED OF LIBELING A RESORT
description: Penthouse magazine and its publisher, Robert Guccione, were exonerated today in a $522 million libel suit brought against them by La Costa, a southern Californian resort and health spa.

title: EXPANSION AT AIRPORTS APPROVED
description: The Port Authority, in the first step of what is expected to be a 15-year, $600 million improvement program for the New York area's major airports, yesterday approved the construction of new cargo buildings at Kennedy and Newark International Airports.

title: CHORUS TO SING CRETE'S LOVE EPIC
description: Not every work starts out with its composer vacationing on Crete, haunted by the countryside and a hymn he remembers from his childhood, experiencing a full-scale attack of deja vu. Nor do many works receive fortuitous assistance from a Greek sea captain.

title: LINKAGE 7-5 CHOICE IN 8-HORSE PREAKNESS
description: Seven colts and a filly were entered this morning for the 107th Preakness Stakes Saturday. To no one's surprise, the Kentucky Derby winner, Gato del Sol, was not among them.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE romance of Kristi Witker, the Channel 11 news reporter, and Richard Coons, an investment banker, wasn't all smooth sailing, butJ oanne Cummings, one of their friends, never had any doubts. She was c onvinced that love would conquer all and when it did, she said, she w as going to give the couple a dinner party.

title: JOHN LOCKE ET AL., AND THE LAW OF THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Killed in Jordan Storm
description: Seven people were killed in a severe storm that pounded Jordan's capital for six hours. Authorities said today that at least 12 others were seriously injured or missing in the storm Wednesday. The police, civil defense units and army helicopters rescued hundreds of people left homeless by flash floods.

title: PLOWING OF PLAINS IN THE WEST STIRS FEAR OF NEW DUST BOWL
description: It has been dry on the high plains of eastern Colorado this spring, as dry as it has been in years. And when the winds come, turning the sky dark with dust and burying fence rows under shifting dunes of soil and thistle, those who are old enough remember the bleak days of the Dust Bowl, nearly 50 years ago.

title: Sports of The Times; Linesman Betty
description: BEVERLY McPHERSON was sitting in the stands watching the officials trot out before a North American Soccer League game Wednesday night. Suddenly she leaped to her feet and pointed at Official No.84 and started clapping her hands.

title: 2 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS SENT TOWARD STATION IN ORBIT
description: The Soviet Union sent two astronauts into space yesterday with plans to board Salyut 7, the new space station that was orbited last month, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: MAJOR U.S. AIRLINES ARE FACING A SEVERE FINANCIAL SQUEEZE
description: The major airlines, as underscored by Braniff International's decision to file for bankruptcy, are experiencing one of the worst financial squeezes in the history of the industry.

title: DEATH KNELL FOR MX?
description: President Reagan's new strategic arms proposals - if seriously considered by both sides - probably sound the death knell for the big multiple-warheaded MX missile.

title: TIRES WILL BRING BACK THE BASS BACK TO WESTWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Shot at the Siberia Pipeline
description: Despite vigorous opposition from the Reagan Administration, Western Europe is determined to buy tens of billions of dollars worth of natural gas from the Soviet Union. Yet the security issues properly raised by Mr. Reagan have not been resolved. That leaves only one last chance to minimize Europe's dependence on Soviet energy: trade American cooperation in constructing the natural gas pipeline for allied measures that reduce the risks of Soviet blackmail.

title: FASHIONS AID BOND DRIVE
description: ''We've never worn mother-daughter clothes before,'' Susan Strasberg said, just before going down the runway of the Imperial Ballroom at the Sheraton Centre with her daughter, Jennifer, 16 years old. ''Stand up straight,'' the actress told her daughter. ''You'll look taller.''

title: ACTION BY HARLEM GATEWAY TENANTS: A SUCCESS STORY
description: Despite signs of urban blight, the so-called Harlem Gateway - that section of the predominantly black Manhattan enclave from 110th Street to 113th Street between Madison Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard -contains evidence that some of its residents are trying to improve their surroundings.

title: Beatcha Takes 2d Leg Of World Cup Pacing
description: Beatcha raced to a world record for a mile and a half tonight as San Simeon, the highly touted horse from Australia, again finished sixth in the World Cup Pacing championship at the Meadowlands.

title: STOP BUFFETING JAPAN
description: Ame ricans, official or private, who express public displeasure over Japanese trade and security conduct should realize that their constant nagging at Tokyo may incite nationalistic, anti-American resentment there. The issues are: Is American nagging really fair to Japan? Is it constructive for the partnership?

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O.  To Meet in City
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. will switch its summer executive council meeting from Chicago to New York City this year, breaking a 10-year span of meeting in the Middle Western city, a federation spokesman said Wednesday.

title: APRIL BERRY STANDS OUT FROM THE CROWD
description: Tall, lean and a little languid, April Berry suggests a swan, stretching its wings beside some ballet lake. Her profile is as aristocratic as that of any stage princess. But Miss Berry won't be dancing swans or princesses this weekend when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater performs at City Center. Instead, she'll be making her New York debut tonight as ''the ditsy, wealthy'' Fontessa, as she describes the heroine of Louis Johnson's ''Fontessa and Friends.''

title: A GROUP FOR THOSE WHO HATE DINING ALONE
description: ''It took some courage for me to come here, but when you dine out alone, you're made to feel like Stella Dallas,'' Harriet Goldhammer, who works at Fortunoff's, confided. ''But maybe this is the answer to having a festive dinner and not being alone.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Kirkpatrick Criticism

title: ALEX WHITTAKER BURGER
description: Alex Whittaker Burger, a fund-raiser for New York hospitals and philanthropic organizations, died last Friday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. Mr. Burger, a resident of New Rochelle, was 79 years old.

title: Lionel Creditors
description: A creditors' committee was appointed for the Lionel Corporation, which has filed for bankruptcy protection, according to Michael J. Scharf, the major shareholder and commmittee chairman. The creditors include the Girard Bank, owed about $6.7 million; Atari Inc. ($5.5 million); Parker Brothers ($3.2 million), and the Milton Bradley Company ($3 million).

title: END OF TORTURE IN NICARAGUA SEEN
description: The torture of prisoners such as has been ''routinely practiced'' in some Latin American countries has been ''effectively eliminated'' in Nicaragua, according to a report on human rights in Nicaragua by the Americas Watch Committee.

title: Musto Is Suing To Keep His Posts
description: Attorneys for Mayor William V. Musto of Union City, who is also a State Senator and who was re-elected a Union City Commissioner Tuesday, filed suit today challenging the constitutionality of a state statute that bars a felon from holding public office.

title: REIBL, VIOLIST, WINS NAUMBURG PRIZE
description: Thomas Reibl has been named the winner of the Naumburg International Viola Competition.

title: POP JAZZ
description: WHEN Bob Crosby gives the downbeat tonight at Roseland, where his orchestra will start a series of four Friday nights of big-band appearances (Larry Elgart's Orchestra will be there next Friday, followed by Harry James, then the Jimmy Dorsey Orchestra directed by Lee Castle), it will be the 47th anniversary of the band leader's debut, which took place at Roseland.

title: DANCE: AILEY WOMEN HAVE THE BEST OF IT THESE DAYS
description: A profile of another of the Ailey new women appears on page C13. BY ANNA KISSELGOFF

title: News Analysis
description: The disclosure that Attorney General William French Smith personally invested in an oil and gas partnership that would give him $4 of tax write-offs for every dollar he put in last year seems likely to rekindle the longstanding debate over the use of tax shelters by high-income taxpayers.

title: Executives Resign Posts at Datapoint
description: The Datapoint Corporation of San Antonio said yesterday that Richard E. Palermo had resigned as executive vice president and from the company's board, but would stay on as a staff vice president. In addition five vice presidents resigned from the company's domestic marketing organization.

title: L.S.U. Dismisses Three
description: Chancellor James Wharton of Louisiana State University dismissed three members of the athletic department today and said five more members could face disciplinary action for financial mismanagement.

title: Advertising; Four-A's Praised At Meeting
description: The new activist American Association of Advertising Agencies won praise today from a representative of a longtime advisory organization, the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Air Force Band Concert
description: A musical tribute to Armed Forces Week will be presented by the Air Force Band of the East from New Jersey's McGuire Air Force Base today at 12:30 P.M. in the lower plaza of the McGraw-Hill Building in Rockefeller Center, Avenue of the Americas and 49th Street. The concert is free and will be canceled if it rains.

title: L.I. WOMAN SENTENCED TO COMMUNITY SERVICE WORK FOR ETHNIC SLUR
description: The first person convicted under a new state law prohibiting harassment with ethnic or racial slurs was sentenced today to 35 hours of community service for using an anti-Semitic obscenity against a neighbor.

title: White Sox 13, Brewers 2
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Lamarr Hoyt, backed by a 20-hit attack including home runs by Greg Luzinski and Ron LeFlore, became the major league's first seven-game winner.

title: 'MARCO POLO,' 'PAIK ON THE AIR,' A.C.L.U. FOUNDER
description: FROM ''Roots'' to ''Shogun'' to ''Masada,'' the spectacular is an entrenched part of the television scene. Now, beginning Sunday evening at 8 on NBC, there is ''Marco Polo,'' brought to you by many of the same people associated with ''Jesus of Nazareth'' a couple of years ago.

title: JAZZ FUSION: GLASS MENAGERIE
description: of-the-road jazz fusion that touched a number of stylistic bases. Given the quartet's relatively modest ambitions - to divert rather than exalt - the concert was a partial success.

title: Injured Football Player Is Awarded $3.5 Million
description: A Federal Court jury has awarded $3.5 million in damages to DeMott Davis, a former high school football player whose neck was broken during a game 12 years ago.

title: JAPAN'S E.R.A. IMPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Not Following John Hinckley's Trial
description: President Reagan said last night that he had not been following the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. ''an awful lot.''

title: RENAISSANCE OF PUPPET SHOWS FOR GROWN-UPS
description: PUPPET shows for adults are hardly new; they date back to antiquity, when nobody distinguished between entertainment for young and old. But they have been undergoing a renaissance in recent years in this country and Europe. And this weekend in New York, they will abound.

title: WHAT TAX CUTS?
description: Most of the argument about the Federal budget has centered on the sanctity (or, on the other side, the fairness) of the tax cuts enacted last summer. It hasn't been a very fruitful argument, partly because the premises are fake. Whichever side wins, there isn't going to be a real tax cut - not for anyone who expects to earn taxable income in the future. In fact, the coming ''tax cuts'' don't do anything for the rich taxpayer that he couldn't do for himself.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday as investors and traders tried to reconcile the hope that rates might soon fall with the fear that rates could rise when Treasury borrowings increase in 1982's second half.

title: ART: MALLARME POEMS INSPIRE GLASS SCULPTURE
description: THE French symbolist, Stephane Mallarme (1842-98), is not the most accessible of poets, believing as he did that language shouldn't reveal, but veil. A friend of artists, he tried to get a number of them to illustrate his cryptic texts. Most confessed their bafflement; Manet and - much later - Matisse were among the few who succeeded. Now Christopher Wilmarth, a sculptor known for his austere, Minimal creations of steel and etched glass, has dauntlessly taken up the challenge. Inspired by the translations of the American poet Frederick Morgan, Mr. Wilmarth has responded wholeheartedly, producing not only a series of sculptures, but etchings, drawings and paintings that deal with the themes of seven Mallarme poems.

title: BRANIFF TICKET VALID ON SEVERAL AIRLINES
description: The major airlines that share Braniff International's domestic routes said yesterday that they had been able to accommodate most passengers holding Braniff reservations, and that they anticipated no problems in continuing to do so.

title: Foreclosure and Humor
description: The fact that Dick Gregory's home is under foreclosure procedures because he is in arrears on a $97,700 mortgage gave the comedian a cue for a joke yesterday.

title: RISE IN MILITARY BUDGET HELD NEAR PRESIDENT'S MINIMUM
description: A senior Defense Department official said today that the increase in military spending would be reduced to 7.2 percent under a Senate budget proposal endorsed by President Reagan. That would bring military spending down to a figure barely above the level the Administration has said is needed to restore the nation's military strength.

title: OPENING STATEMENT
description: Good evening. I have a statement to read. Four times in my life, I have seen Americans plunged into war -twice as part of tragic global conflicts that cost the lives of millions. Living through that experience has convinced me that America's highest mission is to stand as a leader among the free nations in the cause of peace. And that's why, hand in hand with our efforts to restore a credible national defense, my Administration has been actively working for a reduction in nuclear and conventional forces that can help free the world from the threat of destruction.

title: COSMOS RE-SIGN HUNT
description: The Cosmos have purchased Steve Hunt, one of their best and most popular players in the championship years of 1977 and 1978, from Coventry City of the English First Division.

title: METS WIN WITH 13 SINGLES, 4-2
description: Pete Falcone last night fell two outs short of achieving the third consecutive complete-game victory for the Mets at Shea Stadium. Instead, the Brooklyn-born left-hander needed a save from Neil Allen for the 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers that gave the Mets their fourth consecutive triumph and the Dodgers their fourth consecutive defeat.

title: Funds' Assets Reach Record
description: Assets of the nation's 200 money market funds rose $2.15 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to a record $194.07 billion, the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade organization, reported yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: DETROIT (AL) - Reactivated Aurelio Lopez, pitcher, from disabled list. Optioned Marty Castillo, catcher-third baseman, to Evansville of the American Association. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Placed Dave Parker, right fielder, on 15-day disabled list with torn cartilage in his right wrist.

title: 5 Are Hospitalized; Iced Tea Suspected
description: Five patrons of Bally's Park Place Casino-Hotel were hospitalized late Wednesday after drinking iced tea that may have been mixed with an iodine-based kitchen disinfectant, casino officials said.

title: AUCTIONS
description: BROWSERS and buyers alike may feast this weekend on art by such giants as Matisse, Monet, Rodin, Cezanne, Henry Moore, Turner, Renoir, Picasso and Brancusi - without ever going near a museum.

title: F
description: OR more than 25 years, Horace Silver has led a quintet that, despite changing personnel, has maintained a remarkable consistency. The instrumentation has remained the same - trumpet, tenor saxophone, piano, bass and drums.

title: Requiem for an Airline
description: ''It's hard to fathom,'' said a Braniff pilot on learning that his company had suspended operations. ''You can chalk this one up to deregulation.'' Others point to the airline's creditors, who were unwilling to add to Braniff's $733 million debt. Still others blame American Airlines, which fought hard to grab a faltering carrier's customers.

title: Apple Computer Is Suing Franklin
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it had filed suit against the Franklin Computer Corporation of Pennsauken, N.J., accusing it of patent and copyright infringement, unfair competition and misappropriation.

title: JAZZ: THE SUPRISING ARVEL SHAW TRIO
description: tinged background music.

title: BORN TO THE DIPLOMATIC LIFE
description: Sir Anthony Parsons is one of those British diplomats who seem disheveled and a bit distracted. His hair is seldom under control, his shirttail has a tendency to escape from his trousers and he moves with a kind of disjointed energy. There is something happy-go-lucky, cheerful, schoolboyish about him.

title: U.S. WILLING TO REVIVE ISRAELI ACCORD
description: President Reagan indicated tonight that he was eager to revive the agreement of strategic cooperation with Israel that he suspended in December after Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: STAFF, PASSENGERS AND DALLAS SHARE BURDEN OF BRANIFF'S FALL
description: For its employees, its passengers and the airports that its gaily colored planes stopped at, it all began to sink in yesterday. Braniff was not going to fly anymore.

title: SONG: VICTORIA DE LOS ANGLES GIVES 3d PRE-BAROQUE RECITAL
description: EVERY nine years, it seems, Victoria de los Angeles takes it upon herself to sing a recital of pre-Baroque Spanish music at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; she did it first in 1964, and then again in 1973, and yet again Wednesday night in the museum's medieval court.

title: BRITAIN'S PREMIER FIRM ON FALKLANDS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told an anxious House of Commons today that she sought ''a peaceful solution, not a peaceful sellout'' in the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY FUNDS: A 'NEW' POLITICAL ISSUE
description: With startling abruptness, Congress finds itself embroiled in debate over an apparently arcane fiscal issue that Democrats and Republicans alike regard as politically explosive. It is whether to remove Social Security from the Federal budget, reversing a consolidation made 13 years ago in the name of rationality.

title: BALLET: SPOTLIGHT ON DRAMA
description: THE American Ballet Theater has long emphasized dramatic ballets, and dance-dramas were much in evidence at the company's Wednesday performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: BALMY WEATHER HEATS UP DEBATE ABOUT PUBLIC ACCESS TO MIDTOWN PLAZAS
description: Spring has transformed the city's places in the sun. From the humblest bus-stop bench to the rocky slabs of Central Park, winter-tense bodies relax under the warmth while pale faces tilt up, begging a touch of sun.

title: New I.B.M. Copier
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced an advanced version of its I.B.M. Series III copier, which it said offers optional automatic paper feed and reduction capability and can be upgraded in the customer's office.

title: Tournament Delayed
description: The Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey regional baseball tournament, scheduled to open yesterday at St. John's University, was postponed a day because of wet grounds. St. John's (18-13) will face New York Tech (20-11) in the first game of a doubleheader today at noon, followed by Seton Hall (36-11) against Long Island University (17-12).

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINION ON COURT ROTATION PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from an opinion issued yesterday by the New York State Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, on Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke's plan to rotate judges in New York City:

title: No Headline
description: These are the most popular albums and singles, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by sales and radio air play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 12Asia* Asia 22Chariots of Fire Vangelis 33Beauty & the Beat Go-Go's 44Success Hasn't Spoiled Rick Springfield 5 5I Love Rock 'n' Roll Joan Jett & Blackhearts 66Freeze-Frame J. Geils Band 724Diver Down* Van Halen 87Get Lucky Loverboy 99Always on My Mind Willie Nelson 1010Aldo Nova* Aldo Nova Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 12Ebony & Ivory* McCartney & Wonder 21Chariots of Fire Vangelis 34Don't Talk to Strangers Rick Springfield 43I Love Rock 'n' Roll Joan Jett & Blackhearts 5 6867-5309/Jenny* Tommy Tutone 69I've Never Been to Me* Charlene 78'65 Love Affair* Paul Davis 85Freeze-Frame J. Geils Band 913The Other Woman* Ray Parker Jr. 1010Did It in a Minute Hall & Oates Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: QUEENS DEMOCRAT IS TALKED OF AS A 'COMER' IN THE PARTY
description: Outside the office of Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, Democrat of Queens, hangs one of her campaign posters, displayed so that visitors can't miss it. The punch line reads, ''Finally, a tough Democrat.''

title: Bridge: The Von Zedtwitz Grinds Painfully Closer to Its End
description: An event that is one of the toughest - and certainly the slowest - in the New York calendar is the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship. It began six months ago, and four teams, led by John Lowenthal, Peter Leventritt, Drew Casen and Michael Rosmarin, have now reached the semifinals.

title: JOHN LOCKE, ET AL., AND THE LAW OF THE SEA
description: To the Editor: Notwithstanding Mr. Safire's comments, during the Law of the Sea Conference the Reagan Administration strongly supported the concepts of the common heritage of mankind and of the ''parallel system'' of exploitation, under which half the deep-seabed mining would be done by national operators and half by an intergovernmental corporation.

title: State Banking Chief To Seek Senate Seat
description: Muriel Siebert, the New York Superintendent of Banking, announced yesterday that she would resign soon as the state's highest-ranking woman official to seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by Daniel P. Moynihan, a Democrat.

title: Three Americans Reach World Boxing Finals
description: Three fighters from the United States and three from the Soviet Union advanced today to the final round of the World Amateur Boxing Championships.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: starring in ''Conan the Barbarian,'' which opens today - is a practical man. Not for him the obscure French art film, the romance of the lost masterpiece. He thinks the best movie is the one most people are willing to pay to see. ''I like when they say, 'We made $50 million.' That means a lot of people went to see it.''

title: NATIONAL GALLERY PROMOTION
description: John Wilmerding, the senior curator and the curator of American painting at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, will succeed Charles Parkhurst as assistant director. Mr. Parkhurst, 70 years old, will leave the gallery Jan. 31 to become co-director of the museum at Williams College in Massachusetts.

title: Where's Thompson?
description: There were 104 players on the field at a minicamp for the Washington Redskins yesterday, and Coach Joe Gibbs was very upset that not one of them was the wide receiver Ricky Thompson. Thompson was the lone Redskin veteran who failed to notify the team that he could not attend, Gibbs said, which means that his remaining days in Washington could be few.

title: Quebec Calling a Halt To English Stop Sign
description: The English order ''Stop'' will be removed from stop signs at road junctions in Quebec, leaving only the French word ''Arret,'' the Government has decided.

title: BALBONI, GUIDRY STAR AS YANKS BEAT A's
description: The Yankees won their third straight game tonight when they defeated Billy Martin's Oakland A's, 6-4, in a game marked by Steve Balboni's first home run in the major leagues.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle in some editions last Sunday incor- rectly described the peremptory chal- lenge used in criminal trials. Such a challenge, to strike a prospective juror from a panel, requires no expla- nation by lawyers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chase Manhattan's issue of floating-rate series 3 nonrefundable preferred stock has been priced at $50 a share to yield 14.10 percent initially, and the issue has been increased to 5 million shares from 4 million.

title: The Attorney General's Vision
description: Now that questions of propriety have been raised, Attorney General William French Smith says he will take ''a second look'' at a risky tax shelter investment. We hope it's more sensitive than the first. That one led him to join a limited oil-drilling partnership that seems headed for a fight with the Internal Revenue Service. I.R.S. is one of the Attorney General's big clients. If that isn't a conflict of interest, it's a clash of allegiances, unbecoming to the Government's top lawyer.

title: McCann Is Chosen For Track Campaign
description: There are two things you find a lot of around a race track. One is parimutuel ticket stubs. And McCann-Erickson is going to run an ad to get rid of the other.

title: IDEAL TOY CORP. MOVING QUEENS OFFICES TO JERSEY
description: The Ideal Toy Corporation, which once employed 1,500 workers in Queens, will close its operations there this summer, ending a relationship with New York City that began 79 years ago when the company was founded in a Brooklyn candy store.

title: George C. Scott to star in and direct Coward.
description: GEORGE C. SCOTT will star in Noel Coward's ''Present Laughter'' at Circle in the Square. He will also direct. You do not ordinarily associate Mr. Scott with a play by Mr. Coward, of course; he is an extraordinary actor, but when ''Present Laughter'' was done on Broadway in 1946, Clifton Webb played the male lead. Mr. Coward once played it, too. But could they have played General Patton, say, or Foxwell J. Sly in ''Sly Fox,'' as well? Can Mr. Scott really do everything? In ''Present Laughter,'' he may be appearing opposite Tammy Grimes. She was in ''42d Street'' her last time out, and ''A Month in the Country'' the time before that, and is pretty good at doing everything, too.

title: DANCE: KAZUKO HIRABAYASHI
description: THE Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater has always had good dancers. And Miss Hirabayashi is a poetic choreographer. In recent years, however, her work has tended to be unrelievedly dark in tone, rituals with dancers rooted into the ground Wigman-style and imagery stripped of incidental color in the manner of the starkest forms of Oriental classical dance.

title: WRITERS HAIL REISSUING OF CLASSICS
description: In the Pierpont Morgan Library late Wednesday evening, Eudora Welty, the silver-haired American storyteller, stepped slowly onto a platform before 100 invited guests, including some of the country's most distinguished members of the literary community.

title: EX-JUDGE ON THE WORLD COURT
description: Hardy Cross Dillard, a former judge on the International Court of Justice and dean of the University of Virginia School of Law from 1963 to 1968, died Wednesday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 79 years old.

title: Koch's First Club To Remain Neutral
description: The political club where Mayor Koch began his career, after splitting almost evenly between Mr. Koch and Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, decided last night not to endorse a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Loss Increases At Woolworth
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company reported that its loss in the first quarter widened to $16 million, from a restated loss of $2 million in the first quarter of 1981. The company said that poor sales in the United States, Canada and West Germany, coupled with higher expenses, had hurt its results.
