title: Combustion Equipment Plan
description: Combustion Equipment Associates Inc., which filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws a year and a half ago, said that its board had approved a general plan of reorganization that has received tentative acceptance from its creditors.

title: REAGAN TO WEIGH PLANS TO RESOLVE BUDGET DEADLOCK
description: President Reagan said tonight that he was willing for Congress to consider proposals to remove Social Security from the budget calculations as a means of resolving the impasse over the budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: OTHER AIRLINES SEEKING ITS ROUTES
description: The Braniff International Corporation yesterday filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws, the first major United States airline to do so.

title: Making Waste Vanish
description: This skeptic, who has often noted that a neighbor's grass is less green than he says it is, has not trusted the assertion that cities in West Germany, Britain and Illinois routinely succeed in burning garbage to produce electricity. But a visit to the Chicago Northwest Incinerator has turned him into a true believer.

title: Von Bulow Meets Bond To Retain Freedom
description: An attorney for Claus von Bulow posted $50,000 and a list of assets valued at $1 million today to secure his client's freedom while he appeals his convictions for trying to murder his wife, a court official said.

title: FAIRS STRETCH FROM LINCOLN CENTER TO FOREST HILLS THIS WEEKEND
description: An all-day music festival at Lincoln Center on Sunday and a twoday Renaissance street fair in Queens are among the many outdoor events planned in the metropolitan area this weekend.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co. said it had signed a definitive agreement for its proposed acquisition of Geosource Inc.

title: Dutch Queen Consults With Parties in Crisis
description: Queen Beatrix consulted party leaders on the Dutch political crisis today after the collapse Wednesday night of the country's three-party coalition Government.

title: Morgan's Brazil Offer
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York said yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had approved its plan to acquire half the equity and a one-third voting interest in three Brazilian financial institutions - a bank, a leasing company and a money market securities company -owned by Inter-Atlantico of Brazil.

title: Wickes's Sale of Unit
description: The Wickes Companies today reported the filing of an application with the United States Bankruptcy Court here for authority to sell, as previously announced, the agriculture division to the Pillsbury Company for $45 million.

title: Oasis to Buy Libyan Oil
description: The Oasis Group of oil companies has agreed to resume oil purchases from Libya, Leon Hess, chairman of the Amerada Hess Corporation, told the annual shareholders' meeting here today.

title: East Village Arts
description: Painters, sculptors, actors, playwrights and other artists living in the East Village will display their talents through August in an arts festival at the Middle Collegiate Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street. The festival, called ''Something Old-Something New,'' will feature one-time performances and an exhibition of work by more than 100 artists. Information: 477-0666

title: HARRY W. FRANTZ
description: Harry W. Frantz, a correspondent for the United Press in Washington and Latin America for more than four decades, died April 26 in Ithaca, N.Y., where he had lived after retiring.

title: Canadian Aide Deplores U.S. Policy on Acid Rain
description: The United States policy on acid rain was criticized by Canada here today at the United Nations conference on the global environment.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 14, 1982
description: International U.S. flexibility on nuclear arms talks was stressed by President Reagan. Speaking at a televised news conference, Mr. Reagan said that his proposal to reduce the number of warheads on both Soviet and American ballistic missiles did not mean he was unwilling to discuss other types of nuclear weapons with the Kremlin. (Page A1, Column 1.) Britain seeks ''a peaceful solution, not a peaceful sellout'' in the Falklands dispute, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher assured an uneasy House of Commons. Foreign Secretary Francis Pym warned that ''military incidents'' might accelerate. (A1:2.)

title: Leftists in Guatemala Free Embassy Hostages
description: Leftist protesters who seized the Brazilian Embassy here on Wednesday released their eight hostages, including the Brazilian Ambassador, tonight and were granted safe conduct out of the country, reportedly to Mexico.

title: East Side French, West Side eclectic.
description: AS much as we might want a restaurant owner and staff to treat all customers equally, it is easy to understand why the best tables and warmest greetings go to the regular patrons. Nonetheless, all other treatment should be equal for regulars and newcomers. Just how uncomfortable a meal can be when that is not the policy was made obvious during two dinners at Le Perigord on 54th Street, east of First Avenue.

title: U.S. CITES EVIDENCE ON CHEMICAL WAR
description: The State Department made public today what it called ''conclusive evidence'' that toxins and chemical warfare agents have been used in recent months in Laos and Cambodia.

title: SPECULATION ABOUNDS IN KIDNAPPINGS
description: The Sheraton Hotel, home for most of the 700-member press corps that has descended upon Buenos Aires to cover the conflict in the South Atlantic, has become the center of a different story - one about journalists and anonymous kidnappers.

title: Lehrman Comes Out Against the Westway
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, a candidate for governor of New York, yesterday came out against the Westway. The other declared candidates all favor the road.

title: SMUGGLER PATROL BRAVES MONOTONY ON HIGH SEAS
description: A dead man's ashes in one hand, a slim volume entitled ''Prayers at Sea'' in the other, Lieut. Kurt Wellington of the Coast Guard called from the bridge: ''All hands, bury the dead. All hands, bury the dead.''

title: ANTICRIME PROGRAM A CASUALTY OF FIGHT IN ALBANY OVER BUDGET
description: The dispute over the state budget has cut off funds for more than 190 prosecutors, investigators and aides working in a program to prosecute violent criminals and repeat offenders, the state's district attorneys say.

title: ROBERT H. AUSTIN
description: Robert H. Austin, a vice president of the investment banking concern of Kidder, Peabody & Company, died Wednesday at Norwalk (Conn.)

title: Tornadoes and Floods Strike the Southwest
description: By The Associated Press Tornadoes and torrential rains struck the Southwest yesterday for a third day, and floodwaters drove hundreds of people from their homes in Texas and Oklahoma. One twister killed a Texas woman.

title: THEATER: 'GENIUSES' AN APOCALYPRIC PARODY
description: The director and his crew have spent three months in the Philippine jungle making ''Parabola of Death,'' which is variously described as a movie about the war in Angola and as the director's autobiography. They are 28 days behind schedule on this mega-buck epic and have shot only 10 tiny minutes of film. Sound familiar? Before you say, ''play a clef,'' notice that the director is named Milo McGee McGarr and he is Irish.

title: Western Union Overseas Service
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had filed tariffs with the Federal Communications Commission to extend its telex and certain other record communications services to more than 100 countries.

title: REAGAN WILLING TO BROADEN TALKS ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: President Reagan said tonight that his proposal to reduce the number of nuclear warheads on both Soviet and American ballistic missiles did not mean that he was unwilling to discuss other types of nuclear weapons with the Soviet Union.

title: ROTATING JUDGES IN STATE COURTS IS STRUCK DOWN
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that its own Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke, had violated the State Constitution when he put into effect a plan to rotate the assignment of lower-court judges to the State Supreme Court.

title: NEWEST YANKS NO STRANGERS TO TUMULT
description: Butch Wynegar and Roger Erickson, the newest exiles from the Minnesota Twins, joined the tumultuous family of the New York Yankees today.

title: Alexander Retracts Pay Forfeit, Is Fined
description: Doyle Alexander, the Yankee pitcher who broke a knuckle in anger last week when he punched a dugout wall, withdrew his offer to forfeit one month's salary today and was promptly fined by the management.

title: JOGGERS' HEART ATTACK RISK IS LESS THAN THOUGHT, RHODE ISLAND STUDY SAYS
description: Researchers who studied all deaths among joggers in Rhode Island for six years say the risk of fatal heart attacks is less than had been believed, according to a report being published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: A.& P. Agreement
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company and the United Food and Commercial Workers Union said yesterday that A.& P. would form a new subsidiary that would open 20 to 24 currently closed stores in the Philadelphia area by the end of the year. The subsidiary, Super Fresh Food Centers Inc., will operate under an agreement with the union that will include incentive and investment programs for union members. A.& P., which has been closing hundreds of stores recently in an effort to increase profitability, lost $72.9 million in its fourth quarter, ended Feb.27, far wider more than its year-earlier loss of $4.2 million.

title: ACCIDENTS IN THE HOME
description: ''THE HOUSE WHERE EVIL DWELLS,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, and ''The Nesting,'' which opens today at the Embassy 49th Street and other theaters, are cautionary tales about the renting of picturesque houses, at least without finding some earlier tenants who survived their leases. The moral of each: buy a condo in Queens.

title: RIGHT WING RUMBLING AN ISSUE FOR MRS. THATCHER
description: In the midst of the tortuous negotiations to find an end to the Falkland crisis, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has been presented with a new concern - a rumbling of dissatisfaction in the right wing of her own Conservative Party.

title: POLES STOP WORK IN NATIONAL PROTEST
description: Poles staged brief work stoppages and other acts of protest at noon today to mark five months of martial law. Work was disrupted at most major factories in Warsaw. At the steel mill, the siren blared for 25 minutes as strikers jammed its mechanism and at an auto plant, some 500 workers gathered outside the gate after the morning shift, chanting ''Long live Solidarity.''

title: REBEL PRIEST HELD AFTER MENACING POPE
description: The man who lunged toward Pope John Paul II wielding a bayonet at the Shrine of Fatima Wednesday night was identified by a high official close to the police investigation as a 32-year-old Spanish priest and follower of a traditionalist French prelate who is in open opposition to the Vatican.

title: DOLE FINDING ROLE OF THE MODERATE SUITS HIM
description: When the Senate stalemate over the Voting Rights Act finally broke last week, the main author of compromise was Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who artfully bridged the gap between Democratic liberals such as Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Republican conservatives such as Strom Thurmond of South Carolina.

title: Parents Regain Custody Of Siamese Twin Boys
description: The parents of Siamese twin boys regained guardianship of their sons today, one year after the state took custody because of accusations the couple tried to starve the infants to death.

title: Vying for Sampson
description: Acting on their belief that Ralph Sampson, Virginia's junior center, would declare his eligibility for next month's pro basketball draft if he were assured of playing in Los Angeles, the Lakers are continuing to dangle bait before the San Diego Clippers. Los Angeles and San Diego are the contestants in next Thursday's scheduled coin flip to determine which team gets the No.1 choice.

title: ACTRESSES STOP THE SHOW IN 'NINE'
description: Almost every Broadway musical has at least one, and some have two or three, but ''Nine'' has five - five actresses with show-stopping numbers. Anita Morris, Liliane Montevecchi, Shelly Burch, Kathi Moss and Karen Akers all have the kinds of songs that move an audience to cheers.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 14, 1982; The Braniff Shutdown
description: Braniff International filed a bankruptcy petition, becoming the first major domestic airline ever to seek court protection from its creditors. The carrier submitted the Chapter 11 papers to a judge in Fort Worth, near its headquarters, after suspending all its flights. Braniff said a sharp drop in passenger traffic had created a severe cash squeeze. (Page A1.) As a result of the shutdown, most of Braniff's 9,500 employees were out of work and hundreds of passengers were stranded far from their destinations. (D3.)

title: ART: THE CEREBRAL FAIRGROUND OF JACK YOUNGERMAN'S SCULPTURE
description: PINWHEEL fireworks, emblems for a parade in an unknown tropical land, giant twists of cake topping in colors to give even a junk-food junkie pause: these are only a few of the associations aroused by Jack Youngerman's new sculptures at the two Washburn galleries, 42 East 57th Street and 113 Greene Street.

title: Ethyl Acquisition
description: Stockholders of the Ethyl Corporation, a major producer of oil and gas, chemicals, plastic and aluminum, and of the First Colony Life Insurance Company voted overwhelmingly to approve Ethyl's acquisition of the insurer for $207 million, Lawrence E. Blanchard Jr., Ethyl vice chairman and chief financial officer, said at the annual meeting here. The merger is to be completed Friday. First Colony will retain its name, its location in Lynchburg, Va., and its board of directors.

title: HOUSE PANEL ADOPTS DEMOCRATIC BUDGET ON PARTY LINE VOTE
description: The Democratic-controlled House Budget Committee today adopted a $780.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1983, amid general recognition that it was merely a starting point for more debate.

title: EGYPTIAN GOWNS AND ISRAELI TOWELS ON SINAI BEACH
description: A plane belonging to a brand-new airline, Air Sinai, flew the other day over the Red Sea and headed for the modest airport at the southern tip of the vast and silent Sinai Peninsula.

title: Courting
description: It was hardly the first time a young woman had caught a young man's eye and given him her phone number, and nobody would have given it a second thought when it happened in a Manhattan courtroom this week if it hadn't been for a couple of details.

title: George Bledsoe, Bass Player And Singer for Ink Spots, 62
description: George Bledsoe, bass player and singer for the Ink Spots singing group, died, apparently of a heart attack, between shows Wednesday night. He was 62 years old.

title: AUDUBON WITHOUT FEATHERS
description: ''JOHN JAMES AUDUBON AND HIS SONS'' at the Grey Art Gallery, 33 Washington Place, has a great deal that is fresh and unexpected to tell us about one of the great Americans whom we most take for granted.

title: TAX RISE DISCUSSED FOR CALIFORNIANS
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and the Democratic leadership of the California Legislature abandoned the Governor's proposed $27 billion budget for the fiscal year 1983 Wednesday night and turned to discussion of possible tax increases.

title: Military Analysis
description: While the British task force off the Falkland Islands may have established a modest measure of superiority over the Argentine Navy and Air Force, there is continuing concern over the possibility of Argentine submarine attacks and renewed air raids.

title: STAGE: ONE-ACT FESTIVAL AT THE ENSEMBLE STUDIO
description: By FRANK RICH Christine Baranski, that leggy and toothy comic actress, was not used to ideal effect in ''Sally and Marsha'' earlier this season at the Manhattan Theater Club. But in Charles Leipart's ''The Undefeated Rhumba Champ,'' a new one-act play at the Ensemble Studio Theater, she is up to the old tricks one remembers so fondly from her performance as Ms. (cq) America in Ted Tally's ''Coming Attractions.'' What are those tricks? Devastating comic timing, sexiness with a grain of salt, an irrepressible urge to dance. At full throttle, Miss Baranski is definitely a performer to die over.

title: The U.N. Today; May 14, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session Devoted to Disar- mament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: ARGENTINA EXPECTS INVASION ON MONDAY IF THE TALKS FAIL
description: Argentine officials said today that the consensus within the Government is that the British will attempt an invasion of the Falkland Islands Monday if there is no diplomatic agreement before then.

title: MIDTOWN ZONING CHANGES ARE APPROVED
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday approved new zoning regulations for midtown Manhattan that are designed to steer development away from the congested East Side toward the West Side and to the south.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard TRAVELS TO THE ENU. By Jakov Lind. 126 pages. St. Martin's Press. $11.95.

title: Pitney-Bowes Move
description: Pitney-Bowes Inc. said today that it had settled with the Internal Revenue Service on its 1973 tax treatment of a write-off of its point-of-sales terminal business. It would not disclose the amount of the settlement but said it would come from a previously established reserve and would have no effect on 1982 earnings.

title: Donnelley's Cable Move
description: R.R. Donnelley & Sons, the nation's largest contract printer, announced today that it had agreed to purchase the Rockford Loves Park Cablevision Companies for an undisclosed sum.

title: DON'T TURN NURSES INTO CUT-RATE DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quaker State Deal
description: The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporaiton said its Valley Camp Coal Company subsidiary had agreed to sell its Kanawha Valley division mines near Charleston, W. Va., including 53 million short tons of coal reserves for $24 million. It said the buyer was a private company but did not name it. It will mine and sell to the same buyer 14.6 million tons of reserves from the Kanawha Valley division.

title: SLEEPLESS, RAINY NIGHT FOR A BANKRUPTCY JUDGE
description: For Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers of the North District Court, Fort Worth division, yesterday began a little too early for his liking: Shortly after midnight, officials from Braniff International Airways arrived at the judge's home in a Fort Worth suburb to file a Chapter 11 petition for bankruptcy protection.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp. has named Lawrence S. Daniels senior vice president, planning and administration, for its Health and Scientific Products Company.

title: Church Council Delays Vote on Homosexuals
description: The National Council of Churches voted today to wait a year before deciding whether the nation's only homosexual-oriented denomination should be permitted to join the interfaith agency.

title: NINTH AVE. MILE TESTS CITY'S CHAMPION NIBBLERS
description: IT'S that time again - the warmth of mid-May. And the city's biggest block party, the Ninth Avenue International Festival, is back for its ninth year of baking, roasting, grilling, stirring, sandwiching, mixing and finally serving bits and pieces of virtually all of New York's ethnic tastes in a two-day weekend gastronomic binge.

title: Skalbania Withdraws
description: After meeting their front-office payroll on Wednesday, the Montreal Alouettes have only about $3,000 in the bank and won't be able to open training camp on May 28 without an infusion of cash. Because of that, Nelson Skalbania has agreed to withdraw his franchise so that new owners of the team can be found. The announcement came yesterday from Bob Geary, the general manager of the Alouettes, in Regina, Saskatchewan, at a semiannual meeting of the Canadian Football League directors.

title: Market Place; Bullishness On Oil Stocks
description: INVESTORS are only now coming to realize what some analysts have been trying to convey for some time: that, after several months in the doghouse, oil stocks and oil service companies are back in favor once again.

title: S.E.C. CALLS FOR NEW PARTIAL TENDER RULE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed new rules to make it easier for small investors to take advantage of tender offers in takeover situations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are working for a peaceful solution, not a peaceful sellout.

title: COMPANIES' INVENTORIES LOWER
description: Despite slow sales, American companies managed to trim their inventories for the fourth consecutive month in March, chopping five-tenths of 1 percent from their stocks of unsold goods, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MOST PSYCHIATRISTS URGE NOT ABANDONING A CHILD
description: Throwing his son out of the house -telling him, ''You're on your own, do whatever you want'' - was ''the greatest mistake of my life,'' a weeping John W. Hinckley Sr. testified this week at the young man's trial for shooting President Reagan.

title: Dow Off 6.66; Airlines Gain
description: The airline issues were the star performers yesterday, while the stock market over all registered a moderate decline in active trading.

title: PSYCHIATRIST GIVES COURT A PROFILE OF HINCKLEY IN WORLD OF FANTASY
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s mounting identification with a movie character who sought to assassinate a Presidential candidate led him to stalk President Carter in the year before he shot President Reagan, a psychiatrist testified today.

title: PRETORIA POWER-SHARING PLAN IS ASSAILED BY LEFT AND RIGHT
description: The new proposals for giving nonwhites some role in government were caught in a crossfire of criticism today from the extreme right and moderate left of white politics.

title: BRITON AT THE U.N. REPORTS SOME GAIN
description: Prospects for a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands increased here today when one major obstacle to an accord was largely overcome, diplomats said.

title: U.S. EXPELS TWO POLISH DIPLOMATS
description: The United States today ordered two Polish diplomats out of the country in retaliation for the expulsion on Monday of two American Embassy officials in Warsaw.

title: M.T.A. STUDYING 2-TIER FARE PLAN FOR CITY'S RIDERS
description: Transit officials said yesterday that a plan to charge New York City subway passengers a higher fare than bus riders was under serious consideration by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: PUBLISHING: AFFLUENT ADDICT'S STORY
description: BENJAMIN STEIN'S latest book is off to a flying start even before publication. ''Ludes,'' a St. Martin's-Marek Book to be published June 3, has been sold to Bantam Books for $250,000 and to CBS Theatrical Films. ''Ludes'' is the story of Lenny and Linda Brown, a couple on whose lives Quaaludes (the drug methaqualone) have a tragic effect.

title: Haig Arrives in Turkey; To Pursue Plane Deal
description: The United States and Turkey have started talks in recent weeks for the sale and joint manufacture of nearly 300 advanced American fighter aircraft to modernize Turkey's air force over the next decade.

title: JOHN LOCKE, ET AL., AND THE LAW OF THE SEA
description: To the Editor: It is passing strange to see William Safire refer to John Locke and Thomas Jefferson as support for his belief that the seas (and the seabed) are not ''the common heritage of mankind.''

title: Jersey Plans Shift Of Jail Inmates
description: The State Department of Corrections will start taking its inmates out of overburdened county jails next week and put them into the new Mid-State Correctional Facility, formerly the stockade at Fort Dix.

title: IN FIGHT AGAINST CRIME, OVERTIME MAY NOT PAY
description: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically. By M. A. FARBER

title: New Cuts Set By Caterpillar
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the huge manufacturer of earthmoving and construction machinery based in Peoria, Ill., announced today that it was further reducing its production schedule and as a result would indefinitely lay off an additional 8,000 workers in June, bringing the total number of unemployed workers to 17,500, or 38 percent of the production work force.

title: 2d Suspect Seized In 'Village' Slaying
description: A second person was arrested yesterday in the fatal knifing in Greenwich Village last Saturday of a Manhattan teen-ager who was celebrating the end of his senior year in high school.

title: PIANO: FEDER-GILGORE DUO
description: THE Feder-Gilgore Piano Duo was at its best Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall when romping through Poulenc's Concerto in D minor for Two Pianos. The whimsical, eccentric twists given to Mozart and cabaret tunes, the sweeps and outbursts, and the innocent patter, all emerged with ease and aplomb.

title: HOW LIBERALS SEPARATE CHURCH FROM STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcoa and Nippon Form Company
description: The Aluminum Company of America and the Nippon Electric Company of Japan said that they had formed a corporation, the Alcoa-NEC Communications Corporation, to make and market television receiver systems.

title: JOHN LOCKE, ET AL., AND THE LAW OF THE SEA
description: T o the Editor: Although I am less confident than William Safire (''Son of 'Sea Law Sellout' ,'' column May 3) that the way to determine U.S. policy toward the proposed United Nations Treaty on the Law of the Sea is to attempt to divine what John Locke would have thought about the mining of manganese nodules from the deep seabed, it would appear that third-world delegates may also have been reading Locke, and reaching conclusions differing sharply from Mr. Safire's.

title: Car Blast in Spain Kills 2
description: A car carrying explosives blew up today, killing the two occupants. The victims were not immediately identified, but the police speculated that they were Basque terrorists because the explosion occurred near a power plant owned by Iberduero. The company has had a dozen plants bombed by the Basque separatist group E.T.A. to protest the construction of a nuclear plant outside Bilbao.

title: REPORT LISTS MORE I.T.T. PAYMENTS
description: A special investigation into the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has found more than $10 million in previously undisclosed questionable payments during the 1970's, according to a report filed today in Federal court here by a special review committee of I.T.T's board of directors.

title: BRANIFF MISTAKES CITED
description: Dan McKinnon, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, today blamed poor management decisions and the rcession for Braniff International's decision to file for bankruptcy. He said the airline's failure should not be attributed to the Government's four-year-old deregulation policy.

title: STEPHEN SELEY
description: Stephen Seley, an American novelist, died of a heart attack last Saturday in Ibiza, Spain, where he had lived since 1957.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A Manhattan jeweler was seriously wounded and a holdup man was killed when the two exchanged gunfire outside the Victoria Jewelry Store at 204 West 14th Street at 12:50 P.M. yesterday, the police said. The jeweler, Arnold Conte, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital, where his condition was listed as fair.

title: Friday; 'AGAMEMNON' IN CHELSEA
description: The ''Agamemnon'' of Aeschylus, which spans the Greek king's return from the Trojan War to his murder by his queen, Clytemnestra, is being staged at the Greek Theater of New York, 120 West 28th Street, under the direction of Jonathan Ringkamp, a Franciscan brother, who was co-founder of street-theater productions with Geraldine Fitzgerald and who is also a playwright. He has adapted the Edith Hamilton translation of the play. It's on tonight at 8 through June 6. Tickets are $6 ($5 for students, the elderly and groups). Reservations: 869-3981. THEATER SPOOF AT AMERICAN PLACE

title: Addenda
description: * Hodges & Sokolosky International Inc., a new public relations company, at 116 East 78th Street.

title: St. Joe Options Profits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that its estimate of the value of profits, which were based on inside information, from purchases of stock options in the St. Joe Minerals Corporation had been raised to $3.5 million, from $1.6 million.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Denny Admonished
description: Gabe Paul, the president of the Cleveland Indians, said that the right-handed pitcher John Denny might be fined if he missed his scheduled start Sunday as a result of a fit of temper in which he bruised his right thumb Tuesday night at Seattle. Denny had allowed only one hit for seven innings but wound up yielding four runs before being removed in the ninth inning of a 14-inning game, which Cleveland went on to win.

title: Books: Holocaust Event
description: MAX AND HELEN. By Simon Wiesenthal. 163 pages. Morrow. $9.95.

title: House Panel Clears Foreign Aid Bill
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a $10.8 billion foreign aid bill today after voting to tighten controls on exports to South Africa and Iraq.

title: 'TROVATORE' IN PARK SET FOR JUNE 15
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 16th season of free concert presentations of operas in New York parks will open June 15 with Verdi's ''Il Trovatore'' on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: Fighting Weeds
description: Ever since he read a newspaper account suggesting that tall weeds along a roadside may have caused a fatal accident by creating a blind intersection, Eric B. Salem has been reading about weeds, talking about weeds and campaigning to do something about weeds.

title: G.M. Employees
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was recalling about 3,900 employees at its assembly division here and at a number of component plants to raise production of the Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Omega.

title: EXXON'S WRITE-OFF ON COLONY
description: Stockholders of the Exxon Corporation were told yesterday that, as a result of Exxon's withdrawal early this month from the Colony Shale Oil Project in Colorado, the company expected to take an after-tax write-off of a maximum of $125 million, or about 15 cents a share. But the company stressed that its involvement with Colony was not over.

title: EUROPE-U.S. GLUTEN DISPUTE
description: A fast-selling animal feed known as corn gluten, a byproduct of fructose, the sugar substitute, has emerged as a cause of serious trade tensions with Europe.

title: BRITISH WAR ZONES CALLED UNLAWFUL IN SOVIET PROTEST
description: The Soviet Union formally advised Britain today that Moscow regarded the war zones around the Falkland Islands as unlawful.

title: Carey's Son Wins Ruling
description: The Department of Motor Vehicles ruled today that Governor Carey's 28-year-old son, Michael, was not behind the wheel on May 2, when the car he was in struck a parked vehicle and he was charged with driving while intoxicated.

title: JUDGE OVERTURNS ABSCAM CONVICTION OF EX-LEGISLATOR
description: A Federal district judge overturned the bribery conviction of former Representative Richard Kelly today, saying the Government had used ''outrageous'' tactics in the undercover Abscam inquiry.

title: French Official Visits Britain
description: France's Minister of External Relations, Claude Cheysson, arrived here today for talks with British officials on the Falkland crisis and Britain's financial wrangles with the European Common Market.

title: Boeing Shifts On Engines
description: The Boeing Company is willing to refit its old 727-200 airplanes with new engines, its president, Malcolm T. Stamper, said today in the first public indication that the aerospace giant would go along with a plan proposed by several airlines last fall.

title: Spot Oil Prices Firmer
description: Spot prices for crude oil and diesel fuel firmed this week as supply began to tighten, traders said today. Saudi Arabian Light crude was offered at $34.25 a barrel, the first time since January that it had been above the official price of $34. This compared with quotes of $33.20 to $33.50 at the start of the week, the traders reported.

title: ARGENTINE FRIGATES SIGHTED NORTHEAST OF FALKLANDS
description: American military analysts said today that two Argentine frigates had been sighted about 400 miles northeast of the Falkland Islands and that they appeared to be on the lookout for British ships in the South Atlantic.

title: TO CARRY THE BURDEN OF DOWN'S SYNDROME
description: To the Editor:

title: Gary Coleman Starts New Dialysis Treatment
description: A kidney transplant received by Gary Coleman, the 14-year-old star of the NBC-TV show ''Diff'rent Strokes'', is beginning to be rejected by his body and he is undergoing a new kind of dialysis treatment, the National Kidney Foundation announced in New York yesterday.

title: HIGHWAY SAFETY EASES DAMAGE STANDARDS FOR CAR BUMPERS
description: The Reagan Administration eased the Federal standard on automobile bumpers today, deciding to require that front and rear bumpers protect passenger cars from damage at impacts of 2 1/2 miles per hour or less. The current standard requires protection in crashes at 5 m.p.h. or less.

title: ELECTION CAN BLUR PARTY BUDGET LINES
description: It happens every even-numbered year about this time. Congressmen start counting the days until the fall election and filtering their actions through the strainer of politics.

title: GILBERT DENIES DEAL TO SELL ROCKIES
description: Peter Gilbert, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, last night denied a published report that he had reached an agreement to sell the financially troubled National Hockey League team to a group of New Jersey investors.

title: Hunt Joins Cosmos
description: Steve Hunt signed with the Cosmos for the remainder of the season and may play tomorrow against Chicago at Giants Stadium.

title: New Dataspeed Stock Device
description: Dataspeed Inc., a San Francisco consumer electronics company, said it would introduce in December a hand-held electronic device that receives stock market and commodities trading information sent via FM radio.

title: Soccer Club Sued
description: A civil suit was filed by a collection agency Thursday against the Denver Avalanche of the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: THE CUBAN GOVERNMENT'S OTHER 'OVERTURE'
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILS' CARLTON STOPS GIANTS ON 2-HITTER
description: Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies pitched a two-hitter tonight as he stopped the San Francisco Giants, 2-0. Carlton had a no-hitter going for seven and two-thirds innings. It was the Phillies' 11th triumph in their last 12 games.

title: REAGAN HEARS FARMERS' CRITICISM ON INTEREST RATES AND DAIRY POLICY
description: Visiting a farm for the first time since he took office, President Reagan found out at first hand today that not everyone is happy with the way his policies have brought food prices down.

title: Ex-Officer Guilty
description: A former Stamford, Conn., police lieutenant and commander of the first Fairfield County Narcotics Squad, was convicted in Federal court in Hartford Thursday of seeking to buy 2.2 pounds of heroin from Federal undercover agents.

title: Sports of The Times; Mr. Clark's Preakness
description: HIS name is Henry Clark, but almost everybody around the barns at Pimlico refers to him as ''Mr. Clark,'' out of respect for his age and his stature. He's 77 years old, and he's the trainer of Linkage, the favorite for the 107th Preakness today.

title: Gentrifiers: The Guns
description: There are about two million illegal guns in this city. A lot of them are owned by the kind of criminals seen on television, but they are also turning up in non-traditional places - like the offices of landlords, some of whom have turned to violence and mayhem in the pursuit of profits.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Israeli Prices Rise 10.7%
description: The cost-of-living index rose 10.7 percent in April, the largest monthly rise this year, the Central Bureau of Statistics announced today. If the inflation rate so far this year continues, the rate for the year will be 136 percent. Last year it was 101 percent.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The extension of Westchester County called Keskeskeck by the Indians and settled by a Scandinavian named Jonas Bronck in 1641 fell on hard times in the seventh decade of the 20th century.

title: SPANISH PRIEST CHARGED WITH ATTEMPT TO KILL POPE
description: The Rev. Juan Maria Fernandez Krohn was charged by a magistrate today with attempted homicide against Pope John Paul II and ordered held for trial.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 15, 1982; The Economy
description: Producer prices rose just 0.1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported. The Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, a rough measure of future inflation, had dropped 0.1 percent in each of the preceding two months. In the last 12 months, officials said, the index rose 3.1 percent, the smallest 12-month increase since 1976. Most economists expect the index to continue rising at a moderate pace as the economy recovers, food prices rise and energy prices reverse their recent decline. (Page 1.)

title: THAYER TO GIVE UP CHIEF'S TITLE AT LTV
description: Paul Thayer, the 62-year-old chief executive of the LTV Corporation, will relinquish his title on Dec.1 to Raymond A. Hay, president and chief operating officer, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Thayer, who took over leadership of the Dallas-based company in 1970, is credited with rescuing the then-foundering conglomerate from bankruptcy.

title: Index; International
description: For Moscow's guests, life in a luxurious cocoon 2 South Africa gets new version of old security laws 3 Haig ends talks in Turkey with no sign of differences 3 Ombudsman quits U.S. agency charging corruption 3 U.S. reports two Argentine frigates northwest of Falklands 4 Argentine leaders debating the next move 5 Around the World 6 Priest is charged with attempted homicide against the Pope 6 Poland says Solidarity's strike call failed 7 Government/Politics Safety agency eases damage standards for car bumpers 8 Reagans paid additional taxes last year, return shows 28 Governor Kean's nominee for education chief withdraws 30 Mayor Koch asks three Republican leaders for budget help 31 President's visit spices up primary races in Pennsylvania 32 Mayor's transit aide unable to take promised M.T.A. seat 34 Watt plan would open most of U.S. coastline to drilling 35 Social Security issue divides Republicans in Congress 46 Washington Talk Briefing 7 Steven Roberts discusses election-time rush to moderation 7 Health/Science Mount St. Helens erupts with ''a whisper'' 8 PARADE TODAY The Armed Forces Day Parade begins today at 2 P.M., moving up Fifth Avenue from 26th Street to 54th. General Around the Nation 8 Mistrial declared on charges related to approval of DMSO 8 Baymen eye clam beds - and each other - in North Jersey 29 Accident and aftermath bring Darien a sense of tragedy 30 Study doubts second gunman was involved in Kennedy shooting 35 Arts/Entertainment ''Conan the Barbarian,'' adventure-fantasy, is reviewed 13 Graebner's ''Baseball Wives,'' staged Off Off Broadway 13 Handbook on breaking relationships reviewed 15 ''The Raspberry Picker,'' Fritz Hochwalder play, reviewed 15 Gay Delanghe and Sandra Genter offer their works 16 Oratorio Society sings Brahms at Carnegie Hall 47 Style Consumer Saturday: the issue of United States food inspectors 33 De Gustibus: Tastes at table vary with geography 33 Luxury lingerie: a mail-order success 33 Nancy Reagan visits her alma mater in Chicago 33 Obituaries Tom Weatherly, producer and publicity agent 34 Sports Valenzuela ends Mets' streak before sellout at Shea 9 Holzman of Knicks ends 18-year N.B.A. coaching career 9 Cupecoy's Joy, filly, is scratched and Preakness field drops to 7 9 New Jets skip final exams to make the grade 9 Five players ejected, 2 hurt as Tigers beat Twins in 11th, 4-2 10 Clements leads Colonial golf by a stroke on 69-135 11 Lakers beat Spurs for 3-0 lead 11 Dave Anderson on Henry Clark, trainer of Linkage 12 Islanders credit themselves with ''determination'' in playoffs 12 Falcone misses Mets' 3d straight complete game by two outs 12 Features/Notes Man in the News: Enrique Jorge Ros, Argentine negotiator 5 Sports People 11 Going Out Guide 14 Saturday News Quiz 16 About New York 31 Notes on People 47 News Analysis David Margolick examines effect of Cooke v. Morgenthau 29 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 26

title: SOCIAL SECURITY ISSUE SPLITS G.O.P. AS SENATORS BEGIN BUDGET DEBATE
description: As the Senate began debate today on the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1983, Republican lawmakers continued to thrash around the subject of Social Security, disagreeing with one another over how to handle that highly volatile issue.

title: BASEBALL
description: OAKLAND (AL) - Traded Rob Picciolo, shortstop, to Milwaukee (AL) for Johnny Evans, first baseman, and Mike Warren, pitcher.

title: BRIEFING
description: Pelts of Political Animals

title: ALBANY ACCORD CLEARS WAY FOR $3.5 BILLION BORROWING
description: State officials reached agreement today on a formal statement that will allow the state to borrow over $3.5 billion more than a month behind schedule.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Boston International Finance Corp., a subisidary of First National Boston Corp., will make a public offering of $100 million of 14 1/4 percent Eurodollar notes due June 1, 1989, at 99 1/2 percent, to be guaranteed by First National Boston Corp.

title: KOCH SEEKS G.O.P. HELP ON AID
description: Mayor Koch pressed his program of new state aid and taxes yesterday with three friendly and influential State Senate Republicans from New York City.

title: NEW STUDY ON SLAYING OF KENNEDY DOUBTS 2ND GUNMAN WAS INVOLVED
description: Recordings cited by a Congressional panel as evidence that a second gunman was involved in the slaying of President Kennedy in 1963 were made a full minute after the shooting and reflect no proof of a conspiracy, the National Academy of Sciences has concluded.

title: BRIEFING
description: Clash With C.I.A.

title: EX-AIDE IS CHARGING CORRUPTION IN A U.S. AGENCY
description: An unpaid ombudsman, raising charges of possible fraud and corruption, has resigned from the International Communication Agency.

title: CONCERN RISING IN LONDON AS WINTER CLOSES IN ON FALKLANDS
description: In May of 1916, Sir Ernest Shackleton, the British Antarctic explorer, sailed across the South Atlantic, in the neighborhood of the Falkland Islands, and he described it as ''the most tempestuous storm-swept area of water in the world.''

title: Books of The Times; Jargon of Happiness
description: %HOW TO BREAK YOUR ADDICTION TO A PERSON. By Howard M. Halpern. 262 pages. McGraw-Hill. $12.95

title: ENERGY CONCERNS REPORT ON WELLS
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said that it had completed he testing of the Wilma Lunsford No. 1 gas well in Nacogdoches County, Tex.

title: Baker Offering Regrets In Press Secrecy Sweep
description: The Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, says he regrets any inconvenience to the press when the Senate Press Gallery was cleared May 5 for a secret intelligence briefing.

title: THE CITY;
description: Three thieves made off with an estimated $300,000 in jewelry from a ground-floor sales area of Tiffany & Company on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, the police reported.

title: ARGENTINA'S FALKLAND EXPERT
description: Enrique Jorge Ros calls himself a frustrated farmer and frets over the untended plants withering in his widower's apartment in a fashionable section of Buenos Aires. But behind his relaxed, low-key appearance, Mr. Ros, the head of Argentina's delegation to the cease-fire talks here, conceals a shrewd mind, a gargantuan appetite for work and a skill at manipulating difficult governments and intractable diplomats that is the envy of his colleagues here.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM INDIA

title:
PATENTS;
Viability of Semen Of Turkeys Extended
description: A method to extend the viability of turkey semen for artificial insemination of hens has been invented for the Department of Agriculture.

title: Renzo Rossellini, Composer; Monte Carlo Orchestra Aide
description: Renzo Rossellini, the Italian composer who wrote operas, symphonies and scores for films, died today at Princess Grace Hospital after a heart attack.

title: Two Share L.P.G.A. Lead
description: Kelly Fuiks and Julie Stanger Pyne, former Arizona State teammates, shot four-under-par 68's today to share the opening-round lead in the $150,000 Atlanta Ladies' Professional Golfers Association tournament.

title: LUXURY LINGERIE: A MAIL-ORDER SUCCESS
description: It started in 1976 with Sighs and Whispers. That was Bloomingdale's controversial lingerie catalogue with mysterious, sensual photographs by Guy Bourdin of models in poses and sets inspired by Ingmar Bergman's films.

title: Now That the Judges Have Judged ...
description: The final ruling is in, but the crucial decisions are yet to come in the power struggle that took the name of a lawsuit, Robert Morgenthau, District Attorney v. Lawrence Cooke, Chief Judge of New York State.

title: Britoil Stock Sale
description: The sale to the public of 51 percent of the stock of Britoil will take place before the end of the year if market conditions permit, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Geoffrey Howe, said today.

title: Bang the Press Loudly
description: The South Atlantic is getting rough for the press. In Britain, Prime Minister Thatcher abets deplorable attacks on the BBC for its failure to wave the Union Jack robustly enough.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $800 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose $800 million in the week ended May 5, a change that was near market expectations and resulted in only a slight decline in interest rates.

title: SHOOTINGS BY HINCKLEY LAID TO SCHIZOPHRENIA
description: A defense psychiatrist testified today that John W. Hinckley Jr. was ''driven'' by a severe mental illness called ''process schizophrenia'' when he shot President Reagan and three other men.

title: Arrows Lose Opener
description: A goal by Tony Glavin 5 minutes 55 seconds into overtime gave the St. Louis Steamers a 3-2 victory over the three-time champion New York Arrows Friday night in the opener of the Major Indoor Soccer League championship series.

title: RETURN SHOWS EXTRA TAX PAYMENT BY THE REAGANS
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, paid an unspecified amount of additional Federal and California taxes plus interest last year for the years 1978 and 1979, an examination of a copy of the tax return released last month by the White House has disclosed.

title: Actors Company Plans Benefit for Wednesday
description: The Actors Producing Company, a nonprofit Off Off Broadway group, will give a benefit Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. at Jazzmania, 40 West 27th Street, to support its revivals and development of new plays.

title: Sears Employee's Award Raised
description: A judgment against Sears, Roebuck & Company for a patent violation was increased to $8.1 million from $5 million by a United States District Court judge. Judge Nicholas J. Bua ordered the retailer to pay an additional $3.1 million to Peter M. Roberts, a former Sears employee, for ''willfull infringement'' of Mr. Roberts' patent on a socket wrench he designed 18 years ago, as a teenager.

title: Law on CETA Program Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A law that bars anyone who publicly advocates the violent overthrow of the Government from Federal job training programs was declared unconstitutional today by a Federal judge.

title: CHOICE FOR EDUCATION CHIEF SENDS WITHDRAWAL TO KEAN
description: Governor Kean's intended nominee for New Jersey Education Commissioner withdrew his name from consideration today, acknowledging that 66 pages of his 121-page doctoral thesis on urban education had been taken from three other works without attribution.

title: Orbit Oil Tender Offer
description: The Orbit Oil and Gas Company said today that it would make an offer for all outstanding shares and warrants of the Tiber Energy Corporation. Orbit said it would offer $3, plus one cumulative, redeemable, 15 percent, Series A, $20 preferred share of Orbit, for each five shares of Tiber.

title: Argentina Will Allow Rabbis to Visit Troops
description: Three Argentine rabbis have been given permission to visit Jewish troops posted in southern Argentina among the forces facing the British task force in the South Atlantic.

title: TEXAS PRISONS OPENING AGAIN
description: The Texas Department of Correction will resume accepting new inmates ''on a limited basis'' Monday, the chairman of the prison board said today.

title: Prime Computer Cuts Unit Prices
description: Prime Computer Inc. said that it had cut prices of its add-on computer memories to reflect lower prices that it was paying for components.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Terrorists shot and killed a taxi driver today in a new flare-up of separatist violence in which there were two assaults on security forces.

title: THEATER: 'THE RASPBERRY PICKER'
description: The problem, and it's a big one, with ''The Raspberry Picker,'' Fritz Hochwalder's play at the American Jewish Theater in the 92d Street Y, is that it isn't sure whether it's a comedy with serious overtones or a philosophical drama with comic overtones.

title: Dance Films Saturday
description: ''Dancing With Camera,'' films relating to dance, will be shown next Saturday at 8 o'clock at the Collective for Living Cinema, 52 White Street. The program, curated by Elisabeth Ross, includes films by Yoshiko Chuma, Maya Deren, Oscar Fischinger, Simon Forti, Amy Greenfield, Pooh Kaye, Fernand Leger and Dudley Murphy, and Miss Ross. Call 925-2111.

title: CHORAL MUSIC: ORATORIO SOCIETY
description: The 250-singer Oratorio Society of New York crowded Carnegie Hall's stage Thursday evening like one of those choral throngs from another age. It was a reminder of Victorian lushness and its now-discredited mass ''Messiahs'' and Arthur Sullivan oratorios.

title: Dutch Queen Meeting Minor Party Leaders
description: Queen Beatrix, continuing her wideranging consultations stemming from the breakup of her country's three-party coalition Government, met leaders of minor political parties today.

title: Standard Metals Officers Backed
description: The Standard Metals Corporation announced that more than 62 percent of its shareholders had voted in favor of retaining the current management, after a long proxy fight waged by a group of dissidents led by the Oklahoma Publishing Company.

title: 2 DOMINICAN AIDES IN NEW YORK LINKED TO A HEROIN SCHEME
description: Two Dominican Republic diplomats have been accused of conspiring with several other men to smuggle millions of dollars' worth of heroin into the United States.

title: TOM WEATHERLY IS DEAD AT 83
description: Tom Weatherly, an associate producer with William A. Brady Jr. and Dwight Deere Wiman of the 1929 hit revue ''The First Little Show'' and a co-producer of two subsequent ''Little Shows,'' died Wednesday at the Heritage Towers nursing residence in Doylestown, Pa. He was 83 years old.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 15, 1982
description: International Moscow disputed Britain on the combat zones near the Falkland Islands, calling them unlawful. In a formal statement read by a Foreign Ministry official to the British Ambassador in Moscow, the Soviet Union charged that Britain had arbitrarily closed vast expanses of the high seas to ships and aircraft of other countries in disregard of the 1958 Convention on the High Seas. It also rejected what it described as warnings by Britain to the Soviet Union and denied any involvement in the conflict between Britain and Argentina. (Page 1, Column 6.) The U.N. talks on the Falklands were abruptly halted when Sir Anthony Parsons, the British delegate, announced that he was returning to London for further talks with the Government. Diplomatic sources at the United Nations said the bargaining had bogged down over a British attempt to revive part of its control over the islands. Argentina has resisted this effort, insisting that London should stick to a plan that would place the islands under United Nations control until the question of sovereignty was settled. (1:5.)

title: Marcos Swears In A New Supreme Court
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos swore in a new 15-member Supreme Court today, including 12 justices who had resigned in a scandal over the fixing of the bar examination score of a judge's son.

title: Head Shop Ban Upheld in Jersey
description: A New Jersey law banning head shops, which sell paraphernalia for drug use, was upheld by a state appeals court today.

title: BAYMEN EYE NEW CLAMS AND EACH OTHER IN JERSEY
description: Once, when the sea was clean and the clams were thick underfoot, the baymen who roamed the sand flats and shallows of the great tidewater rivers here could rake the bottom for their own keep and call themselves independent.

title: SOUTH AFRICA RECASTING ITS SECURITY LAWS
description: While South Africa's attention was focused this week on proposals for constitutional revisions that would give some nonwhites a role in the central Government, the ruling National Party was busy pushing a new version of its body of security laws through the all-white Parliament.

title: KOCH AIDE UNABLE TO TAKE M.T.A. SEAT
description: Six months after he became Mayor Koch's special adviser on transit matters, Ross Sandler has still not taken a seat on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority because another board member has resisted the Mayor's pressure to step down.

title: The Folly of Binary Weapons
description: The Administration's plan to manufacture a new type of nerve gas shell is a certain recipe for military debacle, diplomatic humiliation and strategic risk. The Senate, which had a chance to delete the necessary funds, failed to save the Administration from its folly by the narrowest of votes.

title: LAKERS LEAD BY 3-0 ON 118-108 VICTORY
description: The Los Angeles Lakers again dominated the San Antonio Spurs tonight for a 118-108 victory that gave them a 3-0 lead in the four-of-seven game Western conference finals.

title:
PATENTS;
Portable Dance Floor
description: A portable, roll-up dance floor with internal lights was patented this week by William Loebner, a manufacturer of theater equipment in Newark.

title:
PATENTS;
New Process Developed To Treat Nuclear Waste
description: A method of treating high-level nuclear wastes such as those created in the United States military programs was patented this week by an Australian geochemist, Alfred Ringwood, who assigned Patent 4,329,248 to the Australian National University at Acton.

title: Roy Cohn Joins Board of Anti-Communist Group
description: After satisfying himself that Western Goals Inc., a militantly anti-Communist educational group, has no ties to the right-wing John Birch Society, Roy M. Cohn said yesterday, he joined the advisory board of the organization.

title: BRIEFING
description: Bolling Speaks Out

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic American Corp. said it was offering to purchase up to 415,000 of National Security Insurance Co.'s common stock, paying for each $12.50 cash and $12.50 principle amount of Atlantic American's 12 percent debentures due 1990.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION DROPS 0.6%
description: Production by the nation's factories and mines, reflecting the continuing recession, fell in April for the eighth month in the past nine, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: BRITISH JETS POUND AIRPORT AT STANLEY FOR A THIRD TIME
description: British Sea Harrier jets carried out another bombing raid Friday night on the airport at Stanley, the main town in the Falkland Islands, the Ministry of Defense announced early this morning.

title: Playboy Posts Loss in Quarter
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. reported yesterday that it lost $22.6 million in its third quarter, ended last March 31. For the comparable period last year, the company had reported net income of $2.7 million, or 28 cents a share.

title: INFORMATION SERVICES FOR ALL THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Bank Proxies
description: C.A. Cavendes, which owns or has contracts to buy 24.9 percent of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., said yesterday that the preliminary count of proxies regarding Florida National's proposed merger with the Alliance Corporation had left the outcome uncertain. The final count will be determined by the United States District Court in Jacksonville, Fla.

title: FIGHTING, FANTASY IN 'CONAN THE BARBARIAN'
description: John Milius's ''Conan the Barbarian,'' starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, the body builder-actor, as the character made famous through decades of pulp fiction and comic books, may make money, but it will only be fully realized as a work of art when Woody Allen takes charge and dubs it into Icelandic. Then, perhaps, it will be the laugh riot it has every right to be, a sort of muscle-bound, Nordic ''What's Up, Tiger Lily?''

title: TWO OIL CONCERNS FACE LOSS OF LEASE TO INDIANS
description: An official of the Interior Department has made a preliminary ruling that oil-producing leases held by the Amoco Production Company and the Sohio Petroleum Corporation on the Wind River Indian Reservation in Wyoming should be canceled. The official said that the oil companies had failed to pay the correct royalties to the tribes and had violated Federal record-keeping regulations.

title: REAGAN'S VISIT SPICES UP PENNSYLVANIA PRIMARY
description: With the voting in statewide primaries only four days away, President Reagan brought the first hint of excitement today to races that will name candidates for Governor and United States Senator.

title: SENATE APPROVES MILITARY BILL INCLUDING CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: The Senate ended 20 hours of debate at dawn today by passing a $177.9 billion military authorization bill for 1983 that includes money to produce chemical weapons for the first time in 13 years.

title: Redmen and Seton Hall Win, Will Meet Today
description: St. John's and Seton Hall moved into the winners' bracket of the Eastern College Athletic Conference regional baseball tournament at St. John's yesterday. St. John's defeated New York Tech, 4-3, and Seton Hall beat Long Island University, 11-5, in New York-New Jersey regional play. Seton Hall will play the Redmen at 3 P.M. today in the double-elimination tournament, following a noon game matching New York Tech and L.I.U.

title: Suited To Last
description: I had a tailor make me a suit of lead. ''Surely you jest,'' he said when I ordered it. ''My good man,'' said I, ''you are obviously numb to the Government's insistence that Americans gird themselves to survive the thermonuclear holocaust. A lead suit will be essential afterwards to withstand the radiation while we rebuild the country.'' He shrugged. ''It's your money. You want twin vents? Cuffs on the pants? Doublebreasted?''

title: Japanese Interest in Wells Fargo
description: Wells Fargo & Company, parent of the nation's 11th-largest bank, said today that the Industrial Bank of Japan was not expected to buy any Wells Fargo stock beyond the 300,000 shares it acquired ''some months ago.''

title: West Virginia's Tax Plan For Schools Invalidated
description: A circuit judge declared today that West Virginia's method of financing public education was unconstitutional, a decision that officials said could raise some residential property taxes as much as 500 percent.

title: TOP STATE COURT TO HEAR CASE
description: A three-judge appellate court today rejected a move by State Senator William V. Musto to prevent the Senate from declaring his seat vacant because of his racketeering conviction.

title: Soviet Military Ship Is Afire Near Latvia, Swedes Report
description: A Soviet destroyer or large frigate was on fire today in the Baltic Sea, 22 miles off Latvia, the Swedish coastal authorities said.

title: HAIG ENDS 'WARM' TALKS IN TURKEY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. ended extensive talks with Turkey's Government today in which he underscored Washington's confidence that the military leaders will carry out their pledge to return the country to democracy by the end of next year or in early 1984 at the latest.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of of an editing error, a review of the Kazuko Hirabayashi Dance Theater in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect closing date. The program will be repeated through May 22.

title: TLATELOLCO, A TREATY WHOSE TIME IS NOW
description: It is not merely statesmanlike restraint - nor even world opinion, national conscience, and tactical circumstance alone -that has kept Britain from threatening Argentina with nuclear weapons as the Falklands crisis has escalated. Britain has pledged not to use such arms against any Latin American or Caribbean party to the Treaty of Tlatelolco, which Argentina has signed but not ratified. Today, the pact offers the kind of international glue that might hold other settlements together. It should be fully implemented as soon as possible.

title: DANCE: BY 2 TEACHERS
description: Both Gay Delanghe and Sandra Genter teach dance - Miss Delanghe at the University of Michigan and Miss Genter at Barnard College -and one of the odd things about their Thursday concert at Barnard College's Marion Streng Studio was the fact that their offerings looked like composition class exercises. Each was an effort to solve a spatial or thematic problem, yet few of the dances had much vitality.

title: NANCY REAGAN VISITS HER ALMA MATER IN CHICAGO
description: ''I was very surprised that she came,'' said 8-year-old Michael Foucher. ''I didn't think she would answer the letter,''

title: South Africans Tell Of a Raid on Angola
description: A Soviet-made military helicopter was destroyed by South African jets during a recent raid on guerrilla bases in Angola, the Defense Force headquarters said today.

title: 2 MUSEUMS MAKE 4-PAINTING SWAP
description: In what they say is a ''historic'' move that will strengthen the collections of each, the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum have agreed to a multimillion-dollar swap of four masterworks. The Modern will get two paintings of Wassily Kandinsky's ''classical'' period from the Guggenheim's collection, and the Guggenheim will get two works of equal value, a Matisse and a Picasso, from the Modern.

title: Dow Plans to Sell $1 Billion in Assets
description: The Dow Chemical Company expects to sell about $1 billion in assets to lower its debt load in the next few years, as well as cut back on capital spending, its president, Paul F. Oreffice, told the annual meeting.

title: CHINA'S BIRTH GOALS MEET REGIONAL RESISTANCE
description: A Communist Party official in Guangdong Province was dismissed from his job at a petroleum plant and expelled from the party recently for ''feudal thinking'' after he and his wife - they already had six daughters -tried once more to produce a son.

title: WEATHER DEVICES IN PARK FIXED
description: Regular readings of the temperature and precipitation at Central Park were resumed Thursday evening by the National Weather Service, after an interruption that began May 5, the agency said yesterday.

title: Upstaging Miss U.S.A.
description: The ultimate focus of attention at this year's Miss U.S.A. Pageant was the winner, Terri Lea Utley, of Cabot, Ark. But in the hours leading up to the televised event, all the commotion was over Donny Osmond, who refused to shave off his month-old beard in defiance of pageant officials who had hired him to entertain.

title: Brooklyn, With Gloves
description: Mark Breland is a 19-year-old from Bedford-Stuyvesant who wants to hit it big in the entertainment business. He is in Munich and has hit it big enough in the boxing ring to make it to today's welterweight final of the world amateur boxing championships.

title: 7 IN PREAKNESS
description: An unusual track bias at Pimlico Race Course and the scratch of Cupecoy's Joy have altered the complexion of the 107th Preakness Stakes here Saturday.

title: Coca-Cola Seeking Soviet Contract
description: Coca-Cola is negotiating with Soviet authorities to start Coke sales and production in the Soviet Union, according to a spokesman for the company's West German subsidiary, Coca-Cola GmbH , in Essen.

title: Garn Bill Aids Thrift Units
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee today introduced a bill that would use Government-backed promissory notes to bolster the net worth of ailing savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks.

title: G.M.'s Salaried Workers Reported Seeking Union
description: Salaried workers at the General Motors Corporation are asking the United Automobile Workers to help organize most of the automobile maker's 129,000 white-collar workers in the United States, a U.A.W. official said.

title: 20 Ordered to Clean Graffiti
description: About 20 people who were unable to pay fines for minor offenses in Brooklyn subways will be penalized by having to clean graffiti from the inside of subway cars. The cleanup will be the first of its kind under a program established by District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman.

title: Day of Decision
description: This is the final day for college players to declare themselves eligible for the the June 29 National Basketball Association draft, and Clark Kellogg, the outstanding Ohio State junior, beat the rush yesterday. Another star,Antoine Carr of Wichita State announced he won't forgo his college eligibility as did his teammate Cliff Levingston. James Worthy of North Carolina was delaying his decision as time was running out.

title: A TROUBLESOME SCHOOL "GATES" POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: TASTE AT TABLE VARIES WITH THE PART OF THE COUNTRY
description: ''Can you imagine tuna fish salad at a Palm restaurant?'' asked Bruce Bozzi, one of the partners in the New York steakhouse famous for its macho menu of lusty beef, chops, potatoes and sea-monstersize lobsters. ''That's what we had to add for lunch in Washington,'' he went on. ''New Yorkers eat the works for lunch -steaks, lobsters, everything.''

title: Alcoa Cuts Back Wages and Prices
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, said yesterday that it had frozen the salaries of its top 1,800 managers, cut increases for other salaried employees in half and is trimming all discretionary expenses.

title: HOLZMAN RETIRING AS COACH
description: The Knicks began making way for their new leadership team yesterday with the long-expected announcement that Red Holzman had retired as head coach and would become a consultant to the club.

title: 76ers' Hollins to Suit Up But Likely Won't Play
description: Lionel Hollins of Philadelphia will be back in uniform Saturday when the 76ers and the Boston Celtics resume their playoff series with Game 3. But Coach Billy Cunningham lists Hollins's playing status as ''very doubtful.''

title: CLEMENTS LEADS COLONIAL BY 1 ON 69-135
description: Lennie Clements, a sophomore on the PGA Tour, conquered a stiff breeze today to take the lead in the second round of the 36th Colonial National Invitation tournament. He shot a 69 for 135, five under par, on the Colonial Country Club course.

title: NEW JETS SKIP FINALS TO MAKE GRADE
description: Some players are only a final examination short of earning a college degree, but many of those at the New York Jets' rookie camp this week skipped their tests to take a chance on making it in professional football.

title: CENTRAL PARK HAPPENINGS-FOR THE BIRDS, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: COOKE SEEKS WAY TO STAFF CITY COURTS
description: Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke said yesterday that he expected to have answers by ''the latter part of next week'' to questions that were raised by the decision of New York State's highest court to void his rotation system for assigning judges to Supreme Court in New York City.

title: LENDERS ARE SKEPTICAL OF BRANIFF REVIVAL PLAN
description: Some of Braniff International Airways' major lenders yesterday expressed doubt about supporting the company's plan to restart operations as a smaller, low-cost carrier. But they said they would listen to management proposals with an open mind.

title: BLOODSTAINS IN VAN TIED TO 4 MURDERS AT GARAGE
description: Serology tests at the New York City Medical Examiner's office have linked bloodstains found in a van to the murder of four persons last month in a West Side garage.

title: REAGAN ADMINISTRATION VS. HISPANIC AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKS SUSPENDED
description: The cease-fire negotiations over the Falkland Islands halted abruptly today when Sir Anthony Parsons, the British delegate, disclosed that he was flying back to London tonight for fresh talks with his Government.

title: Youthful Headmistress Makes Concession to Age
description: ''Working with little ones,'' Douce Fleming Correa was saying yesterday, ''keeps one young.'' Mrs. Correa, who has been working with little ones for most of her life, explained why, at age 76, she feels as if she is still 25. But Mrs. Correa, or Madame, as she is known at the Fleming School, which she founded in 1956 on East 62d Street, has made one concession to age.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47.

title: COURT RULES 'PSYCHOLOGICAL STRESS' MUST BE WEIGHED AT 3 MILE ISLAND
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island could not be restarted until the Government assessed the ''psychological stress'' on people who live near it.

title: MISTER, 'YOUR BENEFITS ARE EXHAUSTED'- THE MOTOWN, MOWED DOWN, WITHOUT-A-JOB AND FEELIN' MIGHTY LOW-DOWN BLUES
description: Three years ago, I stood in the office of Speaker of the House Tip O'Neill with my boss, a newly elected Michigan Congressman.

title: Philadelphia Crime War Has Its 13th Victim
description: A reputed mobster shot to death in the internal war among organized crime in the Philadelphia area had gained considerable power, and his reputation as a ''hothead'' might have cost him his life, the head of the Pennsylvania Crime Commission said today.

title: WATT SENDS CONGRESS PLAN TO OPEN MOST OF U.S. COASTLINE TO DRILLING
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, making only minor concessions to environmentalists, has sent Congress a plan that would open up virtually the nation's entire coastline for oil and gas drilling.

title: New Mercedes Model
description: Mercedes-Benz, a unit of Daimler-Benz of West Germany, plans to begin making small, four-cylinder luxury cars later this year, the trade journal, Ward's Automotive Reports, said here today. The new 201-series car would sell for $25,000, and would be introduced in the United States in late 1983, Ward's said.

title: PRODUCERS' PRICES RISE BY ONLY 0.1%
description: Producer prices edged up only one-tenth of 1 percent in April, continuing the trend of a significant slowdown in price increases, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 5 Circus Elephants Flee; One Is Killed in Fall
description: Five elephants bolted Thursday from a circus near this eastern Oklahoma town and plunged off a ledge.

title: BALBONI'S POWER SURFACES
description: On a team famous for its feuds, fusses and forceful personalities, the gentle, soft-spoken giant commanded the stage today: Steve Balboni, the rookie who made the Yankees forget their troubles for a while with some old-fashioned power hitting.

title: VALENZUELA DEFEATS METS BEFORE 50,360 AT SHEA, 4-1
description: The Mets' four-game winning streak ended with a 4-1 loss to the Dodgers and Fernando Valenzuela last night before a sellout crowd of 50,360, the largest at Shea Stadium since July 5, 1980.

title: MISTRIAL CALLED IN CONSPIRACY CASE INVOLVING 'WONDER DRUG' APPROVAL
description: A mistrial was declared today in a Federal conspiracy trial centering on a reputed scheme to gain Government approval of dimethyl sulfoxide, popularly known as DMSO and widely, often illegally, sold as a ''wonder drug.''

title: Atlantic City Weighs Publicizing of 'Johns'
description: Men who solicit prostitutes in this gambling resort may return home to find their names in local newspapers, the city's Police Chief said today.

title: AFFLUENT CONSUMERS CUT BACK
description: In the East, high-priced women's designer sportswear sales are lagging. In the Middle West, high-income, white-collar customers hurt by the auto industry slump are shopping less. And in Texas, wealthy patrons are passing up new, status clothes.

title: Emergencies Need Open Hospitals
description: If you suffer a heart attack in New York, where will the ambulance of the Emergency Medical Services take you? To the closest participating hospital, public or private, or to a municipal hospital farther away? Obviously it should be the nearest one - unless, of late, that happens to be a private hospital that has closed its emergency doors that day.

title: A GRAND-SLAM SINGLE
description: Lee Lacy galloped from ecstacy to anguish tonight when he accidentally passed a teammate on the basepaths and lost the first grand slam of his career.

title: ISSUE OF U.S. FOOD INSPECTORS
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration continues to support legislation that would halve the number of meat and poultry inspectors despite studies by the Department of Agriculture and the General Accounting Office indicating that the current staff may be inadequate to enforce sanitary and labeling regulations.

title: STATE SUES OVER ATOMIC WASTE
description: New York State filed a $1.08 billion Federal lawsuit today asking that the Getty Oil Company and five utilities be ordered to remove 165 metric tons of spent nuclear fuel rods at a defunct reprocessing plant.

title: Current Reagan Role Offers Big Advantage
description: President Reagan said today that he preferred being chief executive to being a movie actor. The issue came up at a fund-raising party for Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania. Mr. Reagan was asked if he enjoyed being President more than he did acting.

title: Vasquez Loses in Bid To Avoid Board Order
description: Jacinto Vasquez, the jockey, was rebuffed in United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday in his effort to avoid responding to an order from the State Racing and Wagering Board to show cause why his license to ride should not be suspended. Judge Mary Johnson Lowe rejected the motion by Vasquez to enjoin the board from ordering him to appear Monday.

title: 40 YEARS AGO, INTERNED
description: On May 15, 1942, charged with no crime, I and my family forfeited our freedom in the name of loyalty to the United States and went to our wartime internment.

title: AFTER FATAL CRASH, A SENSE OF TRAGEDY IN DARIEN
description: Until the evening of Nov. 25, 1981, Mark Zengo, Keith Nelson and James Leary were classmates, teammates and friends at Darien High School, 17-year-olds progressing toward graduation in June.

title: 8 Businesses Lost In Westwood Fire
description: A fire destroyed a row of stores and caused about $2 million in damages early today in the small business district here, the police said.

title: Islanders Show Determination
description: The Islanders rested confidently today, knowing that their 3-0 victory Thursday night at Pacific Coliseum had not only given them a 3-0 lead in the four-ofseven-game series but also put them one game from a third consecutive Stanley Cup.

title: BROKER GUILTY ON CONTEMPT CHARGE
description: Gary V. Lewellyn, the 33-year-old Iowa stockbroker who faces a welter of charges stemming from his secret purchase of enough shares to control Safeguard Scientific Inc., pleaded guilty to a new charge yesterday.

title: FOR MOSCOW'S GUESTS, LIFE IN A LUXURIOUS COCOON
description: If there is any consolation for the Rev. Billy Graham amid the furor caused by his remarks here this week about Soviet tolerance of religion, it must lie in the fact that he joins a long tradition of visitors who have come away with rosy views of the Soviet system.

title: HUMPHREY SEARLE
description: Humphrey Searle, a British composer, died here Wednesday. He was 66 years old. Mr. Searle, born at Oxford, where he was a classics scholar before attending the Royal College of Music, studied with Anton von Webern in Vienna in 1937-38.

title: Comings and Goings
description: An injured foot has forced Jimmy Connors to default in the opening round of the German Open tennis tournament ... Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini will make the first defense of his World Boxing Association lightweight championship this summer against Ernesto Espana in Pittsburgh or Ohio, according to his manager, David Wolf ... Lupe Pintor of Mexico will defend his World Boxing Council bantamweight title against a Korean, Seung Hoon Lee, on June 3.

title: Your Money; Big Deductible Cuts Premiums
description: WHEN higher premiums for automobile or homeowner's insurance loom, there is a way around them: Insurance costs can be cut by increasing the deductibles.

title: THEATER: A TRIO OF 'BASEBALL WIVES'
description: ''Baseball Wives'' by Grubb Graebner, the new play at the American Renaissance Theater, is a play about the wife of the manager, the wife of the league's Most Valuable Player and the wife of the hot young rookie. The team, incidentally, is the Houston Astros, and in the World Series, presumably with the Yankees, the opposing pitcher is named ''Goose.'' Mr. Graebner is going a long way in this to establish verisimilitude.

title: WITH BRITAIN FIRM, ARGENTINA DEBATES NEXT MOVE
description: Argentine military commanders held a series of meetings here today as reports circulated that Britain had hardened its negotiating position in the crisis over Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands.

title: 'Soul-Searching' by Sampson
description: searching," Sampson said today, "but I have decided to stay for my fourth year.

title: WARSAW MAINTAINS STRIKE CALL FAILED
description: The Polish Government said today that Solidarity's call for a 15-minute general strike and other protest actions on Thursday was a dismal failure and indicated that the people were turning their backs on ''extremists'' out to overthrow Communism.

title: O'Reilly Suspended
description: Terry O'Reilly of the Boston Bruins was scolded by John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, and suspended indefinitely for failing to appear at a May 7 disciplinary hearing in Montreal. Ziegler said O'Reilly's refusal to appear was ''an overt act of defiance.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is always the possibility of a breakdown but of course there is the possibility of a breakthrough.'' - Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, on Falklands negotiations at the United Nations. (4:6.)

title: Bernice Kenyon Gilkyson, 84, Poet and Edtior at Scribner's
