description: Bernice Kenyon Gilkyson, a poet and a former story editor and editorial assistant at Charles Scribner's Sons, died Wednesday at Winsted (Conn.) Memorial Hospital.

title: Stocks Slightly Lower; Airline Issues Up Again
description: Stock prices finished slightly lower yesterday, although several issues fluctuated widely in response to corporate developments. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, ended 1.33 points lower, at 857.78. For the week, the blue-chip barometer fell 11.42 points from last week's close of 869.20.

title: ALEXANDER V. SORENSEN
description: Former Mayor Alexander V. Sorensen of Omaha, who was credited with restoring integrity to a city government racked by scandal in the mid-1960's and for helping initiate downtown redevelopment, died Wednesday. He was 77 years old.

title: New Montreal Team
description: Charles Bronfman, the executive officer of Seagram Distillers and president of the Montreal Expos, may finally have resolved the problems of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League. Yesterday, the C.F.L. awarded Bronfman a new franchise, called The Montreal Football Club and Co. Ltd., after the le got Nelson Skalbania, the owner of the Alouettes, to surrender the franchise. Bronfman has been he awarded all of the Alouette players contracts except those of Vince Ferragamo and Larry Pfohl. Sam Etcheverry, a former Alouette quarterback and coach, was named president and chief executive officer. ... Commissioner Jake Gaudaur of the C.F.L. announced yesterday that a 10th team - from the Halifax-Dartmouth area in Nova Scotia -would be added to the league.

title: Dentsply Plan
description: Dentsply International Inc., a dental products company based in York, Pa., announced its intentions to become a private company by merging into a new corporation.

title: POP: HAIRCUT ONE HUNDRED
description: Today's English pop scene is so consumed by trendiness that groups tend to rise and fall, regardless of their musical merits, according to the season's fashions. But Haircut One Hundred, an English sextet that opened a three-night stand Thursday at the Ritz, has found a way to combat the danger of becoming last month's model by making a cheerfully eclectic pop that blends rap, funk, Beatle-esque nostalgia, salsa and Talking Heads-style yelping into an all-inclusive international style not tied to a single sound.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday, accom- panying an article about narcotics pa- trols off Florida, incorrectly identified military personnel searching private boats off the Bahamas. They were members of the Bahamian Defense Force.

title: News Analysis
description: This week's opinion by the New York Court of Appeals in the case of Cooke v. Morgenthau prompted a sigh of relief from judges and lawyers alike.

title: World Trade Outlook
description: World trade will grow in volume by 2 percent this year after almost no expansion last year, the International Monetary Fund said in a report released here today. The report, presented at meetings of the Interim Committee and other I.M.F. bodies, sees industrial countries' exports rising by 2 percent in 1982 after a 2.7 percent gain in 1981. Imports are projected to rise by 2 percent after falling 2.3 percent last year.

title: WEINBERGER VISITS PLANNED
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will visit military installations in Colorado and Wyoming on Saturday for Armed Forces Day observances, the Pentagon announced today. He is to visit Fort Carson and the North American Aerospace Defense Command in Colorado Springs, and F.E. Warren Air Force Base in Cheyenne, Wyo. He will be principal speaker at the Cheyenne Chamber of Commerce's Armed Forces Day banquet and then return to Washington.

title: Bridge: Stauber's Team Outshines Its Rivals in District Finals
description: If Goliath had survived his encounter with David, he would no doubt have grumbled about the slings of outrageous fortune. One remembers the episode because it is rare indeed for the loser of a fight to be bigger, more experienced and better armed. Whatever the result, the smart money is on Goliath.

title: Connecticut Study Rejects Prison Plan
description: A just-completed study concludes that a plan to renovate several vacant buildings over the next 18 months to house at least 500 Connecticut prison inmates would take too long and cost too much to be feasible.

title: 5 EJECTED, 2 HURT AS TIGERS WIN, 4-2
description: Five players were ejected and two were injured tonight as a result of two fights between the Detroit Tigers and the Minnesota Twins. The Tigers won the game in the 11th inning on Kirk Gibson's two-out, two-run homer.

title:
Patents;
A Device For Missile Guidance
description: WASHINGTON THE Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation of Detroit received a patent this week for electronic equipment that informs spin-stabilized projectiles and missiles of their vertical orientation so that they can respond properly to guidance signals.

title: U.S. GENERAL GOING TO SEOUL
description: President Reagan has named Lieut. Gen. Robert W. Sennewald of the Army to be commander of American forces in South Korea, the Pentagon announced today.

title: NONUNION RIVALS AND DISSENT ARE TROUBLING THE TEAMSTERS
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, once almost impervious to challenges from the trucking industry and from internal opponents, is being confronted by major difficulties.

title: AN APPRECIATION OF NATURE TAKES WING
description: IWAS never an avid nature buff. I get daisies mixed up with blackeyed Susans, know little about rock formations or pond life or cumulus clouds and once mistook a bug with a long stinger for a hummingbird. But last spring, an encounter with the wild in my own backyard gave me a vivid appreciation of the natural world and my own place in it.

title: GASOLINE DECLINE SLOWS
description: Americans are using less gasoline, but recent figures indicate that the decline is slowing. More than 102 billion gallons of gasoline were burned last year, a drop of 2.5 percent from 1980 levels, says the Lundberg Letter, a newsletter that tracks developments in oil and gasoline markets.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Venus Casts A Long Shadow
description: Because scientists generally believe that Venus and Earth started out alike, evidence that Venus, dehydrated by a phenomenon known as the ''runaway greenhouse effect,'' may once have been covered by a ''full terrestrial ocean,'' led to speculation last week that Earth might suffer a similar fate.

title: COS COB STATION A LANDMARK
description: CONRAIL'S Cos Cob power station is being designated a National Historic Engineering Landmark. The designation, made by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers for the ''pioneering achievement'' of the original 1907 electrification system of the railroad's New Haven line, will be officially bestowed at a ceremony Saturday at the Cos Cob train station.

title: Combat Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerusalem
description: To the Editor: How does one square Prof. Sari Nuseibeh's words in ''Jerusalem, Holy City of Islam'' (Travel, April 25) that Islam venerates Jerusalem ''as a city above men, rather than an earthly city that can be conquered by man'' with Islam's actions after the 1949 armistice? On that occasion, it razed every Jewish synagogue except one, including the world-renowned Hurva Synagogue. v. hat kind of veneration was there between 1949 and 1967 when the area in front of the holy Western Wall was used by Islam as a latrine area for animals? Only under Jewish rule have the authorities secured freedom of worship for all Jews, Christians and Moslems, and only now is it governmental policy that all holy shrines be protected and venerated.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: 1919), David McCullough, author of ''The Path Between the Seas,'' tells how a spindly, ailing boy grew into the exuberant, self-confident man who became our 26th President. In the course of it, he pays rewarding attention to Roosevelt's clanlike family - his father a proper blue-blooded New Yorker, his mother a zestful Southern belle. Our reviewer Geoffrey C. Ward called it ''a beautifully told story, filled with fresh detail.'' It won the 1982 American Book Award for Biography.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: PROBLEMS have developed with the air-conditioning units on the county's buses, and county officials say they are working on solutions. One possibility is replacing the windows, which were designed not to open, with sliding windows, so that passengers can at least get fresh air if the air conditioning fails.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THIS WEEK: Unless there is ample rainfall over the weekend, watering will be essential for seedlings, vegetable gardens, young trees and shrubs, perennials and new lawns...Gypsy moth larvae are now vulnerable to Bt, a biological that must be ingested as they feed on young tree leages...Use systemics to prevent leaf miners on holly, birch and columbine...Stake peonies...Clip faded flowers on spring bulbs to prevent energy-wasting seed pods. TOMATO TIME

title: JUDGE'S STATEMENT ON MUSTO
description: NEWARK Following are excerpts from the statement made by Judge H.Lee Sarokin of Federal District Court at the sentencing last week of State Senator William V.Musto, who also is Mayor of Union City, and six co-defendants.

title: THE HOUSE THAT JACK BUILT
description: EAST HAMPTON SPRING'S bounty is apparent everywhere, but it is particularly colorful and abundant on the 22-acre East Hampton estate of the textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen. Unlike most of the angular, modern glass homes in this summer enclave, Mr. Larsen's retreat boasts no sharp architectural lines. It is, in fact, round.

title: The Nation in Summary; Another Judge Knocks Abscam
description: The Government's Abscam investigation - praised by some for ferreting out corrupt politicians, damned by others for unfairly entrapping its victims - took one of its sharpest raps yet last week. Characterizing Abscam as a ''loose cannon rolling around on the deck of the criminal justice system,'' Federal district Judge William B. Bryant overturned the conviction of former Representative Richard Kelly, a Republican from Florida.

title: ROZEMA OUT 60 DAYS
description: Lance Parrish hit a home run into the upper deck of Tiger Stadium with one out in the 10th inning to give the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins today. The victory was the second consecutive extra-inning triumph for the Tigers.

title: JUDGE MOTLEY IS NAMED CHIEF OF COURT FOR SOUTHERN DISTRICT
description: Constance Baker Motley will succeed Lloyd F. MacMahon at the end of this month as chief judge of the Federal District Court that covers Manhattan, the Bronx and six counties north of New York City.

title: Surgery for Delaney
description: Dr. Ronald G. Michels of Baltimore, who last week performed the retina surgery on Leonard, may soon perform the same operation on Joe Delaney, a running back for the Kansas City Chiefs. An examination Friday revealed that Delaney, who rushed for 1,121 yards last season as a rookie from Northwest Louisiana, had a deteched retina in his right eye. Dr. Robert Fletcher of Kansas City said the 23-year-old back might be ready to play again next season. ... Vince Ferragamo, the quarterback whose contract with the Montreal Alouettes was not transferred to the new ownership headed by Charles Bronfman, says he will attend the team's training camp even though he may not be wanted.

title: DESPITE COSTS, ENROLLMENT IS CLIMBING AT PRIVATE DAY SCHOOLS
description: ALTHOUGH increasingly selective and expensive, private day schools in this area are becoming increasingly popular. Enrollment is rising even as the student population at both public and parochial schools in the county is declining, and despite an uncertain economy.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WERE THINGS BETTER IN THE 'GOOD OLD DAYS?'
description: When people discuss "the good old days" they tend to don rose-colored glasses - magnifying the good points and minimizing the bad. Coin collectors, especially, are likely to indulge in selective recall, for the coin market slump of the last two years makes yesteryear seem even more attractive.

title: TRYING TO STEM FANNIE MAE'S LOSSES
description: WASHINGTON DAVID O. MAXWELL concedes he is in a tough spot. As the head of Fannie Mae, the government-sponsored but stockholder-owned mortgage bank, he bears all the woes of the badly battered thrift industry. It's like that crawfish on a railroad track in the story Mr. Maxwell once picked up in the bayous of east Texas.

title: Guyanese Reports Venezuela Called Home Its Ambassador
description: Foreign Minister Rashleigh Jackson said today that Venezuela's ambassador to Guyana has been called home for consultation on the frontier dispute between the two countries.

title: Miss Rush Wins Title
description: Gretchen Rush, an 18-year-old from San Antonio, won the girls' title at the Italian junior tennis championships today by defeating Beth Herr of Dayton, Ohio, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4, in the final.

title: Practical Traveler; WHEN BUZZ SAWS SPOIL A HOLIDAY
description: Sooner or later it happens. You arrive at a distant hotel, eagerly anticipating a carefree vacation, only to find construction workers, scaffolding, cranes, jackhammers and all their attendant noise and dust just outside your balcony door. What can you do about it, and what can you expect of the hotel?

title: FIRST VIOLATORS TO CLEAN SUBWAY CARS GET TO WORK
description: A few weeks ago, 19-year-old Larry Carson was seized by a Transit Authority police officer as he vaulted over a subway turnstile at a station near his Brooklyn home. Yesterday, he and 19 other young fare-beaters and vandals paid for their crimes by removing graffiti from subway car walls.

title: NINTH AVENUE HOLDS A FAIR, AND THOUSANDS EAT IT UP
description: From 37th Street to 57th Street, and from apple cider to zeppole, Ninth Avenue underwent its annual transformation yesterday from neighborhood shopping district to street extravaganza.

title: SMITH A CONTENDER FOR M.V.P.
description: The time to pick the most valuable player in the National Hockey League playoffs was as near today as the Islanders were to the Stanley Cup - one victory away. The three leading candidates were Mike Bossy, Bryan Trottier and Billy Smith of the Islanders.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 16, 1982
description: International British troops returned to the Falklands in force for the first time in six weeks Friday night, destroying Argentine aircraft and military installations in a remote part of the archipelago, the Ministry of Defense reported in London. The attack was described as ''a raid, not an invasion.'' The ministry said the troops returned safely to ships of the British task force with only two ''minor casualties.'' Some Argentine casualties were also reported. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: CRIME
description: John Buxton Hilton's THE GREEN FRONTIER (St. Martin's, $9.95) is somewhat of a departure for this rooted-in-the-30's British mystery writer. True, Detective Superintendent Kenworthy, now retired, is with us. But this is basically a story of World War II, a novel that concerns itself as much with character development (it has a remarkable and redoubtable woman) as with the murder that takes place early on.

title: BRITAIN REPORTS RAID BY ITS TROOPS ON THE FALKLANDS
description: British troops returned in force to the Falkland Islands for the first time in six weeks Friday night, destroying Argentine aircraft and military installations in a remote part of the archipelago, the Ministry of Defense disclosed today.

title: STEPS TO TAKE WHEN FIXING OR REPLACING HOUSE SHINGLES
description: A SPLIT or cracked shingle on the outside of the house does not necessarily have to be replaced with a new one. If there are no sizable pieces missing in the damaged shingle, all that is required in most cases is to drive in a few extra nails on both sides of the crack or split in order to keep the pieces from falling out.

title: Tadashi Sukuki Begins Performances Tuesday
description: Tadashi Suzuki and his theater company, the Waseda Shogekijo, will appear from Tuesday through June 6 in two theaters in adaptations of ''The Trojan Women'' and ''The Bacchae.''

title: Topics; DEMOCRACY, MORE OR LESS; Cable Soap
description: Pitchmen for cable television proudly tout its advantages over the conventional kind: feature films without commercials, culture and children's channels. Still, the supply of distinctive material is not limitless and as cable scrounges to fill its dozens of channels, it drifts uncomfortably close to the undistinguished fare of regular TV.

title: ROBBERS KILL 3 IN QUEENS CLUB
description: Three persons were shot to death and two others were wounded in the holdup of a social club in Jamaica, Queens, last night, according to the police.

title: Lili Gilpatric Married To Kenneth Converse
description: The marriage of Elisabeth Chadbourne Gilpatric, daughter of Marguerite Gilpatric of New York and Chadbourne Gilpatric of Mount Desert, Me., to Kenneth J. Converse took place yesterday in St. Rose Roman Catholic Church in Santa Rosa, Calif. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Converse of Santa Rosa.

title: ELECTION PREVIEW: ONLY IN CALIFORNIA
description: Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr., has given up Zen and outer space for conciliation and a new image. Barry M. Goldwater Jr. is insisting that, notwithstanding the claims of his opponents, he's as smart as his old man. And Maureen Reagan, the eldest daughter of the President, claims that one reason her uncle, Neil Reagan, is opposing her is sibling rivalry.

title: LONDON FEASTS ON AN ARRAY OF TREASURES FROM INDIA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allen Wardwell is director of the Asia Society in New York City. BY ALLEN WARDWELL

title: NEW RIVAL TO HEBREW SCHOOLS
description: COMMACK THE birth of a Hebrew day school in Commack is not being heralded as a blessed event by the family of existing Jewish schools on Long Island. Rather, one facility is worried that the new arrival will drain off prospective students, and another is concerned that it may be forced to close down because of the added competition.

title: Scottish Bishops Urge Pope Not to Cancel Visit to Britain
description: Roman Catholic Church leaders in Scotland have joined in a growing appeal to Pope John Paul II to visit Britain as planned later this month despite the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: NOT JOKING BUT WRITING
description: ME AGAIN Uncollected Writings of Stevie Smith. Illustrated by Herself. Edited by Jack Barbera and William McBrien.Preface by James MacGibbon. 360 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: AT HARVARD, SHE RULES LAMPOONLAND
description: Lisa Henson grew up in a fantasy world inhabited by the likes of Kermit the Frog and the Cookie Monster. She is the eldest child of Jim Henson, creator of the Muppets.

title: IDLE BLACK YOUTHS IN OHIO LOSE HOPE
description: Jawaud Shafeek was graduated from Colonel White High School two years ago and has held just two jobs since then - one as a paper deliverer and one as an actor in a drama produced by a summer youth program.

title: BRINGING BROOKLYN OF THE 1940'S BACK TO LIFE FOR 'THE CHOSEN'
description: Putting the period to a period film is a demanding business, an expensive one, too, that becomes even more challenging if the period is one that lies within the memory of living man. ''The Chosen,'' at the Beekman and Cinema 3, is a case in point, a movie that recalls a Brooklyn of the late 1940's and does so with such fidelity that the tree-lined quiet streets of Williamsburg and the particular Jewish life on them seem to have emerged intact from a just-opened time capsule.

title: Gary R. Donohue to Marry Mary K. Williams on July 3
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Williams of Morris Plains, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary K. Williams, to Gary R. Donohue, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Donohue of Franklin Lakes, N.J. A July 3 wedding is planned.

title: MAY 15, 1941: AND DIMAGGIO'S STREAK BEGINS
description: JUST before the baseball season began in 1941, a bartender in Pittsburgh looked up from behind the bar and saw a man on a stool across from him wearing a Hitler mask. After collapsing on the spot from a heart attack, the bartender moaned to those attending him, ''I saw ruin staring me in the face.''

title: Wrong Teller
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; F.B.I. Arrests 5 Seamen After Boarding Freighter
description: Five crewmen aboard a freighter in the Gulf of Mexico were arrested by Federal agents tonight, after the ship's captain reported that his first officer had been stabbed and tossed over the side, the Coast Guard said.

title: MISSING THE MANY MOODS OF THE DURABLE BILLY WILDER
description: Billy Wilder was honored at the recent Film Society of Lincoln Center gala, and he was eminently deserving of the tribute. But in some respects, he wasn't the ideal honoree. The evening, a black tie event attended by the patrons and benefactors of Lincoln Center, was a program of film clips and testimonials meant to summarize the career of this distinguished veteran director. And it did touch on many important aspects of Mr. Wilder's work, with the possible exception of this one: It's unlikely that any wily, wisecracking character in a Wilder movie would be caught dead, or even straightfaced, at an affair of this kind. For one thing, the prevailing skepticism of his outlook renders Billy Wilder an unusual subject for dewy-eyed testimonial treatment, as does the scope of his career. For another, he has made great films and dreadful ones, large ones and small, films that work delicately and others that are tasteless through and through. This kind of variety isn't easily encapsulated in a single evening's program.

title: New Rules Let States Match Income Data on Food Stamps
description: The Agriculture Department issued rules Friday enabling states to match food stamp applications with records on unemployment compensation and Social Security in order to detect fraud or errors.

title: Topics; DEMOCRACY, MORE OR LESS; Drug Violence
description: In response to community opposition, several Westchester legislators are trying to suffocate the Yorktown Phoenix House drug rehabilitation program. They have introduced legislation to prohibit the state from providing any funds for the program, which it runs jointly with the New York City Board of Education.

title: John Fox Marries Sabrina Sutterlin
description: Sabrina Sutterlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Sutterlin of Harrison, N.Y., and Greenfield, N.H., was married yesterday in the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church to John Stephen Fox, son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Fox of Orlando, Fla. The Rev. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: A Dissent on Jeane Kirkpatrick
description: It is disturbing to see that the United States has clearly abandoned the concept of the United Nations as an organization committed to the common interest of all nations (''Questioning the Value of the United Nations,'' by Bernard D. Nossiter, April 11). United Nations delegate Jeane Kirkpatrick, an able representative of the resurgent cold warriorism that is currently dominating our foreign policy, ignores altogether questions concerning the principles upon which the United Nations was founded.

title: DIOCESE OFFERS DRAFT COUNCELING
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE AYOUNG man, raised in a family atmosphere of deep faith, who attended a Roman Catholic seminary and whose family believes that all life is precious, went to a Catholic priest this year for counseling after he had registered for the draft.

title: GARDENS AND FOOD, WITH A QUARTET
description: ''OUR goal is to offer the most delicious evening of chamber music to be found anywhere in our county,'' says Betty-Jean Hagen, first violinist of the newly formed Westchester String Quartet.

title: U.S. AIDE WARNS OF RISING CHEMICAL WARFARE
description: A State Department official said today that the current use of chemical agents in war -contrary to both international law and practice - could lead to more such warfare if action were not taken immediately to halt it.

title: CHARTING THE CRUISES
description: T he following guide to cruise ships is arranged by destination and primarily covers saltwater cruises. Cruises are also offered on many of the world's major rivers, such as the Mississippi, the Rhine and the Chang Jiang (formerly the Yangtze), but details on these and on most freighter cruises (an exception is Delta Cruise Lines' 100-passenger cargo vessels) are not included. The list, which covers sailings from May 17 to Sept. 30, is the second in a series of four in Travel. The next will appear Sept. 12.

title: Eve Wahrsager Married
description: The marriage of Eve Fierman Wahrsager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Wahrsager of New York City and Pound Ridge, N.Y., to John G. Linn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Linn of Manhasset, L.I., took place yesterday at the Pound Ridge home of the bride's parents. Dr. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony. The bride is a writer. Her husband is with the communications-system division of Bolt, Beranek & Neuman in Cambridge, Mass.

title: A FERVOR OF CREATIVITY GRIPS DEVELOPERS
description: THE city is filling up with office buildings with flared bottoms, p yramid tops, rounded corners and five-sided towers. Mountains of g ranite have been moved to Manhattan. Shiploads of marble have a rrived. When all of these new structures are completed, the city mayh ave so many waterfalls in lobbies and plazas that all it will need i s a man in a barrel to rival Niagara.

title: The Nation in Summary; Delight at the Postal Service
description: Among officials of the Postal Service, the ''swift completion of their appointed rounds'' has usually included frequent trips to Congress, seeking higher postal rates. Not next year, believe it or not.

title: BETTING THE STORE ON ANOTHER TAGAMET
description: THE announcements come out almost faster than the medical journals e valuating them: Company A has a new drug that will help arthritis s ufferers; Company B has another that will alleviate heart disease. T he stock value of the company involved takes off.

title: Susan Joyce, Pianist, In Schumann's Fantasy
description: Susan Joyce, a pianist who made her debut Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall, came well prepared. She had studied with Nadia Reisenberg at both Mannes College of Music and the Juilliard School and then earned a doctorate at the University of Miami, where she continued her piano studies with Ivan Davis.

title: YOUNGBLOOD HOMER CARRIES METS, 6 TO 4
description: Joel Youngblood sparked the Mets to a 6-4 victory over the Dodgers at Shea Stadium last night with a three-run home run in the first inning and persuaded Manager George Bamberger to make a tentative decision on an everyday right fielder.

title: REAGAN PRAISES ARMED FORCES
description: President Reagan paid tribute today to the nation's military personnel as ''the ultimate guardians of our freedom.''

title: ATLANTIC CITY SET FOR A RUNOFF
description: ATLANTIC CITY RESIDENTS of this resort city went to the polls in exceptionally large numbers last week to vote for Mayor for the first time in 70 years, but they will have to do it all over again on June 15.

title: COMMON MARKET HOLDS OFF ON EXTENDING ITS SANCTIONS
description: Delegates from Western Europe's 10 Common Market countries were unable to reach agreement today on a plan to extend sanctions against Argentina in support of Britain in the Falkland conflict.

title: North Korean Agent Shot
description: An armed infiltrator from North Korea was shot dead early today about two miles south of the demilitarized zone, the South Korean Defense Ministry said. Troops were seeking another agent, believed to have infiltrated by sea, the ministry said.

title: Jeri Ellen Riggs Engaged To Peter Adam Gottlieb
description: Mr. and Mrs. David N. Riggs of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeri Ellen Riggs, to Peter Adam Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Gottlieb of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: BALANCHINE AS SONGWRITER
description: It happens this way: Jacques d'Amboise runs into George Balanchine in the elevator at the New York City Ballet. ''What have you got me for this year?'' Mr. d'Amboise asks. ''Come up and I'll play it for you,'' Mr. Balanchine answers. Mr. d'Amboise comes; Mr. Balanchine plays. This year it was a tango, dedicated to beautiful women. Actually, all the songs that Mr. Balanchine writes are about beautiful women; even the song he once dedicated to the Crazy Horse Saloon in Paris had a subtext to it. Mr. d'Amboise uses the songs in the annual benefit gala he holds for his National Dance Institute. Forthrightly, the gala is called the ''Event of the Year.''

title: HARTFORD PARK TO BE IMPROVED
description: HARTFORD'S Bushnell Park, the oldest city-owned park in the country and visited by more than 750,000 people annually, will be getting a $3 million facelift over the next five years. The regrooming will be kicked off on Saturday with a concert designed to rally public support and raise money for the project.

title:
GARDENING;
LAWN WATERING IS OFTEN OVERDONE
description: OVER the last several years much has been written on the subject of lawn care, yet it is not uncommon to see lawns being watered two or three days after a two-and-a-half-inch rain. The same applies to the collection of lawn clippings when mowing. Neither of these practices is necessary or even desirable under normal circumstances.

title: Travel Advisory; BIRDWATCHING, COOKING, WEAVING
description: Two Tours With Taste In Mind

title: ASSAULT ON 'SELF' IN IVY LEAGUE
description: BEFORE my son entered college as a pre-med student, it was my contention that one advantage of attending an Ivy League school was that any student who was accepted was considered to have already demonstrated his potential. I conceived of the Ivy League school as providing a rigorous but protective environment that would actively foster the student's growth.

title: The Conversion of Ronald Reagan
description: Billy Graham and Ronald Reagan turned up a lot of soil last week as, coincidentally, they preached reconciliation to the Kremlin. Moved by public passions about nuclear weapons, the evangelist refined his ideas about religious freedom and the President redefined his view of detente. Mr. Reagan had by far the better script.

title: The Trout of Lake Ontario
description: high concrete wall looking for steelheads in the Black River.

title: GALLUP POLL HAS KENNEDY LEADING DEMOCRATS
description: In the opinion of Democrats across the nation, Senator Edward M. Kennedy easily outdistances all of his potential rivals for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today about the American Bal- let Theater gives an incorrect closing date for its season at the Metropolitan Opera House. It closes June 12.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
From Los Angeles, Vocal Arts Ensemble
description: The Los Angeles Vocal Arts Ensemble, a mixed ensemble of eight players under the direction of the pianist Armen Guzelimian, made its New York debut Thursday at the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodmn House with an all-19th-century program that included Brahms's ''Liebeslieder'' Waltzes (Op. 52) and several sure-fire selections from Rossini's ''Peches de Vieillesse.'' Settings by Schubert and Berlioz were also heard.

title: John Perkins Jr., Miss Doremus Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ellsworth Doremus of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Josephine Doremus, to John Marshall Perkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Perkins of Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: Refuge Adds Acreage
description: The 6,778-acre Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge just grew by 5.3 acres.

title: REAGAN ARMS PLAN CRITICIZED AS RISKY
description: A debate has arisen among Administration experts over whether President Reagan's proposal for reducing strategic nuclear arms would actually increase the risk of nuclear war by heightening the vulnerability of American forces to an attack by the Soviet Union.

title: ON BREAKING LAWS, NOT RULES
description: ISUPPOSE that I'm one of the relatively few who ''made it'' out of Union City. I don't mean geographic escape - that's fairly easy from a city one mile by two miles - but, rather, of the ability to use what was the crucible of my youth to achieve a healthy, successful life.

title: 9 Bodies Found in Salvador In New Outbreak of Violence
description: Nine bullet-riddled bodies were found on the outskirts of the capital Friday in the latest outbreak of political violence in El Salvador, authorities said today.

title: GIVING PERSPECTIVES ON THEN AND NOW
description: ''THOSE who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.'' In the Park Avenue offices of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, where he is a senior vice president and the chief economist, Irwin L. Kellner was quoting the philosopher George Santayana.

title: Best Films on TV
description: Should this Sunday afternoon be a fine, sunny one, chances are few people will stay indoors to watch anything, let alone "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" (1969) at 2:30 P.M. on Channel 5. But those who do will see a treat - an appealing, pungent seriocomic Western, with Paul Newman, Robert Redford and Katherine Ross. The week's latelate schedule throwaways are "Letter From an Unknown Woman," a real beauty, Tuesday at 2 A.M. on Channel 5 and "Shenandoah," a solid Civil War drama also at 2 A.M., Wednesday on Channel 11.

title: Hobart Wins by 22-4, Gains Final in Lacrosse
description: Cal Harris scored four goals and 12 other Hobart players scored as the Statesmen defeated Salisbury State today in lacrosse, 22-4, and reached the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III tournament.

title: EVACUATION PLAN STIRS OLD DOUBTS
description: DURING the years of protest against the building of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, one concern in particular has haunted the people who live in the East End. As picket signs have put it: ''Evacuate - But How?''

title: FASHION
description: Summer Shoes That Are City Slick Summer shoes that are slick enough for the city are often difficult to find. Not so this year.

title: Around the Nation
description: About 20 Ku Klux Klan members who came here to recruit today were shouted down by about 100 protesters at a rally at the Wilmington High School baseball field.

title: A PLACID PASEO IN SAN MIGUEL
description: STEVEN V. ROBERTS is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By STEVEN V.ROBERTS

title: Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: Record Attendance at Fair
description: Officials at the World's Fair here said today that attendence Friday reached a record of 90,224 persons, surpassing the 87,659 who attended the May 1 opening. The officials estimated that by Sunday total attendance would exceed 1 million at the two-week-old exposition.

title: EDWARD VILLELLA: 'DIRECTING DANCE FOR TV CAN BE TERRIFYING'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan reiter is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the dance scene. By SUSAN REITER

title: Around the World; Namibia Plan Workable, U.S. Aide Declares
description: A Western peace plan for South-West Africa, which had been thrown into doubt, can still be carried out on schedule this year, Chester A. Crocker, the American Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said today.

title: Janette Sabety Wed to Mark Shanahan
description: Janette Pari Sabety, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Adrian M. Sabety of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Raymond Shanahan, son of Mrs. Raymond P. Shanahan of Auburn, Mass., and the late Mr. Shanahan. Judge Joseph T. Connolly of the Municipal Court of Glen Ridge, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Sabety home.

title: IN AGE OF TECHNOLOGY, THE THREE R'S ARE NOT ENOUGH
description: America may be on its way to technological illiteracy - with most of its citizens unable to think and function effectively in an increasingly complex technical society.

title: Washington; BEFORE THE BATTLE
description: There are probably only a few days left now before Britain and Argentina either withdraw their forces from the Falkland Islands or fight a war neither of them wants. In this critical period, there have been some interesting developments:

title: Mailbox; Carlisle College Case Not a Valid Analogy
description: To the Sports Editor: Jack Newcombe's ''Carlisle Was a College Team With a Professional Approach'' (The New York Times, May 2) was a very interesting article. No one can find fault with his attacking the overcommercialization and the erosion of amateur standards existing in college football today.

title: RISE IN TUITIONS SIGNALS SHIFT ON COLLEGE COSTS TO STUDENTS
description: Another round of hefty tuition increases at colleges and universities around the country has ushered in the era of the $50,000 bachelor's degree. It has also suggested that educators and legislators are moving to shift a greater percentage of the cost of higher education onto students.

title: Susan-Margaret Pflugfelder Is a Bride
description: Susan-Margaret Allen Pflugfelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John George Pflugfelder of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Kenneth Vincent Lamb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gerard Lamb, also of Pelham Manor. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of Christ the Redeemer by the Rev. David Hoag, the rector, and the Rev. Francis Boyle, pastor of Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church, also in Pelham Manor.

title: A FRESHMAN VIEW OF THE ASSEMBLY
description: THE new kid on the block enjoys one advantage: a fresh view of the territory. As a freshman Assemblyman, I've been taking a close look at state government, checking out my preconceived notions. Like many of you, I confess, my idea of things in Trenton was rather hazy.

title: Guest Observer By L.R. Shannon Saving Al-Zalfador
description: L.R. Shannon is an editor in The Times's Travel Section. Russell Baker, the Sunday Observer, is on vacation. At one of the President's first news conferences, a reporter questioned him about El Salvador. The President -with so much on his mind -replied that the Secretary of State was formulating a policy on that, but we sure were not going to allow Reds to take over in this hemisphere, or in any of the others.

title: RULING ON DETENTION OF HAITIANS EXPECTED AS MIAMI SUIT CONCLUDES
description: Civil libertarians who filed a civil suit seeking to free 2,200 Haitians from Federal detention had their say in court on Friday. In closing arguments, they characterized the detention policy as ''arbitrary, capricious and an abuse of discretion.''

title: The World in Summary; Pretoria's Plan Satisfies Few
description: As expected, South Africa's long-advertised plan for constitutional reform, issued last week, would do nothing for blacks. It would also make the system less democratic for the ruling white minority.

title: Emily Saxe Wed To Mark Nydam
description: Emily Saxe and Mark Allen Nydam were married yesterday at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., by the Rev. Dr. J. Scottie Griffin.

title: IN AUDIO AS IN BASEBALL, THE OUTCOME HANGS ON THE PROPER PITCH
description: If Ludwig von Beethoven could hear a modern performance of his music (assuming he returned to this world with his hearing intact) he would probably throw one of his famous fits. Whatever the merits of the performance, it would seem to him consistently off pitch.

title: GAMBLING ON GAMBITS
description: To escape the close arm-wrestling that characterizes so much contemporary positional play, it is necessary to venture out to the wild frontier of the new gambits.

title: ITALIAN REGION RECOILS AT IDEA OF ATOM PLANT
description: In this rustic region of Apulia, on the inside of Italy's heel, a land of heady wine and heavy olive oil, the possible coming of a nuclear power plant has turned ageless languor into agitation that has surprised not only the authorities but the people themselves.

title: NO CLEAR REASONS OR REMEDIES FOR THOSE HIGH INTEREST RATES
description: When President Reagan met with leading commercial bankers and investment managers last week, he told them privately what he has often said publicly - and again at Thursday's press conference. He and his advisers don't understand why interest rates have remained so high and they want the financial community's help in bringing them down.

title: Worthy Turning Pro
description: A day after Ralph Sampson of Virginia had announced that he would not make himself available for the National Basketball Association college draft, another junior from the Atlantic Coast Conference, James Worthy of North Carolina, declared that he would turn pro next season.

title: GROWTH WORKSHOP ATTRACTING SINGLES
description: MORE than 100 single people sat in pairs on the gymnasium floor at the Mid-Island Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association, laughing, gesturing and telling one another ''how wonderful'' they were. They were under the direction of Dr. William Simon, a psychotherapist and lecturer who was leading a personal-growth workshop on ''Self-Esteem, Sex and Romantic Love.''

title: CHARGES OF CORRUPTION WORRY SRI LANKA PARTY
description: Although national elections are still more than a year away, the ruling United National Party appears deeply concerned over opposition charges that corruption is rampant in the country.

title: WOMAN IS WINNER IN WRESTLING RING
description: LITCHFIELD AFTER struggling for a hold, the wrestler found an opening, clamped on a headlock and brought the challenger down to the mat with a thud. The winner stood up, arms raised in a gesture of victory, and noted with pleasure the proud smiles of her husband and two children.

title: VARSITY PATROL KEEPS PEACE AT MIAMI SCHOOL
description: In football season, Fredrick Walker is a rugged blocker whose job is clearing away tacklers for Miami Norland High School running backs.

title: Shame, Ma Bell
description: To the Business Editor: The comments by chairman Charles L. Brown at A.T.& T.'s annual meeting concerning the proposed antitrust settlement, ''Ma Bell Speaking'' (April 25), are misleading in many respects. No matter how A.T.& T. attempts to sugarcoat it, to me this was not a settlement; it was an unintended collapse of the purpose of the antitrust suit.

title:
GARDENING;
LAWN WATERING IS OFTEN OVERDONE
description: OVER the last several years much has been written on the subject of lawn care, yet it is not uncommon to see lawns being watered two or three days after a two-and-a-half-inch rain. The same applies to the collection of lawn clippings when mowing. Neither of these practices is necessary or even desirable under normal circumstances.

title: BOARD'S VOTE REFLECTS SPLIT ON PBC CLEANUP PROJECT
description: The first siting board for a hazardous-waste facility ever appointed in New York has approved a site in Washington County for a $26.7 million project to bury sediment laden with polychlorinated biphenyls.

title: MORE BUSINESSES FAILING
description: WHENEVER Philip Segneri passes the vacant spot on the Post Road in Westport where his restaurant, La Normandie, stood for the past 14 years, he avoids dwelling on the painful fact that the business he was forced to shut down in February is now no more than a pile of rubble, dust and memories.

title: Betsy Carlson Married To Jonathan Stapleton
description: Betsy Maywood Carlson, daughter of Mrs. Kenneth C. Carlson of Menominee, Mich., and the late Kenneth C. Carlson, was married yesterday to Jonathan Carroll Stapleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Stapleton of Little Compton, R.I. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: REAGAN FAVORS UNADJUSTED FIGURES ON JOBLESS
description: President Reagan, in an effort to put a better face on the unemployment rate, has said in recent trips outside Washington that unemployment actually declined in March and April. The reported statistics from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed the unemployment rate rising to 9 percent in March and to 9.4 percent in April, the highest rate since 1941.

title: No Headline
description: Rebecca West's significance does not derive from the man she lived with or the son she bore. In her 90th year, this distinguished writer deserves a more fitting homage. NANCY MILFORD, New York City, MARY GORDON, New Paltz, N.Y., SUSAN BROWNMILLER, New York City

title: HOW MILITANT FEMMINISTS ARE KILLING THE E.R.A.
description: IN THE last eight years or so, I have found myself cast in the very unwelcome role of adversary to the loudly proclaimed, but very deceptive, women's movement. And it looks like we ''adversaries'' are about to accomplish what many, I suspect, find rather unforgivable: stopping passage of the equal rights amendment.

title: Judith F. Rivkin Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Judith Florence Rivkin to George Peabody Davison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Davison of Locust Valley, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Rivkin of New York, parents of the future bride.

title: HISTORY LIVES IN '1776' PRODUCTION
description: WHEN ''1776'' opened on Broadway in 1969, no one seemed to be waiting for it. The invitational press list, which is usually divided into two nights - first night for television critics and daily newspapers; the second night for weekly papers and monthly magazines - was combined to fill the house for the opening. What followed turned out to be a smash hit that ran for 1,217 performances and won the Drama Critics Circle Award, plus five Tony awards.

title: THE FILM ANNIE SPEAKS HER MIND
description: If there is a perfect 10 in the movies today, it may be Aileen Quinn, a little girl who seems as though she was born to be just that age. She will be 11 in a month, and right now, with her turned-down white anklets, turned-up snub nose, hailstorm of freckles and chubby cheeks, Aileen is quite simply, the epitome of kid: friendly, full of fidgets, with a patina of precocity over a personality that is pure child.

title: STUDENTS CLIMB FOR DIPLOMAS
description: TO earn their diplomas on May 24, two undergraduates of Yale University will have to climb the 200-foot Harkness Tower and put up a banner there.

title: 'All Can Be Taught To Communicate'
description: ''This is the way she is and this is the way she'll always be'' is true for the young autistic child if she continues to be educated by those unfamiliar with techniques proven to be successful in the education of the autistic. Scholarly journals such as the Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders publish research studies demonstrating the success of structured and consistent behavioral approaches to the education of the autistic.

title: Mailbox; The Finesse Is Gone From Pro Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor: George Vecsey has told the truth behind the ''Seamy Side of Hockey'' (The New York Times, May 10th). Ice hockey was once a fast, exciting game of finesse. Today, the rules and penalties are structured and instituted to allow far too much ''dirty'' hockey.

title: Miss Deegan Wed To Keith Haurie
description: Maura Catherine Deegan, a network account supervisor with the MaGavern Guild Company, a New York concern that represents radio stations for the advertising industry, was married yesterday to Keith A. Haurie, a senior financial analyst with McGraw-Hill Inc., in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nicholas Youpa in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Perth Amboy, N.J.

title: Postings; LURING SHOPPERS
description: Almost as well known in Brooklyn as the intersection of Bedford and Stuyvesant Streets is that of Fulton Street and Nostrand Avenue - another hub of the Bedford-Stuyvesant community and only two blocks from the headquarters of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: The Real Thing In the High School of Performing Arts, on 46th Street a few meters east of Times Square, creativity abounds. A fictional look into the institution was provided by ''Fame,'' first as a movie and than as a television series.

title: CLARINET: RUTKOWSKI PRESENTS CENTRAL EUROPEAN PROGRAM
description: Joseph Rutkowski's evening of clarinet music at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday was a Central European one. There was recent music from Poland, then Karel Husa's ''Evocations of Slovakia'' for clarinet, viola and cello and finally 19th-century pieces by Weber and Brahms.

title: 4 Hurt by Bomb in Teheran
description: Four Iranians were slightly injured when a bomb exploded in a mosque south of Teheran today. The official Iranian press agency said the bomb, which was left in a handbag, exploded in the reception office of the Iman Khomeini Mosque just before the weekly meeting of the 500-member Islamic Bazaar Association.

title: Do Unto Others...
description: To the Business Editor: Although I am an American, I live and work in Canada and am wellacquainted with the National Energy Program, of which Professor MacAvoy speaks so harshly. There is considerable debate in Canada over the merits and long-term value of the N.E.P.; and although there may be legitimate grounds for criticism of the program, it is unfortunate that Professor MacAvoy's article is, in part, factually incorrect.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR OFFER VIEWS
description: WITH state spending and state taxes expected to be continuing issues in Connecticut's gubernatorial campaign this year, the major party candidates for Governor were asked by The New York Times to respond to the following questions on the state's fiscal affairs:

title: A Correction
description: The site of the antiques show sponsored by the Bergen County Historical Society was incorrectly reported last week. It will be held today at the Steuben House, Main Street and Old New Bridge Road, River Edge. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and the admission of $2.50 includes house tours.

title: Soviet Space Lab Activated
description: Anatoly Berezovoy and Valentin Lebedev activated systems aboard the new orbiting Soviet space station Salyut-7 today, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, reported. The report said the astronauts adjusted the life support, power, temperatureregulating and radio communication systems. They were sent into space Thursday and the next day became the first astronauts to board the space laboratory, which was sent up last month.

title: WEAPONS DEALERS TO THE WORLD, TAKE NOTE!
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline Astrid Bruzelius Is Married
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Redding Ridge, Conn., yesterday Caroline Astrid Bruzelius, daughter of Mrs. Eugene A. Pharr of Redding, Conn., and the late Axel S. Bruzelius, was married to Robert Weldon Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Weldon Wallace of Baltimore. The Rev. Randall Giddings performed the ceremony.

title: GORDON SMILEY, A DRIVER, KILLED AT INDY
description: Gordon Smiley was killed early this afternoon when his race car veered directly into the wall during a practice lap before an attempt to qualify for the May 30 Indianapolis 500.

title: HERO AND HEROINES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Cathleen Schine is a writer living in New York. WHAT DO WOMEN WANT? By Dan Greenburg. 414 pp. New York: Wyndham Books. $14.95. DECEPTIONS By Judith Michael. 472 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95. By CATHLEEN SCHINE

title: A'S HALT YANKEES' STREAK
description: The four-game winning streak of the Yankees, their longest of the season, came to an end today when the Oakland A's scored four runs in the first inning off Rudy May and went on to a 7-3 victory.

title: IN SEARCH OF ANCIENT SECRETS
description: ARCHETYPES The Persistence of Unifying Patterns. By Elemire Zolla. 140 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95.

title: Susan Blizzard Is Bride of Dr. David R. Halleran
description: Susan Lynn Blizzard and Dr. David Ros Halleran were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle. The Rev. Joseph Flynn performed the ceremony

title: Julia Moran, Is the Bride Of Art Dealer
description: Julia Clarice Moran, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Moran of Latrobe, Pa., was married there yesterday to Robert Claverhouse Graham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Graham of St. Croix, United States Virgin Islands, and Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Robert Reed Vogelsang performed the ceremony in the Unity Chapel of the Presbyterian Church.

title: Interns Suggested As Class Aides
description: This is in reply to the anonymous teacher of autistic youngsters: As a psychotherapist as well as mother of an autistic son, two things stood out for me in your article: about one autistic youngster who has made progress, you wrote, ''When she's absent, I'm devastated and depressed.'' Any teacher, or other helping professional, whose own emotional state is dependent upon a patient or student needs to either develop greater inner resources and professionalism, or another career.

title: FARMS YIELD NEW CROP: RACE HORSES
description: RIVERHEAD BREEDERS of thoroughbred horses are fencing in farmland on the Island's North Fork at a brisk pace. Far from being alarmed, most local officials applaud the coming of the horse farms - unimagined a decade ago - as a highly favorable development.

title: SENATE QUESTIONS SEA-LAW NEGOTIATOR ON LOBBYING
description: Three members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have criticized James L. Malone, the chief Law of the Sea negotiator for the United States, for lobbying in behalf of a former client for an $850 million loan from the Export-Import Bank.

title: A POTPOURRI OF PERSONAL TREASURES
description: It won't be a show that dealers will fly in for and there will be no great names in collecting to bandy about. And, if the rule about antiques being objects made by hand at least a hundred years ago is to be invoked, few pieces will qualify. Still, many are rare and almost all are, for their owners, irreplaceable - hence the title ''The Object of My Affection.''

title: MUBARAK URGES NURTURING OF DEMOCRACY
description: President Hosni Mubarak called on Egyptians today to safeguard the country's nascent democracy ''against those who exploit it,'' an allusion to Moslem fundamentalists who advocate the abolition of Egypt's present Government.

title: GILBERT WARNS N.H.L.
description: Peter Gilbert, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, predicted yesterday that by Tuesday New Jersey would have a National Hockey League team owned fully or partly by him, or someone else, or the league would face a lawsuit.

title:
DINING OUT;
GREEK SURPRISE NORTH OF THE BORDER
description: THE Greek word kafenio means a bistro or gathering place where patrons sip coffee and while away the hours in conversation or games of backgammon. While Kafenio Among the Flowers in Pearl River (just across the New York State line) is pleasantly informal enough to invite lingering, it would be a pity to while away a great deal of time here without indulging in some of restaurant's delicious Greek food.

title: Pirates Drop Griffin
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates have released the pitcher Tom Griffin and signed the free-agent infielder Ken Reitz. Griffin, 34 years old, was acquired from San Francisco last December in a trade for the first baseman Doe Boyland, and was 1-3 in six appearances this season.

title: Durer Discovery
description: The church was reported on the brink of fiscal disaster when its rector noticed hanging in the chapel a dusty old print signed ''Albrecht Durer, 1493.'' A check showed the print to be genuine.

title: I am a former Harlem teacher (Public School 184), and Robert Curvin's article recalled an event that took place on Feb. 11, 1949.  My sixth-grade students had prepared a dramatization of ''Freedom Road'' for the celebration of Negro History Week. By a unanimous vote, the class decided it wanted Jackie Robinson and Roy Campanella to be part of the celebration. The students sent them an invitation and both came!
description: Three decades later, the glow of their visit and participation has not dimmed. ALICE CITRON West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: JERSEY STUDY FINDS AIRBORNE CARCINOGENS IN 3 CITIES
description: A new air-pollution study in three New Jersey cities has detected airborne chemicals that have been found to cause cancer and genetic mutations, but scientists in the project say there is insufficient data to establish the degree of health risk.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TELL ME IF THE LOVERS ARE LOSERS. By Cynthia Voight. 241 pp. New York: Atheneum. $10.95. (Ages 11 to 15) By KATHLEEN LEVERICH

title: 'MARCO POLO'--ITALIAN ELEGANCE AWASH IN AMERCIAN SUDSINESS
description: The key to understanding ''Marco Polo'' can be found at the very top of the credit lists: The Procter & Gamble Company presents a RAI Radiotelevisione Production. American soap opera is joining forces with Italian sumptuousness and the result, as visually stunning as it is often textually ludicrous, is the 10-hour mini-series that begins on NBC tonight, from 8 to 11, and concludes with another three-hour installment on Wednesday. The Monday and Tuesday presentations will each run for two hours.

title: SIDING WITH BRITAIN WAS A U.S. MISTAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: COS COB POWER STATION IS NAMED AN ENGINEERING LANDMARK
description: CONRAIL'S Cos Cob power station is being designated a National Historic Engineering Landmark. The designation, made by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, is for the ''pioneering achievement'' of the original 1907 electrification system of the railroad's New Haven line. It will be bestowed at a ceremony Saturday at the Cos Cob train station.

title: BACK TO 1782
description: Seventy-four-year-old Phineas Meigs was reportedly the last Connecticut soldier to die in one of the last battles of the Revolutionary War, a little-known skirmish that took place in Madison 200 years ago this month. The residents will commemorate the event with a reenactment beginning at 1:15 P.M. next Sunday, following an encampment of uniformed troops and their families on the green Saturday.

title: HOBOKEN GROUPS JOIN TO FIGHT ARSON
description: HOBOKEN THREE community groups have called on Mayor Steve Cappiello to establish a comprehensive program to stop the wave of arson that has left 27 persons dead and many more homeless here since last October.

title: BRANIFF'S CLIPPED WINGS
description: Braniff, after three years of heavy losses, is grounded. On Wednesday, all flights were suspended, employees were told to take their belongings home.

title: COAL- THE OTHER GLUT
description: COAL, dangerous to mine, awkward to handle and dirty to burn, was on the comeback trail. In the anxious days following the 1979 Iranian oil shock, a new generation of coal entrepreneurs scoured Appalachia, mining companies rushed to open new seams and pits, an export market flowered as Europe searched for alternatives to oil, and in Washington, decision

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Chesis-Cutler Duo, Flutist and Harpist
description: The Chesis-Cutler Duo's flute and harp performances last Sunday at the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House were clean, spirited and, at times, musically sophisticated.

title: Goldin Sued by a Construction Union on Contracts
description: Harrison J. Goldin, New York City's Comptroller, has been accused in a civil lawsuit of improperly helping the city's major union of electrical workers monopolize city contracts for electrical installation and repair.

title: A Dissent on Jeane Kirkpatrick
description: It is disturbing to see that the United States has clearly abandoned the concept of the United Nations as an organization committed to the common interest of all nations (''Questioning the Value of the United Nations,'' by Bernard D. Nossiter, April 11). United Nations delegate Jeane Kirkpatrick, an able representative of the resurgent cold warriorism that is currently dominating our foreign policy, ignores altogether questions concerning the principles upon which the United Nations was founded.

title: Topics Democracy, More or Less
description: Uncle Sugar's Sugar

title: PROPOSED YONKERS BUDGET RELIES ON UNCONFIRMED STATE AID
description: City officials proposed a $222 million budget today that relies on $16.4 million in new taxes and $11.3 million in unconfirmed state aid to close a $27.7 million gap.

title: 8 CHINESE MENUS TO CHOOSE FROM
description: NO restaurant on the Island has a menu quite like the one at Dynasty in Roslyn. Inside a small, attractive folder is a collection of mini-menus, one for each category or course - appetizers and soups, poultry, seafood and so forth; eight in all. This arrangement can make ordering rather interesting, especially if each member of a party of four or six selects a dish from a different menu for all to share.

title: Sports Quiz Answers
description: 1, Earl (of bowling and football); 2, Edd; 3, Albie; 4, Espo; 5, Curve; 6, Doc; 7, Erne; 8, Base; 9, Magic (Johnson); 10, Don.

title: Street Narcotics
description: With swarms of pushers selling narcotics openly in New York City's streets and office workers in Wall Street and mid-Manhattan among their steady customers, the police set up a Narcotics Street Enforcement

title: Museum Exhibit
description: It has been a long time since the Newark Museum devoted a major exhibit to the state's outdoors.

title: LAKERS GAIN FINAL ON SWEEP OF SPURS
description: It was not easy to hear what Bob McAdoo was saying to a television reporter at midcourt after the Los Angeles Lakers had defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 128-123, tonight. But his actions spoke loudly.

title: NEW TRANSLATIONS OF THE BIBLE FOCUS ON MODERN RENDERINGS
description: Two new translations of writings sacred to Jews and Christians have been announced, one by the Jewish Publication Society and the other by an independent Christian translator.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE town trucks came the other morning and took away my old living room furniture. It had been sitting on the curb looking even shabbier than it did in the living room - so shabby and torn that people in pickup trucks piled with others' discards would slow down, look it over and drive on, shaking their heads. Even the junk dealers didn't want my furniture.

title: CITIZENS' ACTIVISM GAINING IN NATION
description: When Women Against Military Madness staged a march for nuclear disarmament here last weekend, about 4,000 people from such diverse groups as unions, churches and the American Indian Movement joined in.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: AFLOTILLA of boats decorated in red, white and blue streamers will open dedication ceremonies in Bay Head at noon on Memorial Day for a wildlife refuge in the middle of Twilight Lake. The decision to create the refuge was made by civic-minded citizens five years ago, and the $40,000 needed to build the island was donated by private contributors over the years.

title: REACTION OF YOUTHS TO ILLNESS WEIGHED
description: THE topic was the impact of family illness on children, and Dr. Carole S. Schaffer, medical director of the Children's Service at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center, told the audience:

title: Rebellion at Harvard
description: Members of the Harvard football team have written to The Crimson, the student newspaper, criticizing Coach Joe Restic.

title: Baryshnikov's Brilliance
description: A remark by Joseph Brodsky, quoted in Deborah Trustman's ''Turning Point for Baryshnikov'' (April 11), deserves comment. Of Baryshnikov, Brodsky says, ''He is a dancer.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Women's Work? ''The recruiters lie like nobody's business,'' says Joan Churchill, a filmmaker. ''These women have no idea what they are going to go through.''

title: Shoreham Opponents: No Demonstrations
description: The New York Times has incorrectly identified the Shoreham Opponents Coalition as a group that has organized demonstrations at the Shoreham nuclear plant. Further, the May 2d article describing the principals in Shoreham's licensing hearings stated that the coalition's tactics have ''included trespassing for which members were arrested.''

title: Events Calendar
description: Today - Nyack Street Fair, along Main Street and South Broadway, Nyack, N.Y. 250 dealers in arts, crafts and antiques.

title: FRANKFURT IN THE AGE OF GOETHE WAS A GOOD PLACE FOR ART
description: Quite possibly the most distinguished person who ever bid at an auction sale was Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, who on Aug. 13, 1764, spent quite a tidy sum of money at a house sale in Frankfurt-on-Main. As he was only 14 years old at the time, he must have made quite an impression. (He was bidding on his father's behalf, by the way). But there is no reason to suppose that he saw his activity as in any way unusual. ''From childhood onwards,'' he wrote later, ''I had lived much among painters, and I was used to looking at every object in the context of art, as they did. Wherever I looked, a picture formed itself before my eyes. And whenever I saw something that gave me particular pleasure, I tried to hold fast to it by drawing it, no matter how awkwardly.''

title: Christina Rice Married To Michael J. Connelly
description: Christina Rice, director of finance for the Comsat General Corporation in Washington, a subsidiary of the Communications Satellite Corporation, was married yesterday to Michael J. Connelly, a vice president of the Foster Management Company, a venture-capital firm in Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the couple's home in Washington by Judge Ruth Bader Ginsberg of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: COURT UPHOLDS M.T.A. DEAL ON JAPANESE CARS
description: A legal challenge by a state labor leader to New York's purchase of 325 subway cars from a Japanese manufacturer has been dismissed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: CAMPUSES PREPARE FOR COMMENCEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH seniors at some colleges and universities in the state are putting in long hours at their campus libraries these days, finishing term papers and cramming for finals, others -their degree requirements completed - have caught that almost traditional ailment called ''senioritis.''

title: L.I.U., ST. JOHN'S BEATEN
description: New York Tech eliminated Long Island University, 5-4, and topseeded Seton Hall handed St. John's its first defeat, 6-4, in the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey Regional baseball tournament at St. John's yesterday.

title: GIBSON NOW FACES NEW, TOUGH FIGHT
description: WITH the failure of any of the four candidates in last Tuesday's mayoral election to win, the incumbent, Kenneth A. Gibson, has his work cut out for him.

title: GERMANS WORK TO RID TEXTS OF ERRORS ON JEWS
description: Jews and Christians are working together in West Germany to remove incorrect information about Judaism from German textbooks on religion and politics, according to two speakers at the American Jewish Committee annual meeting in New York City last week.

title: A Case Study at Harvard Law
description: The study of the law was for ages a practical affair. An aspiring lawyer usually learned as an apprentice by clerking in a law office.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Messages for Missionaries
description: The effort to win Christian converts in distant lands is nearly as old as Christianity itself. But last week, missionaries and church leaders suggested that for North American missionaries there may be no frontiers for such conquests left.

title: FILIPINOS TURN BACK FROM GREEN REVOLUTION
description: Two decades after the Green Revolution arrived here, its miracles in high-yield cereal and vegetable production have lost their luster, and Philippine specialists are conducting a nationwide search for indigenous varieties that have become scarce.

title: Miss Hagen Wed To John LeDuc
description: Laura Jean Hagen and John Andre LeDuc, Washington lawyers, were married yesterday in St. John the Baptist Roman Catholic Church in Waunakee, Wis. The pastor, the Rev. Elmer J. Dietzel, performed the ceremony.

title: STILL AT SEA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. AT a tapered table on the 38th floor of United Nations headquarters, Javier Perez de Cuellar labored last week to break the world body's unbroken string of conspicuous nonsuccesses. Both literally and figuratively, he was at the center of the tortuous diplomatic effort to end the fighting over the Falklands and lead Argentina and Britain to direct talks that would settle the question of the islands' ultimate rule.

title: WHEN THERE'S A LEAP FROM JUNK TO ART
description: GLEN COVE WHILE many artists look to the world at large for their subject matter, examining and interpreting aspects of the environment outside their homes and studios, others are captivated by their own intimate surroundings. Their work, whether autobiographical in content or ideosyncratic in its use of materials, is essentially a private domain where both imagery and process reflect an inward-looking, subjective sensibility.

title: DOMINICANS TO ELECT PRESIDENT TODAY
description: A raucous campaign for President ended here Friday night with one candidate calling for a ''new generation'' of leadership and another saying that he was virtually blind but that he had ''abundant faculties'' to run the country.

title: ON THE NURTURING OF THE PLAYWRIGHT
description: To the Editor:$

title: A 'ROADEO' FOR BUS DRIVERS
description: THERE won't be any calf roping or bull riding next Saturday when the ''roadeo'' comes to Milford, but the contestants will be riding something that many people consider tougher to handle than a bucking bronco: a 35-foot, two-ton passenger bus.

title: A SECOND OPINION
description: A SECRET SYMMETRY Sabina Spielrein, Between Jung and Freud. By Aldo Carotenuto. Translated by Arno Pomerans, John Shepley, Krishna Winston. 250pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: A DIFFERENT DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CUTS LIMITING DAY CARE FOR POOR
description: Federal budget cuts in child-care programs have forced public daycare centers in New York City to serve one less meal and snack a day, lower their nutritional standards and raise their fees, according to city officials and day-care administrators.

title: FOOD
description: THE CLASSIC CAPER lthough many herbs and spices normally play what might be called a ''grace note'' role in a dish, there are occasions when one of these so-called minor or minimally used flavorings is given a starring part, or at least becomes integral to the ''classic'' composition of a dish.

title: RATING COMPOUNDS MICHIGAN TROUBLES
description: An announcement that Michigan's credit rating had been reduced to the lowest in the nation has only aggravated the state's problems of a slumping automobile industry, a deepening recession and 15 percent unemployment.

title: Paying Congress
description: To the Business Editor: I read Andy Ireland's ''Congress: You Get What You Pay For'' (May 2) with a great deal of ambivalence. On the one hand I felt that it was almost criminal that the Congress, as Representative Ireland inferred, expected contributions to various political action committees, or PAC's, in return for favorable votes.

title: THE PROFIT MOTIVE
description: The master-point scheme, which allows players to accumulate points and build toward the rank of life master, has been outstandingly successful from the point of the view of the American Contract Bridge League. In the 44 years since clubs began awarding fractional points, and largely because of them, the national body has developed into a highly efficient organization with strong finances.

title: A BOTTLE STORED IS A BOTTLE EARNED
description: very wine enthusiast occasionally experiences the overwhelming urge to establish his own cellar, to create a storage area to house bottles awaiting maturity, to build a place for the bargains discovered in shops or on trips to the vineyards. The desire is not easily suppressed, for wine storage usually makes good economic sense and can add to the total wine experience.

title: DECARAVA--A HIGHLY PERSONAL VIEW OF THE WORLD
description: In the 35 years that Roy DeCarava has been photographing, he has not received an inordinate amount of attention. So it is especially satisfying that we now have not one but two retrospective accounts of his career to consider: a 129-print exhibition at Witkin Gallery (41 East 57th Street, through June 5) and an elegant monograph, ''Roy DeCarava: Photographs,'' published by the Friends of Photography, Carmel, Calif. ($39.50). The work in the exhibition, from the years 1948 to 1980, is arranged more or less thematically; the book's 82 reproductions represent approximately the same time span in chronological order.

title: THE WOOSTER GROUP STIRS CONTROVERSY WITH AN AVANT-GARDE SERIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Don Shewey writes frequently about the performing arts. BY DON SHEWEY

title: M. HARVEY TAYLOR, G.O.P. LEADER
description: M. Harvey Taylor, a political leader credited with influencing the selection of Pennsylvania Republican gubernatorial candidates from 1934 to 1966, died early today. He was 20 days short of his 106th birthday.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: House

title: VISITING ETRUSCAN HILL TOWNS
description: HENRY TANNER is a Times correspondent based in Paris. BY HENRY TANNER

title: Magna Foundation Plans Concert Series
description: The Aston Magna Foundation for Music in Great Barrington, Mass., will mark its 10th anniversary season during the first three weekends of July.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Pope Escapes Another Attack
description: The irony was no less dark for being evident. The Pope's trip to the Shrine of Fatima in Portugal was a pilgrimage of gratitude for his recovery from a wound inflicted by a bullet fired exactly a year earlier.

title: 2 Relays Won by Jefferson
description: The sprint-relay team of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn took two victories today in the 42d annual Eddy Games on the new Union College track here. The quartet of Roger Hunter, Bradley Henry, Adrian Spooner and Rick Amezquita won the 400-meter event in 42.99 seconds and the 1,600-meter event in 3 minutes 19.50 seconds.

title: Siberian Crane Hatched
description: The second Siberian crane to be bred in captivity has been hatched at the International Crane Foundation. A spokesman said the chick, hatched Thursday night, was named Gandhi after Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, because of her interest in preserving the birds.

title: No Headline
description: A recipe on page 100 of The Times Magazine today, for Salade de filets de poisson aux capres, was garbled by a misplacement of type. The last 17 lines of the food article, beginning ''watercress and lettuce,'' should have followed the phrase ''endive leaves'' in instruction 1.

title: Anti-Dumping Drive
description: The tiny oceanfront community of Seaside Park has accumulated some 10,000 signatures on a petition to stop ocean dumping off New Jersey.

title: Michigan Bank Fails; 17th to Collapse in '82
description: A 10-year-old Michigan bank was declared insolvent today, becoming the 17th in the United States to collapse this year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

title: Miss Potter Has Bridal
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass., yesterday Nathalie Appleton Potter, a vice president and associate general counsel of E.F. Hutton & Company in New York, was married to Richard A. Maio, a first vice president and national product manager with E.F. Hutton. The Rev. Russell Dewart, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Postings; OFFICE DISTRICT
description: Until it closed in 1954, the carriage-trade elegance of Wanamaker's department store on East 9th Street drew uptowners as well as Greenwich Villagers. A 1956 fire destroyed the north building but the south one, 770 Broadway, has become an office center, with United States Trust, American Express and General Motors as major tenants.

title: WHEN A NICE VIEW ISN'T ENOUGH
description: WESTPORT A DINING room with a compelling view is always a winner, right? Well, not quite always. At the Cafe de la Plage, on the Sound overlooking Old Mill Beach in Westport, the water view does its best, no matter what the season, and almost makes one forget some rather serious flaws in the cuisine.

title: IL DUCE AS A POVER' UOMO
description: MUSSOLINI By Denis Mack Smith. 429 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: ONGAIS: HARD-EARNED EDGE
description: INDIANAPOLIS IT seems as if they are all back at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, right where they were a year ago: the drivers and crews, the racing fans and the corporate sponsors, the T-shirt salesmen and sun worshippers, the coherent, semicoherent and incoherent. It seems that nothing has changed, that everyone has returned as naturally as spring turns to summer.

title: Mailbox; Repugnant Verdict In Davis v. N.F.L.
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson is correct when he compares the National Football League to a ''soft-drink firm;'' both Coca-Cola and the N.F.L. are designed for public consumption (''N.F.L. Franchises Now Free Agents,'' The New York Times, May 9). It is because of this public role of professional football that the verdict in the ''Davis Case'' is so repugnant.

title: ABUSED WOMEN: PERCEPTIONS VERSUS REALITY
description: THE typical American man would surely react with anger and disgust to the spectacle of another man inflicting physical abuse on his wife. Very likely the witness would feel impelled to intervene, by persuasion if not direct action.

title: ITALY
description: To the Editor:

title: By Theodore W. Libbey Jr.; Joan Wilkerson, Mezzo, Stresses 19th Century
description: The audience's display of appreciation took the form of flowers, enough for a wedding, at the May 8 debut performance of Joan Wilkerson, mezzo-soprano, in Carnegie Recital Hall. Although effusive, such a gesture was easy to understand, for the mezzo's singing was warm enough to have won over an audience of complete strangers.

title: U.S. BIBLE GROUP LEAVING ECUADOREAN INDIANS
description: The Bible-translating missionaries of the Summer Institute of Linguistics, who for 30 years have worked with the Indians in the mountains and jungles of Ecuador, are preparing to leave by May 29 on orders of the Government.

title: 6 CROATIANS CONVICTED OF RACKETEERING CONSPIRACY
description: Six Croatian nationalists accused of engaging in a conspiracy involving murder, arson and extortion were found guilty yesterday by a Federal jury in Manhattan. Four other defendants were acquitted.

title: HAIG REPORTS GAIN IN HIS GREEK TALKS ON ALL KEY ISSUES
