description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou today and said that he had made progress on all key American-Greek issues, including that of United States military bases in Greece.

title: ALOMA'S RULER WINS PREAKNESS
description: Jack Kaenel is 16 years old and has spent more of his days as a jockey riding obscure nags at bush tracks than astride talented thoroughbreds in classic races. Bill Shoemaker is 50 and has won more races and money than any rider in racing history. But today at Pimlico Race Course, Kaenel outfoxed Shoemaker as if their ages and experience were reversed, and rode Aloma's Ruler to a half-length victory over Shoemaker and Linkage in the 107th Preakness Stakes.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Whenever avant-garde European photography of the 20's and 30's is mentioned, invariably Florence Henri's ambiguous self-portrait gets mentioned as well. It is a classic image, and enough to guarantee Miss Henri's reputation for years to come, but somehow it has eclipsed the rest of her Bauhaus-era photography.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Kansas City Kings of the National Basketball Association have announced a restructuring plan that will make Leon Karosen, the president of a local garment company, board chairman. Two other local businessmen will figure in the plan. H. Paul Rosenberg will be the board vice president and Robert Margolin the vice presidentsecretary and legal counsel. ... Ed McQuillin has been named director of the United States Tennis Association's National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: A HISTORIC GARDEN STILL IN BLOOM IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD IN the mid-19th century, many thoughtfully designed gardens were referred to as pleasure grounds - for that was exactly what they were intended to be - garden beds and lawns that provided an atmosphere of sweet scents and a vista filled with the everchanging colors of flowers in bloom.

title: MORGENTHAU WIN STOPS JUDICIAL ROTATIONS
description: In the three years since Governor Carey appointed him Chief Judge of the state's unified court system, Lawrence H. Cooke has emerged as the most powerful judicial figure in the state's history and one of its most controversial.

title: YANKS TRY TO MINIMIZE THEIR TROUBLES
description: ''Trouble,'' said Dave Winfield, invoking a word that follows the New York Yankees like an albatross. ''They've all been talking about all the trouble we've been having.''

title: The World in Summary; Lumps, Bumps For Rich Nations
description: Leaders of the largest industrial economies, in a somber rehearsal of what President Reagan will hear at next month's economic summit in Versailles, agreed last week that the end of recession still is not in sight. Unemployment in their countries, swollen by 10 million jobless in the United States, is still rising, they added.

title: Miss Rand Weds Richard Zuerner
description: Frederica J. Rand, daughter of George F. Rand 3d of Buffalo and the late Mrs. Rand, was married yesterday to Richard Leslie Zuerner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence L. Zuerner of El Cerrito, Calif. The ceremony was performed at St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Buffalo by the Very Rev. Dr. Elton O. Smith, dean of the cathedral.

title: A HOSIERY SHOW AND PIZAZZ
description: It was part Ziegfeld Follies and part Folies Bergeres, with cancan dancers, gun molls, convicts, toreadors, fencers, goddesses, peacocks, American Indians - and blaring music. More of an extravaganza than a fashion show, it was the Hot Sox Company's showing of fall hosiery.

title: Ex-Columbia U. Doctor Charged With Larceny
description: A former Columbia University professor of pediatrics and attending pediatrician at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center has been charged with submitting false vouchers for supplies and pocketing thousands of dollars in reimbursements from the medical center, authorities said yesterday.

title: Jocelyn R. Tucker Becomes Bride Of Felix Charney
description: Jocelyn Raina Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Tucker, was married yesterday to Felix Thomas Charney, son of Helen P. Charney and Felix S. Charney. Both families are of Westport, Conn.

title: SOUNDS OF EXPANSION JOIN THE 'BOOMS!' AT PICATINNY ARSENAL
description: DOVER GLOBAL strife seems remote from this wooded and mountainous Morris County area 40 miles west of New York City. But since the American Revolution, ammunition and weapons have been produced hereabout, a region rich in iron and water resources.

title: No Headline
description: Back in 1961 or 1962, my colleague Herbert Kohl invited Jackie Robinson to graduation exercises at Public School 145, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: IN WEIGHING THE NATION'S DESTINY, JUNTA CAN'T FLINCH
description: Argentina and Britain may be sliding toward a war that neither had ever wanted to fight over the Falkland Islands. For Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a full-scale clash would test the credibility of British arms in defense of the principle that the world's quarrels cannot be settled by the use of force. Beyond the resolution of this paradox lay, perhaps, the future shape of British political life, the solidity of the European Economic Community and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as well as the position of the United States in a volatile Latin America.

title: POPE, ENDING HIS PORTUGAL TRIP, CAUTIONS WORKERS
description: Pope John Paul II returned to Rome today after a four-day pilgrimage to Portugal, which ended with him saying that he supported the struggle of workers for dignity and rights but warning that some movements that espoused the cause of labor were harmful to the general interest.

title: Fare of the Country; RILLETTES: THE PRIDE OF FRANCE'S TOURAINE
description: CAROL KRAMER is a writer and editor who lives in New York. BY CAROL KRAMER

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: C.E. MOREY of Utica, N.Y., built 261 pipe organs between 1893 and 1935, the year he went out of business. The instruments are prized to this day for their sturdy construction and rich sound.

title: Karen Gerber Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Gerber of Freehold, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Karen Michelle Gerber, to Andrew Steven Norott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Norott, also of Freehold. Miss Gerber and her fiance are students at the Brookdale Community College in Lincroft, N.J.

title: SHORT-TERM CREDIT CONCERNS
description: While indicators like last month's retail sales figures, which rose 1.4 percent from March, suggest that the economy may be starting an upturn, one critically important variable continues to worry analysts.

title: TV STUDIO HONES PUPILS' SKILLS
description: ''QUIET on the set,'' the young, blue-jeaned director cried, and immediately a hush fell over the television studio. Stealthily the cameramen zeroed in on the interview team and their guest seated on the raised platform. With all eyes riveted on him now, the floor manager signaled to the three people which camera to address.

title: REBELS SAY AN ETHIOPIAN OFFENSIVE HAS STALLED
description: An offensive begun in February by Ethiopian Government forces in an attempt to crush the 20-year-old Eritrean independence movement has stalled, a spokesman for the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said in New York.

title: Around the World; 16 Polish Union Leaders Have Begun Prison Fast
description: Sixteen interned leaders and advisers of the suspended Solidarity trade union have begun a hunger strike at a prison near Warsaw, a relative of one of the strikers said today.

title: Mark Mariscal to Wed Lori Zabar in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Zabar of New York and Crompond, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Segal Zabar, to Mark R. Mariscal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Mariscal of Phoenix and Sedona, Ariz.

title: RIGHTS MOVEMENT CITES ITS CONCERN
description: The support given Argentina on the Falkland Islands issue by a broad spectrum of Latin American political opinion is sowing confusion and controversy among some American and European human rights groups and liberal-left political organizations.

title: Kibbutzim
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Dale to Wed Katherine B. Michael
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bayard H. Michael of Milwaukee have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Beale Michael, to Anthony Chalmers Dale, son of Mrs. Robert T. Gatchell of Lawrenceville, N.J., and Chalmers Dale of Grand View, N.Y.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The frogs are moving very well. The red-bellied newts too.'' - Lou D'Alessio of the Kingfish Pet stand at the Ninth Avenue International Festival. (40:1.)

title: Call for Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: Remembering Jackie Robinson
description: ''Remembering Jackie Robinson'' (by Robert Curvin, April 4) brought back vivid, pleasant memories.

title: LIMNING THE ROLE OF THE BLACK DANCER IN AMERICA
description: The role of the black dancer in the United States, and by extension, his or her impact throughout the world, continues to be an area of continuing research and investigation - as we are reminded by two current photography exhibitions devoted to the subject. One is a major if selective retrospective of pictures from the New York Public Library -primarily from the collection of the library's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture (515 Lenox Avenue). ''Black Dance in Photographs: From the Mid-19th Century to the Present'' presents 100 items of exhibition quality that range from the most formal study to the most spontaneous action shot.

title: Around the World; Zaire Plans Israeli Ties After a 9-Year Break
description: Zaire plans to renew diplomatic relations with Israel, which were broken in 1973, the Zaire press agency reported today.

title: Hilary Hart Becomes the Bride of Paul W. Brown
description: Hilary Claire Hart, daughter of Mrs. S. Gifford Hart of Valhalla, N.Y., and the late Mr. Hart, was married yesterday to Paul William Brown, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Paul Brown of Albany. The Rev. Gerald S. Levesque performed the ceremony in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: STEPS TO TAKE WHEN FIXING OR REPLACING HOUSE SHINGLES
description: A SPLIT or cracked shingle on the outside of the house does not necessarily have to be replaced with a new one. If there are no sizable pieces missing in the damaged shingle, all that is required in most cases is to drive in a few extra nails on both sides of the crack or split in order to keep the pieces from falling out.

title: HUGH BEAUMONT, ACTOR, DIES
description: Hugh Beaumont, who appeared in the television series ''Leave It to Beaver,'' died Friday, a family spokesman said. He was 72 years old.

title: Cave Wins 1,500 Run in 3:43.2
description: Rick Cave of the Shore Athletic Club, a 25-year-old who never broke 4 minutes 10 seconds in the mile as a collegian, today outkicked Matt Centrowitz to win the 1,500-meter run in 3 minutes 43.2 seconds in the Adidas-Princeton Invitational track meet at Palmer Stadium.

title: Capital Principles
description: To the Business Editor: Please allow me to correct one word in a quote attributed to me in ''Neo-Economist'' (May 9), which accompanied excerpts from my latest book. The sentence should read: ''Sometimes the world changes and you have to change your position just to stay principled.''

title: WAITING FOR MUBARAK
description: The completion of Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai opened a new chapter in Egyptian politics, posing a new set of challenges and possibilities for President Hosni Mubarak.

title: NEW BOATING-FEE PLAN SUBMITTED TO CONGRESS
description: The Department of Transportation has sent Congress a revised proposal for a system of annual user fees for most of the nation's 12 million recreational boat owners as well as operators of commercial boats.

title: ENTREATY IN VERSAILLES: THE WEST WILL PRESS REAGAN FOR ACTION ON ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON WHENEVER anyone used to ask how soon he would be making his first major overseas trip, President Reagan had a standard, semifacetious reply. Traditionally, he said, American Presidents travel abroad to escape their political headaches at home, and he hoped to avoid that precedent.

title: Elizabeth Giovine Married
description: Elizabeth Lee Giovine and Raymond Arthur Vogel Jr. were married yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New Haven.

title: Juvenile-Justice Volume Due
description: The last volume of a 23-volume study of the problems in juvenile justice is to be released Tuesday by Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit at a meeting of the board of fellows of the Institute of Judicial Administration in Philadelphia. As head of the American Bar Association's Institute of Judicial Administration Joint Commission on Juvenile Justice Standards, Judge Kaufman oversaw the project, which recommends changes in the way the 50 states deal with young offenders. The Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger, will attend the presentation of the last volume of the project.

title: Postings; 'LITTLE PARADISE'
description: When Michael M. Smith and his fiancee, Marion Duckworth, undertook to restore the second-oldest house in Queens, they also acquired a family plot. Descendants of an early Dutch colonist, Abraham Rycken - who gave his anglicized name to Rikers Island - lie buried in a small cemetery adjoining the garden.

title: The World in Summary; Truce Holds, More or Less
description: Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization blasted more holes in their tattered south Lebanon cease-fire last week, but both still seemed to prefer a safety net with holes to no net at all.

title: Turner Broadcasting Reports $5.3 Million Loss in Quarter
description: The Turner Broadcasting System Inc. lost $5.3 million in the first quarter of 1982 because of high interest rates and the start-up cost of its second news service, CNN2, the company announced Friday.

title: NEW DENVER PLAN CUTTING BUSING WINS APPROVAL
description: This city's 13-year-old battle over public school desegregation has moved a step closer to a resolution with a Federal district judge's acceptance for one year of a compromise busing plan.

title: The World in Summary; Fresh Polish Protests Defy Martial Law
description: Poland, after five months of martial law, is ruled but not really governed. Last week, authorities repeatedly called out riot police as thousands of workers, farmers and students protested in Warsaw and, travelers said, in other industrial cities.

title: THE GEHRY STYLE
description: Joseph Morgenstern is a journalist and screenwriter living in Los Angeles. By Joseph Morgenstern Even in California, where idiosyncrasy is a mass movement, Frank O. Gehry is in a class by himself. He is the most important architect in the state, indeed in the West. He brings a strong theoretical background and a bourgeois obsession with bottom-line economics to his commercial projects, which are as notable for their low cost as they are for the light-splashed beauty of their interiors. Yet this rumpled, humorous and intense man of 53 is also a defiantly originalartist, who builds with such brutal industrial materials as corrugated steel, raw plywood and chain-link fencing. He can put theory aside in order to raid his unconscious, like a refrigerator at night, for the hunches, whims and contradictions that make his best work inimitable.

title:
THEATER IN REVIEW;
ROCKLAND IS HOST TO 'TOM JONES'
description: THE Penguin Repertory Company in Stony Point, N.Y., one of a number of developing, noncommunity theaters in the area embracing New Jersey, Rockland County and Staten Island, has begun its sixth season with David Rogers's dramatization of ''Tom Jones.''

title: Helen Alling to Be Wed
description: Helen Stearly Alling and William Stuart Westland will be married June 26 at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington, N.Y. The bride-to-be is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Alling of Grandview, N.Y. Mr. Westland is a son of Dr. and Mrs. George Alan Westland of Memphis.

title: 'One Must Start By Caring'
description: I am responding to the anonymous ''This Is the Way She Is.'' I write because I am startled and even angered by the insensitivity in regard to the human needs of the autistic children with whom you work; in regard to the destructiveness of your comments, which undermine the struggles of beleaguered parents who have fought for schooling for their children and who still continue to fight as budgets are cut.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: CARNEGIE HILL
description: IN 1901, Andrew Carnegie, the industrialist and philanthropist, b uilt a palatial mansion on a rise at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, t hen occupied by shanties and generally considered beyond the pale.

title: HAIG'S VISIT A STEP TOWARD CLOSER U.S.-GREEK TIES
description: The visit by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is the biggest step yet toward ending the climate of uncertainty between the United States and the new Socialist Government of Greece, according to American and Greek officials.

title: Israelis Wound an Arab Youth In a New West Bank Incident
description: Israeli soldiers in the occupied West Bank shot and wounded an Arab youth during stone-throwing violence in the Balata refugee camp near Nablus today, the military command reported.

title: NOTES ON FASHION AFLOAT
description: JOHN DUKA is a reporter for the Style Section of the New York Times. BY JOHN DUKA

title: Joan Diamond Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris D. Diamond of Millburn, N.J., have annnounced the engagement of their daughter, Joan L. Diamond, to Bruce H. Leiwant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney E. Leiwant of Verona, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Posthumously Collaborative

title: THE LESSONS THAT ONE BOXER LEARNED FROM INJURY
description: IT was May 1979, and I had lost my second attempt at the welterweight championship to Wilfredo Benitez in Puerto Rico in March. But I was set to fight Thomas Hearns, the Motor City hit man, in Las Vegas.

title: DANCE: WAGONER'S 'STOP STARS'
description: Dan Wagoner is a choreographer with a gentle touch, looking both to the courtesies of other, country days and to the fleet abstractions of Merce Cunningham's dance. The anguished stretch or angry hurtling into the floor is not for him. Solemnity is expressed, most often, with dance approaching stillness. But Mr. Wagoner's new ''Stop Stars,'' performed Thursday at Pace University's Schimmel Center, breaks with that tradition. War is not declared with the world here. But the dance steps out into a haunting void.

title: CHIPPING AWAY AT FREEDOM
description: Despite the Reagan Administration's assertion that it wants to cut back the power over people's lives that the Federal Government excercises, in fact in key areas it has moved in precisely the opposite direction.

title: FIELD ARTILLERY FOR A ROOKIE UMP
description: EARLY this spring, I received a phone call from the director of a local recreation program, asking if I would volunteer to umpire their Little League baseball games. ''All you have to do is make a few decisions,'' he explained. ''How about it?''

title: BLACK CRIME, BLACK VICTIMS
description: Lee A. Daniels is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. By Lee A. Daniels Jean Jones, a 37-year-old personnel specialist for an employment company, had just stepped off the bus one December evening in her Brooklyn neighborhood and was walking home when, turning a corner, she saw a tall, thin man standing near an apparently empty schoolyard a block ahead. Though preoccupied with other thoughts, she instinctively crossed the well-lighted street, preferring to walk past a row of brownstones that faced the schoolyard.

title: REFLECTIONS ON THE SEASON
description: JOHN RUSSELL is chief art critic of The New York Times. BY JOHN RUSSELL

title: VISITING LOTUSLAND
description: QUENTIN CRISP'S most recent books are ''Doing It With Style'' (Franklin Watts), written with Donald Carroll, and ''How to Become a Virgin'' (St. Martin's). By QUENTIN CRISP

title: WOMEN, IN VICTORIAN TERMS, AT YALE CENTER
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN she acceded to the throne in 1837, Queen Victoria drew a veil of respectability over the House of Hanover. The rakish royal uncles were replaced by the embodiment of bourgeois domesticity, whose influence penetrated to the farthest reaches of the empire.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER Bruce D. Schwartz has returned to New York with his fantastical oneman puppet extravaganza ''The Rat of Huge Proportions and Other Works.'' As part of his act, Mr. Schwartz appears wearing a puppet stage around his body, an ambulatory proscenium that is soon filled with a slaphappy Elizabethan Punch and Judy show.

title: Drinking Age Math
description: Should New York raise the drinking age to 19? The numbers say yes. Studies show that the crash rate of 18-year-old drivers is significantly higher than that of 16- and 17-year-olds.

title: Sports of The Times; Hartack Goes to Whip Again
description: IN the jockeys' room at Pimlico yesterday, an apprentice walked up to the little man in the cream sports jacket. ''Mr. Hartack,'' the apprentice said, ''I just want to shake your hand.'' Bill Hartack smiled quickly and chatted with the apprentice, then walked over to get a cup of coffee at the lunch counter. In a far corner, some track security men in yellow T-shirts were sitting around a table, and now one of them called out, ''The last time you raced here, you got booed.'' Bill Hartack waved and smiled quickly. But then his face turned serious again. As a jockey with 4,272 winners before riding in Hong Kong for six years, Bill Hartack was always serious. And now, at age 49, he's serious about becoming a steward in California.

title: VICTORIAN WOMEN, INCLUDING VICTORIA
description: STRONG-MINDED WOMEN And Other Lost Voices From Nineteenth-Century England. By Janet Horowitz Murray. Illustrated. 453 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $22.50. Paper, $11.95.

title: WALL STREET'S ELECTRONIC EXPERIMENT
description: Tomorrow morning, after years of debate and some foot-dragging, a reluctant Wall Street is taking an important step into the electronic age. The step, an experiment in securing better prices for investors, already has some of Wall Street's most established firms fretting for the future of the nation's securities markets.

title:
STAMPS;
BRITAIN PAYS TRIBUTE TO ITS NAVAL HERITAGE
description: While its mighty fleet was occupied in the stormy waters of the South Atlantic off the Falkland Islands and recalling once again the days when Britannia ruled the waves, Great Britain announced a new commemorative issue in tribute to the nation's rich naval and maritime heritage.

title: Lise Anne Pfeiffer Fiancee Of Andrew M. Chapman
description: Frances Winston Pfeiffer of Brentwood, Calif., and George Robert Pfeiffer of Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lise Anne Pfeiffer, to Andrew Morgan Chapman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Chapman of Farmington, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: MORE ON RUSTLING AND MERRILL'S THUNDERING HERD
description: When last we looked, Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest securities firm, was celebrating some success in the steps it took to curb rustling from the Thundering Herd. Its officers expressed jubilation last month when an arbitration panel at New York Stock Exchange ordered a competitor, Drexel Burnham Lambert, to pay damages of $250,000 to Merrill Lynch as compensation for improper recruiting practices. In the case against Drexel Burnham, Merrill Lynch accused four of its defecting executives of copying records and luring away clients.

title: ON CHOOSING THE RIGHT FLOWERS FOR SPECIAL PLACES
description: Flowers fill strategic roles. Their main appeal is cheery color. Blossoms can be refreshing and cooling to provide a feeling of faraway or they can be flashy with hot, showy colors to create a mood of vibrancy.

title: Courts on Trial
description: First of four articles on efforts to restrain the Federal judiciary. By STUART TAYLOR Jr.

title: Foreign Affairs; NO MAGIC FROM HIGH-TECH
description: The search for some rational approach to the nuclear dilemma continues. A conference on ''Security in an Insecure Age'' at the Naval War College here reflected the contradictory jumble that emerges when people, including experts, try to reconcile hopes and fears.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: An Instinctive Collector Lily Tomlin has created some new characters: Purvis Hawkins, a ''soul artist,'' as the comedienne describes him; ''punker'' Agnes Angst, with a rock group called Manic Depressives, and a 1960's protest singer, Holly Oneness. These will be unveiled on Miss Tomlin's latest television special, ''Lily for President?'' to be broadcast on CBS Thursday at 10 P.M.

title:
GARDENING;
LAWN WATERING IS OFTEN OVERDONE
description: OVER the last several years much has been written on the subject of lawn care, yet it is not uncommon to see lawns being watered two or three days after a two-and-a-half-inch rain. The same applies to the collection of lawn clippings when mowing. Neither of these practices is necessary or even desirable under normal circumstances.

title: Frances T. McCarthy Married to Robert I. Elliot Jr.
description: Frances Therese McCarthy, daughter of Mrs. Frank J. McCarthy of Washington, and the late Mr. McCarthy, was married yesterday to Robert Irwin Elliot Jr., son of Mrs. D. Evans Elliot of Point Pleasant, Pa., and Robert I. Elliot of Springfield, Vt. The Rev. Michael Trainor performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: PICKING FAVORITES AONG OPERA WARHORSES
description: The Metropolitan Opera frequently informs us that mainstream, 19th-century Italian operas are becoming increasingly difficult to cast. That hasn't stopped the record companies, which persist in releasing new versions of these standards. What follows is a consumer guide to eight recordings of mostly 19th-century, mostly mainstream Italian operas released this season. The operas are listed in chronological order, and thus provide a kind of road map to the evolution of Italian opera from the period immediately following the Baroque opera seria to post-Wagnerian orchestral complexity and the dawn of musical modernism.

title: Betsy Werthan To Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Werthan Jr. of Nashville, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Betsy May Werthan, to Bart Robin Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund I. Schwartz of Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: NEW MUSIC: CARMEN MOORE
description: The more things change, the more they stay the same; or so one might think after hearing three new compositions by Carman Moore. The works, ''Understudy,'' ''Blue Cubes'' and ''Old Wars,'' were performed at Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village on Friday evening by an ensemble led by Mr. Moore.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FROM EMBARGO TO OSTPOLITIK The Political Economy of West German-Soviet Relations, 1955-1980. By Angela Stent. 328 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $39.50.

title: A WORLD PREMIERE AT HARTFORD STAGE
description: YOU have until next Sunday to catch ''The Isle Is Full of Noises'' by Derek Walcott at the Hartford Stage Company. Aside from being a world premiere, the play marks a first-time visit to Hartford by New York's famed Negro Ensemble Company.

title: SUFFOLK GAINS EQUAL STRENGHT IN REDISTRICTING
description: ALBANY THE new set of political maps for New York State approved by the Legislature last week includes scores of changes that will keep the Island's politicians ruminating and scheming for months.

title: 'First, Acknowledge The Potential'
description: After our initial anger had subsided upon reading ''This Is the Way She Is,'' we felt it necessary to respond on behalf of autistic students and their many dedicated and skilled teachers. As educators of handicapped children, as well as teacher trainers, we have evidenced actual and documented educational gains in autistic students.

title: THE ZIP IN ZERO-COUPON BONDS
description: THE liberalization of Individual Retirement Accounts has sent c reative minds scurrying for ways to tap that huge pool of potential i nvestment money, and one of the newest gimmicks is the zero-coupon b ond.

title: STYLE AND FAST FEET CREATE A CHAMPIONSHIP TEAM
description: HARTFORD THE lighted candle fell to the carpet and the carpet caught fire. Joan Carter ran from her bedroom and woke her sleeping mother. ''She told me to get some water,'' Joan said. ''So I went to the bathroom.''

title: HARTFORD 'MESSIAH' A COMMUNAL EFFORT
description: HANDEL's ''Messiah,'' that most popular of Christmas and Easter music, will get special treatment Saturday when the Hartford Symphony Orchestra and a community choir of almost 100 people join forces to present 13 choruses and other selections from the oratorio.

title: THE DAY A POPE GAVE AWAY THE FALKLANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH LEADS COLONIAL BY TWO
description: Andy North, who has been plugging along in relative obscurity since winning the United States Open in 1978, took a two-stroke lead today in the third round of the Colonial National Invitation tournament.

title: IF MUSIC BE THE FOOD OF SUMMER, PLAY ON
description: Man is the most adaptable of bipeds. Deprived of wine, he will drink Perrier. Deprived of air, he will breathe industrial fumes. Deprived of luscious, vine-ripened tomatoes, he will buy and presumably eat the pink Styrofoam objects that supermarkets offer in their place. So far, at any rate, man has proved a match for anything that nature or his own technological ingenuity could throw at him. Man can even find pleasure in outdoor music.

title: CYCLISTS TO VIE
description: More than 1,000 motorcyclists are expected to compete next Sunday in a Spring Dice Run benefiting the American Cancer Society. In staggered starts from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., the cyclists will leave North Plainfield and proceed 70 miles through five Somerset County parks.

title: TO STOP THE ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: FREEZING IN THE DARK IS NOT OUR STYLE
description: Destruct E nergy Policy,'' does little to assauge Canadian fears that Americansd o not understand what is happening to the north of our common b order.

title: The Region in Summary; The Trenton Strategy
description: However Washington and Moscow regard Trenton's signals on foreign policy, New Jersey legislators are dead serious about them. Last week the State Senate gave final approval to a measure that would enable voters to say whether or not they think the United States and the Soviet Union should agree to a ''mutual verifiable halt'' in atomic weapons production.

title: DEDICATION CEREMONIES TODAY FOR JUDACIA MUSEUM IN BRONX
description: In a case against one wall of the new Judaica Museum in the Bronx is a half-burned Torah scroll. It is the only one of 13 scrolls that survived the Kristallnacht, the night of broken glass, in Ralph Baum's hometown of Elmhorn, a suburb of Hamburg, Germany. On that night, Nov. 10, 1983, almost all the synagogues in Germany were vandalized and the windows of stores owned by Jews smashed.

title: SCHEDULE OF COMMENCEMENT EXERCISES
description: Following is a schedule of commencement exercises in the state. TODAY

title: ONCE-FASHIONABLE RESORT IS ONLY A MEMORY NOW
description: SCHOOLEYS MOUNTAIN ACOUNTRY store and the memories of the oldest residents are all that remain of a 19th-century resort area on the northern edge of Morris County, an area that once lured wealthy families from New York City and Washington with its luxurious hotels and medicinal springs.

title: The World in Summary; Saddam Hussein In Big Trouble
description: Future military historians will surely point to Iraq's war with Iran as an example of how not to do battle. Twenty months after President Saddam Hussein sent the Iraqi Army into Iran's oil-rich Khuzistan province to lay full claim to the Shatt al Arab waterway dividing the two countries, Iraqi forces have been forced to retreat on most fronts back to their own borders.

title: Unemployment Still Hurts
description: With the unemployment rate steaming toward 10 percent, President Reagan keeps trying to minimize the problem. Last month he blamed high unemployment on women crowding into the labor force; this month he observes that joblessness isn't as hard as in the Great Depression.

title: Middletown
description: To the Editor:

title: YOGURT
description: To the editor: Apropos of your article on yogurt (Travel, April 18), let me add a marvelous summertime use for yogurt that I learned several years ago from a Turkish friend.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THEY TURNED OLD MOVIES INTO A TIMELY FILM ABOUT NUCLEAR WAR
description: The movie is about the atom bomb, one of the most serious subjects a filmmaker could choose in these times. Yet in the audience, youngsters and adults alike are convulsed with laughter.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER VOTE STIRS REGIONAL RIVALRIES
description: Each night, southern Californians who turn on their television sets are being warned in doomsday terms that unless a ballot question is approved next month, Los Angeles, with its freeways, palm trees and all, will become a ''desert'' again.

title:
GARDENING;
LAWN WATERING IS OFTEN OVERDONE
description: OVER the last several years much has been written on the subject of lawn care, yet it is not uncommon to see lawns being watered two or three days after a two-and-a-half-inch rain. The same applies to the collection of lawn clippings when mowing. Neither of these practices is necessary or even desirable under normal circumstances.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR OFFER VIEWS ERNEST A. ABATE
description: QUESTION 1

title: STUDENTS ACT AS INTERVIEWERS
description: IN recent years, Connecticut College in New London and Wesleyan University in Middletown have joined a growing number of colleges and universities nationwide in using senior students as interviewers of prospective students.

title: ARCHIBALD HURT
description: The Boston Celtics lost more than a playoff game today when the Philadelphia 76ers beat them, 99-97, before a capacity crowd of 18,346 at the Spectrum. The defending National Basketball Association champions also lost Nate (Tiny) Archibald, their premier playmaker, when he dislocated his left shoulder less than a minute into the third game of the Eastern Conference championship. And they fell behind in the series, 2-1, with the fourth game scheduled here Sunday.

title: 'THIS IS THE WAY SHE IS': PARENTS AND EDUCATORS COMMENT
description: AS an educator and the parent of a child having autism, it is with a deep sense of sorrow, frustration and anger that I respond to ''This Is the Way She Is,'' by an anonymous teacher of autistic children (Opinion Page, May 2).

title: ON WELFARE OR WORKING, POOR IS POOR
description: In recent times, no President has preached the gospel of work more ardently than Ronald Reagan. Yet no President has so increased the effective tax rate on income earned by the poor. To specialists in the arcane realm of welfare policy, that curious paradox comes as no surprise. Indeed, it was inevitable, given Mr. Reagan's determination to achieve large budget savings by cutting programs such as welfare, food stamps and Medicaid, which benefit to low-income working families.

title: JOBLESS RATE LAID TO WELFARE RULES
description: The employment problems of teen-agers are attributed in part to Federal rules that discourage welfare recipients from working, according to a Government study.

title: STAGE: WELFARE HOTEL AND 'SIX O'CLOCK BOYS'
description: ''The Six O'Clock Boys'' is a play about coping. To say this is to give it the back of your hand, of course, because most plays these days are about coping - with sex, with stress, with parents, with loneliness, with whatever it is that gives the playwright angst. Sidney Morris's angst, however, is diffuse; it is also shot through with humbug, but at least it is theatrical humbug. Mr. Morris has written a play that allows Vera Lockwood, a good actress, to be enormously theatrical.

title: Around the Nation; Amtrak Tunnel Closed Because of Safety Fears
description: An Amtrak tunnel south of Baltimore's Penn Station was closed indefinitely today after an inspector heard the 108-year-old structure cracking.

title: SON WINS TITLE THAT ELUDED DAD
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN he was known as the king of the racquet sports in the 1960's, Dick Squires always found one national title to be most elusive - that for squash tennis. The game, which has a tradition dating to the early 1900's, is faster than the more popular game of squash racquets and requires quicker reflexes. Somehow, it stymied Mr. Squires, who finished a frustrated runner-up in the national tournament four times.

title: By Theodore W. Libbey Jr.; William Brown, Tenor, With Esoteric Program
description: The tenor William Brown made his New York recital debut Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, avoiding repertory commonplaces in a program that offered such esoterica as five songs by Carl Maria von Weber for voice and guitar, two Zulu songs accompanied by percussion, two ''catch songs,'' David Baker's piquant ''The Black Experience'' and Priaulx Ranier's haunting ''Cycle for Declamation.'' The performances did not always succeed on a technical level - Mr. Brown's range was a bit limited for some of the music, and his control in softer dynamics was shaky - but there were some fine moments when the drama of a setting brought the soloist to an expressive boil.

title: NEIGHBORS' EFFORT SAVES UPSTATE COVERED BRIDGE
description: The Rexleigh Bridge, one of 21 covered bridges in New York State, has been saved from demolition. The 100-foot-long picturesque bridge, which spans the Batten Kill here in southeastern Washington County not far from the Vermont border, had been scheduled to be torn down since 1979 because it is unsafe. The bridge is suffering from rot in its underpinnings, some of its deck planking has been replaced by plywood that bends under a pedestrian's step and there are gaps in its wooden walls and roof.

title: ARGENTINES PUT BLAME ON BRITISH FOR U.N. DELAY
description: Argentine officials said today that Britain was responsible for delaying negotiations on the Falkland Islands crisis but still expressed hope for a peaceful settlement.

title: Postings; THE GAVEL RISES
description: As part of its annual fund-raising, Connecticut Public Television is inviting home buyers to bid on a brand-new, three-bedroom, twobath ranch-style house in Wallingford, a northern suburb of New Haven.

title: About Cars; 4-WHEEL DRIVE IN A TURBO COUPE
description: hundred-eighty-two feet below, the car is glinting gold in the sun, parked at the lowest point on the continent, poised for a dash across Death Valley and a 9,000-foot climb into the snow of the Sierras. That is just the right kind of trip for a four-wheel-drive screamer like Audi's new Quattro, and the turbocharged version of the company's sport coupe is ready to prove itself.

title: GRATIFICATION TRIUMPHS IN THE ROSEBEN
description: Gratification, a 5-year-old son of Princely Native and the $10.20-for-$2 fourth choice, outran six rivals to triumph by half a length yesterday in the $55,200 Roseben Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: UPGRADED SHIPS JOIN THE FLEET
description: VERNON KIDD is a New York-based actor and writer. By VERNON KIDD

title: Katharine Foote Bride Of Richard J. Howland
description: Katharine Eicher Foote, a research supervisor with Doyle Dane Bernbach, an advertising agency in New York, was married yesterday to Richard James Howland, a group product manager with American Home Products in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Herbert Anderson at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: William J.Sheridan, M.T.A. Board Member
description: William J. Sheridan, a member of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died at his home in Setauket, L.I., yesterday after a long illness. He was 46 years old.

title: Miss Choate Is the Bride Of Executive
description: Caroline Choate, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hyde Choate of Brookville, L.I., and Holderness, N.H., was married at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday to Guy Louis de Chazal, son of Mrs. Louis de Chazal of East Riding, England, and the late Mr. de Chazal. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery, assisted by the Rev. James Collins, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: AFRICAN INTRIGUE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Randy Hogan is a freelance writer, editor and translator. KAHAWA By Donald E. Westlake. 458 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $15.95. By RANDY HOGAN

title: Major News in Summary; Nibbles at the Budget Bullet
description: From beginning to end, Washington's week had that old familiar something. With tomorrow the deadline for Congressional passage of the first budget resolution for 1983, the Republican Senate had just begun debating its budget committee's version of Federal taxing and spending for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1.

title: Elizabeth Fannon Wed To William F. O'Leary
description: Elizabeth Barat Fannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcy Barat Fannon of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Francis O'Leary, son of Dr. and Mrs. James L. O'Leary Jr. of Johns Island, Vero Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr.

title: Howland Murphy to Wed Jean Parker
description: The engagement of Jean Carlton Parker, daughter of Mrs. James P. Parker of Gibson Island, Md., and the late Mr. Parker, to Howland Donaldson Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grayson Mallet-Prevost Murphy of New York and Sandy Hook, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's mother.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS

title: Footnotes to Exhibition On Jewish Pioneers
description: Many thanks for the coverage of my exhibition ''And We're Still Here: 100 Years of Small Town Jewish Life'' (April 25). However, there are a few items that I must note.

title: KATHY WHITWORYH TAKES LEAD ON 137
description: Kathy Whitworth, on the threshold of a Ladies' Professional Golf Association record for victories, shot a four-under-par 68 today for a 137 total that gave her a one-shot advantage over Kelly Fuiks after the second round of the $150,000 Lady Michelob tournament.

title: William Donald Noel To Wed Ann McClure
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas O. McClure of Princeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth McClure, to William Donald Noel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Edward Noel of Ticonderoga, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: A Matter Of Style I was disturbed by the implications of June Weir's article ''Women of Style'' (April 11). Indeed, creative or fashionable modes of dress can be a healthy form of self-expression, just as an attractive appearance can contribute to one's personal or professional success.  However, to consider a woman's talent for imaginative dress ''the 'it' that elevates one woman above the ordinary'' is to reinforce the severely limiting and superficial standards by which women in this society have been taught to judge themselves. One need only consider how silly a similar article on men would seem to understand that this double standard exists. Mary Wollstonecraft expressed the idea neatly when she wrote: ''Taught from infancy that beauty is woman's scepter, the mind shapes itself to the body, and roaming around its gilt
description: In my view, the single mother who executes admirably the role of two parents, or the woman who succeeds in a nontraditional career possesses far more ''personal style'' than a woman who wears an armful of ivory bracelets. SUSAN LOFFREDO Boston

title: A Tightening Vise
description: To the Editor; I have read with great interest and consternation the prognosis for rental rates for commercial tenants (''Office Help Sent to Low-Rent Sites,'' April 4). That covers the 5,000 to 10,000 companies large enough to pass along the cost to the consumer.

title: CHIEF PROSECUTOR DEFENDS METHODS OF ABSCAM
description: The chief prosecutor in the Abscam investigation yesterday reaffirmed his view that the methods used in the undercover inquiry did not flout constitutional rights or ethical considerations and in fact were the kind most likely to safeguard them.

title: The Nation in Summary; A Question of Insanity and Family Tragedy
description: The legal focus in the second full week of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s trial remained his mental state at the time he shot President Reagan and three other men, a crime to which Mr. Hinckley has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. But what emerged in the testimony last week by a Colorado psychiatrist who treated him and by members of his family was a drama of profound sadness and confusion and, finally, impotence.

title: Darcy Joy Rudder Married To Bradford B. Griswold
description: Darcy Joy Rudder and Bradford Bartram Griswold were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in Canton Center, Conn., by the Rev. Evans Sealand.

title: PSYCHOLOGY AND LAW: AN EXPERIMENTAL MARRIAGE
description: Experts show up in courtrooms these days to testify on just about everything. But the latest vogue is a variety of experts that some lawyers claim are nothing more than specialists in common sense.

title: REQUESTS FLOW IN, BUT U.S. AID EBBS
description: THE county's 33 Urban Coalition communities asked for $30 million in Federal funds this year. They will receive $4.15 million. Last year, the coalition communities got more - $4.33 million - and there were fewer communities to share it - 29 instead of 33.

title: GERALD LABRIOLA QUESTION 1
description: IN 1978-79, the cost of running Connecticut was just over $2 billion. This year, that cost will exceed $3 billion. The question our taxpayers need answered is ''Has the billion-dollar spending increase improved the quality of life in our state?''

title: LET FREEDOM LOVE
description: Let Freedom Love

title: SALES OF BIG 3 AUTO MAKERS RISE 20.6%
description: Auto sales were up a strong 20.6 percent for the Big Three auto makers in early May, the companies said; the strongest showing came from General Motors. The sales gain renewed hopes for a successful spring selling season and some recovery for the beleaguered automakers.

title: DOZEN AGENCIES TO QUIT TRADE CENTER
description: New York State has taken the first steps toward moving 8,000 state employees from the World Trade Center in Manhattan to distressed areas of New York City.

title: 'MORALS WITHOUT PREACHING' GOALS OF TWO PLAYS
description: WHEN the performers plunge down the aisle chanting ''Sex, drugs, rock and roll; sex, drugs, rock and roll,'' the high school audiences cheer, whistle and stamp their feet.

title: SOVIET PEACE CHARADE IS LESS THAN CONVINCING
description: When the Rev. Billy Graham departed last week it seemed clear that his sojourn here would be remembered in the West mainly for his observations about the degree of religious freedom he found during his six-day stay. But the value of his visit for the Kremlin probably lay less in the evangelist's generous view of the state-controlled churches than in his attendance at a conference promoting the Soviet ''peace'' campaign, a curious bowdlerization of the movement against nuclear weapons that has been gathering momentum in the West.

title: PROSPECTS
description: OPEC Buys Some Time

title: Garvey Uneasy About Future
description: Steve Garvey's suit was crisp, his tie was straight and the silk handkerchief in his breast pocket was a coordinated shade of burgundy. His timetable for the day called for a morning television taping, a midday business lunch and an evening baseball game, and he was prepared and punctual at each stop.

title: Big and Little Poison Live On
description: Approximately 50 million people solve crossword puzzles. Many are neophytes whose knowledge of sports stars is confined to a few headliners of the past and present. They know that Stengel is Casey, Berra is Yogi and Namath is Joe. But when a five-letter word must be filled in for ''Big Poison of baseball,'' they must turn to some more sophisticated sports fan to learn that Paul WANER was the ''Big'' one and brother Lloyd was the ''Little'' one - as if they cared.

title: Moon Tax Case Jury Recesses for Weekend
description: The jury in the Manhattan trial of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon has adjourned its deliberations until tomorrow morning. Friday afternoon, when Judge Gerard L. Goettel told the jurors that they could continue deliberating or go home for the weekend, they decided to leave. Their deliberations in the tax-fraud case began on Wednesday in Federal District Court.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IS THERE INTELLIGENT LIFE ON EARTH?
description: THE other day, someone told me that, as a novice secretary many years ago, she had failed to catch a typographical error that resulted in a customer's having being sent a letter expressing the wish that he had not recovered from a recent illness, rather than the intended now.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR OFFER VIEWS RICHARD C. BOZZUTO
description: QUESTION 1

title: CONDUCTOR'S FORTE: DOING THE UNEXPECTED
description: FOR a person seeped in music - she has been playing the piano for 28 of her 31 years -Victoria Bond has a surprisingly nonmusical way of describing her rapidly developing career as a conductor. Miss Bond, who will direct the first annual Haydn festival at the Port Washington Public Library this weekend, sees herself as ''a salmon swimming upstream.'' And, at journey's end, despite the odds against her as a woman in what has always been a man's field, she hopes to find the post of musical director of a major American symphony orchestra.

title: GIAMATTI OF YALE TO WEAR A NEW PRESIDENT'S COLLAR
description: A new President's Collar, a gold, silver and enamel necklace commissioned to replace a 1905 ceremonial collar stolen from Yale University almost three years ago, will be worn for the first time by Yale's president, Dr. A. Bartlett Giamatti, at baccalaureate services next Sunday.

title: Blast Kills Barcelona Guard
description: A guard was killed today by a door blasted from its hinges when an explosion wrecked an ammunition depot near Barcelona. A Spanish Army statement said the blast was touched off by a fire.

title: IN THE BASEMENT OF HISTORY
description: THE STRUCTURES OF EVERYDAY LIFE The Limits of the Possible. Volume I. Civilization and Capitalism 15th-18th Century. By Fernand Braudel. Translation from the French Revised by Sian Reynolds. Illustrated. 623 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $30. By PAUL ROBINSON

title: BROOKHAVEN BESET BY PEDDLER ISSUE
description: STUFFED animals, paintings on velvet, hot dogs, roses and designer trash cans have become identified - at least in the minds of many Brookhaven residents - with the trucks that sell them alongside the road. And a law proposed by the Brookhaven Town Board that would severely curtail the vendors has met with so much opposition that the board has recalled it, pending further modification.

title: Elaine Moynihan, John Lisle Jr. Wed
description: Elaine Katherine Moynihan, marketing and communications coordinator for Day & Zimmermann Inc., an architectural and engineering concern in Philadelphia, was married yesterday to John Lisle Jr., who expects to join shortly the finance department of the Reading Company, a real estate investment company in Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia by the Rev. James Trimble and the Rev. Robert Curry, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Index; International
description: Mubarak urges Egyptians to nur- ture democracy 3 Dominicans elect a President today 3 Pope, ending four-day visit to Portugal, backs workers 4 Around the World 5 China preparing for its first su- perhighway 6 Corruption charges worry Sri Lanka's ruling party 8 Iraqi setbacks said to endanger Mideast balance of power 9 An Italian region recoils at plan for atomic plant 11 Haig's visit to Greece a step to- ward better relations 12 Eritrean rebels say an Ethiopian offensive has stalled 13 Critics of Reagan arms plan say it would increase risk to U.S. 17 Europe is told U.S. forces must be available for an emergency 19 Government/Politics Law of the Sea negotiator ques- tioned on lobbying efforts 21 Michigan's problems com- pounded by lower bond rating 28 Study of black teen-age unem- ployment cites welfare rules 31 A suit seeking to free detained Haitians concludes in Miami 34 Planning has begun for Carey's departure from Albany 38 General Around the Nation 26 City is concerned planned upstate plant may taint water supply 46 Study finds airborne carcinogens in three cities in Jersey 47 Religion West Germans work to rid texts of errors on Judiasm 15 New translations of the Bible focus on modern renderings 55 Obituaries Hugh Beaumont, father in TV's ''Leave It to Beaver'' 44 Health/Science W.H.O. study finds a big increase in drinking in 20 years 14 Arts/Entertainment Yale Repertory Theater offers ''Love's Labor's Lost'' 59 Dan Wagoner presents a new dance ''Stop Stars'' 60 Joseph Rutkowski gives clarinet music of Central Europe 64 New compositions by Carmen Moore are heard 64 ''The Six O'Clock Boys'' is staged Off Off Broadway 66 Polish play ''Wielopole Wielo- pole'' has U.S. premiere 66 Marianna Tcherkassky and Fer- nando Bujones dance ''Gi- selle'' 66 Style At Harvard, she rules Lampoon- land 68 A hosiery show and pizazz 68 News Analysis Drew Middleton assesses Argen- tina's military options 18

title: JAZZ FAMILIES BRIDGE THE GENERATION GAP
description: During the early decades of jazz it wasn't at all unusual to find fathers and sons playing together in the same bands and indulging in familial give-and-take - mature musicianship and on-the-job know-how versus youthful innovation and first-time exuberance. In the black neighborhoods of New Orleans and the other cities where jazz flourished early, only the holier-than-thou looked down on music as a profession. It was an honorable route out of the black ghetto, in many cases the only route.

title: THEATER: 'WIELOPOLE' IN U.S. PREMIERE
description: Tadeusz Kantor is a theater conceptualist - director, playwright, painter, scenic designer and theoretician. This creative interrelationship of artistic disciplines within a single individual may help explain the spellbinding impact of ''Wielopole Wielopole.'' In its American premiere at La Mama Annex, this new theater piece represents the second New York visit of Mr. Kantor's internationally celebrated Cricot 2 company. In 1979, the troupe appeared at La Mama with the equally haunting ''The Dead Class.''

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Witness Sentenced In Murder-for-Hire Case
description: A former New York City insurance agent who was granted Federal protection after his testimony on garment center racketeering in the mid-1970's was sentenced to 16 years to life Friday for arranging the murder of a wealthy La Jolla, Calif., lawyer last year.

title:
ANTIQUES;
RUBENSTEIN ON A ROLL: IT'S A PLAYER PIANO
description: PALISADES PARK ''BETWEEN 1911 and 1932, there were some three million player pianos made,'' Vincent Albanese said, and 85 to 90 percent of them were manufactured in the New York metropolitan area.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: JACQUELINE E. SHAFER, administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's Region 2, which takes in New Jersey and New York, said last week that the E.P.A. favored a Congressional proposal that would give industries that pollute rivers, streams and oceans four more years to comply with regulations.

title: STRESS ON THE BUDGET AND THE PROCESS
description: ''The easiest thing is to vote 'no' around here,'' lamented Representative James R. Jones, chairman of the House Budget Committee, as he began the task of getting a majority of his colleagues to vote 'aye' on the budget resolution his committee adopted last week.

title: TURNING A PAGE AT THE TRIBUNE CO.
description: THE cover of the Tribune Company's latest annual report shows a technician climbing a cable television tower toward a serenely blue sky. It is an eminently accurate metaphor for the hopes of the company as it tries to shed its newspaper identity and become, in its own words, ''one of the nation's major providers of information and entertainment.''

title: SOME PLANTS ARE A PESKY NUISANCE
description: Some plants in my garden are scheduled for eviction. One of them, the hardy ageratum, came late into my life. My early gardening years were spent in England where this plant, inexplicably, is not known. In Virginia, where I now live, it lines the roadsides. This should have been sufficient warning.

title: Hughes Land in Arizona Sold
description: Nineteen square miles of land, part of the estate of Howard R. Hughes, the late billionaire, will be sold for $75 million.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: 80. HANNAH ARENDT, by Elisabeth Young-Bruehl. (Yale University Press, $25.) A biography of the German-born philosopher and social critic. THE JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH, edited by Ted Hughes and Frances McCullough.

title: 'MEDEA' AND 'MASTER HAROLD' BRING FIRE TO BROADWAY
description: Euripides' ''Medea,'' which has just returned to Broadway in Robinson Jeffers's adaptation and with the superlative Zoe Caldwell in its central role, was written in 431 B.C. Athol Fugard's ''Master Harold ... and the boys,'' now at the Lyceum in its impeccable Yale Repertory Theater production, was given its world premiere last year. Say it was written yesterday. And then note that in the 2,412 years that have elapsed between the two turbulent dramatic statements, we seem not to have advanced an inch in coping with culture clashes, racial clashes, and the love-hate relationships they breed and breed and breed.

title: U.S. WARNS EUROPE ON MILITARY NEEDS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has told European leaders that the United States must be free to move American military forces out of Europe in an emergency in the same way that Britain has sent forces to the Falkland Islands, according to senior Pentagon officials.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR OFFER VIEWS LEWIS B. ROME
description: QUESTION 1

title: Boston Symphony Schedule
description: The Boston Symphony under Seiji Ozawa will play three programs in its six appearances at Carnegie Hall next season. The dates are Oct. 13-14, Jan. 26-27 and April 13-14. Included in the programs will be Berlioz's ''The Damnation of Faust'' and two works by Richard Strauss, ''Metamorphosen'' and the final scene from ''Salome.''

title: Around the Nation; Fire Destroys Block In Maine Tourist Town
description: Fire raced through a business block in the heart of this popular tourist village this afternoon, destroying at least a half dozen stores, officials said.

title: 3 'MILLIONAIRES' TO PLAY IN CHARITY L.P.G.A. TOURNAMENT
description: NEW ROCHELLE WITH three ''millionaires'' among the many stars scheduled to see action, the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour returns to the county this week. On the agenda is the $150,000 charity Chrysler Plymouth Classic at the historic Wykagyl Country Club on North Avenue here. Regular tournament play starts Friday morning.

title: A FRENZY OF COUPON CLIPPING IN A BID TO CUT COSTS
description: They usually draw you to dog food, breakfast cereals or laundry detergents, but they have already appeared for Paul Masson and Gallo wines and Seagram's liquors, and in such unexpected places as on the back of college football tickets.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC The Jam, who are at the Palladium on Tuesday, are a transatlantic anomaly. The trio is England's most popular rock group and has been for the past several years, but they've never had an American hit. Paul Weller, the Jam's guitarist, singer, and songwriter, does write about particularly British subjects - the sun setting on the Empire, unemployment and rioting, vignettes of class and caste and British city life. But so did the Kinks' Ray Davies, and the Kinks built a sizeable American following. The Jam have the musical goods, too - a supercharged trio sound that recalls the early Who.

title: STATES UNFETTERED BY A FIRST AMENDMENT CURB
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Reminder: The Environment Is International
description: The second United Nations Conference on the Global Environment met in Nairobi, Kenya, last week, in an effort, as Kenya's President, Daniel arap Moi put it, ''to rekindle the spirit of Stockholm.'' But that spirit, inspired by the first conference in Sweden 10 years ago, seemed to be flickering at best.

title: Paul Hicks Weds Caye A. Cavender
description: Caye Ann Cavender, a legislative aide for Representative Ed Jones, Democrat of Tennessee, was married yesterday to Paul Burton Hicks, a legislative assistant to Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Connecticut. The Rev. Robert P. Morrissey performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title:
ART;
TRENTON: ELEGANT, YET HUMANE, SPACE
description: THERE is some very good news from Trenton this week. The spacious and beautiful new galleries of Fine and Decorative Arts that just opened at the State Museum establish it as an almost new institution and one of the most important museums in New Jersey and the region.

title: Duane Marie George Wed
description: Duana Marie George, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo George of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday at the home of her parents to Henry Philippe Loustau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean Philippe Loustau of Triadelphia, W.Va. The Rev. Samuel Purdy of St. Peters Episcopal Church performed the ceremony. The bride and her husband were both graduated from Dartmouth College and are now studying for Master of Fine Arts degrees at the University of Illinois.

title: Harriet Beecher Stowe
description: To the Editor:

title: CLOSE-UP OF THE ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of the Times; BRODEUR: KING OF THE WEST
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia THERE is something of a fairy tale in the transformation of Richard Brodeur from a minor league goalie to a monarch who stirs regal music when he skates into the Pacific Coliseum.

title: G.O.P. CANDIDATES LEAD IN FUND RACE
description: Republican Congressional candidates, already backed by national party committees having more money than their Democratic counterparts, are also establishing clear advantages over Democrats in individual fund-raising efforts, Federal Election Commission records show.

title: MX DEADLINE RAISES HOST OF QUESTIONS
description: WASHINGTON THE Administration may be facing a Dec. 1 deadline to find a home for the MX, the new intercontinental ballistic missile that has been described as a vital to White House plans for lowering that muchvaunted ''window of vulnerability.''

title: AFTERMATH OF BLAST STILL FELTT IN BERGEN
description: PARAMUS SHOCK, astonishment and anger pervaded the faculty, staff and student body at Bergen Community College last week, days after a bomb went off in a hallway that only minutes earlier had been filled with students.

title: MARINAS CONVERTING TO CO-OPS
description: FOR reasons much like those behind the conversion of rental r esidences into cooperatives and condominiums, owners of marinas are b eginning to sell off their slips to boat owners.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
CROSS PURPOSES ON THE ECONOMY
description: CURRENT budget discussions defy conventional economic logic. V irtually all economic analysts - monetarists and Keynesians, D emocrats and Republicans -agree that the central economic task todayi s to reduce the Federal budget deficits.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ON THE ROCKS
description: It is called Geological Field Day and it will feature a special outdoor geology walk, but what the Garvies Point museum has in store for today's visitors is actually a ''rockathon.'' And collectors, beginnners as well as veterans, can take their treasures along for identification and swapping. There will also be films, demonstrations and an open house at the lapidary-jewelry workshop. All this takes place between 10 and 4 at the museum on Barry Drive in Glen Cove. Admission is 25 cents.SOMETHING OLD

title: BALLET: TCHERKASSY-BUJONES 'GISELLE'
description: ''Giselle'' made its seasonal debut in the repertory of American Ballet Theater on Friday at the Metropolitan Opera House, and what a debut it was. Marianna Tcherkassky and Fernando Bujones danced the doomed peasant maiden and nobleman in a performance that will long be remembered, to judge from the hoarse cheers it drew from the audience.

title:
DINING OUT;
A 'NEIGHBORHOOD' JAPANESE SPOT
description: FOLLOWING the welcome trend for Japanese restaurants to establish themselves upcounty, Hama has settled on Central Avenue's northern tip. Done in traditional light, warm wood and rice paper and sparked by seasonal flowers, the small, trim dining room seats 18 at tables and seven more at the sushi counter. The restaurant has the feel of little neighborhood places found throughout Japan, the sort that would not be amiss in more of Westchester's neighborhoods.

title: Lauren R. Place, C.M. Young Wed
description: Lauren Richmond Place, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Foster Place of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Meriam Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Webster Young of Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Everett Bodge performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Weaver-Cobb Canceled
description: The shoulder injury that forced Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Assocation heavyweight champion, to postpone his scheduled title fight against Randall (Tex) Cobb in Atlantic City June 2 has finally led to the bout's cancellation. Beginning June 3, Weaver is obligated under W.B.A. rules to negotiate a fight with the highest ranked contender, Michael Dokes.

title: Q and A; Question:Is there any potential health hazard from traveling through Seveso, Italy, the town that was contaminated with the highly toxic chemical dioxin TCDD? The highway from Italy to Switzerland passes directly through Zone A of the contaminated fenced-off area in Seveso. - C.P., Roslyn, N.Y.; Answer:Thomas Whiteside - author of ''The Pendulum and the Toxic Cloud,'' a review of the problems of the herbicide 2,4,5-T and associated dioxin contaminant - says: ''The levels of the extremely toxic TCDD dioxin in the soil of the most heavily contaminated, and fenced-off, section of Seveso are not much lower than they were on the day of the 1976 accident that caused a toxic cloud to descend on the area. Although constant streams of traffic along the Milan-Como autostrada, which runs by this section, undoubtedly have helped sweep dioxin-contaminated particles about, it seems reasonable to say that any health risks to tourist
description: Charter operators usually sell only through travel agents, who will probably have the brochures of several different operators for you to look at. The agent should be able to help you distinguish among charter offerings; be sure you know precisely what is included and what is not included in any package. Among the questions you should ask an agent are whether the price you are quoted is guaranteed against increase between the time you book and the charter's departure, and under what conditions you can cancel and at what cost, as well as what happens if the charter operator cancels.

title: Amritraj Defeats Lendl In Japan by 7-6, 3-6, 7-5
description: Ivan Lendl was beaten by Vijay Amritraj, 7-6, 3-6, 7-5, in the semifinals of a $200,000 exhibition tournament today.

title: AN ISRAELI ARAB ON ISRAEL'S ARABS
description: THE WEST BANK STORY By Rafik Halabi. Translated by Ina Friedman. 304 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: A STRANGE RECESSION
description: The current recession, now into its 10th month, is unusual in many respects. Interest rates, which generally tend to decline during slumps, have remained high.

title:
In New Jersey;
NEW HOME BUILDERS TAKE DIFFERENT TACKS
description: BUILDERS are going off in two directions,'' said Samuel Herzog, a partner in Wyndmoor Associates in East Brunswick. ''Either they're cutting down drastically on amenities to get the sale price down, or they're going crazy adding things to lure people to buy.''

title: The Region in Summary; Felonious Mayor Tests the Law In Union City
description: Just because a politician is in hot water with the law doesn't mean he's washed up with the voters, as two municipal elections in New Jersey demonstrated last week.

title: ISLAND MAKES GAINS AS HOST TO MEETINGS
description: TO Christopher Harris, sales manager for Gurney's Inn in Montauk, being host to corporate meetings and conferences is more than supplying note pads and a podium. He has hired a bulldozer and driver to haul shiny new Volvos through the sand so that visiting Volvo executives could view them through the dining room window as they ate. He has stocked 96 varieties of beer for a conference of beer wholesalers.

title: GERMAN ANCESTRY LEADS LIST IN A SURVEY OF U.S. ETHNICITY
description: More Americans can trace their ancestry to Germany than to any other country, the Census Bureau has reported. The new study, made public last Monday, said that 28.8 percent of Americans had reported themselves as being at least partly of German ancestry.

title: U.S. SUPPORT FOR BRITAIN IMPERILING LATIN POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to back Britain in the Falkland Islands conflict threatens to undermine the American strategy of combating Communism in Latin America in alliance with conservative governments of the region, according to analysts in the United States and Latin America.

title: Albany Notes; PLANNING FOR CAREY DEPARTURE BEGINS
description: Governor Carey's departure from office is more than six months away, but the planning for the move has already begun.

title: TO BE THE BRANCUSI OF POETRY
description: THE LAST LUNAR BAEDEKER By Mina Loy. Edited and Introduced by Roger L. Conover. With a Note by Jonathan Williams. Illustrated. 334 pp. Highlands, North Carolina: The Jargon Society. $25.

title: DRINKING REPORTED UP AMID A SHIFT IN TASTES
description: Considerable increases in the average per-capita rate of alcohol consumption in recent years have been accompanied by a shift in drinking tastes, according to the World Health Organization.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: TECHNICAL sophistication in art can inhibit expressive depth. An artist can become so concerned with the way he is doing something that he sometimes ignores what he is doing or what he is expressing.

title: The Region in Summary; Mid-Manhattan Gets Rezoned
description: Often described as a concrete jungle with streaks of occasional sunshine, midtown Manhattan may finally be seeing the light. By a 10 to 1 vote, the Board of Estimate last week approved zoning regulations that would create a special midtown district limiting the amount of sky and space new buildings may obstruct.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Lasting Laughs Jack Haley Jr., who was responsible for such Hollywood retrospectives as ''That's Entertainment,'' has once again romped through the archives and, this time, gleaned three hours' worth of cinematic comedy, from the silents through the screwball comedies of the 30's and 40's, right up to today's ''outrageous'' hits. The result is an ABC special, ''Hollywood: The Gift of Laughter,'' which will be broadcast Sunday at 8 P.M. Acting as hosts will be several celebrated practioners of the art of laugh-getting: Carol Burnett, Dom DeLuise, Jack Lemmon, Walter Matthau, Burt Reynolds and Richard Pryor.

title: Military Analysis
description: Argentina's high command is likely to come under pressure for an operation to restore Argentine prestige after a series of British attacks by sea, air and, now, on land in the Falkland Islands, according to military sources here.

title: 'A Special Sense Of Mission'
description: The demands upon teachers involved in the training of the autistic child are profound. The rewards, monetary and personal are small, insufficient, but exist for some.

title: KOCH MUST BALANCE A BUDGET AND AN AMBITION
description: A truism of government is that budgets are political documents, but not often do politics and budget-making coil around each other as tightly as they did in New York City last week. It is not routine, after all, for a Mayor to press for money from a state he hopes to soon run. That fact had several odd consequences as Mayor Koch presented his fifth and possibly final city budget.

title: UCONN SEEKS SPORTS FUNDS
description: A FEW years ago, Joe Soltys, the sports-information director at the University of Connecticut at Storrs, lamented that many people in the southern part of the state perceived the university as a small agricultural college up north, in the middle of nowhere.

title: LOCAL COMPOSERS TO GET A HEARING
description: ''THESE are times of artistic crises, and we are confronted with economic realities that make it very difficult to give contemporary composers a proper hearing,'' said Murry Sidlin, music director of the New Haven Symphony. ''Remember, in the 18th and 19th centuries, practically everything orchestras played was contemporary, but in our own time, the business of music slowly but surely has been edging out the art of music. There is now a desperate need for a statewide service to encourage composers who are living here, and writing music without much hope of having it played.''

title: Attic Ventilators Are Recalled By Sears After Fire Problems
description: The Consumer Product Commission has announced that 11,500 attic ventilators sold by Sears, Roebuck and Company are being voluntarily recalled by the manufacturer because they might cause fires.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PORTLAND
description: DAN HORTSCH is a staff writer for The Oregonian, a daily newspaper in Portland, Ore. By DAN HORTSCH

title: Major News in Summary; Graham Likes What He Sees
description: The Rev. Billy Graham got the full treatment last week as an honored guest in Moscow. And rarely has a politically unattached visitor returned the compliments so generously. Perhaps because Mr. Graham hoped for permission to return for a full preaching tour, he found much to praise, from improved living standards to church attendance and the absence of religous persecution.

title: The Nation in Summary; Builders, Buyers Get Some Help
description: In any recession, the housing industry is usually among the first to languish. The current slump, among the worst and most bewildering since World War II, has dealt housing a blow that may prove to have done structural damage to the industry, with many companies going belly up because of the slide's length and duration. Trying to forestall further damage, to stimulate the economy at large and to avoid voters' ire, an anxious House last week took a modest step and authorized $1 billion to subsidize up to six percentage points of the interest rate on mortgages for 74,000 moderate-income new home buyers. A similar emergency measure, bearing a $5 billion price tag, has been cleared for floor action in the Senate.

title: PIANO RECITAL: FEDER AND ELISHA GILGORE
description: The Feder-Gilgore Piano Duo was at its best Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall when romping through Poulenc's Concerto in D minor for Two Pianos. The whimsical, eccentric twists given to Mozart and cabaret tunes, the sweeps and outbursts, and the innocent patter, all emerged with ease and aplomb.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR OFFER VIEWS RUSSELL L. POST JR.
description: QUESTION 1

title: S. P. Harbinson 3d Weds Diana Drew
description: Diana Love Drew, daughter of Dr. Frances Love Drew and the late Judge John Drew of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Samuel Pollock Harbison 3d, son of Mrs. Samuel P. Harbison 2d, also of Pittsburgh, and the late Dr. Harbison.

title: Sports Puzzle Quiz
description: The following definitions have appeared in crossword puzzles. If you solve all of them, you are the Bo Derek of the sports world. The answers can be found on Page 8. Peeking is foul play. 1 Anthony or Campbell (4 letters) 2 Roush of baseball's Hall of Fame (3 letters) 3 Booth once installed at Yale (5 letters) 4 Nickname for Phil, the Boston-New York hockey star (4 letters) 5 One of Seaver's deceivers (5 letters) 6 Blanchard of Army fame (3 letters) 7 Former featherweight and lightweight champ (4 letters) 8 Item stolen while thousands watch (4 letters) 9 Lakers' prestidigitator (5 letters) 10 Carter who caused many a strike (3 letters)

title: Karen Eckhardt Married To Robert Stinchfield Jr.
description: The marriage of Karen Wils Eckhardt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Eckhardt Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., to Robert Whitney Stinchfield Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stinchfield, also of New Canaan, took place yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Edward Howley, the pastor, and the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of the Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, performed the ceremony.

title: UNCERTAIN CROSSWINDS FOR 'FLAGS OF CONVENIENCE'
description: The latest international conference on flags of convenience has left that maritime issue, involving more than one quarter of the world's shipping tonnage, adrift in arguments.

title: FOR A DEAF CHILD, A 'FRIENDLY TOWN'
description: From the stoop of his mother's house in the South Bronx, Desmond Foster can see vacant lots and buildings hollowed by fire. But that is not all there is to his world. From the time he was 7 years old, Desmond, who is deaf, has also seen the green hills and clear streams of the country in summer, where he goes to visit a family in the Lower Hudson Valley.

title: SPRING ON THE STRAWBERRY TRAIL
description: BETSY WADE is an editor on the national desk of The New York Times. BY BETSY WADE

title: SELLING A CO-OP WITHOUT A BROKER
description: VIRTUALLY everything in today's New York City cooperative housing market is unpredictable - the p rices are in flux, the financing arrangements are fragile and the c o-op boards are finicky. Just about the only thing that has remainedt he same is the broker's fee.

title: SUMMER FESTIVALS IN THE UNITED STATES AND CANADA
description: Alaska ALASKA FESTIVAL OF MUSIC -Anchorage, Aug. 28-Sept. 4. Orchestra performances under Alun Francis, with Peter Nero among the guest performers. SITKA SUMMER FESTIVAL - June 4-25. Chamber-music concerts Tuesdays and Fridays plus two Saturdays.

title: Wetlands Dispute
description: Last September, the state's Division of Coastal Resources, an arm of the Department of Environmental Protection, caused a stir when it approved a request by a developer in Loveladies, Long Beach Township, to fill in 11 1/2 acres of state-regulated wetlands to further the development of a 41-home tract on Barnegat Bay.

title: Correction
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Times Magazine May 16, 1982
