description: William Safire 20 On Language Let Freedom Love L.R. Shannon 32 Guest Observer Saving Al-Zalfador Judy Klemesrud 34 Ivan Lendl Battles to Be Number One Although the professional rating system ranks Lendl Number Three, behind John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors, many regard the young Czech player as king of the tennis courts. Lendl is determined to prove his supporters right.

title: Saving Families From Disintegration
description: I, too, am a teacher of the autistic. However, in contrast with Anonymous, I am unconcerned with labels. There are few autistic children who exhibit all of the classic characteristics.

title:
CAMERA;
SOME RULES TO FOLLOW IN CANDID PHOTOGRAPHY
SAFE HAVEN FOR TROPICAL SPECIES
description: Most mornings, Ned Fetcher climbs into a heavy harness and winches himself to a platform 150 feet above the damp undergrowth of the rain forest. There, disturbed only by an occasional red-headed woodpecker or a family of monkeys, he proceeds with his post-doctoral research into the physiology of tropical trees.

title: World Title To Biggs
description: Tyrell Biggs of Philadelphia became the first world champion in the new super heavyweight class today by outpointing Francesco Damiani, the European champion, 4-1, in the finals of the World Amateur Boxing Championship.

title: IVAN LENDL BATTLES TO BE NUMBER ONE
description: Judy Klemesrud is a reporter in the Living/Style section of The New York Times. By Judy Klemesrud It was a sight that not many people get to see: Ivan Lendl - the ''Ivan the Terrible'' of the tennis courts, the player known for his icy stares, mental toughness and devastating forehand - was actually smiling. The 22-year-old right-hander, whom some consider to be the best player in the world today, was talking about his first memories of tennis, when he was a toddler and his mother, Olga, then ranked No. 3 in their native Czechoslovakia, would take him with her to practice.

title: Cela Wright Becomes Bride of Matthew B. Hobbs
description: Helen Cecilia Wright, daughter of Helen Mann Wright and John H. Wright, both of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Baird Hobbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Warren Hobbs of Chestnut Hill, Mass. Msgr. George T. Deas performed the ceremony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Miss Amory Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Carhart Amory of New York, Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. Amory's daughter, Renee Elisabeth Amory, to William Parker Ketcham, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Parker Ketcham of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: PLANNING FOR THE WORST
description: HARTFORD IN case of impending nuclear war, if you live in Stamford and do not have a car, you would be evacuated for safety to Brookfield, according to the official relocation instructions.

title: SEDUCED AND ABANDONED BY N.Y.C.
description: The Autobiography of Lewis Mumford The Early Years Illustrated. 500 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $19.95. By Paul Goldberger

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AN ACTIVIST'S ODYSSEY FOR BUS SERVICE
description: WHEN word came from Albany that state officials would approve two express-bus runs between the county and Manhattan to compete with Conrail, probably no one was more surprised than Paul Feiner, the political activist who for months had fought hard for the idea.

title: FROM THE GRILL, FOR ALFRESCO DINING--SHRIMPS
description: AS spring gently warms up to summer, thoughts turn to outdoor meals, to barbecues, dinners or drinks on the terrace that belong to casual dining. Shrimp falls into this category because it is so easy to cook. Recently, there has been an abundance in the markets of fresh small red ones sold with their heads on and also of the huge shrimps that are delicious marinated in olive oil and lemon juice and grilled over hot coals.

title: WHY DO PEOPLE LEARN SO LITTLE FROM THE PAST?
description: IT IS becoming increasingly apparent that what newly remarried couples learn from their past marital experience is that they do not learn anything from their past marital experience.

title: Anne Scribner Bigham Becomes Bride Of John Storm Hutchins, Bank Aide
description: Anne Scribner Bigham, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Bigham of New Marlborough, Mass., and the late Julia Scribner Bigham was married yesterday to John Storm Hutchins, son of Waldo Hutchins 3d of Glen Head, L.I., and the late Joan Adams Hutchins. The Rev. Bartlett A. McCarthy, a brother-in-law of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Great Barrington, Mass.

title: KAENEL, 16, NOW 2 FOR 2, AGAINST SHOEMAKER
description: In the first few strides after Cowboy Jack Kaenel rode Aloma's Ruler across the finish line at the Preakness today, the 16-year-old jockey raised his whip in triumph. Moments later, Bill Shoemaker pulled alongside on the 1-to-2 favorite, Linkage.

title: MIDEAST'S BALANCE HELD ENDANGERED
description: The recent military setbacks dealt to Iraq by the Iranians pose a danger to the balance of power in the Middle East as well as to American military and political interests in the region, according to Western and Arab diplomats here.

title: DESIGN
description: Renovated Down To the Last Detail Like beauty, remodeling is at its best when it is more than skin deep. In renovating this interior, the designer managed to transform a set of random existing conditions into an inspired new order that seems every bit as intentional as brand-new construction would. here is perhaps just one thing more terrifying to an architect than facing a blank sheet of tracing paper on the drawing board and that is facing a sheet of tracing paper that shows a set of impossible, pre-existing conditions about which nothing can be done. Renovation is to new construction what an obstacle course is to a sprint - maddeningly difficult but not without its special satisfactions when the race is won.

title: HOW BARYSHNIKOV RUNS HIS BALLET COMPANY
description: Can a still-active performer, a star dancing at the peak of his career, administer a ballet company? The announcement in June 1979 that Mikhail Baryshnikov would take over the directorship of American Ballet Theater surprised the dance world. What could a dancer know about running a ballet company? And could a foreign-born dancer run an American company?

title: Cosmos Hope Hunt Is a Draw
description: The management of the Cosmos hopes that the return of Steve Hunt will help put fans back in the seats at Giants Stadium and help the team regain more speed in its attack.

title: FOR WEEKEND ATHLETES
description: Showing a weekend athlete how to jog, smash a tennis ball, gallop a horse or pedal a bicycle, without being injured, is the aim of a day of lectures and workshops sponsored by Ridgewood's Valley Hospital next Saturday.

title: CABARET: JEREE PALMER'S VARIED STYLES
description: One of the songs that Jeree Palmer, a tall, slim and rather stately woman, sings at Sweetwater's, Amsterdam Avenue at West 68th Street, where she is appearing through May 29, is a song of identity crisis, ''I've Never Been to Me.''

title: Anne Holloway, Christopher D. Greene to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Proctor Holloway Jr. of Fair Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Toolin Holloway, to Christopher Dunning Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E.N. Greene Jr., of Fair Haven, N.J.

title: CANCER-AGENT TESTS PLANNED NEAR RESEVOIR
description: New York City environmental officials are concerned that a proposed hydroelectric plant at an upstate reservoir could sharply increase the level of a carcinogen in the water supply. As a result, they plan to conduct tests at a similar plant where high levels of a precursor of the carcinogen occur.

title: WALKING (NOT CLIMBING) THE ALPS
description: JEREMY BERNSTEIN's latest book is ''Science Observed,'' published by Basic Books. By JEREMY BERNSTEIN

title: Madeleine Cutler Plans to Be Wed
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Frederick Sanford Cutler of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeleine Whitridge Cutler, to William Wilson Thompson 2d, son of Lieut. Col. William Earle Thompson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Thompson of Martinsburg, W.Va.

title: The Rebecca West Profile
description: One should not have to come to Rebecca West's defense; she can manage that very well herself (''Rebecca West,'' by Leslie Garis, April 4). Still, some comment seems necessary.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Just when the dance avant-garde had convinced us that pure-movement was ''in,'' that stories and emotions were passe, along comes the latest experimental jag and gives itself a name, ''ParaNarrative.'' Sunday from 1 to 6 P.M., the ''ParraNarrative'' Spring Dance Festival closes its first exploration by choreographers who say they are ''rethinking the referential import of movement and gesture.''

title: MUSTO CASE HANGS ON FINE LEGAL POINTS
description: TRENTON THE President of the State Senate, Carmen A. Orechio, Democrat of Nutley, is expected to ask tomorrow that a special election be held to fill the vacancy created by the conviction, on Federal bribery charges, of William V. Musto.

title: Italian Killed by Gunmen
description: Gunmen firing submachine guns from a passing car shot and killed a 26-year-old garage owner today in a village south of Naples, the police reported. The police said they were treating the killing as a settling of accounts between rival gangs of the Camorra, the Naples version of the Sicilian Mafia.

title: CABLE TELEVISION COMES TO FAIRFIELD
description: ALONG country lanes and under busy highways, cable television, with its array of around-the-clock programs of films, sports, news and ''adult'' shows, is wending its way into Fairfield County.

title: PHILLIES WIN 6TH IN A ROW
description: Gary Matthews and Bob Dernier hit home runs in the eighth inning to help the Philadelphia Phillies to a 5-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight. It was the sixth consecutive victory for the Phillies and their 12th in 13 games.

title: The Region in Summary; Santa's Agents Were the F.B.I.
description: According to the F.B.I. at least, it hasn't all been fun and games at the Yonkers outlet of Toys 'R' Us Inc., a nationwide toy-store chain. A two-year investigation ended last week with the arrests of five men, including Angelo Grippo, chairman of the Democratic Party in Yonkers, on charges of extorting $13,500 to allow the store to open for the 1980 Christmas buying season.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
You Name It, Cake For All Occasions
description: Cake Decor at Mohegan Lake embellishes celebrations for all ages: birthdays, anniversaries, graduations, holidays, showers, weddings, christenings, bar and bas mitzvahs, first communions and confirmations, with additional trinkets of recognition for retirement parties and sports from chess to hunting.

title: PLAINFIELD SHOWHOUSE
description: The handiwork of 27 New Jersey interior designers who have decorated 34 rooms and hallways of a restored turn-of-the century mansion will be on display all this month in Plainfield.

title: CABLE TV TAKES THEATRICAL TURN
description: THE cable television boom has struck the theater full blast. Some new plays have closed cable deals even before they have opened for previews, and old plays are being recycled for the so-called ''new wave'' medium, which is also channeling short-lived regional theater productions toward preservation for posterity.

title: THEATER:'LOVE'S LABOR'S'
description: The Yale Repertory Theater has ended its season with an amiable but ineffectual ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' directed by Mladen Kiselov. Last year, Mr. Kiselov, a Bulgarian director, offered a lighter-than-air production of ''An Attempt at Flying,'' an epic about a runaway balloon. His attempt at Shakespeare is more in the nature of a student production. As such, it is several cuts below Michael Langham's recent version at the Juilliard Theater Center.

title: THE JOYS OF READING
description: By 1955, when I was 10, my father's reading had gone to his head. My father's reading during that time, and for many years after, consisted, for the most part, of Mark Twain's ''Life on the Mississippi.'' He traveled up and down the East Coast for the family firm; he traveled alone. He would check into a hotel, find a bookstore, and choose for the night's reading, after what I fancy to have been long deliberation, yet another copy of ''Life on the Mississippi.'' He brought all these books home. There were dozens of them on the living-room shelves. From time to time, I read one.

title: Talking Partnerships; SHARING A MORTGAGE ON A HOME
description: YOU'VE found the house you want, but you cannot afford it. The down p ayment may be prohibitive, or perhaps the monthly payments are too h igh.

title: Berardi Beats Hannahs In A.B.C. Masters Final
description: Top-seeded Joe Berardi of Brooklyn scored a 236-216 victory over Ted Hannahs of Akron, Ohio, to win the $40,600 first prize in the $200,000 American Bowling Congress Masters Tournament today.

title: Lisa Lamont Plans Wedding
description: The engagement of Elisabeth Jung Lamont to Charles Stanley Wolcott has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lansing Lamont of New York and North Haven, Me., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Wolcott Jr. of Hamilton, Mass.

title: No Headline
description: Jackie Robinson was much more than just the major leagues' first black baseball player. He was a symbol of determination and dedication for millions like Robert Curvin and myself. No. 42's play on the field changed forever the way blacks and whites thought about one another and broke the ground for generations of talented black athletes.

title: Around the World; Dutch Mediator Studying Government Crisis
description: An official mediator began an attempt today to solve the Dutch Government crisis with a brief meeting with Prime Minister Andries van Agt.

title: HOW PLAYERS ARE RANKED
description: Although Ivan Lendl seems to be winning almost every tournament he plays, he is still ranked only No. 3 on the Association of Tennis Professionals computer - behind John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors. The reason is that five out of the six tournaments Lendl has won this year have been sponsored by World Championship Tennis, the maverick tennis circuit whose results are not included in the A.T.P. rankings.

title: Subletting
description: To the Editor:

title: Future Events Performance the Ploy
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. On Tour May 20 - The itinerary for the 29th house and garden tour from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. to benefit the New York University Medical Center's Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine calls for six stops in the Hudson Valley. Included are Lyndhurst, the Gothic revival mansion that once belonged to Jay Gould; Sunnyside, Washington Irving's home, and Will-O-Woods, a 1939 Art Deco house set above a large lake and overlooking a pond. Tickets are $20, from 340-6196. Parental Aid May 22 - Pinchas Zukerman and Jaime Laredo, the violinists, and their wives, Eugenia Zukerman, the flutist, and Sharon Robinson, the cellist, will give a concert at Alice Tully Hall to benefit the Bank Street School for Children and Bank Street College. The musicians have children enrolled in the school, as has Edward Koren, the cartoonist, who contributed the illustration for a poster depicting a band of his long-nosed furry creatures for the event. Patrons will get a chance afterward to eat omelets at the Ginger Man with the artists who are donating their talents. Tickets for entire evening, $125. For the concert alone, $25 and $50.

title: LIMITING ROUND-THE-CLOCK NOISE
description: TENANTS at 8 East 48th Street say their troubles with nighttime c onstruction noise began in March, soon after a subcontractor for theT ishman Construction Corporation began demolishing buildings across t he street to make way for Tower 49, a 43-story office building.

title: Where to Get More Cruise Information
description: American Canadian Line, P.O. Box 368, Warren, R.I. 02885 (401-245-1350; 800-556-7450 outside Rhode Island). American Cruise Lines, 1 Marine Park, Haddam, Conn. 06438 (203-345-8551; 800-243-6755 outside Connecticut). American Hawaii Cruises, 3 Embarcadero Center, Suite 2500, San Francisco, Calif. 94111 (415-392-9400; 800-227-3666 outside California; 800-622-0666 in California). Astor United Cruises, P.O. Box 13140, Port Everglades Station, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 33316 (305-523-3200; 800-432-3611 in Florida, 800-327-8152 outside Florida). Bahama Cruise Line, 61 Broadway, Suite 2518, New

title: PAUL NEWMAN'S PLACE
description: Six months ago Paul Newman and his wife, Joanne Woodward, bought a 54-acre horse farm in North Salem with the idea of ''turning it into the best horse show and community educational facility in the Northeast,'' according to Nick Karazissis, general manager and head instructor. Their progress in renovating and rehabilitating the place, called Far West Farms, has been so successful that the A-rated Nimrod Horse Show will be held there from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Thursday through next Sunday.

title: Home Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: HONG KONG SPURS CHINA'S FIRST SUPERHIGHWAY
description: China is preparing to build its first modern superhighway -with tollbooths - to link this southern city with the British colony of Hong Kong and the Portuguese enclave of Macao.

title: Major News in Summary; Decision Day On Falklands Seems at Hand
description: Pressures mounted inexorably last week to resolve the Falklands crisis very soon, if not by diplomacy then by full-scale combat.

title: A 'Minute Step' Can Increase Joy
description: ''This Is the Way She Is'' reflects a level of depression, despair and negativism that clearly marks the anonymous author as unfit to teach special-education children.

title: ON SUICIDE
description: With a worldwide increase in the suicide rate, a literature of suicide, like a flower that blooms in the shade, has sprung up. Everyone is trying to claim the body: romantics, rationalists, civil libertarians and psychoanalysts.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: Ken Follett's ''The Man From St. Petersburg,'' one of the two new hard-cover fiction best sellers, was a strong runner-up last week, and the other new title, Rita Mae Brown's ''Southern Discomfort,'' was a runner-up for several weeks. On the nonfiction list, Jonathan Schell's ''The Fate of the Earth'' has moved firmly into third place.

title: GYPSY MOTH CONTROL DISPUTED
description: THOSE tan, moss-like patches on oak, linden and other trees are gypsy moth eggs, and in the next few weeks they will hatch into caterpillars with an apparently insatiable appetite for leaves.

title: THE EDUCATION OF A COLD WARRIOR
description: JOHN FOSTER DULLES The Road to Power. By Ronald W. Pruessen. Illustrated. 575 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: A SHORT, RICH AND TORTURED LIFE
description: WALTER BENJAMIN The Story of a Friendship. By Gershom Scholem. Translated by Harry Zohn. Illustrated. 242 pp. Philadelphia: The Jewish Publication Society of America. $13.95.

title: NEW PROMISES AND POSTURES IN NEGOTIATING NUCLEAR ARMS
description: WASHINGTON THE machinery began moving into place last week. The United States and the Soviet Union were once again at the beginning of a long and painful haul toward an agreement limiting strategic nuclear arms.

title: Elizabeth Walton, Daniel Koob Wed
description: Elizabeth Baird Walton, daughter of Mrs. Robert Clark Walton of Weston, Conn., and the late Mr. Walton, was married yesterday to Daniel James Koob, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hilary James Koob of Slayton, Minn., and Kalani Honua, Hawaii. The Rev. Robert W. Greene performed the ceremony in the Norfield Congregational Church in Weston.

title: West German Bids Moscow Respond to Arms Proposals
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany called on the Soviet Union today to respond positively to Western proposals for disarmament negotiations.

title: PLANTING MORE THAN A GARDEN
description: TUCKED like a footnote at the bottom of a winding hill, the street where I lived more than 30 years ago sat somewhat apart from the rest of the world. All the houses were run down and neglected; time had blanched them a nondescript hue.

title: HOW NEW LINES WILL AFFECT POLITICAL RACES
description: THE State Legislature completed a burdensome task last week, the drawing of new political boundaries for the State Senate and Assembly as well as for the House of Representatives. In the county, it has meant disaster for a few, difficulties for some and opportunities for others.

title: ONE-SHARE STOCKHOLDER TILTS AT UTILITY
description: TRENTON AMAN who used his one share of Public Service Electric & Gas Company stock to get an antinuclear proposal onto the company's proxy statement - and who got almost five million votes for his proposal - plans to pursue the matter with the utility.

title: Kennedy Town Asks Gun Ban
description: The birthplace of President John F. Kennedy and his brother, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, is asking permission from the State Legislature to pass a ban on handguns. Members of the Brookline town meeting voted 115 to 89 Thursday to send a petition to the Legislature. ''

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Dr. Love. ''The greatest thing we have is life. And where there's life, there's hope. The old truisms about love and life - know yourself, love yourself in order to be able to love others, seize the day - are still entirely valid. Life is God's gift to you. The way you live your life is your gift to God. Make it a fantastic one..''

title: Q and A; Subtenant's Rights
description: Question: I am subleasing an apartment with only a verbal agreement. I have been here two years and we have just received a ''red herring'' offering for a noneviction plan to convert the building to a condominium. The woman who has the written lease on the apartment is planning to buy it. What are my rights, if any, of being able to purchase an apartment at the insider price from the sponsors? ... H.M., Manhattan Answer: Because you are a sublessee, you have no right to purchase any apartment in the building at the insider price, which is reserved only for prime tenants. If the prime tenant were to decide not to purchase the apartment at the insider price, you would still not have the right to do so unless she had signed a valid contract assigning her right to purchase to you.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 9 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 5 4 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men. 3 6 5 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A greedy crew at work in the world of horse-racing and computer programming. 4 2 3 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 5 1 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 6 3 15 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 7 4 5 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way love the same woman.

title: Postal Trap
description: ''Earn $750 a month in your spare time from your own home,'' one advertisement promised. Another guaranteed: ''Lose Weight Like Never Before.''

title: The Region in Summary; Richmond Faces Sixth Inquiry
description: Almost every week, it seems, Congressman Frederick W. Richmond faces a new accusation or potential accuser. Last week the trouble was close to home as the House of Representatives ethics committee began a ''preliminary inquiry'' into allegations of misconduct on the part of the four-term Democrat from Brooklyn.

title: New York City To the Editor:$
description: Actors know it's a joke when critics say the play wasn't much but the acting was stupendous. Someone always had to write what the actors were stupendous doing.

title: Ill-Fated Twins
description: From the moment of birth on May 5, 1981, Scott and Jeff Mueller of Danville, Ill, were doomed to notoriety if they survived. They were Siamese twins, joined at the waist and sharing a leg and some digestive organs.

title: NOVA SCOTIA'S CHARMS FOR CAMPERS
description: JAMES FERON is chief of the Westchester bureau of The Times. BY JAMES FERON

Monroe, Conn. $107,000 20 Blue Hills Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; *2*cathedral ceiling and family room, 1 acre; taxes $1,965. Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. $79,500 125 Oneida Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; two *2*kitchens, covered porch, quarter acre; taxes $2,452.

title: A NEW CENTER FOR THE GIRL SCOUTS
description: WHEN Edith Carpenter Macy, then chairman of the Girl Scout National Executive Board, died in 1926 at the age of 54, her husband went to the Girl Scouts and offered to build, as a memorial to her, a training school for Girl Scout leaders. It was a project Mrs. Macy had hoped to accomplish in her lifetime. Within a year, on a 265-acre tract that Mr. Macy had purchased, a rustic stone and timber building, known as the Great Hall, was constructed. That summer, the first group of Girl Scout leaders came from 32 countries to dedicate the training center, Camp Edith Macy.

title: THE 'MISERABLE' FALKLANDS: IN DISPUTE SINCE THEIR DISCOVERY
description: The Falklands, dismissed by Charles Darwin as ''miserable islands,'' have known nothing but controversy ever since the rain-swept, virtually treeless, rocky archipelago was first spotted by European sailors.

title: THE ISSUE OF OFFICE ROMANCES
description: ONCE it was simply a topic of gossip in the typing pool. Nowadays t he office romance is being discussed and debated in the executive s uite where the question is not ''What is this thing called love?'' b ut ''What does it mean for the bottom line?''

title: News Analysis
description: The Rev. Billy Graham's comments on religious freedom in Moscow have aroused considerable discussion, largely because they seemed to place the conservative evangelist in the same camp with liberal church leaders in dealing with the issue of religion in Communist countries.

title: The U.N. Today; May 17, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: COMMON MARKET DELAYS VOTE TO RETAIN ARGENTINE BOYCOTT
description: Foreign ministers from the 10 Common Market countries failed to reach agreement tonight on an extension of economic sanctions against Argentina, which were imposed a month ago in support of Britain over Argentina's seizure of the Falkland Islands.

title: ALL THINGS TO ALL MEN
description: In preaching the Gospel two millennia ago, did the Apostle Paul challenge the dictatorship of the Caesars? The Rev. Billy Graham told ABC's ''This Week With David Brinkley'' today that the answer was no: the first evangelist ''never lifted a finger against Rome.''

title: Military Analysis
description: The military arguments for prompt British landings in the Falkland Islands are multiplying. Supporting the argument, military analysts said, are the evident dangers to the British task force in continuing the blockade in the face of numerically superior Argentine air power and three unlocated submarines. Also on the side backing a landing, the analysts said, was the relative ease of Friday's commando raid on Pebble Island.

title: Big-League Material
description: It took Tom O'Malley, a slick-fielding third baseman, three years to progress in the San Francisco Giants organization from the rookie league to the Class AAA franchise at Phoenix. But his next jump was a quick one.

title: Emmeline Wexer Wed To Robert David Shlien
description: The marriage of Emmeline Wexer, an assistant treasurer at the Bankers Trust Company, to Robert David Shlien, who expects to graduate May 28 from the George Washington University School of Medicine, took place yesterday in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony.

title: VILLAINOUS DEMOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Visa Tensions With Japan WASHINGTON
description: A visa war may break out between the United States and Japan, a further indication of the tensions plaguing the nations' trade relationship.

title: THE 'PUSHED-OUT' YOUTH NO ONE WANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Proxy War Tacticians
description: NOT since T. Roland Berner, the cantankerous chairman of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, started a proxy fight and almost succeeded in taking over the Kennecott Corporation a few years ago, have so many dissident stockholders been taking on so many corporations, insisting that they can do more for the stockholders than the officers can.

title: Coalition Backs Cuomo in Race
description: The New Democratic Coalition, which represents the most liberal elements of the Democratic Party in New York City, endorsed Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday for the Democratic nomination for governor.

title: CHAMBER RECITAL: ROSEWOOD QUINTET
description: THE Rosewood Quintet, five young wind musicians who made their debut in Carnegie Recital Hall a year ago, returned there Saturday afternoon to give us an idea of their progress.

title: ATTACK ON OLMSTED AROUSES FUROR
description: For New Yorkers, it is somewhat like denouncing Shakespeare at Stratford-on-Avon or inveighing against Wagner at Bayreuth. A new pamphlet is challenging the reputation of Frederick Law Olmsted - generally considered to be the father of landscape architecture in the United States and revered by many as the principal designer of Central Park.

title: Rise in Thai Heroin Flow Into Chicago Reported
description: Chicago has apparently become a major distribution center for heroin from Southeast Asia, and the authorities are increasing

title: Queens Trackmen Capture Title
description: Paul Green captured four gold medals and led Queens College to the team title with 163 points as the two-day City University of New York track and field championships ended yesterday at Brooklyn College.

title: A New L.I.R.R. Train On Summer Schedule
description: A new westbound train to serve the East End of Long Island on Sunday and holiday evenings is on the Long Island Rail Road's summer schedule, which went into effect this morning and will remain until October.

title: EYELESS IN GAZA (1); BOSTON, May 16 -While in Israel in March I wrote about the tendency of Israelis to avert their eyes from the unpleasant realities of military rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Half the column was devoted to the military government's practice of banning certain books in the territories - a matter that had first been discussed in the Tel Aviv University literary quarterly by Ory Bernstein, an Israeli poet, lawyer and businessman, and had then been taken up by Amos Elon, columnist for the newspaper Haaretz.
description: In my column I gave a few examples of books ''that at various times have been forbidden,'' including Shakespeare's ''Merchant of Venice,'' Orwell's ''1984'' and Walter Laqueur's ''The Soviet Union in the Middle East.'' When the piece appeared, the occupation authorities responded sharply, denying that they practiced any improper censorship.

title: OUTDOORS: RIVER RAFTING EMERGES IN THE EAST
description: filled rubber boat buckled and bent under the blows like a tent in a gale.

title: Steinbach Bros.
description: When Coach John Anderson of the University of Minnesota makes out his starting lineup for baseball games, he writes the name Steinbach three times. He usually pencils in Tim, a senior, as designated hitter; Tom, a junior, as right fielder, and Terry, a sophomore, as third baseman.

title: Bell Seeking Votes to Close U.S. Department of Education
description: Only one-fifth of the Senate is ready to help President Reagan abolish the Department of Education, and it will be ''a while'' before the Administration moves to dissolve the agency, Education Secretary T.H. Bell has said.

title: LAKERS' PARTY STARTS AT 6 A.M.
description: Despite the early hour of 6 this morning in San Antonio, protocol remained in order at the hotel headquarters of the Los Angeles Lakers. When Pat Riley, the rookie coach, stepped to the front desk, whistling, the attendant asked, ''Was everything here to your satisfaction, sir?''

title: TEAMSTER CHIEF, RECALLING EARLY DAYS, DEFENDS UNION AS 'BEST IN THE WORLD
description: The headquarters of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a pile of marble so huge and gleaming it seems it could cause snowblindness, is in a splendid location, on Louisiana Avenue, across from the Capitol. But Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' president, in his third-floor office looking out his large, tintedglass window with a fine view of the Capitol, said that was no advantage.

title: News Analysis
description: On the penultimate page of a long report on constitutional changes published last week with great fanfare, the Government of Prime Minister P.W. Botha is urged to consider issuing a ''declaration of intention'' that would give the major population groups and their leaders ''some idea of the kind of South Africa which is projected.''

title: Iraqis Report Sinking Two Iranian Vessels
description: Iraqi forces sank two Iranian vessels and killed at least 45 Iranian soldiers in fighting Saturday night and today, an Iraqi military communique reported.

title: EINSTEIN'S WARNING FOR THE NUCLEAR AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: YET AGAIN, SCHOOL PRAYER
description: Prayer in the public schools is back in the news again. Actually, ever since the United States Supreme Court banned devotional reading from the Bible and the recitation of prayers in public schools in 1962 and 1963, the issue never has been out of the news very long. Hundreds of bills have been introduced in Congress to ''repeal'' the Supreme Court decisions, and proponents of school-sponsored prayer have repeatedly pressed for a constitutional amendment overruling these decisions. Politicians know a good issue when they see it.

title: Franc Rumor Denied
description: French Economy Minister Jacques Delors today denied rumors of an imminent devaluation of the franc. Speaking on French radio, he said that the economic approach adopted by the Socialist Government did not merit the criticism that some economists had made. On Friday, foreign-exchange dealers said, the Bank of France sold around 200 million West German marks, the equivalent of about $86 million, to support the franc.

title: KATHY WITHWORTH: BACK ON HER GAME
description: ATLANTA MUCH of golf history has been written in the state of Georgia. And though yesterday's chapter did not take place among the azaleas at Augusta National, the little ceremony that took place on the 18th green of the Brookfield West course in suburban Roswell will go down in history as a moment golf honored one of its true masters - Kathy Whitworth.

title: Lewis Jumps 28-3
description: Carl Lewis capped a sensational weekend today by soaring 28 feet 3 inches twice in the long jump, the thirdbest distance in history, in the U.C.L.A.-Pepsi Invitational track and field meet at Drake Stadium.

title: POLICE CHIEF ON DEFENSIVE
description: When Daryl F. Gates, the police chief of Los Angeles, had to defend himself last week for making what critics contended was a racist remark, he was following a custom established by many of his predecessors.

title: TINY CONNECTICUT TOWN IN A BIG HOUSING BATTLE
description: In this mile-square borough, the elevation is 913 and the population slightly less. Downtown amounts to a pizza parlor across the street from a pharmacy. Fresh blueberry muffins cost 30 cents and a barbershop quartet warbles in the local school on Saturday nights.

title: SYMPOSIUM SEES WAYS APES RESEMBLE HUMANS
description: The family of man gathered on the East Side over the weekend to watch the family of apes. While other New Yorkers were basking in the sun or strolling through street fairs, nearly 1,700 primate enthusiasts sat inside a stuffy auditorium, riveted by slides of apes eating, sleeping, scratching and even kissing.

title: LOUIS SACHS
description: Louis Sachs, a lawyer who specialized in workers' compensation law, died Saturday at his home in New Haven.

title: FED POLICY MEETING AWAITED
description: The fear that interest rates might rise in the second half of this year is widespread in the credit markets, but the more immediate concern of traders and investors is the prospect of a modest loosening of the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy.

title: Jewelry and Coins Stolen at 2 Hotels
description: The wife of a Korean diplomat was robbed at gunpoint in the elevator of a Manhattan hotel, and $400,000 worth of rare coins were taken from a Texas coin collector in another Manhattan hotel, the police said.

title: A'S SERIES IS SPLIT
description: It took eight pitchers and 26 other players 3 hours 42 minutes to play nine innings today, but the Oakland A's finally outlasted the New York Yankees, 7-6, for a split of their four-game series.

title: Bridge: Tournaments Get Tougher With Experts on Increase
description: Although the number of tournament players has changed little in the last two decades, remaining around the 200,000 mark, the number of experts has certainly grown. There are now far more teams capable of giving the favored squads a tough battle.

title: PRODUCTION BY OPEC INCHES UP
description: Increased crude oil output by Iran and Nigeria has increased total production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to 17 million barrels a day, compared to the low of 16 million last month, a Middle East weekly oil publication reported here today.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, 17, 1982
description: International Two Argentine ships were attacked by British planes in the channel between the two main Falkland Islands, and one of the ships was abandoned by its crew, the Defense Ministry announced in London. The attacks were carried out by harrier jets from the carrier Hermes. One of the jets was struck by Argentine antiaircraft fire, but returned safely, the British said. The two ships were believed to be supplying food to the Argentine troops on West Falkland, the more sparsely populated of the two islands. (Page A1, Column 6.) The U.S. Embassy in Buenos Aires denied that it was guilty of any ''inappropriate conduct'' in the Falklands crisis. The unusual statement followed Argentine newspaper reports that Ambassador Harry W. Shlaudeman and other embassy officials had met with opposition political leaders in an attempt to ''destabilize'' the military junta lead by Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri. The newspaper reports had cited unidentified sources high in the Government. Argentine journalists and Western diplomats said the sources for the accusations were leading officers in the junta. (A1:4-5.)

title: Arrows Tie Series With Steamers
description: The New York Arrows defeated the St. Louis Steamers, 5-3, tonight to tie the three-of-five-game Major Indoor Soccer League championship series at one game apiece.

title: Miss Austin Wins Final in Japan
description: Tracy Austin defeated Kathy Jordan, 6-3, 6-1, in the women's singles final of the $200,000 Gunze exhibition tennis tournament today.

title: Bernstein's Fall
description: Halfway through one of his typically impassioned performances of Tchaikovsky's ''Francesca da Rimini'' with the Israel Philharmonic in Houston the other night, Leonard Bernstein lost his balance and tumbled off the podium.

title: Yonkers Marathon Is Won by Hall
description: Competing without sleep after an all-night shift as a security guard, Ray Hall of the Millrose Athletic Association won the 46th annual Yonkers Marathon today.

title: MONDAY, MAY 17, 1982; International
description: OPEC convenes in Ecuador this week for its semiannual price-setting meeting amid strong signs that the world oil oversupply is ending. The mood of crisis surrounding the group at its last meeting appears to have dissipated. (Page D1.)

title: Challenger Injured
description: Lotte Mwale of Zambia suffered a bruised left eye while sparring and may pull out of his fight with Dwight Braxton, the champion, for the World Boxing Council lightheavyweight title next Saturday, Mickey Duff, the challenger's manager, said today.

title: BLACK AMERICANS' COMPLAINTS ABOUT REAGAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Coe Sets Record
description: Sebastian Coe, world recordholder in the mile, began his outdoor season today with an impressive 1,500-meter victory in the Yorkshire County championships in 3 minutes 39.1 seconds.

title: NEW PRESIDENT OF LANE IS NOT ONE OF THE FAMILY
description: In 1898 the Southern Pacific Railroad began Sunset magazine to attract people to the West. In 1914 it was sold and became a literary magazine.

title: YUGOSLAV PARLIAMENT ELECTS A WOMAN AS PRIME MINISTER
description: The Yugoslav Parliament elected Milka Planinc today as the country's first female Prime Minister.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HIGH COST OF HINCKLEY TRIAL
description: The trial of John W. Hinckley Jr., entering its fourth week Monday, is proving to be one of the most elaborate and expensive extravaganzas in the history of criminal law.

title: Delta Appeal to C.A.B.
description: Delta Air Lines has appealed the Civil Aeronautics Board decision to give American Airlines the Dallas-to-London route held by Braniff International Airways, which sought relief from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws last week. The Atlanta-based carrier filed a petition with the United States Court of Appeals in Washington seeking a stay of the board's order on grounds that the award to American was ''erroneous and contrary to established law and previous agency decisions.'' Delta is seeking a temporary restraining order blocking American from flying the route.

title: ISSUES A WARNING
description: British warplanes attacked two Argentine supply vessels today in the channel between the two main Falkland islands, forcing the crew of one to abandon ship, the Defense Ministry announced tonight.

title: POPE SAYS FALKLAND FIGHTING PUTS HIS BRITISH TRIP IN DOUBT
description: Pope John Paul II said today that his visit to Britain, scheduled to begin later this month, had been put in doubt by the conflict over the Falkland Islands.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER SEEKS TO SOFTEN JUNTA'S IMAGE
description: In the last few days, Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, the leader of Argentina's military junta, has begun a public relations campaign to give the junta a more human appearance.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''What bothers me most is not the question of the recent British attacks but the delay in the negotiations, the refusal to accept a normal and reasonable dialogue, which is due entirely to the intransigent position of Great Britain.'' - Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina. (A1:5.)

title: People
description: * James R. Driscoll and John J. Meskil named executive vice presidents of Warwick Advertising.

title: William Sheridan, 46, M.T.A. Board Member
description: William J. Sheridan, a member of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died at his home in Setauket, L.I., Saturday after a long illness. He was 46 years old.

title: WRIGLEY REASSERTS ITSELF IN GUM MARKET
description: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company is aggressively trying to re-establish itself as the nation's leading manufacturer of chewing gum.

title: RED SOX ARE DEFEATED BY THE ROYALS, 5-0
description: Under Manager Ralph Houk this season, the Boston Red Sox won 13 of their first 17 road games, which is one of the reasons they are in first place in the Eastern Division.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR IN TROUBLE OVER MINORITY AID
description: The City Council has passed a sweeping bill to aid minority contractors in getting work with the city, overriding Mayor William J. Green's veto and creating fresh political problems for him.

title: 100 Routed in Upstate Village By Spill of Ammonia on Farm
description: About 100 people were temporarily evacuated Saturday night because of a toxic gas leak in this Orleans County village.

title: NEW PERSPECTIVES ON FATHER AND HIS ROLE
description: He is the bumbling father, the perfect fool of a dad. He has been humored, cajoled, patronized and just plain put up with by longsuffering wives and clever children. As a figure of fun he is a hallowed character in our culture: Dagwood Bumstead of the ''Blondie'' comic strip, Ozzie Nelson of the radio and television show ''Ozzie and Harriet'' or the faintly ridiculous hero of Clarence Day's Broadway play ''Life With Father.''

title: GENERAL MOTORS AGREES TO REPAIR REAR BUS DOORS
description: More than 200 General Motors buses that have remained undelivered because of a dispute over a faulty rear-door mechanism will soon be on their way to New York, officials of the Transit Authority and the company said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The talks are still alive, but time is not on the side of negotiations.

title: NICKLAUS WINS COLONIAL WITH 67 FOR 273
description: The intervals between victories for Jack Nicklaus may be longer, but the victories are still there. The 42-year-old Nicklaus, who had not won a golf tournament since 1980, won the Colonial National Invitation today by three strokes. ''Lots of times I've played well this year, but somebody played better,'' Nicklaus said after winning for the 69th time on the tour. ''The feeling to have won again is a nice feeling. When they get far apart, you sometimes forget how long it is.

title: Zairian Vows Embassy Will Be in Jerusalem
description: The personal envoy of President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said today that his country would set up its embassy in Jerusalem now that diplomatic relations between the black African nation and Israel had been renewed. Announcement of the renewed ties, which were broken in 1973, was made in Kinshasa on Saturday.

title: India and China Opening Talks on Border Dispute
description: India and China start new talks Monday on a longstanding border dispute, but an Indian negotiator has already ruled out any dramatic results.

title: Robert D. Stuchiner Weds Deborah Ellen Kurtzberg
description: Deborah Ellen Kurtzberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence D. Kurtzberg of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan, to Robert D. Stuchiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Martin Stuchiner of New York.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny International, Pittsburgh, has appointed William R. Webber president of its newly formed appliance group.

title: 'SUPER FUZZ' AND BORGNINE
description: IT'S a long wait, but there is one funny gag a few minutes before the end of ''Super Fuzz,'' a film shot in what the Avco Embassy Picture folks in Los Angeles describe as ''the sun-drenched vacation city of Miami, Fla.'' The two cops who are the heroes of this silly peccadillo have fallen into the earth - one from a balloon made of chewing gum - and vanished down a deep hole. Where do children emerge when they dig deep enough? In China, of course, but whether they come out in the People's Republic or Taiwan is, like the rest of the plot, left dangling.

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT EGYPT AND ISRAEL TO RESUME TALKS
description: Americcan officials said today that they expected negotiations on Palestinian self-rule to resume soon after President Reagan conferred with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel next month.

title: Stamp of Clemente
description: Because of efforts by Representative Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx, and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, with assistance from Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, a postage stamp will honor Roberto Clemente, the late Pittsburgh Pirate star.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH WINS 83D, A RECORD
description: Kathy Whitworth achieved a record for most Ladies' Professional Golf Association victories today when she won her 83d tournament, taking the Lady Michelob by four strokes.

title: U.S. RECRUITED NAZIS FOR INTELLIGENCE WORK, INVESTIGATOR SAYS
description: The Government, for intelligence purposes, recruited hundreds of Russians believed to have committed World War II atrocities and smuggled them into the United States after the war in defiance of Presidential orders, according to a former Justice Department investigator.

title: ADELINE R. TERRA
description: Adeline Richards Terra, philanthropist, art collector and wife of President Reagan's Ambassador at Large for Cultural Affairs, died Saturday.

title: WHAT MOVIES WILL BE THE BIG WINNERS THIS SUMMER?
description: HOLLYWOOD POISED on the brink of summer, the movie industry is quivering with anticipation. In a good year, between 25 million and 35 million people go to the movies each week during June and July. And 1982 is expected to be a very good year.

title: TREASURY AND STATE PLAN ISSUES
description: The United States Treasury and the State of New York are among this week's largest borrowers. In the corporate market, about $770 million of notes and bonds are scheduled for sale, and the total of all debt offerings was estimated at $870 million by analysts at Salomon Brothers.

title: CAMPUS ACTIVITIES FOCUS ON STUDENT LOANS ISSUE
description: Student leaders are forming two committees to campaign for Congressional candidates who advocate tuition loans and other student aid, saying that the issue of student financial help had restored political activism to campuses.

title: Hillary Jane Linsky Bride Of Alan Harvie Hudesman
description: Hillary Jane Linsky, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald Linsky of East Williston, L.I., was married yesterday to Alan Harvie Hudesman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hudesman of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbis Joseph Sternstein and Saul Teplitz performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Playing Careers Of the Managers
description: Three of the 26 major league managers never played in the majors. Earl Weaver of Baltimore was a minor league second baseman for 13 years, the last five as a playing manager; John McNamara of Cincinnati was a minor league catcher for 12 years, the last six as a playing manager, and Dave Garcia of Cleveland was a minor league infielder for 15 years, nine as a playing manager.

title: Jeb Stuart Magruder Is Offered Church Post
description: He found religion while serving a prison sentence for his part in the Watergate coverup, and now Jeb Stuart Magruder may be getting his first pastoral post. The 47-year-old former White House aide, who has just completed his studies at the Princeton Theological Seminary, has been asked to become associate pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Burlingame, Calif.

title: 2 Killed at College Dance
description: Two students attending a college dance were stabbed to death on the campus of San Francisco State College Saturday night and another student and a guard were wounded by a man who fled across the city and was arrested waiting for a bus, the police said. The names of the suspect, a 41-year-old Oakland man, and the dead students were not released.

title: Build Housing, Wreck the Budget
description: ''Give me chastity and continence, but not just now.'' - Saint Augustine Government, like Saint Augustine, has difficulty saying no. Even as Congress struggles to cut the budget deficit, it is yielding to new temptations to spend. It is hard to find a worse temptation than the housing bail-out now racing toward passage.

title: FOCUS ON U.S. POPULATION RISE REMAINS IN THE SUN BELT AREA
description: The growth in the nation's population continues to be concentrated in the Sun Belt, with Southern and Western states accounting for more than 90 percent of the increase since the 1980 census, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: JAMES A. DULLEA
description: James A. Dullea, former president of Aluminium Ltd., now Alcan Aluminium Ltd., died Saturday at Fairfield (Conn.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF SAYS STATE FACES MAJOR AID LOSS
description: The State Education Commissioner said today that New York State would get $40 million less in the 1982-83 school year than it was entitled to because the Federal Government had decided to use census data from 1970 rather than 1980 in distributing aid for the education of deprived children.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A ball rolls onto the receiver's court in a tennis match just as he is about to return a serve. Who calls a let? Must it be called before or after the serve is returned?

title: A Royal Concertgoer
description: He's done a lot of things, but he'd never before attended a rock concert. That may help explain why Britain's Prince Charles showed up at one in Birmingham, England, Friday night wearing a gray suit.

title: Cable Concern Sets Changes
description: The nation's largest cable television company is planning to offer the same 11 or 12 channels on each of its systems across the country.

title: DENG BACKERS NAMED TO NEW PARTY POSTS
description: The streamlining of China's swollen bureaucracy has been extended to the ruling Chinese Communist Party, where the 30 departments of the Central Committee are having their staffs pared by more than 17 percent.

title: Former Turkish President Feted on 100th Birthday; Fete in Istanbul
description: Turkey's military regime has banned political gatherings, but the authorities were apparently looking the other way this weekend as right-wing politicians turned out in force for a 100th-birthday celebration.

title: AT LOVE CANAL, SOME HOPE TO START OVER
description: Amid persistent uncertainty and mistrust, local officials are trying to reopen the shuttered apartments of Love Canal in an ambitious but contested plan to rebuild the neighborhood.

title: 60-Second Debate
description: Robert W. Kastenmeier Democratic Representative from Wisconsin and a member of the House Judiciary Committee and its Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights:

title: Bogey On Out
description: No part of a professional golf tournament is duller than Tuesday, when practice is about the only thing that's going on. Now Shootout has been swiped from the realm of country-club gambling to alleviate the Tuesday blahs of pro tournaments, and its first applications have been in - where else? - Texas.

title: Advertising; Billings And Profits Depressed
description: Refreshed in body and spirit, and considerably lighter in the wallet, some of America's leading advertising agency and media people departed the posh precincts of the Greenbrier Hotel over the weekend secure in the knowledge that things could be worse.

title: ASIAN LENDER FACES A CUT IN DONATIONS
description: When Indonesia, Hong Kong and South Korea made their first contributions to the Asian Development Bank last month, it should have been a cause for celebration.

title: PENNSYLVANIA'S NEW WEAPON AGAINST CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: STYLISTS AND SURVIVALISTS
description: MANAGERS, Gene Mauch says, come in ''every conceivable size, every conceivable shape, every conceivable personality.'' No one, not Branch Rickey, not George Steinbrenner, has ever developed a mold from which the perfect, unbeatable manager can be manufactured.

title: ORATORIO: 'EROTOKRITOS' BY TSONTAKIS
description: BEING in the audience for ''Erotokritos,'' the oratorio-drama by George Tsontakis that received its world premiere Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, was a bit like watching a Greek play with English subtitles and musical interludes. The unusual fusion of spoken Greek poetry rendered dramatically, English narration, choral commentary in the ancient Greek manner, dance as a symbolic enactment of plot and music brought to mind such modern hybrids as Stravinsky's ''Oedipus'' and Penderecki's ''Paradise Lost,'' and achieved somewhat of a mythic aspect as well.

title: U.S. EMBASSY IN ARGENTINA DENIES IT IS SEEKING TO UNDERMINE JUNTA
description: The United States Embassy here has been accused by Argentine newspapers of trying to undermine the ruling junta in the Falkland Islands crisis, but it responded today by denying any ''inappropriate conduct.''

title: VOLVO DIVERSIFYING AWAY FROM AUTOS
description: A.B. Volvo, Scandinavia's biggest company, is approaching auto manufacturing as if, over the long term, the company realizes that almost everything else it does has greater potential than making cars.

title: A Silver Lining?
description: Aaron Pryor was on Route 271, near Cleveland, feeling as good as anyone on his way to Buffalo could. The World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion had left his home in Cincinnati looking forward to watching Sugar Ray Leonard defend the welterweight championship against Roger Stafford in Buffalo. But he was anticipating with greater glee fighting Leonard himself later this year, possibly in September.

title: DERNIER LEADS PHILS' VICTORY
description: A slim, 25-year-old ''banjo'' hitter named Bob Dernier has taken over center field for the Philadelphia Phillies with impressive results. His short-distance hitting has helped offset the lack of power by Mike Schmidt, usually the team's most dangerous slugger.

title: D.D.B. Leaves Tourister Bags
description: American Tourister Inc., a subsidiary of Hillenbrand Industries and one of the nation's leading luggage manufacturers, has packed its bags and left Doyle Dane Bernbach, its ad agency for the past 15 years.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Choate, Darwin, Scrooge & Meese

title: BY SUSAN C. FALUDI
description: The Sony Corporation of America will announce today its entrance into the personal computer field with the introduction of a model that will go on sale in the United States this fall.

title: XEROX: NEW CHIEF'S CHALLENGE
description: When C. Peter McColough steps down as chief executive officer of the Xerox Corporation on Thursday, the company will lose one of the last links to its glorious past and one of the major architects of its troubled present.

title: INDY DRIVERS EULOGIZE SMILEY
description: More than a dozen of America's greatest race drivers, including four former winners of the Indianapolis 500, tonight dealt with a reality that their profession rarely allows them to acknowledge.

title: CURRAN WILL FORMALLY ENTER GOVERNOR'S RACE TOMORROW
description: Paul J. Curran will formally declare his candidacy tomorrow for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, with a campaign strategy designed to show that he is the party establishment's alternative to Lewis E. Lehrman.

title: SETON HALL WINNER, 15-0
description: St. John's eliminated New York Tech, 4-0, then lost by 15-0 to top-seeded Seton Hall yesterday in the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey regional baseball tournament.

title: 'Braniff' Dead, Chairman Says
description: A much smaller airline with no international flights may emerge from Braniff International's bankruptcy proceedings, an airline official says.

title: METS, ON 9-RUN 6TH, ROUT DODGERS, 13-4
description: A Met team that has palpitated its way through 15 one-run games yesterday delighted in a 13-4 romp over the Dodgers that featured a wild nine-run sixth inning, the second biggest inning in the team's 21 seasons.

title: HUNT, IN DEBUT, HELPS COSMOS WIN, 3-1
description: Steve Hunt got a standing ovation on his return to the Cosmos today, and and he rewarded a crowd of 36,193 at Giants Stadium with a performance reminiscent of the days when he led the team to consecutive championships.

title: GULF RESOURCES FOE IS ELUSIVE INVESTOR
description: Alan E. Clore, the Swiss investor waging a proxy fight against the management of Gulf Resources and Chemical Company, did not show up at the company's recent annual meeting -nor could he be located for an interview - which surprised few who knew him.

title: RULINGS ON SCHOOL INTEGRATION KEY TARGET FOR CONSERVATIVES
description: When Judge James B. McMillan ordered broad-scale busing to desegregate the public school system in Charlotte, N.@C., more than a decade ago, he was hanged in effigy. He was threatened by mail and telephone and placed under round-the-clock guard by United States marshals. Similar things happened to another Federal District Judge, W. Arthur Garrity, after he ordered the Boston schools desegregated in a series of rulings beginning in the summer of 1974.

title: Italians Will Investigate Alitalia's Midair Fright
description: Transport Minister Vincenzo Balzamo called for a Government inquiry today after a pilot reported a midair explosion near his airliner over an area of southern Italy where NATO maneuvers were taking place.

title: Space Shots' No-Tariff Bill
description: A bill to exempt from tariffs anything imported for use in a space shot is scheduled for a House subcommittee hearing Monday. The bill was introduced by seven House members, led by Don Fuqua, the Florida Democrat who is chairman of the Science and Technology Committee.

title: BILL AIMED AT CLOSING 'TAX GAP'
description: The House Ways and Means Committee begins hearings Tuesday on a tax-enforcement bill that embodies most of the provisions of the pending Senate Finance Committee bill and adds several of its own.

title: EVER-FEISTY SMITH STILL PREFERS A BEER
description: While most of his teammates were howling with victory and champagne in their throats, Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, sipped a beer outside the dressing room and remained truculent.

title: FOR FINNS, ONCE-TABOO TOPICS EMERGE INTO OPEN
description: Only a few months into the post-Kekkonen era, Finland is talking in public about things it did not really dare to mention during the 25-year presidency of Urho Kekkonen.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Yale Varsity Eight Wins
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew achieved that rowing rarity today on Lake Quinsigamond, the perfect race that went exactly according to plan with victory the result.

title: Title to Higueras
description: Jose Higueras of Spain beat Australia's Peter McNamara, 6-4, 7-6, 6-7, 3-6, 7-6, today and won the $250,000 Hamburg tennis tournament in a five-hour match. The two met in the final last year, and McNamara won.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Gets Norwegian American
description: After only seven months together, Norwegian American Cruises and Bozell & Jacobs have bid each other bon voyage. The cruise line, a subsidiary of Hoegh & Company, the seventh-largest corporation in Norway, now goes to Ogilvy & Mather Partners.

title: CLOTHING AS ARCHITECTURE AT M.I.T.
description: It was tense. In a bathroom of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Athletic Center, the fashion designer Ronaldus Shamask explained to his models how to stand very still. In a back locker room, Issey Miyake's assistant gave his models some last-minute instructions in tai chi. And in an adjoining locker room, Gianfranco Ferre, satisfied with his models, helped Mariuccia Mandelli of Krizia and rolled his eyes.

title: FROM INDIA 'ONCE UPON A TIME'
description: IT takes a little while to adjust to the pacing and rhythm of Girish Karnad's ''Once Upon a Time,'' a 13th-century Indian adventure-melodrama, and some might say that the film, which runs more than two and a half hours, uses up more time than is absolutely necessary. Yet ''Once Upon a Time'' has a number of rewards for the curious and patient student of world cinema.

title: BALLET: MISS GREGORY AND MISS JAFFE IN 'GISELLE'
description: CYNTHIA GREGORY, aided and abetted in grand style by Alexander Godunov, turned the American Ballet Theater's ''Giselle'' into an exciting and profound work of drama Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. In a role for which she was once considered out of type, Miss Gregory simply turned in a magnificent performance.

title: SAILOR SLAIN AND 3 WOUNDED BY GUNFIRE IN PUERTO RICO
description: A Navy sailor was killed and three were seriously injured early today when they were shot by unknown assailants while returning to their ship from a night of liberty.

title: ISLANDERS SWEEP CANUCKS FOR 3D STANLEY CUP IN ROW
description: The New York Islanders captured their third consecutive Stanley Cup tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks that completed a four-game sweep of the championship series.

title: Commodities; Futures And Legal Questions
description: THE decision by the Supreme Court that private litigants may bring suit in Federal court against commodity brokers, exchanges and their personnel, instead of being restricted to legal action in state courts, has left many unanswered questions.

title: PROTECTING THE ADOPTION TRIANGLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Nader Group Cites Flaws In New Nuclear Plants
description: A Ralph Nader group said today that thousands of workers would be exposed to radiation and consumers would be cheated if the nuclear industry was permitted to start up power plants with defective steam generators.

title: RIVALRIES UNDERGO CHANGE SINCE DUROCHER-DRESSEN
description: For three years in the early 1950's, Leo Durocher and Charley Dressen waged memorable managerial encounters. Dressen managed the Brooklyn Dodgers and Durocher, who had managed the Dodgers for eight and one-half years, directed the archrival New York Giants.

title: Concrete Pads Suspect In Fatal Bridge Collapse
description: Investigators looking into the East Chicago bridge ramp collapse that killed 13 workers April 15 say the concrete pads that supported steel towers under the ramp had not been built as thick as recommended, The Indianapolis Star reported today.

title: THEATER: PATTI LUPONE IN MAMET'S 'THE WOODS'
description: DAVID MAMET'S ''The Woods'' was not well received in its 1979 New York premiere at the Public Theater, where it was staged by Ulu Grosbard and starred Chris Sarandon and Christine Lahti. Yet the play has always maintained an underground following - largely based on its original, 1977 production at the St. Nicholas Theater in Chicago, where it was directed by its author and starred Patti LuPone and Peter Weller. Last night, Mr. Mamet belatedly recreated the Chicago production in New York -and, as it turns out, pushed his luck more than a bit too far. At the Second Stage, ''The Woods'' stands revealed as the petrified dramatic forest that it is.

title: Fire Destroys 8 Businesses
description: A state fire official said today that there was no indication what started a weekend fire that destroyed eight businesses in a two-story building in this resort. ''I have ruled nothing out yet,'' said Inspector Joseph Levasseur of the Maine Fire Marshal's Office.

title: CHILDREN STAGE NUCLEAR PROTEST IN CENTRAL PARK
description: Julie Warner, an 11th grader at the Dalton School, stood before a microphone at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park yesterday and spoke in images her young audience could understand.

title: MOROCCAN VOWS TO STAY NONALIGNED
description: King Hassan II says that while he would not hesitate to sign a treaty with the United States, Morocco ''always will be nonaligned.''

title: Robbers Kill 3 Patrons At Queens Social Club
description: The police were looking yesterday for two robbers who opened fire without warning in a Queens social club, killing three persons and wounding two others.

title: REMUNDA CADOUX
description: Remunda Cadoux, a teacher of French and Spanish in the New York City school system and the author of more than 20 textbooks on the two languages, died Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old.

title: Sandra Elaine Breisacher Wed to Van David Lessig
description: Sandra Elaine Breisacher, director of special activities of the American Diabetes Association in New York, was married yesterday to Van David Lessig, a vice president in the International Treasury Consulting Group of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York.

title: 'First Lady' Returns
description: It's been more than 40 years since she starred in a school play entitled ''The First Lady,'' but Nancy Reagan seemed to have the role down pat on Friday when she returned to her alma mater.

title: Times Square After the Mall
description: A plan for an ill-conceived Times Square mall, a prescription for traffic chaos, seems to be expiring, and good riddance.

title: Howard Jay Forman Marries Marjorie Katz
description: Marjorie Ellen Katz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Katz of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday in Congregation Beth El to Howard Jay Forman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Forman of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Leon Waldman performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Charles Feld.

title: LOBBYISTS SEEK TO MOLD PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: J.D. Williams, who prefers staying out of sight whether he is hunting ducks or lobbying members of Congress, does not grant interviews, although he made an exception a few years ago to talk to a reporter who happened to be the daughter of a United States Senator.

title: CHIEF OF CORINTHIAN TV TO START NEW COMPANY
description: There comes a time when many executives think about striking out on their own, but few work up the nerve. Philip J. Lombardo thought about it, stewed about it, went through periods of anxiety, and finally decided to go ahead.

title: TV: BBC'S 'TROILUS AND CRESSIDA'
description: THE Shakespeare Plays, the BBC series being carried on public television, gets around this evening to one of the most problematical and fascinating of the 36 works being offered over six years. ''Troilus and Cressida,'' a three-hour production that begins at 8 on WNET-TV, is traditionally listed with ''All's Well That Ends Well'' and ''Measure for Measure'' as one of the ''problem plays.'' Described as comedies, their humor is dark, gloomy and bitter, to say the very least.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE RISE AND FALL OF DIAMONDS. The Shattering of a Brilliant Illusion. By Edward Jay Epstein. 301 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.50. THE DIAMOND WORLD. By David E. Koskoff. 356 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Leonard Released From Hospital
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the world welterweight boxing champion who underwent surgery for a partly detached retina in his left eye last week, was released today from Johns Hopkins Hospital.

title: Racing's New 'Kid' Is a Cowboy
description: ABOUT an hour after Cowboy Jack Kaenel had won the 107th Preakness Stakes on Aloma's Ruler, the 16-year-old jockey was sipping a blackeyed susan (rum, vodka and fruit juices) in the Pimlico executive offices. Soon a waiter appeared, holding a tray with glasses of champagne.

title: SENIOR AT PRINCETON, DISCIPLINED FOR 'PLAGIARISM,' SUES FOR LIBEL
description: A senior at Princeton University who was disciplined for what the university has called plagiarism has sued the school for libel and unspecified damages, contending that she was denied due process.

title: FOLK-POP: THE ROCHES
description: IT'S been three years since the Roches, the critically acclaimed folk-pop trio of sisters who write and sing their own quirky songs, released their debut album. Though they haven't exactly become household words, the Roches have grown in poise and musical assurance. Friday at the Bottom Line, where they appeared for the first time in several months, the trio introduced some impressive songs and carried their tricky close harmonies to an awesome peak of sophistication.

title: Harvester Is Rebuffed
description: The International Harvester Company, the financially pressed manufacturer of trucks and tractors, learned late Friday that the General Accounting Office had rejected the company's complaint that it had been excluded from the initial bidding for a multimillion-dollar Army contract for 25 combat earthmovers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TWO CHINAS

title: Erins Isle Wins The Californian
description: Erins Isle, trailing the field for more than a half-mile, staged a powerful stretch run today to capture the $335,200 Californian Stakes at Hollywood Park.

title: BRIEFING
description: Doctoral Applause

title: 76ers Beat Celtics for 3-1 Lead
description: The way the Boston Celtics tried to stop Andrew Toney today at the Spectrum, it looked as if they were taking numbers to take their chances.

title: The Wrong Right in El Salvador
description: The recent right-wing victors in El Salvador's election present three faces: primitive, traditional and pragmatic. There's a case for American collaboration with their practical wing and acquiescing in the traditional conservatism of another group. But there is no reason whatever to indulge the primitive faction, led by the bloodyminded Roberto d'Aubuisson. That some United States diplomats try to put a moderate face on ''Major Bob'' is not just misguided, it is alarming.

title: Cabaret Show to Aid Symphony Space
description: A cabaret production with music, mime, magic and fortunetelling will be presented today at O'Neals' Times Square in the third spring gala to support the Symphony Space, the four-year-old Upper West Side cultural center.

title: Jane Fonda Exits March After Noisy Protest
description: Jane Fonda was forced to leave a march marking the 34th anniversary of Israel today when Jewish Defense League protesters shouted and waved signs at her.

title: Bell Plans Credit Service
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to file tariff requests in June to offer a data communications service that would allow gasoline stations to verify the credit of customers who pay for fuel with credit cards.

title: COST OF BENEFIT FRAUD IS CITED
description: Fraud, corruption and waste in Federal benefit programs are a ''serious national problem'' that may cost taxpayers $2.5 billion to $25 billion annually, the Justice Department said today.

title: Valuable To Hockey
description: HE will play with injuries but he will not fight. That is the code of honor of Mike Bossy, who was voted the most valuable player in the Islanders' third consecutive Stanley Cup championship last night.

title: CANDIDATE OF RULING PARTY CLAIMS VICTORY IN THE DOMINICAN ELECTION
description: Salvador Jorge Blanco, the candidate of the incumbent leftist Dominican Revolutionary Party, claimed victory early today in Sunday's election for President.

title: MENACHEM SHARON? WELL, NO.
description: To many outside observers, they seem the twins of Israeli politics, so that commentators speak of the Israeli Government as a single unit - the Begin-Sharon Government.

title: Norma J. Ronson, Nurse, Wed to Dr. James Koppel
description: At the Central Synagogue yesterday Norma Jean Ronson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Ronson of New York and Sarasota, Fla., was married to Dr. James N. Koppel, son of Mr. and Alfred Koppel of New York.

title: TENSIONS ARE EASING FOR OPEC
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is gathering for its semi-annual price-setting meeting in Ecuador this week amid mounting evidence of the end of the worldwide oversupply of oil.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot in Leg on IND
description: An off-duty city police officer was shot in the leg early yesterday by two armed men who tried to rob him of a gold chain on a subway train, officials said.

title: Lilco Planning Three-Year Trial For Solar-Aided Water Heaters
description: The Long Island Lighting Company announced today that it would offer solar-assisted heat-pump water heaters to a limited number of customers as part of a three-year trial project.

title: FOR ALOMA'S RULER, UNEXPECTED VICTORY
description: Butch Lenzini had just hoped that Aloma's Ruler would come back in one piece after racing Saturday. That the colt ended up with a blanket of painted daisies for winning the Preakness Stakes was an unexpected bonus.

title: ZIEGLER SEES CLUB IN N.J.
description: John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, said today that the Colorado Rockies would likely move to Byrne Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey next season.

title: MARK TWAIN'S CONTRIBUTION TO CURING RACISM
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRYSLER TO RAISE PRICES OF LUXURY CARS 1 TO 3.2%$
description: The Chrysler Corporation said late yesterday that it would raise prices for some of its 1982 luxury cars by 1 to 3.2 percent. The increase, Chrysler's second this year, came after months of price rebates and other price incentives that the Big Three auto makers have used in an attempt to increase auto sales.

title: THRICE AND FUTURE KINGS?
description: When the word ''dynasty'' was spoken within earshot of the Islanders, they seemed inclined to wince, however briefly and slightly.

title: Challenger Is Injured
description: If the trend continues, championship fights may take their place with old seats from Ebbets Field as collector's items. The fifth delay or cancellation of a title bout in recent weeks occurred yesterday when Lotte Mwale of Zambia, a light-heavyweight who was to have challenged Dwight Braxton for the World Boxing Council crown next Saturday at Atlantic City, was examined by a doctor for the New Jersey Athletic Commission and found to be suffering from double vision and bruises in his right eye.

title: Politics, Courage and Death
description: Maneuvering about the death penalty is by now a sordid springtime ritual in Albany. The Legislature usually passes a bill to expand the use of capital punishment, Governor Carey courageously vetoes it and a core of committed legislators holds firm to prevent an override. This year, however, the proceedings are more ominous.

title: New York Note Yields Reduced
description: Strong demand for New York State's $3.5 billion of notes yesterday enabled underwriters led by Citibank to reduce yields slightly from levels initially proposed. The state's sale of tax and revenue anticipation notes is traditionally the largest single financing of the year in the tax-exempt market.

title: HIGH FLYING PILOTS REPORT SIGHTING LIGHTNING BOLTS THAT SHOOT UPWARD
description: IT has long been assumed that lightning bolts either leap from a cloud to the earth or flash from cloud to cloud. However, it now appears that on rare occasions bolts originate at the tops of storms and travel upward into clear sky.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 'WALL TO WALL ARCHEOLOGISTS'
description: jawed tommy-goff (a highly poisonous snake also known as the fer-de-lance).

title: OPEC's Output
description: The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the oil group was holding its total production to 16 million barrels a day, well below the ceiling of 17.5 million barrels set by the group two months ago as it sought to regain control over world oil markets. Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba also said that OPEC's production in April averaged 15.8 million barrels a day, the lowest in more than a decade.

title: Judge's Role In I.B.M. Suit
description: The Justice Department argued today that Federal District Judge David N. Edelstein in New York had no authority to review the department's decision to drop its 13-year-old antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: NATIONS AIM TO STABILIZE DOLLAR AND ECONOMICS
