description: The United States and other major industrial countries are near a new monetary agreement that would stabilize the dollar's value in currency markets and provide for tighter coordination of economic policies, officials close to the negotiations said today.

title: WHEN SONGBIRDS SPEAK, BRAIN SHOULD GET THE CREDIT
description: IN a six-foot-tall cage at the American Museum of Natural History, a starling flits from perch to perch, casts a quick glance at a visitor and says, ''Hi Sam! Hi kid!'' Not quite Bogart, but very human.

title: ROYALS BEAT YANKEES, 7-0
description: The Yankees who played the Kansas City Royals tonight, George Brett said, were not the ''old Yankees.'' But old or new, Larry Gura stymied them just as he had in the previous five seasons.

title: CBS Executive Named President of Steinway
description: Lloyd W. Meyer, 40, has been named president of Steinway & Sons, the Long Island City, Queens, piano manufacturer that is owned by CBS.

title: Gentrifiers: The Police
description: ''I'm just a pawn on a chessboard that's being used back and forth,'' said one policeman. ''We're being used to salve consciences,'' called out another. ''Where were you three, four, five years ago?'' said a third, cynically. ''Suddenly, the city looks up and says, 'Gee, where did all those (poor) people go?' ''

title: Gulf and Hartford In Joint Venture
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Hartford Insurance Group said that they had formed an insurance partnership in which Transinsco Inc., Gulf's new underwriting management company, would underwrite and issue policies in Hartford's name.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Justice at Lunch

title: DECONSTRUCTING BROWN
description: The Reagan Administration's actions, which amount to a functional repeal of the Supreme Court's Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954, demonstrate that American racism may be deeper and more pervasive than we who celebrated the decision once dared to believe.

title: DANCE: BACH, GESRHWIN
description: THERE were two works to familiar pieces of concert music on the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's Sunday night program at the City Center, and whereas the choreographer of one refused to be intimidated by a potentially troublesome composition, the choreographer of the other got himself into plenty of trouble.

title: Filipinos Vote For Local Officials
description: More than 20 million Filipinos voted today in the first nationwide local elections in 10 years. Maj. Gen. Fidel Ramos, chief of the paramilitary national police, said at least seven people were killed and four were wounded in election-related violence.

title: Yields Reduced On Certificates
description: A slight drop in Treasury bill rates at yesterday's auctions reduced the maximum yields that banks and savings instititions may pay on new three-and six-month savings certificates.

title: Powerboat Racing Aoki's Goal Again
description: Rocky Aoki is a man of numbers. And his favorite is No.1. A quick smile and an outgoing manner tend to mask the tough, successoriented nature of a man driven by self-imposed goals who now hears the call of the sea. It's a matter of love - and unfinished business.

title: REPORTS ON GYPSY BANNED IN TURKEY
description: Turkey's military rulers moved today to cut short an emotional campaign for the abolition of capital punishment by banning further reports about the death sentence given a 23-year-old gypsy woman.

title: 2 Groups Say They Shot Sailors in Puerto Rico
description: Two telephone callers, one purporting to be from a group protesting United States Navy target practice and the other claiming to be from a left-wing terrorist organization, took responsibility today for an attack on four American sailors that left one dead and three seriously injured.

title: N.H.L. to Meet On the Rockies
description: The National Hockey League's board of governors meets in Manhattan today to resume deliberations concerning the future of the Colorado Rockies.

title: 2 East Germans Defect
description: Two East Germans escaped to the West in predawn darkness today, West German border police said. A spokesman gave no details except to say the two men, a 21-year-old zoo employee and a 27-year-old communications technician, successfully crossed the heavily fortified border to the West German state of Lower Saxony.

title: WHAT TO DO, AND NOT TO DO, WITH SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Caterpillar's Engine Plans
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company has tentatively approved development of a new line of small diesel engines that could substantially increase profits in the late 1980's, according to security analysts and company sources.

title: The U.N. Today; May 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: WEDDINGS FLOURISHING
description: ''Ken and I met at work,'' she explained to him over the orchestra's love song. ''We're getting married in the fall.'' He looked into her chestnut eyes and replied: ''You'll need cutware.''

title: Stock Groups For Options
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said it had selected six industry stock groups as underlying securities for an initial listing of proposed group options contracts.

title: TIME FOR TALKS NEAR END, BRITAIN ASSERTS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that Britain had gone ''as far as we can'' in negotiations with Argentina to find a peaceful solution to the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: STOCK TRADING LINK HAS SLOW START
description: The experimental electronic link between the nation's stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market got off to a slow start yesterday.

title: Code-Setting Body Held Liable
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that organizations that issue product standards and codes may be found liable under the antitrust laws for the actions of volunteer members who misuse an organization's name for personal gain.

title: AUTOMATIC SYSTEM TO GIVE WESTCHESTER EARLY FLOOD WARNINGS
description: Westchester County, where flooding from swollen rivers and streams is a common occurrence, signed an agreement with the National Weather Service today for an electronically operated flood-alert system. It is scheduled to be put in operation this fall.

title: Advertising; U.S. Shop's Australian President
description: WHAT must it be like to come to New York from far-off Australia - hardly a major advertising market even though its citizens take it very seriously - and, despite competition from the best brains in the advertising business from throughout the United States, find yourself president of an $80 million agency before you're 40?

title: Stewart Warns Racers
description: Jackie Stewart, the three-time world driving champion, wants cars utilizing aerodynamic ground effects to be abolished from racing.

title: Genentech to Get Mitsubishi Funds
description: Genentech Inc., the genetic engineering company, said a Japanese company had agreed to finance the development of a blood protein that it is synthesizing.

title: Soviet Funds in West Rise
description: The Soviet Union's deposits of funds with Western banks, depleted early last year in Moscow's effort to aid Poland, recovered strongly in the fourth quarter of 1981, the Bank for International Settlements said today.

title: ARGENTINA IS ASSURED ON SHORT TERM DEBTS
description: Argentina's Finance Minister, Roberto Alemann, said yesterday that he had received assurances from bankers in the United States and other countries that they would continue to roll over Argentina's short-term debt until the Falkland Islands dispute is over.

title: KUWAITIS BUY STAKE IN HOECHST
description: In a major Arab entry into Western European industry, Kuwait has acquired roughly 25 percent of Hoechst, the West German chemical giant, West German banking officials disclosed today.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 18, 1982
description: International The Common Market extended its sanctions against Argentina for one week in retaliation for its seizure of the Falkland Islands. The vote, however, was not unanimous. Italy and Ireland disassociated themselves from the ban, but a spokesman for the Irish Government said that Ireland would use its own means to prevent Argentine imports during the coming week. (Page A1, Column 6.) U.N. talks on the Falklands resumed after a two-day break. Sir Anthony Parsons, the British delegate, said he had returned from London ''with instructions to continue the negotiations.'' Remarks by the Argentine envoy, Enrique Ros, were interpreted by diplomats as an indication that he had perceived a shift in Britain's stance. (A1:5.)

title: EDUCATION
description: IN February 1980 the faculty of Villanova University outside Philadelphia was preparing to vote on whether to form a union. Ten days before the scheduled election, however, the United States Supreme Court ruled that faculty members at Yeshiva University in New York City were not eligible to engage in collective bargaining because they were ''managerial.''

title: COURT SAYS SCHOOL ANTI-BIAS RULES COVER WORKERS AS WELL AS PUPILS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the law barring sex discrimination in federally aided education programs applies to employees as well as students.

title: UNILEVER PROFITS UP 5%
description: H.F. Ahmanson & Company, parent company of the nation's largest savings and loan association, reported a first-quarter loss today of $42.4 million. Ahmanson reported earnings of $2 million, or 9 cents a share, in the 1981 first quarter.

title: EFFORT FOR NAMIBIA PACT URGED
description: Five Western Governments called tonight for urgent efforts to resolve a dispute holding up their plan for the independence of South-West Africa.

title: Macmillan Unit Acquired by CBS
description: CBS Inc. said that it had acquired Cassell Ltd., a British publishing subsidiary of Macmillan Inc., for an undisclosed price.

title: Sports of The Times; Stanley Cup Is Back Home
description: MARILYN PICKETT's children asked her to relay instructions to Al Arbour on Sunday night. They wanted the Islanders' coach to rest his best players so that the team would lose and have to play a fifth game back home on Long Island.

title: Egypt and Israel Resume Talks on Sinai Dispute
description: Egypt and Israel resumed talks here today in an attempt to settle a dispute over their new border.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST; Markets
description: The stock market dropped sharply amid growing concern over persistent high interest rates and the condition of the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 12.46 points, to 845.32. The decline was the biggest since Feb. 22, when the Dow fell 13.04 points. In the last six sessions, it has tumbled almost 24 points. (Page D1.)

title: DAILY NEWS WANTS A 25% CUT IN PAYROLL, AND OFFERS BUYOUT
description: The Daily News asked its unions yesterday to give up 1,340 positions, equivalent to a quarter of the total payroll, over the next two years. In exchange, it offered to give the workers $48 million in early retirement pay and to invest an additional $44 million in new and refurbished printing plants.

title: Persistence of Herpes Virus
description: A California pediatrician has shown that the genital herpes virus, the most common cause of serious venereal disease in this country, can live for up to 72 hours on inanimate objects, such as cotton fabric.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''FORGETTING our own frailties, we act as if having a vision was sufficient, that our dream would painlessly become reality.'' This is the reflection of two leaders of the revolt of the 1960's against traditional education and the public-school system. Joel Denker and Steve Bhaerman were among the radical reformers who founded ''free'' or alternative schools and dreamed of liberating new generations of children to learn without subservience to the system -any system.

title: A JAPANESE RESPONSE TO NOH IS DUE FRIDAY
description: TOKYO ONE of the great moments in Japanese theater is the start of a Noh play. A multicolored curtain at the side of the stage is suddenly whisked up. The actors glide into sight, their feet in white tabi socks. They make no sound beyond the rustle of rich silk kimonos. With solemnity, the actors take up positions on stage. The restraint, the formality and the subtlety attached to gestures - the angle of a mask, the shade of a kimono sleeve - all these things are quintessential Japan.

title: Stravinsky Archive To Be Sold to U.C.L.A.
description: The Igor Stravinsky archive of scores, sketches, letters and documents - all part of the now settled 10-year-old dispute over the composer's estate - will be sold to the University of California at Los Angeles, according to a decision last Thursday by Judge Millard L. Midonick of the Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.

title: New Phone Rates
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that new rates for overseas calls have taken effect, changing the minimum calling period to one minute from three. A one-minute call to England will now cost $1.25, to the Continent, $1.42; and to Japan, $2.53. In addition daily discount periods are being introduced, Bell said, which should trim the average charge by about 4.5 percent.

title: Meese Returns to Work
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, returned to work at the White House today after a brief hospitalization. Mr. Meese, was admitted to the Bethesda Naval Hospital, Md., last week for treatment of lower back pain.

title: M.T.A. WARNED OF PENALTY IN HIRING A FOREIGN BUILDER
description: Washington, May 17 - A Reagan Administration official has warned the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that it may face heavy penalties if it awards a subway-car contract to a foreign builder.

title: ANCIENT JEWS OF CHINA: THE LAST TRACE IS FADING
description: In this dusty city just south of the Yellow River, there once flourished a community the local Chinese called ''the people who pluck out the sinew'' and, later, ''the Moslems of the blue caps'' - the ancient Jews of Kaifeng.

title: F.T.C. Curbs a Scuba Group
description: A scuba diving trade association has been ordered not to approve diving equipment unless it actually tests the products, the Federal Trade Commission announced today. The National Association of Scuba Diving Schools of Long Beach, Calif., had been distributing its seal of approval to dealers in bulk.

title: BRITAIN ASKS U.S. FOR SUPPLIES
description: Britain has asked the United States to have a wide variety of military supplies, equipment and ammunition made ready in case they are needed in the Falkland conflict, Administration officials said today.

title: Business and the Law; Bankruptcies Clog Courts
description: THE decision by the Braniff International Corporation to file a bankruptcy petition last week may have been the most dramatic economic disaster story recently, but smaller, quieter versions of the same tale are taking place more and more frequently - so frequently, in fact, that the bankruptcy courts are having trouble keeping up with the rising tide of filings.

title: Sun Myung Moon Paper Appears in Washington
description: Residents of the nation's capital, a onenewspaper city since The Washington Star folded more than nine months ago, found 130,000 copies of a new newspaper, The Washington Times, on sale or being given away this morning.

title: HINCKLEY WITNESS PRESSED ON STAND
description: The trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. today began settling into trench warfare between opposing teams of lawyers and psychiatrists as a Federal prosecutor strove to discredit a defense psychiatrist who testified last week that the 26-year-old defendant was insane when he shot President Reagan and three other men.

title: Israeli Official Warns P.L.O.  Against Violating Cease-Fire
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon today repeated Israeli warnings to the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon not to violate the cease-fire that was arranged there last July.

title: Housing Starts Down
description: Construction of new housing units during the first quarter of this year declined 33 percent from the same period last year, according to a survey conducted by the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company. Housing starts in the three-month period totaled 192,596 units, compared with 288,231 a year earlier. Houston and Dallas continued to rank as the two top housing areas.

title: ASNER CALLS 'LOU GRANT' CENSORED
description: Edward Asner, who is president of the Screen Actors Guild, accused CBS-TV yesterday of bowing to political pressure in dropping his ''Lou Grant'' series for next fall's season. He also denounced Charlton Heston for his role in the recent defeat of a move to merge the Screen Actors Guild with the Screen Extras Guild.

title: EUROPEANS EXTEND ARGENTINE CURBS FOR ANOTHER WEEK
description: A divided Common Market agreed Monday night to extend for one week the sanctions imposed against Argentina a month ago in retaliation for its seizure of the Falkland Islands.

title: EX-JOCKEY INVOKES FIFTH AMENDMENT
description: Jose Amy, the former jockey who has accused many prominent jockeys of fixing thoroughbred races in New York in the mid-1970's, yesterday invoked the Fifth Amendment in response to at least a dozen crucial questions posed by attorneys for the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: WHAT TO DO, AND NOT TO DO, WITH SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: HARLEM'S APOLLO THERATER TO BE A CABLE TV STUDIO
description: A new act is coming to the Apollo Theater. A $1 million investment announced yesterday by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation will be used to help convert the theater into a cable television studio.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: LLOYD'S CANCELS SHIP COVERAGE OFF ARGENTINA
description: Underwriters at Lloyd's of London, the giant insurance market, have decided to cancel standard war risk coverage on ships sailing to Argentina and the South Atlantic waters as of midnight May 27.

title: TEXAN IRKS COLLEAGUES ON BUDGET
description: ''If you have strong views, you're going to create strong impressions,'' Representative Phil Gramm mused recently. ''I didn't come here to be loved, and I have not been disappointed.''

title: Stunt Pilot Killed
description: A retired Navy pilot performing stunts at a air show apparently lost control of his small plane and was killed Sunday. The pilot, Don Smith, 60 years old, was performing a stalling stunt but the plane failed to come out of its spiral and crashed at the Shelby County Airport.

title: Mohawk Data Purchase
description: The Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Dek Identification Systems Inc., a privately held concern, for undisclosed terms. Dek produces photo identification cards used by 24 states for driving licenses, as well as identification cards for students, welfare recipients and others.

title: Bridge: League Makes a Revision In Choosing Tourney Sites
description: Most serious tournament players are in favor of having a national championship in their own backyard, for would this greatly reduce their travel and hotel bills. The American Contract Bridge League has long had a policy of staging one of its three annual tournaments in the East, one in the West and one in a central state. This year, for example, the Spring Nationals were in Niagara Falls, N.Y.; the Summer Nationals will be in Albuquerque, N.M., and the Fall Nationals in Minneapolis.

title: Economic Reporting Awards
description: Ann Crittenden, a reporter for The New York Times, and Stuart Diamond, a reporter for Newsday, on Long Island, have both won first prizes in the Champion Media Awards for Economic Understanding.

title: Motet Choir Presents Renaissance Composers
description: The New York Motet Choir sang music by three Renaissance composers Sunday at Grace Church. From Josquin Des Prez were an Ave Maria, O Virgo Virginum and Tulerunt Dominum Meum; from Orlandus Lassus, the Missa pro Defunctis and Surrexit Pastor Bonus, and from a more mysterious figure of the age, Pierre de la Rue, a Requiem, Delicta Juventutis and music from the Missa Ave Sanctissima Maria.

title: BURGER KING CORP. REPLACES CHAIRMAN
description: Louis P. Neeb will step down as chairman and chief executive of the Burger King Corporation on June 1, the fast-food chain's parent, the Pillsbury Company, said yesterday.

title: Hertz Profit Down In First Quarter
description: The Hertz Corporation's net income in the first quarter fell to $12.6 million from $13.6 million in last year's opening quarter, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corporate Philanthropy
description: Despite the recession, American corporations are willing to give more to philanthropy, according to results of a survey issued today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burroughs Corp., Detroit, has appointed J. Marine Gleason vice president and general counsel.

title: Presidential Prospect
description: She once worked for a young politician whose Presidential ambitions seemed beyond his grasp - until he demonstrated otherwise - and now Evelyn Lincoln thinks she may have spotted another such Presidential prospect.

title: U.N. TALKS RESUME ON FALKLAND CRISIS
description: Negotiations designed to end the fighting over the Falkland Islands resumed here today after a two-day break with some indications of more flexibility in the British position.

title: IMPOTENCE: EXPERTS URGE GREATER ATTENTION TO PHYSICAL CAUSES
description: THE loss of sexual potency, long thought to be an emotional problem in nearly all cases, is now often found to be brought on by physical conditions. And major advances are being reported in successfully treating impotence caused by these conditions and by emotional factors.

title: Bars to Trade Are Opposed
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia proposed today that the major industrial countries agree to a ''standstill'' on protectionist measures threatening further erosion of world trade and then to a reduction of existing barriers in the next five years.

title: A Racial Disagreement
description: A scouting supervisor for the Pittsburgh Pirates said the club, which is down by about 56,000 in attendance from last year, must find more white players if it is to get bigger turnouts. The supervisor, Howie Haak, was quoted in an interview with The Associated Press as having said: ''The people won't come out if you have too many blacks on a team, not if you have nine.

title: 2 British Helicopters Crashed In Retaking of South Georgia
description: Two British helicopters crashed on South Georgia Island while the navy prepared for the assault that recaptured the island from Argentina last month, the Defense Ministry said tonight.

title: F.B.I. Informer Protected
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit ruled today that Alabama cannot prosecute an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the 1965 slaying of a Detroit civil rights worker. The ruling affirmed an order by a lower court permanently prohibiting prosecution of Gary Thomas Rowe Jr. for the murder of Viola Liuzzo, a Detroit housewife who was shot to death after the historic Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march. Mr. Rowe testified against three Ku Klux Klansmen who were convicted of violating Mrs. Liuzzo's civil rights.

title: Acid Rain in Bermuda
description: Although the island of Bermuda lies some 600 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean, it is periodically subject to acid rains derived from the combustion of sulfurous fuels in North America, according to a report in the May 6 issue of Nature.

title: Disputed Korean Film Creating Stir at Cannes
description: A Korean war film starring Laurence Olivier is creating a stir at the 35th Cannes film festival because the $38 million picture was financed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church.

title: Republic Airline Chief Cites Reasonable Fares
description: Daniel F. May, Republic Airline's president and chief executive officer, does not think much of those who put the airline on the endangered list. ''They're all crazy,'' Mr. May said yesterday.

title: Heating Oil Futures Drop on Profit Taking
description: Heating oil futures prices eased yesterday in what brokers said was some profit taking after last week's strong advance. Even so, the near June and July deliveries are trading at levels not seen since the bitter cold days of last January.

title: Majestic Kat Triumphs In Albany at Aqueduct
description: Majestic Kat defeated the filly Cupecoy's Joy and won the $50,000-added Albany Handicap for New York-breds yesterday at Aqueduct, the closing-day feature. Thoroughbred racing in the city resumes Wednesday when Belmont Park opens a 70-day meeting.

title: WHAT TO DO, AND NOT TO DO, WITH SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: RICK KUHN TELLS OF DEATH THREATS
description: Rick Kuhn, the former Boston College basketball player convicted with four other men last November of taking part in a point-shaving conspiracy, has told Federal authorities that he was threatened with death if he cooperated with their continuing investigation into the scheme, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Japan Car Shipments
description: Exports to the United States rose in April, Japan's two largest car manufacturers, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, said today, although overall export and domestic sales fell from a year before.

title: LIBERALS' FEARS ON SECURITY UNIT EASE
description: The creation last year of a Senate subcommittee on internal security and terrorism alarmed many liberals who feared it might signal a revival of inquisitorial hunts for subversives like those of the 1950's. The subcommittee chairman, Republican Senator Jeremiah Denton of Alabama, protested, ''I am no Joe McCarthy.''

title: JUSTICE O'CONNOR NEXT TO TOP IN WEALTH ON SUPREME COURT
description: Sandra Day O'Connor is the secondwealthiest member of the Supreme Court, according to financial disclosure statements made public today.

title: PROPOSAL FOR JEWEL COLLECTION FOR FIRST LADIES IS REJECTED
description: The White House rejected a proposal by the New York jeweler Harry Winston Inc. today to set up a permanent collection of gems for American First Ladies.

title: Delta Queen Is Pulled Free
description: The Delta Queen, a passenger paddlewheel steamer stranded in the middle of the Mississippi River for nearly two days, was pulled free today by two towboats and chugged downstream toward St. Louis. About 70 spectators cheered as the Delta Queen was pulled free about eight miles south of Hannibal, Mo.

title: CAPACITY USE DROPS TO 71.1%
description: United States manufacturers operated their factories at just 71.1 percent of capacity in April, matching the lowest rate since the 1974-75 recession, the Government reported today.

title: REDS TOP SLOPPY METS, 7-2
description: The Mets, who had won six of their previous seven games, turned in a lackluster performance last night, losing to the Cincinnati Reds, 7-2, at Shea Stadium.

title: THE CITY;
description: A $25,000 reward for information about Etan Patz, who disappeared from his home in lower Manhattan three years ago at the age of 6, was offered yesterday by the boy's parents.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES SCHOOL PRAYER AMENDMENT
description: President Reagan today formally proposed a constitutional amendment permitting organized prayer in public schools.

title: DIXIE WALKER, DODGER STAR OF THE 1940'S, DEAD AT 71
description: Fred (Dixie) Walker, the Brooklyn Dodger outfielder whose popularity with Ebbets Field fans in the 1940's brought him the nickname The People's Cherce, died yesterday of cancer in Birmingham, Ala. He was 71 years old.

title: Mitterrand Leaves Tomorrow On an Official Visit to Africa
description: President Francois Mitterrand leaves Wednesday for his first official visit to Africa, with France's Socialist Government eager to maintain and develop longstanding trade and aid links with the continent.

title: READING TEA LEAVES: CHINA-SOVIET DETENTE
description: For the first time since the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979, Peking and Moscow appear to be moving toward detente.

title: Black Leader Asserts Reagan
description: Is Responding to Minorities

title: Florida Bank Merger Vote
description: Officials of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. said shareholders had indicated approval of a merger with the Alliance Corporation, but a lawyer for a dissident group of shareholders challenged the vote.

title: THE PRAYING MAJORITY
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA AND CHINA RESUME BORDER TALKS
description: India and China resumed official talks here today on the protracted border dispute that has soured relations between the two Asian nations for more than 20 years.

title: Baltimore Condemns Houses Over Shifting Amtrak Tunnel
description: City officials today condemned three row houses above an Amtrak tunnel that was closed for a day after officials said a wall shifted and the ground weakened.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: EVERYTHING had seemed out of whack for so long that last week at l east part of the fashion world tried to right itself. Retailers w ere finally facing up to the awful fashion truth that most people d on't go shopping for overcoats in June, have no intention of doing s o and would much rather see crisp linens on retail floors even in t he dead of summer. Traditionally, retailers have chosen to tempt thep erfervid fashion follower with fall merchandise as early as late s pring, baffling and angering the less slavish among us. However, s aid Kal Ruttenstein, vice president for fashion direction at B loomingdale's, that retail state of mind may be changing.

title: Shearson Adds Loan Servicing
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association announced today that it had agreed to sell $795 million of its $820 million loan servicing portfolio to the Shearson/American Express Mortgage Corporation for about $12.5 million.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS TIGHTER CONTROLS ON BANKRUPTCY
description: The State Assembly passed a bill today to tighten the state's personal bankruptcy laws. The bill, supported by a wide range of banking and business groups, is designed to replace a more lenient bankruptcy system enacted by Congress three years ago.

title: SHARING SEOUL'S PROSPERITY
description: Kang Jung Sub recalls vividly his early days in Seoul after he had fled from a farming village in Communist North Korea. Every day was a struggle to avoid starvation.

title: AGENCIES DENY SLOWING AN INQUIRY ON U.S. USE OF NAZI COLLABORATORS
description: The Justice and State Departments denied today that they had attempted in recent years to impede investigations into the recruitment of former Nazi collaborators by American intelligence agencies after the end of World War II.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FEMALE ALCOHOLISM RISING
description: Alcoholism has risen sharply among younger women in the last decade and may affect many women's lives even more negatively than men's, according to a survey of treatment and counseling centers by Redbook magazine.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS FEAR LOSS ON PENSIONS
description: Senate Republican leaders acknowledged today that they lacked the votes to win $40 billion in Social Security savings as part of the budget for the fiscal year 1983.

title: Sun-Nigeria Oil Deal
description: The Sun Company expects to resume purchases of Nigerian crude oil at a minimum of 10,000 barrels a day in June, the company's president, Robert McClements, said yesterday after a meeting of securities analysts. Sun suspended purchases in March, deciding that market conditions meant that it cost the company more to purchase the oil at the posted price of $35.50 than to pay a 5 percent penalty for not taking it.

title: DRUG FOR CROSSED EYES PROMISING IN EARLY TESTS
description: Doctors seeking an alternative to surgery for strabismus, or crossed eyes, are using a drug derived from the toxin of botulism to align the eyes in an outpatient procedure that takes only 10 minutes.

title: QUARTET: THE TOKYO STRINGS
description: THE Tokyo String Quartet gave the world premiere of Benjamin Lees's Quartet No. 3 on Sunday evening in Carnegie Hall, in a program that included works by Haydn and Dvorak. The new quartet is the second commissioned by the ensemble, which recently marked its 10th anniversary; as performed by the Tokyo players, it seemed a worthy if not a remarkably compelling addition to the repertory.

title: NETS PURSUE TOP DRAFT CHOICE
description: While Jerry Buss, the Los Angeles Lakers' owner, was publicly offering the San Diego Clippers a deal worth $6 million last week for their No.1 choice in the coming college draft, the New Jersey Nets were quietly attempting to obtain the Clippers' choice. They still are.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Armstrong World Industries filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to 300,000 common shares, to be offered by Salomon Brothers as selling shareholder.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Susan Bolotin THE KILLING OF BONNIE GARLAND: A Question of Justice. By Willard Gay- lin. Illustrated. 366 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.50. THE YALE MURDER. By Peter Meyer.302 pages. Empire. $12.95.

title: G.O.P. ADS FEATURE CARTER AND O'NEILL LOOKALIKES
description: Republicans today began using actors who look like former President Jimmy Carter and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., in a $1.7 million television advertising campaign to try to persuade the public that the Democrats caused the current recession.

title: Centennial for New York City's Detective Bureau
description: ''The job has changed a lot,'' Cesare Bonanno was saying at Police Headquarters yesterday, and no wonder. It has been 34 years since the 93-year-old Mr. Bonanno retired as a New York City detective, and a generation of criminals has since come of age and gone to jail.

title: GILMAN SERVICES
description: Gilman Services Inc., a drug and cosmetics distributor based in Braintree, Mass., announced that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws for itself and its subsidiaries, Rogers Wholesalers Inc. and Three P. Products. The company, which had started its intent to file last month, said it was still considering selling one or more of its units and was seeking additional capital. Irving L. Gartenberg, an attorney for the company, said that the cost of maintaining heavy inventories, coupled with high interest rates, drove the company into Charpter 11.

title: Paul E. Yergens, Ex-Publisher Of House Beautiful, Dies at 65
description: Paul E. Yergens, former publisher of House Beautiful magazine, died of cancer Sunday at Hilton Head Island Hospital in South Carolina. He was 65 years old and lived on Hilton Head.

title: The Sex of Alligators
description: Field experiments in Louisiana swamps have shown that when the eggs of alligators are incubated at temperatures below 86 degrees Fahrenheit, all the eggs produce females. If the temperature is above 93 degrees, only males are hatched. The effect runs exactly opposite to earlier observations on turtles, where higher incubation temperatures produce females.

title: REVOLUTION IN PLANT GENETICS FORECAST
description: A revolution in the understanding of the genetics of plants will develop within approximately the next five years, a scientist said at a symposium at the Beltsville Agricultural Research Center today.

title: Y Chamber Symphony Joined by Yo-Yo Ma
description: The Y Chamber Symphony's Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y began with splendid ingredients and used many of them wisely. The program, first of all, had originality and substance - Stravinsky's ''Dumbarton Oaks'' Concerto, the Shostakovich Cello Concerto No. 1, the youthful Langsamer Satz by Anton Webern and Mozart's G minor Symphony, No. 40.

title: Market Place; The Squeeze On Profits
description: CORPORATE profitability has been hurt badly by this recession and, with it, the corporate sector's ability to invest in its future. To some extent, the stock market has already taken this into account. But economists now are saying that the impact of the sagging profits has not yet been fully realized.

title: SAMUEL F. THOMAS, DEAN AT HOFSTRA
description: Dr. Samuel F. Thomas, dean of the Hofstra University School of Business, died Sunday night, apparently of a heart attack, shortly after the school's commencement exercises in the John Cranford Adams Playhouse in Hempstead, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: WHAT TO DO, AND NOT TO DO, WITH SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTERS WITHOUT SAY IN JUDICIAL ELECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: J.C. PENNEY'S PROFITS UP BY 4% IN PERIOD, SURPRISING ANALYSTS
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest retailer, reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 4 percent, to $52 million, or 73 cents a share, from $50 million, or 71 cents a share, in the 1981 period.

title: Interest Rates Rise Slightly
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as traders were disappointed and cut prices because of the continued high cost of financing inventories and lackluster investor demand.

title: TENSION AMONG BEIRUT LEFTISTS FLARING DAILY
description: The leftist, mostly Moslem coalition of private armies that holds sway over west Beirut and much of Lebanon is being faced with internal divisions that could shred its political power and lead to an internecine bloodbath.

title: JERSEY SENATE VOTES TO FILL MUSTO'S SEAT BY SPECIAL ELECTION
description: The State Senate, saying that the seat of Senator William V. Musto was vacant because of his conviction and sentencing on Federal racketeering charges, voted to fill the seat by public election on June 23.

title: MOSCOW SENDS A HIGH OFFICIAL TO POLAND
description: A top Soviet adviser flew to Warsaw today for talks with Polish leaders that the press agency Tass described as a ''friendly working visit.''

title: THE DOMINICANS' CHOICE
description: In 1965, Salvador Jorge Blanco was a young constitutional lawyer, helping to draft an agreement that would remove occupying United States forces from this country and lead it toward democracy.

title: Portuguese Preparing Case on Pope's Attacker
description: The police said today that it could take as long as six months to try the Rev. Juan Maria Fernandez Krohn, the dissident Spanish-born priest who lunged at Pope John Paul II with a bayonet last week.

title: CLEVELAND MUSEUM CHOOSES DIRECTOR
description: Evan Hopkins Turner, a former director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, will become director of the Cleveland Museum next year, succeeding Sherman E. Lee. The Cleveland museum is generally viewed as the nation's second museum, after the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: Expos Beat Braves; 2-Hitter for Rogers
description: Steve Rogers fired a two-hitter tonight, and Al Oliver drove in two runs with a triple in the third inning to pace the Montreal Expos to a 4-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: ADEQUATE NOTICE OF EVICTIONS ORDERED
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state may not exercise its power to evict tenants without insuring that they have received adequate notice of the eviction proceedings.

title: Cribbs's Lament
description: Joe Cribbs, the star running back for the Buffalo Bills who failed to appear at a minicamp last week, is unhappy over the way the club is handling his request to renegotiate his contract.

title: PIANO AND PERCUSSION BY THE GOTTLIEB TWINS
description: The Gottieb twins played a concert of piano and percussion music Saturday night that set no new standards for subtlety. Still, the sheer exuberance of this noisy occasion managed to outwiegh the occasional vulgarities.

title: HIGH COURT DECLINES 2 CASES LIMITING PRESS TRIAL COVERAGE
description: The United States Supreme Court declined yesterday to review two lower court decisions that press groups say could endanger public rights of access to criminal court proceedings.

title: Courts on Trial Third of four articles on efforts; to restrain the Federal judiciary.
description: In Alabama, a Federal judge, finding prison conditions ''barbarous'' and ''shocking,'' ordered sweeping improvements in the entire corrections system of the state. In Texas, another Federal judge ordered an end to the practice of putting two inmates in cells built for one. In New York, Federal District Judge Morris Lasker ruled that no additional prisoners could be incarcerated at the Manhattan House of Detention, commonly known as The Tombs.

title: A MORE SEDATE MOOD IN FURS
description: As the fur showings began yesterday, audiences were aware of a definite change in mood. American furriers are voting conservative this year. Their customers are buying furs, but they want investments rather than startlers. There were more fur coats than ever on the city's streets this past cold winter, and despite the tight economy, a surprising number of them were good, dark mink whose current price tag is in the $8,000 or more bracket.

title: RITE OF SPRING IS HELD WITH HOT TAR AND ASPHALT
description: To be sure, there are more poetic and celebrated harbingers of spring than the pungent odor of hot tar or the hiss of steaming asphalt meeting cool pavement. But New York drivers welcome the highway maintenance crews that have now taken to the streets again to tend the winter's crop of potholes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You don't send a life raft to someone who's not drowning.'' - Assemblyman G. Oliver Koppell of the Bronx, questioning transit revenue projections. (A1:1.)

title: 11 Complaints Resolved Concerning Ad Claims
description: Although the label on General Foods' Top Choice dog food contains more non-beef products than beef, both Young & Rubicam and Benton & Bowles created commercials that made a big deal about the beef content, enough to get a competitor to complain to the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. But before an investigation was completed the advertiser dropped the campaign.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Borg Textile subsidiaries in the United States and Canada to an investor group led by Patrick J. Forde, Borg's president. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Power Plant Loan
description: The Allegheny Generating Company, based in New York, said it had obtained a $225 million, four-year loan to finance its 20 percent interest in the Bath County Pumped Storage Hydroelectric Power Project in Virginia.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Betty Coed, Reconsidered

title: CITY MAY LOSE MEDICAID JOBS
description: The state has awarded a contract that would move its Medicaid billing system from New York City to Albany, despite objections from Mayor Koch and 68 state legislators.

title: FALL SWEATERS: DIVERSE AND IMAGINATIVE
description: When Diana Vreeland said the sweater would go down in fashion history as the uniform of the 20th century, she was not referring specifically to the lacy mohair cardigans that older women tend to put over their shoulders on cruises. Nor did she mean the oversize sloppy Joe's or the tight angoras of the pinup era, or the skimpy ''poor boy'' styles of the early 1960's - one of the first successes of the growing ready-to-wear industry in Paris - or the revival of the classic cashmere twin set encouraged by Halston and Saint Laurent a decade later.

title: REAGAN ARMS PLAN WINS WIDE BACKING AT SESSION OF NATO
description: President Reagan's proposal to open talks with the Soviet Union on reducing strategic arms and his willingness to confer with Leonid I. Brezhnev were widely backed today by allied foreign ministers.

title: Francana Buy-Out
description: Sceptre Resources Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas exploration company based in Calgary, Alberta, said it had completed its earlier announced acquisition of the Canadian assets of Francana Oil and Gas Ltd., also based in Calgary, for about $160 million (Canadian). Francana's non-Canadian assets, which consisted of a 28 percent interest in the Adobe Oil and Gas Corporation, based in Midland, Tex., and a 57 percent interest in Trend International Ltd. of Bermuda were acquired earlier by two subsidiaries of the Anglo-American Corporation of South Africa Ltd. for about $68 million in assumed debt. Francana Oil will henceforth cease to exist.

title: Rapist's Mother on Trial In Murder Attempt
description: Ruth Coe, the mother of Fred Coe, who was convicted as Spokane's ''South Hill rapist,'' went on trial today on charges of attempting to murder the prosecutor and judge involved in her son's case.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HAPPY RETURNS

title: THE HOAX OF THE SENTRY CATCHES POLICE OFF GUARD
description: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically. By M. A. FARBER

title: Coastal Court Bid
description: The Coastal Petroleum Company said its motion for contempt of court against the Mobil Oil Corporation had been denied by United States District Court here, allowing Mobil to proceed with its state court suits against Coastal to acquire title to certain mineral lands in Polk County. Coastal is a 90 percent owned subsidiary of Coastal Caribbean Oils and Minerals Ltd.

title: Consort of Viols Joins Corpus & Sacbut Group
description: The music played by the New York Consort of Viols and the New York Cornet & Sacbut Ensemble on Sunday at Corpus Christi Church lay at the boundary of our common conception of secular, non-operatic repertory music. The instrumental works from Renaissance Italy by Gabrieli, Bendusi and others are secular and nonvocal, and they are partly independent of text or ceremonial occasion.

title: Chess: Huebner's Openings Show His Excellent Preparation
description: One of the salient features of Robert Huebner's fine performance in the Cloverline International Tournament in Chicago was his excellent opening preparation. In most of the 33-year-old West German grandmaster's games, his opponents could hardly get the pieces out of the box before he was breathing down their necks.

title: CO-AUTHOR OF BOOKS AND STAGE MUSICALS
description: Fred M. Saidy, who collaborated with E.Y. (Yip) Harburg on the books for the Broadway musical hits ''Finian's Rainbow'' and ''Jamaica'' and was co-author of another, ''Bloomer Girl,'' died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I am a doctor. When I look in a patient's eye with an ophthalmoscope, I see the retina in natural colors, with red blood vessels on a yellow background. But when someone looks in my eye with an ophthalmoscope, I see my own retina, as many people do, in various shades of gray. My ophthalmologist has no explanation. May I have yours?

title: EDITH MOCSANYI
description: Edith Mocsanyi, a concert pianist and teacher, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

title: 3 Scale Himalayan Peak
description: Two Italians and their Sherpa guide reached the top of the world's third-highest peak, the 28,208-foot Kanchenjunga. The Ministry of Tourism said today that the group climbed the north face of the mountain in northeast Nepal and reached the summit May 6. The Italians were identified as Reinhold Messner and Gottefried Mutschlechner.

title: ADMINISTRATION BID ON BREEDER REACTOR IS REJECTED BY PANEL
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, in a surprise ruling, refused today to reconsider its denial of the Reagan Administration's request for accelerated construction of the $3.2 billion Clinch River Breeder Reactor.

title: Kissinger Declares the U.S.  Faced Dilemma on Falklands
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the United States had little choice but to support Britain in its dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands even though that support disrupted United States policies in Latin America.

title: Steinbrenner's Pitch
description: Speaking at Grambling State's commencement exercises, the new doctor of laws said there was a ''lack of communication and trust between the players and management'' that could jeopardize the future of professional sports. The speaker was George Steinbrenner, whose decade-long reign as head of the Yankees has been marked by more management-player controversies than Reggie Jackson could wave a bat at.

title: The Boas Tradition
description: The educator widely credited with bringing a scientific method to the study of anthropology was Prof. Franz Boas, who joined the Barnard College faculty shortly after World War I and died in 1942.

title: QUEENS OFFICIALS FEAR PLAN TO USE CREEDMOOR AS PRISON
description: New York State officials are planning to transfer 400 parole violators from Westchester County to unused buildings at the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens, a move that has caused alarm among community leaders in the vicinity of the mental hospital.

title: Nucorp Reports Loss
description: Nucorp Energy Inc., reported a 1982 first quarter loss of $25 million, or $1.43 a share, compared with a profit of $5 million, or 25 cents a share, in the previous first quarter. Revenues increased in the first quarter to $121.6 million, from $72 million in the previous first quarter. Nucorp is engaged in oil and gas exploration, development and production.

title: SUN COMPANY TRIMS OIL BUDGET
description: The Sun Company, the nation's 12th-largest oil company, said it was revising downward its oil exploration and production spending plans for the next three years, to $1.26 billion a year from about $1.3 billion.

title: G.M.-Toyota Talks
description: The General Motors Corporation opened talks today with the Toyota Motor Company, Japan's leading auto manufacturer, about jointly producing Toyota-designed small cars in the United States.

title: SALVADORAN ARMY LEADER RESIGNS
description: Gen. Jaime Abdul Gutierrez, a leader of the 1979 coup that overthrew a rightist military regime, has resigned as commander of the Salvadoran armed forces, the military authorities announced today.

title: Latin American Festival Set for Aug. 1 to 15
description: Theater companies from all over Latin America and from the United States will take part Aug. 1 to 15 in the third Latin American Popular Theater Festival. As in 1976 and 1980, the event will include performances at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater as well as street presentations by New York groups.

title: Ad Pages Down 1.4%
description: For the first time this year, ad pages of member magazines in the Publishers Information Bureau dipped in March over the comparable month last year. The figure was 11,434, a 1.4 percent drop, according to the P.I.B., a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers Association.

title: C.A.B. TO STUDY LAYOFF AID
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board plans to begin deliberations this week on which airlines qualify for the labor protection provisions of the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978.

title: Cuisine Magazine Cuts
description: Cuisine magazine, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law before being acquired in mid-March by CBS Publications, has announced that it is cutting its 750,000 circulation rate base back by 25,000 of its ''marginal circulation'' with the July edition, and cutting its rates by the same 3.3 percent.

title: Required Reading  Studying the Senate
description: Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, submitting a resolution to the Senate proposing the formation of a study group to examine Senate procedures, May 11, 1982:

title: Reese Schonfeld Of CNN Resigns
description: Reese Schonfeld, president of the Cable News Network, resigned yesterday. He cited 'business differences' with Ted Turner, founder and owner of the two-year-old 24-hour-a-day news network.

title: GUATEMALAN LEADER SAYS JUNTA WILL CALL ELECTIONS THIS YEAR
description: The head of the ruling military junta said today that it would call elections at the end of this year for a constituent assembly to rewrite the Constitution and that general elections would probably be held in 1984.

title: In Defense of the Dandelion
description: This is the time of the dandelion, when its blossom brightens up or - depending on how one feels about it - messes up the lawn. Most people, who hold to a Calvinist notion that a weed-free lawn is a necessary way to grace, look on the dandelion as a weed to be sternly cast out. Others, who have a let-live philosophy of lawns, find that the happy color it adds to the grass in spring makes up for its shabby look the rest of the year.

title: A TEARFUL GALTIERI SAYS HOPE ENDURES
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri said today, after an emotional Argentine Navy Day mass, that he still had hope for peace in the South Atlantic.

title: OREGON'S GOVERNOR LEADING 6 IN POLLS
description: Gov. Victor G. Atiyeh of Oregon, a Republican, appears to be in a solid position to win renomination in his state's primary elections today after a campaign in which he kept his distance from the Reagan Administration's economic policies.

title: U.A.W. Chrysler Group Seeks 'Lifetime Jobs'
description: A 200-member council of the United Automobile Workers resolved today to bargain with the Chrysler Corporation for ''permanent lifetime jobs,'' restoration of cost-of-living allowances and parity with workers at Ford and General Motors.

title: ISRAELIS CAUTIOUS ON TIES TO AFRICA
description: Despite Zaire's announcement over the weekend that it was restoring the diplomatic relations with Israel that it broke in 1973, the prospects that this would lead to an extensive renewal of formal Israeli ties with black Africa seemed uncertain today.

title: Billy Graham Rebuffs Criticism of Soviet Trip
description: The Rev. Billy Graham said today that he expected his visit to Moscow to create controversy. He rebuffed criticism that he had been naive to discuss peace and nuclear war at a church conference.

title: RATE FEARS CITED
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday amid growing concern that interest rates would not fall soon and that recovery from the recession would be further delayed.

title: SERVICES: BUCKING THE SLUMP
description: It is easy to count cars and trucks rolling off assembly lines and ingots of steel being poured. So as production of manufactured goods has slumped, the depth of the recession has seemed alarmingly clear.

title: 'High School' Closes
description: ''Is There Life After High School,'' the musical with book by Jeffrey Kindley and music and lyrics by Craig Carnelia about a highschool reunion, closed after Sunday's matinee at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Directed by Robert Nigro, the production ran for 41 previews and 12 performances. The producers were Clive Davis, Francois de Menil, Harris Masiansky and 20th Century-Fox Productions.

title: RISE IN M.T.A. FARES TERMED UNNEEDED
description: The State Assembly's Democratic leadership said today that increases in bus, subway and commuter rail fares were not needed this year and that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had ''grossly exaggerated'' its projected $406 million deficit.

title: Doyle's First Account
description: As its first account, week-old Doyle-Heekin has landed Securities Groups, previously with Doremus & Company. The account, formerly billing in the very low six figures, is now expected to bill in the seven figures, according to the new agency. Things always look brighter at an address like 500 Park Avenue.

title: Haley and Village Chief Differ on Mosque Funds
description: Since the publication of his book ''Roots,'' which traced his family's origins to the West African country of Gambia, Alex Haley has, he says, given ''appreciable thousands of dollars'' to Gambian causes.

title: United Slashes Hawaii Fares
description: United Airlines said it would slash its oneway coach fare to Hawaii from Los Angeles and San Diego to $119.98 from $310, effective next month.

title: Choral Society Presents Bach's B Minor Mass
description: Bach's B minor Mass is such an awesome work, even on paper, that even modest performances can touch some of its glories. If technical accomplishment is lacking, there still remain dramatic contrasts; if the suppleness of Bach's religious vision stiffens into musical dogma, there still are glimpses of its human face in intimate melodic lines.

title: ALBANY NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON BILL TO LET SOME NURSES TREAT ILLNESSES
description: Negotiators for the Senate and the Assembly have agreed on a bill that would enable registered nurses who receive special training to diagnose and treat illnesses and prescribe certain medications without the direct supervision of a physician.

title: REAGAN TURNS RADICAL
description: Economic disarray, probably more than anything, has caused a precipitous drop in President Reagan's poll standing. And that probably had much to do with his sudden promotion of the so-called ''social issues'' beloved by his right wing.

title: CITY BALLET: MERRILL ASHLEY IN 'BALLADE'
description: THE New York City Ballet may be putting its energies into preparing for its approaching Stravinsky Festival, but you would never have known it from repertory performances Saturday and Sunday nights at the New York State Theater.

title: Two Ounces of Prevention
description: A major triumph of public health has gone largely unnoticed. It is the recent report from the National Centers for Disease Control that some 95 percent of children entering school are now immunized against the seven major diseases of childhood. Indeed measles, which attacked 57,000 children in 1977, has been so reduced that public health authorities hope to eradicate it this year.

title: JEFFERSON'S PREFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: JOSEPH CONDUCTS AMERICAN PHILHARMONIC
description: THE qualities most useful in listening to young or newly spawned conductors are faith, hope and charity, and the greatest of these is charity. Even for most talented, solidly schooled musicians, conducting an orchestra demands more in the way of burning desire, flaming ego and pure executive ability than they have by nature or that they care to nurture. So, let it be merely said of Rohan Joseph, who led the American Philharmonic Orchestra last night at Avery Fisher Hall, that he plainly wants to conduct and has acquired his own full-sized symphonic instrument to practice on. Mr. Joseph, a 28-year-old native of Sri Lanka, founded the orchestra two years ago and has had some success in getting it financed and attracting audiences.

title: Florida Bank Stake Raised
description: C.A. Cavendes Sociedad Financiera, a Venezuelan company that has been one of the key players in the takeover battle for control of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., said yesterday that it had purchased an additional 1.87 million Florida National shares, 12.6 percent of its stock, for $23.4 million.

title: BUSH TRIED TO SWAY A TAX RULE CHANGE BUT THEN WITHDREW
description: Vice President Bush, in an unusual move, intervened with the Treasury in March in connection with proposed rules that would have forced pharmaceutical companies to pay significantly more taxes.

title: Macmillan Aide to Head Oxford University Press
description: Edward W. Barry, a senior vice president of the Macmillan Publishing Company, has been named president of Oxford University Press, New York, effective June 21. The position has been vacant since Byron S. Hollinshead resigned in February in a dispute over control of the department that produces materials for teaching American English as a second language.

title: Judge Delays Decision
description: A Federal judge delayed a decision in injunction proceedings today on whether to allow the Oakland Raiders to move to Los Angeles. Although a Federal jury has decided the National Football League violated antitrust laws in refusing to allow the team to move, the verdict does not in itself allow the Raiders to leave Oakland.

title: S.E.C. DATA: DIFFICULT HUNT
description: It's midday at the public reference room of the Securities and Exchange Commission. A smartly dressed young woman, almost breathless with anxiety, hands James Brodie a form requesting detailed information on a dozen or so American companies.

title: METROMEDIA TAKES CONTROL OF STATION
description: Metromedia Inc. said yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of WCVB-TV, Channel 5, an independently owned ABC affiliate in Boston, from Boston Broadcasters Inc. for $220 million in cash and notes. The price is a record for a television station.

title: Iacocca to Head Drive to Restore Landmarks
description: President Reagan appointed Lee A. Iacocca yesterday as chairman of a commission to raise $100 million to restore the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island in New York Harbor, once the gateway for millions of immigrants.

title: CONCERT: THE JUPITER IN A FRENCH BILL
description: THE Jupiter Symphony's concert Monday at Alice Tully Hall veered off in many directions but remained doggedly French to the end. There were songs by Godard and Satie, a piece for seven cellos by Boulez, Ibert's ''Symphonie Concertante'' for oboe and strings, two pieces by Rameau and a chaste little Habanera for piano written by Chabrier and played by the Jupiter's conductor, Jens Nygaard.

title: Vice President Named At Atlantic Magazine
description: David Auchincloss, publisher since March of The Atlantic magazine, confirmed yesterday that he was bringing in Carol A. Decker as vice president, associate publisher-advertising, from Reader's Digest.

title: SOVIET CRAFT LAUNCHES SATELLITE
description: The two Soviet astronauts in the Salyut 7 space station have launched a small communications satellite into orbit from aboard their large craft, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency.

title: 2 DEFECTIONS THREATEN BEGIN COALITION
description: Two members of Parliament defected from Prime Minister Menachem Begin's shaky coalition today, leaving uncertain the Government's ability to muster a majority for a no-confidence vote Wednesday.

title: INQUIRY ON DONOVAN ASSAILED
description: Private investigators hired by Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan's former company will check members of Congress to find out who is accusing the concern of having links to organized crime, a company spokesman said today.

title: Catholic Prelate Accused Of Conflict of Interest
description: The director of the Los Angeles Archdiocesan Office of Religious Education is reaping huge profits by ordering textbooks from a concern that pays him as a consultant, the National Catholic Reporter has reported.

title: Morocco's King in U.S.  To Discuss Arms Aid
description: King Hassan II of Morocco, whose North African nation is fighting a guerrilla war in Western Sahara, arrived here today seeking American arms and support.

title: U.S. EASING POLICY ON NUCLEAR SALES TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Reagan Administration has adopted a more flexible policy that will allow the United States to increase its sales of nuclear materials to South Africa, the Commerce Department said.

title: Talks Continue On the Rockies
description: After more than 14 hours of discussion that extended past 2 A.M. this morning, the National Hockey League's board of governors had still not reached a decision on the proposed transfer of the Colorado Rockies franchise to the Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: BLONDIE has consistently been successful on the pop charts, but otherwise New York's No.1 pop-rock band hasn't been consistent at all. The group's last album, ''Autoamerican,'' tried everything from movie soundtrack music to arch cocktail jazz to rap to reggae. It was a scattered and uneven album, but it yielded two hit singles, ''Rapture'' and ''The Tide Is High.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am shortly expecting visitors from Australia, and I would like to give them a sample of their native cooking. I have heard of carpetbagger steak made with beef and oysters and wonder if you would supply me with a recipe.

title: BRITISH MILITARY ACTION VIOLATES THE U.N. CHARTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Brock Backs Trade Plan
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, today backed an Australian proposal for a ''standstill'' on protectionist measures by major industrial countries and a reduction of existing trade barriers over the next five years.

title: 1. A Malaysian Summer
description: If an invitation to an impromptu picnic or beach party comes along, one can have an outfit all packed. A sun dress, a quilted hat and a small purse for money or makeup arrive in a matching tote bag with a zippered top and two outside pockets. The outfit is made in Malaysia of batik-printed cotton and comes in six color combinations. Since the dress wraps around and ties, there's no problem about fit. The whole business is $40 at Kathy's boutique, 2 West 23d Street.

title: A.C.C. to Use Shot Clock, 3-Point Goal
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference approved today a 30-second shot clock and a 3-point field goal for the next basketball season.

title: THE SPOON QUESTION, OR HOW TO EAT PASTA LIKE AN EXPERT
description: ''Most restaurants (and hostesses) that feature pasta provide guests with a large spoon as well as the knife and fork. The fork is used to spear a few strands of spaghetti, the tips are placed against the spoon, which is held on its side, in the left hand, and the fork is twirled, wrapping the spaghetti around itself as it turns. If no spoon is provided, the tips of the fork may be rested against the curve of the plate.'' ''The New Emily Post's Etiquette,'' Elizabeth L. Post, 1975 By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: Careers; Students Control Satellite
description: Above the ozone of the mesosphere, a NASA satellite orbits the earth 15 times a day, while down below 15 University of Colorado undergraduates help control it and analyze the scientific data received.

title: SOME NEW FOODS YOU WON'T BE SEEING
description: UNLESS you have spent time recently in Binghamton, N.Y., chances are you've never eaten a Smither's Love Boat. If you have no ties with Dallas, you probably don't know about Knot-a-Bagel, which is a bagel-like bread shaped in a pretzel knot rather than in a circle. And except in certain cities in the upper Middle West, all of us have been denied Tan Amin, a vitamin supplement that purportedly gives your skin a tanlike healthy glow.

title: On the Run
description: It is not that Ronald A. Simoncini did not want to go to college, the 35-year-old Mr. Simoncini confided the other day. ''It's just that when I got out of high school I wanted a Corvette more,'' he said.

title: Inquiry Starts in Jersey On Vehicle Inspections
description: The State Attorney General and a legislative committee today opened investigations into allegations that employees of the Division of Motor Vehicles had accepted payoffs to alter drivers' records or pass unsafe vehicles through inspection.

title: Benjamin Crisler, Journalist; New York Times Film Critic
description: Benjamin R. Crisler, a former film reviewer for The New York Times and a freelance journalist, died Sunday morning at his home in Pacific Grove, Calif. He was 77 years old and had lived in New York and, until his retirement 10 years ago, in Stamford, Conn.

title: Soviet Housing in Kabul Is Reported Bombed
description: An explosion at a large housing complex for Soviet citizens in the Afghan capital of Kabul killed several Afghan guards, Western diplomats reported today.

title: 'RACE D'EP' LINKS PHOTOGRAPHY AND SEXUALITY
description: ''RACE D'EP,'' Paris street slang for homosexual, is a four-part French film that argues that ''gay liberation was not born in the 60's'' but, instead, had its roots in the mid-19th century. The film, which opens today at the Agee Room in the Bleecker Street Cinema, is modestly scaled but not amateurish, acted by what appear to be nonprofessionals who never overreach themselves. It seems to have been shot silent, with soundtrack narration added later.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Like Captain Hook, John T. Flaherty is dogged by crocodiles, and, in addition, alligators. Mr. Flaherty is chief of design in the New York City Bureau of Sewers, but he is also the resident expert on the most durable urban myth in the history of cities, reptiles or waste disposal.

title: Hugging Called an Aid In Heart-Lung Failure
description: Hugging has led to a new method of stimulating the blood flow in patients suffering from heart-lung failures, a physician told the American Lung Association today.

title: 9 Czech Tourists Hiding In Scotland After Tour
description: Nine Czechoslovak tourists were in hiding in Scotland today after leaving a Soviet liner, the Home Office said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt STUFF OF SLEEP AND DREAMS: Ex- periments in Literary Psychology. By Leon Edel. 352 pages. Harper & Row. $20.

title: HINCKLEY TREATMENTS TERMED 'ABSOLUTE CALAMITY'
description: The psychiatric treatments John W. Hinckley Jr. received in the months before he shot President Reagan were ''an absolute calamity'' that worsened his already ''bizarre state of mind'' and may have helped ignite his ''inner rage,'' a defense psychiatrist testified today.

title: Galbreath Is Dismayed Over Scout's Remark
description: John W. Galbreath, chairman of the board of the Pittsburgh Pirates, today termed ''very unfortunate'' the comments of a scout who said the club would have to sign more white players if it wanted to improve attendance.

title: WHEN WESTERNERS ATTACK THE ISRAELI NATIONAL CONSENUS
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSEMBLY PANEL PASSES A 5-DEPOSIT BOTTLE BILL
description: Seated around a narrow table in a tiny conference room packed with lobbyists, reporters and aides, members of the Assembly Commerce Committee today approved a bill to place a 5-cent deposit on bottles and cans sold in New York State. The approval clears the way for the first vote on the measure in the Assembly, in a decade of attempts. Legislative aides say a floor vote could come within two weeks, and supporters are predicting that the bill will pass.

title: Playboy Shifts Finance Officer
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. of Chicago said it had elected Stephen Silverstein, 33 years old, to be senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Sports of The Times; A Golf Warning
description: Plymouth Charity Classic that begins Friday, they visited the office of the tournament director, Peter Busatti.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES HOUSING AID BILL
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today ignored White House objections and approved a $5 billion program aimed at reviving the ailing housing industry over the next five years by subsidizing mortgage rates for qualified buyers of new homes.

title: Ferguson Enterprises
description: Wolseley-Hughes said today that it planned to acquire Ferguson Enterprises of the United States for $30.7 million, subject to approval by the shareholders of both companies. The British company, a heating equipment distributor, said the acquisition of a similar business in the United States would enhance its long-term growth potential.

title: News Analysis
description: The inability of Drysdale Government Securities to meet at least $160 million in interest payments aroused fears yesterday of a chain reaction of failures among other securities firms.

title: PRICES GYRATE
description: Amid great nervousness about the failure of Drysdale Government Securities to make interest payments on schedule, government securities dealers scaled back their speculative activities yesterday and waited for the dust to settle.

title: ANN HIGGINBOTHAM
description: Ann McVicker Higginbotham, vice chairman of McVicker Higginbotham Inc., a New York direct-mail service, died Saturday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: I.B.M. View On Judge
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has joined the Justice Department in challenging the authority of Judge David N. Edelstein of Federal District Court to conduct further hearings in the antitrust case the Government filed against I.B.M. 13 years ago.

title: G.O.P. DROPS PLANS TO SAVE $40 BILLION IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Senate Republicans today withdrew their proposal for $40 billion in Social Security savings over three years, but they committed themselves to assuring the solvency of the Social Security System by the end of the year.

title: I.B.M. Plans 2 New Systems
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would offer a less expensive version of its Displaywriter system and a new Datamaster system with substantially more storage and a new printer.

title: Of Red Ink
description: Some creditors use red ink, but an Iowa debt-collection company used red words in violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

title: ABC Gives Cable, Videotex Plans
description: Elton Rule, chairman of the American Broadcasting Companies, told shareholders at the annual meeting that the company would continue to develop cable television programs through joint ventures and to explore videotex services. ''The 80's will be the decade of telecommunications,'' Mr. Rule said, adding that ABC plans to develop new services to make use of the new technology.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anchor Hocking Corp., Lancaster, Ohio, has elected J. Ray Topper president and chief executive officer.

title: Safeway Outlook
description: Safeway Stores, the country's largest supermarket chain, told shareholders at its annual meeting in Baltimore that it expects improvement this year in both sales and profit despite its firstquarter decline in net income. In the first quarter ended March 30, Safeway reported a 17.1 percent decline in earnings, to $16 million, or 61 cents a share, from $19.3 million, or 74 cents a share. Sales rose 10.9 percent, to $3.98 billion.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 19, 1982; Companies
description: Drysdale Securities informed creditors it could not meet $160 million in interest payments. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York told Government bond dealers it was ready, as a lender of last resort, to help commercial banks meet ''unusual credit demands.'' Chase Manhattan, as the clearing agent for Drysdale's transactions, could be held liable for the amount, some dealers believe. (Page A1.) Fears were expressed in the financial community of a chain reaction of failures among securities firms. (D4.)

title: Disclosure Charges Dropped Against Official at Pentagon
description: A charge accusing a Pentagon official of disclosing classified information has been dismissed, but he will be reprimanded by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, the official's attorney said tonight.

title: PUBLIC LEDGER'S FLAW
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BOOMING BAGHDAD, BULLDOZERS DROWN OUT WAR
description: Nothing in the sounds and sights of Baghdad would indicate that this is the capital of a country at war. The city looks like a single immense construction site.

title: JAILED FARMER TELLS OF FIGHT FOR GRAIN
description: A Missouri farmer who says he is in jail because he decided it was time ''to stand up'' for justice and fight an unfair law pleaded today for Congress to help farmers who have grain locked up in bankrupt elevators.

title: Talks on Olympics
description: Still with no assurance that the Soviet Union will send a team to the 1984 Games, the chairman of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, Peter V. Ueberroth, spent two hours outlining plans to top sports officials in Moscow. Ueberroth said he had assured Sergei Pavlov, president of the Soviet Olympic Committee, that ''efforts will be made to accommodate all nations in the best possible fashion.''

title: Half-Closed Courtrooms
description: Two years ago the Supreme Court, with only one dissent, proclaimed that ''a presumption of openness inheres in the very nature of a criminal trial under our system of justice.'' That didn't stop lawyers from seeking secret justice or judges from trying to restrict the right of the public and reporters to attend criminal trials. The erosion of the openness principle appeared in two cases that, on Monday, the Court declined to hear.

title: Record Spread Posted In Wheat Futures Prices
description: While Chicago wheat futures prices have been slipping in desultory trading for many weeks because terminals there are choked with grain, a severe shortage of wheat at Kansas City, Mo., has caused a rare inversion of prices between the two markets.

title: The U.N. Today; May 19, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Unicef Executive Board - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Interpublic and O.& M.  Appoint New Directors
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications both had their annual meetings yesterday and like the Ogilvy & Mather meeting of last week, no excitement.

title: INCO: BUFFETED BY RECESSION
description: Inco Ltd., the mining giant that has long been the dominant force in world nickel markets as well as a huge copper supplier and a potent entrant into the United States battery market, has struck a vein rich in trouble.

title: St. Bart's Vote On Lease Upheld
description: The Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, removed a legal impediment to the attempt by St. Bartholomew's Church to lease part of its property to a developer who wants to build a 59-story office tower on the site.

title: STUDY FINDS U.S. CUTS HARM THE POOR
description: The Federal budget cuts enacted last year have begun to hurt poor people in a variety of ways, but so far the reductions in Federal aid have not dramatically affected municipal services provided directly by state and local governments, according to a study by researchers at Princeton University.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY BREZHNEV ON NUCLEAR ARMS TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, at a convention of the Young Communist League today, as translated by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: RATES ON OVERSEAS PHONE CALLS DECLINE
description: While prices for many services have been continuing to climb, one has come down: overseas telephone rates. On Monday rates for overseas calls were restructured for the second time in a year. According to Richard Meyer of the long-lines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the 35 percent reduction last year and the new cut averaging 4.5 percent were effected to bring the profit on overseas services, previously much higher, in line with that for domestic operations.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Borg-Warner Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the Borg-Warner Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of up to $200 million aggregate principal amount of its senior unsecured debt securities, to be issued on a delayed or continuous basis.

title: ELECTRIC COFFEE GRINDER
description: THERE is nothing like coffee made with properly roasted, freshly ground beans, especially after a good meal. And although the oldfashioned brass mortar and pestle makes an excellent fine grind, I am quite content to spare myself the exertion and let a machine do the work for me.
