To this end there are many electric coffee grinders to choose from, but I have found none quite as efficient as the Olympia Express model. It is exactly like the professional kind used in many restaurants, but smaller for domestic use. It has two advantages.

title: LEGAL OBSTACLE TO HELP FOR THE MENTALLY RETARDED
description: To the Editor:

title: Kriek Upset in Rome; Gerulaitis, Clerc Win
description: Pablo Arraya of Peru, steadier off the ground, defeated second-seeded Johan Kriek, 6-1, 6-2, today in the first major upset of the $300,000 Italian Open clay-court tennis championships.

title: TV: 'MEDIA PROBES' LOOKS AT POLLSTERS
description: ''MEDIA PROBES,'' an eight-part series being carried on WNET-TV on Wednesdays at 8 o'clock, is the kind of relatively modest but exceptionally informative project that public television still does best. The producers did their professional apprenticeships in the Kit Laybourne is an independent animator whose teaching and lecturing has taken him from Alaska to Thailand. Mickey Lemle's film making is firmly rooted in his editing experience for WGBH-TV, Boston's publictelevision station.

title: Kennan Wins German Prize
description: George F. Kennan, the American historian and longtime diplomat, won the 1982 peace prize of the West German book trade, the Publishers' Association said today. Mr. Kennan, 78 years old, has been in the news here recently for urging the West to renounce the first use of nuclear weapons and strengthen its conventional forces. The prize is worth $11,000.

title: MAGAZINE WITHHELD BY U.S. MAY REVIVE
description: The American Dietetic Association, an organization of 45,000 registered dietitians, is negotiating with the Department of Agriculture to publish a condensed version of the department's magazine, Food/2, which has been a subject of dispute.

title: A BLACK-LEATHER WHITE-COLLAR 'GROUP'
description: YOU wouldn't really call them a motorcycle gang. Oh sure, they wear black leather and thrill to the sound of a well-tuned engine revving at 5,500 r.p.m.'s. And they do speak somewhat rhapsodically about the pull of the open road, about what it's like to lean far into a turn and watch the macadam whiz by. And they tend to travel in a pack that might appear menacing at first glance. But still, you wouldn't really call them a motorcycle gang.

title: REAGAN AND TRUMAN
description: In the last few days, President Reagan has proposed a formula for the reduction of nuclear weapons, and President Brezhnev of the Soviet Union, while rejecting Mr. Reagan's specific suggestions, has agreed that they should get together later in the year to talk this over.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday on opposition to judicial activism in school desegrega- tion incorrectly identified Julius Chambers, a lawyer from Charlotte, N.C. He is president of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., which has no affiliation with the National Association for the Advance- ment of Colored People.

title: FAILURE OF FALKLAND TALKS FEARED AS ENVOYS MEET WITH U.N. CHIEF
description: British and Argentine envoys held separate meetings late Tuesday night with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in an effort to save the Falkland Islands peace talks from collapse.

title: Billy Graham, in London, Gets A Religion Prize of $200,000
description: The Rev. Billy Graham received the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion at Buckingham Palace today and said he would use the $200,000 award to fight hunger and promote evangelism.

title: Rights Group Says Morocco Tortures Political Prisoners
description: Moroccan authorities are holding political prisoners incommunicado for months, even years, and torturing many of them, the human-rights group Amnesty International said today.

title: ARABS AND ISRAELIS-ALL VICTIMS OF EUROPE
description: The real calamity is that both sides are unable to look each other in the eyes, to look into each other's souls. The leaders of Israel and Egypt have signed a peace agreement; the Israeli and Egyptian peoples have not yet arrived at a cordial mutual understanding. Here, perhaps, is the key to the depth of the tragedy.

title: AIDES URGING MORE CONTACT WITH 'REAL PEOPLE'
description: Hours after President Reagan sat in shirtsleeves on a bale of hay last Friday and took questions from a group of Pennsylvania dairy farmers, White House officials began assessing the sometimes heated give-and-take.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amarex Inc. said it had sold producing oil and gas properties in the Anadarko Basin of Oklahoma and Texas to Damson Oil Corp. for $24.9 million, and reached a tentative agreement to sell other producing properties to Damson for about $15.2 million.

title: Funds' Merger Set
description: Directors of Scudder Duo-Vest Inc. and Scudder Special Fund have approved a proposed merger of the two funds. The merger will be taxfree for the shareholders of both funds. Shareholders of Scudder Duo-Vest, a dual-purpose fund offering both capital and income-share stock, met yesterday to approve the change of the fund's name to Scudder Capital Growth Fund which will be the new fund's name if the merger is approved by stockholders of both funds at meetings in September.

title: Suit Over Ali Bout
description: The dream of a pro football player to start a career in boxing by fighting Muhummad Ali in an exhibition has become the subject of a lawsuit in Denver. Lyle Alzado, the defensive lineman recently traded by Cleveland to Oakland, was playing for the Denver Broncos when he pledged his life savings to finance his three-round bout with Ali in 1979.

title: MRS. GANDHI FACING CHALLENGES IN STATE VOTING
description: Millions of Indians will vote Wednesday to chose four state legislatures in what is widely regarded as the most important political test for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi since she returned to power in 1980.

title: Advertising; A Wine That Pops Its Cork
description: Last night marked the debut on the home screens in the New York area of Champs D'ore, a new French sparkling white wine that has a cork cork (as opposed to a plastic cork) that pops like champagne.

title: Protest Over Aid Ends at Wesleyan
description: A six-and-a-half day sit-in by students seeking the reinstatement of a Wesleyan University policy of admitting students without considering ability to pay ended yesterday with no change in the school's new aid plan.

title: SHIPS SAID TO MOVE TO NEW FORMATION
description: Britain's battle fleet has begun to move into assault formation in the South Atlantic for a possible attack on the Argentine-held Falkland Islands, military sources reported tonight.

title: MORE WOMEN PLAYING ORGANIZED SOCCER
description: On a damp, chilly morning, more reminiscent of fall than spring, the rewards of winning an amateur soccer match may elude the uninitiated. But to the 22 women on the field there was no question.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING DOWN 6.4%
description: Despite signs of recovery in recent months, the nation's housing industry suffered a setback in April as housing starts fell 6.4 percent, to an annual rate of 881,000 units, the lowest level since last November, the Government reported today.

title: Quake Hits Greece
description: A tremor registering 4 the Richter scale shook the area of the Gulf of Corinth today, the Seismological Institute of Athens said. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: GOVERNMENT PREPARES TO PROSECUTE MEN NOT YET REGISTERED FOR DRAFT
description: Lists are being compiled of men who have and have not registered for a military draft, the director of the Selective Service System said today, and the Justice Department will start receiving by early summer the names of men who did not register and are subject to criminal prosecution if they knowingly evaded the law.

title: A CHAMPION INSPIRED BY FAMILY TIES
description: It was a long walk for the gray-haired woman with tears in her eyes. She had left ringside when her son, Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, was knocked out in the 14th round by Alexis Arguello in their lightweight title fight last October, and was heading for what would be an emotional post-fight news conference.

title: Colonial Plan
description: The Colonial Commercial Corporation said it filed a plan of reorganization with the United States Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York. Under the plan, creditors would receive convertible preferred stock representing 80 percent of the company's voting power and three million warrants for common stock purchases.

title: FALKLAND STRIFE SPURS DISCUSSION OF ARGENTINE POLITICAL FUTURE
description: Argentina's military leadership and its semi-legal and badly divided political parties are engaged in discussions over the political configuration of Argentina after the Falkland dispute ends in one way or another.

title: A DEALER IN BONDS DEFAULTS ON DEBT
description: A big dealer in Government bonds and notes, Drysdale Government Securities, informed creditors yesterday that it was unable to meet more than $160 million in interest payments, creating considerable concern throughout the financial community.

title: Athletic Head Resigns
description: Dave Strack, the University of Arizona athletic director, has submitted his resignation, effective July 1.

title: Travelers Purchase
description: The Travelers Corporation, a major insurance and financial services concern, has announced an agreement in principle to acquire the Securities Settlement Corporation, the securities clearing unit of Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden, for $2.5 million in cash. Securities Settlement is a wholesale firm, dealing with 50 brokerage firms with 650 brokers who deal with the public. It settles customer transactions, maintains customer accounts and processes customer orders for its correspondent firms.

title: CHOICE WESTERN OYSTER MAKES A COMEBACK
description: The small, succulent Olympia oyster may be on the brink of a modest comeback after 55 years of nearextinction, according to the 104-year-old company that has kept it going.

title: Drilling for Pay Cut
description: Peter Pocklington, owner of the Edmonton Drillers, conferred in New York yesterday with Commissioner Phil Woosnam of the North American Soccer League on Pocklington's plan to dissolve the franchise unless his players accept a 50 percent cut in salaries. Pocklington, who also owns the Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League, said that dwindling attendance and back rent owed to the City of Edmonton for use of Clarke Stadium had forced him to seek a cutback in his payroll for the rest of this season.

title: TAX ON TRANSPORT KILLED IN CABINET
description: The Reagan Administration decided today to reject the idea of a new transportation tax put forward by Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis. The proposal was not ruled out, however, for the fiscal year 1984.

title: GROUND EFFECTS CAR DEFENDED
description: Jim Hall, who introduced the first car using ground-effects technology a decade ago and dominated Indianapolis-type racing in 1980 with the first fully equipped ground-effects machine, said today that his concept was probably here to stay.

title: Ownership of the Falklands: Years; of Fruitless Negotiations
description: 1965 - The United Nations General Assembly approves a resolution urging Britain and Argentina to negotiate a peaceful solution to their longstanding dispute on sovereignty over the Falkland Islands. 1969 - Argentina offers to discuss lifting a ban on direct communications between the mainland and the Falklands. 1970 - Talks open in London between Argentina and Britain, including Falkland Islands delegates. 1971 - Britain and Argentina agree on air and sea communications, postal services, educational and medical facilities for Falkland Islanders in Buenos Aires, and customs measures. 1974 - Britain and Argentina agree to allow trade between Argentina and the islands and to allow an Argentine state company to supply the islanders with petroleum products. 1977 to 1980 - Britain and Argentina hold talks in London, New York, Brazil and Peru. Francis Pym February 1981 - Further talks are held in New York. Argentina rejects a British proposal for a freeze on sovereignty talks while both countries cooperate in economic development of the Falklands. Feb. 26-27, 1982 - Britain and Argentina talk in New York.

title: Settlement Ends Nassau Bias Suit
description: Nassau County agreed yesterday to hire, assign and promote correction officers at the county jail in ways that did not discriminate against women either as officers or applicants for such jobs.

title: A VOLUNTEER OMBUDSMAN TELLS HIS UNHAPPY STORY
description: The story of Arthur E. Imperatore is one of a capital romance gone sour. He came to Washington to serve as the kind of free-enterprise trouble-shooter the White House said big government needed, but left just six months later, disillusioned and angry.

title: Bank Board Shift
description: Andrew DiPrete has resigned from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board for personal reasons, a spokesman for the agency said today. Mr. DiPrete, a 53-year-old Republican lawyer from Rhode Island, will leave the three-member bank board, which regulates savings and loans associations, June 30, a year before his term expires.

title: Herndon Ties Homer Record
description: The Tigers' Larry Herndon, who had a home run in his last time at bat Sunday, hit homers in his first three plate appearances tonight to tie a major league record shared by 13 other players.

title: Jean M. Coon, 52, Attorney
description: For State Education Dept.

title: U.N. PRESSES NEED TO SAVE GLOBAL RESOURCES
description: The second United Nations Conference on the Global Environment ended today with a call for increased national and international efforts to preserve the earth's basic resources.

title: UNBEATEN STREAK AT 13
description: Unbeaten Lamarr Hoyt posted his eighth victory, the most in the major leagues, with a five-hitter and Greg Luzinski drove in four runs tonight as the Chicago White Sox routed the Texas Rangers, 10-2.

title: Bridge: The Grand National Zonal To Be Held June 12 and 13
description: The zonal stage of the Grand National Team Championship will be played here June 12 and 13 to decide which of three teams will advance to the national quarterfinals in Albuquerque, N.M., in July. The New York-Long Island titlists, to be determined this weekend, will battle the New England winners and the champions of New Jersey-Westchester County.

title: Mann Given $500 Fine For Hockey Assault
description: Jimmy Mann of the Winnipeg Jets was fined $500 by a Manitoba provincial court judge today after he entered a guilty plea to a charge of assault causing bodily harm to another player in a National Hockey League game.

title: Hazel H. Hallinan, 91, Journalist and Activist
description: Hazel Hunkins Hallinan, an activist for women's equality since 1917, died Monday at her home in London. She was 91 years old and had been living in London since going there as a newspaper correspondent in 1920.

title: Air Florida Jet
description: Air Florida Inc. said today that it had taken delivery of a new Boeing 737-200 aircraft valued at $13.1 million. The Chemical New York Corproation and the First Naitonal Bank of Dallas provided the financing.

title: THEATER: SAN FRANCISCO MIME TROUPE
description: COLLECTIVELY, the San Francisco Mime Troupe has disproved the George S. Kaufman dictum that satire is what closes on Saturday night. With the Mime Troupe, satire has been running for 23 years. One secret of the company's longevity is its mobility; using a portable stage, it travels from California to Europe and performs with equal adaptability on the street or in theaters.

title: Conoco Gas Well
description: Conoco Inc. yesterday announced a gas discovery in Oklahoma's Washita County. The well, with an open flow rate of about 6.5 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, was drilled 19,000 feet deep in the lower Morrow sand formation. Conoco has a 27 percent interest in the well; 12 other companies own the rest.

title: SUFFOLK WILL INVESTIGATE SUBMISSION OF LILCO PLAN
description: The Suffolk County Legislature voted unanimously today to investigate whether the Long Island Lighting Company broke any laws in submitting to the state an emergency response plan for its Shoreham nuclear plant without the county's permission.

title: No Headline
description: Leon Hess, known as the quiet man of the oil industry, stepped down as chief executive officer yesterday of the Amerada Hess Corporation, which he built into the nation's 19th-largest oil company. Mr. Hess continues as chairman.

title: The Baseball Economy
description: Some major league clubs are in danger of going out of business unless the ''disparity of income'' among teams is adjusted, according to Ballard Smith, president of the San Diego Padres. Smith told sports editors in San Diego: ''I know of 15 major league clubs that have serious economic problems, or would have if they didn't have ownership pumping in the dollars.''

title: Theose E. Tillinghast, Led Aviation Concern
description: Theose E. Tillinghast, a former president of the United Aircraft Service Corporation, died Sunday in a nursing home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: VENEZUELA WANTS LAND TALKS WITH GUYANA
description: Venezuela will seek talks with Guyana on the two nations' territorial dispute when a 12-year moratorium on the issue expires next month, Venezuela's Ambassador to the United States said today.

title: BRITAIN IS REBUFFED BY COMMON MARKET
description: Britain's nine Common Market partners refused today for the first time to allow a member to invoke the organization's traditional veto, on a move by Britain to block farm price increases.

title: A FEW EASY METHODS FOR FREEZING THAT BOUNTIFUL HARVEST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Farrar Capon is an Episcopal priest, author and food writer whose latest book is ''Between Noon and Three'' (Harper & Row). By ROBERT FARRAR CAPON

title: K Mart Net Down by 82.9%
description: The K Mart Corporation's earnings fell 82.9 percent, to $5.9 million, in the first quarter ended April 28 from $34.6 million in the comparable 1981 period, the company reported today.

title: Stocks Retreat; Dow Off 4.47
description: The stock market registered a moderate decline yesterday in active trading with bank and transportation issues posting the largest losses.

title: Hewlett Net Up
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported that earnings for its second fiscal quarter rose 34.3 percent on a 22.3 percent gain in revenues. Hewlett-Packard, a supplier of computers and electronic instruments, said earnings for the three months ending April 30 were $94 million, or 76 cents a share, up from $70 million, or 57 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose to $1.06 billion from $867 million a year earlier.

title: George Washington Wins in P.S.A.L. Track
description: George Washington High School scored 94 points on its home field yesterday to win the Public Schools Athletic League's Manhattan borough outdoor track and field championship. Chelsea finished second with 37 points, and Music and Art was third with 33.

title: Mental Patient Takes Hostages
description: An outpatient at the Connecticut Mental Health Center in New Haven drew a gun on his therapist and four patients in a therapy group last night and took them hostage.

title: BOUND FOR VICTORY
description: One of the most unusual aspects of the Argentine political process is kidnapping. The custom evolved several years ago in response to the soaring cost of 30-second political spots on television.

title: KOCH PICKS 6 NOMINEES FOR COURTS
description: Mayor Koch has nominated six persons, including his criminaljustice coordinator, to fill vacancies in the Criminal and Family Courts.

title: Allright Agrees To Takeover Bid
description: Allright Auto Parks Inc. of Houston, a major parking lot owner, said it reached a definitive agreement to be acquired by Deanlake Investments Ltd., a group of Hong Kong investors, for $101.6 million.

title: HARVARD OFFERS TOP SOCIOLOGY POSTS TO 3 OUTSIDERS
description: Harvard University has offered tenured professorships to three prominent sociologists in an unusual move aimed at rebuilding its sociology department.

title: INCOME SPENDING UP IN APRIL
description: Personal income continued its modest advance this year with a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in April, while personal spending increased by five-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: U.S. Warns Hospitals On Care of Handicapped
description: The Federal Government warned today that hospitals could lose Federal financial support if they denied care to retarded and other handicapped infants.

title: 'THE VULTURE,' POSTWAR ISRAELIS
description: IN a new Israeli-made film, ''The Vulture,'' the postwar letdown of the battle-weary country is depicted in a harsh but brutally revealing way through the character of an alienated Israeli lieutenant who becomes something of a hustler after the 1973 war. The movie, directed by Yaky Yosha, was shown in a censored version in Israel, but is being presented in New York in its entirety, according to its American distributor, New Yorker Films.

title: CURRAN INITIATES HIS FORMAL BID TO BE GOVERNOR
description: Paul J. Curran, a former Federal and state prosecutor, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for the Republican gubernatorial nomination. He became the fourth Republican contender.

title: LAWS THAT DATE FROM REPEAL STILL LIMIT WINE SALES
description: ACOLD spring rain was beating down on the sidewalks of Greenwich Village and the lights of the restaurant beckoned warmly. Inside, arrayed along a mahogany bar dimly lighted by Tiffany lamps, were six bottles of fine Bordeaux. A tasting was under way. The voices were hushed and the participants occasionally glanced at the door, as if in fear of intruders.

title: Ad Pages Down 1.4%
description: For the first time this year, ad pages of member magazines in the Publishers Information Bureau dipped in March over the comparable month last year. The figure was 11,434, a 1.4 percent drop, according to the P.I.B., a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers Association. Revenues looked better, up 5 percent, to $320 million.

title: POLISH CIVIC GROUP SEES BLEAK FUTURE
description: A report issued by a group of a hundred journalists and scholars says martial law has further deepened divisions in Poland and the chances for overcoming the crisis are bleak.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT wasn't until the following morning that Lisa Tannenbaum realized she was in big trouble. Naturally, the night before, on her way back from work, she'd thought absolutely nothing of throwing away her copy of The New York Times as she left the N train at the 63d Drive station in Rego Park.

title: SENATE OVERTURNS RULE ON USED CARS
description: The Senate voted today, 69 to 27, to overturn a Federal Trade Commission rule requiring used car dealers to warn customers about known defects in each vehicle they sell.

title: REACTOR RESTART OPPOSED, 2-1
description: Residents of three counties near the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant voted more than 2-to-1 today against putting the plant's undamaged reactor back into service.

title: RAJSICH EXCELS
description: Gary Rajsich, the Mets' rookie right-fielder, hit his first home run in the major leagues last night, a drive over the right-field wall with two runners on base in the fifth inning. Minutes earlier, Rajsich made a diving catch of Alex Trevino's drive near the line.

title: SUIT ASKS CHILDREN'S TV RULE
description: Action for Children's Television filed suit today against the Federal Communications Commission in an attempt to force the agency to require stations to offer programs for children.

title: One of the Founders Resigns at Coachmen
description: In 1964, three brothers founded Coachmen Industries of Middlebury, Ind., which now is No.2 to Fleetwood in the recreational-vehicles industry. Yesterday, Keith D. Corson, 46, resigned as president for personal reasons, leaving only Thomas H. Corson, chairman and chief executive, to carry on the family name in management.

title: THE KREMLIN'S DEBT TO BILLY GRAHAM
description: To the Editor:

title: M.T.A. TO BUY SUBWAY CARS FROM COMPANY IN MONTREAL
description: With the aid of a loan from Canada, New York will purchase 825 subway cars from a Canadian manufacturer for $662 million, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: U.S. JUDGE IS ASKED TO UPHOLD HAITIANS' DETENTION
description: The Justice Department ended its defense of United States immigration policy in court here today by imploring the presiding Federal district judge to help the Reagan Administration regain control of the nation's borders.

title: TAX-ENFORCEMENT BILL GETS SUPPORT
description: The Reagan Administration and two former Internal Revenue Service comissioners endorsed a multipronged tax-enforcement bill today that also received considerable support, and some criticism, from business and financial community spokesmen.

title: Squatters Occupy Capitol In San Juan After Clash
description: About 250 squatters occupied the Puerto Rican Capitol today and bedded down for the night on mattresses lining the rotunda after the police evicted them from a squatters' village on government land.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 19, 1982
description: International Leonid I. Brezhnev welcomed President Reagan's readiness to resume talks on strategic nuclear arms, but said the American arms proposals were one-sided and prejudicial to Soviet security. The Soviet leader countered with the suggestion that the two sides freeze the deployment of their nuclear arsenals as soon as the negotiations begin. He said a freeze now would prevent either side from taking steps that ''would upset the strategic situation.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) President Reagan rejected Mr. Brezhnev's proposal for an American-Soviet freeze on strategic weapons, but expressed optimism that the Soviet leader had opened the way for arms control talks. ''I think we'll be meeting,'' he said. (A1:5.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOHO VERTICAL

title: Theater Club Will Give Spring Benefit Monday
description: The Manhattan Theater Club will give its 10th spring benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Monday, featuring entertainers who have appeared at the club.

title: ARGENTINE SAY BRITAIN HARDENS ATTITUDE IN TALKS
description: Argentine officials said today that Britain had become tougher in the United Nations talks. ''The British attitude gets tougher each time,'' Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez said as he left the Foreign Ministry today to met with the ruling three-man junta at air force headquarters.

title: East/West Network Takes Over Clipper
description: East/West Network, which already publishes magazines for travelers on nine airlines as well as on Amtrak, will take over the publishing of Clipper, the in-flight magazine of Pan American World Airways with its July issue.

title: A.T. & T. UPGRADES OFFICE SWITCHBOARD
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday introduced several enhancements to its line of office switchboards, a key product area in which it has been steadily losing market share to innovative competitors.

title: FOLK-ROCK:RICHARD THOMPSON'S IDIOM TRANSCENDS FASHION
description: Richard Thompson has the misfortune of being elegantly stylish at what he does but of doing it when his idiom is out of fashion in the marketplace. Fortunately, his kind of music, British-American folkrock, is so basic in its appeal that it may transcend fashion altogether, outlasting the current fad for punk and corporate rock. The audience Monday night at the Bottom Line was no mere reunion of nostalgists; its enthusiasm seemed a clear recognition of Mr. Thompson's importance.

title: BREZHNEV AFFIRMS READINESS TO TALK ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev voiced readiness today for talks on strategic nuclear arms but said President Reagan's plan for cuts was one-sided and prejudicial to Moscow's security. The Soviet leader countered with a proposal for a nuclear freeze as soon as the arms talks begin.

title: Bush, Back from China, Says Rift on Taiwan Can Be Healed
description: Vice President Bush, speaking about his recent talks with Chinese leaders, said today that he was convinced differences between the two countries over United States arms supplies to Taiwan could be resolved.

title: Officers Commandeer Taxi to Catch Youths
description: Three Transit Authority officers, to the cheers of dozens of spectators, commandeered a taxicab yesterday to catch the suspected attackers of a retired businessman, the police said.

title: Socal Lifts Gasoline Price
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it had raised wholesale prices on all grades of gasoline by 1 cent a gallon on May 8.

title: OPEC'S MARKET PANEL APPLAUDS OUTPUT LIMITS
description: OPEC's new market monitoring committee, at a meeting here today, applauded the success of a twomonth-old attempt to limit oil production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Renewing their commitment to the effort, representatives asserted that it had led to today's firmer oil market.

title: Police Car Kills Brooklyn Man, 18
description: A young man running across a highway in Brooklyn was struck and killed by a police car chasing a speeder, the police said. The two officers in the patrol car were slightly injured by flying glass when the man's body was hurled into the windshield of the speeding patrol car on the Belt Parkway near 83d Street at about 11:45 P.M. Monday.

title: A.M.C.'s Jeep Employees Accept New Contract
description: United Automobile Workers at the American Motors Corporation's Jeep plant have voted to accept a new contract, the union said today.

title: India Sees No Progress; In Talks With China
description: India reported little progress today in its talks with China on their 20-year-old frontier dispute. ''Nothing has happened to change our assessment that no breakthrough will be possible at these talks,'' an Indian Government spokesman said.

title: FOR TEEN-AGERS, A PLAY WITH A MESSAGE
description: ELLIE is 14 years old and pregnant. She refused to get an abortion, and now, just a few weeks before delivery, she is having second thoughts about becoming a mother at so early an age.

title: CUT FROM U.S. BENEFITS, DISABLED SEEK WELFARE
description: The first people cut off from Social Security disability benefits in New York State are showing up three or four months later on home relief, a welfare program paid for only by the state and local communities.

title: Zero Mexican Growth Seen
description: Jesus Silva Herzog, Mexico's Finance Minister, forecast today that Mexico's economy will register zero growth over the next 12 months as a result of austerity measures adopted after the recent sharp devaluation of the peso.

title: Judge Orders N.C.A.A.  To Open Its Records
description: In a move that an official says could hamper the enforcement of guidelines for college athletics, a judge in Kansas has ordered the National Collegiate Athletic Association to make its records available to a Birmingham newspaper.

title: 'EIJANAIKA,' MID-19TH-CENTURY JAPAN
description: SHOHEI IMAMURA'S ''Eijanaika,'' opening today at the Film Forum 1, is a handsome, kaleidoscopic Japanese historical film about the years (1866-67) immediately preceding the restoration of the imperial Meiji family, which marked the the triumph of the recently awakened, pro-Western movement in Japan.

title: IN FIRST ADDRESS IN SENATE, BRADY WARNS ON DEFICIT
description: The new Republican Senator from New Jersey, Nicholas F. Brady, made his maiden speech on the floor of the Senate this morning. He warned that the Government needed to act ''strongly, consistently and fairly quickly'' to reassure the private economy.

title: NEW LEADER BIDS TO REVITALIZE CHICAGO DEMOCRATS
description: The Cook County Democratic organization, perhaps the strongest of the remaining old-line urban political machines but badly divided in recent years, is striving to heal itself.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY: WHAT MIGHT BE DONE
description: Despite considerable debate about the future solvency of the Social Security system and its role in balancing the Federal budget, there is little prospect of passage of any significant Social Security legislation until after the Nov. 2 Congressional elections.

title: Goodrich Award
description: The first financial award stemming from the Iranian hostage crisis has been made to an American concern, a settlement of $182,249.87 to the B.F. Goodrich Company, the United States-Iran Claims Tribunal said.

title: War of Words At Big Airlines
description: A war of words has erupted between Eastern Airlines and Pan American World Airways over Eastern's acquisition of most of Braniff International's Latin American routes.

title: BRIEFING
description: Nomination Roadblock

title: Military Analysis
description: Despite the British task force's numerical inferiority in men and aircraft, senior defense sources are confident that the forces can establish beachheads on East Falkland Island and battle the Argentine garrison on even terms.

title: NBC'S AFFILIATES OPTIMISTIC ON NETWORK'S FUTURE
description: At the end of a television season in which NBC-TV dug itself even deeper into its perennial third place in popularity among the three networks, the mood of the owners and managers of NBC's 215 affiliate stations is surprisingly optimistic.

title: SURVEY FINDS WORK RATED HIGH IN U.S.
description: Compared with Western Europeans and the Japanese, Americans take more pride in their work, are more willing to fight for their country and are more likely to believe in God, life after death and the Ten Commandments, according to a survey sponsored by the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Max Factor Expands Role Of Executive
description: Linda Wachner, 36 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Max Factor & Company, a unit of Norton Simon Inc.

title: FROM ADOPT-A-HORSE TO SLAUGHTER A HORSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvester Sets Plant Closing
description: The International Harvester Company, the financially pressed manufacturer of trucks and tractors, announced today that it planned to close its components plant here.

title: COMIC OPERA: HERBERT'S 'ENCHANTRESS'
description: VICTOR HERBERT'S ''The Enchantress,'' a two-act comic opera that opened in 1911 and has collected dust ever since, returned to the stage recently in a revival by the Bel Canto Opera. With a new book incorporating several discarded numbers and borrowings from other Herbert scores, the piece was performed six times during the last two weekends at the Robert F. Wagner Junior High School.

title: NEW DIETING THEORY'S DELICATE BALANCE
description: AS warm spring weather forces millions of Americans to shed their concealing winter raiment, the advertisements for diet plans and formulas, weight-control programs, spas and health clubs seem to multiply like crabgrass in the yard. There's not much time to get rid of the winter's accumulation of body flab before donning T-shirts, shorts and bathing suits.

title: Beyond the Freeze
description: Never mind the slogans from Moscow. As long as Americans and Europeans are parading in the streets for a nuclear arms freeze, the Russians will package ice and call it ice cream; they have a new freeze flavor every month. The newest, in response to President Reagan's bid for arms control talks this year, is a promising ''Yes, but ...''

title: CONCERT: CLEVELANDERS IN A BEETHOVEN EVENING
description: AFTER a decade as the Cleveland Orchestra's music director, Lorin Maazel is leaving to become general manager and artistic director of the Vienna State Opera. This week's concerts by the orchestra in New York, therefore, represent Mr. Maazel's final appearances here as commander of the great ensemble that he inherited after the death of George Szell, who had led the Cleveland for 24 years. Ten years is a long time in anyone's life, but particularly in an artist's career such a span of time often reveals marked changes in maturity and depth.

title: Real Estate; The Deal That Won An Award
description: IN July 1980 the Actors Equity Association was hard-pressed for cash. A referendum asking members for a dues increase failed, and the union was thrown into a serious financial situation.

title: Economic Scene; Support Grows For Policy Shift
description: A consensus is emerging in Congress and the financial community - a c onsensus that has almost but not quite captured the White House - t hat a new mix of fiscal and monetary policies is needed if interest r ates are to be brought down and a sustainable recovery is to be m ade. That new mix would involve a shift from loose fiscal/tight m oney policies to tighter fiscal/easier money policies.

title: Politics by Proxy
description: There's no mystery about one aspect of the Republican Party television ads containing actors who look like former President Carter and House Speaker O'Neill. Of course the Republicans would like to keep on running against Jimmy Carter.

title: NATO COMMUNIQUE ON LUXEMBOURG TALKS
description: Following are excerpts from the communique issued today at the end of the NATO foreign ministers meeting:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In some editions yesterday a review of the New York Choral Society misidentified the singer of the ''Agnus Dei'' in Bach's B minor Mass. She was the mezzo Shirley Close.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Union has invariably come out in favor of renewing talks on strategic arms with the object of working out an understanding without delay and without any strings attached.'' - Leonid I. Brezhnev. (A8:2.)

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Soldier Girls, and Strength

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the questions I am often asked is why I insist on using French names for recipes. It is because the French name is concise: it says in a word or two what would take almost a sentence in English. I think the recipe outlined here serves as a good explanation.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT ROYALS
description: The Yankees, who have carefully concealed the speed they supposedly converted to last winter, displayed some of it tonight as they stole four times and defeated the Kansas City Royals, 6-2. Ron Guidry also contributed some speed in gaining his sixth victory against one defeat.

title: Groucho Marx's Ashes Taken
description: An urn containing the ashes of Groucho Marx was stolen last Wednesday from a sealed crypt at Eden Memorial Park in Mission Hills, the police said today. It was left without explanation that night at the office of Mount Sinai Memorial Park in Glendale, 20 miles away.

title: HOME FREEZER: THE REWARDS OF USING IT WELL
description: WHAT do you find when you look in your freezer? Ice cubes? A hamburger patty with slightly torn wrappings, showing a touch of freezer burn? A half-used package of frozen peas? A carton, with two scoops of ice cream, covered with ice crystals? A can of orange juice of uncertain age?

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MAHOPAC STUDENTS, 150 STRONG, CLAIM THE STAGE AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: How do you get to Carnegie Hall? Practice, says the old joke. Take the yellow school bus, says a group of 150 students from Mahopac, N.Y., who did both yesterday. They brought their violins and trumpets and young voices to the big stage on West 57th Street and, after a rehearsal, performed their annual spring concert - 50 miles from home this time.

title: 3 Ex-Bank Officers Cleared by Court
description: New York State's highest court yesterday reversed the convictions of three former officers of the defunct American Bank and Trust Company who had been accused of misappropriating bank funds to aid an Argentine financier, David Graiver.

title: TWO PILOTS AND A CONTROLLER FAULTED IN JERSEY AIR CRASH
description: The National Transportation Safety Board ruled today that the collision of a helicopter and a small plane near Giants Stadium in New Jersey last fall was the fault of the pilots and of an air traffic controller who was ''preoccupied with a nonessential administrative phone call.''

title: Market Place; Assaying Credit Ratings
description: Investors have been drawn to the credit markets by high interest rates and by the relative weakness in other investments. But if the yields in these markets are high, so are the potential risks. For one hallmark of this recession has been the financial squeeze that has gripped corporations and governments alike, the very organizations that are the borrowers in the credit markets.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: It's Nisqually Capri

title: REV. MOON IS CONVICTED OF INCOME-TAX FRAUD
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, founder and leader of the Unification Church, was convicted in Manhattan yesterday of conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government and filing false income-tax returns.

title: CONTROVERSAL LEADER
description: When Sun Myung Moon was 16 years old, he says in his official biography, Jesus appeared before him on a mountaintop in Korea and told him he had been chosen to ''complete My still uncompleted mission.''

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 16.50 16.50 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.66 14.68 18.75 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.25 12.30 16.54 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.25 12.30 15.47 7-YR. TREAS NOTES 13.77 13.70 14.16 30-YR TREAS. BONDS 13.31 13.27 13.48 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.88 15.61 15.12 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.14 13.04 11.46 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.710 CERTIFICATES *Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HIGH MORALE ASCRIBED TO ARGENTINE SOLDIERS
description: The commander of Argentine troops on the Falkland Islands said today that British attacks so far had caused only light damage and that morale was high as his men awaited an expected British invasion.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Delaney, an outstanding running back for the Kansas City Chiefs, will undergo surgery in Baltimore today to repair a detached retina in his right eye. He is expected to recover in time to start the 1982 season. ... The Tulsa Roughnecks have traded Joe Morrone, 1981 rookie of the year in the North American Soccer League, to the San Jose Earthquakes. ... Coach Stan Albeck of the San Antonio Spurs, seeking a multiyear contract to replace the one that expires May 31, is expected to get an offer from the Chicago Bulls.

title: EARLY ARMS TALKS PREDICTED BY HAIG
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said here today that Leonid I. Brezhnev's speech seemed to clear the way for early talks on strategic nuclear arms, but he rejected the Soviet leader's proposal for a freeze in deployment.

title: EFFICENCY: A PILOT AT DECONTROLS
description: Deregulation, in fundamental ways, is causing beneficial change in the airline industry, notwithstanding the industry's recent financial problems and the unfortunate failure of Braniff Airways.

title: The Pope Is 62
description: It was the 62d birthday of Pope John Paul II, but there was no special celebration yesterday as the Pope put in what Vatican officials described as a normal day's work.

title: Courts on Trial; Last of four articles on efforts to restrain the Federal judiciary.
description: The nation's state courts, increasingly frustrated with the restrictive rulings of the United States Supreme Court, are emerging from its shadow and fashioning a distinctive body of civil liberties protections. Focusing on their own, long-neglected constitutions, and emboldened by the rhetoric of the ''new federalism,'' state high courts are issuing rulings that go considerably beyond current interpretations by the United States Supreme Court.

title: LIMITS OF CAT SCANS CITED BY PHYSICIAN
description: Studies done by more than 10 groups of investigators around the world show that X-rays of the brain taken by CAT scanners cannot be used to determine whether a person is suffering from schizophrenia, according to a report delivered yesterday at the 135th annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association in Toronto.

title: NOW'S FUNDS SOAR SUGGESTING EXTENT OF WOMEN'S POWER
description: The National Organization for Women, which is in the last six weeks of its long-shot effort to get the proposed Federal equal rights amendment ratified, has raised more money for its ratification campaign this year than the most successful - and conservative - political action committees.

title: Texas Air Cautioned
description: Texas International Airlines Inc. could be jeopardized should debt-ridden Continental Air Lines Inc. in which the Texas Air Corporation owns a 51 percent interest, go bankrupt, the auditors for the carrier's holding company said in the company's annual report released yesterday.

title: IRAQ ATTACKS IRANIAN POSITIONS NEAR PORT, THEN WITHDRAWS
description: Iraqi troops attacked Iranian forces that are threatening the Iraqi hold on the oil port of Khurramshahr today. Iran said its troops had smashed the Iraqi move, and Iraq conceded that its forces had withdrawn to their original positions.

title: Standard-Coosa In Takeover Deal
description: The Standard-Coosa-Thatcher Company, a textile manufacturer in Chatanooga, Tenn., said it had entered into a definitive agreement under which the company will be acquired by a group of the company's executives in conjunction with Wolsey & Company, a New York investment company, for a total of about $28 million, or $53 a share.

title: DANCE: PAUL SANASARO
description: WHEN a choreographer appears to change his style in a highly radical manner, his dances pose all sorts of questions. What is responsible for this drastic shift? What epiphany, what turmoil, what extension into another aspect of the artistic personality occasioned the turn in the road?

title: Weinberger Denounces Idea of Nuclear Freeze
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that a nuclear freeze might tempt the Soviet Union to try nuclear blackmail or even a first strike against the United States.

title: Continental Group
description: The Continental Group Inc. said its Continental Financial Services Company subsidiary had agreed to sell its retail property and casualty unit, the Insurance Management Corporation, to Hilb, Rogal & Hamilton Company, which is owned by Insurance Management's officers, for $17 million in cash.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has named Clifton W. Phillips president of Aeronca Electronics Inc.

title: Braves Top Expos, 9-1
description: Bob Horner went four for four and drove in three runs, and Chris Chambliss batted in two runs during a 13-hit attack that helped the Atlanta Braves defeat the Montreal Expos, 9-1, tonight. The loss was the 11th in the last 15 games for the Expos.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 20, 1982; Companies
description: Chase Manhattan, in a reversal, agreed to accept full responsibility for some $270 million in overdue interest payments that it was unable to collect from Drysdale Government Securities. The move allayed fears that several Wall Street houses might collapse. (Page A1.) Drysdale was immersed in the risky practice of trading in shortterm loans backed by Treasury securities. (D1.)

title: Unions Assert 700,000 Jobs May Be Lost in Next 2 Years
description: A.F.L.-C.I.O. leaders released a study Tuesday blaming President Reagan's economic program for the current recession and warning that it would cost 700,000 jobs by the end of the fiscal year 1983.

title: SENATE WON'T CUT MILITARY SPENDING
description: The Senate tonight rejected a proposal to reduce military spending by $13.9 billion over the next three years from the level endorsed by President Reagan and the Senate Budget Committee.

title: Zimbabwe Leader, in London, Confers With Mrs. Thatcher
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today on his first official visit to Britain since the British colony of Rhodesia gained independence and became the nation of Zimbabwe two years ago.

title: ASEA'S NEW CHIEF PLANS PUSH IN U.S.
description: The robots are coming, and the industrial giants are scrambling to get a piece of the market now dominated by Unimation and Cincinnati Milacron. United Technologies, General Motors, Westinghouse, General Electric, I.B.M. and Bendix all are in the business or have plans to get in.

title: 6 Held Hostage For 15 Hours
description: A 30-year-old New Haven man was placed under psychiatric observation this morning after surrendering to the police and releasing unharmed six hostages he had held at gunpoint for nearly 15 hours in the Connecticut Mental Health Center, the police said.

title: BRITAIN'S SPECIAL BOAT SQUAD: A DIRTY BUNCH
description: The Royal Marines who mounted the recent raid on Pebble Island in the Falkland Islands were almost certainly commandos from Britain's Special Boat Squadron.

title: SPATIAL REASONING TIED TO HORMONES
description: Boys who have a severe deficiency of male hormones in the years of puberty grow up to have less ability in spatial reasoning than others who had normal hormone levels, according to a study in Thursday's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: SCHOOL TRIP TO 'VILLAGE' BARRED
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is O.K. So is Rockefeller Center. But Greenwich Village isn't. Or so ruled the school board in West Springfield, Mass.

title: SINGAPORE PLANS TO REVIVE STUDY OF CONFUCIANISM
description: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, disturbed by what it sees as a falling away from certain ancient moral values that are thought to be capable of protecting this modern city-state, has decided to revive the study of Confucianism.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS JAMES BAKER
description: President Reagan has sharply reprimanded a conservative fund-raiser in Texas for seeking the ouster of James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON SAFETY OF COAST NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has received new information that raises questions about whether the San Onofre 1 nuclear power plant near San Clemente, Calif., can operate safely, according to agency documents and officials.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Pacific Southwest Air
description: PSA Inc.'s subsidiary, Pacific Southwest Airlines, will add more than 30 daily flights to its schedule in June, Paul C. Barkley, president, said after the annual meeting.

title: JUDGE REBUKES HINCKLEY WITNESS OVER CAT SCAN
description: A defense psychiatrist was lectured by an irate judge today for balking at undergoing cross-examination on his opinion that John W. Hinckley Jr. was insane when he shot President Reagan.

title: REAGAN TO NOMINATE F.C.C. AIDE TO AGENCY
description: President Reagan announced in Washington yesterday that he would nominate Stephen A. Sharp, general counsel for the Federal Communications Commission, to a seven-year term on the F.C.C. Mr. Sharp, 34, would succeed Abbott Washburn, a fellow Republican, whose term expires June 30.

title: Diplomat Resigns After Drug Charge
description: The Dominican Republic has forced an official in its United Nations Mission to resign and has waived his diplomatic immunity following accusations by United States authorities that he conspired to smuggle heroin into this country, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: A CAPTURED ARGENTINE
description: One consequence of Argentina's invasion of the Falkland Islands may well prove to be the military regime's undoing, although for reasons unrelated to the invasion.

title: Tigers Win 7th In a Row
description: The Detroit Tigers extended their winning streak to seven games with a 6-3 triumph tonight over the Oakland A's.

title: McEnroe to Skip Paris
description: The ankle injury that has hindered John McEnroe for almost three months and caused him to withdraw from this week's Italian Open will likely also keep him out of the French Open, the first of the season's Grand Slam events. Philippe Chatrier, the president of the French Tennis Federation, said yesterday that McEnroe's father told him by telephone Tuesday night that the ''chances were nine out of 10'' his son will miss the French Open, which begins next week.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN FAVORS A CLUSTER OF 100 MX MISSILES
description: President Reagan has designated a cluster plan as the preferred method for basing the MX missiles, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: CLARINET RECITAL: COLOSIMO
description: MURRAY COLOSIMO'S clarinet recital Tuesday afternoon, a part of Town Hall's Dollar Debut series, was a finely schooled, stylistically well-chosen affair. Mr. Colosimo is a Canadian who studied at the Manhattan School of Music, plays often around New York and is completing a doctorate at New York University. He is a fluid technician; in his hands, the instrument, which can sound balky and nasal, assumes its inherent liquidity of tone.

title: 8 CANDIDATES TO MEET WITH PANEL SEEKING A CITY U. CHANCELLOR
description: Eight candidates for the chancellorship of the City University of New York, all of whom had previously been interviewed, have been invited back to meet individually with the search committee this weekend for what is expected to be the final round of interviews, sources close to the search said yesterday.

title: YANKEES SUBDUE ROYALS, 3-2
description: Tommy John, who will observe his 39th birthday Saturday, celebrated his 100th start as a Yankee tonight by pitching one of his typically efficient games. John, the oldest Yankee, received assistance from Rich Gossage in the last two innings but seldom was in serious trouble as the Yankees topped Kansas City, 3-2.

title: Cullen & Taylor Split
description: The two women who founded Cullen & Taylor eight years ago - Karon N. Cullen and Barbara A. Taylor - will be going their separate ways come June 1, each with the accounts they have been handling.

title: FALKLANDS IMPASSE JARRING TO FRENCH ON ISLES IN DISPUTED AREA OFF CANADA
description: No Canadian invasion fleet has been sighted and one is not expected, but the 6,040 inhabitants of these little French-owned islands are at the center of a maritime dispute between France and Canada and are nervously making analogies with the Falklands.

title: A SCOURGE FIT FOR DOCTORS' PROTEST MOVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: PROFITS OFF 17.5% FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: Corporate profits fell 17.5 percent, almost a record, in the first quarter of this year, reflecting the squeeze on companies from declining production and high interest rates, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GUATEMALA LEADER REPORTS AID PLAN
description: The military junta has asked for neither military nor economic aid from the United States, primarily because the country has been offered millions of dollars by evangelical Christians in the United States, according to Gen. Efrain Rios Montt.

title: Topics Clarity, Verity
description: Corrective

title: Report Due On Bell Plan
description: The staff of the Federal Communications Commission will submit its recommendations by June 19 on a proposal by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that it be allowed to establish a new subsidiary to offer advance communications services, an agency official said today.

title: Trial for Ghotbzadeh Is Expected Soon
description: Former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, accused of plotting to overthrow Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic Government, will be put on trial soon, according to the Iranian Prosecutor General.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The time left for negotiations must now be measured in hours.'' - Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations. (A1:6.)

title: A Leader of Solidarity Defiant in Polish Court
description: Jan Rulewski, a Solidarity union leader, defiantly told a judge today that he and 16 other interned activists would continue a hunger strike to protest martial law.

title: Italian Cyclist Wins
description: Silvano Contini of Italy won the sixth leg of the Italian bicycle tour today. Bernard Hinault of France remained the overall leader.

title: Defiant Falklanders In Jail, Letter Reports
description: Some Falkland Islanders who are opposed to the Argentine occupation have been imprisoned, according to a letter from one of the island's residents.

title: KEY EXECUTIVE RESIGNS POSTS AT SUN CHEMICAL
description: Edward E. Barr has resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director of the Sun Chemical Corporation, the company said yesterday.

title: BALLET: AN UNUSUAL PAIR
description: BALLET benefits make strange bedfellows. Who thought we would ever see the day when Merce Cunningham and Roland Petit would be paired on the same program?

title: Former Officer Indicted in Killing
description: A former Roselle Park police officer was indicted on charges of aggravated manslaughter today in the shooting death of a fellow officer at a party on April 17.

title: Pabst Stand on Bid
description: The Pabst Brewing Company indicated that a sweetened takeover bid from C. Schmidt & Sons was not acceptable, but that it would not oppose an all-cash bid of the same value for its stock. Last month, Schmidt raised its bid for Pabst to $209 million, or $20.50 a share in cash plus a $5 subordinated debenture for each common share, from an earlier bid of $183 million, or $20.50 a share in cash. William F. Smith, president and chief executive of Pabst, said, ''We wouldn't oppose a clean-cut and all-cash tender offer for all shares at $25 a share if promptly made.''

title: Arms for Border Inspectors
description: The House passed a bill Tuesday to allow the 100 Agriculture Department border inspectors to carry firearms. The measure now goes to the Senate. It was prompted by increasing attacks on the patrols, which are charged with keeping out infested cattle from Mexico.

title: COURT IN JERSEY SAYS COUNTY JAIL IN OVERCROWDED
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that inmates at the Hudson County Jail were being deprived of their constitutional rights because of severe overcrowding at the 56-yearold facility.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: CRAFT MUSEUM OPENS BRANCH
description: CORPORATE support for cultural facilities has been demonstrated anew by the opening of a branch of the American Craft Museum in the new world headquarters of the International Paper Company at 77 West 45th Street, at the Avenue of the Americas.

title: 500 Face Layoff At Du Pont Plant
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said its 34-year-old Chattanooga plant would idle some obsolete textile nylon-producing equipment and may lay off as many as 500 people within 90 days.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES TRUST FUND, NOT DIRECT AID, FOR CARIBBEAN
description: In an unexpected defeat for President Reagan, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today rejected a request for $350 million in direct aid for the Caribbean.

title: TV: LILY TOMLIN IN COMEDY SPECIAL
description: colored silk blouse and pleated pants, is talking animatedly about Purvis Hawkins, the creamily cool black soul singer she added recently to a long list of memorable characters she began creating for herself more than a decade ago with Ernestine, the purse-lipped, power-loving telephone operator.

title: HERS
description: AS a word, ''upscale'' is nowheresville. You can't even find it in any self-respecting dictionary. As a state of being, a type of person, an advertising philosophy, a style of patio furniture, ''upscale'' already sounds a little wispily nostalgic, like ''new wave'' music. You still hear about the upscaly people from time to time, and sometimes you can spot a few at an upscale get-together, watching each other's home robots pass out cocktail wieners, checking out each other's home computer nooks.

title: '81 SUBWAY CRASH BLAMED, IN PART, ON TRANSIT AGENCY
description: A Federal study has concluded that a subway motorman and the Transit Authority share the blame for a fatal subway accident last year in which the motorman died and 140 passengers were injured.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
TOUCHES OF CEDAR IN CLOSETS
description: THE effectiveness of cedar closets and cedar chests in protecting woolens from moths has long been known to careful housekeepers. If your house was built before 1930, chances are you are lucky enough to have a cedar closet.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Jobs, No Savings

title: COMMANDO WITH A BIBLE
description: One sultry afternoon 20 years ago, in the swampy jungle of northern Borneo, a company of Royal Marine commandos was moving by barge up a winding river, looking for insurgents.

title: BILL LEGALIZES STATE BOND ISSUE
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency illegally issued $105 million in bonds last November because it ignored a law limiting the terms of the bond issue. Today the State Assembly passed a bill to legalize the sale.

title: INDIAN-ESKIMO LIFE IN CHICAGO EXHIBIT
description: CHICAGO Traveling south on Lake Shore Drive, it is easy to overlook the latest addition to the Field Museum of Natural History, a 55-foothigh cedar totem pole.

title: Gunmen Are Sought
description: The police in Montreal are trying to identify two men who pulled guns on Andre Dawson and Jerry White of the Expos on the night of May 6 while the players were shopping in a department store there. Detective Real Mailhot, who is heading the investigation, said he ''presumes'' the two men who drew the guns were members of a special police unit that has been trying to find two black men believed responsible for a series of nighttime robberies.

title: METS DEFEAT SEAVER, 4-2, AS KINGMAN CLOUTS 13th
description: One pitch made the difference last night in the Mets' 4-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium. Tom Seaver, the former Met who has been with the Reds for nearly five seasons, threw the pitch and Dave Kingman, the first baseman, hit it over the center-field fence.

title: U.N. CHIEF APPEALS FOR TIME TO GAIN FALKLAND ACCORD
description: With the Falkland Islands peace talks on the verge of collapse, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar telephoned the leaders of Argentina and Britain today to appeal for more time to reach an accord.

title: LABOR AS LIKUD II
description: Before the Knesset nearly voted no-confidence in Menachem Begin's Government yesterday, the Israel Labor Party briefly seemed close to the political power it had lost to him in 1977. However, power also seemed equally far away. One reason is that many Israelis consider Labor a faded carbon copy of Likud - a Likud II.

title: BARNARD GRADUATES TOLD OF 'COOPERATIVE' ERA
description: Addressing graduates at Barnard College's 90th commencement yesterday, Carol Bellamy, President of the City Council, said there now may be ''an unexpected opportunity for a more cooperative attitude toward the problems of running our lives.''

title: Article 149944 -- No Title
description: New York State completed its annual $3.5 billion spring borrowing program today at a ''very favorable'' interest rate averaging 8.38 percent, Governor Carey announced.

title: Knicks Call Conference
description: The Knicks have called a news conference at noon today to announce their new management team of Hubie Brown as coach and Dave DeBusschere as executive vice president and director of basketball operations. Eddie Donovan, who had been general manager, will be vice president and director of player personnel.

title: FLORAL DESIGNERS SHARE THE SECRETS OF THEIR ART
description: JOHAN WEISZ is inspired by the beauty of flowers and allows their shapes to dictate his work. Rules are abandoned by this internationally known floral designer from Amsterdam, and improvisation takes over.

title: Bradshaw to Lead
description: Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, said he would ''lead the parade'' of players crossing picket lines if the National Football League Players Association should call a strike. ''I think a lot of guys will go in,'' Bradshaw said at a Steeler minicamp.

title: Saudis Plan to Break Off Relations With Zaire
description: The Saudi Government has announced plans to break relations with Zaire to protest the African nation's decision to resume ties with Israel, the Saudi state radio said today.

title: Miami Reports a Drop In Rate of Serious Crime
description: Crime is on the decline in Miami, a port for drug smugglers that in 1980 had the nation's highest murder rate, state officials say.

title: Condor Flock Grows by One
description: California's endangered flock of condors has increased by at least one with a chick hatched in the rugged cliffs of northern Ventura County. A pair of condors were observed nurturing the new offspring ''within the last few days,'' Inez Conner, a spokesman for the National Wildlife Service, said Tuesday. Fewer than 30 California condors are known to exist.

title: Stake in Grindlays
description: Grindlays Holdings P.L.C. said today that Bahrain and the Middle East Bank of Bahrain had bought 3.77 million shares, or 11 percent, of Grindlays. Grindlays Holdings, in which Lloyds Bank has a 40 percent share, controls 51 percent of Grindlays Bank, while Citicorp has 49 percent.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 20, 1982
description: International An extension of peace talks was requested by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, in telephone calls to the leaders of Argentina and Britain as negotiations over the Falkland Islands were on the verge of collapse. Security Council members said they had the impression that he had won ''perhaps 24 hours more.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Britain's membership in the European Economic Community could be in doubt after the nine other members ignored a British veto, President Francois Mitterrand of France said. For the first time, a majority refused to allow the veto that all members had been assumed to enjoy over majority community decisions. (A1:5.)

title: Reduction of Staff Planned by Armco
description: Armco Inc. plans to use voluntary retirements and unpaid personal leaves to reduce its corporate staff by about 150 jobs and lessen the need for layoffs, the company announced.

title: Coal Mission To Europe Set
description: Government officials and representatives of about a dozen coal companies began a mission today to promote long-term coal contracts with Spain, Italy, France and Belgium, according to Commerce Department officials.

title: DOCTOR ADMITS FILING FALSE DATA AND IS BARRED FROM U.S. SUPPORT
description: The Government took steps today to prevent a cancer researcher from getting Federal funds or using experimental drugs after he admitted submitting false data.

title: SOCIALISTS IN FRANCE, ONE YEAR LATER
description: The first year in office of President Francois Mitterrand and his Socialist Government is being marked quietly, both by the Government itself and by the press.

title: WESTERNISMS FADING FAST AS DUNGAREES, LISTED FOR DICTIONARY
description: If Don D. Walker has his way, someday there will be a dictionary in which ''git'' is a verb, as in ''git me some grub''; ''bushwhacker'' is a noun as in one who ambushes, and ''leavin' Cheyenne'' is just another way to say goodbye, as in the old cowboy ballad, ''Goodbye, Old Paint, I'm leavin' Cheyenne.''

title: WOMEN DEMAND SHARE OF JOBS AT A BUILDING SITE
description: About 50 women, some wearing hard hats and with infants in tow, demonstrated for two hours yesterday at a midtown Manhattan construction site to protest what they said was sexual discrimination by the general contractor and subcontractors.

title: Job Training Is a Public Duty
description: Maligned and battered, the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act is in a Capitol Hill garage for extensive repairs and body work.

title: CALIFORNIA G.O.P. UNSURE ABOUT REAGAN'S COATTAILS
description: The television commercials say that Mike Curb is ''the only candidate for Governor who supported Ronald Reagan in 1976 and 1980'' and that Pete Wilson, who is running for United States Senator, is ''a partner for President Reagan.''

title: 2d Extortion Trial Clears Defendant
description: Guido Penosi was found not guilty today of conspiracy to extort money from two entertainers, Wayne Newton and Lola Falana.

title: 2 U.S. Reporters in Uganda Freed After 2 Days' Detention
description: Two American journalists detained by the Ugandan Army for two days were handed over to the United States consul in Kampala today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am buying a house in which the living-room and dining-room walls are paneled with tongue-and-groove pine planks that were finished with a dark oil stain. I would like to lighten these planks, yet I want to retain the rustic look. How can I restore the pine to its original honey color or make it look even lighter? -E.M.K., Manhattan.

title: Pope Invites Church Leaders To Rome for Mass for Peace
description: Pope John Paul II issued an ''urgent and personal request'' to primates of Argentina and Britain to join him at the Vatican at a mass for peace in the Falkland Islands, Roman Catholic officials said today.

title: ARTS AND LETTERS GROUP GIVES AWARD TO KNOPF
description: At the grants and induction ceremony of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters yesterday afternoon, the annual award for distinguished service to the arts was presented to Alfred A. Knopf by John Hersey, the novelist and reporter who is chancellor of the academy.

title: 25 on Chinese Boat Drown
description: An excursion boat capsized in Tianjin on Sunday and 25 people were reported killed. Press reports said 25 people were rescued after the accident in Tianjin's waterside park. The excursion boat rocked violently and then sank with its passenger cabin under water, the papers said.

title: Miss Loren Begins 30-Day Term in Tax Case
description: Sophia Loren began serving a 30-day term in Italy yesterday for tax evasion. She is to be confined in the jail at Caserta, about 20 miles from the city of her birth, Naples.

title: Refinery Shutdown
description: Texaco Inc. announced today that Chevron Erdoel Deutschland G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of Standard Oil of California, and Deutsche Texaco A.G., a subsidiary of Texaco, would close the crude oil refining activities of their jointly owned Caltex Deutschland G.m.b.H. by the end of September. The refinery, near Raunheim, is operating at about 40 percent of its capacity of 4.5 million metric tons a year, Caltex sources said.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE STRUCTURES OF EVERYDAY LIFE: The Limits of the Possible. Vol- ume I. Civilization and Capitalism. 15th-18th Century. By Fernand Braudel. Translated from the French by Miriam Kochan. Revised by Sian Reynolds. Il- lustrated. 623 pages. Harper & Row. $30.

title: Post to Rohatyn
description: He has been so busy with corporate mergers and public financing that Felix G. Rohatyn has not had much time for private philanthropy - until now, that is.

title: TOSCANINI CAN STILL PACK THE HOUSE
description: FIVE years after Arturo Toscanini's death, his reputation remains imposing, even if his legacy is troubled by passing squabbles. The principal squabble has to do with the disposition of his archives, most of which lie out of public view at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts and remain the subject of a dispute between the library and the conductor's heirs, who reportedly want $1.5 million to permit the materials to remain there. And one occasionally hears of complaints about the unavailability of Toscanini's many recordings, which some family members and admirers feel RCA has not disseminated widely or consistently enough.

title: AT CANNES, A SEARCH FOR EXCITEMENT
description: ''We had a rather bumpy time last year,'' Gilles Jacob, director of the Cannes Film Festival, said today. ''We started in the middle of the week. There were the French presidential elections, the assassination attempt on the Pope, and altogether, a number of people thought we were in trouble.''

title: DANCE: DAN WAGONER PRESENTS 'OTJIBWA ANGO'
description: AS dances by Dan Wagoner go, his new ''Otjibwa Ango'' was unusually long, lasting almost an hour. It was also unusually interesting, and one of the things that made it so was the way its thematic implications kept crystallizing and melting.

title: Scattered Clashes Mar State Elections in India
description: Scattered clashes marked voting in four Indian states today in what was seen as an important political test for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Required Reading Looking; Good
description: Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, addressing former members of Congress, May 17, 1982:

title: MACY UP 17.8%
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest department store operator, reported yesterday that it had a 28.5 percent decline in net income in its fiscal first quarter, to $29.1 million, or 60 cents a share, from $40.7 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same 1981 period.

title: BELMONT OPENS AND SIGNALS START OF RACING'S LUSH MONTHS
description: The vernal equinox came and went two months ago, but for local horseplayers, yesterday felt like the first day of spring. The sense of seasonal change, of uplift and renewal, came from the annual return of thoroughbred racing to Belmont Park. Except for a shift to Saratoga Race Track for the last 27 days of August, the runners will be at Belmont until Oct.11, when racing again moves to Aqueduct for seven months.

title: HARVARD BATTLING UNION AT THREE HEALTH SCHOOLS
description: A fiercely contested dispute is being played out at Harvard University as a small, New York-based union, with much of its membership in small textile and cosmetics shops, is attempting to organize office, service and technical workers at three of the university's health-related professional schools.

title: Harvester to Sell Trucks to Pakistan
description: The International Harvester Company announced that it would sell 240 medium-duty trucks and parts to the Government of Pakistan for $8 million.

title: SETBACKS AT POLLS DISMISSED BY RIZZO
description: Sounding more than ever like a potential entry in next year's mayoral races, former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo scoffed today at widespread views that he suffered setbacks in Tuesday's primary.

title: Kean Nominates Education Commissioner
description: Yesterday, five days after his original choice for the position dropped out, Governor Kean of New Jersey nominated Saul Cooperman to be his Commissioner of Education.

title: CELTICS BEAT 76ers, 114-85; TRAIL SERIES, 3-2
description: The signs and the chants at Boston Garden tonight offered encouragement to Robert Parish, the player Boston Celtic fans call ''the Chief.''

title: PAYMENT IS OWED TO 30,000 WHO SERVED AS JURORS IN '82
description: About 30,000 jurors in New York City, along with many part-time stenographers, interpreters and others supplying services to the local courts, have not been paid since January.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST of today's homes were built before energy conservation and the use of alternate sources of energy were objects of concern. As a result, many homeowners are now trying to reduce the huge costs of heating and cooling their residences and providing hot water.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE title, ''Tables & Chairs: Vintage Modern and Recent Burton,'' was interesting enough. On exhibit through May 29 at the Max Protetch gallery is a series of modern classic designs and a few works by Scott Burton, an avant-garde artist who, with Fran Nelson, the architecture director of the gallery, put together the furniture tableau.

title: Bridge: A Time When It Was Best Not to Bid With 13 Points
description: The older textbooks on the game advised the beginner to open the bidding automatically with 14 high-card points and most of the time with 13 points. Nowadays the advice is to open every hand with 13 points, which is sound enough for practical purposes. It is true that there are some hands with 13 points that an expert will pass, but they are very rare indeed.

title: Short-Term Rates Decline; 2-Year Notes Bring 13.77%
description: A ''flight toward quality'' pushed down short-term interest rates yesterday as nervous dealers and investors sought Treasury bills and ignored longer Government securities, which were largely unchanged in price on the day.

title: Rise Urged In Pension Premiums
description: The Federal agency that insures corporate retirement programs today asked Congress to let it more than double the premiums it charges employers to cover an actuarial deficit the agency said would reach $236 million by the end of 1982.

title: Great Southwest
description: The Great Southwest Industries Corporation said it had agreed to buy Southwest Logging and Hydrocarbon Equipments Inc., two affiliated well-service companies in Roosevelt, Okla., for $1 million in cash and notes and up to $3.3 million in the future, depending on future earnings. Richard Cierman, president of Southwest Logging, and Ralph Pittman, president of Hydrocarbon Equipment, are to retain their jobs.

title: True and False
description: An embarrassing political lie shines out from a new Census Bureau report on voting and registration. So does a sober political truth.

title: The U.N. Today; May 20, 1982; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Unicef executive board - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BEGIN NARROWLY SURVIVES NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's fragile coalition narrowly survived a vote of no confidence in Parliament today after a day of back-room bargaining and public name-calling.

title: Broker Merger In Canada Set
description: Richardson Securities of Canada said it had agreed to buy the equity interest of Greenshields Inc. and merge it into Richardson.

title: OPEC Finds Prices Stable
description: On the eve of OPEC's regular spring meeting, oil ministers from several of the 13 member countries predicted today that world oil prices would remain stable for the rest of the year. The consensus was that, to maintain prices, the group would probably continue the emergency production controls that were agreed upon in March and designed to dry up a worldwide oversupply of crude oil.

title: AIDE TO MUSTO BACKED FOR SENATE
description: Hudson County Democratic leaders have chosen Nicholas J. LaRocca, the 69-year-old legislative aide to former State Senator William V. Musto, to run for the seat vacated by Mr. Musto as a result of his conviction and sentencing on Federal racketeering charges.

title: CITY GARDEN DESIGN: HOW ARCHITECTS DO IT
description: ARCHITECTS typically plan buildings, not gardens, and the materials they use - concrete, steel, wood and glass - are hardly components of a leafy retreat. Yet when they are faced with designing their own city yard or roof terrace, their experience and training affect what they do and how they do it. From their various approaches, other city gardeners can learn much about small-space composition and the use of texture, light and color in designing outdoor spaces.

title: Shipping Link Is Reopened
