description: The Coast Guard today reopened the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal about 37 hours after it was closed to large craft because of a collision of a container ship and a barge loaded with a toxic chemical. A recovery vessel transferred 295,000 gallons of phenol from the leaking barge.

title: Appointment Troubles in Trenton
description: Governor Kean's new administration in New Jersey barely extricates itself from one appointment controversy before it faces the embarrassment of another.

title: EYELESS IN GAZA (2)
description: Mr. Justice Brandeis, in a memorable opinion on freedom of speech, said Government should not be able to forbid the expression of political ideas even when a majority considered them ''fraught with evil consequence.'' He warned ''that it is hazardous to discourage thought, hope and imagination; that fear breeds repression; that repression breeds hate ...''

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Russell Lynes is a social historian and author whose latest book is ''More Than Meets the Eye,'' a history of Cooper-Hewitt Museum. By RUSSELL LYNES

title: 40,000 CHEER FOR ISLANDERS AT L.I. PARADE
description: More than 40,000 hockey fans cheered the New York Islanders tonight in a parade that many Long Islanders say is as much of a spring ritual as the team's winning ways in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Disability Relief Is Approved
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a bill allowing people cut from the Social Security disability rolls to continue receiving benefits while they appeal. The bill is designed to ease the effects of a culling of the disability rolls being carried out by the Social Security Administration.

title: SAVINGS BANKS LOST $342 MILLION
description: Savings banks in New York State continued to experience large losses in the first three months of the year, but as a result of a general decline in interest rates, the losses were not as severe as they had been in the fourth quarter, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Banking Department.

title: Wrong Move
description: Lending his name and voice to a radio advertisement for a moving company was a mistake, Paul A. Samuelson, the Nobel Prize-winning economist said yesterday.

title: French Doctors to Boycott Medical Congress in Moscow
description: Five hundred French heart specialists have decided to boycott a world cardiology congress to be held in Moscow next month to protest Soviet policies, their spokesman said today.

title: CHASE BANK WILL PAY OFF INTEREST OWED BY DEFAULTING BOND DEALER
description: Faced with the prospect that it might be blamed if several Wall Street houses collapsed, the Chase Manhattan Bank reversed itself yesterday and agreed to pay off an estimated $270 million in interest payments that Chase is unable to collect from Drysdale Government Securities.

title: MUSIC: 150TH ANNIVERSARY
description: WITH the Bicentennial long gone, one might think that the mid-70's revival of early American music would fade away, too. But that hasn't happened, and an example of the continued concern for the rediscovery and performance of such music is a series that began Monday night at the New York University Theater.

title: Court Upholds Size Limit In Irrigation Dispute
description: The Federal Government may limit the amount of private land irrigated with water from flood control projects, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today.

title: 2 ARE CHARGED IN A 2D HOLDUP OF A BRINK'S CAR
description: Two men charged in the Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County last October were indicted yesterday in an earlier Brink's robbery in the Bronx.

title: Fine Is $1 Million In Marijuana Case
description: A Long Island woman who was one of the principals in a multimillion-dollar marijuana-sales operation was fined $1 million today by a Nassau County Court judge.

title: Florida Bank's Special Meeting
description: Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., the target of a longrunning takeover battle, said yesterday that a quorum of shareholders was not present at a special meeting held last week to vote on its proposed acquisition of the Alliance Corporation, a Florida mortgage and banking company.

title: More Workers Set at Northrop
description: Thomas V. Jones, chairman of the Northrop Corporation, said that the company expected to add 3,500 to 5,000 employees to its staff of 32,400 in the next 18 months. The company is the prime contractor for the Stealth bomber.

title: Third Longhorn Gone
description: Coach Bob Weltlich has lost his third player from the Texas Longhorn basketball team since arriving from Mississippi several weeks ago to replace the dismissed Abe Lemons. Following LaSalle Thompson's decision to turn pro and James Tandy's announcement that he was quitting the team, Denard Holmes, a starter last season, quit as well yesterday and said that Weltlich was trying to force some players off the squad with an offseason regimen of stringent exercise and scrimmages.

title: Reagan to Visit California
description: President Reagan will visit California for six days next week, attending a Republican fund-raising event in Los Angeles and a United States-Mexican conference in Santa Barbara, his spokesman announced Tuesday. Mr. Reagan will fly to Los Angeles next Tuesday for a Salute to the President dinner and will later fly to his ranch northwest of Santa Barbara. He is expected to return to Washington on Sunday.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ACCENT ON DESIGN
description: Design 1925 Symposium, Haft Audi- torium, Fashion Institute of Tech- nology, 227 West 27th Street, 760- 7970.

title: MRS. THATCHER DECLARES 'THE GAP LOOKS BIG' AT TALKS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that Argentina's preliminary response to Britain's final proposal for a peaceful settlement of the Falkland Islands controversy ''does not look very encouraging.''

title: COLUMBIA HAILS APARTHEID FOE
description: The president of Columbia University said yesterday that the university would send representatives to South Africa to award an honorary degree to Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, who was prevented from leaving his country.

title: FRANCE CASTING DOUBT ON BRITISH IN MARKET ROLE
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France said today that Britain's membership in the European Economic Community could be in doubt after the other members ignored a British veto on Tuesday.

title: ALBANIA IS AN UNLIKELY TARGET OF SOVIET MILITARY AGRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: WAY TO UPSET A VETO OF A DEATH PENALTY STUDIED IN ASSEMBLY
description: The sponsors of a bill to restore the death penalty are considering an amendment that they hope will give the Assembly the votes it needs to override an expected veto by Governor Carey.

title: Met Museum to Present 66 Concerts in Season
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will present 66 concerts in its 1982-83 season.

title: Technology; Stereo TV On the Way
description: FOR the television industry, sound has traditionally been a low priority. Sound ''is the weakest link in the technical quality of the whole television system,'' said Daniel R. Wells, a senior vice president of the Public Broadcasting Service. Now, however, the age of high fidelity stereo television is approaching, and some experts predict there will be broadcasts with stereo sound before the end of 1983.

title: U.S. AND MOROCCO REPORTED NEAR ACCORD
description: The United States and Morocco are close to an agreement that would allow American troops and planes to use a Moroccan air base in case of a crisis in the Middle East, according to senior Administration officials.

title: SENATE PANEL RENEWS LONG AND BITTER FIGHT OVER CONGRESS PAY ISSUE
description: Members of Congress are once again grappling with one of the thorniest issues they ever deal with: their own pay. The struggle took another turn Tuesday night when the Senate Appropriations Committee approved an amendment that would require lawmakers to be treated the same as any other taxpayers when they fill out their Federal income tax returns. The rider was tacked onto a special spending bill for the current fiscal year that should come to the Senate floor early next week.

title: Budget Proposed For Rochester
description: The City Manager, Peter Korn, proposed today a ''hold-the-line'' budget for the 1982-83 fiscal year that calls for a 14 percent increase in the real-estate tax and the elimination of 55 municipal positions.

title: Skywriting Squadron
description: Today will be commissioning day at La Guardia Airport for the East Coast Miller Squadron, five World War II airplanes that will be skywriting advertising messages over what large crowds it can find.

title: Sale by Fluor
description: The Fluor Corporation said it had agreed to sell the Coquina Oil Corporation and Coquina Petroleum to the Kerr-McGee Corporation for $265 million. The transaction is subject to Kerr-McGee arranging the financing within 30 days. Fluor acquired Coquina with the St. Joe Minerals Corporation.

title: Knoxville Fair Tops Estimate, Mostly on Hot Dogs and Beer
description: Tourist dollars are pouring into the World's Fair at nearly double the promoters' first estimates because of record-breaking crowds that are buying more hot dogs and beer than expected, officials said today.

title: U.S. Tightens Pollution Rules For Iron and Steel Industries
description: The Environmental Protection Agency issued regulations Tuesday that would require the iron and steel industry to comply with tighter water pollution controls.

title: DISABILITY BENEFIT REVIEWS: FAIRNESS COUNTS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAKING CHEMICALS IN CALIFORNIA'S 'SILICON VALLEY' ALARM NEIGHBORS
description: Not long ago Lorraine Ross learned of what she calls ''a chemical bomb'' in the water coming out of the faucets in her neighborhood.

title: German Plane Crash Kills 8
description: A small commercial plane crashed near here today while apparently trying to make an emergency landing, killing all eight people aboard, the authorities said. The plane, a Cessna Citation, was on a flight from Munich to Hanover when it crashed in a wooded area near Kassel-Calden airport.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LUNCH BREAK

title: NORTH KOREA BLOCKS DEFECTIONS ACROSS DMZ
description: A defector from North Korea stood on the southern border of the demilitarized zone near here recently, looking north across a no man's land of grasses and reeds two and a half miles wide.

title: ARGENTINA SAYS BRITISH DO NOT WANT TO NEGOTIATE
description: The Argentine Government, expecting a breakdown of mediation efforts at the United Nations in the conflict with Britain, charged today that the British did not want to negotiate.

title: Irving Gladstone, 74; Led Principals Group
description: Dr. Irving A. Gladstone, who had been active in the New York City school system and a former president of the Elementary School Principals Association, died Tuesday at University Hospital. Dr. Gladstone, who was a resident of Brooklyn, was 74 years old.

title: PERTAMINA: REBUILDING IS SLOW
description: Just a year ago, Brig. Gen. Joedo Soembono was named president of Pertamina, the Indonesian national oil company that supplies more than 70 percent of this nation's national revenues. His problems: rampant corruption, mismanagement and an unwieldy company that had grown far beyond oil to become mired in debt.

title: CHINESE PROVINCE HAS SEVERE FLOOD
description: China's populous southeastern province of Guangdong has begun recovering from severe floods that marooned 450,000 people and left at least 430 dead.

title: Profits Decline At Shell Group
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the world's second-largest oil company after Exxon, reported today that its net income fell 24.6 percent in the first quarter of this year because of lower oil prices.

title: RECITAL: 'CONNECTION WITH THE PAST' BY THE DA CAPO PLAYERS
description: ''CONNECTIONS WITH THE PAST'' was the title of a program presented Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Da Capo Chamber Players. The ''past'' turned out to be the second decade of this century, represented by Alban Berg's Four Pieces for Clarinet and Piano (Op. 5) and Debussy's Sonata for Flute, Viola and Harp, and the works that connected with it were George Perle's Sonata a Quattro (1982) and Chester Biscardi's ''Di Vivere'' (1981), both of which were written for the Da Capo players and received their New York premieres in this performance.

title: A-PLANT MISHAP IS UNDER INQUIRY BY U.S. AGENCY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is investigating an attempt last month to force the shutdown of the Salem 2 nuclear plant in Salem, N.J., a few hours after workers there voted to go on strike.

title: HIGH LEAD LEVEL FOUND IN 4% OF PRESCHOOLERS
description: Four percent of American preschool children have excessive levels of lead in their blood, according to a survey by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: CITY BUDGET IS CRITICIZED AT 2 HEARINGS
description: New York City's budget, shaped largely in private by municipal officials, got its first public hearings yesterday and the reception was mostly negative.

title: DOME OFFERS U.S. PROPERTIES FOR SALE
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the largest independent oil company in Canada, confirmed yesterday that it was offering for sale its exploration and producing properties in the United States for $700 million to $1 billion.

title: RADIO-CONTROL TOYS ARE FOR ADULTS, TOO
description: FOR his 5th birthday last year, Paul Jude Sorvillo was given a radio-control robot that came in a box and cost around $10 and which, with shouts of glee and the flick of a knob on his hand-held transmitter, he was able to make go forward, backward and turn until it finally turned into the living-room wall once too often. This year the youngster is asking for a radio-control car, or a radio-control horse. Paul, his parents report, thinks such toys are ''incredible'' and ''neat.''

title: People
description: * Peggy Bell-Masterson, a senior vice president of Benton & Bowles Inc., has been appointed creative director.

title: CLEAVER RETURNS TO COAST CAMPUS
description: Eldridge Cleaver, a former Marxist who was a founder of the Black Panthers, came to the University of California campus at Berkeley today to praise President Reagan and the American Way.

title: Clock Plant Move Called Irrevocable
description: The General Time Corporation is sticking by its decision to move its historic Seth Thomas clock operations from Thomaston, Conn., to Norcross, Ga., in November, according to John J. Carson, Connecticut's Economic Development Commissioner.

title: BELGIAN HEROISM, 'AS IF IT WERE YESTERDAY'
description: IF the years of the Nazis were a time when the hounds of hell had been unleashed, it was also a time that turned ordinary mortals into extraordinary heroes. This is brought out hearteningly in ''As If It Were Yesterday,'' a film about Belgians who saved Jewish children at the Carnegie Hall Cinema.

title: FOUR COMPANIES RAISE GASOLINE PRICES 1 to 3
description: Wholesale gasoline prices rose again yesterday when four major oil companies posted increases of 1 to 3 cents a gallon, continuing what one analyst termed an ''irregular but inexorable wave of increases'' that began in early April.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL BID BY NLT
description: In what analysts called a defensive riposte, the NLT Corporation of Nashville, an insurance company, yesterday announced a tender offer worth more than $600 million to raise its stake in the American General Corporation to 50.2 percent from the present 2.2 percent.

title: Canada in Move on Oilfield
description: With billions of dollars of oil revenue at stake, the federal Government asked the Supreme Court today to back its claim to ownership of the potentially rich Hibernia field off Newfoundland's shores.

title: Conviction Is Upheld Despite Nap by Judge
description: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals refused today to overturn a jury conviction even though the trial judge fell asleep on the bench.

title: Youth Convicted In Fatal Robbery
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth was convicted yesterday of taking part in a robbery two years ago in Queens in which a 16-year-old high school honor student was killed as he returned home from a prom. The verdict was returned by a jury of 11 women and one man after two days of deliberation in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: Simplicity Pattern
description: MCO Holdings and the Federated Development Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that they each had acquired 1,428,570 shares, or 10.4 percent, of the Simplicity Pattern Company for a total holding of 20.8 percent.

title: Social Security in 1982, 1984 and 2020
description: Before the hot potato of Social Security is put back in the political cooler, it would be well to remember that this recurrent ''crisis'' routinely evokes a confusion of three different problems. President Reagan's experts are worried because Social Security payments may drive the Federal budget deeper into deficit. Social Security administrators fret that they may not have enough cash to pay next year's bills. And social planners are uneasy because a few decades from now there won't be enough income to pay the benefits of people just now starting to work.

title: Hamsho Bout Set
description: The World Boxing Council light-heavyweight bout between Dwight Braxton and Lotte Mwale, scheduled for Saturday, has been replaced by a bout between the No. 2 ranked middleweight, Mustafa Hamsho, and Gil Rosario. The title fight had to be scrapped when Mwale suffered an eye injury in training.

title: Bank Board Shift
description: Andrew DiPrete has resigned from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board for personal reasons, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday. Mr. DiPrete, a 53-year-old Republican lawyer from Rhode Island, will leave the three-member bank board, which regulates savings and loans associations, June 30, a year before his term expires.

title: Sikorsky Seeks Partners
description: The United Technologies Corporation said today that its Sikorsky Aircraft unit is seeking international business partners to produce its advanced technology family of helicopters.

title: BRITAIN'S ANGERED BY MARKET REBUFF
description: British officials pledged strong action today against the Common Market in retaliation for its decision to ignore a British veto. They complained that Common Market rules had been violated.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, in some editions yesterday an article on the Washington Talk page omitted one question from an interview on Social Security with Representative J.J. Pickle. The question, the next-to-last, was, ''Should Congress levy income tax against some of the Social Se- curity benefits received by people with substantial extra income?''

title: Soviet Plans to Send 1,000 to the Olympics
description: Despite its frequent harsh criticism of preparations for the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, the Soviet Union plans to send 1,000 athletes and officials, more than any other country, the chairman of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it held 6.2 percent of Northwest Energy Company's cumulative convertible preferred A stock, and 7.1 percent of Fairchild Industries cumulative convertible preferred series A stock.

title: Reader's Digest Plans Sales Director Switch
description: Richard F. McLoughlin, publisher of the Reader's Digest, announced yesterday that James T. Sheridan, 55-year-old vice president and advertising sales director, is taking early retirement on July 1.

title: POSTPUNK: THE BRITISH JAM
description: WHEN punk-rock erupted out of Britain five years ago, the Jam was the least flamboyant and most musically adept of a spearheading triumverate that included the Sex Pistols and Clash. But because the Jam's righteously angry social realism was less glamorous than the Sex Pistols' nihilism and the Clash's revolutionary rhetoric, neither the group nor its leader, Paul Weller, guitarist, songwriter and singer, ever quite achieved the notoriety of the Pistols' John Lydon.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: White Zimbabwe Farms Raided by Gunmen
description: A gunman was killed and a farmer was wounded in attacks by armed men on two white-owned farms in southwestern Zimbabwe, the Government said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Dixie Walker's Home Run
description: WE were sitting around the dinner table the other night talking about our earliest memories. The woman on the other side of the table, probably for very good reasons, didn't remember much about her early years except, vaguely, that the war had ended and that she had lived in a lot of different houses in Connecticut.

title: Cosmos Win, 3-2
description: Richard Chinapoo scored the deciding goal with two minutes to play tonight as the Cosmos rallied from a 2-0 halftime deficit to defeat the Portland Timbers, 3-2.

title: Accounts
description: * American Health magazine to Franznick & Cusatis.

title: News Analysis
description: Washington's badly strained ties to Argentina, and its future role as a mediator between Buenos Aires and London, appear to be at the mercy of Argentine politics and the United States commitment to support Britain's military effort in the South Atlantic.

title: HARD TIMES FORCE A WEST SIDE BOOKSHOP TO CLOSE
description: The New Yorker Bookshop - something of an Upper West Side institution - closed yesterday after 17 years in business, victim of an economy that has dealt harshly with neighborhood general-interest bookstores.

title: OUTCRY WAS FEARED OVER DRAFT REGISTRATION TRIALS
description: At a private meeting at the Pentagon last month, some officials expressed worry about a possible public outcry over felony prosecutions of young men who failed to register for the draft, according to a transcript of that meeting.

title: Dow Drops by 4.95; Bank Issues Active
description: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday with some of the bank issues attracting most of the attention. The main casualties were the technology and energy-related issues.

title: American Filtrona
description: The American Filtrona Corporation said it had agreed to buy 51 percent of the Dolinger Corporation from certain sharehodlers at $36 a share and that it would begin a tender offer next week to acquire the remaining shares at the same price.

title: American Airlines Sees Higher Fares
description: American Airlines' president, Robert L. Crandall, told the airline's stockholders today that airline fares will ''hopefully begin to rise on a selective basis.''

title: Genetic Systems
description: The Genetic Systems Corporation said it planned a $9.5 million joint venture with a subsidiary of the Syntex Corporation, the Syva Company, to develop monoclonal antibodies for diagnosis and treatment of human cancer. The initial focus is to be on leukemia and breast, prostate, colon and lung cancer. Final terms are subject to a definitive agreement and approval of both companies, Genetic Systems said.

title: HATCH ANGERED BY PLAN TO SEEK F.B.I.'S SOURCES
description: The chairman of the Senate's Labor Committee reacted angrily today to the hiring of private detectives by a company to investigate activities of the panel.

title: LESSONS IN DRYSDALE'S DEFAULT
description: The wisdom of the the Wall Street adage ''know your customer'' was again demonstrated this week when upstart Drysdale Government Securities, with just $5.5 million of capital, traded its way into the pockets of some of the nation's largest banks by failing to make an estimated $270 million of interest payments due to the banks' customers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the Manhattan Theater Club gave an incorrect ticket price for its spring benefit May 24. Tickets are $150, of which $100 is tax deductible.

title: Detective Guilty Of Taking Bribe
description: A suspended New York City detective was convicted yesterday of accepting a bribe to protect a ring accused of stealing millions of dollars worth of goods in the garment district.

title: BEFORE WRITING OFF SUGAR, REMEMBER HAWAII
description: To the Editor:

title: 14 Win Music Auditions
description: Artists International, a nonprofit organization for discovering and promoting young musical talent, has announced the 14 winners of its 1982 auditions. They are Robert Bank, Gwan-Ying Wu, Carmen Rodriguez-Peralta, Ronald Sadoff and Yulia Lipmanovich, pianists; Katherine Thomas, Sergiu Schwartz and Anne Asinas, violinists; the Royale Trio; Ronald Shawger and David Fisher, cellists; Rie Schmidt and Gretchen Pusch, flutists, and the Orion String Quartet.

title: THEATER: GRANGER'S 'UNHEARD SONGS'
description: PERCY GRANGER'S ''Eminent Domain,'' ending its run at the Circle in the Square, is not a successful play, but it is undeniably the creation of an intelligent, serious writer. If it whetted your appetite to hear more from Mr. Granger, you'll want to see ''Vivien,'' a far superior, one-act work that is being revived at the Ark Theater Company in SoHo.

title: SINGAPORE'S ECONOMY EXPANDS MORE SLOWLY
description: This island republic's economy has at last begun to reflect its Government's two-year-old prediction that growth rates of 10 percent a year could not survive a world recession.

title: No Progress Is Reported in N.F.L.-Union Talks
description: In the least acrimonious talks since negotiations for a new bargaining agreement began last February, the National Football League Management Council and the Players Association met yesterday but reported no progress.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cities Service Co. said that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue up to 2,750,000 shares of its common stock to the First Boston Corp. in exchange for its 6 1/8 percent debentures due 1997, 6 5/8 percent debentures due 1999 and 7.65 percent debentures due 2001.

title: N.H.L. Puts Off Decision on the Rockies' Move to New Jersey
description: Despite 16 hours of discussion spanning two days, the National Hockey League's board of governors could not fit together all the puzzle pieces necessary to complete the proposed transfer of the Colorado Rockies franchise to Byrne Meadowlands Arena. So yesterday at 11:30 A.M., the board's special session was recessed and scheduled to reconvene next week, no later than May 27.

title: Clerc Upset by Tulasne, Gerulaitis Wins in Rome
description: Thierry Tulasne, an 18-year-old Frenchman, upset top-seeded Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina today, 7-5, 6-1, in the second round of the Italian Open clay-court tennis championships. Vitas Gerulaitis had to struggle to beat Diego Perez of Uruguay, 4-6, 6-2, 7-5.

title: Tesoro Lets Deadline Pass
description: Three months ago, the management of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation told shareholders at the annual meeting that a major announcement would be made within 12 weeks regarding a possible sale or redistribution of the company's assets.

title: SQUATTERS OCCUPY SAN JUAN CAPITOL
description: About 200 squatters who had been forcibly evicted from their shanties took over a hearing room of the commonwealth's Capitol today, vowing not to move until they were given new homes.

title: SURVIVAL STRATEGIES FOR SLUMBER PARTIES
description: OVERS and slumber parties are becoming more common at younger ages these days, but that doesn't make them any easier for the children or the parents involved, according to psychologists in the field of family relations. Both children and parents, they say, can often find the prospect of a night away from home intimidating.

title: Arnold & Company Sets John Hancock TV Ads
description: With its hometown agency, Arnold & Company, the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, whose windows made Boston famous, will be taking to network television advertising for the first time in a decade beginning in July. The new theme line is: ''John Hancock can help you here and now.

title: Carey Signs Measures For Reapportionment
description: Governor Carey announced today that he had signed legislation creating new political boundaries for the State Senate, the Assembly and New York's Congressional delegation.

title: PAPER WRAPS STONE
description: stone breaks scissors, scissors cut paper, but paper wraps stone, goes the old children's game. Strength, that is to say, isn't just hardness or sharpness but a sense of what's appropriate.

title: Advertising; Hometown Agency Success
description: THE first night of the recent 64th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Greenbrier in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., marked a first of sorts. A hoedown.

title: News Analysis
description: The 1982 battle to maintain rail commuter fares at current levels and save the 75-cent bus and subway fare has begun with a bombardment of contradictory numbers and words.

title: Imperial Increases Stake in Insurer
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce Trust Company (Bahamas) Ltd. reported yesterday that it had raised its stake to 65,300 shares, or 5.9 percent, in Baldwin & Lyons, a provider of casualty insurance for the motor transport industry.

title: FUR SHOWINGS: CLASSICS AND SURPRISES
description: AS the fur showings continued, the scene got livelier. The house of Alixandre, with Perry Ellis and Yves Saint Laurent (plus Jeffrey Banks for men's furs) on its design roster, could hardly avoid some fireworks.

title: A NEW PHASE FOR MISS LOPEZ
description: Nancy Lopez joined the golf tour in August 1977, after having finished second in the United States Women's Open the previous month. Within a year, she had become the best-known and most-popular female golfer ever, if not the best.

title: THE PROBLEMS THAT NUCLEAR WAR WOULD ERASE
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT BLOCKS SALE OF TURNER ART
description: Two paintings by J.M.W. Turner that were expected to sell for up to $1.5 million and $2 million each were withdrawn at Christie's yesterday by an order from the New York State Supreme Court a few hours before they were to be auctioned. The 1846 Venetian paintings are ''Going to the Ball'' and ''Returning From the Ball.

title: DISABILITY BENEFIT REVIEWS: FAIRNESS COUNTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HAIG ENDS TRIP IN A JOKING MOOD
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has returned from his latest overseas trip feeling very good, so good, in fact, that he is even telling jokes about his relationship with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: STOCKMAN BACKS AMENDMENT FOR BALANCED BUDGET
description: Speaking for President Reagan, David A. Stockman, the budget director, today endorsed the proposed constitutional amendment to require balanced Federal budgets. However, he suggested changing the language to permit suspension of the requirement in a national emergency.

title: Spokane Judge Likens Woman to Hinckley
description: Ruth Coe's physician today compared her plot to kill the judge and prosecutor who sent her son to prison to John W. Hinckley Jr.'s attempt to assassinate the President to get a date with an actress.

title: Geico to Purchase More G.E.F. Stock
description: The Geico Corporation said that it had agreed in principle to purchase the remaining shares of the Government Employees Financial Corporation that it did not already own - 390,869 common and 279,183 preferred shares.

title: MOON'S FOLLOWERS ASSERT FAITH IS UNDAUNTED
description: The man many of them consider to be their Messiah could face a prison term or deportation, but members of the Unification Church say their faith can survive without the physical presence of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: BILLY GRAHAM, BACK HOME, DEFENDS REMARKS
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, returning to the United States yesterday from a trip to the Soviet Union, denied suggestions that he had softened his criticism of Moscow's treatment of religious believers in order to improve his chances of returning to that country to hold evangelistic rallies.

title: A.T.& T. Picks Seven Regional Chiefs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday selected the chief executives of the seven regional holding companies that will be formed when the phone company divests itself of its 22 local operating companies in line with a proposed settlement of the Justice Department's antitrust suit.

title: FIGHTING FOR GULF RESOURSES
description: A preliminary count in the proxy battle for control of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, a Houston energy company, indicated yesterday that a group of dissident shareholders led by the British investor Alan E. Clore may have unseated the company's board of directors.

title: GREEKS ASSESSING TALKS WITH HAIG
description: The Greek Government is only partly satisfied by the weekend talks with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Greek officials and Western diplomats said today. And a quick move by the Soviet Union to publicize recently expressed support for Greek policies is seen as an attempt to overshadow the good faith built up in recent months between Washington and its Greek ally.

title: EVENTS FORCE A CLEARER OUTLINE OF FOREIGN POLICY
description: For roughly a year, the world provided President Reagan an unusual grace period in the area of foreign policy, but reality is now crowding in on him, belatedly forcing a clearer delineation of where his Administration stands.

title: JUDGE REFUSES BID TO QUIT I.B.M. CASE
description: United States District Judge David N. Edelstein refused yesterday to disqualify himself from the 13-year-old antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation. And at the hearing where he distributed the decision, he showed no sign of ending his inquiry on whether he is empowered to review - and possibly reject - the Government's Jan. 8 decision to drop the case.

title: McEnroe to Help Raise Queens Museum Funds
description: The Queens Museum has engaged John McEnroe to help solicit funds to match a $100,000 challenge grant awarded by the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: IS COLUMBIA FACING END OF A LONG CYCLE OF HITS?
description: In the language borrowed from gamblers that is perfectly appropriate to the movie industry, Columbia Pictures has been ''on a roll'' since ''The Blue Lagoon'' became the surprise hit of the summer two years ago. But success in Hollywood has always been cyclical, and the industry - with a considerable amount of malice and glee - is now betting that Columbia's luck is running out.

title: EMERGENCY PLAN WITHDRAWAL WILL COST ROCKLAND $100,000
description: The head of New York State's Disaster Preparedness Commission said today that Rockland County would have to return money it got from the state because of its withdrawal last night from an emergency plan developed for counties around Indian Point.

title: 4 Chicago Banks Join Forces
description: Four small Chicago area banks jointly announced today that they had combined their marketing and operational forces and would operate as a single entity called Affiliated Group Inc.

title: Market Place; How Copper Looks Now
description: INDUSTRIAL metals have been one of the most depressed sectors of the nation's economy, but they could present some opportunities for profit in a recovery. Although metal prices still remain at exceptionally low levels, analysts say it is not too early to start watching the metal markets and maybe to start building a position.

title: THE FALLACY BEHIND THE BALANCED-BUDGET FALLACY
description: To the Editor:

title: DONOVAN SAYS HE 'DEPLORES' DEATH THREAT TO SENATE AIDE
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said today that a reported telephone death threat against a Senate staff member investigating him ''saddens me and it angers me.''

title: A Winter Storm Eases In the Falkland Area
description: As winter closes in on the Falkland Islands, the weather in the South Atlantic has gradually worsened. Although a blackout of weather data from the area has impeded forecasters, F. Gordon Barnes, the meteorologist for the Cable News Network and WDVM-TV in Washington, has compiled data from passing ships, Argentina and Chile to assess conditions on the islands.

title: Trainer Confirms Aloma's Ruler for the Belmont
description: Aloma's Ruler, the winner of the Preakness Stakes last Saturday, will run in the Belmont Stakes on June 5, his trainer, Butch Lenzini, confirmed today.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 21, 1982
description: International Britain rejected an appeal from the United Nations for further negotiations on the Falkland Islands dispute, and the Cabinet was said to authorize the British battle fleet in the South Atlantic to open a new assault. In rejecting the appeal, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons that Argentina had in effect turned down Britain's final proposals for a settlement and that ''it is inconceivable that they would now come genuinely to accept'' the ideas proposed Wednesday night by United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. (Page A1, Columns 3-6.) Argentina braced for a possible attack by Britain on the Falkland Islands, while Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez insisted that Argentina still considered the United Nations mediation effort to be alive. ''Argentina is engaged in the mission of the Secretary General, and it continues to insist upon his mission,'' the Foreign Minister said at a news conference, apparently before learning that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said tonight in New York that his peace efforts had failed. (A1:4-5.)

title: Bath Iron Works
description: The Bath Iron Works Corporation, a subsidiary of the Congoleum Corporation, said yesterday that it had been awarded a $300 million contract by the Navy to construct combat cruisers.

title: Ford Points To Savings
description: Hourly workers at the Ford Motor Company's Dearborn, Mich., glass plant saved the auto maker half a million dollars by building a cost-saving windshield oven and production line in less time than outside contractors had estimated, according to Ford's president.

title: Albeck Re-Signed
description: Putting to rest earlier reports that he might be leaving San Antonio, Stan Albeck was re-signed as coach of the Spurs yesterday. Angelo Drossos, the owner, said that the contract was for three years.

title: WATT TURNS HIS BUFFALO TO THE RIGHT
description: Since 1849 the American buffalo on the Department of Interior's official seal has been facing left. Now, Interior Secretary James G. Watt has set things right.

title: Cubs Rout Dodgers
description: Chicago's Ferguson Jenkins limited Los Angeles to six hits and finished one strikeout short of becoming the seventh pitcher to record 3,000 in a career as the Cubs beat the Dodgers, 8-3, tonight.

title: STUDENTS TO VISIT 'VILLAGE' AFTER ALL
description: After a Massachusetts school board voted Tuesday to ban Greenwich Village from the itinerary of high school students who will visit New York next week, the board reversed itself yesterday and accepted an invitation from the president of New York University, Dr. John Brademas, to include the Village on the tour.

title: WOOLWORTH APPOINTS HEAD FOR BRITISH UNIT
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it had sent one of its most senior executives to head its ailing British subsidiary, F.W. Woolworth P.L.C.

title: ART: A BROAD SURVEY OF AMERICAN STILL-LIFES
description: ARTISTS always did it, of course, rendering on canvas with relish the sensuous forms of flowers, fruits, vegetables, game and other matter. And popular audiences always loved it. But until late in the 19th century, critics, connoisseurs and artists themselves considered still life the lowest form of painting. A rigid hierarchy existed: the loftiest work dealt with allegorical and epic subjects; the imitative portrayal of inanimate objects was seen as distinctly bottom-drawer.

title: OPEC DIVIDED ON OUTPUT
description: OPEC oil ministers expressed sharply different views today about whether to abandon their two-month-old program to limit output by the 13 member nations, now that falling prices seem to have stabilized.

title: 2 Educators Freed in Poland
description: A Warsaw University dean and another educator were released from internment after a written protest from faculty members, university sources said today. The educators, who were released Monday after three days' internment, were among 43 persons officially reported interned after last week's demonstrations against martial law.

title: A MANILA CONNECTION
description: Here is the story of an ostensibly local crime that may be linked to the repressive Marcos regime in the Philippines and possibly could lead to high places in Washington:

title: SUIT ON HOMELESS MENTAL PATIENTS ASKS NEW YORK STATE FOR HOUSING
description: A class-action suit was filed against the state yesterday on behalf of the estimated 6,000 homeless men and women who have been released from state psychiatric hospitals and now live on the streets of New York City.

title: ONE FURTHER STEP
description: The Soviet propaganda agency, Tass, today inadvertently graced the suppressed workers' movement in Poland with a new title: Solidarity is now officially recognized as ''the Underground.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Housing Finance Corp. plans a public offering of $100 million of state-assisted mortgage bonds series F, due in 1992, through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: GOV. BROWN LINKS HIS FUTURE TO ISSUE OF A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has wrapped his political future in the nuclear freeze issue, seizing on a question that transcends fruit flies, controversial appointments to state jobs and a public impression that he too easily shifts positions.

title: Spanish Duchess to Divorce
description: The Duchess of Cadiz, granddaughter of the Spanish leader Francisco Franco, is expecting a divorce from her husband Prince Alfonso of Borbon, a family spokesman said today. She married the Prince, a first cousin of King Juan Carlos, in 1972.

title: Britain Reports Crash Of Fleet Helicopter in Chilean Territory
description: A British Sea King helicopter has crashed in Chile ''in appalling weather'' while on reconnaissance patrol, the Ministry of Defense disclosed tonight.

title: ART SONGS: WILLIAM PARKER
description: WILLIAM PARKER'S knowledge of art songs and of the means of achieving correct performances of them has impressed experienced listeners on both sides of the Atlantic since he first started winning vocal competitions in the 70's. A baritone with a voice of pleasing quality, he is a excellent musician and is ever attentive to the words he sings, having schooled himself sufficiently in the standard languages to sing intelligently in several of them.

title: Death Penalty Bill Pressed in Jersey
description: New Jersey moved closer to reinstituting capital punishment for convicted murderers when the Assembly Judiciary Committee voted 4 to 1 today to approve a bill passed by the Senate.

title: News Analysis
description: Last year, Congress converted to a faith that emphasized the fiscal values of lower taxes and lower Federal spending, in all areas but national defense. But this year, confronted by a slumping economy and impending elections, many lawmakers are reviving the old-time religion that preaches Government responsibility for stimulating the economy in times of distress.

title: Lawyer Lends an Operatic Note to His Argument
description: There was snickering among members of the jury when Steve Jerome, attorney for Robert Infante, accused of kicking a dent in a neighbor's car, sang an operatic aria in his closing argument.

title: LAKERS GAIN NO. 1 DRAFTEE
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, who have already reached the National Basketball Association championship series for the second time in three seasons, yesterday won a coin flip with the San Diego Clippers for the right to the first selection in the college draft June 29.

title: AIDE OUTLINES GAP WITH BRITAIN
description: The Argentine military braced today for a possible British assault on the Falkland Islands, while Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez insisted that Argentina still considered the United Nations mediation effort to be alive.

title: REPORTEDLY AUTHORIZE ATTACK; U.S. EARMARKS CONTINGENCY AID
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today rejected a United Nations appeal for further negotiations on the Falkland Islands dispute. The Cabinet was said to have authorized the British battle fleet in the South Atlantic to open a new offensive.

title: LOOM OPERETTA: STRAUSS'S 'NIGHT IN VENICE'
description: THE new production by the Light Opera of Manhattan of Johann Strauss's ''A Night in Venice,'' which opened at the Eastside Playhouse this month, came across as a briskly animated piece of stage business in a performance Wednesday night, even if the musical execution was weak in places and the new book by William Mount-Burke and Alice Hammerstein Mathias proved a sophomoric and rather inconsistent affair.

title: Alumina Plant
description: An official of Alcan Aluminium Ltd. disclosed that Alcan, Atlantic Richfield and Shell were partners in a $1 billion alumina plant now under construction in Aughinish, Ireland.

title: Money Funds Post Gain; Assets of Money Market Funds Set Mark
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds reached a record $196.24 billion for the week ended Wednesday, up $2.17 billion from the week before, according to the Investment Company Institute, the industry's trade organization based in Washington. The number of funds reporting grew to a record 203, with the addition of three new general-purpose funds.

title: CITY SETS UP GUIDELINES ON TOWN HALL MEETINGS
description: The Koch administration has prepared guidelines for the Mayor's ''town hall'' meetings under which spectators would be admitted on a first-come, first-served basis and could not be excluded because of a suspicion that they would try to disrupt the meeting.

title:
USE A SMALL U.N. FORCE;
The iron dice are rolling again.  Britain and Argentina are lurching toward war. Is there hope left for an interim solution? There is, in the opinion of several senior United Nations officials. The time is ripe, they believe, for creation of a small United Nations peace force. Such a presence in the Falkland Islands could buy time and save lives. Both sides could agree to the stationing of the soldier-administrators there while they resolved their differences diplomatically. Moreover, history provides a striking analogy: the West New Guinea crisis of 1962.
description: West New Guinea, a Pacific island, had been a Dutch colony since the 19th century. But when Indonesia achieved independence in 1949, President Sukarno claimed the territory. The Dutch refused to give it up, and a decade of negotiations yielded no solution. In 1962, fighting erupted between Dutch and Indonesian forces. The United States was caught in the middle between a North Atlantic Treaty Organization member and a third-world country. The Soviet Union took President Sukarno's side and provided Indonesia with critical intelligence. War seemed inevitable then, as it does now in the South Atlantic.

title: Convicted Robber Given Long Term
description: A 31-year-old Hempstead man was declared a persistent felony offender today and sentenced in Nassau County Court to 25 years to life for the armed robbery of a travel agency.

title: Storm Suspends Golf
description: Larry Nelson and Keith Fergus shot sixunder-par 66's today and shared the first-round lead of the $300,000 Atlanta Golf Classic when play was suspended because of an electrical storm. Fifty-four players in the 156-man field failed to complete the round and were scheduled to resume play at 7:30 A.M. Friday. The second-round play will start one-half hour later.

title: G.M.-Toyota Pact Denied
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company ended their second round of talks on joint production of small-model autos in the United States without reaching any concrete agreement, a Toyota spokesman said.

title: Net Off 89.3% At Associated
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, New York, which operates the Lord & Taylor, Caldor and other store divisions, said yesterday that it had an 89.3 percent drop in net income in its first quarter ended May 1, to $469,000, or 3 cents a share, from $4.4 million, or 32 cents a share, in the comparable 1981 period. Net sales, including the Caldor subsidiary acquired in the 1981 second quarter, were up 41.2 percent, to $641.2 million, from $454.1 million.

title: ARCHEOLOGISTS SEARCH FOR A CHRONICLE OF NEW YORK
description: He died in 1771, but the old sea captain's warning still accosts the unwary passer-by: Stop Passenger nor pass unthoughtfully, For what you are that lately too was

title: SEOUL CABINET SHUFFLED AFTER SCANDAL
description: President Chun Doo Hwan appointed a new Cabinet today after all his ministers tendered their resignations in the wake of a financial scandal that led to calls for Mr. Chun's resignation from opposition and church leaders.

title: U.S.-Thai War Games Set
description: Warplanes, 28 naval vessels and more than 8,000 Thai and American military personnel will begin military exercises in the Gulf of Siam next month, officials announced today. The two-week exercise, called ''Cobra Gold 82,'' is designed to ''enhance the spirit of cooperation and readiness of the naval forces of both countries,'' the United States Embassy said. The war games, which will include naval operations and amphibious landings on the Thai coast, are scheduled for June 2-14, although some smaller-scale activities will start at the end of this month.

title: At Fordham Graduation, Poetic Innovation
description: When officials at Fordham University invited the Irish poet Seamus Heaney to deliver this spring's commencement address this Sunday, they found that Mr. Heaney not only gladly accepted but that he also promised to give the address entirely in verse.

title: A HOROWITZ SPECIAL FROM LONDON
description: THE weekend's truly special event takes place tomorrow at 9 P.M. on WNET-TV with the satellite transmission of ''Horowitz in London: A Royal Concert.'' Taped only a few hours earlier at London's Royal Festival Hall, the performance will mark the 77-year-old Vladimir Horowitz's first European concert in 31 years. At the invitation of Prince Charles, the renowned pianist will perform for the benefit of the Royal Opera House. The program is scheduled to include compositions by Schumann, Scarlatti, Chopin and Rachmaninoff. Tickets in London, incidentally, are selling for $100 to $200 each. A stereo simulcast will be carried on radio station WNCN-FM.

title: HOUSE APROVES FUND TO HELP THRIFT INDUSTRY
description: The House of Representatives, struggling to find a way to help the ailing savings and loan industry, today approved a bill that would set up an $8.5 billion fund to bolster savings and loan associations crippled by high interest rates.

title: Cemetery Workers Granted $25 Raise
description: Gravediggers and groundskeepers in 70 cemeteries in the New York metropolitan area will receive wage increases of $25 a week in each year of a three-year contract under an arbitration award announced yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AM International Inc. announced that creditors of its Canadian unit had agreed to continue regular operations while it works out a plan of payment, in accordance with the provisions of the Canadian Bankruptcy Act.

title: 6 PATRONS OF THE ARTS RECEIVE MAYOR'S AWARD OF HONOR
description: In a gathering last night at Gracie Mansion that he termed ''dazzling,'' Mayor Koch presided over the sixth Mayor's Awards of Honor for Arts and Culture, honoring six patrons of the arts for their contributions to New York's cultural life.

title: Architect Leads Tour
description: A stop at the tallest building in Brooklyn, the Williamsburgh Savings Bank, is included on a tour called ''A Bird's Eye View of New York City,'' sponsored today by the 92d Street Y. Stops will also be made at Yeshiva University, the Riverside Church, Marcus Garvey Memorial Park and the Claridge House, a high-rise building at 87th Street and Third Avenue.

title: ART: 'BURCHFIELD'S SEASONS
description: ''BURCHFIELD'S SEASONS,'' at the Kennedy Galleries, 40 West 57th Street, is an exhibition of watercolors made over nearly half a century by a painter who at his best had a great deal to say about both landscape and townscape in his native America.

title: DRYSDALE: CONFUSION REIGNS
description: Even before it failed to pay $160 million in interest due to about 30 securities firms early this week, Drysdale Government Securities had attracted more attention than appeared warranted by its size and history.

title: SENATE TURNS BACK EFFORTS TO MODIFY TAX CUTS FOR 1983
description: The Republican-controlled Senate Friday overwhelmingly rejected Democratic efforts to repeal or defer the third stage of the income tax cut.

title: PERCY THREATENS EL SALVADOR WITH AID CUTOFF
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, warned today that ''not one cent of funds shall go to the Government of El Salvador'' if that nation suspends a land redistribution program.

title: NO FUSS AT MEETING OF JWT
description: The news at the JWT Group's annual meeting yesterday was that there were no fireworks. When Don Johnston, chairman and chief executive, who had weathered months of crisis over $30 million worth of computer manipulation, asked for questions at the end of the meeting, there were none.

title: ITALIAN AMERICANS CRITICIZE THEIR PORTRAYAL ON TELEVISION
description: A research report issued under the auspices of the Commission for Social Justice, an arm of the Order of Sons of Italy, maintains that Italian-Americans are not portrayed fairly on American television.

title: Economic Scene; A Summit Brief For Reagan
description: Here is one man's proposed brief for President Reagan to carry to the economic summit conference at Versailles on June 4-6: The Europeans, Japanese and Canadians are increasingly worried about the economic crisis and the danger of its tearing the Western alliance apart. Even more than they did a year ago at Ottawa, they are blaming the United States for aggravating the crisis by pursuing fiscal and monetary policies that have kept interest rates so high. It would be a mistake for you to try to brush their worries aside. It would be far better to acknowledge the real threat to the Western alliance.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Food Notes column of The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified a Manhattan cheese distributor. It is the Marcel Akselrod Company, 530 West 25th Street, New York, N.Y. 10001 (telephone 675-7777).

title: Proxmire Seeks Inquiry Into H.U.D. Project Sales
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, has asked the General Accounting Office to investigate the selling of housing projects by the Department of Housing and Urban Development without competitive bidding.

title: HOUSING SURGE ALTERS BOROUGH PARK
description: Over the last five years, the Borough Park section of Brooklyn has become one of the most ambitious centers of residential real estate activity in the city.

title: Davis, a Yank 'Exile,' Returns
description: Millie Davis performed minor surgery on her husband's head the other day. Millie, wife of Ron, the former Yankee relief pitcher now with the Minnesota Twins, cut off most of the curls that had adorned his head.

title: MOROCCAN PLAYS DOWN TALKS ON U.S. USE OF MILITARY BASE
description: Morocco's Foreign Minister appeared today to minimize the meaning and extent of a proposed agreement with Washington that would allow United States forces to use Moroccan military facilities.

title: House Votes for Mint To Make Olympic Coins
description: The House voted today in favor of eliminating middlemen in the domestic sale of commemorative coins to support the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles.

title: Mets Off to Best Start Since '76
description: ''So far, so good.'' The words came from George Bamberger, the manager, with regard to the somewhat exalted status of his Mets, who won nine of the 13 games played in a two-week stand at Shea Stadium that concluded Wednesday night.

title: U.S. and Soviet Resume European Missile Talks
description: After a two-month recess, the United States and the Soviet Union resumed negotiations today on limiting intermediaterange nuclear arms in Europe.

title: PIONEER IN RADAR
description: Merle A. Tuve, a physicist whose experiments with short-pulse radio waves have been accepted as the basis for the development of radar, died yesterday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 80 years old.

title: Bridge: A Novice Outdid Another In the New York Pro-Am
description: When experts play with inexperienced players, as happened in the New York Pro-Am event, eyebrows -and blood pressure, too - tend to rise. In general, the experts make a valiant effort to restrain themselves and save their horror stories to tell the other experts later.

title: Rumania to China on the East Side.
description: THE Cadillacs and Rolls-Royces are still double parked along the otherwise dark and deserted street, the blue-glass seltzer bottles and pitchers of golden chicken fat shimmer on the tables, walls are hung with a rag-bag of memorabilia and the singing of Jewish and Israeli folk songs continues at the same ear-shattering pitch - all instant assurances that Sammy's Rumanian-Jewish (but not kosher) restaurant is playing to packed houses.

title: Racing Indictments Seen
description: A year-old investigation into possible race-fixing involving the drugging of harness horses at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways in 1978 is expected to result in several indictments ''in the next month or so, if Washington approves,'' a source close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Quakes Jolt Eastern Turkey
description: More than 50 mud-and-brick houses in a half-dozen villages collapsed in a series of earthquakes in the eastern Turkish province of Erzurum on Wednesday, newspapers reported today. No casualties were reported.

title: F.A.A. Denies It Is Unfair
description: Officials of the Federal Aviation Administration denied today charges by airlines that they were being unfair in awarding the landing rights made vacant last week when Braniff Airways suspended its flights.

title: TEXT OF BRITISH GOVERNMENT DOCUMENT ON THE FALKLAND ISLANDS NEGOTIATIONS
description: Following is the text of a British Government document, entitled ''The Falkland Islands: Negotiations for a Peaceful Settlement,'' and two appendixes issued today by the Foreign Office: Argentine Aggression

title: IN SEARCH OF ADVENTURE OFF BROADWAY
description: FROM the nightmarish vision of violence and death in Tadeusz Kantor's ''Weilopole Weilopole'' to the erotic tableaux vivants of The Talking Band, there is an alluring array of visual and aural imagery on Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway stages this weekend. And, for variety, there is even more than a measure of verbal wit, as in Romulus Linney's ''Goodbye, Howard'' and Jonathan Reynolds's ''Geniuses.''

title: EXECUTIVE AT AMERICAN SWITCHES TO AIR FLORIDA
description: Donald J. Lloyd-Jones, a senior vice president for operations of American Airlines and a former business school lecturer at Columbia University, was appointed president of Air Florida yesterday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an error by a Federal spokesman, a United Press International article yesterday incorrectly reported the employment status of Dr. Marc J. Straus, a cancer researcher. He is on the staff of New York Medical College in Valhalla, N.Y. An article appears on page A16.

title: GUTIERREZ WINS FISHER PRIZE
description: Horacio Gutierrez, the pianist, is the winner of the 1982 Avery Fisher Prize. The prize, announced yesterday, consists of $10,000, engagements with the New York Philharmonic and the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society and a solo recital at Avery Fisher Hall in the Great Performers Series.

title: Midway Airlines
description: Midway Airlines, a Chicago-based carrier, said it was canceling a $20 million conditional order placed in 1979 with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for two DC-9-80 aircraft.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ANDREW GOODMAN really turned 75 years old back on Feb. 13, but neverm ind. He was feted at a birthday party this week the likes of which f ew New Yorkers will ever see. There were almost 900 guests at the N ew York Hilton, plus strolling mimes and jugglers, hundreds of b lack and white balloons, flashing colored lights, a fog machine, s parklers and a stage decorated with a nighttime setting of Manhattans urrounded by scores of twinkly lights.

title: POLICE ARREST 107 IN MARIJUANNA RAIDS AT 74 PLACES IN CITY
description: The police raided 74 storefronts in four boroughs yesterday in which marijuana and hashish were sold, arrested 107 persons and confiscated $20,000 in drugs, a police spokesman said.

title: Who Shares Chase Loss
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank might reduce dividends and some bonuses to help recover some of its $135 million second-quarter loss from the failure of Drysdale Government Securities to pay interest on Government securities, Wall Street analysts said yesterday.

title: OBSTACLE COURSE
description: According to Donald J. Trump, the real-estate man, he and his father, Fred, happened to be out at one of their buildings in Forest Hills, Queens, one day last fall when they saw some victims of cerebral palsy trying to make their way up and down stairs in the lobby.

title: Required Reading;  Describing 'Dense Pack'
description: Discussion of ''Dense Pack,'' a proposal to cluster missile silos, from ''Challenges for United States National Security,'' a report by the staff of the Carnegie Panel on U.S. Security and the Future of Arms Control:

title: Mayor Says 7 Slayings Rekindle Fear in Atlanta
description: The unsolved slayings of seven young black women here have rekindled fears lingering from a 22-month string of killings of young black males that ended last year, Mayor Andrew Young says.

title: ARGENTINES SAY PLANES ARE SET TO STRIKE
description: Argentine military officers said today that the nation's air force was poised to launch a heavy counterattack in the event of any British invasion of the Falkland Islands.

title: CBS Boston Unit
description: New England Television Corporation signed an agreement to continue as the CBS affiliate in the Boston market, taking over Channel 7 on Saturday. New England Television, which purchased the building and assets of the station for $22 million from RKO General Inc., will change the call letters from WNAC-TV to WNEV-TV. RKO General lost the right to operate Channel 7 after the Federal Communications Commission ruled that it had failed to disclose that its parent, the General Tire and Rubber Company, was under investigation for bribery and illegal political contributions.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day on May 3 listing quarterly earnings for 271 cor- porations incorrectly showed the per- cent change of McGraw-Hill's net in- come between the first quarters last year and this year. The company's net earnings rose 11 percent.

title: Dart & Kraft Centers
description: Dart & Kraft Inc.'s food service group said today that it will close six distribution centers by the end of June. It will close centers in Boston, New Orleans and Portland and select independent distributors to deliver its products in those areas. It will also close centers in Birmingham, Ala., Milan, Ill., and Pittsburgh, and consolidate those operations with Atlanta, Chicago and Cleveland, respectively.

title: U.S. MINE UNIT SETS MINIMUM $20 FINE
description: Despite a threat by the head of the miners' union to call a job walkout in protest, the Reagan Administration announced today that it was putting into effect a revised Federal rule permitting fines of $20 for first offenses of minor safety violations.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL COMPLETES PURCHASE
description: The Florida National Banks of Florida Inc. announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of the Alliance Corporation, a mortgage banking concern based in Jacksonville.

title: DEBUSSCHERE TAKES HELM WITH BROWN, PLEDGES TO REBUILD
description: Dave DeBusschere, a major catalyst during the glory days of the Knicks, and Hubie Brown, a successful coach with the Kentucky Colonels and the Atlanta Hawks, joined forces yesterday to rebuild the Knicks. DeBusschere will head the new management team as executive vice president and director of basketball operations, and Brown will be the new coach, replacing Red Holzman.

title: OR PERHAPS WE SHOULD LYNCH SIRHAN SIRHAN?
description: To the Editor:

title: IBM Japan Ltd.
description: IBM Japan Ltd., a unit of the International Business Machines Corporation, said it was holding talks with the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company but would not elaborate on a report in the newspaper Tokyo Shimbun that the talks concerned a possible joint venture to make personal computers in Japan. The newspaper said that I.B.M. would submit a formal proposal on the joint venture before the end of the year. Matsushita declined to comment.

title: VENEZUELANS TO PERFORM
description: Sacred and traditional Venezuelan music will be preformed by the Young Voices and Bows of Caracas (Arcos Y Voces de Caracas) tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street. The young musicians, 7 to 17 years old, are from the Colegio Emil Friedman in Caracas; Dr. Friedman founded the music school in 1949. Conducted by Daniel Bernard, the 85-member ensemble will also perform Mozart's Mass in C (K. 317) Admission is free.

title: Francine Jody Bye Married To James Edward Vogel
description: Francine Jody Bye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore S. Bye of Woodmere, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Woodmere Club to James Edward Vogel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven E. Vogel of New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple Emanu-El in New York performed the ceremony.

title: TEXT OF U.N. LEADER'S LETTER
description: Following is the text of a letter today from Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to the President of the Security Council, Ling Qing of China:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have decided to put an end to the efforts I started on my own.'' - Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. (A12:1.)

title: TIME OF CHALLENGE FOR RISING STARS OF BALLET THEATER
description: AUDIENCES this weekend will have ample opportunity to see Susan Jaffe and Robert La Fosse, who are the darlings of the crowds at American Ballet Theater these days. Critics are impressed, too. The 20-year-old Miss Jaffe has a long, tapering line, a glowing confidence on stage and dark, sultry good looks. Mr. La Fosse, who is 22, has the look of a knowing angel and attacks each role with an innate sense of theater and a keen analytical eye. Their company director likes them, too.

title: Hutton Loses Case
description: A commodities investor has won a $1.1 million judgment against the E.F. Hutton Group Inc. and a former salesman for the firm who was charged with having made excessive trades in the customer's account to generate commissions.

title: FRANCE WEIGHS NEW BRITISH STATUS IN MARKET
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today that France was drawing up suggestions for a possible new status for Britain in the European Economic Community as a way out of the crisis this week.

title: Takeda, Upjohn And Abbott in Tie
description: Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries of Japan announced plans to develop in the United States, Canada and Latin America an antidiabetes compound discovered by Takeda.

title: AUSTRALIA'S FRASER CALLS FOR LOWERING OF PROTECTIONIST TRADE BARRIERS
description: Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser of Australia has called for a reduction in protectionist trade barriers as a ''dramatic and imaginative'' step to pull the Western alliance out of ''economic conditions which are extremely grim.''

title: THE FALLACY BEHIND THE BALANCED-BUDGET FALLACY
description: To the Editor:

title: India and China End Round of Border Talks
description: India and China ended four days of talks today, still sharply divided over a 20-year-old boundary dispute, a spokesman for the Indian Government said.

title: Article 152571 -- No Title
description: Two former vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank and two businessmen were indicted by a New York grand jury yesterday on charges of stealing more than $18 million from the bank in 1979 and 1980, mainly through a series of fraudulent loans.

title: BROOKLYN REHABILITATION ENTERPRENEURS
description: Over cheesecake at Junior's, a Brooklyn restaurant, Daniel Greenbaum and Allen Handelman sealed their real estate partnership in January 1981. They agreed to seek out Brooklyn properties for rehabilitation and resale as cooperatives.

title: FOREIGN CLOSINGS
description: The following stock markets were closed yesterday in observance of the Ascension Day holiday: Amsterdam, Brussels, Frankfurt, Johanesburg, Paris and Zurich.

title: NEW ROCHELLE PACT PAVES WAY FOR CONDOMINIUMS
description: City officials signed an agreement here Wednesday that could lead to the transfer of ownership of Davids Island to a developer in return for construction of high-priced condominiums that could double New Rochelle's taxable real estate. The island is an abandoned but lush 80-acre site 1,500 feet offshore.

title: PSYCHOLOGICAL TESTING OF HINCKLEY SAID TO SHOW LONG MENTAL ILLNESS
description: John W. Hinckley Jr.'s scores on a standard psychological test, less than a week after he shot President Reagan, were ''extraordinarily high'' on ''the scale of mental illness,'' a defense psychologist testified today.

title: 'Rock 'n' Roll: First 5,000 Years' coming in the fall.
description: ''ROCK 'N' ROLL: THE FIRST 5,000 YEARS'' - don't worry; it is a tentative title - will arrive on Broadway in the fall. It will be directed and choreographed by Joe Layton, and the producers will be Jules Fisher and Annie Farge. Mr. Layton is at home with the visual; you do not necessarily whistle the scenery in one of his shows, although you generally remember how it looked - ''Barnum,'' for instance. or ''George M!'' Obviously, a show with ''Rock 'n' Roll'' in the title is built around sound, but its look, multimedia, is important, too. It is the kind of production that the producers call ''an event'' rather than ''a musical.''

title: Man With a Grenade Seizes 109 on Jetliner in Philippines
description: A man with a hand grenade, demanding better conditions for sugar workers and coconut farmers, held 109 people hostage aboard a Philippine Airlines jet today, an airline spokesman said.

title: The U.N. Today; May 21, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. on Seychelles. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BRITISH PLANNERS SAID TO FAVOR DIRECT ASSAULT
description: A British military source said today that Britain had decided, in a shift of strategy, to strike at the main Argentine military positions on the Falkland Islands.

title: One-Man Radio Station Loses 5-Year Fight to Keep License
description: The Federal Communications Commission today revoked the license of a one-man radio station, ending a fiveyear fight by the owner to retain it.

title: Bechtel Rail Line
description: Bechtel Civil and Minerals Inc., a San Francisco-based engineering and construction company, announced that it would build a $40 million rail line to transport coal and limestone from Lockport, N.Y., to a new 625-megawatt electric generating station near Somerset, N.Y. Bechtel, a subsidiary of Bechtel Group Inc., was awarded the project by the Somerset Railroad Corporation, a subsidiary of New York State Electric and Gas Company. Construction of the 16-mile line will begin in June and should be completed by late 1983.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LULU IN HOLLYWOOD. By Louise Brooks. With an Introduction by Wil- liam Shawn. 109 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $15.

title: Breathing Problem
description: A growth of mucous membrane in his nasal passages has given Johnny Bench, the Cincinnati Reds' veteran slugger, increasing problems in breathing.

title: Snipes to Resume
description: Renaldo Snipes, looking to stay in the heavyweight title picture after an injury that almost ended his career last year, will face Tim Witherspoon in Las Vegas, Nev., on June 5. Snipes had received a severe gash on his arm during a post-fight scuffle last October after he had nearly upset Larry Holmes in a World Boxing Council title bout. Snipes was out of action until March.

title: DOCTOR DENIES ROLE IN FRAUD
description: Dr. Marc J. Straus, a cancer researcher barred from getting Federal funds after acknowledging false reports in a study under his name, asserted his innocence today. He said he had ''never been a party'' to fraud.

title: REGROUPINGS; Merger Medicine
description: A spirit of ecumenical cooperation, abetted by self-interest, may just save two valued Brooklyn hospitals - St. John's Episcopal and Brooklyn Jewish. Their governing boards have tentatively agreed on a merger that may avert bankruptcy and serve a community in need.

title: A NICHE FOR NURSES IN COGNITIVE MEDICINE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Not Afraid' in the subway.
description: ''WE ARE NOT AFRAID'' is the title of a new work by the artist Les Levine, and it's on view in the New York subway, where a great many people are afraid. The picture, a color photograph, is of a young couple - the man Chinese, the woman Japanese - looking out at the world, a sunset behind them. What the two are not afraid of (The nuclear finale? Muggers? Unemployment?) is up to the viewer to decide.

title: Bossy Sees 'Dynasty'
description: Some Islanders may wince when they hear ''dynasty,'' but not Mike Bossy. Receiving the Conn Smythe Trophy at ceremonies in Manhattan yesterday as the most valuable player in the Stanley Cup playoffs, Bossy said that now that the Islanders had won three consecutive championships, there was no reason for them to feel they could not keep winning them. ''I'd like to win 10 in a row,'' he said.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: Ever since he started his professional career singing with Earl Hines's band at El Grotto Supper Club in Chicago 35 years ago, Johnny Hartman has been identified as a jazz singer. But he disagrees with the tag.

title: MAX STERN, HARTZ MOUNTAIN FOUNDER AND PATRON OF EDUCATION, DIES
description: Max Stern, founder and chairman of the board of the Hartz Mountain Products Corporation and a philanthropist and fund-raiser for Jewish education, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Jorge Blanco Declared The Dominican Victor
description: Salvador Jorge Blanco was officially declared the winner today of the Presidential election held last Sunday. His main opponent, former President Joaquin Balaguer, conceded after the Central Elections Board made the declaration.

title: Grolier Book Show
description: Books, manuscripts, prints and drawings from the Library Company of Philadelphia, the oldest library in the country, will be on view through June 17 at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street.

title: Auto Output At 1982 High
description: The major domestic auto makers' weekly production of cars has reached its highest level of the year, but year-to-date production remains 28.6 percent behind last year, a trade journal reported today.

title: APPEALS COURT REJECTS TRUMP TAX BREAK
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that Donald J. Trump, the developer, was not entitled to a multimillion-dollar tax abatement for the 59-story office and condominium tower he is constructing on the site of the old Bonwit Teller store in midtown Manhattan.

title: G.& W. Unit Sets $300 Million Credit
description: The Associates Corporation of North America, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, said it had arranged a $300 million revolving credit and term loan facility with a group of 41 banks, led by First National Bank Of Chicago.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 21, 1982; International
description: OPEC oil ministers, meeting in Quito, Ecuador, disagreed over whether their two-month program of production limitations should be continued. The split developed as the officials celebrated the apparent success of the program in stabilizing declining world oil prices by cutting production. (Page D1.)

title: SQUADRON AT EASE, MEMORIES AT THE READY
description: The last time Maj. Gen. Lawrence R. Dewey had inspected Squadron A was in May 1938. The troopers, in crisp uniforms, buttons agleam, had trembled in awe of this West Point-trained descendant of Adm. George Dewey as they waited by their chargers.

title: 2 Israelis to Sing
description: Yehoram Gaon and Hanna Aroni, well known singers in Israel and abroad, will appear onstage together for the first time tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. and Sunday at 2:30.

title: LATIN DIPLOMATS WATCHING TO SEE WHAT U.S. WILL DO
description: Latin American diplomats watched closely today for some indication whether the Reagan Administration would renew its efforts to negotiate a settlement in the Falkland Islands conflict or would cast its lot more actively on the British side.

title: Airport Seeks Braniff Eviction
description: The governing board of the Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport voted to ask a Federal bankruptcy judge for permission to evict Braniff International from its airport facilities and headquarters building.

title: Brewers 4, Angels 1
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Run-scoring doubles by Don Money and Ben Oglivie helped Milwaukee to a three-run first inning, and Moose Haas pitched a six-hitter to end California's six-game winning streak. Money's hit scored Paul Molitor, who had singled, and Cecil Cooper, who had doubled. Oglivie's hit off the losing pitcher, Geoff Zahn (5-2), scored Money for Oglivie's first run batted in since May 9.

title: JAZZ: SPHERE QUARTET'S DEBUT
description: A QUARTET called Sphere, which takes its name from Thelonious Sphere Monk, might be expected to focus on Mr. Monk's music, particularly because it includes two long-term veterans of Mr. Monk's groups - the tenor saxophonist Charlie Rouse and the drummer Ben Riley.

title: Bank Is Suing 88 Utilities
description: The Chemical Bank of New York has asked the King County Superior Court to rule that 88 Northwest utilities that sponsored two nuclear projects that have since been canceled be forced to pay off the bonds for $2.25 billion invested in the plants. The bank is the bond-fund trustee for the Washington Public Power Supply System nuclear plants 4 and 5 at Hanford and Satsop, Wash.

title: STAGE: SCENES OF BOHEME
description: ANTHONY GIARDINA'S new comedy, which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club, announces one of its grave ailments with its title -''Scenes From La Vie de Boheme.''
