This work, a tale of young artists struggling to find themselves in contemporary New York, is indeed a three-act collection of scenes, not a play.

title: Of 2 Washingtons
description: ''Of all the 50 states, only Washington State has not been honored by having a Washington, D.C., street or avenue named for it,'' said Gov. John Spellman of Washington, and he's demanding that something be done about it.

title: POLITICAL LOYALTY TESTS HALTED
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block ordered an end to political loyalty tests for Government scientists today, reversing a practice that had been revived for the first time since the 1950's.

title: LOUISVILLIANS STRUGGLING IN FIGHT AGAINST POVERTY
description: Thousands of horse-racing enthusiasts gathered here recently for the 108th Kentucky Derby, attracted by the pageantry of seeing the thoroughbreds run.

title: Mailgram Switch To Scali, McCabe
description: Trout & Reis, the positioning agency that never used the phone or the mails when it was possible to send a Western Union Mailgram, has lost the account anyway.

title: KNICKS' NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE AND THEIR COACH
description: When Dave DeBusschere was introduced at Madison Square Garden yesterday as the new executive vice president and director of basketball operations of the Knicks, Gerri DeBusschere, his wife of 14 years, watched with pride and wonder.

title: New Zealand Offers To Lend British a Ship
description: New Zealand has offered Britain its only operational frigate, the Canterbury, in order to release a British vessel for service in the South Atlantic, Prime Minister Robert Muldoon said here today.

title: TRAVEL AGENTS' AIRLINE POWER
description: When travel agents lose faith in an airline, as Braniff International can testify, the results can be disastrous. The nation's 19,000 agents sell 65 percent of all airline tickets, and a reluctance on their part to place travelers on a given flight shows up quickly in empty seats.

title: Topics; Regroupings; Zoological Intelligence
description: For nearly half a century Robert Moses' Central Park Zoo has functioned as a popular animal house of detention. The spectacle of lions and gorillas neurotically pacing their small, lifeless cells would have outraged the park's principal designer, Frederick Law Olmsted.

title: Prison Cells, and a Safety Valve
description: New Jersey is desperate for prison space. More than 8,300 prisoners are jammed into prisons built for 7,100. The recent removal of 500 convicts to the Fort Dix stockade and a new 400-bed prison planned for Camden offer some relief. But with the prison population likely to double by 1988, Gov. Thomas Kean wants a $168 million bond authorization to build 1,900 more cells.

title: TEXT OF FALKLAND SPEECH BY PRIME MINISTER THATCHER IN HOUSE OF COMMONS
description: Following is the text of a speech in the House of Commons today by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, as made available by her office:

title: Jan Stephenson Fined
description: Jan Stephenson, one of the leading golfers on the women's tour, is having difficulties professionally and privately. Miss Stephenson was fined $3,000 yesterday by John Laupheimer, the executive director of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, for appearing in a Tokyo tournament last week instead of competing with the tour in Atlanta.

title: Xerox Predicts Lower Profits
description: Xerox Corporation's president, David T. Kearns, speaking at the annual meeting in New York, said that earnings in Xerox's second quarter this year would be lower than the $158.7 million, or $1.88 a share, registered in the same period of 1981.

title: Sale of Atgets at Sotheby's.
description: SCORES of compelling works by such master photographers as Eugene Atget, Julia Margaret Cameron, Gustave Le Gray, Man Ray, Edward Steichen, Alfred Stieglitz, Josef Sudek, Edward Weston and Paul Outerbridge will highlight auctions in three New York galleries over the next several days.

title: Criminal Charges Dropped in Case
description: Judge Angelo J. Ingrassia of County Court today dismissed criminal charges against Carl Fulgenzi, Westchester County's suspended deputy commissioner of public safety services.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., has elected to its board Jane C. Pfeiffer, a management consultant and former chairman of the National Broadcasting Company.

title: Pen Sales Up 7.2% in 1981
description: The National Association of Writing Instrument Manufacturers reported yesterday that sales of pens rose 7.2 percent in 1981, to $781.7 million, from $728.6 million in 1980.

title: MORTGAGE BILL'S BIAS AGAINST OLDER HOMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: Pratt & Whitney said that six American and European companies would begin collaboration with it on the development of a new aircraft engine.

title: News Analysis
description: As the negotiations aimed at bringing peace to the South Atlantic collapsed tonight, documents made public here by the British reflected a gulf of misunderstanding and recrimination between Britain and Argentina.

title: HARVESTER LOSS WIDENS: FAILURE RUMORS DENIED
description: Amid widespread expectation that a bankruptcy announcement was imminent, the International Harvester Company today reported that its loss for the fiscal second quarter more than doubled from a year earlier, to $198.3 million, on sales of $1.5 billion, widening its deficit for the first six months of the fiscal year to $497.7 million.

title: Exhibition Recalls German Immigrants; Exhibition Remembers German Immigrants
description: German immigrants who settled in the East Village during the middle and late 1800's are the subject of ''Portrait of an Emigrant Community,'' an exhibition on view through May 29 at St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, Second Avenue at 10th Street. Among the 100 photographs, documents and other objects on display is an 1852 letter from Karl Steinway to his brother Theodore in Germany, describing life in New York.

title: William (Monk) Montgomery, Bass Player With Ellington
description: William (Monk) Montgomery, a leading jazz bass player, died of cancer today.

title: AMSTAR PRESIDENT ADD'S CHIEF'S POST
description: The Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest producer and distributor of sugar and other sweeteners, mostly under the Domino brand, said yesterday that Howard B. Wentz Jr., president and chief operating officer, had been elected chief executive officer effective July 1.

title: RESTITUTION PLAN IN MURDER CASES UPHELD IN JERSEY
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court yesterday upheld a law that allows the state to require payments to families of homicide victims as a condition of parole for convicted murderers. The court also set guidelines for such payments.

title: Kodak and China In Joint Venture
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it had entered into a cooperative agreement with China to assemble slide projectors at a plant in Shanghai.

title: VICE CHAIRMAN RESIGNS FROM HARVESTER
description: Ben H. Warren, the 56-year-old vice chairman of the International Harvester Company, has resigned, the company announced yesterday without elaboration. Mr. Warren, who has been with the giant farmequipment manufacturer for 32 years, will continue as a member of the company's board of directors.

title: PANEL SETS ASIDE PLAN TO WEAKEN INFORMATION ACT
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to leave the Freedom of Information Act substantially intact.

title: RETURN OF THE SANASARDO DANCE STYLE
description: ''Make it very clear and keep it sober,'' Paul Sanasardo called out the other day as he watched his new dance company move across the floor of his Chelsea studio. ''Some of these things are very new to you. I don't want anyone getting hurt.''

title: Turkey's Prime Minister Starts Visit to Cyprus
description: The Turkish Prime Minister, Bulent Ulusu, flew to northern Cyprus today with pledges of political and economic support for the Turkish Cypriots.

title: Friday; BIRTH OF A MUSEUM
description: The American Craft Museum at 44 West 53d Street is celebrating its 25th anniversary by giving birth - to an American Craft Museum II, in the lobby of International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street. It has opened three exhibitions - one at the new museum, two at the old -to mark the rebirth of papermaking by hand in the

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A MANDATE ON ALIENS THAT IMMIGRATION AUTHORITIES MUST OBEY
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: CAROL BURNETT is tickled. ''Annie,'' in which she plays the soused Miss Hannigan (keeper, if not protector, of a crowd of orphans), has come to town and brought Miss Burnett with it.

title: Ensearch to Buy Unit
description: The Ensearch Corporation plans to purchase Alaska International Constructors, the state's second-largest construction concern, Alaska International said today. The price was not disclosed. Alaska International is owned by Neil Bergt, chairman of Western Air Lines.

title: NICARAGUAN TROOPS ARE REPORTEDLY JOINING REBELS
description: A group of 11 Nicaraguan soldiers crossed into Costa Rica today with plans to join a rebel exile movement headed by the former Sandinist commander Eden Pastora, Costa Rican officials said today.

title: 'SECRET POLICEMAN' FROM MONTY PYTHON
description: ''THE SECRET POLICEMAN'S OTHER BALL,'' which opens today at the Sutton and other theaters, is a live-performance film starring John Cleese, Michael Palin, Graham Chapman and Terry Jones of the Monty Python troupe, plus their friends Peter Cook, Eleanor Bron and Pamela Stephenson, plus such musical performers as Eric Clapton, Pete Townshend, Sting, Jeff Beck and Phil Collins.

title: WINFIELD IS PLACED ON THE DISABLED LIST
description: Dave Winfield yesterday became the latest Yankee starter to be put on the disabled list. The Yankees placed Winfield on the 15-day list after moving Jerry Mumphrey to the 21-day list, which already had Rick Cerone and Doyle Alexander on it.

title: KNICKS' NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE AND THEIR COACH
description: When Hubie Brown, the new coach of the Knicks, was growing up in Elizabeth, N.J., he learned about poverty. His father worked variously as a dock foreman, a high school custodian and a maintenance man, sometimes seven days a week to make ends meet. The son remembered the struggle.

title: Puerto Rican 'Squatters' Leave Capitol Building
description: About 200 squatters who had taken refuge in the State Capitol Building after their shanty community had been razed by the police vacated the building today and went to a camp for the rehabilitation of drug addicts.

title: MIXED REVIEWS FOR NO.1 WOMAN AT WHITE HOUSE
description: ''This ain't so bad,'' Elizabeth H. Dole told guests at a dinner in her honor a few months ago. ''First chance I've had to open my mouth in 13 months.''

title: Mexico City Subway Fire
description: About 18 people were sent to hospitals for treatment of smoke inhalation Wednesday after a rubber tire of a subway car exploded and started a fire, the police said today.

title: Worker Is Slain Chasing Robber
description: A restaurant worker was shot and killed in midtown Manhattan last night when he and fellow workers chased a man who had attempted to hold up the restaurant where they worked, the police said.

title: Stocks Decline; Dow Off 3.42
description: The stock market declined moderately yesterday in active trading with several issues showing big price losses in response to corporate developments.

title: BINGHAM SAYS HE PLANS TO RETIRE
description: Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, a nineterm Democrat from the Bronx, said today that he would not seek reelection in November because a reapportionment plan approved by Governor Carey yesterday would mean an ''agonizing primary contest against a younger Democratic colleague with whom I have no quarrel.''

title: Judge Rejects Request By Burke for New Trial
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a request for a new trial by James Burke, one of five men convicted of taking part three years ago in a point-shaving scheme involving Boston College basketball games.

title: Boundary Asks Canada for Gas
description: A group of 14 gas distributors from the Northeastern United States said Wednesday that it was seeking to buy natural gas from Canada in line with Ottawa's recently liberalized export policies.

title: Drillers Heard
description: Peter Pocklington, who had threatened to dissolve the Edmonton Drillers, announced yesterday that he would continue to operate the franchise. The announcement followed a conference call with the other owners in the North American Soccer League.

title: FLEDGLING DESIGNERS CELEBRATE AS PRIZE WINNERS
description: For William B. Frawley and the 29 other winners of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union fashion design contest, yesterday was a great day. Mr. Frawley, 2l years old, took the bus from Hillsdale, N.J., as he does every day, to go to the Parsons School of Design, where he is studying.

title: NEW PROVIDENCE, NJ - The fighting in the South Atlantic has shed new light on the vital importance of aircraft carriers in modern warfare. In addition, the significant shortcomings of smaller, less costly carriers have been highlighted. This all underscores the need for such leviathans as the U.S.S. Nimitz - a need of which the Reagan Administration is keenly aware. Its fiscal 1983 budget request to Congress included funds for construction of two Nimitz-class vessels - the Navy now has three - which cost at least $2.5 billion each.
description: For many years, budget-conscious Senators and Representatives have argued that the day of the big flattop is nearing an end. They envision a need for several smaller mini-carriers, and when arguing for them cite both the cost and decreased vulnerability of such ships. But would smaller vessels be cost-effective? Could they project American sea power as effectively as Nimitz-class carriers? In an age of highly precise guided-missile technology, would they be any less susceptible to Soviet attack than Nimitz-class carriers?

title: Sports of The Times; The Biggest Rebound
description: THOUSANDS of words were uttered yesterday when the Knicks announced the return of Dave DeBusschere, this time as executive vice president, and the arrival of Hubie Brown as the new coach. But the most important development for the Knicks' future was never put into so many words, only into sly smiles or raised eyebrows. The most important development is that Dave DeBusschere, who grabbed rebounds on the 1970 and 1973 championship teams, has boxed out Sonny Werblin, the Madison Square Garden impresario, just as he boxed out Gus Johnson of the Baltimore Bullets in their memorable duels.

title: A New Dominican Routine
description: They elected a President in the Dominican Republic the other day and the first thing he did was to ask the two main losers to help arrange a smooth transition. All the actors in this constitutional drama are civilians, and both of the losers are former Presidents.

title: 2 Sentenced in Belgrade
description: Two ethnic Albanians were sentenced to jail for spreading hostile propaganda against Yugoslavia, the newspaper Politika Ekspres reported here today. The paper said the men, who are brothers, had distributed an illegal newspaper that ''crudely attacked our system and country'' and had circulated leaflets, written slogans on walls and taped propaganda broadcasts. One man got four years and the other, five.

title: HAIG REGRETS INDONESIA'S VETO OF ENVOY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. issued a statement today regretting that Indonesia had refused to accept one of the Foreign Service's top Asian experts as the next Ambassador to that country.

title: Centel to Buy Aeroplex
description: The Centel Corproation said today that its communciations subsidiary would acquire Aeroplex Inc., which provides maintenance, refurbishing and installation services for telephone booths and equipment for leading telephone companies. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Tigers 11, A's 3
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Mike Ivie twice hit two-run homers, and Larry Herndon went 5 for 5, including two triples, to lead a 17-hit effort and help Detroit to its eighth consecutive victory. Ivie homered in the first inning off the losing pitcher, Tom Underwood (1-3), and in the middle of a five-run fourth inning off Bob Owchinko, a relief pitcher. The winning pitcher, Milt Wilcox (3-2), walked five and struck out four in his third complete game of the season.

title: U.S. PLANS SUPPLIES IF FIGHTING LASTS
description: The United States has earmarked a wide range of arms, including missiles and radar, for transfer to British forces if they get bogged down in a long winter struggle for the Falkland Islands, Administration officials said today.

title: CELEBRATING THE ECLECTIC AT FOLK CITY
description: FOLK CITY, the venerable Greenwich Village nightclub at 130 West Third Street, opened its doors in December 1960. Early performances at Folk City skyrocketed Bob Dylan to fame and fortune, and the club was an early home base for folk performers such as Judy Collins and Joan Baez.

title: PUBLISHING: A TIME TO TAKE CHANCES
description: The book business is now in such a slump that publishers, authors and agents are starting to take unusual risks. Take, for example, ''19 Purchase Street'' by Gerald A. Browne, a romantic thriller by the author of ''11 Harrowhouse,'' that Arbor House will publish in September.

title: Market Place; Movie 'Annie': The Prospects
description: AS a comic strip, ''Little Orphan Annie'' was a long-running hit. As a Broadway musical, ''Annie'' has been a stunning success. Whether the movie ''Annie,'' which opens to the public today, will also be a smash is a matter that has yet to be determined by critics, audiences and the financial community.

title: WOMEN'S GROUPS FAULT REAGAN ON JOBS AND ISSUES
description: On Inauguration Day last year, Ronald Reagan's staff lost the names of more than 400 women who were under consideration for jobs with the new Administration.

title: TOM COUSINEAU PLAYS MARKET AND WINS
description: Tom Cousineau's major while an he was an undergraduate at Ohio State was marketing, which is appropriate, for Cousineau has marketed his football skills as well as any professional athlete. Although he has never played a down in the National Football League, Cousineau has a starting position - weakside inside linebacker - waiting for him, along with a salary reported to be $500,000 a year, which will make him one of the highest paid players in the National Football League.

title: Gulf Sells Plastic Unit
description: The Gulf Oil Corproation said today that it had sold its 60 percent interest in the China Gulf Plastics Corporation to Asia S.A., a private investment company, to concentrate on its chemical resources in the United States. The price was not disclosed.

title: IMAGES OF A STORMY YALE STILL VIVID FOR BREWSTER
description: Most evenings, toward dusk, Kingman Brewster Jr. will walk his dogs, Puzzle the Labrador and Burl the golden retriever. There is no routine - Mr. Brewster says he disdains routine - but often he will find himself on Science Hill or the Old Campus of Yale University, which, for 14 years, was synonymous with him, its president.

title: SENATE ROLL CALL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected a move today to repeal the 10 percent personal tax cut scheduled for July 1983: FOR THE REPEAL - 32 Democrats - 27 Biden, Del. Bradley, N.J. Bumpers, Ark.

title: Aftra Loses Antitrust Suit
description: A small San Diego-based production company today won $9.3 million in damages in an antitrust suit against the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists union.

title: That Wall Street Tremor
description: ''There were some shaky moments,'' reports a senior official at the Securities and Exchange Commission. And although the anxiety about collapse of a firm that speculated in Government notes and bonds was quickly relieved, it stimulated new interest in this least regulated of financial markets.

title: CHASE SELLS DRYSDALE'S BONDS
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday began the laborious job of liquidating $4.5 billion in bonds at Drysdale Government Securities to convert the mountain of paper to cash in the wake of Chase's surprise decision to pay off Drysdale's debts to Wall Street dealers.

title: Imperial Chemical
description: Imperial Chemical Industries said it plans to build a nitric acid plant in Billingham in northeast Britain in early 1983 at an estimated cost of $53.4 million. The plant will produce 330,000 ton of nitric acid a year.

title: CHORAL GROUP: MODERN FARE
description: THE New Amsterdam Singers, a choral group conducted by Clara Longstreth since 1968, has an unusually wide repertory; most choruses seem to specialize in early music or large-scale choral blockbusters. Wednesday night at the Broadway Presbyterian Church, the group offered an appealing collection of 20th-century choral music, concentrating on Kodaly. Choral tone and homogeneity may not have been of the absolutely highest standard, but the group's musicianship and stylistic assurance were continually convincing.

title: AN IDEAL WAR
description: Americans have been subjected to a great deal deal of British propaganda lately. The British Ambassador, Sir Nicholas Henderson, has been ordained an instant personality because he apparently puts ''our'' case on the Falklands war so well. Television news has shown examples of the hysterical jingoism now rampant in sections of the British press. Margaret Thatcher, flushed and opaque-eyed, has been transmitted by nightly satellite across the Atlantic, imitating Churchill or Queen Victoria, or both.

title: HUSTON'S 'ANNIE' MAKES ITS LAVISH DEBUT
description: SOMEWHERE toward the middle of ''Annie,'' John Huston's gigantic screen version of the still-running Broadway musical, Sandy, Annie, Daddy Warbucks, Daddy's beautiful secretary Grace Farrell, and Punjab, Daddy's bodyguard, take themselves off to see a movie at Radio City Music Hall. This is the era of F.D.R., the Depression, the National Industrial Recovery Act, orphan asylums and the Music Hall. Daddy, as is his way, does things right. He buys out the house for one performance.

title: Del E. Webb Pact
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation said it had reached an agreement on the principal terms of an option to buy the 50 percent interest of Claridge Associates, its limited partner, in the Claridge Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, and that the agreement was submitted to the New Jersey Casino Control Commission during license hearings. Webb said that the option price of $4.5 million included Webb's right to sell the property to a third party during or after the three-year option, although Webb had ''no plans to do that.''

title: RATES ON U.S. ISSUES DECLINE
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday for all maturities of Government securities as the Federal Reserve continued its aggressive policy of injecting liquidity into the money market. Although the tax-exempt and corporate bond markets were slow to respond to the stimulus, prices of better-grade issues managed to finish moderately higher for the day.

title: BRIEFING
description: Fiddling Against NCPAC

title: U.S. NEARS FINAL POLICY TO AID SHIP COMPANIES
description: The Department of Transportation said today that new maritime policy goals of the Administration would include efforts to reduce regulations, give more freedom to shipping companies to build vessels abroad and stimulate more foreign investment in American shipping. The aim is to aid the long-troubled industry.

title: Age-Old Challenge Of Getting Noticed
description: You want to know how far agency people will go to get noticed? If you insist, start hanging out at the train depots in Greenwich, Westport or White Plains in the mornings. There you are liable to see these funny chaps from Fusion Advertising and Marketing in Meriden, Conn., giving away copies of their own, occasional tabloid called Inside Advertising, which will be ''published as often as necessary to attract good clients to a great, young agency bent on achieving excellence and vast riches.''

title: GERULAITIS, NOAH UPSET
description: Jose Higueras of Spain upset third-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis, 5-7, 6-2, 7-5, in the third round of the Italian Open tennis tournament today.

title: L.S.U. Eyes Brodhead
description: Faced with an athletic department deficit of $1 million and fears that it could grow to $3.5 million by the end of the decade, Chancellor Paul Wharton of Louisiana State University is expected today to name Bob Brodhead, the Miami Dolphins' director of finances, as the new athletic director. Brodhead would replace Paul Dietzel, who was removed on Feb. 5 amid an L.S.U. inquiry into spending practices that caused the financial crisis.

title: PROBLEMS OF BOSTON PENSION SYSTEM LEAD TO STATE AND FEDERAL INQUIRIES
description: If a Boston police officer of any age should suffer some trauma to his trigger finger and develop arthritis in it, Newell Cook, the City Auditor, explained the other day, the officer would be eligible under state law to retire on a total disability pension.

title: Beatcha Beaten in 3d Leg
description: The order of the first two finishers in the first two legs of the World Cup pacing championship was reversed tonight as Beatcha broke stride at the wire and Genghis Khan went on to beat him by four and one-quarter lengths. In clocking 1:53 1/5 for the mile, Genghis Khan returned $6.80 for $2 as the second choice.

title: STEVE MARTIN STARS IN REINER COMEDY
description: The black-and-white camera pans across a not-too-convincing artist's rendering of Los Angeles roofs at night. The rain pours down in a precise slant. The fullsomely orchestrated Miklos Rozsa soundtrack music promises mystery. Cut to the interior of a cluttered office where Rigby Reardon (Steve Martin), the quintessential 1940's private eye, reads a newspaper whose headline announces the disappearance of a certain Dr. Forrest. Says the headline, ''Noted Scientist, Philanthropist, Was Also a Cheesemaker and Father of Three.''

title: Key Rates
description: ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.N. CHIEF CONCEDES TALKS HAVE FAILED
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar declined to acknowledge today that his Falkland Islands peace effort had failed although some of his aides said privately that this round of mediation was over.

title: Penn Central Corp.  Will Keep Arvida
description: The Penn Central Corporation told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that it had decided not to sell the Arvida Corporation, a real estate developer with extensive land in southern Florida.

title: Michigan Budget Cut Again
description: Appropriations committees in the Michigan House and Senate today approved a $50 million cut in the state's already pared-down budget, with education and social services taking most of the cuts. The cuts require no further legislative action to take effect. Michigan has already enacted record cuts of $270 million and $308 million since the budget was unveiled at $4.85 billion when the 1982 fiscal year started Oct. 1.

title: HAIG READY TO TRY PEACE MOVE AGAIN
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was ready to make another diplomatic effort to end the conflict over the Falkland Islands if Argentina and Britain asked him to do so.

title: NEW TROUPE AT MANNES OFFERS RARE OLD OPERA
description: The Mannes Camerata begins tonight with the beginning. Performances of Marco da Gagliano's opera ''La Dafne'' this evening and tomorrow at Christ Church mark the first public venture for the Mannes College of Music's newly formed Early Music Program. The opera, in turn, is virtually a first in itself - standing as it does beside Monteverdi's ''L'Orfeo'' at the threshold of operatic history.

title: C.B.O.E. Sets New Contract
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange today filed for approval with both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for its new ''Index Value Contract,'' a stock-index contract pegged to the recently created C.B.O.E. 100 Stock Index. The C.B.O.E. 100 is a broadly based index composed of 100 stocks that serve as underlying securities for C.B.O.E.-listed options.

title: Convertible Demand Grows
description: Chrysler workers are working overtime to produce the only American-made convertibles.

title: ZAMBIA'S KAUNDA OFFERS PRETORIA 'GOSPEL' OF PEACE
description: In public at least, there are more hints and fervent hopes than hard facts about the outcome of last month's meeting between President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia and South Africa's Prime Minister, P .W. Botha, representatives of southern Africa's opposed racial and political forces.

title: Mass-Merchandise Test For Christian Reader
description: For 15 years, the Christian Reader, a Digest-size bimonthly from Tyndale House Publishers, Wheaton, Ill., has been available in churches and religious bookstores and has reached a circulation of about 210,000.

title: How to Get Ad Job: $15.50 in Hard Cover
description: From selling to the millions through advertising, Frank Kirkpatrick and his wife, Nancy, went to selling more selectively by buying the J.J. Hapgood Store in Peru, Vt., a general store serving a community of 312. That left Mr. Kirkpatrick time to write.

title: GATE DESIGNED TO PROTECT CHILDREN IS HAZARDOUS, U.S. AGENCY IS TOLD
description: Simple wooden accordion gates, which parents have used for decades to separate small children from hazards, pose a danger themselves, the Consumer Product Safety Commission was told today.

title: Western Air, Union in Pact
description: Western Airlines, whose troubled finances have led some analysts to doubt its ability to continue, said today that its 3,800 agent and clerical employees had agreed to an immediate, 10 percent cut in pay.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Candidates Defeat Leftists in Kerala
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party and its allies swept to victory today over leftist challengers in voting for the State Legislature in Kerala, according to incomplete results.

title: Red Sox Triumph By 11-2
description: Jim Rice batted in five runs with a threerun homer and a double, and Rich Gedman hit a three-run homer tonight to lead the Boston Red Sox to an 11-2 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: DOMINICANS FEAR U.S. SUGAR QUOTAS
description: Dominican officials fear that the new sugar import quotas imposed by President Reagan this month could wipe out any benefits the country would get from the proposed Caribbean aid plan.

title: A.T.& T. Bar Opposed
description: Legislation restricting the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's entry into the electronic publishing field was called ''protectionist'' today by Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: '82 GOWN ISN'T GOING TO TOWN
description: New Brunswick, NJ--Well, it's almost that time. This month, along with thousands of other college students, I will find myself slouching in my seat at an outdoor graduation ceremony, smoldering in my black robe and itching to go out drinking with other seniors to celebrate our success and forget that we won't be able to go out drinking so much anymore.

title: Military Analysis
description: The establishment of a secure and expanding beachhead on East Falkland Island was the primary objective of Britain's amphibious operation today. The exercise may, however, be preliminary to landings elsewhere on the island, analysts said.

title: Mitterrand Visits Ivory Coast In His 3-Nation African Tour
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived today for a three-day visit on his first African tour since taking office a year ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She has 95 percent of the British people behind her. The only time we're together is when we're at war.

title: SOVIET SINOLOGIST IN CHINA FOR TALKS
description: One of the Soviet Union's top Sinologists met quietly here this week with a Chinese Deputy Foreign Minister and with the director of Soviet and Eastern European affairs in China's Foreign Ministry.

title: Boy, 2, Lives a Day After 'Drowning'
description: A 2-year-old Long Island boy died today at Nassau County Medical Center, a day after he fell into a neighbor's pool.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Brands said it had agreed to exchange up to 500,000 common shares and an undisclosed amount of cash for up to $40 million principal amount of its 8 1/8 percent sinking fund debentures due in 1992, held by Goldman, Sachs & Co.

title: The U.N. Today; May 22, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the Falkland Islands at 3 P.M.

title: Air Products Purchase
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., an international supplier of industrial gases, chemicals, process equipment and engineering services, said today that it had completed its $210 million acquisition of the Stearns-Rober Corporation, an engineering and construction company with headquarters here, following approval yesterday by the directors of Stearns-Rober. Air Products has its headquarters in Allentown, Pa.

title: Dye-Stained Janitor Sought in Cash Theft
description: A security camera had it all on film. The janitor was caught taking money from a cash drawer and stuffing it in his sock.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: New York; GENTRIFIERS: THE POLICY
description: When a city is in the grip of a severe housing shortage, as this one is, and the forces of the marketplace lead private developers to build only luxury-priced housing, those who are less than well-to-do are going to need an assist from government policy to see that shelter is within their reach, too.

title: Bridge: U.J.A.-Federation Tourney Brings In Record Amount
description: Generosity of more than one variety marked the U.J.A.-Federation Charity Tournament played Thursday night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street.

title: Yugoslavs Feel Quake
description: An earthquake registering 4.4 on the Richter scale shook the Kosjeric mountains south of Belgrade at 3:59 A.M. today, waking residents. The police reported no casualties or damage.

title: 'Hothouse' Closing
description: ''The Hothouse,'' the comedy by Harold Pinter, will close after its matinee May 30 at the Playhouse Theater unless business improves. Directed by Adrian Hall, the Trinity Square Repertory Company production features George Martin, Amy Van Nostrand, Dan Butler, Peter Gerety, David C. Jones, Richard Kavanaugh and Howard London. The producers are Arthur Cantor and Dorothy Cullman.

title: Man Threatens 110-Story Jump
description: A man scaled an observation-deck fence at the 110-story World Trade Center yesterday, then threatened to jump before being pulled to safety.

title: Red Cross Official Renamed
description: President Reagan today announced the reappointment of Jerome Holland as a governor of the American Red Cross and designated him to serve as principal officer of the organization. Mr. Holland, a former United States ambassador to Sweden, was appointed chairman of the American Red Cross in 1979.

title: CHANDLER T. WHITE
description: Chandler T. White, retired vice president of the General Aniline and Film Corporation in New York City, died Wednesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: Notes on People; West Germany Honors an American General
description: The American general who was wounded in a West German terrorist attack last September was given the Service Cross with Star, the highest award given to foreigners by the West German Government, yesterday.

title: Sun Lifts Fuel Price
description: The Sun Company said today that it had increased the cargo price of two distillate products - No.2 fuel oil, commonly called heating oil, and kerosene - by a cent a gallon, effective yesterday.

title: Tass Reports British Landing
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass reported today's landing by British troops on the Falklands, saying it was believed to be the start of a large-scale military operation to seize the islands.

title: FOR MEXICO AND ITS CHIEF, THE GOLDEN DAYS DECLINE
description: For over five years, President Jose Lopez Portillo seemed to personify Mexico's new image of self-assurance as he presided over an unprecedented economic boom.

title: A Window on Violence
description: For many adults, television is a version of the window on whose sill one props a pillow, folds one's arms and leans out to watch the passing scene. But the views through this particular glass change at a finger's touch, and range from the fact of a news conference to the fiction in which half the men are doctors and all the women look airbrushed. Though the border between real and unreal is often blurred, most of the spectators know the difference - including those who wept when Luke and Laura finally married.

title: Troubles at Temple
description: Don Casey, the Temple University basketball coach since 1973 whose teams have a 102-37 record in the last five seasons, declined to comment yesterday on reports in Philadelphia newspapers that suggested he may be replaced when Dr. Peter J. Liacouras becomes president on July 1.

title: Sally Little Takes 1-Shot Lead
description: Amy Alcott shot a three-under-par 69 in the first round of the Chrysler-Plymouth L.P.G.A. tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today and finished a stroke behind the leader, Sally Little. Then Miss Alcott called Wykagyl ''one of the toughest courses we play on the tour and the best designed course we play.''

title: Around the World; Begin Opens Talks On Widening Support
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin opened negotiations today in an effort to broaden his parliamentary support after his coalition narrowly survived a no-confidence vote this week.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH, FORCE 7TH GAME
description: The Philadelphia 76ers established a National Basketball Association standard for futility tonight. In the second half they made only 7 of 34 shots and scored only 27 points as they lost to the Boston Celtics, 88-75, before a crowd of 18,364 at the Spectrum.

title: ROYALS' LEONARD BREAKS HAND
description: The Royals' Dennis Leonard suffered two broken fingers on his pitching hand tonight when he was hit by a line drive in the seventh inning of Kansas City's 3-0 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: IN THE NAMIBIA TALKS, A NEW APPROACH
description: The five Western nations that have been trying to mediate between South Africa and the South-West Africa People's Organization appear to be revising their tactics in an effort to revive the stalled negotiations on an independence plan.

title: AT BEACHHEAD: 'UNION JACK IS FLYING'
description: Michael Nicholson, a reporter for the Independent Television News, watched the British troops who landed on the Falkland Islands this morning and his report was broadcast tonight in Britain. Here are excerpts from that report, which was subject to military censorship.

title: A DISABILITY BENEFIT REVIEW PROGRAM THAT HAS GONE AWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST IS EAST AND WEST IS WEST, BUT THE RIGHT TWO CAN MEET
description: He was jogging past the lake just after sunrise. She was sitting against a tree, studying. He began to talk to two elderly men strolling along the shore. She tried not to eavesdrop. He asked her what she was reading. She told him it was an advanced mathematics text.

title: 'GATES' PROGRAM PUPILS IN NEED OF ADULT FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE SUBCOMMITTEE SETS DRYSDALE HEARING
description: The Senate securities subcommittee yesterday called Anthony M. Solomon, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, to testify next week at hearings on the the failure of Drysdale Government Securities to make $160 million in interest payments earlier this week. The Securities and Exchange Commission also began an investigation.

title: U. of Connecticut Raises Tuition
description: The University of Connecticut's board of trustees today raised tuition for out-of-state students by $1,600 a year, complying with a mandate from the state's General Assembly.

title: Your Money; The Pitfalls Of I.R.A.'s
description: THE advantages of Individual Retirement Accounts, under the changes in Federal law that went into effect at the beginning of this year, have been widely publicized by the banks, mutual funds, brokerage firms and other concerns offering these tax-deferral opportunities.

title: ANSWERS TO SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. He said that, contrary to popular belief, there were no alligators in the New York City sewer system. 2. The Common Market extended for one week the sanctions against Argentina, imposed in retaliation for its seizure from Britain of the Falkland Islands. It prevented Britain from invoking a veto that would have blocked farm price increases within the Common Market.

title: Guatemala's Envoy Named
description: Guatemala's military Government named Jorge Luis Zelaya today as Ambassador to the United States.

title: Nancy Kissinger Faces Assault Trial
description: Nancy Kissinger, wife of the former Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger, lost a bid today to have an assault case against her dismissed.

title: 252 PIECES OF FEDERAL LAND PICKED FOR POSSIBLE SALE, WATT SAYS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had picked out 252 parcels of Federal land that it was considering selling to offset the national debt by as much as $1.3 billion. Interior Secretary James G. Watt declined to disclose specifically what land was involved.

title: FOR BRITONS, 'ONLY TIME WE'RE TOGETHER IS WHEN WE'RE AT WAR'
description: With its landings on the Falkland Islands, Britain became a country at war today. But having been at a fever pitch of anticipation for days, the news seemed almost anticlimactic.

title:
PATENTS;
Checking Fuel Limits In Nuclear Plants
description: A process to monitor nuclear power systems, which is already in use, was patented this week for Combustion Engineering Inc., Windsor, Conn. Patent 4,330,367 was obtained by Charles R. Musick, the company's product manager of engineering services.

title: BUDD CO. SEEKS TO BAR CANADIAN SUBWAY CAR DEAL
description: The Budd Company will seek an injunction to block the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's award of a $662 million subway-car contract to Bombardier Inc., of Montreal.

title: A BEACH WASHINGTONIANS CALL HOME
description: Senator John Melcher, a silverhaired Montana Democrat, was strolling the boardwalk here in the nation's ''Summer Capital'' last Sunday, one of thousands of Washington politicians, diplomats, bureaucrats, lobbyists, journalists and their spouses and children who started the sand-and-sea season early.

title: New Trial Ordered In Brooklyn Case
description: A reputed member of organized crime convicted of shooting at a police officer must be given a new trial because court officers told jurors they were sequestered because of bribery attempts and fears for their safety, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn ruled yesterday.

title: Gulf's Exploration
description: The Gulf Oil Company intends to concentrate the bulk of its $12 billion exploration program in the next four years in Alaska and Canada, according to a Department of Labor report on the long-term outlook for Alaska's energy industry.

title: MARKET COUNTRIES POSTPONE A STAND
description: Members of the Common Market refrained tonight from any definitive comment on the landing of British troops in the Falkland Islands pending a meeting in Brussels Monday to decide on whether to continue economic sanctions against Argentina.

title: U.S. READY TO SEEK ACCORD BUT REPORTS NO EFFORT NOW
description: The United States pledged today that it would do ''whatever we can'' to advance the chances of a peaceful settlement of the Falkland Islands conflict but said there was no diplomatic initiative under way now.

title: SECURITIES TRADER IS CONVICTED OF FRAUD
description: A former securities trader was convicted yesterday of Federal fraud charges involving the use of secret information to buy stock in companies that were targets of mergers and acquisitions.

title: BOTH SIDES RETURNED TO HARDER POSITIONS, U.N. LEADER REPORTS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that on the eve of the breakdown of his effort to resolve the Falkland crisis, Argentina and Britain both stiffened their positions.

title: U.S. ADMIRAL CALLS BRITISH NAVAL CUTS AN ERROR
description: The Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Thomas B. Hayward, says the British Government made ''a significant error in judgment'' in reducing the size and ability of the Royal Navy in recent years.

title: Notes on People; Friendly Competition for 2 Conductors in Miami
description: Two new productions were being readied yesterday by the Greater Miami Opera for Florida's $5 million New World Festival of the Arts, which opens June 4. Although each opera has a different conductor, there was little of the traditional rivalry between them, even though they must share rehearsal space and time for the orchestra and chorus.

title: IS COURT THE PROPER PLACE FOR MISBEHAVING YOUTHS?
description: One group of children has the legal and child-welfare experts baffled. The youngsters have not broken the law -or, at least, the police have not caught them at it.

title: Unser to Skip Indy
description: Bobby Unser, the three-time Indianapolis 500 winner whose official victory in last year's race was delayed by five months of hearings and deliberations, announced yesterday that he will not compete in this year's race on May 30. ''I've waited too long,'' he said in Indianapolis.

title: PLEAS MADE TO CONGRESS FOR FUNDS FOR THE ARTS
description: Performing artists and their allies made their annual trek up Capitol Hill today to plead with Congress for more Federal funds for the arts, their mission more urgent this year in view of the Reagan Administration's efforts to hold the line on almost all spending.

title: OUTSIDE BUENOS AIRES, BITS OF NEWS ADD TO THE RISING TIDE OF PATRIOTISM
description: For the people of this quiet town west of the capital, it was just another day in a 149-year-old fight. Lujan, home of the shrine to Argentina's patron saint, is a place where pilgrims come by droves and news comes by dribbles. While word of the attempted British invasion of the Falklands, known here as the Malvinas, swept through the capital, this afternoon for the people of Lujan - relying largely on the radio - it did not yet seem to exist.

title: Books of The Times; Beauty, Style, Wit
description: DIANA COOPER. By Philip Ziegler. Illustrated. 336 Pages. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Three Stravinsky Concerts
description: Carnegie Hall will present three fully staged performances of Stravinsky's ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' on June 8, 9 and 10 at 8 P.M. The direction is by Tom O'Horgan, and the work will be given in Sheldon Harnick's English translation. Gerard Schwarz will be the conductor. Information: 247-7459.

title: Secrecy Loses
description: The Freedom of Information Act isn't perfect, but it's an ingenious check against secret, arbitrary government. The Reagan Administration agrees the act has flaws, even argues it is overrated, a nuisance, a hazard to national security and law enforcement. But after months of wrangling, a Senate Judiciary Committee run by the President's party has voted, 15 to 0, to preserve the act against the meddlers. We hope Congress respects that judgment, if it sees any need to amend the law at all.

title:
Patents;
TV Screen Lies Flat On Wall
description: WASHINGTON THE RCA Corporation has made progress toward the development of a flat color television receiver that can be mounted on a wall like a picture. Marvin A. Leedom, director of manufacturing systems and technology research at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., was granted patent 4,330,735 this week for an assembly to guide electron beams to the screen.

title: News Analysis
description: Ever since it burst abruptly into the world's consciousness seven weeks ago, the crisis over the Falkland Islands has been a major test not only of moral principle and international law, but also of the political fortunes of Margaret Thatcher.

title: RUMANIAN PREMIER AND 7 AIDES REPORTED OUSTED
description: Rumania's Prime Minister and seven deputy prime ministers were ousted today, according to parliamentary sources.

title: Landing Site Termed 'Rugged and Rough'
description: A young Falkland Islander who was born near the spot where the British marines landed describes the terrain as ''rugged and rough.''

title: SALES OF 2 BOSTON TV STATIONS ARE MAKING HISTORY AND MILLIONAIRES
description: This is a week in Boston in which both history and millionaires have been made, and dreams realized and relinquished. It is a calendar landmark in the history of American television, and some measure of ethnic progress in this racially divided city.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY DISABILITY CUTOFFS ASSAILED AT CONGRESSIONAL HEARING
description: Members of Congress joined disabled people and state officials today in criticizing the Social Security Administration for the way in which it was removing people from the disability insurance program.

title: Burden Jumps Bail
description: Luther (Ticky) Burden, a former Knick player who was convicted last year on charges of robbing a bank in Hempstead, L.I., in July 1980, has jumped his $60,000 bail. A bench warrant has been signed for his arrest. Burden, 29, who had been living with his wife and children in Hempstead, failed to appear yesterday in Nassau County Court in Mineola, L.I., to begin serving a sentence of six to 18 years.

title: Philadelphia Rails Shut Down
description: Picketing by Conrail workers virtually shut down service in the morning rush hour here today.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL PLANS NEXT MOVE
description: The American General Corporation of Houston said yesterday that it would hold a special board meeting Tuesday in response to the NLT Corporation's $600 million offer for American General.

title: COURTS
description: A series of judicial actions aimed at shielding phases of some criminal trials from public view has stirred fears among press groups that they are entering a new cycle of confrontation over the issue of public access to courts.

title: Briefing
description: The Postage Gap

title: SENATORS APPROVE 784 BILLION BUDGET FOR COMING YEAR
description: The Republican-controlled Senate tonight adopted a $784 billion budget for the fiscal year 1983. It projects a $116 billion deficit, largest in the nation's history.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 22, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose only 0.2 percent in April, continuing the sharp slowing in the inflation rate of the past seven months, the Labor Department reported. The April increase, combining a steep decline in energy prices with higher food and housing costs, marks a reversal of the decline of 0.3 percent in March, which was the first decline in the Consumer Price Index in almost 17 years. Still, for the past 12 months, the index is up only 6.6 percent, the lowest 12-month increase since 1978. (Page 1.) New York area prices rose 0.3 percent. (50.)

title: Around the Nation; Worker and Crane Fall Into 288-Foot Excavation
description: The ground over an abandoned mine shaft in the downtown area collapsed today, plunging a worker into a 288-foot pit half-filled with water.

title: Steinbrenner Holds Talks on Rockies
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, met in Buffalo yesterday with Peter Gilbert to discuss the possibility of Steinbrenner's buying Gilbert's financially troubled Colorado Rockies hockey team.

title: PROSECUTOR IS NAMED IN BROOKLYN
description: The Justice Department yesterday appointed Edward A. McDonald, a career prosecutor, to be the new chief of its Brooklyn-based Organized Crime Strike Force for the Eastern District of New York, the unit that spearheaded the Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: World Airways Deficit Widens
description: Losses for financially troubled World Airways widened in the first quarter, the company reported yesterday. The airline, which introduced discount transcontinental service in 1980, said that it lost $13.3 million in the quarter as revenues fell 16 percent, to $63 million, compared with a restated loss of $3.3 million for the similar period a year ago.

title: OPEC REIN ON OUTPUT EXTENDED
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to maintain its current oil production ceiling of 17.5 million barrels a day ''until further notice.''

title: American Natural
description: American Natural Resources said it had withdrawn from the Alaskan Northwest Natural Gas Transportation Company, which would result in a $17 million charge against its second-quarter earnings. In 1981 American Natural had second-quarter earnings of $23.8 million.

title: Pamela Fiori Is the Bride Of Colton Givner, Ad Aide
description: Pamela Fiori, editor in chief of Travel & Leisure magazine, was married yesterday to Colton Givner, a creative director at Ogilvy & Mather Partners, a New York advertising agency.

title: Observer; BANNED, THANK HEAVEN
description: The school board of West Springfield, Mass., said ''Nosirree!'' when its high school students asked to look at Greenwich Village on their trip to New York. A good thing, too. As a Villager, I didn't want to disillusion a lot of nice kids gawking at my house to ''observe people who live outside the norm free from harassment.''

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SOVIET WEAPONS ARE AIDED BY WESTERN TECHNOLOGY
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said yesterday that the United States and other Western countries had been selling the Soviet Union the technological ''rope to hang us'' but that the Reagan Administration was putting a stop to this.

title: Japan Trade Easing Seen
description: The Japanese Government has decided to liberalize quotas on nine farm and fisheries products and cut tariffs on 40 others as part of a general trade package to open Japan's markets to foreign goods, a Japanese newspaper said today.

title: Weather in Falklands: Windy and in the 40's
description: The weather in the Falkland Islands yesterday was cool and windy with partly cloudy skies, but good visibility, according to F. Gordon Barnes, the meteorologist for the Cable News Network and WDVM-TV in Washington.

title: A FABLE: THE WILL AND THE WAY
description: Once there was a very rich man who was exceedingly good, kind and generous and a leading citizen in his community. He was highly respected and honored by all who knew him. He also was the father of seven sons who loved and revered him.

title: Around the World; Two Die as Blasts Rock Beirut's Moslem Area
description: Two explosions shook the Moslem area of Beirut today within five minutes of each other.

title: DURABLE ORDERS OFF IN APRIL
description: New orders for durable goods dropped a sharp 3.9 percent in April, all but wiping out gains of the previous two months, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the biggest one-month decline since last October.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 22, 1982
description: International British troops attacked the Falklands and established ''a firm bridgehead,'' Defense Secretary John Nott announced in London. He reported that five British ships were damaged, two of them seriously, and that one Harrier jet was missing. Argentina conceded that a British landing had taken place. It was said to have lost 17 planes. Britain attacked a few hours after diplomatic negotiations with Argentina collapsed. Page 1, Column 6.) An Argentine attack failed to dislodge the British troops from their foothold on East Falkland Island, military spokesmen in Buenos Aires admitted. They said in a communique that ''the enemy forces that have succeeded in landing are being attacked by Argentine army units with the help of planes of the three militarty services stationed in the islands. (1:5.)

title: HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCE STATUTES
description: The Reagan Administration proposes to nullify all state laws regulatingt he energy efficiency of major household appliances and leave this a spect of the industry unregulated. But state energy officials told aH ouse subcommittee today that they would fight for their local codes.

title: BUENOS AIRES TEEMS WITH 'SOURCES' ON FIGHTING A THOUSAND MILES AWAY
description: The first official news here today of the British landings on the Falkland Islands was communique No. 68 from the Argentine Joint Chiefs of Staff, which was broadcast by radio stations at about 11 A.M.

title: Tess, Revisited
description: ''Why so often ... the wrong man the woman, the wrong woman the man, many thousand years of analytical philosophy have failed to explain to our sense of order,'' Thomas Hardy said in ''Tess of the D'Urbervilles.''

title: ARRAIGNMENTS HELD FOR 107 DEFENDANTS IN MARIJUANA RAID
description: Arraignments were held yesterday for 107 persons charged with selling marijuana and hashish after their arrests in police raids on 74 storefronts in four boroughs.

title: 'TAXI,' DROPPED BY ABC, PICKED UP BY NBC
description: ''Taxi,'' the Emmy-award winning comedy series canceled by ABC-TV last month, will be picked up by NBC-TV for its fall schedule, network officials and the show's producer, Paramount, said yesterday.

title: LIVING COSTS UP SLIGHTLY IN THE NEW YORK REGION
description: The cost of living in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area edged slightly upward last month. But Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the moderate rise continued the pattern of improvement that began last September.

title: DISEASES CUT BY POLICY OF NO SHOTS, NO SCHOOL
description: A policy of accepting into New York City's public schools only pupils and students who have been immunized has rid the city of virtually all cases of measles and reduced the incidence of mumps and rubella, a legislative hearing was told yesterday.

title: ENERGY COSTS OFF SHARPLY IN APRIL
description: Consumer prices, checked by a steep decline in energy costs, rose only two-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department said today. The April report reflected a continuation of the sharp slowing in the rate of inflation over the past seven months.

title: NANCY HUANG, 5-2, HEADS FIELD IN ACORN
description: The best 3-year-olds of 1982 have been waylaid by injuries and there can be no Triple Crown winner this year as far as the colts are concerned. But the 3-year-old fillies are a different story, and a much brighter one.

title: GLANCING BLOW AT CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: MERGER RULING REJECTS AN OLD YARDSTICK
description: In a decision that cast new light on the changing standards of antitrust enforcement, a Federal Trade Commission judge today dismissed a challenge to the 1979 merger of two companies that make organic pigments. He ruled that market concentration was not sufficient reason to bar the merger.

title: BALLET: GODUNOV TAKES OVER DON JOSE IN PETIT'S 'CARMEN'
description: There were major debuts Thursday at both the New York City Ballet and the American Ballet Theater. At the New York State Theater, Ib Andersen and Heather Watts made their first appearance in Peter Martins's ''The Magic Flute.''

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: Ex-Suffolk Official Gets Prison Term
description: A former Suffolk County Labor Commissioner was sentenced today to a prison term of one and a half to four years and fined $5,000 for perjury. The defendant, Lou Tempera, was released without bail pending an appeal.

title: BRANIFF WORKERS
description: Executone Systems Inc., a unit of the Continental Telecom Corporation, said it would seek to employ temporarily up to 200 former Braniff International workers as sales representatives for terminal equipment and to creat permanent jobs for 20 or more.

title: Around the Nation; Rule on Viability of Fetus Voided in Kentucky
description: A Kentucky appeals court, restoring a murder indictment, ruled today that a jury should decide whether a fetus is a person.

title: THE HOSPITALS NEW YORK AMBULANCES RUSH TO
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN AIDE TELLS OF NEW STRATEGY ON SOVIET THREAT
description: President Reagan has approved a new military strategy in which United States forces need not engage those of the Soviet Union on all fronts simultaneously if a war breaks out, his national security adviser said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bohemia Inc. has sold two ocean-going dredges and four dump barges for $11 million, of which $7.7 million is in cash, to buyers who were not named. As part of the purchase price, the buyers assumed long-term debt associated with the equipment amounting to $3.3 million.

title: Notes on People; For Jersey's 'Suggester of the Year,' a $5,000 Prize
description: Joseph Haas helps to manage a household that includes eight children, and that may have aided him in coming up with a suggestion that is saving the State of New Jersey several thousand dollars a year in mailing costs.

title: Harvester Statement
description: The International Harvester Company, which on Thursday reported a $198.3 million loss for the second quarter, reiterated today that there was ''no truth to the rumors'' that it would file a bankruptcy petition.

title:
PATENTS;
Lighted Microscope Aids the Blind
description: A New York physicist has invented a device to help persons with poor vision read fine print or perform delicate tasks.

title: YANKS SCORE SIX IN 6TH, ROUT TWINS, 12-1
description: A game between the Yankees, many of whom used to be Twins, and the Twins, many of whom used to be Yankees, turned into a 12-1 romp by the home team last night that gave Rudy May his first victory of the season and the Yankees their most runs in a game this year.

title: Harley-Davidson Plans Layoffs
description: The Harley-Davidson Motor Company, citing slumping motorcycle sales, announced that it was cutting overall production by 22 percent, laying off 170 workers here and putting 256 hourly workers on furlough without pay at York, Pa.

title: THOSE CERTAIN EXTRAS A FILM NEEDS TO STAND OUT IN THE BUSTLE AT CANNES
description: With something like 400 films being shown here in the space of two weeks, it seems to take more than quality alone to make any one of them an event.

title: Layoffs at Chessie
description: Chessie System Railroads announced today an eight-week layoff of 1,440 of its 1,765 workers at its freight car and heavy repair shops at Raceland, Ky., and 76 of 163 freight repair workers at Brunswick, Md., 58 of 118 at Grand Rapids, Mich., and 51 of 695 at Cumberland, Md. The company cited declining traffic levels.

title: Life as a Substitute for Death
description: The New York legislators pushing this year's death penalty bill are hoping to buy a few more votes by amending it. They now propose allowing juries to recommend a lesser sentence: life imprisonment with no chance of parole.

title: Arrows Take 2-1 Lead
description: Steve Zungul scored his third goal at 4 minutes 13 seconds of overtime tonight to give the New York Arrows a 9-8 victory over the St. Louis Steamers before a crowd of 18,160 at the Checkerdome. The Arrows lead the three-of-five Major Indoor Soccer League championship series by two games to one. The fourth game will be played here Sunday.

title: Woods of Colts Is Shot
description: Mike Woods, a Baltimore Colts linebacker, suffered a severe spinal-cord injury when he was shot today after he walked into an east side residence while his father and another man were being robbed.

title: Canada to Continue Shipping Nuclear Fuel to Buenos Aries
description: The Canadian Government has rejected opposition demands that it cancel a contract to ship nuclear fuel bundles to Argentina for a nearly completed Canadian nuclear reactor near Buenos Aires.

title: CLAIMS 16 PLANES, REPORTS OF 5 OF ITS SHIPS HIT; Statements by Britain, page 6.
description: British troops attacked the Falkland Islands today and established ''a firm bridgehead'' in the fighting with Argentine troops, Defense Secretary John Nott announced tonight.

title: 25 Hurt in Bleachers Fall
description: A section of bleachers filled with 70 students at Page High School collapsed today, injuring about 25 teen-agers. A hospital spokesman said it was too early to say how badly the students were hurt.

title: BACK IN FOOTBALL, EVEN AFTER A FLOP
description: He tried to establish World Hockey Association franchises in two countries. Then he leaped into the World Football League, creating such a furor in the Canadian Parliament that he was forced once again to move a team to the United States. And now, John F. Bassett, who has seen his teams die in two sports leagues, is back.

title: CAUTION ON COLLEGE-COST ADVISORY SERVICES
description: As the cost of higher education has risen and Federal aid has been restricted, scores of private counseling services have sprung up across the nation to advise families on ways to foor the bills.

title: EVENTS THAT CULMINATED IN SETTING UP OF A BRITISH BEACHHEAD ON FALKLANDS
description: PRELUDE TO THE ARGENTINE INVASION: In late February and March, British and Argentine diplomats met, as they had many times in the previous 17 years, to discuss Argentina's claim to the Falkland Islands, which the British had seized on Jan. 2, 1833. After a few days of reportedly cordial talks, the Argentine Foreign Ministry warned that unless there was a quick resolution to the dispute, Argentina would turn to ''a procedure which better suits its interests.'' March 19 - An Argentine naval transport lands about salvage 60 workers on the Falkland dependency of South Georgia to dismantle an abandoned whaling station. They display the Argentine flag and are told by local British officials that they must leave. The workers stand fast with the support of the Argentine Government.

title: U.S. Envoy Threatened By a Group in Bolivia
description: A paramilitary group has threatened to kill Ambassador Edwin G. Corr of the United States if he does not leave the country within three weeks.

title: 3,600 Workers Strike At Northwest Airlines
description: Almost 3,600 mechanics and baggage handlers for Northwest Airlines went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today to protest contract concession demands by the airline.

title: Forger of Papers For Aliens Is Jailed
description: A 25-year-old Brooklyn College student was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $5,000 yesterday for providing forged documents to illegal aliens seeking to remain in the United States.

title: OFFICIALLY BELITTLED UNEMPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. STEEL TO CLOSE BIG ALABAMA MILL
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Fairfield plant, the South's largest integrated steel mill. Until the late 1970s, the mill was one of the biggest employers in Birmingham, Ala.

title: ROMANCE IN THE RANKS UNITES 2 NEW ENSIGNS
description: Birds do it. Bees do it. Even ensigns and young plebes do it. In the coeducational service academies, they fall, as Cole Porter forecast so universally, in love.

title: PANEL IN CALIFORNIA CANCELS SIRHAN'S 1984 PAROLE DATE
description: Sirhan B. Sirhan's 1984 parole date was rescinded today by the California Board of Prison Terms, which cited death threats he made from prison.

title: BRENTANO'S BANKRUPTCY FILING
description: The Brentano's bookstore chain, which began as a Manhattan newsstand in 1853, filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws yesterday and said that it intended to close half its 28 stores.

title: 'FIGHTING BACK'
description: ''Fighting Back,'' which opened yesterday at Loews State and neighborhood theaters, addresses itself to crime on the streets and, although the message does not get delivered with crystal clarity, the movie is fast-moving, attention-holding and even thoughtprovoking.

title: Latin Leaders Discuss Moves Against Britain
description: Latin American leaders today discussed possible reprisals against Britain over the fighting in the Falkland Islands.

title: El Paso Gas Interest
description: The El Paso Company said today that it had a 48.44 percent interest in a gas well in Okahoma's Anardarko Basin. The well was tested successfully by the Inexco Oil Company, the well's operator, El Paso said. The 1-22 Fourtner, situated in Custer County, Okla., tested gas from 22 feet of the lower morrow sandstone at 15,260 feet at 3.4 million cubic feet daily, flowing through a 3/16 inch choke, the company said.

title: Around the Nation; Church Panel Rules Out Trial of Methodist Bishop
description: A Methodist bishop who assigned a homosexual pastor to a Denver church should not be tried on charges of heresy and disobedience, a church investigative panel decided today.

title:
PATENTS;
Guarding Power Lines Against Earthquakes
description: A protector against earthquakes for the large circuit breakers used in high-voltage transmission lines has been patented for Delle-Alsthom, one of the companies recently nationalized by the French Government.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AGAIN BACKS BELL PACT
description: The Justice Department today rejected proposals for any change in its antitrust settlement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: STOCKS HALT SLIDE WITH DOW UP 3.42
description: Stock prices edged up slightly yesterday in moderate trading that ended a seven-session, 33-point slide in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Dow rose 3.42 points, to 835.90.

title: Farm Chief to Visit Canada
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that he would visit Canada on Tuesday and Wednesday to meet with agricultural leaders. An annoucement said, ''Among the topics tentatively set for discussion in Ottawa are the world grain situation, Canada's long-term grain agreement with third countries, grain-producer prices and the U.S. dairy situation.''

title: Dentsply Facing Suits
description: Dentsply International said yesterday that two suits had been filed against the company and its directors in the Delaware Chancery Court seeking to stop a $100 million transaction to take the company private with substantial ownership in the hands of employees and senior management. Dentsply said it intended to oppose the suits and would continue preparations for the annual shareholder meeting now scheduled for New York on June 28. The suits were filed by Robert and Peggy Corwin and Evelyn Sumers, shareholders who oppose the $25.50-a-share offer.

title: Key Rates
description: Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STATEMENTS BY THE BRITISH ON FIGHTING IN THE FALKLANDS
description: Following are two statements today by the British Defense Ministry on the fighting in the Falkland Islands. Ian McDonald, a ministry spokesman, made available a text of the first at noon. The second, by Defense Secretary John Nott, was broadcast on radio and television at 8:20 P.M. and was transcribed by The Associated Press.

title: ASTROS TOP METS, 5-1, AS SUTTON WINS 7TH
description: Don Sutton, who ended last season with a broken kneecap and a longing to return to Los Angeles, pitched his seventh straight victory tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the New York Mets, 5-1.

title: William (Monk) Montgomery, Bass Player With Hampton
description: William (Monk) Montgomery, a leading jazz bass player, died of cancer Thursday.

title: FOR THE DEVOTEES OF LIVERWURST, MORE GOOD NEWS
description: Lovers of liverwurst appear to be a generous lot and firmly subscribe to the principle that one good turn deserves another. After a description of the superb preservative-free liverwurst in natural casings made by Usinger's in Milwaukee appeared in this column recently, many readers wrote about local alternatives they considered exceptional. Ever on the trail of new and delicious wurst, I dispatched emissaries to the suggested sources and found that, generally, the readers' enthusiasm was not misplaced.

title: Senate Roll-Call
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted a budget outline for the fiscal year 1983: FOR THE BUDGET - 49 Republicans - 46 Abdnor, S.D. Andrews, N.D. Armstrong, Colo. Baker, Tenn.

title: STATE VOTES HURT MRS. GANDHI
description: India's Marxist Communist Party and its allies headed for a landslide victory today over Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's forces in West Bengal State as ballot counting in elections to three state legislatures continued.

title: A THREE-RING BENEFIT SHOW
description: It was, as it most certainly should have been, a Happy Ending topped by a Truly Spectacular Production Number. In fact, the only thing lacking on Thursday night was, to everyone's relief, a cliffhanging climax.

title: Montana Rejects Strike
description: Joe Montana, the quarterback of the San Francisco 49ers, has joined a growing list of stars who have said that they would not honor a possible National Football League Players Association strike this summer over the issue of a fixed percentage of the team's gross income. ''I couldn't go on strike over the issues they're talking about,'' Montana said.

title: Around the Nation; Trial Set for Youth Accused of Killing Envoy
description: An Armenian teen-ager pleaded not guilty today to charges that he assassinated the Turkish consul general here. He is to stand trial July 14.

title: Gulf Resources Proxies Upheld
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation said a Federal judge in Houston had refused its request to void the proxies filed by a dissident group in a struggle for control of the company.

title: Donated Organs Held A Key to Saving Lives
description: A surgeon said Thursday that perhaps a third or more of the 20,000 people who died of liver disease each year could be saved with transplants if more people donated their organs.

title: New NBC News Program
description: A morning television program of NBC News, ''Early Today,'' will have its premiere July 5, Reuven Frank, president of NBC News, has announced at the NBC-TV affiliates' convention in Los Angeles. The program will have personnel from ''Today,'' which it will precede.

title: Around the World; Filipino Crew Seizes An Armed Hijacker
description: A Filipino armed with a grenade hijacked a jetliner today, but the crew members overpowered him to end an eight-hour confrontation.

title: BROADCAST OF TAPES HALTS TRIAL
description: Disobeying a court order, a radio station today played parts of Ruth Coe's taped conversation with an undercover police officer posing as a killer. Minutes later Mrs. Coe collapsed in her attorney's office, causing the judge to halt her murder-for-hire trial.

title: FIGHTING ERUPTS AS STUDENTS GET EARLY DISMISSAL
description: One man was stabbed and several young people were injured yesterday during a melee near a Brooklyn subway station shortly after 400 students were allowed to leave a high school early because of racial tensions, the police said. There was one arrest.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IT'S MAGIC

title: GROSSET & DUNLAP BEING SOLD
description: The Putnam Publishing Group has reached an agreement in principle to acquire Grosset & Dunlap, the book subsidiary of Filmways Inc. The agreement includes the purchase of Ace Books, the mass-market paperback division of Charter Communications, a Grosset & Dunlap company. The agreement's terms were not divulged.

title: Jews Deplore a Map Given at World's Fair
description: Jews in Tennessee have demanded that Gov. Lamar Alexander and World's Fair officials publicly deplore the fair's Saudi Arabian exhibitors for handing out Middle East maps that ignore the existence of Israel.

title: Continental To Buy STSC
description: Continental Telecom Inc., formerly known as the Continental Telephone Corporation, said that it reached an agreement to purchase STSC Inc., a financially ailing computer services company, for $11 a share in cash, or a total of about $24 million.

title: UNLIKELY MONUMENT TO RELIGIOUS FREEDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Bill Proposed in House
description: Three Representatives introduced a bill in the House yesterday to give the National Football League and other professional sports leagues limited exemption from Federal antitrust laws. A major effect of the bill would be to prevent the Oakland Raiders from moving to Los Angeles, despite a court decision two weeks ago that seemed to clear the way for such a move.

title: Around the Nation; Von Bulow Granted Bail To Pursue His Appeal
description: Claus von Bulow signed a $1 million bail document today to assure his freedom from prison during his appeal of a conviction for twice trying to kill his wife, Martha.

title: MISANTHROPE AS CATALYST
description: ANOTHER one of Kingman's Comets was spotted passing through the Flushing sky. It appeared on Wednesday night about 8 o'clock, and it scored three runs.

title: TURNING LEBANESE: A FAMILY STORY
description: In the summer of 1977, I visited a tiny village on Mount Lebanon fragrant with the scent of mint and roses, and wondered why my grandmother had never wanted to come back, not even for a visit. Seventeen years earlier, her children had offered to buy her a plane ticket, and when she firmly declined it the matter was dropped. Yet every spring she asked to be driven to a wide field a few miles from her home in Adena, Ohio, where a slender stream sprang out of the hillside. There she picked mint and held up the sprigs for her children to smell. ''Mit al-Lubnan,'' (''like Lebanon''), she said. She wondered at the sheep in America, with their truncated tails, and told her children about the sheep with large, fluffy tails that grazed on the slopes of Mount Lebanon. My father found her a picture of one in an encyclopedia entry under ''Syria.'' She was content to look at that.

title: Notes on People; 98-Year-Old Earns Her High School Diploma
description: It is never too late to learn, Jessie Ryan said yesterday, and she ought to know. At the age of 98, she received her high school diploma in Madison Heights, Mich.

Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 26

title: Shaft Break Causes Cable Car Shutdown
description: A break in an 18-foot, 9,000-pound drive shaft has interrupted San Francisco's cable car service, and officials say repairs may take anywhere from a few days to two months.

title: Rhode Island Senator Urges A Trusteeship for Falklands
description: Senator Claiborne Pell, the ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, is urging a trusteeship or split sovereignty for the Falkland Islands.

title: U.S. PANEL UPHOLDS ROAD FUNDS RULING
description: A Federal appellate court today upheld an order blocking millions of dollars in Federal highway funds because Pennsylvania has failed to institute an automobile emissions inspection program.

title: G.M.-Isuzu Report
description: TOKYO, May 21 (Reuters) The financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported today that Isuzu Motors Ltd., which is 34.2 percent owned by the General Motors Corporation, would issue to G.M. $200 million worth of convertible debentures to raise funds for the development of a subcompact car for G.M.
