Neither company would comment on the report, which also said that Isuzu would start delivering the new car to G.M. in 1984.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.3 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply rose by $2.3 billion in the week ended May 12, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The rise was slightly above market expectations, pushing up interest rates a bit in late-afternoon trading.

title: LEHRMAN'S ROLE AT RITE AID DISPUTED BY 2 IN COMPANY
description: Lewis E. Lehrman's role in the growth of the Rite Aid Corporation has become the subject of a political controversy touched off by two executives of the company.

title: Seven Players Fined
description: Five Detroit Tigers and two Minnesota Twins have been notified of fines as a result of brawls between the teams in a game May 14, according to a source in the Major League Baseball Players Association. Fines ranging from $100 to $250 were levied against Ron Davis and Jesus Vega of the Twins, and Chet Lemon, Enos Cabell, Richie Hebner, Kirk Gibson and Larry Herndon of the Tigers. All but Gibson and Herndon were ejected from that game, which the Tigers won, 4-2, in the 11th inning on Gibson's two-run homer.

title: Concert Set for June 6 By Male Black Singers
description: Twelve male black singers will perform, arias, songs and spirituals June 6 at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. The concert, presented by the Independent Black Opera Singers Inc., will feature Michael Austin, Clyde Battles, Francois Clemmons, James Kennon-Wilson, Kamal Scott and George Shirley, tenors; Charles Coleman, contratenor; Andrew Frierson, Ben Holt, Peter Lightfoot and Jonathon Sprague, baritones, and Arthur Woodley, bass-baritone. Information: 874-6770.

title: BRITISH CATHOLIC LEADERS TRY TO SAVE VISIT BY POPE
description: British Roman Catholic leaders are pushing hard to save at least part of Pope John Paul II's planned visit next weekend. In Rome today, British and Argentine cardinals met with the Pope for two hours. The cardinals are scheduled to join in prayer with John Paul Saturday at an unusual peace mass in St. Peter's Basilica.

title: LOWER RISES EXPECTED FOR STABLIZED RENTALS
description: A study for New York City's Rent Guidelines Board has found that the index of operating costs for rent-stabilized apartment buildings increased by only 2.8 percent in the last year.

title: ANNUAL MEETING, G.M. STYLE
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Motors Corporation, once again played the reluctant host of the automobile industry's version of the old television game show ''Beat the Clock'' as he presided over the annual meeting of stockholders today.

title: BRITONS GIVEN ONLY 2 OFFICIAL REPORTS DURING DAY
description: For Britons, the first news of the long-awaited landings in the Falkland Islands came just after noon today. In his now-familiar, emotionless tone, the Defense Ministry spokesman, Ian McDonald, said at the regular noon press briefing that raids and attacks by British troops had taken place.

title: BOB MELNICK
description: Bob Melnick, who managed boxers in the New York City area for almost half a century, died in his sleep on Thursday at his home in Seattle. He was 85 years old. Mr. Melnick moved from New York to Seattle in 1968 after retiring as a manager. Some of his more prominent fighters were Ralph (Tiger) Jones, Roger Donahue, Yama Bahama and James J. Woody.

title: New Drug Approved For Acne
description: The Government today approved a new prescription drug for the most disfiguring form of acne. The product, 13-cis retinoic acid, has been shown to cause longterm remission of cystic acne in test patients.

title: Possible DeLorean Backer Withdraws
description: Peter Kalikow, the New York investor who had offered to invest $35 million in the DeLorean Motor Company, withdrew his offer. But John Z. DeLorean, president of the car maker, said immediately afterward that Mr. Kalikow had never been a ''prime candidate'' for financing and that a similar investment was being lined up with a new backer.

title: Camacho Stops Rojas In First, Retains Title
description: Hector Camacho needed only half a round last night to retain his North American Boxing Federation lightweight title last night at the Felt Forum.

title: Wrath of Chiles
description: Because the Texas Rangers had lost 21 of their last 25 games and are 13 games out of first place in the American League's Western Division, the majority owner and two board members of the club have vowed to end the plunge soon ... or else.

title: JERSEY VOTING DISTRICTS UPHELD
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the new map of Congressional districts approved by the State Legislature, and signed by Gov. Brendan T. Byrne hours before he left office on Jan. 19.

title: UNUSUAL TRADING IN CAESARS
description: A secret accumulation of stock is under way in Caesars World, the big hotel casino company, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday. The most likely buyer was thought to be Resorts International, another leading hotel casino company.

title: Around the World; Pact on Bases Expected Between U.S. and Spain
description: The United States and Spain are expected to sign an agreement early next week on the use of military bases in Spain, a Spanish Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST SEES SPLIT IN HINCKLEY MIND AND EMOTIONS IN SHOOTINGS
description: A defense psychologist testified under crossexamination this afternoon that John W. Hinckley Jr. knew ''in his head'' that he was doing wrong when he shot President Reagan but was too insane to appreciate this emotionally.

title: TEXAS OFFICIALS EASE RESISTANCE TO U.S. COURT ORDER ON CROWDED PRISONS
description: Late last year, elected officials and prison administrators in Texas were railing against a Federal district judge and appealing his sweeping orders for reform of the nation's largest prison system.

title: National Distillers
description: The National Distillers & Chemical Corporation, with liquor, wine and petrochemical interests, said it was discussing the possible sale of its Holland House Brands division to Cadbury Schweppes U.S.A. Holland House produces and distributes cocktail mixes and specialty products. The move is part of National Distillers' plan to concentrate on its strengths -chemicals, wine and liquors - said Richard Tilghman, a vice president. Analysts said that Cadbury, a chocolate maker, could offer Holland better retail distribution.

title: AN OLD ARMY FILM OF HUSTON REVIVED
description: A documentary film directed and produced by John Huston for the United States Army Signal Corps in 1946, but not released until last year, will have its first Westchester showing this week as part of observances of Mental Health Month.

title: CALIFORNIA VOTING ON CRIMINAL LAWS
description: Californians will vote next month on a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would sharply limit the rights of criminal defendants and make other sweeping changes in the criminal justice system.

title: Miss Rogers Wed To J.H. Tilton Jr.
description: Constance Lelia Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Allen Rogers of New York, was married yesterday to John Havemeyer Tilton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tilton of Sugar Hill, N.H. The Rev. Ernest E. Hunt 3d performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

title: ALSO KNOWN AS KAILA
description: BRONX PRIMITIVE Portraits in a Childhood. By Kate Simon. 179 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: RULES TIGHTENED ON THE DIVERSION OF AMBULANCES
description: Mayor Koch yesterday established new guidelines aimed at reducing the diversion of emergency ambulances that carry heart attack victims to hospital emergency rooms and coronary-care units in New York City.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE first time that the state offered low-interest mortgages to the public, in June last year, the demand was so great that loan applicants camped out all night in front of banks to be the first in line to apply. However, some of those who spent a cold night on the sidewalk did not get loans, while others who strolled in the next morning did, because some banks had more luck than others in getting through the busy signals on the telephone to reach the office from which the loans were coordinated.

title: Headliners Threatening Words
description: The California Board of Prison Terms might have been ready to forgive Sirhan B. Sirhan his past sins, but they could not ignore those he promised in the future. In rescinding his 1984 parole date last week, the board said it had ''good cause'' to give Robert F. Kennedy's assassin more time - he had threatened, in writing, to kill a prison guard, a prison official and an author who wrote a book about him.

title: Crime
description: Meet a new private eye - Kinsey Millhone. Locale, California, near Los Angeles. Sex, female. Integrity, high. Previous marriages, two; currently single. She appears in "A" IS FOR ALIBI by Sue Grafton (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $12.95.) She's already scheduled to appear in "B' Is for Burglar."

title: Timely Writer Progresses
description: Timely Writer, the overwhelming favorite to win the Kentucky Derby until a stomach infection and emergency surgery sidelined him 12 days before the race, will take another step on his road to recovery when he arrives at Belmont Park by van from Kentucky next Thursday or Friday.

title: THE BEGUILING VITALITY OF ETRUSCAN ART
description: DAVID L. SHIREY is chairman of the newly instituted graduate program at the School of Visual Arts and visiting professor of art at Hunter College. By DAVID L.SHIREY

title: Ballet Today Program
description: Vanessa Harwood and Kevin Pugh, principal dancers with the National Ballet of Canada, will appear tomorrow as guest artists with the Ballet Today Company at the Fashion Institute of Technology's Morris W. Haft Theater. Also appearing will be Yoko Morishita and Agnes de Mille.

title: FEINER CHALLENGES VETERAN MRS. HOCHBERG
description: AUDREY HOCHBERG's decision to seek election to the State Assembly from a newly formed 86th District, which includes Scarsdale, where she lives, as well as White Plains and three-quarters of New Rochelle, apparently has cleared the Democratic field - except for Paul Feiner, also of Scarsdale, who made his bid official last week, too.

title: SMALL, SAVAGE FALKLANDS WAR HOLDS MAJOR LESSONS
description: LONDON PRIMARY principles of modern war on which vast modern military establishments are based are under test in the battle raging on, above and around the Falkland Islands. The outcome of this small, savage war between Britain and Argentina can answer some of the rude questions that trouble the mystique of sea power and perhaps much more.

title: Regulation of Lobbyists A Role of Ethics Office
description: In reading Connecticut Weekly, I noticed a reference to the Secretary of the State's office being responsible for regulating lobbyists (''Session Ends With Few Changes, May 9). In that this is a factually inaccurate statement, I am respectfully taking the liberty to set the record straight.

title: REGAL GERANIUMS ARE GARDEN ARISTOCRATS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Tovah Martin writes frequently on indoor plants. By TOVAH MARTIN

title: THE ENVIRONMENT REVISITED
description: The second United Nations Conference on the Global Environment, like a second honeymoon, was less exciting than the original event in Stockholm 10 years ago. It was, however, significant as the reaffirmation of an ideal.

title: ALEXANDER L. GROSSMAN
description: Alexander L. Grossman, a lawyer and accountant in New York City for 60 years, died Friday at Dobbs Ferry Hospital. Mr. Grossman, who lived in Ardsley, N.Y., was 82 years old.

title: CABANA CONTROVERSY HEATS UP ANEW
description: LIDO BEACH AMONG other unmistakable signs announcing the beach season's arrival has been the continuing escalation of a controversy between Nassau County and cabana renters at Nassau Beach over the status of 498 deteriorated cabanas here. For over seven years cabana renters, seeking to have the 35-year-old units upgraded, have been engaged in on-and-off litigation with the county to determine whether the units should be rehabilitated or destroyed.

title: N. Carolina Gains Final
description: North Carolina's lacrosse team, top-ranked in the country and the defending national champion, blitzed Cornell with a six-goal burst in the second quarter today and won, 15-8, in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: TWINS EAGER FOR RETURN TO FRESH AIR FUND HOSTS
description: Last summer Jose and Tony Irizarry, 9-year-old identical twins who live with their mother in the Fordham section of the Bronx, went mountain climbing and wind-surfing, rode on a ferryboat and chased sea gulls on the beach.

title: PAC READY TO CLIMB TO MONUMENT SITE
description: SALISBURY IN 1887, a Norfolk philanthropist, Robbins Battell, commissioned a tower to be built atop Bear Mountain in the neighboring town of Salisbury to mark the highest point in Connecticut. When Mr. Battell's fieldstone monument was completed, it stood 2,316 feet above sea level, overlooking a point where the borders of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York meet.

title: CLAUDIA TUCKER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Claudia Kring Tucker, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Lewis Edwin Tucker of Houston, and Dr. George Bruce Mansbridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Ronald Mansbridge of Weston, Conn., were married yesterday in Galveston by the bride's father, minister emeritus of the United Methodist Church, at the Galveston Garden Club.

title: White House Is Given New Structural Tests
description: Government surveyors are checking the White House walls to make sure there are no signs of earth movement that could cause cracks, officials reported today.

title: FUTURE OF CONNECTICUT COLLEGE A SOURCE OF DEBATE
description: NEW LONDON CONNECTICUT COLLEGE has begun the largest fund-raising effort in its history and the most significant change in academic direction - and marketing strategy - since admitting men 13 years ago.

title: Nina Primm Is Married To Philip A. McIntyre
description: Nancy Louise Primm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Timon Primm 3d of St. Louis, was married there yesterday to Philip Archibald McIntyre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Randall Pomeroy McIntyre of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Patricia Handloss-Stern performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Crete
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Becker Is Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerrold M. Becker of Lake Success, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Norma Susan Becker, to George Roy Hill 3d, son of George Roy Hill and Louisa Horton Hill, both of New York.

title: The Region in Summary; Bingham Carves Himself Out
description: After nearly 18 years on Capitol Hill, Congressman Jonathan B. Bingham knows a lost political cause when he sees one. Last week, as Governor Carey signed a redistricting plan cutting the state's delegation from 39 to 34, the Bronx Democrat said he would not seek re-election.

title: ON SAFARI, ARMED WITH A CAMERA
description: HARRIET HEYMAN, formerly an editor at The New York Times Week in Review, is a writer who has a special interest in wildlife and conservation. By HARRIET HEYMAN

title: HOME RULE HASN'T CURED WASHINGTON'S BELTWAY BLUES
description: Spring is the capital season along the Potomac, but under the bursts of dogwood, magnolia and cherry blossoms, the nation's capital is not thinking capital thoughts. A mayoral election is at hand, only the third since Congress granted the city a grudging measure of home rule in the 1970's, and citizens are examining the harder aspects of life in the 15th-largest American city.

title: A Gathering of Whitney's
description: THE resemblance of the Whitney men to the centuries-old portraits of Eli Whitney hanging on the walls was startling. The same small, stubborn chins under flat cheeks and deep-set eyes.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CITY OF SMALL WORLDS
description: DAVID HARRIS is a writer who lives in San Francisco. His latest book, ''Dreams Die Hard: Three Men's Journey through the Sixties,'' is forthcoming from St. Martin's/ Marek. By DAVID HARRIS

title: Other Business; NO HORSING AROUND, THIS STUFF'S FOR SALE
description: Call it hindsight, but Mark Costello claims his horses ''leave a lot to be desired.'' And whatever they leave, he wants to sell. Earlier this year Mr. Costello, vice president of properties for the New York Racing Association, was handed the unenviable responsibility of discarding the 250,000 cubic yards of horse manure produced annually at the three thoroughbred racing tracks where New Yorkers play to win. With a slick advertising campaign, he recently began his quest for someone who would solve his problem.

title: Sports People; A Helping Hand
description: While running unsuccesfully for a vacant Congressional seat in January, Colleen Howe incurred $20,000 in campaign debts. Mrs. Howe, the wife of Gordie Howe, the former hockey star, is expected to receive assistance in making up the debt from prominent sports figures at a $50-a-plate buffet fund-raiser June 14 in Hartford. The featured guests will be Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers; Otto Graham, the former star quarterback of the Cleveland Browns, and Al Kaline, the former Detroit Tiger star.

title: CHAMBER- OPERA: PREMIERE OF JACK AND THE BEANSTALK'
description: ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' a chamber-opera with score and libretto by Dominic Meiman, had its world premiere Thursday at Greenwich House in a production by the Broque Opera Company. The production, designed and directed by Marie King, and graced not only with many fine voices but also some highly inventive staging and costuming, took little time to entrance this listener. Mr. Meiman's music took a bit longer, but eventually it, too, proved its worth.

title: Postings; ALL ABAORD!
description: Starting Thursday and continuing through Sept. 13, Grand Central Terminal - the landmark Beaux Arts railroad station that barely escaped the wrecker's ball some years back - will be on view in two places in Manhattan.

title: TOURIST RAIL HOPES TO RUN PASSENGER LINE
description: IT has the best on-time record of any railroad in the state. It shows a yearly profit, which few larger railroads achieve. And it is Connecticut's third-largest tourist attraction, ranking after the Seaport and the Aquarium at Mystic.

title: INCREASED SLAUGHTER OF RHINOS FEARED
description: The conservationists who seek to protect Zambia's herds of wildlife are concerned over conflicting developments that may represent an increase in the illicit killing of rhinoceroses, a declining species in most parts of Africa.

title: Arguello Rallies, Halts Ganigan in 5
description: Alexis Arguello, who had been knocked down by a left hook in the first round, came back today to knock out Andrew Ganigan with one second left in the fifth round and retain his World Boxing Council lightweight title.

title: Suspicious Fires in Fall River
description: Fires struck a vacant cookie factory and two empty multiple-family dwellings early today, and fire officials said the origins of all three blazes were suspicious. Eleven days ago, a $13 million fire destroyed the landmark Notre Dame de Lourdes church and a five-block residential area in this southeastern Massachusetts city. Federal officials have declared the church fire scene a disaster area.

title: LACROSSE TALENT AND ITS COACHING
description: I'm sorry that Gerald Eskenazi feels it is tough to keep the great lacrosse players at home on Long Island. I regret that he had to go as far afield as Hobart and Cornell to find examples of the Island's lacrosse prowess. Apparently no one told him that Nassau Community College has been national junior college lacrosse champions in nine of the last 10 years. PAUL W. BRENNAN Professor Marketing-Retailing Department Nassau Community College

title: Jodi Foord Is Bride
description: Jodi D. Foord, daughter of Dorothy T. Foord of Tenafly, N.J., and F. Andrew Foord of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas E. Volk, son of Barbara S. Volk of Tenafly and Edward W. Volk of Demarest, N.J. The Rev. Robert T. Wolfe performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tenafly.

title: MCGRAW-HILL IS UPHELD IN SHIELDING NEWS SOURCES
description: A Federal appeals court has decided that McGraw-Hill Inc. was not required to disclose confidential news sources in an antitrust case. Reversing a ruling that held the publishing company in contempt of court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit stressed the importance of confidentiality in ''the pivotal function of reporters to collect information for public dissemination.''

title: Best Films on TV
description: Those scheduled, late-hour throwayaws persist - wasted bargains like the powerful "On the Beach," Sunday at 2:30 A.M. on Channel 11 A.M.; neat, punchy "Champion," Wednesday at 2 A.M. on Channel 5; "Man Without a Star," an adult Western, Thursday at 3 A.M. on Channel 9; Joanne Woodward's field day, "The Three Faces of Eve," Friday at 1:30 A.M. on ABC.

title: Maureen Teefy Is Wed To Alexander Cassini
description: Maureen Teefy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Teefy of Minneapolis, was married in New York yesterday to Alexander Cassini, son of Igor Cassini of Milan, Italy, and the late Charlene Wrightsman Cassini. The Rev. F. Forrester Church of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: WHERE FAIR TRIALS CRUSH BASIC RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING THE GAME
description: LATE INNINGS A Baseball Companion. By Roger Angell. 429 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.50.

title: PERNOD IN PARIS, ANTIQUES IN ADAMSTOWN
description: A Quartet Of Outings In Paris

title:
ANTIQUES;
TABLES FOCUS OF SHOW
description: 18th century to describe certain small furniture easily moved from one place to another. Thus Pembroke tables, tea tables, work tables and wine stands were ambulantes carried from one part of a room to another, from room to room as needed or perhaps to take advantage of better light from a particular window.

title: EMPHASIS ON THE FIGURATIVE AT SILVERMINE SHOW
description: THE New England Exhibition of Painting, Drawing and Sculpture, held annually at the Silvermine Guild Center for the Arts at 1037 Silvermine Road in New Canaan, is billed as the ''largest, oldest and most prestigious'' of its kind in the Northeast. The present display is the 33d and will remain through June 4.

title: Cheryl Beil Wed To S. J. Wayne
description: Cheryl Beil, assistant dean of students and coordinator for research and evaluation at George Washington University, was married yesterday to Stephen J. Wayne, professor of political science and public affairs at the university. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Max Ticktin at the couple's home in Washington.

title: Talking Remodelling; IS IT A GOOD IDEA IN YOUR SITUATION?
description: THE house has grown too small. Maybe you just want to move up to a f iner house. Perhaps the kids are growing and, for the sake of h armony, everybody in the family needs more privacy. Husbands and w ives may want separate study areas. Or there may have been job p romotions and raises and you figure you ought to be able to live b etter.

title:
DINING OUT;
CLASSIC FRENCH IN BANDSVILLE
description: THE surface dazzle of La Cremaillere in Banksville would seem convincingly enticing were culinary excellence not at issue. Charming 1750's house, gorgeous floral arrangements, warm dark-wood beams and wainscoting and such. However, the check mounts parlously near to New York City highs, and this does seem to be Westchester's highest-priced restaurant. The combination of such factors does not indicate that one gets what he pays for; quite contrarily, La Cremaillere, once excellent, has laterly become grossly disappointing - in the efforts of the kitchen and the service of the dining room staff. It would seem that only the flowers and the porcelain collection have survived the misfortunes of the last year.

title: WALLACE TO SEEK 4TH TERM AS GOVERNOR OF ALABAMA
description: George C. Wallace called together a few thousand old friends here today to listen to hillbilly music, eat barbecue and hear him announce his candidacy for a fourth term as Governor of Alabama.

title: FOR MEXICO'S NUCLEAR POWER PLANS, THE WORD IS MANANA
description: MEXICO CITY THE polished pitchmen from the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Sweden have become familiar figures along the treelined streets and elegant corridors of this capital city. They have been engaged in an increasingly determined effort to sell the Mexicans an unusual piece of merchandise - a nuclear power plant that they hope will open the door to many others.

title: NATO PREREQUISITE TO 'NO FIRST USE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Future Events Of Divers Functions
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. All American May 27 - Canadian and Latin American diplomats will be among the more than 500 guests at the second spring party to benefit the Center for Inter-American Relations. Those expected at the black-tie dinner-dance at the Tavern on the Green include Javier Perez de Cuellar, Secretary General of the United Nations; Kenneth Taylor, Canadian consul general in New York; Porfirio Munoz Ledo, Mexico's representative at the United Nations, and their wives. Mr. and Mrs. David Rockefeller head the benefit committee. The beneficiary, an affiliate of the Americas Society, is a nonprofit organization to educate Americans about the cultures and societies of other nations of the hemisphere. Tickets are $250.

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
John Lehmann-Haupt Offers Guitar Classics
description: The program with which the guitarist John Lehmann-Haupt made his New York debut last Sunday at Carnegie Recital Hall offered the standard hommage to old masters at the start and a predictable sampling of Tarrega, Albeniz and Villa-Lobos at the close, touched traditionally on Sor and made an obligatory nod in the direction of the contemporary with Frank Martin's nearly 50-year-old Four Short Pieces. Aside from the Martin, there were few surprises, though this would have hardly been significant if the guitarist had played in an arresting fashion.

title: SHOULD AMERICAN JEWS ENCOURAGE CONVERTS?
description: Perhaps no issue in recent years has caused more vigorous debate within the American Jewish community than a proposal made in December 1978, by Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, the most liberal branch of Judaism. Responding to the increasing concern among American Jews about the large number of defections through assimilation and intermarriage, Rabbi Schindler called upon Judaism to cast aside its aversion to proselytizing and undertake an outreach program aimed at non-Jewish partners in mixed marriages and at ''unchurched'' Americans.

title: STUDY OF ANIMALS AIDS SPECIAL STUDENTS
description: ''IS he the kind of snake that can climb up in the trees?'' ''Does he bite?'' ''How big will he get?'' The third-grade children visiting the animal program at the Adaptive Center for Educational Success, the alternative high school in Bedford, fire questions at the student instructor, Peter Stonsby, as soon as he finishes his brief talk on snakes. He answers each child carefully, while removing the tan and black African ball python from its cage.

title: MEANS AND GOALS OF TAX POLICY
description: The seemingly endless debate over the Federal budget is forcing Congress and the nation to confront a profound question - whether direct Government expenditures or indirect tax subsidies are the better way to achieve a social policy objective.

title: CITY BALLET: ROBBINS
description: There's no plot to either Jerome Robbins's ''The Goldberg Variations'' or John Taras's ''Souvenir de Florence,'' which the New York City Ballet offered Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. Yet each contains images of gracious human behavior.

title: Ceausescu to Visit Syria
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania, who has sometimes played a backstage role in Middle East peace negotiations, will pay an official two-day visit to Syria next Tuesday, a Syrian official said here today. The official said a highlevel Soviet delegation was also expected in Damascus next week for talks with Syrian officials.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1974) who, while building a major independent oil company and amassing one of the world's largest fortunes, welcomed public attention as paterfamilias, superpatriot and health crank and secretly sired two illegitimate families. Harry Hurt, a Texas Monthly editor, concludes the story with the recent disastrous attempt by two of Hunt's sons to corner the world's silver supply.

title:
ART;
TAKING A LOCAL LOOK AT 'SOHO'
description: WHITE PLAINS PEOPLE who are interested in the art of today but lack the time for frequent visits to SoHo could not do better than to pay a visit to ''The New Wave Splash - Impact on Visual Arts.'' The show is at the Museum Gallery on the second floor of the White Plans Public Library through June 17.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE VALUE OF THE U.N.
description: Paris, May 22 - It has come to seem natural that the United Nations should be as busy talking as Britain and Argentina are busy fighting in the Falklands. This is a moment to consider the value of the world organization.

title: STATE UNIT POPOSES HOPE CREEK REVIEW
description: NEWARK THE state's Department of Energy, citing changes in economics and capacity requirements, is calling for a complete examination of whether the Public Service Electric and Gas Company should finish building its Hope Creek I nuclear-power plant in Salem County.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Total Eclipse For Transit Tax
description: With the Reagan Administration's rejection of a proposed transportation tax last week, supporters of the plan predicted that the plight of mass transportation would go from bad to worse. ''It's a dark day for the users of mass transit,'' said Jack R. Gilstrap, executive vice president of the American Public Transit Association.

title: Around the Nation; Hospital Denies a Role In Retarded Baby Death
description: Defending itself against a threatened cutoff of Federal funds, Bloomington Hospital says it did not discriminate against a handicapped newborn baby that died there. It said hospitals do not prescribe medical treatment.

title: Children's Books
description: DRAGON'S BLOODBy Jane Yolen 243 pp. New York: Delacorte Press $11.95 (Ages 11 to 14)

title:
MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW;
Frederick Moyer, Piano, Plays Bach and Mozart
description: The New York debut of Frederick Moyer, pianist, Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall was one of those involving affairs in which it was clear from the start that someone worth hearing, and with outstanding potential, had sat down to play. The program -which consisted of Bach's Partita No. 5 in G, Mozart's Sonata in D (K. 576), Chopin's Ballade No. 3, Rachmaninoff's Variations on a Theme of Corelli (Op. 42) and Beethoven's ''Waldstein'' Sonata - seemed designed to establish Mr. Moyer's credentials in variety of styles, but it was more than a loose assortment of divergent pieces.

title: Art Criticism Draws Mixed Reactions
description: It has always been my understanding that criticism educates the reader; that the critic puts into perspective the work viewed, whether it be in relation to the body of the artist's work, or in relation to the broader history of art. However biased the critic may be, one always assumes that the viewpoint is consistent, expressed by one supposedly educated in the history and plurality of art.

title: Around the World; 73 Convicted in Bahrain Of Trying to Stage Coup
description: Seventy-three Shiite Moslem militants accused of having taken part in an Iranian-inspired coup attempt against the Bahrain Government last December were convicted today by the Supreme Court, but received milder sentences than had been widely expected.

title: Television Week
description: Computerized Animation

title: ART IN PUBLIC PLACES STIRS WIDENING DEBATE
description: ''The fastest-growing industry in the United States,'' a Government official joked recently, ''is public art.'' The statement isn't so far-fetched. Public art blossomed in the 19th century, with its rage for battle monuments and statues of heroes on horseback. Another surge came in the 1930's and 40's, when - as Depression aid - the Treasury Department and the Works Progress Administration gave to hundreds of artists commissions for public buildings.

title: DATA SHOW MILLIONAIRE CLUB IN SENATE IS STABLE
description: In 1981, members of the Senate once again were better off than their legislative contemporaries in the House, financial disclosure reports have shown.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
COLONIAL FAIR
description: Taking 20th-century folks back to an era long gone, the Three Village Historical Society will stage its annual Spring Fair today. From noon to 5 P.M. the grounds of the 1730 Thompson House on North Country Road in Setauket will be transformed into a showcase for Colonial arts and crafts, featuring demonstrations of spinning, dyeing, weaving, candle-making and stenciling. There will also be musical entertainment. While the fair is free - except for what you buy - tours of the pre-Revolutionary home will cost $1, or 50 cents for the elderly and 25 cents for children; a bus trip through historic districts in the area will be $2, or 50 cents for children; and antiques appraisals will set collectors back $1 each.HIGH NOTES

title: The Region in Summary; Musto Replaced - Not Entirely
description: State Senator William V. Musto may have fallen from grace with the law, but he remains a high authority in New Jersey politics. Last week, the day after a seven-year jail sentence ended the Democrat's 16-year senatorial career, he handpicked a ''caretaker'' for his seat.

title: Editors' Choice
description: 80. HANNAH ARENDT, by Elisabeth Young-Bruehl. (Yale University Press, $25.) A biography of the German-born philosopher and social critic. THE JOURNALS OF SYLVIA PLATH, edited by Ted Hughes and Frances McCullough.

title: Pleasant Running
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 GET FINE ARTS FELLOWSHIPS
description: Twenty fellowships have been awarded to young artists and writers by the Fine Arts Work Center of Provincetown, Mass., for a session from October through April. The fellows, chosen from 800 applicants, will receive live-in studio space in Provincetown and monthly stipends to pursue art projects.

title: BIG BOOM IN YACHT RACING
description: The bays and inlets of America's eastern coastline will be billowing with sails today, as the ever-expanding fleet of oceangoing sailboats returns to its element for another season of racing.

title: DOING ALL RIGHT BY DOING DOO-WOP
description: Doo-wop, the vocal group music that flourished on big city street corners and in tenement hallways and subway stations beginning in the 1940's, gave rock and roll one of its most cherished myths - the overnight success story. After the Orioles, the Ravens, and the other early ''bird groups'' came out of nowhere to record huge nationwide hits, the owners of independent record labels began looking for similar groups on the streets, on school playgrounds, and at amateur night contests such as those presented weekly by Harlem's Apollo Theater.

title: TEACHING THE AUTISTIC: MORE VIEWS
description: At Benhaven in New Haven, Conn., there are 50 students who arrive with similar or comparable disabilities. The lack of relatedness, the bizarre behavior, the echolalic or otherwise atypical language, the muteness, the self-stimulation, the low I.Q. and low developmental levels are all accepted and recognized as part of the syndrome of autism.

title: A GRACEFUL MOVE 'UPSTAIRS'
description: PHILIP JOHNSON has never been known as a retiring architect. And he i s not retiring now. What he has become is consultant to the firm of J ohn Burgee Architects - the entity that will carry into the future t he practice he and Mr. Burgee have shared as Johnson/Burgee.

title: TAPESTRIES GET A SUDSY FRESH START
description: HARTFORD'S stately Wadsworth Atheneum, the oldest art museum in the country, is not above airing its dirty linen in public when it can draw a paying audience and help keep the budget in balance.

title: THE TWINS START FROM SCRATCH
description: THE Minnesota Twins are the youngest, the least experienced, and the most poorly paid team in baseball. It may not come as a shock to learn that they also have the worst record in baseball - 12-30 - and hold last place in the American League West.

title: MAAZEL, STEPPING DOWN, CALLS ORCHESTRA FLAWLESS
description: After a decade as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra - succeeding the legendary George Szell -Lorin Maazel stepped down after last night's performance at Carnegie Hall. He will become head of the Vienna State Opera in the fall.

title: DUMPS AND DRAGONS ON PRIME TIME
description: FOR seven lean years the residents of the Salem area of Port Washington fought against a giant, stinking landfill just hundreds of yards from their homes, a landfill that is leaking explosive gas and toxic chemicals into their backyards. No one wanted to hear that carcinogens had moved into the neighborhood: not their fellow citizens - myself included - who were soothed and reassured by local officials that their health and property values were sound; not the Town of North Hempstead government, which wallowed in dumping fees and taxes from industry; not Nassau County and New York State. They didn't like the landfill, but claimed they were powerless to take any substantive action.

title: MANNES OFFERS 'DAFNE'
description: The Mannes Camerata's entry into the opera life of New York Friday night was a pleasant one. The music was ''La Dafne, '' Marco da Gagliano's early operatic venture from the year 1608. The place was Christ Church on Park Avenue and the performers, students from the Mannes College of Music's Early Music Program with a few professionals mixed in.

title: Sports of The Times; Steinbrenner On Thin Ice
description: NEARLY a decade ago, George Steinbrenner tip-toed into baseball as somebody who was going to ''stick to building ships.'' But wherever the Yankees' principal owner goes now, it's as if he were preceded by a drum and bugle corps. Percussion and brass. For that reason, George Steinbrenner has little chance of acquiring the anticipated New Jersey franchise in the National Hockey League.

title: Jean Stearns Rath Wed in Connecticut To Bradford Burnett Kopp, Bank Aide
description: At St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield, Conn., yesterday, Jean Stearns Rath, daughter of John Stearns Rath of New York and Litchfield and the late Mrs. Rath, was married to Bradford Burnett Kopp, son of Ruth P. Koff of New York and Norfolk, Conn., and W. Brewster Kopp of Bronxville, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Gurniak, assisted by the Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Sports Authority Is Taken to Task
description: I was pleased to read Robert Hanley's article of March 28 on the development of DeKorte State Park in the Hackensack Meadowlands. Chester P.Mattson is to be commended for his fine job in preserving our vanishing meadows and reclaiming the dumps. (Mr. Mattson is chief environmental officer of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission.)

title: Rangers 3, Royals 1
description: Randy Bass, a pinch-hitter, drilled a sacrifice fly to lead a two-run rally for Texas in the 12th inning. Bass's sacrifice fly came off the Kansas City reliever Dan Quisenberry (1-2) with the bases loaded and scored Leon Roberts, who had opened the inning with a single.

title: About Books and Authors; Wheeling and Dealing
description: PETER DRUCKER has written 18 books since 1939, during which time he has established himself as one of the most influential thinkers and writers on modern management. On June 2, Harper & Row will publish his first novel, ''The Last of All Possible Worlds.'' Why had the 72-year-old theorist waited so long before deciding to tackle fiction? ''Because the ultimate test of the writer is the novel and I never had the courage to try it,'' he said. ''But once I passed 70, I was no longer terribly worried about making an ass of myself.''

title: MOLLOY CAPTURES TRACK TITLE
description: A victory in the final event, the 1,600-meter relay, clinched the team title for Archbishop Molloy yesterday in the 56th Annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships at Brooklyn College.

title: Brezhnev Replies On Nuclear Arms
description: A rare public appearance by Leonid I. Brezhnev last week was a clear sign of the political importance the Soviet leadership ascribes to nuclear arms control. For 30 minutes, the obviously feeble Soviet leader stood and addressed a Kremlin audience, expressing approval of President Reagan's offer of new strategic arms negotiations but attacking his proposals for deep cuts in missile warheads as aimed at achieving superiority for the United States.

title: POLAND STEPS UP AN ANTI-U.S. CAMPAIGN
description: In what appears to be a coordinated campaign, Poland and the Soviet Union have accused the United States of subversion and of trying to plunge Poland into anarchy.

title: CORRECTION
description: The article on the Tribune Company last week incorrectly identified the founder of The Daily News. He was Capt. Joseph M. Patterson.

title: The World in Summary; Salvador Tries For 'Perfection'
description: During the campaign for the March 28 elections, many conservative Salvadoran politicians spoke of the need to ''perfect'' the country's land reform program. But last week, when the Constituent Assembly suspended the ''land to the tiller'' law, perfection looked more like repeal.

title: No Headline
description: It is so very human for survivors to feel personal guilt for their loved ones' tragedies.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cedarhurst $137,000 218 Oakland Avenue *2*6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; formal dining *2*room, eat-in kitchen, fireplace in living room; taxes $2,000. East Setauket $76,000 5 Wels Lane *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; formal *2*dining room, eatin kitchen, full basement; taxes $2,174. Port Washington $150,000 39 Soundview Lane *2*3-bedroom, 18-year-old split-level; *2*1 full and 2 half bathrooms; formal dining room, *2*fireplace in living room; taxes $3,000. St. James $65,000 242 Cedar Street *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old high ranch; formal *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $1,700. Stony Brook $110,000 78 Manchester Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath new colonial; eat-in *2*kitchen with skylight, 3-car garage; taxes $3,400. Woodmere $175,000 1036 Fordham Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath high ranch, L-shaped living *2*room with fireplace, den, maid's room; taxes $3,800. OTHER AREAS Mount Vernon, N.Y. $100,000 335 Collins Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 44-year-old stucco/ stone Tudor/ *2*Norman; full attic, walk to Fleetwood station; taxes $1,900. Cliffside Park, N.J. $180,645 300 Winston Towers *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old condominium; enclosed *2*terrace, wallto-wall carpeting; taxes $1,900. Shelton, Conn. $65,000 9 Fairview Avenue *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, colonial; screened porch, *2*V.A. assumable mortgage, 110-by-50-foot lot; taxes $425.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Douglas Dunn moved through his years with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company with a kind of compelling, sleepy intensity. His own choreography often has that same quality.

title: HORSE SHOW REACHES OUT
description: DARIEN THE Ox Ridge Charity Horse Show continues to grow. When first held in 1930, only members participated in a single-ring program of 35 classes and the only spectators were members and their guests.

title: Sarah Bedell Wed To Stephen Smith
description: Sarah Rowbotham Bedell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Rowbotham of St. David's, Pa., was married yesterday to Stephen Grant Smith, a senior editor of Time magazine. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: MINORITY LEADER FROM PEORIA PLAYS THE HOUSE
description: Representative Robert H. Michel seemed vaguely uncomfortable during a recent Rose Garden ceremony at which President Reagan congratulated Republican Congressional leaders one by one for a compromise budget with the White House that included a proposal for $40 billion in Social Security savings - a proposal the House minority leader regarded as election-year suicide. As he grasped the outstretched Presidential hand he murmured, ''Thank you very much, but I think it's premature.''

title: JENNIFER BARTLETT CREATES AN ARCHETYPAL NEW FOUND LAND
description: There has never yet been an exhibition by Jennifer Bartlett that was not a remarkable event. ''Up the Creek'' and ''To the Island'' are the titles of the two works that make up her present show at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 155 Wooster Street. Each of them comes in 10 separate parts, and the least one can say of them is that they live up to our liveliest expectations.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW RESTAURANT AT AN OLD STAND
description: RESTAURANTS in New Jersey have improved steadily over the last few years. For the most part, the menus in the new establishments have been innovative, and the standard of food preparation has been both upgraded and modernized. Because we have come to expect this, we're disappointed when we confront a new restaurant that offers a hackneyed menu and food.

title: Perspectives: Condominiums; CONFLICT GROWING ON THE ISSUE OF RENTALS
description: OVER a 12-month period starting in 1978, Leonard Levy and his relatives and friends bought 23 condominiums i n Coventry Square, a town-house development in Lakewood, N.J. The i dea came from a cousin who was ready to take on the task of renting o ut the units and managing them.

title: SALES OF STEREOS ARE LESS SOUND AS AUDIO INDUSTRY'S MARKETS SLIP
description: AS surely as the needle tracks the groove, the stereo component i ndustry followed a path of ever-rising sales and profits during the 1 970's boom decade. But a three-year-long sales slump has worsened t his year, as a critical surplus of stereo components threatens the i ndustry's profitability as prices plummet.

title: Chata Robinson And Hugh Smith Will Wed in July
description: Eileen G. Cumming of Penn Valley, Pa., and Robert J. Robinson Jr. of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Chata Ashley Robinson, to Hugh Maguire Smith, son of Mr and Mrs. Gerard C. Smith of Washington.

title: SOUTH AMERICANS INTENSIFY CALLS FOR MEDIATION BY U.N.
description: The British landing in the Falkland Islands intensified calls throughout South America today for reviving the lapsed United Nations mediation and, in several cases, for increasing Latin solidarity moves in support of Argentina.

title: INTRODUCING CHILDREN TO KITCHEN
description: THE four children sat around the table, waiting for the class to begin. As they nibbled on pretzels and sipped juice, they chatted casually about their favorite recipes. They also talked about why they had enrolled in the course, offered for the first time by the Greenburgh Department of Parks and Recreation and billed as a ''professional cooking class for youngsters.''

title: EQUITY'S REVIVAL OF 'APPLAUSE'
description: When ''Applause'' arrived on Broadway at the Palace Theater in 1970, it came with two built-in objects that it was a musical based on what was by then a classic film, ''All About Eve,'' in which Bette Davis and Anne Baxter gave brilliant performances. The other was that it marked the musical-theater debut of Lauren Bacall.

title: Business Conditions; GRIM STEEL PROSPECTS
description: As last quarter's profit statements show, conditions are grim in the steel business. In the first quarter, seven of the nation's 10 leading steel manufacturers lost money.

title:
Comment;
THE DRYSDALE AFFAIR
description: SHOCK waves like those triggered by the March 1980 silver market c ollapse reverberated through Wall Street this week after it was a nnounced that Drysdale Government Securities Inc. was unable to pay $ 160 million (later amended to $270 million) in interest accrued on g overnment bonds that it had borrowed from the Chase Manhattan Bank. C hase, in turn, initially refused to pay that interest to its 30-odd s ecurities firm customers, on the theory that it had acted only as D rysdale's agent. Upon reconsideration, however, Chase agreed to pay.T he default made news because, even in government securities markets,$ 270 million is a lot of money.

title: BEDFORD INMATES DECIDE FUND USE
description: MEMBERS of the Westchester Citizens Committee of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency visited the Bedford Hills Correctional Institution last week to meet with the chairmen of several inmate committees whose efforts have been aided by the creation of a $127,000 fund controlled be the inmates.

title: NEW RULES SOUGHT ON LEARJET SAFETY
description: The National Transportation Safety Board is preparing a new set of recommendations that it hopes might further reduce a disturbing incidence of fatal accidents and near accidents involving Learjet business planes.

title: SOME LATIN NATIONS SAID TO DISCUSS BREAKING TIES WITH BRITAIN
description: The Spanish-speaking countries of the Caribbean region, who have supported Argentina throughout the Falkland crisis, are reportedly discussing the possibility of suspending diplomatic relations with London following the landing of British troops on the islands Friday.

title: GOD AND STATE INSEPARATE
description: To the Editor:

title: FARMLAND PROGRAM GAINS IN 2D PHASE
description: HAUPPAUGE SUFFOLK COUNTY is signing contracts to purchase development rights to 3,354 more acres of farmland in a second phase of the Farmlands Preservation Program.

title: TREES TELL TALE OF ESTATE
description: A UNIVERSITY campus carries with it, over the years, the flavor of its past. Its history may be traced not only by observing the architecture, but also its trees and shrubs. Sometimes the plantings trace the lines of the foundations of buildings long gone; occasionally they give a clue to the tastes and habits of former occupants of the land.

title: Around the Nation; Ex-Wells Fargo Worker Gets 5 Years in Swindle
description: A former Wells Fargo Bank employee who admitted he and a boxing promoter, Harold Rossfields Smith, conspired to embezzle a Wells Fargo Bank out of $21.3 million was sentenced Friday to five years in prison.

title: FORTUNES OF HOOSICK FALLS ARE ON THE RISE AGAIN
description: The state of Vermont may be picturesque, gorgeous, pastoral, verdant, bucolic, scenic, hospitable, beautiful, elegant and historic. But if the residents here along the Hoosic River are asked their opinion of Vermont, they say none of the above apply.

title: LAPIDARY TOUCHES IN JEWELS
description: There is a new temptation for those Washingtonians whose pockets are lined with silver. They can join such international celebrities as former Empress Farah of Iran, Grand Duke Jean of Luxembourg, the late Nelson A. Rockefeller and Valentino in owning the designs of Haroldo Burle Marx, the Brazilian gemologist and jeweler.

title: JERSEY CITY DEBATES VACANCY CONTROL
description: JERSEY CITY EVER since taking office last July 1, Mayor Gerald McCann has advocated the enactment of a vacancy decontrol ordinance as a means of spurring housing development here in the state's second-largest city.

title: CERONE STILL HOPING HE CAN HELP YANKS
description: Last Wednesday, his 28th birthday, began as one of the more depressing days in Rick Cerone's life. His teammates, among them Butch Wynegar, the new catcher, were completing a two-week trip that had been interrupted for Cerone by a broken left thumb and subsequent surgery. The operation May 14 had been judged a success, but he was expected to miss at least two months. His future seemed to have been jeopardized by the freakish injury, which occurred after a tag at the plate, and the trade for Wynegar.

title: Laura Ladd Wed To Luke Bierman
description: Laura McDermott Ladd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin V. Ladd Jr., of Bristol, Conn., was married yesterday to Luke J. Bierman, son of Judge and Mrs. Herbert B. Bierman of Sayreville and Harvey Cedars, N.J. Robert A. Wall, a retired Connecticut Superior Court Judge, performed the ceremony at the Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are planning a trip to London and as we are senior citizens we are afraid to rent a car and drive on the wrong side of the road. We would like to travel to Selborne to see where Gilbert White (''Natural History of Selborne'') lived. Can one get there from London by public transportation, and are there overnight accommodations one could reserve? -P.K., Kinnelon, N.J. Answer:You can take a train from London's Waterloo station to Alton, about five miles northwest of Selborne. Trains leave hourly throughout the business day, beginning at 7:42 A.M.; the trip is scheduled to take one hour and 12 minutes. Return service is similar, hourly throughout the business day, and the fare is $8 a person one way. If you plan to travel by train elsewhere in England it would be good to check with BritRail (630 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-599-5400) about their senior-citizen discount. For a one-week pass, for example, those 65 and over pay the coach rate of $107 and receive a first-class pass that normally costs $147.

title: VENEZUELA'S TIES WITH U.S. PLUMMET AS IT RALLIES BEHIND THE ARGENTINES
description: Banners pledging Latin America's undying support for Argentina's claim to the Malvinas Islands, as Buenos Aires calls the Falklands, hang from freeway overpasses in this pulsating city of 3.5 million people.

title: AT HOME ON THE ROAD
description: SALLY S. CAMPBELL is a writer who lives in Wilton, Conn. BY SALLY S.CAMPBELL

title: Sports People; Linebacker Paralyzed
description: Mike Woods, the 27-year-old linebacker for the Baltimore Colts who was shot Friday morning, was reported yesterday to have ''a severe case of paralysis,'' and doubt was expressed that he would ever play again. Dr. Melvin Shafron, the chief of neurosurgery at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Cleveland, described Woods's condition as ''stable but serious.'' A bullet was said to have gone through the spinal cord and lodged in his neck.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: PELHAM
description: ''W E'RE a small, sleepy town,'' said Anthony J. Noto, the Pelham Town Supervisor. Small, yes, for the town - which actually consists of two villages, Pelham and Pelham Manor - is only 2.4 square miles. Sleepy, yes, with cul-de-sacs, winding roads, fine old trees and some of the most elegant homes in southeastern Westchester County.

title: Susan A. Loney Is Married To George H. Oestreich 3d
description: Susan Allen Loney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Roosevelt Loney Jr. of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church to George Henry Oestreich 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oestreich Jr. of Port Washington, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Almus M. Thorp Jr., assisted by the Rev. Hayes H. Rockwell.

title: TRACING TERMITES IN EVOLUTION
description: TO most suburbanites, termites are overabundant pests that cause millions of dollars of damage to wooden structures. But two scientists at the State University at Stony Brook have placed the primitive social insects at the center of their personal and professional lives.

title: VENISON DOWN UNDER
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a writer who lives in the Hudson Valley. BY R.V.DENENBERG

title: WORLD'S FAIR TOURISTS STEERED TO MORE EXPENSIVE HOUSING
description: The World's Fair housing bureau has steered tourists away from hotels to higher-priced apartments in a remodeled tobacco warehouse where accommodations are much more Spartan.

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR: WHAT U.S. SHOULD DO
description: THE effect on Connecticut of actions taken by the Federal Government is expected to persist as a major issue in this year's gubernatorial campaign. The New York Times asked the Republican and Democratic candidates for the Governor's office this question:

title: Patricia Foisie Is Betrothed to Matthew B. Schiff
description: The engagement of Patricia Abbie Foisie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Foisie of Tamalpais Valley, Calif., and Johannesburg, to Matthew Bart Schiff, son of Ivy Graber Schiff of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Lawrence Robert Schiff, has been announced by Miss Foisie's parents.

title: EITHER SIDE'S VICTORY COULD COST HEAVILY IN WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON AS the Falklands crisis reached a turning point, the United States found itself in an uncomfortable situation, uncertain whether it should concentrate on helping Britain achieve a military victory or on trying again to secure a negotiated compromise that would avoid a humiliation for either side.

title: The Week in Business; A SEVERE DECLINE IN CORPORATE PROFITS
description: Corporate profits fell 17.5 percent, almost a record, in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported. In addition, the gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, fell at an annual rate of 4.3 percent in the quarter, a steeper drop than the 3.9 percent forecast last month. The reports indicate that the recession is likely to continue at least through June, contradicting Administration assertions that it had touched bottom.

title: G.W. Sullivan Marries Dr. Katherine Martien
description: Dr. Katherine May Martien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Martien of Trappe, Md., was married yesterday to Gregory William Sullivan, son of Mrs. Fredrick Eugene Sullivan of Dover, Mass., and the late Mr. Sullivan. The Rev. Robert Bohaker of Oxford, Md., performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Easton, Md.

title: Marie A. Casarella Wed to Executive
description: At the Butler Memorial Chapel of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday, Marie Ann Casarella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Casarella of Irvington, N.Y., was married to Walter Egon Freese 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Freese Jr. of Dix Hills, L.I. The Rev. John F. Lauri performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Oysters
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL IN BRONX TREATS ITS ENVIRONS
description: When Leah Shapira and her husband moved with their infant son to 3504 Rochambeau Avenue in the northwest Bronx 50 years ago, her neighborhood of Norwood, wedged between Van Cortlandt and Bronx Parks, was, she said, ''a lovely area, the next best thing to living in the suburbs.'' And her building was one of the many handsome ones sheltering the area's sizable middle-income population.

title: Topics; DEFENDING WELFARE; Work Incentive
description: Congress has begun to see that the Reagan Administration's changes in welfare law can boomerang. For example, consider the working poor.

title: FAMILIES COPING WITH CORONARIES
description: IN a select group of American homes, a visitor could note the absence of cigarettes on the coffee table but the presence of an exercise bike in the den and of chicken on the dinner table. What sets these homes apart from a random sampling of family dwellings? Commonly, it is the behavior modification following a coronary attack in a family member - most often the adult male.

title: Mailbox; Quit, Sugar Ray; Don't Risk It
description: To the Sports Editor: To answer the question agitating and disturbing sports fans and the fight community regarding Sugar Ray Leonard's decision on whether to quit or continue in the ring after having suffered a detached retina:

title: 25 MEN RETURN TO STREETS OF MEMORY
description: Yesterday morning in Washington Heights, under the surprised gaze of the residents, 25 joking middle-aged men walked the streets of their youth talking of stickball and the long summer evenings when the whole neighborhood was out on the stoops.

title: Around the World; Jakarta Denies Refusing To Accept U.S. Envoy
description: Foreign MInister Mochtar Kusumaatmadja denied today that the Indonesian Government had refused to accept the appointment of Morton I. Abramowitz as United States Ambassador.

title: FIRST-TIME WINNERS
description: An old argument concerns the importance of partnership understanding and preparation. Some players, usually those who lack the enthusiasm and energy to do the necessary work, make do with a minimum of preliminary discussion and maintain that two fine players will always do well together.

title: CANDIDATES LINE UP FOR SURROGATE COURT RACE
description: An old-fashioned scramble is shaping up for a seat on the Manhattan Surrogate's Court, a lucrative source of legal patronage. Nine lawyers have submitted their names to a pair of screening panels. Other candidates might also turn up for the $65,613-a-year judgeship that will become vacant this year with the scheduled retirement of Millard L. Midonick from the two-judge court, the busiest Surrogate's Court in New York State.

title: PROBABLE; Military Analysis
description: A senior British Government official said tonight that he expected the three marine commando battalions and the two parachute battalions now ashore at Port San Carlos in the Falkland Islands to begin harassing raids on Argentine defensive positions, some of them miles from the bridgehead perimeter.

title: SHOULD TAXES PAY FOR COTTON CANDY?
description: Lee Guber, co-producer of the Westbury Music Fair, made these remarks recently at the Downtown Long Island Forum. THE Department of Parks of the State of New York assumes that the citizens of the state living this side of the East River are not too bright, not too tasteful, and therefore can only digest an arts diet of cotton candy, Oreo cookies and cultural Kool-Aid.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 23, 1982
description: International Britain widened its bridgehead on East Falkland Island to 10 square miles and more troops reinforced those already ashore. Defense Minister John Nott announced in London that a British missile frigate, the 3,250-ton Ardent, was sunk in Falkland Sound with the presumed loss of 20 men. British sources said that 5,000 British marines and paratroopers had moved into the bridgehead around San Carlos Bay on the northwestern coast of East Falkland. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Sports People; Hard-Luck Pitcher
description: The Kansas City right-hander Dennis Leonard will be out for six to eight weeks after breaking two fingers on his pitching hand when he tried to protect his face from a line drive Friday night in a game against the Texas Rangers. The liner, by Buddy Bell, ricocheted off Leonard's hand and resulted in a double play, which helped him get a 3-0 victory. Leonard missed a start earlier this season because of a sprained ankle, and he tore a hamstring in spring training.

title: ARMS STUDY GROUP FACING DIFFICULTY
description: The last 12 months have been difficult ones for the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, an organization whose stated goal has been to provide independent analysis of armaments and the global balance of power.

title: OTIS FERGUSON
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen Owen Is Bride Of Richard B. Buckley
description: Karen Anne Owen, daughter of the late Pamela Owen Smith of Shrewsbury, Mass., was married yesterday to Richard B. Buckley, son of Mrs. Alfred Buckley of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Buckley. The Rev. Kendrick L. Norris performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Sachem's Head, Conn.

title: NEW RELEASES HIGHLIGHT MUSIC IN THE FRENCH MANNER
description: One hundred years ago, Erik Satie was dismissed from the Paris Conservatoire for failing to measure up to the standards of that august institution. At 16, he had been a student there for three years. By the time he was 21, he had composed his then startling three Sarabandes, with their unresolved ninth chords. A year later came the three ''Gymnopedies,'' the purity and elegance of which are known and cherished the world around. Almost without trying, it seemed, he had become a composer whose works were to influence Debussy and Ravel and, later, many other composers.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT was suggested to George Washington early in the American Revolution that he use black troops against the British. He rejected the notion, however, although historians have noted that some thought at the time that it might have been appropriate to extend the ideals of the new republic to those still in bondage.

title: ONE CIVIL WAR IS OVER, OTHERS FAST MULTIPLY
description: A few weeks ago, Lebanese political parties marked the seventh anniversary of the start of this country's civil war. Given the continuing level of shooting and shelling, the Government has never been so bold as to designate an armistice day.

title: UPSIDE-DOWN PILING UPSETS HUNTINGTON
description: HUNTINGTON AS work nears completion, there is growing concern that the Town of Huntington may have cut corners excessively in the construction of a $63,000 extension for its municipal marina. At least one town employee and several Long Island marine contractors, none of whom submitted bids for the project, have criticized the decision to install structural piles upside down as a cost-saving measure.

title: IS THERE A DISTINCTIVE INDIAN VIEW OF THE WORLD?; by Gene Thornton
description: The best thing about ''Through Indian Eyes,'' a new exhibition of 19th- and early 20th-century photographs from India, is the collection of hand-painted portrait photographs. They are unlike anything seen in previous exhibitions of Eastern photography, and well worth a trip to the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, where the exhibition continues until July 4.

title: TENNIS ACROSS THE SEA
description: GLEN COVE ''SAY it in French!'' Tony Palafox shouted at the 13-year-old boy who had called his shot out in a tennis practice match at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: The Nation in Summary; Is This MX Mode Final?
description: President Reagan seems about ready to decide what to do with the MX. Officials said last week that while it isn't final, the Closely Spaced Basing System - Dense Pack to its friends in the Air Force - is ''most likely to be selected.''

title: IN FRANCE, THE OPPOSITION IS STILL WAITING FOR RAIN
description: In marking the first anniversary of President Francois Mitterrand's accession to power, France had a choice between two dates - May 10, when he was elected, and May 21, when he took office.

title: MILAN'S METROPOLITANA
description: CAROLE RIFKIND is a writer who lives in New York; her most recent book is ''A Field Guide to American Architecture.'' By CAROLE RIFKIND

title: Three Stravinsky Concerts
description: Carnegie Hall will present three fully staged performances of Stravinsky's ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' on June 8, 9 and 10 at 8 P.M. The direction is by Tom O'Horgan, and the work will be given in Sheldon Harnick's English translation. Gerard Schwarz will be the conductor. Information: 247-7459.

title: CRICKETERS TO OPEN A HALL OF FAME
description: HARTFORD ''EVERYBODY laughed,'' said Michael L. Chambers, recalling the negative reaction that he and a few other members of the Sportsmen's Athletic Club in Hartford encountered two years ago when they suggested establishing the world's first Cricket Hall of Fame.

title: GET READY FOR A FLOOD OF MOZART AND STRAVINSKY
description: If you happen to dislike either Stravinsky or Mozart, this might be a good time to leave town, or at least keep your windows closed and your travel options open. For the next few months, their music will be flooding the New York concert scene to the point of total immersion if not saturation. Enthusiasts of both composers may start bathing in their favorite sounds beginning on Wednesday evening when the New York Philharmonic gives the first of 12 concerts in its annual spring series. The programs, entirely given over to Stravinsky and Mozart, commemorate the 100th anniversary of the former's birth and pay tribute to the latter for no better or worse reason than that people cannot get enough of him nowadays. But that's not the whole Stravinsky picture by any means. Next week, on June 2, Carnegie Hall's second annual spring festival, the newly named Serenades, offers the first of 10 programs by the Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra, featuring works by Stravinsky, Bach, Haydn and Beethoven. Then, of course, we come to July and August, when the Mostly Mozart Festival takes over Avery Fisher Hall to continue one of the most successful cases of obsessiveness in concert history.

title: Postings; A REINCARNATION
description: In the Sandy Hook section of Newtown, Conn., on a well-wooded site straddling the Pootatuck River, stands an early Victorian red brick mill. Powered by the swift-running river, the mill produced some of the earliest Goodyear rubber products and later fire hoses.

title: Bidding Extended
description: To the Editor:

title: British Landing Opens Costlier Phase of Crisis
description: The dark side of patriotism glowered over the Falkland Islands last week. A British armada had sailed 8,000 miles. Argentina, which had not fought a war since the 19th century, had deployed 9,000 troops. Now, throwing overboard seven weeks of mediation, each side invoked high principles of national honor and international morality to justify military action. A dispute that briefly seemed quaint had become a real war.

title: NO PAUCITY OF SPRINGTIME SHOWS
description: AERIAL views of landscapes translated into handmade paper, now featured at the Whichcraft Studio and Gallery in South Orange, are among the more interesting works discovered in a sampling of spring crafts shows in northern New Jersey.

title: THE FAMOUS WRITING SCHOOLS
description: THROUGHOUT the country this month students are graduating from colleges and universities with degrees in creative writing. As they pick up their diplomas many are asking themselves whether the drain on their bank accounts and egos was worth it. What, after all, will a degree in creative writing get them in the world besides a puzzled frown or a snicker?

title: No Headline
description: Lucy Dawidowicz excuses both the United States and British Governments for their failure to act on the Jewish dimension of World War II. Instead, she levels abuse on the Irgun, whose activities made every freedom lover proud.

title: New York Times Magazine May 23, 1982
description: William Safire 10 On Language Burnout Richard F. Shepard 16 Guest Observer Gentrifying the South Bronx David Black 18 The Making of a Doctor Not so long ago, physicians dispensed comfort more often than cures. Now, doctors have at their disposal a vast arsenal of medicines and technologies to combat disease.

title: HOMEOWNERS JOIN TO CURB MOTH PEST
description: IN an effort to avert another season of gypsy moth infestation, homeowners around the state have been joining forces to hire ground or aerial spraying contractors on a group basis.

title: GLOBAL NEGOTIATIONS'S LIFE IS NOW IN U.S. HANDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Van Calcar Is Bride of Craig Anthony Landy
description: Mary Van Calcar and Craig Anthony Landy were married yesterday in St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Wyckoff, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Reginald Redlon, assisted by the Rev. William Carr, a professor of philosophy at Fairfield University.

title: Topics Defending Welfare
description: Economic Indicator

title: CASE FOR LANDLORDS ON CONVERSIONS
description: RECENT publicity has been given to tenant advocates who assert that the owners of apartment buildings converting to cooperative or condominum ownership are taking unfair advantage of tenants and that tenants need greater protections from the law. Numerous proposals for increasing tenants' bargaining power are suggested.

title: Thais Release 38 Foreigners For Bicentennial Celebration
description: Thirty-eight foreign prisoners, including two Americans, were released from prison today as part of an amnesty marking the bicentennial of Thailand's ruling dynasty.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE 100-year-old Vail-Leavitt Music Hall in Riverhead is one step closer to being returned to its Victorian grandeur. With the Town of Riverhead using $40,000 of Federal funds to purchase the property, the opera house, one of only two second-story music halls ever built in the metropolitan area, was recently turned over to a nonprofit citizens' group, the Council for the Vail-Leavitt Music Hall.

title: SUTTON IS HAPPY TO BE ABLE TO PITCH
description: Don Sutton, the hottest pitcher in the National League, unwrapped the bulging ice pack from his right knee, traced the long surgical scar with a finger and said:

title: Cubs 2, Giants 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO (UPI) - Steve Henderson singled in two runs in the fifth inning to lead Chicago.

title:
HOW TO KNOW A TEACHER;
SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THREE or four afternoons a week, Annabel goes to school. She used to go only occasionally, but now that first-grade work is getting more difficult - and more interesting - she goes more regularly. Annabel's teacher's name is, for our purposes, Mrs. Kent, and she holds class only when she is in the mood, but she says it is when Annabel needs to do more work. Classes usually take place between 3:30 and 4:30 in the afternoon, unless either Annabel or Mrs. Kent - in their other lives - has something more important to do.

title: Hegarty Hammer Winner
description: Declan Hegarty of Boston University won the IC4A hammer-throw title today for the second straight year because, he said, he is bigger and wiser. Unfortunately, he added, he is not big enough or wise enough.

title: FLOKATIS: GREEK WARMTH
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The New York Times from Athens. BY PAUL ANASTASI

title: Judge Is Censured for Calling Hispanic Citizens 'Tamales'
description: A judge who was quoted as calling Hispanic Americans ''cute little tamales and Taco Bells'' in front of court workers and was accused of remarks degrading to blacks and Filipinos has been censured by the California Supreme Court.

title: REMAINS OF LONG-ABSENT WHALE WASH ASHORE ON L.I. SOUND
description: The body of a 24-foot-long Minke whale washed up on the shore of Long Island Sound here earlier this week, to the excitement of marine experts, who said the remains were the first sign of the species in the Sound in 40 years.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: SONGS OF HIMSELF
description: ISLA NEGRA A Notebook. By Pablo Neruda. Translated by Alastair Reid. A bilingual edition. 416 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Headliners; Liberation Lawn
description: The grass may have been greener, but that wasn't what aroused Frank Paone.

title: Rare Siberian Crane Hatched
description: The fourth Siberian crane bred in captivity hatched this weekend at the International Crane Foundation in Baraboo, the foundation has announced.

title: OH, THOSE HIGH CAMPAIGN EXPENSES!
description: JOSEPH P. McMANEMIN, who ran for Councilman in the May 11 election in Ridgewood, was urged by one of his fellow candidates to limit his campaign expenditures to $1,500. This was his response:

title: FRAGILE UNITY IN COMMONS POSES RISKS FOR THATCHER
description: LONDON SATURDAY was a stirring morning for Britons. As they listened to radio and television, they heard the pounding of naval guns, the whoosh of missiles and the lap of the waves as war correspondents waded ashore. As they scanned their newspapers, they saw a photograph of three Royal Marines, faces blackened, hoisting the Union Jack over Port San Carlos in the Falkland Islands, seven weeks to the day after other marines on the other side of East Falkland had been forced to surrender ignominiously to the Argentine invaders.

title: OUR TAXES HELP PAY THE SAUDI 'RANSOM'
description: PRICE differences and the lingering surplus in the international oilm arket in the first quarter appear to have placed the four Aramco p artners, Exxon, Socal, Mobil and Texaco - together with American t axpayers - in the unusual position of directly subsidizing Saudi A rabia with as much as $25 million a day and indirectly supporting t he preferred price structure of the Organization of Petroleum E xporting Countries. Whether that process should be termed subsidy or' 'blackmail,'' as others have suggested, is open to serious question.

title: Survivor of Van Crash Leaves L.I. Hospital
description: Kathleen Caemmerer, the only survivor of a van-train collision that killed nine teen-agers in March, has been released from Nassau Hospital.

title: Paula Healey Has Nuptials
description: Paula Jean Healey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Patrick Healey of Clifton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Richard Lathrop Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of Montclair, N.J. Msgr. Joseph J. Gallo performed the ceremony at St. Philip the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.

title: Two Bloodied Flags Are Enough
description: Britain has evidently retaken a piece of the Falklands - enough, at least, to plant the flag and transform the contest. This is an impressive military feat for an armada far from home, but it has exacted a bitter price. Scores lie dead, Britons and Argentines. Even through the mist of censorship and propaganda, one can see the grim wreckage of diplomacy. Two flags in the Falklands should now revive it, and end the bloodshed.

title: THE WARMING OF CHRISTOPHER DURANG
description: For some years now, in works such as ''Sister Mary Ignatius Does It All for You'' and ''Das Lusitania Songspiel,'' Christopher Durang has looked at the world in a highly distinctive, bitingly witty way. His knack for expertly skewering assorted subjects on fine-honed barbs of satire has established him, at the age of 33, as one of playwriting's ranking iconoclasts.

title: THE VERY MIXED BLESSINGS OF PURE LIQUID GOLD
description: In the 16th and 17th centuries, the Spanish economy was deluged with silver from New World discoveries. The economy soared, people became wealthy beyond their grandest dreams and Utopia seemed at hand. But the blessing soon seemed decidedly mixed as corruption flourished; hard work lapsed into memory and the productive segments of the economy languished in underdevelopment. Was the silver a blessing or a curse?

title: CHERYL YEAGER AND PETER FONSECA IN 'THEME' DEBUTS
description: Cheryl Yeager and Peter Fonseca are two of the American Ballet Theater's most promising young dancers, and their debuts in the lead roles in George Balanchine's ''Theme and Variations'' on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House were models of clarity and good dancing. Fast and full of brisk little changes of direction and demanding footwork with no time or space for preparation, the ballet is something of a trial by fire. Miss Yeager's leg work could have been slightly crisper, and Mr. Fonseca seemed a little nervous. But both performers brought an unusual buoyancy to the choreography.

title: ONWARD GOES THE PARAGRAPH
