description: A MEDITATIONBy Juan Benet. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. 366 pp. New York: Persea Books. $15.95.

title: Television Week
description: Horror Story Victor Herman's story is bizarre. In 1931, at 16, he left Detroit with his father, mother, older brother and a younger sister for the Soviet Union.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: There are two new titles on the hard-cover fiction list: John Gregory Dunne's ''Dutch Shea, Jr.'' and John Gardner's James Bond thriller, ''For Special Services.'' The mass-market paperback list turns up another Gardner/Bond, ''License Renewed.''

title: PRISON PROBLEMS UNDERSCORED
description: JERSEY CITY THE ruling by a Superior Court judge last week that conditions in the overcrowded Hudson County Jail were unconstitutional, and his move to have state prisons accept inmates under sentence, underlined the continuing problem facing New Jersey's penal system.

title: THE MAIN COURSE IS THE SEA VIEW
description: ONE sure signal that summer is almost here is the seasonal opening of The Pier. This old-time standby on the Sound in South Norwalk, which is open from May through September, is now in full swing. Boats coming, going and refueling provide visual interest for diners. The three large dining areas of The Pier have head-on views of the water, and the only impediment to thorough enjoyment of the seafront activity is the aroma of diesel fuel that wafts through the open windows when a boat is being refueled below.

title: THE AUDIO-VIDEO ERA BEGINS; by Hans Fantel
description: The marriage of audio and video - after a long and somewhat tentative period of engagement - has finally, in a manner of speaking, been consummated. The nuptial pair has come together from somewhat different backgrounds. Audio looks back on the long and distinguished lineage of the phonograph, spanning most of this century and assured in its respectability. Video, by contrast, is a rather brash parvenue, steeped in the aura of show biz. But the two, regardless of dissimilar provenance, were obviously meant for each other, and now it's happening at last.

title: INTENSE VIEWS MARK DEBATE ON U.S. BUDGET
description: THE minds of Long Island's six Congressmen are filled with figures - very large figures - as Congress creeps toward completing the Federal budget. All six wish that the figure that matters most, the final budget total, could be smaller than the $780.5 billion recommended by the House Budget Committee or the $779.1 billion approved by the Senate's budget makers.

title: U.S. Asks More Aides To Leave Buenos Aires
description: The United States is sharply reducing the number of officials and dependents at the American Embassy in Buenos Aires because of tensions with Argentina over the Falkland Islands conflict, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: DETERRING DETERRENCE
description: President Reagan's new proposal to reduce strategic nuclear weapons has a worthy goal -enhancing deterrence and achieving stability through significant reductions in the most destabilizing weapons. Reductions are fine in concept, but unless he is also willing to forego the deployment of new missiles like the MX and Trident II, his proposal will not accomplish that goal. In fact, it will make the strategic deterrent balance less stable for both the United States and the Soviet Union and thereby increase our vulnerability to a first strike.

title: SOVIET BUILDS BRIDGE QUICKLY ON THE AFGHAN BORDER
description: The Soviet Union has strengthened supply lines to its forces in Afghanistan by rushing to completion the first rail and road bridge across the broad river separating the two countries.

title: POOR GET TRAINING FOR ARTS INDUSTRY
description: Connie Mon studied as an artist, but may find her success as an artisan. She is one of the 15 persons who graduated recently from a training program in New York City that teaches skills in the mechanical arts.

title: The U.N. Today; May 23, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the Falkland crisis at 10:30 A.M.

title: CALIFORNIANS SPLIT ON PROPOSAL FOR NEW COUNTY
description: The foothills and mountains of eastern Fresno County are rural, rugged and, in the minds of some people, ripe for revolution.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: The Used Congress Dealers
description: FOR SALE CHEAP: 1982 Congress. Burns taxpayers' dollars. Stalls in budget debates but serves special interests well, when lubricated with campaign contributions.

title: BUT THAT'S WHAT WE GAVE AWAY
description: TULIPS and daffodils are not the only things blooming on Long Island lawns this year. Tulips may bring joy to the gardener's heart, but to gladden the soul of those intrepid Long Islanders, the junkaholics (junque-aholics if they live on the North Shore), 'tis the season for that other rite of spring - the garage sale.

title: Design; MAN-MADE MIRACLE ON 42D STREET
description: It is hard to say whether Grand Central Terminal today should be called a miracle or a tragedy. That it exists at all in 1982 is extraordinary, given how altogether out-of-date its primary purpose - the provision of arrival and departure facilities for the longdistance trains that once crisscrossed the continent -has become. But the terminal is not what it once was, and not only because the elegant red carpets leading to the 20th-Century Limited's platform have given way to the messy, basementlike corridor that is the approach to the 4:05 to Stamford, Conn., about as grand a conveyance as the place now sees. It is not only the trains that have changed: it is the building, and more importantly, the buildings surrounding the building.

title: BREWED IN SCOTLAND- A PRIZE COMEDY
description: Quick quiz: If the British-made ''Chariots of Fire'' won the American Academy Award for best original screenplay, what film won the British Academy Award?

title: Cosmos' Chinapoo Is a Poised Rookie
description: His cool is dazzling. In a rookie, poise such as his is rare, so rare as to be suspect. Richard Chinapoo, the rookie, started this soccer season with the Cosmos and with several strikes against him. He was drafted low, in the third round, and went to camp without a contract. He isn't an American citizen, so he must compete with all the Cosmos' international stars for a job. He has had to prove himself coming into games off the bench.

title: Phillip L. Halpern Marries Marcia Louise Wierda
description: Marcia Louise Wierda, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Wierda of Manhasset, L.I., and Rock Hall, Md., was married yesterday to Phillip Lawrence Halpern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Halpern of East Williston, L.I., and Lauderhill, Fla. State Supreme Court Justice John S. Lockman performed the ceremony at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in Port Washington, L.I.

title: The Nation in Summary; INformation Is Still Free
description: The Republican-run Senate Judiciary Committee isn't regarded as the most progressive panel in the land, but last week it took a vote that even many certified liberals applauded. After more than a year's consideration, it decided to let the Freedom of Information Act stand.

title: Elisa Hampton Is Wed To Dr. Craig G. Cogger
description: Elisa Charlotte Hampton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hampton of Greenwich, Conn., and Dr. Craig George Cogger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cogger of East Hartford, Conn., were married yesterday at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: ARTS-IN-SCHOOLS IN FUNDS SQUEEZE
description: THE Creative Arts in Education program, a project of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford now in its eighth year, faces cuts in Government financing and the belt-tightening that most artsin-education programs are already experiencing. But Joyce Schmidt, director of the program, is determined to keep the projects going.

title: Aggie Grey
description: To the Editor:

title: MASSACHUSETTS' CONFLICT IN BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: eminent centers of the young biotechnology industry, has found itself embroiled in a public policy debate that threatens to alienate the very industry that the state is counting on for growth in the next decade.

title: TOTTENHAM TIED IN CUP FINAL
description: Terry Fenwick headed in a goal with five minutes of overtime remaining to give the Queen's Park Rangers a 1-1 tie with Tottenham Hotspur in the Football Association Cup final at Wembley Stadium today.

title:
SPORTS;
TWO L.I. GIRLS VIE FOR SHOT-PUT TITLE
description: THE similarities between June Reid and Cheryl Klein are startling. Both are quiet-spoken yet powerful high-school athletes who can benchpress more than 210 pounds and hurl a four-kilo shot-put more than 30 feet. They each hold county records - Miss Reid in Nassau and Miss Klein in Suffolk in the girls' shot-put. And their most consuming similarity, as the State Track championships next month approach, is that they both want to be this year's state titleholder.

title: ONE OF 'LES SIX' STILL AT WORK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Laura Mitgang has written an honors thesis on Germaine Tailleferre at Oberlin College. By LAURA MITGANG PARIS Germaine Tailleferre, the only woman in the post-World War I group of young composers known as Les Six, and one of the two members who are still living, celebrated her 90th birthday last month. And shortly before that, the Paris Opera paid homage to her with a performance of her new ''Concerto de la Fidelite'' for high voice and orchestra. She continues to work, to play the piano, and to see old friends.

title: ITALY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH TURNED TO A SCHOOLTEACHER IN LAYING GROUNDWORK FOR THEIR LANDING
description: In planning its attack on Port San Carlos in the Falkland Islands, the British military was guided by Carol Miller, who for 20 years was the tiny hamlet's schoolteacher before she returned to Britain last year.

title: Melanie Roden Is Bride of Frederick H. Bartlett 3d
description: Melanie Winner Roden, an assistant to the book-distribution manager in the publications department at the Museum of Modern Art, was married yesterday to Dr. Frederick Henry Bartlett 3d, a resident physician at the St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. The Rev. Meredith J. Spencer performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Huntingdon Valley, Pa.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: THE HOME AQUASTAT IS A FUEL SAVER IF ADJUSTED IN THE SPRING
description: OWNERS of homes that are heated by a hot-water system often do not realize that worthwhile fuel savings can result from a simple adjustment of the aquastat in the early spring. The aquastat is a device that controls the temperature of the water inside the boiler - much as a thermostat does for the air inside the house.

title: Midwife Remark Angers a Reader
description: As the satisfied mother of a midwife-delivered baby, I was incensed by the comment of Vincent Maressa, executive director of the New Jersey Medical Society (''Midwives Seek Greater Role,'' April 25): ''How can a nurse provide medical services? She provides nursing services.''

title: 9 MORE GAIN SPOTS FOR INDY
description: Michael Chandler and Dale Whittington turned in the fastest qualification runs today as nine more drivers made it into the tentative starting lineup for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: PRODUCE PRICES LIKELY TO RISE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK NEW JERSEY consumers can expect to pay more for fresh fruits and vegetables this summer than they have in the last five years. They can also expect to find smaller quantities of some fruits.

title: TEACHING AUTISTIC CHILDREN: MORE VIEWS
description: I, unlike the author of the anonymous ''This Is the Way She Is,'' only had one year of experience teaching when I, not so blindly, requested to teach the only class of autistic children in my school. Maybe I was young and naive, inexperienced and foolhardy, but I loved children.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Congressional vote table last Sunday incorrectly reported the vote of Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, on a hous- ing bill to provide $1 billion in Govern- ment subsidies to aid the housing in- dustry. Representative Roukema voted against the bill.

title: 'JOY' WINS ACORN
description: Nine days ago, Robert Perez slammed the door of his white Lincoln Continental and sped out of the backstretch at Pimlico Race Course. He had just scratched his filly, Cupecoy's Joy, from the Preakness Stakes because he thought that he and his horse had been ridiculed and mistreated.

title: Prospects
description: Pre-Summit Spat

title: Linda Oliver Married to Dr. Peter Grape
description: Linda Louise Oliver, manager of emergency services at the Wellesley Center of the Harvard Community Health Plan, was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Ashton Grape, who expects to start a cardiology fellowship in July at West Roxbury Veterans Administration Hospital in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Missel performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Moorestown, N.J.

title: PLANES AND MISSILES FILL THE AIR DURING ATTACK
description: Kim Sabido of Independent Radio News and Robert Fox of the British Broadcasting Corporation were with the British forces aboard the troopship Canberra and at Port San Carlos in the Falkland Islands. Following are excerpts from the reports they filed to London, which were subject to military censorhip. Jets Hit by Ships' Missiles By KIM SABIDO

title: MISS NAGAMINE MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: Yasuko Nagamine, a Japanese dancer of great stamina and a woman of equally great determination, made her New York debut Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall in a production entitled ''Musume Dojoji''(The Woman in the Temple).

title: A BIT OF A MYSTERY
description: HERRICKS ISN'T it mysterious how Agatha Christie's trifling mysteries can bring out the best in amateur groups and the worst in professional companies? For the Nassau Repertory, a professional theater by definition and recently in accomplishment, Dame Agatha's ''Spider's Web'' seems a rather ragged finale to a classy season.

title: Robert Thompson Arrison Weds Cynthia Mills Hiatt
description: Cynthia Mills Hiatt and Robert Thompson Arrison were married yesterday at the Glen Manor House in Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Charles Baldwin performed the ceremony.

title: TIPS FOR BARBECUING AND SAUCES TO GO WITH THEM
description: THE steaks are ready to go on the grill. But how about the grill? Is it ready? All too frequently, any thought of preparing the barbeque equipment for another season of outdoor cooking occurs to whoever is in charge of this activity about 10 minutes before the fire has to be lit.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: WATERCOLOR is a rebellious, disobedient, intractable medium. Unless it is in well-controlled and authoritative hands, it does whatever it wants: romping, cavorting, dripping or streaming headlong on a surface.

title:
ART;
EAST MEETS WEST IN PRINTS
description: NORTHPORT DESCRIBE a work of art as a Japanese print and you have inevitably pigeonholed it in the minds of your readers or listeners. The term conjures up white-faced courtesans in elaborate robes, fierce samurai warriors and famous characters of the Kabuki and Noh theaters, decoratively rendered in the traditional woodcut technique. Because this centuries-old art form has long been popular and influential in the West -and because its style and content are so characteristically Japanese - we may be excused for thinking that this is all Japanese printmaking consists of.

title: COMMUTER FOR DAY REFLECTS
description: IAM one of those people who drive to work. And every day it's the same. The ringing alarm clock. The rounded spoon of instant coffee. The orange juice. Perhaps toast if I'm hungry. The ride from New Rochelle to White Plains. Listening to the same songs on the same station, as I drive through the same streets.

title: Q and A; Tenant Protection
description: Question: My husband and I moved into a two-family home that the landlord is trying to sell. When our lease expires, would a new owner be able to evict us or raise the rent greatly? ... L.F., Englewood, N.J. Answer: According to Aaron Knight, director of the City of Englewood Building Department, you cannot be evicted simply because the building has changed ownership.

title: 'LADY MACBETH'- AN OPERATIC CHALLENGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harlow Robinson teaches in the Slavic Languages Department at SUNY-Albany and is writing a biography of Sergei Prokofiev. By HARLOW ROBINSON

title: Sports People; A Kicker Complains
description: Rafael Septien, the place-kicker for the Dallas Cowboys, is complaining that the club let him play all last season with a hernia, telling him that he had a pulled groin muscle.

title: IN THE PUBS, BRITONS ARE LINKED BY CONCERN FOR PRINCE ANDREW
description: Because they almost always do on a Saturday, Alice and Hilda Morgan went down to the King's Arms Pub around noon today for a gin and tonic and a chat with their neighbors.

title: Other Races Serve As Indy Appetizers
description: The Indianpolis 500 is the biggest and the best-known show around Indianapolis, but it's not the only one. Although a quarter of a million people jam the Indianapolis Motor Speedway to watch the household names in racing compete for the most prestigious prize in motor sports, central Indiana is overflowing with racing activity during the month of May.

title: CO-OP LIMITS URGED
description: LYNBROOK ''FOR some reason, the government of Lynbrook doesn't really care if it wipes us out,'' said LeRoy W. Fitzgerald, a disabled resident of Lynbrook for more than 16 years. ''To me, it is genocide of one class of citizens.''

title: WAR DRUMS AND PEACE
description: HATS off to the Westchester Choral Society and its ambitious director, Lyndon Woodside, for what proved to be a fascinating premiere of David Fanshawe's ''African Sanctus'' (or at least most of it: four of the 13 sections were omitted). Unlike the ''Missa Luba'' and other folk masses where the Latin texts have been fitted to native chants and rhythms, Mr. Fanshawe has composed an original score for mixed choir and percussion, dovetailing the live music with actual tapes of authentic songs, dances and calls to worship from many parts of Africa.

title: By WILLIAM A.SCRIVENER
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK IN THIS trim little town, many of whose residents fled from nowdesolate parts of the Bronx and Manhattan, a proposal to open a video-game arcade has become a focus of fear and resentment. ''We don't want it on The Avenue,'' meaning Anderson Avenue, the main street, one resident shouted at a recent meeting of the Borough Council, and applause rumbled through the room.

title: HEALTH CARE ISSUE STIRS COURT FIGHT
description: The question whether a wealthy 63-yearold woman, committed to a mental institution against her will, may refuse all medical treatment to the point of endangering her life has touched off a legal battle here.

title: GRAND MUSIC IN GREAT IRISH HOUSES
description: DESMOND RUSHE is a critic and columnist for The Irish Independent in Dublin. By DESMOND RUSHE

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN MY wife, who can't type, was graduated from college the other day. It was a lovely ceremony in a green valley on a Long Island campus. She marched in with all the other students - including a surprising number of mothers and fathers - who were receiving their master's degrees in education.

title: PEKING CAUTIONS AGAINST THE DANGER OF SPIES
description: The Chinese Government has cited the sensitive subject of state secrets in explaining the prison term imposed on a newspaper editor here who leaked details of a Communist Party session last summer to a foreign journalist.

title: Miss Braga, J.A. Figg 3d Are Married
description: Allegra Beatrice Maud Braga and James Alfred Figg 3d were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Atkinson Braga in Alpine, N.J. The Rev. Thom W. Blair performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: ABORTION
description: I read Robert Miner's review on "At the Center (Feb. 21) with a growing sense of horror. Although he writes with complacent authority, Mr. Miner, judging from his review, probably never has been in a center offering abortions.

title: Raffles
description: To the Editor:

title: THINGS TO CONSIDER WHEN ENTERING A CONTEST
description: Many enthusiastic amateurs and aspiring professional photographers dream of winning a prize in a photographic contest. Aside from the motivation provided by the prizes offered, there is also the enticement of seeing your picture reproduced in magazines and newspapers, and maybe even exhibited in public displays.

title: BUSINESS SYMPOSIUM
description: Effects of recent state legislation on Connecticut businesses and industries will be assessed by the Manufacturers Association of Southern Connecticut Inc. in a symposium to be held from 2 to 4:15 P.M. Wednesday in the library of Sacred Heart University, Bridgeport.

title: Cynthia J. Heye Married To Stephen L. Hopkins
description: Cynthia Johanne Heye, daughter of Mrs. Carl W. Heye of Lyme, Conn., and the late Mr. Heye, was married yesterday to Stephen Lewis Hopkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin C. Hopkins of Boonton, N.J. The Rev. David Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Biology And Destiny
description: Men and women differ in their hormonal makeup. But whether that biological difference makes an intellectual difference is hotly contested, even by scientists who agree that men are generally superior in tests of mathematical skills, while women score higher in verbal skills. A new study of male hormonal levels and their influence on intellectual ability, though small in size and narrowly defined in subject, probably will sharpen the debate.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Omega Brass Quintet Plays Susato Dances
description: The brass quintet made a considered argument for its continued existence as a musical form last Sunday, when the Omega Quintet made its debut in Carnegie Recital Hall. Even one who finds the repertory for five brass instruments somewhat limited and its tonal color somewhat blinding found moments of pleasure in this recital.

title: No Headline
description: Lucy Dawidowicz concludes her remarkable article with the question: ''But if another terrible crisis should arise to threaten the survival of Jews anywhere in the world, will American Jews have any more resources than they had in 1943?'' At least a partial, perhaps hopeful, answer to her question is to be found, in a negative sort of way, in her own account. While Jewish leaders evidently did substantially more than has been generally known, I could not help noting the absence then of effective grass-roots support and advocacy. What the Jewish community has learned from the Holocaust horrors is the need to develop the capacity throughout the country to affect public policy - by sophisticated public-relations operations, by alliances with the widest possible range of other groups in furtherance of common goals, by the use of political and legislative techniques guaranteed all Americans by our Constitution. HYMAN BOOKBINDER, Washington Representative, The American Jewish Committee, Washington

title: NEW GROUP FIGHTS DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: JUNE HOSKING'S daughter suffered permanent brain damage in 1974 when her car was struck broadside by another vehicle whose driver was drunk.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Guides to an electronic land. It sounds, from all you hear about it, like a wonderful yet slightly frightening place. A land crowded with contrivances whose green-lit screens resemble those of television sets and whose banks of keys are quite like those of typewriters -contrivances that the small-business man can employ to make a living, the householder can use to perform all manner of chores, the whole family can repair to for fun and games. The land of the personal or home computer.

title: Miss Tansill Wed To Fellow Chef
description: Audrey Usher Tansill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Tansill of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul Joseph Montalto Jr., son of Mrs. Frank Rosabianca of Bayville, L.I., and Mr. Montalto of Franklin Square, L.I. The Rev. Bruce Rodgers performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I..

title: THE USES OF TRADECRAFT
description: MOLE By William Hood. 317 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $15.95.

title:
Economic Affairs;
KOWTOWING TO THE ELDERLY
description: POLITICIANS live in abject fear of old ladies and old men. Compared w ith the political power of the elderly, the clout of the oil lobbiess eems trivial.

title: Irony Observed
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAY AIRPORT SITES, REGIONAL PLANNERS URGE
description: DEVELOPMENT of new office projects on the gently rolling acres surrounding the Westchester County Airport should be delayed and new emphasis be given to placing such buildings in downtown areas, the Regional Plan Association has recommended.

title: Karen Marie Hasby Wed to Lawrence L. Epstein
description: Karen Marie Hasby, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jarl Joseph Hasby of Victor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lawrence Lansman Epstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Epstein of New York and Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony in the Interfaith Chapel at the University of Rochester.

title: Lucia Vail Is the Bride of John Rhodes
description: Lucia Vail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vail of Bedford, N.Y., and Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to John Rhodes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon S. Rhodes of Bryn Athyn, Pa. The Very Rev. Dr. Sturgis L. Riddle performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: BACKWARD GOES THE PAGINATION
description: TAKE FIVE By D. Keith Mano. 583 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: INSTRUMENTAL: CONTEMPORARY
description: The Washington Square Contemporary Music Series offered some fiercely serious music Thursday at New York University's University Theater. There were impressive moments and even a few noble ones.

title: THE NEW FEMALE RUNNER IS A TRAINED COMPETITOR
description: ADECADE ago, only 78 women lined up to run the 6.2-mile Mini Marathon in Central Park; in the New York City Marathon that year, the women's winning time of 3 hours 18 minutes 41 seconds would have placed only 145th among the women in the race 10 years later.

title: CORRECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: ADAM CLYMER
description: If money is the mother's milk of politics, as Jesse (Big Daddy) Unruh used to proclaim while he was Speaker of the California Assembly, then the Democrats are getting skim while the Republicans lap up heavy cream.

title: TELTSCHER ADVANCES TO FINAL IN ITALY
description: Eliot Teltscher defeated Pablo Araya of Peru, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, today and reached the final of the $300,000 Italian Open tennis championships against Andres Gomez of Ecuador. Gomez beat Mats Wilander, the Swedish teen-ager, 5-7, 6-4, 6-3.

title: Lawyer Marries Julia E. Johnson
description: Julia Ellen Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Johnson Jr. of West Chester, Pa., was married yesterday to William A. Blanchard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert N. Blanchard of Rye, N.Y. The rector, the Rev. H. Bruce Lederhouse, performed the ceremony in St. John's, Tuckahoe, Episcopal Church in Yonkers.

title: U.S., IN U.N., VOWS SUPPORT FOR 'ANY INITIATIVE' ON PEACE
description: The United States, carefully balancing between Argentina and Britain, tonight promised support for ''any initiative'' to end the Falkland Islands conflict with ''peace and honor.''

title: Business Conditions; A ROBUST BOOK REVIVAL
description: In the face of findings that 20 million to 30 million Americans are functional illiterates and that home computers and cable television are absorbing leisure time, book sales are showing surprisingly robust growth. Last year sales were 9 percent above 1980's levels, and books did even better in this year's first quarter.

title: Banks Elsewhere
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Dodgers 3, Cardinals 2
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Pedro Guerrero's two-run single through the middle was the key hit in the fifth inning when Los Angeles got all of its runs.

title: Teaching the Autistic: More Views
description: For the last two years, as coordinator of parent training for a school that services autistic and mildly to severely handicapped students, I have met and worked closely with over 80 families. Each family has its own history, own horror story, and each has learned how to function daily with its handicapped offspring.

title: OUR LETHAL SYSTEM OF TAXING ESTATES
description: To the Editor:

title: CAROLINA REVIVES ITS STUMP MEETING
description: Roger Scott, a grizzled survivor of decades of rough-and-tumble political wars in the tobacco and soybeans territory of Dillon County, has avoided battle scars by skillfully wielding a vast country wisdom and an irreverent political wit.

title: NUCLEAR-ATTACK-PROOF SATELLITES ARE HIGH ON THE PENTAGON'S LIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: PHONY FALKLAND ISSUES
description: The real issue of the full-scale war that began in earnest Friday is not possession of some rocky outcroppings in the South Atlantic. It is not colonialism, imperialism, democracy, dictatorship. The real issue is clear, simple, direct: It is whether one nation may use armed force to seize disputed territory from another.

title: THE AIM IS QUALITY AND INFORMALITY
description: ABOUT two years ago, the Secret Road Inn in Miller Place changed hands. Changes in cuisine, in style and even in the dimensions of the place ensued. Instead of a French restaurant occupying a couple of small rooms in an old house, it has become a pleasantly informal seafood restaurant with its main dining room now situated in a skylit, porchlike extension that was added to the rear of the house. The setting is airy and casual in this part of the restaurant, where a working fireplace was also added to enhance the atmosphere in chilly seasons. There is still a raw, unfinished look about it, and a good deal of landscaping needs to be done around the house so the expanse of windows will overlook more than bare earth and construction debris.

title: Postings; CO-OP SPECIAL
description: Of course, the view of Lower Manhattan is spectacular and there is nothing like being on the water. But the real selling point for Bay Street Landing, says Key Land Inc., the developers, is the commuting time.

title: Sally Little Leads by 3 Strokes on 71-139
description: Sally Little, who has three victories this year on the tour, aimed at the fourth today when she increased her lead to three strokes after two rounds of the Chrysler-Plymouth L.P.G.A. tournament. Forced to scramble in a cold rain, Miss Little shot a one-under-par 71 for 139, 5 under for 36 holes of the 54-hole tournament.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC

title: Sports People; Colorado Expels 2
description: Two Colorado football players have been expelled for trying to sell copies of final examinations in history courses to an undercover campus policeman. Mark Morgan, a defensive end, and Lee Dudick, an offensive lineman, were arrested by the campus police May 12 after Morgan had allegedly sold a copy of a test for $35. The players told the campus police they had found copies of seven exams in a trash barrel, and said they would appeal.

title: Pappas Bowling Victor
description: George Pappas swept past four opponents and took the $21,000 top prize today in the $125,000 AC-Delco Classic. Pappas, 35, of Charlotte, N.C., was seeded fifth going into the championship round. He fired a total of 883 pins for four games, taking a 234-214 decision from Charlie Tapp of St. Paul in the championship game.

title: NEW TAX BREAKS SPURRING PRESERVATION
description: FIVE months after they took effect, Federal tax incentives e ncouraging the rehabilitation of both historic and nonhistoric o lder buildings are generating a groundswell of interest among large a nd small developers, preservationists and government officials.

title: PRESIDENT APPEALS FOR G.O.P. BUDGET
description: After the Senate passed a budget late Friday night that has the tacit support of the Reagan Administration, the President made his first public appeal today for the House to produce a budget resolution that would more closely conform to his objectives.

title: Around the Nation; Refugee Groups March To Protest Communism
description: Two hundred demonstrators, many of them refugees from Communist countries or members of a group affiliated with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, rallied outside City Hall today. They came to condemn what organizers described as world ''Communist tyranny.''

title: NEIGHBORS ASSIST CANCER STUDY
description: OUTSIDE the laboratory at New York's Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the sign said: The Richard Molin Memorial Foundation Laboratory for Research on Nutrition and Cancer. Inside, the conversation shifted from blood cells to patients to fund raising.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: WHEN Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes played the New Westchester Theater in Tarrytown Monday night, everyone wanted to be part of the action. Southside, as he is often called, whips his audiences into a frenzy; he sings and dances and leaps, leans down into the front row and pulls back only a little when fans threaten to drag him from the stage.

title: MIME AND DANCE
description: Yass Hakoshima, a mime who mixes dance with theater and blends Japanese and Western traditions, will present his ''Metaphor in Motion'' Tuesday evening at the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange.

title: WOMEN'S ROLE IN POLITICS SEEN IN A NEW LIGHT
description: TRENTON THE 1982 elections have become a watershed for women candidates in New Jersey, thanks to Representative Millicent Fenwick of Bernardsville.

title: INEFFECTIVE GUARDS HURT 76ERS
description: PHILADELPHIA THE gold dust twin backcourt of the 76ers - Maurice Cheeks and Andrew Toney - went mining for riches Friday night. They ended up in the pits.

title: SUPERMARKET DESIGN BLOCKED
description: EAST HAMPTON ON Long Island, a supermarket is a supermarket is a supermarket, except in the Village of East Hampton, where a design review board this month unanimously rejected an architect's plan for renovating the local A. & P., maintaining that the plan was ''offensive.''

title: Khans Challenged
description: In the United States, the sport of squash racquets has been dominated by the name Khan since Hasim Khan arrived from Pakistan and won the North American Open in 1956. Either he or a cousin, a brother, a nephew or one of his sons has won that tournament almost every year since.

title: Curbing Drunks
description: Each year, according to the Federal Government, drunken driving causes half of the country's 50,000 car deaths, 800,000 crashes and 750,000 serious injuries. California got tough last Jan. 1.

title: UNIVERSITY OF CHICAGO OFFICIAL TO BE THE NEW SCHOOL'S HEAD
description: Dr. Jonathan F. Fanton, vice president for planning at the University of Chicago, has been named president of the New School for Social Research, an institution in Greenwich Village noted for its leadership in adult higher education.

title: TEACHING AUTISTIC CHILDREN: MORE VIEWS
description: Teaching the autistic is a demanding vocation with no guarantee of success or failure. But negative attitude and open hostility toward any child will create a climate in which most children cannot thrive.

title: The World in Summary; Heads or Tails, Begin Still Won
description: Menachem Begin's chances of calling early Israeli elections, when he wants them (in November), may actually have increased last week following a raucous confidence vote that his Government narrowly survived.

title: DOES RENTING A 'WRECK' PAY OFF?
description: T he seven-year-old Ford Pinto had numerous scars, missing trim and a highly conspicuous dent in the right front fender. Yet despite its aging battered look, the car was everything that Rent A Wreck had promised. It worked - and well.

title: THE VERSATILE BOB HOSKINS SHOWS ANOTHER SIDE OF HIS TALENT
description: Bob Hoskins is the type of actor who, were it not for exceptional talent, would hardly be noticed. Physically, he could fit just about everybody's image of the local butcher. But Mr. Hoskins is abundantly talented and is becoming a star seemingly in spite of himself.

title: NOTES: THE KITCHEN IS GOING TO TOUR HERE-AT LAST
description: The Kitchen has long been a leading New York center for the avantgarde performing arts - vanguard music of every kind, performance art, dance and video. There have been several European tours of groups of artists sponsored by the Kitchen. But until now, there had not been a national tour of this sort.

title: MUSIC OR LAW?  HE CHOSE BOTH
description: ''IDON'T have to sit around and say I'm bored,'' said Bruce J. Bergman of Long Beach. ''It doesn't happen.'' And there's a good reason. At the age of 38, which he reached the other day, Mr. Bergman is: (1) a Councilman in the City of Long Beach, (2) counsel to the Garden City law firm of Ain, Joseph, Libert & Weinstein, (3) a deputy Nassau County Attorney, (4) a musician who heads his own band and also appears as a freelance guitarist, (5) a writer on music and law, (6) a member of the faculty of the Real Property Institute of New York University, (7) chairman of the Real Property Law Committee of the Nassau County Bar Association, (8) the husband of the former Linda Cantor and the father of their two children, Jennifer, 8 years old, and Jason, 4.

title: RAFFLES
description: To the Editor:

title: James Atlas
description: James Atlas is the author of ''Delmore Schwartz: The Life of an American Poet'' and an associate editor of The Atlantic. By James Atlas here are no waiters bearing fruit drinks in hollowed-out pineapples, no towel attendants bustling about, no tourists sunning themselves by the poolside of the Hotel Normandie in Trinidad. The stucco walls are smudged; the concrete terrace, cracked and seamed; the restaurant is a gloomy cave. In the lobby, two young men in thin white cotton shirts lounge on a vinyl couch watching television. A taxi lurches up the gouged, unpaved lane toward the scrubby jungle that cascades down from the hills beyond.

title: POSSIBLE COVER-UP ON NAZIS IS FOCUS OF NEW U.S. INQUIRY
description: Confronted with evidence that key files were tampered with, the Government has reopened investigations into a possible cover-up involving suspected Nazi war criminals living in America.

title: EVIRONEWS
description: THE recommendation last week by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency that NL Industries Inc. of Sayreville stop dumping chemicals 15 miles east of Long Branch and use instead a site 106 miles off the coast is not binding on the company.

title: 'NINE' ADDS UP TO A GIMMICK, WHILE 'HOTHOUSE' FILLS A GAP; by Walter Kerr
description: Sometimes I think we really are living in Pinterland, and that only Harold Pinter will ever be able to make sense of it. Consider the case of film director Federico Fellini and a current Broadway musical called ''Nine.'' Once upon a time, though well within living memory, Federico Fellini wanted very much to make a motion picture but could not for the life of him come up with an idea for a motion picture. He therefore made a motion picture about a film director who could not come up with an idea for a motion picture. The result was known as ''8 1/2,'' with the '' 1/2'' meant to indicate that something was missing.

title: Susanne Leary Plans July Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Neal Leary of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susanne Leary, to Paul Thomas Shoemaker, son of Louise Proehl Shoemaker of Philadelphia and the Rev. Bryce W. Shoemaker of Baltimore.

title: THE JURY IS STILL OUT ON KEAN'S PRISON PLAN
description: The old Fort Dix Stockade, renamed the Mid-State Correctional Facility and refurbished with $4.6 million, began receiving the first of its 500 state prison inmates last week as part of New Jersey's large-scale effort to relieve its overcrowded prisons.

title:
On Long Island;
BUYING A HOME WITH BARGAIN EXTRAS
description: DEVELOPMENT houses may look alike from the outside, but they are nota ll created equal. Options such as fireplaces, skylights, a irconditioning, burglar alarms, imported-tile floors and two-car g arages, to name a few, can add thousands of dollars to the basic p rice of a house.

title: by Tony Schwartz
description: ''Television did have an effect on me right from the beginning. In first grade, I was a member of a four-kid gang that went around imitating TV Westerns. We'd disrupt class to play out scenes, picking up chairs and hitting people over the head with them - except, unlike on TV, the chairs didn't break, the kids did. Finally, the teacher called my parents in and said, 'Obviously, he's being influenced by these TV shows, and if he's to continue in this class, you've got to agree not to let him watch television anymore.' So, from first to second grade there was a dark period during which I didn't watch TV at all. And I calmed down and the gang broke up.''

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Dave McKenna, who has been building a steadily-growing following of enthusiastic supporters during the past 30 years for the rhythmic drive, intensity and soaring spirit of his piano solos, likes to say that he does not think of himself as a jazz pianist, although virtually everyone who has ever heard him play places him high in that category.

title: Fashion; by Carrie Donovan
description: SUMMER SHINE Extravagant evening clothes, shimmering with beads, are no longer limited to wintertime wear, as evidenced by these Galanos 'gems.'

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ALL is not blissful in the Matawan Borough Girls' Softball League. Dr. Joseph S. Wallace, dentist, spurned coach and father of the 10-year-old centerfielder for The Sluggers, is threatening to haul the women running the league into court because, he contends, the league's bylaws are discriminatory.

title: DEMOCRATS AND G.O.P. IN OHIO SEE THE LABOR VOTE AS VITAL TO 1982 CAMPAIGN
description: Ohio Democrats and Republicans agree that, at this point at least, the poor economy, high interest rates and record unemployment constitute the issues of the 1982 political campaign.

title: THE LESSONS OF A LACKLUSTER SEASON
description: The perfect symbol for the now officially concluded 1981-82 theater season is not a performance or a play - or even a $40 ticket stub - but a pile of rubble that sits on West 45th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. That rubble, you may recall, was once the Morosco, which gave way for the Portman hotel. Unlike so many of the season's ostensible dramatic events, the razing of the Morosco and its neighbor, the Helen Hayes, truly did galvanize the entire theatrical community into fierce debate and high emotions. In part, the debate was totally rational: Two no doubt well-meaning camps had conflicting visions of a healthy future for the Times Square theater district.

title: 20 MEN LOST AS FRIGATE IS SUNK
description: British reinforcements poured ashore on East Falkland Island today as the beachhead established on Friday was widened to 10 square miles, Government officials reported tonight.But a British missile frigate hit in the landing attack sank in Falkland Sound with the presumed loss of 20 lives.

title: Around the Nation; Northwest Pilots Cross Machinists' Picket Lines
description: Northwest Airlines pilots and flight attendants crossed picket lines of striking machinists today, enabling the airline to continue an abbreviated domestic schedule.

title: WHAT'S DOING
description: By WAYNE KING; Wayne King is a correspondent in the San Francisco bureau of the Times.

title: ART AND COMMENT
description: More than 100 paintings, drawings and prints by Paul Cadmus will be on view at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers until July 11 in the first retrospective of the 77-year old artist's work ever assembled. His 50-year career began with a splash in the 1930's when his painting titled ''The Fleet's In,'' depicting rowdy sailors and girls carousing in a Manhattan park, so offended the United States Navy that it was removed from exhibition and disappeared entirely until recently.

title: THE U.N. MARKS GAINS IN OUTER SPACE; by Samuel A. Tower
description: As space becomes ever more usable and explorable, the United Nations is keeping pace with periodic issues for the changing circumstances of outer space. On June 11 the U.N. is putting out a new issue of four commemoratives on ''Exploration and Peaceful Uses of Outer Space.'' It is the third issue on the subject in a decade.

title: 9 FOOD OUTLETS IN NEW YORK FAIL CITY SANITARY INSPECTION
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of nine food outlets that were cited last week for violations of the city's health code.

title: Weather in Falklands: Snowstorm Is Nearing
description: The weather around the Falkland Islands for most of the day yesterday was cool with some high clouds and good visibility, according to F. Gordon Barnes, meteorologist for the Cable News Network and WDVM-TV in Washington.

title: American Jews and The Holocaust
description: Lucy Dawidowicz's article ''American Jews and the Holocaust'' (April 18) contains numerous errors of fact. More important, it is marked by several conceptual shortcomings. Here are some of the high points:

title: U.S. SEES SETBACK TO ITS LATIN TIES
description: Reagan Administration officials say the Falkland Islands conflict is creating a long-term, major shift in attitudes and policies throughout South America that will inevitably harm United States interests.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Supreme Court Clarifies a Ruling on Bias
description: Title IX, an anti-discrimination law beleaguered for almost a decade by statutory ambiguity (and lately, conservative objections), last week was clarified by the Supreme Court. The Justices ruled, 6 to 3, that the 1972 Federal statute, which provides for the cutoff of Federal aid to any ''education program or activity'' that discriminates on the basis of sex, applies to employees as well as to students.

title: ART SONG: HOMAGE PAID TO EMILY DICKINSON
description: One of the best ways to present lieder is to offer a variety of composers setting the same poet. The exercise, at its best, can illuminate both sides of the art song's delicate equation between words and music. Emily Dickinson is one of America's most enigmatically complex poets, and partly for that reason, the Alliance for American Song's ''Homage to Emily Dickinson'' on Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall proved a fascinating affair.

title: RENTALS FOR ELDERLY GET FEW APPLICANTS IN MOUNT KISCO
description: SPONSORS of 70 bargain-priced apartments for the elderly in Mount Kisco expected an avalanche of applications when they began renting this spring.

title: Unrelenting Briton In Cup Challenge
description: A punching bag hangs in the stern of Peter de Savary's 147-foot motor yacht Kalizma, and each day he goes through a workout. The brash, 37-year-old chairman of England's Victory Syndicate, a challenger for the America's Cup, doesn't wear gloves because he wants to toughen his hands for grinding winches.

title: Beverly Willis Reid Bride Of Cameron Arthur Hatton
description: Beverly Willis Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nash Reid Jr. of Armonk, N.Y., was married yesterday to Cameron Arthur Hatton, son of Mrs. Elmer Horvath of Mahopac, N.Y., and the late Charles Hatton of Washington. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title:
ANTIQUES;
FUTURE IS NOT DIM FOR OLD FIXTURES
description: SUMMIT IF YOU have an attic, you probably have stored there an old chandelier or lamp in need of repair that you have forgotten about. Good, old lighting equipment is hard to find. The Lamp Clinic at 513 Morris Avenue is one place to keep in mind. The shop stocks 40 or so chandeliers dating from about 1870 through the 1940's. It will refurbish chandeliers and lamps, redoing the metal and wiring.

title: Richard Pious Marries Susan D. Weil
description: Susan Delancey Weil, daughter of Mrs. Peter Weil of Mount Kisco and Cooperstown, N.Y., and the late Mr. Weil, was married yesterday to Richard Pious, son of Mrs. Edward Pious of Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., and the late Mr. Pious. The Rev. William Fuller of New York performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Weil home in Mount Kisco.

title: Unseeded Players Gain N.C.A.A. Singles Final
description: Brad Gilbert of Pepperdine and Mike Leach of Michigan, both unseeded, won semifinal matches today and will meet for the National Collegiate Athleitc Association singles championship Sunday.

title: Growing Oil
description: There were buoyant hopes at the University of Arizona in January 1981 that within five years an Arid Lands Studies project at the school could be turning tons of desert plants into oil. Jack Johnson, director of the project, said a 40-acre biofuels facility being developed in Tucson would extract the oil from such plants as buffalo gourd, guayule and gopher weed.

title: Mailbox; Excluding Borg Hurts the Game
description: To the Sports Editor: I am shocked at the Association of Tennis Professionals' arbitrary rule regarding the number of tournaments a player must enter a year. The players have a right to choose what tournaments they will play without the threat of arbitrary penalty imposed by a tennis bureaucracy.

title: METS WIN IN 12TH
description: In one of their haunting performances, the Mets endured 10 strikeouts by Nolan Ryan tonight, took a 5-1 lead into the ninth inning, but then were tied when Terry Puhl hit a grand slam for the Houston Astros off Neil Allen.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 10 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 4 4 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 3 5 2 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 4 2 5 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men. 5 3 6 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A greedy crew at work in the world of horse-racing and computer programming. 6 6 16 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 7 7 6 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way love the same woman. 8 3 DINNER AT THE HOMESICK RESTAURANT, by

title: A PRESIDENT'S PRESCRIPTION
description: BEYOND THE IVORY TOWER Social Responsibilities of the Modern University. By Derek Bok. 318 pp. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. $15.95.

title: May 23, 1982
description: NONFICTION BEYOND THE IVORY TOWER: Social Responsibilities of the Modern University. By Derek Bok. 14 THE BILL JAMES BASEBALL ABSTRACT 1982.

title: Headliners; Returning the Favor
description: As a member of the Weather Underground, Bernardine Dohrn made no secret of the contempt in which she held the Government. Last week, the Government held her in contempt, sending her to jail for refusing to furnish a handwriting sample to a grand jury probing last year's Brink's shootout in Rockland County and other robberies.

title: Sports of The Times; Christmas Comes Every 4 Years
description: JIMMY NICHOLL's living room was the biggest on the block that summer of 1966 in Belfast, Northern Ireland. ''We had a house, and the rest of the buildings were flats,'' Nicholl recalls. ''Our living room became a little bit of a bar, with all the neighbors dropping by to watch the games on television.''

title: LARCHMONT IS PETITIONED ON COMMUTER PARKING
description: COMMUTING from the village of Larchmont, the busiest station on the New Haven Line, according to Conrail statistics, is becoming increasingly difficult for residents of the surrounding area who frequent the station. Now a group of Larchmont Woods residents has petitioned the village of Larchmont to be exempted from nonresident parking fees and have threatened a boycott of Larchmont stores if they are not granted the exemption.

title: Carl P. Leubsdorf Weds Susan Page
description: Susan Lea Page, White House correspondent for Newsday, was married yesterday to Carl Philipp Leubsdorf, Washington bureau chief of The Dallas Morning News. The nondenominational ceremony was performed at the couple's home in Washington by the Rev. Jerry Musick of the Christian Heritage Assembly of God Church in Oxon Hill, Md.

title: LANDING TESTS THE UNITY OF THE ARGENTINE FORCES
description: Britain's attack on the Falkland Islands is testing the ability of the three branches of Argentina's armed forces to pull together and conduct a joint operation.

title: Padres 12, Pirates 3
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - Sixto Lezcano and Terry Kennedy each hit home runs and combined to drive in seven runs for San Diego.

title: THE ACADEMIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Notes; THOSE AGAINST BEQUEST TO ATTACK P.L.O. AIMS
description: Attorneys for the American Jewish Congress and the Anti-Defamation League are scheduled to question a prominent official of the Palestine Liberation Organization on Wednesday and Friday of this week in an effort to block a $30,000 bequest to the P.L.O. by the late Fred Sparks, a Pulitzer-Prize winning journalist and a Jew by birth.

title: The World in Summary; Dominican Vote Marks Transition
description: While the United States and the Dominican military kept a discreet distance, Salvador Jorge Blanco, a left-of-center lawyer, won the presidency by a substantial margin last week. He heads the Dominican Revolutionary Party, which is affiliated with the Socialist International,

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices; ART
description: Anything can happen when artists are asked to choose work by other artists for a show. A cool abstractionist like Richard Diebenkorn picks a funky figurationist, George Rodart (both are from California), whose ''Temptation of Eve'' shows the barebreasted mother of us all rejecting a serpent in no uncertain terms.

title: TEACHING THE AUTISTIC: MORE VIEWS
description: The most successful educators are those who believe that people are more precious than money. What a loss to the world if Helen Keller had not had Anne Sullivan but a teacher like Anonymous.

title: THE COMPOSER AND THE MUSIC TEACHER
description: NADIA BOULANGER A Life In Music. By Leonie Rosenstiel. Illustrated. 427 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $24.95.

title: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER IS IN LIVELY TRANSITION NOW
description: As we were saying last year, the kind of premieres and choreographers introduced into American Ballet Theater will do much to determine the profile the company will have with Mikhail Baryshnikov as its new artistic director. As it happens, the company's three major new ballets this season were all good. None was a masterpiece but each was a better version of what each choreographer tends to do elsewhere and, in this sense, Mr. Baryshnikov's testing of the choreographic waters made for a more adventurous season than expected.

title: SEVENTH AVENUE'S SHARPEST EYE
description: EVERYTHING in the office is oversized, from the giant pretzel p ropped against one wall to the four-foot kitchen whisk leaning a gainst the sofa and, not least, to the man behind the desk. Measuredb y either his physical girth or his influence on the marketplace of f ashion, there is nothing small about Bernard Ozer. On Seventh Avenueh e is known as the man with the keenest eye for trends - and the g reatest gift for spreading them all across America. Mr. Ozer's view o f himself is terser, if no less grand. ''I'm an entity,'' he said.

title: The Region in Summary; Something for The Victims
description: Convicted murderers in New Jersey can be required to make restitution as a condition for parole, the State Supreme Court ruled last week in upholding a 1979 law. But Thomas Trantino, a prisoner who hoped to be paroled as a result of the ruling, may not benefit from it very soon.

title: Yankee Reminiscence Recalls Some Memories
description: The article by Sam Schraeger about the New York Yankees' spring training in Asbury Park in 1943 (Speaking Personally, March 28) brought back many memories.

title: Medalist Eliminated in Travis
description: One day after they had placed first and second in the medal round, Gary Vandeweghe and George Zahringer were eliminated in the quarterfinals of match play in the Walter Travis Memorial golf tournament today.

title: CHIEF JUDGE GIVES NEW PLAN TO AID NEW YORK COURTS
description: New York State's Chief Judge has proposed new guidelines to govern the assignment of lower court judges to bolster an understaffed State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: FRANCE'S APPALACHIAN TRAIL
description: HENRY S. REUSS, Democrat of Wisconsin, is a member of the United States House of Representatives. By HENRY S. REUSS

title: TURNING SHOREHAM ON TURNS MANY OFF
description: In the mid-1960's, as Long Island's older suburbs swelled and split-levels rose where potatoes once sprouted, the Long Island Lighting Company hooked up more new customers than any other electric utility in the nation. With forecasters predicting nothing but growth, the company anticipated a period of rapid expansion that was to culminate in the construction of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Nelson Leads by 3 in Atlanta
description: Larry Nelson opened a three-stroke lead in the Atlanta Golf Classic today, moving to 15 under-par in the raindelayed third round.

title: The World in Summary; Long Reach of a Scandal in Seoul
description: Having gained power in a palace coup following the murder of President Park Chung Hee in 1979, Chon Doo Hwan tried to gain some legitimacy for his regime by launching a drive to ''purify'' South Korean political and economic life. Thousands of people were arrested or purged, but apparently, the anticorruption campaign didn't go far enough.

title: A LOOK AT WRITERS AND ARTISTS OF THE PAST AT MUSCOOT
description: SOMERS SOMETHING new about something old has been introduced at the county-owned Muscoot Park - a once-a-month series of lectures on late Victorian ''American Writing and Art.'' Jack Robbins, a member of Muscoot's advisory committee and a trustee of the nearby John Jay Homestead, is the commentator.

title: TEACHING AUTISTIC CHILDREN: MORE VIEWS
description: In past years, parents of autistic children often denied the label of ''autistic'' since that alone was enough to prohibit a child's participation in most programs. With their success in convincing the New York Legislature that specific regulations of the education law were needed to properly serve the autistic and with the establishment of special programs and services for them, parents are now finding that the educational establishment is unilaterally removing the label of ''autism'' from children, thus again effectively denying them the programs and services they need.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: THE SLAVEHOLDER AS FACTORY OWNER
description: THE RULING RACE A History of American Slaveholders. By James Oakes. 307 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: A NEW MAJOR: FITNESS AIDES FOR CORPORATIONS
description: EFFORTS by a number of corporations to get their executives into good physical condition - and keep them there - have not gone unnoticed at colleges.

title: Laura Dalley Is Wed to James E. Tobin
description: At St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday, Agnes Laura Dalley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Cutting Dalley Jr. of Washington, was married to James Emmett Tobin, son of Mrs. Emmett James Tobin of Waterloo, Iowa, and the late Mr. Tobin. The Rev. A. Theodore Eastman performed the ceremony.

title: CONTAMINATED MILK PROBLEM IN HAWAII NEARS END
description: After two months of turmoil in which fresh dairy products virtually disappeared from Honolulu grocery shelves because of a scare over pesticide contamination, medical and scientific experts are still unable to agree whether the contaminated milk could have harmed humans.

title: U.S. Puts Landing Slots Of Braniff Into Lottery
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will hold a lottery to give away 250 airport landing and departure spaces held by Braniff International.

title: No Headline
description: Lucy Dawidowicz omits any reference to the specific act of rescuing over 50,000 Rumanian Jews, which I performed with the support of the War Refugee Board and President Roosevelt's personal intervention. Lucy Dawidowicz treats every aspect of the Transnistria death camp in Rumania except this key rescue episode.

title: Beauty; by Deborah Blumenthal
description: THE SHOCK ABSORBERS So-called 'exercise' sandals are often regarded as summer cure-alls for sore feet. The reality is somewhat more complicated, the experts explain here. A prototype of the Famolare line of waved-sole sandals.

title: CITY AGENCY REPORTS 1.4 MILLION GRANTED INCOME-AID BENEFITS
description: About 20 percent of New York City's population - 1.4 million people - has been receiving benefits from income-support programs, according to a new Human Resources Administration study.

title: Philadelphia Opera Season
description: The Opera Company of Philadelphia's 1982-83 season will feature productions of Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra,'' Puccini's ''La Rondine,'' a double-bill of Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' and Stravinsky's ''Oedipus Rex,'' Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale'' and Bizet's ''Carmen.'' Jose Carreras, the tenor, will appear in concert Oct. 17. Performances are at Philadelphia's Academy of Music (215-732-5811).

title: FORCING THE ACTION
description: How do you win with Black against a conservative player who won't risk sharp play, or offer a genuine gambit, or do anything to jeopardize a draw?

title: A Library Staff Is Defended
description: Phyllis Howe (''The Village Improper,'' Opinion Page, April 25) should use her wit to vent her frustrations of ''a person without a country'' in a more positive way rather than to denigrate the staff of a local library (need we say Bronxville?).

title: Index; International
description: Soviet pressure suspected behind Poland's anti-U.S. campaign 3 Stockholm arms institute facing difficulties 4 Around the World 5 A Chinese journalist is convicted of leaking state secrets 6 Washington asking Arabs to press Iran to end war 7 In their pubs, Britons are linked by concern for Prince Andrew 14 Security Council resumes debate on the Falklands Islands crisis 14 Britain seen unlikely to win full support of Common Market 16 Some Latin nations said to discuss breaking ties with Britain 16 Pope hopes to go ahead with British trip 16 First bridge completed across Soviet-Afghan border river 18 Government/Politics Californians to vote on criminal law changes 11 Democrats and G.O.P. woo Ohio labor vote 20 Massachusetts Democrats reject Governor and back Dukakis 20 Candidates lining up for Surrogate Court election 34 General Around the Nation 20 A.&P. and union to reopen some Philadelphia stores 21 Last link in new Florida Keys highway is dedicated 25 Agency reports 1.4 million in city receive income-aid benefits 39 PARADES TODAY A parade marking the 34th anniversary of Israeli independence begins today at 11 A.M., moving up Fifth Avenue from 57th Street to 86th. A Norwegian Day parade in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn begins 1:30 P.M. at Fifth Avenue and 90th Street and moves to 67th. Education/Welfare Teachers union to collect dues after losing right to checkoff 29 University of Chicago official is named to head the New School. 30 City agency reports 1.4 million granted income-aid benefits 39 Arts/Entertainment Two Cheryl Yeager and Peter Fonseca make ballet debuts 43 New Amsterdam Symphony offers all-Gershwin evening 44 Mannes Camerata offers the opera ''La Dafne'' 45 ''Applause'' revived by Equity Library Theater 47 Yasuko Nagamine makes her New York dance debut 51 City Ballet offers ''Goldberg Variations'' and ''Souvenir'' 54 Style Caseworker to history's victims 56 Lapidary touches in jewels 56 Features/Notes Man in the News: Gen. Mario Menendez of Argentina 13 News Analysis Drew Middleton assesses possible next steps in the Falklands 12

title: ARGENTINA'S HOME FRONT IS ITS WEAK SPOT
description: BUENOS AIRES ARGENTINA'S military regime, battling British forces in the Falklands this weekend, also had to contend with a deteriorating economy and political restlessness at home. Neither threatened as yet to undermine the war effort - or the junta - but the effects of a protracted war were less certain.

title: IN KYOTO, THE DEFINITIVE JAPANESE INN
description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG is cultural correspondent and former chief music critic of The Times. By HAROLD C.SCHONBERG

title: Defendant Gets Mental Care After Airing of Crucial Tapes
description: A woman accused of trying to arrange two murders was in a psychiatric ward today after collapsing when a radio station defied a judge and broadcast tapes of her conversation with an undercover police officer posing as a hired killer.

title: THE CALL THAT DIDN'T COME
description: ON the morning after Mother's Day, I heard on the radio that there were 21 million phone calls to mothers this year, but my No. 2 son, who lives many states away, didn't call and couldn't even care enough to send me a card.

title: AN ENTERPRISE FOR TREKKIES
description: They were soaked with rain and huddled in blankets, but the 500 fans who had waited for hours yesterday to see the New York preview of the new ''Star Trek'' movie - ''Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan'' - considered it part of the fun.

title: U.S. ASKING ARABS TO PRESS IRAN TO END WAR
description: The United States, worried about Iraqi setbacks in the war with Iran, is quietly seeking help from Islamic nations to step up pressure on the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to reach a settlement with Baghdad, State Department officials said today.

title: SCARS OF DIVORCE NOW A COMMON COMPLAINT
description: ''SO I put out every stitch of his clothing in the driveway, suits, jackets, pants, everything, and I drove the car back and forth over them three times in each direction.''

title: A line of type was dropped from a caption last week accompanying the article on the electronic stock market. The caption should have read as follows: ''If the firm is itself a market maker, it may fill the order from stock it owns or match the buy order with a sell order. This is known as 'internalization.' ''
description: Also, in a chart on page 19 listing the 30 stocks to be traded in the new system, the quotes for the Barnett Banks of Florida were incorrect. The company's 12-month, high-low range was 29 1/2 to 18 3/4, and its May 13 closing price was 20 5/8.

title: PART OF CARNEGIE MUSEUM COLLECTION TO BE SOLD; by Ed Reiter
description: United States silver dollars from the numismatic collection of the Carnegie Museum of Natural History will be sold at public auction Sept. 14 in New York. The sale is being conducted by Spink & Son USA, Inc., a recently established New York subsidiary of the famous London firm, and it will be the first coin auction to be held by that office.

title: TO A CODGER, ALL TIME IS ONLY YESTERDAY
description: LAST March, I spent a day at the Red Sox spring training camp in Winter Haven, sitting in the Florida sun with all the codgers who had come to watch the team work out, codging the hours away. My grandstand seat was so close to the field that I could see the players well, and one sight struck me as remarkable. It was a Red Sox coach and former star, Johnny Pesky, who looked as if he could still go out and play. His hair was black, his face unlined. But the real marvel was this: He didn't have a paunch.

title: VISITING DETROIT FOR THE GRAND PRIX
description: Grand Prix auto racing, the most glamorous and sophisticated form of international motor sports competition, is coming to the motor city of Detroit for the first time from June 4 to June 6. Three Grand Prix races will be heldin the United States this year, but this will be the only one east of the Mississippi.

title: Expos 4, Reds 2
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Warren Cromartie knocked in two runs with a homer and a single, and Scott Sanderson won his first game since April 30 for Montreal.

title: Helen Talman Married
description: Helen Reynolds Talman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carter Edmonds Talman Jr. of Richmond, was married there yesterday to Daniel Jeremiah Haughton 2d, an associate in the television-stations divisions of the National Broadcasting Company in New York. The Rev. Charles Austin Joy performed the ceremony at St. James's Episcopal Church. Mr. Haughton is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gayle Haughton 3d of Birmingham, Ala. The bride is an assistant underwriter with the American International Life Insurance Company in New York.

title: Decathlon Leader
description: Daley Thompson, a Briton who set a record of 8,622 points here two years ago, led today with 4,632 points halfway through his attempt at a world decathlon record at an international track meet. Thompson's total was 146 points beyond his 1980 achievement at the same stage of competition.

title: THE LURE OF OLD FISHING FLIES; by Ann Barry
description: ''There's a romance in all of this. It has a devilry all its own, and once you get your nose in it, you can never get it out,'' said Jim Deren, about fishing in general, and collecting the paraphernalia of the sport in particular. As the proprietor for some 45 years of a Manhattan shop called the Angler's Roost , Mr. Deren's nose is obviously entrenched.

title: FORESTS NOW COVER THREE-FIFTHS OF NEW YORK, SURVEY SHOWS
description: Despite its image as an urban state, New York is now growing enough timber to cover more than three-fifths of the state, a new United States Forest Service survey shows.

title: ORIOLES GET 3D SHUTOUT IN ROW
description: Dennis Martinez pitched the Orioles' third consecutive shutout, and John Lowenstein homered for the second day in a row today to lead Baltimore to its fourth straight victory, a 6-0 triumph over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Washington; REAGAN'S FALKLAND TEST
description: The Reagan Administration has made a valiant effort to avoid a war between Britain and Argentina over the Falkland Islands. But now that the war has started and the British have established their garrisons on the islands, it is important to note the United States military commitments to Britain.

title: Television Week
description: Spanning the Years Monday will mark the 99th anniversary of the official opening of the Brooklyn Bridge. Appropriately, at 9 P.M., Channel 13 will present ''Brooklyn Bridge,'' an hour-long documentary that uses still photos, archival materials and new footage to recount how the bridge was built and what the span has meant to artists, authors, poets, playwrights and photographers over the decades.

title: TEACHING AUTISTIC CHILDREN: MORE VIEWS
description: Yes, I agree, it seems like a waste of time sitting in a room with six children who do the same thing over and over again, but what is this anonymous teacher doing with them? Obviously they cannot learn to read and write as other normal children, but they can and must learn other things that are not classified ''educational.''

title: Investing; A MEASURED ENTHUSIASM FOR OIL STOCKS
description: ANYONE who owns an automobile can hardly help notice that gasoline p rices are going up again. Not by very much, but enough to indicate t hat the slide in oil prices may be over and, as a consequence, oil s hares may be on the verge of recovering their attractiveness.

title: Personal Finance; CHECKING ACCOUNTS WITH MONEY-FUNDS
description: IF you can't beat 'em, join 'em. That seems to be the emerging p hilosophy of the nation's banks toward money market funds, as f inancial institutions across the country begin to link up with theira rchrivals for the consumer's deposits.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR IS REBUFFED
description: The first Democratic State Convention in eight years turned its back today on the sitting Democratic Governor, Edward J. King, and instead nominated former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Constance Wallace Bride Of Timothy H. Manahan
description: Constance Vauclain Wallace, manager of Black River Farms, a thoroughbred breeding farm in Oldwick, N.J., was married yesterday to Timothy Hudson Manahan, an engineer with the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark. The Rev. John Scobell performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, Greenville, Del.

title: No Thonx?
description: To the Editor:

title: Postings; COMMEMORATIVE
description: That Corinthian-columned landmark with the seemingly endless inscription on its east facade about rain and snow and gloom of night is to receive a new name tomorrow. After almost 70 years of being known as the United States General Post Office in Manhattan, the building that fills the entire area between 31st and 33d Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues, will be renamed after the nation's 53d Postmaster General -James A. Farley.

title: Children's Books
description: KIND HEARTS AND GENTLE MONSTERSBy Laurence Yep 177 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.50. (Ages 11 to 14)

title: IDEAS ABOUT LIFE
description: THE GROWTH OF BIOLOGICAL THOUGHT Diversity, Evolution and Inheritance. By Ernst Mayr. Illustrated. 974 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $30.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Buffalo Stallions of the Major Indoor Soccer League will not renew the contract of Coach Ray Klivecka when it expires June 1. Club officials said they were looking for a replacement.

title: White Sox 7, Indians 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Harold Baines hit a two-run homer and a run-scoring single to lead Chicago to its sixth straight victory.

title: On Language; by William Safire
description: Burnout

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: No Headline
description: Lucy Dawidowicz devotes most of her article to criticism of the ''Irgunists.''

title: Food; Flip Flopping
description: Ever intrigued by the origins of words pertaining to food, we recently undertook to discover the source of crepe, the French ''pancake'' that has become so much a part of the American dining scene. There are even chain restaurants around the nation that deal in crepes filled with savory or sweet fillings.

title: Other Business; DRESSING FOR SUCCESS, TOKYO-STYLE
description: TOKYO Each weekday morning, Maki Kawanishi, a secretary at Sony's Tokyo headquarters, slips on a vest created by fashion designer Issey Miyake and begins her workday, just as do 30,000 other Sony employees throughout Japan. Her taupe v-neck vest with the haute-couture pedigree is Sony's new company uniform.

title: Guest Observer; Gentrifying the South Bronx
description: It's time for a new plan for the South Bronx. It's been a while since Jimmy Carter stood in the devastation and said that something had to be done about it. Ronald Reagan, whose Government takes upon itself the affairs of people elsewhere on earth, is trying to make the South Bronx rehabilitation project palatable to private enterprise. Mayor Koch - who is served a graphic reminder of it every time he drives between City Hall and Albany -has no money to make a difference. So far, one thing is clear: No one is doing anything about the South Bronx.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
EAST END WITCH DRAMATIZED
description: EAST HAMPTON IN 1657, 35 years before Salem tried and hanged its famous witches, East Hampton did some witch hunting of its own. For two years, Roger Myers has been living with that witch - figuratively, of course - piecing together in dramatic form the events that brought Elizabeth Garlick to the docket, accused of sorcery.

title: A WINIKOW SHIFT ON DEATH PENALTY
description: ALBANY FOR the first time in the eight years she has served in the State Senate, Linda Winikow rose from her seat, representing the 38th district, and voted last Monday for legislation to restore the death penalty in certain cases of murder. The bill was passed by the Republican-led Senate by a vote of 41 to 17.

title: ARGENTINE COMMAND SAYS TROOPS ARE STILL FIGHTING TO EXPEL BRITISH
description: Argentina said today that its forces on the Falkland Islands were still fighting British troops who have established a beachhead near Port San Carlos.

title: FIGURING THE GAME
description: THE BILL JAMES BASEBALL ABSTRACT 1982 By Bill James. 213 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: BED AND BREAKFAST IN JEFFERSON COUNTRY
description: MAURICE CARROLL is a reporter for The New York Times. BY MAURICE CARROLL

title: SOME INVASIVE PLANTS ARE BEST AVOIDED; BY CARL TOTEMEIER
description: THE mere mention of crabgrass has been known to send suburban homeowners into shock, and an overheard conversation about dandelions in someone's lawn might well lead to the assumption that they were the scourge of the earth.

title: THOUGHTS WHILE HELD CAPTIVE BY AN 'ESCAPIST' MOVIE
description: The warm weather has finally arrived and, with it, such a glut of so-called escapist movies that it's not easy to escape them. They're everywhere, in all sorts of shapes and dimensions. They are bigbudget ones for care-worn kiddies to escape by and soft-core porn ones for the man in the family with a briefcase. They're everywhere, like the furious ghosts in ''The House Where Evil Dwells,'' waiting just outside the door to rush in at the first opportunity and occupy our consciousnesses.

title: MUSICAL SURPRISES A HIGH NOTE ON VISIT TO CHINA
description: AMONG the many pleasant surprises that Ellie Mao Mok, a voice teacher from Larchmont, experienced during her trip with an American group to China was picking up a German song and finding her father's name on it as the translator.

title: Reading and Writing; THE POSTMAN'S LAMENT
description: ''It's the decline of letters,'' my postman said, slapping my mail into the palm of his hand. Observing the commercial size and color of the envelopes, I was in no hurry to take them.
