As my postman lounged against his truck, I thought of those fortunate people in the past who had received incendiary letters, soul-searching letters, witty, passionate, profound letters, letters filled with the unpredictable evolutions of daily life. Such letters were the literature, the essays and poems, of the nonprofessional. To write them was to talk to oneself in the aura of another. They were a long articulation, a perpetual refinement and revision of the self. And they were filled too with the pathos of distance, with the unwonted space between those who had been close.

title: The Region in Summary; Jury Draws Line Between Moon and Church
description: The Unification Church recently won tax-free status as a religion, but that didn't give its founder, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, a personal exemption. On its fifth day of deliberations, a Federal District Court jury in Manhattan last week convicted the Korean evangelist of income tax fraud.

title:
CENTER FOR HANDICAPPED TRIES TO DEVELOP;
SENSE OF SELF
description: TOMS RIVER ALTHOUGH handicapped persons living away from home are often thought of as ''inmates'' of cold custodial-care institutions, a walk through the Toms River Convalescent Center gives a different picture.

title: POPE STILL HOPES TO VISIT ENGLAND
description: Leaders of the British Roman Catholic Church said today that Pope John Paul II would travel to Britain on Friday despite the fighting in the South Atlantic, unless church officials there advised him not to.

title: A HIGH-SPIRITED GOVERNOR
description: The British assault had been under way for more than four hours when Brig. Gen. Mario Benjamin Menendez, the new Argentine Governor of the Falkland Islands, picked up the telephone and called President Leopoldo Galtieri.

title: The Region in Summary; Death or an Alternative
description: In has become an annual rite for the State Legislature to offer up a capital punishment bill for sacrifice under Governor Carey's pen. The death penalty measure that easily passed the Senate last week, however, may find life after veto.

title: ITALY
description: To the Editor:

title: UPSTATE ATOM PLANT, SHUT SINCE JANUARY, IS ALLOWED TO RESTART
description: Federal regulators granted permission today for a low-power startup of the Robert E. Ginna nuclear power plant. The facility has been closed since Jan. 25, when a tube ruptured and released slightly radioactive steam into the air.

title: Mailbox; Racing's in Need Of Bill Hartack
description: To the Sports Editor: Let's hear it for Bill Hartack (''Hartack Goes to Whip Again,'' Dave Anderson's Sports of The Times, May 16). Many of us who love racing and, above all, horses, have been waiting it seems eons for someone official and influential to incisively articulate and, more important, tackle the problems, abuses, and tragedies afflicting the very big business of horse racing.

title: Business Conditions; MISERY AS AN INDICATOR
description: The November elections are still six months away, but with the economy sure to be an important issue, voters are likely to hear politicians cite the so-called ''misery'' or discomfort index with increasing frequency.

title: A LACKLUSTER 'CAN-CAN'
description: WHEN ''Can-Can'' opened on Broadway in May 1953, it was a smash hit that ran for 892 performances. A season back it was revived and closed almost immediately.

title: Mothers at Home Need Wide Support
description: As a psychotherapist who treats children as well as adults, I applaud Andrea Lublinski for her support of mothers who stay at home with their children in the very early years (''Mother Nurturers: A Prize for Society,'' Opinion Page, May 9). What irony that in recent years the commonest complaint heard by psychotherapists is that of people feeling emotionally empty, detached and depleted, who have difficulty in maintaining close and intimate relationships with others, while those women who are devoting themselves for a time to the care and nurturing of their children are criticized by a large segment of the society.

title: ART CRITICISM DRAWS MIXED REACTIONS
description: May I express my appreciation for Helen Harrison's consideration of my painting ''Anatomy Lesson - Unlearned'' in her review. It is always a satisfaction to an artist to be mentioned in a review, but it is of special significance when the reviewer homes in on the intentions of the work.

title: SOME PHILADELPHIA A.&P.'S TO REOPEN UNDER PACT
description: An unusual labor agreement has raised a prospect of new life for some A.&P. stores in the Philadelphia area. Some will be bought by their workers through an employee stock ownership plans.

title: U.F.T. STARTS DRIVE TO GATHER ITS DUES
description: Myra Entenberg, a slim and energetic teacher at Public School 116 on East 33d Street, is playing an important role in keeping the United Federation of Teachers afloat financially. She is one of the union's 1,000 chapter chairmen working to assure the payment of dues following the union's loss of the right to deduct them automatically from paychecks.

title: Chinese Say They Fear Fighting Could Spread
description: China expressed fear today that the intensified fighting in the Falkland Islands could grow into a larger war and appealed to Britain and Argentina to find a peaceful settlement.

title: STATE'S DELEGATION SPLIT ON THORNY ISSUES
description: IN THE legislative thicket that the House of Representatives must negotiate in the rest of the current session, three issues - the budget, the Clean Air Act and ocean dumping - promise to rank among the most controversial.

title: 'OLYMPICS' TO TEST MIND AND MATTER
description: EAST BRUNSWICK MARC OPPEN plans to wear a garden on his head. Adam Siegelheim will wear 28 red flags, each representing a college in New Jersey, and Jason Annunziata will connect dots in the shape of the state.

title: IT'S AN UPBEAT TIME FOR THE MUSICAL KRALS
description: MONTCLAIR JACKIE CAIN and Roy Kral, the husband-and-wife team who have applied their unusual jazz-based vocal styles to everything from Gershwin to Sondheim and Billy Joel for more than 30 years, are enjoying another of those upbeat periods that come to performers who have solid roots and who learn to adapt without really changing.

title: PHILLIES DEFEAT BRAVES
description: Pete Rose hit a two-run double to cap a fifth-inning rally that led the Philadelphia Phillies past the Atlanta Braves, 5-2, today. The victory snapped a four-game losing streak for the Phillies.

title: FEDERATION IS SET UP TO PRESERVE GREAT LAKES
description: A conference of about 100 people representing conservation organizations in the Canadian provinces of Ontario and Quebec and the eight Great Lakes states voted here today to form an international federation of citizen groups dedicated to preserving the Great Lakes.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
LOOKING FOR THE PAST SOMEWHERE IN THE FUTURE
description: WHEN I became a widower a few years ago, I realized that I was becoming an old maid. However, with the feral instinct of a young buck and the memory of a consummate marriage to a beautiful woman, I sought vainly to replicate what I discovered to be an impossible dream.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Who's in the Driver's Seat?
description: The Federal Trade Commission can propose consumer protection regulations, but Congress can dispose of them thanks to a 1980 law allowing legislative vetoes. Congress seemed bent on doing just that - and for the first time - last week as the Senate voted 69 to 27 to overturn a rule requiring used car dealers to specify the known defects and warranty provisions for cars they sell.

title: Around the World; An American Climber Is Killed on Everest
description: A mountain climber from New York City plunged to her death from a point 3,000 feet below the summit of Mount Everest, the Chinese Mountaineering Association said today.

title: Patricia Connor Is Wed
description: Patricia Myles Connor, daughter of Mary A. Connor of Leonia, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Warren Barbour Eickelberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Warren Eickelberg of Amityville, L.I. The Rev. Hilary Milton performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Freelance Guides
description: To the Editor:

title: Television Week
description: Exposure Quotient Many veteran actors prefer not to work in television. For instance, Robert Preston, who says: ''It can't be a first choice.

title: Miss Belden, James Nail Have Bridal
description: Catherine Cluett Belden, an assistant in the public-relations department of the New York Zoological Society, was married yesterday to James Douglas Nail, an account executive with Ogilvy & Mather Direct Response in New York. The Rev. Arthur Hargate performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal church in Bedford, N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. David Brown.

title: Penn Crew Triumphs
description: Pennsylvania's heavyweight varsity eight beat Northeastern by half a length today and won the Burk Challenge Cup for the first time since 1977. Penn led all the way in rain, covering the 2,000 meters in 6 minutes 43.1 seconds.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: WORKING PAPERS Selected Essays and Reviews. By Hayden Carruth. 239 pp. Athens, Ga.: University of Georgia Press. $19.95.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Motif Designs in Larchmont is a custom interior-design shop with dramatic savings beginning tomorrow on the manufacturers' suggested list prices for Levolor Riviera miniblinds: 50 percent off on more than 100 solid and specialty colors and a 40 percent reduction for arrangements with stripes. The sale ends June 12.

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: David Black's most recent books are ''The King of Fifth Avenue,'' a biography of August Belmont, and a novel, ''Minds.'' By David Black ne of the first patients Aaron Kenigsberg treated as a third-year student at New York University School of Medicine was a teen-age girl who had run away from home. She came to Bellevue Hospital in New York City, where Aaron was doing his obstetrics-gynecology clerkship, complaining of pain in her pelvic area. Most of the doctors assumed she was pretending to be in pain in order to get a free bed and meals. She did not want to go home. She was severely depressed. When her mother was called, she said it would be better if the girl committed suicide.

title: 'Outside the Norm'
description: Dear Massachusetts School Board: Many years ago I moved to Greenwich Village so I could be a Bohemian. (That's what my parents called it anyway.) This makes me exactly the kind of person the juniors and seniors of West Springfield High School said they want to see on their field trip to New York this week - someone who lived ''outside the norm free from harassment.''

title: NOW IS THE TIME TO CURE THE ILLS OF OUR SCHOOLS
description: THE time is propitious for Governor Kean to call for a Drumthwacket Conference on Schooling and Learning. The new Governor, his staff and the Legislature need a statewide forum on education now more than ever before.

title: BUSY SEASON EXPECTED AT BEACHES
description: STATE park officials, who last year were subjected to increasing complaints that recreational areas were poorly maintained, expect huge numbers of visitors at the 88 parks and beaches this summer season - and they are preparing for it.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are back on the Falkland Islands and back in strength.''

title: The World in Summary; To Britain's Outrage, the Majority Ruled
description: Postwar Europe's early dreams of creating its own ''United States'' evaporated long ago in a Common Marketplace noted mainly for economic logrolling and tradeoffs that spread money around by keeping prices artificially high. Last week, in a surprise re-interpretation of rules developed to protect the partnership's narrow national interests, the 10-member Community slid into its worst crisis yet.

title: O'NEILL RESIGNS AS EDITOR OF DAILY NEWS
description: Michael J. O'Neill resigned yesterday as editor of The Daily News and was replaced by James G. Wieghart, who had been executive editor. The shift in editorial leadership at The News, the nation's largest general-circulation newspaper, was announced by the paper's publisher, Robert M. Hunt.

title: More Jingles
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''There's a Song in Their Art'' (May 2), jingles substitute for strong selling ideas, especially when these ideas are either in short supply, or the product is not significantly different than the competition, or in situations where the probability of brand switching is high.

title: Frank Hoffecker 3d Weds Leslie West
description: The marriage of Leslie Branton West, assistant foreign editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, to Frank Shawn Hoffecker 3d, a sales engineer with the Dev-Air Corporation, distributor of pneumatic equipment in Paoli, Pa., took place yesterday. The Rev. Gregory S. Straub performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Chestertown, Md.

title: Feld Ballet Will Open Joyce Theater on June 2
description: Five new ballets and a revival will highlight a season by the Feld Ballet, its first in New York in four years, beginning June 2 at the new Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue at 19th Street.

title:
Other Business;
AN M.B.A. AU VIN, THE LATEST FROM THE CHICAGO SCHOOL
description: CHICAGO It's not enough to speak authoritatively about macroeconomics or cost-benefit analysis, to dress for success and use the right fork, according to the University of Chicago. Not if you think that bellying up to the bar for a beer is appropriate at a business lunch.

title: GLOOM HITS 76ERS AFTER CELTICS TIE SERIES
description: In a near-empty dressing room at the Spectrum Friday night, Julius Erving reflected the gloomy mood of the Philadelphia 76er fans after an 88-75 loss to the Boston Celtics that tied the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship series at 3-3. It was the second straight season the 76ers had lost a 3-1 edge to the Celtics.

title: Rebecca Faunce, T.W. McDermott Are Wed in Rye
description: Rebecca Winslow Faunce, fashion editor of Town & Country magazine, was married yesterday to Thomas Welstead McDermott, a sales representative with the Tastemaker division of J.P. Stevens & Company. The Rev. Donald W. Poole performed the ceremony in the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: CASEWORKER TO HISTORY'S VICTIMS
description: When Susan Thames Pettiss was in the fifth grade in Mobile, Ala., she was asked what she would like to be when she grew up. ''My mother wasn't a circus acrobat or President of the country, so I said I would like to be a plain lady like she was,'' she recalled the other day.

title: Ballet Stars to Present Du Pre Benefit June 20
description: Stars of the ballet world will perform June 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House in ''Diamond Night at the Ballet With Margot Fonteyn,'' a benefit for the Jacqueline du Pre Research Fund.

title: The Nation in Summary; Some Minor Discomfort
description: Vice President George Bush and Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan endured separate embarassments last week. Mr. Donovan, accused by Federal Bureau of Investigation informants of making labor payoffs and ties with organized crime, apparently approved a move by his New Jersey construction firm to hire private detectives to investigate the Senate Labor Committee investigating him. The firm's attorney, Theodore Geiser, confirmed the investigation, but denied that Mr. Donovan authorized it.

title: The Academies
description: To the Editor:

title: Yogurt
description: To the Editor:

title: SANCTIONS' FULL RENEWAL NOT EXPECTED BY BRITISH
description: British officials conceded today that they were unlikely to win full renewal of the sanctions against Argentina from Common Market allies when the question is taken up by the 10 foreign ministers in Brussels on Monday.

title: The Nation in Summary; Reagan Does a Vanishing Act, With His Budget
description: For the first time in months, a principal player in the budget drama stayed for the most part discreetly in the wings - and for good reason. With the Senate slogging through midnight sessions on one version of 1983 spending and revenues, and the House only just settling in to debate seven others, the major event of the week remained the fact that President Reagan's second budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, ceremoniously unveiled as a true bullet-biting compromise, had collapsed.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: Some $1.3 million in cash was missing from the state treasury in Ohio, along with pertinent records, and a former cashier who had charge of the money was reported to have amnesia.

title: Shift in Strategy
description: One of the Reagan Administration's arguments for a big military budget was that the United States should be prepared to fight a conventional war with the Soviet Union and its allies on a number of fronts. But as the budget request has been pared, so apparently, have the aims of American military strategy.

title: BOBCAT RESTORATION FACES OPPOSITION
description: TRENTON A proposal by the state's Department of Environmental Protection to reintroduce bobcats into the Pine Barrens is meeting opposition from an antihunting group and at least one Assemblyman.

title: Alice de Picciotto Wed
description: Alice de Picciotto, daughter of Elisabeth and Maurice de Picciotto of New York, was married yesterday to Neil Mason, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Mason of Warminster, Pa. Village Justice Richard E. Lanza of Mamaroneck, N.Y., performed the cermony at the Woman's Club of White Plains. The bride, an alumna of Mount Holyoke College, is with the Irving Trust Company. Mr. Mason, who graduated from Pennsylvania State University, is director of Eastern marketing at the Market Compilation and Research Bureau in New York.

title: LAST LINK IN FLORIDA KEYS HIGHWAY DEDICATED
description: The first time it was built, in 1912, people called it the Eighth Wonder of the World. It was a railroad line that went out to sea, 113 miles from the Florida peninsula to the island-city of Key West.

title: Caroline Shippen Davis Wed
description: The marriage of Caroline Shippen Davis to Samuel Garrison Chapin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler G. Chapin of New York and Plymouth, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. Shippen Davis Jr., in Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, brother-in-law of the bride and chaplain at the Stanford University Medical Center, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Around the World; Salvador Relief Chief Is Feared Kidnapped
description: The director of El Salvador's Green Cross relief agency was reported missing and feared kidnapped in a raid by unidentified gunmen on his home Friday. The Green Cross has been accused by rightists of aiding leftist rebels.

title: WHO NEEDS WALL STREET ANYWAY?
description: ONE puzzling aspect of the investment industry that I continually encounter in New Jersey is the blind assumption on the part of stockbrokers and high-ticket investors alike that Wall Street is the only place to profitably transact business.

title: A GUIDE TO BANKING'S HOTTEST MARKET
description: CITICORP'S official line is that it doesn't compete with the homegrown Florida banks down here. But its Miami offices, which occupy almost three floors of a downtown skyscraper, don't give that impression. They bespeak activity, expansion and success.

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: CIELINE
description: In her otherwise fine review of Herbert R. Lottman's "The Left Bank: Writers, Artists and Politics From the Popular Front to the Cold War" (April 4), Mavis Gallant makes three errors: She quotes an overheard conversation, in which Louis Ferdinand Celine is supposed to have complained that the Nazis "were not getting rid of Jews fast enough"; she dismisses Celine as a "right-wing writer"; she complains that because of the draining effects of political and economic events in the 1930's and 40's, no first-rate piece of literature was created.

title: MARGARET JOVA MARRIED TO JORGE M. GRUNBERG
description: Margaret Ynes Jova, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Jova of Washington, was married there yesterday to Jorge Miguel Grunberg y Merlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miguel Grunberg of Buenos Aires. Judge Malcolm R. Wilkey of the United States Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the Sulgrave Club.

title: Lacrosse Talent And Its Coaching
description: Gerald Eskenazi's piece on the pre-eminence of Long Island as a reservoir of lacrosse talent mentions Sewanhaka High and its string of 99 victories (''About Long Island''). The great and legendary players of that era would not want to omit mention of the architect of those victories, Coach William N. Ritch, long of Huntington, currently retired in New Hampshire - a Hall of Famer as player and coach.

title: Navy Whales
description: When the United States Navy took two beluga whales, male and female, to British Columbian waters for advanced training in retrieving sunken torpedoes, an environmentalist group slashed the netting of their pen last Oct. 30. The male whale swam out.

title: STORM OVER DONOVAN INQUIRY GATHERS MOMENTUM
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, already the subject of an investigation in New York by a special prosecutor, found himself the center of a public political storm here this week that pitted him against one of the Administration's staunchest supporters on Capitol Hill and saw a union leader call for his resignation.

title: POLICE TO TESTIFY ON EX-DENVER EDITOR'S DRUG HABIT
description: Michael Balfe Howard, once a social and civic leader in Denver, admitted last November that a ruinous cocaine habit had not only cost him his job two years ago as editor of a major newspaper here but also led him to the brink of suicide.

title: Notes on People; Koch Urges a Pardon for Sophia Loren
description: It's not the sort of thing he does every day, Mayor Koch was saying yesterday, but this was a special case. After all, he'd had Sandro Pertini, the President of Italy, to lunch at Gracie Mansion just last month, and he'd once met Sophia Loren at City Hall.

title: Church Boiler Explodes, Injuring 10 in Milwaukee
description: Ten people were injured today when a steam boiler exploded in a church basement just five minutes after services had ended.

title: David P. Morgan Dies at 87; Retired Chemical Executive
description: David Percy Morgan, a retired chemical company executive, died last Friday at Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 87 years old and lived in Stockbridge, Mass.

title: 'Attendance' Is Not Sales
description: WHILE the swing of New York's turnstiles toward the Mets and away from the Yankees was being measured this season, baseball history was discovered to need an eraser, or at least an asterisk. Bill Veeck and the 1948 Cleveland Indians deserve to retain the American League season attendance record that the Yankees were credited with surpassing in 1980.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a schedule change, the date for the L'eggs Mini Marathon was incorrectly reported in the sports section yesterday. The race will be run May 31, beginning at 10:30 A.M. at Tavern on the Green.

title: FEAR OF CRIME IS CHANGING HOW PEOPLE USE 2 PARKS
description: Precinct 23 One Neighborhood Battles Crime A series of articles appearing periodically. By M. A. FARBER

title: Knight Proposed As Olympic Coach
description: Bobby Knight of Indiana has been recommended by the men's games committee of the Amateur Basketball Association-U.S.A. to be coach of the 1984 Olympic basketball team.

title: FREED SOLIDARITY LEADER SPEAKS OUT IN POLAND
description: The tall, gray-haired and bearded man stood erect as he addressed the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland seated on a throne before him in a church that was bursting with people. But his jaws trembled and his hands shook as he read the text he had composed.

title: LEBANESE SECTS UNITED AGAINST FOREIGN FOES
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; May 24, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the Falkland Islands at 10:30 A.M.

title: IN HIS CAMPAIGN, WALLACE REPLAYS PAST BATTLES
description: The nameplate says ''George C. Wallace, Governor,'' which he is not, but has been three times, wants to be again and in Alabama souls perhaps will always be.

title: India's Congress Party Forms State Government
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party, which suffered a setback in regional elections Wednesday, succeeded in forming a government today in Haryana, one of two states where the opposition had forced a stalemate after no party was able to gain a majority.

title: TONEY EMERGES AS 76ERS' KEY MAN
description: The Philadelphia 76ers had just emerged from an unusual pre-game hiatus in the dressing room for the final game of their National Basketball Association semifinal series with the Boston Celtics today. The 76ers paced about the sidelines, greeting one another with handshakes and words of encouragment.

title: HOROWITZ PLAYS LONDON FOR FIRST TIME SINCE '51
description: Vladimir Horowitz was given a rapturous reception Saturday at a piano concert that was his first European appearance in nearly 31 years.

title: WOLFIE'S RASCAL WINS PETER PAN STAKES
description: Howie Tesher rolled up the collar of his trenchcoat as he stood beside Wolfie's Rascal in the winner's circle at Belmont Park after the Peter Pan Stakes yesterday. He shivered for a moment, either because of the chilling rain or the overwhelming irony of the moment.

title: PRESIDENT IS NAMED AT MUNSINGWEAR
description: Donald P. Brown has been named president and chief operating officer of Munsingwear Inc., the Minneapolis apparel maker. Raymond F. Good, 53 years old, remains chairman and chief executive.

title: TORIES' CHAIRMAN RULES OUT SNAP BRITISH ELECTION
description: Cecil Parkinson, chairman of the Conservative Party, said today that there was no chance that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher would call a snap election this fall in the hope of profiting from a successful military campaign in the Falkland Islands.

title: VENEZUELA SEES NEW OIL BOOM
description: In terms of speed, efficiency and results, what is happening on the table-flat, rattlesnake-infested plains north of the Orinoco River would seem to fulfill any oil wildcatter's dearest hopes.

title: Susan Schlessinger Bride Of John Andrew Jaeger
description: Susan Schlessinger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Schlessinger of New York and Southbury, Conn., was married yesterday to John Andrew Jaeger, son of Gloria Jaeger of New York and the late John Jaeger.

title: Thomas W. Purcell 3d Weds Elizabeth Ann Stern
description: Elizabeth Ann Stern, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Stern of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Williamson Purcell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Purcell Jr. of Richmond. Walter Lawton, leader of the Ethical Society of Westchester in White Plains, performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club.

title: Connors Is Favored In the French Open
description: Jimmy Connors was among several tennis players who came to Paris a few days early to get in extra practice for the French Open, the world's premier clay-court tournament.

title: Fergus Victorious On 1st Extra Hole
description: Keith Fergus sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a playoff today to beat Ray Floyd and win the Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: AUCTION PRICES FOR QUALITY WORKS HOLDING FIRM
description: Auctions of 20th-century art in New York's galleries this month proved surprisingly strong, somewhat quieting the fears in the art market that the deepening recession would take its toll on art auctions. Instead, the sales established a number of important art and artists' records and demonstrated that prices for quality paintings and sculpture continue to hold firm or to escalate. The prices on lesser works, however, are lower than a year ago.

title: SOVIET FARM PLAN SAID TO STRESS PRIVATE PLOTS
description: The Soviet Union's long-awaited ''food program'' is expected to be announced early this week and Soviet informants say there has been an effort to include a new emphasis on private plots and decentralized management of farming.

title: BALANCING CHILDREN AND A LEGAL CAREER
description: They work 50 to 80 hours a week, sometimes through the night, sometimes through the weekend, under pressure they describe as unremitting. They are young lawyers, associates in major New York law firms on the arduous track to partnership.

title: PRESIDENTIAL ERROR ON ARMS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: DOUGLAS DUNN'S 'GAME TREE'
description: STAGECRAFT can be deceptive. Yet on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery, it did appear as if Patrick O'Rourke's lighting designs for Douglas Dunn's ''Game Tree'' consisted entirely of white light. Just as white light, though combining all colors, can look quite colorless, so the hourlong work for Douglas Dunn and Dancers contained many kinds of movements yet gave the impression of an overall sameness. It was choreographic white light.

title: 2 VOLCANOES FOUND IN ANTARCTICA
description: Two small active volcanoes, 30 miles apart, have been discovered in Antarctica, bringing to five the total number known on that continent. The new ones have erupted so recently that their debris blankets part of the Larsen Ice Shelf on the Weddell Sea side of the Antarctic Peninsula.

title: Czyz Stops Coolidge in 5th
description: ATLANTIC CITY May 23 (AP) -Bobby Czyz, the New Jersey middleweight champion, stopped a bloodied Bob Coolidge in the fifth round today.

title: Sports World Specials; Shorts of Many Colors
description: At San Pasqual High School in Escondido, Calif., the color of the shorts that students wear to gym classes recently caused a controversy and it took the trustees of the district school board to resolve it.

title: TV: 'BOURNONVILLE' BILL AND TEEN-AGE MODELS
description: TV's ''Dance in America'' returns tonight at 8 o'clock with ''Bournonville Dances,'' featuring members of the New York City Ballet. There is a good deal of backstage significance to the program because it marks the debut in the series of Edward Villella as producer. Mr. Villella has, of course, long been associated as a dancer with the City Ballet and George Balanchine.

title: ROCK-JAZZ: LATE BRONZE AGE ECLECTICISM
description: THE Late Bronze Age, the esoteric rock-jazz quartet from Atlanta that made its New York debut Thursday at the Mudd Club, has achieved cult critical favor as a band that does ''everything.''

title: Added Security Set At Madison High
description: Security will be increased today at James Madison High School in Brooklyn as the school reopens after several days of racial tension. An added complement of police officers will patrol outside the building, at 3787 Bedford Avenue in the Flatbush section.

title: TRAVIS TO BALDWIN
description: John Baldwin of Meadow Brook, maintaining his steady play despite gusting winds and rain, captured the Walter J. Travis Memorial invitation golf tournament today.

title: Susan C. Hooper Wed To Thomas E. Bodiker
description: Susan Charnelle Hooper and Thomas E. Bodiker, account supervisors with New York advertising agencies, were married yesterday in Remsenburg, L.I. State Supreme Court Justice Lester E. Gerard performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Leonard H. Charnelle.

title: WHEN A BRITISH BOSS DISMISSES A WORKER
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN FOR BOMBARDIER INC.
description: Bombardier Inc., the Montreal-based company that is best known for bringing the snowmobile to North America, has spent much of the past decade in a patient effort to capture a major share of the North American market for mass transit equipment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I do not know if at any time in our history we have been so strongly united and so strong in spirit as we are now, although we are living through a period of pain, conflict, failure and crisis.'' - Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland. (A4:4.)

title: Bottle Laws Work
description: If people who drink beer or soda outdoors simply drove or walked home with their bottles or cans, there would be much less litter along the highway. But they don't and so the New York Legislature will consider two bills intended to reduce littering. One is speculative: it would impose taxes to finance something called ''total litter control.'' The other, proved practical in other states, including Connecticut and Vermont, is limited to beer and soda bottles and cans. It deserves to become law.

title: EL SALVADOR HAS NO RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Poisoning The Well
description: Last October President Reagan telephoned Morton I. Abramowitz, one of this country's top professional diplomats, and said: You're my man for Indonesia. Last week the State Department announced that the appointment was being withdrawn - because the Indonesian Government would not accept Mr. Abramowitz as Ambassador.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: OBSCURE FINDERS AID WALL ST. DEALS
description: They are the unknown firms in the securities industry. Most stock and bond customers have never heard of them and many professionals in the business have never dealt with them. Even officials of the Public Securities Association, the national trade group for dealers in municipal and Government securities, cannot provide any information about them.

title: Martha Goldfarb Married
description: Martha Leslie Goldfarb, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Goldfarb of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Bresnick. Rabbi Stephen Klein performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Myron Bresnick, in Scarsdale, N.Y. The bride is an artist. Her father was a psychiatrist. Mr. Bresnick is vice president of Grange Communications Inc., a film production and distribution company of which his father is president.

title: BRIEFING
description: Information Glut

title: STEEL INDUSTRY'S DIM OUTLOOK
description: Not since 1959, when the steel industry was in the middle of a 15-month slump, have steel executives gathered in New York for their annual meeting under worse circumstances.

title: RUTHVEN CONTROLS BRAVES
description: The Philadelphia Phillies decided about four years ago to take a second chance with Dick Ruthven. Ruthven, a 6-foot-3-inch righthanded pitcher, had spent his first two major league seasons with the Phillies, winning a total of 15 games and losing 22 in 1973 and 1974.

title: Susan Robbins Is Bride
description: The marriage of Susan Robbins to Dr. Eric Henley took place yesterday in the chapel at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass.

title: Rosemary Konner Is Married Upstate
description: Rosemary Konner, daughter of Joan Konner of Sneden's Landing, Palisades, N.Y., and Jack Konner of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday at her mother's home to Robert S. Steinbaum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Steinbaum of Mantoloking, N.J. Rabbi Marton Guttman of Newark performed the ceremony.

title: CALLS FOR CEASE FIRE
description: The official Soviet press agency, Tass, issued a statement today condemning Britain for its ''armed invasion'' of the Falkland Islands and demanding an immediate cease-fire and resumption of negotiations.

title: Advertising; Conde Nast Goes After 'Good Life'
description: NOW that we've thoroughly digested the news that Vanity Fair is coming back, Conde Nast Publications has another surprise from the wonderful world of magazines. It is changing its 81-year-old House & Garden magazine from moderate mass to extreme class with the January issue.

title: POPE ISSUES PLEA FOR AN END TO WAR
description: Pope John Paul II today repeated an appeal to the leaders of Argentina and Britain to ''effect an immediate cessation of hostilities and a resumption of negotiations'' over the Falkland Islands.

title: Legislature to Get Kean Tax on Fuel
description: Governor Kean's proposal to impose a 5 percent sales tax on motor fuels is scheduled to be introduced in the Legislature today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday on a speech by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Wein- berger in New York City incorrectly identified Leonard H. Marks. Mr. Marks is the chairman of the Foreign Policy Association.

title: 1,000 Back Argentina At Central Park Rally
description: About 1,000 Argentines and other Latin Americans rallied in front of the statue of the Argentine liberator Jose de San Martin in Central Park yesterday in a show of support for Argentina in its fight over the Falkland Islands.

title: MAKING LABOR STATISTICS MAKE SENSE
description: In the first week of any month that Congress is in session, Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, appears before the Joint Economic Committee to report how many people were working the month before and how many were not and to explain why.

title: CONCERT: ALL-GERSHWIN
description: WHERE is it written that all-Gershwin programs must consist of the Rhapsody in Blue, ''An American in Paris'' and small change? Certainly there is more to Gershwin's oeuvre that deserves to be heard before it is forgotten - the Second Rhapsody and the ''I Got Rhythm'' Variations for piano and orchestra, and the suite from ''Porgy and Bess,'' called ''Catfish Row,'' are three scores that come to mind.

title: Transactions;
description: %BASEBALL

title: Missouri Farmer Back in Jail
description: A Missouri farmer, jailed for refusing to say who helped him retrieve his soybeans from a bankrupt grain elevator, is back behind bars after a week of lobbying in Washington. Wayne Cryts, of Puxico, was allowed out of jail farmer to testify before subcommittees examining bankruptcy laws. He returned to Pope County jail Friday.

title: Bridge: Tourney Tests Whether 4 Is Actually Better Than 5
description: Four is worse than six but better than five. This conventional wisdom about the size of bridge teams was put to the test yesterday in the District Grand National final at the New York Hilton. The team of four, which had to play without rest, was Michael Becker, Ron Rubin, Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag. The team of five, which was forced to make frequent partnership changes, was Alvin Roth, Neil Silverman, Brian Glubok, Ethan Stein and Joel Friedberg.

title: 2 From C.W. Post Killed in Collision
description: Two students from C.W. Post College Center in Greenvale were killed and three others were seriously injured when their car careered across a highway dividing line and smashed into another auto, the police said today. The two occupants of the second car were also injured.

title: EXPERTS CITE SPECIAL STRAINS
description: An array of complex, stressful factors that are a special part of the black experience in America has blended with the normal pressures of marriage to produce a soaring divorce rate among blacks, according to experts on the black family.

title: Kansas Church Vandalized
description: Vandals caused about $9,000 worth of damage early Saturday at the Evangel Temple Church, hours after the congregation destroyed $10,000 in rock music records, tapes and Tshirts. The words ''rock and roll will never die'' were carved into a church door, the police said. Rocks were tossed through a stained glass window, three tires on a church bus were slashed and pews were damaged.

title: LEBANESE SECTS UNITED AGAINST FOREIGN FOES
description: To the Editor:

title: CRYSTAL'S IZOD DIVISION APPOINTS NEW LEADER
description: E.T. Catlett has been appointed president of the Izod men's division of David Crystal Inc., a New York clothing manufacturer, succeeding Leonard Resnick, who moves to the new position of chairman of the division.

title: 3-Month-Old Boy Dies in Auto Crash
description: A 3-month-old boy was killed and his mother critically injured today when a man said to have been driving his car while intoxicated failed to negotiate a curve and crashed into a car carrying a family of three, the police said.

title: Nigel Gosling, British Critic Of Art and Dance, Dies at 73
description: Nigel Gosling, a British art and dance critic who was a pioneering champion of American modern dance, died of cancer Friday in London. He was 73 years old.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With one out and a man on third, the batter lays down a suicide squeeze bunt; the runner easily scores as the batter races for first. The third baseman, realizing he has no play at either base, gets down on his hands and knees and blows the ball foul. What is the ruling?

title: UTILITIES SET NEW ISSUES
description: The United States Treasury is scheduled to sell $9.8 billion of bills today and $3.75 billion of new five-year notes on Wednesday. In the corporate market, utilities dominate this week's new issue market, with four debt issues totaling $340 million plus two issues of preferred stock.

title: Going Out Guide
description: SALUTE TO FATS

title: Washington Watch; Soviet Pipeline Is Challenged
description: West trade hawks and doves are headed for another confrontation over a Senate vote expected early this week on the ever divisive issue of the Yamal gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe and whether the Administration should take tougher action to block it.

title: Sports World Specials; Perpetrator of the Pickoff
description: When an opposing player reaches base against Dean Kazinci, a lefthanded pitcher for Fairleigh Dickinson University, the base runner is in big trouble. While posting a 10-5 record during his freshman fall and spring baseball seasons at F.D.U., Kazinci picked 44 runners off first base.

title: HARVESTER BOARD ASKS FAST ACTION
description: Directors of the International Harvester Company have urged the company's management to complete ''expeditiously'' a financial restructuring plan for the manufacturer of heavy equipment and trucks.

title: EX-OFFICEHOLDERS SEEK NEW FORTUNES IN PRIMARIES
description: Former Gov. Bill Clinton acknowledges that increasing car license fees was a mistake and asks for a ''second chance.'' Former Representative Jim Guy Tucker attacks Mr. Clinton and seeks a new, anticrime image. Former Lieut. Gov. Joe Purcell says his experience is what counts.

title: Mitterrand Backs Britain
description: President Francois Mitterrand pledged France's solidarity with Britain in the Falkland conflict today. It was his first statement on the conflict since British forces landed in the Falkland Islands Friday. ''Our solidarity with Great Britain should not be placed in doubt,'' he said at a news conference on the last day of a visit to the Ivory Coast.

title: Legislator Pursues Suit On New Florida Districts
description: Gov. Bob Graham today signed into law a bill that carves Florida into 19 Congressional districts, four more than it has now, but a state representative said he may pursue his lawsuit asking a Federal court to assign the boundaries.

title: DUTCHESS ISSUES HEALTH WARNING IN MEASLES CASES
description: An epidemic of measles has prompted the declaration of a limited health emergency in Dutchess County and an emergency immunization program to check the spread of the disease.

title: Martenson Will Head Arts Agency Theaters
description: The National Endowment for the Arts named Edward A. Martenson of Yale University's drama program, director of the agency's theater program last Monday.

title: Sports World Specials; Palmer Forsees a Trade
description: At noon last Thursday in Macy's, the aisles of the men's apparel section on the ground floor were jammed. Several hundred people were milling around a desk where a handsome, sun-tanned man was autographing baseballs, pictures and shopping bags.

title: CABARET: A DUO CELEBRATES GERSHWIN
description: A PROGRAM of Gershwin songs called ''Strawberries,'' after the vendor's cry in ''Porgy and Bess,'' was performed last Tuesday and Wednesday at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, by Barbara Lee and Brooks Morton. It justified the vendor's description of his fruit, ''So firm and fine and just off the vine.''

title: Commodities; Financial Futures Linchpin
description: WHILE the default of Drysdale Government Securities shook the financial world last week, the affair was easily absorbed by the new linchpin of the Government securities market - financial futures.

title: IN SALVADOR, DISCONTENTED OFFICERS
description: The displacement of Col. Jaime Abdul Gutierrez as commander of the Salvadoran armed forces last week suggests that more conservative officers have consolidated their control of the military. It also widens the gap between these hard-liners and more reformist younger officers - an underground faction that has begun to talk about joining with a broad range of other moderates, including mainstream Christian Democrats and members of the rebel opposition, to form a centrist coalition government.

title: Indy Field Is Set
description: The fastest lineup ever for the Indianapolis 500 was completed today as Gary Bettenhausen and three other drivers secured starting spots with qualifying runs of more than 194 miles per hour.

title: U.S. MOVES ON BRANIFF DRAW FILE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's plans to conduct a lottery Thursday of the valuable take-off and landing schedules held by Braniff Airways, which has filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws, offer short-term opportunities for many airlines but also have stirred a controversy with Braniff.

title: BONE IN THE THROAT
description: -Secretary of State Haig is traveling to the Middle West this week to deliver a rare address on the Middle East.

title: Addenda
description: * Ogilvy & Mather International is acquiring a minority interest in the Swedish agency of Schellenberg Marketing & Werbung.

title: 1948 BRITISH-ARGENTINE CLASHES IN ANTARCTIC ENDED PEACEFULLY
description: The fighting over the Falkland Islands is not the first confrontation between Britain and Argentina. In 1948, after a succession of incidents, both countries sent naval task forces to Deception Island at the northern tip of the Antarctic peninsula to support their claims to that region.

title: Eugene P. Quaglia Marries Carol A. Saunders, Teacher
description: Carol Ann Saunders, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Saunders of New City, N.Y., was married yesterday to Eugene P. Quaglia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Quaglia of Nanuet, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Lipman performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: NO TRADE BILL, PLEASE
description: The Congress is awash with new trade bills, and there is a risk that one or more may pass into law before the session is over.

title: ANGELS WIN, 7-2, AS TRADES PAY OFF
description: In the last few years, the California Angels have been free with their bankroll and extremely active in the trading market in an attempt to become competitive in the American League West. But the results were disheartening as the Angels finished no higher than fifth in the last two seasons.

title: Woodhull Hospital Taking Patients
description: Woodhull Hospital, a multimillion-dollar structure that has stood unused in Brooklyn for four years, is to accept its first patients today.

title: Sports World Specials; Forgotten, but Not Gone
description: For those avid fans who devour every statistic on the sports pages, a clarification about the standing of the American Soccer League, the oldest professional soccer league in the United States, is in order.

title: RILEY, A COACH AND CARPENTER, REBUILDS HIS BASKETBALL CAREER
description: LOS ANGELES TINY beads of perspiration dotted the forehead of Pat Riley. They swelled across his well-tanned brow and rolled slowly down his face. He looked up, then adjusted his wire-rimmed glasses.

title: SALVADOR BLOCKS THE ENFORCEMENT OF LAND PROGRAM
description: In less than one month as a legislative body, El Salvador's Constituent Assembly has blocked most of the country's land redistribution effort from being carried out.

title: CHIEF AT UNR INDUSTRIES ADDS CHAIRMAN'S POST
description: David S. Leavitt, 56, has been elected chairman of financially troubled UNR Industries, a Chicago holding company with interests in industrial, commercial, transportation and consumer products. Mr. Leavitt, who has been chief executive, president and chief operating officer, succeeds Edwin E. Hokin, 66, who retired but who will remain as a director and chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Hokin also will serve as a consultant.

title: Notes on People; Plan for a Bob Hope Veterans Hospital Dropped
description: He has entertained American troops all over the world, sometimes risking his life to do it, so it seemed like a good idea to name a veterans' hospital after Bob Hope.

title: Costa Ricans in Jerusalem
description: Costa Rica today became the first nation to move its embassy in Israel back to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber BRONX PRIMITIVE: Portraits in a Childhood. By Kate Simon. Viking. 179 pages. $13.95.

title: U.N. CHIEF IS URGED TO RENEW EFFORTS
description: The Security Council heard repeated calls today for Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to renew his attempts to make peace over the Falkland Islands.

title: COX, AT VASSAR, OUTLINES USE OF LEARNING
description: Vassar College held its 118th commencement today, as graduates, faculty members and 4,000 spectators sat huddled under umbrellas and makeshift coverings in continous rain at the school's outdoor theater.

title: Color South Africa Non-Black
description: If Prime Minister P.W. Botha and his party agree, he might soon become President of South Africa, in the Gaullist mode, with power enough to name even non-whites to his cabinet. That is the nub of a long-awaited constitutional plan proposed by a ''multiracial'' advisory committee. On its face, this vague plan looks like a rational step away from white supremacy in a race-haunted society. But incredibly, the plan is quite specific in one crucial respect: the 4.5 million whites would share no political power whatever with the two-thirds of the population that is black.

title: Miss Biederman Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia Ann Biederman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Biederman of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William Jeffrey Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Robbins of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club.

title: REFUGE IN QUEENS FINDS FRIENDS TO ANCHOR SHORE
description: There were sharp honking sounds as braces of Canada geese flew by, not an unusual occurrence these days at the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge. But over the weekend in this urban wilderness there was occasionally another sound - that of David Roosma's harmonica.

title: Asbestos Ltd.  Insurance
description: The Asbestos Corporation Ltd. said Friday in its annual report that it had enough damage insurance to cover a substantial portion of any damages that might be assessed it under several pending United States lawsuits.

title: IN UNLIKELY BOTSWANA, SINISTER SPY PLOTS UNFOLD
description: When the British decided to turn what was known as Bechuanaland into an independent state called Botswana, they looked around and discovered there was nothing resembling a capital in which to hold an independence ceremony.

title: SHAKE-UP OF STATE MORTGAGE UNIT FOLLOWS MISMANAGEMENT CHARGES
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which has floated hundreds of millions of dollars in bonds to pay for low-cost mortgages, is being investigated in a shake-up that has followed charges of incompetence and mismanagement.

title: Curing the Criminal Habit
description: As the name suggests, a ''career criminal'' makes crime a way of life, and it is likely that just a few of them commit a lot of offenses. A Baltimore study, for example, showed that 243 drug addicts may have committed half a million crimes. That is why many police and prosecutors have set up special programs to pursue habitual felons, with encouraging results.

title: IN BOSTON, A GROUP PROMOTES BLACK-WHITE CONTACTS
description: When Irene Smalls moved here from New York seven years ago to take a marketing job with Gillette, she didn't know anyone. So all she did during her first few months here, she says, was ''go to work and come home, go to work and come home.''

title: Lockhart & Pettus Plan New Branch in Atlanta
description: Keith E. Lockhart and Theodore P. Pettus will be opening a branch of their Lockhart & Pettus agency in Atlanta on June 1.

title: Market Place; Stock Index Futures
description: THE quick growth of the stock index futures contract, first introduced by the Kansas City Board of Trade in February, is spurring various strategies for using it.

title: Media General Talks
description: Media General Inc. said Friday that it was discussing a possible acquisition of the William B. Tanner Company, a private Memphis concern that buys and sells advertising time on radio and television stations. Tanner, which operates six regional offices, has revenue of about $100 million, according to Alan S. Donnahoe, vice chairman of Media General.

title: TEXT OF BRITISH STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a British Defense Ministry statement today on the fighting in the Falkland Islands:

title: 6 EX-CABINET OFFICERS OUTLINE BIPARTISAN PLANS TO CUT DEFICIT
description: A bipartisan group of former top economic officials plans to outline a program of sharp Federal spending cuts and large tax increases to slash projected budget deficits over the next three years.

title: Military Analysis
description: For the past 48 hours British forces, according to reports from the South Atlantic, have methodically strengthened and expanded their beachhead in the Port San Carlos area while Argentine ground forces, according to British officials, have done little to oppose them.

title: PRESS TELLS ARGENTINES THAT THEY ARE WINNING
description: Whatever may be happening on the Falkland Islands, many Argentines, buoyed by optimistic press, television and radio reports, believe they are winning.

title: ELECTRICAL WORKERS TO VOTE ON PACT AFTER STRIKING TO BAR CONCESSIONS
description: Several hundred striking members of the United Electrical Workers crowded into the auditorium of East Allegheny High School here today and heard union leaders say that the workers' nearly seven-month strike against American Standard had succeeded in stopping company demands for wage and benefit concessions.

title: Linda Rose Sherman Is Bride of Robert E. Martin
description: The marriage of Linda Rose Sherman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Sherman of Mountainside, N.J., to Robert Edward Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Martin of Jackson, N.H., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Superior Court Judge Lawrence Weiss of Union County performed the ceremony.

title: J.I. Browndorf, Executive, Weds Mary Chess Heffron
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls yesterday, Mary Chess Heffron, daughter of Mrs. Michael J. Higgins of Singer Island, Fla., and John L. Heffron of Rochester, was married to Joel I. Browndorf, son of Mrs. Morris E. Silverman of Philadelphia and the late Irving M. Browndorf. The Rev. Harris Riordan performed the ceremony.

title: OPERA: 'LADY MACBETH' AT SPOLETO
description: With one exception, there is little to amaze the ear at this year's Spoleto Festival. Over the weekend, Erich Leinsdorf conducted the New York Philharmonic in two very bland programs, including the ever-present Beethoven Fifth Symphony and the ever-present ''Firebird'' Suite of Stravinsky.

title: OUTDOORS: FISHING THE DELAWARE RIVER FOR SHAD
description: NARROWSBURG, N.Y. A DAY of shad fishing with Joe Purcell left me with the notion that he knows virtually everyone in Sullivan County. He also knows the habits of the Delaware River's shad and how to catch them.

title: Fidrych 'Satisfied' After First Start
description: Mark Fidrych, the 1976 American League rookie of the year who became popular for his colorful on-thefield antics, made his first International League appearance of the season Saturday night, pitching five and two-thirds innings and giving up five hits.

title: Iceland's Rightist Party Seen Gaining in Elections
description: Iceland's rightist Independence Party appeared to have gained in local elections Saturday.

title: WHEN CHILDREN SWEAR
description: The child comeshome from nursery school and proudly pronounces a new word-an obscenity. Its mother flinches. "Where did you learn that?" she asks with astonishment that is evident to the child. "From my friend," the child replies.

title: Notes on People; Hard Times
description: Remember Robert G. (Bobby) Baker? As the top aide to Lyndon B. Johnson when Mr. Johnson was Senate majority leader, he was one of the most influential Congressional employees in the 1960's - before his conviction for income-tax evasion in 1967.

title: YANKEES WIN, 4-2
description: In weather at Yankee Stadium that Ron Guidry thought more suitable for hunting than pitching, the Yankees yesterday extended their winning streak to five games and lifted their record above .500 for the first time this season with a 4-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: CATHY MORSE WINS ON 74-216
description: Cathy Morse, who has not played much golf this year because of the death of her fiance in January, gained her first triumph in four and a half years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour today.

title: GOMEZ TURNS BACK TELTSCHER IN FINAL
description: Andres Gomez of Ecuador, capitalizing on a powerful serve and forehand, defeated Eliot Teltscher, 6-2, 6-3, 6-2, today to become the third South American in three years to win the Italian Open tennis championship.

title: A RUNNER'S 'ULTIMATE'
description: STU MITTLEMAN wrestled and found it too competitive. He wanted to explore sports and life for himself, so he experimented with karate, yoga, meditation, diets, fasting and long-distance swimming.

title: SMALL GENERATORS FOR POWER BACKED
description: New York State's Public Service Commission has acted to let individuals and private companies generate their own electricity and to require utilities to tie the private power plants into their systems.

title: AN INSIDE 'OUTSIDER' RECALLS POSTWAR INTELLECTUALS
description: FOR New York intellectuals, it was a time of momentous undertakings and great expectations. There was, in the years immediately after World War II, a sense that the same expansive postwar spirit that had given birth to Eliot and Hemingway in the 20's might well create a second artistic flowering in the Greenwich Village of the 40's and 50's.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 24, 1982
description: International Six Argentine planes were shot down and probably three others in fighting over the Falkland Islands, the British Defense Ministry announced in London. The reported losses occurred as Argentine planes mounted a new attack on British ships in San Carlos Bay and on the beachhead that the British established on East Falkland. The Defense Ministry report said that a British frigate was damaged but that it was not known whether there were casualties. (Page A1, Column 6.) A major air attack was carried out by Argentine planes on British ships that had moved in to support a British beachhead in the Falklands, the military command in Buenos Aires reported, adding that results of the attack ''are in the process of evaluation.'' A spokesman for the command said that preliminary reports were that one British ship was badly damaged and Argentina lost ''several'' planes. (A1:5.)

title: THE ISLANDERS TAKE LANDING WITH SERENITY
description: It was a few minutes after four o'clock on Friday morning at the sheep station of Port San Carlos in the Falkland Islands. Dawn was still an hour away, but Isabel Shore and her husband had been awakened by their 12-year-old son, who said he had heard noises on the beach at the far end of the family garden.

title: Apparel Maker In Debt Accord
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, an apparel manufacturer based in New York City, said Friday that it had reached agreement with creditors on a modification of a financing plan.

title: HILTON HOTEL FIRE KILLS 4 IN CHICAGO
description: A fire apparently touched off by a smoldering cigarette spread thick, choking smoke through the upper floors of the 25-story Conrad Hilton Hotel today, killing four people and injuring 20, fire officials said.

title: BALLET: 3D DEBUT IN 'PILLAR'
description: NOWHERE is the special nature of a ballet more evident than when its current casts fail to reach the high level of those who made it live in the first place.

title: Lesotho Cabinet Official Is Wounded in Ambush
description: Gunmen ambushed and wounded a Lesotho Cabinet minister, Peete Peete, and four members of his family as they were returning in their car from church this morning, the Lesotho radio reported.

title: POET SALUTES FORDHAM U. GRADUATES
description: Their academic gowns soaked with rain, members of the 137th graduating class of Fordham University heard the Irish poet Seamus Heaney admonish them in verse at commencement exercises yesterday to make scholarship and art ''fragrant with personality and moral feeling.''

title: IRANIANS ASSERT IRAQI FORCE IS CUT OFF
description: Iranian forces have launched a new attack to retake the Iraqi-occupied port city of Khurramshahr, and a military communique broadcast by the Teheran radio today said that they had imposed a ''complete siege on Iraqi troops there.''

title: A BASEBALL TOWN PINES FOR A TEAM ALL ITS OWN
description: Today there is no ambiguity when, of a lazy afternoon over a Chardonnay or a Schlitz, the talk turns to the Washington Senators.

title: SPEAKERS AT U. OF CONNECTICUT STRESS NUCLEAR-ARMS DANGER
description: Members of the graduating classes at the University of Connecticut were told today at the 99th annual commencement exercises here that it was essential that they join the drive toward nuclear disarmament.

title: Rev. William D. Lyons, Pastor in Queens, Dies
description: The Rev. William D. Lyons, pastor emeritus of the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church at 31st Street and Ditmars Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, died Thursday at the church rectory. He was 73 years old.

title: 6 ARGENTINE JETS REPORTED DOWNED IN FALKLAND RAID
description: Six Argentine aircraft were shot down and three others were probably downed in fighting between British and Argentine forces over the Falkland Islands, the British Defense Ministry announced Sunday night.

title: Tenneco Offshore Liquidation Study
description: Outside directors of the Tenneco Offshore Company have made a tentative recommendation at the annual meeting to liquidate the company by placing its assets in a royalty trust. But no action was taken at the meeting on Friday, and the move would require approval of holders of the nearly 4.8 million shares outstanding.

title: NEW YORK STRUGGLING TO FIND PERMANENT HOMES FOR HOMELESS
description: By opening armories, an old schoolhouse and a new $7 million dormitory in the last year, New York City officials say they have been able to provide emergency shelter for every homeless person who asked for it. They have overcome, they say, what last spring was seen as a looming crisis.

title: YOUTHS' SUMMER JOBS HARDER TO FIND
description: Jim Hercek, who is graduating from high school in Metuchen, N.J., this spring, was hoping to get a summer job with the construction company he worked for last summer. ''But this year the guy said he couldn't hire me because he just doesn't have enough work,'' Mr. Hercek said. For the last two months he has been looking for a job, but has found no openings.

title: HATFIELD BILL WOULD BAR FEDERAL ABORTION FUNDS
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield, a moderate Republican, has introduced an antiabortion proposal designed to give permanent form to the prohibitions on Federal financing of abortion enacted in each of the last five years.

title: Arafat Welcomed in Pakistan After 3 Days of Talks in India
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was welcomed in Pakistan today after three days of talks in India with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who joined him in condemning what they called Israeli aggression.

title: PATRESE, ALONE AT FINISH, WINS
description: Riccardo Patrese of Italy benefited from a wild finish and won the Monaco Formula One Grand Prix today when his Brabham was the only leading car left in the race at the end.

title: FOR BRITAIN, A WEEK IN WHICH TALKING STOPPED AND WAR BEGAN
description: As British troops dug into positions on East Falkland Island today, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher spent a quiet Sunday at Chequers, her first day in weeks without a Cabinetlevel meeting.

title: HUGE TOKYO RALLIES PROTEST ATOM ARMS
description: Hundreds of thousands of people demonstrated in three separate rallies in Tokyo today calling for a halt to the nuclear arms race.

title: FED INCREASES BANK RESERVES
description: The Federal Reserve has made bank reserves more plentiful in the banking system, leaving analysts to debate whether the extra funds are an early sign of a slight easing of monetary policy or merely intended to assure the money markets that the financial difficulties of Drysdale Government Securities would not spread to other firms.

title: Arlene Rosenbloom Wed
description: Arlene K. Rosenbloom, an account executive with the publicrelations concern of Carl Byoir & Associates, was married yesterday to Lawrence W. Mandell, president of the Mid-Atlantic Steel Company. Rabbi Frederick Dworkin performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Englewood, N.J. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Jesse Marksamer of Brooklyn and the late George Kostick. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Mandell of Teaneck, N.J.

title: 76ERS DETHRONE THE CELTICS IN SEVENTH GAME BY 120-106
description: Before the Philadelphia 76ers dethroned the Boston Celtics, 120-106, for the Eastern Conference championship today, Coach Billy Cunningham said he thought his 76ers needed mostly a big game from Julius Erving.

title: HUNT SCORES TWICE AS COSMOS WIN, 3-2
description: Just when the Cosmos were turning the game into a rout at Giants Stadium today, the Fort Lauderdale Strikers turned the rout into a game.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Water Works Co., Wilmington, Del., has elected to its board Marilyn Strode Lewis, president of the Solanco Publishing Company, Quarryville, Pa., and Paul W. Ware, director of the Business and Industry Fund of Franklin & Marshall College, Lancaster, Pa.

title: Northwest Airlines Says It May Replace Strikers
description: Northwest Airlines said today it might begin tapping a pool of unemployed airline workers to replace 3,600 striking mechanics and baggage handlers and try to restore full service.

title: Dr. Jeffrey M. Bern and Carolyn Allen Have Bridal
description: Carolyn Betsy Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurens Allen of Birmingham, Ala., formerly of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Michael Bern, son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Bern of Montgomery, Ala. Rabbi Alex Goldman, assisted by Cantor Sidney Rabinowitz, performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green.

title: MONDAY, MAY 24, 1982; The Economy
description: A plan to cut budget deficits with more taxes and less spending will be offered today by a bipartisan group of five former Treasury Secretaries and a former Commerce Secretary. The panel, unhappy with current plans to reduce the worrisome deficits, says it could raise revenues by up to $450 billion over three years. (Page A1.)

title: Thankful for The Rain God
description: EACH summer Tlaloc the Rain God hurls fierce storms across the Valley of Mexico and its surrounding mountains. Last summer Tlaloc cost Tony La Russa a glimpse of one promising pitcher in the Mexican League -but in return the rainstorm helped La Russa discover Salome Barojas, the outstanding rookie relief pitcher, who has 10 saves so far this season.

title: Weather in Falklands: New Storm Approaches
description: Low clouds hung over the Falkland Islands today and higher cloudiness signaled the approach of yet another storm, the National Weather Service said.

title: CONCERT: DINO ANAGNOST
description: DINO ANAGNOST'S desire to cover a lot of musical territory in the concert of English music he conducted Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall resulted in a rather spotty program and some rather routine performances. Presented by the New York State Chapter of the Friends of the Winston Churcill Memorial and Library at Westminster College in Fulton, Mo., the event involved the musical services of the Little Orchestra Society; the Orpheon Chorale; Janet Hill, violist, and Gene Boucher, baritone.

title: DECISIONS DECISION-MAKERS REFUSE TO MAKE To the Editor:   Your editorial of April 29 regarding action by the Board of Estimate on midtown Manhattan zoning amendments focused primarily on the issue of ''grandfathering'' projects on which a certain amount of work already has been undertaken. I was disturbed by your conclusion that, although you could not decide on the merits of the grandfathering issue, the broader zoning change should be approved and the grandfather issue should ''be left to the courts to decide on a specific case.''
description: There is a growing trend in government at all levels for the legislative and executive branches to abdicate substantial amounts of their law- and policy-making authority to other branches of government. Under these circumstances, the ultimate decision-making often is left, by default, to a judiciary that lacks adequate understanding of the political process that was involved.

title: STEEL PLAN HURTS AREA IN ALABAMA
description: Almost in the shadow of the United States Steel Corporation's plant lies downtown Fairfield, a Birmingham suburb where the company built its first mill about 75 years ago.

title: HAIG REPORTS BREZHNEV NOTE AND SEES EARLY ARMS TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, had replied to President Reagan's letter urging an early start in talks on reducing strategic arms and that the two sides might be able to announce a date for those talks soon.

title: Western Features Sells Sponsored Comic Strips
description: The latest advertising incursion into previous ad-free areas of print is the sponsored comic strip, according to Editor & Publisher.

title: Alan Eisenberg Marries Claire Copley
description: Claire Copley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Copley of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Alan Eisenberg, executive secretary of the Actors Equity Association.

title: Begin Attacks U.S.  On Jordan Arms Sales
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger had misrepresented the facts to justify what Mr. Begin said was a plan to supply American weapons to Jordan.

title: News Analysis
description: Until last week, morale had never been better at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank holding company. Bank-stock analysts as well as the company's executives had been ebullient about

title: FOR THE CHAMPION, N.C.A.A. TENNIS IS A SPRINGBOARD TO PROS
description: The serve had bounced up to about shoulder height and Michigan's Mike Leach pounced on it, whipping a topspin cross-court forehand past Brad Gilbert of Pepperdine. With that shot, Leach won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 98th tennis tournament today, a distinction that has usually forecast success on the professional tour.

title: DESAULNIERS WINS IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: Although no Khans were in the championship match, Mike Desaulniers knew who to thank after winning the first World Series of Squash with a 15-5, 15-12, 15-6 victory over Gordon Anderson at the Yale Club yesterday.

title: NEW GRADUATES SAID TO FIND FEWER OFFERS OF EMPLOYMENT
description: Students in the college class of 1982 in the New York area, graduating at a time when the nation's unemployment rate is at its highest level in 40 years, are finding that job offers are down, according to placement officials, employers and students.

title: METS' JONES BLANKS ASTROS
description: Randy Jones, who nearly lost his job in baseball last year, won his sixth game of the season for the Mets tonight when he stopped the Houston Astros, 2-0, on a four-hitter.

title: THEATER: MARATHON '82 PRESENTS SECOND SERIES
description: A YOUNG man is munching Dipsy Doodles in a hospital waiting room when three elderly North Carolina women enter, sit down opposite him and start chattering like three birds on a branch. The three are sisters, and their brother, Howard, is dying. Howard, we are told, is famous, a former Under Secretary of the Navy in Calvin Coolidge's Administration. The women, trying to ''practice repose,'' are as close and as quarrelsome as elderly sisters can be. Romulus Linney's ''Goodbye, Howard'' is off and running on a wry course of eccentric comedy.

title: PRINCETON WINNER IN IC4A
description: It was a long time between victories for Princeton. The Tigers, who won the first IC4A outdoor track and field championshp in 1876, won their second team title today.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Not America, Just New Jersey

title: Sports World Specials; Who's in First?
description: Which major league baseball team has won the most games in history? Well, it depends ... The Chicago Cubs, who have been in existence since 1876, recorded victory No.8,000 on May 13. They will celebrate the achievement, which took 107 years and 15,337 games, on Friday when posters commemorating the 8,000th triumph will be given to everyone attending the game against the Los Angeles Dodgers at Wrigley Field. The team's publicity department has been describing the Cubs as ''the first professional sports team to win 8,000 games.''

title: John Paul Beatifies 5, Including 2 Canadians
description: Pope John Paul II beatified two Canadians, a French nun who founded a teaching order, a Dutchman known for his work with lepers and a 17th-century Spanish woman in a ceremony today in St. Peter's Square.

title: Notes on People; The Job Search
description: Like others graduating from college this year, the 95 seniors who received their degrees yesterday from Eisenhower College in Seneca Falls, N.Y., face a higly competitive job market.

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: PSYCHIATRISTS WORRY OVER IMAGE IN HINCKLEY TRAIL
description: The month-old trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. is plunging ever deeper into the realm of psychiatric jargon, ink blot tests and learned theorizing about whether he really felt compelled by the film ''Taxi Driver'' to shoot President Reagan.

title: Marijuana Detector Unveiled By Researcher on West Coast
description: A medical researcher has unveiled what he described as a foolproof marijuana detector that can quickly and accurately determine if a person is under the influence of the drug.

title: Hobart Captures Lacrosse Crown
description: Larry Grimaldi scored at 2 minutes 29 seconds of overtime today to give Hobart a 9-8 victory over Washington College and its third consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III lacrosse title.

title: HINDUS SEEK TO REVISE ROLE IN INDIA'S HISTORY
description: A former Government official is campaigning for acceptance of his belief that the Taj Mahal and other Indian tombs and shrines credited to Moslem emperors were actually built by Hindu rulers.

title: A Honeywell Executive To Run Vector Graphic
description: Fred A. Snow, vice president of market planning and research operations for Honeywell Information Systems Inc., will join Vector Graphic Inc. on June 1 as president and chief operating officer.

title: I.Q., in Japan and America
description: An Irish psychologist has ascertained that Japanese children have an average I.Q. score that is 11 points higher than that of their American counterparts. How should American school kids respond?

title: PLAY BALL! (OR SUCH)
description: The 8-year-old pitcher stands on the mound, chewing an enormous wad of bubble gum and trying to look as menacing as possible. This is no mean feat when you are almost completely concealed by the steerhide of your baseball glove, and your oversized baseball pants are billowing in the spring breeze like queen-sized sheets hung out to dry.

title: Renault-A.M.C. Deal
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault S.A. said today that it would distribute the American Motors Corporation's CJ-7 four-wheel drive Jeep-type vehicles equipped with diesel engines in France and Belgium next month. It said it hoped to sell 12,000 in the first year.

title: DIASONICS'S RECESSION-PROOF PRODUCT
description: Until two years ago, many executives in California's Silicon Valley might have sympathized with Albert Waxman's attempts to get his fledgling company, Diasonics Inc., off the ground. Today, they might understandably be envious.

title: STEINBRENNER SAID TO RENEGE ON AID
description: Dave Winfield said last night that George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, has defaulted on a contract to donate $300,000 a year for 10 years to the David M. Winfield Foundation for under-priveleged children.

title: Hooker Chemical Laying Off About 360 Workers Upstate
description: About 360 salaried and hourly workers at the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation will be laid off immediately, a company spokesman said today.

title: Toxic Waste Dump Cited by Legislator
description: The chairman of the State Senate Select Committee on Crime asserted yesterday that 60 tons of highly flammable and toxic waste had been dumped this month by city order at a Brooklyn landfill across from the Starrett City housing complex. He said it should be dug out to avert fires.

title: A Chronology
description: Two decades of events related to pesticide regulation:

title: Dim Light in the Subway Tunnel
description: It is logically impossible for all the governmental critics of New York's transit to be right. If Assemblyman Kremer is right that the Transportation Authority's budget is extravagant, Lieutenant Governor Cuomo can't be right in urging it to purchase subway cars more expensively from a domestic manufacturer. Both, however, could be wrong.

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: DANDY WINE, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plea by Track Stars
description: In Rome, Sebastian Coe and Kip Keino, attending the first meeting of the International Olympic Committee's recently formed athletes' commission, appealed for a higher standard of judging. Peter Tallberg, an I.O.C. member who heads the athletes' group, suggested that retired athletes be used as referees.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SUING LEGAL FUND IN A DISPUTE ON USE OF INITIALS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People plans to sue the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. to halt what it says is the unauthorized use of its initials by the civil rights litigating group.

title: Topics; Motivations to Learn; Sour Apples
description: The makers of Apple computers want to donate one to each of the 82,000 public schools in the United States. But this idea is marred by Apple's insistence on a special tax break, which would make the Treasury bear 92 percent of the cost of its generosity.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
