description: WHEN President Reagan was on the operating table after his attempted assassination last year, the surgeon, Dr. Benjamin L. Aaron, had difficulty feeling the bullet in the spongy lung tissue. Thinking it might have traveled to some other area, he ordered an Xray, which showed that the bullet was still in the lung.

title: Profits Up 3.9% at Mitsubishi
description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. today reported a 3.9 percent rise in after-tax profits, to $52.7 million, in the year ended March 31, from $50.7 million in the preceding year. The company said that sales increased by 26.8 percent, to $7.04 billion, from $5.55 billion.

title: Sweden Recounts Effort To Locate Wallenberg
description: Sweden released documents today detailing its efforts over 20 years to discover the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, who saved thousands of Jews from the Nazi holocaust and was captured by the Soviet Union.

title: Weather in Falklands: No Major Storms Seen
description: The weather is clear over the Falkland Islands, with no major storms within 50 to 100 miles, the National Weather Service reported today.

title: MORALE OF ARGENTINE TROOPS APPEARS LOW, BRITISH REPORT
description: British correspondents in the South Atlantic reported today that the condition of Argentine troops defending the Falkland Islands seemed poor.

title: Pittston Deal
description: The Pittston Company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that on May 3 it purchased the capital stock of Burlington Northern Air Freight Inc. from Burlington Northern Inc. for $177 million, which it financed through loans from six banks, including Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Levi Strauss Appoints President for Hat Unit
description: When Mike Gibbons was manager of a Levi Strauss jeans distribution center in Florence, Ky., a local newspaper interviewed him and said that he wore many hats.

title: SALVADOR ASSURES U.S. ON LAND PLAN
description: The State Department said today it had been assured by the Constituent Assembly in El Salvador that key provisions of that country's land redistribution program would be carried out despite a new decree that has aroused concern about the future of the program.

title: When Left Is Right
description: The way they are telling it in Vermont, Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York financier, had just finished delivering a highly charged commencement address with a distinctly liberal cast at Middlebury College Sunday afternoon when Steven C. Rockefeller, the college's dean, rose to remind the graduating seniors that, upon receiving their diplomas, they were to move the tassels on their mortarboards from the right to the left.

title: THE MUSTO EXPERIMENT
description: From time to time, there arises in the land a mood of sore confusion over what is a crime and what is not.

title: JUSTICES AGREE TO ACT ON RULES IMPEDING ABORTIONS
description: The Supreme Court set the stage today for an important test of women's ability to exercise their constitutional right to obtain abortions.

title: Pan Am Fare Action
description: Pan American World Airways today joined other competitors on routes vacated two weeks ago with the suspension of service by Braniff International. Pan Am's promotional fares, good until June 30, include $89 one-way tickets between Dallas-Fort Worth and New York and between Dallas-Fort Worth and Miami. Last week, Trans World Airlines announced an $89 promotional fare between New York and Dallas good until the end of the month.

title: KANTOR'S THEATER PIECE AWARDED THE TOP CHOICE
description: The Obie award for best Off or Off Off Broadway theater piece of the 1981-82 season has been given to the Polish playwright Tadeusz Kantor for his ''Wielopole, Wielopole.''

title: A Senior Statesman
description: Senator Barry Goldwater went to Newport Beach, Calif., to give a rousing defense of the principle of candidates' riding on other candidates' coattails, particularly paternal coattails.

title: Air Scheduling System Studied
description: The Justice Department has begun a nationwide investigation of whether airlines that run computerized scheduling systems have violated antitrust laws, a department spokesman said today.

title: PSYCHIATRIST BARRED FROM ADMINISTERING EXPERIMENTAL DRUG
description: A psychiatrist who pioneered the use of tranquilizers and antidepressant drugs in the treatment of mental illness has agreed, in a Federal court action in Manhattan, to stop using experimental drugs on patients and in his research.

title: Chief Officer Quits At Stanley Works
description: Differences in ''style and management philosophy'' with the board of directors has led to the resignation of Vaughn E. West, 53, president and chief operating officer of the Stanley Works in New Britain, Conn., the company said yesterday.

title: Court Affirms U.S. Acted Illegally on Haitians
description: The United States violated the rights of 4,000 Haitians by holding mass deportation hearings to clear a ''staggering'' backlog of aliens from southern Florida refugee camps, a Federal appeals court held today.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT'S OPEN TO EGYPT'S AID
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who initiated the Arab world's diplomatic break with Egypt because of the peace treaty with Israel, says he would welcome the presence of Egyptian soldiers to help Iraq in its war with Iran.

title: THATCHER ANSWER TO THE POPE
description: Following is the text of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's reply to Pope John Paul II on his appeal for a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands, as made public by 10 Downing Street:

title: 'FLAT' INCOME TAX GAINING ADVOCATES
description: Proposals for a radical change in the individual income tax, the principal engine of Federal revenue, are receiving increasing attention on Capitol Hill.

title: ACTION BY JERSEY UTILTIY MAY LEAD TO RATE CUT
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company agreed today to a cut in its energy adjustment charge that would reduce electric rates by $250 million.

title: DELOREAN PLANT MAY CLOSE MONDAY
description: Receivers for the DeLorean Motor Company's sole manufacturing unit in Belfast, Northern Ireland, said yesterday morning that they would close the plant next Monday, suspending production and laying off most of the 1,500 employees.

title: American Bakeries Shift
description: Leonard Toboroff was named acting chief executive officer of American Bakeries Inc. yesterday to replace Neil S. Leist, who was injured in an auto accident during the weekend. Mr. Toboroff, a New York lawyer, is a director of the company.

title: Meat and Cancer Revisited
description: While the high incidence of breast and colon cancer in countries where meat is a staple food has led scientists to suspect that meat, because of its saturated fat content, may be a contributing factor, a recent study by Dr. L.J. Kinlen of Oxford University not only failed to confirm this link but also found an increase of cancer of the esophagus among vegetarians and infrequent meat eaters.

title: Bridge: Roth's Team Is Victorious In District Grand National
description: One team edged into the lead at the start of the match, and kept its edge long enough to win. That was the story of the District Grand National Team final Sunday at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Tosco Proxy Tally To Be Delayed
description: The Tosco Corporation said that the preliminary results of the May 11 voting by shareholders to settle the proxy battle waged by a dissident group led by Kenneth M. Good would not be completed until Wednesday.

title: Spain's Governing Party Rules Out Early Election
description: Spain's governing center-right party said today that it did not plan to call for early national elections following the party's defeat in regional elections Sunday.

title: COUNTIES ASSAIL STATE A-PLANT EMERGENCY PLANS
description: The eight counties in New York State that lie within 10 miles of a nuclear generating station sent representatives here today to confer with each other and to complain that the state was complicating their emergency planning.

title: LAME-DUCK CONGRESSMAN'S LAMENT
description: Representative Edward J. Derwinski says he is not exactly feeling sorry for himself, but ... On March 16, running in a newly redrawn Illinois district embracing 85 percent of his old territory, he lost the Congressional seat he had held for nearly 24 years, almost half his lifetime.

title: 2 DRAFT TEXTS AT U.N. URGE A CEASE-FIRE
description: Ireland and Panama circulated draft resolutions today urging a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands, but diplomats here gave neither text much chance of approval by the Security Council.

title: Nobel Laureates' Sperm Bank Reports Its First Birth, a Girl
description: The Repository for Germinal Choice, set up in 1979 to make available the sperm of Nobel Prize winners and other ''creative, intelligent people,'' announced its first baby today.

title: KIRKLAND ASSAILS OSHA CUTS
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., today assailed Federal cuts in job site inspections, saying that the right to a safe workplace was as basic as ''the right to freedom of speech, religion or a fair and speedy trial.''

title: IN MEXICAN ELECTION, THE WINNER IS RUNNING HARD
description: Dressed in his Sunday best, the old peasant leaned across a rough-hewn table covered with children's drawings and poured out his troubles to ''the candidate of my party.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Lucky Stores
description: Lucky Stores Inc. announced that its Gemco unit, a Californiabased retailer, had agreed to purchase the pharmaceutical inventories of 27 Fedmart pharmacies, which that company closed in southern California. Lucky Stores would not release the value of the purchase.

title: Corning Glass
description: Corning Glass Works Inc., a diversified glass and ceramic products manufacturer in Corning, N.Y., said it had agreed in principle to acquire the stock of the RCA Research Corporation Inc., a small subsidiary of the RCA Corporation in Japan, but did not disclose the amount.

title: FINANCING QUIRK DRYSDALE STUDIED
description: In the wake of the Drysdale Government Securities default on interest payments, the executive committee of the Primary Government Securities Dealers Association met late yesterday to consider changes in short-term financing techniques widely used in the market for United States Treasury securities.

title: 3,009 STUDENTS GIVEN DEGREES AT YALE
description: Serenaded, satirized and soaked during two rainswept days of graduation activities, 3,009 students received degrees today at the 281st commencement of Yale University.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alexander & Alexander said it had acquired a 20 percent interest in Industries-Assekuranz, a West German insurance broker, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Gasoline Futures
description: The staff of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission today recommended approval of the Chicago Board of Trade's plan for futures trading in leaded and unleaded regular gasoline. The proposed trading unit is 1,000 barrels of 42 gallons each with an initial daily trading limit of 3 cents a gallon.

title: CREDITORS ACCEPT ITEL REORGANIZATION
description: The Itel Corporation, a computer leasing company that had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with its secured lenders' and unsecured creditors' committees on terms to treat most of its $330 million in secured debt in a proposed plan of reorganization.

title: Italian Guerrilla Suspect Is Slain by Police
description: A guerrilla suspect who was convicted in his absence of taking part in the abduction of a United States Army general was fatally wounded today in a gun battle with the police near the coastal town of Viareggio, the police said.

title: BASIL SOLLITTO, HOSPITAL OFFICIAL
description: Basil Joseph Sollitto, who became associate administrator of Columbus Hospital in Newark after a distinguished military career, died May 12 at American Hospital in Miami. Mr. Sollitto, who lived in Scotch Plains, N.J., was 62 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOME THINGS NEW

title: C.I.A. SPOUSES WHO MUST COME IN FROM THE COLD
description: To the Editor:

title: G.& W.'s Amfac Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it owned 3,681,900 shares, or 26.1 percent, of Amfac Inc. It said the shares had been acquired for investment purposes.

title: BEIRUT BOMB KILLS 12 AT FRENCH EMBASSY
description: A car bomb exploded inside the French Embassy compound here today, killing 12 people and wounding 27, a French Embassy spokesman said.

title: LARRY RILEY AND JOANNE CAMP WIN DERWENT ACTING AWARDS
description: Larry Riley and Joanne Camp have been named winners of the 38th annual Clarence Derwent Awards as ''the most promising male and female actors on the metropolitan scene'' during the last theater season. Mr. Riley is playing an Army private in Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play'' at the Negro Ensemble Company. He also appeared this season in ''Maybe I'm Doing It Wrong.''

title: N.H.L. to Consider Purchase of Rockies
description: A new option for settling the Colorado Rockies' problem has been raised: the National Hockey League could purchase the team, then place it in Byrne Meadowlands Arena as an expansion franchise.

title: A.M.C. Cuts Small-Car Price
description: The American Motors Corporation, which is 46 percent owned by Regie Nationale des Usines Renault of France, said today that it was reducing base prices of its French-built Renault Le Car subcompacts by as much as $300 through July 20.

title: Small Cassette For Video Next
description: A group of 12 Japanese companies using the VHS format for videotape recorders said today that they would soon begin marketing a compact video cassette as the first step toward a mini-video system.

title: 8 MARKET NATIONS AGAIN EXTEND BAN AGAINST ARGENTINA
description: In a new sign of support for Britain, a majority of the Common Market countries agreed Monday to extend indefinitely the economic sanctions imposed against Argentina in retaliation for its invasion of the Falkland Islands.

title: RABID BATS FOUND IN WESTCHESTER
description: Health officials reported today that two rabid bats had been found this month in Westchester. They urged all county residents to have their dogs and cats inoculated against rabies.

title: RULING LIMITS USE IN COURTS OF CONFESSION
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that when a minor confesses a crime to a parent while in police custody and is overheard by the police, the confession generally may not be used against the youth at his trial.

title: DOW UP 0.48 IN WEAK MARKET
description: Stock prices finished mostly lower yesterday in the slowest trading since the end of March. At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.48 point, to 836.38, after being off almost 3 points at 3 P.M. Analysts attributed the improvement in the last hour of trading to the news that Bankers Trust had cut its broker loan rate to 14 3/4 percent from 15 1/2 percent. Later, several other banks followed suit.

title: CABERET: RETURN OF ORSON BEAN
description: year hiatus during which he has occupied himself with the Broadway theater, television, starting a school based on the theories of the Summerhill Society of England, writing a book inspired by the theories of the psychiatrist Wilhelm Reich, living in Australia, being wealthy, being poor, being a house-husband and being a late-blooming hippie.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alagasco Inc. elected Rex J. Lysinger, president and chief executive officer, to the office of chairman.

title: Alcoa Closes Texas Smelter
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it was permanently closing its 145,000-ton-a-year aluminum smelter at Point Comfort, Tex., which would require major capital investment to meet environmental standards.

title: Stocks Without Shares
description: Why buy steak when all you crave is the sizzle? Investors in stock option contracts have long been able to gamble on individual stocks without buying the actual shares. Now, with Government approval, three exchanges offer futures contracts keyed to various stock market indexes. That makes it possible to bet on broad trends in stock prices without buying any commodity or business share.

title: Jordan, Case & McGrath Uses 'Nameonics' Again
description: O.K., class, which agency coined the word ''Nameonics'' to describe its theory of increasing the impact of advertising by getting the product name into the advertising theme?

title: New Title for Commissioner
description: A new state law has changed the title of the head of the New York State Labor Department from Industrial Commissioner to Labor Commissioner. Commissioner Lillian Roberts said the new title ''should more accurately reflect my role - that of serving the labor force of our state.''

title: John Falter, Artist, 72, Dies; Illustrated Magazine Covers
description: John Falter, an artist and illustrator whose works included magazine covers, World War II recruiting posters and portraits of American celebrities, died last Thursday in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia.

title: 76ers UP, DOWN, AND UP
description: With time to reflect on one of his most satisfying victories, Billy Cunningham recounted yesterday the emotional ups and downs of the seven-game Eastern Conference championship series between the Philadelphia 76ers and the Boston Celtics.

title: Unit of Flow General Guilty On Interest Conflict Charges
description: Flow General Inc., which manufactures biological and research equipment and also conducts research for various Government agencies, announced yesterday that its General Research subsidiary had pleaded guilty to three charges relating to conflicts of interest in connection with the September 1980 procurement of an Army contract.

title: FURS: SIMPLICITY VS. EXTRAVAGANCE
description: As this year's fur showings came to an end, a definite schism made itself clear. With prices up and money tight, American designers expect their customers to think of a fur coat as an investment and are working good pelts into fairly classic lines. The Europeans apparently haven't heard of a recession. Theirs are the startlers: dyed furs, embroideries, fringe, ruffles and every trick in the book.

title: Vote in Greece Assures Spain's Entry to NATO
description: The Greek Parliament tonight overwhelmingly approved the protocol for Spanish membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, thereby finalizing Spain's entry into the alliance.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Air International Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell two million units, each consisting of one share of common stock and one common stock purchase warrant, through an underwriting group managed by First Affiliated Services.

title: AID HOUSING AS GOVERNMENT IS DISMANTLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Nippon Telephone
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, a state-owned company, said it would establish a new company here to design and manufacture custom large-scale integrated circuits for delivery to Nippon Telephone. The new company will be capitalized at about $430,000, of which 50 percent will be put up by N.T.& T., and the balance by nine major commercial banks, including the Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank.

title: FOSTER IS SURE HITS WILL COME
description: George Foster considered the question: If you were filing a scouting report on George Foster after six weeks with the Mets, what would you say?

title: ARGENTINE DIPLOMAT ON A HIGH WIRE
description: For Nicanor Costa Mendez, Argentina's Foreign Minister, the Security Council meetings that he is attending in New York are the latest delicate step in a diplomatic high-wire act.

title: STATUE FIGHT ENDS IN A DRAW
description: Both Rockies could come home again, everyone finally agreed. Sylvester Stallone, who plays Rocky Balboa, the bloody but unbowed hero of the movies ''Rocky'' and ''Rocky II,'' would return to his hometown for the premiere tonight of ''Rocky III,'' to help the city celebrate Century IV, its 300th birthday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When nutrients are absorbed by blood from the small intestine, what determines which nutrients will go where so all tissues and organs, which have different requirements, get whatever they need?

title: CANNES FESTIVAL, AT 35, SEEMS SEDATE
description: It is as hard for the outside world to penetrate the crowds of the Cannes Film Festival as it is to receive a telephone message, or to steer a path in the lobby of the Carlton Hotel through the photographers, the sightseers and the little deals dressed up as big ones.

title: BUSINESS ECONOMISTS PESSIMISTIC
description: The nation's leading business economists released a grim forecast today that shows only a weak recovery in the last half of 1982, with high unemployment and high interest rates continuing to the end of the year.

title: California's Farm Exports
description: Another moderate year for California's agricultural exports is seen by the Security Pacific National Bank. Price declines, high interest rates, a strong dollar and recession abroad should limit the growth of such exports to 6.1 percent in 1982, the bank said today, resulting in a new total of $6.2 billion.

title: The Birthday Bridge
description: When it turns 100 next year, there will be a six-month celebration, ending with a parade, a sound-and-light show and fireworks.

title: One 'Old Gray Mare' Who Has a Few Plans
description: ''The old gray mare,'' Claire Bibuld Jacobs was saying about herself yesterday, ''ain't what she used to be.'' Yet Mrs. Jacobs, an 80-year-old great-grandmother has plans:

title: A Number of Account Movements Reported
description: There are a number of account movements to report on. Friendly Frost, which operates 38 appliance, video, stereo and lawn care products outlets in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area, has turned to the six-month-old Zlotnick Company for broadcast advertising.

title: Financial Futures Show A Standoff in Prices
description: Financial futures prices were at a standoff yesterday as buyers and sellers cautiously followed the cash markets. Brokers said both sides of the market were evenly matched and that trading over all was uncommonly dull.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Fri- day incorrectly reported the Xerox Corporation's earnings for the second quarter of 1981. They were $179.7 mil- lion, or $2.13 a share.

title: Padres 8, Cubs 2
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Ruppert Jones went 3-for-3 and drove in three runs as San Diego took advantage of three Chicago errors to help unbeaten Tim Lollar record his fifth victory. Bill Buckner, the Cubs first baseman, was lifted from the lineup by Manager Lee Elia after he had to be restrained by teammates from going after another Cubs player in front of the Chicago dugout during the sixth inning.

title: VALENTINE'S HOMER LEADS METS PAST BRAVES, 5-3
description: Ellis Valentine, making his first start in two weeks, came through with his first home run since last Sept. 24 and his first two runs batted in of the season as the Mets defeated the Atlanta Braves, 5-3, tonight.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 25, 1982
description: International New European support for Britain was expressed by eight members of the 10-member Common Market. They agreed to extend indefinitely economic sanctions imposed against Argentina in retaliation for its seizure of the Falklands. Italy and Ireland again refused to participate in the ban on Argentine imports. At the same time, Britain retreated considerably on two internal Common Market issues. (Page A1, Column 6.) Seven Argentine jets were downed during repeated sorties against British ships off the Falklands in the third large Argentine attack in four days, the Defense Ministry announced. But it conceded that several of the figher-bombers had penetrated a screen of British jets and missiles and had hit several frigates and destroyers. No details were disclosed, but the ministry said that a frigate hit in Sunday's raids had sunk. (A1:3-5.)

title: Market Place; Technology And High P/E
description: Few would view Seagate Technology as a bargain at current prices. Shares of this manufacturer of Winchester disk drives sell at 100 times earnings. Yet Seagate broke into black just last year.

title: Limited Stores
description: Limited Stores Inc. said it had accepted for payment about 80 percent of the shares of Lane Bryant Inc. The company recently agreed to purchase all of Lane Bryant's shares at $29 each. The company also said that shareholders had approved changing the company's name to Limited Inc. and to change the state of incorporation to Delaware.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DENIES SUPPLYING ARMS TO ARGENTINA
description: Defense Minister Magnus Malan said in Parliament tonight that, contrary to a published report, South Africa had not supplied Argentina with missiles or spare parts for planes.

title: BRIEFING
description: Pre-Summit 'Charm School'

title: ROCK: SEXTET LED BY HUEY LEWIS
description: HUEY LEWIS and the News, the San Francisco-based sextet that recently scored a top-10 single with ''Do You Believe in Love,'' consists of masterful practitioners of an eclectic pop-rock that blends the rich harmonies of California rock and the metronomically plucked beat of new wave, with strong rhythm-and-blues influences into an ingratiating brew. Along with formidable technique, the sextet boasts a potential superstar in Huey Lewis, a charismatic frontman who combines a rich, bluesy baritone with the good looks of a 1950's rock idol.

title: Spot Oil Price Holds Steady
description: Crude oil prices held steady in spot trading in Europe and home heating oil prices rose, market sources said today.

title: Dayco Files Suit Against Agent
description: The Dayco Corporation, an Ohio-based automotive products manufacturer, said it had filed a $38 million lawsuit against one of its former sales agents, the Foreign Transactions Corporation, charging that the company defaulted on a promissory note and misrepresented certain foreign sales transactions.

title: Panel to Review Evers College
description: The chairman of the board of trustees of the City University of New York has established a special committee of trustees to review conditions at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn.

title: ARGENTINA CALLS FOR AN O.A.S. MEETING
description: Argentina moved today to reconvene the Organization of American States to consider specific measures against Britain for its military actions in the Falklands.

title: BILL YIELDS OFF SHARPLY AT AUCTION
description: Underscoring last week's drop in short-term rates, the Treasury sold $9.8 billion of three-month and six-month bills yesterday at sharply lower yields than those prevailing at the previous Monday auction.

title: Beverly Hills Savings
description: Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said today that it would not consider valid more than half of the votes cast for Sheldon Appel for a seat on the company's board because it believed he and others had solicited votes on his behalf illegally. A preliminary count showed he had the highest total of any of seven candidates for the five-member board - 903,706 votes. The company said it had adjourned the annual meeting until Thursday, pending completion of the vote count.

title: Talking Business with William De Lancey of Republic Steel; The Big Issues Facing Steel
description: William J. De Lancey, the 65-year-old chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, will be in New York this week to lead his final annual meeting as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the industry trade association. Mr. De Lancey, who is stepping down from his position at the nation's fifth-largest steelmaker, has run the association for the last two years.

title: BRITISH JOURNALISTS VOICE COMPLAINTS OVER BEING 'USED' BY THE GOVERNMENT
description: On Friday morning, the major British newspapers reported with surprising unanimity that the task force in the South Atlantic was planning ''hit-and-run raids'' on various parts of the Falkland Islands, rather than any full-scale invasion.

title: CHINA ATTACKS MAO MYSTIQUE IN A NEW PLAY
description: The late Chairman Mao Zedong, summoned back to life on a drab theatrical stage, soliloquizes about a revolutionary career that has cost the loss of six loved ones, including his second wife and eldest son, and wonders where it has taken him.

title: DEATH IS DIFFERENT
description: The New York State Legislature is debating the death penalty again, with prospects somewhat brighter than usual for overcoming Governor Carey's veto. But before the legislators act, they ought to study well the case of Timothy George Baldwin, who very nearly went to the electric chair this week in Louisiana - despite serious doubts that he had committed the murder charged to him.

title: OHIO CANDIDATE TELLS OF PAYING FOR PROSTITUTE
description: Jerry Springer, who is running for Governor of Ohio, is using a television advertisement in which he acknowledges that he once paid for the services of a prostitute.

title: PLAN GAINING FOR PAYING REALTY TAX TWICE A YEAR
description: Aides to Mayor Koch and City Council leaders reached tentative agreement yesterday on a bill to require many property owners to pay real estate taxes twice a year instead of quarterly. The measure would save the city $32 million to $44 million a year, depending on the terms of the final agreement, officials said.

title: Rome Airports Struck Briefly
description: Ground staff staged a four-hour work stoppage at Rome's two main airports today, only hours after air traffic controllers had ended their latest one-day strike. Today's stoppage, part of a campaign for better pay and working conditions, caused some delays at the airports at Ciampino and Fiumicino.

title: REPORTERS GIVE CLOSE-UP VIEW OF WAR
description: Two British reporters who witnessed the Argentine attack today at San Carlos Bay were Brian Hanrahan of the British Broadcasting Corporation, who was in a helicopter, and Michael Nicholson of Independent Television News, who was aboard a ship. Here are excerpts from their reports, which were subject to military censorship.

title: DOESN'T HOLD WATER
description: To the Editor:

title: IF PRIVATE CABLE TV HAS NO REGARD FOR PUBLIC INTEREST, CITIES DO
description: To the Editor:

title: Switching Sports
description: Wiley Brown, a 6-foot-8-inch senior who played forward for Louisville's basketball team, signed a two-year contract with the Philadelphia Eagles. Brown, who has not played football since high school, said he hoped to increase his weight to 240 pounds and be a tight end. Though he lost his right thumb in childhood, he made allstate in basketball and football as a high school senior in Georgia.

title: Plagiarism Penalty To Be Reviewed
description: A judge ordered a Princeton University committee today to review its recommendation for the discipline of a student accused of plagiarizing parts of a Spanish term paper.

title: Lendl Gains In France
description: Ivan Lendl took 1 hour 36 minutes today to get past the first round of the French Open tennis tournament, ousting Fernando Maynetto, a 26-year-old member of the Peruvian Davis Cup team, 6-0, 6-4, 6-1.

title: INSULATION LAWSUITS ABOUND
description: At the height of the energy crisis in 1977, Michael and Josephine Wagner spent $1,250 to put urea-formaldehyde foam insulation into their house in Toms River, N.J. Two weeks later Mr. Wagner collapsed and was taken to the hospital.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 9, Found Slain
description: A 9-year-old Brooklyn boy who had been missing since Saturday afternoon was found dead of head injuries yesterday morning, the police said. The boy, Paris Turner of Riverdale Avenue in the Brownsville section, was found at 9:15 A.M. in an abandoned building at 536 Junius Street, a short distance from the playground where he was last seen at 2 P.M. Saturday, according to Sgt. Tom Fahey, a police spokesman. The boy was reported to have left the playground at Riverdale and Van Sinderen Avenues with an unidentified man, Sergeant Fahey said.

title: ISUZU AGREES TO BUILD SUBCOMPACT FOR G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation has agreed with Isuzu Motors Ltd., one of its Japanese affiliates, for Isuzu to develop and produce a subcompact car that is expected to replace the current Chevrolet Chevette.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gordon (Scotty) Stirling, assistant to the president of the Golden State Warriors, was named to succeed Joe Axelson as the National Basketball Association's vice president for operations. Axleson is leaving the N.B.A. post to return to the Kansas City Kings as their president and general manager. ... A subcommittee of Florida State's Athletic Board endorsed the finding of a university investigative committee that cleared the basketball program of most charges of wrongdoing leveled by James Bozeman. The report now goes to the full board, which will make recommendations to the university president. ... Gerry Cooney, who will challenge Larry Holmes for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship June 11, sparred six rounds during two workout sessions in Las Vegas and said he felt ''very good.''

title: HOUSE, MAKING FIRST CHOICES, BARS 3 LIBERAL BUDGET PLANS
description: The House of Representatives, making its first choices on next year's budget, today rejected three liberal proposals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're either going to get better locks or dumber chimps.'' - Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis. (B5:4.)

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: without pay. This do-it-yourself approach results in about $1.5 million in annual payroll savings, not counting fringe benefits and pensions that would normally have to be paid to campus labor. As a result, annual tuition, room and board at this 125-year-old liberal arts college in central Illinois is currently a modest $4,200, less than half the going rate on comparable campuses.

title: Weed Control by Weevil
description: Half a century ago a handsome European wildflower, noted for its purple blossom, tall prickly stalk and nodding head, was imported into a Kansas garden. The musk thistle, or nodding thistle, Carduus nutans, soon won favor with gardeners who liked its powder-puff head and its musky scent, which seemed to repel dogs and other animals.

title: MOTIVATIONS TO LEARN; Urban Roundup
description: Many public school officials shrug off high rates of truancy as a problem beyond their control, or at least beyond their financial means. To Newark's Superintendent Columbus Sal-ley, however, the problem didn't seem impossible: young people are especially visible on the streets during school hours.

title: KREMLIN PROMOTES 2 OFFICIALS TO HIGH-LEVEL POSTS
description: The Communist Party's Central Committee today named Yuri V. Andropov, the 67-year-old head of the K.G.B., to an important new post on the party Secretariat that could widen his responsibilities and strengthen his position as a possible successor to the party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: FOR YOUNGSTERS AND STARS, DANCE INSTITUTE'S 4th GALA
description: Dancing policemen, twirling nuns, 800 delighted children and a sprinkling of celebrities filled the stage of the Felt Forum last night for the National Dance Institute's fourth annual benefit, called the Event of the Year.

title: BREZHNEV OFFERS PROGRAM TO INCREASE FOOD SUPPLY
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev today pledged a ''radical turn'' toward improved food supplies through a combination of powerful new regional structures and heavy infusions of money.

title: Afghan Ends East Berlin Trip
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan flew home today after a six-day visit to East Germany, the official East German press agency reported.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS O'NEILL ON PENSION ISSUE
description: President Reagan today accused Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, of practicing ''sheer political demagoguery'' in an effort to make Social Security an issue in the elections this fall.

title: Angels Sign Goltz
description: Dave Goltz, the right-handed pitcher who was cut recently by the Los Angeles Dodgers while they still owed him $1.7 million, has signed with the California Angels for the major league minimum salary of $33,500. Whatever Goltz earns with the Angels will be subtracted from the amount owed him by the Dodgers. ... Eddie Chiles, the principal owner of the Texas Rangers, locked Arlington Stadium and hired off-duty policemen yesterday for what he described as a showdown with Manager Don Zimmer, General Manager Eddie Robinson and Ranger players. The team is 11-25, and a spokesman said the owner wanted to find out why, without members of the media walking about.

title: Dr. William Dunham, Taught History at Yale
description: Dr. William H. Dunham Jr., George Burton Adams Professor Emeritus of History at Yale University, died last Thursday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: CARGO SHIP TO LINK UP WITH SALYUT 7
description: The cargo spaceship preparing to link up with the Soviet Union's Salyut 7 space platform is bringing food, fuel and mail to the two cosmonauts aboard, Tass, the Soviet news agency, said today.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER: 'SILENT SPRING': A TROUBLED LANDSCAPE
description: IT is 20 years since Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring'' first warned against the environmental and health damage caused by chemical pesticides. In the years since, her book has often been cited as perhaps the most influential single factor in creating public concern about the future of the world's ecology. It was Rachel Carson, many people agree, who initiated the modern environmental movement.

title: HINCKLEY'S IMAGE TRACED BY DOCTOR
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. still sees himself ''as an errant child who has done something bad, not terrible, not unspeakably awful,'' a defense psychiatrist testified today.

title: Key Rates
description: Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Economy
description: A pessimistic forecast was released by the nation's leading business economists. They look for only a weak recovery in the last half of 1982, with high unemployment and high interest rates. But they also expect inflation to remain in check, with price increases averaging under 6 percent this year and next. (Page D1.)

title: Oil Demand Down 7.5%
description: Oil demand in six key world markets dropped by 7.5 percent in the first quarter of this year as users saved more fuel and switched to other forms of energy, according to a leading industry newsletter.

title: 'IRACEMA,' VICTIM OF BRAZIL'S AMAZON POLICY
description: THE systematic devastation of the Amazon basin, on behalf of a kind of progress and development that could change the ecoloogy of the hemisphere, is the subject of the Public Theater's new program, ''Brazil Is My Home: The Films of Jorge Bodanzky and Wolf Gauer.''

title: E.P.A. Ordering Schools To Act on Asbestos Peril
description: All elementary and secondary schools in the country must be inspected for dangerous asbestos materials, the Environmental Protection Agency ruled today.

title: AGAINST ARMS AID FOR IRAQ
description: It would be a mistake to heed the advice of those in Arab capitals and in Washington who are urging that Iraq be given military support to prevent decisive Iranian successes in the Gulf war. Arab and Western leaders committed to regional stability should, rather, direct their efforts at securing a total Iraqi withdrawal from Iranian territory, thus ending to the fighting.

title: MUSIC: MAAZEL FAREWELL
description: LORIN MAAZEL conducted his final concert as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra Saturday night in Carnegie Hall, devoting the program to Verdi's Requiem, the work with which he and the orchestra greeted New York listeners at the start of his tenure in 1972. Paradoxically, perhaps, the moment of greatest feeling came after the performance was over - when the Paris-born conductor, who will become general manager and artistic director of the Vienna State Opera in September, at long last came out for a solo bow.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Telegraph Company said that it would apply for licenses to operate cellular mobile radio telephone systems in a number of major markets in a series of joint ventures with the FMI Financial Corporation and several privately owned radio common carriers. The company said that it would submit applications to the Federal Communications Commission by June 7, the deadline set for applications for the nation's top 30 markets.

title: G.P.U. Nuclear
description: G.P.U. Nuclear, a unit of the General Public Utilities Corporation, said it was temporarily closing its Oyster Creek nuclear generating station to repair a seal on a turbine component. It called the repair minor and said it expected to restart it later this week.

title: CONTRACTORS TRY TO STEER WARSHIP WORK INTO CITY
description: A consortium of New York defense contractors based at the former Brooklyn Navy Yard has submitted a bid for a $400 million contract to refit the World War II battleship U.S.S. Iowa.

title: BALLET: 'LE TOMBEAU'
description: ''LE TOMBEAU DE COUPERIN'' was a high point of the New York City Ballet's Ravel Festival in 1974. It is one of George Balanchine's prettiest ballets, catching the flowing, formal patterns and melodic warmth of the score in dance that is all luminous architectonic changes wrought on a shifting ensemble of 16 dancers and performed with smiles, quick, courteous tilts and bows and hands placed gently in partners' hands.

title: TV: 'COMMERCIALS,' A TIME MACHINE
description: IT had to happen. Commericals, those program interruptions that usually manage to irritate just about everybody, have been given a prime-time special of their own. ''Television's Greatest Commercials'' can be seen on NBC-TV tonight at 10 o'clock, and the hour is a startling reminder of how advertiser spots are an entrenched part of the television experience. After all, according to one statistic bandied about by the hosts, Ed McMahon and Tim Conway, the average viewer sees 50,000 commercials in a single year. That's a lot of impinging on the national consciousness.

title: SOLDIER WHO KILLED THREE BLACKS ORDERED TO SERVE AT LEAST 60 YEARS
description: Joseph Christopher was sentenced today to 60 years to life in prison for murdering two black men and a black youth during a 26-hour period in the fall of 1980.

title: MEXICO'S ECONOMY: NEED FOR SACRIFICE IS STRESSED
description: When Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog disclosed earlier this month that Mexico faced a period of zero economic growth, high inflation and a tumbling peso, the response in business circles, at least, was not all negative.

title: 'TRICKLE DOWN' AND AWAY
description: -President Reagan has justified the inequities of his economic-recovery program by claiming that they are necessary for the creation of wealth. But his proposals rest on faulty assumptions about how wealth is created.

title: FRIGATE LOST
description: Seven more Argentine warplanes were shot down during repeated sorties against British ships off the Falkland Islands today, the Ministry of Defense announced tonight. It was the third large Argentine attack in the last four days.

title: UNUSUAL PROJECT HELPS POOR BECOME HOMEOWNERS
description: For weeks now, Dorothy Jones has been sitting in the door of a condemned shack watching her new house go up across the street.

title: Valle's Plans Stock Shift
description: Valle's Steak House, the chain of family-style restaurants that has been negotiating to go private, said yesterday that it expected to sign an agreement this week to be acquired by a new corporation for about $17.5 million.

title: RULING RESTRICTS ACCESS TO F.B.I. DATA, EVEN IF PUT TO POLITICAL USE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government may shield from public disclosure information that it originally compiled for law-enforcement purposes, even if the information was later used for political purposes.

title: Advertising; Graduates Advised on Job Hunt
description: IT'S cap and gown time and college graduates, convinced by parents, professors and peers that they are wonderful writers, will be descending on New York to make their services available to the advertising agency business.

title: Joe Sawyer, 75, Created Role Of Sgt. O'Hara in 'Rin Tin Tin'
description: Joe Sawyer, who appeared in more than 300 films and was Sgt. Biff O'Hara in television's ''Rin Tin Tin'' series, died of liver cancer April 21 in Oregon. He was 75 years old.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt CHINA. Alive in the Bitter Sea. By Fox Butterfield. 468 pages. Illustrated. Times Books. $19.95.

title: RACHEL CARSON-A SCIENTIST WITH A POET'S VISION
description: SHE once told a friend that in the next life she wanted to be reincarnated as a tern, the swift and graceful bird that epitomized the wildlife and ocean shore she loved so well. And it was this concern for the world of nature that eventually led Rachel Carson to draft the often bitter landmark work, ''Silent Spring.''

title: GANDHI SIDE TAKING 3 OF 4 STATES
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's loyalists appeared today to have gained control of three of the four state legislatures elected last week, but they failed to win clear-cut majorities and declined in electoral popularity.

title: IRAN SAYS IT HAS RECAPTURED PORT AND TAKEN 30,000 IRAQI PRISONERS
description: Iran said today that its forces had recaptured Khurramshahr, the major Iranian port city that Iraqi troops took in October 1980. All 30,000 Iraqi troops there surrendered and their commander was killed, Iran said.

title: ERROR FOUND IN S.A.T. QUESTION
description: Mathematics scores are being recalculated for 300,000 students who took Scholastic Aptitude Tests around the nation on May 1 because three students proved there was a faulty answer, the College Board said yesterday.

title: DARKNESS OF SCHIZOPHRENIA BEGINS TO LIFT A LITTLE
description: WHAT is schizophrenia, anyway? The term has been bandied about in a flurry of labels and descriptions at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. as psychiatrists argue whether the young man was sane or insane at the time he shot President Reagan. Although the psychiatrist who briefly treated Mr. Hinckley before the shooting did not find him severely disturbed, expert witnesses for the defense now contend that Mr. Hinckley suffered from what is widely regarded as the most severe mental illness of all - schizophrenia.

title: National Medical
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc., a Los Angeles-based hospital management company, today announced that it had signed leases adding three medical facilities to its chain.

title: Conigliaro Improving
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox slugger who has been in a coma since he suffered a massive heart attack last January, has spoken his first coherent words since then, his mother said last night. Theresa Conigliaro said she had left her son's room at Shaughnessy Chronic Disease-Rehabilitation Hospital in Salem because nurses had arrived to give him respiratory treatment.

title: Gilman Services
description: Gilman Services Inc., a wholesale distributor of pharmaceuticals, which recently filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, announced that it closed its Rogers Wholesalers warehouse in New York on Friday.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: FROM the flyleaf with its motif of a top-hatted gent in evening capet o the last chapter where Conde Nast gazes at his Park Avenue p enthouse, the scene of his many famous parties, and wryly says, ''I u sed to own all this,'' ''The Man Who Was Vogue, the Life and Times o f Conde Nast,'' (Viking, $18.95) by Caroline Seebohm, describes in f ascinating detail how the man behind the famous name and pince-nez p ainstakingly constructed a magazine empire and lost it.

title: Contempt Hearing Put Off
description: A judge today postponed a hearing to determine whether radio station officials should be held in contempt of court for broadcasting taped evidence in the trial of a woman charged with trying to hire a killer to avenge the rape conviction of her son. Superior Court Judge Robert Bibb set the hearing for Wednesday. He is also considering a defense motion for a mistrial in the nonjury trial of Ruth Coe, the mother of Frederick Coe, the convicted rapist.

title: REAGAN MOVES ON MILITARY PRIORITIES
description: With the unpublicized signing of an eight-page national security memorandum one week ago, Ronald Reagan moved to exercise what White House officials say is more personal control over military and strategic planning than ever before in his Presidency.

title: The U.N. Today; May 25, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the Falkland Islands at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: News Analysis
description: It began as a miscalculation born of frustration. But once begun, there has been for Argentina no turning back in the Falkland Islands war.

title: A CLOWN: BILL IRWIN
description: in both senses of the word. As he tells us in his uproarious entertainment ''The Regard of Flight,'' at the American Place Theater, he does not do tricks. He does ''moves.'' Then he shows us a typical ''hat move.'' Placing his squashed cabbage of a derby upside down on the floor, he dives into it headfirst, and comes up standing with the hat so firmly in place that it is pulled down over his eyes and ears.

title: Sports of The Times; The Unjust Monkey
description: NOW the monkey can return to the Philadelphia Zoo, or wherever the monkey resides between its invisible excursions to the muscular shoulders of unjustly maligned athletes. The monkey always wears a collar, the kind that is known as a ''choker.'' And after the Philadelphia 76ers had advanced to the National Basketball Association championship playoff, Julius Erving addressed himself to the monkey.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF THE WAR BETWEEN IRAN AND IRAQ
description: Sept. 4, 1980 - Iraq says war starts with Iranian artillery attack on Iraqi border town of Khanaqin, 90 miles northeast of Baghdad. Sept. 17, 1980 - President Saddam Hussein of Iraq announces cancellation of a 1975 accord with Iran that he said gave Iran sovereignty over certain disputed areas along the Iraq-Iran border, including part of the Shatt al Arab. Sept. 22, 1980 - With an attack by Iraqi fighter-bombers on 10 Iranian airfields after weeks of border clashes, war between the two countries is considered to have begun. Sept. 24, 1980 - The war broadens as Iran and Iraq strike at each other's oil installations and Iraqi troops push into Iranian territory. Sept. 24, 1980 - President Carter pledges neutrality, stresses American support for international efforts to halt fighting and to arrange a negotiated settlement. Sept. 25, 1980 - Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie reports after a meeting with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union that the two Governments affirmed their neutrality in the war. Sept. 28, 1980 - The United Nations Security Council unanimously calls on Iran and Iraq to end their fighting and accept mediation of their dispute. Sept. 29, 1980 - President Hussein of Iraq tells the United Nations that his country would accept the Security Council's call for an end to hostilities and the start of mediation. Oct. 3 and 4, 1980 - In heavy fighting, Iraq and Iran struggle for control of the Iranian oil port of Khurramshahr. Oct. 8, 1980 - Iranian troops in Khurramshahr sink three foreign ships, registered in China, Panama and Dubai, as fighting continues in the oil port. Oct. 16, 1980 - Iraqi troops advance on the burning Iranian oil center of Abadan, shell the city and seize the radio center. Oct. 17 and 18, 1980 - Prime Minister Mohammed Rajai rules out a cease-fire in appearances before the Security council. Oct. 19, 1980 - Abadan is reported by Teheran radio to be surrounded and cut off from the rest of the country. Oct. 24, 1980 - Iraq announces its forces have taken complete control of Khurramshahr.

title: CONGRESSMEN ASK REAGAN TO PRESS FOR END TO MARTIAL LAW IN TAIWAN
description: Several members of Congress, citing President Reagan's condemnation of martial law in Poland, are asking the Administration to press Taiwan's military Government to end the 33 years of martial law there.

title: WILLIAM D. ARCHIBALD
description: William D. Archibald, the founder and chairman of the board of Archibald & Kendall Inc., a Manhattan company that imports and processes spices, died yesterday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains.

title: Arab Nations Urged To Deny U.S. Base Rights
description: Algeria's Foreign Minister urged Arab nations today to deny the United States use of their territory for basing of the Rapid Deployment Force.

title: Reinvested in Belmont
description: Harbor View Farm's Reinvested, the third-place finisher in the Kentucky Derby, will be entered in the 114th Belmont Stakes June 5 at a supplementary cost of $20,000, his trainer, Stanley Hough, said yesterday.

title: Mrs. von Bulow Mixed Drugs, Capote Asserts
description: Truman Capote, the author, has portrayed Martha von Bulow in a magazine interview as a user of drugs and alcohol. A lawyer said today that the statement could be used in a bid by her husband, Claus von Bulow, for a new trial.

title: New Tobacco Tax Advances in Jersey
description: The State Assembly voted 44 to 18 late today to raise the tax on a pack of cigarettes in New Jersey by 5 cents, to 24 cents.

title: Georgia Election Plans Barred Over Districting
description: A three-judge Federal panel today barred Georgia officials from proceeding with plans for Congressional elections this year under a redistricting proposal that the Justice Department said discriminated against blacks.

title: Electrical Workers Vote To End 205-Day Strike
description: Members of Local 610 of the United Electrical Workers voted today to end a 205-day strike against two American Standard plants and accept a three-year contract.

title: NO TIME YET TO NORMALIZE TIES WITH VIETNAM
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNNINGHAM ACCUSED AT TAX TRIAL OF DESTROYING EVIDENCE OF EVASION
description: The chief Federal prosecutor for Manhattan asserted yesterday that Patrick J. Cunningham, the former state Democratic chairman, had engaged ''in a massive scheme consisting of lies and the destruction of evidence'' to cover up income tax evasion.

title: Anacomp Plan
description: Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis-based computer services company, said that a divestiture plan, developed in connection with its tender offer for the DSI Corporation, had received Justice Department approval. Anacomp, which has offered to buy all of DSI's common stock outstanding at $6.25 a share in cash, or an estimated $21.9 million, said that it would begin purchasing DSI shares yesterday before its offer expired at 5 P.M. As of last Friday, Anacomp said it held 62 percent of DSI's stock.

title: FARLEY HAILED BY RENAMING OF POSTAL SITE
description: New York City's General Post Office was named yesterday after the late James A. Farley, a politician who took pride in running the United States mails like a business.

title: ARGENTINA SAYS ITS JETS DAMAGED A BRITISH TROOPSHIP AND A FRIGATE
description: Argentine jets struck today at British ground forces and naval units around their beachhead on the Falkland Islands, seriously damaging a troopship and hitting a frigate, the military command here reported.

title: Patrols Increased At Madison High
description: Extra police patrolled James Madison High School in Brooklyn yesterday as community, school and police officials met to discuss two recent assaults at the school.

title: MRS. THATCHER REJECTS POPE'S APPEAL FOR CEASE-FIRE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today rejected an appeal from Pope John Paul II for a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands and said Argentine troops must pull out first.

title: U.S. FACES LAWSUIT OVER SCHOOL FUNDS
description: New York and at least nine other states intend to file suit this week seeking to force the Department of Education to use 1980 census data in allocating funds for the teaching of poor children.

title: DR. H.C. SOLOMON DIES AT AGE OF 92
description: Dr. Harry C. Solomon, a pioneer in the development of techniques for psychiatric treatment, died Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 92 years old.

title: EDUCATION
description: MORE than a century ago, the great American jurist Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. wrote that ''the life of the law has not been logic: it has been experience.'' But while America's elite law schools salute Holmes as a giant of the bar, they have been reluctant to apply his dictum to the study of law itself.

title: Chess: Soviet Union's Belyavsky Wins Tourney in Sarajevo
description: Aleksandar Belyavsky, 29-year-old co-champion of the Soviet Union, won the traditional Sarajevo International Tournament with a heavy 12 1/2-2 1/2 score. And he needed it, because the Yugoslav grandmaster Vlado Kovacevic pressed him all the way, finishing with 12-3 to take second place.

title: MILWAUKEE RAILROAD SALE ASKED
description: The trustee for the Milwaukee Road told a Federal judge in Chicago yesterday that he had signed a letter of intent to sell the railroad to the Grand Trunk Corporation.

title: Required Reading;  Position Changed
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, changing his position on televising Senate proceedings, the Congressional Record, May 21, 1982:

title: ECONOMICS OF LIFE AND DEATH ARISES IN DEBATE OVER KIDNEY THERAPY
description: No one at his office could tell, but by the end of the afternoon Ben Schoen's vision was beginning to blur just a little and he was feeling slightly tired. His body was signaling him that it needed help. Over the weekend he had eaten a steak, which had dumped large amounts of urea, creatinine and other potentially lethal waste products into his blood; fluid was building in his body. At 5:30, he put down his papers at the Justice Department, where he works as a lawyer, and hopped into his new rust-colored Toyota Supra.

title: BILL REQUIRING DEPOSIT OF 5 CENTS ON BOTTLES PASSES ASSEMBLY
description: For the first time in more than a decade of efforts, the Assembly tonight passed a bill to require a 5-cent deposit on bottles and cans of beer and soda sold in New York State.

title: ENERGY DEPT'S END PROPOSED
description: The Reagan Administration, bowing to pressure from Congress, sent legislators a modified proposal to accomplish its long-sought aim of dissolving the five-year-old Department of Energy.

title: MUSKIE CALLS FOR A U.S. RESOLUTION VOWING TO ABIDE BY '79 ARMS PACT
description: Former Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie has suggested that Congress pass, and President Reagan sign, a joint resolution by which the United States would promise to abide by the unratified strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979 so long as the Soviet Union does.

title: 2 CHIMPS GET BRIEF TASTE OF FREEDOM
description: Two chimpanzees escaped from their cages in the Central Park Zoo yesterday, sending zookeepers and police officers scrambling after them and for a time leaving in doubt just who were the pursuers and who were the pursued.

title: 3 Climbers Killed in Nepal
description: Two Spanish climbers and a West German photographer were killed in separate avalanches this month while mountain climbing, the Ministry of Tourism said today.

title: SCHWEIKER SEEKING TO LOOSEN NURSING HOME RULES
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed dropping a requirement for annual inspection of the nation's nursing homes and replacing it with a flexible policy based on past compliance with health and safety rules.

title: Blast Kills Two in Barcelona
description: An explosion, said by the police to have been caused by a leftover bomb from the Spanish Civil War, rocked a factory here today, killing two workers and seriously wounding two. The police said the explosion occurred in the building's basement, where the bomb had apparently been stored during the 1936-39 conflict.

title: Rations for Marines Provide Varied Menu
description: Among the 60 pounds of gear that each of the British marines on the Falklands carried ashore are what they call ''ratpacks'' - their rations.

title: TIME AND HARD TIMES ALTER BLUE-COLLAR BLUES
description: Ten years ago, Lordstown was the most explosive story in American industry, the symbol of a new kind of worker - young, militant, balking at authority, unwilling to put up with repetitive, tedious work.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON PATENT DAMAGES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide how damages should be computed in cases of patent infringement. The Justices agreed to hear an appeal by the General Motors Corporation, which was ordered by a Federal court to pay the Devex Corporation $19.8 million for infringing a patent on a method of manufacturing metal bumpers.

title: Police Look for Woman To Ask About Hilton Fire
description: The police said today that they were searching for a woman they described as a prostitute to question her about the fire at the Conrad Hilton Hotel that killed four guests and injured 24.

title: Trees Cloned By Rayonier
description: ITT Rayonier, the forest products unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday that its researchers had successfully cloned, or replicated, slash pine trees from tissue cultures.

title: CARLTON DEFEATS REDS, SEAVER
description: Steve Carlton tossed a four-hitter for eight innings and had a pair of singles tonight in leading the Philadelphia Phillies to a 9-1 rout over Tom Seaver and Cincinnati. The loss was the Reds' sixth in a row.

title: HOYT'S UNBEATEN STREAK AT 14
description: Lamarr Hoyt earned his ninth straight triumph tonight as the Chicago White Sox beat the Kansas City Royals, 3-1.

title: REAGAN'S RESPONSE TO BUDGET PLAN
description: President Reagan, responding to a proposal by six former top economic officials for deep spending cuts and large tax increases, said today that he was in ''general agreement'' on the need to reduce Government spending.

title: BRIEFING
description: Honoring Dr. Hammer

title: POLAND'S WEAK CASE AGAINST SCIENTIST
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER ROW PROJECT FINISHED WITH FLOURISH
description: Forty-second Street's $9 million Theater Row officially became a completed reality yesterday. The south side of the blocks between 9th and 10th Avenues has been recreated during six years from a massage parlor, burlesque house and derelict tenements into small theaters, restaurants, recording studios and other businesses.

title: TREASURY MARKET RULES CALLED ADEQUATE BY U.S.
description: Officials of the Treasury Department and the New York Federal Reserve Bank told a Senate securities subcommittee today that broad regulation of the market in Government securities was unnecessary despite last week's collapse of Drysdale Government Securities Inc.

title: TRADERS IGNORE PRIME RATE
description: The credit markets remained stalled yesterday, ignoring Citibank's reduction of the prime rate as well as an easing of the pivotal Federal funds rate. The market's malaise, dealers said, sharply cut trading activity.

title: Woman Gets Suspended Term For Aiding in Sister's Suicide
description: A 72-year-old woman pleaded no contest today to voluntary manslaughter in the death of her ailing sister, who begged for her assistance in committing suicide, and a judge gave her a six-year suspended sentence.

title: Truckers' Group Ends Strike
description: A group of independent truckers who said they were leading a strike to protest deregulation of the industry has decided to end its three-week walkout. James Herald, a spokesman for the group, said after a meeting Monday that the truckers had decided to regroup. The truckers, who are seeking reregulation of the trucking industry and a fuel surcharge, voted Friday, 41 to 36, to continue the strike but conceded that support was eroding, Mr. Herald said.

title: President Expands Grand Trunk Lines
description: John H. Burdakin, president of the Grand Trunk Corporation, once ran the 46-mile Panama Canal railroad. He is now leader of a 2,100-mile rail system, but that is still not big enough for him.

title: CAREY PROPOSES HEALTH FACILITIES AS STATE PRISONS
description: Governor Carey announced today that three state mental health facilities and a portion of a fourth would be converted into medium-security prisons.

title: THE WAR OF SUPPLIES
description: When we think of war, we think most of the tanks, ships, aircraft and other weapons that each side has, and we talk most about the strategies that the commanders will use as they move their weapons about. As often as not, though, wars are won or lost on the question of supplies.

title: Wrong Fight for the N.A.A.C.P.
description: In its time, the venerable National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has produced great leaders like W.E.B. Dubois, Walter White and Roy Wilkins. It justly takes credit for ending lynchings and winning the vote for black Americans in the South. It played a major role in ending overt segregation all over America.

title: Garrett Runs Again
description: Mike Garrett, who won a Heisman Trophy at Southern California before starring as a running back in the pros, is waging a write-in campaign in San Diego for the Republican nomination to Congress in California's 44th District. His move, with two weeks to go and $20,000 to spend, was termed ''insulting to the voters'' by his rival in the primary, Shirley Gissendanner.

title: A SHIP'S LOSS IS WITNESSED AT BEACHHEAD
description: Brian Hanrahan, a correspondent for the British Broadcasting Corporation, watched the frigate Antelope sink on Monday. Here is his report, which was passed by military censors:

title: Embarrassing Questions; Shelter Storm
description: President Reagan defends the tax shelter dealings of his friend, Attorney General William French Smith, by driving home a point that no one contests. He points out that tax shelters ''are things passed by Congress to encourage investment of speculation in certain undertakings.''

title: Rebel Bombs Black Out 3 Salvador Provinces
description: Leftist guerrillas blacked out three provinces today in sporadic attacks across northern and eastern El Salvador, military officials said.

title: Rod Stewart, Citing Violence, to Return to Britain
description: Several years after he moved from Britain to California to avoid high British taxes, the rock singer Rod Stewart says he is moving back to his native land to get away from violence in the United States.

title: Steinbrenner Drops Rockies
description: George Steinbrenner has apparently withdrawn from talks to buy the Colorado Rockies. ''He's not doing anything with us now,'' a spokesman for Peter Gilbert, the Rockies' owner, said last night.

title: Brentano's Meeting Set
description: Brentano's Inc., the chain of 28 bookstores that filed for protection from creditors under the Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act last Friday, will meet with its creditors tomorrow to discuss plans for a reorganization, according to the company.

title: BIRTH RATE HIGHEST FOR LATINS IN U.S.
description: Hispanic people, the nation's fastestgrowing minority, have a birth rate 75 percent higher than the rest of the population, and Hispanic mothers are younger and less educated, according to a Government report made public this week.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE is no question in any serious cook's mind that we feast with our eyes as well as our palates and that the presentation of a dish adds a good deal to its appeal.

title: JUDGE ASKS MORE DATA IN BELL PLAN
description: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene today ordered the various parties to the proposed antitrust settlement between the Justice Department and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to file new, clarifying comments on the plan and prepare for a public hearing at the end of June.

title: WITNESS SAYS HINCKLEY TRAILED ACTRESS WITH GUN
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. once followed Jodie Foster around with a pistol and still likes to think that he has ''altered her life forever,'' a defense psychiatrist testified today.

title: 3 From British Copter Found in Chile's South
description: Three crewmen from a British Sea King helicopter were found today in good condition a week after their craft made a forced landing in southern Chile while on a scouting mission for the British fleet, the Chilean Foreign Ministry announced.

title: RIDERS' WAIT FOR L.I.R.R. IS 'DRY' NOW
description: Commuters who use the Long Island Rail Road will no longer be able to get drinks while waiting on the platforms for trains at Pennsylvania Station, Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn and Jamaica, Queens.

title: IN SOUTHERN AFRICA, DROUGHT TURNS DREAMS INTO DUST
description: Christopher Simon cast a short line on a stunted pole into the waters of Lake Kariba, trying to catch ''very small fish'' to eat. At his side lay a crude catapult, designed to fire stones at small birds, also for the pot. He was, he said, a hungry man.

title: License Is Sought For Mobile Phone
description: Telephone and Data Systems Inc., a Chicago-based telephone holding company with interests in cable television, radio paging and other communications operations, announced that it planned to file for a license as a wireline common carrier for a cellular mobile radio telephone in June.

title: Top Schlitz Management To Get Cash
description: Employee stock options will be translated into hefty cash payments for top officers of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company if its acquisition by the Stroh Brewery Company goes through without a hitch.

title: BRAVES VANQUISH METS, 10-2
description: The Mets' team that was trounced by Atlanta, 10-2, tonight looked more like the Mets teams Joe Torre used to manage in the nearly five years he ran the club.

title: Economic Scene; How Germans Handle Rates
description: FRANKFURT BUSINESS in West Germany is still weak, but the country's central bank, the Bundesbank, is taking steps to promote recovery by pushing down interest rates.

title: Jacob's Pillow Festival To Celebrate 50th Year
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival will celebrate its 50th anniversary from June 29 to Sept. 5 in Lee, Mass. Performing will be soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet, June 29-July 3; the Paul Taylor Dance Company, July 6-10; New Directions From Japan, July 13-15; New Directions From England: Second Stride, July 16-17; les Grands Ballets Canadiens, July 20-24; Winning Ballroom Teams, July 27-31; Pillow Parade, Vanaver Caravan, Jacob's Pillow Dancers, Martha Partridge and Douglas Nielsen and Cynthia Gregory and Richard Cragun, Aug. 3-7; Elisa Monte and Dancers, Aug. 10-14; Metropolitan Opera Ballet, Aug. 17-21; Clive Thompson Dancecompany, Aug. 24-28, and the Maria Benitez Estampa Flamenca, Sept. 2-5.

title: ISRAEL SAYS IT DOWNED 2 SYRIAN MIG's
description: Israeli jet fighters shot down two Syrian MIG's over Lebanon today after a dogfight erupted during an Israeli reconnaissance mission, the military command announced.

title: REGAN SAYS FARE NEEDN'T INCREASE MORE THAN 15
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has ''overstated'' its deficit projections for New York City's transit system and can balance its budget with a fare increase of no more than 15 cents, the State Comptroller said yesterday.

title: Gas Is Discovered At Louisiana Field
description: The Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation, a subsidiary of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, announced that it had discovered a deep gascondensate reservoir in the North Maurice Field in Lafayette Parish, La.

title: Italian Communists Still at Odds With French
description: The leaders of the Italian and the French Communist Parties, the two largest Communist movements in Western Europe, ended their first talks in two years with a statement that showed that differences, mainly over Soviet policies, remain as deep as ever.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES DEMOCRATS' STAND
description: President Reagan brought his fight with Congressional Democrats to California tonight, accusing them of being ''proponents of negativism, the advocates of 'no.' ''

title: U.S. SEEKS CONSENSUS ON ECONOMIC CURBS ON SOVIET
description: Ten days before the economic meeting of the major industrial nations at Versailles, the Reagan Administration remains unable to win agreement from other participants on several of its proposals for discussion, including a curb on credits to the Soviet Union.

title: ROCK: SEBASTIAN AND NRBQ
description: UNEXPECTEDLY bright rock-and-roll sparks flew Sunday at the Bottom Line, where the folk-pop singer and songwriter John Sebastian shared the bill with the East Coast cult band NRBQ. An affably unpretentious entertainer, Mr. Sebastian has never sounded better.

title: SCALLOP SHELLS AS DISHES
description: WHEN I worked at a Paris restaurant over 30 years ago, a large bag of freshly caught scallops in their shells arrived almost every morning.

title: Salvador's Aid Rides on Reform
description: Does the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have the courage of its chairman's convictions? Charles Percy said last week that if El Salvador retreated from its land reform commitments, then under American law ''not one cent'' more in aid could go to its Government. As he spoke, the reform program was effectively gutted by El Salvador's resurgent right, whose leader, Roberto D'Aubuisson, plainly assumes that America's word and backbone are made of rubber.

title: 'AC/DC,' BAND IN A FILMED CONCERT
description: ''AC/DC: LET THERE BE ROCK,'' which opened a one-week engagement last Friday at the Ziegfeld Theater, is a dull, cheaply made concert film that should appeal only to diehard fans of the hugely popular Australian rock quintet.

title: Excerpts from speeches, page A16.
description: Argentina repeatedly called today for a negotiated peace in the Falkland Islands with the help of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: DIVERSION OF AMBULANCE CITED IN PATIENT'S DEATH
description: A New York City legislator reported yesterday that an ambulance carrying an 89-year-old woman who was suffering from a heart attack had been turned away from Flushing Hospital and Medical Center in Queens because the hospital's emergency room was closed to cardiac cases.

title: North Sea Well
description: -The British National Oil Corporation said today that as operator it had completed a successful North Sea oil well. The well flowed at a stabilised rate of 5,100 barrels daily with no water through a one-inch choke.

title: Michael Carey Is Exonerated Of Charge of Drunken Driving
description: A drunken-driving charge against Michael Carey, the 28-year-old son of Governor Carey, was dismissed by a judge here today.

title: Linkage to Be Entered In the Belmont Stakes
description: BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) Linkage, the beaten favorite in the Preakness here a week and a half ago, is headed for the Belmont Stakes after all, his owner said today.

title: 'GREGORY'S GIRL,' COMEDY OF TEEN-AGERS
description: A LOT of movies are easy to resist, including those in which a major character is dying of cancer, two or more characters are beheaded on screen or when the entire plot depends on someone's not going to the police in the second scene. Extremely rare is the movie that is irresistible. Offhand, I can think of only two kinds, one being any Billy Wilder film co-starring Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau.

title: TRACY AUSTIN FACING TEST IN COMEBACK
description: After five appearances at Wimbledon and two United States Open championships, Tracy Austin has finally entered the French Open.

title: Colorado Supreme Court Upholds School Tax Plan
description: The Colorado Supreme Court on Monday upheld the state's system of financing public schools despite complaints that some districts could afford field trips to Paris while others could not afford to fix the roof.

title: BALLET THEATER: ANASTOS PRESENTS 'CLAIR DE LUNE'
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER offered the world premiere of Peter Anastos's ''Clair de Lune'' Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the occasion afforded opportunities for reflection on what is surely an unusual choreographic career.

title: U.N. Gets Antinuclear Plea
description: A petition calling for abolition of nuclear weapons signed by 500,000 people, most of them Japanese, was delivered to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cullar today by a group of Roman Catholic bishops from Japan.

title: Japan Lifting Fruit Fly Bans On Two Counties in California
description: Japan lifted its restrictions on fruit and vegetables from two California counties today, ending restrictions imposed last year because of infestations of the Mediterranean fruit fly.

title: News Analysis
description: For more than a decade, the New York State Assembly has pondered the merits of bills to require a deposit on beer and soda bottles and cans sold in the state.

title: PITFALLS IN LEGISLATION TO MODERNIZE AMERICAN IMMIGRATION LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: JOAN MILLER
description: JOAN MILLER'S DANCE PLAYERS celebrated their 11th birthday with a benefit gala Sunday afternoon at Martin Luther King Jr. High School. A good combo provided live music and Miss Miller's troupe was augmented by several guest dancers: John Parks, Dyane Harvey, Loretta Abbott and Al Perryman. Like most galas, this one featured brief pieces in varied styles and of varied quality, but all designed to show off guests and company alike.

title: Teachers' Survey Finds Discontent on Increase
description: A new survey finds discontent growing among public school teachers, with less than half of them certain they would enter the profession if they had it to do over.

title: CONCERT: 36 CELLISTS AT VIOLONCELLO SOCIETY BRITHDAY BENEFIT
description: FOR its 25th anniversary, the Violoncello Society invited three dozen cellists to the 92d Street Y Sunday for a benefit concert featuring works for multiple-cello ensembles. After playing host to that many end pins, the floor of the new acoustic shell at the Y may never be the same again.

title: The Situation in the Falklands
description: FIGHTING

title: A TAME TRIP TO THE 'VILLAGE'
description: The forbidden was glimpsed, and it was disappointing. That was the opinion of some of the 43 students from West Springfield, Mass., who toured part of Greenwich Village yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. You recently wrote about artichokes, which have long been one of my favorite vegetables. I am on a low-sodium diet and have been told that artichokes have a high sodium content. Is this true?

title: OFFER BY POPE TO VISIT ARGENTINA IS REPORTED
description: Pope John Paul II has offered to come directly to Argentina from his British visit, the Vatican's representative here said late tonight. The visit to Britain is now definitely set to begin on Friday.

title: RACISM IN THE U.S. FOCUS ON ARMS
description: To the Editor:
