title: LIFE IN HOMER, GA.: SIGNS OF PROGRESS AMID PASTORAL SERENITY
description: Most local folks assume that Homer was named for ''the blind Greek,'' as George Hill, who is 76 years old and a courthouse fixture, referred to the author of the Iliad. Considering what there is to see here, he allowed as how that was not a bad choice of names.

title: CONNORS 'FLUTTERS' BUT WINS
description: Jimmy Connors beat Bruce Manson, 6-3, 6-3, 6-1, today, and said afterward that the ankle injury that forced him to withdraw from a tournament in Hamburg, West Germany, earlier this month had given him no trouble in his first-round match at the $917,000 French Open.

title: Oil Merger Is Set
description: The Texas International Company, an Oklahoma City-based gas and oil exploration company, said it had agreed to acquire the 48.5 percent of the Phoenix Resources Company's common shares that it did not already own for a total of about $74 million. A Texas International official said the company would exchange 1.1 of its shares for each of the remaining 5.33 million shares of Phoenix, following the approval of both boards of directors. Texas International has controlled 51.5 percent of Phoenix Resources, an oil and gas company, since 1978. Yesterday, Texas International's stock closed on the New York Stock exchange at 13 7/8, down 1/4, after reaching a high of 14 3/8 earlier in the day.

title: Santa Fe Venture
description: Santa Fe Industries said today that its Santa Fe Energy Company subsidiary had entered into a joint venture exploration agreement with the Belco Petroleum Corporation and Berexco Inc. Santa Fe, acting as operator, will evaluate a portion of the Springer Trend in the eastern Anadarko Basin in central Oklahoma. Ten wells are being drilled.

title: Council Approves Realty Tax Plan
description: The City Council approved a bill yesterday requiring real estate tax payments twice a year, instead of quarterly on all commercial and residential property with an assessed valuation of more than $30,000.

title: LEAGUE MAY ENTER WINFIELD DISPUTE
description: George Steinbrenner, the defendant in a Federal suit filed yesterday on behalf of the David M. Winfield Foundation, could face a problem with baseball officials as a result of his agreement with the foundation.

title: ADMINISTRATION SEEKS INCREASE IN THE CEILING ON THE FEDERAL BUDGET
description: Worried about an impasse in Congress that could delay some Federal payments, the Reagan Administration asked Congress today to act within a month to raise the ceiling on the Federal debt.

title: PALMER RECORDS 250th VICTORY
description: Jim Palmer, starting his first game in almost three weeks, got his 250th career victory as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Texas Rangers, 10-3, tonight.

title: News Analysis
description: Britain appeared to win a victory Monday in Brussels when seven of its nine Common Market partners agreed to extend indefinitely the sanctions imposed against Argentina in retaliation for its invasion of the Falkland Islands. But the victory may be expensive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The application of the right of self-determination to the case of the Malvinas Islands is a simple travesty.

title: F.D.A. Won't Bar Sales of Lilly Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration said it had withdrawn a proposal to ban sales of Ilosone, an antibiotic that has been marketed by Eli Lilly & Company since the 1950's. A study in 1973 had linked the drug, sold generically under the name erythomycin estolate, to a higher incidence of liver cancer.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SUIT PUTS RIVALRY IN OPEN
description: Tensions that have been building for years burst into the open today with the filing of a lawsuit by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People against the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc.

title: EAST EUROPE'S BURDEN OF DEBT
description: While Poland and Rumania have borne the brunt of the problem thus far, Eastern Europe's huge $60 billion debt to the West is putting strains on almost every member of the Communist bloc.

title: MURIEL SIEBERT JOINS G.O.P. RACE FOR U.S. SENATOR
description: Muriel Siebert, who resigned Tuesday as New York State's Superintendent of Banks, yesterday announced her candidacy for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate. She cited her background of state service and 22 years of work on Wall Street.

title: POLICE MOVE SITE OF JUNE 12 RALLY BACK TO THE PARK
description: The site of the disarmament rally on June 12, which had been moved to First Avenue and 42d Street, has been moved back to the Great Lawn in Central Park, the Police Commissioner said yesterday.

title: OUT OF THE BUDGET BATTLE, A SENSE OF BIPARTISANSHIP
description: After a period of intense party rivalry on Capitol Hill, a new sense of bipartisanship has begun to seep through the House of Representatives. The main flowering of this spirit is an alternative budget proposal, drafted by moderates from both parties and aimed at ''the broad sweep in the middle'' of Congress, as one lawmaker put it.

title: ABC Debentures
description: The American Broadcasting Companies, based in New York, said yesterday that it planned to buy back $18.03 million principal amount of its 9.35 percent sinking fund debentures for $6.2 million in cash plus 200,000 shares of common stock. The debentures, held by Morgan Stanley & Company, are due July 15, 2000. ABC said the exchange would increase second-quarter net income by $4.6 million, or 16 cents a share.

title: Japanese-U.S.  Antitrust Case
description: A Japanese buyer of American wood chips is subject to United States antitrust laws, a Federal District Court judge ruled Monday in San Francisco.

title: CABARET: SHERYL LEE RALPH OF 'DREAMGIRLS'
description: IN the hit Broadway musical ''Dreamgirls'' Sheryl Lee Ralph plays Deena Jones, the lead singer of a pop-soul trio called the Dreams, whose sound and demeanor strongly recall Diana Ross and the Supremes. Throughout the show, the vocal resemblance between Miss Ralph and Miss Ross is so striking as to be at times uncanny.

title: Petro-Lewis Buys Oil Sites
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said it had completed the acquisition of certain oil and gas properties from Clayton W. Williams Jr. and a private partnership for $109 million, effective May 1.

title: 3 WOMEN AND THE CAMPAIGN FOR A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Helen M. Caldicott became terrified by the prospect of nuclear holocaust as she sat by the sea in Australia as as 14-year-old and read ''On the Beach,'' a novel about the aftermath of nuclear war.

title: COMPROMISE EFFORTS FAIL ON SUBSIDY FOR HOUSING
description: Congress and the White House seemed today to be headed for a confrontation over a plan to rescue the hard-pressed housing industry with a $5 billion program to subsidize mortgage rates for home buyers over the next five years.

title: THEATER: 'MONDAY AFTER THE MIRACLE'
description: up to ''The Miracle Worker'' is too rarely as powerful as it promises to be.

title: Koreans Perform Their National Classics
description: Westerners have become uncomfortable with any synthesis of the arts, preferring instead to segregate their music, art and dance into relatively private worlds. Korea's performing tradition, as seen and heard at the Asia Society Monday evening, was quite another story - the sense of sound, of gesture and of color all interlocked into a single experience.

title: Dobbs Ferry to Wagga Wagga - or Bust
description: It was Balloon Day on April 19 at Springhurst Elementary School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and among the fifth-graders sending helium-filled balloons aloft, with stamped and self-addressed envelopes attached, was Justin Fiore.

title: Arrest in Woods Case
description: A 17-year-old suspect was arrested today in the shooting last Friday of Mike Woods, a Baltimore Colts linebacker, who is paralyzed from the neck down. The police said witnesses picked the suspect's picture out of mug files.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chase Manhattan Corp. said it had entered into a revised underwriting agreement that reduced the value and quantity of a new issue of floating rate series E perpetual preferred stock to 4 million shares, valued at $200 million, down from a previously announced 5 million shares, valued at $250 million.

title: UNIONIST FILLS JOB WITH ZEST
description: Doris Turner breezed into her office at District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees the other day, flashing smiles and offering cheery greetings to clerical workers on the floor.

title: U.S. COURT STALLS GEORGIA ELECTIONS
description: Georgia's Attorney General Michael J. Bowers, joined by Gov. George D. Busbee and other state officials, today asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to block a lower court order prohibiting the state from going forward with plans for elections to fill its 10 Congressional seats.

title: Valle Family Members To Become Consultants
description: Valle's Steak House began in 1933 as a seven-stool cafe in Portland, Me., and under the founder, Donald D. Valle, grew to be a 30-restaurant chain. Arthur W. Hanson became manager in 1959 of a Valle's steak house in Kittery, Me. Now, as president of the company, he will soon see the last Valle family member leave active management.

title: 4 KENTUCKY INCUMBENTS WIN
description: Former Gov. Bill Clinton, seeking the Democratic nomination for a rematch with Gov. Frank D. White, finished well ahead of the field in the Arkansas primary yesterday, but failed to win a majority and was forced into a June 8 runoff.

title: STATES' BILL OF RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIBANK'S PRIME RATE CUT TO 16%
description: Amid generally declining interest rates, Citibank, the nation's second-largest bank, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent.

title: RETROSPECTIVE
description: On the fourth floor of the American Museum of Natural History, 77th Street and Central Park West, are the Halls of the Early and Late Dinosaurs, the showcase of the museum's collection, the world's largest, of these ancient creatures that once ruled the global roost.

title: Caesars World Income Slides
description: Caesars World Inc., the big hotel casino company, announced that its net income for the April 30 quarter plunged 67.6 percent, to $1.2 million, or 6 cents a share, from $3.7 million, or 14 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Revenues rose two-tenths of 1 percent, to $140 million, from $139.7 million the year before.

title: 23 Killed in Philippine Clash
description: Communist rebels ambushed a convoy of trucks carrying Government troops and civilians, setting off a fierce gun battle in which 9 soldiers, 4 civilians and 10 guerrillas were killed, a military report said today.

title: Mexican Aide Asserts Corona Admitted Killings
description: A Mexican consulate official told a jury today that Juan V. Corona once confessed to him that he hacked to death 25 migrant farm workers whose bodies were dug up 11 years ago this month in what was then the worst mass-murder in the nation's history.

title: Crack on Bridge Halts Train Service
description: All B, D and QB train service over the Manhattan Bridge to and from Brooklyn was suspended yesterday just before the evening rush hour after a crack was discovered in a beam over the tracks on the bridge's northern edge.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL REJECTS NLT OFFER
description: Directors of the American General Corporation unanimously rejected a recent tender offer from the NLT Corporation at a special board meeting yesterday, charging that it was an attempt to thwart an earlier takeover bid for NLT by American General.

title: The U.N. Today; May 26, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: City Marathon Taking Entry Requests June 3
description: Entry-form requests for the New York Marathon in October will be accepted starting June 3, the New York Road Runners Club, which organizes the race, said yesterday.

title: Trial Ends for Woman Charged in Revenge Case
description: Final arguments ended today in the trial of a mother accused of seeking revenge for her son by trying to hire a killer for the men who sent him to prison.

title: SUNSET, STAR RISE
description: The Republicans have hired two actors to impersonate former President Carter and Speaker Tip O'Neill in a television commercial. This is the newest development in the politicians' eternal quest for ways to fool all of the people all of the time.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT is the most remarkable graffito in the metropolitan area, and now it can be reported that its mission has been accomplished. We refer of course to the block-letter message ENTROPY, painted in black on an outcrop of diabase jutting over the southbound lanes of the Palisades Parkway.

title: MODEL OF A VIKING SHIP TO FULFILL OLD FANTASIES
description: ''It's a simple story,'' Dr. Lynn Halmrast said. ''It's the fulfillment of a fantasy, a Walt Disney production coming to real life. It strikes a lot of chords.''

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The graduates come forth from law schools this month, confident in the knowledge of contracts and civil procedure, and among them is Jacob Landers. His resume will flutter onto desks at law firms, in the company of hundreds of others, neat and black and white.

title: TURNING THE TABLES, SORT OF, ON A CRITIC
description: IN most families a special occasion calls for a celebration in a restaurant. But in the family of a restaurant critic that is hardly the case, for the very nature of a celebration, it seems, is that it be marked by something out of the ordinary.

title: Questor to Merge
description: The Questor Corporation said its board had approved an offer by Q Associates to buy Questor for $14.25 a share, subject to shareholder and court approval.

title: CON ED COAL CONVERSION PLAN DEBATED
description: June Jackson said her asthma medication had to be doubled after the Consolidated Edison Company began burning 1.5 percent sulfur oil - instead of 0.3 percent - in a test at its Ravenswood 3 electric generator in Queens. She represented the Long Island City Inter-Block Association.

title: Comissiona Conducts 'Meistersinger' Prelude
description: In his farewell concert as music adviser to the American Symphony Orchestra Sunday, Sergiu Comissiona conducted Wagner's Prelude to Act I of ''Die Meistersinger'' and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4, but made sure to include - lest the parting be too pleasant, one is tempted to think -William Schuman's Concerto for Violin and Orchestra in its 1959 revision. The soloist in the Schuman was Ruben Gonzalez, the concertmaster of one of Mr. Comissiona's other orchestras, the Houston Symphony.

title: This Time, Climber Is Getting Permission
description: A follow-up: Daniel D. Goodwin, the ubiquitous ''human fly'' who just cannot seem to get enough of climbing buildings, plans to scale another one June 2, but this time with permission.

title: TV: A PAIR OF MOVIES, MYSTERY, FAMILY DRAMA
description: TWO new television movies are on tap this evening at 9 o'clock. ''Rehearsal for Murder,'' on CBS-TV, is a classy mystery drama starring Robert Preston and Lynn Redgrave. ''In the Custody of Strangers,'' on ABC-TV, is a heated family-ordeal drama starring Martin Sheen, Jane Alexander and Mr. Sheen's son, Emilio Estevez.

title: JOSEPH G. MUNZ
description: Joseph G. Munz, former chairman of the board and trustee emeritus of the Hamburg Savings Bank, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Olympic Athletes to Get $4 Million in I.O.C. Aid
description: The International Olympic Committee plans to spend as much as $4 million to help athletes get to Los Angeles for the 1984 Games.

title: Bank Merger Proposals Set
description: The North Carolina National Bank, with $7.8 billion in assets, said yesterday that it had proposed a merger with the Caburrus Bank and Trust Company, a Concord-based bank with $116 million in assets. It would exchange 1.1 million shares of North Carolina National for the 4,000 common shares of Caburrus, which is 43 percent owned by a trust belonging to Charles Cannon, founder of Cannon Mills.

title: Venezuelan Cabinet Shuffled
description: President Luis Herrera Campins of Venezuela, in his second Cabinet reorganization in two months, replaced three ministers Monday night. He swore in Felipe Montilla as the new Education Minister, Guido Diaz Pena as Minister of Information and Tourism and Guillermo Yepez Boscan as Youth Minister.

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 26, 1982; The Economy
description: Citibank lowered its prime lending rate to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent. The move came amid generally declining interest rates and reflected the bank's confidence that the easing would continue. It was the first reduction in the prime rate by a major bank since March. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan described the Citibank move as a good sign for the economy. Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said the central bank would continue to fight inflation by holding down monetary growth. (Page D1.)

title: Abraham Goldstein, 79, Dies; Authority on Contract Bridge
description: Abraham Goldstein, a leading contract bridge player and teacher, died Monday at Deepdale Hospital, Queens, at the age of 79. He lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Dodgers 5, Pirates 2
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Steve Garvey cracked a run-scoring double in the sixth inning to break a 2-2 tie for Los Angeles as Fernando Valenzuela pitched a five-hitter.

title: HOUSE VOTES DOWN STRINGENT BUDGET
description: The House today rejected, 242 to 182, a plan offered by conservatives that would have produced a balanced Federal budget by making severe cuts in social programs. Meanwhile, intense maneuvering continued over three other budget plans for the fiscal year 1983.

title: Alzado Ahead
description: In a Denver court, Lyle Alzado, the Oakland Raider defensive lineman, lost a $185,000 judgment to Meyer Blinder, an investor who backed his 1979 exhibition fight with Muhammad Ali and who contended that Alzado had promised to make up the difference between $250,000 in up-front money and the amount generated in ticket sales. But Alzado walked out of the courthouse $7,000 richer, because the same jury found that Mr. Blinder had pledged to protect him from financial losses connected with the bout and therefore owed him $192,000.

title: Bridge: Transfer Bids Make Difference at Right Time
description: One of the most popular conventions in modern tournament play is the transfer bid, developed by Oswald Jacoby of Dallas. The basic idea is relatively simple: two diamonds shows heart length, and two hearts shows spade length - at least five cards in each case. But difficulties arise with other responses, and there are several schemes.

title: Seaver Struggling
description: Tom Seaver, whose 260 career victories and ability to discuss the mechanics of his work have earned him a reputation as the thinking man's pitcher, doesn't know how to explain some dismal performances that have left him with a 1-6 record and a 6.86 earned run average this season. ''If I knew what was wrong I'd stop it,'' he said after giving up seven runs in five innings to Philadelphia Monday night as Cincinnati lost its sixth straight.

title: U.S. VIEWS DEFEAT OF IRAQIS BY IRAN AS A MAJOR PERIL
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Iran's rout of Iraqi forces threatened the stability of Persian Gulf states and was creating a situation potentially more dangerous to Western interests than the unresolved Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Brazilian Jetliner Crash Kills 2 and Injures 15
description: A jetliner with 119 people aboard crashlanded at an airport in a rainstorm and broke into two pieces late Monday night, killing 2 persons and injuring 15 others, officials said.

title: U.S. VETERANS AGENCY REVISES ITS AGENT ORANGE PAMPHLET
description: At one time veterans who asked the Government about Agent Orange, a defoliant used in the Vietnam War, received a pamphlet listing the diseases that have been associated with exposure to dioxin, a toxic contaminant in the substance.

title: ROLL CALL ON THE TWO BILLS
description: Following are the votes by which the State Assembly passed a bill requiring a nickel deposit on soda and beer containers - the ''bottle bill'' - and another bill providing for a tax on beverage containers to promote recycling and litter cleanup.

title: Caterpillar Salaries
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it would indefinitely freeze the salaries of its 23,750 United States managers, weekly salaried employees and others working abroad, starting June 1, and would suspend cost-of-living adjustments and salary rises normally granted at this time of year. It cited market slumps.

title: Advertising; D.D.B. Still Hopes To Merge
description: Most of the advertising community discovered only recently that Doyle Dane Bernbach International and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, both in the top 10, were having merger discussions - when they announced the talks were being terminated.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard Uncivil Liberties. By Calvin Trillin. 206 pages. Ticknor and Fields. $10.95.

title: ARGENTINA TELLS OF RAID ON SHIPS
description: Argentina said today that it had sent waves of warplanes against British ships and repulsed an air attack by British Harriers on Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands. The military command said the planes seriously damaged one British warship.

title: AUTO SALES ROSE 15.3% IN MID-MAY
description: New car sales by the nation's Big Three auto makers increased 15.3 percent in mid-May, the companies said today, providing encouragement that the recent upturn in sales would continue.

title: Shares Issued By Grand Met
description: Grand Metropolitan said today that it planned to raise 25.4 million pound sterling through an underwritten one-for-seven rights issue of 74.7 million ordinary shares at 174 pence each

title: HAIG SAYS BRITISH APPEAR IN POSITION FOR EARLY VICTORY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. asserted today that ''the British appear to be in a position to bring the war in the Falklands to an early conclusion'' and urged them to be ''magnanimous in victory.''

title: THE POP LIFE
description: MEMPHIS THERE isn't much left of Beale Street. The half dozen downtown blocks of this historic Memphis thoroughfare used to be lined with theaters where America's finest black entertainers performed, and with department stores that carried everything from dry goods to voodoo paraphernalia to the kind of colorful flashy jackets and slacks that black bluesmen such as B.B. King and young white singers such as Elvis Presley wore on stage. The side streets that shot off Beale in both directions were lined with saloons where itinerant blues pianists rocked and rolled and tried to stump one another with spectacular feats of polyrhythmic dexterity.

title: Gasoline Futures
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved the Chicago Board of Trade's plan to trade futures of leaded and unleaded regular gasoline. James Culver, director of economics and education for the commission, said that the terms were nearly the same as those for the Board of Trade's heating oil futures contract, which calls for delivery of a depositary receipt against the contracts, rather than immediate physical delivery of a product.

title: Research
description: Question One came in an April poll by Patrick Caddell, Jimmy Carter's pollster, who now works for William Brown, a candidate for governor of Ohio. Referring to Jerry Springer, a Brown rival for the Democratic nomination, the question asked:

title: Careers; Overseas Work Has Drawbacks
description: ALL is not well with corporate middle managers who serve abroad and then return to the home office. That is apparent from two recent studies of working abroad - one by the Conference Board, the business research organization, and the other by Korn-Ferry International, a management recruiting firm.

title: PIANIST: AN EMIGRE'S DEBUT
description: IN her New York debut recital at the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House yesterday afternoon, Mara Miropolskaya, a recent emigre from the Soviet Union, left no doubt whatsoever that she is a pianist willing to be involved in her work. At times, her subjective approach and physical intensity seemed to be her own worst enemy, sending her into a frenzied, pianistic form of overdrive that scarcely suited the sonatas by Scarlatti with which she opened her program, and opened the door to undisciplined and even careless playing in Beethoven's Sonata No. 32 in C minor (Op. 111).

title: New Trial Is Ordered in Iowa In Ford Motor Liability Case
description: The Iowa Court of Appeals ruled today that the jury in a Ford Motor Company products liability case should have been told that the company knew about a defective shift lever at least six years before plaintiffs said it caused an accidental death.

title: HELPING A LARGE COMPANY DECIDE NOT TO LEAVE TOWN
description: Paine Webber Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, became fed up with Manhattan office rents. Last year it was planning to move all of its back-office operations to Jersey City, which would have meant a loss of 2,000 jobs for New York City.

title: U.S. and Soviet Meet Again On Medium-Range Weapons
description: United States and Soviet negotiators met for three hours and 40 minutes today in the newly resumed talks on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Mercedes Sets Truck Transfer
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said today that it would concentrate its commercial vehicle activities in the United States at the Freightliner Corporation., the United States truck manufacturer that the West German auto maker acquired last year.

title: A JARRING CHANGE AT STEINWAY
description: Their pianos have been known for exquisite craftsmanship and quality of sound since 1853, and change, when it has come, has tended to be orderly, precise - and quiet. Thus, when CBS Inc. announced last week that Peter M. Perez, the respected president of its Steinway & Sons unit, had resigned ''to pursue personal interests,'' the news of the thinly disguised ouster struck like a discordant note.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Harvey R. Siegel, whose loan to a reputed underworld figure in 1976 placed in jeopardy the long-awaited merger of the Harwyn Industries Corporation with the parent company of the Seattle SuperSonics, has resigned as president of Harwyn to help facilitate the move. ... The Jets have signed Bob Crable, the linebacker from Notre Dame who was their No.1 draft choice last month, to a series of one-year contracts. ... Buck Williams of the Nets, Kelly Tripucka and Isiah Thomas of Detroit, Jay Vincent of Dallas and Jeff Ruland of Washington make up the all-rookie team selected by the coaches of the National Basketball Association.

title: Checker-Potamkin Pact
description: The Checker Motors Corporation and its majority owner, the Checker Taxi Company, have settled litigation with Victor H. Potamkin, a Manhattan Cadillac dealer, and certain Potamkin affiliates, it was announced yesterday. The settlement with Mr. Potamkin involved the sale by Checker Motors of all the stock outstanding of the National Transportation Company to that Potamkin affiliate for $7 million in cash.

title: City Stores' Losses Narrow
description: The City Stores Company, which operates the W.& J. Sloane furniture chain, said yesterday that its losses from operations declined to $1.46 million in the first fiscal quarter ended May 1 from a deficit of $3.5 million in the same quarter the year before.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE arrival of the new Beaujolais in this country after the harvest in France each fall is probably the most publicized annual event on the wine calendar. Curiously, the arrival of the more mature Beaujolais from the same vintage the following spring occurs virtually without fanfare, even though the wine is usually far superior.

title: WEINBERGER REVISING A COMMITTEE TO STUDY MX MISSILE CLUSTER PLAN
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has reconvened a committee of prominent military specialists to renew a study of bases for the MX intercontinental missile, a Defense Department spokesman said today.

title: Bell's Cellular Radio Plans
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company informed the Federal Communications Commission today that it intends to stay in the new cellular radio business after its proposed divestiture of the 22 local telephone companies.

title: HOW BUYING HABITS FOR FOOD ARE CHANGING
description: "I'm always saying I don't know how people with families manage,'' Gloria Gregurovich commented the other day while pushing her cart through a Manhattan supermarket. ''I'm just shopping for myself and my cat, and I suddenly have to make choices. I just cut out the nonessential items.''

title: COOKBOOK RECITATION UNEARTHS LITERATURE
description: ''AS if a cookbook had anything to do with writing,'' Alice B. Toklas once said. But in Paul Schmidt's reading at the Manhattan Theater Club last week, he showed that a good cookbook is more than a list of recipes.

title: Savannah Burn Victim Dies; Hospitals Barred Admission
description: A Georgia man with burns over 95 percent of his body died today of complications from his injuries. The victim, John Lacey, a 27-year-old Savannah housepainter, was burned May 5 when gasoline he was using to clean paint off himself burst into flames.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS GRANT AID FOR ISRAEL
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, voicing concern about American arms shipments to Arab countries as well as the impact of Israel's withdrawal from Sinai on its security, voted today to increase grant aid to Israel over the objections of the Reagan Administration.

title: DEERE NET TUMBLES BY 96.7%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that continued weak demand for replacement tires and plant closings helped depress net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1982 by 81.5 percent as sales dipped 8.1 percent.

title: Steelers Find Success Taxing
description: The Internal Revenue Service has notified members of the Pittsburgh Steelers that they must pay taxes on the value of the Super Bowl rings they received in 1979 and 1980 because the rings contain gold and diamonds worth several thousand dollars.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan returned to California for a Republican Party fund-raising dinner last night in an unfamiliar role, as a potential political liability for Republicans in his home state.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 16.00 16.50 20.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.88 13.71 17.79 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.62 11.56 15.94 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.81 11.70 14.93 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 13.71 13.65 13.90 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.21 13.21 13.24 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.58 15.60 14.98 MUNCIPAL BONDS 13.13 13.13 11.37 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.470 CERTIICATES** * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Press Ownership in Canada
description: The federal Government said today that, in the name of freedom of the press, it plans to forbid new acquisitions by Canada's two largest newspaper chains.

title: ARMY GETTING NEW TANK-LIKE PERSONNEL CARRIERS
description: With speeches and demonstrations using live ammunition, the Army on Wednesday will accept the first two production-line models of the Bradley Fighting Vehicle at a ceremony at the Infantry Center here. The vehicles, named in honor of the late Gen. Omar N. Bradley, are hybrid personnel carrier-tanks.

title: Anka Fined $2,000
description: As a penalty for violations of United States Customs regulations, Paul Anka has been fined $2,000, and, under a plea-bargaining arrangement, the singer has agreed to donate the $25,000 proceeds from a recent concert to victims of crimes.

title: JOHN'S 5-HITTER STYMIES JAYS, 8-0
description: If Tommy John were to write a ''how to pitch'' book, all he would have to do is put last night's game into words. John didn't pitch a perfect game, but he made pitching look ridiculously easy as the Yankees trounced the Toronto Blue Jays, 8-0, at Yankee Stadium for their sixth straight victory.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: MORE AUTHORS TURN TO VANITY PRESSES
description: WITH the turmoil in El Salvador dominating the headlines last year, Frank J. Devine dashed off a book about his recent experiences as the United States Ambassador to that war-torn nation from 1977 to 1980. After several commercial publishers turned it down, Mr. Devine took his manuscript to Vantage Press. Six months and some $5,000 later, Mr. Devine was the proud author of ''El Salvador: Embassy Under Attack,'' a 208-page memoir.

title: 18 Die in Fire in France At Home for Teen-Agers
description: At least 18 people died and 2 were gravely injured when fire gutted a home for mentally handicapped teen-agers in this small southwestern French town today, the police said.

title: People
description: * Ethel Rosner, a vice president of Ted Bates Advertising/New York, has been appointed director of the agency's Spot Television Broadcast Buying Unit.

title: AIDE SAYS INTERNAL FORCES STILL THREATEN HANOI
description: A senior Vietnamese official interviewed in a Polish newspaper has depicted his country with unusual candor as one troubled by grave military, economic and political problems.

title: THE CLASS OF 1982
description: One of this year's graduates at the University of Illinois, obviously a student of ancient history, notes that it is now just 50 years since I was in his place, and he implies that I must have learned something since then and asks for a comparison between the Depression class of 1932 and the depression class of 1982.

title: A REGIONAL TURKEY
description: After decades of neglecting the Middle East, Turkey is rediscovering it. In so doing, Turkey may be finding an identity as a bridge between the Middle East and Europe that could subtly change the country's traditional relationships. Closer Middle Eastern ties are helping the economy and making the Turks less dependent on, and perhaps less conciliatory toward, Western Europe. They are also increasing Turkey's strategic importance to the West.

title: Aramco Gas Plant
description: A major gas plant at Uthmaniyah in eastern Saudi Arabia has begun full-scale production with the starting up of its fourth and final gas processing operation, the Arabian American Oil Company said today. The plant is designed to process 1.5 billion cubic feet of sour gas and 28,000 barrels of liquid hydrocarbons daily.

title: Mining New Guinea's Gold Mountain
description: Ever since 1969, when the Kennecott Corporation began to explore this area, the copper and gold lodes atop nearby Mount Fubilan have been the stuff of corporate dreams.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES OF ARGENTINE FOREIGN MINISTER AND BRITISH DELEGATE
description: Following are excerpts from the speech to the Security Council today by Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina, from the reply by Sir Anthony Parsons, Britain's representative at the United Nations, and from a reply by Mr. Costa Mendez, as recorded by The New York Times: The Speech by Mr. Costa Mendez

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are some who treat gift wrappings as gently as a baby. The knots in the ribbons are carefully untied, the tape is eased from the paper with a fingernail and the tissue lining in the box is separated with a delicate touch.

title: U.S. Oil Use Revision
description: The Energy Department's Energy Information Administration expects oil demand in the United States to average 15.5 million barrels daily in 1982, down from its estimate of 16 million barrels made in February, J. Erich Evered, the administrator, said yesterday. Mr. Evered said the revision had been made after first-quarter demand trailed the agency's expectations by one million barrels a day.

title: Controversy at Temple
description: Peter Liacouras, who becomes the president of Temple University on July 1, broke his silence yesterday on published reports that he planned to dismiss Don Casey, the university's highly successful basketball coach, and replace him with a black. Casey, who has two years remaining on his contract, is white, and the reports had said that Mr. Liacouras thought a black coach would be more suitable for Temple, which is situated in a predominantly black neighborhood of North Philadelphia.

title: E.P.A. ASSAILED ON RULE FOR LEAD IN GASOLINE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has been advising oil companies that they are free to increase the lead content of regular gasoline by nearly 10 percent above the published limit.

title: Sun Electric Loss
description: The Sun Electric Corporation said it expects a second-quarter loss - although narrower than the $1.5 million loss of the first quarter - and is cutting officers' salaries by 10 percent and those of other upper management by 8 percent, effective June 1. Earlier, Sun said its board had voted to omit payment of a dividend. It last paid 18 cents a share on March 15.

title: United May Cancel Big Boeing Order
description: United Airlines, the airline subsidiary of UAL Inc., announced today that it had entered into negotiations with the Boeing Company to ''cancel or substantially delay delivery'' of 20 new-generation Boeing 767 aircraft worth $1 billion.

title: Sports of The Times; Renovating a '77 Valentine
description: HE was the Reggie Jackson of Montreal just long enough to know he loved it. He was a big bachelor who thrilled the crowd with his arm and his home runs and who went home to California in the winter to tinker with his cars.

title: AFTER ALL, WHAT IS THE SPRINGTIME FOR?
description: Spring is a time for flowers and for things to turn green and for kissing. Some might quarrel with this, noting that kissing is good any time of the year. But could Bertrand Fourcade, above left, who is the publisher of the French edition of Vogue, properly kiss the hand of Josephine Wilson if it was covered with the wool mitten of winter? And would Sirio Macchione, above, owner of the restaurant Le Cirque, be able to receive a buss from an obviously satisfied diner if he had a fall muffler about his neck? Yes, spring is definitely a time for kissing - across the seats of motorcycles parked on Madison Avenue, on benches in Central Park, in the public gardens of the city, on the steps of the Public Library, on Fifth and other avenues, everywhere. Why not?

title: 34 Injured in Collapse Of Retreat Center Balcony
description: A second-story balcony at a children's ranch collapsed under the weight of 70 children today, injuring 34 persons who had gathered for a birthday party.

title: Budget Fantasies
description: What if President Reagan had responded with real leadership in January when his proposed 12-digit deficits met with such universal criticism? Then as now, the worst enemy of his economic program was high interest rates. They threatened the economic recovery he hoped for later in the year. They reflected deep worries in the financial community about the future. But by proposing huge and growing deficits, the President did not attack the enemy; he surrendered.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Seven Styles of Canes Margie Whitmore must use a cane because she has had multiple sclerosis for 10 years. When she shopped for canes she found the dark colors too dreary and the clear plastic ones too clinical. What she wanted was a cheerful, cane with a feminine touch, so she designed her own. Mrs. Whitmore found a manufacturer to make the canes and decided to sell them herself. The Margies come in seven styles: bunches of violets, flowery vines or red and pink roses on a white background, red strawberries or gold butterflies on black and green vines or daisies on a brown background. They're available by mail for $49.95, plus $3 postage, from Raising Cane, 175 Devon Road, Essex Fells, N.J. 07021; 201-226-5058.

title: JUNTA LEADS ARGENTINES IN PATRIOTIC OBSERVANCE
description: This day is one of the most solemn days of Argentine patriotism, so, washed in a warm sun, Buenos Aires took today off to recall May 25, 1810, when 251 of the first citizens of this city met and made decisions that led to independence from Spain six years later.

title: STATE SENATOR BACKS JOINT CUSTODY IN DIVORCES AND DRINKING AGE OF 19
description: The Republican-led Senate gave final approval today to a measure that would require judges to consider joint custody of children in divorce cases if one or both of the parents request such an arrangement.

title: JAZZ: INGHAM PROJECTS ON SOFT PIANO
description: THE customary role for a pianist in a restaurant that prides itself on its food is to be unobtrusive, to provide a soft coloring that blends into the overall sound of the room without interfering with conversation or distracting one's attention from the chef's work. Keith Ingham, who plays piano starting at 7:30 P.M. at Ambrosia, 216 East 49th Street, follows the proper pattern of this role but he has managed to expand it subtly and effectively for those diners who have jazz ears.

title: Closing at St. Regis
description: The St. Regis Paper Company's kraft paper mill here will close Monday for three weeks, affecting about 600 workers, company officials said today. This is the second threeweek closing in two months.

title: IRAQ ADMITS ITS FORCES HAVE YIELDED KEY PORT
description: Iraq acknowledged today that its forces had retreated from the Iranian port city of Khurramshahr in the face of Iranian attacks.

title: Sale of Wien Air
description: Household International Inc. said it had reached a definitive agreement for the sale of its Wien Air Alaska Inc. subsidiary to Eagle International Corporation for $50 million in cash, subject to approval of the Civil Aeronautics Board. Eagle is owned by Neil G. Bergt, chairman of Western Airlines.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it would supply 16 large compressors to the Great Plains Coal Gasification Project in Utah.

title: Military Analysis
description: Fighting between Argentina and Britain in the Falkland Islands is focused, temporarily at least, on the trial of strength between the Argentine Air Force and the ships of the British fleet and the supporting Harrier fighters and antiaircraft missiles and guns.

title: A. PEIRCE SAUNDERS
description: A. Peirce Saunders, a former dean and senior master of the Hill School, Pottstown, Pa., died Sunday at his home, Great Oak Farm, in Pottstown, after a long illness.

title: LEWELLYN PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Gary Lewellyn, the stockbroker who is accused of embezzling $13.5 million from his father's bank in the tiny town of Humboldt, pleaded not guilty today to eight charges of embezzlement and making false statements to bank officers. Mr. Lewellyn, who has already pleaded guilty to a criminal contempt charge in New York, did not volunteer any grounds for his latest plea.

title: Anacomp-DSI Tie
description: Anacomp Inc., an Indianapolis-based computer services company, said that it had acquired or received tenders for 89 percent of the outstanding stock of the DSI Corporation and that it had extended its offer for the remaining shares through June 3.

title: SWITCH IS SOUGHT IN B-52 MONEY
description: The Pentagon says it still wants to eliminate the oldest B-52 bombers despite a Congressional directive to retain the eight-engine craft as a key part of the nation's strategic force.

title: 25 STATES RAISE TAXES TO OFFESET RECESSION LOSS
description: At least 25 states and many cities and counties have raised taxes this year, trying to make up revenue losses caused by the recession and, to a lesser degree, by Federal budget cuts.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Breaking Food Codes

title: Iarusci of Cosmos Is Sidelined
description: The Cosmos announced today that Robert Iarusci, one of their sweepers, suffered a fractured vertebra in his lower spine and would be out for at least three weeks.

title: Clausen Cites Bank's Aims
description: The president of the World Bank, A.W. Clausen, said today that the bank planned to strengthen its role as a catalyst for international investment.

title: INTENSIVE CENSUS WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary in some editions yester- day gave an incorrect first name for the founder and chairman of Archi- bald & Kendall Inc. He was Walter D. Archibald.

title: House Sales Down by 4.5%
description: Sales of existing houses dropped 4.5 percent in April, bringing a halt to two months of gains for that part of the troubled housing industry, a survey by a private real estate group indicated today.

title: ARA: EXPANDING IN RECESSION
description: It's almost as if there were no recession. ARA Services Inc. is in the process of acquiring its second company this year. It is also proceeding with a $20 million expansion of its child-care center network. And, according to industry analysts, the $2.9 billion conglomerate can keep up that sort of growth almost indefinitely.

title: ABC-TV to Sell Spots For Commentary Ads
description: Last July ABC-TV began testing whether corporations, which in increasing numbers seem to want to run advocacy or issue advertising, would like to do it on late-night television.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The picture published with the television program listings yesterday was mislabeled by its supplier, the Public Broadcasting System. It showed John Clymer, the artist.

title: POLITICIANS' WIVES AND 'PEACE LINKS'
description: When Betty Bumpers sat down with friends to put together an organization that would encourge women to get involved in the nuclear arms debate, they puzzled over what to call themselves.

title: Market Place; Health Science Fund's Promise
description: PUTNAM HEALTH SCIENCES TRUST appears to have proved that an exciting idea plus a strong marketing effort can overcome shareholder apathy in a bear market. The Putnam Management Company's newest investment vehicle - a mutual fund that will invest exclusively in health science equities - has just sold a quarter of a billion dollars worth of shares.

title: MANDATORY SEX EDUCATION UPHELD IN JERSEY BY STATE'S HIGHEST COURT
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that requiring sex education in public schools does not violate the United States Constitution.

title: French-Saudi Talks Planned
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France will visit Saudi Arabia this weekend for talks with King Khalid and Crown Prince Fahd, his spokesman said today. The talks are expected to cover developments in the Iraq-Iran war, Monday's bomb attack at the French Embassy in Beirut and the cooling of relations between France and the Arab world following President Francois Mitterrand's visit to Israel last March, French diplomatic sources said.

title: REPORTS 3 OF FOE'S PLANES DOWNED
description: Argentine fighter-bombers launched a new attack against British ships off the Falkland Islands today and severely damaged a sister ship of the sunken destroyer Sheffield, British officials reported tonight. The destroyer appeared to be sinking, and a full-scale rescue operation was under way.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 26, 1982
description: International The likelihood of a British victory in the Falkland conflict was suggested by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. He asserted that ''the British appear to be in a position to bring the war to an early conclusion'' and urged the British to be ''magnanimous in victory.'' Administration officials said that Washington had begun to supply the British with war materiel, and a senior Pentagon spokesman warned Moscow not to interfere in the conflict. (Page A1, Column 6.) Argentina appealed repeatedly for a negotiated peace in the Falkland war with the help of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. As the United Nations Security Council ended a fifth day of debate on the conflict, Britain called on Argentina to remove its troops from the islands. (A1:5.)

title: Cable TV Industry Fighting 'Dishes'
description: A dispute is brewing over some of the most profitable airwaves around. On one side are Showtime, Home Box Office and other cable television programmers whose shows bounce off satellites into local cable systems. On the other are manufacturers of receiving ''dishes'' that can pick up virtually anything from the satellites and display it on home television sets, bypassing cable distribution systems in the process.

title: Space Agency Investigating Possible Legionaires' Disease
description: Two specialists in disease control are investigating the possibility of an outbreak of legionnaires' disease here, the space agency said today.

title: Conigliaro's Condition Is Greatly Improved
description: Tony Coligliaro, who had been in a coma four and a half months, has begun to speak a few words to his family and is recovering ''amazingly and exceptionally well,'' his doctor said today.

title: Occidental Layoffs
description: The Occidental Chemical Company, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of Los Angeles, plans to lay off 154 workers in addition to the 225 announced May 1, company officials said Monday. The layoffs at the phosphate mining and processing operation would amount to about 18 percent of its total staff.

title: Dow Off 1.81 Despite Rate Cut; Early Rally Dissipated
description: The stock market, despite a cut in interest rates, registered a moderate decline yesterday in accelerated trading. The biggest price movers were issues responding to specific news developments.

title: Cummins Engine Plans More Cuts
description: The Cummins Engine Company, a maker of diesel engines for heavyduty trucks, said it would put into effect new cost-cutting measures on top of previously announced cutbacks in response to ''continuing declines in business activity.''

title: Ecuadorean Plane Held at Kennedy
description: An Ecuadorean cargo airliner was detained at Kennedy Airport yesterday by the United States Customs Service, which questioned the licensing of the cargo and sought clearance from the State Department before releasing the plane.

title: WOOING VOTERS WITH BEAN AND BARBECUE
description: sawing contests, and you have the 34th annual Mount Nebo Chicken Fry, one of the edible classics of American politics.

title: Shattering the Morale Of Insurance Agents
description: If you have an inferiority complex about being in the life insurance business, wait a while. The new ad campaign from Life of Virginia will make you feel even worse.

title: IMPERILED VICTORIES OVER WHOOPING COUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: AN ANTHONY SALUTE
description: THE Mary Anthony Dance Theater celebrates its 25th anniversary this year, and a new dance by Anna Sokolow, presented by the company Saturday night in the Marymount Manhattan Theater, was a perfect tribute to Miss Anthony. Set to vocal music by Mahler, Miss Sokolow's ''Elegy'' is a duet that explores affectionate mutual dependency with poignant simplicity.

title: Weather in Falklands Is Calm
description: A few low clouds were visible over the Falkland Islands this morning, according to photos collected by the National Earth Satellite Service. Charles Kadin of the service said the islands were generally clear in the photos although there might have been some overnight rain. The sea to the west was mostly clear for about 200 miles, he said.

title: Steven Richman Leads Harmonie Ensemble
description: The Harmonie Ensemble, under the baton of its music director, Steven Richman, lived up to its name Monday night with a program of wind music by Mozart and Richard Strauss in the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House. The choice of works - Mozart's Serenade No. 10 in B-flat for 12 wind instruments and bass, and Strauss's Symphony for Wind Instruments in E-flat (1945) - was apt, for not only is the Strauss work dedicated ''to the spirit of the divine Mozart at the end of a thankful life,'' but also its finale quotes the rondo theme from the concluding movement of Mozart's serenade.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First Jersey National Bank/South elected Walter E. Cramer vice chairman of its board of directors.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN preparing for a vacation abroad, chances are you will think about clothing, cameras, suitcases, tickets, transportation and hotels and perhaps even points of interest and restaurants in the cities you expect to visit. But you may fail to plan for the one factor that can make the biggest difference in whether you have an enjoyable trip -your health.

title: Report Faults 2 Drivers In Fiery Tunnel Crash
description: A bus driver's inattention and excessive speed combined with a drunken driver's disabled vehicle caused the explosion that killed seven persons in the Caldecott Tunnel last month, a California Highway Patrol report said today.

title: REPERTORY THEATER: 'TRISTAN & ISOLT'
description: OBSESSIVE love is under artistic scrutiny in a fanciful pair of plays created and performed by the Talking Band and presented in repertory at La Mama. ''Gioconda and Si-Ya-U,'' reviewed last fall in its premiere at the Dance Theater Workshop, is about a romance between the Mona Lisa and a Chinese revolutionary. The new work, ''Tristan & Isolt,'' is a mythic retelling of the Celtic legend. The principal theme of both pieces, as expressed in ''Tristan,'' is that ''love can't be denied.''

title: Jenkins Is Seventh To Strike Out 3,000
description: Ferguson Jenkins of the Chicago Cubs tonight became the seventh major league pitcher to strike out 3,000 batters. He fanned San Diego's Gerry Templeton in the third inning of a 2-1 loss to the Padres to reach the milestone.

title: Toads Invade Florida Town
description: An invasion of tiny, bug-eyed green toads has descended on this central Florida town.

title: Winning a Delay but Losing a Battle in the House
description: He was hardly the first member of Congress to talk to a graduating class at a high school in his home district, but Representative James R. Jones of Oklahoma may have been the first to get the unanimous consent of the House of Representatives to do so.

title: N.F.L. UNION SAYS VOTE IS SUPPORTING A STRIKE
description: Strike-authorization votes taken among players on half the teams in the league show ''nearly'' unanimous support for a walkout if a new collective bargaining agreement is not reached, the leadership of the National Football League Players Association said today.

title: Senate Witness Urges Drug Control in Racing
description: A proponent of legislation to establish Federal standards for drug use in horse racing told a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today that the industry faced a ''national crisis'' because of widespread administering of both permitted and illegal drugs to horses.

title: Knight Royalty
description: The Knight Royalty Corporation said today that it had a working capital deficiency of about $1.1 million on March 31, which it hoped to correct by offering unspecified oil and gas properties for sale at $7.5 million. The company reported a loss of $397,294 on revenue of $1,187,586 for the nine-month period ending March 31.

title: Cosmos Tie Napoli on Romero's Goal, 2-2
description: The Cosmos and Napoli of Italy opened the third annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tonight by playing to a 2-2 tie at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 28,887.

title: Harvester Selling Its Insurance Unit
description: The International Harvester Company, the debtridden manufacturer of construction and farm equipment, announced that it was looking for a buyer for its insurance company subsidiary, the Association Life Insurance Company.

title: Loesch, With 68 for 140, Gets Dodge Open Lead
description: Rod Loesch of Wee Burn in Darien, Conn., shot a four-under-par 68 today and took a two-stroke lead in the $60,000 Dodge Open golf tournament with a two-round total of 140.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Don Casey will stay on as Temple University basketball coach for the last two years of his contract, scotching reports that he would be replaced when Peter J. Liacouras takes over as president July 1. ... Bob Fletcher, the owner of the car Gordon Smiley was driving when he was killed in a crash at Indy two weeks ago, says he had been concerned about Smiley before the accident. ''He was too aggressive,'' Fletcher said, ''like he was in too big a hurry to prove he was as good a driver as anyone out there.''

title: ALL TOO MANY PIANISTS ARE ATHLETES, NOT ARTISTS
description: The school year is approaching its end, and about the time the boys and girls go out to play full-time many of them will also be beginning a vacation from one of their organized athletic activities - piano lessons.

title: Santa Fe Coal
description: Santa Fe Industries said that it would invest $140 million in the development of a coal mine, the Lee Ranch Mine, in the San Juan Basin of New Mexico. The Tucson Electric Power Company has agreed to buy 15 million tons of coal from the mine to fuel its Springerville, Ariz., plant during the period 1984-91. The mine will be operated by the SF Coal Company, a unit of Santa Fe Industries.

title: BUSH REPORTS 23 GIFTS IN 1981 VALUED AT MORE THAN $17,000
description: Vice President Bush has listed 23 gifts from friends and well-wishers valued at more than $17,000 in his 1981 financial disclosure statement, his spokesman said today.

title: 'Hazzard' Stars Quit in Dispute on Profits
description: The filming of next season's series television shows beginsin a couple of weeks, and that is usually preceded by some stars of hit shows threatening to quit.

title: New Jersey Paper Dismisses Writer Who Falsified Column
description: A staff writer for The Press of Atlantic City has been dismissed after admitting he did not attend a closed union meeting about which he wrote a column, newspaper officials said today.

title: Excerpts from speech, page A10.
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States would play ''a more active role'' in coming weeks in trying to end the Iraqi-Iranian war. He seemed to warn Iran that if it spread the conflict into neighboring nations Washington would protect its ''vital interests'' in the Persian Gulf.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: IT is time to think about keeping summer clothes ironed and crisp. There are small ironing boards for those with limited space and some handy storage items for equipment.

title: U.S. MOVING TO FREE DATA ON PROBATION
description: A proposed change in the rules of procedure for Federal courts has upset many judges and probation officers who say it would give the public and the press too much information.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have a coffee table with a marble top that is stained in several places. How can I remove these stains? - M.S., Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Petersen Publishing Plans Two New Titles
description: The Petersen Publishing Company in Los Angeles, which already has 13 monthly magazines catering to leisure-time activities, has two more on the drawing board.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Housing Finance Corp. is offering $225 million in stateassisted mortgage bonds priced to yield 15.40 percent, to be sold through a group led by Salomon Brothers.

title: METS DEFEAT BRAVES BY 6-4 AS SWAN EXCELS IN RELIEF
description: Wally Backman hit his first major league home run tonight to drive in three runs in a four-run fifth inning, and Craig Swan gave up two hits in six innings of shutout relief as the Mets rallied to beat the Atlanta Braves, 6-4.

title: Greek Leader in Yugoslavia
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece arrived today for three days of talks with Yugoslav leaders.

title: Colorado Asks Athletes About $6,000 in Calls
description: As many as 20 athletes at the University of Colorado were being investigated in the belief that they illegally charged calls to third-party numbers and used fraudulent credit-card numbers to make $6,000 worth of long-distance calls from their dormitory, university officials confirmed Tuesday.

title: League Requests Data On Winfield's Contract
description: Lee MacPhail, who as league president approves the contracts of American League players, said yesterday that he had asked the Yankees for a copy of the written agreement between George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, and the David M. Winfield Foundation, which is suing Steinbrenner in Federal court.

title: AMERICAN CAN AGREES TO BUY TRANSPORT LIFE FOR $152 MILLION
description: The American Can Company, taking a further step into the financial services industry, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Transport Life Insurance Company for $152 million.

title: Aston Villa Wins Cup
description: A goal by Peter Withe in the 67th minute gave Aston Villa a 1-0 victory over Bayern Munich of West Germany today in the final of the Champions Cup.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Brentano's Inc. in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the amount owed by the book chain to the Ingram Book Company. It is $277,000.

title: President Adds Job At Payless Cashways
description: Payless Cashways Inc. of Kansas City, Mo., which operates a growing chain of do-it-yourself building-materials stores in the Sun Belt, announced the appointment yesterday of David Stanley, president and chief operating officer, to the additional post of chief executive.

title: Old-Fashioned Welfare
description: Welfare workers used to combine two jobs: they dealt not only with payment problems but also gave general counsel. Then a decade ago, Washington encouraged states to separate these functions, hoping for better service at less cost.

title: Productivity Drop Slows
description: Productivity of all private business in the United States, including farming, declined at an annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, a slight improvement from the 1 percent rate of decline initially estimated, the Labor Department reported today.

title: QUICK SENATE PASSAGE LIKELY FOR NEW ANTICRIME MEASURE
description: With President Reagan's endorsement, senior Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee introduced a new package of anticrime bills today and predicted quick Senate approval.

title: Amex Seeking Index Options
description: The American Stock Exchange has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve trading of options on future movements in the Amex market value index. The exchange also expects to consider plans, it said yesterday, for options based on other indexes.

title: Stieb's 4-Hitter Stops Yankees
description: As if the Yankees did not already know it, Dave Stieb showed last night why they have tried for two years to pry him from the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Fetus Memorial Service Is Endorsed by Reagan
description: President Reagan has endorsed a plan by anti-abortion advocates to conduct a memorial service for nearly 17,000 fetuses and embryos discovered earlier this year in a repossessed shipping container, the White House said today.

title: COMEDY: DURANG'S 'BEYOND THERAPY'
description: Some day, I swear, the explosive comic brilliance of Christopher Durang will erupt on Broadway. The only question is when. It didn't happen in 1978, when this playwright's ''A History of the American Film'' capsized in a spectacularly ill-conceived production. And it didn't happen last night, when Mr. Durang's latest play, ''Beyond Therapy,'' pretty much wilted of its own volition at the Brooks Atkinson. But we must be patient with this gifted fellow - he'll get there yet. In the meantime, we can make the wait pass faster by revisiting ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You,'' the Durang chef d'oeuvre now safely ensconced Off Broadway.

title: BRIEFING
description: Message From H.U.D.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision by Pope John Paul II to go ahead with his six-day visit to Britain and to add a two-day visit to Argentina presents him with some of the toughest political and religious challenges of his papacy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My days of stay in Great Britain will still be an incessant prayer in favor of peace, raised together with all God's people, who carry sculptured in their hearts the words of Christ: 'Blessed are the peacemakers, because they will be called the sons of God.' '' - Pope John Paul, in letter to President Leopoldo Galtieri of Argentina. (A18:4.)

title: U.S. SEEKS NEWSPAPER DIVESTITURE
description: The Justice Department filed suit today to force the Tribune Company of Chicago to sell five Florida publications that it acquired in 1980, an antitrust challenge that seems likely to have wide repercussions in the newspaper industry.

title: Nuclear Freeze Rejected
description: The Alexandria City Council, bucking a trend, has rejected a resolution urging an immediate freeze on the production, testing and deployment of nuclear weapons. The measure was rejected Tuesday night by a vote of 3 to 3 after Councilman Nelson Greene abstained.

title: 'MISSING' AND A TURKISH FILM SHARE TOP PRIZE AT CANNES
description: ''Missing,'' the United States film starring Jack Lemmon that was denounced by the State Department, shared the top prize today at the 35th Cannes Film Festival, along with a Turkish movie made by a convicted murderer.

title: New Rules on Arms Exports Adopted by Cabinet in Bonn
description: The West German Cabinet approved new guidelines for arms exports today amid controversy over the country's role as a supplier of arms to Argentina.

title: New Disk Camera
description: The Continental Camera Corporation of Rahway, N.J., said that it would introduce a line of disk cameras that are less expensive than Kodak's disk cameras and can use Kodak's disk film. The disk cameras, ranging in price from $27.95 to $59, are to be delivered this June. The cameras, made in Taiwan, lack certain featues of the Kodak models.

title: French Prime Minister Visits Lebanese Leader
description: Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy of France arrived today to demonstrate his country's determination to maintain close ties to Lebanon despite a violent campaign against French interests here.

title: The U.N. Today; May 27, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HANDLING CHILDREN'S NUCLEAR WAR FEARS
description: AS children are increasingly exposed to images of nuclear war on television and in print, parents, teachers and mental-health professionals are being confronted with the psychological effects of those images.

title: WORLDLY TRAVELERS SET STORE BY LITTLE GANDER
description: ''The Cubans are crazy for gum,'' said Shirley McIlmoyl, ''They don't just buy a pack or two. They buy a whole box.''

title: Bank Gives Aid to Sports
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank made a $100,000 grant to New York City yesterday to help offset budget cuts for high school sports and recreation-center programs.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO SHIP ARMS TO ARGENTINA
description: Israeli military equipment on an Ecuadorean cargo plane detained by Federal authorities in New York on Tuesday was destined for Argentina, according to a senior Reagan Administration official.

title: Weather Mixed in Falklands
description: Rainclouds covered East Falkland Island this morning, but West Falkland was mostly clear, the United States National Earth Satellite Service reported. The satellite photo taken at 8 a.m. eastern daylight times also showed a band of scattered showers to the north and south of the islands, where British and Argentine forces are battling.

title: BECOME 'INVOLVED,' KEAN TELLS RUTGERS GRADUATES
description: Governor Kean asked the graduating students at Rutgers today to get involved in the problems of society and urged them not to turn away from politics.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 82 Vietnamese Saved in Sea
description: The United States Navy frigate Brewton rescued 82 Vietnamese refugees aboard a leaky 30-foot boat 390 miles south of Ho Chi Minh City, a Navy spokesman said today. The Navy said the 29 men, 22 women and 31 children were rescued Monday after crewmen on the Brewton spotted flares from the wooden boat.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH A PRAYER AMENDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: McIntyre-Taylor Dance
description: Dianne McIntyre and Cecil Taylor will present evenings of ''movement, sound and ritual'' today through Sunday at the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South. The dancerchoreographer and jazz musician will appear with the Sounds in Motion dance company in their new ''Eye of the Crocodile.''

title: FARES IN JERSEY TO GO UP IN JULY 10 TO 50 PERCENT
description: The NJ Transit Corporation, the state's transportation agency, today approved increases in bus and rail fares that ranged from 10 to 50 percent, effective in July.

title: Manville to Cut 1,000 Employess
description: The Manville Corporation, hard hit by the housing industry's troubles, said it will reduce its worldwide salaried work force of 8,800 by at least 1,000 by this fall through layoffs and early retirements.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A sports article yesterday about Tracy Austin included an incorrect description of her match against Chris Evert at Wimbledon in 1977. Miss Austin won the first game but lost the match in straight sets, 6-1, 6-1.

title: New Football League on TV
description: The United States Football League's credibility as a potentially successful venture was heightened considerably yesterday when the new 12-team league and ABC Sports announced a two-year network television agreement.

title: BRIDGING THE GAP BETWEEN HOME AND OFFICE
description: THE decision to redesign an office can be almost as traumatic as the one to renovate a home. Although the concerns and functions of office design are far different from those of residential projects, there are many crossovers, especially when designers see office projects as reflections of their personal tastes and sensibilities.

title: Court Seeks NLT Answer
description: The United States District Court of the Southern District of Texas told the NLT Corporation to answer the American General Corporation's contention that the early payment provision of its tender offer violated state and Federal laws.

title: Jersey Utilities Board Allows Drop in Rates
description: The State Board of Public Utilities approved a $250.3 million reduction in rates for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company today, making possible a drop of 5 to 10 percent in electric bills next week.

title: Bridge: 'Second Negative' Is Used; To Reach Right Contract
description: Most experts who use standard bidding methods employ a ''second negative'' after a strong artificial opening of two clubs. The first negative is, of course, two diamonds, and the second negative is three clubs if that is available.

title: Technology
description: At this moment, several of the nation's electric utilities and their counterparts abroad are holding a conference to discuss experiences in running nuclear power plants. Drillers for the Cities Service Company in Manila are conferring with company officials in Houston and Tulsa, Okla. And about two dozen writers from around the nation are conducting a continuing discussion about the new electronic media.

title: KAREN AND DELL'OLIO VOTED INTO COTY HALL OF FAME
description: Some surprises and lively debate occurred yesterday at a meeting of the Coty Awards Committee, which chose the winners of the 40th annual Coty American Fashion Critics Awards and nominees for the Winnie.

title: Arrows Still Champions
description: The New York Arrows, the only champion the Major Indoor Soccer League has known, won their fourth straight title by defeating the St. Louis Steamers, 8-6, before a crowd of 11,023 at Nassau Coliseum tonight in the fifth and deciding game of the final playoff.

title: CHARLES KRULL
description: Charles Krull, 68, former Mayor of East Rockaway, died Tuesday in South Nassau Communities Hospital after suffering heart failure.

title: OUTSPOKEN U.S. ENVOY DRAWS SOME CANADIANS' IRE
description: The most talked-about ambassador in Ottawa these days is the one from the United States, and not all the talk is complimentary.

title: THE VARIED GLORIES OF SPRING AZALEAS
description: THE azaleas are in bloom. Pink, purple, mauve, rose, orange or white petals shroud the shrubs and few leaves can be seen. The best time to buy azaleas is now while they are in bloom. So many hybrids are available that seeing their true colors is the safest way to plan.

title: LINES ARE BLURRED IN BUDGET BATTLE
description: Last year, Representative Harold C. Hollenbeck followed the sentiment in his northern New Jersey district and reluctantly backed President Reagan's budget. This year, the moderate Republican lawmaker is jumping ship, saying his party's budget proposal will cut too deeply into social programs that are vital to his constituents.

title: IMPRESARIO AT WORK: PLANNING THE PRESIDENT'S TRIP
description: The scene: Buckingham Palace. Eighteen American officials are seated across a table from 18 British officials, working out arrangements for President Reagan's forthcoming trip to Europe.

title: GASOLINE OUTLOOK FOR MEMORIAL DAY
description: As millions of motorists take to the highways for the Memorial Day weekend, they will find that gasoline prices are lower than they were a year ago -by about 15 cents a gallon - the first time in five years that this has happened. Supplies are plentiful and many service stations on major routes will be open around the clock.

title: Arkansas Community Seeks Cause of Balcony's Collapse
description: The authorities said today that they would hire an engineering consultant to find how why a large, wooden balcony collapsed in a prayer service at a children's ranch, injuring 26 people.

title: MEETINGS IN CITY BACK ATOMIC FREEZE
description: ''This is a town meeting, and this is my town,'' said Toni Fitzpatrick at a meeting in Murray Hill Tuesday night at the Community Church on 35th Street near Park Avenue. ''I want to make a statement that nuclear war is not unthinkable. We dream about it, we have nightmares about it.''

title: Saving Banks' Outflow Rises
description: Withdrawals from the nation's 435 savings banks exceeded deposits by $1.8 billion in April, an outflow second only to the record deposit loss of $2.03 billion in April 1981, a trade group reported yesterday.

title: M.S.A.'s CHIEF USES A PROMOTIONAL FLAIR TO OUTSELL OTHERS
description: John P. Imlay Jr. considers his software company the Jaws of the industry. To illustrate the point, he arrived at a company party one day accompanied by a live shark in a tank.

title: 2 Charged in Illinois Killings
description: Two men charged with murder in two of five killings were bound over for trial and held without bond today, leaving a pair of Rock River communities shaken. Circuit Judge J.M. Hansen of Whiteside County said he found probable cause to try Ronald Robinnett of Lyndon, 20 years old, and Edward Nelson of Rock Falls, 17, for murder in the beating and drowning deaths of two men.

title: APRIL TRADE DEFICIT AT 6-YEAR LOW
description: America's foreign trade deficit narrowed to $322 million in April, the closest the nation has come to a balance in merchandise trade since a one-month surplus more than six years ago, the Government reported today.

title: A.M.C. Workers To Defer Raises
description: About 5,200 American Motors Corporation salaried workers will defer 11 percent of their future wage increases and some vacation time over the next three years to help the No.5 American car maker pay for future product development, A.M.C. said today.

title: GETTY MUSEUM TO BUILD THREE NEW INSTITUTIONS
description: The Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., often thought to be the richest institution of its kind in the world, made it known yesterday that it intended to build and operate three new and separate institutions in the Los Angeles area. The ambitious multimillion dollar project will comprise a museum, a center for advanced studies in art history and a conservation institute equipped with everything that modern technology can make available to those whose duty it is to see that great works of art do not fall apart.

title: Britain Denies Afghan Charge On the Smuggling of Treasure
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that charges of treasure smuggling against a prominent British archeologist imprisoned in Afghanistan were ''absolute nonsense.''

title: Ship Fire Forces Evacuation
description: Fires and explosions aboard a 189-foot ship docked for repairs sent clouds of smoke and ammonia over parts of Seward Tuesday, forcing the evacuation of about 1,000 people from the harbor area and nearby schools. Firefighters decided to allow the blaze to burn itself out, and crews towed the freezer ship Westpro out of the harbor. No injuries were reported.

title: BUENOS AIRES TELLS OF GROUND ACTION
description: Argentina said tonight that its forces on the Falkland Islands had engaged British units operating from the British beachhead and had shot down two helicopters and damaged two others.

title: HAIG CANCELS A PITTSBURGH SPEECH TO ATTEND O.A.S. MEETING TODAY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today canceled plans to give a speech in Pittsburgh on Thursday in order to represent the United States at an emergency meeting of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States.

title: Hitachi Chip Capacity
description: Hitachi Ltd., a major maker of computer memory chips, said today that it would more than double its production capacity of 64K RAM, or random access memory, chips to 2.2 million a month by the end of this year. Half of Hitachi's production is exported, and the company said market demand was growing fast at home and abroad.

title: PROPOSAL FOR AID TO SALVADOR CUT BY SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, strongly criticizing El Salvador's recent moves to alter or delay key land redistribution programs, called today for a $100 million reduction in military aid proposed for that country.

title: CONGRESS VETOES F.T.C. RULES ON DISCLOSURE OF CAR DEFECTS
description: Congress vetoed proposed Federal rules today that would have required dealers to disclose major defects in used cars and state the extent of any outstanding warranties.

title: BRITAIN DECLARES RETAKING STANLEY IS NEXT OBJECTIVE
description: British troops are poised for a drive across East Falkland Island toward the Argentine garrison at Stanley despite the ''grievous'' loss of a destroyer and a merchant ship in air raids on Tuesday, Defense Secretary John Nott declared today.

title: ENDORSEMENT BY REAGAN HEATS UP JERSEY PRIMARY
description: President Reagan's only endorsement in the country in a 1982 primary race has transformed a Congressional campaign here.

title: STATEMENT OF U.N. HEAD TO COUNCIL
description: Following is the text of a statement to the Security Council by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar:

title: RECESSION AND HOUSING SLUMP FORCE APPLIANCE WORKERS INTO JOBLESS RANKS
