description: They are handing out 20 tons of free government surplus cheese at the electrical workers' union hall here, and for the laid-off General Electric Company appliance workers coming to get it, the charity has a bitter taste.

title: Chinese Rebuff Proposal To Ignore Taiwan Issue
description: The Chinese Communist Party newspaper today questioned the wisdom of maintaining ties with the United States while the Reagan Administration sells arms to Taiwan.

title: Meanwhile, in That Other War
description: You'd never know it at the United Nations, but the Falklands is not the world's only war. Much as Margaret Thatcher's Britain is slowly reversing the land grab by Argentina, Ayatollah Khomeini's Iran has been heaving back an invasion by Iraq, at vastly greater cost. You don't have to like the Ayatollah to welcome his military good fortune or the rebuff to the effort of Iraq's Saddam Hussein to shatter Iran.

title: U.S. NAVY WORRIED BY BRITISH ABSENCE FROM NORTH ATLANTIC
description: The prospect of a prolonged British naval deployment in the South Atlantic has begun to worry senior American naval officers who believe that it would lead to additional missions for the United States Navy in the North Atlantic, according to Defense Department officials.

title: ACID RAIN: COAL WASHING ISN'T NEARLY ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 More Banks Lower Prime
description: Two regional banks yesterday followed the lead of Citibank and reduced their prime lending rates.

title: News Analysis
description: In the Congressional debate over the Federal budget, which is on the House floor this week, the ''bottom line'' is the deficit: How much does Congress plan to borrow, rather than raise by taxes, to pay for the goods and services it wants to deliver to the voters?

title: Goodyear Layoffs
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said 111 more employees in its Earthmover division would be laid off indefinitely June 12. About 360 workers have been placed on layoff since the first of the year at the Topeka plant. Ray Cunningham, a Goodyear spokesman, said that the latest layoffs would affect workers who had been with the company as long as 14 years.

title: Montana Bank Fight Ends as Head Resigns
description: ''We're just going to let the dust settle for a while,'' Stephen Adams said yesterday. The dust he raised was in Montana, where Mr. Adams succeeded in ousting the president of the Bank of Montana System and taking firm control of the board.

title: Expos Defeat Astros in 10th
description: Charlie Lea held the Houston Astros to one hit in nine innings, retiring 26 of 27 batters, and the Montreal Expos went on to score a 4-0 victory in 10 innings tonight.

title: Garcia Balks At Paychecks
description: Damaso Garcia, the second baseman for the Toronto Blue Jays, will miss another paycheck Sunday.

title: Fisk Irks Umpires
description: Carlton Fisk of the White Sox, who had vigorously protested a called third strike in the eighth inning of tonight's 7-4 victory over the Royals, threw his bat into the dugout after the game in the direction of Umpire Nick Bremigan.

title: Tosco Dissidents Lose
description: The Tosco Corporation said today that its nominees for five contested board seats defeated those of a dissident group by a 5-to-3 margin, according to a preliminary count of shareholder votes cast at the oil refiner's annual meeting on May 11.

title: TWO DEMOCRATS IN ARKANSAS FACE A TOUGH RUNOFF JUNE 8
description: Bill Clinton, the 35-year-old former Governor of Arkansas who is trying to regain the office after his surprising defeat in 1980, faces a difficult runoff contest on June 8.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Fruit of the Loom Licensing named Robert M. Siegelo senior vice president-chief operating officer. * Kidde Inc. elected Richard R. Barnitt a senior vice president.

title: 80's BROWNSTONING: DIVIDE AND CONQUER
description: MOST apartment dwellers have, at one time or another, peered wistfully into the windows of well-kept brownstones and wondered what it would be like to live in a house in the city. The charm of rooms with high ceilings and architectural detailing and a small garden out back are obvious enough. But how, given today's real-estate prices and the scarcity of all types of housing in New York, is such graciousness affordable?

title: Military Analysis
description: The air-sea battles around the Falkland Islands have raised questions about NATO's naval balance in the North Atlantic as well as about the design and construction of the ships used to carry out British and United States naval strategy.

title: AMERICANS GET A FAILING GRADE IN GEOGRAPHY
description: The level of geographical literacy in the United States has been found ''appallingly low'' compared with that in other industrialized nations, according to a recent report by a panel of educators.

title: SCIENTISTS DIVIDED ON ACID RAIN ISSUE
description: A panel of scientists gave the Senate Environment Committee widely conflicting opinions Tuesday on whether enough is known about acid rain to justify action now to curb the pollution.

title: SYLVIA HANIKA LOSES IN PARIS
description: Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, the losing finalist at the French Open tennis tournament last year, was defeated today in her first appearance in the event this year.

title: A HELPING U.S. HAND IN IRAN'S WAR EFFORT
description: To the Editor:

title: ROSENBERG CASE LINKED TO BREAKING OF SOVIET CODE
description: A former official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation has asserted that the United States broke Soviet spy codes in the 1940's and that this led to knowledge of the involvement of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in an atomic espionage conspiracy, ABC News said yesterday.

title: REAGAN CONFIDENT G.O.P. WILL PREVAIL
description: President Reagan has made it clear in a series of political appearances in southern California that he expects Republican candidates to win in November even without a full recovery of the economy.

title: IRAQIS SAY BATTLES ARE CONTINUING
description: Iraq's military command reported continued fighting today around the Iranian city of Khurramshahr and said Iraqi troops had killed 238 Iranians.

title: SENATE'S CHAMPION COMMUTER
description: As a recent Senate Budget Committee meeting edged past 9:15 P.M., Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. picked up his jacket and briefcase and bolted for the exit. He was going home, not to Chevy Chase, Md., or McLean, Va., or one of the other Washington suburbs, but to Wilmington, Del., more than 100 miles away.

title: TRIP TO ARGENTINA IS SET BY THE POPE
description: Pope John Paul II will visit Argentina on June 11 and 12 after his trip to Britain, Government and Roman Catholic Church officials announced here today.

title: BANKERS CAUTIOUS ON FOREIGN LOANS
description: Many of the world's largest banks are cutting back on their international lending, especially to poorer countries, as a result of economic and political problems around the globe, according to bankers attending the International Monetary Conference here.

title: CANADA INCREASES WASHINGTON LOBBY EFFORTS
description: The Canadian Government, concerned about recent American decisions on environmental, energy and commercial issues, has increased its lobbying effort here with members of Congress.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 27, 1982
description: International British troops are poised for a drive across East Falkland Island toward Argentine forces in Stanley despite the loss of two ships in Tuesday's air strikes, Defense Minister John Nott announced. He said that 24 men had been killed aboard the two vessels and that about 25 had been wounded. Addressing a grim House of Commons, Mr. Nott said that the destroyer Coventry had capsized after being bombed and strafed and that the container ship Atlantic Conveyor, being used as a makeshift aircraft carrier, had been crippled by two Exocet missiles. (Page A1, Column 6.) The first report of key ground contact in the Falkland war was reported by Argentina's military command. It said its forces had engaged British units operating from their beachhead and had shot down two helicopters and damaged two. It was not clear which side had initiated the clash. (A21:1.)

title: THE DISCREET CHARM OF THE BROWNSTONE
description: ONE summer morning, long before I knew a lintel from a dentil from a dormer, I stood on a pretty Greenwich Village street with my college roommate, looking for a For Rent sign. We knew the Village (and New York) only through movies, and thought it a fine place for us to live.

title: DIVISION HEAD AT GENERAL ELECTRIC
description: James L. Lawson, a retired physicist and planner for the General Electric Company who contributed to the development of radar, nuclear-particle accelerators and electronics, died Tuesday at his home in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 66 years old.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: ANGRY WRITERS TALK OF FORMING A UNION
description: Some months ago the following half-page advertisement, outlined by a heavy black border, appeared in CODA, the Poets & Writers newsletter: Arthur A. Cohen joins with his readers in mourning the untimely death of his highly praised novel ACTS OF THEFT 1980 published (but hardly publicized) by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich now available at better remainder stores everywhere No flowers please Contributions to PEN or CODA appreciated

title: PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM READY TO PICK MISS d'HARNONCOURT
description: Anne d'Harnoncourt, curator of 20th-century paintings at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, is expected to be named the museum's director by the board of trustees at a meeting Thursday. She would replace Jean Sutherland Boggs, who resigned to oversee construction of two museums in Ottawa.

title: TV DEVICES LIMIT CHILDREN'S VIEWING
description: IN the past, parents seeking to control their children's television viewing habits at all times had to resort to hiring a strict baby sitter or removing the picture tube. But today new electronic devices may offer parents fine-tuned control over their television sets -even when they are not at home.

title: The House vs. the Poor
description: Two dense clouds hang over the House of Representatives this morning as it reaches the finals of its endless budget tournament.

title: Opposition Coalition Calls on Marcos to Quit
description: A recently formed coalition of opposition leaders vowed today to boycott elections until President Ferdinand E. Marcos steps down.

title: CONCERT: MOZART-STRAVINSKY
description: THE first concert last night in Avery Fisher Hall of the New York Philharmonic's ''Mozart-Stravinsky Spring Series,'' as it is prosaically but accurately entitled, might have seem cursed. Last week, the original conductor, Rafael Kubelik, canceled because of illnesss, and this week, Jon Garrison, the tenor soloist, bowed out for the same reason.

title: Ousted Polish Leader Named to State Council
description: Stanislaw Kania, who was ousted as Communist Party leader during the growth of the independent labor movement, was named today to the Council of State.

title: Wishing Reagan Well
description: The Rev. Benjamin L. Hooks, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, is no fan of some of President Reagan's policies, but he likes Mr. Reagan just fine.

title: G.& W. to Shut Mine
description: Gulf and Western Industries said today that it would close its Jefferson City, Tenn., underground zinc mine on Friday for an undisclosed period.

title: Reagan's Pick for Paraguay
description: President Reagan announced today that he intends to nominate Arthur H. Davis Jr. of Golden, Colo., to be Ambassador to Paraguay.

title: Dow Off 5.8 in Broad Selling
description: A broad stock market retreat accelerated yesterday as investors apparently remained skeptical about the prospects for a sustained rebound from the recession.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: MEDICAL AID FOR BABIES BACKED
description: Calling it a statement ''in favor of life,'' a bipartisan group of Congressmen introduced legislation today that would prohibit the denial of food and treatment to handicapped babies.

title: UNLIKELY 'MANILA CONNECTION' IN TWO KILLINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Jury to Examine L.S.U. Athletic Funding
description: A special grand jury will investigate the financial problems of Louisiana State University's athletic department.

title: HEALTH CHAIN ACCUSED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Quality Care Inc., a health care service company in Rockville Centre. L.I., of selling fradulent franchise agreements to investors to finance its rapidly expanding private nursing home business.

title: SUMMITS: ARMS VS. IDEAS
description: -National security adviser William Clark said the coming NATO summit meeting would produce ''a strong reaffirmation of alliance unity, vitality and resolve.'' But from the Versailles economic conference a few days before, Mr. Clark expects only an ''atmosphere of realism'' and some ''new thinking.''

title: GOODBYE TO ALL THAT
description: When British forces went ashore in San Carlos Bay, many Americans must have found themselves caught up as I was in oldfashioned emotions and hopes of war. A daring landing 8,000 miles from home had succeeded. The Falklands affair might end, it seemed, by teaching a lesson to Argentina's loathsome rulers and would-be aggressors everywhere.

title: Conoco Well Cost
description: Conoco Inc. said that the well it began drilling May 13 in the Georges Bank area off Massachusetts would cost about $15 million and take two to three months to reach a target depth of 12,000 feet. Conoco, a unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said it had 30 percent of the well in Block 145. Exxon has 25 percent, Diamond Shamrock 12.5 percent, Gulf Oil 12.5 percent, Getty Oil 10 percent and the Sun Company 10 percent.

title: CHAD BELIEVED TO SEEK CLOSER LIBYA TIES
description: Threatened by rebel forces and under mounting African pressure to reach an accommodation with his enemies, President Goukouni Oueddei of Chad is apparently seeking a rapprochement with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Plans a Benefit Auction
description: A pair of Natalia Makarova's toe shoes and dinner for two with the principal dancers Virginia Johnson and Lowell Smith are among the items to be sold at an auction-and-performance festival by the Dance Theater of Harlem on June 5 in Aaron Davis Hall of City College, West 135th Street and Convent Avenue.

title: HOUSE PICKS THROUGH VARIATIONS ON THREE BUDGETS
description: ''The irony is that everybody is in the same ballpark,'' Representative James R. Jones, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said today. ''But it's a big playing field, and there are some significant differences.''

title: Market Place; Phibro Draws Bulls and Bears
description: Big mergers are always news on Wall Street, but a consolidation that took place last Oct. 1 particularly captured the attention of the investment community. Quite simply, never before had there been a merger quite like this one.

title: Banking on Vanity and Genes
description: A California sperm bank has announced its first birth, a child born last month after her mother was inseminated with sperm from an ''eminent mathematician.'' The bank, which accepts deposits from Nobel Prize winners, was founded as ''a means of breeding higher intelligence.'' Recipients who buy for that reason should realize they are chasing a chimera.

title: ROYAL SAUDI FAMILY IN MIAMI SHOWS IT HAS A GIFT FOR GIVING
description: Elvis Presley used to buy Cadillacs for perfect strangers. This indulgence titillated the less than well-to-do, who found it hard to fathom wealth so great that the possessor thought little of squandering handsome figures higgledy-piggledy. But compared with what is going on now in Miami, Mr. Presley's presents were peanuts.

title: SCIENTISTS MOLD INDUSTRY AT BIG BELL LABORITORIES
description: In the solitude of their cells, with their theories and complex instruments, the scientists at Bell Laboratories often work in a kind of blissful myopia. Almost nothing can spoil what the author W.I.B. Beveridge called the ''great sense of well-being and satisfaction'' that comes from ''the thrill of discovery.''

title: CALIFORNIA HISPANIC CANDIDATE STRESSING ETHNICITY IN CAMPAIGN
description: Mario Obledo frankly explains that he built his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor of California on his Hispanic background.

title: 76ERS SILENT ON PLANS FOR LAKERS
description: Billy Cunningham, the coach of the Philadelphia 76ers, refused today to tell how his team would defend against the Los Angeles Lakers in the opener of the National Basketball Association finals Thursday night.

title: MOON INVOKES 5TH AMENDMENT IN U.S. CIVIL TRIAL
description: Under the threat of jail or a fine, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon answered scores of questions about the Unification Church yesterday, but invoked the Fifth Amendment against self-incrimination nine times on questions about his yacht, residences and commercial ventures and some of the sexual doctrines of his church.

title: G.D. Searle Plant
description: G.D. Searle & Company, the developer and marketer of pharmaceutical and medical products, announced that it had opened a $15 million biological development pilot plant for the study and production of genetically engineered substances at its research and development complex in High Wycombe, England. Searle said that the plant is designed specifically to introduce potential products using recombinant DNA technology for commercial use directly from the laboratory.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. received a contract from Combustion Engineering Inc.'s C-E Lummus unit to supply 16 large compressors to the Great Plains coal gasification project.

title: Two Cities in California Reject Evacuation Plan
description: Governmental bodies here and in nearby San Jose have voted against taking part in Federal contingency plans calling for mass evacuation in case of a nuclear attack.

title: Sale by Beatrice Foods
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said today that it had agreed in principle to sell its Kelley Manufacturing subsidiary to the company's management. Terms were not disclosed. Kelley is expected to have sales of $10 million this year, Beatrice said.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SABBATICAL: A Romance. By John Barth. 366 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: Borg-Warner Bid
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said it had received 91.1 percent of Burns Internatinal Securities Services class A common stock in a tender offer that expired yesterday.

title: Estes' Son Gets 3 Years in Jail
description: Thomas P. Estes, son of the former president of the General Motors Corporation, Elliot Estes, was sentenced to three years in a Federal prison today on charges of making false statements to obtain $900,000 in loans.

title: Club's White-Only Policy Termed Legal in Alabama
description: The Rotary Club in this city, where a majority of residents are black, can legally bar nonwhite members because it is a private club, the State Attorney General's office said today.

title: SERVICES THAT CAN DRESS UP YOUR PARTY
description: EVEN the most imaginative hosts and hostesses sometimes lack the time, accessories or taste to create the look they want in party table settings, centerpieces and other trimmings.

title: GLASS CREATIONS WITH EXUBERANCE
description: A refreshing sense of freedom prevails in the group exhibit at Glassmaster's Guild, which opened Sunday and will run through June 16.

title: GEORGE DUGAN, EX-EDITOR, 72
description: George Dugan, who had been religion news editor and a reporter for The New York Times for 31 years until his retirement in 1978, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 72 years old and a resident of Hillsdale, N.J.

title: K.G.B. CHIEF QUITS FOR HIGHER DUTIES
description: Yuri V. Andropov stepped down today as head of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal-security organization, two days after being appointed to a senior position in the Communist Party secretariat.

title: THE SOVIET UNION AS A TOURIST ATTRACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL TO AID THRIFT UNITS FACES ACCOUNTING SNAG
description: In an opinion that could mean another blow to the beleaguered thrift industry, a Treasury official said today that a House-passed bill designed to rescue savings and loan institutions might be useless because it did not comply with generally accepted accounting principles.

title: Hanover's Loss From Drysdale
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation disclosed yesterday that its bank subsidiary, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, had lost about $9 million as a result of securities transactions with Drysdale Government Securities.

title: Northwest Air Lays Off 1,200 Flight Attendants
description: Northwest Airlines, whose mechanics and baggage handlers are on strike, today laid off more than 1,200 nonstriking flight attendants.

title: CONCERT: MAHLER'S FIFTH BY ISRAEL PHILHARMONIC
description: THE last time this reviewer heard Zubin Mehta and the Israel Philharmonic play Mahler's Symphony No. 5 was three years ago in Washington, shortly after Mr. Mehta had taken over as the orchestra's music director. On that occasion, the Israelis did not have the wind and the brass sections to pull it off. The good news about last night's performance of the piece at Carnegie Hall was that now they do.

title: A JAZZ TRIO: MICHEL LEGRAND
description: If Michel Legrand were not an extremely successful composer of film scores and popular songs (''The Windmills of Your Mind,'' ''What Are You Doing the Rest of Your Life,'' ''Watch What Happens''), he could probably be doing equally as well as a jazz pianist or as a cabaret entertainer.

title: No Headline
description: The Burroughs Corporation of Detroit yesterday announced the election of Paul G. Stern, 43 years old, as president and chief operating officer. Thus, W. Michael Blumenthal, 56, chairman and chief executive officer, has completed the key management changes that he began when he took over the computer company 18 months ago.

title: JOHN WEITZ'S DESIGN FOR LIVING
description: THE 25 manufacturers in this country who produce merchandise labeled John Weitz are mostly in the men's fashion field. So are the almost equally large number of producers in Japan. But Mr. Weitz frequently has ideas about design in nonfashion areas. He took 35 of those notions, in such areas as bathtubs, car tires and restaurant menus, sketched them and built a display around them. For his own birthday party, he invited 40 friends to lunch at the Four Seasons Wednesday to view his ideas and asked 230 people to see them at the cocktail hour. Mr. Weitz was 59 years old.

title: VICTORIAN VIGNETTES
description: It is a mixture, but a pretty grand one at that. "People don't always understand," said Herve Aaron, president of Didier Aaron, the prominent antiques concern, of his current show.

title: PHILIP MORRIS DEAL IS OPPOSED
description: The investment by Philip Morris Inc. in Rothmans International, a British tobacco company, has run into trouble in the European Economic Community.

title: Newsweek Shifts Account
description: Newsweek magazine is moving its advertising account out of Foote, Cone & Belding after a seven-year relationship. The domestic advertising budget last year was almost $3 million, according to Leading National Advertisers.

title: Guy Lombardo's Widow Dies
description: Lilliebell Lombardo, the widow of Guy Lombardo, the band leader, died yesterday in Deepdale General Hospital in Little Neck, Queens. Mrs. Lombardo, who was a resident of Freeport, L.I., was 82 years old. Mr. Lombardo died in 1977.

title: G.O.P BROCHURE GETS FACE LIFT, LITERALLY
description: After run-ins with with such powerful personages as Ronald Reagan and Darth Vader, the Senate Republican fund raisers are test-marketing a newly revised campaign brochure.

title: WITNESS CONCEDES LYING BY HINCKLEY
description: In the most dramatic cross-examination since the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. began April 27, a defense psychiatrist reversed himself today and conceded that the defendant had apparently lied to him about how he had loaded his pistol the day he shot President Reagan.

title: POLAND SOUNDS OUT CREDITORS
description: Two senior officials of Bank Handlowy, Poland's foreign trade bank, yesterday completed three days of informal talks in New York with American bankers regarding the rescheduling of Poland's large debts.

title: A Sight Problem
description: Not long after a rare neurological disorder cost them the services of Jim Eisenreich, the Minnesota Twins are now worried about Dave Engle, another of their young outfielders. When Engle was a child, the pupil of his right eye was damaged in an accident, and he believes the resulting scar may be the reason why he is having trouble seeing fly balls hit directly at him in the Metrodome, the Twins' new indoor stadium.

title: IF FIRST IT'S TRIED IN NATAL-ZULULAND...
description: -Many solutions have been proposed for the South African problem but little progress has been made. Hence, it is not unreasonable to be skeptical about one of the most recent proposals, too: the Buthelezi Commission's plan for a multiracial democratic government in Natal, one of the four provinces. Yet this proposal deserves serious consideration for two reasons.

title: WEST POINT CLASS WARNED BY TOWER
description: John G. Tower, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, warned the graduating class of the United States Military Academy today that ''a decade of complacency'' had significantly eroded the nation's military posture in comparison with against that of the Soviet Union.

title: Ad Club Reschedules Annual Awards Dinner
description: Because of a conflicting advertising industry event, the Advertising Club of New York has rescheduled its annual Andy Awards dinner to June 21 from June 3.

title: AMERICAN ALLY NO.1
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 L.I. Men Are Accused Of Ethnic Harassment
description: Two residents of Kings Point, L.I., were charged yesterday with painting swastikas and anti-Semitic epithets on the garage door of a neighbor and with planting a voodoo doll bearing a Star of David on the neighbor's lawn.

title: TRAFFIC OUTLOOK: SMOOTH SUMMER, BUT TROUBLE DOWN THE ROAD
description: As New Yorkers take to the roads for their first long weekend of the season, they are likely to encounter fewer traffic bottlenecks than on Memorial Days past.

title: COVERS UP
description: Millions of feet trample them and thousands of wheels ride over them each day, yet they never gain attention until they blow sky-high in a freak accident. Yet they have caught the eye of an artistphotographer, Hertha Bauer, whose ''Mostly Manhole Covers of Manhattan'' displays about 100 of them in the Community Gallery, at 30 East 35th Street (683-4988).

title: DOCUMENTARY BY CBS ON VIETNAM QUESTIONED
description: At least two key figures in a recent CBS News documentary that said there had been a conspiracy by the United States military to cover up critical intelligence about the size of enemy forces during the Vietnam War said yesterday that considerable evidence contradicting the program's thesis had been excluded or ignored by CBS News.

title: Father of a Vietnam Casualty Found Not Guilty in Shooting
description: A man whose only son died in Vietnam was found not guilty today of killing a 13-year-old boy who came to his door trick-or-treating on Halloween wearing Army fatigues and carrying a toy machine gun.

title: Construction Value Down
description: The recession in construction markets deepened in April, with the value of new construction down 16 percent from the month before, according to a company that monitors construction.

title: ISRAELIS' ANXIETIES
description: To the Editor:

title: CASINOS BUYING VIDEO GAMES AS DEALERS AND SLOT MACHINES
description: Video games are moving out of the penny arcades and into casinos, where some day it is expected that the beeping, flashing television screens will be as common as the clanking slot machines of today.

title: DOWN ON FARM IN CHINA, FACTORIES ARE SPROUTING
description: A group of young women chatted as they sliced apart the newly printed pages of an engineering journal with schoolroom rulers, oblivious to the clatter of printing presses that spewed forth instruction manuals for an electric fan.

title: Dancers Set a Series To Push Disarmament
description: Dancers for Disarmament will present a series of performances and workshops featuring 30 dance companies and soloists from next Thursday through June 6 at the Public School 122 arts complex, 150 First Avenue at Ninth Street.

title: 'DON'S PARTY,' FROM AUSTRAILIA
description: BRUCE BERESFORD'S ''Don's Party,'' an Australian comedy adapted by David Williamson from his well made play, is a well made film that, although it contains some sharp characterizations, a number of funny lines and one uproarious confrontation scene, never disguises its carefully schematized origins.

title: Baseball a 'Fun Game'
description: Bill Buckner, the Chicago Cubs first baseman who was involved in a scuffle with his manager, Lee Elia, on Monday, returned to the lineup last night and said the incident was part of what makes baseball ''such a fun game.'' Buckner said he had ''had scraps with managers before, but this one happened out where everyone could see it.''

title: An Argentine Captive Being Sent to Britain
description: The commander of the Argentine garrison on South Georgia island when it was recaptured by British forces is to be brought to Britain.

title: REACTION TO NEW ISSUES MIXED
description: A flurry of new issue activity in the corporate bond market met with mixed results yesterday, investment bankers said. Among the new issues announced for sale today were $400 million of the World Bank's 14 3/4 percent, 10-year bonds that were increased from $250 million and priced at 100 by the First Boston Corporation and $225 million of the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation's 15 1/4 percent, 10-year bonds that were increased from $150 million and priced at 99 1/4 to yield 15.4 percent by Salomon Brothers.

title: PARLEY WARY OF CHALLENGE TO EINSTEIN THEORY
description: Specialists in relativity, convened yesterday by the New York Academy of Sciences to comment on a recent challenge to Einstein's general theory of relativity, were cautious in their assessments.

title: BUSINESSMAN SAYS DONOVAN GOT INSIDE DATA ON HIGHWAY PROJECTS
description: A New Jersey businessman said yesterday that he believed Raymond J. Donovan, now the United States Secretary of Labor, was receiving inside information during the 1960's that enabled Mr. Donovan's construction company to win millions of dollars in New Jersey highway contracts.

title: Ex-Umpire's Problems
description: Steve Fields, whom the National League hired as a replacement when the major leagues' umpires struck briefly in 1979, says he'll file a $1 million suit against the league this week as a result of his dismissal last fall. That dismissal was only the culmination of Fields's problems, which really began as soon as the umpires' strike was settled.

title: Heroin Is Seized; 3 Canadians Held
description: Three Canadians were arrested at the New York Statler Hotel yesterday when, according to the police, they sold 4.4 pounds of heroin to an undercover member of the narcotics division for $525,000.

title: Albert A. Lappin, 84, Is Dead; Ex-Head of Goodyear Rubber
description: Albert A. Lappin, former president and chairman of the board of the Goodyear Rubber Company, died today at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 84 years old.

title: Advertising; Frequency Of Blacks In TV Ads
description: If TV commercials using black actors and actresses have a positive effect on black consumers, while not having a negative effect on white consumers, it would be natural for big national advertisers to use such advertising in heavily black markets.

title: Airbus Industrie
description: Air India signed a firm order for three Airbus Industrie A300B4-200 aircraft and spares, worth $200 million, Airbus said.

title: Lawyer Says Tests Suggest Dump Is Leaking Chemicals
description: Soil contaminated by hazardous substances has been detected in two drainage ditches near a landfill that had been used as a chemical dump, according to a lawyer for several families in this upstate community.

title: GYPSY MOTH LARVA CAN CAUSE A RASH
description: Gypsy moth caterpillars not only consume the leaves from millions of acres of forest, but they can also give people a rash, The New England Journal of Medicine reported today.

title: Stevens Jumps 83% in Quarter
description: J.P. Stevens & Company reported yesterday that net income for the quarter ended May 1 jumped 83 percent, to $5 million, or 35 cents a share, from $2.8 million, or 19 cents a share, for the same period last year. Sales, however, fell to $472 million, compared with $510.8 million last year.

title: FRACNCHISING INSURANCE FIRMS
description: Rick Armstrong, a property and casualty insurance broker with Milum & Associates in Newport Beach, Calif., has been in the business for more than 10 years. But about a year and a half ago, his firm bought a franchise from Insurance Systems Unlimited, and now the franchiser's name and logotype appear along with Milum's in all of its materials.

title: LABOR UNIT URGES REAGAN TO ACT ON INTEREST RATES
description: Asserting that its members could see no signs of an end to the recession, the executive council of the A.F.L.- C.I.O. urged President Reagan today to use the Credit Control Act to force a lowering of interest rates.

title: FILIBUSTER GOES ON
description: The Senate refused today to kill a $5.2 billion housing measure designed to create 700,000 jobs and 400,000 housing units.

title: TOXIC WASTE ENTREPRENEUR
description: Dressed in gray flannel slacks and a blue blazer, Russell W. Mahler, 56 years old, looked more like the judge's peer than a prospective convict. But Mr. Mahler, a tall, distinguished-looking Cornell graduate, pleaded guilty last month to conspiracy and risking an environmental catastrophe in Pennsylvania.

title: MARIJUANA LINKED TO SALMONELLOSIS
description: Researchers have discovered that contaminated marijuana can cause an illness usually identified as food poisoning. They attribute a nationwide outbreak last year of salmonellosis, usually caused by tainted food, to tainted marijuana.

title: K Mart Planning $2 Billion Outlay
description: The K Mart Corporation will invest more than $2 billion in new stores and equipment through 1986, despite declining profits in the last 10 quarters, its chairman, Bernard Fauber, said.

title: Father's Leave Hinges on His Being Pregant
description: The first policeman in Buffalo ever to seek maternity leave is Lieut. Timothy Scioli, who maintains he is entitled to the leave because his life will be disrupted as much as his wife's when she gives birth in a few days.

title: HERS
description: IAM 8 or 9 years old, and my brother's friend Phil is sleeping over. Phil is as tall as a tree, with huge feet and hands and a prematurely deep voice that make him seem, at 13, almost like a grown man. Like my brother, Phil loves rock music. He wants to buy a motorcycle. He dresses like a slob. He is my dream man.

title: 15 Die in South-West Africa
description: West Africa, May 26 (UPI) - A head-on collision between a truck and an army vehicle killed 15 tribesmen on Tuesday, an army spokesman said today. The tribesmen were in the truck on their way from an army base to Nkurenkuro.

title: TEXT OF THE U.N. RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of the resolution approved unanimously today by the Security Council:

title: SOVIET IMPORTS OF GRAIN FROM ARGENTINA PUT OFF
description: The Soviet Union has postponed half of its June purchase of Argentine grain, according to shipping and grain officials here.

title: BOXING OPINIONS
description: AT the time, Sugar Ray Leonard was developing into a welterweight contender. He was in Miami Beach early in 1979 for a fight with Fernand Marcotte and he was talking to Dr. Ferdie Pacheco, who had been ostracized by Muhammad Ali's entourage. For more than two years, Ali's one-time physician had been saying that Ali, then the heavyweight champion, shouldn't be fighting.

title: R.O.T.C. ROLE IN HIGH SCHOOLS DEBATED
description: The science classes that met on the fourth floor of Julia Richman High School yesterday morning were like any other in New York City's public school system, except for a few things - most of the students wore Navy uniforms and they addressed the teacher as ''commander.'' And the science was military.

title: TOYS 'R' US AND SYNTEX CLIMB
description: Litton Industries reported yesterday that its net income for the quarter ended April 30 dropped 13 percent, to $77.4 million, or $1.89 a share, from $89.1 million, or $2.18 a share, for the same period last year. The figures for last year's quarter, however, reflect a gain of $6 million from the sale of a publishing subsidiary.

title: Severe Kidney Disease Called Higher in Blacks
description: Black Americans were found to be four times as likely as whites to suffer severe kidney disease requiring the victim to undergo dialysis or transplant, a study from Alabama said today.

title: Papp, Vietnam-Bound, to Aid Veterans
description: He is on his way to Vietnam with a special veterans delegation that will try to trace missing American servicemen and study the effects of the defoliant Agent Orange. But wherever he is and whatever he is doing, Joseph Papp is always an impresario.

title: RADIO STATION CITED IN AIRING TAPE FROM TRIAL
description: The manager of a Spokane radio and television station was found in contempt of court today for broadcasting tape-recorded conversations between the defendant in a murder-forhire trial and a police officer posing as an assassin.

title: Dance Festival at Kitchen
description: ''Dancing in the Kitchen,'' a festival of dances by choreographers whose work has been performed at the avant-garde center between 1978 and 1982, will take place from next Thursday through June 8 at the Kitchen, 484 Broome Street. Twenty-eight choreographers will be featured in six programs, which begin at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $5; $20 for the series. Information: 925-3615.

title: S.& P. OUTLOOK LISTS 'STOCKS TO AVOID'
description: Because Wall Street is generally more inclined to tell investors when to buy stocks than when to sell them, the current issue of The Outlook, a newsletter of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, is expected to catch attention.

title: International
description: The U.S. foreign trade deficit narrowed to $322 million in April, the closest the nation has come to a balance in merchandise trade since a one-month surplus more than six years ago. Economists were cautious in their assessment, with one saying that the April result might be a ''fluke.'' (Page D1.)

title: Text of resolution, page A20.
description: A unanimous Security Council asked the Secretary General today to revive his peacemaking role in the Falkland Islands crisis and report back in seven days. Javier Perez de Cuellar, however, told the Council its instructions were too vague to be helpful.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ABASEMENT that gets damp or wet after every rainy period is virtually useless. Since it may represent a substantial part of the total inside area, it is almost always worthwhile to seal it permanently. It can provide extra space and will increase the value of the house.

title: COURT SETS BACK MOVE TO CONTROL 42D ST. ARCADE
description: An appeals court has ruled that New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs does not have authority either to regulate the hours during which a 42d Street amusement arcade may remain open or to require its owner to carry liability insurance.

title: A COLT NAMED VICTORIOUS IS ONE TO WATCH
description: Until 2-year-old thoroughbreds make their first start, they are all equal, potentially either champions or perpetual losers. There is no way of knowing which ones will do well, but with a few there is special reason to hope.

title: MIDDLE EAST
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s address before the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, as released by the State Department:

title: ARRAY OF SHOWS AND COURSES IN DESIGN
description: Rhode Island School of Design Textile Show, Chuck Levitan Gallery, 42 Grand Street (at Thompson), 966- 2782.

title: ABC Adds New Slots; For Commentary Ads
description: Not only will the ABC-TV Network sell time for advocacy advertising in the late night area of programming, from midnight to 1 A.M., as it has offered during its test period, but also from 6 A.M. to 7 A.M. each weekday.

title: Mobil Wins Florida Suit
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said yesterday that a Florida state court had ruled that Mobil's claim to 4,000 acres of phosphate mines in Polk County was superior to claims by the Coastal Petroleum Company. Judge Oliver L. Green of the circuit court for Polk County ruled that Mobil's title came before and was superior to any interest of Coastal under a state lease.

title: BILL GOES TO CAREY
description: The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would raise New York's legal drinking age from 18 to 19. The vote was 105 to 8.

title: S.I. Man Sentenced to Prison For $4 Million Customs Theft
description: A Staten Island man was sentenced today to five years in prison and fined $10,000 for his role in two schemes that bilked the United States Customs Service out of more than $4 million in import duties.

title: Busboy Accused Of Arson at Hotel
description: A 20-year-old busboy at the Marriott Hotel here has been charged with arson for having twice thrown burning bedsheets down the hotel's laundry chute, the police said today.

title: DOES YIDDISH TRANSLATE? AN ANSWER WITH MUSIC
description: As in much Yiddish conversation, there is a question - one question? No, many questions! - raised by the opening of ''Vagabond Stars,'' a new English-language musical drawn from turn-of-thecentury Yiddish theater, at the Jewish Repertory Theater tomorrow night.

title: Tall Tale
description: A short long-and-short-of-it story: At Le Club yesterday, Milton Goldman, an executive of ICM Inc., the theatrical agency, gave a lunch for the agency's 21 clients who have been nominated for Antoinette Perry Awards.

title: E. Don Tull is Dead at 75; Executive of Diesel Company
description: E. Don Tull, who worked his way up from the production line to the presidency of the world's largest independent producer of diesel engines, died Tuesday. He was 75 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 16.00 16.00 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.60 13.27 17.32 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.60 11.55 15.30 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.71 11.70 14.27 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 13.81 13.76 13.76 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.34 13.26 13.11 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.72 15.64 14.88 MUNCIPAL BONDS 13.19 13.15 11.31 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.470 CERTIFICATE** * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Stocks Retreat; Dow Off 3.81
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday in the face of continuing negative factors such as high interest rates, a Federal budget impasse at home and intensifying wars abroad. ''The psychology in Wall Street,'' summed up John R. Groome of the United States Trust Company, ''is just terrible.''

title: Alabama Officers Freed Of Torture Charges
description: An all-white Federal jury, which first tried to return a verdict of 11 to 1 for acquittal, changed its vote to 12 to 0 and found five officers on the Bessemer police force not guilty of torturing black prisoners.

title: THE MUSIC OF JAVA AT MUSEUM
description: DEBUSSY first heard a gamelan in 1889 at the Paris World Exhibition, and it profoundly influenced his ideas about sound. Today they can be found at several American universities. In Java, where they have existed in their present form since the 16th century, they are believed to possess kasekten, a supernatural power, and they receive regular offerings of incense and flowers and are often given names.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: When Shirley Horn arrived in New York from Washington 20 years ago to play jazz piano and sing at the Village Vanguard, she was sponsored by Miles Davis, discovered and recorded by Quincy Jones and hailed by Sidney Poitier.

title: Graham Says Soviet Trip Increased His Crowds
description: Billy Graham, the evangelist, said today he had ''no apologies to make'' over his trip to the Soviet Union, but he acknowledged that ''some of the criticism may be justified''

title: U.S. INSISTING SALVADOR PURSUE LAND PROGRAM
description: The Reagan Administration warned El Salvador today that the United States was insisting on further progress in its land redistribution program and on the curbing of ''abuses'' by Salvadoran security forces.

title: CEDELL DAVIS OFFERING DELTA BLUES TRADITION
description: Although the history of the generation of guitarists of the Mississippi Delta who brought the blues north to Chicago in the 1940's has often been told, many of the musicians who stayed in the South to carry on the blues tradition are only now being discovered by historians and blues aficionados. CeDell Davis, the singer-guitarist who will make his New York debut tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street, is a perfect case in point.

title: Ex-Sun Chemical Head Reports New Venture
description: When Edward E. Barr resigned last week as president and chief operating officer of the Sun Chemical Corporation, the company and Mr. Barr would say only that he planned to pursue other business interests.

title: Maltbie Leads by Shot on 68
description: Roger Maltbie took the lead late today in the weather-delayed Memorial Tournament with a four-under-par 68 at Jack Nicklaus's Muirfield Village Golf Club.

title: ARGENTINE AIR FORCE IS EMERGING AS A KEY FACTOR
description: The Argentine Air Force, which was lukewarm to the invasion of the Falkland Islands two months ago, has emerged as a determined and central element in holding off the British effort to retake the archipelago.

title: DECISION ON SUGAR IS DELAYED
description: Domestic sugar refiners failed yesterday to get a preliminary injunction against the reimposition of sugar import quotas proclaimed by President Reagan on May 5.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Sympathy For the Israelis Has Increased
description: Israel's withdrawal from Sinai on April 25 came at a time when there was greater sympathy for Israel in the United States than there had been for almost a decade, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some editions yesterday, a review of the opening program of the New York Philharmonic's Mozart-Stravinsky Spring Series misidentified the tenor in ''Les Noces.'' He was John Gilmore.

title: Plessey Income Up by 51.8%
description: The Plessey Company announced yesterday that strong gains by its telecommunications operations helped raise net income in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year, ended April 2, 51.8 percent, to $37.8 million, or $1.56 per American depositary receipt, from $24.9 million, or $1.04 per A.D.R. in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. An A.D.R., which represents stocks of foreign companies, is equal to 10 ordinary shares.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM PLANS A MAJOR RESTRUCTURING
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that its board was studying a plan to restructure the company in a fundamental way. If accepted, the proposal would result in the partial liquidation of some of Tesoro's operations and the formation of two new companies to handle the remainder of its business.

title: HANA MANDLIKOVA ADVANCES
description: Betty Stove, 36 years old and still serving, has been devoting most of her time over the last two years to coaching Hana Mandlikova. So it was with some anguish today that she endeavored unsuccessfully to defeat her pupil in the French Open tennis tournament.

title: U.S. TRADE REACTION MIXED
description: Reagan Administration officials praised Japan today for announcing a broad set of trade liberalization measures, but they cautioned that many American and European objections to Japanese trade barriers remained to be resolved.

title: ONCE AGAIN A MEXICAN LEADER TILTS AT CORRUPTION
description: Six years ago, while campaigning for office, President Jose Lopez Portillo described corruption as ''a cancer'' eating away at Mexican society and he renewed the pledge of many of his predecessors to attack the problem.

title: Clock Gains in Big East
description: Big East Conference basketball coaches today voted to recommend that a 45-second shot clock be used for the first time next season except for the last five minutes of games.

title: DIOCESE ON L.I., NOW 25, REDEDICATES CATHEDRAL
description: With bells tolling in the spire, Bishop John R. McGann today marked the 25th anniversary of the Diocese of Rockville Centre by rededicating the refurbished St. Agnes Cathedral.

title: Court Orders N.C.A.A.  To Give File to Paper
description: The Kansas Supreme Court today said the National Collegiate Athletic Association must give The Birmingham (Ala.)

title: LIBRARY'S FRIENDS LAUGH (OUT LOUD) FOR MONEY
description: The tone of the second annual literary lunch yesterday of the Friends of the New York Public Library was set by the writer Fran Lebowitz. Upon entering the vast, blocklong South Reading Room, with its Italianate gilt ceiling, Miss Lebowitz looked around and advised, ''You'd better hurry - this place is going co-op.''

title: 'CURE' FOR SUBWAY TUBING CHALLENGED
description: The Fire Department has determined that a fire-retardant coating proposed for potentially hazardous plastic electrical tubing used in subway station public-address systems is of ''limited value.''

title: MORE WOMEN HAVING FIRST CHILD IN 30's
description: The number of well-educated American women having their first child during their 30's rose dramatically in the 1970's. The rise was due in part to the desire of increasing numbers of women to complete their education and establish their careers before beginning a family.

title: Interest in Rentex
description: Sketchley P.L.C. said today that it had entered into a preliminary agreement with certain shareholders of the Rentex Services Corporation to buy 61.5 percent of Rentex's issued shares at $13 each, or a total of $13.6 million. Rentex is based in Mount Laurel, N.J.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''U.S. material support for Britain is illegal and repugnant to the inter-American defense treaty. The future of the inter-American relationship is under threat.'' - Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez of Argentina. (A8:6)

title: SENATE PANEL ENDORSES McMAHON AS C.I.A. DEPUTY
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence voted unanimously today to approve John N. McMahon as Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.

title: BALLET: 2 APPROACHES TO KITRI IN 'QUIXOTE'
description: ''DON QUIXOTE'' was very merry indeed when it was presented at the American Ballet Theater's Wednesday matinee and evening performances at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mikhail Baryshnikov's current streamlined version of Marius Petipa's classic is the most successful of his attempts to make this 19th-century comedy convincing. If some plot complications have been cut away, there is just enough plot left so that the production does not become an unrelieved, and therefore monotonous, suite of dances. The result resembles an operetta. You know it's silly, yet you still find it captivating.

title: Purchase by MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said that it had signed a contract to buy two office buildings on nine acres of land in Arlington, Va., for $68.5 million from Rose Associates, a New York real estate developer. Company headquarters would remain in Washington, the company said.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe West, a 220-pound National League umpire, was on his way to work the Cubs-Padres game in San Diego when he saw a police officer chasing a theft suspect. He tackled the suspect, held him for the officer and went on to the ballpark. ... Bill Rogers, Craig Stadler and Bob Rosburg will be inducted into the All-American Collegiate Golf Hall of Fame at a dinner in Manhattan June 22. ... Roberto Cabanas, the Cosmos midfielder who has been sidelined with cracked veterbrae since last year's playoffs, will return to the lineup for tomorrow's game against Nacional of Uruguay in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup tournament.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 28, 1982
description: International Britain opened an offensive from its beachhead at San Carlos Bay against the Argentine troops in the Falklands, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced in the House of Commons. Unofficial reports in London said that paratroopers were moving south toward the Darwin area and that marines were advancing east toward Stanley, the main island settlement. (Page A1, Column 1.) Argentina reported ground clashes and a series of British air raids on the Falklands and said that one British plane had been shot down. (A9:1-4.)

title: Sohio Is High Bidder in Alaska
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and its majority owner, the British Petroleum Company, jointly submitted the highest bid in a state and Federal sale of Alaskan oil leases.

title: Mariners Beat Boston For Fifth Straight, 10-6
description: Gary Gray belted a three-run homer, and Rick Sweet and Todd Cruz hit homers with the bases empty tonight, as the Seattle Mariners won their fifth straight game by defeating the Boston Red Sox, 10-6.

title: Sting, Uruguayans Tie
description: The Chicago Sting, the North American Soccer League champion, and Nacional of Montevideo played to a scoreless tie tonight before 8,747 fans at Comiskey Park.

title: A DRAWING IS HELD FOR BRANIFF'S SLOTS
description: It was lottery day at the Federal Aviation Administration today, and the proceeding, conducted in a small, dimly lit amphitheater evoked the atmosphere of the National Football League draft or a bingo game.

title: RAILROAD MAY SAVE $132 MILLION
description: Amtrak, the nation's passenger railroad, announced wage settlements with six unions today that it said could save the company more than $132 million over the next three years and provide a base for expanding the rail system.

title: Queen Says She Prays For Safety of the Fleet
description: Queen Elizabeth II said Wednesday that she was praying for victory and for the safety of the Falkland task force, in which her second son, Prince Andrew, is serving.

title: Moshe Dayan's Son Dismisses Father's Talents
description: The eldest son of Moshe Dayan, who was left out of his father's will, has written a book about his father seven months after the Israeli soldier-diplomat's death in which he mocks his military, writing and political skills and calls him a philanderer.

title: Bill T. Jones to Give 3 Free Dance Programs
description: The dancer and choreographer Bill T. Jones will give three free performances in Manhattan and Brooklyn this weekend. Today at 1:30 P.M., Mr. Jones will perform with members of his ensemble and advanced students of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Studio at the studio, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street.

title: C.F.T.C. Appointment
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Fowler C. West, a longtime staff director of the House Agriculture Committee, to be a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Mr. Fowler, a 41-year old Democrat, would succeed David G. Gartner, whose five-year term expired in April.

title: LEONARD DEFERS HIS DECISION
description: In a subdued atmosphere that he later described as ''like the last hurrah,'' Sugar Ray Leonard said today he might take as long as six months before deciding whether to retire or return to boxing.

title: Loesch Wins Tourney By Shot With 74-285
description: Rod Loesch, a 27-year-old assistant pro at Wee Burn in Darien, Conn., won the $60,000 Dodge Open by one stroke today after a two-over-par 74 in the closing round. His 285 for the four rounds at Rockaway River Country Club's 6,584-yard course was three under par.

title: JAZZ: BERTONCINI AND MOORE
description: THE premises at 128 West 13th Street that once housed Reno Sweeney, the trend-setting cabaret of the 1970's, is now a restaurant, Zinno, which adds quiet, subtle jazz to its food. The room uses duos, piano and bass or guitar and bass, set up in an alcove between the dining room and the bar.

title: C.I.A. SET FOR GROWTH
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTMENT PULLBACK BY CANADA
description: The Government announced here tonight that it would begin soon to sell off its controversial controlling interest in the Canada Development Corporation.

title: SERIOUS PROBLEMS SEEN IN SENATE INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: Six years ago, in the wake of disclosures about foreign assassinations, illegal domestic spying and other abuses by United States intelligence agencies, the Senate formed a special committee to make the intelligence community accountable to Congress.

title: Pan Am Planes
description: Pan American World Airways said it had taken delivery of three new Boeing 727-221 jetliners equipped with engines designed for use in high-altitude, high-temperature airports such as Mexico City's.

title: Letter: On Federal Regulation Health Care and the F.T.C.
description: To the Editor: Your May 7 editorial ''Laws for Sale'' is unworthy of The Times. In equating campaign contributions with a single legislative issue - legislation to define Federal Trade Commission jurisdiction over the professions -and concluding that dentists are buying votes and Congress is selling them, you take a cheap shot at both.

title: Wicor Purchase
description: Directors of Wicor Inc. and Sta-Rite Industries Inc. approved terms of a definitive agreement for Wicor to acquire Sta-Rite for $20.1 million. Wicor, a holding company for gas distribution and gas and oil exploration operations, will begin a cash tender offer on Friday for 1,150,000 shares at $17.50 a share. It reserved the right not to purchase any shares if fewer than 850,000 shares were tendered, and to purchase up to an additional 450,000 shares for the same price.

title: Plane Maker Seeks Duty
description: The Commuter Aircraft Corporation, which is designing a mediumsized commuter airplane, filed a petition yesterday with the Federal Government asking for import duties on similar-sized foreign aircraft being sold in the United States.

title: 69 SENATORS VS. A BAD USED-CAR RULE
description: To the Editor:

title: ART SONG: PALMA TOSCANI
description: IF more singers had an interest in art songs equal to Palma Toscani's, our lyric world would be richer for it. Appearing at the Abraham Goodman House Tuesday, Miss Toscani offered a fascinating program of works for voice and various combinations of instruments.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEITHER rain nor heat nor unseasonable cold could keep determined partygoers from their appointed rounds this week. There were two or three big events every night, and some people seemed to get to all of them.

title: Maryland Track Woes
description: A major problem with Maryland racing, according to Chick Lang, the general manager of Pimlico, is a five-eighths-mile-track named Timonium.

title: RECITAL: SOLOS ON 2 PIANOS
description: WHEN opportunity allows them the options, pianists tend to be very choosy about the instruments on which they perform. Most are looking for the modern concert grand that combines maximum power with infinite subtlety.

title: SALVADOR'S PRESIDENT WILL LET LAND BILL STAND
description: El Salvador's President, Alvaro Alfredo Magana, said today that he had decided not to veto legislation that suspends the rights of peasants to buy the small plots of land they work as tenant farmers or sharecroppers.

title: I.M.F. SEES WORLDWIDE STAGNATION
description: The International Monetary Fund predicted today that world economic growth would remain ''unsatisfactory,'' but warned against using expansionary policies to fight the higher joblessness facing most countries. It also said that debt burdens would bring additional ''serious strains'' to poor nations.

title: SENATE PASSES HOUSING BILL DESPITE REAGAN VETO THREAT
description: The Senate rebuffed President Reagan and its own leadership tonight and approved a $5 billion program to stimulate the ailing housing industry by subsidizing mortgage rates over the next five years. The key vote approving the measure was 63 to 27.

title: Growing Up in a family of achievers.
description: ''Isn't that Mary McFadden?'' - but no celebrity spots her back, even though Miss Shire, with two Academy Award nominations behind her, is more famous than most of the people in the room.

title: American Property
description: The formation of American Property Fund, a real estate investment company that will focus exclusively on the acquisition of the ''highest quality'' income-producing properties throughout the country, was announced yesterday by Jay M. Messer, who will serve as the Miami-based concern's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Federated's Lazarus Retires as Chairman
description: Ralph Lazarus stepped down yesterday as chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc. after a lifetime career there. The company's board named Howard Goldfeder, president and chief executive officer, to succeed him.

title: MEMORIAL DAY: A 3-STATE GUIDE TO THE START OF SUMMER
description: NO matter that the solstice is three weeks away; summer as a way of life starts today. The Memorial Day weekend ushers in the season just as Labor Day snuffs it out, and there are all kinds of ways to get into the spirit over the next four days in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Beverly Hills Savings
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday the re-election of its five-member board of directors at its annual shareholders meeting. In early May, the association filed suit charging Severyn Ashkenazy, a Beverly Hills hotel owner, and a group of associates with illegally conspiring to acquire control of Beverly Hills Savings by acquiring its capital stock. The group is also the target of a similar suit by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: M.T.A. CHIEF CHARGES U.S. ENDANGERS SUBWAY CAR DEAL
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the agency's plan to buy 825 subway cars from a Canadian manufacturer had been ''seriously jeopardized'' by ''silly squabbles'' in the Reagan Administration and by ''political actions'' in Congress.

title: Horsemen Vote Boycott Over Drug Restriction
description: Horsemen at Arlington Park voted unanimously today to boycott the track starting Tuesday unless the Illinois Racing Board allows them to treat certain horses with the medication Lasix on race days.

title: A who's who of U.S. artists.
description: AMERICAN art of the 19th and 20th centuries, including works by such artists as William Merritt Chase, Winslow Homer, John Singer Sargent, Edward Hopper, Andrew Wyeth, Charles Demuth, Edward Potthast and Frederic Remington, is in the spotlight next week in sales at New York's two major auction houses.

title: Cities Service Cites Threat of Takeover
description: The Cities Service Company said yesterday that it ''has reason to believe'' that a group led by the Mesa Petroleum Company of Amarillo, Tex., was ''conspiring'' to put together a deal that would force the company's breakup or liquidation.

title: RECALL OF COUNCIL EXPECTED IF EFFORT BY U.N. CHIEF FAILS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has ruled out another round of ''revolving-door diplomacy,'' aides said today, and intends to recall the Security Council in a few days if, as expected, he fails to win a cease-fire in the Falkland Islands.

title: France Is Said to Deny 8 Exocets to Peru Ship
description: A Peruvian Navy ship left Le Havre a week ago without its scheduled consignment of eight French-made Exocet missiles, harbor officials said today.

title: ROCKLAND PHYSICAN THINKS HE IS THE BOY IN HOLOCAUST PHOTO TAKEN IN WARSAW
description: It is one of the indelible images of history: a Jewish boy, arms in the air and terror in his eyes, standing on a Warsaw street under the watchful gaze of a Nazi soldier. Though others, largely women and children, stand in horror nearby, the boy seems utterly abandoned, his fate seemingly sealed.

title: Aspen Wind Quintet
description: The Aspen Wind Quintet will appear tonight at 8 at Bargemusic at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn.

title: ART: NADELMAN'S WOMEN, AN ANNIVERSARY TRIBUTE
description: IN a spirited tribute to the 100th anniversary of Elie Nadelman's birth, the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, has mounted a show of nearly 100 works by the Polish-born artist (1882-1946), who is now considered to be one of this country's most accomplished sculptors.

title: Bridge:
description: Two events with roots in the earliest days of contract bridge, will be contested at the New York Hilton Hotel during the next nine days.

title: Advertising; Splitting The Cost of Split Tests
description: IT is probably safe to assume that an ''A-B split'' means nothing to most people. But in the test, test and test again world of direct marketing, an A-B split is the key to discovering the pulling power of magazine ads.

title: U.S. SHIFT EXPECTED ON EUROPE FORCES
description: In a speech in Bonn next month, President Reagan will offer a plan for reducing Eastern and Western ground troops in Central Europe that builds on existing Western proposals, Administration officials said today.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN VICTIMS
description: The economics of Central America, designed to serve the rich, have failed to meet the needs of the poor majorities. This is the core of the crisis there. Will President Reagan's proposed new economic aid program help transform these unjust, inefficient economies? Or will it exacerbate the crisis, strengthening the economic and political structures that have kept Central Americans poor and hungry for so long?

title: I.B.M. Appeals To End Case
description: The International Business Machines Corporation asked a Federal appeals court to order Federal District Judge David N. Edelstein to ''cease immediately'' all proceedings related to the Government's antitrust case against I.B.M.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard THE YOUNG REBECCA. Writings of Re- becca West, 1911-17. Selected with an in- troduction by Jane Marcus. Illustrated. 402 pages. Viking. $25. 1900. By Rebecca West. Illustrated. 192 pages. Studio/Viking. $19.95. THE RETURN OF THE SOLDIER. By Re- becca West. Introduction by Victoria Glendinning. 188 pages. Dial/Virago. Paper, $6.95.

title: Subway Inspector Crushed to Death
description: A subway car inspector was fatally crushed under a car that fell off its jacks in the Bronx yesterday morning, officials said. The inspector, Louis Peterson, 45years old, of Manhattan, suffered severe ''crushing injuries'' to the chest and experienced traumatic cardiac arrest when the train fell at the Westchester Yards at about 10:45 A.M., according to the Emergency Medical Service.

title: Clevepak, UNC Forge a Link
description: The Clevepak Corporation, a manufacturer of paperboard, packaging and industrial products in White Plains, announced yesterday that it had elected to the board Keith A. Cunningham, president and chief executive officer of UNC Resources Inc., a diversified energy concern. The election expands Clevepak's board to eight members.

title: JAPANESE REDUCING MORE TARIFFS TO TRY TO MOLLIFY U.S. AND EUROPE
description: For the second time in five months, Japan today announced measures to stimulate imports, mainly by cutting tariffs on such items as computers.

title: A NUCLEAR WAR'S DEVASTATING EFFECT ON CLIMATE
description: To the Editor:

title: IMPROVISING BY OLD AND NEW DREAMS
description: OLD AND NEW DREAMS, the quartet that is performing at the Greenwich Village jazz club Lush Life tonight through Sunday, is a band with a mission.

title: THE SEQUOIA RETURNS TO SERVICE IN STYLE
description: The Sequoia - revarnished, recarpeted, refurnished and reupholstered within the 48 hours before a catered breakfast reception yesterday - is once again the Presidential yacht. Well, almost.

title: PUBLISHING: CONVENTION, A TIME TO CHASE GLOOM
description: LIKE domestic auto makers and home builders, book publishers have been hard hit by the economic recession, although that might not be readily apparent when the American Booksellers Association opens its 82d anniversary meeting and 35th trade exhibition tomorrow in Anaheim, Calif.

title: Sports of The Times; Bill Mears's Eight-Foot Race
description: THE biggest race Bill Mears ever won was ''some little old modified stock car race'' worth only $1,000, unless you want to count the race last Memorial Day to put out the fire that was enveloping his son.

title: LICENSE GIVEN TO ECUADORAN JET
description: The State Department issued a transit license today for an Ecuadorean airliner carrying Israeli military equipment, but the Customs Service continued to detain the plane in New York pending further investigation.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Chemical New York Corp.'s Chemical New York N.V. is issuing $150 million in guaranteed floating-rate subordinated notes, to be sold through a Credit Suisse-First Boston Ltd. group.

title: Britain Won't Query Argentine on Torture
description: The British Government has formally rejected Swedish and French requests that it interrogate a captured Argentine Navy officer about accusations of torture activities, Swedish officials here said today.

title: ZELLERBACH'S REVIVAL STRATEGY
description: An accountant from the Portland, Ore., office stood up at the annual meeting of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in the middle of May and brazenly asked why costs at the company's headquarters here were almost double the allowance at the rival Georgia-Pacific Corporation.

title: Economic Scene; Bonn's View Of Versailles
description: BONN ONE of the great values of summit conferences is that, like public executions, they marvelously concentrate the mind. This holds not only for the seven leaders of the major industrial democracies who will be meeting at Versailles, France, June 4 to June 6, but for their principal ministers and advisers, who are hard at work now on the problems that they hope can be solved at or before the meeting.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 28, 1982; The Economy
description: The House rejected all three budget plans for fiscal 1983, the Republican version, the bipartisan one and the Democrats'. The vote put the budget negotiations in limbo, and signaled the collapse of the coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats that had brought President Reagan his economic legislative victories of last year. (A1.) The Senate acted to repeal tax benefits it had voted for itself and to end a filibuster against a housing relief bill. (A16.)

title: Friday; A JAPANESE EURIPIDES
description: The celebrated Japanese director Tadashi Suzuki and his company - Waseda Shogekijo - will stage his version of Euripides's ''The Bacchae'' tonight at 7:30 through June 6 at the La Mama Annex Theater, 74-A East Fourth Street, between Second Avenue and the Bowery. Mr. Suzuki is known for his adaptations of Greek tragedies in which he combines Noh and Kabuki as well as avant-garde elements. This presentation, co-produced by La Mama and the Japan Society, will be bilingual: three American guest actors trained in Suzuki methods will speak English while the rest of the cast - including the acclaimed actress Kayoko Shiraishi -will speak Japanese. Tickets are $10. Reservations: 475-7710 or 475-7908. CUT-UPS AND PLASTER PETS

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption accompanying an article yesterday about efforts toward a writers union incorrectly characterized Robert Ludlum's position. He said, ''I don't know how you try to organize something as ephemeral as hundreds of thousands of pieces of paper.''

title: IRAN REPORTS NEW BATTLES ON ITS CENTRAL FRONT
description: Iran said today that its troops, having routed Iraqi forces in the south, were now battling other Iraqis on the central front.

title: American Eagle
description: American Eagle Petroleums Ltd. said it would make an offer for all the outstanding common and warrants of the Tiber Energy Corporation in a share exchange. The tender offer, which is not being made to United States Tiber holders, would exchange 1.5 American Eagle common, $4 of its convertible debentures and one share purchase warrant for each two shares of Tiber. The offer is conditional upon American Eagle's receiving 1.6 million of the Tiber common shares.

title: BELL-FENWICK PRIMARY POSING TOUGH CHOICES
description: Luther M. Smythe is the model of a modern Republican. He is loyal to his party and his President, conservative in most matters at home and abroad. He has voted in every primary election in New Jersey since 1951, and he will be at the polls again on June 8 to help select the Republican candidate for the United States Senate. But, oh, how he is twisting at the thought of that task.

title: The Sakhalin Deal
description: A Kremlin master plan to create energy dependencies in key industrial nations around the world - while turning a profit for the Soviet Union - is now becoming apparent.

title: Southern Pacific
description: The Southern Pacific Transportation Company, a subsidiary of the Southern Pacific Company, said today that it planned to lay off a significant number of employees because of depressed conditions in the housing and car industries. The company said most of the layoffs would be in its 37,000-worker railway division. It said it could not specify the number of workers to be laid off.

title: FOR 'ROCKY III,' A SEARCH FOR PROBLEMS
description: FIRST ''Rocky.'' Then ''Rocky II,'' and now ''Rocky III'' ''Why?'' you might query. ''Pourquois pas?'' Miss Piggy might rejoin. ''It's money dans la banque.''

title: Protectionism Is Not Defense
description: For Congress as a whole, the big defense issue is how to get the most bang for the fewest tax bucks. But for individual members, even those with national responsibility, that problem often yields to a contradictory parochial goal: how to get the most defense bucks for their own states. The current maneuvers of the House majority leader, James Wright of Texas, offer a case in point.

title: LONGER-TERM RATES UP A BIT
description: Interest rates rose slightly for debt issues due in five years or more yesterday as traders and others showed little willingness to buy notes and bonds in advance of a three-day weekend. Among shorter maturities, however, rates were about unchanged.

title: Money Fund Assets a Record $199.93 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose sharply again during the week ended Wednesday, to set another record high. The weekly increase raised the total by $3.69 billion, to $199.93 billion, according to the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade organization.

title: Pyro Coal Stake
description: The Pyro Energy Corporation said it would acquire rights to additional coal interests from Alcoa Fuels Inc., a subsidiary of the Aluminium Company of America. About 40 percent of the reserves will be bought for $19.5 million cash, the rest leased.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Canada Inc. said it was resuming a second work shift at the company's Brampton, Ontario, plant which had been discontinued last Dec. 18, and might rehire about 600 workers.

title: ARGENTINA TELLS OF GROUND COMBAT AROUND BEACHHEAD
description: Argentina tonight reported ground fighting and a series of British air raids on the Falkland Islands, and said one British plane had been shot down.

title: Exxon Views Shale Oil Role
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it may yet resume work on the Colony Shale Oil Project in Colorado, the nation's most ambitious synthetic fuels plant, despite having quit the project earlier this month because of skyrocketing costs.

title: Research Spending
description: Businesses plan to increase research and development spending 17 percent this year, to $59.7 billion, according to a survey released yesterday by the McGraw-Hill Publications Company. Research and development spending rose 16 percent in 1981 from the previous year and is expected to be up at least 37 percent, to $81.9 billion, by 1985, the survey said.

title: Business Aide to Reagan Criticizes Food Stamps
description: J. Peter Grace, a businessman who heads President Reagan's Government spending watchdog committee, said today the Federal food stamp program was basically a subsidy for Puerto Ricans.

title: FRNCH COMMUNISTS' DISTANCE FROM KREMLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: POACHERS PROWLING YELLOWSTONE FOR ILLICT HARVEST OF ELK ANTLERS
description: The season is spring, but for dozens of people arriving in the tiny tourist towns that border Yellowstone National Park, it is harvest time.

title: WGBH DANCE AND ISRAEL PHILHARMONIC
description: PUBLIC television has been having its problems lately. Federal financing is being cut back. There have been complaints from various Washington quarters about the ''propaganda'' in documentaries dealing with subjects like Nicaragua and the Western Sahara. Competition for cultural programming is intensifying as cable television continues to expand. What is poor public television to do to keep a low, safe and inexpensive profile for survival? Consider, if you will, the possibilities in ballroom dancing.

title: Magazine News
description: Richard Ekstract, who is still running CES Publishing, which he sold to International Thomson Business Press for $11.5 million last August, is also running Viare Publications.

title: ART: OFFBEAT ALICE NEEL, NOT A PORTRAIT AROUND
description: and-soul search. We come to know the sitter not merely as a physical object but as a restless and perturbed spirit. ''What have you done with yourself, and with your life?'' is the question Miss Neel asks of her sitters, and rare is the man or woman who comes up with a triumphant answer. (She herself did pretty well, though, when she painted her own portrait in the nude not so long ago.)

title: Index; International
