description: Once again a Mexican leader tilts at corruption A2 Iran reports fierce fighting with Iraq on a new front A4 Around the World A5 British merchant ships playing key role in Falklands conflict A8 U.S. insisting Salvador pursue land program A10 Government/Politics Senate panel backs Reagan choice for C.I.A. deputy A7 Connecticut adopts ''right to know'' law on toxic substances B2 Washington Talk Required Reading A14 Senate intelligence panel beset by serious problems A14 Briefing A14 General Around the Nation A12 Amtrak reaches wage agreement with 6 nonoperating unions A12 Hinckley contrite on absences from trial B4 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Monday is Memorial Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: NUNS' GROUP OPPOSES ABORTION STRATEGY OF BISHOPS
description: A small but significant division has emerged in the Roman Catholic Church's strategy for overturning the 1973 Supreme Court decision that made most abortions legal.

title: HEADED SCOTT PAPER AND FEDERAL RESERVE
description: Thomas Bayard McCabe, who served as president and chief executive officer of the Scott Paper Company for 39 years and as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board for three years, died yesterday at his home in Swarthmore, Pa. He was 88 years old.

title: Coast Guard Gets Its 17th Commandant
description: Adm. James S. Gracey was sworn in yesterday as the 17th commandant of the United States Coast Guard.

title: 'CALIFORNIA STYLE,' AT LAST, WELCOMED TO LONG ISLAND
description: Strolling through the Hamlet, an 86-acre development of 320 condominiums just off Exit 40 of the Long Island Expressway, a visitor could be forgiven for thinking that he had taken the wrong turn on the drive from Manhattan and had wound up in Florida or California. The conservative, colonial-style houses found throughout the rest of Long Island are unseen here.

title: ARGENTINE ASSAILS U.S. AT O.A.S. TALKS
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, delivered a scathing attack on the United States today for supporting Britain in the Falkland conflict, and he said the future of United States relations with Latin America ''is under threat.''

title: SOUTH AFRICAN BLUEPRINTS FOR NON-WHITE ADVANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: AT THE ALVIN, 'PATENT LEATHER SHOES'
description: IF anyone on Broadway deserves our unwavering spiritual support right now, it is the ushers at the Alvin Theater. The Alvin is one of the best musical houses in town, but how would you like to have worked there, day in and day out, since ''Annie'' moved away last fall? In recent months, the Alvin's occupants have been ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' ''The Little Prince and the Aviator'' (which closed in previews) and ''Little Johnny Jones.'' And, as it turns out, bad news doesn't always come in threes. Last night, a fourth turkey came to roost at the Alvin, and, though I didn't see ''The Little Prince,'' the theater's new tenant must be the sorriest of them all.

title: MOSCOW'S CHANGING OF THE GUARD AT THE K.G.B.: YURI V. ANDROPOV
description: If there were any doubt that powerful men in the Kremlin are positioning themselves for the end of the Brezhnev era, it seemed to be dispelled with the announcement on Wednesday that Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov, a career Communist Party official, had been relieved of his duties as head of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal security agency.

title: Volcker View On Drysdale
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Government might have to impose some controls over the trading of government securities as a result of the Drysdale affair. Drysdale Government Securities has been unable to pay almost $300 million that it owes to several banks that had been involved with the broker in securities trading.

title: 7 Women on a Hunger Strike In Support of Rights Proposal
description: Seven women who are refusing food in support of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment entered the 10th day of their hunger strike today.

title: LABOR FEDERATION COUNCIL URGES RATIFICATION OF ARMS TREATY
description: The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. declared today, that as a sign that the country really wants nuclear arms control, the Senate should ratify the second strategic arms limitations treaty as soon as possible.

title: ROCKIES ARE SOLD AND MOVED TO MEADOWLANDS
description: There will be a National Hockey League team in Byrne Meadowlands Arena next season, and it will be owned by three New Jerseyans, including the man for whom the arena is named.

title: GRIFFIN O'NEAL (TATUM'S BROTHER) IN 'THE ESCAPE ARTIST'
description: ''THE ESCAPE ARTIST'' appears to be an extended but preliminary sketch for an adventure-fantasy film that has yet to be made. Based on a novel by David Wagoner, it's the story of a worldly wise teenage orphan boy, Danny Masters (Griffin O'Neal), who runs away from his grandmother's house to win fame as a magician and, in the process, to clear his father of a crime that is never made clear.

title: Garment Workers Accept 19% Raises
description: Garment workers and apparel manufacturers have reached basic agreement on new three-year contracts that provide more than 19 percent in pay increases but delay the first raise for six months, the union said yesterday.

title: IN WASHINGTON, A ROUND OF PARTIES FOR ART'S SAKE
description: Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza and his Brazilian-born wife, Denise, flew into Washington just hours before an elegant black-tie dinner given in their honor Wednesday night at the National Gallery. This morning, there was a press breakfast, followed by a Capitol Hill luncheon. And for this evening, the couple reserved Pisces, a private Georgetown club, for a dinner-dance to celebrate the opening of ''20th-Century Masters,'' an exhibition of works culled from the Thyssen-Bornemisza art collection.

title: U.S. Veterans' Group On Its Way to Vietnam
description: A group of seven American veterans of the Vietnam War arrived here this morning en route to Hanoi and described its hopes of promoting reconciliation between the United States and Vietnam.

title: DISTANCE SUITS THE DELAHOUSSAYE STYLE
description: When Eddie Delahoussaye stepped out of a car outside Barn 10 at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon, Eddie Gregson hurried over from under the shed row to greet him warmly. It was the first time that the two had been in the same place at the same time since May 1 in Louisville, Ky., when Delahoussaye rode Gato del Sol, trained by Gregson, to a 2 1/2-length victory in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Jet Hijacked Over Italy; Hostages Freed in Tunisia
description: A Royal Air Maroc jet with 9 crew members and 91 passengers aboard was hijacked today after leaving here for Morocco. A spokesman for the airline here said a single hijacker forced the crew to fly to Tunis, where he released all his hostages and surrendered.

title: Market Place; Chart House: New Direction
description: DESPITE setbacks in certain of Chart House's restaurant properties, the company's shares have acted well. Perhaps the market is convinced this operator of Burger King restaurants is making a successful transition into other restaurant formats.

title: Union Carbide Site
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it had chosen Moses Lake, Wash., as the site for an $85 million silicon plant announced last May. Production is to begin in 1984. The plant will produce polycrystalline silicon, a material used for virtually all semiconductor devices, discrete and integrated circuits.

title: JERSEY CLAIMS TITLE TO COASTAL PROPERTY NOW PRIVATELY HELD
description: New Jersey laid claim today to privately held coastal land valued at millions of dollars and stretching from the New York border to the tip of Cape May County.

title: Poles Switch Walesa To a New Location
description: Lech Walesa, head of the suspended Solidarity labor union, has been moved to a new location after nearly six months of solitary confinement under martial law, the Government said today.

title: OLD SLOGANS DON'T FIT TODAY'S RACE ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Enough to Live
description: ''If they are old enough to vote and old enough to fight, they are old enough to drink.'' So runs the traditional argument against raising the drinking age.

title: CANADA PLANNING TO LIMIT NEWSPAPER CHAINS
description: The Canadian Government is preparing legislation that is intended to limit the growth of newspaper chains as a way of protecting freedom of the press from private monopoly interests.

title: Mancini Near Home
description: It is purely coincidental that Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini chose a city with a suburb named Champion Heights for his first defense of the World Boxing Association's lightweight title. But it is not coincidental he chose Warren, Ohio, as the site for his bout with Ernesto Espana of Venezuela.

title: James W. Gessner Dies at 51; Missouri Railroad Executive
description: James W. Gessner, president and chief executive of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, died Monday of a heart attack.

title: Drivers Feel Effect of Disputed 1981 Indy
description: The drivers' meeting had concluded today, the rules and regulations had been discussed, and Mario Andretti, the winner of the 1981 Indianapolis 500 from May 25 until Oct. 8, did not appear at all pleased.

title: Jail Release Order Blocked in Jersey
description: A state appeals court today stayed parts of a Superior Court judge's order that could have cut in half the sentences of up to 100 prisoners at the Hudson County Jail next Tuesday.

title: 15 CHANGES ASKED IN U.S. WATER ACT
description: The Reagan Administration, already embroiled in a drawn-out battle over the Clean Air Act, has unveiled a list of 15 changes it would like to be made in the Clean Water Act, the country's principal water protection law.

title: BRITAIN LAUNCHES 2 FALKLAND DRIVES OUT OF BEACHHEAD
description: British paratroopers and marines moved out of their beachhead at San Carlos Bay today in an offensive against Argentine troops in the Falkland Islands, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher announced in the House of Commons.

title: SELF-INTEREST
description: -Just imagine for a minute that Argentina is a parliamentary democracy dedicated to neutrality and nonviolence. And let us see Britain - as some of our Latin American neighbors do - as a has-been colonial power grasping at the last straws of prestige. Then how would we feel about Argentina's efforts to return the Falklands to the national patrimony? Ah, but democracies don't do things like that, one might object. Yes they do, and even with a wink from other democracies.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Billboard, a trade publication. Singles and albums are determined by national sales and radio air play reports. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 13Tug of War* Paul McCartney 22Success Hasn't Spoiled* Rick Springfield 31Asia Asia 45Diver Down* Van Halen 5-Original Musiquarium I* Stevie Wonder 64Chariots of Fire Vangelis 712Dare* Human League 88Aldo Nova Aldo Nova 99Always on My Mind Willie Nelson 1011Blackout Scorpions Singles ThisLast WeekWeek 11Ebony & Ivory* McCartney & Wonder 22Don't Talk to Strangers* Rick Springfield 33I've Never Been to Me Charlene 44867-5309/Jenny Tommy Tutone 55The Other Woman* Ray Parker Jr. 66'65 Love Affair Paul Davis 78Don't You Want Me* Human League 811Always on My Mind* Willie Nelson 99Did It in a Minute Hall & Oates 1010Get Down on It Kool & the Gang Copyright c 1982 by Billboard Publications Inc.

title: Auto Racer Cleared
description: A commission of inquiry of the International Auto Sport Federation has cleared Jochen Mass of West Germany of responsibility in the accidental death of Gilles Villeneuve during qualifying for the Belgian Grand Prix May 8.

title: STATE ROLL-CALL ON THE 2 BILLS
description: Following are the votes by which the State Senate gave final legislative approval to a bill requiring a nickel deposit on soda and beer containers - the ''bottle bill'' - and another proposal instituting a tax on beverages and containers to promote recycling and the cleaning up of litter.

title: MOROCCO GRANTS U.S. ACCESS TO AIR BASE
description: The United States and Morocco formally completed an agreement today that will allow American military planes to use air bases in Morocco during emergencies in the Middle East and Africa.

title: MOON, ON STAND, TELLS OF HIS RELIGIOUS BELIEFS
description: Testifying under oath for the first time about his religious beliefs, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, leader of the Unification Church, said yesterday that he had met and had conversations with Jesus, Moses and Buddha. ''I have the possibility of becoming the real Messiah,'' he said.

title: MOSCOW'S CHANGING OF THE GUARD AT THE K.G.B.: VITALY V. FEDORCHUK
description: A voice answering the telephone at K.G.B. headquarters, when asked for background information on the agency's new chairman, answered firmly, ''No one will give you that information.''

title: 41,614 SEE METS BEAT YANKEES IN MAYOR'S TROPHY GAME, 4-1
description: Nelson Doubleday lifted the Mayor's Trophy high last night, toured the Mets' clubhouse to congratulate his players on their 4-1 victory over the Yankees, and then was told that the crowd of 41,614 was the largest at Yankee Stadium this year and the largest for this intercity game since 1972.

title: Wang Planning Computer Line
description: Wang Laboratories entered the personal computer business, introducing a line of computers geared for office workers and available this fall.

title: LOUISE ISELIN MILLS
description: Louise Iselin Mills, a volunteer fund-raiser in New York for many years, died of pnuemonia at her home in Camden, Me., yesterday.

title: METHOD OF INTERVIEWING IN POLL
description: The accompanying article is the first of two based on the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The second, to appear Sunday, will deal with public attitudes toward a proposed nuclear freeze and arms reductions in relation to the Soviet Union.

title: Car Workers Are Rehired
description: The number of United States auto workers on indefinite layoff declined to 235,631 this week from 236,907 workers last week, the major domestic car makers said today.

title: DEEP TAX RATE CUTS PROPOSED
description: Two Democratic tax writers, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, today proposed deep cuts in personal income tax rates and the repeal of many deductions now allowed.

title: Lakers Win After Outscoring 76ers, 40-9
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, recouping after a first half of sloppy ball-handling and poor defense, rallied for a 124-117 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in the opening game of the National Basketball Association finals at the Spectrum tonight.

title: Amoco Increases Gasoline Prices
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said its Amoco Oil Company subsidiary was raising prices an average of 3 cents a gallon to distributors in its Western region.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acton Corp. elected George M. Phillips president and chief operating officer. Mr. Phillips succeeds Samuel J. Phillips, who will remain as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Required Reading Courts v. States
description: Representative Douglas Applegate, Democrat of Ohio, in published remarks concerning the Federal courts, May 13, 1982:

title: Cresitello Quits Jersey Senate Race
description: Former Mayor Donald Cresitello of Morristown withdrew today from the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator and endorsed former Representative Joseph A. LeFante of Bayonne.

title: Waldorf Enthralls A Runaway Boy
description: A 10-year-old runaway, impressed with the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel as a place where ''you get what you ask for,'' was found asleep in a lobby chair, exhausted from a day of unauthorized sightseeing, officials said yesterday.

title: POLL FINDS SUPPORT OFF FOR G.O.P. AND ITS POLICY BUT NOT FOR REAGAN
description: The American public, nearly six months before Election Day, shows sharply diminished support for the Republican Party and the policies of the Reagan Administration on issues ranging from Federal spending to unemployment to inflation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: BRITISH REFITTING OIL-RIG REPAIR SHIP
description: A former oil-rig maintenance ship sailing under the Swedish flag has been bought by a British company and is being outfitted here as a repair ship for use in the Ascension Island region of the South Atlantic, the ship's captain said today.

title: THEATER: RUTH DRAPER'S 'CHARACTERS'
description: FOR the most part, Patrizia Norcia, the sole person on stage in ''Cast of Characters,'' the entertainment at the Cherry Lane Theater, is dealing in charm - her own and the late Ruth Draper's. The word entertainment is used advisedly here; Miss Norcia is recreating some of the monologues that Miss Draper made famous, and although the monologues are more than patter, they are less, though not much less, than plays. They are entertainments.

title: 'MAYA,' FULL OF YOUTH
description: ''MAYA'' is a poor, or rather, impoverished, version of ''Fame.'' Instead of taking place around the rehearsal studios and backstairs of the High School for Performing Arts, the setting for this selfindulgent film is the High School of Fashion Industries. Watching a group of artistic youngsters doing their talented ''thing,'' as in ''Fame,'' is much more fun than seeing a story built around inanimate fashion dummies.

title: Esmark Net Down by 13.2%
description: Esmark Inc. reported yesterday that weakness in its chemical and high fidelity and industrial operations depressed net income in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1982, ended May 1, by 13.2 percent, while revenues edged up 3.2 percent.

title: BRIEFING
description: Humphrey Portrait in Place

title: CONABLE TO RUN AGAIN
description: Representative Barber B. Conable, a Republican from Rochester who is the ranking member of the House Ways and Means Committee, announced yesterday that he would seek election to a 10th term.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about Saudia Arabian royalty in south Florida in- correctly described security arrange- ments for Sheik Mohammed al-Fassi. His family employs off-duty police officers of Hallandale, Fla., who re- placed off-duty officers from Holly- wood, Fla.

title: O'NEILL SIGNS WORKER 'RIGHT TO KNOW' BILL ON TOXIC CHEMICALS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today signed legislation requiring Connecticut companies to disclose information about toxic chemicals used in their plants.

title: Head of Steel Group
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, David Roderick, was elected chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute yesterday, succeeding William De Lancey, the chairman and chief executive of the Republic Steel Corporation, who had served two one-year terms as head of the industry trade group.

title: CON ED'S COAL BURNING TEST QUESTIONED BY TWO GROUPS
description: Two environmentalist groups contended yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company's test on coal conversion failed to disclose the full effects of potential pollution. They said the test used oil with less sulfur than the proposed coal, and for only half the time planned for coal.

title: HOUSE VOTES DOWN ALL ITS BILLS TO SET 1983 BUDGET GOALS
description: The House this morning rejected 1983 budget plans proposed by Democratic leaders and a bipartisan coalition after turning down a Republican budget plan endorsed by President Reagan, creating turmoil that cast doubt on the future of the budget process.

title: POPE BEGINS VISIT TO BRITAIN TODAY
description: Pope John Paul II will arrive in London soon after dawn on Friday for a six-day visit to a country utterly preoccupied with war rather than spiritual pursuits.

title: Play-or-Pray Option
description: Wallace Francis has been agonizing over his decision whether to play another season as a wide receiver for the Atlanta Falcons or enter the ministry, and yesterday he said he would make his choice by Tuesday. ''I don't want to take the Falcons down to the wire on this,'' he said.

title: RIGHTS UNIT SAYS BUDGET CUTS IMPERIL MOVE TO CURB RACISM
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights, under a new chairman appointed by President Reagan, warned today that budget cuts proposed by the Administration would probably reduce the enforcement of civil rights laws.

title: News Analysis
description: With the annulment or suspension of most of the land redistribution effort and with the country controlled by the political right and the army, El Salvador's politics have come almost full circle, to where they were before a coup two and a half years ago. And United States policy appears to be boxed in.

title: ONE ROCKIES PLAYER WELCOMES THE MOVE
description: The move of the Colorado Rockies to the Meadowlands has excited at least one player on the team, as well as fans in New Jersey. ''There's a lot of good hockey fans back East, not like it was in Colorado,'' Bob Lorimer, a former Islander defenseman, said last night. Speaking from his in-laws' home in Port Huron, Mich., Lorimer, who was traded by the Islanders to the Rockies last October, tried to explain what went wrong in Denver:

title: After The Exocet
description: What is to be learned from the sinking of the British destroyer Sheffield by a single relatively outmoded air-to-surface missile? Secretary of the Navy John Lehman thinks it's that the United States should build two more huge Nimitz-class carriers to be the centerpieces of costly naval ''battle groups.''

title: Royal Shakespeare bringing 'Good' to Booth in October.
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''Good,'' a play by C.P. Taylor, will open at the Booth Theater in October. ''Good'' was Mr. Taylor's last play, written especially for its star, Alan Howard, who used it to win the London Theater Critics' Award as best actor of the season. Mr. Howard plays a humane college professor, a ''good'' man - hence the title - forced to deal with Nazism in Germany in the 1930's. Sometimes, when faced by crisis, he hears music - marches, tangos, popular songs; they make up his reveries - and in addition to the cast of 10, there will be 5 musicians on the stage of the Booth. In London, where ''Good'' is now a hit at the Aldwych, it has been described as ''searing'' and ''moving and painful.'' Presumably, it is about the banality of evil as much as anything else.

title: Mego Sees Loss
description: Mego International Inc., the financially troubled toy maker and distributor, projected a loss of between $18 million and $20 million on sales of about $73.7 million for its fiscal year, ended Feb. 28. The company had a loss of $26.6 million on sales of $66.9 million for the year before.

title: Taking (Just About) Every Precaution
description: The Rev. Bernard O'Leary is a cautious sort. So when the Roman Catholic priest dropped off some winter clothes at his new parish in Wayne, W.Va., a while back, he made sure that moths would not be able to get at the boxes containing everything from his favorite flannel shirts to a brand-new goose down parka.

title: GOVERNMENT SHIFTS ITS CANCER RESEARCH AIMS
description: The Federal Government is putting new emphasis on research aimed at preventing cancer through dietary means rather than continuing to concentrate on a strategy of trying to eliminate all causes of cancer from the environment, the Secretary of Health and Human Services said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; May 28, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FRED W. BARTLETT
description: Fred W. Bartlett, former chairman of the Socony Mobil Oil Company, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Sumter, S.C. He was 84 years old and lived in Sumter.

title: Gunmen Rob Class At Brooklyn Tech
description: Twenty-one students and a teacher were robbed at gunpoint yesterday in their fourth-floor classroom at Brooklyn Technical High School by two young men.

title: Final Approval on a Bottle Bill Voted in Albany
description: The State Senate gave final legislative approval today to a bill to require a 5-cent deposit on beer and soda containers sold in New York State and to an alternative littercontrol bill supported by the bottling industry.

title: CITY NOW FINDS OVERTIME CONTROLS INADEQUATE
description: The Koch administration, which had insisted that its control of overtime expenses was firm, said yesterday that it had uncovered evidence that the controls were inadequate.

title: STUDY FINDS STEEP DROP IN REPRODUCTIVE DEATHS
description: The total number of women who died in pregnancy or in efforts to avert pregnancy or childbirth has decreased dramatically in recent decades, according to a report published in today's issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Texas Drug Patrol Planned
description: Gov. William Clements of Texas has requested the use of military ships and airplanes to patrol the Texas Gulf Coast for drug smugglers. The Governor said Wednesday that he had asked President Reagan to make available to Texas military and naval equipment already used experimentally in Florida.

title: Judge Shanley N. Egeth Of New York Civil Court
description: Shanley N. Egeth, administrative judge of the Civil Court of New York City and an acting State Supreme Court justice, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 57 years old.

title: WARNING EVOKES HINCKLEY STATEMENT ON ABSENCES
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., who was absent from the courtroom all day Wednesday, spoke out at his trial for the first time today, telling Federal District Judge Barrington D. Parker in a steady, composed voice, ''I don't wish to come and go on a whim or anything like that.''

title: Greece Is Withdrawing From NATO Exercises
description: Greece said Wednesday that it would not take part in any further NATO military exercises because of what it called Turkish violations of Greek airspace.

title: Acquisition by Chase
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved the application of The Chase Manhattan Bank to purchase the Suburban Coastal Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest mortgage banking company.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BANKERS IN A LEAKY BOAT
description: As usual, this year's International Monetary Conference was a stylish affair, with much wining, dining and sightseeing. But unlike at previous sessions of the conference, there was unity here among the 250 bankers who attended: They all seemed to be preoccupied with the same problems.

title: Long Island University Names Business Dean
description: A banker has been chosen as dean of the School of Business Administration at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University. The school announced yesterday that John H. Vogel, chairman of the National Bank of North America, will take over Sept. 1. Mr. Vogel, 65, retires today after a 48-year finance and banking career. He will remain a director at the National Bank of North America. His successor at the bank, which has assets of $6.4 billion and 157 branches in New York City and its suburbs, has not yet been announced.

title: Nicaragua and Honduras Ask for Aid After Floods
description: Nicaragua and Honduras appealed for international relief aid today as a tropical storm flooded large areas of both countries, killing 177 people and leaving 55,000 homeless. Troops were mobilized to take food and medicine to thousands of people isolated in the last four days in at least 50 communities in the two neighboring Central American countries.

title: BRITISH MERCHANT VESSELS ARE PLAYING VITAL ROLE IN SUPPORT OF COMBAT FLEET
description: The loss of the Atlantic Conveyor to two Exocet missiles illuminates the role played by the merchant ships of Britain in the Falkland Islands operations.

title: Bid for Questor
description: The Questor Corporation said directors approved its sale to Q Associates for $14.25 a share. Q Associates, a group of private investors led by Daniel Lufkin, Questor's chairman, already owns 1.5 million of Questor's shares outstanding and through this offer plans to acquire the remaining 8.2 million. Questor shares closed today at $13.625, unchanged, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ideal sushi setting and trendy cafes.
description: ALTHOUGH the Japanese raw fish specialties sushi and sashimi are becoming relatively commonplace in New York, they are usually dispensed in settings notably devoid of charm. But the new Takesushi, on Vanderbilt Avenue near 45th Street, is a handsome exception. The same skillful preparations of sashimi, the sliced raw fish, and sushi, the raw and cooked fish compacted on warm, mild vinegar rice, are turned out here as at the other Takesushi on 45th Street and Avenue of the Americas, and as they were at the former location on East 48th Street.

title: 'LUCKY STAR' FROM CANADA
description: ''LUCKY STAR,'' which opens today at Loews Tower East and Paramount, is frail little Canadian-made melodrama set in the Netherlands in 1940. It is a movie that, by being so inept, has the effect of mocking the innocence it would celebrate. About the only good thing one can say about it is that Max Fischer, who wrote and directed it, may have learned that there is more to making a film than having a camera, film stock, actors and money.

title: Linda Ann Gage Married
description: Linda Ann Gage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Peter Gage of New York and Rumson, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Timothy Michael O'Connor, son of Agnes O'Connor of Hicksville, L.I., and Francis X. O'Connor of Babylon, L.I. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrest Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The bride, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, will retain her name. She is a granddaughter of the late Walter Reade, founder of the Walter Reade movie-theater chain.

title: CITIES SERVICE ASSERTS IT PLANS TO BID FOR MESA
description: The Cities Service Company, which said earlier it had ''reason to believe'' the Mesa Petroleum Company was putting together a group that might attempt to take it over, decided yesterday, in a preemptive move, to act first and attempt a takeover of Mesa.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 29. 1. As a result of party pressure against Mr. Packwood, who has publicly criticized the President, the photo was altered in a revised brochure. The President's picture remains the same, but Mr. Packwood's has been replaced by one of Senator Howard H. Baker Jr.

title: NOTED BRITISH JUDGE QUITS AFTER CHARGES OF RACISM IN A BOOK
description: One of Britain's most prominent judges announced his resignation today after his recently published book provoked sharp reaction and calls for his retirement.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL FAILS TO CURB NLT
description: A Federal judge in Houston yesterday denied the American General Corporation's request for a temporary restraining order to bar the NLT Corporation of Nashville, an insurance company, from its $600 million tender offer for about 48 percent of American General's shares. But the judge scheduled a hearing on American General's request for a preliminary injunction for June 3.

title: A PLACE FOR UNDERACHIEVERS IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: ADOPTEES' AGONY
description: To the Editor:

title: MULTIMEDIA: LAURIE ANDERSON
description: Laurie Anderson's concert Thursday at the Paladium - her first New York appearance since the release of her debut album, ''Big Science'' -had the aura of a homecoming event, with much of the SoHo art world in attendance. And in her hour-and-a-half-plus set, Miss Anderson wove nearly two dozen ''bits'' from her mixed-media work in progress, ''United States,'' into a funny-scary evocation of technological nightmare that grew darker as the evening progressed.

title: ARGENTINA PRESSES O.A.S. FOR SUPPORT
description: Latin American Foreign Ministers debated tonight an Argentine request that the United States stop supplying weapons to Britain in the Falkland Islands crisis.

title: WOMAN IS FOUND GUILTY IN REVENGE MURDER CASE
description: Ruth Coe, a Spokane social leader, was found guilty today of trying to hire a man to murder the prosecutor and the judge who sent her son to prison for a series of rapes.

title: Hunger Strikers Rest a Day In Rights Amendment Vigil
description: Women fasting for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment for the last 10 days declined today to hold their vigil in the Capitol rotunda in favor of rest and relaxation.

title: MANY GASOLINE REFINERS BEGIN ALLOCATING SUPPLY
description: Major oil companies have started restricting gasoline sales to jobbers and service stations because of rapid depletion of stocks over the last six weeks, according to several industry analysts. Most analysts stress, however, that no shortages at service stations are expected to result from the restrictions,

title: CORRECTION
description: An article by United Press Interna- tional about the Cannes Film Festival, printed on Thursday, incorrectly named the author of the book on which the film ''Missing'' was based. The book, ''The Execution of Charles Hor- man,'' is by Thomas Hauser.

title: Of Unionism and the N.F.L.
description: LARRY WILLIAMS is a pieceworker on the assembly line of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company in Pittsburgh, and he is a Steeler fan. So he read with interest the comments by Terry Bradshaw, the Steeler quarterback, concerning the possibility of a strike by the National Football League Players Association if a new collective bargaining agreement is not reached with management.

title: The Pope's remarks, page 5.
description: Pope John Paul II today began a six-day pastoral visit to Britain, the first by a reigning Pope in the 1,900-year history of the papacy. He appealed to Britain and Argentina ''to put aside the weapons of death'' in the Falkland Islands.

title: VETERAN DRIVERS WARY OF INDY ROOKIES
description: ''How loud is loud?'' Johnny Rutherford said. ''Or how high is up?'' There was no need to ask the annual pressing questions: How fast is fast? Or, how fast is too fast?

title: DISPUTE STALLS OPENING O'NEILL HOME
description: In 1937, when Eugene O'Neill and his wife, Carlotta, built Tao House, the California home that the playwright referred to as his ''final home and harbor,'' they had to have an access road constructed to lead from the house to the main road. This narrow, winding private road ran for a mile through a portion of the 157 acres of the O'Neill estate.

title: U.S. SEES VIOLATION OF TRADE ACCORDS IN M.T.A. PROPOSAL
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the plan of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to buy 825 subway cars from Canada violated international trade agreements. And it said that it was considering ''all of our options'' for action against the Canadian Government and the manufacturer.

title: Around the Nation; Illinois Paper Reports Accord in Libel Suit
description: A Federal judge has approved a $1.4 million tentative settlement between The Alton Telegraph and James Green, a builder who won a $9.2 million libel judgment against the newspaper.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell $1.3 billion in the latest week, a decline that was close to economists' forecasts, and one that confirmed a sharp slowing in money supply growth after rapid growth in early April.

title: 'VISITING HOURS'
description: When the soundtrack music comes up behind the credits of ''Visiting Hours,'' you get the eerie feeling that you've heard this movie before. You have, but ''Visiting Hours'' is an especially clumsy, overwrought example of slash-and-hack melodrama.

title: E. R. Rowley, Ex-Chief Of NL Industries, Dies
description: Edward R. Rowley, former chairman and chief executive officer of NL Industries, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Carefree, Ariz. He was 73 years old.

title: Friends of the Arts Plan C.W. Post Dance Series
description: Friends of the Arts will present ''Dazzling Dance,'' a fourperformance series in the 1982-83 season at the C.W. Post Concert-Theater in Greenvale, L.I.

title: PRODUCING JOBS WILL HELP CURE THE BUDGET
description: To the Editor:

title: LEADER OF ORGANIZER
description: The majority owner of the team that will bring National Hockey League competition to New Jersey next season is a massive achiever who works hard to succeed - and usually does. John Joseph McMullen and his partners, Brendan T. Byrne and John C. Whitehead, will attempt to turn the former Colorado Rockies, a team dismal on the ice and at the box office, into a competitive franchise that will fill the seats at the 19,000-seat Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The cost of the venture to the trio has been estimated at more than $30 million

title: Ford Sales Abroad
description: The Ford Motor Company said its overseas affiliates sold 556,200 cars and trucks in the 1982 first quarter, up from 553,900 a year earlier, with cars up slightly but trucks off 8 percent. It said sales were down in several Latin American markets, including Argentina and Mexico, due to depressed economies, although European car sales reached a record 352,000.

title: 'PROMISING' YOUTH IS SENT TO PRISON
description: A Bronx man whom his lawyer called "the most promising" child in a family of achievers was sentenced in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to 13 years in prison for his part in a $9,000 bank holdup.

title: EARNING AN ADDED PENSION ISN'T DOUBLE-DIPPING
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME HELP IN STOPPING SMOKING
description: Sixty percent of the cigarette smokers in America - more than 30 million people - have tried unsuccessfully at one time or another to part company with tobacco, according to the Office on Smoking and Health of the United States Public Health Service. Another 30 million people are ex-smokers, the health service says.

title: Around the World
description: Three Soviet prisoners of the Afghan resistance movement arrived in Switzerland today to be interned by the Swiss Government after being released into the custody of the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: GANG STRIFE ON RISE AMONG CALIFORNIA VIETNAMESE
description: The Anh Dao Vietnamese restaurant on a busy street in San Jose was nearly filled with 40 to 50 people on a clear day last January when two men, one slender and quick, the other stocky and muscular, walked in the door.

title: DOW DECLINES 5.42 AS TRADING SLOWS
description: An early gain by the stock market evaporated yesterday as equities retreated in slow pre-Memorial Day weekend trading. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 5.42 points, to 819.54, as volume on the Big Board fell to 43.9 million shares from 44.7 million on Thursday. Declining stocks outnumbered advancers, 767 to 689, with 427 issues unchanged. Yesterday's drop marked the 11th trading day in the last 13 in which the Dow declined.

title: CAPITAL
description: British forces have captured Darwin and Goose Green, overrunning the second largest Argentine installation in the Falkland Islands, the Defense Ministry announced tonight.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Giants signed their No.2 draft selection, Joe Morris, the running back from Syracuse. ... At a meeting in Rome of the International Olympic Committee, Julian K. Roosevelt, the 67-year-old former gold medalist in yachting, became the first American elected to the I.O.C's executive board since Avery Brundage stepped down as comittee president in 1972. ... The San Diego Chargers acquired the veteran linebacker Jeff Siemon from the Minnesota Vikings for an undisclosed draft choice. ... The Minnesota Twins, deep in last place, nonetheless extended the contract of Manager Billy Gardner through next season. ... John McEnroe leaves for Europe today to play some tuneup matches for Wimbledon. He passed up the French Open to rest his ailing ankle.

title: U.N. Reports Walesa To Be in Good Health
description: Lech Walesa, the interned leader of the banned Solidarity trade union movement, is in ''good physical and moral condition,'' according to a report by a special investigator sent to Poland by the International Labor Organization.

title: Florida Fails in Suit to Force Resumption of Refugee Aid
description: A Federal district judge on Friday refused Florida's request that the Reagan Administration be forced to resume aid to 32,000 Cuban and Haitian refugees.

title: BRIEFING
description: New Sporting Life

title: Dorsey Sells Unit
description: The Dorsey Corporation reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had sold the net assets of its glass container subsidiary to members of the subsidiary's management and a group of outside investors for $35 million in cash and a $5 million, 12 percent note.

title: Around the World; 2 in Singapore Cabinet Exchange Positions
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew today announced a Cabinet shuffle that gives one of his younger ministers full charge of the island's defense.

title: G.O.P. COMMERCIALS UPHELD BY AGENCY
description: The Federal Communications Commission has rejected a complaint challenging the airing last fall of Republican television commercials supporting President Reagan's economic program.

title: Ray Denied Parole Till 1985
description: The Tennessee Board of Paroles voted Thursday to deny James Earl Ray a parole hearing for at least three years. Mr. Ray, serving 99 years for assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., asked the five-member board to schedule a parole hearing on the ground that he had served enough of his sentence to warrant one. By a 4-to-1 vote, the board decided to tell the prisoner to ask again in May 1985.

title: BRIEFING
description: Windfall for Democrats

title: H.E. Van Surdam Dies; College Football Figure
description: Henderson E. (Harry) Van Surdam, a member of the National Football Hall of Fame who composed music about the sport that he had played, coached and officiated, died today at Hoosick Falls Health Center. He was 100 years old.

title: U.S. Allows Departure Of Plane to Ecuador
description: Customs officials today authorized the departure from Kennedy International of an Ecuadorean plane believed to be loaded with Israeli-made military equipment. The plane had been detained for four days.

title: Young Dancers to Show Competition Wares
description: Young performers who will compete in the Jackson International Ballet Competition late next month will perform in ''Tribute to the Jackson Competition'' on next Friday and June 6 at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: ARGENTINE P.O.W. CALLS AIR FORCE CASUALTIES HIGH
description: Ian Bruce of The Glasgow Herald is with the British troops in the Falklands and filed the following pool dispatch, which was cleared by military censors:

title: ARABS TRYING TO DETER AFRICAN ON ISRAEL TIES
description: The Arab League began a diplomatic initiative today to prevent black African nations from following Zaire's example and restoring relations with Israel.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Tuesday about a benefit for the National Dance Institute incorrectly described a reading from Eugene O'Neill's oneact plays of the sea. It was given by Kevin Kline. Colleen Dewhurst, who was scheduled to appear, could not attend.

title: Holly Net Loss At $4.4 Million
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $4.4 million in its fourth fiscal quarter, in contrast to a $5.1 million profit in the 1981 period.

title:
Patents;
Rapid Gasoline Knock Test
description: WASHINGTON A new method of determining the antiknock quality of gasoline has been invented for the Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla. The process, which is computer-operated, is described as rapid and requiring only small samples for examination.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Gray Matter

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 2 Broadway Stars Play for Strawberries
description: When Kaye Ballard and George Rose, stars of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' on Broadway, made a personal appearance yesterday afternoon, they did not get union scale for their services.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL COLLEAGUES
description: National leaders of the Democratic Party today mildly rebuked conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives who deserted the party's leadership and sided with President Reagan in this week's budget debate.

title: OVERHAUL OF IMMIGRATION LAW GAINS IN SENATE
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a bill to overhaul the nation's immigration law in a major step toward resolving a long-term dispute.

title: A CENTRAL PARK RETREAT UNDER CITY ATTACK
description: To the Editor:

title: Goodrich Sets Salary Cuts
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company announced that it would cut executive salaries up to 15 percent and further curtail capital spending.

title: Costly Cuts for Health Care
description: Give the penny-wise-and-pound-foolish prize to the Reagan Administration for eliminating Federal aid to health maintenance organizations. For years Washington has run a modest $35 million program of grants and low-interest loans to fledgling H.M.O.'s, which offer enrollees full medical coverage for a prepaid fee.

title: CLEARING SUMMIT OBSTACLES
description: The economic summit meeting in Versailles, France, will not unfold for another week, but much of the work has already been done.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON SHOWS WIDER LOSS
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially troubled farm-implement maker based in Toronto, reported yesterday that its loss more than tripled in the second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, to $25.7 million, from $8 million a year earlier.

title: Maxwell Perkins Award
description: Jean Stone, being the ''editor-in-residence'' since 1934 for her husband, the novelist Irving Stone, has had many personal rewards, but now her professional efforts have been officially recognized.

title: DIRECTOR OF THE C.I.A. REPORTS $442,000 IN INCOME FOR 1981 AND STOCK IN 45 CONCERNS
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, reported income of at least $442,000 last year in financial disclosure forms made public today.

title: NORTH SEA OIL PRICES RISE $2.50
description: Britain and Norway announced today that they would increase their prices for North Sea oil by about $2.50 a barrel, the latest sign that the world's oversupply of oil is ending.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Memorial Day is the time to remember what those who survived can never forget: near misses, the whistle of the shell, the wound, the heartbeat, the cessation of same, the noises, the colors, the casualties of combat.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amfac Inc. announced the merger of the W.G. Allen Group of Companies into Amfac Distribution Corp.

title: Northwest Airline and Union Conduct 24-Hour Negotiation
description: Negotiators for Northwest Airlines and its striking mechanics, baggage handlers and kitchen employees met without a break for 24 hours, then took time out to rest.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.8%
description: The Government index designed to gauge future economic performance rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the first increase in the leading indicators in a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today, for the first time in history, a Bishop of Rome sets foot on English soil. I am deeply moved at this thought.'' - Pope John Paul II. (5:1.)

title: Boise Cascade Trims Staff 11%
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation announced the immediate termination of 92 corporate headquarters employees, or 11 percent of the staff, in a cost-cutting move attributed to the sagging economy.

title: LEADING WAY TO TOP
description: Robert D. Hormats, chief Sherpa for the United States in economic summitry, has as his counterparts for the upcoming meeting the following:

title: LTV Restructures J.& L. Steel Unit
description: The LTV Corporation has announced a restructuring of its Jones & Laughlin steel subsidiary. Three steel divisions have been restructured into two, a new executive vice president position has been created and divisional presidents have been assigned enlarged responsibilities, company officials said.

title: Your Money; Tax-Exempt Money Funds
description: BY now, the enormous development of money market funds since they first came into wide-scale public acceptance during the last decade has become familiar to investors and noninvestors alike. But relatively few are aware of what has recently become the most rapidly growing portion of this industry: tax-free money market funds that invest in short-term debt of state and local governments.

title: Around the Nation; G.M. Moves to Reassure White-Collar Workers
description: In an apparent effort to ward off a whitecollar unionzation drive, the General Motors Corporation today in effect returned to its old system of basing layoffs on seniority instead of performance. It also instituted job security measures.

title: MENSTRUAL STRESSES AS A LEGAL DEFENSE
description: A 24-year-old Brooklyn mother, acccused of assaulting her 4-yearold daughter, has maintained in a novel extension of the defense of diminished capacity that her case should be dismissed because premenstrual stress prompted her to act irrationally.

title: ARGENTINES REPORT FIGHTING AT DARWIN TO REPEL BRITISH
description: The Argentine command said tonight that ground and air forces were battling to repel British troops trying to secure a position in the Darwin area south of Britain's beachhead on East Falkland Island.

title: BankAmerica Bid Supported
description: The Justice Department today urged the Federal Reserve Board to approve the proposed acquisition by the BankAmerica Corporation of Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount brokerage firm.

title: News Analysis
description: ''There's a sense of real paralysis, of fear and confusion and polarization,'' Representative Leon E. Panetta said today, surveying the rubble of three major budget plans that went down to defeat Thursday night.

title: Holiday Closings
description: On Monday, all United States stock and commodities markets and most businesses will be closed for Memorial Day. In addition, some markets in Britain and on the Continent will be closed in observance of the Whitsun holiday.

title: MAY FARM PRICES UP BY 2.2%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose 2.2 percent in May but were still 2.8 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Energy Belongs in the Cabinet
description: The word from James McClure, the chairman of the Senate Energy Committee, is that the President's plan to abolish the Energy Department is ''a merger, not a dismantlement.'' He's right. Most of the functions would shift to an expanded Commerce Department. But reassuring as that may be, the wisdom of the change should not be measured semantically. There is little to gain by destroying the department, and much to lose.

title: Reagan Asks Mexicans To Consider U.S. View
description: President Reagan appealed to a group of Mexican officials today to understand the reasons behind the United States support of Britain in the Falkland Islands fighting.

title: PESTICIDE FILES ORDERED RELEASED FOR POISONING SUIT
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to release information about a pesticide that is being blamed for the illnesses of three farm workers.

title: ISRAEL SEES SOVIET GAIN AS U.S. SHUNS IRAN
description: Iran's recent successes in its war against Iraq have reinforced Israeli convictions that the United States is making a serious error by neglecting long-term Western interests in Iran.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 29, 1982
description: International The British overran a garrison in the Falklands manned by 1,000 Argentine troops and captured Darwin and Goose Green, the Defense Ministry in London announced, encouraging speculation that the British were on their way to Stanley, the islands' capital. The base was Argentina's second largest there. (Page 1, Column 6.) Argentine troops fought to push back a British drive on Darwin on East Falkland Island, the Argentine command in Buenos Aires said in a communigue issued moments after the Defense Ministry in London announced that British troops had taken both Darwin and Goose Green. The communique said that Argentine troops had totally recovered the terrain and controlled the situation tactically. (4:1-2.)

title: Itel Financial Report
description: The Itel Corporation reported today that its unrestricted cash balance increased in April to about $303 million from $5 million, and that its estimated net income for April was about $2.1 million. Itel, which leases transportation and other capital equipment, released the information in a report required by the United States Bankruptcy Court. The company, based in San Francisco, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act on Jan. 19, 1981, after accumulating debts of $1.3 billion.

title: Military Analysis
description: With the reported elimination of any threat from the Argentine garrison in the Darwin-Goose Green sector, Non-British military experts here and at NATO headquarters in Brussels said a major move toward Stanley might now be mounted. They noted that what 48 hours ago was a dangerously exposed flank to any eastward movement had now become a base for an eastward march.

title: Coca-Cola to Buy A Large Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Company announced a definitive agreement to buy the Associated Coca-Cola Bottling Company, one of its largest independent bottling companies, for about $417.5 million, with the intent of eventually selling the bottler to new owners.

title: JERSEY SENATE HOPEFULS SEEK DEMOCRATS' NOTICE
description: Democrats in New Jersey are unaccustomed to functioning as the ''out'' party. But these days, with a Republican President, a Republican Governor and a lively Republican contest for the Senate, the nine candidates for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat find they have to work especially hard to attract and hold an audience.

title: Argentina May Halt Flights
description: The Argentine Air Force said tonight that it was prepared to halt air transportation agreements with France, the Netherlands and West Germany because of their support for the Common Market boycott against Argentina. It said flights would be suspended after 30 days. Flights between Argentina and Britain have already been halted.

title: 'Ellis Island' to Be Shown
description: Meredith Monk's ''Ellis Island'' will be shown at the Goethe House-German Cultural Center, 1014 Fifth Avenue, on June 8. The 28-minute film about the experiences of immigrants entering the United States at the turn of the century will be shown from 6 to 9 P.M. Admission to the film, the latest by the composer and choreographer, is free.

title: Indians 5, White Sox 2
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - John Denny pitched a five-hitter, and Mike Hargrove and Andre Thornton keyed a five-run third inning to give the Cleveland its fifth straight victory.

title: A Change of Goals
description: This year's valedictorian at Queens College, Karl H. Talts of Corona, Queens, started out wanting to be an engineer, but the tragedy that struck his Estonian-born parents in recent years changed his career goal drastically.

title: William C. Lewis Jr. Is Dead; Air Force Brigadier General
description: William C. Lewis Jr., a retired brigadier general in the Air Force, who was Senator Margaret Chase Smith's top aide and closest friend, died Wednesday. He was 69 years old.

title: BARNUM LIVES ON
description: There is a natural affinity between a used-car salesman and a Congressman. Neither one wants you to know what's under the hood. For this reason there is nothing surprising about Congress's rejection of new Federal rules that would have forced used-car dealers to tell their customers about serious defects in their merchandise. Do Congressmen advertise the cracks in their brains? Why should a used-car salesman have to advertise the holes in his radiator?

title:
PATENTS;
Fine-Etching Process For Electronic Circuits
description: A process for finely etching electronic circuits has been developed at the research laboratory of the International Business Machines Corporation in San Jose, Calif.

title: WHEN THE ARMY FORCES 'STRENGTH' ON A CONSCRIPT
description: To the Editor:

title: A FREED POLE SAYS UNION MUST LIVE
description: The national chairman of the Rural Solidarity union, released from internment at the end of April, said in an interview on his father's farm here today that the authorities had tried to undermine the union from within and had never negotiated in good faith.

title: Huntington Hartford Loses Eviction Fight
description: Huntington Hartford has lost his legal fight to block the board of directors of the cooperative at 1 Beekman Place from evicting him because they find his tenancy ''undesirable.''

title: LaPorte Retains Title
description: Juan LaPorte of New York retained his United States Boxing Association featherweight title at the Felt Forum last night by pounding Alberto Collazo of Pittsburgh in a fight stopped by Referee Arthur Mercante before the start of the sixth round. LaPorte, 22, registered his 12th knockout in a 20-3-0 career. He is ranked third by both the

title: EXCERPTS FROM JOHN PAUL'S REMARKS AT AIRPORT AN CATHEDRAL
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Pope John Paul II on his arrival this morning at Gatwick Airport and from the homily he delivered in Westminster Cathedral during a mass. The text was made available by Vatican officials traveling with the Pope. At Gatwick Airport

title: Recalls Are Announced By Ford and Chrysler
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today a recall of more than 141,800 Escort and Continental model cars because of the potential for vehicle fires because of air-conditioners or leaking gasoline.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S RESOLVE WINS APPROVAL AT HOME
description: As Britain struggles through one of its most difficult periods since World War II, the woman at the center of it all remains a picture of calm and resolution.

title: WHITE HOUSE SHIFTING MIDEAST STAND
description: In the Middle East as elsewhere in the world, the Reagan Administration is now talking a different, more realistic line from the one of a year ago.

title: DEPARTING U.D.C. CHIEF REVIEWS WORK
description: Richard A. Kahan left office yesterday as president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, a post he had held since 1978. He is also stepping down as president of the Convention Center Development Corporation and the Battery Park City Authority.

title: HINCKLEY DEFENSE RESTS AS KEY MOVIE IS SHOWN
description: John W. Hinckley Jr. watched intently today as the film ''Taxi Driver,'' which defense psychiatrists have testified helped to shape his bizarre thoughts and his sense of compulsion to shoot President Reagan, was played for the jury at his trial.

title:
PATENTS;
Delaware Still First On Per Capita Patents
description: A summary issued this week by the Patent and Trademark Office shows that, with one patent issued for every 1,787 residents, Delaware continued in 1981 its 47-year reign as the state getting the most patents on a per capita basis.

title: 2 UNLIKELY SETTINGS FOR COMBAT
description: Like most pastoral battlegrounds, the Falkland Island settlements of Darwin and Goose Green are unlikely settings for shrieking jet planes, parachute drops, rattling machine-gun fire and the sudden, agonizing combat in which they were caught up yesterday.

title: Bridge: Some Canadians Did Well In Play for Vanderbilt Cup
description: Since the site of the Spring Nationals in Niagara Falls, N.Y., was only a few yards from the Canadian border, it is not surprising that there was a large contingent from above it. What was surprising was that the most famous Canadian players, including some with world reputations, were eliminated early in the Vanderbilt Cup while some of their compatriots did very well indeed.

title: Wrong Car; Wrong Place, Wrong Time, Wrong Car
description: The two cars were stopped at a red light in Milwaukee, and all of a sudden, Pamela Czerwinski said later, her brakes failed. Her car began to creep forward and crunched into the back of the other car.

title: Asking Too Much of Schools
description: As new fiscal storm clouds gather, Mayor Koch asks New York's Board of Education to tithe more than its fair share to the cause of balancing his budget. While the Police and Sanitation Departments, for instance, received increases, the school system would sustain a much deeper reduction than seems warranted by declining enrollments.

title: It's 1770. THERE'S A FALKLAND CRISIS.
description: -This is not the first time that the Falkland Islands have been at the center of world events. Over 200 years ago, they caused a major international crisis and nearly led to world war. The scenario was much the same then as now.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 45.

title: GENERIC DRUGS ARE RARELY SUBSTITUTED
description: Pharmacists are virtually ignoring laws p ermitting the substitution of less expensive generic formulations f or brand-name drugs, according to a comprehensive study recently r eleased by the National Center for Health Services Research, an arm o f the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: MALTBIE LEADS MEMORIAL BY 6
description: The second day of the Memorial Tournament today consisted of two segments: Roger Maltbie for superb golf and Arnold Palmer for sentiment and theater.

title: Harvester To Sell Assets
description: The International Harvester Company plans to sell several large assets to repay some of its debt and improve its solvency, the concern's chief financial officer said today.

title: DEATH RATE SOARS IN COCAINE CASES
description: The rate of cocaine-related deaths quadrupled from 1976 to 1981 while the rate of cocaine-related hospital treatment showed a sixfold increase from 1975 to 1981, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: EACH CLUB HITS 4 HOMERS
description: The Metrodome, this city's monument to home run hitters, is, according to Ron Davis, ''the worst place in the world for a pitcher.''

title: Books of The Times The Black Community
description: This Was Harlem: 1900-50. By Jervis An- derson. Illustrated. 390 Pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: New Zealanders Protest
description: About a thousand demonstrators marched through Auckland today protesting the visit of the American nuclear-powered cruiser Truxtun. The police said the march was peaceful, and there were no arrests.

title: Woman Killed by Tornado
description: A tornado that cut through a section of Conway County in central Arkansas early today killed an elderly woman in her mobile home, wrecked barns and damaged homes. Sheriff Carl Stobaugh said Laura Ramsey, whose age was unknown, was killed when her mobile home ''just exploded'' when it was struck by the tornado.

title: Treasury Bill Auction Rate
description: The Treasury sold new three- and six-month bills yesterday at average rates of 11.52 percent and 11.589 percent, respectively. The weekly bill auctions, usually held on Monday, were advanced to Friday because the Government security markets will be closed on Monday for the Memorial Day holiday.

title: Lane Bryant Bid
description: Limited Stores Inc. said it had received and accepted for payment more than 90 percent of the outstanding shares of Lane Bryant Inc. in response to its tender offer for all shares at $29 each. The offer expired yesterday.

title: BALLET: KIROV STARTS LONG PARIS STAND
description: The Kirov Ballet from the Soviet Union has not performed in the United States since 1964. But perhaps no foreign ballet troupe has affected American ballet as strongly in recent years as the great Leningrad company that trained and nurtured Rudolf Nureyev, Natalya Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: KOCH AND STATE LEADERS REACH ACCORD ON TAXES
description: Mayor Koch has reached basic agreement with state legislative leaders on a package of tax increases for New York City, including a surcharge on the personal income tax.

title: Europe's Iran Sales Start to Recover
description: Industrialists in Western Europe are cautiously attempting to expand sales to Iran, as indications emerge that Teheran intends to re-establish traditional trade ties.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Respite for Haig

title: 2 KILLED AND 8 WOUNDED IN RAMPAGE IN MARYLAND
description: A masked man drove a car through the glass lobby doors of an I.B.M. building here today and went on a shooting spree, killing two workers and stalking and wounding at least eight others as they cowered in office cubicles and corridors.

title: Astros Win, 8-3, Fanning 17 Mets
description: On a wet and generally disastrous evening in Shea Stadium, the Mets struck out 17 times last night, Randy Jones lasted less than two innings, and the Houston Astros broke a five-game losing streak by mauling the home team, 8-3.

title: Ray Nash, Professor of Art At Dartmouth, Is Dead at 77
description: Ray Nash, professor emeritus of art at Dartmouth College, a graphic-arts historian and calligraphy expert, died May 21 at his home in Royalton, Vt. He was 77 years old.

title: Low Clouds Over Falklands
description: Low clouds covered the Falkland Islands this morning, the United States National Earth Satellite Service reported. The service's spokesman, Thomas Baldwin, said that a cold front extended northwest from the islands and that thick rain clouds covered the area to the south.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 29, 1982; The Economy
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose 0.8 percent in April, its first increase in a year. Few analysts were willing to say that the increase indicated recovery was near, however. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige noted that it was concentrated in the financial components. Until such areas as home building show rises, he said, it is premature to look for any upturn. (Page 35.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SANDS OF TIME

title: Electronic Data
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said it is providing reservation and other data processing services to 25 commuter airlines that were formerly served by Braniff International. E.D.S. acquired Braniff's data processing, software, contracts and other assets for undisclosed terms.

title: Navy Expects to Reach Goal On Female Enlistment for '85
description: A shortage of civilian jobs coupled with pay increases for the military should help the Navy reach its goal of having 45,000 enlisted women by 1985, according to a Navy spokesman.

title: 76ers MUST ESCAPE TRAP TO EVEN SERIES
description: Billy Cunningham of the Philadelphia 76ers and his coaching counterpart, Pat Riley of the Los Angeles Lakers, agree that adjustments are essential in the National Basketball Association championship round.

title: PRESIDENT DENOUNCES BUDGET PROCESS
description: Calling the Federal budget process ''the most irresponsible, Mickey Mouse arrangement that any governmental body ever practiced,'' President Reagan suggested today that it be abolished.

title: Padres Reject Scott
description: The pleasant climate of San Diego does not extend, at least for the time being, to the baseball field. Manager Dick Williams is angered by a decision of Ballard Smith, the Padres' president. Smith, in turn, refuses to budge. And caught in the middle is Tim Flannery, a 24-year-old second baseman. The problems began last week when Juan Bonilla, the Padres' regular second baseman, broke a bone in his wrist, an injury that is expected to keep him out for the rest of the season. Flannery, who batted .254 in 37 games with San Diego last season, was available to fill in, but Williams thought he had a better idea: Why not sign Rodney Scott? Scott is a weak hitter but was one of the National League's leading base-stealing threats until let go by Montreal recently after three seasons there, and he had played for Williams, whom the Expos dismissed as manager last season. Smith did not think much of the idea, though, saying that Williams and General Manager Jack McKeon could have the last say on decisions about players unless ''one might have a negative impact on the rest of the club and what we're trying to accomplish here.'' Scott had left Montreal with a reputation as a player who was perenially unhappy, and Smith did not think he would fit in. Now it is Williams who is unhappy, and on several occasions since Smith rejected the idea of signing Scott, the manager has been publicly critical of Flannery, who won the job by default.

title: PRIDEFUL NEW JERSEY ADOPTS A FRANCHISE
description: It may not be much of a hockey team at this point, but the beleaguered team that was transferred Thursday from Denver to East Rutherford is cause for celebration in New Jersey.

title: Around the Nation; Pennsylvania Teen-ager Is Given Death Sentence
description: A jury today directed the death penalty for a teen-ager, described as having no remorse, who was convicted of killing two children with shotgun blasts.

title: Ring Around The Collar
description: You rarely hear about white-collar crime these days. Nearly all the headlines speak to the rise in violent crime, burglaries, robberies, muggings. Not without good reason - the public is justifiably frightened about street crime, particularly in cities.

title: Letter: On Education Aid For Medical Students, Monumental Debts
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL TO MAKE 2 INVESTIGATIONS OF JUDGE FRIESS
description: A State Supreme Court justice ordered the State Commission on Judicial Conduct yesterday to make separate inquiries into two charges of misconduct against Judge Alan I. Friess. The charges, one of which involved his flipping of a coin to determine a sentence, were originally contained in a single complaint.

title: Lincoln Chamber Group Adds to Its Roster
description: The Emerson String Quartet has joined Frederica von Stade, the mezzo soprano, on the membership roster of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Vandals Can't Halt Wards I. Art Show
description: The first few days of this year's open-air sculpture show on Wards Island did not go very well, so its undaunted organizers are planning to reopen the show today.

title: EISENHOWER MANUSCRIPT USED BY SON FOR A BOOK
description: Fifteen years ago, when he was 77 years old, former President Dwight D. Eisenhower began to write a book on a subject that fascinated him - the British-American alliance in World War II. It dealt with what made the alliance work, who its real leaders were, where they agreed or differed militarily and politically.

title: POPE'S COMMUTER TRAIN ARRIVES AT RUSH HOUR
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in London this morning in the most English fashion possible: by commuter train. True, it was no ordinary commuter train. The front was painted papal yellow, British and papal flags were fixed to the windscreen, a special directors' coach was attached, and the only passengers were members of the official party.

title: HOLDOVERS OF THE PRETENTIOUS
description: Fanciness in food is perceived in many ways by both the public and restaurant owners, and at various periods certain ingredients are acknowledged as gastronomic status symbols. If such ingredients do not contribute to the inherent quality of a dish, they are mere artifices and serve as guides to a restaurant owner's or a chef's pretensions. A few such examples follow as warnings of what to expect.

title: IRAQ'S ARMY IS BELIEVED TO BE REELING
description: A few months ago, Iraq had an army of more than 210,000 men equipped with more than 2,300 tanks, 2,000 armored vehicles, 335 combat aircraft and many batteries of artillery. Much of this army was occupying a deep salient in Iranian territory.

title:
PATENTS;
Audible Warnings On Photo Problems
description: Polaroid cameras with automatic ranging systems that focus the lenses according to the distance of the subject being photographed may be provided with an audible system to warn the operator of other conditions that may affect the picture. The new feature is not yet in production.

title: MOON WINS BID TO CALL OFF TRIAL IN FEDERAL COURT
description: The United States Court of Appeals yesterday ordered an end to a civil trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan and expunged the testimony given in it by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon. It also ruled that the testimony could not be used against Mr. Moon in any other civil or criminal case.

title: Seton Hall Loses, 6-4,
description: Maine scored five runs in the seventh inning to defeat Seton Hall, 6-4, today in the opening round of the national collegiate Northeast regional double-elimination baseball tournament.

title: HEAD OF REAGAN PANEL APOLOGIZES TO PUERTO RICANS
description: Faced with calls for his resignation, the head of a Presidential panel said yesterday that he had made an ''oratorical mistake'' when he described the Federal food stamp program as ''basically a Puerto Rican program,'' and offered his apologies.

title: FOR NUCLEAR POWER, NEW BLOWS
description: The American nuclear power industry, already crippled by soaring costs, depressed energy demand and public opposition, has been dealt a new series of blows in recent days. Experts now see little hope for a revival of the business for at least 10 years, and possibly not until the next century.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL RETURNS A $50,000 PAYMENT
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that he returned a $50,000 severance payment he received from a California steel company 11 days before taking office last year. He also said he would limit his tax deductions on two energy-drilling enterprises to the cash he actually invested, which is only a third of the deduction for which he believes he is eligible.

title: Around the World; Nicaragua and Honduras Say 200 Died in Flooding
description: Nicaragua and Honduras said today that at least 200 people had died and about 65,000 had been made homeless in floods described as their worst in nearly 50 years.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * CBS Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell $150 million principal amount of 10-year notes to be offered through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley.

title: Ivaco to Reduce Capital Outlays
description: Ivaco Inc. expects to reduce 1982 capital spending to about $35 million from more than $60 million a year ago, Paul Ivanier, president, said at the company's annual meeting here.

title: IRAN SAYS IT WILL NOT BE 'ADVENTUROUS' IN GULF
description: A leading Iranian official, in apparent response to concern expressed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said today that Iran was ''not adventurous'' and did not want to interfere in the flow of Persian Gulf oil to the West.

title: 5 DIE IN STOLEN AUTO AFTER RUNNING POLE AT L.I. STREET CORNER
description: Five persons were killed early today when their stolen car smashed into an electric utility pole after racing through the streets of this village at up to 90 miles an hour, the Nassau County police said.

title: BUDGET CHAIRMAN URGES LAWMAKERS TO MEET HALFWAY
description: The Budget Committee chairman suggested today that the House of Representatives ''split the difference'' between the Democratic and Republican budget plans it voted down by wide margins early this morning.

title: G. HEILEMAN OFFERS $24 A SHARE FOR ALL OF PABST
description: The Pabst Brewing Company got a second suitor late yesterday when the G. Heileman Brewing Company announced a $24-a-share cash offer for all of Pabst's 8.2 million shares outstanding, a total of $196.8 million.

title: A SYRIAN CITY AMID RUBBLE OF REBELLION
description: Hama is a broken city. In the first three weeks of February, Syrian armed forces and local Moslem rebels fought building to building in the alleyways, mosques and covered bazaars of this western city of 180,000 people, the traditional center of religious opposition to the secular Government of President Hafez al-Assad.

title: Red Smith Race Today
description: Red Smith, the former sports columnist for The New York Times who died last January, will be remembered today at Belmont Park by the inaugural running of the Red Smith Handicap. The mile and a quarter race on the inner turf course, with an added purse of $100,000, was known as the Edgemere in its previous 22 runnings.

title: Synanon Church Loses Its Tax-Exempt Status
description: The Internal Revenue Service removed the tax-exempt status of Synanon Church Friday. No reason was disclosed.

title: Indian Bureau Cutting Staff
description: The Bureau of Indian Affairs said today that it planned to cut the number of its regional offices to five from 12 and eliminate 372 jobs to save $16 million annually. The bureau has been sharply criticized by Indian groups since it announced last February its intention to reorganize.

title: STATE'S NEW COMPUTERS DELAYING 50,000 CHECKS
description: Technical problems with a new computer and accounting system installed by the state two months ago has delayed the payments of more than 50,000 checks totaling tens of millions of dollars, state officials said today.

title: GETTING THE FIRST DEGREE
description: In June 1888, Samuel Clemens -Mark Twain - received his first honorary degree, a master of arts, conferred by Yale. He was notified of this honor by his friend Charles H. Clarke, editor of The Hartford Courant, to whom he wrote: ''I feel mighty proud of that degree. In fact, I could squeeze the truth a little closer and say vain of it. And why shouldn't I be? I am the only literary animal of my particular subspecies who has ever been given a degree by any college in any age of the world, as far as I know.''

title: Hormones for Athletes
description: Dr. William Taylor, a specialist in sports medicine, reports that a new synthetic growth hormone could produce a generation of gigantic athletes.

title:
PATENTS;
NASA Aide Invents Acoustic Tooth Cleaner
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration received a patent this week for an invention unusual in its field - a tooth cleaner. Joseph S. Heyman, a section head at the Langley Research Center, Hampton, Va., was granted patent 4,331,422.

title: Angelo R. Bianchi
description: Mr. Bianchi, who lives in South Orange, served as New Jersey Banking Commissioner from 1978 until this year, and has campaigned on a program to bring down high interest rates and encourage more savings. He said Federal policies that led to the issuance of high interest notes had drained available capital and changed the nation's banking system.
