title: In Percent Yesterday previous Day Year Ago PRIME RATE* 16.00 16.00 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 13.38 13.69 17.56 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.59 11.60 14.80 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.75 11.71 13.80 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 13.86 13.81 13.57 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 13.45 13.34 12.94 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 15.76 15.72 14.58 MUNCIPAL BONDS 13.21 13.19 11.21 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.470 CERTIFICATES** * Split rate, 16.00-16.50 ** Maximum rate
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Harnessing a Loser
description: Say what you will about Frank Crnkovich, a 65-year-old harness-racing driver from South Haven, Mich.; he is at least persistent.

title: D.A.V. IS PUSHING 'RIGHTS' CAMPAIGN
description: More than a million veterans live in New Jersey, and the Disabled American Veterans is working to make sure that they know their rights and to protect them against cuts in benefits.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Something's In the Air
description: By allowing a little more tiger in your tank, the Environmental Protection Agency has grabbed a big tiger by the tail. Environmentalists were outraged last week over disclosures that the E.P.A. had quietly given oil companies the green light to increase the lead content of regular gasoline up to 10 percent above the published limit.

title: TWO WEEKS BEFORE THE MAST
description: JOANNE A. FISHMAN regularly writes about boating for The Times. BY JOANNE A.FISHMAN

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Outdoors; WHAT HAPPENED TO THE NATION'S STRIPED BASS POPULATIONS?
description: ONE of the nation's most highly regarded food and game fishes, the striped bass, is in trouble throughout most of its range. Most East Coast bass populations have been declining steadily since 1974, and commercial landings reached a 30-year low in 1979. Spawning success has fallen drastically in many areas and the reasons for this are not clear. In some instances it has been the degradation of spawning habitat. The striper is an anadromous fish, procreating in freshwater with the offspring, after varying periods of time, dropping down to saltwater to attain maturity. The adults usually return to the saltwater shortly after spawning is done.

title: Alva Baker Married
description: Alva Darcia Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Waverly Baker of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday to Gregory Alexander Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar A. Campbell of Springfield Gardens, Queens. The Rev. George Thomas performed the nondenominational service at the Riverside Church.

title: Jillon M. Stoppels Becomes a Bride
description: Jillon Marie Stoppels, daughter of Judge and Mrs. A. Dale Stoppels of Grand Rapids, Mich., was married there yesterday in the Central Reformed Church to Anderson Hunter Dupree Jr., son of Professor and Mrs. Dupree of Providence, R.I.

title: Jonathan Weiner Weds Deborah A. Heiligman
description: Deborah Ann Heiligman, an assistant editor of Scholastic News Explorer magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan David Weiner, senior editor of The Sciences, the publication of the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: COLLEGE-AID PROJECT FINDS WAYS TO HELP
description: FINDING the money for college is getting more difficult, but students at the New Rochelle High School are getting unusual help. Providing the only service of its kind in a Westchester County school system, the nonprofit Financial Aid for College and Technical Schools program, or Facts, helped New Rochelle seniors find nearly $1 million in loans, grants and scholarships last year and expects the same level of financing for this year.

title: AUTHORITIES SEEKING A MOTIVE IN MARYLAND I.B.M. SHOOTINGS
description: The authorities sought today to piece together the resentments that led a former salesman to stage a seven-hour shooting spree Friday in the building of International Business Machines Corporation where he once worked, killing two persons and injuring 10 others.

title: RECITAL: ASPEN WIND QUINTET
description: There was water music in Brooklyn on Friday night, though none by Handel, when the Aspen Wind Quintet played works by Elliott Carter, James Wintle, Reicha, Villa-Lobos and Poulenc at The Barge, moored in the East River at Fulton Ferry Landing just below the Brooklyn Bridge. The program opened with Mr. Carter's Woodwind Quintet (1948), a work typical of that composer's writing in those days, which is to say animated, involved, even tricky at times, but not overly concerned with metric subdivisions or rhythmic impossibilities.

title: DRIVE-INS, LIKE CHEAP GAS, FADE INTO YESTERYEAR
description: They were once the hit of suburbia, in the days when the girls in pedal pushers and the boys in blue jeans packed into '57 Chevies to watch Annette Funicello and Frankie Avalon cavort in ''Beach Blanket Bingo'' or ''Bikini Beach.'' But for many drive-in movie theaters these days, the allure - and the profits - of old are wearing out,

title: MUSICAL: A CACTUS OWNS 'LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS'
description: ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' at the WPA Theater, drawn from a lowbudget 1960 horror movie by Roger Corman, is a Faustian musical about a timid clerk who sells his soul to a man-eating cactus. Admittedly this is rather a rarefied idea for a musical comedy, but the evening is as entertaining as it is exotic. It is a show for horticulturists, horror-cultists, sci-fi fans and anyone with a taste for the outrageous.

title: THE LUCRATIVE ALCHEMY OF PHOTOGRAPHY ART MARKET
description: Ever since photography was born in the 1830's, its artistic value and expressive potential have provoked lively debate. Recently, however, these time-honored esthetic questions have been given a new twist by a very contemporary phenomenon - the much-publicized photography ''boom'', in which both the artistic prestige and the prices of photography have quickly risen to unprecedented highs.

title: PENTAGON DRAWS UP FIRST STRATEGY FOR FIGHTING A LONG NUCLEAR WAR
description: Defense Department policy-makers, in a new five-year defense plan, have accepted the premise that nuclear conflict with the Soviet Union could be protracted and have drawn up their first strategy for fighting such a war.

title: A WRITER WHO TRUSTS HIS READERS
description: COLLECTED STORIES By V. S. Pritchett. 520 pp. New York: Random House. $20.

title: New Jersey Guide; DELAWARE RAFT RACE
description: A cannon's boom at 8 A.M. next Sunday will send nearly 80 rafts off to a Le Mans-type start in the 13th Great Delaware River Raft Race. ''We used a howitzer from the New Jersey National Guard to start the race last year,'' said Gail Bolte, a spokesman for the High Life Ski Club of New Jersey, a Denville-based organization that sponsors the event. ''It's a loud bang.''

title: Tigers 7, A's 4
description: Lance Parrish hit a two-run homer and scored two runs, and Milt Wilcox and Elias Sosa combined for a five-hitter for Detroit.

title:
STAMPS;
TRIBUTE TO THE OLDER GENERATION
description: Anew 20 cent commemmorative recently issued by the United States Postal Service depicts one of the happiest consequences of growing older-the joy of having of grandchildren.

title: LIGHT, COLD, MOLECULES: THE FANTASTIC STUFF OF NEW COMPUTERS
description: The digital watch, personal computer, pocket-sized calculators and a host of other mini computing products owe their existence to the ability to cram complex electronic circuits onto chips of silicon no larger than a telephone button.

title: by Nora Johnson
description: WHO KILLED SAL MINEO? By Susan Braudy. 318 pp. New York: Wyndham Books, $14.95. THE WINNERS Part II of Joyce Haber's The Users. By Dominick Dunne. 378 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster, $14.95.

title: Fictional Prototype
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: This spring, a number of publishers are making available in paperback notable literary works that have been out of print or otherwise hard to come by. The following is a representative sampling.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; N.A.A.C.P. Seeks Clear Distinction
description: What's in a name? A distinguished place in the history of black Americans and in the budgets of civil rights supporters, according to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. For years, the association has accused the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund Inc., its former legal arm, of belittling its past and undermining its financial prospects by using the N.A.A.C.P. initials. ''It confuses people,'' said Jerry Guess, a spokesman for the association, which filed suit last week to stop the practice.

title: SENATE RACE IN NEW MEXICO VIEWED AS CLOSE
description: Based on political polls, former Gov. Jerry Apodaca and Attorney General Jeff Bingaman are in a tight race for the Democrat nomination for the Senate in the June 2 primary election.

title: CAN THE NUMBERS OF ILLEGAL ALIENS BE CONTROLLED HUMANELY?
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee, by a vote of 16 to 1, last week approved a bill that would overhaul the nation's immigration laws. The sponsor of the bill, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Antonia Hernandez, director of the Washington office of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, disagree on many of the underlying issues. In separate interviews, they discussed their concerns with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. At the outset, each was asked whether the nation had lost control of its borders and whether there should be more enforcement of the immigration laws.

title: Tax as a Remedy
description: To the Business Editor: Professor William Nordhaus has taken us around the barn in his discussion of the projected budget deficits - ''Cross Purposes on the Economy'' (May 16). In so doing, he collected a lot of smelly stuff we have been fed for years and insisted it is still good for us.

title: The Nation in Summary; Court Steps In On Georgia Races
description: Although pegged by some opponents as a consistent anti-civil rights fastballer, the Reagan Administration has recently thrown a few curves.

title: The World in Summary; K.G.B. Chief Joins the Club
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the veteran Soviet intelligence and internal security chief, hung up his cloak and moved his dagger to a new and probably more powerful office last week. He was ''relieved'' after 15 years as head of the K.G.B., the Committee for State Security, and joined the small circle of Politburo members who also run day-to-day Communist Party affairs as permament secretaries of the Central Committee.

title: Defiant Controller
description: When the air traffic controllers struck in violation of Federal law last August, Steven L. Wallaert became a symbol of the strikers' defiance of President Reagan's back-to-work order. Mr. Wallaert, president of Local 291 of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization in Norfolk, Va., was widely photographed being taken to jail in shackles.

title: UNTAMED MEDICAL COSTS
description: Tough monetary policies, bountiful harvests and the oil glut have all contributed to the decline in consumer prices. However, one component, medical costs, has been bucking the trend.

title: Dr. Susan Roellke Married
description: Dr. Susan Elaine Roellke and Dr. Douglas Alan Long were married yesterday at the Union Congregational Church in Dennis, Mass. The Rev. David Powers performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Roellke of Dennis, will begin her residency in pediatrics at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester in July, when the bridegroom will start a residency in internal medicine at Boston City Hospital. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Wittum Long of Elizabeth, N.J.

title: COLUMBIAN GUERRILLAS TRYING TO DISRUPT WAR
description: Guerrillas burned buses and bombed other targets, including a church, today on the eve of the presidential election, despite the presence of hundreds of soldiers with machine guns who patrolled Colombian cities.

title: The 'Good Deal'
description: Many people can't resist a ''good deal.'' When a ballpoint pen salesman offered one to the City Clerk of Ozark, Mo., she ordered six gross of pens.

title: RACQUEL WELCH: 'I LIKE A CHARACTER WITH BACKBONE'
description: ''Ireally wanted to sufficiently immerse myself in a character so that people wouldn't see me as Raquel Welch anymore,'' said Raquel Welch. ''That is to say, the Raquel Welch they see on the Academy Awards presentations. It was important for me to do that, and I think I succeeded.''

title: GERMAN FUN
description: Wilhelm Busch (1832-1908) was Germany's most acclaimed graphic humorist of the 19th century. Through his comic burlesques for Fliegende Blatter (the formost German humor magazine of the time) and his macabre morality tales (published weekly in Munchner Bilderbogen) he achieved a popularity not only in his native land but throughout Europe.

title: Sarah Conly Is Bride
description: Sarah Gothlin Conly, a costume designer in New York, was married yesterday to John Michael Deegan, an assistant staff scenic designer with the Metropolitan Opera Association. The Rev. Dr. George A. Pera of Alexandria, Va., performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dudley Conly of Gladwyne, Pa. Mr. Deegan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John William Deegan of Newtown, Conn.

title: CELEBRATING REAL LIFE WITH 'GREGORY'S GIRL' ET AL.
description: Real life is a spotlighted space surrounded by darkness. It's a situation comedy without a laugh track, a disordered succession of temporary achievements, disappointments, cliches, quandaries, promises, fears and pleasures. Most lives are chaotic but undramatic. This is why we turn to the orderliness of television's situation comedies, soap operas and game shows, and even to the news, which, trimmed to fit the same gap between the same commercials every night, reassures us by that sameness, whether war has broken out or Miss Kankakee has been discovered stuffing her bra.

title: G.M. ADDS A JAPANESE CAR
description: General Motors said its Japanese affiliate, Isuzu Motors, will develop and produce a subcompact car that is expected to replace the Chevrolet Chevette by 1984.

title: ARGENTINA HOLDING U.S. RESPONSIBLE FOR UPSETS
description: Argentina has stepped up its verbal attacks on the United States, suggesting that it will be held responsible for any Argentine setbacks in the Falkland Islands.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE ESCAPE FROM ELBA The Fall and Flight of Napoleon, 1814-15. By Norman MacKenzie. Illustrated. 299 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $14.95.

title: Sports People; Highway Robbery
description: Don Klosterman, the general manager of the Los Angeles Rams, has been criticized in recent years for losing key players.

title: John Baker, Tegan Reid To Be Wed
description: The engagement of Tegan Surfleet Reid to John Coalter Baker has been announced by Harriet Webb White of South Kent, Conn., and Alfred R. White of Kent, Conn., mother and stepfather of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of James A. Baker 3d, chief of staff at the White House, and Mrs. Baker of Washington.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: ART Among living artists, few have added as much to the gaiety of nations as Niki de Saint Phalle, whose recent work can be seen through June 12 at the Gimpel & Weitzenhoffer Gallery, 1040 Madison Avenue at 78th Street.

title: SHARING IDEAS ON JOBS AND BABIES
description: MANHASSET ''I FIGHT against acting like a pregnant woman - on the subway I hold my coat and pocketbook in front of me so that people won't get up to give me a seat.''

title: The World in Summary; Turn of Fortune For Iraq Makes A Region Tremble
description: Iran, anarchic and revolutionary, looked like easy pickings 20 months ago when Iraqi forces stormed across the border, eventually seizing 7,000 square miles of Iranian territory. But last week the invaders were on the run. They had inadvertently ignited Iranian nationalism, uniting mullahs and military. Iranian forces in two days of sharp battle retook Khurramshahr, the key port city on the disputed Shatt al Arab waterway frontier. They took thousands of prisoners as demoralized Iraqis broke ranks, tore off their shoes and swam for their lives.

title: THOSE FLEXIBLE 4x5 VIEW CAMERAS; by Jack Manning
description: Despite the tremendous popularity of the 35mm single-lens-reflex camera, there has been a large increase in the sales of 4x5 view cameras. Even Nikon, long a leader in the 35mm field, has recently introduced a full line of lenses designed especially for the 4x5 camera. Deardorf, a Chicago based manufacturer that for over half a century has been making fine view cameras (which sell for over $1,000 today), has back-orders from anxious customers who have to wait six to eight months for delivery.

title: THE TWO FACES OF SPIELBERG-HORROR VS. HOPE
description: As a child growing up in the 50's, Steven Spielberg knew, just knew, that another magical and somehow terrifying world lay just beyond the placid surface of his family's suburban life. Even the tiny crack in his bedroom wall, illuminated by the hallway light, promised all sorts of awful marvels. ''I remember lying there, trying to go to sleep,'' he says, ''and I used to always imagine little Hieronymus Bosch-like creatures inside, peeking out and whispering to me to come into the playground of the crack and be drawn into the unknown there, inside the wall of my home in New Jersey.''

title: Sponsorship
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SANDWICHES ARE STANDOUTS
description: GLASTONBURY TO a non-hockey fan, Gordie's Place is the antithesis of the image the raucous, fast-moving sport evokes. This handsome restaurant, ensconced in a dramatic, contemporary building reminiscent of a ski lodge, is a study in bright blue and Kelly green, with high ceilings, walls of pine siding, laminated oak tables and attractive dining areas separated for greater intimacy.

title: LIKE HUCK AND JIM
description: DOWN THE RIVER By Edward Abbey. Drawings by Edward Abbey. 242 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: 'MUST-PLAY' RULING DEBATED
description: YORKTOWN WELL aware that it is frustrating for a substitute to spend the season sitting on the bench for entire games while watching his team's regulars in action, Yorktown's Board of Education last February adopted what was considered a radical athletic policy.

title: A JOB WITH FEW DUTIES AND NO LACK OF CANDIDATES
description: ''It's not a final resting place,'' said John S. Dyson, when asked why he wanted to be lieutenant governor of New York, a post that doesn't seem to have much to offer on its own. Mr. Dyson is betting a hefty sum - much of it his own money - on it. Rivals are wagering large amounts of political capital. But if the job is a stepping stone, it has been an awfully slippery one.

title: Sports People; Frozen Assets
description: Jan Stephenson, the professional golfer, has had her assets frozen through a temporary restraining order obtained by her husband, Larry Kolb, in Fort Worth. The action by her husband is part of his fight against Miss Stephenson's efforts to annul their marriage, which took place March 5.

title: Another View On Utilities Regulation
description: Thomas E. Conine's column (''New Views on Regulation of State Utilities,'' May 2) demands response. His views are extremely well presented, but, unfortunately, his content does not match the quality of his style and organization.

title: SUCCESS AND CONDORS ELUDE BREEDING PROJECT
description: A nine-month effort to trap a pair of the nearly extinct California condors for a breeding experiment comes to a temporary halt this holiday weekend without a bird in hand so far. The quest is scheduled to be resumed next September when a new mating season begins.

title: ROMY SCHNEIDER, THE ACTRESS, DIES IN PARIS APARTMENT AT 43
description: The actress Romy Schneider was found dead today in the Paris apartment where she lived. She was 43 years old. Authorities said the Austrian-born actress had died of natural causes. ''Apparently she suffered some kind of cardiac arrest,'' said a representative of the Public Prosecutor.

title: Mexican Spa
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgian to Meet Palestinians
description: The Belgian Foreign Minister, Leo Tindemans, will meet Palestinian mayors during a three-day visit to Israel starting tonight, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Dr. J.F. Wedgwood Weds Ruth Glushien
description: The marriage of Ruth N. Glushien, an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York, to Dr. Josiah F. Wedgwood, a resident pediatrician at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: BALLET THEATER:'QUIXOTE' IN STREAMLINED VERSION
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov's ''Don Quixote'' is probably all things to all people. There isn't much of Cervantes's visionary knight in this production, and there is even less in the streamlined version that American Ballet Theater performed Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. The ballet is packed, instead, with enough frothy color to conjure up the ''Russian Spain'' of productions from Marius Petipa on.

title: WINE
description: THE DELIGHT OF SEEING RED enophiles who invest in future pleasure by purchasing wines when they are young, immature and relatively inexpensive often focus on the reds of Bordeaux, and with good reason. Bordeaux produces more fine red wine than any other region of France, and much of it ranks with the best in the world.

title: ON COMMUNISM'S POOR
description: -For those who worry about world poverty, the plight of the poor in Marxist-Leninist nations should be an issue of the utmost interest and concern.

title: The World in Summary; Shaking Up Agriculture
description: The Soviet Union, struggling with food deficits so serious the Kremlin still hasn't announced figures for last year's crop disasters, last week came up with its answer to agribusiness -new layers of agribureaucracy.

title: A DARING CHOICE
description: LINDENHURST IN the flush of praise lavished on Athol Fugard's '' 'Master Harold' ... and the Boys,'' this season's outstanding new play, Studio Theater is presenting the playwright's ''A Lesson From Aloes,'' which the Critics Circle adjudged last season's best play. A local theater couldn't be more au courant - or more daring.

title: Anne Kunze Is Married
description: Anne Kunze, a marketing administrator for General Electric in Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to James Alan Ruegger, owner of Hillside Construction Inc. in Metuchen, N.J. The Rev. Francis E. Potter, an uncle of the bridegroom and a retired pastor of the Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony in the Voorhees Chapel of Douglass College in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Flea Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: D.A.R. IS SEEKING AN 'ACCURATE' IMAGE
description: SOMETIME early tomorrow morning a dozen or so women dressed in white and wearing blue sashes will gather near the Bronxville train station. Shortly after 9 A.M., having lined up behind flag-bearing Boy Scouts, they will begin to wend their way through streets lined with spectators. The village's annual Memorial Day parade will be under way and, as is their custom, the Daughters of the American Revolution will be on the march.

title:
ART;
SURPRISES IN 'CONTAINERS'
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON THIS year marks a departure for the Elaine Benson Gallery, now opening its 17th season with a characteristically diverting exhibition on the theme ''Containers'' (through June 8). Traditionally, the inaugural extravaganza has been followed by clusters of individual shows, but this season theme shows will be featured exclusively.

title: Testimonial to Vision Of DuMont Is Hailed
description: The April 25 article announcing the commemoration of the first instructional telecast on the East Coast provided a fitting testimonial to the vision of one of television's greatest innovators, Dr. Allen B. DuMont. This writer takes pride in having been associated with the DuMont Laboratories in 1952 and succeeding years as a consultant in educational television.

title:
Speaking Personally;
BEHIND A HIGH SCHOOL CLASS' 50-YEAR REUNION
description: ''For it's always fair weather when South Siders get together. Though the world may forsake thee, we will always loyal be.'' SOUTH SIDE HIGH SCHOOL SONG- circa 1932-33

title: 72% IN POLL BACK NUCLEAR HALT IF SOVIET UNION DOESN'T GAIN
description: Most Americans support the concept of a freeze in Soviet and American nuclear arsenals, but they turn against the proposal if it means that the Soviet Union would gain a military advantage, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Union Is Called Answer To Freelancers' Plight
description: Little sympathy can be extended to the freelance writer who saw no need for a National Writers Union (Letters, May 2), despite a litany of the various ways in which freelancers are both underpaid and exploited by the markets on which they depend for a living.

title: Television Week
description: Preoccupied With TV For almost 10 of his 21 years, Lance Kerwin has been a professional actor -but his preoccupation with television as a viewer was nearly his undoing. As Mr. Kerwin explained recently, he was addicted to television and could not read when he reached the fourth grade in Newport Beach, Calif.

title: COLUMN ON GARDENING FAULTED ON PESTICIDES
description: Could someone please explain to me how, in this ''free country'' of ours, it can be legal for aerial spraying of pesticides to take place over residential areas?

title: AIRLINE DEREGULATION IS A 'TERRIBLE FAILURE'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORS, FRIENDS, COLLABORATORS, ENEMIES
description: GROUP PORTRAIT Joseph Conrad, Stephen Crane, Ford Madox Ford, Henry James and H.G. Wells. By Nicholas Delbanco. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: William Morrow and Co. $11.50.

title: Around the Nation; Computer Chips Valued At $3 Million Recovered
description: The authorities have recovered more than $3 million worth of stolen computer chips to break up what they believe was a major theft ring that preyed on California's semiconductor industry.

title: ENERGY EFFICIENCY: HOW TO GAUGE IT
description: WHEN it comes time for a purchaser to figure the cost of home o wnership, two of the most important tools are a cigarette and a s crewdriver.

title: 1,470 INTERVIEWED IN ATOMIC SURVEY
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from May 19 to May 23 with 1,470 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Cat People' First, back in 1942, came ''The Cat People'' (a power-of-suggestion thriller many fans prefer to Paul Schrader's new, gory remake). Then two years later, ''The Curse of the Cat People'' arrived.

title: Belgrade Play Called Insulting by Moscow
description: The newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya criticized Yugoslavia's National Theater today for staging a play that it said portrayed Stalin as a drunkard and expressed doubts about the ideas of Marx and Lenin.

title: TIME-SHARING RESORTS UNDER INQUIRY
description: The State Attorney General's office says it has stepped up investigations of the time-sharing resort business because of increasing complaints from New Yorkers about high-pressure sales tactics involving deception and misrepresentation.

title: 'SHENANDOAH' WINS DESPITE ITS DIALOGUE
description: THE resource material for ''Shenandoah'' was a 1965 movie that starred James Stewart. According to Steven H. Scheuer's, ''Movies on TV, 1978-79 Edition,'' it was a ''tear-jerker'' and ''basically familiar material.'' The musical version that opened on Broadway in 1975 ran for more than 18 months despite mixed notices.

title: POPE AND ANGLICAN LEADER PROMISE A NEW UNITY EFFORT
description: Pope John Paul II and the Archbishop of Canterbury announced plans today to set up an international commission to study steps that could lead toward eventual reunion between the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches.

title: USE OF TRADE CENTER RENTALS FOR TRANSIT URGED
description: The executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has proposed that revenues from renting space vacated in the World Trade Center by the State of New York be used to create a fund to rehabilitate crumbling roads, bridges and mass-transit systems in the two states.

title: YANKS TRIUMPH; TWINS FALTER AND LOSE, 6-4
description: The Yankees and the Minnesota Twins made Metrodome history today. They didn't hit one home run in a game the Yankees won, 6-4.

title: DENT, DEMOTED AND DEPRESSED, TRIES TO FIND HIS WAY
description: AS the late afternoon sun slanted across the grass at Yankee Stadium one day last week, Bucky Dent, alone on the field, pushed the sleeves of his nylon windbreaker above his elbows and set his face in concentration. Like a determined scrub striving for an everyday job, he took grounder after grounder at shortstop off the bat of Doug Melvin, one of the Yankees' batting-practice pitchers.

title: Lotusland
description: To the Editor: Quentin Crisp's fey tribute to Hollywood's Chateau Marmont in ''Visiting Lotusland'' (Travel, May 16) was only one of many published accolades this venerable and beloved establishment (circa 1927) has inspired over the years.

title: A CALL FOR 'SUBSIDIZED CREDIT' TO COUNTER HIGH INTEREST
description: BEFORE long, Felix G. Rohatyn believes, some form of ''subsidized c redit'' will be required to counteract the high interest rates l ikely to plague housing and other construction for some time.

title: 6 MEN SHOOT 2 AND ROB 75 IN A RESTAURANT
description: Six gunmen burst into a crowded restaurant here early today, shot two men, raped a woman and accosted several others, ordered the 75 other patrons to undress and left after 45 minutes with cash and jewelry.

title: STAMFORD'S AIR AGAIN AN ISSUE
description: STAMFORD ''STAMFORD is the carbon monoxide capital of the nation,'' Representative Toby Moffett has found, and air quality in the rest of Connecticut is not much better.

title: Orioles 3, Blue Jays 1 Blue Jays 11, Orioles 10
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Dave Revering drove in five runs in the second game, including a game-winning two-out single in the ninth inning, to give Toronto a split.

title: Text of O.A.S. resolution, page 16.
description: After 17 hours of emotional debate that ended early this morning, foreign ministers from Latin America today condemned Britain's attack on the Falkland Islands and urged the United States to halt its aid to the British.

title: ROBERT S. LEWIS
description: Robert Shippen Lewis, a managing engineer of special projects for the Robins Engineers and Constructors Divison of Litton Systems Inc. in Totowa, N.J., died Friday while on the way to his home in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE SPOTLIGHT IS ON JUDAICA
description: For collectors of Judaica -some of whom may be looking ahead to a significant sale of such material at Sotheby's this Tuesday and Wednesday - two current exhibitions at the Jewish Museum could serve as a preview. ''Fragments of Greatness Rediscovered: A Loan Exhibition From Poland'' includes nearly 90 examples of art and artifacts reflecting nine centuries of the Jewish experience in Poland through the 1930's. ''The Mamluk Revival: Metalwork for Religious and Domestic Use'' is devoted to a small selection of 19thcentury objects by Jewish artisans in Cairo, Jerusalem and Damascus who revived the crafts of the people who inhabited the Eastern Mediterranean from 1250 to 1517.

title: Annalisa Cozzi Is Wed To William W. Burr
description: Annalisa Cozzi was married yesterday to William Winthrop Burr. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee of St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., performed the ceremony in Oyster Bay, L.I., at the home of William H. Long Jr., grandfather of the bridegroom.

title:
Dining Out;
SUSHI AND SUCH IN HACKENSACK
description: WHEN the word was out that a European-trained Japanese chef had opened a restaurant in downtown Hackensack a couple of months ago, we optimistically wasted no time in getting there.

title: Around the World; Goldwater Tells Taiwan Arms Sales Will Continue
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, a firm supporter of the Nationalist Chinese Government on Taiwan, said tonight that there was no indication in the United States that arms sales to Taiwan would be stopped.

title: A SUMMER SEA THAT TEAMS WITH LIFE
description: PETER BENCHLEY is the author of ''Jaws'' and ''The Deep''; his most recent novel is ''The Girl of the Sea of Cortez,'' just published by Doubleday. By PETER BENCHLEY

title: INNOCENCE ABROAD-AMERICAN IMPRESSIONISM ON TOUR
description: PARIS

title: The Region in Summary; Claimed in The Name of New Jersey
description: Where tides shifted generations ago along the New Jersey oceanfront, property ownership may shift in the months to come. Last week the state laid claim to millions of dollars worth of Jersey shore under a centuries-old doctrine putting tide-washed lands under public ownership.

title: TEEN-AGERS DESERVE BETTER TREATMENT
description: Images are the very stuff of television. From the sit-coms to the soap operas to the commercials, viewers are constantly receiving messages about what is fashionable, acceptable or preferable. Is anybody listening? Enough, evidently, to make advertisers spend fortunes in aggressive efforts to peddle their products. But concerned observers have been worrying for years that television's ability to sell may go far beyond the latest in detergents and hair sprays. The little screen may be having a powerful effect on the most basic attitudes and values of society.

title: Hungarian Cuisine
description: To the Editor:

title: Janice E. Liverance Wed To John Thirkield Gelb
description: Janice Eve Liverance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Herrick Liverance of Chapel Hill, N.C., was married there yesterday to John Thirkield Gelb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Stuart Gelb of New York. The Rev. Peter James Lee performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Chapel of the Holy Cross.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
VANCOUVER
description: MOIRA FARROW is a reporter for The Vancouver Sun.

title: Jacqueline Neill Collins Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Jacqueline Neill Collins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard William Collins of New York and Millbrook, N.Y., was married to John Paul Hullar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Edward Hullar of Clinton, N.Y.

title: AFTER 50 YEARS, A HOMECOMING
description: STRATFORD THE 1932 graduating class of Stratford High School came back for a reunion last weekend and, like reunions everywhere, it was a test of remembrance.

title: THE FELD CHRISTENS ITS NEW HOME
description: ''It's looking beautiful, isn't it?'' said Cora Cahan. As she said that, Miss Cahan, the executive director of the Feld Ballet, was standing on a stage littered with crates and cables and she was peering into an auditorium that contained only one single seat. Yet she was happy. And so was Eliot Feld, the Feld Ballet's artistic director and choreographer, who stood beside her, positively beaming.

title: Art; STATE MUSEUM: THE BEGUILING PYRAMID
description: TRENTON DO YOU remember when pyramids were a fad a few years ago? Pyramidal shapes were seen hanging from the necks of even the most sedate types. Some pyramid cultists turned their beds into pyramidal shapes, sleeping more soundly under them, they said, and a few extremists went so far as to build pyramid houses.

title: THE CASE OF THOSE WHO CAN'T AFFORD TO HOLD JOBS
description: For a time last year, Pamela May was a woman with prospects. Although partly supported by welfare, she had a job. She worked as a billing clerk, had acquired a background in computer programming and was in line for promotion. With a little luck and a little time, she and her three small children might finally have won their independence and weaned themselves entirely from the public dole.

title: BRITISH SAY TROOPS TOOK 900 CAPTIVES IN FALKLAND DRIVE
description: Britain took about 900 Argentine prisoners during its recapture of Darwin and Goose Green on the Falkland Islands, but the commander of a British parachute battalion was killed during the action, the Ministry of Defense announced tonight.

title: VIEW OF FORGOTTEN LANDSCAPIST
description: YONKERS GOOD news for those who feel that art shouldn't be contemplated on an empty stomach: the Hudson River Museum is now sporting a cafe. Open during museum hours, the space is on the lower, auditorium floor and has a great view of the river. Current esthetic events at the museum, meanwhile, include a show reviving the landscapist J. Francis Murphy (1853-1921). It is on view in the Trevor Mansion through July 4, together with a selection of black-and-white photographs by Richard Weiss (through June 6).

title: ARTS CENTER: RALLY AND DOUBTS
description: THE proposed Long Island Performing Arts Center is drawing opposition from a bicounty group of arts organizations while its supporters prepare for a rally next Friday.

title: IRAN, IRAQ AND THE GULF
description: Iran's military advances have created two critical problems for the conservative monarchies of the Persian Gulf, on whose stability much of the West's economy depends. Saudi and Gulf state leaders must seek to ensure that when the Iranian revolution reaches the border with Iraq, it does not spill over it and make its way down to the Gulf. And as it becomes clear that Iraq has lost the war, its Arab neighbors in the Gulf region must also prepare for a change of regime in Baghdad, where President Saddam Hussein has staked his power and prestige on the outcome of the war.

title: CROWDS ARE DWINDLING AT A MEXICAN BULLRING
description: The gaily painted Plaza Monumental bullring was once the pride of northern Mexico and drew cheering crowds. These days crowds rarely disturb it.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TOY BANKS FROM PAST FEATURED AT MARKET
description: RIDGEFIELD EDWARD and Vivian Forrer of Kent, report they will take a station wagon full of nostalgia to the Ridgefield Flea Market next Saturday in the form of mechanical toy banks.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ALL the partisan wrangling of the General Assembly session that adjourned May 5 was forgotten last Wednesday when legislative leaders and a number of lawmakers from both parties showed up in the State Senate chamber.

title: Susan Stone And Banker Are Married
description: Sarah Gunnison Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Stone Jr. of Middletown and Madison, Conn., was married in Middletown yesterday to Frederick Charles Maynard 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Weekapaug, R.I. The Rev. William A. Spurrier performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Wesleyan Memorial Chapel on the Wesleyan University campus.

title: U.S. AND ALLIES FACE DIFFICULT ECONOMIC TALKS
description: The United States and France have reportedly agreed on how to begin rebuilding the international monetary system. Page 4. By SANDRA SALMANS

title: CATTUS ISLAND PARK: A WELL-KEPT SECRET
description: kept secrets. Although it is the largest facility in the Ocean County park system, no county or municipal road signs lead motorists to its Cooper Environmental Center and several miles of nature trails.

title: Correction
description: The Week in Business column last week incorrectly described the impact of Drysdale Government Securities' default on the Chase Manhattan Bank's profits. The default will result in a second-quarter after-tax writeoff of $135 million.

title: Tennis Title to Indiana
description: Heather Crowe scored a 6-2, 6-3 victory in a singles match today that helped Indiana beat California-Berkeley, 6-3, for the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's Division I tennis championship.

title: Strawberries
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article, ''Spring on the Strawberry Trail'' (Travel, May 16) but was disappointed that you neglected to cite New York state as being noted for its small-town strawberry festivals.

title: Helping a Guide Dog
description: Francis X. Clines is a reporter for The Times's Washington bureau. Russell Baker, the Sunday Observer, is on vacation. Once there was a blind man living on welfare whose guide dog, Shep, had her daily food allotment revoked during an earlier wave of budget economies by government officials. This was done on the state level, a decade before there was a President Reagan or a safety net, and one can only imagine the grand uproar and the swift recovery, complete with paw-shaking photo opportunities, if this or any President had ever taken the food from a seeing-eye dog named Shep.

title: How One Family Saved Through an Energy Audit
description: When Linda and Michael Sartori bought their 51-year-old West Hartford house in the fall of 1979, they could tell at first glance that it was a big energy user, but it took an energy audit to help evaluate what to do about it.

title: THE LURE OF BASS FISHING
description: Fishermen are always being described as ''avid,'' and my friend Geoff Ward and I fill the bill. We fish for largemouth bass in various New York and Connecticut lakes from early June to late October, then spend the long winter waiting for the thaw, sharpening hooks, touching up the facial features of artificial plugs and urging each other to recall past triumphs on the water.

title: Q AND A
description: QUESTION: I will be in Palermo, Sicily in August. Is ther a boat I could take from there to a port in Greece? - W. R., West Palm Beach, Fla. ANSWER: Ferry routes out of Palermo lead to Tunis and Naples. You could take a ferry to Naples and a train from there to Brindisi, a major Adriatic port where you can take a ferry to Corfu or Patras (Patrasso in Italian and Patrai in Greek). Or you could rent a car in Palermo and drive to Messina, take a ferry across the Strait of Messina to Reggio di Calabria and continur north and east around the Gulf of Taranto to Brindisi.

title: MEMORIES THAT LINGER
description: ''IN THE last few years, I've been haunted by these memories,'' said 66-year-old Anthony Iannarelli of Fair Lawn, ''and they don't go away.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I rejoice that the successors of Gregory and Augustine stand here today in the church which is built on their partnership in the Gospel.'' -Robert Runcie, Archbishop of Canterbury, at an ecumenical service with Pope John Paul II. (18:1.)

title: Coal May Be King, But It's Doing Well
description: To the Business Editor: Your coal article contained much accurate information, but arrives at an unwarranted negative assessment. I believe there is more to be said.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
A THREAT AHEAD FROM WORD PROCESSORS
description: THE rapid spread of low-cost word processing and computing equipmentr epresents a technological revolution that carries the potential of f ar-reaching changes in the structure of the labor market and the e conomy. This electronic revolution in the office may change who doesw hat sort of work, create some jobs and eliminate others, and c onsequently affect pay scales considerably.

title: Around the World; Soviet Said to Promise Arms for Mozambique
description: The Soviet Union has promised Mozambique continued military aid, the official press reported today.

title: THE WORST IS NOT NECESSARILY OVER IN 1983 BUDGET IMPASSE
description: The coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats that controlled the House of Representatives last year collapsed last week as the lawmakers failed in four days of voting to pass a budget. The question now is whether the House will ever be able to find a majority to adopt a spending plan for 1983.

title: British Troops Advance; Peace Efforts Do Not
description: The test of endurance between the Royal Navy and the Argentine Air Force evolved last week into a fierce fight on ground, sea and air for the main Falkland Island.

title: CONGRESS IS HIT WHERE IT LIVES BY FEARS OVER HOUSING
description: Demonstrating once again its election-year political sensitivity, Congress has begun reacting to the spreading fear that the American dream of homeownership is in serious jeopardy.

title: SUMMIT WORRIES ON RATES
description: Last July, when leaders of the West's seven-largest industrial countries gathered in Ottawa for their annual economic conclave, complaints about the damaging effects of high interest rates in the United States dominated the agenda. Since then, interest rates in the United States and elsewhere have declined substantially.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BATS, those nocturnal mammals that live on insects and proliferate in August and September, have arrived early this year. Already rabies has shown up in some of the animals, which is causing some concern at the County Department of Health.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 11 THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from nuclear extinction. 2 2 5 THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.'' 3 6 17 NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is strained by the Civil War. 4 3 3 THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his own romantic past. 5 4 6 CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men. 6 7 7 THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way love the same woman. 7 5 7 TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) A greedy crew at work in the world of horse racing and computer programming.

title: Excerpts from speeches, page 18.
description: In the birthplace of English Christianity, in the noble Gothic cathedral that Anglicans everywhere consider their mother church, the Bishop of Rome and the Archbishop of Canterbury embraced today.

title: Transit
description: To the Editor: James Q. Wilson, the reviewer of David Brodsly's ''L.A. Freeway: An Appreciative Essay'' (April 18), is described as ''a Southern Californian who happens to teach at Harvard.'' I am a New Yorker who happens to teach at U.C.L.A., but I hope I would have the sense not to pretend to be an expert on New York, even after only eight years' absence.

title: Letters; On St. Bart's
description: To the Editor:

title: TO FREE WALLENBERG
description: To the Editor:

title: Radiology Closings: 'Patients Will Suffer'
description: The recent article on the New York State Department of Health conflict with hospitals on Long Island with regard to radiology services (''State Seeks Limits on Radiology Units'') requires that someone speak up for the patients, whose point of view was omitted. I am an oncologist (cancer specialist) practicing in Long Island and will suffer no financial damage if the X-ray therapy departments at the hospitals where I practice are closed down. But my patients and others will suffer inordinately.

title: A Chef in the Kitchen at Last
description: It may be no favor to Al Haig to observe that the Reagan Presidency has finally found its ''single voice'' in foreign affairs - the slightly hoarse voice of its Secretary of State. That's not saying much for an Administration whose life is one-third over, and it could arouse the Potomac cannibals to new combat.

title: EMOTING OVER THE FIGURE
description: With the return of the figure to respectability in painting, we are going to have to steel ourselves to expect a good many celebratory shows on the subject. In fact, two such are with us right now: ''Focus on the Figure: Twenty Years,'' at the Whitney Museum (through June 13), and ''Agitated Figures: The New Emotionalism,'' at the Hal Bromm Gallery, 90 West Broadway (through June 19). The Whitney show, organized by Barbara Haskell, curator at the museum, puts current work by Expressionist-oriented younger artists in context with older figurative canvases of the past 20 years, while the downtown show, organized by the dealer Hal Bromm for Hallwalls, the vigorously alternative space in Buffalo, concentrates entirely on the present emotive, Expressionist tendency.

title: KOSHER FARE IN A FRIENDLY PLACE
description: IF you're looking for a warm, friendly, ''haimisch'' atmosphere, Ben's Kosher Restaurant in Greenvale, a new branch of the original establishment in Baldwin, is the place for you. As you stand on the inevitable line, waiting to be seated in the evening, a chef emerges from the kitchen bearing a platter of tiny, crisp potato pancakes or chopped liver spread on pieces of bread and offers them around. Just a ''nosh'' to prevent starvation. Everyone, from the deli countermen to the waitresses, seems happy to see you.

title: Compensating Owners Of Tidal Wetlands
description: Several weeks ago, I noted with interest the article concerning real estate in our area affected by the State Tidal Wetlands Act (''Wetlands Owners Fight State Price''). A very recent decision by Judge Leonard Silverman of the New York State Court of Claims deals precisely with the issues in the article.

title: Bermuda Offshore Race Draws 183 Boats
description: The Bermuda Race, the major biennial offshore competition that starts June 18 in Newport, R.I., has attracted 183 boats, one of the largest fleets in recent years.

title: Headliners; Civil Rights Perceptions
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission last week criticized Reagan Admnistration budget proposals as reaching ''a new low point in a disturbing trend of declining support'' for civil rights enforcement.

title: Television Week
description: A Teacher Learns ABC-TV describes ''Benny's Place'' as the ''drama of a proud man driven to a frenzy of action when he feels that his job, his dignity and his very life are threatened by time and younger men.'' The television film will be broadcast Monday at 9 P.M.; it stars Louis Gossett Jr. and Cicely Tyson.

title: LEGISLATORS CHOOSE PIERRO AMID DEBATE
description: lawyer, Village Justice of Port Chester and Republican - was selected by the Board of Legislators last week, in a politically charged session, to fill a seat that has been vacant since last October, five months before the death of Legislator John L. Messina.

title: Female Images
description: To the Editor:

title: MORGAN STANLEY'S MAN IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO His name is David S. Phillips and he is managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company. To anyone the least bit familiar with the sociology of Wall Street, the name, the title and the firm summon a distinct image - a man in his middle years, Ivy League-educated, reared somewhere in the Boston-to-Washington corridor, probably white, Anglo-Saxon and Protestant.

title: Rigid Enforcement Of Laws Needed
description: Laurie A. O'Neill's straightforward article (''Halt to Gun Permits Draws Ire in Town,'' May 9) made interesting reading. It will probably evoke a spate of responses from the anti-handgun forces; this letter is from the ''loyal opposition'' in anticipation of such opinions.

title: Headliners; A Bit Too Clinical?
description: Whatever problems Dr. Barry Singer encountered in teaching ''The Psychology of Sex'' at California State University-Long Beach, homework was not among them - he gave students course credit for their non-marital sexual experimentation.

title: Around the Nation; Strikers at Northwest To Vote on New Contract
description: A Northwest Airlines official said tonight that negotiators for a striking machinists' union had agreed to take a new contract offer to their members for consideration, but a union spokesman later said union leaders were recommending rejection.

title: WAGES ARE CURBED
description: The Quebec government, which is trying to revive its drive for independence, was obliged this week to announce unpopular budgetary measures to meet one of the severest financial and economic crises of any province in Canada.

title: Katharine Vogel Is Bride
description: Katharine Edith Vogel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ross Vogel of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Harvey Leon Frazier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otis Daniel Frazier of Fredericksburg, Va. The Rev. Robert Hancock Armstrong performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Chester, Va. The bride is a great-granddaughter of the late Alexander Grosset, founder and president of Grosset & Dunlap, the publisher.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages)NEW YORK Week of May 24 Week of May 17 Week of Mar. 1 Conventional 16.80 16.86 17.32 Rollovers 16.71 16.79 17.12 Adjustable Rate 16.41 16.46 16.76 Source: HSH AssociatesNEW JERSEY Conventional 16.54 16.62 17.55 Rollovers 16.52 16.57 16.91 Adjustable Rate 16.34 16.41 16.74 Source: HSH AssociatesCONNECTICUT Conventional 17.46 17.46 17.64 Rollovers 17.00 17.00 17.50 Adjustable Rate 16.58 16.60 16.73 Source: The Millard Group Inc.CO-OPS (N.Y.C) Conventional 18.03 18.05 18.16 Rollovers 17.09 17.19 17.75 Adjustable Rate 17.11 17.21 17.67 Source: HSH Associates

title: Judith A. Ford, Consultant, Bride of Matthew C. Baber
description: Judith Anne Ford, a personnel consultant with Dartmouth Consultants Inc., a recruiting concern for corporating-training programs in New York, was married yesterday to Matthew C. Baber, an associate with Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment company. The Rev. Charles Staiger performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Babylon, L.I.

title: COMPOSERS WHO LOVED THE BIG BANG
description: When Zubin Mehta crams 220 musicians of the New York Philharmonic and the Israel Philharmonic on one stage Wednesday night for a joint performance of Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique,'' he will be pursuing a fantasy of bigness and loudness that seems to be part of mankind's biological heritage. Perhaps a craving for double-barreled Berlioz, the ''1812'' Overture and other explosive displays was implanted in our proto-genes at the time of some cosmological bigbang - or maybe the desire to be startled by noise is merely one of those flights back into childhood that music often allows us to enjoy without shame. ''Boo!,'' cries Berlioz, and we shiver in infantile delight. In any event, Mr. Mehta is obviously drawn to such spectacles: he conducted the same Berlioz work in 1967 with the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Montreal Symphony, and in 1976 with the Los Angeles and the Israel orchestras.

title: GRAVEL MINE PLANS STIR UP A DISPUTE
description: DOVER TOWNSHIP THIS Ocean County community is the scene of a controversy, now at a standstill, pitting residents and town officials against an out-oftown contractor that wants to mine gravel.

title: LAW ON CHILD CUSTODY IS REVISED
description: Governor Carey, responding to a recent decision by the United States Supreme Court, has signed legislation requiring the state to supply stronger proof before it is allowed to remove children from parents whom it considers abusive or neglectful.

title: BONDS' CHANGING FACE
description: BONDS

title: A BILLION-DOLLAR PLAN FOR WEST MIDTOWN
description: I t is no overstatement to describe the 42d Street redevelopment plan as the most ambitious commercial renewal effort ever launched under mayoral auspices in New York City. The developers were selected on a preliminary basis last month, but the real challenge lies ahead.

title: MUSIC: CARDEW BENEFIT
description: Last December, Cornelius Cardew, a 45-year-old British composer, was killed by a hit-and-run driver in London. Mr. Cardew was not well known by the general musical public in America. But he was perhaps the most admired esthetician and moralist among the British avantgarde, and this month - his birthday was May 7 - has seen memorial concerts in London, on May 16, and New York. The New York concert took place Tuesday night at the Symphony Space, sponsored by the Kitchen as a benefit for Mr. Cardew's family.

title: Anne Smith Is Bride of John Goodhue
description: Anne Wickham Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Smith of Etna, N.H., was married yesterday to John Thayer Goodhue Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y. The Revs. Emmett Jarrett and Peter Camp performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Hanover, N.H.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FOREST HILLS
description: FOR all but the newest of New Yorkers, mention of Forest Hills e vokes one of two images - or sometimes both. One is of star-studded t ournaments at the West Side Tennis Club, long the most romantic of t he city's sport scenes, where the National Amateur and later the U nited States Open were played inside the turreted, half-timbered r esidential colony of ''exclusive'' Forest Hills Gardens.

title: SPRING TAKES TORONTONIANS BY SURPRISE
description: A history professor at the University of Toronto has a private theory on spring in this special North American city.According to him, every year about this time there is one very long night when city crews in silent trucks work their way up and down the many miles of well-kept streets in Canada's largest metropolis, methodically replacing the tall, leafless and barren trees that have stood there so starkly for the last eight months.

title: ACADEMIC CUTS PLANNED FOR MISSOURI DRAW FIRE
description: Budget-conscious administrators at the University of Missouri's main campus here have proposed dropping some programs and sharply curtailing others. But the plan has brought a flood of protest letters, emergency hearings in the State Legislature and criticism from three of the university's nine board members.

title: 'NEW JERSEY'S GOT IT!' HAS NOW HAD IT
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY may have it, but Borden R. Putnam, Commissioner of the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development, doesn't want it.

title: BOOKS: ABOUT NEW JERSEY OR BY NEW JERSEYANS
description: MAKING waves at vacation time - and not the easy, tranquil kind - a variety of books about New Jersey is throwing light on public faces, private places, personal gains and historic causes.

title: Leader at U.N. Pauses In His Falkland Effort
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar paused in his Falklands peace efforts today but officials denied that the talks were already deadlocked.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHY would an international group of scholars meet at a Long Island home to discuss the Russian avant-garde? Because David Burliuk, one of the leaders of the Cubo-Futurist movement, spent the last 26 years of his life in Hampton Bays, surrounded by art works and mementos of the days when he and his friends shocked and offended the public with their experimental paintings, poetry, films and theatrical events.

title: Packing for China
description: To the Editor: Good advice in Patricia Langan's ''China Bound? Pack Smart'' (Travel, May 9). I would like to add that a pocket flashlight might also be helpful because shops use such low wattage that one often needs help to decide on a purchase.

title: Out West
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING THE HOUSE-SITTING GAME
description: WITH summer fast approaching, many householders are wondering who w ill water the plants, walk the dog and take in the mail while they a re away on vacation. Or they may worry that their vacation will b ecome the perfect opportunity for a burglar to drop by for a visit.

title: BOOK LOVERS' PLACE
description: ''My husband had been looking for 10 years for someone to discuss Joyce with. He couldn't do it with me - I'm not a Joycean - but after we bought the bookstore a year ago he formed a Joyce Club and now they can all drown in each other's passion,'' said Lila Beldock Cohen, owner of Paperback Alley, 984 Sullivan Avenue, South Windsor. Joyceans will gather at the shop June 15, and one Tuesday each month, to discuss, read and generally commemorate the Irish author's works and spirit.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Mysterious Island' ''Mysterious Island'' (1961) is still another variation of a Jules Verne fantasy and it's ever so much fun, with a nice, professional finish. The 1961 film is showing on Saturday at 3 P.M. on Channel 9.

title: COUNSELING COUNSELORS FOR FRESH AIR FUND CAMPS
description: ''It is late at night and, as you are walking by a cabin, you hear a 9-year-old child crying. What do you do ?'' This was one of several hypothetical questions posed by a 25-yearold camp director, Almistad Webster, to a young applicant for a counselor position at Camp Hayden-Marks Memorial in Fishkill, N.Y. It is one of four summer camps operated by the Fresh Air Fund.

title: YANKS TRIUMPH; NIEKRO SHARP IN 5-2 VICTORY
description: The Mets kept striking out and losing last night as Joe Niekro stopped them on five hits and nine strikeouts and pitched the Houston Astros to a 5-2 victory in Shea Stadium.

title: Walking the Alps
description: To the Editor:

title: Shame, I.T.T.
description: To the Business Editor:

title: COHALAN TIED TO LEHRMAN
description: WITH the Republican State Committee designating meeting only three weeks off, only one Long Islander, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan, appears to have a realistic chance of a statewide candidacy in either major party, but his chances are dependent on a man he hardly knows, Lewis E. Lehrman.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECHES BY POPE AND ARCHBISHOP
description: Following are excerpts from speeches by the Archbishop of Canterbury and Pope John Paul II at a service today at Canterbury Cathedral, and the text of their joint statement after the service, as provided by the Vatican Press Office: Archbishop of Canterbury

title: Hilary I. Wiener Is Married To Scott Foreman Zarrow
description: Hilary Iris Wiener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Wiener of Fresh Meadows, Queens, was married yesterday to Scott Foreman Zarrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zarrow of Tulsa, Okla. Rabbi Irving Block performed the ceremony at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

title: Robert Brody to Wed Arlene Susan Berman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel I. Berman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Arlene Susan Berman, to Robert Brody of Rowayton, Conn., and East Hampton, L.I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Louis Brody of Brooklyn.

title: MEETINGS, MEMOS AND MOTHERHOOD
description: RETURNING to work after years of motherhood is a little like plunging into an icy lake the first day of spring: you are afraid of the chill, but at least you remember how to swim.

title: SEXTET: JIMMY HALL'S BLASTERS
description: Jimmy Hall, the lead singer and saxophonist of Wet Willie, the Alabama-based white rhythm-and-blues band that flourished during the 1970's, has embarked on a solo career that has produced two albums to date. And on Thursday he and his sextet, the Ghetto Blasters, brought their mixture of harmonized Southern rock and rhythm-andblues to the Bottom Line.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: BALDWIN IHATE to say this, but I never felt better in my life. What I mean is, I say ''hate'' because I was so used to hating first and getting to like something in my own good time, afterward; what I mean is, that's how a native New Yorker looks at life, even after he becomes an Islander; what I mean is - ah, take a walk, will you?

title: Senate Warning To San Salvador
description: Although the State Department said last week it was still ''uncertain'' about El Salvador's intentions toward land reform, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee feared the worst. The Republicancontrolled committee voted 12-0 to cut $100 million from the Administration's $166 million request for military aid to El Salvador for next year if the new Government changed the land reform program ''in a manner detrimental to the rights of the beneficiaries.''

title: THE STORY BEHIND DELIUS'S FINAL WORKS
description: One of the more affecting and heart-warming chapters in the history of music concerns Eric Fenby, an English musician, who was indispensable in the creation of Frederick Delius's last compositions. World War I had forced Delius to return to his native England from the Continent, where he had been living and could work in peace, and the move apparently dried up his creative powers. Back at his home in Grez-sur-Loing, not far from Paris, after the war, he became a helpless, blind paralytic, the result of an early disease. It seemed doubtful at the time that he would ever compose again.

title: RETURN OF THE BATTLESHIP
description: In this year of the centennial of Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth, and the probable resuscitation of the Iowa, William Honan's articles recalled an extraordinary event that happened at sea while President Roosevelt was aboard the Iowa, in November 1943, en route to the Teheran Conference, where he and Winston Churchill met with Stalin for the first time.

title: Future Events Music and Dancing
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Foreign Relations June 2 - Sol M. Linowitz, former United States delegate to the Organization of American States and former special Presidential negotiator in the Middle East, will receive the second annual Hans J. Morgenthau Memorial Award at a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof to benefit the National Committee on American Foreign Policy. Angier Biddle Duke, last year's recipient and the former Ambassador to El Salvador, Denmark, Spain and Morocco, will make the presentation. The nonpartisan committee was founded in 1974 by Professor Morgenthau to stimulate informed interest and concern in the problems confronting the United States in its foreign relations. Tickets, $200, from 628-0218.

title: Mailbox; That Was Dixie Walker
description: To the Sports Editor: It was early May 1942 at Ebbets Field, the Army-Navy Relief game between the Brooklyn Dodgers, with Dixie Walker in right field, against the New York Giants.

title: TRADITIONS OF SPRINGTIME
description: Roger Swain's article reminded me of a question on the ''President's Exam,'' given entering freshmen at Vassar College in the day of Henry Noble MacCracken.

title: BRINGING BACK THE 50'S
description: SUZANNE SLESIN is assistant editor of the Home Section of The New York Times. By SUZANNE SLESIN

title: A PURPOSEFUL BLURRING OF ILLUSION AND REALITY; by Andy Grundberg
description: Those in search of a model post-Modernist artist need look no further than Robert Cumming. His work oversteps the traditional boundaries between visual media, relies on verbal as well as visual cues, refers to theater in its use of illusionism and serves to undermine our faith in the veracity of representation. These are precisely the qualities advanced by today's theoretical critics as criteria for post-Modernist art - art, that is, which actively seeks to throw off our Modernist inheritance. The photographs, drawings, sculptures, books and permutations thereof that Cumming produces, although refined in appearance, are not really the locus of his art; they are more like artifactual evidence of it.

title: DARTMOUTH PAPER STIRS CAMPUS RAGE
description: All seemed collegial. As the sound of chimes floated softly through the long twilight from the clock spire across the mall, the student editors of The Dartmouth Review gathered last night with their mentor on the terrace of the brick, Georgianstyle Hanover Inn for drinks, jokes and their weekly appraisal of events.

title: TRIP WILL TEST PRESIDENTIAL PROGRESS ON FOREIGN ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON In between horseback riding and clearing brush at his Santa Barbara ranch last week, President Reagan pored over a fat briefing book on the conference of leaders of the big industrial democracies that he will attend this week in Versailles. Before leaving for Europe on Wednesday, he will have studied five more briefing books on issues and personalities he will encounter.

title:
GARDENING;
HARD-TO FIND PLANTS MERIT ATTENTION
description: THE number of known plant species is on the order of 300,000, yet the average garden may contain no more than a dozen or two. Certainly, not all plants are suitable or even desirable for garden culture, and to use too many in a limited space would be to create a hodgepodge rather than a garden.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle May 23 incorrectly characterized the breadth of support among black leaders for the gubernatorial can- didacy of George C. Wallace in Ala- bama. Mr. Wallace has been endorsed by Johnny Ford, the mayor of Tuskee- gee. E.D. Nixon, who helped the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. organize the Montgomery bus boycott in the 1950's, has expressed support for Mr. Wallace.

title:
Antiques;
DIVERSE ATTRACTIONS IN BRANCHVILLE
description: BRANCHVILLE TAKE an anvil, a baton, a lumber truck, a humpback trunk and a washstand, and you will have some of the ingredients for the first Branchville Antiques Fair, which will be held next Saturday on the site of the annual Sussex County Farm and Horse Show.

title:
COMMENT;
LE BUDGET
description: AS a ''moderate'' Frenchman, who feels by inclination nearer to M ontesquieu than Rousseau, I came to this country a few months ago r eady to admire the working of the checks and balances that are meantt o be the basis of the American political system. But the budgetary c ivil war gives one pause about the effects of these famous checks a nd balances.

title: Salvadoran Relief Aide Is in Custody of Police
description: Juan Francisco Zamora, the head of the Salvadoran Green Cross, who was reported kidnapped a week ago, has been in police custody on charges of aiding ''subversives,'' the authorities said.

title: AS SUMMER NEARS, FESTIVALS BECKON
description: SUMMER festival time is fast approaching, so in this column and the next I'd like to look ahead to the enticements of Music Mountain, Yale in Norfolk, Silvermine and other Connecticut centers of warmweather listening.

title: THE FAILED MISSION
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski does not fault the military in the execution of the plan.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices; DANCE
description: No one quite knows how to classify certain choreographers. Most of them come from modern-dance backgrounds. But because they have questioned traditional modern-dance esthetics, some observers call them ''postmodern,'' although other dancegoers consider that term too fancy.

title: The Failed Mission
description: As I was a member of the United States Embassy staff in Teheran on Nov. 4, 1979 (and subsequently, an unwilling guest of the Iranian Government for 14 months or so), it was not without a measure of personal interest that I read Zbigniew Brzezinski's article on the hostage rescue attempt (''The Failed Mission,'' April 18). Most incredible was Dr. Brzezinski's admission that he desired to take some Iranians as ''counterhostages'' during the rescue attempt.

title: Photo Center Hours
description: Extended visiting hours will be in effect through Labor Day at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street. The center will be open Tuesday through Friday, noon to 8 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Admission is $2 ($1 for students and the elderly); free on Tuesdays from 5 to 8 P.M. Information: 860-1783.

title: Hurting Rabbits
description: Animal lovers were angry because Revlon Inc. was putting shampoos, mascara and other cosmetic substances in the eyes of 1,800 rabbits a year to test the safety of its products. The procedure at issue was the Draize test.

title: A FLAT-SCREEN TELEVISION SET TO FIT IN YOUR BACK POCKET
description: Flat-screen, hand-held television sets - talked up in the television industry for years - are finally coming to market, and Japan's Sony Corporation and England's Sinclair Research are now trying to manufacture enough to distribute in the United States in time for Christmas. And the target date is apt: Either set will fit snugly in anyone's Christmas stocking.

title: The Region in Summary; Last Call for 18-Year-Olds
description: It took years to persuade Governor Carey that keeping alcohol out of 18-year-olds would keep more 18-year-olds out of emergency rooms. Last week, assured that Mr. Carey would sign it, the Legislature gave final approval to a measure raising New York's legal drinking age to 19.

title: Joggers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dumping: A Message For Connecticut
description: In his Long Island Opinion article ''Dredging: View From Connecticut,'' Whitney Tilt carefully tiptoes around the real issue in Long Island Sound dumping. No one objects to Mamaroneck or other harbors dredging their channels.

title:
GARDENING;
HARD-TO FIND PLANTS MERIT ATTENTION
description: THE number of known plant species is on the order of 300,000, yet the average garden may contain no more than a dozen or two. Certainly, not all plants are suitable or even desirable for garden culture, and to use too many in a limited space would be to create a hodgepodge rather than a garden.

title: Sports People; Gerulaitis Fined $2,500
description: Vitas Gerulaitis of Kings Point, L.I., has said he will appeal a fine of $2,500 imposed for his behavior in the French Open tennis tournament.

title: THE THEATER: 'THE FREAK' RESTAGED
description: Depending on one's point of view, Edgar Cayce, the early 20thcentury faith healer, was either a clairvoyant or a charlatan. Granville Wyche Burgess's play ''The Freak'' is pro-Cayce, but it is not didactic. One ends the evening allowing for the possibility of Cayce's talent - a tribute less to Mr. Burgess's play than to the performance by Dann Florek in the title role. Originally produced at the WPA, ''The Freak'' reopened Thursday at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater. It has suffered in the transition to a larger stage. What has remained constant, however, is Mr. Florek's perceptive characterization of this so-called ''miracle man.''

title: COSMOS TURN BACK NACIONAL BY 3-1
description: The Cosmos defeated Nacional of Uruguay, 3-1, in the second round of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup today before 14,212 fans. The crowd was the smallest to watch a soccer game at Giants Stadium since 1977, the Cosmos' first season here.

title: MANAGEMENT GOSPEL GONE WRONG
description: BOSTON It is a long way from the manicured grounds of the Harvard Business School to the sweat and grime of an assembly line. Most of the students who emerge from this elite campus for choice jobs in industry will come no closer to steel mills than the case studies they dissected. But from this cloistered world, two professors, Robert H. Hayes and William J. Abernathy, have come forth with a stream of articles and ideas that are beginning to reshape the thinking of American business about why the nation's bedrock industries, such as autos and steel, have withered in the face of foreign competition.

title: A CONTRAST IN CONTENT: SQUEEZE VERSUS ELTON JOHN
description: With the release of their fifth album, ''Sweets From a Stranger'' (A&M SP-4899), the English pop quintet Squeeze can lay claim to being the most artistically significant British pop group since the Beatles.

title: Mailbox; When a Rainout Should Be Called
description: To the Sports Editor: Enclosed you will find five tickets to last Sunday's Yankee game. As you will recall, the game was delayed for more than two hours before starting and then played entirely in the rain.

title: FOR SOME, A WAR NEVER ENDS
description: PICTURES of a time. World War II. I view a piece of history through pictures of a handsome man, a soldier; through pictures of my father. Perhaps, in that moment, there was hope. Perhaps, for a second, atrocities forgotten. An individual rising out of a rank and serial number.

title: Talking Co-op Deals; OCCUPIED UNITS LURE INVESTORS
description: WANT to buy a cooperative or condo-minium apartment for 50 to 70 p ercent below the market value? People are making such deals, but t here are some rather large hitches.

title: Angels 5, Brewers 4
description: Reggie Jackson hit a game-winning home run over the center-field fence with one out in the 10th inning. The homer, Jackson's seventh of the season, came on a 3-1 pitch from the relief pitcher Jamie Easterly (0-1). Luis Sanchez pitched one inning of relief for his third victory.

title: Around the World; U.S. Considering Sending Relief Aid to Nicaragua
description: The United States Ambassador to Nicaragua said today that Washington was considering granting its first direct aid to Nicaragua in more than a year because of floods that Nicaragua said killed more than 100 people, left 60,000 homeless and caused $200 million in damage.

title: Mary Henderson Fiancee of Seldon Taylor Clarke
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Henderson of Rumson, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Louise Henderson, to Seldon Taylor Clarke, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Turkington Clarke of Richmond.

title: Socialist International Panel To Consider Falkland Issues
description: Socialist International leaders began arriving here today for a meeting of a special commission on the Falkland crisis, which has created a rift between the West European parties and those of Latin America.

title: RETURN OF THE BATTLESHIP
description: William Honan's articles on the reactivation of Navy battleships was interesting and well-written.

title: BOTTLE BILL IN ALBANY TAKES CUE FROM L.I.
description: ALBANY IN the waning moments of the five-hour Assembly debate on the statewide bottle bill, Patrick Halpin, the newly elected Democrat from Babylon, stood up at his back-row desk to speak. Not only was the five-cent deposit on beer and soda containers an idea whose time had come, he said, ''but it also makes good politics.''

title: A NEW CHILL ON ORGANIZING EFFORTS AT SOUTHERN TEXTILE MILLS
description: RALEIGH, N.C. OF all the leading unions that are struggling against the recession and management's new bargaining power, few face a greater struggle than the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.

title: WHERE THE FANS ARE: WHY TEAMS MOVE
description: FEW subjects in sports are more emotionally charged than the relocation of a sports franchise from one city to another. The controversies surrounding the Raiders' desire to move from Oakland to Los Angeles or the Rockies' transplant from Colorado to New Jersey are recent examples.

title: 'STAND UP AND BE HEARD' AND OTHER 'LESSONS' OF MULTI-TOWN
description: I wish to thank Mr. Dorman for a very enlightening lesson.
