I wish t hat almost a decade ago, I and my neighbors living in the immediate v icinity of the Hempstead Resources Recovery Corporation would have h ad the courage but mostly the foresight to question our local g overnment's ability to resolve to our satisfaction the problem of s olid waste in our town.

title: BACCHUS IN CALIFORNIA, SHAKESPEARE IN STRATFORD
description: To the Home Of the Bard

title: WHERE PETS GET EMERGENCY CARE
description: HARTFORD HE was carried into the hospital at midnight, the victim of a hitand-run accident. His anguished cries and the stricken looks of his companions dismayed those in the waiting room.

title: The Region in Summary; Legislature Pours From Both Ends
description: Environmentalists got the bottle bill through the New York State Legislature last week, but the beverage industry got even. Although lawmakers approved the proposal, which requires a 5-cent deposit on cans or bottles of soda and beer, they also passed an industrybacked bill calling for a 5-cent-a-case tax to be used to promote recycling.

title: NEW LOOK AT TONALISM: BEAUTY DESPITE FLAWS
description: HUNTINGTON ONLY a decade ago, tonalism was a word that was heard with more frequency, primarily because of an exhibition celebrating tonalist art in San Francisco. Like many other American art forms, tonalism has experienced something resembling a revival, and the artists who espoused it have experienced rediscovery and renewed attention.

title: FOOD
description: INNOCENCE FOUND

title: MARTHA GRAHAM PURSUES NEW VISIONS
description: Sitting in her studio, facing her dancers, Martha Graham watches a semicircle of couples, allowing a visitor rare entry into her creative process. The women have just been placed on the floor by the men. Miss Graham suggests with good humor that ''it would be a good idea if you kept in mind that it's a love duet. It doesn't matter with whom you're in love - wine or poetry, as Nietzsche said. But you're drunk. It's about the male-female principle.'' Dissatisfied with the women's response to their partners, she urges a greater sense of passion.

title: Column on Gardening Faulted on Pesticides
description: Carl Totemeier's column about gypsy moths (April 18) is the kind of scare mongering that panics the public into over-spraying with broad-spectrum pesticides.

title: STOCKING UP ON WINS
description: Bridge experts in a favorable locale can multiply like the proverbial rabbit, although rather less rapidly. Consider for example the environment of the New York stock market.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Rolling Trough

title: CHALLENGE ON CUTS AT OTIS
description: YONKERS FRUSTRATION among politicians and bitterness among employees have greeted the recent announcement that 93 Otis Elevator workers here would lose their jobs because of ''deteriorating'' business conditions.

title: Labor Party Leader in Israel Criticizes Military Aid to Iran
description: Shimon Peres, the leader of the opposition Labor Party, tonight criticized the Israeli Government for giving Iran military aid in its war with Iraq.

title: Unquenchable Fire
description: For 19 years, the fire had burned slowly under Centralia, Pa., in old coal mine tunnels. Residents complained bitterly of poisonous fumes and governmental failure to put out the fire.

title: MAN WHO TOOK 4 HOSTAGES FACES CHARGES IN INCIDENT AT TV STATION
description: A 28-year-old man was charged today with kidnapping, assault and burglary after he took four people hostage at a television station and forced an announcer at gunpoint to read a statement on the air, the police said.

title: A NEED FOR HEROES FROM NINE TO FIVE
description: AMERICA'S boardrooms need heroes more than Hollywood's box offices n eed them. Heroism is a leadership component that is all but f orgotten by modern management. Since the 1920's, the corporate worldh as been powered by managers who are rationalists, who do strategic p lanning, write memos and devise flow charts. But we are not talking a bout good ''scientific'' managers here. Managers run institutions; h eroes create them...

title: A TOOL THAT STARVES THE GOLDEN GOOSE
description: To most people, ''discounted cash flow'' is just a puzzling piece of jargon. To business, however, it is a basic tool, as common as an attache case, as influential as the computers. Few factories are built, new ventures launched, or other expensive commitments made unless they satisfy the test of discounted cash flow. And according to Robert H. Hayes of Harvard, this basic yardstick is badly warped.

title: SKIP BY NIGHT FIRST
description: Finishing with a burst of speed, Keystone Arbor Stable's favored Skip By Night won the $148,000 George Morton Levy Memorial Pacing final at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Transit
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Red Smith Handicap
description: IN the hours before the first running of the Red Smith Handicap at Belmont yesterday, one of the late sports columnist's friends glanced at the program and shook his head.

title: BENEFICIARIES UPSET BY NEW RULES FOR FEDERAL STAFFS' CHARITY DRIVE
description: Regulations proposed recently to manage the Federal Government's annual charity fund-raising drive have disturbed and disappointed some beneficiaries, especially groups set up to assist blacks and women.

title: BLUE CROSS-BLUE SHIELD GIVEN INCREASES AFFECTING 4.2 MILLION
description: The State Department of Insurance has approved an increase in monthly premiums averaging 15.6 percent for 4.2 million individual and small-group subscribers to hospital insurance coverage provided by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York.

title: CARIBBEAN LOG: FROM NOVICES TO OLD SALTS
description: BONNIE BARRETT STRETCH writes about art, antiques and photography. BY BONNIE BARRETT STRETCH

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 30, 1982
description: International 900 Argentine prisoners were taken by Britain during its recapture of Darwin and Goose Green on the Falkland Islands, the Ministry of Defense announced in London. The British reportedly advanced on two fronts toward Stanley, the Argentine-held capital of the Falklands. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: WRITER ON THE WAY TO BEING AN AUTHOR
description: ''AWRITER could write two books,'' said Harvey Rachlin of Manhasset Hills, ''but one who produces three or more books is an author.'' At the age of 30, Mr. Rachlin is well on his way toward authorship under his own definition. Behind him are ''The Songwriter's Handbook,'' a reference work for the beginner and professional that has gone through seven printings and sold more than 25,000 copies since publication by Funk & Wagnalls in 1977, and ''The Encyclopedia of the Music Business,'' another reference work, covering everything from copyright law to recording and producing, which was published by Harper & Row last year. That book, Mr. Rachlin notes, has been deemed a best reference book of the year by the American Library Association.

title: Royals 14, Rangers 1
description: Paul Splittorff and Don Hood teamed to pitch a four-hitter, and Hal McRae had five hits and drove in three runs for Kansas City.

title: 10 KILLED AND 100 INJURED BY TORNADOES IN ILLINOIS
description: At least 10 people were killed today and more than 100 were injured when tornadoes smashed through three southern Illinois counties, the authorities said.

title: OF TIME AND THE WRITER
description: ROBERT SHERRILL is a reporter for the Durham Morning Herald in Durham, N.C. By ROBERT SHERRILL

title: Crafts
description: MONTCLAIR AWIDE assortment of jewelry and other objects, some of which provide a new look at an old Japanese metal-working technique, can be seen in pieces now on view at the Vitti Artisans Gallery.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSICThere is an art to dual pianism. It does not just happen when two pianists sit down at two pianos.

title: THE TAXPAYERS' BUDGET AMENDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: WAYNE WANG-HE MADE IT THE YEAR'S UNLIKELIEST HIT
Going Buggy On the Budget
description: It was not a good week for political parties, especially the Republican. On Capitol Hill, where the House worked four long days and nights only to reject seven versions of a Federal budget for 1983, party unity fared less well than stubborn conviction and election-year anxiety. Among the American public, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll, Congressmen, particularly those who support President Reagan's positions, are faring less well than Mr. Reagan.

title: BEYOND MILLS:MONEY IN THE BANK
description: RALEIGH, N.C. The Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, although best known for organizing J.P. Stevens & Company, is much more. The union also owns the Amalgamated Bank of New York, with about $1.3 billion in assets.

title: Around the World; Five New Ministers Fill Out Dutch Cabinet
description: Five new Cabinet ministers were sworn in today by Queen Beatrix to complete an interim minority Government of Christian Democrats and Democrats '66.

title: WINE DEALER'S NOVEL APPROACH
description: THIS has been a vintage year for Don Zacharia, better known to oenophiles in the tri-state area as ''Zachy.'' His first novel, ''Match Trick,'' was published in the spring by Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. Reviewers from such disparate publications as the Library Journal and Playboy magazine have hailed it as ''funny,'' ''outrageous'' and ''poignant - an exuberant novel.''

title: Sports People; Limon Beats Navarette
description: Rafael (Bazooka) Limon of Mexico, trailing on all three judges' cards, landed 13 straight punches in the 12th round to knock out Rolando Navarette and regain the World Boxing Council junior lightweight championship at Las Vegas, Nev. Limon, who held the title for three months in 1980 and 1981, started his barrage in the waning seconds of the 12th round, and his last punch sent Navarette to the canvas as the bell rang to end the 12th. Under Nevada rules, the bell cannot save a fighter except in the final round.

title: FOR BRITAIN, THE SOBERING IMPLICATIONS OF VICTORY
description: LONDON Last week's events were enough to keep even the phlegmatic British in emotional turmoil. On Monday came the news that seven Argentine planes had been shot down in a savage battle over the Falklands; up. On Tuesday a horrific photograph of the frigate Antelope exploding; down. On Wednesday, two more British ships lost; down again. On Thursday, British troops broke out of their beachhead; up again. Then on Friday, Pope John Paul II became the first of the 263 Bishops of Rome to set foot in England, a thrill just possibly topped when the Defense Ministry announced the capture of Darwin and Goose Green.

title: ARMS TALKS MUST AIM AT OVERALL PARITY FOR EQUAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: POOL SALES RISING AFTER RECORD YEAR
description: MANY Long Islanders have planned to celebrate this Memorial Day weekend at the nearest swimming hole - their backyard pool. There are at least 100,000 private pools on the Island, according to estimates by officials of the Island's growing pool industry. They report that sales this year are ahead of last year's, and that last year's sales set a record.

title: ROWERS IN A 'TRIPLE CROWN' BID
description: KENT CORKS flew from champagne bottles like tiny rockets and the winners, giddy with victory, sunshine and fatigue, joined hands and danced in circles, sang school songs and traded hugs and handshakes. Elsewhere, there were the losers, huddled and weeping with disappointment or quietly gathering up their equipment for the trip home.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; At Risk From Contraceptives
description: Both pregnancy and the ending of pregnancy through abortion have become significantly safer over the last 15 years or so, according to a study published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association. At the same time, however, a statistic has emerged on deaths from contraceptive use that is becoming a matter of concern to physicians.

title: TRENTON PURSUING A CULTURAL REVIVAL
description: TRENTON IN 1892, the Trenton Elks sponsored ''a new and original comedy in three acts'' by Brander Matthews and George H. Jessup. It was entitled ''A Gold Mine'' and it starred Nancy Goodwin.

title: GIVING THE HALIBUT ITS DUE
description: HALIBUT is an underrated flatfish that is often overlooked in favor of the more glamorous and expensive members of its family. Sole and turbot - both of which are flown in from Europe - cost twice the price and are most frequently to be found on the tables of highpriced restaurants. Halibut is delicate and close-textured, less refined than either sole or turbot but much better tasting than its budget cousin flounder (which is also known as gray or lemon sole). A lean and nonfatty fish, it is available all year round.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
description: 80. BRONX PRIMITIVE, by Kate Simon. (The Viking Press, $13.95.) A memoir of the travel writer's Bronx childhood. HANNAH ARENDT, by Elisabeth Young-Bruehl.

title: RULING LETS PREGNANT PROSECUTOR STAY ON CASE
description: The way the defense lawyers saw it, having a visibly pregnant woman prosecute a murder case in which the victim was stabbed in the abdomen would ''consciously or subconsciously'' prejudice the jury against the defendants. This was true even though the victim was a man, the lawyers argued, and therefore the pregnant prosecutor should be taken off the case before it came to trial.

title: MEDAL HONORS THE 'BLACK MADONNA'; by Ed Reiter
description: Life in Poland is bleak these days, but even in this time of lingering national trauma there are causes for celebration. One such occasion will take place this summer, when Polish Catholics mark the 600th anniversary of their ''Black Madonna'' shrine and a new medal, authorized by the Vatican, will enable people around the world to share in the observance - at least vicariously.

title: THE CUBAN CONNECTION IN HUDSON
description: ''STREET BEAT,'' by Stewart H.Benedict, is a true story about the narcotics racket in Jersey City. Although cast as a novel to protect identities, two such identities - those of the book's heroes - are easy to determine.

title: Headliners His Word Against Theirs
description: The Rev. Sun Myung Moon may not be ''the true Messiah,'' but he has the potential - or so he testified in Federal District Court in Manhattan last week.

title: Postings; USING THE ROOF
description: For 77 years, the Gotham Hotel has stood 21 stories tall at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street, topped by an elaborate copper cornice that made a fine Beaux Arts statement on the midtown skyline. Now the hotel has sprouted two new floors above the cornice line, a many-angled metal framework that will be sheathed in glass and that makes no design gestures to the masonry building below.

title: The World in Summary; Solidarity's Spark Glows
description: Polish authorities still refuse to talk seriously with them, but after more than five months under martial law, Solidarity's independent leaders show no signs of capitulation. The Government last week transferred Lech Walesa, Solidarity's leader, to a new place of internment near the Soviet border.

title: LARGE CUTS IN MILITARY BUDGET URGED
description: Barry Commoner, co-chairman of the Citizens Party, told delegates gathered for the party's national convention in New York yesterday that nothing short of large cuts in the military budget would resolve the nation's economic and social ills.

title: ON ST. BART'S
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Law School Upheld on Admissions
description: As leaders of the seven major student organizations at Rutgers Law School in Newark, we are writing in response to the letter (March 7) from an angry parent whose son was denied admission to our school.

title: PASSING PARADE: OVERDUE SALUTE
description: EVER since the end of World War II, Memorial Day has become more significant for me. I am increasingly aware of how blessed life is, especially for those who served and survived without serious injury.

title: Timothy F. Howe Weds Anne Berry
description: Anne Elizabeth Berry, a founding member of the Rockville Dance Company in New York, was married yesterday to Timothy Furnivall Howe, a financial analyst in the treasury division of the National Bank of North America in New York. The Rev. Mark Anschutz performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va.

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: Red-Hot 'Freeze'

title: Kathy Hite Shoots 71-208 and Leads by 2
description: Kathy Hite withstood half a dozen challenges today to maintain her lead after three rounds of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association's Corning Classic.

title: A REPORT FROM PEKING
description: CHINA, Alive in the Bitter Sea. By Fox Butterfield. Illustrated. 468 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: Daniel Carpenter Bacon To Wed Susan Makrianes
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James K. Makrianes of New York of the engagement of his daughter, Susan Moreland Makrianes, to Daniel Carpenter Bacon, son of Dr. and Mrs. W. Benjamin Bacon of Beverly, Mass.

title: FRENCH REPORT A MONETARY ACCORD WITH U.S.
description: A French Government official said today that a preliminary accord had been reached with the United States to move toward reconstruction of the international monetary system along the lines established at Bretton Woods in 1945.

title: 'Improper' Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING WITH THE CHINESE
description: FROM THE CENTER OF THE EARTH The Search for the Truth about China. By Richard Bernstein. 260 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.95.

title: Rebecca Allen Is Married to Steven Niles Barlow
description: Rebecca Watson Allen and Steven Niles Barlow were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the bride's uncle, the Reva.

title: KNOCK, KNOCK, ANYONE HOME?
description: day weekend that encompasses Memorial Day signals the beginning of summer and means: ''Get out of town.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM O.A.S. RESOLUTION ON THE WAR
description: Following are excerpts from the resolution on the Falkland Islands approved today by the Organization of American States by a vote of 17 to 0 with 4 abstentions:

title: Aramco 'Ransom'
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Brown's argument that ''Our Taxes Help Pay Saudi 'Ransom' '' (May 22), is interesting but does not square with facts. It assumes that the four companies that buy Aramco oil -Exxon, Mobil, Texaco and Socal -pay the full corporate income tax.

title: AN OVER-40 ATHLETE SWEATS TO BEAT THE UNRELENTING TOLL OF AGE
description: IHAVE a new set of heroes this year: George Blanda, who played pro f ootball until he was 48; Gordie Howe, who played on the same hockey t eam as his sons; and, especially this spring, some baseball p layers: Gaylord Perry, who just won his 300th game at 43; Carl Y astrzemski, 42, off to his best start in years; and Pete Rose, who i s 41 and seems to be going on 12.

title: The Nation in Summary; Hinckley's Side Finishes Defense
description: In most trials in which the mental state of a defendant is at issue, the testimony of one or two ''expert'' witnesses will do. Not in the matter of John W. Hinckley Jr.

title: THE RUMANIAN SHUFFLE IN A FEW EASY LESSONS
description: WASHINGTON

title: Henry Goldman to Marry Katherine Wyse in July
description: Mrs. Lee Guber of New York and Marc A. Wyse of Pepper Pike, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Lynn Wyse, to Henry Frank Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Goldman of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: DISSIDENT PREDICTS OUSTER OF KOREAN
description: Predicting that President Chun Doo Hwan will be out of office by fall, the leader of the banned New Democratic Party says South Korea must then move toward ''the restoration of democratic institutions.''

title: by Vance Bourjaily
description: ONE WAY TO SPELL MAN By Wallace Stegner. 177 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: Environews
description: SET AMID factories and sprawling housing developments, River Side, a tiny homestead farm in the Burlington County community of Cinnaminson, is an agricultural island in a sea of industrial and residential growth.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE GHOSTS OF AUSTWICK MANOR By Reby Edmond MacDonald. 144 pp. New York: Atheneum/Margaret K. McElderry. $9.95. (Ages 9 to 13) By JANE LANGTON

title: CLUES TO THE DRIFT OF CONTINENTS AND THE DIVERGENCE OF SPECIES
description: In 1910, Alfred Wegener, a German meteorologist and explorer, began a long quest for evidence supporting the seemingly preposterous notion that the continents drift hither and yon. He eventually found it in a strange guise -the global distribution of marsupials, animals such as kangaroos and opossums that carry their young in a pouch. Marsupials, Wegener pointed out, are largely confined to Australia and South America, which are separated by thousands of miles of ocean. Yet, ''even the parasites of the Australian and South American marsupials are the same,'' he wrote. The phenomenon, he concluded, ''dates back to the time when Australia was still joined to South America via Antarctica.''

title: No Headline
description: Untied shoelaces, flapping shirttails, wrinkled dungarees, turnedup collars, sleeves rolled to irregular lengths ... . One need look no further than the photograph of the copter bay of the Nimitz for an explanation of the ''technological'' failure of the rescue mission.

title: STUFFED VEGETABLES ISRAELI STYLE
description: JANE FRIEDMAN is a writer who lives in Jerusalem. By JANE FRIEDMAN

title: Hoyt's Streak Is Ended at 14
description: After his 14-game winning streak ended today, LaMarr Hoyt, the Chicago White Sox pitcher, dealt with the setback as just another game.

title: NOTES: CHICAGO OPERA SURVIVES A CRISIS
description: The Chicago Lyric Opera has long counted as one of America's leading companies, but in recent years it has shown signs of struggling. Some observers date its financial difficulties to the late Carol Fox's commission of Krzysztof Penderecki's ''Paradise Lost,'' intended for the Bicentennial and finally produced in 1978. Whatever the cause, the money woes finally led to Miss Fox's forced resignation as general manager.

title: No Headline
description: May 30, 1982 NONFICTION CHINA: Alive in the Bitter Sea. By Fox Butterfield. 1 DOWN THE RIVER. By Edward Abbey. 6 THE ESCAPE FROM ELBA: The Fall and Flight of Napoleon, 1814-15. By Norman MacKenzie. 10 FROM THE CENTER OF THE EARTH: The Search for the Truth About China. By Richard Bernstein. 1 THE GENIUS OF WILHELM BUSCH: Comedy of Frustration. Translated and edited by Walter Arndt. 18 GROUP PORTRAIT: Joseph Conrad, Stephen Crane, Ford Madox Ford, Henry James and H.G. Wells. By Nicholas Delbanco. 4 A HISTORY OF VENICE. By John Julius Norwich. 3 LULU IN HOLLYWOOD. By Louise Brooks. 7 MABEL. By Betty Harper Fussell. 7 ONE WAY TO SPELL MAN. Tugwell. 10 YANKEES AT THE COURT: The First Americans in Paris. By Susan Mary Alsop. 10 FICTION BLOOD ROYAL. By Arden Winch. 15 COLLECTED STORIES. By V.S. Pritchett. 5 THE COLLECTED STORIES OF AMADO MURO. Introduced by William Rintoul. 8 DEATH'S CLENCHED FIST. By James Sherburne. 15 THE ENGLISH LADY. By William Harrington. 19 FOR SPECIAL SERVICES. By John Gardner. 19 GRAVE DIGGER. By Joseph Hansen. 1 KAMAL.

title: Reagan Assails Budget Delays
description: President Reagan renewed his criticism of the ''ridiculous'' Congressional budget process today and blamed Democrats for coming up empty after ''a wild five or six days'' battling over a spending plan for the fiscal year 1983.

title: Navy Ousts Seton Hall; Maine Upsets Delaware
description: Navy scored six runs in the first inning and went on to eliminate Seton Hall, 15-5, today in the Northeast Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament.

title: UNDER FULL SAIL ON THE BARQUE SEA CLOUD
description: N otwithstanding all that has been said about the beauty of a ship under full sail, very few people have ever seen one. A ship coming in or going out of ports, with her ordinary sails, and perhaps two or three studding sails, is commonly said to be under full sail; but a ship never has all her sail upon her, except when she has a light, steady breeze, very nearly dead aft and likely to last for some time. Then, with all her sails, light and heavy, and studding sails on each side, alow and aloft, she is the most glorious moving object in the world. Even those who have been to sea a good deal are unlikely to have beheld such a sight, for from the deck of your own vessel you cannot see her, as you would a separate object.

title: ARGENTINE HINTING OF SHIFT TO SOVIET
description: President Leopoldo Galtieri warned today that Argentina might seek help from ''other latitudes'' in its war with Britain over the Falkland Islands.

title: Karen Sargent Will Be a Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Sargent of Rock Hill, S.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Rose Sargent, to Arthur James Raporte Jr., son of Mr. Raporte of Rye, N.Y., and the late Bernice Olcott Raporte.

title: JAZZ: STEPHEN ROANE DUO
description: When a jazz duo consists of piano and bass, one assumes that the pianist will be the leader, in fact if not in name, because the bass in this circumstance is normally the subsidiary, supporting instrument - unless the bassist is someone such as the late Charles Mingus, who was subsidiary to no one.

title: Miss Brooks Has Nuptials
description: Rosalind Hickox Brooks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Brooks of Cambridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to Robert Clarke Stowe, son of Mrs. Richard Henry Stowe of Ludlow, Mass., and the late Mr. Stowe. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church by Bishop John Bowen Coburn of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts.

title: E.C. Houston Jr. to Wed Miss Simons
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wadsworth Simons Jr. of New York and New Marlboro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Cade Simons, to Edmund Coy Houston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Houston of Middletown, N.J.

title: Gifts to Universities for Year Set a Record of $4.23 Billion
description: Cash gifts to American colleges and universities reached a record of $4.23 billion in 1980-81, rising above $4 billion for the first time, the Council for Financial Aid to Education says.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR: GRAND MASTER OF THE PLAYOFFS
description: PHILADELPHIA THERE was a faint knock at the door. It caught Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the occupant of the bright, spacious hotel room, in the middle of a thought. He hesitated before responding.

title:
CRAFT;
JEWELRY ON EXHIBIT--AND FOR SALE
description: THE small crafts gallery area of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers normally highlights works by several contemporary American designers. These exhibits are thoughtfully organized and mounted, despite the limited space, to illustrate the types of work being produced today in a variety of media. What sets these displays apart, however, from other museum offerings, is that they feature works that are also for sale. The gallery space, located just outside the museum's Red Grooms-designed bookstore, is an extension of that marketing area, and represents an effort to marry the exhibit and selling spaces in a positive fashion. It is encouraging to see superiorquality modern crafts in a museum and know that they are obtainable by the consumer.

title: A SOVIET PROJECT TEMPTS EUROPE
description: PARIS Beset by rising numbers of jobless people and ever gloomier recession, European leaders attending the Versailles economic summit meeting this week will undoubtedly ask President Reagan why he wants to sabotage the very project that they are counting on to help reverse their staggering job losses.

title: JUST A LITTLE PLACE IN THE SUN
description: but mostly about the East End, Montauk, the Hamptons, Sag Harbor - all the places the ''beautiful people'' play.

title: FROM PIPES TO CARS, FANS OF BING CROSBY BUY PIECES OF HIS LIFE
description: Bing Crosby fans, from as far afield as Europe and Australia, gathered at an auction house here Friday to bid on 1,400 lots of the late singer's possessions, including his pipes, his golf clubs, pocket watches, gold clips and some of his shirts, ties and socks.

title: Biliingual Editing
description: PERHAPS because Manuel Puig's earlier novels carry such titles as ''Betrayed by Rita Hayworth'' and ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' the title of his forthcoming novel - ''Eternal Curse on the Reader of These Pages'' - does not seem all that unusual. What is different about this novel is that Mr. Puig, an Argentine, wrote the book in English. Moreover, it is set entirely in New York's Greenwich Village, through whose streets a moody, down-at-the-heels American pushes the wheelchair of a demanding 74-year-old exile from Argentina.

title: Saudis Cut Costa Rica Ties
description: Saudi Arabia severed diplomatic and economic relations with Costa Rica today after the Central American nation decided to transfer its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, the official Saudi press agency said. Israel annexed the eastern sector of Jerusalem after capturing it from Jordan in the 1967 war and declared the city its capital in 1980.

title: MORGAN SHARES LEAD AFTER MALTBIE SLIPS
description: Roger Maltbie's six-stroke lead disappeared late today in the weather-disrupted third round, and, abruptly, the Memorial Tournament became a contest again.

title: Anne Alsop Plans June 26 Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Reese F. Alsop of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Spring Denny Alsop, to Peter Saltonstall Gardiner, son of Mrs. Charles Byrd of Manchester, Mass., and Benjamin Gardiner of San Francisco.

title: EBBETS FIELD ERROR
description: To the Editor:

title: A CORNUCOPIA OF SUMMER EVENTS IN COUNTY
description: WESTCHESTER parents in search of something to do with their children this summer need never roam beyond the county lines. There is a kaleidoscope of youth-oriented activities in the lower Hudson Valley, including fiddling celebrations and fire engine pumping contests, classes in sheepshearing, swimming and square dancing - enough adventures to fill the time between Memorial Day and Labor Day, for the family hearty enough to attempt such a feat.

title: I-88 LINKED TO THE THRUWAY AT EXIT SOUTH OF SCHENECTADY
description: One of the last major links in the Interstate System of highways in New York State was opened today, connecting Interstate 88 to the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway at Exit 25-A south of Schenectady.

title: CANDIDATES SPEAK OUT ON CRIME
description: ALONG with taxes and state spending, controlling crime is a major concern among many Connecticut voters, according to most public opinion polls. The Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor were asked by The New York Times for their views on ''What is the biggest problem with Connecticut's criminal justice system?''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JOURNEY TO AN 800 NUMBER By E. L. Konigsburg. 138 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14) THE ANIMAL, THE VEGETABLE, & JOHN D JONES By Betsy Byars. Illustrated by Ruth Sanderson. 150 pp. New York: Delacorte. $9.95. (Ages 9 to 13) By MICHELE SLUNG

title: Politics; BATTLE LINES ARE DRAWN ON BUDGET
description: TRENTON POLITICS has replaced the spirit of bipartisanship that Governor Kean, a Republican, and the Democratic leadership of the State Legislature loudly trumpeted at the beginning of the year.

title: Best Films on TV
description: There's one good thing about this week's late-late throways - old friends like ''The Fugitive Kind'' (Sunday), ''The Perils of Pauline'' (Wednesday), ''The Rose Tattoo'' (Thursday), ''Winning'' (Friday) and ''Dead of Night'' (Saturday) - they are usually televised at an earlier hour.

title: BY JOHN B.FORBES
description: MONTCLAIR DURING the week, many of them wear Wall Street pin-stripes. Comes the weekend, however, and they don armor and helmets and, as the New Jersey Lacrosse Club, battle some of the best teams in the country.

title: Television Week
description: A Dossier on Hoover Since the mid-60's, ABC-TV has helped to promulgate the image of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as coolly efficient, straight-as-6-o'clock crime fighters. From September 1965 through September 1974, the network presented -with J. Edgar Hoover's cooperation - the drama series ''The F.B.I.'' And last year, again with the bureau's blessings, ABC began a new series, ''Today's F.B.I.''

title: AMATEUR SOFTBALL A DRAW FOR WOMEN
description: STRATFORD ''IN softball, Raybestos and success are synonymous,'' said Kathy Arendsen, pitching star of the Raybestos Brakettes, an amateur women's softball team and winner of 16 national championships and two world championships in 1974 and 1978. From its initial season in 1947 through 1981, the team has won 1,774 games and lost 231.

title: Around the World; Flooding and Landslides Kill 20 in Hong Kong
description: Widespread flooding and landslides caused by torrential rains killed at least 20 people and left more than 2,000 homeless in Hong Kong's hillside shantytowns, authorities said today.

title: ANOTHER COMEBACK FOR MARK FIDRYCH
description: ending strikeout, and the gangly right-handed pitcher sprinted off the mound toward the home team's dugout like a commando. The record crowd cheered him all the way to a homemade sign above the dugout that read: ''Welcome Back, Mark!''

title: The Region in Summary; Sex Education Mandate Upheld
description: New Jersey has moved a step closer to implementation of an order requiring all of the public schools to offer instruction in all of the facts of life - but not to force all students to face all of the facts.

title: Carol Palmer Has Bridal
description: Carol S. Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Palmer 3d of Fort Washington, Pa., was married yesterday to Frank L. Newburger 3d, son of Mr. Newburger Jr. of Rydal, Pa., and the late Dorothy Newburger.

title: ALERT SYSTEM FOR ELDERLY IS UNDERGOING TESTS
description: A variety of electronic devices are being tested for elderly homebound people who may not be able to use a telephone in a health emergency.

title: Television Week
description: Immigrants' Plight The misery faced by an uneducated, farming family who came to the United States from a refugee camp in Thailand is the focus of ''Becoming American,'' a presentation in the ''Non Fiction Television'' series on Channel 13, Friday at 9 P.M. Ken and Ivory Waterworth Levine made the documentary, assisted by Marhsall Hurlich, an anthropologist at the University of Washington.

title: STATE UTILITY POOL MAKES BEST USE OF CHEAP POWER
description: At 10:20 A.M. one recent weekday, New York State's 5.5 million electric customers were using 15,044 megawatts of power. That power could have been generated by cheap falling water or expensive oil at any combination of several hundred generators, in the state or elsewhere.

title: VIETNAM RELEASES INFORMATION ON MISSING AMERICANS
description: Vietnam released information today about four American soldiers who were believed killed in the Vietnam War and said more bodies of dead soldiers would be returned to the United States.

title: IN ARGENTINA, PRIDE AND ANGER
description: BUENOS AIRES THE theater where Israeli pianist Israela Margalit appeared last week was filled with some of this cosmopolitan city's cultured elite, the sort of people who were among the few to be appalled by their Government's seizure of the Falkland Islands two months ago. But when a recording of the national anthem was played before the concert, they all stood and sang out loudly. It was characteristic of the spirit of determination that has taken hold in the face of growing British military pressure and the spreading beachhead on the Falklands.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON APARTMENT SALE
description: BRIDGEPORT FOR 285 families in two housing developments in this city, the Federal bureaucracy in Washington and multimillion-dollar private investments may have seemed to be worlds away. But earlier this month, those powerful forces converged on Park Towers and the Evergreen Apartments.

title: COLLEGES OFFER TIPS TO FUTURE FRESHMEN
description: EAST BRUNSWICK VISIT the college you think you want to attend. Better still, visit several so you can compare them. Talk with students, sit in classes and stay for lunch to check the food. Find out if the faculty is approachable, and call ahead to make the sure the admissions officer knows what you want to do on your visit.

title: Six Dance Troupes Set For Ballet International
description: Six European dance companies will perform in Ballet International at the Brooklyn Academy of Music next season.

title: Sarah Hamilton Atwater Will Be Bride In October of Robert Charles Mayer Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julian W. Atwater of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Hamilton Atwater, to Robert Charles Mayer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer of Washington.

title: 1892 MUSEUM ON BARNUM GETS REPAIRS
description: BRIDGEPORT THE Barnum Museum, a warehouse of information on the famous showman, is undergoing emergency repairs to a leaky roof and water damage inside.

title: IT'S WINE COUNTRY NOW
description: ''THIS area is booming!'' exclaimed David Tower, who is about to build a winery on the East End, thus joining the expanding ranks of grape growers and wine makers on Long Island.

title: AVANT GARDE: EVENING WITH TREVOR WISHART
description: One ascended to the SoHo loft of Experimental Intermedia Foundation Thursday night not quite knowing what to expect from Trevor Wishart. The answer came in an unusual evening of musique concrete, film and live improvisation that stretched the ears and mind more than many.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HETTY AND HARRIET Written and Illustrated by Graham Oakley. 32 pp. New York: Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8) By ELAINE EDELMAN

title: BALLET THEATER: NATALIA MAKAROVA RETURNS
description: Natalia Makarova, who was incapacitated earlier this season with a knee injury, returned to the stage at American Ballet Theater's Friday night performance at the Metropolitan Opera House. She was paired with Robert La Fosse in ''Other Dances,'' Jerome Robbins's tender suite to Chopin piano music.

title: DO SQUIRRELS OFFER CLUES TO HUMAN ILLS?
description: EAST ORANGE ''WOULD you like to meet my pet flying squirrel, Rocky?'' asked Prof. Jacalyn Giacalone Willis as she entered her home on the edge of the Upsala College campus in this Essex County community.

title: WAS THE ICE CREAM DOPED OR DOPEY?
Coal May Be King, But It's Doing Well
description: To the Business Editor: While I thought the coal piece was interesting, some of its conclusions are amazing and others are just plain erroneous. Your characterization of one of the world's most valuable natural resources as being dangerous to mine, awkward to handle and dirty to burn may have been intended to prejudice the understanding of the average reader, but it does not fool anyone who knows about the industry. Certainly, all of the buyers of American coal are still going out of their way to buy substantial quantities. As of this date, coal exported through Chessie facilities at Baltimore and Newport News is 2.6 million tons ahead of the same period last year, or more than a 26 percent increase.

title: STOKOWSKI, AN AUDIO PROPHET; by Hans Fantel
description: In all the recent tributes to the late Leopold Stokowski on the occasion of his 100th birthday last month, hardly anything was said of the great conductor's unique role in the development of the phonograph. Far ahead of almost anyone - and surely long before most musicians - he realized that music in the 20th century would be heard mostly through electronic means rather than in the presence of the performer; and this prescience spurred an intense concern for the techniques of broadcasting and recording which at times occupied him nearly as much as his musical activities. The biographical neglect of this aspect of Stokowski's career is all the more regrettable since new information has recently come to light from the archives of Bell Laboratories.

title: THE CHANGING MENU OF CHURCH SUPPERS
description: DURING the early years of the South Salem Presbyterian Church, whose 230 years makes it one of the oldest churches in the Westchester area, people would come to church on Sunday for the whole day. At noon, they would gather in the Meeting House, the only building that was heated in the winter, and eat food brought from home. Although today no alcohol is allowed in the church building, in the early days rations of rum were given to help keep parishioners warm during the services. Invoices for this rum can be found in the church's archives.

title:
GARDENING;
HARD-TO FIND PLANTS MERIT ATTENTION
description: THE number of known plant species is on the order of 300,000, yet the average garden may contain no more than a dozen or two. Certainly, not all plants are suitable or even desirable for garden culture, and to use too many in a limited space would be to create a hodgepodge rather than a garden.

title: Hard-Pressed Institute Selling Smart Chimps
description: A group of chimpanzees, including at least four that learned human sign language, are being sold to a New York facility because Oklahoma's Institute for Primate Studies is running short of money.

title: Around the World; Walesa Will See Family, His Parish Priest Says
description: Martial law authorities will let the detained Solidarity union leader Lech Walesa have a brief reunion with his family on his ''name day'' next Thursday, Mr. Walesa's parish priest, the Rev. Henryk Jankowski, said today.

title: A Prison Escape in Indonesia Leaves 11 Dead and 16 Free
description: Eleven prisoners are dead and 16 are still at large after an escape this week from the prison on the island of Nusa Kambangan in central Java, it was reported today.

title: FIVE THEORIES ON THE RIGHT MARKET TRACK
description: THE financial markets are giving off conflicting signals. A few p eople detect the glimmer of a turnaround in both stocks and bonds, w hile many others see only more of the dreary same. It isn't easy forp eople with nest eggs to worry about to know whether to stay liquid, t o keep their cash in money funds until the economy revives, to buy b onds, enter the stock market, or go back to bed.

title: Sports People; Low Profile for Bates
description: Billy Ray Bates, the guard whose flamboyant dunk shots and instant offense off the bench for the Trail Blazers have made him a hero in Portland, checked out of a hospital recently with plans to play summer basketball and alter his habits.

title: Bombings in Rome Damage 2 More Offices Linked to U.S.
description: Bomb explosions damaged the offices of Pan American World Airways and the Italian subsidiary of the U.S. Intercontinental insurance company, the police reported today.

title: Martha Borie Engaged To Thomas W. Wood
description: Mrs. Robert Masters Browning of North Pomfret, Vt., and J.R. McAllister Borie of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha McAllister Borie, to Thomas Washburn Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Wood of St. Paul.

title: GREELEY STREET THEATER IN SEARCH OF SUCCESS
description: CHAPPAQUA THEY are four dramatists in search of success, and they are pinning their hopes on a new play in June and on the rest of their first subscription series that follows. All residents of northern Westchester, they are involved in the latest production of the Greeley Street Theater, based in the Chappaqua Library.

title: GOING UNDERGROUND IN SILICON VALLEY
description: JOHN HENRY 'ONE EYED JACK' JACKSON, 44 years old, is waiting for his trial to begin, where he will face charges of grand larceny, conspiracy, and the buying, receiving and possession of stolen and altered property. The courtroom setting is familiar to Mr. Jackson, who is currently out on bail. He has been convicted four times on lesser counts, involving passing bad checks, forgery and burglary.

title: Nancy Davis Wed To S. A. McCrary
description: Nancy Locke Davis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Luther Davis of Wayland, Mass., was married there yesterday to Stuart Ashton McCrary, son of Dr. W. Ashton McCrary of Lake City, Iowa, and Marilyn F. McCrary of Des Moines. The Rev. Roger W. Smith performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Holy Spirit.

title: FREE TRIP TO CANAL
description: Carl Kriegeskotte, director of the Marsh Sanctuary, a county environmental facility in Mount Kisco, will lead a free field trip from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. next Sunday to a section of the historic Delaware and Hudson Canal at High Falls, N. Y., a 90-minute ride into the Catskills. Opened in 1828 and in operation until 1898, the canal was the principal supplier of coal to New York City, serving as the link between the coal fields of Pennsylvania and Kingston, N. Y., where it joined the Hudson River.

title: Best Films on TV
description: 'Midnight' Here is the week's cleverest, most sophisticated comedy. It's about an American chorus girl (Claudette Colbert) stranded in Paris, and pursued by a smitten cab driver (Don Ameche), who innocently gets involved in a marital tangle that leads to a weekend at a country chateau full of rich worldlings.

title: HOOPER SHOWS POWER IN FRENCH VICTORY
description: Dressed in red from shoulder to thighs, Chip Hooper looked like a basketball player making a dunk as he raised his racquet above his 6-foot-6-inch body, jumped high off the red clay and unleashed a booming smash. The smash was among his arsenal of weapons in a 6-3, 6-4, 6-7, 7-6 victory in the French Open over Jimmy Arias, the 5-8 teen-ager with whom he often practices.

title: AVANT GARDE: 'BOHEMIOLA'
description: David Weinstein's piano piece ''Bohemiola'' at Roulette Friday night sounded like a small sermon on the evils of modern tuning. Mr. Weinstein's keyboard was divided into six separate tunings; and if their combination achieved anything, it did momentarily wash our ears clean of equal temperament's impurities.

title: SCHOOL AIDE SUING ON CENSORING ISSUE
description: CARLE PLACE THE former faculty adviser to the Carle Place High School newspaper, the Crossroads, is charging that the principal set up censorship blockades.

title: The Editorial Notebook Remembering the NOK
description: The following passage is from ''Neverlight,'' a new novel about Vietnam by Donald Pfarrer. He was Lieutenant Commander something. She hardly saw his uniform and did not see his face at all, but she caught the rank. Richard had said all lieutenant commanders were soft in the head. She forgot the reason, but Richard declared that even good men went bad on promotion to that rank.

title: Postings; SAVING A MANSION
description: At the turn of the century, Morton Freeman Plant, who made a fortune in the railroad and hotel business, built a grand mansion in Groton, Conn., on a bluff overlooking Long Island Sound. It had 20 bedrooms and a banquet hall that could accommodate 100 people and it cost more than $3 million.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
ART TAKES SHAPE AT ALBEE 'BARN'
description: MONTAUK AT first glance, the Barn is simply that - a huge, white building of undetermined architectural origin, set down almost haphazardly in a clearing of dense, overgrown woods and brush. A peek inside the structure and an adjacent red-shingled low-lying building, however, suggests that there is more going on than meets the casual eye.

title: Martin B. Brix Marries Kim Robinson Pierce
description: At the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday, Kim Robinson Pierce was married to Martin Bradley Brix by the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop.

title: Sally Kilbridge Is Wed To Richard Covington
description: Sally Ann Kilbridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Xavier Kilbridge of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Richard Peace Covington, son of Dean Covington of Rome, Ga., and the late Mrs. Covington. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: HARTFORD BOXER SEEKS TOP-10 RANK
description: HARTFORD HE has won all 22 of his professional fights, 14 by knockout, is ranked 10th among the world's welterweights by Ring magazine and is regarded as the best fighter from Connecticut since Willie Pep was the featherweight champion more than three decades ago. Yet Marlon Starling attained his greatest measure of celebrity when his jaw was broken by the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, Thomas Hearns, while sparring.

title: VIETNAMESE FARE IN ABIDJAN
description: PRANAY B.GUPTE is a Times correspondent based in Nairobi. BY PRANAY B.GUPTE

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HOLIDAY EVENTS
description: When it comes to marking Memorial Day, variety is the spice of holiday weekend life. There's the traditional route, with family barbecues and small-town parades. Today at 2 P.M., Huntington, with its ever-present militia on call, will show its historic colors along New York Avenue and East Main Street. Tomorrow at 10 A.M., the annual Memorial Day Parade along Main Street will add another dimension to Bay Shore's Arts Festival.

title: THE NEW FACE OF KABUKI
description: Steve Lohr is a New York Times correspondent based in Tokyo. BY STEVE LOHR

title: HIGHLAND BLADE WINS RED SMITH ON TURF
description: It was the kind of race its namesake would have enjoyed: a driving finish, a hard-luck horse finally getting to the winner's circle in an important race and a controversial aftermath. When it was over, Highland Blade had won the inaugural running of the Red Smith Handicap.

title: FOYT, 47, ENDURING AT INDY
description: Back when hundreds of thousands of fans did not have to wait more than four months for the official Indianapolis 500 winner to be announced, in the days before racing cars wore wings and before litigation replaced good old-fashioned fist-fights as a means of settling disagreements, the concerns were the same as they are today.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THIS WEEK: Time off to relax and enjoy the three-day holiday weekend. FOR READING

title: Gant Beats Challenges To Win 300-Mile Race
description: Harry Gant held off a two-way challenge for first place with less than 20 laps to go today and won the Mello Yello 300 sportsman's race at Charlotte Motor Speedway.

title: Q and A; The Sound of Music
description: Question: A pianist moved into a brownstone next to mine. Although he is ''reasonable'' about his practice hours (9 A.M. to 10 P.M.), my apartment has become a veritable sounding board for his music. I have complained three times, suggesting that he install insulation, but to no avail. What can I do to preserve my right to relative peace and quiet? ... M.A., Manhattan Answer: John Cunningham of the City Department of Environmental Protection (telephone 566-0108) says the city's Noise Pollution Control Code prohibits ''any excessive or unusually loud sound, or any sound which either annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of a person. ...''

title: 'SHENANDOAH' WINS IN DARIEN DESPITE ITS DIALOGUE
description: TO refer to ''Shenandoah'' as a musical is stretching things a bit. Based on a 1965 movie starring James Stewart, it opened on Broadway in 1975 and ran for more than 18 months, despite mixed notices. Yes, there are songs, but only one of them even approaches being memorable. That one, entitled, ''Freedom,'' is performed with relish in the Darien, Conn., production by Tricia Witham and Jimmy Tate, a youngster who comes close to walking off with the entire show as Gabriel, a slave child.

title: SALVADOR EVICTS PEASANTS FROM LAND
description: The shirtless peasant affectionately touched the tomato sprigs with the tip of his machete. ''It's prohibited that I come here anymore,'' Luis Alonso Burgos said. ''I can't work here.'' Mr. Burgos, who is missing his upper teeth, cannot read or write, except to sign his name. He thinks he is 44 years old.

title: Telicommunity: An Inside View
description: As the program director of Telicommunity from December 1980 until January 1982, I feel compelled to respond to the letter to the editor of May 2, written by Barbara Gore Suter.

title: Traditions of Springtime
description: Thank you so much for Roger Swain's article ''Reading the Signs of Spring'' (April 25). It was so beautiful and refreshing, just like being there! SYLVIA MCKENNA, Elkins Park, Pa.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; States Demand A Fresher Slice Of Education Pie
description: Basing policy decisions on 1980 census data may not guarantee accuracy; but basing them on census figures 10 years old is one way to guarantee inaccuracy, New York and nine other states argued last week. The states filed suit in Federal District Court in Washington, D.C., to prohibit the Department of Education from using the 1970 census data in distributing the $2.4 billion designated for the education of poor children for the coming school year.

title: TO A DRIVER'S WIFE, STRENGTH IS A SHIELD
description: She is living by a creed of strength. Most of the wives of drivers in the Indianapolis 500 insist that they have to. But when Barbara Smiley speaks of her husband Gordon's fatal accident at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway two weeks ago, the armor slips and her voice gives way to tremors.

title: SUPERPOWERS FEEL THE HEAT OF COSTLY 'BRUSH-FIRE' WARS
description: PARIS TWO quick grabs for land, gravely miscalculated as cheap and easy, have bogged down into raging wars still without prospect of solution. The battle for the Falkland Islands and the fighting between Iran and Iraq are what used to be called ''brush-fire wars'' a generation ago - not directly involving the East-West confrontation but weighing on superpower interests with threats to upset regional power balances.

title: THE PURPLE HEART: HOLDERS REMINISCE
description: WHEN John Guarracino of Hoboken was in an Army hospital during World War I - he had been hit in the foot by shrapnel and, later, gassed - he neglected to correct his misspelled name on hospital records.

title: Tower of Babel
description: To the Editor:

title: REPAIRING A GARDEN HOSE MAY BE SIMPLER THAN YOU THINK
description: THIS is the time of year when garden hoses probably get more use - and take more abuse - than almost any other piece of outdoor equipment around the home. Carelessly handled, hoses get stepped on, kinked and driven over until they finally crack or develop leaks that make them almost useless.

title: HOW FLOOD GAUGES WILL WORK IN AREA
description: ANEW flood-alert system being planned by the county is looked on by officials in flood-prone communities as having the potential for saving lives and protecting property but many also point to the need for flood-control measures.

title: GARDENING CAN BE EASY-FOR SOME PEOPLE
description: Along with such certain indices of spring as sneezing and the moveable ice cream truck, I always know that the season is here because my yellow flowers bloom.

title: TWO FALKLAND TABOOS
description: Warlike acts are going on in the South Atlantic, but to say that Britain and the Argentines are at war is to enter an area of taboo. ''War'' has become a terrible word, signifying the doorway to planetary destruction. But a deeper taboo seems to be in operation, and that has more to do with morality than with historical rights, colonialist greed, imperialistic aggression and the rest of the popular shibboleths.

title: Katherine Foran Bride of David Heim
description: Katherine Louise Foran, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Lott of Minneapolis, was married yesterday to David Heim of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Heim of Wheatridge, Colo. The Rev. Charles A. Park of Christ Episcopal Church in Stroudsburg, Pa., performed the ceremony at the couple's country home in Saylorsburg, Pa.

title: Foreign Affairs; A STRANGE MATCH
description: President Francois Mitterrand, host at this week's Versailles economic summit, has brought about a quiet, and unexpected, change in French foreign policy during his first year in office.

title: THE DANDELION: A TRUE AMERICAN BEAUTY
description: SPRING has arrived and so have the dandelions. Here by the porch, there by the drive, everywhere - even over by the well. For years I struggled to get rid of them. One summer I wore out a pair of leather gloves trying to dig them up. Another summer our dog Fred almost died from drinking the weed killer I mixed in the garage.

title: COUNTING DELEGATES AND POLITICAL CHANCES
description: HARTFORD FOR Rick Story, a blue box is something out of that television commercial for a charge card. He never leaves home without it. As an added precaution, he also keeps an identical blue box for safekeeping - in a bank vault. The blue box, which resembles a salesman's sample case, contains sets of brown books with page after page of names and information about some 5,000 Republicans who have been active in Connecticut politics for the past 10 years.

title: In Memoriam
description: If the district attorney's office releases the remains, a memorial service is to be held in Los Angeles for 17,000 aborted fetuses and embryos recovered from the backyard of a Santa Monica medical laboratory. President Reagan will probably not attend, but he says in a letter to the California Pro Life Medical Association, ''Your decision to hold a memorial service for these children is most fitting and proper.

title: Washington; MEMORIAL DAY 1982
description: On Memorial Day weekend, of all times, the Argentine generals, of all people, have been lecturing the world on the horrors of war at the United Nations, of all places.

title: TRADITIONS OF SPRINGTIME
description: Roger Swain explained the mystery of bird migration very nicely by stating it was governed by the change in day length. One of my third-grade students once had a better explanation: ''It's a family tradition.'' JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y. ------

title: WHEN AIRLINES AND OTHERS DEFAULT
description: Although much has been done to help consumers affected by the collapse of Braniff International Airways on May 12, severe shortcomings are evident in the travel industry's ability to protect the public when companies default.

title: SUBWAY AUDIT LINKS DECLINE TO INEFFICIENT PARTS PROCEDURE
description: Inefficiencies in getting spare parts have forced ''rampant cannibalization'' of some subway cars to provide needed parts for others, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday. He called it a ''significant'' factor in the decline of the system's passenger service.

title: Ray F. Sadler 3d, Martha Mahoney To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Mahoney Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Stanley, Idaho, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Bronson Mahoney, to Ray F. Sadler 3d, son of Mrs. Sadler Jr., of Coconut Grove, Fla., and Newfane, Vt., and the late Mr. Sadler.

title: THE TRADE-OFFS OF PLAYING OUT OF DOORS
description: As the weather warms, music at Lincoln Center tends to turn itself inside out. The Center's plazas and parks - in January, chilly and barely noticed avenues to its theaters and concert halls - become musical venues of their own in June.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YEAR-OLD Pamela Hamilton had just taken her first sip of creme sherry, and she wasn't too sure if she liked it. ''My dad,'' she explained, giggling, straightening the shoulders of her whitelace dress, ''will be opening some Dom Perignon champagne later.''

title: MINING THE OBSCURE
description: A quarter of a century ago it was the then world champion, Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, who was pre-eminent for his handling of positions difficult for both sides. Currently it is Robert Hubner, a 33-year-old West German grandmaster, who thrives on complicated, obscure middle games.

title: No Headline
description: MABEL By Betty Harper Fussell. Illustrated. 239 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95. LULU IN HOLLYWOOD By Louise Brooks. Illustrated. 109 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.

title: Carolina Lacrosse Winner
description: North Carolina won its second successive National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship today by defeating Johns Hopkins, 7-5, at Virginia's field.

title: by Roy Blount Jr.
description: THE SHELL GAME Reflections on Rowing and the Pursuit of Excellence. By Stephen Kiesling. 200 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $10.50.

title: Children, Schools And Television
description: We should like to offer our hearty endorsement of the Opinion article by Francis Zappone (''Teaching Children How to View TV,'' May 9).

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WITH the June 15 runoff election for Mayor and seven members of the Newark City Council little more than two weeks away, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and City Council President Earl Harris are locked in a tough head-to-head contest.

title: Congress, in Easy Payments
description: If there is any group the public distrusts more than politicians, it's used-car dealers. Congress seems bent on proving you can't trust either.

title:
GARDENING;
HARD-TO FIND PLANTS MERIT ATTENTION
description: THE number of known plant species is on the order of 300,000, yet the average garden may contain no more than a dozen or two. Certainly, not all plants are suitable or even desirable for garden culture, and to use too many in a limited space would be to create a hodgepodge rather than a garden.

title: 12 Presented in Rye
description: Twelve women from Westchester County were presented last night to Terence Cardinal Cooke at the St. Vincent Debutante Ball at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y. Proceeds from the 21st event will go to St. Vincent's in Harrison, N.Y., a psychiatric hospital founded in 1879 by the Sisters of Charity.

title: Houston Takes N.C.A.A. Golf
description: Houston won its 14th National Collegiate Athletic Association golf title today.

title: (ENTER POUND AND ELIOT)
description: Eileen Simpson's current book, ''Poets in Their Youth,'' gives us some idea of how poets talk to one another, as opposed to the way they talk to themselves and their readers in their poems. Inspired by Mrs. Simpson's recollections, I've been wondering about the conversation between T.S. Eliot and Ezra Pound when Eliot first saw Pound's revision of his rough draft of ''The Waste Land.'' As there is no verbatim record of the occasion, I have ventured to surmise from what we know of each man what he might have said. For purely dramatic reasons and without a shred of evidence, I've assumed that Pound showed Eliot a clean copy of the revised version. *

title: A MISERY THAT MAKES IT HARD TO LOVE COMPANY
description: PARIS Leaders of the West's largest economies will meet again this week at Versailles to try to recapture the prosperity that has eluded them since the big oil price increases of the 1970's. Again this year, they are trapped by concerted stagnation of their economies, with prospects for more of the same in 1983. Since their annual meetings began at Rambouillet, France in 1975, unemployment in the industrial democracies is up 40 percent to more than 25 million people and it is still rising.

title: HIS OBSESSION IS A CULTURE IN DECLINE
description: For more than 20 years A.R. Gurney has written a play nearly every year and seen them attain modest appreciation at best, with regional theater productions or the occasional run in London. At worst, however, his plays met with devastating reviews and a swift demise. The playwright figured that his habitual lack of success had something to do with his habitual choice of topic, which is upper middle-class WASPs. Despite the occasional comparison of Mr. Gurney with John Cheever or Philip Barry, reviewers often seemed to regard his preoccupation more as a mildly amusing anachronism than as a compelling subject for serious drama.

title: Philadelphia
description: To the Editor: What's doing in Philadelphia? Plenty, as William Robbins and Leslie Bennetts tell us (Travel, May 9). But has the wonderful and unique Reading Terminal Market disappeared since I last visited it? It is/ was a lively place six mornings of the week.

title: CHANGES AT KINGS PARK UPSET NEIGHBORS
description: KINGS PARK TO boaters out on Long Island Sound, the Kings Park State Psychiatric Center's Building 93 is an 11-story landmark that helps them find their way home. To persons concerned with the history of the treatment of mental disease, its Victorian facade and monumental scale hark back to the days when this institution was a destination of no return for ill New York City residents.

title: The Region in Summary; Hartford Wants Poisons Posted
description: Ignorance is hardly bliss to those who work in or live near plants where toxic chemicals are used. But in Connecticut, a law signed last week by Gov. William A. O'Neill will soon give them the ''right to know.''

title: MODELS KNOWN FOR THE PARTS OF THEIR SUMS
description: When most people hear the words ''fashion model,'' they probably envision a young woman under the age of 30 who has a beautiful face, a willowy figure and a big bank account.

title: EXPOS GET 8TH VICTORY IN ROW
description: Charged by the 28,037 spectators in Olympic Stadium and a television audience watching across North America, Gary Carter hit a three-run eighth-inning home run today to help the Montreal Expos to a 4-1 triumph over Cincinnati.

title: VILLAGE SAVES AN OLD CHURCH
description: MASSAPEQUA AFTER the vandals struck, the Bible was found in the cemetery. The brass doorknob from the church door was also found there. Thrown about the graves of the Floyd-Jones family on that 1967 night were objects from inside the Old Grace Church.

title: SCHOOL STANDARDS CRITICIZED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE president of Rutgers, the State University, says he wants to give public education back to the public. The president, Dr. Edward J.Bloustein, is calling on all New Jerseyans to take stock of the state's secondary schools in an effort to upgrade their performance and produce better students.

title: FESTIVAL RINGS WITH RIDICULE OF CIVIL DEFENSE PLAN
description: The sound of chain saws filled the air here today, that and ridicule of a 197-page ''crisis relocation'' document that would send one-fifth of the 103,000 people of Alexandria, Va., to safety in this tiny mountain crossroads in the event of imminent nuclear attack.

title: Sports of The Times; Indy's Firemen take the Heat
description: JOHN WILLIAMS swings his red pickup truck onto the main track at the speedway. None of the 33 contestants is practicing on this quiet Friday afternoon, so Mr. Williams is the fastest one going, at about 70 miles per hour.

title: THEATER: 'CAUCASIAN CHALK CIRCLE'
description: ''The Caucasian Chalk Circle,'' Bertolt Brecht's mythic fable about the imbalance of injustice, offers a natural environment for a young theater company. Because of Brecht's non-naturalistic, epic style, actors -changing costumes and masks - can easily undertake a variety of characters of all ages.

title: by Ray Walters
description: The profits of doom. Probably the most ancient author ever to make our best-seller list is Michel de Nostredame (1503-66), a French physician popularly remembered as Nostradamus. As a part-time astrologer and mystic, he wrote thousands of verses, in a crabbed, obscure mixture of French, Proven,cal, Italian, Greek and Latin, predicting events that would happen between his lifetime and the end of the world.

title: by Newgate Callendar
description: The title of Christopher Leopold's THE NIGHT FISHER OF ANTIBES (Hamish Hamilton, $14.95) is, of course, taken from the Picasso painting, and the great Pablo himself makes an appearance at the beginning and end of this war story set on the Riviera in 1940. Mr. Leopold postulates the Picasso made a preliminary sketch of "Night Fishers," and it becomes a canvas around which much action whirls. A dealer desperately wants it. So does the Italian Government, which has just declared war on France. So does an Italian adventurer-playboy. The plot is complicated and full of unexpected developments, and at the end the story becomes simply unbelievable. But it is a tribute to Mr. Leopold's graceful writing that the reader sticks with him. The characterizations are sophisticated, and the book has a certain wit.

title: Susan A. Hall Engaged to Robert Elliott Weeden
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Hall of Watsonville, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Adrienne Hall, to Robert Elliott Weeden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan N. Weeden of Rye, N.Y.

title: In the Arts: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Tom Verlaine, who will be at the Ritz Friday and Saturday, used to lead a band called Television. Beginning in the mid-1970's, Television built a loyal following and won a recording contract through appearances at CBGB, often on the same shows with up-andcoming groups like Blondie, The Talking Heads, and the Patti Smith Group.

title: SELECTION OF SCHOOLS FOR FUTURE SAILORS
description: There are schools teaching sail handling, steering and navigation all along the East and West Coasts of the United States. In the Caribbean, however, the vast majority operate in the Virgin Islands, offering a wide array of teaching methods, types of vessels and cruising opportunities. Following is a selection of the programs available.

title: Postings; REMEMBERING
description: The high wall at 35-10 20th Road in Astoria, Queens, encloses that rarest form of urban real estate, a private cemetery. In it are buried nearly 100 members of the Lawrence family, many of them military men going back to Revolutionary War days.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Decoration Day, Decorations and More
description: Decoration Day in Larchmont has come to mean suitable gifts for any holiday, gifts with taste and imagination and often with custom touches. The six-year-old shop moved nextdoor and quadrupled in size last February, adding wicker and antiques to silk and dried flowers, basketry and bric-a-brac.

title: OPERA: CONCERT ROYAL GIVES 'POPPEA'
description: Although some might put in claims for Monteverdi's own earlier operas, his ''L'Incoronazione di Poppea'' of 1642 may well count as opera's first undisputed masterpiece. This consummate erotic drama, set to a morally ambivalent pageant of a libretto by Busenello and graced with Monteverdi's most intense, amusing and voluptuously lyrical music, surpasses all that came before it and everything up to Mozart that followed.

title: The Nation in Summary; Another Heat For the Hare And Tortoise
description: The blown-dry look may be about to undergo its sharpest test of the spring primary season. After the votes in the Democratic primary for Governor were counted in Arkansas last week, Bill Clinton, a young, slick former Governor, had finished first. But not far enough ahead of a decidedly unslick former Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General, Joe Purcell, to avoid a runoff. Mr. Purcell, known as a terrible speaker, is thought to have a good chance of finishing first on June 8 because of lingering doubts that Mr. Clinton is, as he claims, a born-again homebody.

title: Peter Borowitz to Marry Talanat Lapid in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arye Lapid of Brussels and Kiron, Israel, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Talanat Asenat Lapid, to Peter Leonard Borowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Ira Borowitz of Shaker Heights, Ohio. An August wedding is planned.

title: President to Lay Wreath
description: President Reagan will lay a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and deliver a speech at Arlington National Cemetery on Memorial Day, the White House announced Friday.

title: No Headline
description: In response to Whitney Tilt's defense of dredge spoil disposal in Long Island Sound, this will be heard as yet another howl of protest from a Long Islander. His contention that these howls come only from those who have no interest in recreational or commercial use of the Sound would be laughable if the danger that his notion might be accepted by some was not so very serious. While callously dismissing the concerns of Long Islanders over the Army Corps of Engineers dumping program, Mr. Tilt does mention that our distress is shared by ''some fishermen on the Connecticut shore'' without mentioning how many people are ingesting the finfish and shellfish that Connecticut and Long Island fishermen depend upon for their living.

title: Mailbox; Celtic Pride, Even in Defeat
description: To the Sports Editor: When the Boston Celtics and their fans realized that the team was about to be eliminated by the Philadelphia 76ers, the Celtics and their fans showed a lot of class in defeat.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a schedule change, the date for the L'eggs Mini Marathon was incorrectly reported in the sports section last Sunday. The race will be run tomorrow, beginning at 10:30 A.M. at Tavern on the Green.

title: A Key Economic Indicator Shows a Gain
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department said. It was the first gain since April 1981 and while the rise was a bit larger than expected, it was greeted with caution. Commerce Secretary Baldrige said it would be ''premature to draw any firm conclusions about the timing of a business upturn.''

title: City Opera to Produce 'La Traviata' on L.I.
description: The New York City Opera will give a free, fully staged performance of Verdi's ''La Traviata'' July 17 at 8 P.M. in the Harry Chapin Theater, Eisenhower Park, in Nassua County.

title: WILLIAMS CAPTURES 200 IN P.S.A.L. MEET
description: Ken Williams of Prospect Heights High School, facing the fastest New York State schoolboy in the 200 meters, held off Roger Hunter of Thomas Jefferson to win the 200 yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championships.

title: AID TO DEMOCRACY ABROAD IS WEIGHED
description: President Reagan is expected to announce plans soon for a quasi-governmental program aimed at promoting democracy in developing countries and, where possible, in Communist nations, White House officials said today.

title: THEATERS AND CHURCHES ARE THE CITY'S NEW BATTLEGROUND
description: Churches may be thought of as sacred and theaters as profane, but the two building types have a lot in common in New York. They are both places in which crowds gather, they both constitute a major share of the city's inventory of architectural treasures, and they are both customarily housed in smaller, free-standing buildings. And that may be their undoing - for in many cases the air space above a church or a theater has more financial value than the structure itself.

title: Footnotes
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAN WON'T INVADE, MUBARAK REPORTS
description: President Hosni Mubarak says that assessments he has received indicate that Iran, which recaptured its port city of Khurramshahr from Iraqi forces this week, will not invade Iraq.

title: 'STAND UP AND BE HEARD' AND OTHER 'LESSONS' OF MULTI-TOWN
description: ALL right, class, let's have a follow-up social-studies lesson to balance the one that Michael Dorman of Dix Hills presented recently on this page regarding the Multi-Town solid waste disposal plant (''Multi-Town: What's Missing?'').

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: EXTORTIONIST UNDER STUDY IN DONOVAN INQUIRY
description: The case of a man sentenced to prison last year for extortion is being studied by the special prosecutor investigating allegations of wrongdoing against Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan.

title: SOCIALISTS TRY TO FIT PRINCIPLES TO CARIBBEAN
description: When the Socialist International last week called for a cease-fire in the Falklands and set up a special commission to monitor developments in the war, it was by no means the first time the European-dominated body had inserted itself into an issue of great consequence for the Western Hemisphere and United States policy in the region. After Salvadorans surprised the Reagan Administration and maybe even themselves by turning out in droves to vote in March, a Socialist International meeting scathingly denounced the ''so-called'' elections and argued anew that only negotiations with the guerrillas could end the civil war.

title: Extra Cost for Mayberry
description: John Mayberry, whom the Yankees acquired from Toronto May 5, cost them more than they had disclosed. When they made the deal, they said they were sending Dave Revering, their first baseman, and Jeff Reynolds, a minor league third baseman, to the Blue Jays.

title: A SYMBOL OF THE MISSING THOUSANDS: DURANGO'S YOUNG UNKNOWN TRAVELER
description: It was raining hard that dreary fall afternoon when the slight figure pulled up the hood of his jacket and dashed out into the highway 10 miles east of Durango. The pickup truck driver did not have time to hit his brakes. The pedestrian struck the right side of the truck, fell backward and died against the curb.

title: Jennifer Dickens Married to John James McHugh
description: Jennifer Ann Dickens, daughter of Ann Lee Huckenbeck of Manchester, Conn., and William Paul Dickens of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to John James McHugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph McHugh of Westport, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Michael Galasso in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Hartford.

title: Around the Nation; Four Paintings Stolen From a Detroit Museum
description: Thieves who ''knew exactly what they were doing'' took four 17th-century paintings from the Detroit Institute of Arts, including one work attributed to Rembrandt, museum officials said Friday.

title: Index; International
