description: Salvador evicting peasants from their land 3 Crowds are thin at Mexican bull- ring 4 Iran reportedly assures Arabs that it will not invade Iraq 5 Mubarak reports reason to be- lieve Iran won't invade Iraq 6 Around the World 7 Guerrillas trying to disrupt Co- lombian election today 8 Banned foe of Seoul regime pre- dicts Chun's downfall 9 Kenya moves to outlaw its multi- party system 10 Japanese to try to spread aware- ness of nuclear war's horrors 13 Quebec announces tax increases and wage curbs 14 Argentines holding U.S. responsi- ble for any setbacks 16 Government/Politics Cities trying to cope with big li- ability judgments 21 New rules for Federal charity drive worry beneficiaries 22 Close Senate race seen in New Mexico primary 25 Commoner of Citizens Party calls for defense cutbacks 26 Goldin report assails delays in getting spare subway parts 27 A ruling keeps a pregnant prose- cutor on a murder case 31 General Nuclear evacuation plan ridi- culed in West Virginia town 20 Around the Nation 24 From pipes to cars, Bing Cros- by's fans buy pieces of his life 24 Extortionist under inquiry in Donovan investigation 30 Education/Welfare Conservative journal at Dart- mouth causes campus furor 23 Plan at University of Missouri to cut departments draws fire 24 Arts/Entertainment Brecht's ''The Caucasian Chalk Circle'' performed 44 David Winstein offers avant- garde piano piece 45 Ballet Theater puts on astream- lined ''Quixote'' 45 Jimmy Hall and the Ghetto Blast- ers perform 46 Musical benefit staged for Cor- nelius Cardew's family 46 Natalia Makarova returns to the dance stage 47 ''The Freak,'' Edgar Cayce's story, is restaged 47 Concert Royal offers the opera 'Poppea' 47 ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' Faus- tian musical, is staged 47 Style Models known for the parts of their sums 48 News Analysis Drew Middleton on new options in the Falkland war 16

title: PASSING ON AS MUCH AS YOU CAN
description: NOTHING before it has so changed the laws governing gift and estate t axes as President Reagan's Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981. When t he changes are fully effective in 1987, only a fraction of 1 percento f all estates will be subject to Federal transfer taxes.

title: Return of the Battleship
description: In this era of rapid communication, economic interdependence, multipower alliances and precision-guided weapons, the Navy would be foolish indeed to rely on a few slow-moving battleships to play any decisive role in the sort of ''emergencies'' described in William Honan's articles, ''Return of the Battleships,'' (April 4 and April 11). Instead, battleships are merely details in an overall policy of global interventionism.

title: JOHN J. CULLIGAN IS FIANCE OF DEBORAH ANN HIDALGO
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raciel Hidalgo of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Hidalgo, to John J. Culligan of Ridgefield, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Culligan of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: Kim Howie Wed To C. L. Olsen
description: Kim Devereaux Howie, a project manager with the Fund for the City of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher L. Olsen, an architect with I.M. Pei & Partners in New York. The Rev. Albert H. Heusmann performed the Lutheran ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: CASINO-LAW FRAMERS LOOK AT THE ERRORS
description: ATLANTIC CITY FOUR years ago, the casino era began in this seaside city. Now, says State Senator Steven P. Perskie, one of the prime movers of the legislation that made it all possible, if he had it to do all over again he would do it differently because ''all of us underestimated its impact by a wide margin.''

title: 'GENIUSES' IS WINNING SATIRE; by Walter Kerr
description: Jonathan Reynolds's ''Geniuses,'' now at Playwrights Horizons and planning a move to another Off Broadway house, is, roughly speaking, a satirical comedy about moviemaking. I use the phrase ''roughly speaking'' advisedly, because Mr. Reynolds's play eventually begins to speak - and to behave - very roughly indeed, especially for a piece that first presents itself as lightminded parody. Furthermore, the kind of moviemaking that is getting its head kicked in here has nothing to do with Hollywood sound stages or the West Coast's oldfashioned ways. It has to do with the much newer fashion of going halfway around the world (in this case to the Philippines) to make portentously titled spectacles (in this case ''Parabola of Death'') about suitably catastrophic events (in this case ''war in Angola'') complete with helicopters, typhoons that tear down half the scenery and directors with three names (in this case Milo McGee McGarr).

title: THE MAKING OF A DOCTOR
description: David Black's most recent books are ''The King of Fifth Avenue,'' a biography of August Belmont, and a novel, ''Minds.'' BY DAVID BLACK

title: Sports People; Argentina Is Willing
description: At a news conference in Alicante, Spain, the Argentine soccer coach, Cesar Menotti, said his team would play against any of the British teams in the upcoming World Cup if it came to it. ''We cannot win sovereignty over the Malvinas on the soccer field. We are sportsmen and we will behave as such,'' he said.

title: Penthouse Settles Suit Filed Against The Record in Bergen
description: The publishers of Penthouse magazine and The Record, a daily newspaper here, have settled a $50 million libel suit filed against The Record in 1979, the newspaper announced today.

title: Rex Pingle to Wed Miss Crossman Next September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Farrell Crossman of New York and Norfolk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Febiger Crossman, to Rex Eugene Pingle, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Kenneth Pingle of Fostoria, Ohio.

title: HOW WE JOIN AND SEPARATE AS WE LIVE
description: WHEN my son was a toddler, he became obsessed with a ritual. He would toddle down a neighbor's walk waving an energetic good-bye to me, at the end of the walk he would turn around, grin broadly, shout a gusty hello and rush back toward me. This intense interest in parting and connecting went on for well over two months. I was continually amazed at the newness with which he approached each departure and re-connection, realizing that something very important was being worked through.

title: Goa
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Times Magazine May 30, 1982
description: William Safire 7 On Language Red-Hot 'Freeze' Francis X. Clines 10 Guest Observer Helping a Guide Dog Steve Lohr 12 The New Face of Kabuki When the Grand Kabuki comes to America in June, Tamasaburo Bando will make his first Western appearance. Japan's superstar ''onnagata'' - the actor in Kabuki's all-male cast who specializes in female roles - Tamasaburo has brought fresh excitement and a new young audience to the traditional art form.

title: Miss Krug Bride Of Assemblyman
description: Katherine Ann Krug, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Krug of Oak Brook, Ill., was married yesterday to State Assemblyman John C. Dearie, Democrat of the Bronx. The Rev. Gilbert Graham performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Chicago.

title: MILITARY AIDES OFFER VISION OF FUTURE WAR
description: While most sections of the new document on defense guidance prepared for Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger are concerned with policy and strategy, the military planners in one passage provided a graphic view of their thoughts on future wars:

title: Padres 4, Cardinals 2
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Tim Flannery's bloop double over the outstretched glove of the third baseman Ken Oberkfell drove in Sixto Lezcano with two out in the ninth inning for San Diego's third run.

title: Military Analysis
description: Argentina must turn to its air force, to date its most effective service but one that, if British assertions are correct, could now be seriously depleted, if it is to turn the tide of the war in the South Atlantic.

title: 7 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of seven restaurants last week that were cited for violations of the city's health code.

title: Statement on Retarded Assailed as 'Untrue'
description: The article by Maureen Duffy on May 2 started out so readably and held out so much promise for its contribution to an understanding attitude toward disabled persons that I was especially disappointed at the intrusive parenthetical comment early in the piece:

title: CELLO-PIANO: SOVIET EMIGRES
description: Tanya Remenikova, cello, and Alexander Braginsky, piano, played music by Veracini, Schubert, Bloch and Shostakovich at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night. The two are married, were born and trained in the Soviet Union and left their country for the West in 1972.

title: OUR SEABORNE WINDOW OF VULNERABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars; THE INDY 500 PACE CAR PROGRAM
description: BOB STEMPEL has been described as a man on the fast track, and today - in Indianapolis - he is just where he wants to be. Robert C. Stempel is 48 years old, a man regarded as one of the chief troubleshooters at General Motors. He has headed Pontiac and been Chevrolet's chief engineer. Until last February, he ran G.M.'s European operations. Now he is back, running Chevrolet, and today he is exercising his further reputation as a product specialist. When the engines roar, that will be be his silver-and-blue Camaro out there pacing the Indianapolis 500.

title: Postings; DECALCOMANIA
description: ''Abandoned buildings are like cancer,'' said Frank Dell'Aira, an assistant commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. ''They spread from one to the other and that's how whole neighbohoods are lost.''

title: THE MOST BEAUTIFUL CITY IN THE WORLD
description: A HISTORY OF VENICE By John Julius Norwich. Illustrated. 673 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
A 'NEW BREED' SPOT IN GREENBURGH
description: ANEW breed of restaurants has been gaining favor in the county. Mimicking their Manhattan prototypes, these places gleam with burnished oak and mahogany, stained-glass panels, reflecting walls - delighting the eye more often than the palate. Innovation would seem reserved for the variously tinted alcoholic froths served up in balloon glasses. Recognizing Juniper's in Greenburgh as a member of this club, we approached with some trepidation, expecting the plants to be better fed than we. However, although the menu is, for the most part, pro forma, the kitchen did manage a few surprises that make this address worth remembering when you happen to be in the neighborhood.

title: Sports People; Devine Takes a Post
description: Bing Devine continues to shuttle between baseball and football. Devinewas named president and chief operating officer of the St. Louis football Cardinals yesterday, his second tour with that team.

title: Kissinger Bleak on Falklands
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that there was little the United States could do diplomatically to help resolve the Falklands crisis. In an interview on Cable News Network's ''Newsmaker Saturday'' program, he said, ''We're going to have a very difficult time in Latin America after this.''

title: Coal May Not Be King, But It's Doing Well
description: To the Business Editor: Given that the coal market is suffering from overproduction and lack of demand, its overall prospects are much brighter than the bearish evaluation given by Robert D. Hershey Jr. in ''Coal - The Other Glut'' (May 16).

title: STRAWBERRIES
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSPICUOUS CONSUMPTION
description: WORLDLY GOODS By Michael Korda. 353 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95. By JULIAN SYMONS

title: CARE OF POOR IS CUT BY PRIVATE HOSPITALS
description: An increasing number of private hospitals in New York City are restricting clinic care to patients who either are medically insured or can afford to pay fees, according to city health officials and the hospitals themselves.

title: Giants 9, Pirates 5
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Jack Clark drove in six runs with two home runs, including his fourth career grand slam, to lead San Francisco.

title: MULTIPARTY SYSTEM IS UNDER ATTACK IN KENYA
description: Kenya's ruling hierarchy, reflecting an increasing sensitivity to opposition, has resolved to turn this pro-Western nation into a formal one-party state, thereby legalizing a style of government that has effectively prevailed for many years.

title: Sports World Specials; Not So Tranquil
description: In December, the Naval Academy began a search for a football coach to succeed George Welsh, who resigned to become coach at Virginia. Officials let it be known early that they were interested ''in a man who understood the Naval Academy and how it operates, one who could represent this institution with the qualities it is known for around the country.''

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: What is the Prince of Wales trophy in the National Hockey League, and who won it for the 1981-82 season?

title: Cathy Levitt Nislick Bride Of Larry Scott Schumer
description: The marriage of Cathy Levitt Nislick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Nislick of Wyckoff, N.J., to Larry Scott Schumer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schumer of East Meadow, L.I., took place yesterday at the Nislick home. Rabbi Jacob I. Nislick, retired executive director of the Hebrew Institute of Long Island and grandfather of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Recovery Forecast by Regan
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the United States was ''on the brink'' of economic recovery, but that it could be an anemic one and end in a depression if current huge budget deficits were not controlled.

title: DANCE: 2 SPOLETO PREMIERES FROM LAURA DEAN'S TROUPE
description: Dance is playing an unusually important part at this year's American Spoleto Festival, and one of the festival's major dance events occurred Saturday night when Laura Dean Dancers and Musicians offered the world premieres of two works at the Garden Theater. As usual, Miss Dean was responsible for both the choreography and the music of her creations. Yet if the new pieces resembled her older works in certain respects, they also suggested that Miss Dean has developed some fresh choreographic concerns.

title: Think of Wars
description: If Memorial Day means anything, it is that martyrs to freedom can survive only in the deeds and thoughts of the living. If the resolute residents of Warsaw did not weekly clean up after the police to rebuild the memorial cross of flowers and candles that has come to symbolize the Solidarity movement, there would soon be nothing to memorialize. But as long as they do, feeble as may be their political power, withered hopes and dreams are kept alive.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it's important that they remember us, but I think it would be better that they remember not to have any more wars.'' - Melville T. Miller, World War I veteran. (B2:5.)

title: 3 OTHERS SOUGHT FOR QUESTIONING ON L.I. ATTACKS
description: New York City detectives are searching for at least three more personsthe police believe terrorized and robbed dozens of people in two separate incidents on Long Island late Friday and early Saturday, the New York City police said yesterday.

title: CONSERVATIVE LEADS IN COLOMBIAN VOTE
description: Belisario Betancur, the Conservative Party candidate, took a strong lead in presidential elections today. The main candidates are former President Alfonso Lopez Michelsen of the ruling Liberal Party and Mr. Betancur of the Conservative Party. But a Liberal dissident, Luis Carlos Galan, who started the New Liberal Party because of his opposition to Mr. Lopez Michelsen, could split the party's votes and help Mr. Betancur achieve a victory.

title: Bridge: Younger Generation Leads Field Into Goldman Finals
description: Two young partnerships of great promise headed a star-studded field into the final session of the Goldman pairs last night at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Durden Captures Montreal Race
description: Benji Durden of Stone Mountain, Ga., took the lead after 12 miles and easily won the Montreal International Marathon today.

title: WEATHER OR NOT, MANY FLEE CITY FOR WEEKEND
description: With enthusiasm, desperation and little regard for the elements, New Yorkers scattered to the outer territories for the Memorial Day weekend, kicking off the summer season on beaches, in parks and in vacation cottages. Under skies that stayed overcast and drizzly for much of the weekend, they left by the thousands, while those who were left behind celebrated the relative quiet of the city streets.

title: Business People; FORMER MARKET MOVER FINDS A NEW CHALLENGE
description: Fourteen years ago, just before the mid-1960's go-go market began to sour, Gerald Tsai Jr., then 40 years old, sold his Wall Street mutual funds company to the CNA Financial Management Corporation for $20 million in stock.

title: Charles N. Andreae 3d Marries Jane Enid Durkin
description: Jane Enid Durkin, a legislative correspondent with Representative Clint Roberts, Republican of South Dakota, was married yesterday to Charles Norman Andreae 3d, a staff member of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. Msgr. Richard H. Holmes performed the ceremony in St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Rock, N.J., assisted by Dr. Albert Busch of the Rolland Park Presbyterian Church in Baltimore.

title: BOLIVIA CHECKS IF DRUG SUSPECT HAS ENVOY PAST
description: The Bolivian Embassy in Washington said yesterday that it was checking the status of a man who described himself as a Bolivian cultural attache in Mexico City when he was arrested Saturday at Kennedy International Airport in New York on charges of importing cocaine.

title:
Music Noted in Brief;
Music of North India At Alternative Museum
description: The alternatives that met the eye were almost as fascinating as those that met the ear Saturday at the Alternative Museum, where Sheila Dhar, assisted by Bob Becker, tabla player, and two tanburists, was heard in a program of North Indian vocal music. Viewed straight on, the ensemble was framed against the background of the museum's current exhibition of modern art by an unlikely looking row of whitewashed Corinthian columns.

title: White House; CLARK EMERGES AS A MAKER OF POLICY
description: By now, it is accepted that in the months since he became President Reagan's national security adviser last January, William P. Clark has taken charge of the foreign policy machinery of the Administration.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE POPE'S REMARKS AT COVENTRY AND LIVERPOOL
description: Following are excerpts from the texts of Pope John Paul II's remarks today at an outdoor mass near Coventry and at Speke Airport near Liverpool: Coventry

title: The Region; Assembly Backs Plan for Thruway
description: The State Assembly has approved a proposal under which the Federal Government would provide millions of dollars for repairs on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. In return, the state would have to remove all tolls on the Thruway by 1996.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE BOOK KNOWN AS Q: A Considera- tion of Shakespeare's Sonnets. By Rob- ert Giroux. 334 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $17.95.

title: ART-ROCK: THE MAELS
description: rock band led by the brothers Russell and Ron Mael, has made records for more than a decade without ever achieving mass acceptance. But with a new album, ''Angst in My Pants,'' and a catchy hit single, ''I Predict,'' that's full of amusingly nonsensical prophecies chanted in a style that's close to electropop, this pair of smarty-pants media satirists has finally begun to transcend cult status.

title: Westphal Plans To Stay a Knick
description: Paul Westphal, who left the Seattle Super-Sonics to sign with the Knicks, today said he expected to remain with New York next season.

title: WHY WORKERS SUE OVER JOB DISABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: THRONGS GREET POPE IN 2 ENGLISH CITIES
description: Pope John Paul II traveled today to the heart of England, where he was greeted by the largest crowds of his visit so far and made an impassioned plea against the horrors of war.

title: SEVERAL LOS ANGELES POLITICIANS EDGE TOWARD MAYORAL RACE STARTING LINE
description: With statewide polls showing Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles leading all contenders in his bid to become Governor next fall, almost a dozen local politicians are testing the political wind to see if it might blow them into City Hall.

title: Washington Watch; Arab Boycott And Checks
description: WASHINGTON THE Commerce Department is still uncertain about antiboycott enforcement procedures related to the checks that American banks process from the Middle East that bear the notation ''Do Not Negotiate in Israel.''

title: Yanks Top Twins on 2 in 10th
description: Chances are the Minnesota Twins will win another game this season. They nearly won one today, but a ball that bounced into the stands instead of hitting the wall forced them into extra innings, and the Yankees won, 8-6.

title: URUGUAY OUSTS U.S. EMBASSY'S POLITICAL AIDE
description: The State Department said today that the chief of the political section of the American Embassy in Montevideo had been declared persona non grata by the Uruguayan Government, accused of ''interfering with internal Uruguayan matters.''

title: Pentagon Reports Contract Awards
description: The Raytheon Company has been awarded a $379.3 million contract by the Army for various line items for Patriot weapons system production in the fiscal year 1982, the Defense Department said last week.

title: TOWN-HOUSE DEVELOPMENTS GROW IN SUBURBS
description: The pattern of single-family zoning in suburban settings around the metropolitan area is gradually cracking under the pressure of changing housing needs in the 1980's, according to many officials and consultants involved in the development process.

title: Adobe Stake Reported
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company and the Minerals and Resources Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday that they owned 4,385,062 shares, or 27.1 percent, of the Adobe Oil and Gas Corporation. The shares were acquired as part of a reorganization of Francana Oil and Gas Ltd.

title: INDIANS WIN SEVENTH IN ROW
description: In his previous 11 major league seasons, Toby Harrah had never hit higher than .293, his average in 1975 with the Texas Rangers. But his average for this season shot up almost 100 points above that figure yesterday as he hit his 10th homer and lined a single to help the Indians win their seventh straight game, 4-2, over the Chicago White Sox in Cleveland.

title: The Doctor Soars Again
description: IN the hallway outside the Philadelphia 76ers' dressing room, Julius Erving stepped onto a small platform and turned toward the microphones and notebooks assembled in front of him. ''What's up?'' Dr. J asked. ''You,'' somebody suggested. Up there on another level throughout the 76ers' 110-94 victory yesterday that squared the National Basketball Association championship series at one game each before it resumes in Los Angeles tomorrow night, Dr. J seemed to be up there about two or three feet above the court. Up there playing a different game than anybody else. Up there doing at altitude what other players can only try to do at sea level - 24 points, 14 rebounds, three assists, unrecorded acrobatics.

title: SPAIN ENTERS NATO AS FIRST COUNTRY TO JOIN SINCE 1955
description: Spain, depositing an instrument of ratification with the State Department, formally became the 16th member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today.

title: RETAILERS SEE BETTER 3D QUARTER
description: Retailers' hopes are rising around the country for a gradual improvement in sales and earnings, starting in midsummer. The reasons, they say, are moderately improved sales of clothing and home furnishings in April and May and the expected benefits of a $45 billion addition in buying power from the further reduction of Federal income taxes and higher Social Security benefits, both of which become effective July 1.

title: Flu Takes Toll At French Open
description: When Sue Barker pulled out of the French Open tennis tournament on the first day last week, she was reported to be ill in England with stomach flu, and nobody paid much attention. But the virus has since affected at least 16 women and seven men in the French tournament, with many of them defaulting.

title: COSMOS FACE STING
description: The saga of the Cosmos-Chicago rivalry will continue this afternoon at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., when their game will decide the winner of the third annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup.

title: KIRKPATRICK FEUD WITH HAIG IS NOTED
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, engaged in a heated argument last week over United States policy in the Falkland Islands, aides to Mrs. Kirkpatrick said today.

title: Markets Closed
description: All United States stock and commodities markets and most businesses are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. Some foreign markets in Europe also remain closed in observance of the Whitsun holiday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co. said its optical recording project had purchased the Dicovision pilot plant in Costa Mesa, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: STAGE: 'ANIMAL CRACKERS' AT THE ARENA
description: With a fanfare, native bearers enter carrying a palanquin, and on it lolls Captain Spalding, the African explorer (''Did someone call me schnorrer?''). Flicking his eyebrows and his cigar, the captain glances at the stately Mrs. Rittenhouse and wisecracks, ''You're one of the most beautiful women I've ever seen - and that's not saying much for you.'' Then he sings, ''Hello, I must be going.'' ''Animal Crackers'' - the musical not the movie - is aloft and flying at the Arena Stage.

title: 32-1 SHOT CAPTURES SARANAC
description: Harbor View's Prince Westport, the longest shot in the race, won the $58,400 Saranac Stakes at Belmont Park by 2 1/2 lengths yesterday. Earlier, two top candidates for next Saturday's Belmont Stakes engaged in drills.

title: PARISH DISCOVERS PAIN ON PENTECOST
description: Roman Catholics in this hilly town of Colonial heritage joined today in the annual worldwide observance of Pentecost, the feast marking the birth of the church nearly two millenniums ago, but there was little joy in their celebration. A bitter conflict has erupted over a decision by their Bishop to create a new parish by splitting the original one, St. Joseph's, into two parts.

title: Socialists Postpone Parley
description: Socialist International leaders today postponed for three weeks a meeting of a commission set up to monitor the Falkland conflict. The commission, organized by the group in Helsinki last Thursday, was expected to hold an emergency meeting here this weekend.

title: AT BRITISH BEACHHEAD, A COLD AND MUDDY WAR
description: The first accounts of how British troops are living on the beachhead in the Falkland Islands paint a picture of sleepless nights in cold, muddy foxholes, with dry rations, dirty clothes and a constant fear of death.

title: NCNB Proposes An Acquisition
description: The NCNB Corporation said Friday it agreed in principle to acquire Exchange Bancorp Inc. of Tampa, Fla., for $31.92 a share in cash, or a total of about $134 million, pending approval of regulatory agencies and directors and shareholders of the companies.

title: COMMON THEMES SOUNDED ACROSS U.S. AT '82 COMMENCEMENTS
description: With this holiday weekend, the first great wave of commencement addresses washes over the classes of 1982 at colleges across the nation, and among the inevitable calls for rekindling of the American spirit and the partisan, three major themes have emerged.

title: 2 Translation Prizes, Wilder Award Given
description: The 1982 winners of the Translation and Thornton Wilder prizes have been announced by Columbia University's Translation Center.

title: Floyd Takes Memorial by 2
description: Ray Floyd went through ''a very emotional experience'' today in winning the Memorial Tournament by two strokes. He said he had ''rerouted'' his mental attitude ''away from negative thinking,'' meaning a reluctance to play in this golf tournament, one of the most prestigious on the tour.

title: BRITISH OIL READY TO GO PUBLIC
description: The setting was a modern meeting room in an equally modern office building here, and the agenda was a discussion with reporters of last year's results of the British National Oil Corporation, just the sort of news conference that usually follows an annual meeting. But for the moment, the corporation has no shareholders and, hence, no annual meeting.

title: Around the World; Iraq Says It Bombed Iranian Oil Sites
description: Iraq said today that its air force had bombed Iran's main oil export terminal in the Persian Gulf and an oil refinery in retaliation for the shelling of civilian targets in Iraqi territory.

title: ARGENTINE ANGUISH LINGERS FOR THOUSANDS MISSING SINCE 1970'S
description: In the midst of the war over the Falkland Islands, the unanswered questions about the thousands of disappearances in Argentina in the mid-1970's still linger.

title: British Pilot Rescued Behind Enemy Lines
description: The pilot of a Harrier jet who bailed out of his crippled plane behind the Argentine lines on Thursday was rescued today by helicopter, a dispatch from the war zone said.

title: Letter: On School Promotion Students Need Services, Not 'Gates'
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS ON RADIATION CONTROL SHARE CRITIQUES OF JOURNALISM
description: Cancer-causing and chromosome-changing effects of nuclear radiation have been overstated and misstated by journalists, state radiation experts were told this week.

title: Craig, U.S. Goalie, Charged in Crash
description: Jim Craig, the goaltender on the United States' gold-medal 1980 Olympic hockey team, was issued a citation today charging him with driving to endanger after an accident on a rain-slicked highway that left one woman dead and another critically injured, the police said.

title: THE COSTAL STATES' CASE AGAINST THE NEW LAW OF THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Pacific Cuts
description: The Southern Pacific Company said Friday that it was laying off 1,465 railroad employees, or about 4 percent of its total rail work force. They layoffs are scattered throughout the company's 14-state, 14,000-mile rail system from Oregon to Texas.

title: Baker to Ask That High Court Set Salaries of Congressmen
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., explaining he was tired of endless disputes over Congressional pay increases, says he wants the Supreme Court to set lawmakers' salaries.

title: Mark G. Trost Marries Suzan Denise Prince
description: At Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I., yesterday Suzan Denise Prince, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Prince of Long Beach, L.I., was married to Mark Gary Trost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Trost of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff performed the ceremony.

title: Panel Backs Blue Bell
description: Blue Bell Inc. said Friday that a committee of outside directors set up to review company operations had expressed confidence in the company's management.

title: Lisa J. Gruenberg Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Joy Gruenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gruenberg of Syracuse, was married in Fayetteville, N.Y., yesterday to Martin Carmichael 3d, son of Mr. Carmichael Jr. and Stacy Tobin Carmichael, both of New York. The Rev. Nick Cardell, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Wellington House.

title: Military Analysis
description: The British victories at Goose Green and Darwin, where British paratroops were reportedly outnumbered 2 to 1, appear to vindicate the NATO doctrine that aggressive, well-officered infantry constantly on the move can defeat a larger enemy force tied to fixed defenses.

title: STOP THE AIR WAR ON GYPSY MOTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: Litco Shares Sold
description: Compagnie de l'Occident pour la Finance et l'Industrie, a Luxembourg corporation, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday that it had sold 30,900 shares of the Litco Bancorporation of New York, reducing its ownership to 5.3 percent, or 140,417 shares.

title: Around the Nation; Hunger Striker in Illinois Taken to Hospital Twice
description: Sonia Johnson, one of seven women taking part in a hunger strike to try to win passage of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution, was taken to a hospital today for the second time.

title: R.C. Apfel Weds Jai Imbrey
description: Jai Alison Imbrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Imbrey of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Robert C. Apfel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Apfel of Hollis Hills, Queens. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony at the Potomac, Md. home of the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas Allen, friends of the bride's parents. Mrs. Apfel is an account executive with Rowland Company, a public relations and advertising agency in New York. The bridegroom is an assistant vice president in the public finance department of the Chemical Bank in New York.

title: Bonnett, in a Ford, Wins World 600
description: Neil Bonnett, who dropped out of last year's race after an accident, passed Bill Elliott with 12 laps to go and captured the $455,000 World 600 at Charlotte Motor Speedway today.

title: Trucking Costs
description: The average cost of owning and operating a heavy truck rose nearly 14 percent in 1981 and a hauler will spend more than $520,000 to run a tractor-trailer over the next five years, a study released today showed. In its annual study, the Hertz Corporation said that the cost of running a truck had tripled since the Arab oil embargo of 1973. It said that the average per-mile cost to operate a five-axle diesel tractor-trailer was 82.3 cents a mile in 1981, compared with 72.45 cents the year before and 27.4 cents in 1971.

title: Elizabeth Mae Older Wed
description: Elizabeth Mae Older, a press representative with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was married yesterday to David Harris Green, an editor on the general desk of The Associated Press in New York.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 31, 1982
description: International The loss of 12 British troops and the wounding of 31 Friday at Goose Green in the Falklands, the biggest battle so far in the war with Argentina, was announced by the Ministry of Defense in London. The ministry officially confirmed that another British force, operating along the north coast of East Falkland Island had captured without fighting two settlements about 30 miles from Stanley, the islands' capital. A battalion of Royal Marine commandos reportedly took Douglas and a battalion of paratroopers took Teal Inlet. (Page A1, Column 6.) Aerial attacks on the British fleet continued Argentina said. The joint military command in Buenos Aires reported that the ''nucleus'' of the fleet was attacked with bombs and Exocet missiles and that the ''damages are being evaluated.'' There was said to be evidence that the British carrier ''Invincible'' had been damaged, but this was denied by Britain. (A5:1-5.)

title: CREWS SEARCH FOR 15 PERSONS MISSING IN WAKE OF TORNADO
description: Rescue crews searched dozens of shattered buildings today for more victims of a tornado that cut a 15-mile path of destruction through southern Illinois on Saturday, killing at least 10 people and injuring more than 100.

title: ELLEN BURSTYN TO HEAD ACTORS EQUITY
description: For the first time in its 69-year history, Actors Equity will have a woman as its president. Ellen Burstyn, 49 years old, winner of Academy and Tony awards for best actress in 1975, was selected as the union's top officer, succeeding Theodore Bikel.

title: Suspect in Shootings Called Withdrawn by His Neighbors
description: Neighbors of the man charged with shooting several people at a Maryland office of the International Business Machines Corporation say he had become withdrawn in the last year, it was reported today.

title: OUTPOSTS IN ISLAND CAMPAIGN
description: The settlements of Goose Green and Darwin, situated two miles apart on a narrow isthmus that connects the two main sections of East Falkland Island, are clusters of farm houses surrounded by corrals, hen houses and auxiliary sheds related to the raising of sheep.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dis- patch from San Salvador last Monday incorrectly reported the number of political parties that won seats in El Salvador's new Constitutent Assem- bly. Four rightist parties won 36 of the 60 assembly seats.

title: Lisa Goldwasser Married
description: Lisa Debra Goldwasser, an assistant director of BAR/BRI Professional Testing Centers and Conviser-Miller CPA Review, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Glenn Absatz, an intern in the orthopedicsurgery department of the New York University Hospital. Rabbi Louis Stein performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's family in Upper Saddle River, N.J. She is a daughter of Nathan Goldwasser and the late Mrs. Goldwasser. Dr. Absatz is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour I. Absatz of Plainview, L.I.

title: Gulf Resources Accord Is Sought
description: Lawyers for Alan E. Clore, leader of a dissident stockholders committee of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, said last week that the group had appealed to the company's directors to ''terminate wasteful litigation.''

title: DeLorean Plan To Save Plant
description: John Z. DeLorean said in an interview last week that he would meet with Sir Kenneth Cork on Thursday to present a plan supported by two West Coast investors aimed at eventually re-starting car production at the Government-owned plant in Northern Ireland.

title: Abroad at Home; WHICH SIDE ARE WE ON?
description: An early casualty of the Falklands war was the Reagan Administration's basic Latin policy: the policy of smiling on right-wing regimes in the region and enlisting them in the fight against Communism. But do officials know it is dead?

title: TO SOME, CALL TO ARMS IS BUT AN ECHO
description: David Laskin came of age without the uniform or the gun. He made his passage to maturity on a college campus instead of a parade ground. He has never heard a first sergeant's bark, marched miles in the rain or sat in a foxhole at night and watched on the blank screen of darkness the images of home.

title: MEMORIAL DAY, 1944: LOOKING BEYOND VICTORY
description: Recurrent in all our tributes to those who fall in battle is a dominant resolve that their sacrifice somehow shall bear fruit. How, we do not know, except in terms of generalities, even platitudes, about a bright new world which shall rise out of the desolation of war. This is our answer, and the only answer we have, to the wanton waste of blood and treasure which is the essence of war.

title: EUROPE'S TROUBLED ECONOMY
description: European nations, confused about American strategy and divided in their own policies, are facing the prospect of an economic upturn with only modest expectations.

title: Going Out Guide
description: FOR THE BIRDS

title: The City; Police Link Drugs To Queens Killing
description: A man was found fatally shot Saturday night in his Queens apartment, in what the police said was a drug-related killing. The police in the 110th Precinct said the victim, Leslie Hibbert, 52 years old, was discovered by his wife in the hallway of his apartment at 88-12 Elmhurst Avenue at about 7:50 P.M. He had been shot once in the chest.

title: Miss Spuzich Wins
description: Sandra Spuzich forced a playoff with Patty Sheehan on the 18th hole and then won the Ladies Professional Golf Association Corning Classic today with a par 4 on the first playoff hole.

title: AUSTRIA'S PROBLEMS WORRY ECONOMISTS
description: In Austria, there have been no giant bankruptcies, like Belgium's Cockerill-Sambre Steel Company, or any controversial remedies, such as France's industry nationalization plan. But beneath the surface of apparent tranquility, there is an undercurrent of concern about the economy this spring.

title: Mr. Biaggi's Police Tax
description: Political winds are finally blowing some life into Representative Biaggi's plan for a $500 million ''superfund'' to fight crime in New York City. Mayor Koch, cool to the idea at first, endorsed it after the City Council and Mario Cuomo, a rival for Governor, gave it their blessing. The Mayor should not have changed his mind.

title: FISCAL WARNING BREAKS LONG SILENCE
description: For several years, rarely had a public word been heard from them - the three business representatives on the State Financial Control Board. Budget after budget, they had gone about their work with quiet, subtle dispatch, managing to preserve an anonymity unusual for those in and around government.

title: Business Digest; MONDAY, MAY 31, 1982; International
description: ''Europessimism'' has greeted a modest economic upturn in the six major Common Market countries. Even though their growth is expected to be 1.2 percent this year, the six nations will express uneasiness about the course of United States economic policy when they meet in Versailles, France, to discuss economic problems with the U.S., Japan and Canada. (Page D1.)

title: Essay; ARIEL SHARON'S VISIT
description: The roller-coaster relationship between the Reagan and Begin administrations has begun a cautious new climb. We can recall the euphoria at the start, followed by the plunge after the foolish attempt to buy Saudi friendship with Awacs, down to the nadir when the Israeli Prime Minister exploded at the unprecedented ''punishment'' of withholding American aid.

title: Reagan Returns to Capital
description: President Reagan returned to the White House today after a four-day vacation in California. Edwin Meese 3d, Presidential counselor, told reporters traveling with Mr. Reagan aboard Air Force One that there would be a meeting at the White House on Monday to discuss the next step in the budget process. The House failed in several attempts to adopt a budget resolution on Friday.

title: TV: 'BENNY'S PLACE,' A TRIBUTE TO WORKERS
description: ''BENNY'S PLACE,'' on ABC-TV tonight at 9 o'clock, is one of those do-good projects that could have been done better in several respects but, whatever the faults, still commands respect and encouragement. The teleplay, written by J. Rufus Caleb, was the winner of this year's ABC Theater Award at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center. The production, directed by Michael Schultz, has been sensitively mounted under the guidance of Herbert Brodkin as executive producer. The strong cast is headed by Louis Gossett Jr. and Cicely Tyson.

title: ARGENTINES ASSERT THEY HIT A CARRIER
description: Argentina said tonight that its warplanes had attacked and put out of commission a British aircraft carrier, hitting it with bombs and an Exocet missile.

title: Issue and Debate; ARE CHANGES NEEDED IN BANKRUPTCY LAWS?
description: A staggering number of people and businesses are going bankrupt these days. And while it is generally accepted that the recession is causing most of the business failures, the consumer credit industry thinks that personal bankruptcies are increasing primarily as a result of recently liberalized Federal laws.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World A2 Uruguay ousts U.S. Embassy aide A2 Colombians elect president as troops guard voting areas A3 In Soviet, success of peace campaign stirs its doubts A3 Moynihan calls for interim nuclear arms accord A3 British attack: Of a type ''not seen since World War II'' A4 At the British beachhead, cold nights and muddy days A4 Peru says U.S. must press Britain to resume talks A5 Issue of thousands missing since '70's lingers in Argentina A5 Haig and Mrs. Kirkpatrick said to argue over Falkland stand A5 Washington Talk Briefing A8 Decision File A8 White House: Clark emerges as a maker of policy A8 Head of O.A.S., an Argentine, sees public duty to be neutral A8 Congressional pages get an inside view of Capitol Hill A8 MEMORIAL DAY Parking - Sunday rules; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; special delivery and express-mail delivery only. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules; subways and buses on Sunday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: U.S. MONEY MARKET: A MANIPULATOR'S PARADISE
description: To the Editor:

title: PERU WARNS U.S. ON LATIN RELATIONS
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry of Peru appealed to the United States today to press Britain to accept a diplomatic solution to the Falkland Islands conflict.

title: Commodities; THE BREAK IN SUGAR FUTURES
description: THE blow that the world sugar futures market had been bracing for since May 5 finally landed last Friday, when the price of the spot July contract plunged 0.42 cent a pound, to 7.80 cents. For the week, the loss was 0.45 cent. The other deliveries showed somewhat smaller losses for Friday and the week. Each hundredth of a cent is equivalent to $11.20 on each contract of 112,000 pounds.

title: The Region; A Viking Ship Calls at Buffalo
description: A reproduction of a Viking ship arrived here today on a voyage that is to take her from the Great Lakes to Norway.

title: A BLESSING IS INVOKED FOR PEACE
description: Standing at the door of the Riverside Church after his sermon yesterday, the Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin said he was pleased that ''so many nations warring with each other had shown up.''

title: 2 MORE OUTPOSTS CLAIMED BY BRITISH IN STANLEY THRUST
description: British troops driving toward Stanley, the Falkland Islands' capital, have taken two more settlements, the Defense Ministry confirmed today.

title: Around the World; Americans in Hanoi Urge Defoliant Study
description: A group of American veterans proposed today that United States scientists come to Vietnam to investigate the effects of Agent Orange, a highly toxic defoliant used by American forces during the war.

title: 76ERS TIE PLAYOFF BY 110-94
description: There was a new look to the Philadelphia 76ers today as they defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 110-94, to even the National Basketball Association finals at 1-1 in the Spectrum.

title: BENNETT SETS LOW PROFILE FOR HUMANITIES AGENCY
description: It's a long way from Public School 92 and Holy Cross Boys School in Flatbush, where he grew up in the long afternoon shadow of the Dodgers at nearby Ebbets Field, to the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humanities in Washington. But thanks to his own strong academic credentials and the support of neo-conservatives, William J. Bennett, who faced strong opposition among some senators, is now at the helm of the agency that finances everything from esoteric literary studies to television documentaries.

title: METHANE SOUGHT BY 3 L.I. TOWNS FROM LANDFILLS
description: Hoping to turn underground methane gas from a danger into a revenue source, three Long Island towns have signed contracts with Getty Synthetic Fuels to mine their landfills for the gas.

title: Steel Pay Cuts Upstate
description: Steelworkers at the Guterl Specialty Steel Corporation have voted, 308 to 31, to accept cuts in pay and fringe benefits to prevent further layoffs and help save the struggling company. Members of Local 2857 of the United Steelworkers of America voted Thursday to accept a pay cut of 60 cents an hour beginning Monday, and agreed to give up three paid holidays this year and one week of vacation time next year. Wage scales were not released, but the concessions were expected to save Guterl $1.5 million during the next 16 months.

title: Pope Honors the Poles Who Live in Britain
description: In the final London appearance of his British tour, Pope John Paul II paid tribute today to his fellow Poles who have chosen to live in Britain rather than their homeland.

title: Andrea S. Bienstock Is Married to Nathan A. Bicks
description: The marriage of Andrea Sali Bienstock to Nathan Allan Bicks took place yesterday in the Plaza Hotel. Rabbi Samuel Mendelowitz performed the ceremony.

title: Around the World; 3 Salvadorans Held In Slaying of Mayor
description: A Christian Democratic Party mayor and her 18-year-old daughter were slain by gunmen Friday, and today a party spokesman said that three men, two linked to the National Guard and one a civil defense worker, were being held as suspects in San Francisco Chinameca, 19 miles southeast of the capital.

title: FUND-RAISING BAZAAR WITH INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS
description: The big, square, red-lettered signs were suspended by wires from the ceiling of the East Side International Community Center. ''Turkey'' one read; ''Nepal'' another. Still others indicated New Zealand, Haiti, Japan, South Africa, Mexico, Indonesia and South Korea. And there was ''Tombola.''

title: STATE APPEALING RULING ON CARE AT WILLOWBROOK
description: New York State has appealed a Federal judge's finding that the state had failed to comply with a 1975 consent judgment for the care of the mentally retarded at Willowbrook in Staten Island.

title: LAST DRAFTEE GLAD HE'S OUT
description: The last man, as Dwight Elliot Stone has come to be known, yielded to the inevitable on June 30, 1973. His status as the final American draftee to be inducted into military service made him something of a celebrity.

title: ORDERS FOR TOOLS RISE 11.6%
description: Orders for new machine tools rose 11.6 percent in April, to $153.8 million, from $137.8 million in March, according to the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Rangers 8, Royals 1
description: Doc Medich scattered six hits and Billy Sample hit two home runs to lead Texas. Medich (3-5) walked two and struck out two as he pitched his first complete game this season.

title: CHURCH RITE IN POLISH COAL REGION BECOMES CRY AGAINST ARMY RULE
description: Tens of thousands of marching men converged today on this shrine of the Virgin Mary in the heart of the Silesian coal-mining region for the annual men's pilgrimage.

title: Briefing
description: How to Win Friends

title: Decision File; Mouthwashes Evaluated
description: Do the ''germ killers'' in mouthwashes and gargles really clean the mouth? Absolutely not, asserts a recently published study sponsored by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: UNFORESEEN BUSINESS BARRIERS FOR WOMEN
description: A new study of female executives has found unforeseen barriers impeding their advancement in corporations and unexpected similarities in the career frustrations of both male and female managers.

title: PAPER IN MINNESOTA WILL HALT PUBLICATION AND THEN MERGE
description: The Duluth Herald, a 99-year-old afternoon newspaper, will cease publication July 30 and will merge with The Duluth News-Tribune on Aug. 2, employees were told Friday.

title: Sports World Specials; A Course-in-One
description: It was one of those occasions in which one thing leads to another. A few golf aficionados were discussing their favorite courses in the metropolitan area and then the favorite holes on those courses.

title: GREGSON NEAR RECKONING DAY
description: ''I WAS obsessive, completely obsessive, about winning a Kentucky Derby,'' Eddie Gregson said. He was also precise and methodical. When Gato del Sol won the the Del Mar Futurity last Sept. 9, his trainer sat down and drew up a list of races to carry the colt to Louisville and beyond. Except for one insignificant variation - running in the San Felipe March 21 instead of the San Rafael March 5 after the colt ran a slight temperature and missed a workout -Gregson stuck to his chart.

title: M. Michael Reid Weds Angela B. Wormser
description: Angela Boeseke Wormser, a special-education teacher at the Coleytown Developmental Center in Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to M. Michael Reid of Ridgefield, Conn., a vice president of manufacturing and construction services for Lone Star Industries in Greenwich, Conn.

title: BRITISH ASSAULT ON DARWIN: 'A TYPE OF ATTACK NOT SEEN SINCE WORLD WAR II
description: Robert Fox, a BBC correspondent with the Second Battalion of the Parachute Regiment in the Falkland Islands, witnessed the British capture of the Argentine positions at Darwin and Goose Green on Friday and Saturday. The following is his account, filed today as a pool dispatch and cleared by the British military censors.

title: AID TO DEVELOPERS BY CITY IS IN DOUBT
description: New York City's major tax abatement program for developers is due to expire tomorrow, and its chances of being extended are in doubt because of unexpected opposition in the State Legislature.

title: Coast Federal Merger Accord
description: Coast Federal Savings and Loan Association, based in Los Angeles, and Monterey Savings and Loan Association, based in Monterey, announced Friday that they had agreed to merge into a new institution to be called Coast Federal Savings of America. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Winifred C. Gass Married To Lieut. James P. Hogle
description: Winifred Caitlyn Gass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manus M. Gass of River Edge, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Second Lieut.

title: Wickes Allowed To Keep 2 Units
description: The Wickes Companies said Friday that under a ruling made by the United States Bankruptcy Court it could keep its Red Owl supermarket chain and Snyder Drugs chain despite an earlier contract it had made to sell the chains to Thorofare Markets Inc.

title: Around the Nation; Arsonists Hit 4th Church In Harrisburg Area
description: A Unitarian church near here was damaged by fire today, the second Sunday in a row that a church near the city has been struck by a suspicious blaze.

title: Around the Nation; 3 Armenians Arrested For Bomb at Airport
description: The police bomb squad defused a bomb next to an Air Canada freight terminal at Los Angeles International Airport today, and three Armenians were later arrested on Federal charges related to the explosive device.

title: Music Noted in Brief; 1982 Hispanic Festival Pays Homage to Turina
description: The 1982 Hispanic Festival celebrated the slender charms of Joaquin Turina on Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall. This year is the 100th anniversary of Turina's birth, and to remember his music, Thruston Johnson, violinist, and David Garvey, pianist, played the Duo Sonatas Nos. 1 and 2, the Fantasy Suite ''El Poema de una Sanluquena'' and the ''Homenaje a Navarra'' from ''Ciclo Plateresco III'' (Op. 102).

title: BT Mortgage Merger Barred
description: BT Mortgage Investors said Friday that its shareholders had not approved the trust's acquisition by Charan Industries by the requisite two-thirds vote.

title: Business People; BEECH'S CO-FOUNDER AND CHAIRMAN RETIRING
description: The end of an era has come at the Beech Aircraft Corporation. Olive Ann Beech, who has been involved in the aviation industry since 1925, has announced that she will retire in September as chairman of the company she founded with her husband, Walter, in 1932.

title: EXPERTS IN HINCKLEY TRIAL CITE POEMS AND PUZZLINGS OF TROUBLED MIND
description: ''I remain the far side of crazy,'' John W. Hinckley Jr. wrote in a poem some time before he shot President Reagan to impress a movie actress.

title: Sports World Specials; The Sisters Krolewski
description: When a field of 6,100 women and girls begins the L'eggs Mini Marathon this morning in Central Park, the family of Casimir and Rosemarie Krolewski will be well represented. The Krolewskis, of Coventry, R.I., have 10 children; five of their seven daughters have entered the 10,000-meter (6.2-mile) race.

title: Mets Strike Early And Halt Astros, 9-5
description: After two days of suffering at the hands of Nolan Ryan and Joe Niekro, the Mets rebelled at Shea Stadium yesterday. They mauled Bob Knepper for four runs in the first inning, added three in the second and eventually overpowered the Houston Astros, 9-5.

title: WAR AND PEACE IN SOVIET: CONTRADICTIONS ABOUND
description: Few aspects of Soviet life today seem as ambivalent as popular attitudes toward peace and war. At the end of a Communist Youth League convention in Moscow recently, thousands of youths held a mass antiwar rally, one of numerous demonstrations being staged around the Soviet Union before the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Fruit of the Loom Licensing promoted Robert M. Siegel, formerly vice president, to senior vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Baker Is in Peking to Discuss Strain in U.S.-China Relations
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, arrived here today to discuss strained relations over Washington's arms sales to Taiwan and to convey a message from President Reagan to Chinese leaders. There was no indication what Mr. Reagan's message contained.

title: Shoemaker Is 5th
description: Sangue, a 4-year-old Irish-bred filly, won the $139,150 Yerba Buena Handicap by 2 1/2 lengths today on the Golden Gate Fields turf.

title: Albert Norden Is Dead; Key East German Aide
description: Albert Norden, the oldest member of East Germany's Politburo and one of East Germany's early leaders, died today, the East German press agency reported. He was 77 years old.

title: Elizabeth Howlett, T.H. Roberts Wed
description: Elizabeth Howlett, daughter of Mrs. Ewan Watts Fletcher of Concord, Mass., and William Crossman Howlett of Great Falls, Va., was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Thomas Henry Roberts, son of Mrs. Thomas Hagan Roberts of East Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Roberts. The Rev. Thomas Powers performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Around the Nation; Phosphate Strip Mine Approved in Florida
description: The Florida Department of Environmental Regulation granted conditional approval Friday to a company seeking to open a strip mine for phosphate ore in a major watershed area of southwestern Florida.

title: Lendl Upset by Wilander in 5-Set Match
description: Mats Wilander, a 17-year-old Swede with a steady baseline game, eliminated Ivan Lendl from the French Open tennis tournament today by winning, 4-6, 7-5, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, in a four-hour struggle and moving into the quarterfinals.

title: V.A. AND CONGRESS CLASH ON AID PLAN
description: While Congress wrestled over details of a budget of $780 billion last week, the Veterans Administration and a handful of members of the House were engaged in a dispute over two obscure programs that are to cost $77 million this year.

title: MOYNIHAN URGES ARMS MOVE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan suggested today that Congress and President Reagan should act to transform the unratified 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty into a so-called interim executive agreement with the Soviet Union that would have binding effect.

title: Relationships; HELPING EXECUTIVES AFTER A DISMISSAL
description: FOR the corporate executive whose identity has long been melded w ith a company's, the anguish of being dismissed is compounded by h aving to face the world stripped of title and associations. The q uestion that this person most dreads is, ''How are things at the o ffice?'' According to experts, the resulting lies or isolation can h ave damaging psychological and professional consequences.

title: Rochester Man Found Slain in Cave Upstate
description: A Rochester man missing for 10 months has been found dead in a cave in this western New York community, and the police say he was murdered.

title: LAKERS TRY TO EXPLAIN A LOSS
description: When the Los Angeles Lakers trailed the Philadelphia 76ers by 15 points late in the opening game of the National Basketball Association finals last Thursday night, Earvin (Magic) Johnson remembered what it was like to lose. So, he became instrumental in the 40-9 scoring surge for the Laker victory.

title: AFTER WAVE OF MERGERS, ANALYSTS DEBATE PLUSES
description: The roll call of the fallen includes some of the most distinguished names in American corporate ranks: Conoco, Marathon Oil, Kennecott, C.I.T. Financial, Sunbeam, Salomon Brothers, 2Oth Century-Fox, Standard Brands and Seven-Up.

title: 14 BRENTANO'S STORES, GROUPED IN REGIONS, WILL STAY OPEN
description: The Brentano's bookstore chain, which filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws on May 21, plans to keep open, at least temporarily, its two Manhattan stores and 12 others in Long Island, New Jersey, the Washington area, California and St. Louis.

title: BROOKLYN DIAMONDS PRODUCE A JEWEL
description: ON an afternoon several weeks ago, a cab pulled up beside a baseball field in Brooklyn. The passenger, wearing a fedora, rolled down the window and asked a man nearby, ''Is this where Shawon Dunston is playing?'' ''Yes,'' said the passer-by. The man got out of the cab and, carrying two suitcases, he headed for the ball field.

title: IN CHANGING BIRMINGHAM, ROTARY CLUB VOTES TO STAY WHITE
description: Just as this predominantly black steelmaking city was shedding its historic image as a haven for racism and becoming known as a center of Southern progress, even aiming to give thriving Atlanta a race for leadership of the South, the trend has been betrayed by a local service club.

title: Bancal Plans 7% Staff Cuts
description: The Bancal Tri-State Corporation, a holding company for the Bank of California, said Friday that it would lay off 300 employees by July 1, or 7 percent of its staff.

title: POP: CARROLL'S ANTHEM EULOGIZES PEERS
description: and-roll performer, has earned at least a footnote in the annals of rock history through his song ''People Who Died.'' This wild, careening roll-call of the singer's dead friends, many from self-induced drug overdoses, is both a eulogy and a victory anthem that's full of disturbing contradictory emotions - anguish, triumph and excitment - about appalling fatality.

title: Klan, Shunned 2 Weeks Ago, Holds Second Vermont Rally
description: Two dozen white-robed members of the Ku Klux Klan paraded onto the town common in a steady drizzle Saturday for a recruitment drive, defying the anti-Klan feelings vented against them in a noisy protest two weeks ago.

title: School Science, School Prayer
description: In the schools of medieval Europe, arithmetic, geometry and astronomy were standard courses. In America today, they are anything but standard. By almost every major criterion, science and math education is in serious decline.

title: The Region; Surgeon Guilty Of Malpractice
description: The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners has found a Plainfield neurosurgeon guilty of three counts of gross malpractice, one involving the death of a patient.

title: ONCE A HANDICAPPED INFANT IS ALLOWED TO LIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORNELL GRADUATES ARE URGED TO SET 'GREAT GOALS'
description: Cornell University's president, at a commencement ceremony that began today in a light drizzle but ended in bright sunshine, congratulated the 4,200 graduates for a ''healthy skepticism'' but urged them to seek roles of leadership in the world.

title: VETERANS' BURIAL COST PAID BY BUSINESSMAN
description: 'LOS ANGELES, May 30 (AP) - A concerned businessman is paying burial costs for indigent veterans whose bodies began stacking up at the county morgue after Federal spending cutbacks last year.

title: Business People; CHIEF TO STEP DOWN AT AILING KEYSTONE
description: J. Walter Tucker Jr., 56 years old, will step down as chief executive officer of financially pressed Keystone Consolidated Industries, effective July 1. Mr. Tucker, who will remain vice chairman and a director, asked that Glenn A. Simmons, 54, the company's president, succeed him.

title: MISSISSIPPI REPUBLICANS PLAN RARE EFFORT TO DEFEAT STENNIS
description: A moderate young Republican lawyer, Haley Barbour of Yazoo City, Miss., is heavily favored to win his party's nomination Tuesday for the first major bid by state Republicans to unseat John C. Stennis, the Democrat who is dean of the United States Senate, this fall.

title: Jeffrey Boak Marries Elizabeth Pelgrift
description: Elizabeth DeLancey Pelgrift, daughter of Robert Youngs Pelgrift of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Schroeder Pelgrift, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Lynn Boak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Boak of Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. Robert L. Edwards, who is retired, and the Rev. Richard B. Griffis of Hartford performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Month Ends Badly for Penske
description: ALL month long the Penske team ruled Indianapolis, sending out two missiles that were vital seconds faster than anybody else's missiles. On the next-to-last day of the month - the day that really counted - the Penske team no longer ruled Indianapolis. One missile caused a collision before the race ever began and the other missile finished half a car length behind the winner.

title: A TIME FOR NEUTRALITY FOR ARGENTINE AT O.A.S.
description: The King of Morocco was having a party, a lavish gathering that flowed through the Moroccan Ambassador's residence and out into an incense-filled tent on the lawn. While even the powerful were getting lost among the more powerful, Alejandro Orfila could hardly be missed.

title: MUSIC: BILL AND MARY BUCHEN
description: BILL AND MARY BUCHEN'S ''On the Beach'' on Saturday at the Battery Park Landfill took its audience for a walk. With a clear sky above and sand underfoot, with the wonders of Lower Manhattan's skyline on one side and the calm waters of New York Harbor on the other, the music was hard-pressed to compete with its setting.

title: Music Noted in Brief; SERKIN SOLO FEATURED IN 'MOZART-STRAVINSKY'
description: The second concert in the New York Philharmonic's ''Mozart-Stravinsky Spring Series'' on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall offered the actual Philharmonic: the first had enlisted only winds, pianists, percussionists and singers. Thursday's concert also offered Zubin Mehta, who had been busy across town the night before with his other orchestra, the Israel Philharmonic.

title: G.E. Raises Dividend
description: The board of directors of the General Electric Company have raised the quarterly dividend 5 cents a common share, to 85 cents, payable July 26 to shareholders of record June 9. The increase raised the annual dividend to $3.40 from $3.20.

title: Dangers in Oil Debt Cited by Study
description: The mounting debt for oil purchases in many nations, coupled with trade deficits suffered by the United States, could lead to a collapse of the world economy in the coming decade, according to a study published here.

title: CAPITOL PAGES: WITNESSES TO HISTORY
description: President Carter once told a group of Congressional pages that if he had possessed their knowledge of Congress when he came to Washington, he might have been more successful in his dealings with Capitol Hill.

title: CONVENTION PACE BRIGHTENS BOOK-SALES OUTLOOK
description: Sunny California has been overcast the last two days, but delegates to the American Booksellers Association convention here seem convinced that the dark clouds that have hovered over the publishing industry for years are finally about to blow away.

title:
'THE WHOLE PROBLEM OF COURAGE NEEDS A REDIFINITION';
I was made livid with anger when I read in the newspaper the Green Berets' complaint that their ''bad boys'' are giving them a ''bad image.''
description: The Green Berets are specialists in violence, and this requires a special toughness, close to impenetrability, in the regions where we, the soft-muscled intellectuals, exercise our own specialty called thinking, which, together with judging (another specialty of ours), must always precede acting in a civilized society. Not in the Green Beret society, which is no society, but a special service sector of it that excludes both thinking and judging, because they would destroy the purpose of that service.

title: OUTDOORS: WHERE THE BLUES ARE
description: BLUEFISH have showed up all along the coast, at least as far north as Cape Cod, and in some instances their arrival was so early, anglers were caught with their tackle in disarray.

title: HOW CEMETERIES BRING US BACK TO EARTH
description: A while ago, we said goodbye to a beloved aunt in a rural Wisconsin cemetery pulsing with birdsong. It was a splendid morning, gusty and bright. Puffy white clouds went sailing across the deep blue sky and calves were bawling in the distance. Later, we would sing hymns in a pretty church that smelled of coffee and candle wax, but first we stood blinking in the sunlight while a choir of robins, red-winged blackbirds and meadowlarks lustily serenaded the casket.

title: Sports World Specials; Golden Opportunity
description: What some people refer to as ''the Maltese Falcon of tennis'' was moved last week from a vault in the Essex House on Central Park South to Wallach and Sons, goldsmiths and jewelers in Manhasset, L.I. The Hamlet Challenge Cup, estimated to be worth $80,000, is covered by 105 ounces of 24-carat gold.

title: SPACE TRANSPORTATION SEEKS CAPITAL
description: It sounds like the brainchild of a mad scientist and an eccentric millionaire. The Space Transportation Company of Princeton, N.J., has a billion-dollar plan to sell tickets to outer space.

title: The Region; Inquiry Is Sought On Gasoline Costs
description: A Long Island consumer advocate said yesterday that he had asked the United States Justice Department to investigate whether oil refiners were ''creating an artificial depletion of reserves'' so as to cause shortages and higher gasoline prices in the New York metropolitan area during the summer months of increased driving.

title: An Amusement Park For Jersey Is Studied
description: Development of a Walt Disney-type family amusement center outside Atlantic City is under discussion by members of Governor Kean's administration, officials say.

title: FOUR WHO FOUGHT FOR FRANCE WITH 369TH LAUDED IN HARLEM
description: They fought in the trenches for 191 days - longer than any other American unit. They never lost a foot of ground or had a single soldier captured, though 1,500 died. But they were not allowed to fight beside their countrymen because they were black.

title: WATT'S LEFT TURN
description: To the Editor:

title: 'BIG MAC' SUPPLANTS BIG STEEL AS MANUFACTURING JOBS LAG
description: Karen Brieck and Phyllis Wilburn sat in a booth and smoked one cigarette after another, six, eight, perhaps 10 in all, and talked of why they had gone to work selling hamburgers at McDonald's. It was, they said, a matter of necessity.

title: JOHNCOCK FINISHES FIRST IN CLOSEST INDY 500
description: The race that America's greatest drivers and most sophisticated cars could not start on the first attempt eventually became a frantic, one-on-one, wheel-to-wheel chase today.
